title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: More Water Restrictions Possible
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that unless the city's upstate reservoirs received 15 more inches of rain over the next several weeks, the city might turn to a Stage 2 drought emergency, up one level from the one now in place. While the state is still analyzing the effects of the weekend's downpour, water shortages are almost certain next year, the mayor said.

title: Patricia Kroh; Flower Arranging Expert, 97
description: Lenore Patricia Kroh Freudenheim, a flower arranging expert and author of four books on the subject, died on April 26 in Longboat Key, Fla. She was 97 and lived in Longboat Key.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MACHINES CORP., Armonk, N.Y., said it had raised its quarterly dividend to 15 cents from 14 cents a share, payable June 10 to shareholders of record May 10.

title: Nets Throw Away Margin for Error
description: The Nets came back to Indiana with the luxury of a one-game lead and two games remaining to seize their first-round playoff series. That luxury is now stripped to bare necessity.

title: Andersen Trial in Phoenix Opens With Views on Fraud
description: The trial of Arthur Andersen's second-largest financial problem -- its audits of a Baptist foundation that collapsed and led to criminal prosecutions -- began today with a plaintiffs' lawyer maintaining that Andersen had ignored warnings that the charity was a Ponzi scheme years before the foundation fell apart.

title: CALENDER
description: From Italian Tables

title: Mayor Moves to Separate Judges' Jobs and Politics
description: In a significant policy shift, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has reverted to a system for appointing judges established by former Mayor Edward I. Koch, a system rejected by Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: A Fast Ends, With Sweetness and Pomp
description: PASKHA, the dome of sweetened cheese traditionally served at Russian Orthodox Easter, is a wonderful variant on the standard baked cream-cheese cake.

title: Letting Golf Courses Go a Little Wild; Clubs Spray Less and Make Way For Native Plants and Coyotes
description: For years, they have been viewed as the environmental monsters of the suburbs -- impossibly green swards that live on a diet of heavy doses of pesticides and endless supplies of water.

title: Joseph and Toronto Knock Down Islanders
description: The Islanders' delightful turnaround season finally ended tonight in a 4-2 loss to the Maple Leafs in Game 7 of their opening-round playoff series.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Names Financial Officer
description: Verizon Communications, the telephone company, has named Doreen Toben chief financial officer to succeed Frederic V. Salerno, who announced his retirement on Monday. The appointment is effective immediately, Verizon said. Ms. Toben, 52, was financial officer at the Telecom Group, Verizon's biggest unit. She is taking the job a week after Verizon reported a $501 million first-quarter loss and said profit and sales this year would be less than forecast.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Applica, which makes and sell small appliances, to Bennett Kuhn Varner, Atlanta, to handle advertising for its consumer products division, initially for new products. Billings were estimated at more than $4 million. Applica is relocating its consumer products division to Miami Lakes, Fla.

title: Ontario Fosters Cross-Border Electricity Trade
description: The ties that bind the United States and Canada will become a little tighter this week when the province of Ontario, home to more than a third of all Canadians and 40 percent of Canada's economic activity, throws open its electricity market.

title: Mainstreaming Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Chinese Still Stuck In the Past
description: IN a world going madder by the hour, it is almost refreshing to run into some familiar political posturing -- a veritable golden oldie of socialist suppression.

title: A Faculty for Pulitzers
description: After LOUIS MENAND won the Pulitzer Prize for history last month, the City University of New York totaled up its cadre of Pulitzer Prize winners and surprised itself with the result: nine active or retired CUNY professors have won the prize. Mr. Menand, a distinguished professor of English at the CUNY Graduate Center, won for his book ''The Metaphysical Club.''

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Money & Business section on Sunday about the business practices of the Federal Agricultural Mortgage Corporation, also known as Farmer Mac, misstated the amount charged by Paine Webber to advise the company in 1988. The retainer guaranteed Paine Webber $200,000 for four months' work, not three, making the monthly payment $50,000, not $66,000.

title: Guggenheim Fellowship for Professor
description: SHELDON WEINBAUM, a distinguished professor of mechanical and biomedical engineering at City College, has won a Guggenheim Fellowship in molecular and cellular biology. The National Academy of Sciences also made him one of its 72 new members this week. Karen W. Arenson

title: At Indian Pt. Hearing, Crowds, Speeches, but Not Much Listening
description: The battle lines were clearly drawn tonight over the Indian Point nuclear power plant as its critics and defenders sparred over its fate before county legislators.

title: Homes of Shame: Outrage, and Calls for Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Bias Incidents Against Muslims Are Soaring, Islamic Council Says
description: The Council on American-Islamic Relations said today that bias incidents against Muslims soared nationwide after Sept. 11, with two-thirds of the incidents reported in the last year occurring less than six months after the terrorist attacks.

title: Women's Health Needs
description: To the Editor:

title: He Chose Cheese Steak Over Fancy
description: LIFE, the saying goes, is what happens while you're making other plans. Having figured this out, Gary Thompson, whose story has been shaped by World War II, Vietnam and most recently by Sept. 11, has stopped making plans and started making cheese steaks.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the New York State Senate's approval of a bill to allow voter-sponsored ballot initiatives referred incorrectly to its main backer, the state's Independence Party. Its affiliation with the national Reform Party founded by Ross Perot ended in September 2000.

title: The Real Winners Stand Up, Holding a Ticket Out of Debt
description: Six days after a group of nursing home workers began bickering over $58.9 million they thought they had won in a multistate lottery, the real winners, Jorge and Joanne Lopes of Manalapan, N.J., stepped forward today to claim their money and contemplate their new life.

title: Corrections
description: The On the Road column in Business Day yesterday, about ideas for revamping the air travel industry, misspelled the surname of the billionaire investor who has expressed disillusionment with it on occasion. He is Warren E. Buffett, not Buffet.

title: Rumsfeld Delays Decisions on Canceling and Trimming Arms Programs
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld is not canceling any weapons programs for now, according to a draft of planning guidelines that he is completing this week, even though aides and advocates of military reform sharply criticize several systems as a waste of money.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Velella and His Father Indicted, Officials Say
description: State Senator Guy J. Velella of the Bronx and his father have been indicted on charges of helping a company win contracts with state agencies in return for cash payments, law enforcement officials and people close to the senator say.

title: Charity Tied to Terror
description: The Justice Department arrested the head of an Islamic charity in Chicago, saying that he and his organization had funneled money to Al Qaeda and had close ties to Osama bin Laden. Enaam M. Arnaout, 39, the Syrian-born director of the Benevolence International Foundation, was charged with lying under oath.

title: An Academic Voice at City Hall (One That Carries)
description: ESTER R. FUCHS is neither meek nor muted in voice. This much is evident as Ms. Fuchs, an adviser to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, holds forth on a recent afternoon from her snug cubicle in the converted bullpen on the second floor of City Hall. The mayor has his own cubicle a row away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VEGA, TIMOTHY
description: VEGA-Timothy. On April 29, 2002, passed away in his sleep. Beloved son of Patricia Vega. Loving brother of Suzanne, Alyson and Matthew. Dear uncle of Sachi and Ruby. Beloved son of Edgardo Vega. He will be deeply missed by his girlfriend Lauren and his countless friends. Service Friday 2pm, ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. & Amsterdam.

title: Homes of Shame: Outrage, and Calls for Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Recipe: Karkady Cooler
description: Time: 5 minutes

title: Toward Mental Health Parity
description: President Bush said some encouraging words this week about the need for a health care system that will treat mental illness with the same urgency as physical illness. The president seemed to suggest that health insurance should cover mental problems on the same terms as other medical problems. If the president is serious about this issue, he will need to lean on recalcitrant House Republicans, the chief impediment to reform, to pass a bill elevating mental health coverage to a par with medical and surgical coverage.

title: Tyson, in Training, Is a Man on an Island
description: In what some may consider an unlikely setting for a fighter training for any fight, let alone the heavyweight championship of the world, Mike Tyson is preparing here in Maui for his June 8 bout in Memphis with the titleholder, Lennox Lewis. Tyson is training in a gym not far from the Haleakala volcano, which before Iron Mike showed up was the lone volcano on this lush, splendiferous island.

title: The Hidden Victims
description: In recent months, the explosion of Arab satellite TV stations and Web sites has had a profound impact on Arab public opinion by showing live, nonstop images of the Israeli crackdown on Palestinians in the West Bank. These TV and e-mail images have fueled massive demonstrations across the Arab world, and in both Egypt and Bahrain protesters have been shot. Could this roiling Arab street actually topple a regime? No -- none of the Arab regimes are in any danger right now. But Arab regimes' surviving or not surviving is not the right question. The right question is how they will survive.

title: Barbados Bargains
description: The Sandy Lane resort on Barbados is taking up to 30 percent off regular summer rates for multiday stays through Oct. 31. Some extras are also included, under the Active Choice or Family Fun programs. A 10-night stay begins at $420 a night, based on double occupancy (versus $600 for a double room in summer). A five-night stay begins at $480 a night for two people. The extras under the Active Choice plan include a full American breakfast, a daily round of golf at the resort's 27-hole course and a spa treatment. The Family Fun program includes full breakfast, 50 percent off a connecting room for up to three children younger than 12, a spa treatment for the parents and four hours' baby sitting each night. Information: (866) 444-4080 or www.sandylane.com .

title: In Spain, Old Growths and New Beginnings
description: WE were on a vineyard-covered mountain, clawing our way up a dirt track in a Ford pickup. ''It's taken me two years to build these roads,'' Josep Lluis Prez, the owner of Clos Martinet, said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Andersen Trial in Phoenix Opens With Views of Fraud

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It was a momentum story that ran out of momentum.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: Guilty Plea In Landlady Death
description: A Westhampton man pleaded guilty yesterday in Suffolk County Court to fatally stabbing his 79-year-old landlady last August, the authorities said. The man, Wilfredo Velasquez, 28, acknowledged killing his landlady, Katrin Czaplick, after she tried to evict him, a spokesman for the Suffolk district attorney said. Mr. Velasquez, who pleaded guilty to second-degree murder, is scheduled to be sentenced on May 29 to 25 years to life in prison, the spokesman said. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: 4 Militants Die in Clashes With Allies Near Pakistan
description: American and Australian troops killed four suspected Taliban or Al Qaeda fighters along the Afghan frontier in the past two days, military officials said today, as hundreds of allied troops under United States command swept the border area near Pakistan.

title: Lindh Lawyers and Prosecutors Spar Over Secret Witness
description: Lawyers in the case of John Walker Lindh, the Californian caught in Afghanistan and accused of aiding al Qaeda, had a sharp dispute today over whether a secret government witness should be required to testify for the defense.

title: West Side Plan Envisions Jets And Olympics
description: While public attention is focused on rebuilding Lower Manhattan, and the city and state budgets are in crisis, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's administration is pressing forward with efforts to transform the far West Side of Manhattan with office towers, a new transit line and parks.

title: Mets Look to Minors to Fill the Line-up
description: The Mets needed a body, and fast. They had already lost last Wednesday when Al Leiter was forced to bat in the seventh inning of a tied game. Mike Piazza, Rey Ordonez and Timo Perez remained out with injuries Thursday and if that night's game was not rained out, the Mets planned on making a move.

title: Support City Parks
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Terayon Shares Drop On Forecast
description: Shares of Terayon Communications Systems, a large maker of cable modems, lost almost half their value yesterday after the company offered a disappointing second-quarter forecast. The shares closed down 51 percent, or $2.52, to $2.40. After the markets closed on Monday, Terayon, based in Santa Clara, Calif., posted a first-quarter loss of 21 cents a share. Analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial had expected a loss of 18 cents a share. Terayon also lowered its 2002 revenue forecast to $200 million to $250 million from $300 million to $320 million.

title: Corrections
description: The listing of winning numbers in some copies yesterday for the New York Take 5 lottery misstated one of the numbers drawn on Monday. They were 4, 5, 11, 19 (not 9) and 21.

title: An Abrupt Departure Is Seen as a Harbinger; Leadership Shake-Up Could Spread As WorldCom and Its Rivals Regroup
description: The abrupt departure of Bernard J. Ebbers from WorldCom came sooner than Wall Street expected, but long after many investors and analysts began viewing it as inevitable.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Farrakhan Barred
description: A court upheld the government's decision to bar Louis Farrakhan, leader of the Chicago-based Nation of Islam, from entering the country. Referring to Mr. Farrakhan's ''notorious opinions'' and to the uneasy state of race and religious relations in Britain since Sept. 11, the Court of Appeals overturned a lower court decision last year holding that there was no justification for the ban, which had been in effect since 1986. Mr. Farrakhan's lawyers, who say he has distanced himself from earlier comments praising Hitler and calling Judaism a ''gutter religion,'' said they would consider appealing. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: What's Green And Proud And Marches?
description: IF you have spent even a few minutes tracking the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, you've got an idea how toxic the fallout can be from that woebegone region. But who'd have imagined that it could drift to these shores and land on, of all groups, the Girl Scouts, that enduring symbol of duty, honor and cookies?

title: Panel Will Not Release Andersen Notes
description: Officials with the House Energy and Commerce Committee said today that they would not provide notes and other related records of interviews with David B. Duncan, the Arthur Andersen partner who orchestrated the widespread destruction of documents related to Enron, to lawyers for the firm.

title: Market Place; S.E.C. Queries Large Brokers On Research
description: Taking the first step in its broad investigation of possible conflicts of interest among stock analysts, the Securities and Exchange Commission has asked about a dozen Wall Street firms for detailed information about their research practices, people involved in the inquiry said today.

title: Broadcast Tower Is Urged for Governors I.
description: A 2,000-foot-tall tower with a restaurant and observation deck on top, modeled on the Space Needle in Seattle, is being pushed by television executives as a replacement for the broadcasting antenna that was lost when the World Trade Center towers fell, broadcasting executives say.

title: Partisan Fight On Job Losses Casts Shadow On Trade Bill
description: The Senate prepared today to take up legislation that would give President Bush added power to negotiate trade deals, with passage complicated by a partisan dispute over how to help workers who lose their jobs to international competition.

title: Key Republican Backs Cloning in Research
description: With the Senate split over whether to ban human cloning for medical research, an influential Republican, Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, broke with President Bush today to join Democrats in supporting the science.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Industrial Strikes Set
description: Setting the stage for what could be the first serious strike Germany has had in seven years, members of the metal workers' union voted to begin a series of strikes on Monday in Berlin and in the state of Baden-Wrttemberg, which is home to DaimlerChrysler, Porsche and a big part of the country's equipment manufacturers. The union, IG Metall, which represents 2.7 million workers, is demanding annual wage increases of more than 4 percent. Employers have refused, and bargaining broke down last week. Economists have warned that a generous wage settlement will slow German economic growth, which is already the lowest in Europe. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: Some Can Never Be Too Rich or Too Fat
description: Some American butter makers are turning out richer butters, with more butterfat than the federal minimum of 80 percent. This is good news for serious home bakers because more fat means less moisture, making pastry easier to handle and yielding better results. Even in clarifying lower-moisture butter for cooking there is less residue to skim off.

title: And Kidd Can Also Play Some Defense
description: Playing with a gritty resolve in the less glamorous realm of defense, Jason Kidd led the Nets to a regular season of unprecedented success. Today, he earned a little glamour in the process.

title: Study Finds New Drugs May Carry Extra Hazards
description: Serious adverse effects from drugs often do not show up until after the drugs are marketed, researchers report today in an article that urges doctors to avoid prescribing new medicines if older, better-known ones are available.

title: MSNBC Picks News Veteran As Top Editor
description: Jerry Nachman, the outspoken media figure who once ran the newsroom at The New York Post, has been hired as the editor in chief of MSNBC, where he will also be host of his own late-afternoon talk show.

title: Corrections
description: The Home Video column in Weekend on Friday, about cult films, misstated the given name of the director of ''Canadian Bacon.'' He is Michael Moore, not Roger.

title: Church Basketball Director Leaves After Abuse Charge
description: The director of the Riverside Church youth basketball program, the prestigious proving ground for dozens of professional players, has left his job amid accusations that he sexually abused a teenage player nearly 20 years ago.

title: INSIDE
description: New U.S.-North Korea Talks

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: London Synagogue Attacked
description: Vandals ransacked a synagogue in northern London, smashing windows, stamping on an Israeli flag, splattering green paint over the ark, where the Torah is kept, tearing up prayer books and painting a swastika on the rabbi's lectern under the Star of David. The attack at the Finsbury Park Synagogue late Saturday shocked members, many of whom are elderly Holocaust survivors, and startled a country that has been largely immune to the sort of anti-Jewish vandalism that has been taking place in France. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Faraway School Close to Mount Vernon Woman
description: Vivian Ayers lives in Mount Vernon, N.Y., but closest to her heart is a boarding school nearly 700 miles away, here in South Carolina.

title: Saluting Spectacles Of the Past
description: History comes wrapped in modernity in ''Xtravaganza,'' an ambitious multimedia valentine to creators of show-business spectacles who dreamed big and sometimes died broke.

title: Corrections
description: A biographical sketch on Sunday about a World Trade Center victim, Gerald Thomas O'Leary, 34, a sous-chef at Cantor Fitzgerald whose own father had died at 34, misstated his relationship with his grandfather. His grandfather was his role model, but did not rear him after his father's death.

title: Diversity Comes to a Place With a Retail Pedigree
description: The advertising agency Foote, Cone & Belding has agreed to lease 270,000 square feet at 100 West 33rd Street, completing the conversion of the century-old building from an unsuccessful vertical mall to one that will have a mix of office, retail and showroom tenants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODY, ALEXANDER
description: BRODY-Alexander, 90, Optometrist on April 28. U.S. Army Air Forces, W.W. II. Survived by wife, Claire; daughters Jessica Perlmutter, Laurie Brody, Naomi Kaplan; granddaughters Anna, Lily, and Sophie Perlmutter; Katherine Brody; and Leah, Emily, and Eva Kaplan; sister Belle; brothers, Joseph and Samuel. Memorial Service June 9th. Donations to The Center for Hospice Care, Milbourne, NJ or Cancer Care, NY.

title: Pakistan's Dubious Referendum
description: To no one's surprise, Gen. Pervez Musharraf almost certainly won a rigged referendum in Pakistan yesterday awarding him another five years as president. Even less surprising, the general's aides proclaimed the results a vote of confidence. But either out of indifference or protest, most Pakistanis declined to participate in an election that was preceded by curbs on dissent. The balloting has actually diminished General Musharraf's stature and he must now take aggressive steps to restore democracy with a vigorously contested parliamentary election, due in October.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Nominee For Bergen Prosecutor
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey has nominated a Hackensack lawyer, John L. Molinelli, as the next Bergen County prosecutor. The nomination, which was announced on Monday, requires confirmation by the State Senate. Mr. Molinelli, 44, practiced criminal law and was a prosecutor for the boroughs of East Rutherford and Carlstadt. If confirmed, he will succeed William H. Schmidt.

title: A Tricky Matter of Balance Of Standards and Exams
description: CRITICS of standardized tests lament that teachers are now being compelled to ''teach to the test.'' Most people are befuddled by this complaint. As President Bush said, if we are teaching math and reading, teaching to math and reading tests makes sense.

title: Cabinet's New Look at N.Y.U.
description: JOHN SEXTON, New York University's president-elect, announced further additions to his senior cabinet last week.

title: Figaro Outwits the Count, But Without a Single Aria
description: Theater's wiliest servant goes to Florida in a new translation of ''The Marriage of Figaro,'' the last play in the roster of the Jean Cocteau Repertory's season. To be sure Palm Beach has households much richer than the noble establishment of Count Almaviva, the lecherous lord of Beaumarchais's 1784 assault on social customs, judges and lawyers and much else in the French ancien rgime. But the noisy laughter aroused by this production might be regarded as too robust in the modern resort. Versailles was not as picky as we are.

title: Homes of Shame: Outrage, and Calls for Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Won't Recuse Herself or Cancel Psychiatric Exam for Defendant in Terror Case
description: The only person arrested so far on charges of conspiring in the Sept. 11 terror attacks has moved to dismiss the judge in his trial, accusing her of bias and a conflict of interest, according to court documents released today.

title: Vivendi Takes More Lumps As Shares Fall
description: Nervous about a continuing swirl of negative news surrounding Vivendi Universal, investors pummeled the stock today, pushing it down 7 percent at one point, to a five-year low. The stock later recovered somewhat to close at 35.39 euros ($31.99) a share in Paris, off 2.8 percent.

title: Homes of Shame: Outrage, and Calls for Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Landlord Gets 20 Years to Life in Killing of Tenant, 68
description: The landlord of an Upper East Side apartment building who was convicted of fatally shooting a tenant, then stepping over the dying woman to tend to his building's trash, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison yesterday, after mumbling to a judge that he was ''sorry about what happened that day.''

title: An Abrupt Departure Is Seen as a Harbinger
description: The abrupt departure of Bernard J. Ebbers from WorldCom came sooner than Wall Street expected, but long after many investors and analysts began viewing it as inevitable.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Talks Continue
description: France Tlcom is continuing to negotiate with several banks interested in buying a 48 percent stake in MobilCom from Gerhard F. Schmid, the company's founder, people close to the companies said. Other possibilities are also under consideration, including a bid for all of the wireless company, which has 5.7 billion euros of debt, by Orange, France Tlcom's wireless subsidiary. Orange already owns 28 percent of MobilCom, which is based in Germany. But reaching a deal with a group of banks, including ABN Amro, Merrill Lynch, Deutsche Bank and Socit Gnrale, remains the priority, these people said. An agreement is likely within the next month, although there is still a possibility the talks could fall apart, in which case MobilCom would probably seek bankruptcy protection. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Do You Want Cheese Steak or Cheese Steak?
description: THE sign on the West Third Street facade of BB Sandwich Bar says ''Open.'' That's really all you need to know, because BB offers no menu. No options are available. You cannot choose ciabatta, onion compote, watercress or any other of the fancy signatures of sandwiches du jour. At BB Sandwich Bar, you have it their way, and I, for one, am very happy about that.

title: Hindu Party Wins in Critical Vote
description: After a marathon debate that ended in the wee hours this morning, the Hindu nationalist-led government defeated a motion to criticize it for failing to control Hindu mobs who have killed hundreds of Muslims in the western state of Gujarat over the past two months.

title: Merrill's Apology Fails To Cool Investors' Anger
description: A rare public apology from the chairman of Merrill Lynch & Company has not managed to defuse the anger of investors large and small over the conflicts of interest that they contend colored the advice of Merrill's stock analysts.

title: Leader of Islamic Charity Is Accused of Lying to Court
description: The Justice Department arrested the head of an Islamic charity in Illinois today and said there was extensive evidence that he and his organization had close ties to Osama bin Laden and had secretly funneled money to his terrorist network, Al Qaeda.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCLAVE, SCOTT
description: McCLAVE-Scott. On April 29, 2002, at age 41. He is survived by his wife Jane Novatt, his parents Bill and Mary Ben, his sister Lori, his brother Michael and his nieces and nephews. A loving, gentle soul who enriched all those who knew him. He lives on in our hearts. Services today, May 1, 12 noon at Campbell's, 1076 Madison Ave.

title: U.N. May Drop Inquiry at Jenin As Israel Resists
description: Israel challenged the United Nations today by once again blocking a proposed fact-finding mission to examine fighting earlier this month in the Jenin refugee camp, prompting Secretary General Kofi Annan to consider disbanding the investigative team.

title: Chrysler Signs Deal With Martha Stewart
description: The Chrysler Group in Auburn Hills, Mich., a division of DaimlerChrysler, and Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia in New York said yesterday that they had signed a multimillion-dollar marketing agreement. As part of the deal, Chrysler products will be advertised in Martha Stewart's media properties, including her magazine, television and radio shows, and Web site.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Pact On Crime And Terrorism
description: The presidents of Turkey, Georgia and Azerbaijan, three neighbors with concerns about drug trafficking and domestic and international terrorism, signed a security agreement to increase cooperation against terrorists and organized crime and improve security for the planned Baku-Ceyhan oil pipeline from Azerbaijan to Turkey. The agreement, which marks a new level of cooperation between the countries, was signed in the Turkish Black Sea port of Trabzon. Douglas Frantz (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUCAS, ELEANOR H.
description: LUCAS-Eleanor H. On April 30, 2002. Loving mother of Nora Lucas and Tony Weiner. Ecstatic grandmother of Molly. Dear sister of Josephine Hogan. Visiting Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc. in Larchmont. Mass Friday, 10:30am, at Sts. John & Paul Church in Larchmont. Interment is private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGAL, MARVIN
description: SEGAL-Marvin. Age 78, of Long Beach, NY, on April 30. Beloved and devoted husband of Doris. Cherished and adored father of Scott and Edan, and Danny and Wendy, and loving grandfather of Courtney and Jake. A man of great warmth, love, compassion and humor, with the desire to live life to its fullest. He will be greatly loved and missed by all who knew him. Services Thursday, May 2, 11 AM, Gutterman's Funeral Home, 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I. 516-764-9400.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIKER, MYRON
description: PIKER-Myron. Pike, your friendship, spirit, warmth, personal dignity and dedication, always to good causes, will be missed by all of us. We offer our condolences to Joan and the Piker family. Cecile and Jerry

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Rowland Vetoes Budget
description: Saying he wanted to ''save them from themselves,'' Gov. John G. Rowland criticized Democrats on Monday and vetoed a 2003 budget passed by Democratic majorities in the House and Senate. Mr. Rowland said the budget failed to reduce spending enough while imposing a tax on millionaires that he derided as ludicrous. The $13.5 billion budget plan would have imposed a two-year surcharge of 1 percent on the roughly 6,500 residents who earn more than $1 million a year. Democratic lawmakers said that with the current budget still $350 million in the red, it was only fair to target the wealthy. Mr. Rowland has not ruled out a tax increase, but said he would not begin to negotiate one until Democrats agreed to more spending cuts. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: High-Intensity Priorats Muscle Their Way In
description: THE wines of Priorat are not for the faint of heart. Tucked away in the mountains west of Barcelona, Priorat's tiny vineyards turn out some of the most powerful, intense wines in the world. A decade ago hardly anyone had heard of Priorat, much less sampled any of the wines. Today, Priorat is one of the world's hottest wine regions, and one of the most controversial.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Chechen Declared Dead
description: Russia's military said it had killed a second top rebel field commander in Chechnya, Shamil Basayev, less than a week after announcing the death of another leading fighter there, the Arab-born guerrilla Khattab. Chechen opposition leaders denied the claim. The Russian military has made claims about Mr. Basayev's death in the past. But he has managed to survive, even after an ambush in January 2000. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Recipe: Raspberry Hibiscus Sauce
description: Time: 5 minutes, plus chilling time

title: Classroom Overcrowding Takes a Back Seat to Repairs, Study Says
description: Although the New York City schools system received more funds for construction in recent years than ever before, it created fewer extra seats to relieve classroom overcrowding, using much of the money for repairs, according to a report from the Educational Priorities Panel, a coalition of 24 civic organizations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, SIDNEY
description: BERNSTEIN-Sidney. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of a highly respected community leader, husband of Ethel and father of Richard (and Amelia) Bernstein, YU Guardians and Barry (and Betsy) Bernstein. Heartfelt condolences are extended to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Robert M. Beren, Chairman YU Board of Trustees

title: Yao Turns Heads Of Fans and Scouts
description: Chad Reeser sneaked around his school like a member of the paparazzi, hiding out in vacant stairwells, peering through the small square glass of the gymnasium door. Reeser, a 20-year-old student at Moody Bible Institute, was like the rest of the curiosity seekers who lined the corridors of this downtown private college. On the day of Yao Ming's first audition with the N.B.A., Reeser wanted to catch of glimpse of the 7-foot-5 center from China.

title: Fox to Announce Its Top N.F.L. Crew
description: Fox Sports is expected to announce tomorrow that Joe Buck, Cris Collinsworth and Troy Aikman will be its No. 1 N.F.L. announcing team. Collinsworth will shift from the Fox studio, and Aikman is moving up from the No. 2 announcing team after one season as an analyst.

title: Technology Briefing
description: SOFTWARE NAVISION CONSIDERS ALLIANCE The Danish software company Navision confirmed yesterday that it was considering a an alliance with an unidentified partner, but it declined to confirm reports about talks with Microsoft that had caused its shares to rise 21 percent. Navision, which specializes in customer relations software, has been successful in Europe but has failed to penetrate the American market. The Financial Times reported yesterday that Microsoft was negotiating to acquire Navision. A Microsoft spokeswoman, Erin Brewer, had no comment. (AP)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Nuclear Plant Closed
description: Russia's first nuclear power plant reactor, in the city of Obninsk, south of Moscow, was shut down yesterday, because, as Russian Mayak radio reported, its further operation became pointless. The radio station reported that the reactor had come to the end of its life after almost 50 years in operation. The power plant will now be turned into a museum, though the shutdown process will take up to four years. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Broker's Profit Is Up
description: Fiscal fourth-quarter profit at Nomura Holdings Inc. more than doubled as the brokerage firm, the biggest in Japan, sold 5,400 English pubs bought by the departing Guy Hands and captured investment-banking fees from its rivals. Net income in the period, which ended March 31, rose to 74.2 billion yen ($580 million) from 27.1 billion yen a year earlier. Mr. Hands, who quit as head of Nomura's principal finance group on April 1, helped the firm's trading profit jump 48 percent with the pub sales. Earnings per share in the quarter jumped to about 37.8 yen from 13.8 yen, according to Bloomberg calculations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COCHRAN, GRACE W.
description: COCHRAN-Grace W. Died April 28, 2002 in Morristown, New Jersey. Wife of the late Samuel Cochran, Jr. Mother of Samuel, 3rd and Peter Hale. Also survived by four grandchildren. Interment private. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Whitman Blasts McGreevey Over Criticism of Nominees
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey has set off a testy exchange with his predecessor, Christie Whitman, by accusing her of eroding the quality of the State Supreme Court by selecting justices based on their political credentials rather than judicial qualifications.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Google Gaining On Yahoo, Report Says
description: The research firm WebSideStory released a report yesterday indicating that Google was gaining market share among Internet search sites and could challenge the longtime leader, Yahoo. Of all search referrals worldwide, 36.35 percent come from Yahoo while 31.87 percent are from Google. In June 2000, Google generated 1 percent of search referrals, while Yahoo had about 46 percent. The study was conducted by the StatMarket unit of WebSideStory. The firm said the next most-used service was MSN, which fielded 12.73 percent of requests. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: There's Deceit, And Then There's Deceit
description: When Woody Allen's newest movie, ''Hollywood Ending,'' is spitting one-liners, the picture has the gone-delirious feel of Theolonious Monk crunching notes, a wired, jazzy rhythm specific to this comic. Once the energy from the jokes dies down, we're left with a project so stale you feel like opening a window to let some air in.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Empire Builder

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VON EUEN, HANS H.
description: von EUEN-Hans H. Criminologist, 88, dies. Born December 21, 1913, Berlin, Germany. Doctors of Jurisprudence, Psychology and Political Science. W.W. II US Army veteran awarded Bronze Star. During Cold War served U.S. Government as consultant and patriot. Died at home in Oregon March 23, 2002. Survived by Jessica, wife of 55 years, sons John and Peter, four grandsons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIGGOTT, RUBY MURIEL
description: PIGGOTT-Ruby Muriel. November 6, 1912-April 28, 2002. Beloved sister of Dorritt, and loving aunt of 5 nieces and 2 nephews from Canada. Also known as Aunt Ruby to many friends. Viewing Thursday 3:00-9:00, R.G. Ortiz Funeral Home, 2580 Grand Concourse, Bronx. Service at 7:00 PM. Funeral Friday 9:30 AM. Interment at Rosehills Memorial Park, Putnam Valley.

title: 6 Colombian Rebels Indicted in '99 Killings
description: Six members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, the country's largest rebel group, were indicted today in connection with the killing of three Americans in 1999, Attorney General John Ashcroft announced.

title: No Authors, No Books
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STEINFELD, JULIAN S.
description: STEINFELD-Julian S. March 25, 1924 to May 1, 2001. In loving memory

title: Taking the Long View, The Present Is Epilogue
description: THE FUTURE OF THE PAST

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the reaction of a largely gay congregation in San Francisco to the abuse scandals in the Roman Catholic Church misstated the given name of the priest who addressed worshipers at Most Holy Redeemer. He is the Rev. Donal Godfrey, not Donald.

title: Piazza Announces Return With Authority
description: Manager Bobby Valentine began his pregame session with reporters today by offering the Mets' injury report. Mike Piazza's return was the good news, tempered by the lingering injury to Rey Ordez's left side.

title: 'Harry and Louise' Battle 'Harriet and Louis' in Ad Debate Over Cloning Research
description: Harry and Louise, the fictional couple who helped doom President Bill Clinton's health care plan, are back at their kitchen table.

title: Gordon R. Willey, 89, Archaeologist Who Broadened Studies
description: Dr. Gordon Randolph Willey, a Harvard archaeologist who broadened the study of vanished societies from the examination of the tombs of the elite to include the economic and social lives of ordinary people, died on Sunday in Cambridge, Mass. He was 89.

title: UAL Begins Search for Successor to Interim Chief Executive
description: UAL, the parent company of United Airlines, said yesterday that it was starting a search for a chief executive to succeed Jack Creighton, who took the post temporarily last October.

title: Report on Towers' Collapse Ends Mostly in Questions
description: When federal investigators began their study of the collapse of the twin towers in October, they planned to evaluate exactly how structural steel, floor supports, fireproofing and other building components gave way in a deadly sequence of failures after hijacked jets first rammed the towers and set them on fire.

title: North Korea Is Prepared To Negotiate, U.S. Reports
description: The Bush administration said today that North Korea, one of the three countries President Bush had identified as part of an ''axis of evil,'' was prepared to restart negotiations with the United States on a range of issues, apparently including its missile and nuclear weapons programs and the use of troops on the South Korean border.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Rebound At BASF
description: The German chemical producer BASF reported a surprising jump in profit during the first quarter as its top executive predicted that the economic outlook finally seems to be improving. Net income climbed to $502 million, 72 percent higher than in the first quarter of the prior year, as global prices for chemicals gradually began to recover and BASF reduced its costs. Perhaps more significant was the upbeat outlook for world markets provided by BASF's chairman, Jrgen Strube. Mr. Strube, who had slashed spending on research and marketing, said, ''the earnings trend has turned the corner,'' a reversal of the pessimism he had expressed previously. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: Downtown Dallas Project Mired in Disputes
description: Thomas O. Hicks fiddles with a gold ring with a big star on it, smiling only when he can change the subject from the controversies over the proposed 20-acre development next to the arena used by one of the sports franchises he owns to the fortunes of the teams themselves.

title: Airport Guards' Salary Plan Upsets Congress
description: Democratic congressmen complained today that the administration was proposing excessive salaries of $70,000 plus overtime for checkpoint guards under the new airport security system.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Orthodox Holy Thursday and Orthodox Good Friday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow and Friday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, LAWRENCE HOWARD
description: LEVY-Lawrence Howard, 42. Son of Phyllis & the late Eugene Levy. Beloved brother and uncle. Graveside services at New Montefiore Cemetery, Wellwood Avenue, Farmingdale, L.I. today 1 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSHEN, MORRIS
description: KIRSHEN-Morris. On April 27, 2002 at age 96. He is survived by his children Carl Kirshen and Judith Levine, daughter-in-law Marjorie Kirshen, grandchildren Bob and Jim Levine and Sarah Kirshen, and brothers Harry & Max Kirshen. He was very much loved and will be remembered for his intelligence, his humor, his wealth of knowledge matched only by his modesty, and above all, for the warmth and love that was apparent every time he smiled. A businessman and a scholar, he led a complete life that touched many people. A memorial service will be held Saturday, May 4, at 2 PM, the Ethical Culture Society of Bergen County, 687 Larch Avenue, Teaneck, NJ 07666.

title: Pettitte Relieved to Have Tendinitis
description: Andy Pettitte was relieved and resigned about his lingering left elbow injury. He was relieved that there is no structural damage, just tendinitis. He was resigned because he will not test the elbow for 10 days and may not pitch his next game for the Yankees for as much as a month.

title: Editors' Note; NEW TODAY -- WINES OF THE TIMES
description: A panel of four writers from the Dining section will debate and rate wines -- on a scale of one star (passable) to four stars (extraordinary) -- every other Wednesday, under the principle that four palates are better than one. The first challenge: the rugged reds from the Priorat region of Spain. (With a dish that complements these powerful wines.) PAGE F7

title: Crab Season: Broil 'Em!
description: A YEAR ago, at the start of soft-shell crab season, I made an unusually fortunate discovery in the usual way: accidentally. I had long been a fan of grilling soft-shell crabs, but mostly out of laziness. Soft-shell crabs are best sauted, not so much for the crust they develop -- most are more than a little crunchy naturally and retain their crunch no matter how you cook them -- but because cooking in a pan helps retain at least some of their flavorful juices.

title: Technology Briefing | Executive Pay: $1 And Options At Siebel
description: Siebel Systems, which makes business software, cut the salary of its chief executive, Thomas M. Siebel, to $1 last year from $2.5 million in 2000 as sales and earnings fell short of forecasts. Mr. Siebel did receive options to buy 7.95 million shares, a package valued at as much as $487 million over 10 years if the stock appreciates 10 percent a year, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. About half the options are worthless at today's share price. Shares of Siebel, based in San Mateo, Calif., fell 59 percent last year. Mr. Siebel received $174.6 million from exercising 3.07 million options last year.

title: Don't Shun Genetic Research, W.H.O. Advises Poor Lands
description: Despite their pressing, immediate health needs, developing countries should devote some time and money to keeping up with genetic research because of its promise in battling the diseases most important in the third world, the World Health Organization said in a report released yesterday.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: ILLINOIS: CALL FOR RESIGNATION The state attorney general said Gov. George Ryan, a fellow Republican, should consider resigning because a bribery scandal involving the governor's aides had caused an "extraordinary erosion of trust." The attorney general, Jim Ryan, the Republican nominee for governor, is the most prominent Republican yet to suggest that the governor, who is not related, should think about quitting. Governor Ryan, who is not seeking re-election, has said he will not consider resigning. He has not been accused in the scandal, which has led to 42 convictions. (AP)

title: Method May Transform Cells Without Cloning
description: A team of scientists from Norway and the United States say they are developing a technique that transforms one type of cell from the body into another type without using cloning or embryonic stem cells.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Past and Present

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: U.S. Resident Detained
description: A United States-based Chinese democracy advocate has been detained in southern China after sneaking into the country to investigate recent labor unrest, colleagues in the United States said. Yang Jianli, 38, was detained on Friday in Kunming, Yunnan Province. Mr. Yang, a Chinese citizen with permanent United States resident status, is president of the Boston-based Foundation for China in the 21st Century, which advocates democracy and the rule of law. A spokesman for the American Embassy in Beijing confirmed to The Associated Press that Mr. Yang had been detained and said diplomats were in contact with Chinese officials. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOOKER, CHARLES
description: LOOKER-Charles, 93. Died on April 26 after a long illness. Beloved father of Andrew N. and Thomas G., grandfather of Charles A., father-in-law of Tamsin B., husband of the late Jeanette Albert (died 1988), dear companion of Miriam Horowitz. Charles Looker was a member of the law firm, Proskauer, Rose, Goetz and Mendelsohn (now Proskauer Rose, LLP) for 72 years. He headed the Estates and Trusts Division and was a managing partner of the firm. Among his many charitable works, he was a life trustee of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies and, through the Kathryn and Gilbert Miller Fund, he helped establish the Miller Theater at Columbia University and Miller Health Care Institute for Performing Artists at Roosevelt Hospital. Private services.

title: Clearing the Polluted Sky
description: President Bush has called his Clear Skies initiative ''the most aggressive initiative in American history to cut power plant emissions.'' It is unfortunate that many environmentalists and some legislators have opposed this plan. It provides for a huge reduction in emissions and uses innovative strategies to fight air pollution.

title: A Dish That Takes a Punch, Using a Wine of a Different Color
description: FOR lunch one day in Priorat, I was served chicken with prunes, and with it I drank, of course, a Priorat red. It may seem that a wine with the heft of a Priorat would overpower the mildness of chicken. But, in fact, it struck the perfect balance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRONSTIEN, ANNIE (SILVERMAN)
description: BRONSTIEN-Annie (Silverman). So sudden, our dearest Annie, your life was a gift to us all. Wife, mom, stepmom and friend. Always a heart of gold, a woman of style, a treasured friend, and a colleague beyond measure. You were the sunshine that lit up a room, the quiet strength on whom we all could depend. A soldier to your general & the best mommy in the world. Annie, we remember your radiant smile, your endless energy and your zest for life. All of us who were touched by your love will hold you in our hearts forever. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Stephanie Silverman Dance Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PICCOZZI, JOHNNIE
description: PICCOZZI-Johnnie. 90. Of Miami Springs, FL passed away on April 24, 2002. Johnnie was a PGA teaching Pro and lifetime member. Johnnie's career spanned more than 25 years which included Head Pro at Island's End Country Club (1965-1990). Also the AssistantHead Pro at the Doral Country Club and an Instructor with the Jimmy Ballard Golf School. Johnnie's other notable achievements included a Broadway career as a Choreographer during the 1930's, Dance Instructor, Grocery Store Owner, Bayman and a WW II Naval Veteran and Good Person. Johnnie is survived by his sister, Edith Carbone of Venice, FL., children Jay, Sharon, Michael, Amy, Chris and 10 grandchildren, 2 great-grandchildren and his Dearest Friend Ena. A memorial service for Johnnie will be said at St. Agnes Parish on May 4th, at 10 a.m. In lieu of flowers, his family has requested donations be made in his name to: Vitas Hospice Charitable Fund, 100 South Biscayne Blvd, Suite 1500 Miami, FL 33131

title: Teenager Who Lured Deliveryman to His Death Pleads Guilty
description: The last of five Queens teenagers accused in the murder of a deliveryman for two bags of Chinese food pleaded guilty to robbery yesterday, in exchange for an expected sentence of 17 years in prison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NUGENT, COLONEL ROBERT E.
description: NUGENT-Colonel Robert E., of Holland, MI, on April 26, 2002. Devoted husband of Jacqueline Verbrugge for 47 years. Loving father of Greg, Chris and Carol. Grandfather of Alex and Elizabeth. Brother of Rev. John Nugent, CM; James, Eileen and Martha Ann. Born Brooklyn, NY. Loughlin Hall of Fame. Rutgers Hall of Fame. All American Swimming Team. 1948 AAU National Champion. NYAC Hall of Fame. Pilot U.S. Air Force Strategic Air Command. Head Swimming Coach Air Force Academy. Southeast Asia command pilot. 6000 hours flying, including 1000 combat hours. Highly decorated. Silver Star, 3 Bronze clusters, Vietnamese Cross of Galantry, and the Vietnam Campaign Medal and many others. Professor of Aerospace at Dennison University Tactical Air Command. A Civil Air Patrol scholarship established in Bob's name for the most deserving Cadet. Retired in 1983 to teaching and volunteer coaching. Bob touched countless lives as a role model and mentor helping guide the careers and lives of many successful military and civilian students, employees, co-workers, friends and acquaintances. He was a devoted husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle, friend and teacher who will be missed by many. Contributions in Bob's memory may be made to The Robert E. Nugent U.S.A.F. Academy Memorial Fund, c/o Macatawa Bank, PO Box 3119, Holland, MI 49422.

title: Roberts Rises to Occasion for Depleted Toronto
description: Halfway through their series with the Islanders, the Maple Leafs lost their captain and 41-goal scorer, Mats Sundin, to a broken wrist. On Monday, they discovered they would lose the valuable forward Shayne Corson to a suspension.

title: Bush Uses Familiar Themes On Stump in Silicon Valley
description: President Bush mixed policy and politics today in dot-com-busted Silicon Valley, delivering a speech that emphasized ''compassionate conservatism'' and raising $1.8 million for Bill Simon Jr., the Republican candidate for governor.

title: Senate Panel Criticizes Hospital Buying Groups
description: The business practices of the nation's two biggest groups that negotiate contracts for hospital products were sharply criticized today by lawmakers from both parties who threatened Congressional action if the companies did not reform themselves.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Uproar Over Underwear Check
description: Parents demanded the resignation of an official at a suburban San Diego high school after reports that she lifted girl's skirts in front of male students and faculty members, checking for inappropriate underwear before a dance on Friday. Students at Rancho Bernardo High School said the vice principal, Rita Wilson, was screening girls to make sure they were not wearing thong underwear.

title: Ex-Governor to Look Into Union Stock Deal
description: The board of Ullico, a union-owned insurance company, has named James R. Thompson, the former Illinois governor, to investigate the private sale of company stock that resulted in big profits for its directors.

title: Low-Tech Alternatives
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLDCOM LEADER DEPARTS COMPANY IN TURBULENT TIME
description: Bernard J. Ebbers, who spent 19 years building WorldCom into one of the biggest long-distance companies and Internet carriers in the world, has resigned as chief executive, president and director, the company said yesterday.

title: China's Communists Try to Decide What They Stand For
description: Over dinner at a crowded restaurant in central Beijing, a longstanding Communist Party member who works for the government spoke words that would have been unfit for public consumption just a few years ago.

title: Ft.com Adopts Fee System
description: The Financial Times said yesterday that it plans to start a three-tier system of access to its Web site, ft.com., charging up to $300 a year for in-depth examinations of industries or countries and other specialty services while leaving most of its daily newspaper accessible at no charge. Part of the popular Lex column will remain free, but most of it will be reserved for subscribers who can pay annual fees of either $110 or $300, depending on the level of services and archival access.

title: Homes of Shame: Outrage, and Calls for Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: A Lawyer's Religion
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Rules Against U.S. On Material-Witness Law
description: A federal judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday that the government may not use a law that allows detention of material witnesses to hold people for grand jury investigations, a decision that if upheld could curtail a major investigative tool used by law enforcement since the Sept. 11 terror attacks.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Music Stops In Protest
description: More than 25 online sites will stop broadcasting music this morning until late in the day to protest legislation that imposes royalties on music played on the Internet. The sites, led by Radio and Internet Newsletter in Chicago, oppose a 1998 law, passed with the Digital Millennium Copyright Act, that will permit record labels to charge for music played online. Previously, radio stations paid royalties only to composers. Congress ordered the creation of a fee structure, which will start on May 22, to offset the threat of digital copies of songs being created by capturing online music. The broadcasters worry that the rates, 14 cents a song per listener, with an annual minimum of $500, will harm the online stations and threaten listener privacy. John Biggs (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the editor of The New Yorker, David Remnick, misstated the role of a predecessor, Tina Brown, in developing the magazine's table of contents. She expanded it; she did not start it. A version existed from 1928, originally called ''Departments in This Issue.''

title: Patients, Not Numbers
description: Though House Republicans said last week that they are drafting legislation to increase Medicare payments to doctors, there is no guarantee that the recent cuts in these payments will be reversed, or even mitigated. Many doctors say they will drop Medicare patients because they can't afford to absorb the cuts -- set to reach 17 percent over three years -- even as their expenses go up. These cuts also reduce their income from private managed care health plans, which adjust their reimbursements according to Medicare fees.

title: Parents Outraged at Official Who Checked Girls' Underwear
description: LOS ANGELES, April 30  Parents demanded the resignation of an official at a suburban San Diego high school today after reports that she lifted girl's skirts in front of male students and faculty members, checking for inappropriate underwear before a dance on Friday.

title: Telescope Opens Window on Dawn of the Universe
description: Using its new main camera, the rejuvenated Hubble Space Telescope has produced a stunning set of images of dynamic processes in the far reaches of the universe, scientists said today.

title: Hispanics Still Backing Catholic Leaders, for Now
description: The ladies of the Guadalupe Society of St. Frances of Rome church had finished serving tamales and tripe soup at their communion breakfast last Sunday when they heard the protesters arrive.

title: City's Tax Collections Weaken, but Bloomberg Says His Budget Can Handle It
description: New York City's tax collections came in weaker than expected for the month of April, but Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the problem did not appear to be so grave that it threatened to throw his budget plan seriously out of kilter.

title: Our Towns; Their Right? To Remain Silenced
description: The immigration clerk was standing behind thick glass, but she sounded as if she were speaking from the other side of the Looking Glass: ''If I did know, I couldn't tell you. The people who know won't tell you.''

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Pop and Jazz Guide column of Weekend on Friday about Masters of Groove, who performed at the Jazz Standard last week, misstated the instrument played by Pee Wee Ellis. It is the saxophone, not the trombone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, ANNIE BRONSTEIN
description: SILVERMAN-Annie Bronstein. The Metropolitan Montessori School community is deeply saddened by the loss of Annie Bronstein Silverman. Annie will be remembered for her wonderful smile, generous heart and her immense capacity to love. Our sympathies to her husband, Larry; her son, Micky; and all other members of the family that was so important to her.

title: Giants Are Promoting Reese To Player Personnel Director
description: Marv Sunderland, the Giants' director of player personnel, is stepping aside and will be replaced by Jerry Reese, who is one of the first African-Americans to ascend to the job in the National Football League.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: Human Rights Worker Slain
description: The Nobel Peace Prize winner Rigoberta Mench condemned the killing of an accountant working for her foundation, which is pursuing genocide cases against current and former government officials. The police said Guillermo Ovalle was shot dead on Monday by one of three heavily armed men, apparently during a robbery at a small cafeteria. But an official with the Rigoberta Mench Foundation said that 10 minutes before the shooting the group's office received telephone calls in which someone played a recording of a funeral march. In recent weeks, forensic anthropologists working on identifying the remains of massacre victims from the 1960-96 civil war have been subjected to death threats. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Jeb Bush Weeps as Drug Remarks Turn Personal
description: Gov. Jeb Bush cried today at a drug conference as he thanked audience members for their support while he and his wife dealt with the drug-related arrest of their daughter.

title: PROFIT AT BP, HURT BY LOWER ENERGY PRICES, IS OFF 69%
description: BP reported a 69 percent decline in first-quarter profit yesterday, stung by lower energy prices and slowing demand. BP earned $924 million, or 7 cents a share, excluding one-time charges, in the quarter, compared with $3 billion, or 17 cents a share, a year earlier. Output rose 0.8 percent in the first quarter, far less than the 5.5 percent target that BP had set for all of 2002. The slow start is causing some analysts to question whether BP can meet its goal, which is slightly higher than that set by its rivals. Lord Browne, BP's chief executive, said the company remained confident of meeting its target and expected production to increase significantly in the second half of the year. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: A Town Reels When Son of Slinky Takes Revenge
description: Perhaps the most gripping thing about the ultimately disappointing Japanese horror film ''Uzumaki'' is the patient way the picture develops mood.

title: DYNEGY GETS $900 MILLION CREDIT LINE
description: Dynegy Inc., the energy and pipeline company, posted a first-quarter loss of $140 million, but said it had obtained $900 million in credit to protect its energy trading business. The credit agreement gives Dynegy $1.4 billion in available cash and credit, the chief executive, Chuck Watson, said. Shares of Dynegy rose $4.15, to $18 a share. Dynegy said revenue declined 37 percent as it wrote off start-up costs at its telecommunications business and prices fell for natural gas and electricity. The credit agreement was significant because it might persuade Moody's Investors Service not to lower Dynegy's credit rating, a move that would raise its cost of operations.

title: Study Hints at Mass Killing of the Taliban
description: A tangle of abandoned clothes, half-covered in sand, lies just off the desert track. Pieces of white bone are strewn among the mess and the smell of decaying bodies drifts over the site.

title: Wide Racial Disparities Found in Costs of Mortgages
description: A far greater share of black and Hispanic homeowners with above-average incomes still have mortgages with higher interest rates than whites with comparable incomes, according to a study to be released today. The research suggests that conventional banks, despite recent progress, have failed to reach many minority borrowers who would qualify for good mortgages based on their salary and credit history, housing experts said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROZETT, CYNTHIA
description: ROZETT-Cynthia. It is with great sorrow that the Board of Trustees, League, Administration and Staff of Parker Jewish Institute for Health Care and Rehabilitation mourn the passing of Cynthia Rozett, past President of Parker League & member of the Parker Board of Trustees. Cynthia was an exceptional leader and innovator whose tireless efforts and progressive vision helped build a dynamic volunteer force and support a myriad of health care programs that now serve thousands of older adults each year. A loving wife, mother and grandmother, Cynthia will be forever remembered for her kindness and generosity. Services May 1 at 11:30 AM, Schwartz Bros., 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, NY. Barbara N. Kurshan, Chair, Parker Board of Trustees, Barry T. Zeman, President, Parker Jewish Institute for Health Care & Rehabilitation Florence Spencer, Suzanne Sussman, Lillian Wilner; Co-Presidents, Parker League

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the reaction of a largely gay congregation in San Francisco to the abuse scandals in the Roman Catholic Church misstated the given name of the priest who addressed worshipers at Most Holy Redeemer. He is the Rev. Donal Godfrey, not Donald.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WADE, CLINT
description: WADE-Clint. A public relations professional since 1954, died April 27, 2002, following a stroke. He lived in Manhattan and Roxbury, CT. During his career, he worked for United Press International, advised the presidential campaign of Tennessee Sen. Estes Kefauver, and was a consultant and friend to many national business leaders, including trading-stamp and hospitality and travel magnate Curtis L. Carlson and family. A lover of Manhattan life, Mr. Wade used to joke, ''You're not gone until the New York Times says you're gone.'' This is for you, Clint. Mr. Wade was born in Cornelia, GA, on August 4, 1925. He is survived by his sister-in-law, Helen Wade, and nephews and nieces Jim Wade, Craig Crenshaw, Beth Farrell, David Crenshaw, Bill Crenshaw, Karin Combs, John Baker and Julie Baker. A funeral Mass will be held at 2PM, Wednesday, May 1, at St. John the Evangelist Church, 348 E. 55 St., NYC. After the service, family and friends will meet from 3-7 PM at Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 352 E. 87 St. A funeral Mass also will be held at 11AM, Thursday, May 2, at St. Patrick's Church, Roxbury, CT. Burial will be at St. Patrick's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Patrick's Church.

title: Second Acts: Jay Gatsby's Self-Invention, Reinvented
description: The Metropolitan Opera commissioned John Harbison's opera ''The Great Gatsby'' to celebrate the 25th anniversary of James Levine's company debut. Naturally, Mr. Levine, who conducted the premiere in December 1999, has strong attachments to the work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, NETTIE
description: GROSSMAN-Nettie. Age 80, passed away on April 29, 2002. Devoted wife of Murray for fifty years, sister of David, survived by nieces, Karen and Abby, and grand nephew, Jesse, and grand nieces, Sonja.

title: Corrections
description: A biographical sketch on Sunday about a World Trade Center victim, Gerald Thomas O'Leary, 34, a sous-chef at Cantor Fitzgerald whose own father had died at 34, misstated his relationship with his grandfather. His grandfather was his role model, but did not rear him after his father's death.

title: Recipe: Brewed Hibiscus
description: Time: 35 minutes

title: Edison Schools' Stock Halts Dive
description: Shares of Edison Schools, the nation's largest for-profit operator of public schools, halted a weeklong slide yesterday that had eroded more than half the stock's value.

title: The Fall of a Telecom Gunslinger
description: The ultimate deal maker has been dealt away. Under pressure from his board of directors, Bernard Ebbers, perhaps the most celebrated telecom entrepreneur of the last quarter century, has resigned as chief executive of WorldCom, the beleaguered communications empire he stitched together with more than 75 acquisitions. The abrupt departure of Mr. Ebbers, first reported in yesterday's Wall Street Journal, provides a fitting exclamation mark to the meltdown of the nation's telecom sector, which has cost shareholders a staggering $2 trillion.

title: Cabbies Entitled to Hearings, Judge Rules
description: A federal judge in Brooklyn has ruled that the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission must give cabdrivers a chance to defend themselves before it can revoke their licenses for illegally refusing to pick up people who hail them.

title: Coomer's Homer Helps Yankees Belt a Nemesis
description: With a curveball that seems to tumble down from the upper deck, a leg kick that rivals Orlando Hernndez's and a flaky, imperturbable personality that would make the zaniest left-handed pitcher beam, Barry Zito has always provided a stubborn challenge for the Yankees.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: HARTFORD: ROWLAND VETOES BUDGET Saying he wanted to "save them from themselves," Gov. John G. Rowland criticized Democrats on Monday and vetoed a 2003 budget passed by Democratic majorities in the House and Senate. Mr. Rowland said the budget failed to reduce spending enough while imposing a tax on millionaires that he derided as ludicrous. The $13.5 billion budget plan would have imposed a two-year surcharge of 1 percent on the roughly 6,500 residents who earn more than $1 million a year. Democratic lawmakers said that with the current budget still $350 million in the red, it was only fair to target the wealthy. Mr. Rowland has not ruled out a tax increase, but said he would not begin to negotiate one until Democrats agreed to more spending cuts.

title: A. J. Levinson Is Dead at 73; Was Advocate for Living Wills
description: A. J. Levinson, who pressed a national campaign to improve what she called ''the quality of death'' by promoting living wills, and who educated both professionals and the public on ways to bring dignity to dying, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 73.

title: Senator and Father In Corruption Case
description: State Senator Guy J. Velella of the Bronx and his father have been indicted on charges of helping a company win contracts with state agencies in return for cash, law enforcement officials and people close to the senator say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, AARON
description: GREEN-Aaron. With deep sorrow The Kramer Family mourns the passing of our beloved cousin. May Mildred, her children and grandchildren derive solace from Aaron's legacy of Ahavas Eretz Yisroel and Ahavas Habrios. Kramer Family Reunion Comm.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: MORE WATER RESTRICTIONS POSSIBLE Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that unless the city's upstate reservoirs received 15 more inches of rain over the next several weeks, the city might turn to a Stage 2 drought emergency, up one level from the one now in place. While the state is still analyzing the effects of the weekend's downpour, water shortages are almost certain next year, the mayor said. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Special Suffix For Tribes
description: Federally recognized American Indian tribes will be eligible for a special domain name suffix that identifies the tribe as a government entity, the Department of the Interior and the General Services Administration say. Until the change, sites for Indian tribes ended in nsn.us. A tribe's domain name suffix will now include the .gov designation. The Hopi tribe's new domain name, for example, will be www.hopi-nsn.gov. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: This Dynasty Stuff
description: Former President Bush swats away talk about what he dismissively calls ''this dynasty stuff'' or ''this legacy crud.''

title: Top Executive at ABC Television Leaves After One Year in the Job
description: After what numerous executives described as a long period of uncertainty and even dysfunction at the highest management level of ABC, the network announced yesterday that Steven M. Bornstein was stepping down as president of ABC Television, the top executive position at the company.

title: WorldCom Leader Departs Company in Turbulent Time
description: Bernard J. Ebbers, who spent 19 years building WorldCom into one of the biggest long-distance companies and Internet carriers in the world, has resigned as chief executive, president and director, the company said yesterday.

title: Former Mariners Now Star for Other Teams
description: It was the top of the hour in the Yankees' clubhouse on Saturday, time for the lead story on SportsCenter. The cluster of players who had arrived before the team bus gathered on and around the sofas in the visitors clubhouse at Safeco Field. Whoever said baseball players don't care about baseball should have watched this scene.

title: Suit Against Hewlett Deal Is Dismissed
description: The fight over the future of Hewlett-Packard -- one of the most costly and acrimonious proxy contests in corporate history -- appeared to have all but ended yesterday, after a Delaware court dismissed a suit by Walter B. Hewlett.

title: Pinkies Up And Pass the Butter
description: In 1910, the Viennese architect Josef Hoffmann designed a set of corn holders in sterling silver. Reproductions of them could become this season's special wedding gift. (After all, who needs three blenders?) The set is available, for $280, only at the gift shop of the Neue Galerie, the museum of Austrian and German art at 1048 Fifth Avenue (86th Street; 212-628-6200). The shop also has a bridal registry with some Viennese reproduction dinnerware, flatware, crystal and table linens. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LESHAN, EDA
description: LeSHAN-Eda. A Memorial Service will be held May 4, 2002 at 3 PM at The New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th St.

title: Gore on Climate Change
description: To the Editor:

title: Grand Jury Indicts Former N.B.A. Star in Fatal Shooting
description: Jayson Williams, the former New Jersey Nets star, was indicted by a grand jury in Hunterdon County today on charges that he fatally shot a limousine driver at his house in February then tried to mislead investigators by making the death appear to be a suicide.

title: Miami 5-Year-Old Missing For Year Before Fact Noted
description: State and local officials are looking for a 5-year-old girl who was supposed to be in state custody but who no one noticed until last week had been missing for more than a year.

title: Top Pakistani Wins a Ballot; Few Surprised
description: Here in the North-West Frontier Province, the vote for President Pervez Musharraf is, Yes! It's yes in Punjab. Yes in Sindh. Yes in Baluchistan.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Bridgeport: Assistant Pastor Resigns
description: The Rev. Alfred J. Bietighofer, assistant pastor at St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Parish, abruptly resigned late Monday, a day after allegations came to light that he had groped four men when they were minors in the late 1970's and early 80's. Father Bietighofer, 64, left the church with the Bridgeport Diocese's consent after The Connecticut Post first reported the men's accusations on Sunday. At the time of the reported abuse, Father Bietighofer was assigned to Blessed Sacrament Church in Bridgeport. The resignation came two days after the Rev. William D. Donovan, pastor of Holy Family Parish in Fairfield, resigned amid allegations of sexual misconduct. Bishop William E. Lori has defrocked both priests, a church official said. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Your Coat or Your Ear

title: Investigators Breach Security In 4 U.S. Buildings in Atlanta
description: Congressional investigators said today that they had forged identity badges and easily breached the security of four federal buildings here, and they warned that many other government buildings were wide open to terrorists who used similar methods.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULD, ROGER V.
description: GOULD-Roger V. April 29, 2002. Husband of Erin Graves, son of Lois and Robert; brother of Tony. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Saturday, May 4, 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in his name to People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals.

title: Officials Examine Conditions In Homes for the Mentally Ill
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn and Manhattan said yesterday that their offices were investigating adult homes for the mentally ill in New York City to determine whether poor conditions in the homes resulted from criminal conduct by their operators and health care providers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SARNOFF, RICHARD ALAN
description: SARNOFF-Richard Alan. A new Spring, another birthday without you. It is incomprehensible-you who had so much to give are no longer here. We yearn for you. Mother, Dad, Stuart.

title: Hynix's Board Leaves Micron at the Altar
description: In startling defiance of the company's creditors, its own management and the South Korean government, the board of Hynix Semiconductor voted unanimously today to reject a takeover of most of its assets by Micron Technology, saying the price was too low. The board said it was determined to keep Hynix alive on its own.

title: Ex-Officer Admits to Day of Drinking But Denies He Was Drunk at Wheel
description: Joseph Gray, the former police officer on trial for manslaughter, testified yesterday that he drank up to 12 beers but was not drunk when his minivan plowed into a pregnant woman and her family last August as they walked home from a shopping trip in Brooklyn.

title: Torunn A. Garin, 54, Noted Food Engineer
description: Torunn Atteraas Garin, a chemical engineer who worked on notable food projects, died last Friday at her home in Bronxville, N.Y. She was 54 and also had a home on Tortola, in the British Virgin Islands.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: Doctor's Medal To Be Revoked
description: A doctor who worked at a Vienna clinic where nearly 800 mentally and physically handicapped children were experimented upon and put to death during the Nazi period will be stripped of a state medal given to him years after the war, the government announced. Heinrich Gross, 86, made a postwar career as a neurologist, for which he was given the award, using the brains of the dead children. It was only in 1997, after journalists described the source of his medical library, that Dr. Gross was charged with multiple infanticide. Last year he was declared unfit to stand trial because of dementia.

title: Homes of Shame: Outrage, and Calls for Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Top Executive Says He Is Leaving Sun Microsystems
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 1 — Edward J. Zander, the gregarious executive who oversaw daily operations at the troubled computer maker Sun Microsystems , plans to retire on July 1, the company said today.

title: Well, They Sure Learned Their Lesson, Didn't They?
description: ''Heloise and Abelard,'' the new opera by Stephen Paulus and Frank Corsaro presented by the Juilliard Opera Center at the Juilliard Theater last week, needed to be approached with care.

title: After Only A Month, 4 Managers Are Gone
