description: Major league managers probably will not want to pick the numbers 6, 15, 22 and 23 for the next Big Game lottery. Those were the numbers that turned out to be unlucky for four members of their clan, Tony Muser of Kansas City becoming the fourth yesterday.

title: After Arrest, Campus Queues for H.I.V. Tests
description: On the tiny campus of Si Tanka Huron University here, students like Wildmike Pata have a lot on their minds: home, finals, and H.I.V.

title: Same Stage, but Every Night's a New Show
description: VALUE shows up in the strangest places. At the famously expensive Alain Ducasse, where a three-course prix fixe dinner runs $160 and a cup of herbal tea is $12, an $18 cheese plate is a fabulous value. Each selection is perfectly ripe, and a serving is easily enough for two.

title: British to Hand Captives to Afghan Courts
description: British Royal Marines preparing for a joint operation against remnants of Al Qaeda and Taliban forces in eastern Afghanistan said today that they would not hand any prisoners directly into American custody but would turn them over initially to the Afghan government.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Economy Growing
description: Canada's gross domestic product rose 0.5 percent in February, Statistics Canada said, beating economists' forecasts of a 0.3 percent advance. The improvement was led by a 2.3 percent growth in manufacturing output, mostly reflecting a surge in the automotive sector. G.D.P. growth in January and February was up 4.8 percent at an annual rate from the fourth quarter of 2001, and economists expect the March figure to push first-quarter growth to more than 5 percent. Statistics Canada also said that industrial product prices posted their third consecutive monthly increase in March, with a 0.6 percent rise. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Audit Finds Medical Costs Too High for Nassau Jail
description: The average cost of medical care for jail prisoners in Nassau County is triple the amount paid in adjacent Suffolk and more than double the rate in Westchester, according to an audit released today by Nassau's comptroller.

title: INCREASED SALES LIFT PROCTER & GAMBLE'S PROFITS
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that its quarterly earnings rose 16 percent after it cut costs and increased sales of Crest electric toothbrushes and Tide detergent. Net income rose to $1.04 billion, or 74 cents a share, from $893 million, or 63 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. Sales rose 4.1 percent, to $9.9 billion, the biggest gain in two years. Revenue from health care products rose 11 percent, and sales of fabric and home-care products rose 2 percent, helped by new fragrances for Tide and Ariel detergent. Sales of beauty products rose 18 percent, aided by the $4.95 billion acquisition of the Clairol hair-products unit, which added an estimated $400 million to sales.

title: Homes of Shame: Outrage, and Calls for Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Tell Mom Lip Smacking Is Polite
description: Roses good enough to eat? These are. For Mother's Day or a wedding centerpiece, Franois Payard, far left with Craig Harzewski, arranges 24 cupcakes with buttercream blooms in a pot at Payard Ptisserie and Bistro, 1032 Lexington Avenue (73rd Street). The cupcakes are chocolate or vanilla and will keep for four days. A pot is $120; four or more, $100 each. A week's notice is needed; (212) 717-5252.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSS, EVELYN
description: MOSS-Evelyn. The Hillel family expresses its profound sympathy to Board of Directors Chairman Neil Moss on the loss of his beloved mother, Evelyn. Mrs. Moss was a devoted wife, mother and community volunteer. She is survived by sons Melvin and Neil; brother Morris Friedman; sister Jean Weiss; grandchildren Scott Andrew, Pamela Beth, Meredith, Katherine; & great-grandchildren Zoe Sophia and Drew Henry. May the Moss family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Edgar M. Bronfman, Chair Lynn Schusterman and Michael Steinhardt, Co-Chairs Richard M. Joel, President

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Kremlin's Man Wins Post Near Chechnya
description: A Kremlin-backed former secret police general has been elected president of the southern Russian republic of Ingushetia. Human rights advocates warned that Murat Zyazikov's unexpected victory in a runoff could destabilize the republic if, as the Kremlin would like, he seeks to force war refugees to return home to neighboring Chechnya. After the other candidate, Alikhan Amirkhanov, won the first-round vote, efforts were made to disqualify him with accusations of bribery and election law violations.

title: I.B.M. Chairman Lines Up A Book Deal for Himself
description: Louis V. Gerstner Jr., the chairman and former chief executive of I.B.M., has discreetly negotiated a deal to publish a book about his tenure at the company, and, unlike most executive-authors, he has already quietly written much of it by himself.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: INDUSTRIAL STRIKES SET Setting the stage for what could be the first serious strike Germany has had in seven years, members of the metal workers' union voted to begin a series of strikes on Monday in Berlin and in the state of Baden-Wurttemberg, which is home to DaimlerChrysler , Porsche and a big part of the country's equipment manufacturers. The union, IG Metall, which represents 2.7 million workers, is demanding annual wage increases of more than 4 percent. Employers have refused, and bargaining broke down last week. Economists have warned that a generous wage settlement will slow German economic growth, which is already the lowest in Europe. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: Leafs Send a Message And Send Isles Home
description: Maybe it was only an accident that Gary Roberts of the Toronto Maple Leafs crashed into goalie Chris Osgood of the Islanders last night and left him flat on his back for a few minutes of pain after Roberts tied the score in the first period. And it could have been another accident when Roberts -- undeterred by a black eye or blue Islanders jerseys around him -- rumbled through the crease a few minutes later, knocking over both Osgood and defenseman Roman Hamrlik, who limped off to the dressing room with a minor injury.

title: Sondheim Reprise Puts Music Ahead of the Journey
description: A bright and beckoning path cuts through the fairy-tale thicket of whimsy and woe that is ''Into the Woods,'' the musical by Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine that opened last night in a new revival at the Broadhurst Theater.

title: Hardtack Gets a Battlefield Promotion
description: The Army is always looking for ways to please its hungry troops. ''We keep a top-10 list of their requests, just like Letterman,'' said Jerry Darsch, the director of the Defense Department's combat feeding program in Natick, Mass. ''Heading the list was some kind of pocket sandwich, a nutritious snack that didn't need refrigeration to stay fresh for a long time,'' which, for the Army, means three years. The result: barbecued chicken, pepperoni or pizza-style sandwiches, 300 calories each, in plastic pouches. Sucrose esters keep moisture from causing spoilage, and proper acidity holds bacteria at bay. The pouch has a packet containing iron, which helps maintain freshness. How do the sandwiches taste? More than just edible: they are nicely seasoned.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Homicide Inquiry Urged
description: The City Council's Black and Hispanic Caucus called yesterday for a new investigation into a 1991 killing in which the only suspect tried was acquitted. The caucus called on the Police Department, the City Human Rights Commission and the state attorney general's office to open investigations into the beating death of Manuel Mayi Jr. Prosecutors say that Mr. Mayi, 18, a Dominican-American, was beaten to death with baseball bats by a group of Italian-American youths after he sprayed graffiti on the outside of an Italian restaurant. Mr. Mayi's friends and family have long pressed for a wider investigation of the case. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Conch Surprise: When Ceviche Is Not Quite Ceviche
description: YEARS ago, I spent some time fishing off Eleuthera, in the Bahamas. We'd fish in the early morning, before the sun got too high, and by 10 a.m. we'd be back ashore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISNER, ELLA
description: WEISNER-Ella. On April 30, 2002. Beloved mother of Alan, Gary and Philip & mother-in-law of Marilyn, Vivian and Mary Beth. Cherished grandmother of seven. Services on Wednesday at 9:45 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Theatrical Candle In a Shrine to Sept. 11; A Small Play Offers a Focus for Solace
description: The other night, Tim Robbins nearly lost it. He was onstage at the Flea Theater in Lower Manhattan, playing a grieving fire captain in ''The Guys,'' a two-character drama based on the events of Sept. 11, which occurred just a few blocks south of the little playhouse. He had come to an especially poignant moment, when the captain has to write a eulogy for one of his men, a beefy firehouse cutup named Barney.

title: Japan's Central Bank Paints A Brighter Economic Picture
description: Mirroring the growing view that Japan will emerge from recession later this year, the Bank of Japan upgraded its economic forecasts today in one of its twice-yearly reviews. But it gave no sign of abandoning its ultraloose monetary policy, with short-term interest rates effectively at zero.

title: Departure Turns Youthful Rhapsody Bittersweet
description: There was a flower shower on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall when the conductor Mischa Santora concluded his last concert as the music director of the New York Youth Symphony, a post he held for five years. Mr. Santora had just led the eager players in a confident and affecting performance of Brahms's ''German Requiem,'' with two fine soloists, the soprano Lauren Flanigan and the baritone Zheng Zhou, and a combined choir from the State University of New York at Buffalo and Queens College (directed by Harold Rosenbaum).

title: Red, Hot And Cool: It's Hibiscus
description: ''WOW! What is this?''

title: Staging 'Edward III,' by (They Think) Shakespeare
description: So well known are Shakespeare's English kings, from the tragic Lear and the pitiable Richard II to the evil Richard III and the heroic Henry V, that it is strange to discover an unfamiliar monarch. But now the Royal Shakespeare Company is staging here its first production of ''Edward III,'' written in the early 1590's and only recently recognized by scholars and publishers as the 39th play in the Shakespearean canon.

title: Surprisingly, the Euro Rallies, Raising Hopes of Further Gains
description: Is the euro turning? That is a question that currency analysts have been asking since the new currency was introduced in 1999. But if they have dared to say yes, they have been proven wrong.

title: The New Left, From Fiery to Fading
description: ''The Sorbonne should be razed, and Chris Marker put up in its place,'' the poet Henri Michaux is reported to have said, a remark that seems almost reasonable in light of ''A Grin Without a Cat,'' a fascinating 1977 documentary by Mr. Marker that opens today, in a restored and updated version, at the Film Forum in the South Village.

title: Petra Journal; A Fabled Place Forsaken, Contaminated by War
description: The Bedouins in these parts were once so reluctant to let foreign travelers explore the magnificent sandstone ruins of this fabled city that visitors came disguised as Arabs and dared not pause to sketch.

title: When Letter of the Law Does Not Spell 'Clarity'
description: The law of war is at once an oxymoron and highly developed. Various conventions and protocols lay out numerous rules for acceptable conduct in military operations. But applying them in densely populated towns like those on the West Bank can be difficult.

title: Technology Briefing | Executive Pay: $77 Million For E*Trade Chief
description: The E*Trade Group, the online brokerage firm, paid its chief executive, Christos M. Cotsakos, left, $77 million in 2001. The compensation included $29 million in restricted stock, a forgiven $15 million loan and $15 million for taxes after the loan was reclassified as compensation, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. E*Trade had a $241 million loss in 2001. Mr. Cotsakos received $797,880 in salary and a bonus of $4.1 million, compared with $756,346 in salary and a $1.4 million bonus in 2000. The company paid $2.4 million in taxes on stock that vested, and $279,678 in taxes on retirement contributions. He also gained $11 million by exercising stock options.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PULLANO, JOYCE, M.D.
description: PULLANO-Joyce, M.D. Friends & colleagues of Dr. Joyce Pullano, President of the Medical Board at New York Community Hospital of Brooklyn, mourn her passing. New York Presbyterian Health Care System Herbert Pardes, M.D., President & CEO Arthur Klein, M.D. Senior VP & COO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDNER, CHARLOTTE
description: LINDNER-Charlotte. On April 30, 2002. Dear mother of Carol & Bob Gelb, Greg & Linda Kaplan, Amy Kaplan and David Brauner. Cherished grandmother of Lev, Aaron, Lisa, Daniel, Sara, Jesse and great-grandmother of Ben and Jack. Dear companion of David Eckstein. Sister of the late Herbert Fisch. Services Thursday, May 2, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENNETT, MARTHA J.
description: BENNETT-Martha J. On April 27, 2002, after a long illness. Beloved wife of Charles & devoted mother of Sherryl Genone, grandmother and great-grandmother. Interment in Arlington National Cemetery, Thursday, May 16, 2002, 10 AM.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Watering Limits Relaxed
description: State water regulators yesterday temporarily lifted the ban on watering lawns to allow residents in most of South Jersey to water lawns with a hand-held nozzle on Tuesdays and Thursdays for odd-numbered addresses and on Wednesdays and Fridays for even. The new policy expires on June 28 but could be extended. Details of the order can be found at the State Department of Environmental Protection's Web site at www.njdrought.org/ao02-15.htm.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Signs Three Bills
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed three new bills into law yesterday. One, introduced at his request, raises the salary threshold for those who must file financial disclosure reports with the city's Conflicts of Interest Board. Another raises the purchase price of City Council chairs for retiring members. The last one, which lingered in the Council for years, strengthens human rights protections for the transgendered. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: To Close the Income Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Search for Sept. 11 Suspect Focuses on a Visit to Spain
description: Last July 9, an important Al Qaeda member arrived at a small airport near here on a tourist flight from Germany. Unlike millions of other foreigners who flock here to the Gold Coast in search of sun and fun, Ramzi Muhammad Abdullah bin al-Shibh slipped into a shadow world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, LINDA
description: BERNSTEIN-Linda. To Mother Pearl: Thank you for bringing Linda into this world and making it possible for me to share life with the girl of my dreams. She had it all, and she gave it all, everyday. I know your pain. May God bless and keep our little girl safe and warm enternally. Marshall

title: Ashcroft Pushes for Legislation to Ban Virtual Child Pornography
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  Attacking a recent Supreme Court decision as "a dangerous window of opportunity for child abusers," Attorney General John Ashcroft pushed today for new legislation that would ban computer-simulated pornography and withstand judicial scrutiny.

title: Spanish Notes From Underground
description: IN New York, it is not unusual to eat below street level. But Suba is something else. The descent to the dining room is a plunge into the netherworld, a series of twists and turns along a staircase made from industrial grating that delivers you, eventually, to a weirdly lighted windowless brick room. The platformlike dining area is surrounded by a moat of rushing water, illuminated to give off a fitful, flickering light.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: States' Attack On Microsoft May Be Hurt
description: A federal judge indicated today that she might not allow nine states challenging the Microsoft Corporation's antitrust settlement with the government to introduce evidence that their lawyer has said is a ''central part of our case.''

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: Deal For Lead-Tainted Properties
description: The Doe Run Company, the nation's largest lead smelter, must buy out 166 houses in Herculaneum, where half the children under 6 who live near the smelter have high levels of lead in their blood, under an agreement with the state. If the company fails to complete the buyout, it could be fined $1 million. As part of the agreement, the state will not force the company to alter the way it transports lead ore to the smelter. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Harlan's Holiday Slow In Final Derby Work
description: Maybe the pressure of being the much-maligned morning-line favorite is getting to Harlan's Holiday. Harlan's Holiday, an Ohio-bred, had his final Kentucky Derby workout today and pretty much fought with his regular rider, Edgar Prado, every step of the half-mile breeze.

title: NEW STRATEGY SET BY U.S. AND SAUDIS FOR MIDEAST CRISIS
description: President Bush and Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia, during private discussions over five days last week, agreed on a new strategy of joint action and pressure to break the deadlock in the Middle East crisis, American and Saudi officials said today.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: LONDON SYNAGOGUE ATTACKED Vandals ransacked a synagogue in northern London, smashing windows, stamping on an Israeli flag, splattering green paint over the ark, where the Torah is kept, tearing up prayer books and painting a swastika on the rabbi's lectern under the Star of David. The attack at the Finsbury Park Synagogue late Saturday shocked members, many of whom are elderly Holocaust survivors, and startled a country that has been largely immune to the sort of anti-Jewish vandalism that has been taking place in France. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Mother Is Held After Girl, 5, Is Found With Heroin
description: The mother of a 5-year-old girl sent alone on a commercial flight from Colombia to New York with more than two pounds of heroin hidden in the lining of her suitcase has been taken into custody in Colombia, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Civil Rights for the Transgendered
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg yesterday signed into law a bill that extends New York City's human rights protection to transgendered people -- a group that includes cross-dressers and people who have had or will soon have sex-change surgery. The new law, which passed the City Council 45 to 5, is an important step forward in fighting prejudice and in protecting the rights of some of society's most vulnerable citizens.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Murder Trial Moved
description: The suspended trial of four men charged with the kidnapping and murder of the Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl was moved today to Hyderabad from Karachi for security reasons, officials said. A third judge was selected for the case after the prosecutor, Raja Qureshi, said the previous judge could not guarantee his safety. No date has been set to resume the hearings. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Homes of Shame: Outrage, and Calls for Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Begins Taking Over Screening At Airports
description: The nation's first fully federalized team of airport security screeners, who officials promise are better trained, better motivated and kinder than those employed by private contractors, was put to work this morning, assuming duties at two of Baltimore Washington International Airport's five piers.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Union Chief Defeated
description: District Council 1707, a union that represents 30,000 workers in day care, home health care and Head Start programs, has elected a challenger, Raglan George Jr., its executive director. The American Arbitration Association, which conducted the vote on Monday, said that Mr. George received 2,966 votes to 1,871 for Josephine LeBeau, above, who has headed the council since 1994. Mr. George has been director of day care and Head Start for the council, which is part of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: American Adventure Begins For Johannesburg and Mate
description: A touch of mystery always makes the Kentucky Derby more interesting. This year's dose of intrigue is provided by Ireland's challengers, Johannesburg and Castle Gandolfo, who arrived at Blue Grass Airport tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORTEIG, GEORGE E.
description: ORTEIG-George E. On April 29, 2002. Beloved husband of Betty. Loving father of Elise Hunnicutt, Celeste Russell, George and Raymond Orteig. Caring grandfather of four granddaughters. Family may receive friends at the Bennett Funeral Home today 2-4 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be held Thursday 9:45AM at Immaculate Heart of Mary Church.

title: QWEST REPORTS EIGHTH CONSECUTIVE QUARTERLY LOSS
description: Qwest Communications International Inc. posted its eighth consecutive quarterly loss as sales fell. The first-quarter loss widened to $698 million, or 42 cents a share, from $46 million, or 3 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. Sales fell 14 percent, to $4.37 billion. Qwest, which has lost money since buying U S West Inc. almost two years ago, increased its debt by about $5 billion from a year ago amid a slowdown in corporate spending for phone and data services. The company is trying to sell assets to avoid defaulting on a $3.39 billion loan at year's end.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: COCA-COLA NAMES HEAD OF LATIN AMERICAN DIVISION
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that Steven J. Heyer, the president of its new-ventures division, would assume oversight of one of the company's most embattled economic markets: Latin America. While business in many other areas surged in the most recent quarter, Coke's sales in Latin America were listless, particularly in Brazil and Argentina. But perhaps more important, the management shift has intensified longstanding speculation that Mr. Heyer, 49, a rare company outsider who arrived last year from Turner Broadcasting, is being groomed as the successor to Douglas N. Daft, the chief executive. Greg Winter (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, MARY T.
description: SULLIVAN-Mary T. On April 29, 2002. Devoted wife of the late Daniel. Beloved mother of Mary Randall, Timothy, and Patricia Gall. Loving grandmother of Mary Kate, and Tim Randall, Meghan, Lauren, and Catherine Sullivan. Visiting Wednesday 7-9 P.M. and Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. McLaughin Funeral Home, Third Ave at 97th Street, Brklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 10:30 A.M. at Saint Ephrem Church.

title: You'll Never Find This Table Airing Dirty Linen
description: With a table like this, who would use a tablecloth? It is one of a kind, an Art Deco design by Lee Weitzman of Chicago, made in Canada of curly maple, with black and mother-of-pearl accents. The table seats six at Atelier, the restaurant in the new Ritz-Carlton on Central Park South. "We wanted this table to be the focus of the room, the power table," said Ronan Henaff, the manager of Atelier, which opens on Saturday. Tables without cloths are a fashion statement at some high-end restaurants. The Zenlike Kai uses only slate place mats. Shiny lacquer tabletops are bare at Opia. And Industry (Food) shows off its polished wood.

title: Consumer Confidence Slipped During April
description: Consumer confidence fell during April, a private research group reported today, as higher energy prices and a declining stock market tempered optimism about economic growth.

title: Boston Priest Eases Position on a Boycott
description: A priest who announced that his church would not participate in two major fund-raising campaigns for the Archdiocese of Boston said today that he did not intend to show a lack of support for archdiocese leaders, including the archbishop, Cardinal Bernard F. Law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCULLOCH, PATRICIA ROBINEAU
description: McCULLOCH-Patricia Robineau. On April 27. Loving wife of the late John I.B. McCulloch. Devoted mother of Jeanne, Darcy and Catherine. Beloved stepmother of Mary Elizabeth, Keith, Roderick and Scott. Beloved aunt of Richard, Frances, William and Timothy. Cherished grandmother of Samuel, Alexander, Charlotte, Harry, Alistair and Eloise, and 12 step-grandchildren, and seven step-great-grandchildren. Memorial service at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church on Friday, May 17, at 3 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Luard Scholarship at The EnglishSpeaking Union, 144 East 39th Street, New York, N.Y. 10016.

title: Leonard Melfi Memorial
description: A public memorial for the playwright Leonard Melfi will be held on Sunday at 2 p.m. at La MaMa Annex, second floor, 66 East Fourth Street, East Village. Mr. Melfi died in Manhattan last October at age 66, but his family did not learn of his death until February. Fellow playwrights, including Edward Albee and Lanford Wilson, are expected to speak, and excerpts from Mr. Melfi's work will be performed.

title: You'll Never Find This Table Airing Dirty Linen
description: With a table like this, who would use a tablecloth? It is one of a kind, an Art Deco design by Lee Weitzman of Chicago, made in Canada of curly maple, with black and mother-of-pearl accents. The table seats six at Atelier, the restaurant in the new Ritz-Carlton on Central Park South. ''We wanted this table to be the focus of the room, the power table,'' said Ronan Henaff, the manager of Atelier, which opens on Saturday. title: Egypt Assails The Lumping Of U.S. War With Israel's
description: President Hosni Mubarak criticized Washington today for allowing Israel to lump the Palestinian struggle to end occupation into the same category as the war on terrorism, and he echoed the impatience of other Arab officials with the lack of peace initiatives from the United States.

title: 2 French Officials Suspended 3 Years In Skating Scandal
description: The French figure skating judge Marie Reine Le Gougne and the president of the French ice sports federation, Didier Gailhaguet, were suspended from any involvement in international skating for three years today after the International Skating Union ruled that they had colluded to fix the result of the pairs event at the 2002 Winter Games in Salt Lake City.

title: Soulful Songs of Sorrow In America and Abroad
description: Some adventurous label should record Thomas Quasthoff's encores. ''Swing Low, Sweet Chariot,'' ''My Way'' and now ''Ol' Man River'': unless you have heard Mr. Quasthoff sing such things, you might imagine the worst kind of crossover pandering. After all, what business does an exquisitely refined German baritone have singing treasured Americana, even Sinatra standards?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LACOVARA, DR. PETER
description: LACOVARA-Dr. Peter. For all that you gave us-for the pride we had in being your family-we remember you with gratitude and love.

title: A Student Math Winner
description: JAN K. SIWANOWICZ, a City College junior, is one of the five individual winners of the prestigious William Lowell Putnam Mathematical Competition, along with two students from Harvard, one from M.I.T. and one from Duke University. Each won $2,500. The annual contest, which does not rank the five winners, draws nearly 3,000 of mathematics students from the United States and Canada.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PAKISTAN: MURDER TRIAL MOVED The suspended trial of four men charged with the kidnapping and murder of the Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl was moved today to Hyderabad from Karachi for security reasons, officials said. A third judge was selected for the case after the prosecutor, Raja Qureshi, said the previous judge could not guarantee his safety. No date has been set to resume the hearings. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Damage Control
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

Slide Show: A Town House Tour
Slide Show: A Selection of Perches
Tacoma Steps Out Fearlessly
description: Come July 6, the glass artist Dale Chihuly will present Tacoma, Wash., with the ultimate glass menagerie: artwork that will be displayed on a 482-foot-long public space called the Bridge of Glass.

title: Jury Sees Site Where Officer's Van Killed 4
description: Jurors in the trial of a former police officer charged with running down a pregnant woman and members of her family last August had a firsthand look yesterday at one final piece of evidence: the scene of the crash.

title: NATO Planes to End Patrol of U.S. Skies
description: NATO airborne-radar planes that have circled American skies since last fall will return to Europe this month, alliance and Pentagon officials said today.

title: Metro Matters; Map Exposes Fault Lines Of the City
description: RALPH GENTLES, a street map and pen in hand, stared at the sidewalk on 42nd Street in front of Grand Central Terminal yesterday morning, then made a tiny scratch on his map to denote a patch of uneven sidewalk. A puddle in a nearby crosswalk got an ant-sized circle. A sidewalk crack rated a squiggle (picture the sign of Zorro, writ small).

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Freedom Of Information
description: The Senate unanimously approved the nation's first freedom of information law, requiring the government to open records and files to the public. The law, which has been approved by the lower house, is considered an important step toward ending seven decades of government corruption and abuses shrouded by secrecy. It requires all branches of government to provide documents within 20 days to any citizen who requests them. Officials can withhold records only if their release endangers public or national security, or violates individual confidentiality. A commission is to monitor agencies' compliance.

title: Mother Criticizes State System For Losing Girl in Its Custody
description: Two days after Florida officials disclosed that the state had lost a Miami girl in its custody -- and had not noticed for more than a year -- the girl's mother, a former crack addict, said the authorities took no better care of her daughter than she had.

title: HBO Will Feature Cowboys in 'Hard Knocks'
description: HBO and NFL Films said yesterday that they would jointly produce a second ''Hard Knocks'' training camp series, this season with the Dallas Cowboys.

title: Subtracting $100 or More From the Pocket PC Equation
description: Although the phrase ''shiny brand-new Pocket PC hand-held'' may cause the casual technology watcher to think ''more than $500,'' prices for the devices have been creeping down. The new Toshiba e310 even comes in below the $400 mark.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Former 3com Chief At Start-Up
description: L. William Krause, the former chief executive of the 3Com Corporation and Exodus Communications, has been named president and chief executive of Caspian Networks, a telecommunications equipment company. He succeeds Bill Sickler. Mr. Krause was also chief executive of Stom Technology, a digital imaging company, from 1991 to 1998. Caspian, based in San Jose, Calif., makes routing and switching equipment for Internet providers. In February, it received $120 million in its fourth round of financing. It has raised more than $260 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILGROM, IDA
description: MILGROM-Ida. We extend condolences to Israeli Deputy Prime Minister Natan Sharansky and his family on the passing of their mother, a tireless champion with them in the Soviet Jewry and Zionist Movements. NCSJ: Advocates on behalf of Jews in Russia, Ukraine, The Baltic States & Eurasia Harold P. Luks, Chairman Robert J. Meth, President Mark B. Levin, Executive Director

title: Auriemma Says His Future Looks a Lot Like His Present
description: Now that the Connecticut women's basketball team has recorded its third national championship and second undefeated season in eight years, what does Coach Geno Auriemma do for an encore?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRILLING, MICHAEL
description: DRILLING-Michael. On April 30, 2002, at 66, after a courageous battle with cancer. Beloved husband and best friend to Martha. Proud and loving father of Eric, Betsy and Neil, Paul and Amy, and Abby and Gerard. Adored Grandpa to Julia and Lily, Zoe and Olivia, and Hannah. Dear brother to Linda. A sweet and decent man and a true friend to all. He will be deeply missed. Donations can be made to Mycosis Fungoides Foundation, PO Box 374, Birmingham, Michigan 48012.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BESWICK, TERRY
description: BESWICK-Terry. April 30, 2002. Partner of Salvatore Dirschberger. Son of Lanelle & Lee Beswick. Brother of Christy and Cheryl. Nephew of Donna Reeves. He was much loved and respected by his friends and colleagues at Lehman Brothers and will be deeply missed. Friends may call Friday, May 3, 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Service on Saturday, May 4, at 9:30 A.M. at Frank E. Campbell.

title: Footlights
description: Honor Bound

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUFSON, ROBERT
description: MUFSON-Robert. Age fifty-six passed away on April 30 in Boca Raton, FL. after a courageous and extraordinary battle with cancer. A man of boundless energy and creativity, Robert wrote poetry in celebration of life as his illness ravaged his body. A successful custom home builder, he played a major role in the development of a number of communities in Boca Raton. He was the chief benefactor of ''Boca Hoops'' creating an annual sportsmanship award. Survived by his children Betsi, Richard, Harris, Brett, Whitney, granddaughter Clara and devoted fiancee Marjory Dobbin and her children Rachel & Michael Dobbin. Donations in memory of Robert may be made to the charity of your choice, or the Children's Bereavement Center, 1501 Venera Ave, Suite 225, Coral Gables, FL. 33146. Services May 2, 2002, B'nai Torah Congregation, 6262 SW 18th Street, Boca Raton, FL. Interment Mt. Nebo Cemetery, Miami, FL.

title: Where Courtesy Is as Rare as a Free Seat
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. to Reconsider Applicants Rejected for Aid After Attack
description: The director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency promised members of the New York Congressional delegation yesterday that the agency would immediately reopen more than 7,000 applications for housing assistance that the agency denied after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: Dollar Falls As Top Official Casts Doubts On Intervention
description: After saying his goal was to avoid upsetting the financial markets, Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill did just that today by sparring with members of a Congressional committee about the nation's financial condition and leaving some investors with doubts about his willingness to defend the weakening dollar.

title: AOL Shifts Key Contract To Google
description: America Online said yesterday that it had chosen Google to provide Web search results and the advertisements that appear next to them.

title: From Prison, Music of Hope
description: Four years ago, John Fort was on top of the world. A producer and rapper known for his work with the Fugees, he was considered one of the brightest stars in their creative entourage and had just signed a solo deal with Columbia Records.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Restaurant Workers Upset
description: Hundreds of restaurant workers demonstrated at Rockefeller Center yesterday to call on Restaurant Associates, which runs Cucina & Company and several other restaurants at the center, to sign a new contract. Members of Local 100 of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union voted last week to strike this spring against 11 restaurants run by Restaurant Associates. The main issues are wages and unionization at other Restaurant Associates sites. The contracts for 700 workers at the 11 restaurants expired on Feb. 28. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: QUARTERLY PROFIT UP 5.7% AT OXFORD HEALTH PLANS
description: The managed care provider Oxford Health Plans said yesterday that its earnings rose 5.7 percent in the first quarter as it signed up more members and kept a lid on medical costs. Oxford, which is based in Trumbull, Conn., posted net income of $71.4 million, or 78 cents a share, compared with $67.6 million, or 65 cents a share, a year earlier. The latest result was 4 cents a share higher than the estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. Revenue increased 8.4 percent, to $1.17 billion..

title: Msgr. George Higgins, Adviser To U.S. Bishops, Is Dead at 86
description: Msgr. George G. Higgins, for decades a major adviser to the nation's Roman Catholic bishops, an outspoken supporter of organized labor and an influential figure in improving ties between Catholics and Jews, died yesterday in LaGrange Park, Ill. He was 86 and lived much of his life in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DRILLING, MICHAEL
description: DRILLING-Michael. Your friendship, sense of humor and golf instruction will always be in our hearts. You fought a big battle. We will think of you drinking a Diet Pepsi while playing a great game of Golf in the sky. Our deepest love to Martha, Eric, Betsy and Neal, Abby and Gerard, Paul and Amy. Fran and Bruce

title: Embracing Squid, Tentacles and All
description: Weekly highlights from 150 forums  from being creative with calamari to dream basketball match-ups.

title: In Afghan War, Top Exiles Printed Themselves a Fortune
description: Years of hyperinflation have rendered this country's currency so worthless that few people here thought it possible for it to diminish even more.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Tuesday about Seattle Slew, the horse who won the Triple Crown in 1977 and is currently 28 years old, misstated the age at which two other famous horses died. Secretariat was 19, not 24; Mr. Prospector was 29, not 27.

title: Instead of a Password, Well-Placed Clicks
description: XY$Z4#T. It is a password only a security expert could love.

title: Indonesian Official Urges U.S. to Resume Military Assistance
description: A senior civilian official here has said that the United States should drop restrictions imposed almost three years ago on assistance to the Indonesian military and help restore what he called the ''tarnished reputation'' of this nation's army.

title: Again, an Auction Game for Two; A Weakened Phillips Has Little Presence in Spring Sales
description: On the eve of the Impressionist, modern and contemporary art auctions, which take place here next week, it is startling how radically the landscape of auction house rivalry has changed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKITRICK, ERIC L.
description: McKITRICK-Eric L. On April 24, 2002 in New York City at age 82. Historian and author. Funeral services will be held on Saturday May 4 at 1pm at Grace Church, Broadway & 10 St. in NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Organ Fund of Grace Church or to Amnesty International.

title: WYETH RECALLS AN INJECTABLE ANTICOAGULANT DRUG
description: Wyeth has recalled thousands of lots of an injectable clot-busting drug after it found a compound from rubber containers had tainted some vials. Wyeth, which is based in Madison, N.J., and recently changed its name from American Home Products, discovered specks of an unidentified crystal substance in some lots of the drug, an injected version of heparin sodium, Douglas Petkus, a company spokesman, said. The recall will cause a temporary shortage of the product, which helps the blood move smoothly through vessels. The drug is given to people with cancer and diabetes and those who undergo some operations, the Food and Drug Administration said.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: Carpenters On Strike
description: About 3,000 union carpenters went on strike yesterday, after negotiations on a statewide contract stalled over wage increases and random drug testing. On Tuesday, the union, the New England Regional Council of Carpenters, rejected the latest offer from management, including hourly wage increases up to $8.05 for highway construction workers, who now make $28.85 an hour. The union had sought an increase of up to $10.05 per hour. It also opposes random drug testing and pre-employment physicals, said Bert Durand, a spokesman for the union. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Cirrus Sales Fall 58%
description: Cirrus Logic, which makes computer chips, reported a loss for its fourth quarter as sales dropped 58 percent. The loss for the quarter ended March 30 was $80.8 million, or 98 cents a diluted share, in contrast to net income of $3.95 million, or 5 cents a diluted share, in the period a year earlier, the company said. Sales fell to $83.6 million from $199.7 million. Cirrus has lost sales as demand has fallen for DVD and MP3 players. But it said it had added customers in Asia and expected sales to increase 5 percent to 6 percent in the first and second quarters.

title: $2,000 Down and No More to Pay: A Place to Live After the Storm
description: Whether in the Jenin camp in the West Bank or in a Central American village hit by flood, inexpensive housing is desperately needed. Designers have come up with solutions. In Bhadli, India, left, damaged by an earthquake last year, 100 homes were built with public and private money for $1,000 to $2,000 each. (The higher figure is enough for a 450-square-foot house, for four people.) ''Every house has been built on its original site,'' said Brinda Somaya, an architect at Somaya & Kalappa Consultants in Bombay. In El Salvador, Oxfam builds 300-square-foot houses for $1,200. ''It's possible to provide adequate housing for every family of four for $1,000 to $3,000,'' said Bruce Wilkinson, a senior vice president of World Vision, a relief agency that works with Habitat for Humanity. In July, Habitat will ship 250 kits ($300 each) to Mazar-i-Sharif, the devastated northern Afghan city, to repair earthen homes. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Accident Cuts Phone Service To Thousands
description: A construction accident on Tuesday at the site of the planned Manhattan headquarters of Bloomberg L.P. cut phone service to thousands of homes and businesses, and officials said yesterday that telephone service would not be fully restored until Saturday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Harm From Acid Rain Persists
description: Acid rain continues to harm aquatic life in Adirondack streams, according to a study presented last week at the Northeast Natural History Conference. The study concluded that 19 of 22 streams in the western part of Adirondack Park surpassed the acidity threshold for wildlife and that 16 contained toxic levels of aluminum, which can kill fish. The researcher, Gregory Lawrence of the United States Geological Survey, said dangerous levels of aluminum have been detected in the streams for 15 years or more. Hope Reeves (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

Services on Saturday, May 4, 11 AM at St. Mary's Church, 669 West Avenue, Norwalk, CT. Call at the Magner Funeral Home, 12 Mott Ave., Norwalk, CT. on Friday from 5-8 PM.

title: It's Official: Hewlett-Compaq Merger Won
description: The final results of the Hewlett-Packard proxy contest, announced yesterday, confirm that shareholders approved the company's merger with Compaq Computer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, LENA
description: KAPLAN-Lena, 92. On April 29, 2002. Beloved wife of Herman. Devoted mother of Sheldon (Jeanne) Kaplan and Ruth (Barry) Singer. Cherished grandmother of Roy (Sandy) Kaplan, Michael Singer, Robin Kaplan and Andrew (Michele) Singer. Loving greatgrandmother of six.

title: Bin Laden Relative Linked to '93 Trade Center Bombers, Affidavit Says
description: In supporting its arrest of the leader of an Islamic charity this week, the Justice Department has made public new information tying a wealthy Saudi businessman, who is Osama bin Laden's brother-in-law, to several people convicted in the bombing of the World Trade Center in 1993 or in unsuccessful plots to bring down airliners and assassinate the pope.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEI, MARK
description: WEI-Mark. Died at 84 years of age on April 30, 2002 in his home in Manhattan. Born in Hong Kong, China, Mr. Wei came to New York from China in April of 1941. Mr. Wei began his insurance career at Chubb & Son, Inc. in 1947 and retired after 35 years of service. At the time of his retirement, he was Senior Vice President and a member of the Board of Directors of Chubb & Son, Inc. Mr. Wei also served as a Director of the American Institution of Marine Underwriters, the National Cargo Bureau and the Security Bureau, Inc. He was a former Chairman and Director of the American Cargo War Risk Reinsurance Exchange and the Cargo Reinsurance Association. Mr. Wei received a B.A degree from St. John's University in Shanghai, China and a Master's Degree in Business Administration from Colorado College. He also attended law school at Indiana University. During World War II, he served as a lieutenant in the United States Marine Corps in the Pacific Theater and in the Far East. At the time of his death, Mark was a director and Principal in Kemark Financial Services, Inc. headquartered in Pearl River, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hofstra University, Mark Wei Athletic & Scholarship Fund, c/o Michael D'Amato, 101 Hofstra University, Hempstead, NY 11549.

title: Staples Selects Competition Lineup
description: Staples named nine agencies yesterday to compete in a review for the broadcast creative part of its account, with billings estimated at $50 million to $70 million.

title: Designing the Buildings And the Stuff Inside
description: Christian Biecher, 38, a French architect, was confirmed as a design star last month when he was toasted as Designer of the Year at a show of his furniture and lighting at the Muse des Arts Dcoratifs in Paris. Mr. Biecher, right, is equally well known as an architect for, among other things, the retro restaurant Korova in Paris, with an aquarium shaped like a Lava lamp, and a shop for Joseph on the Rue St.-Honor. An American company, Bernhardt Design, will show Biecher sofas, chairs and low tables at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair in New York this month. ''I wanted the comfort and sculptural form of a car seat floating on a light foot,'' he said of his Abra chair. The Abra sofa, left, is $2,300. Information: (212) 888-3232. MALLERY ROBERTS LANE

title: Corrections
description: A film review yesterday about Woody Allen's ''Hollywood Ending'' misspelled the given name of the composer and pianist to whose crunching notes the movie's one-liners were compared. He was Thelonious Monk, not Theolonious.

title: Free-Spirited Dwellings in a Tract-House Nation
description: IN this quiet suburb southwest of Chicago, an inventor named Ben Skora has transformed an old kit house from Sears, Roebuck & Company into what he calls a ''futuristic electronic residence.'' With the flick of a switch, a hidden bar rumbles out from a wall panel. From there, it is just a few steps down to the sunken living room, which is rigged to spin at a gentle speed on a turntable hidden beneath plum-colored carpeting.

title: Former Nets Star Faces New Homicide Charge
description: A new, more serious homicide charge, aggravated manslaughter, was filed today against the former New Jersey Nets star Jayson Williams in the fatal shooting of a chauffeur at Mr. Williams's country estate.

title: NORTHROP SEEKS TALKS WITH TRW ON HOSTILE BID
description: Northrop Grumman, a large military contractor, said yesterday that it was willing to halt its $6.7 billion hostile offer for TRW for 75 days to begin talks with TRW, a smaller contractor and automotive parts maker. TRW, which has described the bid as inadequate, has insisted that Northrop hold off on a tender offer for three years through a so-called standstill agreement as a condition for opening talks, Northrop said. TRW, based in Cleveland, said it was willing to address the standstill period's length. The statements came two days before TRW shareholders are scheduled to vote on a proposal that would allow Northrop to proceed with its offer. Northrop, of Los Angeles, which initiated the bid in February and raised it last month, said it would walk away if the proposal failed.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Cisco Buys Two Companies
description: Cisco Systems, the leading maker of networking equipment, said yesterday that it had acquired two closely held companies for as much as $258 million in stock. The acquisitions of Hammerhead Networks of Billerica, Mass., and Navarro Networks of Plano, Tex., are expected to be completed in Cisco's fourth quarter, which ends in July. Cisco, based in San Jose, Calif., expects to take a related charge of up to 2 cents a share. It already owns 11 percent of Hammerhead, which makes software that runs on Cisco s hardware for service providers, and 14 percent of Navarro, which makes networking chips. Shares of Cisco fell 95 cents, to $13.70, after the announcement. Craig Griffin, a director for business development, said the acquisitions were in areas that already created substantial profits for Cisco. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEZER, PEARL
description: FREEZER-Pearl. Of New York City on April 25, 2002 at age 84. Widow of Herbert Freezer. Mother of Harlene Freezer. Donations to New York City Ballet, or the Alzheimer's Association.

title: Threat to Privacy In a Driver's License
description: To the Editor:

title: Reversing Course on Farm Policy
description: The farm bill agreed to by a House-Senate conference committee last week is a regrettable reversion to some of the worst policies of the past. Its salient feature is a $50 billion increase in subsidies to big producers of row crops like corn and wheat over the next 10 years. That represents a 50 percent jump over present levels and a complete reversal of Congress's promising attempts six years ago to wean farmers of all subsidies.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Editor Shot To Death
description: A newspaper editor in the central city of Togliatti has been killed after publishing articles on corruption in the local government and on ties between local criminal groups and the automobile producer Avtovaz, which is based in the city. A report on the Internet news service Gazeta.ru said Valery Ivanov had died from six bullet wounds in his head and chest. Mr. Ivanov was also the general director of a local television station whose previous two directors were killed, according to Gazeta.ru.

title: Man Admits Stealing Retirees' Millions
description: A New Jersey man who the authorities say deceived retirees into believing he was a wealthy and influential investment expert pleaded guilty yesterday to stealing more than $27 million of their money, Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, said.

title: Many Yankees On the Bases Never Get Home
description: The Yankees' plan this season was to stuff the lineup with hitters who clog the bases. A high on-base percentage would naturally lead to more runs.

title: U.S. Drops Last Link of Iraq to 9/11
description: Federal authorities have concluded that there is no evidence that Mohamed Atta, the suspected ringleader of the Sept. 11 attacks, met with an Iraqi intelligence officer before the hijackings.

title: Sports of The Times; Moment Of Truth For Nets
description: THE only time the Nets advanced to the second round of the National Basketball Association playoffs, in 1984, they jumped to an early lead against the Milwaukee Bucks in Game 6. Quickly calling a timeout, the Bucks' coach, Don Nelson, later the Knicks' coach briefly and now the Dallas Mavericks' coach, crouched in front of his players.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Mahwah: School's Charter Forfeited
description: The founder of the Green Willow Charter School has forfeited the school's charter after failing to find a suitable building for the start of the 2002-3 school year, the State Department of Education said. Green Willow's charter was among nine approved in January 2001, but the school's opening was delayed to allow for more planning, said Faith Sarafin, a department spokeswoman. She said Green Willow, which would have served Mahwah, Ramsey, Saddle River and Upper Saddle River, must apply for a new charter to open in the future. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARMSTRONG, DR. CHRISTINE MEGAN
description: ARMSTRONG-Dr. Christine Megan, 50, died April 28, 2002, at Presbyterian Village, Austell, GA. Christine will be remembered with great love and affection by her family and friends. Her death was the result of a long, courageous and dignified battle with brain cancer, which was diagnosed and treated in 1986. She was an inspiration. Dr. Armstrong was born on December 4, 1951, and graduated from Rye Country Day School in Rye, NY, in 1969. Christine was a fine scholar, having graduated with honors from Duke University in 1973. She enrolled in the Doctoral program in Art History at Princeton University. Christine's 1989 Doctoral dissertation, The Moralizing Prints of Cornelius Anthonisz, was considered a definitive work on the prints of Cornelius Anthonisz, a Dutch printmaker in the 1500's. It was published by Princeton University Press in 1990. Her career took her to Sotheby's PB 84 auction house and the Philadelphia Art Museum as a print curator. In the 1985-86 academic year, she became an assistant professor of Art History at the College of Wooster in Wooster, Ohio. Memorial gifts may be made to the Armstrong Family Scholarship in honor of Christine Armstrong at Washington and Lee University, Development Office, Lexington, Virginia 24450. For information, call H.M. Patterson & Son Spring Hill, Atlanta, GA., 404-876-1022.

title: John P. Morris, 76, Teamsters Vice President

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: TiVo In Software Deal With AOL

Although AOL said it would pay TiVo an undisclosed development fee for the applications, a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission indicated that AOL, a subsidiary of AOL Time Warner, had already made a $4 million payment. title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Gold Profit Drops

Income was $46 million, or 9 cents a share, a decline down from the $87 million, or 16 cents a share, recorded a year earlier. Production slipped by 7.6 percent and costs climbed to $263 an ounce from $246. The average realized gold price was $329 an ounce, up from $320. Barrick said that for the first time, it had sold half of its mines' output on the spot market, where the price averaged $290. Its hedging program realized an average price of $365. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OWEN, KENNETH DALE
description: OWEN-Kenneth Dale. The son of Lucille Eagle and Richard Owen, was born August 24, 1903 and passed away on April 28, 2002, in the town of his birth. He was the great-great grandson of Robert Owen, the Welsh social reformer and owner of the celebrated textile mills in New Lanark, Scotland. Robert Owen purchased the town of New Harmony in 1825, creating a Utopian community in the hope of bringing educational, and social opportunities to every man, woman and child. Kenneth Owen spent his youth in New Harmony but graduated from Memphis Central High School, where he lettered in varsity basketball and track, breaking the interscholastic high jump record in 1922. He earned a degree from Cornell in 1926, moved to Houston in 1927 and worked as a field geologist in Texas during the 1920's for The Humble Oil Company. Pursuing the innovative and pioneering career of his forebear, David Dale Owen, the First Indiana State Geologist, K D, discovered a highly productive oilfield that became the financial basis for his formation of two successful Houston based companies, Gulfshore Oil Company and Trans-Tex Production Company. Mr. Owen's financial enterprises allowed him to pursue other life time passions. With the help of Wayne Haygood, Indian Mound Farm, in New Harmony became one of the top purebred Hereford cattle breeding operations in the world. His scientific mind and discriminating eye enabled him to become one of the most respected standard-bred breeders in the country, winning the coveted Hambletonian in 1967. In the late 80's when he retired from the Hambletonian Society it was said ''During the 45 years that Ken Owen has been in harness racing, he has not only set new standards as a breeder, but he has also symbolized the brightest form of sportsmanship and integrity our sport has known.'' Mr. Owen took an active interest in restoring properties originally owned by his family in New Harmony. The house, in which he was born, the David Dale Owen Laboratory, was his New Harmony home. He also restored the RappMaclure-Owen Mansion and the Rapp Granary. The Granary was headquarters for pioneer geologic investigations during the Owen community endeavors from 1825-1860. He was one of seven founding members of the New Lanark Association, Ltd. In Scotland, an organization restoring the original Robert Owen industrial properties. Mr. Owen is a member of the American Association of Petroleum Geologists, a Legion of Honor member of the Society of Petroleum Engineers of the American Institute of Mining Engineers, The American Petroleum Institute, The Houston Geological Society, The American Hereford Association-Honor Gallery Award, and The Trotting Horse Hall of Fame Museum. He was an emeritus member of the Cornell University Council, Equine Advisory Council of the New York State College of Veterinary Medicine, and he held an honorary Doctor of Science degree from the University of Southern Indiana. Mr. Owen was appointed Tennessee Ambassador of Goodwill by Governor Sundquist, commissioned a Colonel by the State of Kentucky and awarded Indiana's highest honor as a Sagamore of the Wabash by Governor Frank O'Bannon. He was married to Jane Blaffer of Houston Texas for 61 years. He was the adored father of three daughters: Jane Dale Owen, Anne Dale Owen, and the late Caroline Owen Coleman, and the grandfather of Ingrid Arneberg, Erik Owen Arneberg, James Owen Coleman, Abigail Owen-Pontez, and great-grandfather to Sarah. While Kenneth Dale Owen has been acknowledged for a multitude of distinguished achievements he will be most remembered for being a gentle man to the very end. All who knew him will miss his honesty, his keen eye, his dry wit, his innate since of fairness and his love for all living creatures. The family would like to thank all those whose care and concern allowed Kenneth Owen to live life to its fullest. The funeral will be held in New Harmony, Indiana on Thursday, May 2nd and the date for the Memorial Services in Houston, Texas is pending. Memorials may be sent to the Owen-Maclure Foundation 5120 Woodway, Suite 9007, Houston, Texas 77056.

His valued counsel as a Director and Trustee will be missed by all who knew him. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to the Looker family. Joseph S. Mishkin, Chairman Pauline Raiff, Chairman-Elect Alan R. Morse, President & CEO

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: 34-Year-Old Weekly Closes
description: The issue last Thursday of The Maine Times, a weekly devoted to state news, was its last. The publisher, Christopher Hutchins, an executive from Bangor who bought the paper in 1999, told employees on Monday that it was closing. In a statement, Mr. Hutchins said that he had ''spared no expense to keep it afloat'' but that the 34-year-old paper with a circulation of 3,600 could not survive on its low advertising revenues and subscription rates.

title: As WorldCom Struggles for Stability, Its MCI Phone Unit Underwhelms Wall St.
description: As the new president and chief executive of WorldCom, John W. Sidgmore, tries to restore Wall Street's faith in the company, one big question involves the future of MCI, WorldCom's most visible link to the typical phone user.

title: Economic Scene; A model for evaluating the use of development dollars, south of the border.
description: THE Bush administration is casting about for new ideas on how to use $5 billion of aid a year for poor countries to achieve accountability and results in economic development. It would do well to look south, to the Progresa program in Mexico, for a successful model that has reduced child labor, increased educational levels and improved health and nutrition for the poor.

title: Crossing a Freeway Is Like Walking on Glass, But Tacoma Steps Out Fearlessly
description: The glass artist Dale Chihuly's popularity has been booming for years, but Chihuly-mania seems to have reached a peak now, with his creations appearing in dozens of exhibitions around the world. Come July 6, Mr. Chihuly will present his hometown, Tacoma, Wash., with the ultimate glass menagerie: artwork that will be displayed on a 482-foot-long public space called the Bridge of Glass. The project will provide a pedestrian link over Interstate 705 between the Washington State History Museum and the new Museum of Glass: International Center for Contemporary Art.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Trial Set In Wendy's Case
description: The murder trial for John B. Taylor, below, one of the two men accused of staging a May 2000 massacre that left five workers at a Wendy's restaurant in Flushing dead and two others badly wounded, is set to begin Sept. 10, the authorities said yesterday. Mr. Taylor, a former employee of the restaurant, on Main Street, could be sentenced to death if convicted. A co-defendant, Craig Godineaux, has pleaded guilty and is serving a life sentence in prison with no chance of parole. Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

title: RANGERS TALK TO DEVILS' ROBINSON
description: After waiting a day for the Devils' president and general manager, Lou Lamoriello to get back to him, Glen Sather, the Rangers' president and general manager, received formal permission from Lamoriello yesterday to speak with former Devils' coach Larry Robinson about the Rangers' coaching vacancy.

title: Hard-Drive Magic: Making Data Disappear Forever
description: THE State of Pennsylvania learned the hard way that files do not actually disappear when they are sent to the Recycle Bin on a desktop.

title: Surfing From Site to Site With the Click of a Remote
description: When channel surfing begat Web surfing, the remote control did not stray far from the television. But a new wireless device could make switching from CNN.com to ESPN.com as easy as switching from CNN to ESPN.

title: Lehman Brothers Lays Off 60 in Europe
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings laid off 60 bankers and support staff members at its European business today after earnings declined in four of the last five quarters.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CIRKER, MINETTE
description: CIRKER-Minette. Lovingly remembered on your birthday. ''Rest my sweet darling''. Stanley

title: Guilty Plea Made in Investment Fraud Case
description: William J. Zylka, who portrayed himself to investors as the scion of a wealthy family and an international business success, has admitted stealing $27.7 million from an offshore investment fund, according to authorities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASCH, MORRIS
description: BASCH-Morris. We mourn the loss of our beloved friend and treasured colleague. A gentle soul, his warmth and humor endeared him to all who knew him. Heartfelt condolences to Sylvia, Debbie, Jeff, Norman, Irene, Heshi, Wendy and all the grandchildren. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The Greenblatt Family

title: California Priest Is Accused Of 8-Year Sexual Relationship
description: A 31-year-old man said yesterday that the Rev. David F. Granadino, who is now pastor of a close-knit parish in the Archdiocese of Los Angeles, cultivated a sexual relationship with him when he was a boy and continued it for eight years.

title: QUARTERLY LOSS WIDENS AT PRIMEDIA ON RISING EXPENSES
description: Primedia, the publisher of magazines like Motor Trend and Seventeen, said yesterday that its loss widened to $139.6 million in the first quarter on higher expenses and lower advertising at its trade publications. The loss in the quarter ended March 31 expanded to 65 cents a share, from $85.8 million, or 54 cents, a year earlier. Sales slipped to $412.1 million from $414.2 million. Primedia, with about $2 billion in debt, is selling $250 million in assets to raise cash and is closing the unprofitable Teen magazine in a bid to stem losses. Revenue from Primedia's trade publications, which include Satellite Broadband and Global Telephony, fell 22 percent in the quarter, though the company, which is based in New York, said the worst of an advertising slump might be over.

title: Creator of Melissa Virus Gets 20 Months in Jail
description: The New Jersey computer programmer who unleashed the Melissa virus in March 1999, disrupting more than a million e-mail accounts worldwide and costing businesses an estimated $80 million, was sentenced today to a year and eight months in federal prison.

title: Plan by Pataki Said to Remove House Seats Of 2 Democrats
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has drafted a congressional redistricting plan that would eliminate the seats of two Democrats, Carolyn B. Maloney of Manhattan and Maurice D. Hinchey of Saugerties, according to officials who have seen parts of the plan or discussed it with the governor's aides.

title: Put Up a Design Statement
description: JUST when you think you have seen every possible design for sitting, perching, lounging or slouching, a new crop of chairs springs up. ''Designers make their reputations on a chair,'' George Marcus, who teaches the history of design at the University of Pennsylvania, said. ''It's the one object that affords a designer the most freedom. Just think of the Eames chair, the Aalto chair, Mies's Barcelona chair and Jacobsen's Egg chair.'' This year's contenders for the next classics include a chair that looks more like a room divider and another that resembles a bundle of rags.

title: Suit Seeks to Halt Bush Plan On Entry of Mexican Trucks
description: A coalition of labor, environmental and consumer groups filed suit yesterday to block new Bush administration rules that could admit thousands of Mexican trucks to the United States starting this summer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, GERALD D.
description: STERN-Gerald D. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Gerald D. Stern, and extend sincere condolences to his family. Alex C. Solowey, President

title: Raids Launched in Afghanistan to Search for Al Qaeda
description: BAGRAM AIR BASE, Afghanistan, May 2  Heavily equiped soldiers of the British Royal Marines, their faces blackened with camouflage paint, climbed aboard Chinook helicopters today at a forward operating base south of Kabul to head into the mountains.

title: Silicon Pets, but the Pride Is Real
description: DIANE wasn't well. Sadly, she was suffering from D.H.S. Her owner, Harry Brattin, placed a white muffler around her neck and separated her from the rest of his brood. She sat quietly on a metal desk in the meeting room while the others scampered around the floor playing.

title: Staples Selects Competition Lineup
description: Staples named nine agencies yesterday to compete in a review for the broadcast creative part of its account, with billings estimated at $50 million to $70 million.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Heroes Of Capitalism
description: The world's last major Communist power celebrated May Day by citing some private businessmen as ''model workers,'' an honor once reserved for plumbers and plasterers, welders and wheelwrights and other exemplary members of the proletariat. The government-sponsored All-China Federation of Trade Unions awarded medals to the heads of four privately owned companies; another 17 businessmen were declared ''model workers'' in the northwestern province of Shaanxi, where Mao once made his revolutionary headquarters. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Where Courtesy Is as Rare as a Free Seat
description: To the Editor:

title: Pitchers At the Fair
description: This is the weekend of the national booksellers convention, the sales-pitch happening of the year, and so it's understandable that when you talk of producing a commercially successful book you have to consider that seemingly anomalous inhabitant of the literary world, the publicist. It's true. Once a book is written, often the most important individual in an author's life after the editor is the public relations person.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: The 'Our Town' Gang

title: The Shock of Gadget Glitches
description: Ihad a great time working on "Piloting Palm," which tells the story of how Palm and Handspring began and grew.

title: Threat Is Seen to Microsoft Windows
description: The Microsoft Corporation's Windows software would collapse like a ''house of cards'' under an antitrust proposal by nine states to strip Internet Explorer from the operating system, a computer scientist testified today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARGIULO, GENE
description: GARGIULO-Gene. It is with deepest regret that we mourn the passing of Gene Gargiulo, our friend and collegue. He will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to the family. HCFP/Brenner Securities

title: A Practical Muse for Musicians With AIDS
description: Six years ago Gerald Busby's companion died of AIDS. ''I fell apart,'' said Mr. Busby, a composer who also has AIDS. ''I couldn't work. I thought I was going to die. I just thought, Everybody who has this dies; who cares?'' Hurting financially, too, he moved from a four-room apartment in the Chelsea Hotel to a one-room studio in the hotel, his scores stuffed in suitcases.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Billiton's Profit Down
description: BHP Billiton, the international mining, energy and steel group, reported a 33 percent decline in net earnings for its third fiscal quarter, and cautioned that it still sees little evidence of stronger demand for many of its products. Citing cutbacks in base metal production, lower petroleum prices and difficult conditions in steel markets, the group, which is based in Melbourne, Australia, said that profit attributable to common shareholders fell to $406 million from $604 million a year earlier. Revenue in the period, which ended March 31, slipped 8 percent, to $4.3 billion. Paul M. Anderson, the chief executive, said that high inventory levels, slack demand and lackluster commodity prices, would continue to hurt the company's earnings. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLECHER, MILTON
description: BLECHER-Milton. May 2, 1914. Daddy-who can believe 10 years? Don't worry, I'm wearing my hat. Happy Birthday Daddy. I miss you. Love, Nani.

title: Army Digs In Its Heels and Saves Howitzer Plan, for Now
description: A pitched, if brief, battle broke out today on Capitol Hill and at the Pentagon after lawmakers were informed that Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld had decided to kill an $11 billion program to build a artillery system known as the Crusader.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LESHAN, EDA
description: LeSHAN-Eda. A Memorial Service will be held May 4, 2002 at 3 PM at The New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th St.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Brewer Takes Liquor Stake
description: Japan's second- biggest beer producer, the Kirin Brewery Company, will buy 32.4 percent of a French food services company, Socit Immobilire et Financiere Pour L'Alimentation, to gain a stake of more than 3 percent in Pernod Ricard, the maker of Martell Cognac and Chivas Regal Scotch. Kirin, which lost the top spot in Japan's beer market last year to Asahi Beer, wants to diversify into other markets. Last year, Kirin took stakes in the San Miguel Corporation, the Philippine brewery, and Takeda Chemical Industries' food business. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Virtually Rebuilt, a Ruin Yields Secrets
description: EVERYONE knows that the Roman Colosseum is an architectural marvel. Built so that thousands of people could be ushered in and out in minutes, it is a testament to the genius of Roman engineering. Or is it?

title: London Diary: The Carpet Beat Me
description: HERE I was, waving my white card, bidding on Lot 2, ''a fine antique kaskai carpet from southwest Persia,'' and competing with a bank of 10 telephones and a back wall lined with Iranian rug dealers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONBLATT, ISIDORE
description: MONBLATT-Isidore. On April 30, 2002. W.W. II veteran and Lehman Brothers Assistant Comptroller, but he would like to be remembered most as Nancy's adoring, devoted husband of 60 years, loving father to Steve, Joan and Cathy and doting grandfather to Rebecca and Gabriela. We will always remember you with all the love in the world. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to SloanKettering Memorial Hospital.

title: Burnley Journal; In a British Election, the Alienated vs. the Aliens
description: On the one hand, there is a poster on a boarded-up storefront in this depressed northern town, warning that a vote for the British National Party is a vote for ''fear, violence, and race riots.''

title: Police Step Up Job Site Patrols After a Melee
description: Two days after a violent clash between two rival groups outside an Upper East Side construction site, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that he was taking aggressive action to stem further violence.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Charges Filed In Sex Ring
description: A Union County social worker was charged yesterday with aiding a prostitution ring involving girls smuggled from Mexico and held captive in a Plainfield brothel, federal prosecutors said. Four others have been arrested in the case. Sergio Farfan, the social worker, the prosecutors said, had patronized the brothel, where girls were forced to perform sexual acts for $35 and give the money to the operators. Bail was set at $100,000. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: The War on Terror Enters Phase 2
description: How goes the Bush administration's war against Al Qaeda? It has, in its quiet way, entered Phase 2: international police and intelligence work with military operations greatly reduced. Perhaps even more than last year's predominantly military phase, the current phase requires close and sustained international cooperation.

title: The Memory Palace of Mrs. Kim
description: I told my husband I'll either do my Ph.D. or I'll do a house,'' said Wan Kyun Rha Kim last week. Mrs. Kim, who wore a silk lace jacket with a cascade of pink silk roses, sat in her kitchen serving coffee and pang, Korean steamed buns.

title: The Heavy Lifters Of Raw Computation
description: Q. Is a mainframe computer the same thing as a supercomputer?

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Acting To Avert Court Crisis
description: Chief Justice Roy Moore of the state Supreme Court moved to avert a judicial crisis by accepting an emergency $500,000 allocation from Gov. Don Siegelman that will allow the resumption of jury trials halted by a budget dispute. Last month, Chief Justice Moore announced that he was suspending jury trials in all civil cases and most criminal cases because the state's court system needed an extra $2.7 million this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AKIN, ROBERT M. III
description: AKIN-Robert M. III, age 66, on April 29, 2002. Survived by wife Ellen, children Susan, Robert and Johanna, brother William and three grandchildren. Memorial service, Saturday, May 4, 2:30, Mt. Kisco Presbyterian Church. In lieu of flowers, donations to Hackley School, Tarrytown NY 10591.

title: Arafat Emerges From Besieged West Bank Headquarters
description: RAMALLAH, March 2  By turns bitter and triumphant, Yasir Arafat emerged from a monthlong Israeli siege today to survey the damage done to the unofficial Palestinian capital, as leaders on both sides sought new footing after the deadlock here was suddenly broken by American and Saudi Arabian pressure.

title: Iverson Leads Charge, Forcing Decisive Game
description: His jump shot, his drive, even his crossover dribble had failed Allen Iverson for three quarters, making him a disappointment in the Philadelphia 76ers' ultimate game of the season. The trade rumors and the criticism that had dogged him before his Game 3 masterpiece on Sunday were just minutes away from being resurrected for a long and tumultuous off-season.

title: The Stress Defense
description: On the evening of Dec. 27, 1991, a Manhattan resident named Ramon Roche ended an argument with his common-law wife by killing her. Court records show that he stabbed and slashed the woman, Lillian Rivera, nearly two dozen times. The medical examiner said she suffered wounds to the face, neck, chest, arms and hands.

title: To Borrow, Must One Beg?
description: JOHN C. JORGENSEN, a Manhattan engineer who owns a weekend house in the Berkshires, was inching up the West Side Highway one day last month when he heard a compelling advertisement on the radio. It was promoting a home equity line of credit at 4 percent, about 10 points lower than it was when he bought his first apartment a decade ago. Stuck in traffic, he leaned forward when the announcer got to the best enticement of all: no closing costs.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sony Raises Web Exposure
description: Looking to increase its links to the Internet, the Sony Corporation said that it would buy 1 percent of RealNetworks Inc., a provider of online digital video technology. Sony, the world's largest electronics company, is looking for additional ways to sell the game software, music and movies it produces. Sony hopes to make its popular PlayStation 2 game console a one-stop vehicle for downloading entertainment in the home. Sony, which will pay an estimated $11 million for the stake, will also work with RealNetworks to develop software and ways to distribute digital media using Sony products. Ken Belson (NYT)

Devoted father of Barbara Salzman (Ira), Linda Handelman and Sandy Slomin (Lori). Adored grandfather of Jason and Heidi Salzman, Jennifer Salzman, Jaime and Adam Handelman. Beloved stepmother of Mary Elizabeth, Keith, Roderick and Scott. Beloved aunt of Richard, Frances, William and Timothy. title: A Losing Magazine?
description: Losses at The New Yorker magazine total between $6 million and $8 million this year, down from the $30 million the magazine lost in 1993, former editor Tina Brown's first full year.

description: BUDOW-Sunny (Shprintzie). Hello, Love-18 years without you. You are always in our hearts. Saul, Fern, Stephen and Family
