title: Lieberman Keeping Eye on Gore and '04
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut is grateful to Al Gore for choosing him as his Democratic running mate in 2000, but he leaves no doubt that he hopes the former vice president stays out of the 2004 race. The senator now wants the top slot for himself, and has begun assembling a team of strategists.

title: Technology Briefing | Software : Peregrine Falls After Changing Auditors
description: Shares of Peregrine Systems, a maker of business software, dropped almost 50 percent yesterday to a four-year low after it delayed the release of fourth-quarter results because it had changed auditors. Shares fell $3.40, to $3.45. Peregrine hired KPMG as its auditor on April 5 after dropping Arthur Andersen. ''People in this market are trading first and asking questions later,'' said Dave Briggs, head of equity trading at Federated Investors. ''The assumption is they must have something to hide.'' Peregrine had planned to report results today for the quarter ended March 31. A Peregrine spokeswoman, Kate Patterson, said KPMG needed time to complete its work. The company said it would provide more information next week.

title: Newspaper Tally Is Withdrawn
description: The Audit Bureau of Circulations released, then withdrew, its accounting of newspaper circulations yesterday.

title: COMCAST REPORTS $88.9 MILLION LOSS IN FIRST QUARTER
description: Comcast, the cable television operator planning to buy AT&T's cable unit, said yesterday that it had a first-quarter loss of $88.9 million on investments and the expense of buying and upgrading systems for digital TV and Internet services. Sales rose 20 percent, to $2.67 billion, more than analysts had expected. Cable revenue rose 12 percent. Profit, excluding items like depreciation and interest, rose 27 percent, to $808.2 million, or 85 cents a share.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Trade: Whispering With Japan
description: Australia and Japan decided to work toward a bilateral free trade agreement, but the step was so tentative that it was not mentioned in the official communiqu concluding a two-day visit by Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi. The prime minister, John W. Howard, left, said after their meetings that both sides want an agreement, but ''there will be difficulties.'' As in preliminary free trade talks now under way with the United States, Australia considers its agricultural exports as a central issue. Both the United States and Japan have crop subsidies that Australia claims are protectionist obstacles to free trade. Japan is Australia's largest trading partner, with annual two-way shipments of about $20 billion. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Starring Role for Blue Vinyl Siding
description: When Judith Helfand's parents put blue vinyl siding on their ranch house in Merrick, N.Y., in 1994, the fake-grain aesthetics bothered her less than the presence of polyvinyl chloride, which is hard to recycle and dangerous to produce. Ms. Helfand, a filmmaker, persuaded her parents to reclad the house in salvaged planks and, with Daniel B. Gold, went on to make ''Blue Vinyl,'' a documentary about PVC hazards that will run on HBO on Sunday. (The old vinyl was cut up and plastered with anti-PVC stickers.) The film focuses on rare cancers among workers in factories, including one she visited near Venice, above. Allen Blakey, a Vinyl Institute spokesman, called the film ''entertaining'' but ''way off the facts.'' EVE M. KAHN

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Priceline Reports A Profit
description: Priceline.com, the name-your-own-price Internet service, said yesterday that it had a first-quarter profit of $3.89 million, or 2 cents a diluted share, because of cost cutting. For the period a year earlier, the company reported a loss of $13.8 million, or 7 cents a diluted share. Sales in the most recent quarter fell 2.9 percent, to $261.9 million, from $269.7 million. Excluding stock-based pay, preferred-stock dividends and other costs, profit would have been $5.27 million, Priceline said. It said second-quarter profit, excluding certain items, would be 3 cents to 5 cents a diluted share on revenue of $320 million to $350 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call estimated 4 cents a share on sales of $376 million.

title: China's Heir Apparent Wins Cordial Reception From Bush
description: The man expected to become China's next leader had friendly meetings with President Bush and other top officials today as he neared the end of his first visit to the United States.

title: Cut! She's Chewing the Scenery; A Shih Tzu and Her Stage Mother Strive for Stardom
description: Gayle Kirschenbaum is obsessed with her dog. And, like many pet owners, she is convinced that her fellow humans delight in hearing endless stories about Chelsea, a 13-pound black and white Shih Tzu that she calls her ''dog-ter.''

description: Merrill Lynch & Company is considering a simpler stock-rating system that would make more frequent use of a word seldom heard on Wall Street: sell.

description: A study that was initiated after thousands of broodmares aborted mysteriously last year has shown a higher level of abortions by broodmares exposed to Eastern tent caterpillars and the caterpillars' waste.

title: The Beat Movement As Lived by Ginsberg
description: Allen Ginsberg was not only the Beat movement's second-best-known luminary after Jack Kerouac; he was also its most assiduous visual chronicler. Ginsberg's black-and-white photographs of Kerouac, Gregory Corso and others are definitive snapshots of an era.

title: Balanchine In a Variety Of Lights
description: It was exciting to be in the New York State Theater on Tuesday night, for the New York City Ballet opened its spring season with a marvelously danced program of three masterpieces by George Balanchine.

Sony, the world's largest electronics company, is looking for additional ways to sell the game software, music and movies it produces. Sony hopes to make its popular PlayStation 2 game console a one-stop vehicle for downloading entertainment in the home. Sony, which will pay an estimated $11 million for the stake, will also work with RealNetworks to develop software and ways to distribute digital media using Sony products. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUSE, MARY
description: HUSE-Mary, New York, NY. Died on April 30, 2002 in Greenville, SC. Surviving are her husband, Rupert Huse, children and grandchildren.

title: Magazine Award Winners, if Not Profit Champions
description: The National Magazine Awards ceremony, held yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria, has become the place where the traditional measures of publishing success -- size and profitability -- defer to editorial excellence.

title: Seeking an Epiphany at Center
description: They filed into the rickety old brick gymnasium one at a time, like a caravan of fans at an Indiana high school game in 1950. By the time Yao Ming stepped on the court he was not merely a Chinese national treasure. In a Webcam world, he had become a piece of basketball folklore more talked about than seen.

title: 2 Restaurant Chains Reassess Agencies
description: Long John Silver's, the seafood chain owned by Yorkshire Global Restaurants, is considering three agencies in a review for its broadcast creative account, with spending estimated at $20 million to $40 million.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Norwich: Child's Death Ruled a Homicide
description: For the second time in a week, the state medical examiner has ruled that a child's death was a homicide. The medical examiner's office on Tuesday said that Daniel Morgan III, 3 months old, died from blunt trauma to the head. Last week, Angel Torres, 15 months, died from similar trauma. Gary Kleeblatt of the State Department of Children and Families said it was rare to have two such cases in so short a time period. Last year, three children were killed in Connecticut homicides, Kleeblatt said. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Auto Sales Increased 2.9% in April; Only Ford Lagged
description: Every major automaker except Ford Motor reported sales increases last month, evidence of an economic recovery that helped propel the stock market today.

title: Youth Hurt at Party Dies After Week in Coma
description: A high school football player died Tuesday night of head injuries he received last week during an after-school drinking party where, police officials said, he was punched in the jaw by a teammate and fell onto a concrete patio.

title: Britain Starts Inquiry Into U.S. Toy Maker
description: Hasbro Inc., the toy maker, may have illegally fixed the prices of toys and games in Britain with the help of retailers and distributors, British officials said.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in World Business yesterday about large takeover deals in South Korea misstated the ranking of Daewoo Motor, whose main assets are being acquired by General Motors . It is the third largest automaker in the country, behind Hyundai and Kia, not the fourth.

title: Drug Suspect Killed in Fight With U.S. Agent, Authorities Say
description: A 31-year-old unarmed suspect in a drug investigation was shot and killed on a Brooklyn street yesterday after he struggled with a federal drug agent who had chased him down and tackled him, the authorities said.

title: Grand Renewal in the Bronx
description: There was a time, 15 or 20 years ago, when the New York Botanical Garden had taken on the rough edges of its surroundings in the Bronx. A rawness seemed to frame the grounds, and a mustiness had crept into the monumental Library Building. The grandeur of the garden's original design, 250 acres of remarkable plantings, including historic collections of conifers, lilacs and azaleas, seemed obscured. The garden drew lots of visitors, many from the immediate neighborhood, but it was valued as much for its open space as for its plants.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brockport: Hazing Suspected In Injuries
description: Two freshmen at the State University of New York's Brockport campus, including James King, son of the SUNY chancellor, Robert L. King, left, were hospitalized this week with infected leg wounds that may have resulted from fraternity hazing. Marion Schrank, vice president for student affairs at Brockport, said the Brockport police and the university were investigating reports of hazing, illegal under New York State law and against university policy. Chancellor King condemned the incident, but declined to discuss it. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary of the designer Rudolph de Harak on Tuesday misstated the name of the group that honored him with a lifetime achievement award in 1993. It was the American Institute of Graphic Arts, not Artists. A picture caption referred incorrectly to his work on the covers of McGraw-Hill paperbacks, including ''Personality and Psychotherapy.'' He designed the covers; the covers did not just incorporate his designs.

title: Tending to the Great Lawn, and Its Human Element
description: DROUGHT was the scheduled topic of discussion, but it had rained buckets the night before and so midmorning Maria Hernandez, the supervisor of the Great Lawn at Central Park, was dealing with the sodden ball fields and explaining what makes the grass grow.

title: Manufacturing Index Shows Slackening In Pace of Growth
description: Manufacturing expanded less than expected in April, according to a report of purchasing managers released today, suggesting that the economy's rebound slowed after the strongest quarterly growth in two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, NANCY (NEE MERGENTIME)
description: SILVERMAN-Nancy (nee Mergentime). Beloved wife of Irving, dear sister of Molly Bayer, devoted mother of Suzy Weisman, Ellen Siegel, William Silverman, Peggy Friedland and loving grandmother of Jolie, Deb, David, Erica, Daniel and Johana. She was our family queen. We will forever cherish her memory. Contributions may be sent to your favorite charity.

title: The In Crowd, 20 in All
description: This is the full field of 20 entered in the 128th Kentucky Derby, the most puzzling one in recent memory. The Churchill Downs oddsmaker, Mike Battaglia, set the morning line; Joe Drape made the selections in order of preference and provided the comments and honestly believes each of his first 10 selections can win this wide-open affair.

title: As Opponent Complains of Nastiness, Unions Make Nice to Newark's Mayor
description: Mayor Sharpe James picked up three key union endorsements today, as this city's rancorous mayoral race entered its final two weeks with fresh charges of political dirty tricks and negative campaigning.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Bridgeport: Not Guilty Plea In Sex Case
description: A man charged with impregnating a 10-year-old girl he met through an adopt-a-godparent program pleaded not guilty in Superior Court on Tuesday. James Kave, 75, of Bridgeport is being held in lieu of $500,000 bail and is charged with six counts of first-degree sexual assault, eight counts of risk of injury to a minor and two counts of fourth-degree sexual assault. If convicted, Mr. Kave faces up to 100 years in prison. In 1984, he was convicted of a sexual assault. The girl, six months pregnant, is in the custody of the State Department of Children and Families.

title: The Intrusion Explosion
description: Forget all about old-fashioned consumer surveys or even focus groups. The hot new technique in exploring your buying decision is called ''observational research'' or ''retail ethnography.'' This buying-spying uses hidden surveillance cameras, two-way mirrors and microphones concealed under counters.

title: Lewis Takes Lateral And Goes to Redskins
description: He has been jilted and he has done some jilting, but Marvin Lewis finds himself the defensive coordinator for the Washington Redskins. Not a head coach. Not yet.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Orthodox Holy Thursday and Orthodox Good Friday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: A.I.G. Makes Plans for Post-Greenberg Era
description: Maurice R. Greenberg, who as one of the longest-serving chief executives in America has been criticized for failing to develop a succession plan at the American International Group, reorganized his top ranks yesterday to provide for his eventual departure.

title: National Briefing | Washington: House Dismisses 11 Pages Over Marijuana
description: Eleven pages in the House of Representatives have been discharged for smoking marijuana, a spokesman for Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the minority leader, said. None were sponsored by Democratic lawmakers, the spokesman added. The dismissals were first reported on the Web site of Roll Call newspaper. The pages, high school juniors, perform administrative duties, including carrying messages to members and preparing the House or Senate chambers for sessions.

title: BLOCK SAYS EARNINGS WILL BE AT HIGH END OF FORECAST
description: H & R Block said yesterday that it prepared a record number of tax filings this year and that its income in the fiscal year that ended on Tuesday would be at the top of a range it had forecast earlier. The company, which is based in Kansas City, Mo., reported $2 billion in fees for tax preparation and related services from Jan. 1 to April 15 and said it had served 18.1 million clients. Block said it expected a profit near $2.30 a share for the year. It previously forecast a profit of $2.20 to $2.30 a share. The company also raised its forecast for fiscal 2003 to $2.60 to $2.75 a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call expected the company to earn $2.29 a share in fiscal 2002 and $2.55 in fiscal 2003.

title: U.S.-Led Raids in Afghanistan Press Search for Qaeda Fighters
description: Hundreds of American-led forces are hunting for Al Qaeda holdouts in Afghanistan, although two senior Afghan commanders whose troops also joined six raids in the past three weeks said today that only two suspects had been detained and none killed so far.

title: Deep Sorrow Chased by Joy
description: Pomerium

title: Basque Separatists Set Off Car Bomb Near Site of Big Soccer Game
description: The Basque separatist group E.T.A. detonated a car bomb close to a stadium in Madrid yesterday afternoon, hours before the start of an important European soccer game. Seventeen people were hurt, none seriously, in the blast. A second bomb, 30 minutes later, may have destroyed the bombers' getaway car.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Ashcroft's New Push On Internet Pornography
description: Attacking a recent Supreme Court decision as ''a dangerous window of opportunity for child abusers,'' Attorney General John Ashcroft pushed for new legislation to ban computer-simulated pornography. The measure, introduced on Monday in the House, has newly detailed references to computers and the Internet and is meant to be more precise than the version that ran afoul of the justices. David Stout (NYT)

title: You Say House Arrest, I Say Paradise
description: FIRST the judge handed down a bit of name-calling: ''common criminal,'' ''thief,'' ''convicted felon.'' Then scorn: ''You have allowed yourself to go from respected to being ridiculed.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Utility's Profit Falls
description: Scottish Power said its profit fell 9.7 percent in its 2002 fiscal year, but said that a recovery was under way, driven by its operations in the United States, where it owns PacifiCorp. Profit before tax, good will, amortization and exceptional items declined to 567 million ($829 million), compared with 628 million in the previous fiscal year. Revenue in the period, which ended March 31, was flat at 6.3 billion. The utility company took 1.3 billion in one-time pretax charges, in part, to account for the disposal of Southern Water, which it sold in March to a consortium led by the Royal Bank of Scotland Group, and for reorganization costs.

title: Arena Plan For Newark Is Said to Stall On Insurance
description: The McGreevey administration and the YankeeNets organization were close to agreement today on the terms of the joint state and private financing of a sports arena in downtown Newark, some officials close to the negotiations said. But others said some last-minute clarifications and apparent differences over those items were blocking the signing and announcement of a memorandum of understanding on the $355 million arena.

title: World Business Briefing: Australia:
description: TRADE: WHISPERING WITH JAPAN Australia and Japan de- cided to work toward a bilateral free trade agreement, but the step was so tentative that it was not mentioned in the official communique concluding a two-day visit by Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi. The prime minister, John W. Howard, left, said after their meetings that both sides want an agreement, but "there will be difficulties." As in preliminary free trade talks now under way with the United States, Australia considers its agricultural exports as a central issue. Both the United States and Japan have crop subsidies that Australia claims are protectionist obstacles to free trade. Japan is Australia's largest trading partner, with annual two-way shipments of about $20 billion. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Lieberman Has One Eye on '04 Run, the Other, Quite Expectantly, on Gore
description: Al Gore plucked him from the sidelines where he was a junior senator and put him on the Democratic national ticket in 2000. They almost made it to the White House, in fact beating George W. Bush and Dick Cheney in the popular vote.

title: Hearing Text, Not Tunes, on Your MP3 Player
description: TALKING computers are nothing new. Computers in sci-fi movies have been chatting away for years (think HAL in ''2001''), the physicist Stephen Hawking uses a voice synthesizer to communicate, and the occasional nerd still thinks it's cute to record a computer-generated answering-machine greeting.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: U.N. Effort To Revive Peace Talks
description: A United Nations Security Council team visited rebels and Rwandan troops ensconced in the eastern city of Kisangani to try to resurrect peace talks. Recent negotiations failed after the Rwandans and their rebel allies, who have long controlled the Congo River town, which is rich in diamonds and lumber, refused to accept President Joseph Kabila as head of an interim government.

title: Corrections
description: A television review of the PBS mini-series ''Commanding Heights'' on April 3 included erroneous credits supplied by the producers. Parts 1 and 2 were produced and directed by William Cran and Part 3 by Greg Barker -- not by Daniel Yergin and Sue Lena Thompson, who were executive producers for the series. Part 3 was also written by Mr. Barker; Mr. Yergin and Mr. Cran wrote only Parts 1 and 2.

title: A Culture Invested in Indigo, From Plant to Kimono
description: Here in a dark, damp factory west of Tokyo a man with navy-stained fingernails quietly, devotedly stirs a rectangular pool of blue. Beside the pool, sunk into the ground, sit eight earthenware vats of frothy indigo dye, Noriyuki Murata's fermented concoction.

title: PG&E Reports Earnings
description: The PG&E Corporation said today that it earned $631 million in the first quarter, reversing a loss from a year earlier. The company, based in San Francisco, said it earned $1.71 a share. A year earlier, the company posted a loss of $951 million, or $2.62 a share.

title: Kidd Named All-N.B.A.
description: Jason Kidd was named to the all-N.B.A. team yesterday for the fourth consecutive season. He became the first Net to achieve the honor.

title: Extremist has exploited issues that haunt the nation's political class from left to right : Le Pen, breaker of taboos
description: PARIS:  The man talks about "internment camps" or "transit camps" for illegal immigrants and "special trains" to carry them out of France. He designates himself nudgingly as a David fighting Goliath, and, half a breath later, more mockingly, as a nightmare bogeyman here to scare the hell out of, nudge, you know who.

title: A Skin Show at the Cooper-Hewitt
description: Modern design has long been preoccupied with surface, whether it be the aerodynamic teardrop or the glass wall. An exhibition at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum digs even deeper with ''Skin: Surface, Substance and Design,'' which opens on Tuesday. The more than 200 objects and photographs include Jurgen Bey's chairs, left, trapped in soft green plastic, and Petra Blaisse's wall of fabric, above. The exhibition focuses on ''the deliberately clinical and artificial,'' Ellen Lupton, its curator, said. ''This is not about macram and polished stone,'' she said. Through Sept. 15; Cooper-Hewitt, 2 East 91st Street; adults, $8. JULIE V. IOVINE

title: ISRAEL LIFTS SIEGE AS ARAFAT YIELDS SIX WANTED MEN
description: Palestinians trapped for a month in Yasir Arafat's humbled compound here erupted in celebration early this morning after Israeli forces withdrew in an American-brokered compromise.

title: Wider Inquiry Into Towers Is Proposed
description: After a seven-month investigation into the collapse of the World Trade Center left open more questions than it answered, federal officials proposed today that an expansive new effort determine exactly why the towers fell and how other buildings might be protected.

title: The Pro-Life Case for Cloning
description: Senator Orrin Hatch, a conservative Republican and longstanding opponent of abortion, jolted social and religious conservatives this week when he came out strongly in favor of therapeutic cloning. The Utah Republican offered a way of thinking about this divisive issue that could prove far more persuasive with wavering senators than the cramped policy championed by President Bush. Mr. Bush favors a ban on all human cloning, whether to make a human baby or for research on potentially lifesaving therapies.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: MEXICO: FREEDOM OF INFORMATION The Senate unanimously approved the nation's first freedom of information law, requiring the government to open records and files to the public. The law, which has been approved by the lower house, is considered an important step toward ending seven decades of government corruption and abuses shrouded by secrecy. It requires all branches of government to provide documents within 20 days to any citizen who requests them. Officials can withhold records only if their release endangers public or national security, or violates individual confidentiality. A commission is to monitor agencies' compliance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELSTEIN, LEO
description: EDELSTEIN-Leo. 90 years old. Died on May 1, 2002. Beloved husband of Edith. Adored and adoring father of Rhonda (Dr. Aaron) Harrison and Dr. Barbara Edelstein (Dr. Kenneth Goldman). Beloved grandpa of Jonathan and Alison Goldman and David and Brett Harrison. Died peacefully after a short illness. He will be remembered and loved by all those he touched in his long and healthy life. He will be missed but never forgotten. Services Thursday 11:00 AM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 N. Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: Seizing Arms And Leaving An Upset Town
description: When 200 American soldiers descended on Monday from a mountain crag into a tiny village on Afghanistan's eastern border with Pakistan, they found small children playing outside who quickly fled into their houses or were snatched up by their mothers.

title: Britons Say They Work Longer Hours, but They Produce Less
description: Britons are working longer hours than they did a decade ago, but are less productive than their counterparts in the United States and continental Europe, according to a survey released today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEDBY, MAGNUS ERLING
description: MEDBY-Magnus Erling. Born in Tromsoe, Norway, Magnus was a resident of Staten Island, N.Y. He died April 29, 2002 at 70 years of age. Beloved & devoted husband of Louise (Wechsler) & cherished brother-in-law of Joyce Wechsler. He leaves family in Norway: a brother, two sisters, children Per Tore and Mary Ann, and six grandchildren. He spent most of his working life in the Norwegian merchant marine rising to Chief Engineer, then thirteen years as Building Manager at Helen Keller Services. In lieu of flowers, donations to the charity of your choice.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: A Bill To Seize Drunken Drivers' Cars
description: The Legislature has passed and sent to the governor a bill to allow the authorities to seize the vehicles of drivers who have lost their licenses because of drunken driving or reckless homicide. The bill is intended to reduce the number of drivers who continue to drive after losing their licenses. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

A Distant View

title: No Absence Earns Bonus For Mayor In Bridgeport
description: Taxes are climbing. A budget deficit is looming. The mayor is awaiting trial on federal charges of racketeering, bribery and conspiracy. There seems to be no end to the indignities of living in Bridgeport, Conn., these days.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Brokers Indicted In Theft
description: Two principals of a Midtown brokerage firm were indicted yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on charges of stealing about $3 million from a German bank, the district attorney's office announced yesterday. The two principals, Russell Shain and Samantha Topola, both of Brooklyn, were charged with multiple counts of grand larceny and criminal possession of stolen property, and could face up to 25 years in prison if convicted. The firm, which is defunct, and various companies controlled by Mr. Shain and Ms. Topola, have also been charged with facilitating the theft, which related to selling block shares on the London Stock Exchange. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: There's Talk About a Talk Show

title: Hunting Down Pieces To Set a Proper Table
description: I FIRST saw the house that belonged to my husband's aunt and uncle, Sophie and Jack, about 20 years ago. It was in Malverne, N.Y., built in the early 1940's after Jack and Sophie's first child was born and they left Greenwich Village for Long Island.

title: FORD FOLLOWS G.M. IN BACKING OFF NO-INTEREST LOANS
description: Ford Motor joined General Motors yesterday in backing away from no-interest loans on new cars and trucks. Ford raised some cash discounts by $500 to $3,000, matching a level set by General Motors two days ago. Industrywide auto sales rose in April for the first time this year. The increased demand may help build profit at General Motors and cut losses at Ford and DaimlerChrysler's Chrysler unit, analysts said. Ford's latest incentive program, which runs through July 1, continues the zero percent financing on some vehicles in some regions.

title: A Hudson Niche, With Roots
description: FOR more than a year, Suzanne Bennett and Susana Meyer hunted for their ideal weekend getaway. The Manhattan theater professionals -- Ms. Bennett is the artistic associate at a women's theater and Ms. Meyer manages performers -- searched through three Hudson Valley counties.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Strong Chip Sales In March
description: Chip sales in March fell 25 percent from the previous year but recorded the strongest month-to-month increase since 1986, a trade association reported yesterday. The Semiconductor Industry Association said the short-term growth suggested that chip makers had worked through much of their excess inventory, and demand for electronics had begun to rise. Global sales in March were $10.75 billion, rising 7.2 percent from February. The sales fell sharply from the $14.41 billion reported in March 2001, but the 25 percent decline was the narrowest in months. Revenue increased in all regions, led by higher prices in dynamic random access memory, or DRAM, chips. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: INSIDE ART
description: Marble Head Of a Queen

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about a deal reached by Louis V. Gerstner Jr., the chairman and former chief executive of I.B.M., to write a book for HarperCollins about his tenure at the company misspelled the surname of an associate publisher who commented on the deal. She is Carie Freimuth, not Freimath.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Interest Rate Cut
description: Concerned over a run-up in the Swiss franc's value, the Swiss central bank reduced its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point, to 1.25 percent. The franc, which had been trading at seven-month highs, weakened after the cut, falling to 1.4583 to the euro and 1.6097 to the dollar. The central bank said the strong franc had threatened to dampen economic growth in Switzerland's export-dependent economy. Separately, the European Central Bank left its rates unchanged. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CLOSTER, BELOVED REUVEN
description: CLOSTER-Beloved Reuven, Gone five years already. Still miss your Wisdom, Humor and Love. Steve

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We have to give Tom Ridge a real job. Never has a person been given so much responsibility with so little authority.''

title: Castle Gandolfo Has Unusual Gate Test
description: As expected, the two Kentucky Derby challengers from Ireland, Johannesburg and Castle Gandolfo, cleared quarantine Wednesday evening. And at 2:45 p.m. today, Castle Gandolfo took a soggy stroll to the Keeneland starting gate to get a certification he needs before he can run in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATKINSON, CLINTON J.
description: ATKINSON-Clinton J. Please join Clint's family in celebrating his life on Friday, May 10, at 4 PM, All Souls Church, Lexington at 80th St.

title: Bob Akin, 66, Auto Racer Who Won at Sebring Twice
description: Bob Akin, who twice won the 12 Hours of Sebring, America's oldest automobile endurance race, died on Monday of injuries sustained during a test run last Friday. Akin, of Pocantico Hills, N.Y., was 66.

title: A Worthy Hate-Crimes Bill
description: In the wake of Sept. 11, President Bush sent out a welcome message that this nation would not tolerate attacks on Muslims or any other Americans because of their religion or national origin. Now Congress has a chance to back up the president's promise by passing an important hate-crimes bill, the Local Law Enforcement Enhancement Act, which would expand the scope of the federal government to investigate and prosecute anyone who targets racial and religious minorities, gays, the disabled and other groups because of hate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADDEO, JULIA, NEE DURANTE
description: ADDEO-Julia, nee Durante. Passed from this world on May 1, 2002, at age 106. A sweet, gentle woman who was loved by all. Mother of the late John, the late Alfred, the late Gloria Messina, the late Eugene, Anita Shargay, the late Joseph, and Richard; grandmother of 20 and great-grandmother of 34. Viewing Friday, 2-4 and 7-9, Oelker & Cox Funeral Home, 262 Main St., Mt. Kisco, (914) 666-5891. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, May 4, at 9:45am, St. Francis of Assisi, Mt. Kisco. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, Queens. Donations in her name may be made to Catholic Charities, 1011 First Avenue, New York, NY 10022.

title: Miller Has the Ball. How Scary Is That?
description: There were 20.1 seconds left in this heirloom of a game, 21 seconds to playoff nirvana in New Jersey. The Nets, who had not been to the second round of the playoffs in 18 years, had a 5-point lead and Kenyon Martin on the free-throw line. But there was little bedlam in the building. In the back of everyone's mind, all the spectators knew that if Martin did not make 2 free throws, it might not be over.

description: Spanierman Gallery

title: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: Modest Growth Seen
description: World trade, which contracted sharply last year, will resume growing this year, though only at a 1 percent pace, the World Trade Organization forecast in its annual report. Global trade in goods grew 12 percent in 2000 but retreated by 4 percent last year, the worst since 1982, largely because of the slump in technology industries, especially in the United States and Asia. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Budget Deal Remains Fluid, With Key Details Unsettled
description: A day after Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders shook hands on the framework of a budget deal, the agreement appeared to be about as solid as butter left out overnight, as staff members struggled today to shore up critical details and resolve outstanding disagreements.

title: Burnitz Is Giving the Mets Just What They Wanted
description: PHOENIX, May 2  There was one thing Steve Phillips did as the Mets' farm director that really irked Jeromy Burnitz.

title: Bush Pushes Senate on Court Nominations at Law Gathering
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 — President Bush told a White House gathering of lawyers and law professors today that Senate Democrats are putting justice at risk by stalling on many of his federal court nominations.

title: The Bronx Cheers A Homer By Giambi
description: Some of the Yankees saw it coming last week, when Jason Giambi ignored the boos in Oakland and hit like himself.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  O'CONNOR, HIS EMINENCE JOHN CARDINAL.
description: O'CONNOR-His Eminence John Cardinal. Cardinal O'Connor is still sorely missed for his inspirational homilies and is always remembered in our prayers and thoughts. Margaret Mary McDermott

title: India Jet Hits Building and Kills 7
description: NEW DELHI, May 3  A MIG-21 fighter jet, a warhorse of the Indian air force, caught fire today and crashed into a three story bank building in the northwestern city of Jalandhar. Seven people were killed and 14 wounded in a fire that roared for hours.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWEDOCK, HARRY
description: SCHWEDOCK-Harry. In Ben Lomond, CA, on May 2, after a long illness. Beloved husband of Linda, beloved father of Nancy Moules, Gail Lazaroff and Deserae Shipman. Dear brother of Sondra Israel and Alice K. Small. Cherished grandfather of Kelly, Jake, Kate, Kevin and Riley.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: First Virtual May Face S.E.C. Action
description: First Virtual Communications Inc., which makes video-conferencing software, said the Securities and Exchange Commission might bring civil action against the company. The S.E.C. said that it intended to recommend civil enforcement proceedings against the company, its executive chairman and two former officers, the company said in a news release. Company officials were not immediately available for comment. The proceedings relate to the April 1999 revision of the company's financial results for the previous year, First Virtual, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., said.

title: Catholics Back Strong Steps on Abuse, Poll Finds
description: American Roman Catholics say that priests who sexually abuse children and teenagers should be barred from participating in parish life and that any accusations of abuse should be investigated by local law enforcement rather than the church, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: The Early Bird Catches a Nap
description: BY 11 a.m. on Saturdays, many well-rested and recharged people are just climbing out of bed.

title: Making a Pilgrimage To Utopia-by-the-Sea
description: SEASIDE is a disconcerting place. Driving toward it on Highway 98 from Pensacola, to the west, is like running a gantlet. Hit Fort Walton Beach, and you're nearing the heart of the Florida Panhandle. The traffic thickens. Huge chain hotels form a wall between road and beach to the right; sprawl stalwarts like TGI Friday's and a (shuttered) Kmart crowd each other to the left. Then, at the east end of Destin, just past a giant digital sign flashing the words ''Hot Tub'' in red letters, there's a respite.

title: Banks Balked As Andersen Tried to Get A Settlement
description: In the end, the scuttling of talks aimed at settling securities lawsuits against Arthur Andersen by Enron stakeholders came down to a decision by Wall Street to try to limit its own liability for Enron's collapse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PECK, DOROTHY DUNHAM
description: PECK-Dorothy Dunham. Died Tuesday, April 30, in Jacksonville, Florida. She was born in 1906 in Brooklyn, NY, the daughter of Fredrick Cool & Alma Gelhausen Dunham. She attended the Berkley School in Brooklyn, New Rochelle, NY, High School, and graduated from Wellesley College in 1927. Always involved in volunteer work, she was a member of many organizations, including the Garden Club of Rye (NY), the Twig Organization of Rye, and she was a member of the Board of Managers of United Hospital in Port Chester, NY. She had resided at Vicar's Landing in Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida, for the last eleven years. Dorothy was predeceased by her husband, Edgar Wallace Peck, President of Peck & Peck. She is survived by her son, E. Wallace Peck of Ponte Vedra Beach; her daughter, Margaret Peck Johnson of Alken, SC, her seven granchildren and nine greatgrandchildren. For information, call Quinn-Shalz, a Family Funeral Home & Cremation Centre, Jacksonville Beach, FL, 904-249-1100.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Woman Is Sentenced For Fraud
description: A Pennsylvania woman, who was accused of stealing a man's life savings and fraudulently collecting thousands of dollars in security deposits and rent from Lower East Side residents for public housing, pleaded guilty and was sentenced yesterday to two to six years in prison, the district attorney's office said. The woman, Mary Garcia, 51, promised people that she could deliver leases for the New York City Housing Authority and collected payments and fees.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COACH INC., New York, the seller of luxury leather goods, said it planned a 2-for-1 split of its common stock for shareholders of record as of June 19. Coach's common shares have more than tripled in value since they were first sold to the public in October 2000.

title: Los Angeles Inner City Beset By Chronic Health Problems
description: Ten years after riots burned through the inner city here, Los Angeles is marking the occasion with a cascade of speeches, and to a remarkable degree, the talk is rosy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINK, EDWARD
description: FINK-Edward. Of Fort Lee, NJ. Beloved husband of Constance. Devoted father of Maxine Cole and Carol Kowitt. Loving grandfather of David, Adam, Joshua and Benjamin. Services Friday 10:30AM ''Gutterman-Musicant'', Hackensack, NJ, (1-800-378-1892).

title: Sports of The Times; A Big Game Nets Can Call Their Own
description: THERE were tears on the Nets' bench as the final seconds ticked away. Tears of joy, and of relief, that by the time one of the great playoff games in memory and maybe in history was finally ending, Reggie Miller was out of bullets and chances, out of what could have been one of the worst Nets nightmares of all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCARTHY, SR. MIRIAM DOLORES.
description: McCARTHY-Sr. Miriam Dolores. Beloved member of the Sisters of Charity of Mount Saint Vincent, died Wednesday, May 1, 2002 at Convent of Mary the Queen. Born in Brooklyn, she was the daughter of the late William and Josephine Sullivan McCarthy. Her sister, Muriel Jones, and her brother, William, also predeceased her. Dear aunt of grandnieces and nephews. Reposing at the Convent of Mount Saint Vincent, 6301 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, NY on Friday, 1:00 to 8:00pm. Funeral Mass Saturday, 10am at the convent. Interment to follow at St. Joseph's Cemetery, Yonkers, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Development Fund of the Sisters of Charity of New York, 6301 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, NY 10471.

If signed by President Vicente Fox the bill would disqualify parties from elections if they fail to comply. Parties that hold open primaries would be exempt. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: Ida Milgrom, 94, Dies; Helped Free a Son Held by Soviets
description: Ida Milgrom, a teacher, economist and musician who helped to lead an international campaign to free her son, the Soviet dissident Anatoly B. Shcharansky, from prison, died on Wednesday in Jerusalem. She was 94.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Shell's Profit Falls
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group reported a 42 percent drop in first-quarter profit, amid a slump in energy prices. Net income fell to $2.26 billion, compared with $3.89 billion in the period a year earlier. Rivals like BP and Exxon Mobil have recently reported steep slides in first-quarter profit, reflecting the slowing economy's weakened demand for oil and natural gas. Royal Dutch/Shell said it was proceeding with a cost-cutting program that would help it meet growth targets in a difficult environment. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

description: * Hershey Foods, Hershey, Pa., consolidated the media buying for its account, with billings estimated at $150 million, at OMD, New York, part of the Omnicom Group. The media planning duties remain divided between the agencies that create campaigns for Hershey products: DDB Worldwide, part of Omnicom, and Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of WPP.

description: Calpine, the nation's largest independent power producer, said here today that it had a first-quarter loss of $74.3 million after scaling back expansion plans and canceling $3 billion of turbine purchases.

description: Mariss Jansons led the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra in an interestingly bifurcated program on Tuesday evening at Carnegie Hall. Before the intermission, he conducted substantial new works by Christopher Rouse, a composer who always writes colorfully and challengingly for orchestra, and Michael Hersch, a relative newcomer whose music has attracted considerable attention in recent seasons.

title: Residential Real Estate; Co-ops and Town Houses in Harlem
description: Another chapter in the transformation of Harlem is being written on Frederick Douglass Boulevard and the blocks that adjoin it on 120th and 121st Streets. A 73-apartment co-op building and nine town houses are under construction in a development called Harriet Tubman Gardens, with the first residents to move in during the fall.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Drug Maker's Profit Is Down
description: The largest drug maker in Ireland, the Elan Corporation, said its first-quarter earnings fell 35 percent on investment losses. Net income dropped to $50 million, or 14 cents a share, from $76.4 million, or 22 cents, in the period a year earlier. Revenue rose 3.3 percent, to $443.6 million.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Giuliani Endorses Faso
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani made a rare return trip to City Hall yesterday to endorse Assemblyman John J. Faso, a Republican who is running for state comptroller. Before endorsing Mr. Faso, the former minority leader in the State Assembly, Mr. Giuliani walked through his old haunts with his successor, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. Mr. Bloomberg noted that it was just about six months ago that Mr. Giuliani endorsed his candidacy for mayor outside City Hall. ''It worked out quite well,'' Mr. Bloomberg said. Michael Cooper (NYT)

description: ''Deuces Wild'' is a film that desperately wants to be a music video circa 1983. All that's missing from its absurdly stagy scenes of gang warfare on the streets of Brooklyn in 1958 is the pounding screech of Michael Jackson's ''Beat It.'' The music we get instead is a tepid rock score by Stewart Copeland spiced with mostly obscure grade-B oldies-but-goodies.

description: Halfway through ''ABC Africa,'' Abbas Kiarostami's new documentary, the screen goes dark. It is midnight, and the power has been turned off in the Ugandan city of Masaka, leaving the director and members of his small crew, who had been filming a cloud of mosquitoes, with no illumination. And for about five long minutes, the audience is also in the dark, listening to idle conversation (in Farsi, with English subtitles) as the portable, battery-powered digital video camera keeps rolling.

description: The Army inspector general was told to examine whether Army personnel had tried to challenge civilian authority by improperly enlisting Congress to try to save an $11 billion artillery program. Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld expressed anger that someone in the Army's legislative liaison office might have faxed ''talking points'' defending the Crusader automated howitzer program to Capitol Hill shortly after the service was told it had 30 days to study alternatives if the program were canceled. The program has not yet been killed, Mr. Rumsfeld said, although he suggested it was in jeopardy. Thom Shanker (NYT)

title: That's My Spidey
description: Spider-Man seems to be everywhere these days, which is just the way I like it. The movie version of the comic I created 40 years ago with the artist Steve Ditko opens today, and almost everyone I meet asks the same question: Why is Spidey still so popular after all these years?

description: Again and again, the Nets took each dagger Reggie Miller threw at them and responded with a vengeance, refusing to let their record-breaking season end in futility.

title: ON STAGE AND Off; Counting Down To Tony Night
description: So here we are again, at the end of one race and the beginning of another. Endings first: when the curtain fell on the opening night of ''The Man Who Had All the Luck'' at the American Airlines Theater on Wednesday, it was the end of Tony eligibility for the 2001-02 season, concluding a year when Broadway swooned -- and rallied -- as never before. At the same time, it signified the beginning of what promises to be one of the most interesting Tony contests in several years.

title: Moscow Journal; Where 'Living While Black' Means Living in Fear
description: Taddele Gebre, a refugee from southern Sudan by way of Ethiopia, had his most recent brush with fear last month in the Moscow metro. Returning home from church, he entered a subway car and found himself facing about 20 youths, some with shaved heads.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Dispute Over Trade Bill
description: Republicans threatened to kill a trade bill being considered by the Senate after Democrats inserted a provision that would assist steelworkers who lost their health insurance when their employers went bankrupt. Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic majority leader, called the measure a ''bridge'' for the workers while Congress debated how to deal with the problem. Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, said he would use Senate rules to block the bill, which would grant President Bush more authority in negotiating trade deals, as long as it contained the steel provision. Richard W. Stevenson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Voluntown: School May Close A Month Early
description: Facing a budget shortfall, the local Board of Education may close the only elementary school in the town, which is northeast of New London, on Monday, leaving about 380 students homebound. Donald Mann, the board chairman, said the school is facing a $77,000 budget shortfall after incurring unexpected costs this year. State law prohibits the board from spending during a budget deficit. The State Department of Education is prepared to seek a court injunction to force the school to remain open until the matter is worked out. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Onstage and Backstage, a Chinese Tale of Operatic Passions
description: ''Actors thrive on adoration,'' someone says about the opera performer Lin Chung (Chao-te Yin) in ''Fleeing by Night.'' But that doesn't seem to be the case for this stricken stage cynosure; he's more the crying-on-the-inside type --deep inside. This backstage look at his world, set in 1930's China, could be called ''Peking Soap Opera Blues.'' It is a melodrama that gives almost every character an opportunity to choke back thwarted desires quietly in a corner, the shadows not quite masking the pained eyes.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Trying For A Fresh Start
description: In an effort to secure good relations with Indonesia, the president-elect of East Timor, Jos Alexandre Gusmo, visited President Megawati Sukarnoputri to invite her to the tiny nation's independence celebration on May 20. East Timor voted nearly three years ago to break from Indonesia, which ruled the former Portuguese colony after invading it in 1975. Ms. Megawati's aides have said she will attend despite the objections of some military officers and veterans. The military opposed independence and several officers are being tried on charges stemming from violence at the time of the vote. Jane Perlez (NYT)

title: Muscles Ripple, Webs Unfurl, Hormones Race
description: THE first thing you see, after the house lights dim and before the credits begin, is a flurry of comic book panels accompanied by the Marvel logo. These inky, pulpy images are followed by the glossy, silvery letters of the title, and the contrast suggests that comic books and large-scale Hollywood blockbusters may not be as compatible as the movie studios would have us believe. Traditional comic books are cheap, stubbornly low-tech and sometimes slow moving.

title: McGreevey Abandons a Plan to Tax Commuters From Pennsylvania
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey said today that he would give up his proposal to tax commuters from Pennsylvania. The plan was strongly opposed by legislators, including some in his own party, because Pennsylvania then could similarly start taxing commuters from New Jersey.

title: 36 Hours | Niagara-on-the-Lake
description: THOUGH situated in Ontario only 20 minutes from the thunderous roar of Niagara Falls, it is impossible not to feel light years away from its touristy neighbor up river the moment you enter Niagara-on-the-Lake. Visitors flock to this quiet village to take in the Victorian architecture, tour the nearby wineries, or visit battle sites from the War of 1812. But the main reason people return to Niagara-on-the-Lake year after year is the theater. The Shaw Festival, held from the beginning of April to the end of November, specializes in the works of Bernard Shaw (1856-1950) and his contemporaries, showcasing, in the words of the festival's artistic director, Christopher Newton, ''plays about the beginning of the modern world.'' Among others whose works are regularly featured are Nol Coward, Oscar Wilde, Lillian Hellman, Arthur Miller, Anton Chekhov and Agatha Christie, as well as the music of Gershwin and Porter. If you come, be sure to book ahead. While roughly a dozen productions are performed each season in three different theaters, the sites are not large (about 1,400 seats in total) and at the height of summer tickets can be scarce.

description: Tom Gerety, who has served as president of Amherst College since 1994, announced he was resigning, effective June 30, 2003. Mr. Gerety, 55, said that most of the projects undertaken in his tenure -- including the raising of $270 million over five years that ended in June 2001 -- were ''either completed or nearing completion,'' and that it was a ''good time to make the transition.'' The college, in western Massachusetts, expects to form a search committee for a new president in the next few weeks.

On a couple of new DVD's, Mr. Lee says he wanted the average person to identify with Spider-Man, a k a Peter Parker, which meant giving him more feelings and saddling him with worries about girls, family and friends.

Except that in South Asia such a system is called democracy.

title: A Day for Sunday Drivers on Two Wheels
description: No sideswiping taxis, no fume-belching buses, no zigzagging skaters, no oblivious jaywalkers, no manic bike messengers. One day a year, bicyclists in New York City can negotiate the streets, highways and bridges of the five boroughs without many of the usual distractions. That day this year is Sunday, when 30,000 riders are expected to take part in Bike New York, the car-free, 42-mile pedal parade that is the nation's largest bicycle rally.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Norwalk: Law To Reduce Pollution
description: Gov. John G. Rowland signed legislation yesterday to force the state's six oldest and most polluting power plants to reduce sulfur dioxide emissions. The law gives coal- or oil-burning power plants in Bridgeport, Middletown, Milford, Montville, New Haven and Norwalk until Jan. 1, 2005, to reduce the emissions by roughly 9,000 tons a year. Last year, Mr. Rowland vetoed a similar bill because he said it could lead to power shortages. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINNEY, ATTORNEY A. SEARLE,
description: PINNEY-Attorney A. Searle, age 81, of Brookfield, CT, retired senior partner in the law firm of Pinney, Payne, Van Lenten, Burrell, Wolfe and Dillman of Danbury, CT, died on Tuesday, April 30, 2002 at his residence. He was the husband of the late Evelyn (Roberts) Pinney. Attorney Pinney was born September 14, 1920 in New Milford, CT, a son of the late Jairus Searle and Elsie M. (Lightfoot) Pinney. Educated in the Danbury, CT public schools, he graduated from the Danbury High School, Class of 1938, and received a Bachelor of Arts Degree from Tufts University in 1942. Upon graduation from Tufts University, he entered the U.S. Army Air Force, serving as a navigator on B-24 bombers in Europe. Earning the rank of Second Lieutenant, he was honorably discharged in 1945. Through the G.I. Bill, Attorney Pinney entered Harvard University School of Law, from which he graduated with a Bachelor of Law Degree in February, 1948. Attorney Pinney began his career as an associate with a law firm in Bridgeport, CT until the fall of 1948, at which time he, with his life long friend, the late Supreme Court Justice T. Clark Hull, joined the late Judge Louis George to form the law firm of George, Hull and Pinney in Danbury. The firm merged in 1958, and became known as Sherwood, George, Hull and Pinney, and subsequently expanded through the 1960's and 1970's to become known as Pinney, Payne, Van Lenten, Burrell, Wolfe and Dillman, from which Attorney Pinney retired as Senior Partner after more that 50 years of practice. A resident of Brookfield, CT since the late 1940's, Attorney Pinney was active in civic affairs in both Brookfield and Danbury. He served on the Executive Committee of the Danbury Industrial Corporation, and was a member of the Housatonic Industrial Development Corporation. He was also an active member in the administration and growth of the Danbury Hospital Development Fund. He served as a member of the Connecticut State University System since 1979, and was its Chairman from 1991 through 1995. In appreciation of his service, Pinney Hall, a dormitory on the Western Connecticut State University's westside campus was named in his honor. Attorney Pinney was a member of the State of Connecticut House of Representatives, where he served as Minority Leader of the Connecticut General Assembly and was Republican State Central Committee Chairman during the 1960's. As a member of the Connecticut Bar Association, he was Chairman of the Statewide Grievance Committee, a member of the Judicial Council on Legal Ethics, the Committee on Professional Discipline and the Committee on Liaison with the Courts. In recognition of his many contributions to the Bar he was named the recipient of the John Eldred Schields Distinguished Professional Service Award in 1991. He was appointed Chairman of the Judicial Council on Legal Ethics by the Chief Justice of the State of Connecticut to develop the necessary procedures for implementing rules changes in the attorneys' disciplinary process. Locally, Attorney Pinney was a member of the Congregational Church of Brookfield, served as a Town Counsel for the Town of Brookfield from 1951 through 1975, was a member of the Board of Trustees of the Wooster School from 1960 through 1991, was a member of the Board of Directors of the Savings Bank of Danbury since 1972, on which he served as Chairman. He was also the recipient of the Cecil J. Previdi Award in 1997 which is awarded by the Mayor of the City of Danbury in recognition of his contributions to the business community. He was an avid reader of British mystery novels and loved to travel. Attorney Pinney is survived by his sister, Alma Jean Hayman, of Roanoke, VA, and his nephew, Vincent White, of Lakeland, FL. Memorial services will be held on Thursday, May 16th at the Congregational Church of Brookfield, Route 25, Brookfield Center, Connecticut at 11:00 A.M. Interment will be private. There are no calling hours. The Hull Funeral Home, Sixty Division Street, Danbury for further information.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Dealing With Cable Debts
description: NTL, a large British cable company, reached an agreement with its lending banks on a reorganization that would give bondholders control of the company, its chief executive, Barclay Knapp, left, said. The holders of about half the face value of NTL bonds agreed to the plan earlier this month. Under the terms of the agreement, bondholders would swap $10.6 billion in debt for equity. Some NTL subsidiaries incorporated in the United States will file for bankruptcy protection on May 6, to better allow the company to reorganize its operations. Separately, Telewest Communications, another British cable company, said it would eliminate 1,500 jobs, or 14 percent of its work force. Telewest said it lost 166 million ($243 million) in the first quarter. Analysts have long speculated that Telewest may follow in NTL's footsteps and restructure its debts. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

It is the Subcommittee on the Constitution, not the Subcommittee on Commercial and Administrative Law.

title: Who Needs Architecture, When Dinner Is Calling?
description: SEASIDE is a self-contained never-never land, and that's part of its charm. But for all of its spiritual isolation, the place is physically closer to a wider variety of distractions, some of which are reminders that the Panhandle is the most typically Southern part of Florida. Food is one reminder.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: 15 Years For Corrupt Detective
description: A former Chicago chief of detectives was sentenced in federal court to 15 years and eight months in prison for masterminding a jewel theft ring that stole millions. The defendant, William Hanhardt, 73, pleaded guilty to racketeering in interstate theft last October. Mr. Hanhardt has also been ordered to pay $5 million in restitution. Prosecutors had sought a sentence of 25 years for Mr. Hanhardt, who retired in 1986. His ring robbed eight jewelry salesmen in the 1980's and 1990's.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett-Packard To Change Symbol
description: Hewlett-Packard, which announced on Wednesday that its proposed merger with Compaq Computer had been formally approved in a shareholder vote, said yesterday that it would change its Big Board trading symbol from HWP to HPQ on Monday. Hewlett expects to close its merger on May 3. The trading of Compaq common stock will be suspended before the opening of the market on May 6. Compaq shares, which currently trade under the symbol CPQ, will be suspended before the market's opening on Monday, the company said. It will officially introduce itself with a ceremony on Tuesday. Shares in Hewlett-Packard closed the day at $17.09, up 23 cents. Compaq shares also closed up, ending the day at $10.76. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: A Weekend Of Going Nowhere
description: The Police Department yesterday asked drivers to stay out of Manhattan this weekend, especially on Sunday, when officials expect two parades and a bike tour to bring traffic in some areas to a near standstill. Street closings Sunday during the Cuban Day Parade along the Avenue of the Americas and the Salute to Israel Parade on Fifth Avenue will also significantly affect bus routes, as will Bike New York, a five-borough bike tour, Chief Michael Scagnelli said. ''If you drive in, you will be sitting in traffic,'' he said. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Job Cuts At AT&T
description: AT&T Canada said it was cutting its work force by 1,000 people, or about 20 percent. The troubled company, which is based on Toronto and has debts of 4.7 billion Canadian dollars ($3 billion), also said it had reached a new agreement with bank lenders to pay for its business plans through late 2003. Its first-quarter loss was 157.6 million Canadian dollars ($101 million), a slight improvement over last year, mostly because of lower amortization expenses. Revenue was 1 percent lower at 383.8 million Canadian dollars. AT&T Canada, which is 31 percent owned by the AT&T Corporation, is awaiting a critical regulatory ruling, expected later this month, on complaints about high access network charges levied by Canada's two biggest phone companies, Bell Canada and the Telus Corporation. Bernard Simon (NYT)

We will miss his wisdom and guidance in interfaith dialogue. International Jewish Committee for Interreligious Consulations Seymour D. Reich, Chairman Rabbi Dr. Leon Feldman, Secy.

title: This Small Tool Suits Any Occasion
description: THERE should be a secret handshake or some sort of covert signal of recognition when you meet another person who owns a Leatherman tool. It is not that we are smug exactly, but we do have a notable little edge of confidence and capability.

title: Decisive Weekend Is at Hand
description: This is the weekend of decision for N.C.A.A. Division I lacrosse. The regular season and conference tournaments will end tomorrow and the 12 berths in the N.C.A.A. tournament for men and the 16 for women will be filled Sunday.

title: Now That Yasir Arafat Is Free
description: With Yasir Arafat ending his monthlong confinement in Ramallah by calling Israeli troops Nazis and Ariel Sharon coming under pressure from his Likud Party to reject a Palestinian state, peace is not at hand in the Middle East. Yet the freeing of Mr. Arafat, the withdrawal of most Israeli forces from Palestinian cities, the disruption of the Palestinian terror campaign and the deepening American-Saudi commitment to a peace offensive all indicate that this is a pivotal moment.

title: Court Says First Amendment Doesn't Shield Nike From Suit
description: California's highest court ruled yesterday that the First Amendment did not shield Nike from a lawsuit accusing it of fraud for asserting that its overseas workers received adequate wages and that its working conditions complied with safety regulations.

title: Venezuelan Says Revolt Hasn't Derailed His Plans
description: Relaxing with a cigarette, wearing jeans, loafers and leisure jacket, President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela hardly looked like he had been to the edge of the political abyss and back. But in an interview away from the presidential palace, Mr. Chvez said the experience of being ousted from office last month in a popular uprising, then restored to power two days later, had not fundamentally changed him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, ARLENE
description: KELLY-Arlene. Former Lynbrook resident, on May 1, 2002. Beloved wife of John J. Loving mother of Donna and Alex Vock, Christine, Jenine, Elaina and Adam Cannizzaro and the late Christopher John. Dear grandmother of Elais and Noah. Family will receive friends Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9pm at the Flinch and Bruns Funeral Home, Inc., 34 Hempstead Ave (Corner Peninsula Blvd), Lynbrook. Religious service 8pm. Memorial service and interment, Tuesday, 1pm at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Memorial SloanKettering Hospital would be appreciated.

title: Boston Priest Is Arrested On Charges of Child Rape
description: The Rev. Paul R. Shanley, who is accused of molesting at least 26 boys while he was a priest in the Boston Archdiocese, was arrested today in San Diego and charged with three counts of child rape.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the Federal Emergency Management Agency's reopening of more than 7,000 rejected applications for housing aid misstated the location for a meeting called by community groups with complaints about the agency. It will be 2 to 5 p.m. on Sunday at Public School 124, 40 Division Street, in Manhattan, not at 141 Worth Street.

title: U.S., IN SURPRISE, ANNOUNCES GLOBAL TALKS FOR MIDEAST; ISRAEL BACKED BY CONGRESS
description: On a day when Congress moved to express unqualified political solidarity with Israel, the Bush administration committed itself today to join Europe, Russia and the United Nations in a conference on Middle East peace early this summer.

title: The Hubble Achievement
description: It seems hard to believe that we have already grown used to seeing images from the Hubble Space Telescope in the dozen years since it was first launched. But the startling pictures released this week from a newly restored Hubble are a reminder that we had, in fact, begun to take for granted our ability to peer into deep space, an ability no generation of humans has ever possessed before. In a sense, these new images, produced with cameras and power sources that were added or rejuvenated during a space shuttle flight in March, feel something like learning to see all over again. They remind us what an astonishing chapter of astronomical understanding, for scientists and laymen alike, the Hubble Space Telescope has opened.

title: Renting It Out, Reluctantly
description: AS summer approaches, Terry Forrest, a schoolteacher from Westbury, N.Y., dreams about lounging on the sweeping porch of his spacious summer home overlooking Lake Placid, going for a bracing dip in the lake before breakfast and greeting the day's sunset with a refreshing gin-and-tonic.

title: Free Open-Air Screening of Met's 'Tosca'
description: A live performance of ''Tosca'' that is closing the Metropolitan Opera's season -- and perhaps the Met career of Luciano Pavarotti -- will be shown free on a big screen in Lincoln Center Plaza on May 11 at 8 p.m., the Met's general manager, Joseph Volpe, announced this week.

title: Lawyer Says Driving Drunk Doesn't Make Officer Guilty
description: An off-duty police officer was clearly driving drunk last August when his minivan struck a pregnant woman and her family in Brooklyn, but he was not responsible for their deaths, his lawyer told jurors yesterday during closing statements in his manslaughter trial.

description: Adding further turns to a tangled tale, a French court acknowledged a claim today by Vivendi Universal that a wireless electronic voting system used at its shareholder meeting last week had malfunctioned and ordered the company to convene a new meeting as quickly as possible.

title: Union Shoots Down Extra Playoff Games
description: The National Basketball Players Association denied Commissioner David Stern's request to extend the first-round playoff series format from a maximum five games to seven, Stern said last night. ''A two-game extension would be an infusion of millions of dollars,'' Stern said before last night's Nets-Pacers game. ''It would raise the salary cap. It would raise the basketball-related income. But they're not interested in it.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PREZZANO, WILBUR J., DDS,
description: PREZZANO-Wilbur J., DDS, 90, of Vero Beach, Florida died on May 1, 2002. Loving husband of Adelaide. Devoted father of sons Dr. Peter, Vero Beach, Fl; Wilbur, Jr, Charleston, SC; Richard, West Lake Village, CA; Robert, Alpharetta, GA; Paul, Pittsford, NY, 13 grandchildren and six greatgrandchildren. Dr. Prezzano was the former President of the American Association of Orthodontists, American Board of Orthodontics, Dental Society of the State of NY, NY Academy of Dentistry, and the Ninth District Dental Society. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Indian River Hospital Foundation, Vero Beach, Fl 32960

title: Florida Getaway
description: The island of Key Biscayne, five miles from downtown Miami, has a 402-room Ritz-Carlton that opened last July. The resort's Summer Island Getaway plan includes a room, valet parking, full breakfast for two and 20 percent off spa services for $199 a night and up, for two people. Valid dates: May 29 through Sept. 28. Call the resort directly at (305) 365-4500 or the Ritz-Carlton resorts at (800) 241-3333. On the Web: www.ritzcarlton.com .

title: Case of Lost Miami Girl Puts Focus on an Agency
description: The disappearance of 5-year-old Rilya Wilson while in state custody is just an extreme example of an overburdened agency's struggle to keep up with the demands of caring for an increasing number of vulnerable children, state officials and child advocates say.

title: Child Rape Charges Filed Against Priest
description: The Rev. Paul R. Shanley, who is accused of molesting at least 26 boys while a Roman Catholic priest in the Boston area, was arrested in San Diego on three counts of child rape.

title: Children Who Live in Dread
description: Most of the debris from the World Trade Center has been removed, and discussions about what to build on the site have begun. But a survey of New York City's schoolchildren released this week reminds us that the psychological wounds of this disaster will linger for years. Indeed, the study, sponsored by the Board of Education, shows that thousands of children will need counseling help to free themselves of the dread that has gripped their lives since Sept. 11.

title: Merrill Research Chief Will Leave in 6 Months
description: Thomas W. Davis, a vice chairman of Merrill Lynch & Company who oversees the firm's research department, said yesterday that he planned to leave the firm in six months.

title: An Actor Prepares, Without Mask and Mirror
description: MORE gamin than advertised, Billy Crudup no sooner pops up -- unassuming and unrecognized in his leather jacket and boot camp haircut -- from the Eighth Avenue subway than he veers into the catacombs beneath the Royale Theater. There, polite as a Shubert Alley tour guide, he picks the safest path past a gantlet of Dumpsters. This may not be the only way for a Broadway star to gain access to his dressing room, but it is Mr. Crudup's way.

description: MAIMIN-Joseph G. Beloved husband of Carolyn. Adored father of Barbara and Steve Regen and Hank Maimin. description: This town in the forest is a place of dark secrets some new, some old and some underscoring the paradoxes that swirl around the strength here of Jean-Marie Le Pen, the extreme right-wing insurgent who will challenge President Jacques Chirac in a runoff vote for the presidency of France on Sunday.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Executive Shift At Palm
description: Palm Inc., the maker of hand-held computers and software, said yesterday that Todd Bradley, currently the chief operating officer of the company's Solutions Group, would become its president as well. He will be primarily responsible for the company's hand-held computer hardware. The move can be seen as a step toward the division of Palm into separate hardware and software companies. ''We're building the management bench strength we need to support the eventual external separation of our two Palm businesses,'' the chief executive, Eric A. Benhamou, said in a statement. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: S.E.C.'s Leader Evolves Slowly In a Climate Enron Altered
description: Harvey Pitt was insistent. The way companies account for the stock options they give to executives, he told a Senate panel in late March, had absolutely nothing to do with the collapse of Enron, whatever the conventional wisdom held.

title: National Briefing | Plains: South Dakota: More Arrests For H.I.V. Exposure
description: The police have arrested two more men on charges of having unprotected sex, though they knew they were infected with the virus that causes AIDS. One of the men, James Lee Woods, 41, was charged with four counts of H.I.V. exposure involving three men. The other, William Kenneth Jenigen, 35, was charged with exposure that involved three people. The two, who lived together in Aberdeen, could face up to 15 years in prison for each charge if they are convicted. A college student in Huron was arrested last week on similar charges. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WADE, CHARLES
description: WADE-Charles. No one could have known a more loyal and sincere friend than Charles Wade. We had known each other for over 30 years and had worked together for over 20 years. He was a man of integrity and dignity; his sincerity, along with his insight, were appreciated by all who knew him. He will be deeply missed. My deepest condolences to his family and to his son, Charles Wade Jr. Robert Shapiro City Center Real Estate, Inc.

title: A Maxi City Gives Thumbs Up To a Mini Car
description: I HAD a Mini for 24 hours last week on a crisp day before the rain came. Cobalt blue and with a Union Jack tattooed to its roof, the 12-foot-long car was as cute as a puppy, and just as magnetic.

title: Arrests Made In a Sweep Against Thefts Of Identities
description: Federal authorities announced a nationwide sweep of identity theft arrests today, charging the people with using false credentials to cover up a murder, sell homes belonging to the elderly and exercise 176,000 stock options belonging to an unknowing company executive.

description: McCULLOCH-Patricia Robineau. On April 27. Loving wife of the late John I.B. McCulloch. Devoted mother of Jeanne, Darcy and Catherine. Beloved stepmother of Mary Elizabeth, Keith, Roderick and Scott. Beloved aunt of Richard, Frances, William and Timothy. Cherished grandmother of Samuel, Alexander, Charlotte, Harry, Alistair and Eloise, and 12 step-grandchildren, and seven step-great-grandchildren. Memorial service at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church on Friday, May 17, at 3 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Luard Scholarship at The EnglishSpeaking Union, 144 East 39th Street, New York, N.Y. 10016.

title: Bush Drops Unpopular Plan To Raise Cost of Student Loans
description: In the face of strong Congressional opposition, the White House has abandoned a proposal that would raise the cost of federally backed loans for college students, administration officials said today.

title: Paper Maker From Dublin Being Courted By U.S. Firm
description: Madison Dearborn Partners, a private equity firm based in Chicago, is in talks to acquire the Jefferson Smurfit Group, the large paper and packaging company in Ireland, people close to the companies said today.

title: Extra State Aid Fails to Speed Teachers' Deal
description: Even with a tentative state budget that provides more education aid, the New York City school system was embroiled in conflict yesterday as teacher contract talks deteriorated, budget cuts still loomed for classrooms and control of the system remained beyond the mayor's reach.

title: New Violence Over Rights Raises Fear In Guatemala
description: Rising threats and deadly violence against rights workers in Guatemala have prompted fears of a new crisis of political violence as the country tries to recover from decades of civil war.

title: Snowmobile Letter Surprises E.P.A. Leader and Interior Chief
description: Gale A. Norton, the secretary of the interior, and Christie Whitman, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, both say they were caught by surprise this week when the E.P.A. issued a letter supporting a ban on snowmobiles in Yellowstone National Park.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Level 3 Will Buy Software Spectrum
description: Level 3 Communications Inc., a telephone- and data-network operator, agreed to buy Software Spectrum Inc. for $122 million to gain sales of business software and services. Software Spectrum, based in Dallas, has about 9,000 large and midsize businesses as customers and had sales of $1.21 billion in 2001. It has operations in North America, Europe and the Asia-Pacific region. Level 3, based in Broomfield, Colo., agreed to pay $37 a share, more than double Software Spectrum's closing price Wednesday of $16.65. Level 3 plans to combine Spectrum with Corporate Software, another software-services provider it acquired in March. Yesterday, Software Spectrum shares rose $19.38, to $36.08. Shares of Level 3 rose 30 cents, to $3.92.
