title: Sharon Says Prisoners Implicate Arafat in Financing of Terrorism
description: After releasing Yasir Arafat before dawn from a monthlong siege, the Israeli government declared late tonight that other Palestinian leaders under Israeli interrogation had implicated him in financing terrorist attacks.

title: Colombia's Elections
description: To the Editor:

title: Angered at Hynix's Rejection, Micron Ends Its Rescue Talks
description: Micron Technology said today that it was withdrawing from talks over the future of the bankrupt Hynix Semiconductor, dashing the lingering hopes of South Korean government officials that a deal could still be salvaged for Micron to acquire Hynix's memory chip business.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: DEALING WITH CABLE DEBTS NTL , a large British cable company, reached an agreement with its lending banks on a reorganization that would give bondholders control of the company, its chief executive, Barclay Knapp, left, said. The holders of about half the face value of NTL bonds agreed to the plan earlier this month. Under the terms of the agreement, bondholders would swap $10.6 billion in debt for equity. Some NTL subsidiaries incorporated in the United States will file for bankruptcy protection on May 6, to better allow the company to reorganize its operations. Separately, Telewest Communications , another British cable company, said it would eliminate 1,500 jobs, or 14 percent of its work force. Telewest said it lost 166 million ($243 million) in the first quarter. Analysts have long speculated that Telewest may follow in NTL's footsteps and restructure its debts. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The economically named Rouge takes its theme seriously. A red velour curtain, tied back with a slender gold cord, strikes an elegant visual note at the entrance to the upstairs dining room. Red curtains with red tassels frame the three large windows that look out onto 62nd Street. On the wall hang cryptic portraits of heads, in black and white except for the hair, which is colored red. The whole idea is appealing and silly at the same time, while offering not a clue about the cuisine.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: More Chances For Women
description: Congress has approved a bill aimed at increasing the number of women in Congress. Under the bill at least 30 percent of candidates for Congress must be women, who currently hold 17 percent of the seats. If signed by President Vicente Fox the bill would disqualify parties from elections if they fail to comply. Parties that hold open primaries would be exempt. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: YES-Cablevision Row Benefits Mets So Far
description: For more than a week, Leo J. Hindery Jr., the chairman of the YES Network, has insisted that 30,000 to 50,000 subscribers have defected from the ranks of Cablevision for the Yankee-friendly confines of DirecTV's satellite service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRAVEN, JAY H.
description: CRAVEN-Jay H. Of Manhattan Beach, California. The directors, officers and staff of Sterling Bancorp and Sterling National Bank extend their deepest, heartfelt sympathies and condolences to his beloved wife, Cheryl; his adored children, Isabella (7) and Jack (5); his mother, Antoinette Nardi; brother, Michael Nardi; sister, Suzanne Nardi; niece and nephew, Nicole and Christopher Nardi, and to the entire family of our Chairman Louis J. Cappelli and Virginia M. Cappelli, his fatherand mother-in-law, on Jay's tragic passing, April 29, at age 40. He had graduated from Wildwood High School, New Jersey, and the University of Vermont. Jay was Regional Vice President of Clear Channel Radio Sales. He led a full, active life, achieving more in his brief life than many who live much longer. Among other enthusiasms, his zest for sports was realized with his two-hour Sunday morning radio show ''For Sports'' on Los Angeles Station 1150. Jay's courage during a long illness, his steadfastness and love and devotion to family were shining examples of how life should be lived and adversity faced. He will never be forgotten. There will be a Memorial Mass at St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church, Wildwood, New Jersey, on May 23, 2002, at 11:00 A.M. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Jay H. Craven Scholarship Fund, P.O. Box 595, Wildwood, New Jersey 08260. John C. Millman, President

title: Cameron Homers In 4 Straight At-Bats For the Mariners
description: A day after first-month statistics revealed that home runs were down 19 percent from last season, Mike Cameron single-handedly tried to reverse that trend last night. Cameron, a center fielder for the Seattle Mariners, slugged a record-tying four home runs at Chicago's Comiskey Park, all in the first five innings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOOKER, CHARLES
description: LOOKER-Charles. To the entire Looker family and all of Charles' loved ones, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Board of Trustees Richard F. Daines, M.D., President & CEO Peter S. Heller, Chairman, Miller Institute Advisory Board Mitchell Kahn, M.D., Director, Miller Institute

title: INVESTORS PUNISH XEROX AFTER CREDIT RATING IS CUT
description: The stock and bonds of Xerox fell yesterday after Moody's Investors Service slashed the company's credit rating three levels on concern that falling sales will make it more difficult to repay debt. Xerox's shares fell $1.08, or 12 percent, to $7.99. Yields surged to 12.2 percent on its notes maturing next year. Xerox's rating, already below investment grade, was cut to B1 from Ba1 on Wednesday. The downgrade affects about $9 billion in debt. Moody's said it was concerned because the cash generated from Xerox's copier business dropped by about half last year.

description: An Indian casino in far northern New York State is operating under an invalid agreement with the state, an appeals court ruled today, in a decision that appears to call into question the legality of any casinos in New York State.

title: Kidd Proves His Detractors Wrong
description: Fair or not, the criticism was going to be leveled at Jason Kidd, even though Keith Van Horn and Richard Jefferson had missed two crucial free throws each, even though fate seemed to be in cahoots with Reggie Miller, even though Kidd had already lifted his previously forlorn franchise to unimaginable heights.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Mozambique: Trial In Journalist's Killing
description: The Supreme Court has decided that there is enough evidence to try the six men accused of killing the country's best known journalist, Carlos Cardoso, the state news agency reported. Mr. Cardoso was investigating accusations of corruption in the banking sector when he was killed in November 2000. A trial date has not yet been set for the six men, who include a former bank manager and a prominent businessman. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Inmate Escapes On Way To Jail
description: A man on his way to a jail in Westchester County from a grand jury proceeding in Bronx Criminal Court escaped from a vehicle yesterday near 161st Street and the Major Deegan Expressway, near Yankee Stadium, the police said. The man, Kevin Saxon, 33, also known as Keith Jackson, was being taken to Westchester County Jail in Valhalla when he escaped the armed, civilian escorts from the Manhattan district attorney's office. He was wearing handcuffs when he jumped out of an unmarked, four-door vehicle stuck in traffic. Mr. Saxon has an extensive criminal record but was not armed, said Detective Kevin Czartoryski. Mr. Saxon, who is suspected of running a $2.5-million-a-year heroin ring in Harlem, was indicted a year ago on nine counts, including murder. If convicted he faces life in prison. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: House and Senate Support Israel in Strong Resolutions

description: British royal marines, heavily laden with equipment and their faces blackened with camouflage paint, climbed aboard Chinook helicopters today at a forward operating base south of Kabul to head into the mountains of southeastern Afghanistan.

title: Downtown: Shaken But Bouncing Back
description: Politely put, Lower Manhattan is a mess. Almost eight months after the attack on the World Trade Center, police barricades and detours are still plentiful, as are awestruck tourists. Backhoes crowd the streets and jackhammers assault the ears. Touching memorials adorn fences and facades right alongside less savory memorabilia merchants.

title: MERISTAR HOTELS TO MERGE WITH INTERSTATE
description: MeriStar Hotels and Resorts said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Interstate Hotels Corporation for $53 million in stock in a move that will combine two hotel managers. MeriStar will issue 4.6 shares of its stock in exchange for each of Interstate's 12.2 million outstanding shares, a spokesman for MeriStar said. Based on MeriStar's closing share price yesterday of 95 cents, Interstate shareholders will get $4.37 a share, a 67 percent premium to Wednesday's closing price of $2.61. MeriStar will also assume $15 million of Interstate debt. The combined company will manage 412 hotels, including Marriotts, Hiltons and Sheratons, worldwide. The new company, to be named the Interstate Hotels Corporation, will be based in Washington.

title: Aiding Colombia's War on Terrorism
description: While the United States' attention is fixed on fighting terrorism in Afghanistan, the Middle East and Asia, a grave threat lurks in the Americas. Colombia is the leading theater of operations for terrorists in the Western Hemisphere. Under the false pretense of a civil war, Colombian guerrilla groups have ravaged the nation with violence financed by cocaine consumers in the United States. The Bush administration, appropriately, is pushing in Congress to have anti-narcotics aid expanded to strengthen Colombia's ability to defeat terrorists.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POLLACK, EMANUEL
description: POLLACK-Emanuel. On May 2, 2001. Forever in our hearts. Remembering you today and everyday with love. Bill, Robin, Sarah and Marsha

title: STOCK SALE PLANNED FOR PRICEWATERHOUSE UNIT
description: PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting firm, said yesterday that it had filed an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a public offering of stock in its consulting unit, PricewaterhouseCoopers Consulting, as early as August. The new company will take a new name before the offering, which will be underwritten by Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. PricewaterhouseCoopers had previously indicated that the consulting business would be separated from the accounting firm, after an effort to sell the unit to Hewlett-Packard collapsed two years ago. Since the bankruptcy of Enron last year, all accounting firms have been under pressure to split their consulting and accounting businesses. Jonathan D. Glater (NYT)

description: Aclubhouse attendant picked up a pair of Nick Johnson's Adidas cleats before the Yankees' game last night against Oakland. "Throw some hit gel in there," Johnson said. If only it were that easy.

description: A group of construction and real estate executives recommended yesterday that New York City build simpler schools -- using standardized design elements like doorknobs, lights and clocks -- to speed construction and save money.

The family used some of those funds to buy Adelphia stock and bonds.

description: A dozen Democratic senators proposed tougher work requirements for welfare recipients today, changing the politics of the national debate over the future of the federal program that assists more than five million poor people.

title: AURORA FOODS TO CLOSE ITS BAGEL PLANT NEAR BUFFALO
description: Aurora Foods, a maker of frozen foods, is closing a Lender's bagel plant in West Seneca, N.Y., eliminating 204 jobs, or about 10 percent of its work force. Aurora, which also makes Duncan Hines cake mixes, said it would spend about $30 million before taxes this year on the closing. Production at the plant, near Buffalo, will stop May 31, though workers will be paid through July 2, the company said. Production will be moved to Aurora's plant in Mattoon, Ill., the world's largest bagel bakery, the company said. Shares in the company, which is based in St. Louis, fell $1.33, or 22 percent, to $4.61.

title: In Higher and Higher Gear
description: The Dominican jazz pianist Michel Camilo plays it close to the edge. His music is effervescent to the point of distraction; it is suave to the point of frilliness. But what saves it -- and this process typically happens several times in one of his well-made sets -- is a crescendo that passes between him and his drummer, Horacio Hernandez.

title: On the Sidewalks of New York
description: I FIRST came to New York City when I was a child, 9 or 10, on a morning train from Boston, with my great-aunts Ruth and Grace. It was just before Christmas and snowing a little. I remember being floored by the scale of the place, but I also noticed how pretty, almost dainty it was: the silvery arcs of the Chrysler Building; the dark filigree of Central Park trees glimpsed from a cab window; later, lights twinkling. Who knows how this happens, but the city got into my system. I couldn't have said at the time, ''This is where I want to be.'' But it was where I wanted to be. I still feel that way.

title: National Briefing: Washington

Richard W. Stevenson (NYT)

On a couple of new DVD's, Mr. Lee says he wanted the average person to identify with Spider-Man, a k a Peter Parker, which meant giving him more feelings and saddling him with worries about girls, family and friends.

title: They Were Two Wild Ones, Make No Mistake

Both were strong-willed, flamboyant exhibitionists who stood out in an era when women were routinely squelched. Both modeled for artists, and each became part of the Dada-Surrealist circle, Kiki in Paris and Elsa in New York.

title: Dell's Share-Price Bet Cost It $1.25 Billion

title: His Genes, Our Genome
description: So now the world knows what I have known for more than a year: A good chunk of the DNA used to map the human genome belongs to J. Craig Venter, the scientist who led the effort at Celera Genomics (racing against the National Institutes of Health) to come up with the first rough look at our genes. Four years ago, when the possibility of mapping the human genome was first discussed, Dr. Venter asked my advice about the ethics of this undertaking. I said that a crucial issue would turn out to be whose genes were selected for mapping. From a scientific point of view anyone's genes would be fine; the detail of the first map would be relatively crude, making the tiny genetic differences that exist among human beings irrelevant. But, as I've often found -- and as the current battle over cloning human stem cells for medical research is making clear -- much more than pure science is at issue when genetics is the subject.

title: Derby Dreamers Have Shot at Coming Up Roses
description: The sheiks from Dubai, a prince from Saudi Arabia and a well-heeled consortium of thoroughbred connoisseurs from Ireland all have horses ready to make the 128th running of the Kentucky Derby their own. None of them intimidate Glen Corbett, a jockey who has come in from Altoona, Iowa, to make his Derby debut aboard a horse called Lusty Latin. Nor does anyone scare Wilson Brown, who doffs his white cowboy hat, pats his ample belly and insists It'sallinthechase is going to represent Jones, Okla., just fine.

description: The Flatiron Building was certainly not New York's first skyscraper, but it has outlived most of its contemporaries, and its distinctive wedge shape has helped ensure its special place in the cityscape ever since its opening in 1902. MACROMEDIA FOUND GUILTY OF INFRINGING AN ADOBE PATENT
description: A jury has found Macromedia guilty of infringing on an Adobe Systems patent that covers a way of organizing a computer program's user interface. Adobe, of San Jose, Calif., said Thursday that the patent at issue covered its reconfigurable tabbed palette patent, used in its Photoshop image-editing program. Adobe said it was awarded $2.8 million in damages by the United States District Court in Delaware and expected the court to issue an injunction to stop Macromedia's infringement. Macromedia, of San Francisco, makes software for image editing, Web design and multimedia. It said it did not expect the judgment to impact its financial condition or market position.

title: 3 Killed in Raid in Nablus; Peace Conference Idea Wins Initial Support on Both Sides

title: Clinton Forgoing Media Job (for the Present)
description: Bill Clinton is not heading for a job as host of a daily syndicated talk show for NBC-TV, but he is eventually likely to seek a part-time position in television or radio, people familiar with his thinking said yesterday.

title: New Era in War Crimes Justice
description: In the aftermath of World War II and the Nuremberg tribunal, the idea arose of creating a permanent international criminal court that could try the most heinous international criminals. The plan foundered during 50 years of superpower rivalry. The end of the cold war and an explosion of ethnic brutality led to ad hoc tribunals for Rwanda and Yugoslavia. But there was no mechanism for trying Idi Amin or Saddam Hussein or others who evade their nations' justice.

title: Is the Pope Catholic?
description: Pope John Paul II turns 82 this month, and he looks more mortal by the day. In his photo op with the American cardinals last week, he was so infirm and unintelligible that you wanted to avert your eyes out of pity. But let's not. The uncomfortable and largely unspoken truth is that the current turmoil in the Roman Catholic Church is not just a sad footnote to the life of a beloved figure. This is a crisis of the pope's making.

title: Barbara Castle, British Radical, Is Dead at 91
description: Barbara Anne Castle, a onetime Labor cabinet minister and determined socialist whose radical, ill-timed attempt to tame Britain's mighty trade unions doomed her political career, died yesterday. She was 91.

description: A citywide manhunt was under way yesterday for a convicted killer who escaped on Thursday from the custody of two armed investigators in a car stuck in traffic in the Bronx.

title: A Trainee Noted for Incompetence
description: Although the authorities say none of the 19 hijackers on Sept. 11 were tied to an F.B.I. intelligence alert issued by an agent in Arizona two months earlier, one hijacker, Hani Hanjour, had come to the Federal Aviation Administration's attention earlier last year, when he trained in Phoenix.

title: A Slip, a Sniff, a Sneeze: Woody Allen in Snippets
description: Until the very end, where you realize you've been sucked into watching a promotional spot, ''Woody Allen: A Life in Film,'' tonight on TCM, is a nicely amusing collage. Not terribly illuminating, perhaps, but a wry revisiting of all those great Woody Allen moments that are beginning to grow hazy in the memory.

title: Abitibi Faces Rating Cut
description: Moody's Investor Service said today that it might lower its ratings on $3.15 billion of bonds issued by Abitibi-Consolidated, a leading maker of newsprint, because low newsprint prices could make repaying debt more difficult.

title: U.S.-Russia Talks Inch Nuclear Deal Closer
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and Foreign Minister Igor S. Ivanov of Russia said today that they had made substantial headway toward negotiating an agreement on reducing nuclear weapons that could be signed by President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin at a summit meeting in Russia in three weeks.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Wednesday about the search for an important suspect in the Sept. 11 attacks misstated the movements of Ramzi bin al-Shibh, who was thought to have crossed paths in Spain with Mohammad Atta, the mastermind of the attacks. Mr. Shibh flew from Germany on Sept. 5 to Madrid, not Pakistan. At that point, investigators lost track of him, but they believe he may eventually have gone to Pakistan.

title: A Test of Love for Labor and Management
description: She's a sassy, grown-up tomboy with the coltishness of a girl and the heart of a woman. He's a handsome man with a handsome voice and a virile, straight-spined strut. She's part brass and part glass; he's more like a mixture of velvet and sandpaper.

title: The Study of Shopping
description: To the Editor:

title: Lenders Trying An Alternative To Foreclosure
description: As the recession of the last year caused a sharp increase in the number of people falling behind on their mortgage payments, the nation's lenders decided to take a risk.

title: When They Smoke Behind Closed Doors
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Setback For Sulzer
description: A device sold by the Swiss medical technology company Sulzer Medica that tests heart valves was pulled from the British market after a patient died when a piece of the device broke off during surgery, the company said. The company has accepted responsibility for the product, which was made by another company but distributed by Sulzer, and is providing replacements. The news came just days before Sulzer was to appear in court in the United States for approval of a settlement for about $1 billion in connection with defective hip and knee implants. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Mocked in Europe of Old, African Is Embraced at Home at Last
description: The young African woman was lured to Europe with false promises of fame and fortune. She was paraded naked before jeering mobs. She was exhibited in a metal cage and sold to an animal trainer. When she died in Paris in 1816, she was penniless and friendless among people who derided her as a circus freak.

title: Beliefs; Crucial data is still needed to understand the extent of sexual abuse in the Catholic Church.
description: Do you think you have learned all you need to know to understand the sexual-abuse scandal that has overtaken the Roman Catholic Church in the United States? Think again.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Seeking U.S. Help Against Rebels
description: Prime Minister Sher Bahadur Deuba will be in Washington next week to plead for military aid to battle Maoist rebels whose influence has now spread across the tiny Hindu kingdom. The Bush administration has already asked Congress for $20 million. Officials said security forces killed at least 90 Maoists at two locations in western Nepal on Thursday. More than 3,600 people have died since the insurgency began in 1996. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: How Do West Virginians Spell Pork? It's B-Y-R-D
description: A traveler curious about the unusual number of federal public works in this state that were not just procured by but prominently named after Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia should pause for reflection at the State Capitol rotunda.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: VIETNAM: COMMUNIST DEFENDS CAPITALIST GIANT A Vietnamese labor official stepped forward to defend Nike the day after California's highest court ruled that the sportswear company could be sued for asserting that overseas workers, including those in Vietnam, were paid adequate wages and that working conditions complied with safety rules. "The standards Nike asks its contractors in Vietnam to conform to are very good compared to other workplaces," Vuong Van Viet of the Vietnam General Confederation of Labor told Reuters. He said that salaries, social benefits and work hours were good and that protective measures were required whenever a toxic substance was used. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: A Skittish Recovery
description: So, where's the rational exuberance? The economy posted an impressive 5.8 percent annual growth rate in the first quarter, its best performance in two years. The recession is over, and the economy will likely grow at a healthy if less spectacular clip the rest of the year.

title: National Briefing | South: Tennessee: DNA Evidence Clears Convict
description: On the basis of DNA evidence, a state judge in Memphis has vacated the conviction of a man who has served 22 years of a 119-year sentence for rape and robbery. The inmate, Clark McMillan, is still in jail because of a two-year sentence for unrelated federal weapons violations. Mr. McMillan's lawyers, Peter J. Neufeld and Kemper Durand, said 22 years was the longest time ever served in the nation by a convict cleared on DNA evidence. Mr. McMillan will remain in custody until the Federal Bureau of Prisons decides whether to credit his 22 years in state prison to the federal sentence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSS, ROCHELLE
description: MOSS-Rochelle. The Officers, Trustees, Clergy and Members of Park Avenue Synagogue mourn the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend to the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Geoffrey J. Colvin, Ch. of the Bd Paul S. Schreiber, President

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Hard Line On Peace Talks
description: President Chandrika Kumaratunga's party announced that it opposed lifting a ban on the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, a group labeled terrorists by the American and British governments, before peace talks begin. The Sri Lanka Freedom Party is also against allowing the Tigers to run the country's north and east -- which they have fought to make a separate Tamil nation -- on an interim basis unless there is a final settlement in place. The Tigers have demanded the ban be lifted before talks. Mrs. Kumaratunga is a powerful player and could make it difficult politically for the new prime minister, Ranil Wickremesinghe, to proceed with talks. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: South Korea Finds Fortune By Shunning Japanese Ways
description: South Korea, long in Japan's shadow, is blazing a new trail for Asian economic development.

title: Seattle Puts Last Week And Lilly Behind It
description: Six days after nearly pitching a no-hitter in Seattle, Ted Lilly pitched against the Mariners last night at Yankee Stadium, and if he had dominated once more, it would have been an anomaly. The norm for a young pitcher is to succumb to the temptation of trying to recreate near perfection.

title: Hide This Until You Die. Very Truly Yours, Ernest
description: Ernest Hemingway was a prolific letter writer. By one estimate, he left behind 8,000 to 10,000 letters, most of which have never been published.

title: A Scratch, Then a Scramble, on Derby Eve
description: James Bond's quivering lip telegraphed the news. Bond, a trainer, was not going to make his long-awaited debut in America's most famous race. Pat Day's blanched face reflected how miserable a feeling it is for a jockey to lose a good chance of capturing a second blanket of roses. Both men were stunned when Buddha, the Wood Memorial victor and the second choice in the morning line, came up lame overnight and was scratched this morning from Saturday's 128th running of the Kentucky Derby.

title: Surprise Best Seller Blames U.S.
description: In the weeks after the Sept. 11 attacks, Noam Chomsky, the M.I.T. linguist and political provocateur, was constantly on the telephone, giving interviews to news organizations. In late September, he received an e-mail message from Greg Ruggiero, a senior editor of Seven Stories Press, a New York publisher. The editor of a series of political pamphlets for Seven Stories, Mr. Ruggiero had published several Chomsky pamphlets and said he wanted to publish something quickly about Sept. 11.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Vandalism At Dachau
description: As an exhibition describing the Nazi period opened at the Dachau concentration camp, the police announced that vandals overturned memorial stones at the site and at a nearby Jewish cemetery last Saturday night. Dachau, opened in 1933, was the Nazis' first concentration camp and served as a model for others. More than 30,000 people were murdered there while thousands of others died of starvation, sickness and torture. Steven Erlanger (NYT)

title: Israel Has Nothing to Hide
description: What changed Israel's initial decision to accept a United Nations ''fact-finding committee'' on the Jenin refugee camp into a furious rejection?

title: HIGHEST IN 8 YEARS
description: The unemployment rate surged last month to 6 percent, its highest level in almost eight years, the government said yesterday in a sign that many companies are too worried about the economy to begin hiring again.

title: When They Smoke Behind Closed Doors
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | United Nations: No Breakthrough In Iraq Talks
description: The United Nations and Iraq ended three days of talks on disarmament with an agreement to meet again, but no breakthrough on the return of weapons inspectors to Baghdad. Iraq's foreign minister, Naji Sabri, called the discussions ''useful, frank and focused'' but said no dates had been set for the next round. Mr. Sabri last met with Secretary General Kofi Annan on March 7, the first high-level talks in a year. United Nations weapons inspectors began searching Iraq for weapons of mass destruction after the 1991 Persian Gulf war but left as the United States and Britain prepared to bomb the country in 1998, and they have not been allowed to return. Daniel B. Schneider (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about efforts to let pilots carry guns on the job misspelled the given name of a spokeswoman who said the Transportation Department had not decided whether stun guns would be allowed. She is Deirdre O'Sullivan, not Dierdre.

title: Buildings Face Tax Increases After Scandal
description: The city Finance Department has begun issuing penalties in the scandal in which federal prosecutors say that many of the city's property tax assessors took bribes to illegally slash the tax bills for some of Manhattan's most valuable real estate.

title: Ordering Groceries in Aisle 'www'
description: Tatiana Hoover lives two blocks from the D'Agostino supermarket at 91st Street and Columbus Avenue, and yet for the last few months she has been ordering her groceries from that store via the Internet.

title: Mining Pieces of Wreckage For Clues to a Fatal Crash
description: Pulled from Jamaica Bay after the Nov. 12 crash of American Airlines Flight 587, the pieces of the plane's tail have been washed, labeled in blue marker with arrows and notations, and arranged on sawhorses for autopsy in a NASA laboratory here. But investigators say the pieces will give up their secrets slowly.

description: BRITAIN: POOR TELECOM OUTLOOK The British mo-

title: GOODYEAR MUST PAY $36.9 MILLION IN DEATH OF TEXAS MAN
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company was ordered to pay $36.9 million to the family of a man who died from injuries suffered in a traffic accident that a South Texas jury said was caused by tire failure. Goodyear, North America's largest tire maker, was ordered to pay $14 million to the estate of Paul Rios Jr. of Hebbronville, Tex., who died in April 2001 from his injuries, the jury said, and additional millions to members of his family. ''Goodyear will vigorously appeal this outrageous decision,'' Chris Aked, a Goodyear spokesman, said. He said that Mr. Rios bought the tire, a nine-year-old Kelly-Springfield, not long before the accident and that the tire should never have been sold in the condition it was in. The manufacturer is not at fault, Mr. Aked said.

title: Redistricting Is Squeezing Signature Drives
description: The Legislature has waited so long to draw new lines for Congressional districts that it will be forced to delay and shorten the period for candidates to collect the signatures they need to get on the ballot, city and state officials say.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Communist Defends Capitalist Giant
description: A Vietnamese labor official stepped forward to defend Nike the day after California's highest court ruled that the sportswear company could be sued for asserting that overseas workers, including those in Vietnam, were paid adequate wages and that working conditions complied with safety rules. ''The standards Nike asks its contractors in Vietnam to conform to are very good compared to other workplaces,'' Vuong Van Viet of the Vietnam General Confederation of Labor told Reuters. He said that salaries, social benefits and work hours were good and that protective measures were required whenever a toxic substance was used. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Burmese Dissident's Expected Release May Have Hit a Snag
description: After 18 months of talks and conciliatory gestures, Myanmar's military government seems on the verge of taking the politically risky step of releasing from house arrest the pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi.

title: British Troops Find Bunkers, But No Taliban or Qaeda Men
description: At dawn today, British troops began to comb the rugged mountains of southeastern Afghanistan, entering a suspected lair of Qaeda and Taliban forces in one of the largest ground operations of the eight-month war.

title: Mental Health Parity
description: To the Editor:

title: Investigation Begun Into Action by Army Secretary on a Weapon
description: The Pentagon's senior spokeswoman left open the possibility today that Army Secretary Thomas E. White would be punished for his role in trying to block the cancellation of an $11 billion artillery system.

title: Ex-Officer Guilty of Manslaughter In Crash Following Drinking Bout
description: The former police officer who struck a pregnant woman and her family with his minivan after drinking beer for an entire day in Brooklyn last year was convicted yesterday of the most serious charges he faced -- four counts of second-degree manslaughter. The former officer, Joseph Gray, 41, faces up to 15 years in prison.

title: Roger V. Gould, 39, an Influential Researcher of Social Upheavals
description: Roger V. Gould, an influential sociologist who sought explanations for social upheavals large and small in the subtle texture of interpersonal relationships, died on Monday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 39 and made his home in New Haven.

title: Valentin and the Mets' Continue Offensive Show
description: When the Mets' offense finally started cranking in Phoenix this week, the injured Rey Ordez joked that if the Mets kept scoring so many runs, they would not need his defense. But the joke could be on Ordez; his absence is one of the reasons for the Mets' scoring surge. Tonight, his replacement, John Valentin, homered and drove in four runs to power Pedro Astacio past the Astros, 11-3, at Astros Field.

title: Northrop Takes Steps Toward Friendly Deal With TRW
description: Northrop Grumman is planning to hold talks with the top executives of TRW today about negotiating a friendly takeover deal after Northrop's $6.7 billion hostile bid was rejected by TRW shareholders.

title: MOODY'S LOWERS RATING OF VIVENDI'S LONG-TERM DEBT
description: Moody's Investors Service cut the rating yesterday on Vivendi Universal's long-term debt by one notch, to Baa3, near junk level. Moody's expressed concerns about Vivendi's ability to reduce its debt load and about off-balance-sheet obligations that would go up as the share price goes down. In a statement, Vivendi assured investors that the downgrade would create no immediate liquidity problems. The company complained that the downgrade failed to consider weak market conditions and said it was confident that it would meet its goals for 2002, based on first-quarter results. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: Rural Pipe Bombs Injure 5

description: GERMANY: VANDALISM AT DACHAU As an exhibition describing the Nazi period opened at the Dachau concentration camp, the police announced that vandals overturned memorial stones at the site and at a nearby Jewish cemetery last Saturday night. Dachau, opened in 1933, was the Nazis' first concentration camp and served as a model for others. More than 30,000 people were murdered there while thousands of others died of starvation, sickness and torture.

title: Police Say Woman Gave Teenager a Party With Drugs, Drink and Nudity
description: A Long Island woman was arrested Thursday and charged with being the host of a teenager's overnight birthday party that, the police say, featured alcohol, marijuana and a lap dance by a nude 14-year old girl.

title: A Triple Crown Winner In the Other Bridge Group
description: The selection process for the International Olympic Committee's Grand Prix immediately preceding the Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City in February was complicated by the fact that there are two bridge organizations in North America. One is the American Contract Bridge League and the other is the smaller American Bridge Association, which was founded in 1932 by African-American players at a time they were barred from many competitions.

title: Prosecutor Says That Boy, 16, Killed to Silence Witnesses
description: A February shooting spree in which a 16-year-old boy is accused of killing six people in two South Jersey towns was motivated by an argument with a neighbor, prosecutors said yesterday. The killings continued, they said, as the boy tried to eliminate potential witnesses.

title: MICROSOFT FOUNDER SELLS USA NETWORKS STAKE
description: Paul G. Allen, a co-founder of Microsoft who is chairman of Charter Communications, has sold the last of his stake in USA Networks, the company said yesterday. Mr. Allen sold nearly 20 million shares for $28.50 a share on May 2, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The sale raised $568.6 million. In November, he sold eight million shares at an average price of $20 a share. A spokesman for USA Networks said that Mr. Allen received his stake in July 1997, when USA Networks bought his controlling interest in Ticketmaster. A spokesman for Mr. Allen did not return a phone call seeking comment. Some media investors speculated that Mr. Allen was raising cash to buy more cable systems. Geraldine Fabrikant (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article yesterday about Bike New York misstated the dates of the three-day consumer trade show associated with it. The show started Thursday; it did not end on that day. It runs through today, from 10 a.m. to 9 p.m.

title: Burying Valleys, Poisoning Streams
description: Late yesterday afternoon, the Bush administration approved a change in federal regulations that will henceforth legalize the environmentally destructive practice of dumping mining wastes in valleys, streams and wetlands. The rule change is aimed primarily at allowing mining companies in West Virginia and other parts of Appalachia to continue to use a ruthlessly efficient form of coal mining known as mountaintop removal.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Party's Message Is Delivered
description: With a general election scheduled for May 17, more than half of all mail handled by the state-owned postal service is being stamped at automated distribution centers with the logo and slogan of the country's dominant political party, Fianna Fail. The party is paying $10,000 per month for the ads in space that had previously been sold only to charities. The high court rejected a Labor Party senator's bid to stop them but ruled that the postal service must provide him with a franking machine so his own outgoing mail and campaign materials do not bear the Fianna Fail logo. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Tennessee: Suit Says Company Discouraged  Religion
description: Sixteen Muslims, current and former workers at the Whirlpool plant in La Vergne, filed a federal lawsuit against the company, saying supervisors warned workers not to pray on their breaks, followed them to restrooms to see if they were praying, fired those found praying and pulled scarves from women's heads. The suit seeks damages of $310,000 each, and ''reasonable accommodation'' of religious practices and beliefs. Whirlpool officials said that nine similar grievances filed with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission have been dismissed.

title: Long Shot in Kentucky Oaks Catches and Passes the Favorite
description: Farda Amiga, a 20-1 shot, caught favored Take Charge Lady inside the sixteenth pole and drew away for a one-and-a-quarter-length triumph today in the 128th Kentucky Oaks.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Pop and Jazz Guide in Weekend yesterday about the Kenny Garrett Quartet misstated the telephone number of Iridium in Manhattan, where it is playing through tomorrow night. The number is (212) 582-2121.

title: British Far-Right Party Makes Slight Gains in Local Elections
description: The far-right British National Party gained a tiny toehold in British mainstream politics on Thursday, winning three council seats in the racially divided town of Burnley as local elections were held across the country.

title: Capitol Hill's Gesture to Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Enrolling Economic Diversity
description: Today poor and middle-class families must spend nearly twice as much of their income as their counterparts did a generation ago to send their children to four-year public colleges. Members of Congress and state legislators should take heed, for federal and state funding for financial aid has lagged behind college costs for years, contributing to a disturbing social stratification in our nation's colleges and universities -- both public and private.

description: BASEBALL

title: Bridgeport Bishop Joins Group Developing Policy on Abuse
description: Bishop William E. Lori of Bridgeport was appointed today to the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops Ad Hoc Committee on Sexual Abuse, the group working to develop national standards for dealing with sexual abuse by clergy members.

title: MetroStars Try to Find Ways to Score
description: Entering tonight's game against the Dallas Burn at the Meadowlands, the MetroStars find themselves in the all-too-familiar situation of trying to find a way to score without their star forward, Clint Mathis.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CITRIN, HILLARY ANNE
description: CITRIN-Hillary Anne. It's amazing that 20 years have come and gone since you left us for a better place. With the change of each season the pain of your loss is as if it were yesterday. Although they never met you, your nephews, Ethan and Hunter, carry with them many of your beautiful qualities and love you as if you were here. You are with us always and we miss the smile, the humor and the warmth that you brought to our family. I miss you, Hillary. Love, Dad and I and Ethan and Hunter and Our Family

title: Senate Seeks Inquiry Into FEMA 9/11 Role
description: A Senate committee has asked the General Accounting Office to undertake a broad examination of the Federal Emergency Management Agency's response to the Sept. 11 attacks, including a review of the way the agency has determined eligibility for its programs, the amount of money the government expects to spend on the recovery effort and the steps it is taking to safeguard public funds.

title: Chivalry on the Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: Enron Officials Propose to Spin Off a Smaller Energy Concern
description: The Enron Corporation is seeking permission to bundle some of its core assets to form a smaller energy company that could be spun off by the end of the year as a separate unit operating outside the company's Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings.

title: Some Chinese See the Future, and It's Capitalist
description: In the 50 years since Mao Tse-Tung decreed that art and science must serve socialism, China has not had much of an ivory tower. Mao's brief romance of the nation's top minds while the Communist Party consolidated power gave way to repeated purges and persecutions that continued through his death in 1976.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIELONKA, JOHN
description: ZIELONKA-John. The Council of School Supervisors and Administrators of New York City mourns the passing of John Zielonka. We will miss his passion for living, his intelligent wit, his unique insights, and his friendship. CSA extends its sympathy to his wife, Judy, and their children, Jana and Michael.

title: Senator Presses for Information on Enron
description: The chairman of a Senate panel investigating Enron warned White House officials today that they might face subpoenas for information on their contacts with Enron executives unless the administration demonstrated it was moving toward compliance with earlier informal requests.

title: Democracy in Asia
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, PAULA (FRIEDMAN)
description: WEISS-Paula (Friedman). On May 2, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Sydney. Devoted mother of Herman and Carol and Richard and Isabel. Adored grandmother of Linda, Jeffrey, Jill, Cathy, Len, Michael, Stephen and Rosa. Cherished great grandmother of Jonathan, Matthew, David, Jane, Kate and Leigh. Private graveside service Sunday. Shiva Sunday night and Monday.

title: AKZO NOBEL SUES BARR LABS TO BLOCK GENERIC DRUG
description: Akzo Nobel and its Organon unit said they had sued Barr Laboratories to block the sale of a generic form of Organon's top-selling antidepressant drug, Remeron. Barr is the latest generic drug maker to be sued by Akzo Nobel, the Dutch chemical company, to block low-cost forms of Remeron, which had sales of 169 million euros ($154.1 million) in the first quarter of this year. Officials with Barr Labs, which is based in Pomona, N.Y., could not be reached for comment. Akzo Nobel said it filed the suit in United States District Court in Newark.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFF, HERBERT H.
description: SCHIFF-Herbert H., 85. A philanthropist and business leader, died May 2, 2002. He is survived by wife, Betty T. Schiff, daughters, Suzanne Gallant, Patricia (Richard) Hershorin and Jane Schiff; 6 grandchildren and 4 great grandchildren; sisters, Florence ''Fredi'' Levin & Mildred Lee. A graduate of University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School 1938, he became chairman and CEO of SCOA Industries. Mr. Schiff was then chairman/president of The Schiff Company from 1985-2000. While chiefly known then for his financial acumen, he was deeply involved in local and national organizations through his philanthropy. Schiff was chairman emeritus of the Board of Governors of Yeshiva University's Wurzweiler School of Social Work. He had served as its founding chairman. He was a member of the Board of Trustees of Yeshiva University for 15 years & received their honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degree. Honorary vice-president of JDC and the American Jewish Committee and emeritus trustee of Peddie School, he served as trustee of American Friends of the Hebrew University and the United Jewish Appeal; director of American ORT; president and chairman of the Education Foundation of the American Retail Federation; director of BancOhio National Bank; Executive committee member of Brandeis University and advisory council for Capital University; director of American Footwear Industries Association, National Retail Merchants Association and Ohio State Council of Retail Merchants. He was the recipient of numerous awards from many organizations, philanthropic as well as industry related. Memorial contributions may be made to the United Jewish Communities Israel Emergency Fund. Funeral services are Sunday, May 5, 2 P.M., at Temple Israel, Columbus, Ohio.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hynix Names Executive
description: Hynix Semiconductor named Park Sang Ho, left, a co-president, to be its new chief executive, replacing Park Chong Sup, who resigned this week. Mr. Sup stepped down after Hynix's board rejected a deal he had helped negotiate to sell the company's memory-chip business to Micron Technology. He remained with the company, though, and was put in charge of selling the non-memory businesses, which Micron had not intended to buy. The board, which stunned Micron, the South Korean government and Hynix's creditors on Tuesday by rejecting Micron's $3 billion bid, appears intent on standing on its own, even though it has $6.8 billion in debt, analysts said. Mr. Ho, 54, the new chief executive, joined Hynix Semiconductor in 1999. He worked previously at I.B.M. and the Hewlett-Packard Company.

description: A listing in the Classical Music and Dance Guide in Weekend yesterday about a concert by the Terry Riley Trio at the Miller Theater at Columbia University misstated the day of the performance. It is tonight, not tomorrow night.

title: Citing RNA, Studies Suggest A Much Deeper Gene Pool
description: Two scientific papers published this week suggest that there might be many more human genes than thought, or at least that the human genome has hidden levels of complexity that are only starting to be revealed.

title: Cameron Is as Good As It Gets, for a Night
description: Born 14 years after Rocky Colavito hit four home runs in a game for the Cleveland Indians in 1959, Mike Cameron never fathomed that he would become the first American Leaguer since Colavito to accomplish the feat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMAN, HELEN HELFSTEIN
description: ZIMMERMAN-Helen Helfstein. On May 3, 2002. Helen Helfstein Zimmerman, beloved wife of Dr. Louis Zimmerman, loving mother of Peter, Max Zimmerman of Towson, MD, Mindy Zimmerman Colton of Orlando, FL. Dear mother-in-law of Paul Franklin Colton, devoted sister of the late Henrietta Weissman, Milton Helfstein and Pearl Lieberman, loving aunt of Florence and Marvin Rudich, Joan and Murray Gellen and Doris and Richard Warner. Services will be held in Baltimore, MD. For information call Sol Levinson and Brothers Home. 800-338-1701.

title: Pride in President May Have an Expiration Date
description: It has been months since they took down the American flags that had been fastened to virtually every sign post on Main Street here. At least that long ago, Stone Creek Furniture stopped blasting ''God Bless America'' endlessly from speakers outside the shop.

title: Losses Widen at Loral
description: Loral Space & Communications said yesterday that its first-quarter loss widened because the value of some of its assets had declined.

title: Nets Take First Step but Have More to Do
description: With weary smiles, the Nets traipsed out of their film room today, giving in to gravity after floating in euphoria the night before.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCULLOCH, PATRICIA ROBINEAU
description: McCULLOCH-Patricia Robineau. On April 27. Loving wife of the late John I.B. McCulloch. Devoted mother of Jeanne, Darcy and Catherine. Beloved stepmother of Mary Elizabeth, Keith, Roderick and Scott. Beloved aunt of Richard, Frances, William and Timothy. Cherished grandmother of Samuel, Alexander, Charlotte, Harry, Alistair and Eloise, and 12 step-grandchildren, and seven step-great-grandchildren. Memorial service at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church on Friday, May 17, at 3 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Luard Scholarship at The EnglishSpeaking Union, 144 East 39th Street, New York, N.Y. 10016.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Dr. Robert E. Rothenberg on Tuesday misstated his position at three New York medical institutions. At French Hospital and Polyclinic Postgraduate Medical School and Health Center in Manhattan, both now defunct, he was a trustee and attending surgeon, not chief of surgery. Earlier, at Jewish Hospital in Brooklyn, he was an attending surgeon, not chief surgeon.

title: Storytelling in the Quiet Light of Song
description: The baritone Stephen Salters, who gave his Naumburg recital on Monday night at Alice Tully Hall, is a man of thorough confidence, huge charm and a vocal allure that comes brimming off the stage. He started his program with an unaccompanied traditional song, repeating over and over again the same words: ''This little light of mine, I'm gonna let it shine.'' And that was what he did for the next two hours, except that his light was not so little and was joined by the light (also not so little) of David Zobel at the piano.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULDOWNEY, JEROME T.

title: The Puritans Run Amok Over Smoking

title: FRENCH POLLS SEE CHIRAC  LANDSLIDE IN VOTE TOMORROW
description: On the last day of France's tense presidential campaign, polls continued to predict a landslide for the center-right president, Jacques Chirac. But it may be a hollow victory, won simply because most of the electorate objected to the extremist views of his opponent, Jean-Marie Le Pen, whose share of the vote, polls suggested, could be greater than ever before.

title: F.B.I. Told of Worry Over Flight Lessons Before Sept. 11
description: An F.B.I. agent in Phoenix told counterterrorism officials at the bureau's headquarters last July that he had detected an alarming pattern of Arab men with possible ties to terrorism taking aviation-related training, and urged a nationwide review of the trend, according to F.B.I. officials.

title: No Extra Jail Time For Man Sentenced In Melissa Virus
description: The New Jersey computer programmer who unleashed the Melissa computer virus was spared any additional jail time in his sentencing on state charges yesterday, two days after he received a 20-month sentence in federal court.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: After Reunions, Divided Again
description: Relatives who had not seen one another since the Korean War bid tearful farewells at the end of five days of visits among members of divided families. South Korea's television networks showed the departure of 466 South Koreans from North Korea. The reunions were the first since February of last year and the North is not expected to agree to another round until it receives more food aid from the South. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Defeat On Assisted Suicide
description: The Legislature has rejected a bill that would have made the state the second in the nation after Oregon to legalize doctor-assisted suicide. After a debate in which some lawmakers wept, the 25-member Senate voted 14 to 11 against the bill on Thursday, the last day of the session. Supporters had said the bill was vital to personal choice, while opponents said it was riddled with loopholes. Michele Kayal (NYT)

title: CONOCO AND PHILLIPS PLAN JOB CUTS AFTER THEIR MERGER
description: Conoco and the Phillips Petroleum Company will lay off an undisclosed number of workers in three cities after they merge later this year to form the nation's third-largest oil company. Jobs will be trimmed in Houston, the combined company's headquarters; in Tempe, Ariz.; and in Ponca City, Okla., the companies said. Most of the cuts will be made by the end of 2003. Conoco and Phillips expect to save $750 million a year from the merger, which is expected to close as early as the third quarter.

title: Pipe Bombs at Mailboxes Injure Five in the Midwest
description: Pipe bombs accompanied by threatening anti-government notes exploded in or near rural mailboxes in a stretch of northwestern Illinois and northeastern Iowa today, injuring three letter carriers and two residents, the authorities said.

title: In Drive for Peace Progress, White House Saw Jenin Inquiry as Expendable
description: The Bush administration dropped its backing for a United Nations fact-finding mission into Israel's actions in the Jenin Refugee Camp because the contentious issue became a distraction from progress toward peace, senior administration officials said this week. Israel and the United Nations could not come to terms on the mission.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: HYNIX NAMES EXECUTIVE Hynix Semiconductor named Park Sang Ho, left, a co-president, to be its new chief executive, replacing Park Chong Sup, who resigned this week. Mr. Sup stepped down after Hynix's board rejected a deal he had helped negotiate to sell the company's memory-chip business to Micron Technology . He remained with the company, though, and was put in charge of selling the non-memory businesses, which Micron had not intended to buy. The board, which stunned Micron, the South Korean government and Hynix's creditors on Tuesday by rejecting Micron's $3 billion bid, appears intent on standing on its own, even though it has $6.8 billion in debt, analysts said. Mr. Ho, 54, the new chief executive, joined Hynix Semiconductor in 1999. He worked previously at I.B.M. and the Hewlett-Packard Company .

The agreement , which applies only to the Corona plant, stems from problems the F.D.A. cited at the plant from 1998 through 2001, said Patty Eisenhaur, a Watson spokeswoman.

'Cherry'
description: In the restless years of middle age Cherry used to sit in the bow-window of his library, turning the pages of the journals he had kept in the Antarctic three decades before. Absorbed in those far-off years, he jotted notes in the margins, as if the expedition had not yet reached its conclusion. ‘All Scott’s men had been altered,’ he wrote crossly. ‘ Scott should have asked the doctors for their advice.’ Beyond the trimmed lawns outside, the familiar figure of Tilbury, the head gardener, stooped over the rhododendrons. The rooks returned to their nests in the elms, briefly darkening the sky. Cherry leafed through the flimsy notebook, recalling the rippled glaciers that tumbled down Mount Erebus, their gleaming cliffs casting long blue shadows; the crunching patter of dogs on the march; the pale, shadowless light of the ice shelf and a smudgy sun wreathed in mist. ‘Those first days of sledging were wonderful!’ he had written. In the quiet of his library he heard again the hiss of the Primus after a long, hard day on the trail, and smelt the homely infusion of tobacco as the night sun sieved through the green cambric of the tent. He tasted the tea flavored with burnt blubber, and felt the rush of relief as tiny point of light from the kippered hut glimmered faintly in the unforgiving darkness of an Antarctic winter. ‘Can we ever forget those days?’ he wrote.

description: THE sign in the shop window said ''Skate or Die,'' but there was nothing half so ambivalent about the action inside. Last week at Resurrection, the vintage clothing store on Mott Street that is prime hunting grounds for fashion stylists and idea-starved designers, trendsetters were clattering through a half-pipe of exclamations and heartfelt sighs as they pawed over an unlikely new trove of fashion inspiration: box-fresh Vans sneakers from the 1980's printed with skulls and spider webs, Vision skateboard T-shirts and a jacket once worn by a member of the famous Southern California Zephyr skate team.

title: The World; Europe's Identity Crisis
description: AS the European Union moves inexorably toward completion, Europeans are awakening to a less sovereign, less comfortable world, prompting the kind of anxiety among the elderly and the poor that continues to feed the growth of the far right.

title: Business; A Handicapper's Guide to the Trial of Andersen
description: NO defendant will be visible in the courtroom. The white-collar prosecution will be presented to the down-home Texas jury by a couple of East Coast organized-crime busters. The chief witness will admit to committing a crime, while the defense will say he is an innocent man who's lying. At stake is the survival of the once-powerful accounting firm, Arthur Andersen.

title: Timeless Wyoming, At a Gallop
description: IN the six days we rode on horseback through central Wyoming's Great Divide Basin, we encountered only one other human being: A rancher, out checking on his cattle.

title: Harry Potter and the Quest For the Unfinished Volume
description: Each time Rachel Ruskin, 11, enters a bookstore in her New York City neighborhood, she walks straight to the information desk to ask a question pressing on the minds of millions of children around the country: When will the next Harry Potter book appear?

title: April 28 - May 4
description: FRANCE VOTES As the French go to the polls today, President Jacques Chirac seems set to be re-elected by a landslide. After Jean-Marie Le Pen, the far-right candidate, stunned the nation by qualifying for the runoff, the mainstream right and left rallied behind Mr. Chirac. May Day marches turned into huge nationwide protests against Mr. Le Pen. The main question seems to be the size of Mr. Chirac's victory, but having failed to predict Mr. Le Pen's earlier success, pollsters have been wary about forecasting figures.

title: 'The Long Recessional'
description: Rudyard Kipling never wasted time investigating his roots. He as 'not a bit interested' in his ancestry, he reflected in old age, and only wished that a pestering inquirer would desist from hunting down his 'pedigree'.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: A Quartet Remixes Its Mixed Chemistry
description: A CLASSICAL-MUSIC ensemble bears little resemblance to a professional football team -- except when it comes to changing personnel. Players lost to retirement, injury or free agency may be replaced adequately or even well, but if the process happens too often, or if those lost are franchise players, the team risks sacrificing its very identity.

title: Lawsuit or No, a Grahamfest Is On
description: IT might seem a little frivolous to describe ''Indisputably Martha Graham'' as a party. Some of Graham's most solemn signature works will be danced, after all, in a program that ranges over 45 years of this pioneering choreographer's illustrious career. But the performance by the Martha Graham Dance Company on Thursday at City Center promises to be a festive reunion. Company members have not performed together formally since May 2000, when the Martha Graham Center of Contemporary Dance, the umbrella organization for the company and its school, suspended operations because of financial problems.

title: April 28-May 4: NATIONAL; TROUBLED ADULT HOMES
description: New York City's adult homes for the mentally ill are plagued by neglect and misconduct, and federal prosecutors are investigating whether the poor conditions resulted from criminal conduct. The inquiry began in response to a series of three articles in The New York Times detailing a yearlong investigation into 26 of the privately run homes. That investigation found that residents were being supervised by untrained workers and exploited in schemes that seemed intended to generate fees from government health care programs. And it revealed that from 1995 through 2001, 946 residents died; 326 were under 60. Clifford J. Levy

title: The Consequences Of Illegal Immigration
description: ''Immigration Issues Sprout Like the Daisies'' [April 28] speaks about the controversy over illegal aliens on Long Island.

title: Planning for a Retirement Move
description: STUDIES show that about 80 percent of Americans say they want to stay right where they are when they retire. For them, the decisions have been made. The same may be true for those who simply plan to retire wherever their children or other relatives live.

description: ALCALAY-Frances. Born August 18, 1915 died April 22, 2002. Beloved wife, mother and grandmother. She will be in our hearts forever.

title: Ideas & Trends; It's Alive! It's Alive!
description: IT was the early 1970's, the dawn of the era of gene-splicing, when Prof. Paul Berg, a Stanford University biochemist, proposed slipping a bit of DNA from a cancer-causing rodent virus into a bacteria, E. coli. Even his colleagues were alarmed. So Professor Berg, faced with panicky accusations he was breeding some kind of Andromeda strain, temporarily halted his own research and helped impose a moratorium. Congress, frightened, wanted a ban.

She had the ball, but was unsure where to kick.

title: Theft of Plates Reveals Wires, Fruit and Dead Cats
description: Thousands of the city's 200,000 lampposts are missing their base plates, and the reasons for their absence are as varied as the quirky, unexpected items that wind up inside the uncovered compartments.

title: Family Scars
description: Only five years ago, patients had to wait just two to three years for a kidney transplant. These days, it is often five. With waiting lists growing, the ailing are increasingly turning to those closest to them -- healthy siblings, children, even friends -- for an organ to save their lives. In fact, last year, organ donations from the living in the United States surpassed those taken from cadavers for the first time. But in the wake of two recent deaths of transplant patients at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York (in one case, a man donated 60 percent of his liver to his brother only to die of an infection three days later), doctors are re-evaluating whether it's wise or ethically sound to operate on the able-bodied to aid the sick. Liver transplants are far riskier than kidney transplants; still, as doctors warn all would-be donors, no surgery is without risk of complications. And so, those who wish to give an organ face a difficult choice, as do patients who must grapple with putting their loved ones in harm's way.

title: April 28-May 4: NATIONAL; MORE CHURCH TROUBLES
description: New accusations and legal actions added to the sex abuse scandal rocking the Roman Catholic Church. In San Diego, the Rev. Paul Shanley, who openly lauded ''man-boy love,'' was arrested on child rape charges in Massachusetts. In Los Angeles, four men sued Cardinal Roger M. Mahony under federal racketeering laws. Saying it had too many other accusations to deal with, the Archdiocese of Boston backed out of a multimillion-dollar settlement with 86 people who said they were abused by the Rev. John J. Geoghan, whose conviction on abuse charges started the scandal. A nationwide poll conducted by The Times and CBS News found that about 8 in 10 Catholics want abusive priests removed from the church. And an Associated Press survey found that 177 priests nationwide had resigned or been suspended since

title: All Over the Map And Proud of It
description: SOME festivals draw pilgrims to an out-of-the-way town: Bayreuth, Germany; Aix-en-Provence, France; Glyndebourne, England. Some are spread throughout a city, woven into its fabric: the Edinburgh Festival in Scotland, the Festival d'Automne in Paris. But the Lincoln Center Festival has to be one of the hardest to pin down.

title: 'Oxygen'
description: Inside the house his father's clocks were striking the hour. Faintly, the chimes carried to where he stood in the garden, a lank young man in a summer sweater and shapeless blue trousers, wiping the lenses of his glasses with the corner of a crumpled handkerchief. He had spent the last hour with the hose watering the flower-beds and giving the ground around the younger trees a good soaking, as he had been instructed to. Now, having carefully coiled the hose, he made his way back towards the house, his progress shadowed by a cat that pushed through the stems of delphiniums and peonies and oriental poppies. At the top of the house, the light in Alice's room shone dully from between half-open curtains.

title: A Spectrum of Watercolor Technique
description: WATERCOLOR painting is comfort art. With washes of transparent color, the artist is able to capture light and atmosphere, achieving luminous effects that suggest immediacy and freshness. Though watercolor offers an opportunity for rich, expressive results, many painters defy the fluidity of the medium by controlling their brush strokes to create images of uncompromising realism. Both modes of execution challenge the watercolorist, yet captivate the viewer.

title: When Europeans and Americans Disagree
description: The discordance in European and American public views of events in the Middle East has grown ever more evident in recent weeks. And yet, because Europeans and Americans are strong allies and are committed to the same set of values, it cannot be that one party is completely right and the other completely wrong. Common sense suggests that we not explain our differences on this issue based on knee-jerk bias against the other side, even though clichs and prejudices have come to color most discussions of these differences.

title: E-Mail Haunts Automakers
description: MESSAGES spread quickly in cyberspace, too quickly sometimes for the truth to catch up. Shortly after Sept. 11, someone composed an e-mail message that purported to list the donations that various automobile companies had made to relief efforts. The message cited CNN Headline News as the source of the information, and contrasted large gifts said to have come from Detroit-based companies with negligable, or nonexistent, contributions from foreign automakers.

Hernando perfectly timed the ball's bounce, but instead of taking a gracefully compact cricket swing, he unleashed a gruesome baseball uppercut. The ball flew by him and banged against the wickets for an out.

The capital of Maharashtra state on India's west coast, this city of nearly 12 million people draws its food from many Indian regions and cultures and has countless foreign restaurants as well.

title: 'Lake Effect'
description: In summer we slept on the beach. We would park our cars on a side street and hike through the trees to the ravine and then down to a secret little shore that only we knew about. We would get a fire going and drink red wine and look at the lights winding along the north coast and, to the south, at the haze above Chicago. Out on the lake, we could see the red hazards of ships, and sometimes a speedboat splashed its tiny wake onto the rocky sand. Jamie told stories about the lake, which he said was over a thousand feet deep, and about the ships that had gone down beyond the horizon, voices vanishing in the cold water. When the wine was gone, we sat talking about girls and fights, or what we would do next week or next month. Who could see beyond next month?

title: What Doctors Don't Know (Almost Everything)
description: I work as an internist in the Canadian Arctic, in a region called Kivalliq, on the west coast of Hudson Bay. There are no highways there, and the more recent social changes of the south have not penetrated the tundra any more deeply than the road system has. The eyewear is distinctly out of fashion, and the church remains influential.

title: Bombes Away
description: About 18 years ago, I was pushing my year-old son, Eddie, in a stroller, with his 4-year-old brother, Frank, walking beside and tormenting Skeletor, his action-figure friend. We were headed home up University from Washington Square Park on a broiling Sunday afternoon when a belligerent pitchman handed me a DoveBar together with a lot of malarkey. It was about a buck, and I was feeling thin and wiped out by the summer as I always do. The Dove was, of course, ice cream frozen around one of those underweight tongue depressors and appeared to be related to a Popsicle or Good Humor bar. But when I actually bit into it -- hard chocolate shell, contrasting soft vanilla ice cream inside -- it was clearly a Popsicle or Good Humor that had been to grad school. I lied to the boys, telling them it was a rubber toy for the dog, which they seemed to buy even though we didn't have a dog, and mimed throwing it away. Smitten, I searched out DoveBars for the next few months and devoured them wherever they stood. With all the competition in 2002, the Dove may not seem quite so revolutionary, but in '85 it was totemic.

title: BAR ASSOCIATION
description: Governor McGreevey last week revived the New Jersey State Bar Association's review process for State Supreme Court nominees. Under the agreement signed by the governor, a 25-member committee would scrutinize a 20-page questionnaire submitted by a nominee and then vote to declare a nominee qualified or unqualified and testify at hearings if a nominee is found unqualified. The system was used for 30 years until Christie Whitman, then governor, ended it in 1999 when the bar association questioned her nomination of Peter G. Verniero, her attorney general. The system will be used for the governor's choice to replace Associate Justice Gary L. Stein, who will retire Sept. 1.

title: CRIME
description: The title of Tony Hillerman's new mystery -- THE WAILING WIND (HarperCollins, $25.95) -- is itself enough to give anyone the shivers. Especially when Joe Leaphorn, the retired Navajo tribal policeman whose counsel we have come to trust in this series, reminds us of an old Spanish legend in which the voice carried on the wind is that of ''a lost woman with a lost child whose sorrowful cries can be heard at night.'' Both the title and the book's underlying theme of the universal yearning for precious things lost suit this melancholy tale about men who go tearing after fabulous gold mines and fail to see the treasures they have at home.

title: My Sister's Unbeautiful Mind
description: Peggy's group home is in Oakland, near Pittsburgh, where I spent every possible moment when I was 16 and 17. Driving through the streets now, I'm flooded with memories of tooling around in Mom's car, stoned and giggling with friends. I pass the site of the ''O,'' where we got fries and root beer, and the Carnegie Museum, where I took Saturday art classes, and Western Psych, where Peggy was hospitalized 35 years ago, when we still thought she'd recover from paranoid schizophrenia.

title: Smoke to Go With the Steam
description: IN a crucial early scene of Adrian Lyne's new adultery drama, ''Unfaithful,'' Richard Gere, who plays Edward Sumner, a well-off businessman, husband and father, is being visited at his Manhattan office by his wife, Connie, played by Diane Lane. By most standards, the Sumners have it all: an apparently loving marriage, a beautiful home in Westchester County, a sweet son and a cute dog. Everything, however, is about to come crashing down around them. Connie is being drawn into an affair with a younger man, a romance so intense that she will spin out of control. Nothing has happened between them yet, but she's already feeling pangs of guilt.

Somebody, it turns out, who knows a thing or two about executives profiting even as their companies struggle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDWASSER, MARTIN
description: GOLDWASSER-Martin. Formerly of Brooklyn Heights, passed away May 3, 2002 at age 95. He is survived by his wife Elizabeth S. Teter, son Hank, daughter Janet, grandchildren Jonathan, Missy Carvin and Douglass Dowty, and a sister, Esther Natt. He was preceded in death by his first wife, Paula Neumann in 1983, after forty-nine years of marriage. Martin graduated from Erasmus High School in Brooklyn, earned his Bachelor of Science degree from City College, and his DDS from New York University. He was a skilled and caring dentist, who over half a century, saw the children and the grandchildren of his first patients come to him for treatment in his practices in Manhattan and Brooklyn. Dr. Goldwasser gave of himself to others, volunteering many hours over the years at dental clinics in Brooklyn. He was a lifelong pacifist and Conscientious Objector, doing alternative service in state mental hospitals in Maryland during World War II. In later years, he spent many hours counseling young men about peaceful alternatives to military service in his work with the Metropolitan Board for Conscientious Objectors. His hobbies included stamp collecting, bird watching, and bicycling. He lived a full life, and will be remembered with love by us all. A memorial service will be held in June. Contact Hank Goldwasser at (914) 347-6672 after June 1 for details.

title: Who Foots the Bill?
description: Itemized lists like this one, which hospitals send to private insurance companies and patients almost never see, are filled with bloated charges -- the average bill is marked up 116 percent over the cost. But nationwide, private insurers reimburse only about half of what hospitals charge them. That's because many hospitals have prenegotiated contracts with insurers to establish a discounted rate of payment. And those rates vary wildly -- one carrier may reimburse 30 percent; another, 60 percent. The effect, analysts say, is that hospitals spike their prices so they can offer insurers a better-looking deal, without losing money. ''We have a gigantic system of trying to get someone else to pay the bill,'' says Stuart Altman, professor of national health policy at Brandeis. ''It's called cost-shifting. And hospitals are always trying to find pockets that will get them the profits they need.'' Dawn MacKeen

title: Jolts of Anxiety
description: Every medical device makes a promise, and the promise Lorraine Flood's defibrillator made was that it would allow her to live longer. So in June 1998, eight years after her first heart attack on the eve of her son's wedding, Flood underwent an hourlong operation to implant a pager-size defibrillator under the skin of her left chest. She was told that the electronic device would monitor her irregular heartbeat, which was causing frequent bouts of palpitations and dizziness, and apply a shock if the rhythm degenerated into something dangerous. The device worked much like the paddles used in the E.R. -- but it would always be inside her. ''I was so relieved,'' Flood recalled. ''I used to worry, 'If something happens, I may not survive it.''' But then her defibrillator started working.

title: Mental Illness And Treatment Dollars
description: I agree with ''Financial Neglect of Mental Illness'' [opinion, April 28] that financing for mental illness should be on equal footing to financing for medical problems. But the distinction between the two is where the problem lies. Cutting-edge brain research has revealed that many psychological disorders are due to biological factors. In such cases there is no difference between severe psychological difficulties, like those that cause violent, irrational behaviors, and neurological disorders in general. One day, the public as well as the government will look back and laugh at the era when psychological problems were considered by some to be ''only in our heads.''
