title: QUICK BITE/Hopewell; A Spoon, a Straw and a Thermometer
description: It takes self-confidence to name your masterpiece the oxymoron special. But what else was Karen Bendix, the owner of Karen's at Brookside in Hopewell, going to call her iced hot chocolate? The drink ($3.50 small, $5.50 large) is chocolate ice cream mixed with ice and topped with whipped cream and chocolate jimmies. There are staple flavors like chocolate and vanilla available at the roadside shop. Strait-laced tastes, however, are quickly forgotten when a Devil Dog shake (shakes are $2.50 small, $3.15 , $4.50 large) -- not really a shake, but a tribute to the Drake's Cake made from two chocolate ''buns'' with a creamy filling -- or a cup of raspberry cappuccino ice cream ($2.50) are discovered. For 27 years Karen's of Brookside, a multicolored building that looks like something out of Wonkaland set at the busy intersection of Routes 31 and 518, has served 100 flavors of ice cream at one window and has grilled burgers ($2.95 and $4.95) and cheese steaks ($3.95 and $6.95) at the other. Nancy Zamboni, a Mercerville resident, and her son, Jonathan, made a recent afternoon stop for some curly fries. Jonathan, 14, later indulged in soft-serve mango ice cream. ''We've been coming here since Jonathan was in kindergarten,'' Ms. Zamboni said. The owner, Karen Bendix, points out that a visit isn't as indulgent as some patrons believe: the ice cream is low-fat. Before making a nighttime run, you might consult a thermometer. Closing time varies according to the temperature. The posted hours says the stand closes at 10 p.m. if the temperature is 75 degrees or hotter, at 9 if it is 65 to 74 and at 8 if the temperature is lower. And if it's colder than 55, Ms. Bendix adds, she can be found in Florida. Wendy Ginsburg

title: Dr. Levine's Dilemma
description: At 9:15 in the morning, Dr. Jim Levine ducks out of Exam Room 6 while a medical assistant gives his patient an EKG. He goes to his office and sits at his computer to take notes on the possible case of strep sitting in Exam Room 3, a young woman wrapped in about 17 layers of clothes and still shivering. ''Grade II tonsils,'' he types, ''with exudate on right.'' Levine is 33, but in body type and energy he reminds you of a 14-year-old boy. His movements are quick and barely contained, and he walks faster than lots of people run.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: MORE than 20 years after seeing Francis Ford Coppola's ''Apocalypse Now,'' all I remembered were a few scenes, a few lines (like Robert Duvall's ''I love the smell of napalm in the morning'') and the film's overall sense of shocked sadness. Seeing APOCALYPSE NOW REDUX (2001) is transporting, and even on a small screen, Vittorio Storaro's Oscar-winning cinematography is devastating. When this director's cut is described as containing ''additional footage,'' that doesn't mean five or ten minutes; the new film is more than an hour longer than the original. Captain Willard (Martin Sheen) and his men make an overnight visit to a French plantation along the river, and moviegoers see much more of Marlon Brando's Colonel Kurtz. But the most powerful scenes are those that made it into the original film - Saturday at 8 p.m. on Showtime.

So, on Mother's Day, next Sunday, it seems only right to celebrate Mom's creativity by choosing a gift that tweaks the mold with wit and practicality. Here are some new variations on tried-and-true themes, for families of all ages.

title: A Poet of Outcasts Who's Come Inside
description: SUNLIGHT wouldn't seem to be Tom Waits's element. His songs tend to take place in rainy nocturnal realms filled with outcasts and freaks, where his slurred gargle of a voice and his junkyard assortment of sounds won't upset passers-by. Yet there Mr. Waits was on a bucolic northern California afternoon a few weeks ago, lunching on minestrone soup in a small-town restaurant near his home, and talking affably about how he has created and maintained his own peculiar zone -- more like a back room or a bunker full of debris -- in American music.

title: A Steakhouse That's Easy on the Wallet
description: PRIME steaks followed by near insolvency are the norm at prestigious Long Island steakhouses. A piece of red meat at one of these big-beef emporiums often costs at least $30. That price usually includes nothing additional beyond a sprig of parsley. Diners who have the audacity to feel that meat alone is not a meal must ante up an extra $5, $6 or $7 for each potato or  la carte vegetable dish.

title: Testing for Lead Paint in a Co-op Unit
description: Q When I sold my co-op apartment in Brooklyn last July the co-op's managing agent insisted that I pay for a lead-paint test as a condition for setting a date for the closing. I was told that the test had to be done even though both I and the buyer waived any right to insist on such a test. At the closing, the co-op's managing agent billed me $750 for the lead-paint test. Is a lead-paint test required when a co-op apartment is sold? Were they within their rights requiring this as a condition of setting a closing date? . . . William R. Dalsimer, Southampton, N.Y.

title: 'The Fall of Light'
description: In an autumn long ago, the Foleys crossed the country into the west like the wind that heralds winter. Where exactly they had come from is uncertain. The family's origins vanish in the lost pages of the country's history. It was in the County Wicklow, or perhaps Carlow. There was Francis Foley and his four sons. They rode horses through the night, travelling with all their possessions in raggle-taggle fashion, leading a small cart on which lay a large wooden telescope. The midnight creaking of the cartwheels and the clattering of the hooves on the road stirred those who slept on the edges of their beds in thin dreams. The Foleys fled through the fields of Tipperary and across the wide green of all that country until they reached the river. Then they stopped and slept beside their horses beneath the hidden moon of that October, their breaths misting on the darkness like visions and their eyes in sleep seeing the home forever lost to them now.

title: Face Forward
description: Chelsea Mulder was born with Crouzon syndrome, a genetic condition in which the sutures of the skull and face fuse prematurely. Before her 3rd birthday, she had undergone three operations to make room in her cranium for her growing brain. But for Chelsea, 10, the main thing about Crouzon was having a boy call her Funny Face on the playground. That was before Chelsea had what she calls her ''makeover'' at the Rush Craniofacial Center at Rush-Presbyterian-St. Luke's Medical Center in Chicago. There, in 1995, Dr. John Polley and Dr. Alvaro Figueroa developed a halolike contraption (pictured below) to treat severe craniofacial deformities. By pulling at the site of a fracture in a process called distraction osteogenesis, they were able to grow bone in her face. After eight weeks the halo came off, and Chelsea was transformed.

Married to Dr. John Trinkaus in 1954, they had three children, Joanne Dillon, Dr. Robert Trinkaus, and John William Trinkaus, and three grandchildren, Christopher Dillon, Brianne Dillon, and Rebecca Trinkaus. Irene, an accomplished pianist and violinist, was a graduate of the Baruch School of the City College of New York, where she was active in the Newman Club. She was formerly employed as an accountant for the National Health Council in New York City. When her children were young, she served as a volunteer leader in a number of youth associations including: the Boy and Girl Scouts, the 4H Club, and the Catholic Youth Organization. She courageously battled multiple sclerosis since 1968, and fought valiantly against colon cancer, to which she subsequently succumbed after a two year struggle. Friends may visit Sunday from 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 PM at the New Hyde Park Funeral Home, Inc., 506 Lakeville Road, New Hyde Park, NY. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday, 10:15 AM, at Notre Dame R.C. title: April 28-May 4: SCIENCE; ROBO-RAT
description: Imagine a voice in your head whispering, ''Turn right.'' And if you did, the flavor of luxurious dark chocolate would flood your empty mouth. That, in essence, is how scientists steer their new remote-controlled rats, reported in the journal Nature. The impulses sent by electrode directly into the rat's brain are more bribery than mind control. If the voice said, ''Jump off a cliff,'' you would think, ''I don't care for chocolate that much.'' But the technology of transmitting sensations directly into the brain could lead to, for instance, artificial limbs that provide a sense of touch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSLEY, ROBERT
description: MOSLEY-Robert. The celebrated bass-baritone Robert Mosley, who thrilled The Met and other major opera audiences as Porgy in Porgy and Bess, Amonasro in Aida, the title role in Rigoletto and many other roles, died April 30 after a long illness. Mr. Mosley was a pioneer in breaking the barriers for Afro-American classical singers, and he will be remembered with gratitude by the many young artists of all races with whom he was always willing to share his knowledge, encouragement and unconditional support. A memorial service will he held at Trinity United Methodist Church in Wilmington, NC at 1:00 pm Saturday, May 11, 2002 by Rev. Skip Williams. The family will receive friends at the church one hour prior to the service. In lieu of flowers, his wife has requested donations to the Robert Mosley Musician Grant, c/o Judith Cantor, CPA, PO Box 97682, Raleigh, NC 27624. This fund will be used to provide financial aid to struggling musicians in the form of tuition scholarships as well as private study, and will be available to all musicians across the country in need.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIGAL, ROBERT ELIHU
description: SIGAL-Robert Elihu. Of Jerusalem, Israel, died on April 16, 2002. He was the elder son of the late Dr. Jacob Sigal and the former Anna Helen Land and stepson of the former Roberta Rosenfeld. He was born on July 5, 1936, in Hartford, Connecticut, and graduated from Phillips Academy in Andover, Massachusetts; and Yale University Class of 1958, where he was a member of the varsity football and lacrosse teams. He received his law degree from Boston University Law School and a Master of Laws in taxation from New York University. He was married to the former Nancy Krawitz, of Milford, Pennsylvania, and practiced law with his fatherin-law, Sidney Krawitz for eleven years before moving with his family to Atlanta, Georgia. He continued to practice law in Atlanta, where he was also an active member of the Atlanta Jewish Federation and Congregation Beth Jacob. In 1983, he moved to Jerusalem, Israel, and until his recent illness, he had traveled throughout the world as Public Relations Director for Bayith LePleitot-Girls Town Jerusalem Orphan Homes, an orphanage for 600 girls. In addition to his widow, he is survived by his children, Rabbi Jonathan Sigal, of Amsterdam, the Netherlands; Amy Grawitzky, of Los Angeles, California; Juliet Sklar and Joshua Sigal, of Jerusalem, Israel; and nineteen grandchildren. He is also survived by his sister, Sally Ann Siegel, of New York City; and by his brother, Richard L. Sigal, of New York City and New London, Connecticut. Donations in his memory may be sent to the Robert E. Sigal Memorial Medical Fund, Bayith Lepleitot, Inc. -Girls Town Jerusalem Orphan Homes, c/o the USA tax-exempt office, 1362 East 21 Street, Brooklyn, New York 11210. This special fund will be used exclusively for medical care: the physical, dental, psychological and opthalmalic services so urgently needed by the orphans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEI, MARK
description: WEI-Mark. Died at 84 years of age on April 30, 2002 in his home in Manhattan. Born in Hong Kong, China, Mr. Wei came to New York from China in April of 1941. Mr. Wei began his insurance career at Chubb & Son, Inc. in 1947 and retired after 35 years of service. At the time of his retirement, he was Senior Vice President and a member of the Board of Directors of Chubb & Son, Inc. Mr. Wei also served as a Director of the American Institution of Marine Underwriters, the National Cargo Bureau and the Security Bureau, Inc. He was a former Chairman and Director of the American Cargo War Risk Reinsurance Exchange and the Cargo Reinsurance Association. Mr. Wei received a B.A degree from St. John's University in Shanghai, China and a Master's Degree in Business Administration from Colorado College. He also attended law school at Indiana University. During World War II, he served as a lieutenant in the United States Marine Corps in the Pacific Theater and in the Far East. At the time of his death, Mark was a director and Principal in Kemark Financial Services, Inc. headquartered in Pearl River, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hofstra University, Mark Wei Athletic & Scholarship Fund, c/o Michael D'Amato, 101 Hofstra University, Hempstead, NY 11549.

description: CONROY-Ann Barbara Omara. Died peacefully on Friday, March 29, 2002, at 76. Loving wife of the late Robert Gerard Conroy. Devoted mother of Robert, Kimberley, Curtis and Kyle. Beloved grandmother of Katherine, Caroline, Sean, Garrett, Finlay, Pierce and Riley. A graduate of Barat College, Lake Forest, IL, and Villa Schifanoia, Florence, Italy. She possessed remarkable charm, beauty, intelligence, good humor, loyalty and optimism. She loved humanity and adored conversations with friends and strangers alike. Most importantly, she is loved and missed by her family and countless others whose lives she enriched with her festive spirit, warmth and generosity. A memorial service will be held at Saint Vincent Ferrer Church at 66th Street and Lexington Avenue in New York, NY, on Monday, May 13, at 11 AM. Donations may be made to the U.S. Fund for UNICEF, P.O. Box 97296 Department 1800, Washington, DC 20077-7660.

Each morning, a half-dozen men huddle out front, waiting for the bank clock to strike 6 and the restaurant to unlock its doors so they can replant themselves on their rightful counter stools. By 6:45, Main Street is lined with pickup trucks, their exhaust white in the frosty air as they head over for first shift at Dresser-Rand, Wellsville's biggest employer, manufacturer of electric-generating steam turbines.

title: Mind Games
description: I know one guy who hasn't been to a doctor in 40 years. His avowed plan is to be alive one day and dead the next. He doesn't want to see anything coming from afar. He is a rare bird these days, as Old World as his Italian father and 11 Italian uncles. He is a veterinary surgeon. Once in a while he tells me about some colleague of his who has got into the hands of the doctors. They always say to him, ''I should have gone to a vet.'' Vets do what doctors used to -- diagnose the injury or the condition, patch it up as best they can and remind you that these things happen and that in life we are also in the midst of death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, MEL
description: WASSERMAN-Mel, 72, died peacefully in his sleep at his home in Carmel, CA on Monday April 29, 2002. As co-founder of CEDU Education with his wife Brigitte, Mel has touched the lives of thousands of families. CEDU was founded in 1967, when they welcomed troubled children into their home. Since then, it has grown into a world-renowned program with six schools working so successfully with troubled children and their families. Mel's lifework lives on through his teachings, philosophy, and within the countless thousands whom he has touched so deeply. Mel made a difference in such a real way. He gave of himself freely, and always brought value to other people's lives. He was truly larger than his own life. Mel is survived by his wife Brigitte, his brother Al, and his three children, Mark, Dana, and Stacy. Mel was blessed with eight beautiful grandchildren, Jessica, Alexandra, Kristina, Kendall, John, James, Spencer, and Logan. Mel's extended family includes all those whom he touched, and welcomed into his home. We love him dearly and he will always be in our hearts. In keeping with Mr. Wasserman's wishes, there will be no service. The family suggests that memorial contributions be sent to the Boys & Girls Club of the Monterey Peninsula, 1332 La Salle Ave, Seaside, CA 93955.

title: Private Sector; A Glass Ceiling That Can't Be Missed
description: Not surprisingly, when Maurice R. Greenberg, the venerable leader who hopes to never stop leading, introduced his choice of possible successors at the American International Group last week, it was an all-male cast. There are few women in the higher echelons of insurance and A.I.G. is no exception. Mr. Greenberg, who turned 77 yesterday, contended that A.I.G. has a fair share of women executives even if not in the inner circle. But the company operates in 140 countries and some, he suggested, might not greet a woman with the same respect routinely accorded chiefs of the other sex. ''In a lot of countries in the world, it would be very difficult for a woman to be a good C.E.O.'' he said. ''I don't make the rules. I have a responsibility to do the best we can for shareholders.'' Joseph B. Treaster

But as every parent knows -- whether faced with a fractious toddler or a churlish teenager -- invention is frequently a mother's necessity. So, on Mother's Day, next Sunday, it seems only right to celebrate Mom's creativity by choosing a gift that tweaks the mold with wit and practicality. Here are some new variations on tried-and-true themes, for families of all ages.

title: Hollywood Gotham
description: In CELLULOID SKYLINE: New York and the Movies (Knopf, $45), James Sanders sets out to define a dualism particular to New York -- that between the real city and the mythic city, or movie city, and how the two ''reflected each other, changed each other, taught each other.'' Sanders, who wrote a documentary series about New York with Ric Burns, is an architect by trade and a sociologist by extension, and architecture is where his strength lies. Maybe a more apt subtitle of the book would have been ''New York: Its Buildings, Landscapes and Movies.'' From his opening chapters, he lavishly delineates the foregrounds and backgrounds (both on the screen and in the society) of hundreds of films set in New York. In fact, he seems intent on citing every movie that took place in New York -- he comes close, from 1903 (''At the Foot of the Flatiron'') to 1999 (''Ghost Dog: The Way of the Samurai'') -- and by doing so ends up discussing some unworthy films. But his exhaustive research is supported by a multifaceted understanding (and love) of the city. And when it appears the book could become another narrow look at New York-equals-Manhattan, he takes a wide-angle view of the other boroughs, lovingly evoking ''Marty,'' ''True Love,'' ''Queens Logic,'' ''Working Girl'' and ''I Like It Like That.'' The ample movie stills are refreshingly unpredictable and perfectly illustrate Sanders's fresh ways of thinking and seeing. Michael J. Agovino

title: E.R., Unscripted
description: Sandra Scott's night begins with a resuscitation and ends, after dawn, with a pile of paperwork. In between is a 12-hour shift at Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn. Scott, a 34-year-old specialist in emergency medicine, has worked at Kings County since 1998. Because Kings County is a publicly financed hospital in a low-income neighborhood, many who come in are uninsured, but the hospital is obliged to treat them. Which means that Scott sees a wider range of cases than doctors in most E.R.'s. In addition to dealing with cuts and bullet wounds, on any given night Scott will treat everything from miscarriages and S.T.D.'s to dental problems and what one patient believed was sleep disturbance caused by a spell.

title: Public Colleges, Broken Promises
description: The United States set out nearly 30 years ago to ensure that Americans who qualified academically would not be turned away from college for financial reasons. The bedrock of the program was a dual system: state legislatures subsidized public universities to keep tuition low, while the poorest students could get federal Pell Grants that largely covered the remaining costs. Within a few years of setting that goal, the attempt to secure the broadest possible access to college seemed secure. Since then, spiraling tuition and declining support for poor and working-class students have combined to roll back one of the more farsighted policies of the 20th century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMAHON, THOMAS
description: McMAHON-Thomas. National benefits leader. A financial executive who dedicated his life to making the lives of others better, died on Friday in Napa, California. He was 55. Tom (as he preferred to be called) was Senior Vice-President of Finance and Administration for the Pacific Maritime Association, sponsor with the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union of one of the nation's largest multi-employer retirement and health plans, providing benefits to thousands of working and retired longshoremen and their families. A plan administrator, Tom initiated the first tax-qualified multi-employer 401(k) plan in the nation. As a national financial and benefits leader Tom was serving on the Secretary of Labor's Advisory Council on Pension and Welfare Benefit Plans at the time of his death. He served on the Board of Directors and the Executive Committee of the Employee Benefit Research Institute in Washington, D.C. Tom was a national leader of Financial Executives International, and the AICPA where he provided special expertise on retirement and health issues, and advocated the extension of economic security programs to all working and retired Americans. A native of Sherman, Texas, Tom was a graduate of the University of Texas at Arlington, where he received his BBA in 1968, became an officer and fighter pilot in the Navy during the Vietnam war, returned to earn his MBA in 1972, and then became a CPA. He served on the UTA Business School Advisory Board and the University of Texas Chancellor's Advisory Committee. He and his wife Jeannette established a Professorship in Ethics at the School in 1998, which served as the catalyst for the UTA McMahonCoburn Ethics Colloquium. The same dedication to helping others caused them to endow a scholarship in the MBA program at the University of Washington in Seattle. He was honored by the University of Texas at Arlington with the Distinguished Alumni Award in 1998. Tom was active in the Big Brother program in Seattle, Washington and maintains a close relationship with his ''little brother,'' Steve Anderson of Menlo Park, California. Tom is survived by his wife Jeannette Coburn. For information about the memorial service go to www.mcmahon.info. For more information contact Richard Pierce Funeral Services, 707-226-744.

title: N.J. Law
description: ''Open and Shut'' (Mysterious Press, $23.95) starts with a discussion of the Lincoln vs. the George. The trip is from Manhattan to New Jersey, where the action stays. in settings like Paterson, Lyndhurst, Alpine, Loveladies and other New Jersey locations. At the center of it all is Andy Carpenter, a defense lawyer reared in Paterson, who is trying to save a man on death row who had been convicted in a case prosecuted by Mr. Carpenter's father. The man's retrial is part of a briskly paced plot that also involves the lawyer's father, his love life, his dog, money and an old secret. This is the first novel by David Rosenfelt, a Paterson native himself, who moved to California and worked in the movie business. As several early readers have noted, this is a very assured first novel, and it's packed with cleverly sarcastic wit, between drives on the parkway and the turnpike. The official publishing date is Thursday.

title: DROUGHT RESTRICTIONS
description: State environmental officials last week eased a ban on lawn watering in the southwestern, northwestern and south coastal regions of the state. Residents may water two days each week (the days depend on whether a home's address ends in an odd or even number), and in some central and coastal counties, residents may water three days a week. The new policy will be reviewed by the state on June 28. Lawn watering is still prohibited in Passaic, Bergen, Hudson and Essex Counties and in part of Morris County. The Department of Environmental Protection commissioner, Bradley M. Campbell, said the state would need 18 to 26 inches of rainfall in the next few months to reverse the drought. The state has opened a Web site, www.njdrought.org, with information about rules and drought status. Jeremy Pearce

title: The Seductress of Vanity

Wexler is known for her high-caliber clientele -- among them Barbra Streisand, Stephanie Seymour and Candace Bushnell - and on one memorable day, three different bodyguards arrived with three different charges. (''I thought, My mother would be really proud,'' Wexler recalls.) But the patients aren't checking one another out in hopes of celebrity sightings. They're looking for ideas: is she trying something I should know about?

title: At Large in the Blogosphere

The current craze is for something called a blog. The name is the diminutive of ''Weblog,'' an online news commentary written, usually, by an ordinary citizen, thick with links to articles and other blogs and studded with non sequiturs and ripostes in sometimes hard-to-parse squabbles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VEHSLAGE, STEPHEN T.
description: VEHSLAGE-Stephen T. Age 62, died peacefully May 5 in Greenwich Hospital, Greenwich, CT after a yearlong battle with brain cancer. He graduated from the Haverford School, Haverford, PA in 1957 and from Princeton University in 1961. He spent his business career with the IBM Corporation where he was for many years a senior executive with IBM Europe and later a Vice President and Director of IBM Americas Far East. He served for many years as a director of True North Communications. He was a past president of the Round Hill Club in Greenwich and a current director of the Prouts Neck Country Club, Prouts Neck, ME. He was a gifted athlete, excelling in racquet sports, soccer and golf. In squash racquets he was three-time National Junior Champion, three-time Intercollegiate Champion at Princeton, Canadian National Champion in 1964, U.S. National Amateur Champion in 1965, and North American Open Doubles Champion in 1967; he won the U.S. Court Tennis Doubles title in 1967. While at Princeton, he was a two-time First Team All-Ivy selection in soccer. He was also an avid and accomplished fly fisherman. He is survived by April, his beloved wife of 40 years, a daughter Cynthia Vehslage Meyers and husband Stephen of Niscayuna, NY, a son Stephen, Jr. and wife Emmy Starr of Wilton, CT and six grandchildren, and by a brother, Ramsay W. Vehslage of Princeton, NJ. Burial will be private. There will be a memorial service at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Riverside, CT on Friday, May 10 at 11:00 AM. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to Family Centers, Inc, 40 Arch St., Greenwich, CT or to Greenwich Hospital, 5 Perryridge Rd., Greenwich, CT 06830.

title: Mumbling Toward November
description: Normally, with an election approaching, Republicans and Democrats in Washington would be trying to carve out separate identities by sharpening their differences. That is not happening so far this season. Part of the reason is that the war on terrorism has until recently crowded out serious debate on domestic issues. Another is that both parties, for their own peculiar reasons, are still tentative about their agendas. While Republicans are nervous about the economy, the Democrats are unsure about what course to take on the federal budget. They have criticized President Bush's tax cut for deepening the federal deficit. But at the same time they are leery of big new spending measures. They are going to have to show some boldness if they plan on keeping the Senate and taking control of the House.

His friend, whose name was also not available, was beaten during the attempted robbery, the police said. He was in stable condition last night at St. Vincent's Manhattan Hospital. The two men were walking on West 39th Street near Avenue of the Americas about 2:10 a.m. when the four men approached them, the police said. When the victim resisted, he was shot in the chest. Investigators arrested one suspect, identified as Stephen Robinson, 16, on assault charges. The other three men, including the suspected gunman, remained at large.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERTZIG, MORRIS
description: HERTZIG-Morris. 93, died at Sweetbrook Care Center, Williamstown, MA, May 4th, 2002. Born in Chicago, IL, August 3rd, 1908, the son of Harry and Celia Tannenbaum Hertzig, he was raised in Brooklyn, NY. Following graduation from Boys High School in Brooklyn, he attended the College of the City of New York City College from which he received his undergraduate degree, Phi Beta Kappa, in 1929, and a Master's Degree in Mathematics and Education the following year. His long association with the New York City school system began with his appointment as a teacher of mathematics at Haran High School in 1929. He also taught mathematics at Grover Cleveland High School, before becoming the Chair of the Department of Mathematics at Townsend Harris High School in Manhattan. He then became Chairman of the Department of Mathematics at the newly opened Forest Hills High School in 1941. In 1947, he was appointed Principal of Junior High School 252 in Brooklyn, and later served as the Principal of Junior High School 217 in Queens. Always an inspiration to students, it was during his years as a junior high school principal that his efforts to insure that all students reached their educational potential truly flowered. Long before the women's movement gained momentum, he regularly visited the homes of academically able girls for the purpose of convincing reluctant parents to permit their daughters to register for college preparatory courses in high school. He had a profound effect on many students as he guided them and instilled in them an unending thirst for knowledge and success. Shortly before his retirement in 1971, he served for two years with the Board of Examiners of the City of New York, devoting himself to making sure that newly appointed teachers and administrators possessed the requisite skills to perform their jobs. Following his retirement to Lake Worth, FL, he became an active member of that community. A founding member of the Foreign Policy Discussion Group, he also served on the Board of the local Public Radio Station. He was a founding member of the Adult Education Program held at the Palm Beach Community College and served on the Board of Directors for many years. He continued to spend summers on Lake Sebago in Raymond, ME, receiving a constant stream of visitors, including many former students, whom he delighted with guided tours of the improvements he had made to the property, including a 200 foot long rock retaining wall along the shore of the lake. His wife, Grace Koenig Hertzig, whom he married on March 29th, 1934, died on June 18th, 1989. He is survived by a son, Dr. Robert Hertzig of Williamstown, MA, and a daughter, Dr. Margaret E. Hertzig of New York City, a brother, Bernard Hertzig of Lake Worth, FL, a sister, Dorothy Weiss of Boca Raton, FL, four grandchildren, Megan Hertzig Sharon, Jeremy S. Hertzig, Sarah E. Birch and Dr. Martin L. Birch, as well as his devoted companion, Janou Walcutt. He is sorely missed. Graveside services will be held at Beth Moses Cemetery, Long Island, NY, on Sunday, May 12th, 2002 at 11 AM.

The hourly rate since 1986 has been $25 for out-of-court work and $40 for time in court. The commission, New York State Judicial Institute on Professionalism in the Law, along with client advocates and many bar and community associations, has petitioned to raise the rate to $75 for felony and family court matters and $60 for nonfelony criminal cases. The commission's chairman, Louis A. Craco, said there was an urgent need to stymie the ''critical deterioration in the quantity and quality of legal services to the poor caused directly by the utterly inadequate rates of pay for assigned counsel.'' The program, which was advertised in The Daily News, offered a study-at-home program for $10 to $150 and a diploma after passing at-home tests. But equivalency tests cannot be taken through correspondence courses or at home, a spokeswoman for Mr. Spitzer said. All 260 passengers were killed after the vertical part of the tail fell off and the plane crashed in Belle Harbor a few minutes after taking off from Kennedy Airport en route to Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic. Aviation experts are still inspecting the tails of other Airbus A300-600's, the model that crashed. A spokesman for American Airlines would not comment, citing company policy on pending litigation. title: National Briefing: Science and Health
description: CHUG, DON'T SIP Heavy tea drinking could reduce the risk of dying after a heart attack, a new study says. Researchers at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center in Boston tracked 1,900 people for the study, the results of which were reported in the American Heart Association journal Circulation. Those who drank the most tea  about 19 cups a week  were the least likely to die in the three to four years after an attack; they had a 44 percent lower death rate than nondrinkers. Researchers suspect the findings are linked to flavonoids, antioxidants found naturally in various foods derived from plants. Tea is a major source of flavonoids in American diets. (AP)

In the Andalusian town of Ronda, we stared into the gorge that inspired the scene in Hemingway's ''For Whom the Bell Tolls,'' in which Franco's supporters were tossed from the cliffs. In Granada, we toured the glorious Alhambra and got lost in the corkscrew streets of the Albaicn, the town's Moorish quarter. But when I think back on the trip, those evocative scenes aren't what first come to mind. What I remember is our torturous negotiation over beds in Granada.

title: Technology Briefing: Internet
description: BILL ADDRESSES DOMAIN-NAME DATA Two members of Congress introduced a bill late last week that would make it a crime to provide false contact information when registering an Internet domain name. The bill was introduced by Representative Howard Coble, a North Carolina Republican, and Representative Howard Berman, a California Democrat, in response to concerns that false information about domain name registrants would hamper criminal investigations. The bill would modify the criminal code so that "whoever knowingly and with intent to defraud provides material and misleading false contact information to a domain name registrar" would be subject to fines and possibly imprisonment.

Travel agents are still reporting sharp declines in bookings in that region, as much as 25 percent in some cases. description: Telefnica Mviles became Mexico's second-largest cellular phone provider yesterday after buying 65 percent of Pegaso, a Mexican wireless unit of Leap Wireless International, for $87 million. Pegaso will retain its 35 percent stake, while the Sprint Corporation, Leap Wireless and Qualcomm sold their shares. Telefnica, already the largest telecommunications provider in Latin America, will inherit more than two million cellular clients in Mexico. It plans to increase its customer base to more than seven million by 2005. Graham Gori (NYT)

description: The Bush administration has accused Cuba of producing small quantities of germs that can be used in biological warfare and says Libya and Syria are also violating international treaties by making unconventional weapons.

title: Inquiries Could Hurt Ratings of Investment Firms
description: Merrill Lynch & Company and other investment banks may see their credit ratings cut should state and federal investigations of their research practices lead to criminal indictments, Moody's Investors Service said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMAHON, THOMAS
description: McMAHON-Thomas. National benefits leader. A financial executive who dedicated his life to making the lives of others better, died on Friday in Napa, California. He was 55. Tom (as he preferred to be called) was Senior Vice-President of Finance and Administration for the Pacific Maritime Association, sponsor with the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union of one of the nation's largest multi-employer retirement & health plans, providing benefits to thousands of working and retired longshoremen and their families. A plan administrator, Tom initiated the first tax-qualified multi-employer 401(k) plan in the nation. As a national financial and benefits leader Tom was serving on the Secretary of Labor's Advisory Council on Pension and Welfare Benefit Plans at the time of his death. He served on the Board of Directors and the Executive Committee of the Employee Benefit Research Institute in Washington, D.C. Tom was a national leader of Financial Executives International, and the AICPA where he provided special expertise on retirement and health issues, and advocated the extension of economic security programs to all working and retired Americans. A native of Sherman, Texas, Tom was a graduate of the University of Texas at Arlington, where he received his BBA in 1968, became an officer and fighter pilot in the Navy during the Vietnam war, returned to earn his MBA in 1972, and then became a CPA. He served on the UTA Business School Advisory Board and the University of Texas Chancellor's Advisory Committee. He and his wife Jeannette established a Professorship in Ethics at the School in 1998, which served as the catalyst for the UTA McMahonCoburn Ethics Colloquium. The same dedication to helping others caused them to endow a scholarship in the MBA program at the University of Washington in Seattle. He was honored by the University of Texas at Arlington with the Distinguished Alumni Award in 1998. Tom was active in the Big Brother program in Seattle, Washington and maintains a close relationship with his ''little brother,'' Steve Anderson of Menlo Park, California. Tom is survived by his wife Jeannette Coburn. For information about the memorial service go to www.tmcmahon.info. For more info contact the Richard Pierce Funeral Services, 707-226-744.

title: Honeybee Shows a Little Gene Activity Goes Miles and Miles
description: Midway through a honeybee's fleeting, bittersweet, and, yes, busy little life, a momentous transformation occurs: the 2-week-old worker must abandon her cloistered career as a hive-keeping nurse, and venture out into the world to forage.

title: NBC Left at the Gate In Its Derby Coverage
description: After War Emblem's four-length victory Saturday in the Kentucky Derby, NBC's Tom Hammond belatedly told viewers, ''Bobby Frankel said earlier in the week that he feared War Emblem loose on the lead.''

title: Rightist Candidate in Netherlands Is Slain, and the Nation Is Stunned
description: Pim Fortuyn, a maverick right-wing populist who was a leading candidate in national elections scheduled for next week, was shot and killed tonight, deeply shocking a country that sees itself as peaceful and egalitarian, and raising the specter of violence stalking European politics.

title: Cadillac Recasts Itself as a Full-Line Manufacturer
description: Cadillac, which until recently had embodied the essence of conservatism, embraces risk these days.

title: Seattle Slew, Last Living Triple Crown Winner, Dies
description: Seattle Slew, who was widely considered the last of the super horses as he was the only living winner of the Triple Crown, died in his sleep today at the Hill 'n Dale Farm in Lexington, Ky., officials said. The horse was 28 years old.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENAMY, ROSLYN (NEE HEIDECORN)
description: BENAMY-Roslyn (nee Heidecorn). Age 72. Of Teaneck. Beloved wife of Daniel. Devoted mother of Philip and Lois, Leonard and Ewa, David and Shelley and Leah and David. Cherished grandmother of Gabriel, Maxx, Sarah, Shai, Ayal and Na'ama, loving sister of Charlotte Healey. Loving aunt of Phyllis and Danny Macchia. She was a docent at the Jewish Museum in New York City and a Professor Emeritus of Rockland Community College SUNY, a worldwide traveler and Fulbright scholar. Roslyn was an activist who believed in and worked for Tikkun Olam, the repair of the world. May her efforts be continued. title: $11 Billion Artillery System Is Dead, Officials Say
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld has decided to kill an $11 billion Army artillery system without further review, senior Pentagon aides said today. The decision sets the stage for a showdown with the weapon's influential supporters in Congress and the embattled Army secretary who fought to save it.

title: Chirac's Pick: A Premier Friendly to Small Business
description: Moving quickly to capitalize on his landslide re-election victory on Sunday, President Jacques Chirac of France selected a center-right prime minister, Jean-Pierre Raffarin, today to restore his conservative base and lead his party into the crucial legislative elections next month.

title: LABOR PROVISION VIOLATION WILL COST UNITED $8.9 MILLION
description: An arbitrator has ruled that United Airlines, part of UAL, must pay flight attendants $8.9 million for violating the terms of a labor contract by employing attendants from Air Wisconsin after acquiring that airline, a union spokeswoman said yesterday. United bought Air Wisconsin in 1992 and operated it as a separate carrier, using Air Wisconsin's attendants rather than United's. The arbitrator ruled on April 27 that the move violated a labor agreement requiring United to use flight attendants from a seniority list. ''It really sends a message that the flight attendants stand behind their contract,'' said Dawn Deeks, a spokeswoman for the Association of Flight Attendants. The $8.9 million will be split among attendants employed in 1992 and 1993, she said. A United spokesman said the airline had no comment. Air Wisconsin is now privately held, though it remains a feeder carrier for United. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: Wildlife Fund Takes Down Wrestlers in Name Game
description: The Federation is dead, pinned in the legal ring by a conservation-minded panda. No amount of drop kicks or People's Elbows could save the Federation from extinction.

title: Medical Students Sue Over Residency System
description: Every March, graduating medical school students wait anxiously for Match Day, when a computer tells them where they will spend the next several years as medical residents in teaching hospitals.

title: Deal to End Church Siege Is Snagged on Angry Details
description: While there is a consensus between Israeli and Palestinian negotiators on how to settle the siege at the Church of the Nativity here, the release of more than 100 people inside was held up today by the details.

description: The Indonesian government has arrested a prominent Islamic militant, the first such move here since the United States declared its war on terror.

title: Steinbrenner in Stands Puts Pressure on Yanks
description: As the Yankees prepared to play the Tampa Bay Devil Rays for the first time in spring training, Roger Clemens hollered across the clubhouse. ''This is Game 1 of the World Series,'' he said, and he was only half-kidding.

title: Survey Finds Anxiety but Few Canceled Trips
description: THE events of last September have not had a substantial effect on most Americans' vacation plans, according to the latest nationwide New York Times/CBS News poll. But many people acknowledged that fear for their safety has caused them to rethink their travel arrangements for this summer.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Action Sought On Hindu-Muslim Violence
description: The upper house of the Indian Parliament unanimously adopted a resolution calling on the central government to intervene in the western state of Gujarat and halt murderous attacks by Hindu mobs on Muslims that have left more than 900 people dead, most of them Muslims, since a Muslim mob set fire to a train carrying Hindu activists, killing 58. Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee said: ''The reins of government are in our hands. We are responsible.'' His Hindu nationalist movement, the Bharatiya Janata Party, which governs Gujarat State and has been blamed for failing to stop the violence, opposed a more critical motion in the lower house but supported the milder upper-house version.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Regret Over Canceled Talks
description: The Unification Ministry voiced regret over North Korea's cancellation of what were to have been the first North-South talks on economic problems in the past 17 months. The North said comments by the South Korean foreign minister, Choi Sung Hong, during a recent trip to Washington made the discussions, which were to start today, impossible. The North has demanded Mr. Choi's dismissal for saying President Bush's tough stance against the North may have led to its being more open to talks. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Court Is Told Microsoft Kept Strategy Even After Ruling
description: The Microsoft Corporation bundled more multimedia features into Windows XP even after a judge ruled the company had illegally integrated extra functions into the operating system to protect its monopoly, a company executive testified today.

title: Bush Expected to Name 2 Economists to Federal Reserve Seats
description: President Bush is preparing to nominate two prominent monetary economists -- Ben S. Bernanke of Princeton University and Donald L. Kohn, a top aide to Alan Greenspan -- to open seats on the Federal Reserve Board, government officials said today.

title: Freed Burmese Democracy Leader Proclaims 'New Dawn'
description: Radiating joy and confidence, the woman known throughout Myanmar as the Lady stood before a cheering crowd today for the first time in years and proclaimed, ''It's a new dawn for the country.''

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: 120 City Workers To Retire Early
description: A total of 120 employees of New Haven have agreed to take early retirement as part of the city's plan for balancing the 2002-2003 budget. The early retirements, which will cost $430,000 in salary payouts, will cut $5.2 million from the city's payroll, leaving the $354 million budget balanced, said Controller Mark Pietrosimone. The police department will be most affected by the buyouts, as it is losing 22 civilian employees. Mr. Pietrosimone said that with the loss of manpower, other city employees were being asked to shoulder additional responsibilities for added compensation. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: On First Try, District Maps Drawn to Fit Parties' Needs
description: Representative Benjamin A. Gilman defended his district and his incumbency in front of a court-appointed special master in a Manhattan courtroom yesterday, saying that Sullivan, Rockland and Orange Counties were among the state's fastest growing and diverse regions and deserved a representative with seniority.

title: School Board In Roosevelt Resists Ouster
description: The school board in the long-troubled district in Roosevelt, N.Y., made a final effort today to stay in office, defending its record at a hearing presided over by the state official seeking its removal, Education Commissioner Richard P. Mills.

title: Israelis Seek to Build Physical Barrier in West Bank
description: For the last month, squads of construction crews have been busily throwing up chain-link fences all along the road leading to a disputed Jewish neighborhood on the southern edge of Jerusalem.

title: Bush, at School, Promotes Education Bill
description: President Bush visited a once-failing elementary school today in a neighborhood brimming with Arab immigrants to press educators and parents to put into effect the education bill that he signed this year and to celebrate the successes of young Arab students.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Khmer Rouge Leader Charged
description: In a legal move to extend his imprisonment pending trial, the government charged the former chief torturer of the Khmer Rouge with crimes against humanity. Kang Kek Ieu, who was known as Duch, administered Tuol Sleng prison where at least 14,000 people were tortured and sent to their deaths. He was arrested in May 1999 and was previously charged with genocide. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Apple Introduces New Service
description: Apple Computer yesterday gave a brief demonstration of iChat, an instant messenger program that is intended to be compatible with America Online's AOL Instant Messenger Service. Apple demonstrated its new instant messenger client at the first day of the company's annual World Wide Developer Conference that began yesterday in San Jose, Calif. Officials of AOL, a unit of AOL Time Warner, said that this was the first time they had permitted another company to independently build an Instant Messenger client that was compatible with the AOL service that reaches 150 million users. The Apple program is planned for a late summer release as part of a new version of the company's Mac OS X operating system that was also demonstrated yesterday. John Markoff (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Profit Climbs At Henkel
description: The German chemical group Henkel posted higher first-quarter results than expected and maintained its full-year outlook to increase its operating profit by at least 10 percent based on expected stronger growth in the United States. Sales by the adhesive maker increased 3.9 percent, to 2.4 billion euros, and the operating profit rose 3.1 percent, to 162 million euros ($149 million), compared with the prior year's first quarter. The positive data was seen as a result of the group's restructuring program, which included job cuts and the sale of unprofitable units and stakes to focus on Henkel's consumer products. Petra Kappl (NYT)

description: Deepening the mystery of the biological attacks that terrified the nation last fall, federal investigators have discovered that the anthrax sent through the mail, in general, grew more potent from one letter to the next, with the spores in the final letter to be opened -- the one sent to Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont -- the deadliest of all.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Computer Network Expects A Loss
description: The Computer Network Technology Corporation, a Minneapolis-based maker of computer-networking hardware and software, said yesterday that it would post a loss for its first quarter. Shares closed yesterday at $6.97, down $1.80. The company said it now expected an operating loss of 10 cents to 15 cents a share, on revenue of about $45 million. Wall Street analysts were expecting a profit of 2 cents to 4 cents a share. The company also said yesterday that Nick Ganio, vice president for worldwide sales and marketing, had decided to leave the company to pursue other interests. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Informal Inquiry on Purchase of Railtrack Shares
description: Schroder Salomon Smith Barney is conducting an internal investigation into suspicious trades in the shares of Railtrack, the insolvent company that owns Britain's railroad tracks and stations, a spokesman for Schroder Salomon Smith Barney said today.

title: Some Thoughts On Airline Security
description: Once again, we turn to the aviation consultant Michael Boyd for some final thoughts on the new era in security (www.aviationplanning.com). Mr. Boyd strongly opposes the so-called trusted traveler plan, which would allow passengers who agree to detailed prescreening to carry ''smart card'' ID's that would allow them expedited passage through airport security. Mr. Boyd says people can go from being an acceptable risk to an unacceptable one with no trace.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Recovery Seen In Chip Industry
description: ASML Holding N.V., Europe's largest semiconductor-equipment maker, reiterated yesterday that it sees evidence the chip industry is recovering from its worst year ever. Worldwide computer-chip sales rose 7.2 percent in March from February, the biggest month-on-month increase since April 1986, the Semiconductor Industry Association said last week. While that suggests demand is improving, investors said they were not convinced the recovery would last. Shares of ASML fell 9 cents, to 21.11 euros after earlier rising as much as 5.9 percent.

title: National Briefing: West
description: COLORADO: WILDFIRE RAGES NEAR HOUSES Fire managers called up more crews to battle a 400-acre wildfire that had chased 2,000 people from their homes in the forested foothills near Evergreen, about 25 miles west of Denver. No homes were damaged, but the blaze was within a quarter-mile of at least one house and within two miles of subdivisions. The Jefferson County sheriff's office evacuated everyone within two miles of the fire on Sunday. (AP)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Brewery Earnings Fall
description: Companhia de Bebidas das Amricas, or Ambev, the world's fourth-largest brewer, said first-quarter profit fell 9.2 percent as beer sales volume declined and some costs rose. Ambev's first-quarter net income fell to 222.8 million reais ($96.5 million), or 59 centavos per American depository receipt, from 245.3 million reais, or 63 centavos, a year ago. The results were worse than the 232.5 million reais net expected by analysts. Price rises from last year helped Ambev, whose brands include Brahma, Skol and Antarctica, offset a 12 percent decline in demand because of unseasonably wet weather in the first two months of the year, the height of Brazil's summer. Revenue rose 9.6 percent in the first quarter, to 1.66 billion reais from 1.52 billion reais.

title: Biologists Sought a Treaty; Now They Fault It
description: A treaty enacted nine years ago to conserve and exploit the diversity of species on earth is seriously impeding biologists' efforts to catalog and comprehend that same natural bounty, many scientists say.

Mr. Morand had been vice president and brand director at MacLaren McCann Canada, Toronto. Both agencies are owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies.

description: What the airlines giveth to your legs, the airlines can taketh away.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Earthlink's President Resigns Post
description: Citing ''personal reasons,'' Michael S. McQuary, the president of EarthLink, the No. 3 Internet service provider in the United States, has resigned, the company announced yesterday. Garry Betty, left, EarthLink's chief executive, will assume Mr. McQuary's day-to-day responsibilities. Mr. McQuary joined the company when it merged with Mindspring, a rival Internet provider, in early 2000. He was chief operating officer of that concern. Although Earthlink has been losing dial-up customers in recent months, it still has 4.9 million subscribers. Two weeks ago EarthLink shares fell more than 16 percent after the company said its quarterly loss had not narrowed as much as analysts had expected. Although the company did not elaborate on Mr. McQuary's reason for leaving EarthLink, a spokesman confirmed that his wife gave birth to triplets last year. The couple now has five children. The stock market reacted negatively to Mr. McQuary's departure. Shares in EarthLink fell 87 cents, or 11 percent, to $7. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Dodging Peanuts: To Some, a Lifelong Challenge
description: A college student who knew she was allergic to peanuts died after eating chili that had been thickened with peanut butter. Another college student died after eating cookies with a label that failed to mention peanuts as an ingredient because the manufacturer, not wanting to waste some leftover peanut cookie batter, added it to the batter for some other kind of cookie.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Pay Disclosed
description: The Credit Suisse Group listed the pay of its top managers for the first time, except for its chairman and chief executive, Lukas Mhlemann. The company, Switzerland's second-largest banking group, said it paid 28 managers some $85 million in salaries, bonuses, shares and options. Under new disclosure rules, Mr. Mhlemann does not have to disclose his individual pay, estimated at more than $9 million, until next year. The chairman of a rival, UBS, Marcel Ospel, set the pace by revealing his $7.3 million pay packet last month. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: National Parks Are Sprucing Up Facilities and Enhancing Security
description: IN normal times, almost every year is a record-setting one for the National Park Service. But last year was not, as visits to the nation's 385 sites dropped sharply after Sept. 11, particularly among travelers from overseas.

description: FEINBERG-Samuel. On May 5, 2002. Loving devoted husband, father and grandfather. Survived by wife Nettie. Daughter Alice Batson. Sons Lawrence and Richard. Grandsons Jacob, Teddy and Ian. Daughters-in-law Sandra and Nana and son-in-law Kevin. Worked for Fairchild Publicatoions from 1937 to 1993. title: McGreevey Threatens to End Deal With Car Emissions Tester
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey threatened today to break a $400 million contract with the company that runs the state's troubled auto emissions inspection program unless the contractor agrees to a substantial cut in its fees over the next few years.

title: New Resistant Gonorrhea Migrating to Mainland U.S.
description: Strains of gonorrhea that are resistant to a major class of antibiotics have reached the mainland United States after steady migration from Asia to Hawaii and now to California. Meanwhile in Hawaii, researchers have identified the first cases in the United States of gonorrhea resistant to multiple drugs.

title: Big Discounts for Those Who Will Listen
description: WITH some frequency I receive marketing material on time shares inviting me to stay at a luxurious Florida resort for some ridiculously low price. These offers always seem too good to be true and I toss them in the trash. The most recent offer, from the Marriott hotel chain, came by mail and was followed by a phone call. Because I am a member of Marriott's frequent-guest program and, more significantly, I had just bought air tickets to take the family to Orlando to visit my mom in April, I said the words a telemarketer longs to hear: ''Sure, I'm interested. Tell me more.''

title: Paul Szasz, 72, Legal Expert; Helped Draft 2 Constitutions
description: Paul Szasz, a longtime United Nations expert on international law who helped draft Constitutions for the new states of Namibia, in southwest Africa, and Bosnia and Herzegovina, which was carved out of the former Yugoslav Federation, died April 30 at his home in Germantown, N.Y. He was 72.

title: One Day on Welfare, the Next He's Showing in Paris
description: Last Thursday morning, in his office at 552 Seventh Avenue, amid the swatches and silvery trinket-box clutter of his desk, Ralph Rucci received the official word from Paris that he could show at the haute couture collections in July. So finally, officially, he was in the big league. It was going to cost him a bundle: the big-league suite at the Ritz, at $1,500 a night; the show, all the top models, Carmen and Erin. But he didn't care. Finally, he, Ralph Rucci, was going to be among the elite -- Chanel, Dior, Gaultier, where a basic little suit starts at $15,000.

title: KENNAMETAL AGREES TO BUY TOOL UNITS FROM MILACRON
description: Kennametal, an industrial tool maker, agreed to buy Milacron's Indian and European metal-cutting tool units for about $170 million to increase sales to European automakers. The units, Widia and Werko, have sales of about $240 million a year, Milacron said in a statement. Shares of Milacron fell 36 cents, to $12.99; Kennametal fell 69 cents, to $39.95. Kennametal, based in Latrobe, Pa., plans to sell $100 million to $150 million in stock and will issue debt and borrow to pay for the acquisition. Milacron, based in Cincinnati, will use the proceeds to pay down debt, which was $586 million at the end of March, said a spokesman, Al Beaupre. The company will post a gain of $10 million to $12 million, or 30 cents to 36 cents a share.

description: While many European telecommunications companies are floundering, the state-controlled Swisscom has managed to amass a $2 billion war chest.

title: Canadian-Led Troops Revisit Caves in Eastern Afghanistan
description: Hundreds of Canadian-led troops are searching caves in the Tora Bora region of eastern Afghanistan for the first time since the aerial bombardment of that rugged mountain redoubt ended in December, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Mirando City Journal; A Forbidding Landscape That's Eden for Peyote
description: The South Texas sun beats on the landscape here like an anvil, turkey vultures circle overhead and the scent of distant gas wells drifts across desolate plains of mesquite chaparral and cactus. This is harsh country, but also a land, some say, that offers spiritual enlightenment.

description: Don't say it's early, the caller told Larry Lucchino. That's the easy way to duck comment on a positive development, the trite view adopted by every conservative, overly cautious person associated with a team off to a good start.

title: As Expected, Fed Leaves Interest Rates Unchanged
description: The Federal Reserve's policy-makers voted today to leave short-term interest rates unchanged, and the Fed suggested it did not expect to alter that stance for some time.

description: Bush administration officials said today that the new International Criminal Court should expect no cooperation from the United States, and that its prosecutors would not be given any information from the United States to help them bring cases against any individuals.

title: First Arguments in Death Penalty Appeal Focus on Technicalities
description: For the first time in a generation, lawyers and judges argued today in New York's highest court about whether a convicted killer should be put to death.

title: Hornets Convinced They Have Upper Hand
description: The Charlotte Hornets spent their practice today defiantly spinning their 99-93 loss to the Nets in Game 1 on Sunday into a reason they could win the Eastern Conference semifinal series.

title: Schundler Urges Vote on Newark Arena
description: Bret D. Schundler, who has been virtually invisible since his overwhelming defeat when he ran for governor of New Jersey last year, stepped back into the political spotlight yesterday, calling for a referendum on any state-backed borrowing to build a proposed $355 million arena in Newark.

title: How the Towers Collapsed
description: The federal investigation into the collapse of the World Trade Center towers on Sept. 11 has been unable to pinpoint what engineering elements were critical in the disintegration of the buildings or how best to resist a recurrence. Even so, the six-month study -- conducted by the American Society of Civil Engineers and the Federal Emergency Management Agency -- has revealed some disturbing facts about modern skyscrapers that are potentially worrisome for those who work or live in high-rise buildings around the country.

title: When a Neanderthal Was Mugged
description: To the Editor:

title: At Last, Colleges Answer, And New Questions Arise
description: There was plenty to do beside wait and worry once the last test was taken, the last essay written, the last application mailed.

title: Out of the Kitchen, And Other Getaways
description: WHEN he wearies of selling his grills, where does George Foreman go to relax? Or Anthony Bourdain, when he's tired of dishing kitchens? These and a few other boldfaced names were asked, too.

title: Rumsfeld Defends Army Secretary Under a Double Cloud
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  The White House and Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld expressed support today for Army Secretary Thomas E. White, who has been under fire over Army lobbying in favor of an artillery system that top Pentagon officials want to cancel.

title: Finding Tragic Humor Eight Months Later
description: The first time I saw Reno's ''Rebel Without a Pause'' exactly five weeks had passed since Sept. 11. We were all still pretty shaky, and the idea of turning the World Trade Center disaster into humor was questionable. (Well, you could ridicule Osama bin Laden at that point, but that was all.)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: BMC Software Posts 4th-Quarter Loss
description: BMC Software Inc., whose software runs mainframe computers, said yesterday that it had a fiscal fourth-quarter loss as sales fell. The loss was $1.8 million, or 1 cent a share, in the quarter ended March 31, in contrast to net income of $23 million, or 9 cents, a year earlier, a spokeswoman, Jane McMillian, said. Sales fell 22 percent, to $331.8 million from $424.5 million, the eighth consecutive decline. BMC said first-quarter revenue will be $312 million to $320 million, beating the average forecast of $297 million in a Thomson Financial/First Call survey of analysts. BMC shares gained 32 cents, to $15 in regular trading.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Reservoirs Drop and Stocks Follow
description: The government said it might seek to buy fresh water from nearby countries as a severe drought persisted into the beginning of what is usually Taiwan's rainy season. Stocks fell 4.5 percent on fears that semiconductor factories might have to cut production to conserve water. On Friday, the government allowed a freighter full of water to sail from mainland China to the Taiwanese island of Matsu, while the city of Taipei declared that it was cutting water by 20 percent for large corporate and government users and stopping all water to car washes, swimming pools and fountains. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Phone Privatization
description: The government plans to complete the privatization of Korea Telecom, the company that operates most of South Korea's telephone service, by the end of May. The Ministry of Information and Communication said that the government would sell its 88.57 million shares of Korea Telecom, worth $4 billion, making up 28.36 percent of the company's stock, including 14.53 percent of its shares and 13.83 percent in exchangeable bonds. The government is looking for institutional investors but would make certain no single interest gained control of the company. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Editors' Note; SPECIAL TODAY
description: Vacation

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Media Talk column of Business Day yesterday about the selection of an editor at The Denver Post misstated the current job of the newspaper's former publisher, Gerald E. Grilly. He is chief operating officer of MediaNews Group, The Post's owner, not of the joint operating agency in which The Post is a partner with The Rocky Mountain News.

title: Attendance Is Off After Five Weeks
description: Major League Baseball attendance was off 5 percent in the first five weeks of this season, averaging 26,626 through Sunday's games, about 1,400 people below the level for the same period last season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLOTKIN, SAMUEL
description: PLOTKIN-Samuel. The officers, Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Samuel Plotkin, a cherished friend who expressed a commitment to helping those in need. Mr. Plotkin's legacy lives on in the exemplary activities and extraordinary generosity of the Plotkin family. We extend our deepest sympathies to Mr. Plotkin's son, Fred, and his wife, Janet; to his son, Stuart, and his wife, Anita; to his daughter, Gail Staal, and her husband, Murray; to his daughter, Talib Ilutzi, and her husband, Herb Schwartz; to his 8 grandchildren; to his two great-grandchildren; and to the entire Plotkin family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: Putting Down Their Pen, Picking Up A Good Book
description: When you write page turners for a living, what do you read on a lazy summer vacation? Here, a few best-selling authors reveal their plans. NORA KRUG

title: Attention, Holiday Shoppers: Bargains Abound
description: MEET Alison Denny of Port Charlotte, Fla., 51 years old, retired psychiatric nurse, mother of three, grandmother of seven and a typical American traveler. What makes her typical is that she goes away three or four times a year in the United States. ''The other day, my sons and I were talking about taking a trip to the Netherlands,'' she said. ''My family is originally from there. But I told them not this year. It's much safer to stay within our own borders.''

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; After his gloom went over like a lead balloon, Trump tries to sell happiness, in junk bonds.
description: SIX months after threatening to default on junk bonds issued by his three Atlantic City casinos, Donald Trump is back, marketing a new deal to investors.

title: The Charm of the Same
description: I AM 9, 15, 20, 31. I am lying on my stomach on the sun-bleached porch, shoulders already red, warm Diet Coke in a Boston Celtics tumbler by my side. I have made my initial pilgrimage to my favorite of Martha's Vineyard's five quirky libraries, and the book open in front of me is F. Scott Fitzgerald's ''This Side of Paradise'' or Louisa May Alcott's ''Eight Cousins'' or a florid 1950's romance by Rosamond du Jardin.

title: Religion and Health: New Research Revives an Old Debate
description: In the last decade, dozens of scientists have claimed they have found evidence of links between religion and health, and the idea has caught on. News articles with headlines like ''Spirituality Is Good Medicine'' and ''The Prayer Cure'' have reported the findings as if they added up to just another instance of science confirming the obvious: that spiritual faith helps people stay healthy and live longer.

title: Prosecutors Will Introduce Past 'Bad Acts' By Andersen
description: Federal prosecutors in the criminal trial of Arthur Andersen are planning to introduce evidence of the firm's involvement in other accounting scandals for the purpose of establishing its motive in the destruction of thousands of documents related to Enron, lawyers in the case said today.

title: Home Lender Offers to Settle Claims of Predatory Practices
description: A major home equity loan company that government agencies and consumer advocates once described as a symbol of predatory lending has reached a proposed $1.65 million settlement in a class-action lawsuit waged on behalf of thousands of borrowers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARMAN, MALCOLM
description: BARMAN-Malcolm. On May 3, 2002. He is survived by wife, Marion; son John; daughter Rosemary; son-in-law Steven Orbach; and granddaughther Rachel Orbach. A graduate of Columbia Grammar and the University of Pennsylvania, he was an attorney who devoted the latter part of his life to his real estate interests in NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDOW, MITCHELL
description: LANDOW-Mitchell. Of Palm Beach, FL. Beloved husband of the late Beulah Kinsman Landow. Passed away May 6, 2002. He was born in 1905. Mr. Landow, formerly of Manhattan, is survived by Mrs. Landow's family. His quiet dignity will be missed. The Bassine and Cohen Families

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: An Antibiotic Alternative
description: When a young child has an ear infection, many parents are not satisfied unless they leave the doctor's office with a prescription for antibiotics, even though the infections almost always clear up by themselves and the overuse of antibiotics poses a public health problem.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''What went through my head is, 'This is the Netherlands, the Netherlands, a nation of tolerance.' ''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEWEL, CLARA R.
description: TEWEL-Clara R., 86. Of Sunrise, FL, formerly of Flushing, NY, passed away on May 4, 2002. She is survived by devoted husband Norman; loving children Arlene Tewel, Rita Ackerman & Kenneth Tewel; son-in-law Congressman Gary Ackerman and cherished grandchildren Lauren, Corey & Ari. She will be dearly missed.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Time Limits In Abuse Cases Questioned
description: The time limit for prosecuting sex abuse of minors should be greatly extended, Nassau County's district attorney, Denis Dillon, said yesterday. State law now bars cases after the victim reaches the age of 23. Mr. Dillon urged state district attorneys to support a cutoff age of 33. After youngsters are abused ''it can take years before they are able to come forward and talk,'' he said. His recent review of church files of complaints found all the cases too old to pursue. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Danger of Missing Booster Shots
description: Millions of Americans lack immunity to tetanus and diphtheria because they fail to follow federal guidelines that call for regular booster shots against the diseases, a new study finds.

title: No Bill for a Room, But RV's Ring Up Costs of Their Own
description: FOR people with large families who do not make flight and hotel arrangements far in advance, the economics of renting a recreational vehicle can be attractive. By putting his family up in an RV to go to Florida, Scott Wright, a printer in New Jersey, said, he saved about $5,000 on air fare and thousands more on hotel rooms over his 11-day vacation. He parked his RV at a campground in Fort Wilderness in the Disney World complex for $75 a night, a fraction of the cost of a room in a Disney World hotel, but twice as much as many private RV sites.

title: Ancestral DNA
description: Q. How could I preserve my DNA for my descendants to study?

title: Rollin', Rollin', Rollin', Keep Those RV's Rollin'
description: WHEN Kevin P. Pidgeon and Tina Eftimiadis started planning a March vacation, they had Disney World on their minds. Her two teenagers, Stephanie and Peter, would be on spring break, as would his son, Noah, age 5. There was one problem: Kevin wanted to fly but Tina was afraid, a hangover from the terrorist attacks.

title: A New Reason to Eat Your Beans
description: High levels of folate, the B vitamin found in foods like citrus fruits, leafy green vegetables, beans and grain products, can lower the risk of stroke, a new study reports.

title: Hearing on Technology Reveals Other Heroes of 9/11
description: In the aftermath of Sept. 11, firefighters and police officers were lionized. Rescue workers and cleanup crews were celebrated for their endurance and bravery. Politicians like former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani became international celebrities.
