title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NARDI, SULAMITH (SCHWARTZ)
description: NARDI-Sulamith (Schwartz). Died May 3, 2002, Jerusalem. Widow of late Dr. Noah Nardi. Mother of Eran, Meira (Bossen), Tsviah and four grandchildren. Daughter of late Dr. Abraham & Fanny, sister of late Isaac and surviving brother David. Granddaughter of Zvi Hirsch Masliansky, renowned Yiddish Orator. Distinguished career advisor to five Israeli Presidents. Hebrew University scholar. Teacher more than 50 years. Appointed by Golda Meir to be first Israeli Delegate UNESCO. Advisor to late Rabbi Abba Hillel Silver in battle for establishment State of Israel. First editor Hadassah Newsletter. Gifted writer. Honored by State of Israel. Adored by entire family including devastated cousins Ed, Jim and Marshall Weinberg.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUTENSKY, IRWIN
description: BUTENSKY-Irwin. Of Teaneck, New Jersey, an avid hiker. Beloved husband of Francine (nee Will), devoted father of Melissa Butensky, cherished father-in-law of Samuel Kaplan, dear brother of Gloria Salzman, loving brother-inlaw of Manny Salzman and Joyce Himelman. Much loved uncle and grand-uncle, cousin of Allan Kroningold. Information, ''GuttermanMusicant'' 1-800-522-0588.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the college application process for three New York City high school students referred incorrectly to a comment by the counselor at the Collegiate School, Bruce Breimer. Mr. Breimer said he had discouraged a senior from making an application for early decision at Yale this year because the student's credentials were not competitive. He did not take that action to improve the prospects of another Yale applicant.

title: Beyond Birth Control: The Pill Tackles New Duties
description: Lori Rice was 10 when she started menstruating, and every month was an ordeal. ''I was having a lot of problems with my period -- cramping and heavy bleeding,'' said Lori, now 15. ''The pain was the worst. I missed a lot of school, and it got worse the longer I had my period.''

title: Justice Dept. Reverses Policy on Meaning of Second Amendment
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  The Justice Department, reversing decades of official government policy on the meaning of the Second Amendment, told the Supreme Court for the first time late Monday that the Constitution "broadly protects the rights of individuals" to own firearms.

title: A Princeton Senior Is Setting the Bar Higher
description: Tora Harris stood alone in the shadows at the edge of Princeton's Jadwin Gym, silently lifting weights. He did not change his self-constructed training schedule after a milestone victory at the Penn Relays last month. Instead, while the rest of the track and field team practiced outside with their coach under a bright sun, laughing and joking, Harris worked by himself. He prefers it that way.

title: Fetisov's Task: Reviving Russian Sports
description: Thirteen years after abandoning the Soviet Army hockey team for the National Hockey League, Vyacheslav Fetisov has come home to Russia.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Synagogue Attacked
description: Vandals damaged a synagogue in the southern city of Rostov-on-Don on Sunday evening, according to the Ria-Novosti news service. A guard put out a fire that was set but later in the evening the synagogue's windows were smashed. The incident was one in a series of recent anti-Semitic attacks in Europe. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: In Boston
description: With all the scaffolding clamped to its downtown, Boston is a city obscured. The State House is shrouded in construction sheets and the Big Dig, the grand tunnel project that has been going on since roughly the Pleistocene era, has every other street cordoned off with concrete hedgerows. What is a pity for tourists becomes a serious pain for business travelers.

title: Vanney Enjoys View From Posting in Corsica
description: Since moving to Corsica to play for Bastia in the French First Division, GREG VANNEY has discovered life on a charming and fabled island.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Drug Deaths Decline
description: The introduction of state-run rooms where addicts can use drugs helped cut the number of drug-related deaths in 2001 by 9.6 percent from the previous year, a Health Ministry report said. The decline, to 1,835 deaths, was the first in four years. There are about 20 drug consumption rooms in Germany, run by state authorities. In March, seven cities began ''heroin-supported therapy'' in which addicts get heroin under medical supervision. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Editors' Note; Editors' Note
description: An article yesterday about a parade in Manhattan marking Israel's 54th anniversary reported that 100,000 people had registered to march and hundreds of thousands more lined Fifth Avenue in support. The article also said that anti-Israel protesters numbered in the hundreds.

title: Splits Over Palestinian Statehood and Arafat Role Are Unresolved
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 - President Bush and Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel remained divided today about how quickly to move toward the creation of a Palestinian state and whether to deal with Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader. Mr. Sharon's visit was abruptly broken off by news of a suicide bombing in Israel, which interrupted their Oval Office meeting and jeopardized the administration's hopes of rapidly restarting a political dialogue.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Bill Addresses Domain-Name Data
description: Two members of Congress introduced a bill late last week that would make it a crime to provide false contact information when registering an Internet domain name. The bill was introduced by Representative Howard Coble, a North Carolina Republican, and Representative Howard Berman, a California Democrat, in response to concerns that false information about domain name registrants would hamper criminal investigations. The bill would modify the criminal code so that ''whoever knowingly and with intent to defraud provides material and misleading false contact information to a domain name registrar'' would be subject to fines and possibly imprisonment. Susan Stellin (NYT)

description: Hope Clark

title: Nets' Bravado Intact Despite Sloppy Game 1
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 6  Nets Coach Byron Scott learned the tenets of playoff basketball from Coach Pat Riley with the Lakers, and today, Scott embellished them with his own bravado.

title: Investigators at Odds Over Extent of F.B.I. Spy's Cooperation
description: A feud has erupted among federal counter-intelligence officials over whether the former F.B.I. agent Robert P. Hanssen has told the government the whole truth about his life as a spy for Moscow.

description: The sale of Michael Ovitz's ailing Artists Management Group to a lesser-known company called the Firm comes at a time of turmoil and uncertainty among managers and agents that has not been seen since Hollywood was making movies like ''The Wizard of Oz'' and ''Gone With the Wind.''

title: Christie Whitman Holds Her Ground
description: One big exception to the Bush administration's pro-industry attitude on environmental matters has been Christie Whitman's support of tough new restrictions on diesel-powered buses and trucks imposed by her predecessor at the Environmental Protection Agency, Carol Browner. Last week Mrs. Whitman's persistence paid off when a three-judge panel of the federal appeals court in Washington upheld the rules despite industry arguments that it did not have the technology to produce the cleaner fuels and engines the standards will require.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the Russian conductor Yevgeny Svetlanov in late editions on Sunday misspelled the surname of a pianist critical of his work. (It was correct in a reprinted version yesterday.) He is Alexander Toradze, not Torade.

title: Clinton Sees a Role for G.I.'s
description: Former President Bill Clinton said yesterday that a global force including Americans would be necessary to bring peace to the Middle East, and that he would support President Bush in efforts to create such a force.

title: Bannu Journal; Where Al Qaeda's the Quarry, G.I.'s Are Elusive
description: This region is full of invisible Americans.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the Columbia University historian and author Eric L. McKitrick yesterday misstated the title of one of his books. It was ''Andrew Johnson and Reconstruction,'' not ''Andrew Jackson.''

title: Marijuana and Criminality
description: To the Editor:

title: Letting Optimism Ring Out of Chaos at a Time of Need
description: Just when New York could use it, Haydn's ''Creation'' arrived on Sunday afternoon, reassuring us that chaos is banished, God is ascendant, and the world is in C major. This oratorio, a great hymn to the Enlightenment, took Europe by storm at the end of the 18th century; if its shining optimism has had more trouble penetrating the despondency of our own times, it seemed to reach a sold-out audience at Carnegie Hall.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BUKETOFF, IGOR
description: BUKETOFF-Igor. A memorial service for conductor, orchestrator and educator, Igor Buketoff, will take place Thursday, May 9th at 10:00 A.M. at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 921 Madison Ave. at 73rd St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. James' Church, 865 Madison Ave., New York, NY 10021, or to Bargemusic, Fulton Ferry Landing, Brooklyn, New York 11201.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, ANGELA FRANCES ALLEN
description: KRAMER-Angela Frances Allen. May 2, 2002. After a long illness. Daughter of Terry Allen Kramer and the late Irwin H. Kramer. Sister of Toni Allen Goutal and Nathaniel Charles Allen Kramer. Also survived by seven nieces and nephews. Memorial service Wednesday, May 8, 6 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Sather Interviews Brooks
description: Glen Sather, the Rangers' president and general manager, interviewed Herb Brooks yesterday for the head coaching job.

title: Church Woes Are Invading TV Pilots; Story Lines Mirror Public Disenchantment With Catholic Hierarchy
description: ''The Calling,'' a prospective ABC television drama, has a pious plot about a seminarian engaged in a personal search for God. But the script has a twist that is likely to be troubling to Roman Catholic bishops: the church is extraneous and even a hurdle in the spiritual quest.

title: Cadillac On Marquee At Winter Garden
description: In the latest indication of a growing corporate presence on Broadway, the Shubert Organization announced yesterday that it had struck a deal with General Motors to rename its historic Winter Garden Theater the Cadillac Winter Garden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAVENICK, ARNOLD JOSEPH
description: HAVENICK-Arnold Joseph. Of Palm Beach, FL, died on May 6, 2002. He was born in New York on April 26, 1916. Devoted husband of Tillie; father of Nancy (Stephen) Fiverson and Fred (Barbara) Havenick of Coral Gables, FL; devoted grandfather of Izzy Havenick, Jenny Havenick, Alex Havenick, Michael Havenick of Coral Gables, FL, Peter Fiverson of New York and Lori (Marc) Cooperman of Livingston, NJ. Funeral service will be held at Temple Israel in West Palm Beach, 1901 North Flagler Drive at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Israel Emergency Fund.

title: Check Out The Tour's Reputation
description: AN increasing number of Americans research their travel plans online. According to Forrester Research, 23.4 million households investigate and book their reservations on the Internet. In the first quarter of this year, consumers spent $7 billion on online travel purchases, accounting for 41 percent of all e-commerce in the United States, said Dan Hess, a vice president of ComScore Networks, a data analysis company. But while everyone is feeling more confident that Web transactions are safe, the possibility of fraud still exists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOUKAD, JOSEPH E.
description: MOUKAD-Joseph E., 91. On May 3rd, 2002. Beloved husband of Anne Connorton Moukad. Devoted father of Rosemary, John (Lori) and the late Joseph D. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday, May 6th, 6-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Church of the Epiphany, Second Avenue at 22nd Street, Tuesday, 11 AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to St. Vincent's Hospital, 170 West 12th Street, New York, New York 10011.

title: Finding the What, When, Where and Why of the Supertwister
description: At dusk on April 28, this town 30 miles south of Washington became No. 94 on the list of unlucky places struck since 1880 by F-5 tornados, the rare class of supertwisters that produces almost unimaginable destruction.

title: A Chief Economist Is Named at S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission named a University of Southern California professor, Lawrence E. Harris, as its chief economist and head of its office of economic analysis.

title: CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER PLANS TO LEAVE MICHAELS STORES
description: Michaels Stores said yesterday that its chief financial officer, Bryan M. DeCordova, would leave the company in the fall. The company, an arts-and-crafts retailer based in Irving, Tex., said it was starting a nationwide search for a new chief financial officer and expected to complete the search before Mr. DeCordova's departure. Michaels Stores owns and operates 713 Michaels stores in 48 states and Canada, 142 Aaron Brothers stores on the West Coast, and one wholesale operation in Dallas.

title: Camera Is Left Behind to Zoom In on North Pole's Weather
description: After melting holes through the floating ice at the North Pole last month to retrieve an array of instruments tethered to the sea bottom a year ago, a team of scientists left an observer behind.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the Russian conductor Yevgeny Svetlanov in late editions on Sunday misspelled the surname of a pianist critical of his work. (It was correct in a reprinted version yesterday.) He is Alexander Toradze, not Torade.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the search in Cambodia for a mysterious horned creature known as khting vor misspelled the name of King Arthur's sword, to which a wildlife researcher referred in apologizing for his rashness in saying that the animal indeed existed. He said that just one set of real horns among dozens of reported fakes would be his vindication -- ''my sword Excalibur'' (not Excaliber).

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Fiat Sales Decline
description: Fiat's Italian auto sales fell 21.7 percent in April compared with a year ago, in the fourth consecutive month of declining sales for the company, the Transport Ministry said. The loss was attributed partly to declining overall car sales in Italy; car registrations there shrunk from 87,333 in April 2001 to 61,340. Fiat recently introduced a midsize car, the Stilo, which has performed below expectations. Fiat had a 2001 loss of 445 million euros ($408 million), its first in eight years, as Fiat Auto lost market share to rivals. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: East Meadow: Advice On Health Care In Jail
description: Federal experts will advise Nassau County on health care for the inmates at its jail here, Senator Charles Schumer said yesterday. A recent audit found Nassau spending $10,207 a year per inmate, or triple the amount spent in adjacent Suffolk. Nassau is under a court order to improve care, to settle a federal suit filed after an inmate suffered a beating and died. The county was planning to hire a health consultant for up to $250,000 when Mr. Schumer wrote to the United States Bureau of Prisons for free advice. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Daly Has Reaction To Pills, Wife Says
description: John Daly had an allergic reaction, including numbness in one arm, after taking diet pills, but did not suffer any lasting effects, his wife said yesterday.

title: New Parks Lose Magic Quickly
description: While major league baseball teams continue to build new ballparks, or hunger for them, attendance at the most recent generation of parks shows a potentially disturbing trend: if you build it, they will come, but only for a while.

title: Afghan Grave Site Yields Bodies Believed Linked to Bin Laden
description: BAGRAM AIR BASE, Afghanistan, May 7  Canadian troops and American criminal investigators have exhumed 23 bodies from a grave site in the Tora Bora mountains that they suspect was used to bury Al Qaeda fighters, perhaps including some who provided security for Osama bin Laden.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: 'I Can Sing Anything . . .'

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: State Passes Bill To Help Gay Partners
description: Seeking to help the families of victims of the Sept. 11 attack, the Legislature gave final approval yesterday to a bill that encourages federal officials to give benefits to same-sex partners of the dead, but stops short of according them the same rights as widows and widowers. Gov. George E. Pataki introduced the bills and has said he will sign them. In September, the governor issued an executive order directing the state crime victim board to give awards to domestic partners. Ken Feinberg, the special master who oversees the distribution of the Federal Sept. 11 Victim Compensation Fund, has said he will follow state laws in deciding who gets benefits. Mr. Feinberg cautioned, however, that he might still be bound by marriage and probate laws, which do not cover same-sex partners. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

description: An article yesterday about a parade in Manhattan marking Israel's 54th anniversary reported that 100,000 people had registered to march and hundreds of thousands more lined Fifth Avenue in support. The article also said that anti-Israel protesters numbered in the hundreds.

description: EDELMAN-Sidney. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia. Loving father of Barbara and Susan. Adored grandfather of Russell and Douglas. Sid was truly one of a kind. He touched our lives deeply and always knew how to make us laugh and smile. He will be in our hearts forever. Donations in his name may be made to The American Diabetes Association Memorial and Honor Program, POB 2680, North Canton, OH 44720.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOGGARD, BISHOP J. CLINTON
description: HOGGARD-Bishop J. Clinton. On Sunday, May 5, 2002. Beloved father of Jay Clinton Hoggard and Dr. Paul Hoggard. Grandfather of Jamal and Kalila Hoggard. He is also survived by a brother Francis Hoggard, two daughters-in-law, other relatives and friends. From 9-11 A.M., Thursday, May 9, friends may call at Trinity A.M.E. Zion Church, 3505 16th St NW, Washington, D.C., where funeral services will begin at 11 A.M. Interment Cherry-Hoggard Family Cemetery, Ahoskie, N.C. For more info, McGuire F.H., 202-882-6600.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Teachers Union Plans Strike Vote
description: As the union representing New York City teachers moved ahead yesterday with plans for a strike authorization vote, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said the strike threat was not affecting the pace of contract negotiations, and he predicted that the two sides could reach agreement. Randi Weingarten, the teachers' union president, decided to seek authorization for a strike last week, after negotiators for the city said they were too busy to deal immediately with round-the-clock contract talks. If the union's delegate assembly votes today to authorize a strike, ballots will be sent to the 100,000 members, a process that will take several weeks. Such a vote would allow the union leadership to call a strike anytime between June and September. City teachers last struck in 1975. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Mid-Atlantic
description: WEST VIRGINIA: FLOOD DAMAGE CLOSES SCHOOLS Schools in McDowell County may not reopen this year because of damage from last week's floods, officials said. Floods and mudslides caused by torrential rain were blamed for six deaths, and six people are missing. In addition to more than 500 homes and businesses damaged or destroyed in West Virginia, an elementary school in McDowell County was destroyed and 11 were damaged. (AP)

As the article said, a lawyer for The Morning News wrote letters to the site's operator. The paper has not sued.

title: Europeans Cheer Defeat Of Le Pen, but Worries Cling
description: Such are Europe's rivalries that the tribulations of one land often stir the schadenfreude of others. But today, the relief among the continent's leaders at President Jacques Chirac's resounding victory over the far-rightist Jean-Marie Le Pen seemed unanimous.

title: National Briefing: New England
description: MASSACHUSETTS: JURY SET FOR F.B.I. AGENT'S CORRUPTION TRIAL A jury was seated in the trial of a former F.B.I. agent accused of protecting his mob informers from prosecution. The agent, John J. Connolly, left, now retired, is charged with racketeering, obstruction of justice and conspiracy. He is accused of providing the mobsters, James J. Bulger and Stephen Flemmi, with confidential law enforcement information. Over two decades, the two provided Mr. Connolly and the F.B.I. with information that helped dismantle the Mafia in New England, court papers say. Along the way, prosecutors say, Mr. Connolly and his supervisor, John Morris, essentially gave them a free pass to commit crimes short of murder. Mr. Bulger is on the F.B.I.'s Most Wanted list, facing murder charges. Mr. Flemmi is in custody, awaiting trial in 10 killings. (AP)

title: U.S. Provides List for Passengers
description: At last, a list. The Transportation Security Administration updated its list of things that passengers may and may not bring on board a plane. You may carry on: walking canes and umbrellas, nail clippers and nail files (which previously were being confiscated), tweezers, safety razors and disposable razors, syringes with proper medical labeling, and eyelash curlers. The list of forbidden items is long, from ammunition to toy weapons. It includes real weapons, knives of all sorts, most hand tools, sports bats, golf clubs and -- just in case there was any doubt -- hand grenades, dynamite and rifles.

title: Indonesia: Old Temples, Few Tourists
description: BEFORE Sept. 11, Indonesia, the most populous Muslim country in the world, was barely on the horizon as a tourist destination for Americans. Distance, coupled with arduous airline connections and a general lack of knowledge, meant that the most frequent visitors were aficionados of wildlife in Kalimantan, the beaches of Bali and the grand temples of Java. Now, even these hardy travelers have disappeared. There has not been such a downturn since Indonesia developed a tourism industry in the 1980's, according to hoteliers and travel agents.

title: German union strikes at heart of auto industry
description: FRANKFURT:  Germany's biggest industrial union began its first strike in seven years Monday as 50,000 workers walked off the job, igniting fears that a series of widening one-day stoppages aimed at winning a substantial pay increase would derail the recovery of Europe's largest economy.

title: Two Executives Change Jobs in New York
description: Two well-known executives are being named to new posts.

description: It is the feeling that makes every driver's heart sink into his emergency brake: the lopsided confirmation that a tire has just gone flat.

title: Spider-Man's Summer Comes Early
description: In the new movie ''Spider-Man,'' the Green Goblin isn't onscreen for more than a few seconds before you notice that his mask doesn't move when he talks. It's a stiff rictus of hatred, and pointy-headed at that. Then you notice that Spider-Man's face doesn't move when he talks either. And though the aeronautical battles between Spider-Man, played by Tobey Maguire, and the Green Goblin, played by Willem Dafoe, have a certain kinetic attraction, it's clear that in this superhero movie, all the real action will take place when Spider-Man slips off his mask and returns to being Peter Parker, the conflicted everyman in love with the girl next door, played by Kirsten Dunst. This is a formula that's worked since Spider-Man was first created by Stan Lee and Steve Ditko for Marvel Comics 40 years ago, and it obviously worked last weekend, when ''Spider-Man,'' with $115 million, beat out Harry Potter, with $90 million, for the biggest opening weekend ever.

Scientist, biophysicist, executive & educator, Emeritus Professor of Physics at New York University, Senior Vice-President and Chief Scientific Officer of Technicon Corporation, Past President of the National Science Teachers Association and the New York Academy of Sciences. Some said it wouldn't last, but his devotion to his beloved wife Marion spanned 59 years until they were parted only by the untimely intrusion of death on May 6, 2002. Loving father of Michael, father-in-law of Julie, grandfather of Josselyn & Alexander. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, at 11:15AM Wednesday. Visitors will be received at home, 3515 Henry Hudson Parkway, Apt. 11A, Bronx, N.Y. 10463 from 4:00-8:00 P.M., Wednesday, May 8th. On the left, civil libertarians are cheering proposals to give convicts greater access to DNA testing to prove their innocence. On the right, prosecutors and police seek broader authority to take biological samples from individual suspects for DNA analysis.

description: Electricity traders at Enron drove up prices during the California power crisis through questionable techniques that company lawyers said ''may have contributed'' to severe power shortages, according to internal Enron documents released today by federal regulators.

title: National Briefing: Rockies
description: OHIO: CONVICTED CONGRESSMAN SEEKS 10TH TERM Representative James A. Traficant Jr., who was convicted of racketeering and bribery last month, officially entered the race for re-election as an independent. Mr. Traficant was found guilty of taking payoffs and kickbacks from businessmen and his own staff members. He could receive up to 63 years in prison at his June 27 sentencing and could also be expelled from Congress by his colleagues. The conviction does not prevent Mr. Traficant, a nine-term Democrat, from running again for Congress. (AP)

title: Godot Can Wait: Bits of Beckett, Puzzling as Ever
description: Bob Jaffe, an actor who qualifies as chairman of the Samuel Beckett Enthusiasts, is presiding over the organization's convention at the moment. Such, at any rate, is the effect of '' . . . And Then You Go On,'' Mr. Jaffe's one-man show at Here in SoHo. A monologue knitted together from excerpts from 13 of Beckett's puzzlingly self-scrutinizing works, the show is a lionizing tribute to this great Irish writer, and it is inarguably a deserving one. And like a testimonial, the show will hold meaning for the reverent and amusement for the expert. Other theatergoers, however, are less likely to be fulfilled.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: TEACHERS UNION PLANS STRIKE VOTE As the union representing New York City teachers moved ahead yesterday with plans for a strike authorization vote, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said the strike threat was not affecting the pace of contract negotiations, and he predicted that the two sides could reach agreement. Randi Weingarten, the teachers' union president, decided to seek authorization for a strike last week, after negotiators for the city said they were too busy to deal immediately with round-the-clock contract talks. If the union's delegate assembly votes today to authorize a strike, ballots will be sent to the 100,000 members, a process that will take several weeks. Such a vote would allow the union leadership to call a strike anytime between June and September. City teachers last struck in 1975. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: APPLE INTRODUCES NEW SERVICE Apple Computer yesterday gave a brief demonstration of iChat, an instant messenger program that is intended to be compatible with America Online's AOL Instant Messenger Service. Apple demonstrated its new instant messenger client at the first day of the company's annual World Wide Developer Conference that began yesterday in San Jose, Calif. Officials of AOL, a unit of AOL Time Warner , said that this was the first time they had permitted another company to independently build an Instant Messenger client that was compatible with the AOL service that reaches 150 million users. The Apple program is planned for a late summer release as part of a new version of the company's Mac OS X operating system that was also demonstrated yesterday. John Markoff (NYT)

title: Summer Rates in Anguilla
description: Anumber of resorts on the Caribbean island of Anguilla are offering summer packages. The Rendezvous Bay Hotel, for example, has rates of $90 to $175 a night per room, good through Dec. 14. Tax and service charge are extra. Through Dec. 15, the Allamanda Beach Club on Shoal Bay has rates of $87 to $165 a night with tax and service charge; guests who stay seven nights pay for six. All rooms have kitchens. Parsons, who will become AOL Time Warner's chief executive later this month, said today that the company still faced significant problems and still had to answer questions about its strategic direction. description: Nets Coach Byron Scott learned the tenets of playoff basketball from Coach Pat Riley with the Lakers, and today, Scott embellished them with his own bravado.

description: One of the significant subplots in the current Israeli-Palestinian confrontation is that while Prime Minister Ariel Sharon loudly denounces Yasir Arafat for seeking to draw the international community into the conflict, Israel's actions push inexorably toward that result. Secretary of State Colin Powell's announcement that an international conference will be held this summer is but the latest indication.

title: An Impressionist Gets Her Due, Belatedly, in France

But one artist, Berthe Morisot, was somehow overlooked. Was it because she was a woman? Was it because she was better known as a favorite model of Manet? Or was she really a minor artist? Whatever the reason, even the centenary of Morisot's death was ignored here in 1995.

title: Ending Repression in Myanmar

Now the world's most prominent political prisoner is free. How free is an open question, however. No one should confuse her liberty with real democratization until she and the rest of Myanmar's political opponents can carry out a full range of political activities.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: No New Car Plant
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation dismissed reports that it was near a decision to build a second plant in Mexico. Construction of a Toyota assembly plant in Tijuana to supply the North American market is set to begin next month. But Barbara McDaniel, a Toyota spokeswoman, said government officials were prematurely predicting an expansion by the company to produce positive headlines at a time when many foreign-owned factories in Mexico have closed and moved elsewhere in search of cheaper labor. Mexico has lost nearly 500,000 manufacturing jobs in the last year. Graham Gori (NYT)

title: Trimmed, Marinated and Ready for the Wok
description: Many Chinese dishes cook in minutes, but the trimming, chopping, seasoning and marinating you have to do beforehand can take considerable time. For those seeking shortcuts, Deluxe Food Market, 79 Elizabeth Street (Hester Street), sells seasoned and marinated meat, poultry and seafood, right, that is ready for the steamer or wok. It's the newest and largest of a chain of Chinatown markets. Marinated rib-eye, spareribs with black beans, chicken with mushrooms, ground pork with preserved vegetables, sole with garlic and ginger, sea bass with black beans and marinated frogs' legs are just a few of the dozens of choices. Most are $2.29 to $5.99 a pound, and yield extremely tasty results. Pigs' ears and tripe, which are complicated to clean and trim, are also available, seasoned and ready to cook. The store also sells fresh, unmarinated but well-trimmed meat, some vegetables and condiments, and prepared dishes like roast chickens ($6 each), pork buns and dumplings, and offers hot prepared dishes at $2.75 a portion. There is also a bakery and sushi counter. Everything is clearly labeled in English as well as in Chinese.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: MALAYSIA: A MUSLIM LEADER CRITICIZES MUSLIMS Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said Muslims had only themselves to blame for the poverty, misery and violence afflicting much of the Islamic world. Speaking to religious affairs ministers from the Organization of the Islamic Conference, a group of 57 countries, he said Muslims spent too much time fighting among themselves and were neglecting the pursuit of knowledge and the creation of wealth. "We Muslims and our countries are not very Islamic," he said. "We cannot even regard each other as brothers. To be very crude, the fate of the Muslims of today is of their own making."

title: E.P.A. to Lead Cleanup Effort Of Homes Close to Ground Zero
description: The federal Environmental Protection Agency will lead an effort to clean up and test apartments south of Canal Street in Lower Manhattan that were fouled by the dust and ash from the destruction of the World Trade Center, a person who was briefed on the plan said.

title: Hearing on Merrill Is Delayed a Week
description: Officials of Merrill Lynch visited the office of Eliot L. Spitzer, New York's attorney general, yesterday to discuss a resolution to his investigation of the firm's stock analysts, but they retreated to the drawing board.

title: Clinton to Represent Bush at Timor Event
description: President Bush has chosen former President Bill Clinton to lead a United States delegation to East Timor's independence celebrations later this month, a senior administration official said today.

title: New York Contemplates Shielding Data It Collects
description: The Pataki administration has proposed legislation that would severely restrict public access to any information the state collects in its efforts to thwart terrorists.

title: A Costly Rebirth for a Big Old Resort
description: A sprawling mountain resort that was built here in the late 1920's and had been closed since 1986 will open its doors to guests again on May 22 after a four-year restoration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAVENICK, ARNOLD

Cherished son-in-law, brother-in-law, nephew, cousin and friend. We mourn the passing of this man of kindness, intellect, depth, integrity and wit. Contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society or Beth Israel Synagogue of Norwalk, Services Wednesday 1PM Beth Israel Synagogue, 40 King St, Norwalk, Ct.

title: As a Hurdle Is Cleared, Building Begins At Ground Zero
description: In the most visible sign yet that the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan has begun, workers yesterday began the first step in erecting a new skyscraper on the site where 7 World Trade Center once stood.

title: Vote Totals Are In, And Scott Is Put Out
description: The Nets' Byron Scott said Monday that he deserved to win the coach of the year award. Yesterday he called Tim Duncan's winning the Most Valuable Player award over his captain, Jason Kidd, a disgrace. He also had time to tweak the Charlotte Hornets by insisting the Nets would have ''total control of the series'' if they won Game 2.

description: ZINOVOY-Gary. Of Closter, NJ. Beloved husband of Marilyn (nee Kestenbaum), cherished son of Bella and the late Sidney, devoted father of Sandy and Scott, dear brother of Murray Zinovoy and Jean Jones. Services Wednesday, 12:30 PM, at ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 402 Park St., Hackensack.

title: Haitian Capitalism and a Hunt for Diamonds in the Sea
description: Raoul Peck's 52-minute political documentary ''Profit and Nothing But!'' is a disappointingly flat, hectoring film from the gifted Haitian filmmaker who most recently brought us ''Lumumba.''

title: Rolling Stones Gather for a Tour, Floating on a Blimp in the Bronx
description: How did the Rolling Stones cross the park? The same way they plan to tour the world: slowly and with lots of pomp. At Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, the Rolling Stones announced their next tour yesterday afternoon; it is to take this 40-year-old group to four continents over the next year. The itinerary includes performances at stadiums, arenas and nightclubs.

description: I was feeling pretty happy, in a guilty-pleasure sort of way. It was a banner week for schadenfreude.

title: Where Schnitzel Meets Ahi Tuna for a Beer
description: A CENTURY ago, almost every American city had one German restaurant, where men with handlebar mustaches drank beer from large steins at a long bar and families gathered for schnitzel, sausages with sauerkraut and apple strudel drenched in whipped cream. Sawdust on the floor was a trademark.

title: Syosset School Arts Program Is Honored
description: Syosset Central School District on Long Island won three awards last month for its arts education program: the Kennedy Center Alliance for Arts Education Network Award, the National School Boards Award and the New York State Alliance Award. The district offers a wide assortment of arts courses, some in conjunction with the New York City area's cultural institutions. Stephanie Rosenbloom

title: U.S., in a Shift, Tells Justices Citizens Have a Right to Guns
description: Reversing decades of official government policy on the meaning of the Second Amendment, the Justice Department told the Supreme Court for the first time late Monday that the Constitution ''broadly protects the rights of individuals'' to own firearms.

title: Resort Rates Drop in Aruba
description: As summer approaches, Caribbean resorts drop their prices. La Cabana All-Suite Beach Resort on Aruba, for example, drops prices by almost $100 a night in some room categories. Rates start at $132 a night, for one or two people, and go up to $205. If guests prefer an all-inclusive rate (with all meals, drinks, water sports), that starts at $490 a person, based on double occupancy, for three nights. Prices are valid through Dec. 20. Information: (800) 835-7193 or www.lacabana.com/resort .

description: A day after a suspect in 16 sexual attacks in the city fled from a police interrogation room in the Bronx, the police yesterday identified him as Jose Santiago and asked for the public's help in recapturing him.

title: CREDIT SUISSE NAMES NEW CO-HEAD OF GLOBAL MERGERS
description: Credit Suisse First Boston named George Boutros co-head of its global mergers and acquisition group, expanding the role of one of its top technology bankers. Mr. Boutros, 41, will run the firm's mergers and acquisitions group with Don Meltzer, according to an internal memo sent to all employees yesterday by Adebayo Ogunlesi, head of investment banking; Mr. Meltzer; and Frank Quattrone, head of the firm's technology group. Credit Suisse is giving Mr. Boutros greater responsibility as it seeks to broaden its investment banking business on the West Coast at a time when technology mergers are in the doldrums. Since joining Credit Suisse four years ago, Mr. Boutros has helped capture some of the firm's most lucrative technology transactions.

title: Allies Exhume 23 Bodies Thought to Be Qaeda Fighters
description: Canadian troops and American criminal investigators have exhumed 23 bodies from a grave site in the Tora Bora mountains that they suspect are the remains of Al Qaeda fighters, perhaps a security contingent for Osama bin Laden.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: ARIZONA: PROVIDING CARE DESPITE PROTESTS Doctors in Phoenix have begun caring for a boy recovering from brain surgery despite protests from his parents. After a brain tumor was removed from the boy, Samuel Schaffer, 9, last month, doctors wanted to follow up with chemotherapy and radiation treatments. His parents, Stephen and Wendela Schaffer, refused, citing religious beliefs though they do not attend a church or belong to a denomination. The case was referred to child welfare workers, who placed Samuel under the supervision of doctors. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

description: Senators heaped scorn today on some of the directors who presided over Enron's rise and fall, grilling them on their failure to recognize the severe accounting problems that ultimately led to the company's collapse.

description: The jurors hearing a major lawsuit against the DuPont Company over pollution from its former explosives plant here visited the 600-acre site today for a firsthand look.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Rival's Gain Hurts Broadcom
description: The shares of Broadcom, the world's largest maker of cable-modem chips, fell $5.22, or 17 percent, to $24.72, after its top customer, Motorola, said it would also buy semiconductors from Texas Instruments, which said yesterday that it would provide chips and software for Motorola's high-speed Internet cable modems. Texas Instruments, which makes chips for about two-thirds of the world's cellphones, is trying to build sales to makers of cable modems and phone network gear.

title: Investors' Fears Drag S.&P. to Lowest Level in 7 Months
description: The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell to its lowest level in seven months yesterday, reflecting investor concern that an economic rebound would fail to revive profits as much as expected.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: MICHIGAN: A PUSH FOR MORE WORKERS A group of seasonal Michigan businesses that rely on foreign workers for summer staff is suing the Immigration and Naturalization Service over delays in processing temporary work visas since the Sept. 11 attacks. The 13 companies filing suit are on the shores of the Great Lakes and include hotels and restaurants.

title: Day in Town Takes an Unexpected Tryst
description: Sex is such a profoundly disruptive force in Adrian Lyne's film ''Unfaithful'' that as you watch it with your heart in your throat, you realize the degree to which Hollywood has succeeded in reducing screen sex to a fashion accessory. Its purpose in most movies nowadays is to embellish a story with enough (but not too many) discrete fillips of titillation and soft-core fantasy to quicken the pulse without causing palpitations.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Canadian Bank Unit On Block
description: The Bank of Nova Scotia said it was considering selling its Argentine subsidiary, Scotiabank Quilmes, and had hired a Buenos Aires-based investment bank to advise it. The Canadian bank, which has written off $451 million of losses in Argentina, said last month that it would not put any new capital into Quilmes. If the unit is sold, Bank of Nova Scotia would be the first foreign bank to pull out of the country since the current banking crisis began late last year. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: New Chip Plant
description: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, which makes computer chips to order, plans a new semiconductor plant in China to serve the growing mainland market. The company's chairman, Morris Chang, told shareholders that he was scouting for a site. Pressure from executives has led Taiwan's government to ease restrictions on mainland investments. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: The Forensic Challenge of a Lifetime, Regrettably
description: DR. ROBERT SHALER, the director of forensic biology in the New York City medical examiner's office, sounds much as he did in the chaotic weeks shortly after Sept. 11. There's a brusqueness to his voice on the telephone, yet he is exceedingly polite as he efficiently dispenses with your call.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Federal Aid For Radio And TV Stations
description: Gov. George E. Pataki announced yesterday that $3.27 million in federal grants have been awarded to help reimburse New York public television and radio stations for the costs of replacing transmission systems, including antennas, transmitters and other equipment destroyed in the World Trade Center attack. The money for the radio stations, WNYC-FM (93.9) and WKCR-FM (89.9), and one television station, WNET-TV (Channel 13), will come from disaster aid the Bush administration has promised New York. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: New York Dominates Beard Awards
description: NEW YORK chefs, restaurants and wine professionals nearly swept the major categories in this year's James Beard Foundation awards. The awards, which were presented on Monday night at the Marriott Marquis, are in honor of Mr. Beard, the culinarian, who died in 1985.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Trumping The Governor
description: The state's highest court ruled that Acting Gov. Jane M. Swift lacked the power to fire two members of the Massachusetts Turnpike Authority in February. Ms. Swift fired the members after they voted to delay by six months a scheduled toll increase on the turnpike. At the time, the governor said that the board members were fiscally irresponsible. The Supreme Judicial Court said that the dispute appeared to involve a difference of opinion, which was not sufficient reason to remove members of an independent state authority. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: Mets Double Play Combo Struggling
description: Roberto Alomar finally stepped out of the starting lineup Sunday, felled by a chronic back condition that flared up over the weekend. "I thought I had the day off," Alomar said smiling to a group of approaching reporters. Then shortstop Rey Ordonez began teasing him, asking Alomar about his return to second base, where Alomar started the Mets' first 30 games. Alomar shot back, referring to Ordóñez's recent injuries, "He shouldn't ask me. He should know."

title: Head of Private College Group Will Leave
description: JAMES C. ROSS, president of the Commission on Independent Colleges and Universities, which represents more than 100 private colleges and universities with more than 400,000 students in New York State, has announced he will step down. In his eight-year tenure, he has pressed for increases in the Tuition Assistance Program and for state support for private colleges. Karen W. Arenson

title: GEORGIA-PACIFIC TO SELL SHARES IN PAPER UNITS
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation, based in Atlanta, plans to sell stock in the units that make Dixie cups, shipping boxes and pulp and paper as part of a move away from its building products business, which has been plagued by asbestos liability. An initial offering has been set for the third quarter, the company said. Georgia-Pacific's stock has lagged competitors because of concerns about thousands of lawsuits related to asbestos used by the company more than 20 years ago. The tissue, box and pulp and paper units together are more profitable than the building products businesses. The tissue and box businesses had sales last year of $9.75 billion, about 40 percent of Georgia-Pacific's $25 billion in total sales.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Another Graduation Requirement
description: Students at eight high schools in the San Fernando Valley are angry at a new rule preventing them from attending graduation unless they promise to go to college, trade school or into the military. Officials in the district, part of the Los Angeles school system, say they want to increase expectations for the area's 3,700 seniors, who tend to come from low-income families. About 95 percent of students have complied, though some say they have simply gotten letters from community colleges so they can take part in ceremonies. Kate Zernike (NYT)

title: Jobs for Prospective Teachers
description: Starting this fall, the After-School Corporation will offer part-time jobs to scholarship students from the City University of New York with the goal of inspiring them to become teachers. The corporation hopes to hire up to 300 students receiving federal work-study grants, to work up to 15 hours a week at its after-school programs in 157 city schools. The yearlong jobs will pay up to $12 an hour, financed by the federal government and the corporation. Abby Goodnough

title: Student, 21, Is Arrested in Nevada in 5-State Bombing Spree
description: The authorities arrested a 21-year-old college student today on a highway 40 miles east of Reno, Nev., in connection with a rash of 18 pipe bombs planted in rural mailboxes in five states in recent days.

title: Golf and Guitar; No Signs of Anger
description: People in this rural farming town 60 miles south of Minneapolis who knew Luke Helder, and there are not that many, said today that they could not believe he could be responsible for the trail of bombed mailboxes across the belly of the country.

title: A consultant issues a report that looks at how public service ads could be greatly improved.
description: MAYBE it was more than a coincidence that public service advertising was the one category in which the American Association of Advertising Agencies did not present an O'Toole Award for creativity at its annual conference last month.

title: Judge Allows States to Present New Evidence Against Microsoft
description: The federal judge hearing the Microsoft antitrust case said today that she would overlook procedural errors by the states pursuing sanctions against the company and allow them to present new evidence about a restriction they have proposed.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: SOMALIA: KIDNAPPING PROMPTS U.N. SHUTDOWN The United Nations said it was suspending all activities in Mogadishu to protest the April 28 abduction of one of its Somali workers, the 14th such incident since 1995. Maxwell Gaylard, the United Nations' aid coordinator for Somalia, said a polio vaccination campaign scheduled for next week and other programs had been called off until Mohamed All Abokor is released. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Italy Without All the Distracting Art
description: IT'S natural to eye Arezzo a little suspiciously. It looks funny, with low, paneled ceilings that belong in a rec room and vaguely Japanese beams, with a cheap shine on them, running the length of the room. Birch logs and branches, scattered here and there, pretty much exhausted the obviously tiny decorating budget. There is no art on the white walls. But far, far back in the dining room a telltale beacon, flame from a small wood-burning oven, flashes a reassuring message. Arezzo really is what the name suggests: a neighborhood trattoria.

title: No Credit Awarded for Being Ex-Net
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 7  When P. J. Brown came to the Nets eight years ago, he was a gentleman. This week he returned to Continental Arena as a finalist for the N.B.A.'s sportsmanship award.

title: National Briefing: Plains
description: OKLAHOMA: ONE LAW, TWO AFFECTED STATES Gov. Frank Keating signed new water pollution standards that Arkansas officials said would harm development in their state. The rules are intended to reduce levels of phosphorus in the Illinois River and five other Oklahoma waterways. Arkansas will be affected because the Illinois River flows from Arkansas into Oklahoma. A 1992 Supreme Court decision said upstream states are subject to downriver water quality regulations. (AP)

title: Tear Down the Wall
description: The blue wall of silence, the tradition of the police lying or looking the other way to protect their own, rose up in a Brooklyn courtroom last week. Joseph Gray, a former police officer, was convicted of manslaughter for a horrific drunken driving accident that left four young people dead. It now appears that some of Mr. Gray's colleagues may have tried to help him get off. If so, they should be dealt with in the strictest possible terms.

description: The Rev. Paul R. Shanley, one of the priests at the center of the clergy sexual abuse scandal in Boston, pleaded not guilty today to charges of child rape and was ordered held on $750,000 cash bail.

description: The Pataki administration issued an array of initiatives yesterday that would begin reshaping the system of care and oversight for thousands of mentally ill people living in the state's deeply troubled adult homes.

title: France Announces Cabinet With a New Security Post
description: President Jacques Chirac, under pressure to show results before next month's crucial legislative elections, announced the appointment of a conservative interim cabinet today, putting a steel magnate in charge of the economy and creating a powerful new security post to get tough on crime.

description: Throughout California's energy crisis early last year, President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney strongly opposed any government intervention or price controls intended to rein in the surging costs of electricity.

Bishop Sharon Rader of Wisconsin has served as secretary of the council since 1996. Laurie Goodstein (NYT)

description: WASHINGTON, May 8  The House of Representatives, as expected, approved a plan this afternoon to send nuclear waste to Yucca Mountain in Nevada.

description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the Police Department would pay $100 to anyone who turns in a handgun, sawed-off shotgun or assault weapon to the police, as part of the department's efforts to reverse an increase in shootings around the city.

title: Duke Biologist Wins Award
description: When James Jarvis, a nature-loving homeless man, lived in a cave in Inwood Hill Park in northern Manhattan, he collected rocks and fossils. His son, ERICH JARVIS, left, inherited his father's love of nature but leads a more conventional life as an assistant professor of neurobiology at Duke University, where he studies the neurobiology of vocal communication among songbirds and runs a laboratory of 15 people. This week, the National Science Foundation gave him its Alan T. Waterman Award, its highest honor for a young researcher, which it gives to one young scientist or engineer each year.
