title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWEEN, AUDREY L., RN, MSN.
description: SCHWEEN-Audrey L., RN, MSN. Pioneer in nursing education, died at age 66 after a long illness on May 1, 2002 surrounded by family and friends. Professionally and privately her skills, generosity, energy, warmth, creativity and sense of humor have brought comfort and happiness to a multitude. She is survived by husband Peter H. Schween, M.D., and daughter Astrid, cellist of the Lark Quartet. Funeral services were held at The Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.

title: South Korea Faces a Test Of Conscience Over the Draft
description: With his cocoa colored smock, wire rimmed glasses and a sheepish grin that he flashes from beneath schoolboyish bangs, there is little about Oh Tae Yang to suggest steely combativeness.

title: Church Hedges a Bet
description: The decision by the Archdiocese of Boston to back away from a settlement with 86 people who say they were abused by John J. Geoghan, a former priest, was the product of at least two sorts of financial calculations.

title: National Briefing: Mid-Atlantic
description: MASSACHUSETTS: TRUMPING THE GOVERNOR The state's highest court ruled that Acting Gov. Jane M. Swift lacked the power to fire two members of the Massachusetts Turnpike Authority in February. Ms. Swift fired the members after they voted to delay by six months a scheduled toll increase on the turnpike. At the time, the governor said that the board members were fiscally irresponsible. The Supreme Judicial Court said that the dispute appeared to involve a difference of opinion, which was not sufficient reason to remove members of an independent state authority. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: ANOTHER GRADUATION REQUIREMENT Students at eight high schools in the San Fernando Valley are angry at a new rule preventing them from attending graduation unless they promise to go to college, trade school or into the military. Officials in the district, part of the Los Angeles school system, say they want to increase expectations for the area's 3,700 seniors, who tend to come from low-income families. About 95 percent of students have complied, though some say they have simply gotten letters from community colleges so they can take part in ceremonies. Kate Zernike (NYT)

title: Study Finds Far Less Pesticide Residue on Organic Produce
description: The first detailed scientific analysis of organic fruits and vegetables, published today, shows that they contain a third as many pesticide residues as conventionally grown foods.

title: The Cricketing of an Indian Village
description: Based in Bombay, the Hindi film industry -- affectionately known as Bollywood -- is one of the largest in the world, but its products are rarely seen beyond India and the Indian communities abroad. The musical ''Lagaan,'' however, has leapt over the usual boundaries. It became a genuine popular success in London last year, crossing over to a general audience, and now it is reopening in New York, after having played the Indian neighborhoods last summer, and opening in Los Angeles. Its New York venue is the Film Forum in the South Village, where the regular audience of refined filmgoers might be expected to view ''Lagaan'' with condescension.

title: In South Africa, the Excitement of Youth
description: STACKED just inside the front door at Vaughan Johnson's Wine Shop at the Victoria and Alfred Waterfront shopping center here in April were 20 cases of wines from Rupert & Rothschild, one of the hot new wineries of South Africa's Western Cape.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, HAROLD
description: HOROWITZ-Harold, 81. Of New York on May 7, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Frances Kossar. Brother of the late Hannah Kramer and Celia Young. Loving uncle of Susan Kramer and Janet Sanders. Devoted brother-in-law of Joseph Kossar and Alice Weinberg. Services 1:00 PM, Thursday at the Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Forest Avenue, Paramus, NJ. Donations may be made to Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center Oncology Dept., or Calvary Hospital, Bronx, NY. For more information contact Louis Suburban Chapel, Fair Lawn, New Jersey.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Suicide Follows Killing
description: A woman stabbed her husband to death early yesterday after a dispute inside their Maspeth home and then ran outside and took her own life, the police said. The couple's 11-year-old daughter was at home during the 4:30 a.m. episode. Neighbors who found the girl bloody in the street called the police. When officers arrived at the 58th Road home, Armando Moreno, 44, was found fatally stabbed once in the chest, the police said. Two blocks away, his wife, Yolanda Moreno, 46, was found dead after stabbing herself with a kitchen knife in the stomach, chest and wrists, the police said. The couple had no history of domestic violence, the police said. The girl was treated for trauma at Elmhurst Hospital Center, the police said. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A profile on Monday about Gen. Richard B. Myers, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, referred imprecisely to the timing of his selection for his post. President Bush chose him in August, not after Sept. 11.

title: Winning It All Motivates Bonds
description: In a white room with black curtains stood the slugger Barry Bonds, doing his news media duties before bashing baseballs in batting practice. He wore the usual look: a cap backward, a diamond cross dangling from his left ear lobe and a smile, once in a while, flashing across his face.

title: Judge Says Andersen's Past Can Be Evidence
description: The federal judge in the obstruction of justice trial of Arthur Andersen ruled today that federal prosecutors could present evidence to the jury of other accounting scandals involving the firm. That opened the way for the government to establish a motive for Andersen officials to destroy documents related to Enron.

title: Young Women at Risk
description: United Nations special sessions may not cure the ills they address, but they should at least not push the world backward. The session on children that opens today threatens to do that because the Bush administration wants to limit the access of teenage girls to sex education and reproductive health services, even though they are at special risk of contracting AIDS. The administration prefers a standard that emphasizes abstinence, which has not proved effective in the United States at delaying sexual activity.

title: The Life of a Medical Resident
description: To the Editor:

title: Splits Over Palestinian Statehood And Arafat Role Are Unresolved
description: President Bush and Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel remained divided today about how quickly to move toward the creation of a Palestinian state and whether to deal with Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader. Mr. Sharon's visit was abruptly broken off by news of a suicide bombing in Israel, which interrupted their Oval Office meeting and jeopardized the administration's hopes of rapidly restarting a political dialogue.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Solemnity of the Ascension, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Union for New York City Teachers Takes First Step Toward a Strike
description: Delegates of the union representing New York City teachers voted overwhelmingly yesterday to authorize a strike, a last-resort tactic meant to increase pressure on city negotiators and to appease angry teachers who feel their union has not been sufficiently forceful in the long-stalled talks over a contract.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOOSEN, MORTON A.
description: MOOSEN-Morton A. May 7, 2002. We mourn the loss of a most special man whose life force, creativity and generous devotion to those he loved remain as a remarkable legacy. Wife, Vicky; children, Deborah, Alexandra, Ross and Bruce; grandchildren, Jessica, Daniel, Matthew, Joshua, Zachary; sisters and brothers Sheila, Zita, Charles, Irwin and their families.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Kevyn Aucoin, 40, an Artist Whose Best Work Was Unseen
description: Kevyn Aucoin, the makeup artist who attained an unusually wide-reaching fame ministering to faces both iconic and ordinary, died yesterday at the Westchester Medical Center. He was 40.

title: Prosecutor Says Haunted Skakel Has Admitted To '75 Killing
description: Opening the state's case against Michael C. Skakel in the 1975 murder of Martha Moxley, a prosecutor told jurors today that Mr. Skakel had confessed repeatedly to the killing, and that there had been a ''concerted effort'' by the Skakel family ''to prevent the discovery of the actual murderer.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: North Lindenhurst: Wrestling Rings Banned
description: The Babylon town board voted unanimously last night to ban wrestling rings, boxing rings and similar structures in residential neighborhoods, a town spokeswoman said. The vote had been postponed twice, after teenagers and other wrestling fans protested the proposal. The ban, an amendment to the town's zoning code, was suggested after neighbors complained about the noise generated by wrestling events and practices taking place in a professional-style wrestling ring in one resident's backyard. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Buddha Injury Minor; Travers Now the Goal
description: Less than a week after one of the most bitter disappointments of his training career, Jim Bond brightened considerably yesterday and his thoughts turned to what he hopes will be a bright future for the star of his stable, Buddha. The news arrived that tests on Buddha, the gray 3-year-old who had to be scratched from the Kentucky Derby because of lameness in his left front leg, had revealed nothing more serious than a bruised hoof.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 26 about negotiations between New York City and the state attorney general's office to end a lawsuit that is blocking the development of the city's community gardens misstated the total amount paid by preservationists for 111 gardens in 1999. It was $4.2 million, not $1 million.

title: Fed Is Content Not to Raise Interest Rates
description: With new data suggesting that inflation will remain under control, the Federal Reserve voted unanimously today to hold its benchmark interest rate unchanged, saying the durability of the economic recovery remained uncertain.

title: Lou Thesz, 86, Skilled Pro Wrestler, Dies
description: Lou Thesz, the most celebrated professional wrestler of the mid-20th century and one of the last who relied on physical skills rather than show business gimmicks, died on April 28 in a hospital in Orlando, Fla. He was 86 and had undergone triple-bypass surgery and aortic valve replacement three weeks before.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-18

title: OFF THE MENU
description: A Nod to Shanghai

title: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: Ferry Death Toll Passes 200
description: Officials said they had recovered the bodies of 209 people who drowned when a ferry sank Friday on the Meghna River in a furious storm. Almost 100 people were able to swim to shore or were picked up by other boats. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: National Briefing: New England
description: U.S. FINDS STUDENT VISA FRAUD A ring that used stand-ins to take English-language proficiency exams for 130 foreign students was broken up, federal prosecutors said. In raids in 13 states and the District of Columbia, they said, 58 people were arrested. Many colleges and universities require the test as proof that foreign students comply with the terms of student visas. The scheme operated from May 1999 until last month, the authorities said. Mahmoud Firas, 36, of Riverside, Calif., and Begad Abdel-Megeed, 21, of Alexandria, Va., were named as the main test takers. (AP)

title: Morris Shamos, Physicist and Educator, 84
description: Morris Herbert Shamos, a nuclear physicist and science educator who attracted attention with his arguments that only those seeking careers in science should have to wrestle with a full scientific curriculum, died on Monday at New York Hospital. He was 84.

title: Suspected Suicide Bomb Kills 14, Mostly French, in Pakistan City
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 8  At least 14 people, most of them French, were killed and more than a score seriously wounded today when a red Toyota pulled up alongside a shuttle bus in front of the Sheraton Hotel in downtown Karachi and exploded, leaving a deep crater and scattering arms, legs and other body parts over a wide area.

title: An Arugula Nosegay, For $16 a Pound
description: ''They have a kind of walnutty taste,'' Harris Uslander, 7, said, sampling the arugula flowers at the Windfall Farms stand in the Union Square Greenmarket. A first grader with an advanced-placement palate, Harris was at the market with his class from the Village Community School. He was right on the money. The pretty little white and burgundy flower clusters, available on and off during spring and summer, add a bit of intriguing flavor to salads, along with unusual visual appeal. Windfall Farms, in Montgomery, N.Y., sells the flowers for $16 a pound on Wednesdays and Saturdays.

title: New Dean at Quinnipiac University
description: HANS BERGMANN, an English professor at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va., for more than 25 years, will become the new dean of the College of Liberal Arts at Quinnipiac University in Hamden, Conn., on July 1. A private institution, Quinnipiac enrolls 4,600 full-time undergraduate and 2,100 graduate students. Stephanie Rosenbloom

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: A Push For More Workers
description: A group of seasonal Michigan businesses that rely on foreign workers for summer staff is suing the Immigration and Naturalization Service over delays in processing temporary work visas since the Sept. 11 attacks. The 13 companies filing suit are on the shores of the Great Lakes and include hotels and restaurants. John Carpenter (NYT)

title: National Briefing | West: California: The $200 Million Gift
description: David Geffen, a co-founder of Dreamworks, the entertainment company, has donated $200 million to the school of medicine at the University of California at Los Angeles, which will now be known as the David Geffen School of Medicine at U.C.L.A. The gift from Mr. Geffen, 59, is the largest ever to a medical school in the United States. Rick Lyman (NYT)

title: Zucchini Becomes Art, Thrilling Nuts and Chips
description: Margaret Dorfman, a sculptor in Berkeley, Calif., takes paper-thin slices of zucchini, beets, papaya and other fruits and vegetables, cures them until they resemble parchment and fashions them into fragile little ruffled, translucent bowls. Each one takes 10 to 12 days to make.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Rates Increased
description: The Bank of Korea surprised forecasters by raising its benchmark interest rate one-quarter point, to 4.25 percent. The increase, the bank's first in 19 months, came a week after a team from the International Monetary Fund in Washington said one was needed to head off inflation. The bank said upward pressures on prices were mounting, in part because of rising oil prices and real estate values, and it cited ''a steep increase in household lending at low interest rates,'' a reference to the rising use of credit cards. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Bloomberg's Salon, Where the Powerful Mix Over Meatloaf
description: A few times a month, 20 or so New Yorkers open their closets and contemplate what to wear to eat meatloaf at the Beaux-Arts town house of the 108th mayor of New York.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: New Documents on Enron Give California Ammunition

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about effects of the delay in drawing new lines for Congressional districts in New York misidentified the justice of the State Supreme Court in Manhattan who appointed a referee to create a redistricting plan. It was Herman Cahn, not Marcy L. Kahn.

title: Teachers' Union: Threatening, But Not Exactly Darth Vader
description: IN 1973, when his films were getting critical raves and not the ''enough, already'' groans that are more common these days, Woody Allen made a comedy called ''Sleeper.'' In it, he played a man who awakens after being frozen for 200 years, to be told that the civilization he knew was destroyed when ''a man by the name of Albert Shanker got hold of a nuclear warhead.''

title: Joint 6-Year Law Degree Program
description: Adelphi University and New York Law School have created a joint law degree program that allows students to complete a bachelor's degree and a law degree in six years, spending three years at each school.

title: At Workshop, Students Tackle Real-Life Problems
description: Nzingha Dorner once gazed at the neglected structures and blighted buildings in her neighborhood and thought that replacing them took little more than some cash and a dream. She has since learned that developing a piece of property is not that simple.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Talks On Nuclear Program
description: A delegation from an international consortium arrived to talk about the next step in making nuclear reactors for North Korea. Under a 1994 agreement North Korea agreed to abandon its nuclear weapons program and the United States agreed that the consortium, which also includes South Korea and Japan, would build two reactors to fulfill the North's energy needs. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: National Briefing | West: California: Allowing Jail Recordings
description: The State Supreme Court has ruled that law enforcement officials may secretly and without a warrant record inmates' jail conversations to gather evidence of crimes. The court said such recordings were lawful because prisoners had no expectation of privacy, but made an exception for consultations with lawyers. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Buenos Aires's Restaurants: On the Grill
description: IN Argentina, people do not live by beef alone (except most of the time). Here are some fine restaurants in Buenos Aires:

title: World Briefing | Africa: Somalia: Kidnapping Prompts U.N. Shutdown
description: The United Nations said it was suspending all activities in Mogadishu to protest the April 28 abduction of one of its Somali workers, the 14th such incident since 1995. Maxwell Gaylard, the United Nations' aid coordinator for Somalia, said a polio vaccination campaign scheduled for next week and other programs had been called off until Mohamed All Abokor is released. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Trimmed, Marinated and Ready for the Wok
description: Many Chinese dishes cook in minutes, but the trimming, chopping, seasoning and marinating you have to do beforehand can take considerable time. For those seeking shortcuts, Deluxe Food Market, 79 Elizabeth Street (Hester Street), sells seasoned and marinated meat, poultry and seafood that is ready for the steamer or wok. It's the newest and largest of a chain of Chinatown markets. Marinated rib-eye, spareribs with black beans, chicken with mushrooms, ground pork with preserved vegetables, sole with garlic and ginger, sea bass with black beans and marinated frogs' legs are just a few of the dozens of choices. Most are $2.29 to $5.99 a pound, and yield extremely tasty results. Pigs' ears and tripe, which are complicated to clean and trim, are also available, seasoned and ready to cook. The store also sells fresh, unmarinated but well-trimmed meat, some vegetables and condiments, and prepared dishes like roast chickens ($6 each), pork buns and dumplings, and offers hot prepared dishes at $2.75 a portion. There is also a bakery and sushi counter. Everything is clearly labeled in English as well as in Chinese.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, ANGELA
description: KRAMER-Angela. It is with great sadness that we mourn the passing of our beloved friend and client, Angela Frances Allen Kramer. Our hearts go out to Terry Allen Kramer and the entire Kramer Family. Ken Greenhut Peter Drezner RSM McGladrey, Inc.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ABM INDUSTRIES INC., San Francisco, a provider of building maintenance services, completed a 2-for-1 stock split announced on March 12 for shareholders of record on March 29.

title: Cisco Buoyed By Earnings, But It Sees No Turnaround
description: Cisco Systems reported profits for its fiscal third quarter today that were better than expected, as belt-tightening, drastically lower costs for parts and a slight rise in sales helped the company turn around from a steep loss a year before.

title: Corrections
description: A profile on April 25 about Cardinal Roger M. Mahony, the Roman Catholic archbishop of Los Angeles, referred incorrectly to his parents. He was born to Victor James Mahony and the former Loretta Marie Baron, who raised him; he was not adopted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, NORMAN
description: GREENBERG - Norman. The Board of Governors and members of Montammy Golf club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their beloved member, and extend their heartfelt sympathy to the family. Kenneth R. Orr, President

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: BMW Sales Are Up
description: Bayerische Motoren Werke, or BMW, is still selling almost as many cars as it can produce. The company said its first-quarter sales were 10.8 billion euros ($9.9 billion), 14 percent higher than a year ago; net income rose 3.8 percent, to 632 million euros ($580 million). Sales of the new Mini brand cars, introduced last summer, continue to climb sharply. At the top of the line, BMW's 7 Series cars also posted strong gains despite criticism in the automotive press. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLOTKIN, SAMUEL
description: PLOTKIN-Samuel. It is with great sadness that the entire Beth Israel Medical Center family acknowledges the passing of Samuel Plotkin, beloved father of our devoted friend, Fred Plotkin, whose support of Beth Israel and its many programs and services has been a source of enormous pride for all of us. To Fred, his family and all his father's loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Board of Trustees Matthew E. Fink, MD, President and CEO Robert G. Newman, MD, President Emeritus

title: People
description: * AnnaMaria DeSalva was named to the vacant post of executive vice president for North America operations at GCI Healthcare, New York, part of the GCI Group division of the Grey Global Group. She had been director for the Bristol-Myers Squibb Foundation, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERFIT, JEAN
description: PERFIT-Jean. Age 90, of Boca Raton, FL, on May 7th, 2002. Devoted wife of Irving, loving mother of Roberta, Stephen and Helen. Grandmother of Allyson, David, Lara, Joshua, Margot and Suzie. Great-grandmother of Evan, Zoe and Max. Graveside services May 9th, 11:00 AM, United Hebrew Cemetery of Staten Island. Jean was a lifetime member of Hadassah. Donations may be made to Hadassah of Englewood, N.J.

title: Garca to Play at Buick
description: IRVING, Tex., May 7  With the Buick Classic being held June 6-9, the week before the United States Open, the world's top players have been forced to make tough decisions regarding their schedules.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIEVES, LAWRENCE
description: KIEVES - Lawrence. Dance Theatre Workshop's Executive Director and Producer, Board, staff and community deeply mourn the loss of this beloved friend and family member.

title: Firmly Committed To Classical Form
description: MorganScott Ballet

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLIEGELMAN, AVRA L.
description: FLIEGELMAN-Avra L., 77. Of West Palm Beach, FL, passed away on May 6, 2002, formerly of New York City. She is survived by her loving nephew Irving (Andrea) Trager. Cherished grand-nephew Jordan Trager. She was the Executive Vice-President and Publisher of The Broadcast Information Bureau and was a Member and former Treasurer for The Woman's League for Israel Midtown Chapter. Graveside services will be held on Friday, May 10, 11 A.M. at Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hastingon-the-Hudson, NY. For more information call I.J. Morris Funeral Directors, 1-800-624-8282.

title: Condition: Mint
description: ASPARAGUS may introduce spring, but mint screams the word. The perennial herb is among the first edible greens out of the ground each year, and it is rampant enough to be considered a weed by those who aren't fond of it. By now every decent seller of vegetables, whether supermarket or truck stop, should be loaded with fresh mint, and the home cook's only decision is what to do with it -- a matter best contemplated, perhaps, over a mojito or a mint julep.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Swisscom Discount For Rivals
description: The Swiss Federal Communications Commission told Swisscom that the same network-access discount that it gives its Internet service provider, Bluewin, must also be given to rivals. Swisscom is under pressure to cut prices and modify business practices to bring them in line with other European countries. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Mendoza's Bullpen Reconnaissance
description: Ramiro Mendoza inspected the Oakland Athletics' lineup posted on the clubhouse door at Yankee Stadium last Thursday. He pointed to the name "LIDLE" next to the spot for the A's starting pitcher and made a throwing motion with his right hand. "Right-hander?" Mendoza asked a reporter. Yes, he was told, Cory Lidle throws right-handed.

title: Fell the Invader With a Fork
description: It was with much sympathy that I read recent news of the failed attempts by the California Department of Fish and Game to eliminate or even to control the fast-breeding, rapacious northern pike in the waters of Lake Davis. Apparently impervious to mind-boggling efforts like electrocution, poisoning the entire lake or precision bombing (one fish at a time?), the savage renegades now threaten trout fisheries and further terrorize Northern California with the possibility of swimming into open waters, there to chow down on salmon, steelheads and many more fish highly prized by that other fast-breeding, rapacious species, humankind.

title: 240 Pounds, Persistent And Jazzercise's Equal
description: As a plus-size fitness instructor, Jennifer Portnick's motto has been, ''Don't change your body, change the rules.'' On Monday, she did.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: A Change At Swatch
description: Nicolas Hayek, 73, who led the revival of the Swiss watch industry as the head of the Swatch Group, said he planned to step down as chief executive next month but would stay on as its chairman. He has been grooming his son, Nicolas Hayek Jr., 47, as his successor. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFF, HERBERT
description: SCHIFF-Herbert. The Officers, Board of Directors and staff of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) mourn the passing of our friend and honorary Board Member, Herbert Schiff. For many years, Herb moved JDC forward as an organization through his careful decisions and decisive actions. Serving on JDC's Board of Directors and Executive Committee, he was single-handedly responsible for the establishment and initial financing of critical JDC infrastructure. Herb traveled the world several times over to review Jewish rescue and relief projects on a first hand basis. A studied individual who made decisions based on his own meticulous research, Herb's counsel and guidance were valued tools in enhancing the work of the JDC and in bettering the lives of hundreds of thousands of his fellow Jews. We extend our hearfelt condolences to his wife Betty, his three daughters Suzanne, Patricia and Jane, and the entire family. Eugene J. Ribakoff, President Jonathan W. Kolker Chairman of the Board Michael Schneider Executive Vice President

title: Rumsfeld Gives His Support to Beleaguered Army Secretary
description: Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld and White House officials expressed strong support today for Secretary of the Army Thomas E. White, saying he was not to blame for a lobbying campaign to protect an $11 billion artillery system that Mr. Rumsfeld wanted to cancel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAMOS, MORRIS H.
description: SHAMOS-Morris H. Scientist, biophysicist, executive & educator, Emeritus Professor of Physics at New York University, Senior Vice-President and Chief Scientific Officer of Technicon Corporation, Past President of the National Science Teachers Association and the New York Academy of Sciences. Some said it wouldn't last, but his devotion to his beloved wife Marion spanned 59 years until they were parted only by the untimely intrusion of death on May 6, 2002. Loving father of Michael, father-in-law of Julie, grandfather of Josselyn & Alexander. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, at 11:15AM Wednesday. Visitors will be received at home, 3515 Henry Hudson Parkway, Apt. 11A, Bronx, N.Y. 10463 from 4:00-8:00 P.M., Wednesday, May 8th. The family requests that in lieu of flowers contributions be sent to the Morris Shamos Fund, NYU College of Arts and Science, 25 W. 4th Street, NY, NY 10012; attn: Alan Shapiro.

title: Remarks by the Israeli Prime Minister
description: Following are excerpts from Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's news conference last night in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THEOPHILOS, ELIZABETH
description: THEOPHILOS-Elizabeth Terzis, 80 of Atlanta, GA, formerly of New Providence, NJ. Died on May 2nd at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital in NYC. During World War II, Mrs. Theophilos, who was born in Passaic, NJ lived in Connecticut and served in the Aircraft Warning Service for the Connecticut Defense Counsel. She graduated with honors from Stafford Hall School of Business in Summit and was an Executive Secretary at Ciba-Geigy (Novartis) for 15 years until her retirement in 1990. Two daughters, Judith Dorphley and Pamela Server, five grandchildren and one great-granddaughter survive her. Services will be in Litchfield, CT.

title: HOFSTRA TWO-SPORTS STAR SIGNS WITH JETS
description: Doug Shanahan, a former Hofstra All-American in football and lacrosse, is a member of the United State lacrosse team that will compete in the world championships in Australia in mid-July. But Shanahan may consider a change in his travel schedule. Shanahan, a safety, is expected back at Hofstra in late July, when the Jets open training camp.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Airport May Need Reconstruction
description: Terminals at Newark International Airport could need extensive reconstruction to accommodate bomb detection machines required by the federal government, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday. If it is determined by federal evaluators that the airport requires explosive detection systems, large and heavy machines that screen checked baggage, floors could need to be shored up, walls moved and new conveyer belts installed. No official dollar figure for the project is yet available, the spokesman said.

title: INSIDE
description: Killing Won't Delay Dutch Vote

title: She, Too, Dreams of Being Spider-Person
description: To the Editor:

title: So, Spider-Man! Brilliant Disguise!; The Real Mild-Mannered Parkers Are in a Superhero's Fictional Lair
description: Much of ''Spider-Man,'' the blockbuster action movie, was filmed on location in Queens, the comic book domain of the web-slinging superhero. As it happens, the realism of the Spider-Man comic transcends the mere film.

title: Pumping Iron With a Cake
description: A classic of Viennese pastry is Dobos torte, usually made with seven thin layers of yellow cake interspersed with chocolate butter cream. Not content with that for his steakhouse clientele, Ren Lenger, right, an Austrian pastry chef who is the chef de cuisine at Strip House, 13 East 12th Street, bakes a delicious towering 12-layer all-chocolate version that is served there and at Michael Jordan's: The Steak House, in Grand Central Terminal. The cake weighs 20 pounds. How does he get it from 12th Street to Grand Central? ''Our delivery guy does it,'' Mr. Lenger said. ''And he goes to the gym twice a week.'' The cake is sold to go, on 24 hours' notice, for $150 from (212) 328-0000. Delivery is not available, so start your push-ups now.

title: Triple Crown Legend Is Gone: Seattle Slew Dies in Sleep at 28
description: It was Sept. 16, 1978, and Angel Cordero finally landed the ride of his life: he was aboard Seattle Slew for the Marlboro Cup Handicap. The colt swept the Triple Crown the previous year and had won 11 of 13 races over all with the jockey Jean Cruguet, but now it was Cordero's turn atop a horse he had long admired.

title: Education Suffers in Africa As AIDS Ravages Teachers
description: The virus that causes AIDS is spreading so rapidly in parts of Africa that it is killing teachers faster than nations can train them, undermining an international effort to enroll all children in school by 2015, a report by the World Bank said today.

title: Costas to Sign Deal To Stay at NBC
description: Bob Costas will remain NBC's anchor for its Olympic coverage through the 2006 Winter Games under a new contract that is expected to be announced next week.

title: More Enron Mischief
description: The people who ran Enron always insisted that the company had nothing to do with the California energy crisis. The crisis, which peaked in the winter of 2000-2001, was variously attributed by them and their friends in Washington to California's environmental regulations, to shortages of natural gas and new generating capacity and to a flawed system of deregulation. But incriminating documents released Monday by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission suggest that market manipulation by Enron and possibly other companies aggravated the crisis. California officials welcomed the documents as the ''smoking gun'' necessary to help them recoup billions in overcharges.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''About $30 billion was extorted from this state. Those who claimed that there was no price manipulation here were just plain wrong.''

description: Pepsi Bottling Group Inc., the largest bottler of PepsiCo Inc. beverages, said today that it had offered to buy Mexico's leading Pepsi bottler for 11.9 billion pesos ($1.25 billion) in cash and debt.

title: Michael Todd Jr., 72, a Creator Of Smell-o-Vision for Movies
description: Michael Todd Jr., son of the producer of ''Around the World in 80 Days,'' who took over his father's production business and made a Smell-o-Vision film that combined movies with changing odors, died on Sunday at his home in County Carlow, Ireland. He was 72.

title: U.N. Prepares For a Debate On Dire Needs Of Children
description: As world leaders gathered here on the eve of a landmark special session on children, tales of abomination were hardly in short supply today. Some 10 million children died of preventable diseases in the 1990's, a United Nations review found. Infant mortality rates deteriorated in large swaths of Africa. Aid from rich nations to the poor lagged at a time of unprecedented global prosperity, and in much of the developing world, the number of people who lived on less than $1 a day shot up over the last decade.

title: Mark Militello
description: FOR the paella that I serve in my restaurants, I prefer short-grain Spanish rice. For risotto, I like vialone nano, a type of arborio. But for the Caribbean dishes, I yield to my Haitian cooks, Pascal Dieumeme and Orenus Olean. They like Uncle Ben's.

description: This is the place that launched a million trips.

title: Following the Money, A Casino Finds Quail Salad
description: TO persuade friends to meet me for dinner at a restaurant called Rain last week, I had to drop names. The chef came from the French Laundry, I said. The design was by David Rockwell. Todd English and Jasper White have restaurants nearby. So does Michael Jordan.

title: Preventing Child Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Tourism Still Struggles, but Improvement Is Noted
description: Restaurants are struggling. Hotel occupancy, and certainly room rates, are nowhere near their peaks of 2000. And other New York tourist destinations -- from Broadway theaters to museums -- have a long way to go before they recover. Yet the number of foreign visitors to the city is increasing, and Linda M. Conlin, an assistant secretary of commerce, went to Manhattan yesterday and gave local officials credit for bringing those visitors there.

title: Sports of The Times; A Champion Who Kept Going Till the End
description: IN the final days, his legs skewed out so badly that one of his loving owners, Mickey Taylor, had to prop up his flank with a bare upraised palm, just to keep him moving.

title: A Shift in Headquarters By D&B, the Publisher
description: D&B, the financial information publisher formerly known as Dun & Bradstreet, has sold its 42-acre corporate campus in Murray Hill, N.J., and will move its headquarters this fall to a recently renovated office building it has leased in Short Hills, N.J.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Water Rationing For Capital
description: Officials in Taipei said the capital would begin water rationing on Monday in response to a drought that has persisted past the usual start of the rainy season. Water will be turned off to a fifth of the city's two million people for 24 hours in a five-day rotation. The drought has alarmed Taiwan's computer industry, which uses large quantities of water in chip production. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMAREST, DANIEL A.
description: DEMAREST-Daniel A. On May 3, 2002, of lung cancer. Lawyer and trustee. Retired partner of the former law firms of Beekman & Bogue and Gaston & Snow, he specialized in corporate and securities law. He graduated from St. George's School in Newport, RI in 1942, served in the U.S. Army 194346, graduated from Harvard College in 1948 and Harvard Law School in 1951. At the time of his death, he was a Trustee of The Lachaise Foundation, a Director of The Bay Foundation and a Director of The Josephine Bay Paul and C. Michael Paul Foundation, and was a longtime member of The Knickerbocker Club and The Holland Society. Survivors include his sister, Rosemary R. Demarest of New York City, and his nephew, David R. Demarest of San Anselmo, CA. Donations in memory of Daniel Demarest may be made to The Juilliard School, attn: Development Office, 60 Lincoln Center Plaza, New York, NY 10023-6588, or to Cabrini Hospice, attn: Ms. Mary Cooke, Director, 227 East 19th Street, New York, New York 10003-2693. Funeral services will be held on Saturday, May 11, 2002 at 11 A.M. at The Church of the Heavenly Rest, Two East 90th Street, New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCALI, THOMAS
description: SCALI-Thomas. The entire Long Island College Hospital family mourns the passing of Thomas Scali, M.D., devoted physician and esteemed colleague and friend. He will be greatly missed by all who knew and worked with him. We extend our deepest condolences to his family and all of his loved ones. Mark McDougle Executive Vice President & COO Edmund Giegerich, M.D. Sr. Vice Pres. of Medical Affairs Jagdish K. Gupta, M.D. President, Medical Staff Lewis Kohl, D.O., Chairman Dept. of Emergency Medicine

description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Competitor Aims At Blackberry
description: Good Technology, a Silicon Valley start-up, yesterday introduced its first product, a mobile e-mail service that is intended to challenge Research in Motion's popularity among corporate customers. Good Technology, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said it had signed up customers like VeriSign and Electronic Arts. The service, called GoodLink, which costs $45 a month, synchronizes messages, addresses and calendar items with Microsoft Exchange, the server behind Outlook. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Providing Care Despite Protests
description: Doctors in Phoenix have begun caring for a boy recovering from brain surgery despite protests from his parents. After a brain tumor was removed from the boy, Samuel Schaffer, 9, last month, doctors wanted to follow up with chemotherapy and radiation treatments. His parents, Stephen and Wendela Schaffer, refused, citing religious beliefs though they do not attend a church or belong to a denomination. The case was referred to child welfare workers, who placed Samuel under the supervision of doctors. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: The Motto at Auction: Spend, Spend, Spend
description: Steering clear of a depressed stock market? Can't find the perfect house or apartment? What do you do with all that extra cash?

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Netflix Sets Offering Price
description: The online DVD rental company Netflix set the price of its initial share offering at $13 to $15 a share. The company, based in Los Gatos, Calif., hopes to raise as much as $82.5 million by selling 5.5 million shares. Netflix filed to go public in March. It will trade on the Nasdaq market under the symbol NFLX. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Clues on Italy's Role at Nativity Church
description: Italy said today that it had never been asked whether it would allow some of the Palestinian militants holed up in the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem to come here.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Challenging Pornography Law
description: Immediately after Gov. Bob Taft signed a law extending Ohio's antipornography laws to the Internet, a coalition of newspapers, publishers, booksellers and video distributors sued to challenge it. The group says the law, which makes criminal the distribution to minors of materials with sexual subject matter, ''extreme or bizarre violence,'' the ''repeated use of foul language'' and the glorification of criminal activity, will ban constitutionally protected speech. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: It's Ortiz the Pitcher, Not Bonds, Who Hits the Mets Hard
description: Several Mets players and coaches in the first-base dugout moved from the bench to the top step near the railing when Barry Bonds strolled to the plate in the first inning last night at Shea Stadium. The better vantage point was a difference of only a few feet, but it was the incredible Bonds, so every inch mattered. Even for the Mets, the team trying to beat Bonds and the San Francisco Giants.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Acquisition By Microsoft
description: Microsoft said yesterday that it would acquire Navision, a Danish business-planning software company, for $1.3 billion in cash and stock. Microsoft said the acquisition would bring together the strengths of Navision and Great Plains Business Solutions, an American company that Microsoft bought last year for $1.1 billion. Both companies make software aimed at small and midsize businesses. The deal requires clearance from antitrust authorities and 90 percent acceptance of the offer. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: RANGERS TO SPEAK WITH KINGS ASSISTANT
description: Dave Tippett, an assistant coach with the Los Angeles Kings and a former teammate of Eric Lindros, appears to be next on the interview list for the Rangers' president and general manager, Glen Sather, in his search for a head coach.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: 100 Lashes For Premarital Sex
description: A 19-year-old woman who became pregnant after having premarital sex has been sentenced to 100 lashes by an Islamic court in the northern state of Bauchi. The woman, Adama Yunusa, acknowledged having had sex with her fianc, Isa Katagum, who escaped punishment. The court said the sentence would be carried out after the baby is born. A third of Nigeria's states have adopted Islamic law since the transition to civilian rule three years ago. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

description: Musiq

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNITZER, ELAINE (GELLERMAN)
description: SCHNITZER-Elaine (Gellerman). Beloved wife of the late Louis. Loving mother of Murray and the late Toby Schulman. Adored aunt, cousin and friend, ''Ettie'' was the glue which held the family together. She will always be remembered by those who knew her. Services at 11:15 A.M. on Thursday at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Shiva at 308 East 79th Street.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the appointment of a new prime minister in France by President Jacques Chirac misspelled the surname of a columnist for Le Figaro who commented on the political challenge facing Mr. Chirac. The columnist is Jean d'Ormesson, not D'Omersson.

title: Under Siege, Fiercely Longing for Peace
description: Rose Hazboun and Eva Dabdoub, sisters and co-sufferers, have just about had it with the siege of Bethlehem and of their church, the Church of the Nativity -- now full of gunmen, sympathizers, peace activists and strangers of all kinds.

title: Lakers' Run Falls Short as Spurs Even the Series
description: For the fifth game in a row, the Los Angeles Lakers did not resemble the explosive squad that has captured consecutive N.B.A. championships. This time they paid for it, losing Game 2 of their Western Conference semifinal series tonight to the San Antonio Spurs, 88-85.

title: From New Orleans, a Feeling Of Time Standing Still
description: Down

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Appeals Order To Raise Lawyer Pay
description: The city and the state attorney general yesterday appealed a State Supreme Court justice's order to raise the hourly rate paid to lawyers who are assigned to represent the poor in New York City courts. In addition, the city invoked a stay on the order to raise the hourly rate to $90 for work in and out of court, said Kate O'Brien Ahlers, a spokeswoman for the city's Law Department. On Monday, Justice Lucindo Suarez issued an order that would more than double the hourly rates, which are $25 an hour for out-of-court work and $40 for work in court. Lawyers who defend the poor have long sought to raise the rates, which are among the lowest in the nation.

title: New Rules to Screen Students
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  Foreign students seeking to do advanced work in sensitive subjects and technologies taught only at American universities or laboratories will be screened by a special panel that will include representatives of intelligence and law enforcement agencies under new regulations unveiled today by the Bush administration.

title: Sometimes What a Neighborhood Needs Is a Steak
description: FROM the night it opened in late March, Carne, a small steakhouse-style restaurant a few blocks south of Morningside Heights, has drawn a steady stream of diners from the neighborhood. Professors from Columbia, families with infants, dating couples, elderly men, solitary people with newspapers -- they've all come to what is really little more than a bar and grill.

title: Off the Boardwalk, It's Cotton Candy Deluxe
description: Petits fours can't compete. As a treat for diners at Cello, 53 East 77th Street, Laurent Tourondel, the chef, spins tufts of surprisingly tart and refreshing green-apple cotton candy and places a jar of it on each table. A serving fork is provided, but few diners bother with that nicety: this boardwalk snack did not take on airs when it moved inside. The new Cinnabar Chinese restaurant, 235 West 56th Street, also serves after-dinner cotton candy, and so does Bleu in Greenwich, Conn., and Ling & Javier in Houston.

title: Argentina Shakes, Uruguay Rattles
description: Not long ago, the beaches of Uruguay were filled with Argentine tourists, its banks stuffed with Argentines' offshore wealth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLORMAN, HARRIET STEIN
description: FLORMAN-Harriet Stein, 56. On May 7, 2002, beloved mother of Larry, Jonathan & Jill, dear sister of Paul, Charlotte and Maxine, adored aunt of many nieces and nephews. Harriet will be with us forever. After battling for 12 years she succumbed to her illness. She had strength & determination that will always be remembered. We love you and will miss you.

title: Power to the People (New Music, Too)
description: Like all contemporary music ensembles, Bang on a Can routinely goes through the hassles of applying to foundations and government arts agencies for grants to support the commissioning of works. But the ensemble has found a way to avoid excess paperwork, and to empower its loyal audience in the process.

title: Miscues, Missteps and the Fall of Andersen
description: From the moment in January when Arthur Andersen's lawyers discovered that e-mail messages about Enron were missing -- thousands of them, from computer after computer in Andersen's office here -- the accounting firm began grasping at straws.

title: How Enron Got California To Buy Power It Didn't Need
description: Fat Boy. Death Star. Get Shorty. These were the cocky nicknames that Enron traders gave the complex trading strategies they employed in 2000 and 2001 to maximize gains in California's wholesale electricity market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANHEIM, FRANK J.
description: MANHEIM-Frank J., 91, former partner in Lehman Brothers, peacefully at home in London, May 5, 2002. Much loved husband, father, grandfather. Private family service.

description: In percent

title: The Late, Great Light Show; Chicago's Photographers and Their Abstract World
description: An odd object part chicken coop, part miniature theater, part trapeze -- sits in the first room of the exhibition ''Taken by Design: Photographs From the Institute of Design, 1937-1971'' at the Art Institute of Chicago. It is a light box designed in 1937 by one of the first students at the New Bauhaus, Nathan Lerner (the man who later designed the sponge mop, the plastic honey-bear container and the mesmerizing push toy that pops colored balls).

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Training For Robotic Pets
description: Sony's Entertainment Robot America division plans to publish a kit of software development specifications and tools that are intended to encourage owners of its Aibo robotic dogs to create new attributes for their mechanical pets. The tool kit will be posted on the Internet for free downloading starting on June 3 at www.aibo.com/openr, Sony said. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, DANIEL J., JR.
description: MURPHY-Daniel J., Jr. May 3, 2002 of Gladwyne, PA, age 81. Beloved husband of Mary Ann (nee Fluehr). Loving father of Ian A. of Florida, Keith J. of Exton, PA, Meredith A. Krechmer of King of Prussia, PA, Daniel J. III, D.V.M. of Washington, DC and Mary Jane Dutton of Phila., PA. Proud grandfather of Elsie F. and Brian D. Krechmer; Jamie W. and Garrett D. Dutton. Mr. Murphy was actively involved in power boat racing all of his life. Relatives, friends, members of The Republican Senatorial Inner Circle, of which he was a life member and American Legion Post 356, Narberth, PA, are invited to his viewing Wednesday 9-10AM at St. John Vianney Church, 350 Conshohocken State Road, Gladwyne, PA. Funeral Mass Wednesday 10 AM. Entombment Holy Cross Cemetery, Yeadon, PA. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to Waldron Mercy Academy, 513 Montgomery Avenue, Merion, PA. 19066; St. Joseph's Preparatory School, 1733 Girard Ave., Phila., PA 19130 or St. Lucy's School For Visually Impaired Children, 130 Hampden Road, Upper Darby, PA. 19082 would be appreciated. For information contact the Hollen Funeral Home: 215-698-2500.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUYSKENS, WILLIAM S.
description: MUYSKENS-William S. On May 3, peacefully at home. Loving husband of Janet (Hamilton). Devoted father of son Derek and daughter Lisa. Memorial service Saturday, May 25, at Salisbury Congregational Church, Main St., Salisbury, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to SVNA, 30 Salmon Kill Rd., Salisbury, CT 06068.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: MALAYSIA: A MUSLIM LEADER CRITICIZES MUSLIMS Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said Muslims had only themselves to blame for the poverty, misery and violence afflicting much of the Islamic world. Speaking to religious affairs ministers from the Organization of the Islamic Conference, a group of 57 countries, he said Muslims spent too much time fighting among themselves and were neglecting the pursuit of knowledge and the creation of wealth. "We Muslims and our countries are not very Islamic," he said. "We cannot even regard each other as brothers. To be very crude, the fate of the Muslims of today is of their own making." (Reuters)

title: Game 2 Is a Most Valuable Victory for the Nets
description: A sellout crowd at Continental Arena began chanting ''M.V.P! M.V.P!'' before the national anthem and did not stop until the final buzzer, honoring Jason Kidd even as his shots kept falling short of the basket.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITTON, ANN LOUISE
description: MITTON-Ann Louise. On May 4, 2002. Loving mother of Michael, Jeffrey and Tara, & grandmother of Adrian and Alexa. She was devoted to her many friends and a dedicated volunteer at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The family will receive friends May 13th, 123PM, at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, NYC.

title: Bloomfield College President to Depart
description: JOHN F. NOONAN, the president of Bloomfield College in Bloomfield, N.J., since 1987, will leave when his term ends in June 2003. During his presidency, the college added minority faculty members, created several new academic programs and opened a new library.

title: Giants Want Depth At Quarterback
description: Even though Kerry Collins has been extremely durable, the Giants continue to search for depth at quarterback. Yesterday, the Giants signed the free-agent quarterback John Welsh from the University of Idaho and cut Montclair State quarterback Ed Collins.

title: Audette Answers Call for Canadiens
description: The Montreal Canadiens have Donald Audette to thank for their 2-1 overtime victory tonight over the Carolina Hurricanes in Game 3 of their Eastern Conference semifinal series.

title: A 'Who Was Who' Weighs In on Art
description: In ''The Murals of Rockefeller Center,'' the painters Diego Rivera and Frida Kahlo share a railroad compartment with John Dillinger; George Gershwin does a Groucho Marx imitation to entertain Charles Lindbergh and President Coolidge; Pablo Picasso exchanges schoolboy insults with Henri Matisse. And the Rockefeller family is a slapstick circus.

title: Elections to Proceed in the Netherlands, Despite Killing
description: Dutch political leaders decided today to go ahead with the general elections next week, even after the killing of Pim Fortuyn, a right-wing politician who had stood a chance to become the country's next prime minister.

title: Wrong Payouts Are Uncovered In Pension Plan
description: The Labor Department's inspector general has found that more than 20 percent of cash-balance pension plans violated the law by not providing workers with all the benefits due them.

title: Deal to End Bethlehem Church Crisis Is Derailed (No One Told the Italian Hosts)
description: Israeli and Palestinian negotiators reached an agreement today to end the five-week siege at the Church of the Nativity, but the deal stalled after Italy said no one had asked its consent to send a group of Palestinian militants into exile there.

title: Recipe: Mustard and Chive Butter Garnish With Asparagus
description: Time: 10 minutes plus chilling

title: Studies in Favor of Indian Point's Closing List Power Effects
description: Closing down the Indian Point nuclear power plant, despite the grim predictions about blackouts and soaring electricity costs, might not be as painful as the plant's owners have contended, according to two new studies commissioned by opponents of the plant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFF, HERBERT H.
description: SCHIFF-Herbert H. American Friends of The Hebrew University deeply mourn the passing of Herbert H. Schiff, of Columbus, Ohio, and Sarasota, FL. He was a dedicated leader and supporter of many local and national organizations. As a long-time supporter, he formerly chaired The Audit Committee, and served on The Board of Directors. He was also an Honorary Governor of The Hebrew University of Jerusalem. Our deepest sympathies go to his wife, Betty, and his entire family. American Friends of The Hebrew University Ira Lee Sorkin, President Keith L. Sachs, Chairman of the Board

title: Senate, by 64-35 Vote, Passes Farm Bill Costing $180 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  The Senate passed the most important farm bill in years today, assuring farmers of billions more in subsidies over the next decade.

title: National Briefing: South
description: TENNESSEE: A VOTE FOR SCHOOL UNIFORMS The Memphis school board has voted to require all 117,000 students in the district to wear uniforms starting in the fall. Lora Jobe, a board member, first proposed mandatory uniforms for underperforming elementary schools. Other members expanded the measure after expressing worries that a limited requirement would stigmatize some children. David M. Halbfinger (NYT)

title: The Life of a Medical Resident
description: To the Editor:

title: Hijacking Mideast Peace
description: The suicide bombing at a billiards hall south of Tel Aviv last night that slaughtered at least 15 Israelis coincided, probably not by chance, with the Oval Office meeting between Ariel Sharon and President Bush. The aim of the terrorists is to prevent any effort to negotiate an end to the Middle East conflict. To deny them that power, the United States must seize control of the political agenda in the region and insist that responsible Israeli and Palestinian leaders not let renewed violence sabotage efforts to construct a lasting peace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLMES, F. STACY II.
description: HOLMES-F. Stacy II. On Sunday, May 5, 2002. Husband of Ann Levine, brother of Henry Cobb Holmes, uncle of Sukanya Emily Holmes & Denwood Nathan Stacy Holmes. A graduate of Harvard, Class of 1956, all-Ivy soccer player, Marine officer and satirical songwriter. His ability to make others laugh will be missed.

title: Chinese Jet, Carrying 112, Crashes in Sea Near the Coast
description: A flight from Beijing to Dailan spiraled into the sea on Tuesday night, apparently killing all 112 people aboard.

title: A Purchase Puts Vivendi Even Deeper In Utilities
description: Even as its share price continued a disastrous downward spiral, Vivendi Universal, the troubled French conglomerate, said today that its water subsidiary would spend about $600 million to acquire another utility in southern England. The move expands Vivendi's presence in a business where the chief executive, Jean-Marie Messier, once promised it would reduce its exposure.

title: JETBLUE STOCK FALLS AFTER ANALYSTS CALL IT OVERVALUED
description: Shares of JetBlue Airways dropped yesterday after analysts working for companies that underwrote the company's initial public offering released mixed ratings. The stock closed at $49.60 on the Nasdaq stock market, down $4.90, or 8.99 percent. Samuel Buttrick of UBS Warburg, which helped underwrite the airline's initial public offering on April 12, wrote in a research note that the stock appeared overvalued even though JetBlue was a ''great airline.'' He said JetBlue's stock was 35 times his fiscal 2003 earnings forecast of $1.55 a share, and he set a 12-month target of $38 a share. Analysts from Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley, which also underwrote the offering, rated the stock a midterm buy and an equal-weight, respectively. The latter rating means the stock is valued fairly. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Korea Telecom in Last Leg Of 15-Year Push to Privatize
description: Fifteen years ago, South Korea began trying to convert its government-run phone monopoly into a nimble, competitive privately owned company attuned to profits rather than politics.

title: Michael Bryant, 74, an Actor; Iago, Yes, but Also a Badger
description: Michael Bryant, a quietly virtuosic character actor who was a mainstay of the National Theater in England for the last 25 years, died on April 25 at his home in Richmond, Surrey. He was 74.

title: Market Place; For financial firms, proposed new rules on analysts are the least of their problems.
description: BIG investment banks and brokerage firms have done plenty of complaining about new regulations that are intended to reduce the influence their investment bankers have over their stock analysts. But the firms know that the proposed rules, which could be approved today, are the least of their problems.

title: House Passes a Bill Intended to Increase Security at Borders
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 — By a vote of 411 to 0, the House passed a border security bill today that is intended to strengthen enforcement of immigration laws, keep terrorists out of the United States and keep better track of foreign students.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Appeal In Crown Heights Case
description: Lemrick Nelson Jr., whose 1997 conviction in the Crown Heights civil rights case was overturned by a federal appeals court in January, asked the United States Supreme Court yesterday to review portions of the appeals court ruling that rejected legal arguments he had made. Under the appeals court decision, which said the jury had been selected improperly, he will be retried. He could be released without further proceedings if he prevails in the Supreme Court on claims that civil rights laws were applied improperly to charges that he killed a Hasidic scholar, Yankel Rosenbaum, during four days of violence between blacks and Orthodox Jews in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn in 1991.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POMPOSELLO, JOSEPH R.
description: POMPOSELLO-Joseph R. Of Yonkers, died May 5, 2002 at age 60. Born November 5, 1941 in the Bronx to Arthur and Connie Bellafatto Pomposello. He was a hair stylist, NYC dance instructor and award - winning ballroom/Latin dancer. Survived by brothers, Arthur and Thomas Pomposello. Visitation on Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Sinatra Memorial Home, 601 Yonkers Ave, Yonkers, NY. Funeral Mass, Friday, 10 AM at St. Francis Chapel, Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: CALIFORNIANS CALL ENRON DOCUMENTS THE SMOKING GUN
description: Documents showing that Enron manipulated California's power market were described today by politicians, lawyers and consumer groups as the smoking gun they needed to help recover billions of dollars they say the state was overcharged by Enron and other companies for electricity in 2000 and 2001.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: AFRICA SOMALIA: KIDNAPPING PROMPTS U.N. SHUTDOWN The United Nations said it was suspending all activities in Mogadishu to protest the April 28 abduction of one of its Somali workers, the 14th such incident since 1995. Maxwell Gaylard, the United Nations' aid coordinator for Somalia, said a polio vaccination campaign scheduled for next week and other programs had been called off until Mohamed All Abokor is released.

title: Rumsfeld Says He Plans to Kill $11 Billion Artillery Project
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today what he had been expected to say  he plans to kill the $11 billion Crusader artillery project  and thereby set the stage for a showdown in Congress.

title: Local Police Should Not Do an I.N.S. Job
description: The Bush administration is moving toward giving state and local police an expanded role in enforcing the nation's immigration laws. Although this move is being justified as part of the war on terrorism, it will do little to stop terrorists and will frighten immigrant communities.

title: Two Cities, Two Elections And Two Different Worlds
description: AFTER studying the riots that erupted in 1967 here and in other urban centers, a commission appointed by President Lyndon B. Johnson warned that the nation was ''moving toward two societies, one black, one white -- separate and unequal.''

title: WorldCom Seeks Big Loan
description: WorldCom is expected to borrow $2.65 billion from its banks as part of negotiations to rework the terms of its financings, executives close to the company said yesterday.

title: PRUDENTIAL REPORTS 35% FALL IN QUARTERLY PROFIT
description: Prudential Financial, the second-biggest life insurer in the United States, said yesterday that first-quarter profit had fallen 35 percent because it had sold securities at a loss and pared its fees for managing assets. Net income was $263 million, or 46 cents a share, compared with $403 million, or 69 cents, a year earlier, before Prudential sold shares in an initial public offering in December. Prudential, based in Newark, said profit dropped because of $96 million in net investment losses and lower earnings from equity-linked products.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CITRON, CASPER
description: CITRON - Casper. Legendary broadcaster. Memorial service Friday, May 10 at 11 AM at NewYork Historical Society, Two West 77th Street at Central Park West. Memorial donations may be made to The Humane Sociey of the US, 2100 L St, NW, Washington, DC 20003. Info, contact 303-777-2242.

description: BROWN-James ''Buster''. NY Committee to Celebrate Tap Dance Day mourns one of the last performing members of the Copasetics. Teacher, choreographer, dear friend, over 70 years a performer. He will be greatly missed.
