title: Pastry Chef, 28, Is Found Dead In an Upper East Side Apartment
description: The police are investigating the death of a 28-year-old Upper East Side woman whose body was found on the floor of her apartment on Monday afternoon. An autopsy was inconclusive, the police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, JERRY
description: SCHNEIDER-Jerry. Age 45. Died May 6, 2002 at home in Brooklyn after a two year struggle with lymphoma. Ever the tireless handyman, Jerry will be missed always by his mother Helen, sister Esther, brother-in-law Franklin, nieces Rebecca and Devorah, and his many friends in Bensonhurst.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  VOLTZ, JEANNE A.
description: VOLTZ-Jeanne A. (1920-2002). Saturday, May 11, at 3:00 PM at Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, W. End Ave. at 86th. Memorial donations to Les Dames D'Escoffier NY Scholarship Fund

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on April 27 about anti-Semitism in the Muslim world misstated the location of the Middle East Research Institute. It is in Washington, not Israel.

title: Suddenly, People Are Thinking Rent
description: Jeff McKay, a media consultant, was jogging toward ground zero three weeks ago when he started seeing ''For Rent'' signs in Battery Park City high-rise buildings. He raced home, called a real estate agent and learned that there were cheap rental deals, not just in Battery Park City but all over Manhattan. In the same call, he found out that the value of his own little penthouse co-op on Perry Street had skyrocketed.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Scout Leader Admits Molesting Boy
description: A former Boy Scout troop leader charged with molesting a boy in his troop on a regular basis in 1996 and 1997 pleaded guilty yesterday to four counts of third-degree sodomy and will be sentenced this summer. Prosecutors recommended a sentence of two years and eight months to eight years for the former scout leader, Jerrold Schwartz. He admitted yesterday in State Supreme Court that he had engaged in sexual intercourse on numerous occasions with the boy in his office at East 80th Street and First Avenue. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: The Sincerest Form of Flattery: The Networks' Self-Commemoration
description: Try not to weep if you missed ''CBS: 50 Years From Television City,'' the network's loving tribute to (get out your handkerchiefs) its studio building. There are plenty more chances to get choked up during this emotional television month. In ''20 Years of Must-See TV,'' NBC will celebrate something dear to the hearts of all viewers, the network's ratings dominance on Thursday nights. (The program doesn't flinch from the traumatic moment when ''Frasier'' moved to Tuesdays.) ABC will look back at ''That's Incredible!'' letting us relive those exhilarating moments that disappeared from our lives back in 1984 along with the show's believe-it-or-not tidbits. We're promised another look at a 2,000-person human domino chain.

title: High Profiles
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Shapely Home for Chips and Dips
description: From the housewares company Wovo and its consultants at Smart Design comes a sculptural hors d'oeuvres server in bright red, blue or white.

title: Two Resorts in Mexico
Slide Show: Sliding Doors (and Walls)
description: Sometimes a room is called upon to do double duty. Adding doors or walls can block out light and air. Lightweight fabric panels, however, are a flexible, decorative way to provide a private corner of calm.

title: Monaco's Grand Prix Fever
Newport, Oregon
Life in Seville
Survivors of Firefighters Ask To Look Into Union Charity
description: A group of widows and families of single firefighters who died on Sept. 11 have asked the New York State attorney general to investigate the main firefighter union's handling of tens of millions of dollars in donations they believe were made to immediately assist the survivors of those lost in the World Trade Center disaster.

title: Abject and Nihilistic but Still Enthusiastic
description: Is Nick Cave a caricature yet? In the years since his brutal postpunk band, the Birthday Party, split up in 1983, he has transformed himself into a gloomy balladeer, chronicling a world of abject lovers and heartless strangers. At the Beacon Theatre on Friday night, he was so starkly lighted that when you looked at his face, all you could see were shadows.

title: A Neglected Law Enforcement Asset
description: State and federal databanks containing DNA profiles of convicted criminals and suspects offer law enforcement officers a powerful new tool for catching sexual assailants with a criminal record and preventing them from striking again. The same databanks can also be used to help establish a person's innocence. But budgetary constraints have hurt the effectiveness of this weapon by limiting the authorities' ability to analyze thousands of semen samples collected from rape victims.

title: A Party-Crashing Teenager Always Gets Into Trouble
description: Everyone knows that high school proms, rampant at this time of year, are a dangerous idea foisted upon us by the formal-wear industry. Yet for generations, parents have looked the other way, dressing up their teenagers like adults and sending them out to indulge.

title: Northrop Suspends TRW Bid Until Autumn
description: Northrop Grumman, the military contractor, has agreed to halt its $12.2 billion hostile takeover bid for TRW, a military and auto parts company, until Sept. 30, while it reviews TRW's financial information, according to a regulatory filing.

title: Pataki Proposes Changes To Rockefeller Drug Laws
description: As protesters in New York and Albany spoke out against the state's harsh penalties for drug crimes today, Gov. George E. Pataki put forward yet another proposal for breaking a deadlock with Assembly Democrats over reducing sentences for drug offenders.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: A Plant of Many Faces

title: Adelphia to Put Some Cable Systems Up for Sale
description: Adelphia Communications said yesterday that it was putting several of its cable systems on the market in an effort to raise cash.

title: Otis Blackwell, 70; Wrote Hits for Presley and Others
description: Otis Blackwell, who wrote ''All Shook Up,'' ''Don't Be Cruel,'' ''Great Balls of Fire,'' ''Fever'' and more than 1,000 other songs, and had a major part in shaping the sound of rock 'n' roll, died on Monday in a hospital in Nashville, where he lived. He was 70.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Maryland Governor Declares Moratorium on Executions
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  A moratorium on executions in Maryland was declared today by Gov. Parris N. Glendening, who decreed that no one would be put to death until completion of a study to determine whether racial bias infects the death penalty in the state.

title: Reason Cited for Ousting Of Terror Inquiry's Director
description: The staff director of the Congressional panel investigating the government's handling of the Sept. 11 attacks was forced to resign last month because he did not alert the committee that he had hired an employee who was being investigated for failing a C.I.A. polygraph exam, government officials said today.

title: Robertson Selling His Horses in Response to Protests From His Followers
description: Reacting to criticism from followers who did not approve of his involvement in horse racing because of its connection with gambling, the Christian Coalition founder Pat Robertson has decided to disband his racing operation.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Return Of Political Gift
description: Facing criticism from some Republicans, the state attorney general, Bill Lockyer, left, a Democrat, said he would return $50,000 in political contributions from the Oracle Corporation to avoid the appearance of a conflict in his office's investigation of a state contract awarded to the software company. It was reported earlier that after the state agreed to a software licensing agreement with Oracle worth an estimated $95 million, a state technology official accepted a $25,000 contribution from the company for Gov. Gray Davis's campaign. The governor, a Democrat, has insisted he knew nothing about the deal with Oracle. James Sterngold (NYT)

title: Qwest Said to Get Several Bids for Yellow Pages Unit
description: Qwest Communications International received at least three offers worth more than $8 billion in the first round of bidding yesterday for its yellow pages business in what could become the biggest leveraged buyout since Kohlberg Kravis Roberts bought RJR Nabisco in 1989, executives close to the auction said.

title: A Garden Learns to Sip, Not Gulp
description: IT may be hard to comprehend the drought on land surrounded by water, but Ken Druse and Louis Bauer are facing the same restrictions in their garden this spring as everyone else in New Jersey.

title: Georgetown and Princeton Favored
description: The N.C.A.A. women's lacrosse tournament begins today with Georgetown and Princeton as the favorites and Yale as the surprise absentee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYONS, BEVERLY
description: LYONS-Beverly. Beloved mother and wife peacefully on Sunday May 5, 2002. Born in Brooklyn on April 16, 1923. Survived by loving husband Dr. Alvin V. Lyons, children Jo-Lynne and husband John Seeger, Richard Green, Daniel Lyons and partner Stanley Cushing, Deborah Lyons and partner Midge Zarling and grandchildren Avery, Emerson, Hanna and Nathaniel. Remembered my many for her smile and good humor, excellence as a dental hygienist, her volunteer work and love of swimming and the ocean. Services will be held at 10AM, May 9th in Chula Vista, CA. Condolences in the form of charitable contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Assn.

title: Nepal Battle Intensifying After Attack On Rebels
description: The warfare between the Royal Nepal Army and Maoist guerrillas has intensified over the past week in the heartland of Maoist-controlled western Nepal, an isolated, mountainous region where battles are being fought many hours' hike from the nearest road.

title: OLIN WILL ACQUIRE CHASE, A MAKER OF BRASS PRODUCTS
description: Chase Industries, a maker of brass rods based in Montpelier, Ohio, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by the Olin Corporation of Norwalk, Conn., in a stock swap that values Chase at 21 percent less than the closing price on Tuesday. Stockholders of Chase will receive 0.64 Olin share for each Chase share. The exchange would give Chase shareholders stock valued at approximately $11.52 a share, based on Olin's closing price of $18 a share on Tuesday. Citicorp Venture Capital, which owns about 48 percent of Chase's shares, has already agreed to vote in favor of the acquisition.

title: INSIDE
description: Rally on Wall Street

title: S.I. Democrats Likely to Pick A Marchi Foe
description: In each election year beginning in 1980, State Senator John J. Marchi has had the distinction of being the candidate not only of his own Republican Party, but also of the Democratic Party on Staten Island. But this year, that pattern appears to be coming to an end.

title: A Garden A Mother Will Love
description: This Mother's Day, anticipating a water shortage, say it with a container garden. The one at right was created by Kathy Pufahl, a container specialist and owner of Beds and Borders, a wholesale grower in Laurel, N.Y. She used an urn with a 16-inch diameter. ''Put a lot of plants in there, as many as you can fit,'' she said. She planted two each of petunia Surfinia miniwhites, Ipomoea margaritas and verbena Apple Blossoms, one each of dusty miller Cirrus, coleus Florida Sunset and Helichrysum petiolare. Fertilize often and prune the helichrysum. The cost of these plants was $64.99 at McArdle's Garden Center, Greenwich, Conn. (203-661-5600), and $57.95 at Marders, Bridgehampton, N.Y. (631-537-3700). For other nurseries with these plants, Bedsandborders.com. LINDA LEE

title: North Koreans Seek Asylum At Consulates In China
description: Seven people tried to barge into consulates in the northeastern Chinese city of Shenyang today, the latest in a string of attempts by desperate North Koreans to gain political asylum by taking refuge in Western diplomatic compounds in China.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSTROVE, LESTER, M.D.
description: OSTROVE-Lester, M.D. Good friend and golf buddy, a truly kind and gentle man. We'll miss his company on and off the golf course. Sam Schwartz and Herb Spiegel

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Irish Guerrillas Sentenced
description: Three members of the renegade Real I.R.A. were sentenced in a London court to 30 years imprisonment each for trying to buy arms in Slovakia for their program of terror aimed at bringing down the Northern Ireland peace plan that the mainstream Irish Republican Army and its political arm, Sinn Fein, support. Declan Rafferty, Fintan O'Farrell and Michael MacDonald were arrested last July by British agents posing as Iraqi arms dealers. The Real I.R.A. carried out the 1998 bombing of Omagh in Northern Ireland, which killed 29 people in the deadliest act in three decades of conflict.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: EasyJet Acquires DBA Option
description: EasyJet, the discount carrier, said yesterday that it had an option to acquire British Airways' German subsidiary, DBA, for about 40 million euros, or $37 million. Under the agreement, EasyJet will pay British Airways 5 million euros in expenses plus an additional 600,000 euros a month until it exercises the option, which expires March 31, 2003, and can be extended until July 3. On Friday, EasyJet said it was in talks to buy Go Fly from 3i, the venture capital firm. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Thursday about the growth of a Senegalese brotherhood of Sufi Muslims known as the Mourides referred imprecisely to one of their practices denounced by traditional Islamic scholars. While the Mourides do pray facing the Atlantic Ocean, away from Mecca, they do so only once a year, not routinely.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGH, AMAR
description: SINGH-Amar, 69. Late of Bryn Mawr, PA; passed away on May 7, 2002. Beloved husband of Sally Singh (nee Sarah Leonard), devoted father of Karun, Sharda, Natasha and Nikhil; also survived by his daughter-in-law, Moira, and his grandchildren, Mikhaela and Gabriella. Family and friends are invited to the Memorial Service on Saturday, May 11th, 2 PM, at Our Mother of Good Counsel Church, 31 Pennswood Road, Bryn Mawr. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be sent to either Haverford College, C/O Ms. Anne Magginis, Annual Giving Secretary, The Haverford Fund, Haverford College Office of Institutional Advancement, 370 West Lancaster Avenue, Haverford, PA. 19041, or to Haverford Cricket Library Association, C/O Ms. Carol Babb, Administrator, The C.C. Morris Cricket Library Association, 370 West Lancaster Ave., Haverford College, Haverford, PA. 19041.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Pavarotti Cancels
description: Luciano Pavarotti, who was scheduled to sing last night in a performance of ''Tosca'' at the Metropolitan Opera, canceled because he has the flu. It was the second-to-last ''Tosca'' performance of the season. Mr. Pavarotti, 66, is expected to sing on Saturday night to end the Met season, and possibly his career in the house. The performance will be relayed to a large screen on the Lincoln Center Plaza, with free tickets available to the public. The tenor Francisco Casanova sang the role of the painter Mario Cavaradossi last night, opposite Maria Guleghina in the title role.

title: Postal Theory: Mail Sorter Acted as Mill For Anthrax
description: Postal investigators say a chance extra run through sorting machines by the anthrax-tainted letter sent last fall to Senator Patrick J. Leahy may explain why its clumps of spores were smaller and more dangerous than those in a letter mailed the same day to Senator Tom Daschle.

title: Lessons From the Mideast Agony
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Arrested for Campaign Sign Removal
description: Four people, including a close aide to Mayor Sharpe James, face criminal mischief charges for removing campaign signs belonging to Mr. James's opponent in Tuesday's election, the police said.

title: From Symantec, Security Tools For Online Users of Mac OS X
description: Apple's OS X operating system, with its attractive interface, has gained plenty of fans since its debut last year. And more users took it to heart when Microsoft shipped its Office X software suite for Macintosh a few months ago.

title: 2 Senior Executives In West Coast Swing
description: Senior executives on the West Coast are changing jobs.

title: Redoubled Grand Slam Succeeds but Loses
description: The prestigious Cavendish Pairs, with 14 countries represented, begins tomorrow in Las Vegas, and as usual there will be a lot of money on the line. The Calcutta Pool, in which players and their supporters invest in the hope of a lucrative payoff, is likely to match the million-dollar total of a year ago. The winners then were the star Polish pair of Jacek Pszczola and Michal Kwiecien, who captured the World Pairs title four years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABINOW, PAULA (SCHERER)
description: RABINOW-Paula (Scherer), 82. May 6, 2002. Loving companion of Samuel Lerner; widow of Marvin Scherer and Irving Rabinow; dear mother of Hannah Scherer and Andrew Scherer, and daughter-inlaw Claudia Slovinsky; cherished grandmother of Maya and Eli Scherer; beloved sister of Ruth Stark and brother-in-law Morton Stark. Service Saturday, May 11, 2002, 3 PM at The Ethical Culture Society, 8 West 64th Street.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: No Bonuses At Allied Irish
description: Executives of Allied Irish Banks will not receive bonuses for 2001, the bank said in its annual report, citing the loss of $691.2 million in five years through fraudulent foreign exchange trading at Allfirst Financial, an American subsidiary. The remuneration committee awarded no bonuses to directors including the chief executive, Michael Buckley, left, who was eligible to receive 250,000 euros ($226,000), or to Frank P. Bramble, head of Allied Irish's American operations, who was eligible to receive 1.3 million euros ($1.18 million). The losses, which were accumulated by a trader in Baltimore, John Rusnak, were discovered in February. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROMMUND, RUDI A.
description: BROMMUND-Rudi A. Of Sagaponack, NY on May 7, 2002 at age 74. Beloved husband of Marlene. Also survived by brothers, nephews, and nieces in Germany. Reposing Friday beginning at 1 p.m. at the Brockett Funeral Home, Inc. 203 Hampton Road, Southampton, NY. Funeral service at the funeral home, Friday at 2 p.m. Private cremation to follow. Memorial donations to East End Hospice, PO Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978 would be appreciated.

title: Legend to Watch a Legend in the Making
description: At the age of 90, the golf legend Byron Nelson has seen many great players come and go. When asked to name the best player he has ever watched, however, Nelson did not hesitate.

title: Vitriol of Newark Campaign Seeps Into Debate
description: In their first and only joint appearance before next Tuesday's election, Mayor Sharpe James and his opponent, Councilman Cory Booker, engaged in a spirited -- and at times mean-spirited -- debate this evening, questioning each other's honesty, integrity and ability to govern while painting starkly different portraits of New Jersey's largest city.

title: Pass a Hate-Crimes Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Editorial Observer; 'The Osbournes,' an American Second Act
description: Back when the Rolling Stones were gamin pups, rock and roll didn't look like an old man's game. Everybody believed in term limits. ''Better to burn out than to fade away,'' wrote Neil Young, one of the handful of artists in his generation, now in its late 50's, who continue to matter. Plenty of rock stars incinerated themselves along the way, for the good of the game, if you like. But the vast majority of them did what the rest of us have done: watch in surprise as each year adds another layer of varnish to the already lacquered past. Even a band like the Stones, who announced their summer tour plans in the Bronx on Tuesday, have turned into a tribute band, performing their old repertoire as if they really were the Rolling Stones, when everyone knows they're not.

title: U.S. Women Roll Over Suriname
description: Striker Kelly Wilson scored five goals Tuesday night as the United States women's Under-19 national team defeated Suriname, 15-0, at Dwight Yorke Stadium in Bacolet, Trinidad and Tobago. Wilson, who plays for the University of Texas, scored a natural hat trick (three straight goals) in a 12-minute span of the first half.

title: WARNACO CREDITORS FIGHT CLAIM BY FORMER CHAIRWOMAN
description: Creditors of the Warnaco Group, the lingerie and clothing company, are fighting a claim by the former chairwoman, Linda J. Wachner, that Warnaco owes her more than $25.1 million. Ms. Wachner was ousted Nov. 16, five months after Warnaco, based in New York, sought bankruptcy protection. Some investors attributed the company's collapse to her management decisions and hefty salary. In January, Ms. Wachner asked the bankruptcy court in Manhattan to award her ''not less than $25.1 million'' as compensation. The company's unsecured creditors' committee and secured lenders, in a joint objection filed yesterday, said that Ms. Wachner bore the ultimate responsibility for Warnaco's performance during her tenure.

title: Mexico Reopens Inquiry
description: The federal election board has reopened an investigation into the financing of President Vicente Fox's 2000 election campaign at the request of the two major political parties that oppose him.

title: Art Sales Bring Strong Prices for a Second Night
description: Sotheby's held a strong sale of Impressionist and modern art last night, with a Czanne still life bringing $16.7 million, a Degas pastel snapped up for $16.5 million and a Giacometti bust sold for $13.7 million. Yet the atmosphere there felt less buoyant than it did at Christie's sale the night before, even though Christie's results weren't as good.

title: Lessons From the Mideast Agony
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing
description: SOFTWARE

title: Filling the Hole in the Sky and the Ache in Hearts
description: IT can happen at the oddest moments; during the final scene, for instance, of ''Trick,'' the lighter-than-air romantic comedy from 1999 that ends as the hero strolls triumphantly down Seventh Avenue South at daybreak.

title: Harris Enjoys Long-Awaited Starring Role
description: The cheers hailing the Nets backup guard Lucious Harris echoed clear across the country to his mother, Nancy, in Los Angeles on Tuesday night.

title: U.S. Attack On Warlord Aims to Help Interim Leader
description: The Central Intelligence Agency, using a missile fired from an unmanned surveillance drone, tried on Monday to kill an Afghan factional leader who has vowed to topple the current government, Pentagon and administration officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 27 about complaints on a change of date for the entrance test for New York City's science high schools misstated the name of one school. It is Brooklyn Technical High School, not Brooklyn High School of Technology.

title: Bomb Suspect Gave Few Hints Of Violent Plan
description: In hindsight, the tiny changes people saw in Lucas J. Helder's behavior still do not seem to add up to danger.

title: New York Times on the Web Gets a New Top Editor
description: New York Times Digital, the Internet division of The New York Times Company , announced today that Leonard M. Apcar would become editor in chief of its flagship Web site, The New York Times on the Web.

title: Campus Court At Harvard Alters Policy On Evidence
description: Harvard College has raised the standard under which it will bring charges against students in its campus court, responding to years of complaints there and at other colleges that students have been put through disciplinary hearings for crimes like sexual assault based on little more than an accusation.

title: F.B.I. Says Pre-Sept. 11 Call For Inquiry Got Little Notice
description: Robert S. Mueller III, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, acknowledged today at a Senate hearing that his agency had paid too little attention to a July 2001 memorandum written by an F.B.I. agent in Phoenix who detected a disturbing pattern of Middle Eastern men attending American flight training schools.

title: Andersen Makes 3 Deals To Sell Parts of Firm
description: Arthur Andersen announced separate deals yesterday with KPMG Consulting, Deloitte & Touche and Ernst & Young to sell various parts of its business, the first of what is likely to be a series of transactions that Andersen rushes to conclude before the criminal case against it goes to a jury.

title: Buster Brown, Tap Master And Charmer, Is Dead at 88
description: Buster Brown, one of the last veteran tap stars who danced together as the Copasetics, died on Tuesday at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. He was 88 and lived in Manhattan.

title: More Men's Teams Benched As Colleges Level the Field
description: Over the next few days, the men's track and field teams at Vermont, Tulane and Bowling Green will be running their final races, bringing to an end both their seasons and the history of their programs. Like the men's indoor track team at Massachusetts, the teams will vanish as budget-trimming administrators bend to the pressure of keeping participation levels of male and female athletes nearly equal, as mandated by federal law.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about preparations by the United Nations for its special session to discuss the needs of children misstated the number who died of preventable diseases in the 1990's. It is estimated at 130 million, not 10 million. The article also misstated the number of countries that met their pledge to devote an average of 0.7 percent of their gross domestic product to development assistance. It is five, not four. (Luxembourg did, along with Denmark, the Netherlands, Sweden and Norway.)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Game Maker In Disney-Pixar Deal
description: The video game maker THQ Inc. has been granted exclusive rights to publish interactive games based on three forthcoming movies from the Walt Disney Company's Disney Interactive and the Pixar Animation Studios unit of Pixar Inc. Under the terms of the deal, THQ of Calabasas Hills, Calif., can publish games based on the movies, ''Finding Nemo,'' ''The Incredibles'' and ''Cars,'' for personal computers as well as for game consoles made by Sony, Microsoft and Nintendo. THQ has already produced popular games for hand-held computers based on other Disney/Pixar movies, including ''Toy Story,'' ''A Bug's Life'' and ''Monsters Inc.'' News of the deal, which runs through 2008, lifted shares of THQ by $3.34, or 10.3 percent, to $35.67. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, ROSE
description: LEVIN-Rose. Died May 7, 2002 in her 99th year; formerly of Far Rockaway,N.Y. Widow of David, survived by her daughter Grayce Perlbinder, her son and daughterin-law Michael and Eileen Levin, her niece Helene Haynes, grandchildren Richard Perlbinder, Mallory and Roger Probert, Lisa Perlbinder and Tom Porter, Sherry and Asher Najer, Linda and Jerry Latman, Alan Rosenberg and eight great grandchildren. Her life was a blessing. Funeral May 9th, 2:30PM, Boulevard Riverside, Broadway, Hewlett, New York.

title: For a Storage-Solutions Company, Plenty of Space
description: USM Modular Furniture, a Swiss company, opened a showroom in SoHo last week designed by Thomas McKay (at far left) of MSM Architects in New York. USM's 1963 Haller modular storage system (in photo) of enameled steel and chrome was just chosen for the permanent design collection of the Museum of Modern Art. The components come in 11 colors, as well as black, white and matte silver, and can be installed as entire wall units. A small piece could serve as a bedside table ($1,300). Also pictured are Ana Bilski, the marketing manager, and Ted Zakowski, the president. USM, 28-30 Greene Street (Grand Street).

title: Children of War in Sierra Leone Try to Start Over
description: He was 14 years old when the rebels seized the capital here, back in 1998, and forced him to join them. A boy with a precocious intensity and frigid self-assuredness, he rose quickly in the ranks and earned the fighting name Poison.

title: Expert Sees No Direct Ties to Skakel in Killing
description: Henry C. Lee, the former head of the Connecticut State Police and a renowned forensic criminologist, testified today that state prosecutors have no direct scientific evidence, like fingerprints or DNA, to connect Michael C. Skakel to the 1975 killing of Martha Moxley.

title: Palestinians Prepare Exit From Church
description: In an elaborately choreographed agreement, more than 100 Palestinians prepared to leave the Church of the Nativity early this morning after a deal was reached to end the five-week standoff at one of Christianity's holiest sites.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: Delaying Tax Refunds
description: To reduce a cash flow problem, the state will indefinitely hold $167 million in income tax refunds from 415,500 taxpayers, state officials said. While other states have delayed income tax refunds by a week or two because of budget crunches, Missouri is the only one to impose such a drastic policy. The state collected $100 million less in income tax revenue than it did last year because of the sluggish economy. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GETRAER, JOSEPH, ESQ.
description: GETRAER-Joseph, Esq. Beth Israel Synagogue of Westport/Norwalk mourns the untimely passing of its beloved member of the Board, Joseph Getraer, Esq. of Greens Farms, Connecticut. A pillar of the Jewish Community and a leading philanthropist supporting our synagogue's Aleph Bet Preschool and Hebrew School, he will be sorely missed by his many friends within our growing congregation. Our condolences are extended to his devoted wife, June, and to his father-in-law, Gary Shulman, and to his son, Andrew, who serves with distinction as the Hillel Director of Rutgers University and to daughter-in-law, Jean, and grandchildren, Sandy, Benjamin, Alexander and Lindsay. Rabbi Yehoshua S. Hecht Spiritual Leader David Beck, M.D. President, Beth Israel Synagogue

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KHADIR, OMAR
description: KHADIR-Omar. On May 7, 2002. Born Nov. 29, 1937 in Casablanca. Lived in New York since 1965. Chief Chef to the Moroccan Ambassador to the UN and to other distinguished people. We will miss his warm charm and good sense of humor. He was a wonderful companion and friend. God bless. Funeral services at Campbell's, Madison Avenue and 81st Street, Friday, 11:30 AM. Philip Hahn

title: Critic's Notebook; Music Infuses the TriBeCa Film Festival
description: ''It's about melody, sensitivity and logic,'' the drummer Dwayne Broadnax says about his boss, the blues singer Jimmy Scott, whose tough but boyish voice and unusual affliction are the subject of the intimate documentary ''Jimmy Scott: If You Only Knew,'' one of the selections of the first TriBeCa Film Festival. Mr. Broadnax's astute line on his employer's approach to music could also be used as a method to program a film festival. And those watchwords (sensitivity and logic especially) are integral to the development of a film festival's personality.

title: SULZER MEDICA SAYS JUDGE APPROVES IMPLANT SETTLEMENT
description: Sulzer Medica A.G.'s $1 billion settlement of defective hip-implant claims was approved by a federal judge yesterday, the company said. Judge Kathleen O'Malley of Federal District Court in Cleveland determined the settlement was fair and reasonable after two days of hearings, a Sulzer spokeswoman said. The accord still may face roadblocks. Plaintiffs have until May 15 to decide whether to opt out of the settlement and pursue individual claims. Sulzer Medica then will have five days to decide whether to withdraw the settlement if too many people reject it. The company's Sulzer Orthopedics unit, based in Austin, Tex., began recalling hip implants in January 2001, saying they may loosen. Of the 31,000 patients who received the implants, more than 2,760 had them replaced.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Solemnity of the Ascension, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Florida Footsteps Of a Harlem Great
description: A police officer who was cruising through a poor section of Fort Pierce on a recent afternoon said he had never heard of Zora Neale Hurston, and he was puzzled when a visitor asked directions to her grave.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Kansas: Errant Judges
description: The Wichita City Council has agreed to pay $2.7 million to settle a class-action lawsuit accusing its municipal court judges of violating the rights of thousands of citizens who were found in contempt of court, jailed or ordered into a city work program for not paying traffic or misdemeanor fines. From 1997 to 1999, the lawsuit charged, the municipal court violated due process rights by ordering people with outstanding fines to appear in court, then to pay or be jailed.

title: Key Test Off Mound for Pettitte
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., May 8  All through spring training, it was Andy Pettitte's mantra: he did not want to be left behind in Tampa, the Yankees' spring training home.

title: MOODY'S CUTS GEORGIA-PACIFIC CREDIT RATING TO JUNK
description: Moody's Investors Service said yesterday that it had cut to junk level the rating on $10 billion in bonds by Georgia-Pacific. Low commodity prices may make it more difficult to reduce debt as the company splits, Moody's said. The rating was cut to Ba1 from Baa3. Georgia-Pacific said on Tuesday that it would split and sell stock in its consumer products and packaging business as part of a spinoff from its building products unit, which is plagued by asbestos liability. Georgia-Pacific has about $13 billion in debt. The consumer products company will take on $8.1 billion to $8.8 billion in debt, assuming the initial offering raises $1 billion to $1.5 billion.

title: Cultivating BlackBerry As a Hybrid
description: A COUPLE of years ago I accompanied my wife to a plastic surgeons' convention. There on the exhibition floor, among the booths hawking surgical instruments, implants and sutures, I came upon the strangest sight: a company selling hands. They were absolutely perfect prosthetic hands, staggeringly realistic even to the touch, complete with fingerprints, pores and tiny hairs. The price: $10,000 each.

title: Stalin's Dreams, Prisoners' Nightmares
description: For an exercise in ludicrous juxtaposition, try watching ''Survivor'' tonight on CBS, then switching over to TLC to hear some real survivors tell their unrelentingly grim stories in ''Gulag,'' a documentary on the Soviet system of forced-labor camps.

title: Franklyn Branley, 86, Advocate Of Improving Science Education
description: Franklyn M. Branley, a persistent advocate for improving science education for children both as the chairman of the Hayden Planetarium and as the author of more than 140 books, died on Sunday in Brunswick, Me. He was 86.

title: In May's Sunshine, A September Chill; Battery Park City Re-emerges Amid Reminders of Attack
description: There are few neighborhoods in New York City where the annual arrival of spring is as palpable as it is in Battery Park City. And there are few neighborhoods, in this equivocating spring of 2002, in which reminders of Sept. 11 remain as hauntingly present.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSWELL, FLORENCE G.
description: ROSWELL-Florence G. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University and its Fisher Landau Center for the Treatment of Learning Disabilities records with profound sorrow the passing of a dear friend and esteemed leader in the treatment of adults & children with learning disabilities. The Florence G. Roswell Learning and Technology Laboratory at our Center stands as testimony to her very special insight and wisdom in helping those with learning disabilities gain new literacy skills and confidence. To her children, Betty and Arthur Roswell, and the entire family, we offer our heartfelt condolences. Yeshiva University Dr. Norman Lamm, President Robert M. Beren, Chairman Board of Trustees Albert Einstein College of Medicine Robert A. Belfer, Chairperson Board of Overseers Dr. Dominick P. Purpura The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Dr. Mary S. Kelly, Acting Director Fisher Landau Center for the Treatment of Learning Disabilities

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Software company shareholders demand a voice on the issuing of stock options. It may be a first.
description: SHOULD the owners of a company be allowed to have a say when a company hands out millions of stock options?

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Trial Starts For Ex-Nazi
description: A Hamburg court has opened the trial of a former Nazi SS officer who is charged with ordering the massacre of 59 prisoners in Italy in 1944. Friedrich Engel, 93, denied having ordered the killings. He was sentenced in absentia to life imprisonment by an Italian court in 1999 for four massacres, and the case came to national attention last year when German television reported that he was living in Hamburg. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Four Days in Ireland
description: The Sheen Falls Lodge, in Kenmare, County Kerry, Ireland, is offering summer three-night packages that include daily buffet breakfast for two and one dinner for two in La Cascade, the hotel restaurant. The rate, good May through August, is about $1,005 to $1,488 per couple, depending on exchange rates. Information in the United States: (888) 947-4336.

title: Towns for the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROONEY, MARJORIE ANNE NEE WEINBERG
description: ROONEY-Marjorie Anne nee Weinberg, 62, of Staten Island. Daughter of the late Margaret and Carl E. Weinberg. Died on May 7. Devoted mother of Erin and Keith and grandmother of Olympia. Marge grew up in Tenafly, NJ and graduated from Trinity College in Washington, DC and Hofstra Law School. She was an attorney admitted in New York and a former President of the Richmond County Bar Association. Reposing at the Meislohn-Silvie Funeral Home, 1289 Forest Ave., Staten Island, Thursday and Friday, 2-4 and 7-9. Funeral service Saturday, May 11, 10 AM, at Trinity Lutheran Church, 309 St. Paul's Ave., Staten Island. If so desired, donations to The Fresh Air Fund would be appreciated.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Unions Expand Strikes
description: IG Metall, Germany's largest industrial union, announced yesterday that it would expand its strikes to eastern Germany as employers continued to reject demands for a 6.5 percent raise. Union members in western Baden-Wrttemberg and eastern Berlin-Brandenburg voted for the strike last week, but so far the one-day rolling strikes have been only in the West. The Gesamtmetall employers federation, which has offered a 3.3 percent raise plus bonuses, said the wider strike would affect the economy. Desmond Butler (NYT)

title: Lessons From the Mideast Agony
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Session Begins to Tally The Perils of Being Young
description: ''We are street children. We are the children of war. We are the victims and orphans of H.I.V./AIDS.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Bank's Profit Rises 6%
description: Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria, the country's second-largest bank, posted a 6 percent rise in first-quarter earnings despite losses in Argentina. Net profit at the bank was 587 million euros ($537 million) compared with 553 million euros in the same period in 2001. BBVA said it still expected a 10 percent rise in annual earnings. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Serious Computing, Big Fun
description: Grid technology -- a mainly software-driven effort to make greater computing power available to individuals via the Internet -- has been nurtured in the nation's supercomputing laboratories. And its early applications have been reserved for serious scientific chores like climate modeling and high-energy physics simulations. But a start-up venture, Butterfly.net Inc., has decided to have a little fun with grids -- in computer games. The company plans to announce today its Butterfly Grid, software development tools and a network for so-called massively multiplayer video games, which can be played by thousands of people at a time. Butterfly.net is not a game publisher. ''We want to be a utility, supplying the infrastructure, everything behind the game,'' said David Levine, chief executive of Butterfly.net. I.B.M. will supply most of the underlying technology for the game grid, which will be demonstrated to the video game industry at the Electronic Entertainment Expo in Los Angeles on May 21. I.B.M. is hoping the game grid will be the first of many business uses for grid technology. ''This is the first ray of light,'' said Scott Penberthy, an I.B.M. vice president. Steve Lohr (NYT)

title: RANGERS CONTACT KINGS' TIPPETT
description: In another move to address their head coaching vacancy, the Rangers contacted Dave Tippett yesterday for an interview with Glen Sather, the Rangers' president and general manager.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: Yale Surgery Accreditation
description: The general surgery residency at the Yale University School of Medicine will lose its accreditation status unless residents' hours are reduced, according to the Chicago-based Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education. The council found that residents were working 100 hours or more a week rather than the recommended 80 hours or fewer, and were on call too many nights a week. Peter N. Herbert, chief of staff and senior vice president for medical affairs at the School of Medicine, said a plan to spend $1 million to hire physician assistants, nurse practitioners and administrative personnel, to reduce residents' hours, has already been approved and will be implemented by July 1, when the program will be again reviewed by the council.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Ithaca: $500 Million In Research
description: Cornell University announced a $500 million initiative in ''new life sciences'' to pursue interdisciplinary research in areas like genomics, neuroscience, basic ecology and environmental science. About $100 million has already been raised, and Cornell expects to hire at least 50 new faculty members and create up to 100 new graduate fellowships. The new project, announced yesterday, builds on Cornell's five-year-old genomics initiative; the university has already announced plans for a new life science technology building to be completed in 2006. Cornell has put together a panel of outside advisers, including Harold E. Varmus, president of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and former director of the National Institutes of Health, to help oversee the new initiative. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: EUROPE MACEDONIA: MINE KILLS NATO SOLDIER An Italian soldier in the NATO peacekeeping force died and a German was seriously wounded when their vehicle hit a land mine in formerly rebel-held territory in Macedonia, the Italian and German defense ministries said. The incident occurred northeast of the city of Tetovo, near the border with Kosovo. The soldier served with the 700-member force deployed in Macedonia after a peace agreement last year between ethnic Albanian rebels and the government. (Reuters)

title: Instant Islam: Trying to Find A Global Faith In the Details
description: In Nigeria, a Muslim lawyer discusses the benefits of recently reinstated Shariah law, strict Islamic injunctions that endorse amputation, stoning and flogging as punishment for crimes like adultery and theft. ''Once Shariah is there, people go to bed without even locking the front door,'' says this man, whose manner is pleasant and reasonable.

title: Spreading by the Web, Pop's Bootleg Remix
description: The song may sound familiar at first, thanks to the unmistakable guitar riff from Nirvana's classic ''Smells Like Teen Spirit.''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Citigroup Buys Lender
description: Citigroup has acquired the Marufuku Company, the consumer finance company, for 60 billion yen ($469 million), adding 200,000 customers to a business that charges interest rates of almost 30 percent and has few defaults. Citigroup is expanding in a lucrative market in consumer financial services in Japan. It also bought the Japanese consumer finance businesses of the Associates First Capital Corporation in 2000 and the Taihei Company, which makes unsecured personal loans, earlier this year.

title: California May Have Had Big Role in Enron's Fall
description: One of the deepest mysteries in the collapse of Enron has been the role that the power crisis in California played in the company's rise and fall.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROBINSON, REBECCA
description: ROBINSON-Rebecca. In loving memory of Rebecca Robinson. We miss you. Love, Aaron, Eefeh, Osborne, Fantei and Jo

title: Group to Inform Drivers of Rights in Searches
description: The Black Ministers Council of New Jersey today announced a campaign to inform minority drivers that they have a right to refuse to submit to so-called automobile consent searches, which have been the focus of the fight over racial profiling.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Accord On Genetic Tests
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and the Burlington Northern and Santa Fe Railway Company announced a mediated settlement in the first lawsuit charging that genetic testing of employees violated federal disabilities law. The commission asserted last year that the railroad had tested, or sought to test, 36 workers who claimed carpal tunnel injuries, without their knowledge or consent. The railroad denies that it violated the disability law, but agreed not to use genetic tests in future medical examinations, and to pay up to $2.2 million to the employees involved.

title: Like a Blinking Chameleon, A Morphing Music Machine
description: What do you get when you ask both electrical engineers and optical engineers to create a new digital audio player? A powerful personal music machine with a glowing exterior, of course.

title: Jersey City Officer Is Shot; Teacher Captures the Suspect
description: A 43-year-old police officer was shot twice and seriously wounded today after he stopped a couple in a Jeep outside a high school at the end of the lunch hour, the authorities said.

title: At Last, Cedar-Lined Places to Unwind Aprs Work
description: IT was only a matter of time before New Yorkers, who have been called every kind of bum, would want to be ski bums too. Not in Aspen or the Alps, but right here. That bottled mountain water you see in every hand is going to people's heads.

title: Can't Stand It? Ban It
description: THE recent decision by a West Side co-op board to ban smoking by new owners and the new stricture by the village of Southampton banning the public hanging of laundry in the front yard should give hope to quality-of-life buffs everywhere. Together they suggest the emergence of a grass-roots movement nudging communities toward that explicitly arcadian atmosphere that was the dream of our forefathers.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Judge Orders Arrest Of Former Oil Chief
description: A federal judge ordered the arrest of the former director of the national oil company, Pemex, in an embezzlement investigation, officials said. Mexico's comptroller general, Francisco Barrio Terrazas, has been investigating allegations that the former director, Rogelio Montemayor, helped divert tens of millions of dollars to the Institutional Revolutionary Party, which ran Mexico from 1929 until 2000. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Tokyo Journal; Death Does Them Part (Wives Make Sure of That)
description: In Japan, where career opportunities for women are few, where divorce can mean a life of hardship and stigma, and where most female names are still formed using a word for child, a woman's independence has always come at a steep price.

title: Being Russell Baker
description: To the Editor:

title: Celebrating With a Giddy Hip-Hop Rant
description: Cee-Lo had no choice but to invent his own style of hip-hop. What else could he do with a voice like that? He wheezes and whinges like a preacher gone berserk, countering slick bursts of oratory with slow, moaning laments. His greasy sing-rapping was featured on two great albums (and one dud) by his group, Goodie Mob, as well as on last year's disc by Dungeon Family, the Atlanta collective that also includes OutKast.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Off-Limits Money
description: The State Legislature, struggling to close a $930 million budget gap for next year, has been stopped by a state court from raiding an education fund for extra money. The Legislature had tried to take $90 million of $120 million committed for upgrading and maintaining public schools next year, but the Arizona Center for Law in the Public Interest sued, and won by arguing that taking money appropriated for the schools was unconstitutional. Legislators plan to fight the suit. James Sterngold (NYT)

title: Metro Matters; Cutting Costs On Security For Giuliani
description: A PREDICAMENT.

title: Technology Briefing | INTERNET: '.Pro' Domain Advances
description: A new domain reserved for professionals, .pro, moved a step closer to reality as the group that oversees the Internet's address system, the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, completed a contract with RegistryPro Inc. to operate the new domain. One of seven new top-level domains to be added to the Internet's address system, .pro will be limited to registrants who certify their professional credentials through a process RegistryPro is developing with various professional associations. RegistryPro is owned by Register.com, a domain name registrar based in New York. The company said it expected .pro addresses to begin functioning by early 2003, at the latest. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: MICHIGAN: TERRORISM WATCH Federal officials are organizing citizens to be on the lookout for terrorists in and around Detroit's waterways. The heavily traveled commercial shipping lanes on the Detroit and St. Clair rivers carry ships to the Great Lakes and beyond. They also mark the border between the United States and Canada. Suspicious activities include small boats that pull up alongside freighters and people who appear to be monitoring or taking photographs of ships or bridges. The program, overseen by the Coast Guard, is already in place in Maine, Illinois and Louisiana.

title: At Least 14 Die in Attack on French Group in Pakistan
description: At least 14 people, most of them French, were killed and more than 20 seriously wounded today when a suicide car-bomber pulled a red Toyota alongside a shuttle bus in front of the Sheraton Hotel in downtown Karachi and exploded it.

title: Radio Patter From the Past: Vintage D.J.'s Rock On
description: THE disc jockey's voice, oddly compelling, comes booming out of the computer speakers as if shot from a cannon. Although the man has a honeyed Deep South accent, the manic pace of his verbal fusillade makes it hard to decipher everything he is saying. After a furiously enthusiastic pitch for ''The Omega Flour Cookbook,'' which ''don't cost you one red copper,'' he cues up a record: ''Hey, here's a record that's getting hot, man: 'Booted,' by Roscoe Garner!''

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Widening Income Gap
description: The income gap between the Seattle metropolitan area and rural Washington is the widest it has been in 30 years, new Census Bureau figures show. King County, which includes Seattle, accounted for 38 percent of the state's wealth. Officials say that while Seattle's technology and dot-com economy rose and then fell in the 1990's, the state's rural economy remained stagnant or declined.

title: Footlights
description: Evergreen

title: An E-Mail Affliction: The Long Goodbye
description: GETTING out of an e-mail exchange ought to be easy: you simply don't answer.

title: Corrections
description: A timeline in Business Day yesterday with an article about the unraveling of Arthur Andersen omitted a label for the dates of defections of international affiliates. The dates shown represented the announcement of deals to join other firms; in some cases the announcements of departures from Andersen occurred days or weeks earlier.

title: Boy, 13, Is Fatally Stabbed With Knife He Drew in Fight
description: A man fighting off a 13-year-old boy who had pulled a knife grabbed it and fatally stabbed him in Brooklyn on Tuesday night, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 18 about the plan for a deposition by Cardinal Bernard F. Law of Boston in a sexual abuse lawsuit referred incorrectly to its unusualness. (The error also occurred in an article on the subject on Tuesday.) Other American cardinals have indeed given sworn statements in legal cases; Cardinal Law is not the first.

title: Bill on Border Security and Immigration Passes in House
description: The House overwhelmingly approved a bill today to increase the security of the nation's borders and to toughen enforcement of immigration laws, clearing the measure for President Bush, who has said he will sign it.

title: 'No Wrestling' Zones
description: The Town of Babylon on Long Island is considering banning backyard wrestling rings.

title: School Board Ousted In Roosevelt by State
description: The state education commissioner, Richard P. Mills, ousted the entire board of the distressed Roosevelt school district yesterday, clearing the way for the first takeover of a local school system in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPENCER, FAITH BARRETT
description: SPENCER-Faith Barrett. On May 7, 2002, at Hospice of Stamford CT Hospital. A native New Yorker, she had homes in Stamford, CT, and Lenox, MA. Loving wife of the late Girard L. Spencer Jr. Beloved mother of Dr. Melissa Young. Sister of James Barrett, of Laguna Niguel, CA, and Barbara Wiener, of Tucson, AZ, niece of Victoria Codiroli, of Clarks Summit, PA. devoted friend of Lloyd D. Schwalb, of Lenox, MA. Memorial Service on Saturday, May 11, 2002, 2:30 P.M. at Christ Church, 17 Sagamore Rd, Bronxville, NY. Telphone Parish House: 914-337-3544.

title: Mets' Farm Club Gets TV Contract
description: The Brooklyn Cyclones, who had a phenomenally successful first season last year playing in Coney Island, will have 10 games televised this season on Fox Sports New York. The games will be called by Curt Menefee, the co-anchor of the MSG Network's revamped ''SportsDesk.''

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Liberty Buys OpenTV Stake
description: Liberty Media, the cable and media company run by John C. Malone, left, has agreed to buy a controlling interest in the interactive television company OpenTV for $185 million in cash and stock. Liberty Media will purchase a 43 percent financial stake and a 87 percent voting stake in OpenTV from MIH Holdings, a company with holdings in the subscription television industry. OpenTV, based in Mountainview, Calif., is one of the largest providers of interactive television software, used in 24 million set-top boxes around the world. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about plans for a complete edition of the letters of Ernest Hemingway referred incorrectly to those addressed to the writer Martha Gellhorn. Excerpts from them have indeed been published. They appear in ''Shadow Lovers: The Last Affairs of H. G. Wells'' (Westview Press, 2001), by Andrea Lynn, which explores Gellhorn's relationships with both Wells and Hemingway.

title: A Frothing Paradise Of Pumps and Steam
description: MY friend Ford's obsessions always have been infectious.

title: 'Dickens' Is to Close
description: ''The Mystery of Charles Dickens,'' a one-man play with Simon Callow, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Belasco Theater, 111 West 44th Street. The show, written by Peter Ackroyd and directed by Patrick Garland, will have run for 20 regular performances and 7 previews.

title: Corrections
description: A drawing credit with an article last Thursday about the court-ordered house arrest of Diana D. Brooks, the former chief executive of Sotheby's, and another with a report in the Currents column on April 25 about discounts on air-conditioners misspelled the illustrator's surname. He is Michael Sloan, not Sloane.

title: Streaming Onto the Movie Screen, With Nary a Scratch
description: THE movie theater experience isn't the same for everyone. Sure, the popcorn is probably comparable in most theaters and the seats are, too, but the quality of the image on the screen can vary. Yet today there is a technology that can bring near-perfect movie quality to theaters everywhere: digital projectors.

title: As Israeli Forces Head to Gaza, End of Church Siege Seems Near
description: JERUSALEM, May 9  Israeli tanks moved towards the Gaza Strip today, reservists were called up and military officials threatened airstrikes in preparation for retaliation following the latest Palestinian suicide bomb that killed the attacker and 15 other people south of Tel Aviv two days ago.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Pornography Sting
description: A state-created Web site designed to look like a child pornography site has led law enforcement officials to more than 200 people in 29 states and 16 countries, said an official with the Department of Law and Public Safety. No charges have yet been filed, said a department spokesman, John Hagerty. The Web site, built in February, contained no illegal material, and said it was ''rebuilding its collection.'' Law enforcement officials announced yesterday that they had searched the homes of many suspects who accessed the site, seizing their computers as evidence. Officials said the suspects could face criminal charges carrying a sentence of 5 to 10 years and a $150,000 fine. Teachers, police officers and students were among those identified as suspects in the sting.

title: Budget Office Says Tax Receipts Fell Sharply, Increasing Deficit
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  The Congressional Budget Office said today that tax receipts through April were $75 billion below its projections, insuring that the federal budget deficit this year will be far bigger than anticipated.

title: The Hidden Price of a Good Deal
description: In the world of electronics and software, the manufacturer typically suggests a sky-high price for its goods. Why? So that the various computer stores and mail-order joints can set their own, much lower prices.

title: Kirch Pay TV Unit Files for Bankruptcy
description: In a move that will affect Hollywood movie studios as well as the world of soccer, the Kirch Group's pay television company filed for bankruptcy today after negotiations with creditors collapsed.

title: At a Cultural Crossroads, Yo-Yo Ma Becomes a Spice Trader
description: One thing that has made Yo-Yo Ma's work so interesting in recent years has been the elevated level of curiosity that he seems to bring to it. He could easily conduct his career as everyone else does -- and as he did until recently -- playing recitals and the big concertos, and recording the cello repertory over and over. But Mr. Ma has been working hard to reinvent the role of the touring virtuoso, at least for himself.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Andersen Reaches Deals To Sell Parts of Its Business

title: Megachurches As Minitowns
description: PATTY ANDERSON and her husband, Gary, found faith where they least expected it -- he on the free-throw line and she swathed in sweats in an aerobics class.

title: House Backs Plan to Store Atomic Waste In Nevada
description: The House voted overwhelmingly today to go ahead with a nuclear waste site at Yucca Mountain in Nevada, brushing off arguments of environmental and terrorist risks.

title: Global Crossing Using Up Cash to Keep Network Going
description: Global Crossing burned through nearly $140 million of its cash in March as it sought to prevent customer defections and keep its 27-country network functioning in a relatively normal fashion, the company disclosed yesterday in a court filing.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Another Journalist Arrested
description: The authorities have arrested a fourth journalist and charged him with publishing false news but charges were dismissed against one. The other three -- two Zimbabweans and an American who works for a British newspaper -- reported accusations made by the opposition party that a supporter had been beheaded by government-backed militants. The journalists and opposition party officials, who say they were misled, have acknowledged that the story was false.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: MEXICO: JUDGE ORDERS ARREST OF FORMER OIL CHIEF A federal judge ordered the arrest of the former director of the national oil company, Pemex, in an embezzlement investigation, officials said. Mexico's comptroller general, Francisco Barrio Terrazas, has been investigating allegations that the former director, Rogelio Montemayor, helped divert tens of millions of dollars to the Institutional Revolutionary Party, which ran Mexico from 1929 until 2000. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: A Before-the-Renovation Sale
description: Alpine Designs, a shop specializing in antique Asian furnishings and decorative objects, has been on Fifth Avenue for 26 years. John Kang, the owner, sells Chinese, Japanese and Thai pieces as well as items from his native Korea. The 8,000-square-foot emporium -- spread out over two floors -- has long been the haunt of decorators and designers. Now, it is about to be renovated, and every one of the more than 1,000 pieces is 50 percent off until June 10. (The store will then be closed until August.) The early-19th-century pewter and wood chest from northern Korea above is now $1,500. The 19th-century wood vessel from Thailand, on the left of the chest, is $550. Wall hangings are $500 to $1,000. The shop is at 230 Fifth Avenue (26th Street); (212) 532-5067.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Baltic Fleet To Shrink
description: The navy will slash nearly half the work force of its Baltic Fleet as part of a broader plan to cut costs and end conscription by shrinking the nation's military, the chief of the fleet, Adm. Vladimir Blauev, told the Interfax news service. The 19,000-sailor fleet will lose 8,600 positions, he said. The Kremlin hopes to build a far smaller but more modern military to replace the current one, which has been forced since the collapse of the Soviet Union to reduce training, mothball equipment and cut benefits. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Sentenced In Kidnapping
description: A man who held a police detective at gunpoint for more than three hours inside an Upper East Side station house this year pleaded guilty to kidnapping yesterday, and was sentenced to 25 years to life in prison. During a hearing in State Supreme Court, the man, Adrian V. Leibovici, of Rego Park, Queens, apologized and asked for forgiveness from the detective, Michael Ahearn, a 14-year veteran. Also, in an unusual move, Mr. Leibovici asked the judge to impose the maximum sentence. He said that would satisfy everyone involved, including himself. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: CARDINAL LAW SAYS PEDOPHILE MATTER WAS LEFT TO AIDES
description: Answering questions under oath for the first time about what he knew and did in the case of a pedophile priest, Cardinal Bernard Francis Law said today that he was aware of accusations against the priest as early as September 1984 but that he turned the matter over to his top aides and never followed up to learn specifically what they did.

title: Expanding Free Trade
description: President Bush, who managed to ram an important free-trade bill through the House by a one-vote margin, now has a chance to get it through the Senate and into law. To do it he will have to throw his weight behind a useful Democratic proposal aimed at softening the impact of trade agreements on workers who lose their jobs.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: The Bronx: Ex-Counselor Pleads Guilty
description: A former counselor at a Bronx juvenile detention center yesterday confessed to using teenage girls in a prostitution ring, said the Bronx district attorney, Robert T. Johnson. The counselor, Everton Duncan, 35, pleaded guilty to four counts of third-degree promotion of prostitution and one count of endangering the welfare of a child. An undercover police detective testified that Mr. Duncan had agreed to provide six 16- and 17-year-old girls for sex at a bachelor party. Mr. Duncan is scheduled for sentencing June 18. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: CVS REPORTS 21% DROP IN FIRST-QUARTER PROFIT
description: First-quarter profit for the CVS Corporation, the second-largest drugstore chain, fell 21 percent as it lowered prices and increased advertising. Net income fell to $175.7 million, or 43 cents a share, from $221.7 million, or 54 cents, a year earlier, the company said. Sales rose 11 percent, to $5.97 billion. The chief executive, Tom Ryan, is using lower prices, coupons and television advertising to try to woo customers who were lost to rivals including Wal-Mart Stores Inc. when the company reduced hours last year because it did not have enough pharmacists. Shares rose $1.91, to $35.53.

title: Senate Passes Major Expansion of Farm Subsidies
description: The Senate today passed and sent to the White House an election year farm bill that greatly increases spending on agriculture and reverses a six-year-old decision to wean farmers from subsidies.

title: Economic Scene; In accounting for options, knowing about diluted earnings is a powerful tool.
description: THEY say economists are people who are good with numbers, but don't have the personality necessary to be accountants. Well, economists will have to start working on their personalities, since some of the thorniest economic policy issues these days involve accounting.

title: Democrats Sense Gov. Bush Of Florida Could Be Beaten
description: Sensing vulnerability in Gov. Jeb Bush's re-election bid, state Democratic Party leaders are pressing Mr. Bush to act more forcefully in the case of Rilya Wilson, the 5-year-old girl who disappeared while under state supervision.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: So Long, Folks. Glad We Had This Time Together, but Stardom Beckons.
description: Carol Burnett is entertainment royalty, and ''Hollywood Arms,'' a play drawn from her 1986 autobiography, ''One More Time,'' has the sheen of the official story. Written by Ms. Burnett and her daughter Carrie Hamilton, it's a proverbially bittersweet tale set in the low-rent shadow of the Hollywood hills, about a dysfunctional but well-intended family and the sweet-tempered, responsible girl who grew up to become a star.

title: Hornets Face Home-Court Disadvantage
description: Having been a part of the National Basketball Association for nearly 40 years, Paul Silas knows that players garner energy, intensity and adrenaline from raucous home crowds. So when asked today what type of fan turnout he expected for Game 3 of the Charlotte Hornets' Eastern Conference semifinal series against the Nets, Silas responded with hope rather than reason.

title: A Telescoping Table Lends Relief to Rumpled Laps
description: Traveling laptop users may note that the lap doesn't always work well as a desk. A long session can leave it hot and sweaty. The Table Tote, a lightweight, portable desk from PC Tables, offers the lap a breather.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Lap Belts On School Buses
description: Officials from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration told Congress that requiring lap belts on large, new school buses would have ''little, if any, benefit in reducing serious-to-fatal injuries'' in head-on crashes. Though recommending against requiring seat belts in most buses, safety officials conclude that lap belts would probably be beneficial on smaller buses, which are more prone to rollovers than larger buses. Jacques Steinberg (NYT)

title: Ned Rorem Limns the World of Loss
description: ''Another Sleep,'' Ned Rorem's new song cycle, is a memorial for Jim Holmes, Mr. Rorem's companion of more than 30 years, who died in 1999. It's so open and so personal that on one level all you can do is embrace it and be moved by it. It consists of 19 songs with lyrics by a range of poets, ''sewn together,'' in Mr. Rorem's words, and includes three songs the composer wrote in the late 1940's. The poetry is various, but the message, in this context, is unambiguous: the themes are loss and death and the gray emptiness of surviving alone.

title: CORNING'S LONG-TERM DEBT RATING IS LOWERED
description: Moody's Investors Service said yesterday that it had cut the long-term date rating of Corning to Baa3, the lowest investment grade, from Baa1. Corning makes fiber for optical networks. The rating cut reflects ''growing concern that the recovery in the company's telecommunications operations will be delayed until well into 2003,'' Moody's said. A reduction to junk status is possible.

title: Remembering the Johnson Treatment
description: Publication of Robert Caro's magisterial ''Master of the Senate'' -- it is the third volume in his biography of Lyndon Johnson and covers 1949 to 1960 -- has reignited interest in the singular man who gave us the great Civil Rights Act of 1964 -- and then Vietnam. Mr. Caro concludes from long and deep study that when Johnson's vivid sense of compassion came into conflict with his powerful ambition -- he wanted not just to be president but to surpass his hero, Franklin D. Roosevelt -- ambition won out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERGER, FANNY

title: G.E. CHIEF SAYS COMPANY MAY MEET EARNINGS GOALS
description: The chief executive of General Electric said yesterday that the company was on track to meet its earnings goals for the year. But the company will face pressure over the next several years because of lower gas turbine sales, said the executive, Jeffrey R. Immelt. He said the company was on track to earn more than $16.5 billion, or $1.65 to $1.67 a share, for 2002, excluding accounting changes. The company also remains comfortable with analysts' 2003 earnings projections calling for double-digit earnings growth. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call expect earnings of $1.65 a share in 2002 and $1.82 in 2003.

title: As McGreevey Unveils a Plan For New Arena, Critics Scoff
description: Taking on a project that eluded two of his predecessors building an arena for the New Jersey Nets and Devils in Newark -- Gov. James E. McGreevey announced the outlines of a new financing plan today that he said would not put taxpayers at risk if revenue from the project slowed or dried up.

title: 34, Including 12 Children, Killed as Bomb Rips Military Parade
description: MOSCOW, May 9  A bomb stuffed with bolts and nails and hidden in roadside bushes ripped through a military parade in southwest Russia today marking the end of World War II. At least 34 people died, including at least 12 children, Russian television reported, and another 130 were hospitalized.

But as the lights went up, the spectators were reminded that they were not in Florida but in Southern California, watching an extraordinarily vivid videotape of a launching projected on a large, wide-screen display.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Amcor Buys Bottler
description: Amcor announced yesterday that it would buy the bottling assets of Schmalbach-Lubeca, now owned by the German insurance giant, Allianz, for 2.88 billion Australian dollars or $1.55 billion. Amcor said the purchase would make it the world's largest producer of plastic soft drink bottles. It said it would issue equity and debt to finance the deal and would exercise its option to sell its 45 percent stake in Kimberly-Clark Australia back to its American parent for $379 million. Desmond Butler (NYT)

title: Shades of an Overshadowing Kind
description: ''Shades are the new light fixtures,'' said Fernando Santangelo, the designer at Trans.Luxe, a custom lampshade company in SoHo. ''They are no longer just an accessory to a lamp. Shades can be hung from the ceiling as a fixture.'' Sandra Santos, the owner of the shop, makes the shades by hand in her basement workshop under the store, which opened this winter. Trans.Luxe has metal frames in many shapes; they can be adapted to all kinds of needs and tastes. Fabrics include linens, silks and cottons in solids, stripes and patterns, and there are numerous French papers in many textures and colors. You can also supply your own fabric. A small fabric shade starts at $30. The lantern-shape silk lampshade, used as a ceiling fixture above (foreground), is 20 inches in diameter and costs $300. Trans.Luxe is at 10 Greene Street (Canal Street); (212) 925-5863.

title: Desperation Breeds Reform
description: New York State's budget process has long been a public embarrassment. Now, however, the shame has finally spread to the Legislature itself. As state leaders began working on this year's budget in earnest this week, the Senate majority leader, Joseph Bruno, stormed out of one session and declared the entire budget process ''dysfunctional.'' To show his displeasure, Mr. Bruno marched over to the Senate, which he controls, and got his colleagues to pass 10 budget reform measures, some of which have been gathering dust for years. For anybody longing for a better government in Albany, for a budgeting system at least as efficient and transparent as the one in the United States Congress, this was an encouraging moment.

title: Mr. Atta Goes to Prague
description: In pro football, an adept offensive lineman tricks his opponent in what is called a ''misdirection play.'' He blocks his man toward the center; as the defender pushes back hard, the misdirecting lineman gives way, seemingly overcome by the counter-charge -- as his running back scoots through the hole near the center left by the defender.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ NARDI, SHULAMIT
description: SCHWARTZ NARDI - Shulamit. Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, mourns the passing of a lifelong Zionist and Hadassah activist. From 1931-1933, she served as national president of Junior Hadassah. In 1934, she emigrated to Israel, where she worked closely with Henrietta Szold on Meir Shefeyah, Hadassah's youth village. In the 1940s, she served as editor of the Hadassah newsletter, the forerunner to Hadassah Magazine. In March, 2002, she received Hadassah's prestigious Women of Distinction Award at a Knesset ceremony. She leaves behind an extended family in Israel and in the U.S. May they be comforted among the mourners of Jerusalem and Zion. The family has asked that contributions in her memory be made to Meir Shefeyah, C/O Hadassah, 50 West 58th Street, New York City 10019. Bonnie Lipton, National President

title: Soriano Homers Twice And Yanks Flex Muscle
description: The Tampa Bay Devil Rays have the lowest payroll in baseball; the Yankees have the highest. The Devil Rays are the youngest team in the American League; the Yankees are the oldest. The Devil Rays have lost 13 games in a row; the Yankees have not done that in 89 years.

title: Franco Faces Further Elbow Surgery or Retirement

Franco walked so languidly that he seemed to want to absorb every element of another sunny day at the ballpark. By then, Franco realized something was seriously wrong with his left elbow. A few hours later, he knew that his prosperous, overachieving 18-year major league career was in jeopardy.

Like many obsessed spring cleaners, the customer wanted to get her house in order but wasn't sure how. Steered toward another aisle, she found file folders and bookshelves and, restored to calm, left.

title: In Washington, a New Hotel With a Well-Lettered Past
description: The neoclassical streetscapes of Washington were created in part by the 19th-century architect Robert Mills, who also designed the Washington Monument. In the 1830's he filled entire blocks with colonnaded government office buildings. Those long stone temples were exhausting to navigate, however, making them inefficient workplaces. By 1996 one of his masterpieces, the marble post office on F Street, right, seen in an 1846 daguerreotype, had been shuttered. On June 15 the post office will reopen as the 184-room Hotel Monaco, above. Because the building is a National Historic Landmark, the Kimpton Hotel and Restaurant Group, which leases it, was not allowed to make significant changes during the $34 million renovation. Mills's vaulted ceilings and the spiral staircases were restored. The bathrooms were designed as removable modules, in case the building is ever restored to its original form, and the upholstered headboards, above, are not attached to the walls. Each room will have a plaster bust of Thomas Jefferson on its mahogany armoire. ''He's the patriarch of American architecture, and he was a good friend of Robert Mills,'' Cheryl Rowley, the hotel's interior designer, said. Almost all of Kimpton's 36 boutique hotels are in historic structures, but, said Thomas LaTour, chairman of the Kimpton group, ''I don't have any other drop-dead buildings.'' The introductory room rate starts at $169 a night; the hotel is at 700 F Street N.W.; (877) 202-5411. EVE M. KAHN

title: Losses and Injuries Mounting, the Mets Fall to the Giants

Their grip on first place in the National League East has become tentative; they are now tied with Florida. They are not scoring many runs, with only five in the last four games. And there was additional bad news surrounding their 8-2 loss to the San Francisco Giants last night in chilly Shea Stadium before 29,267 fans.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: City Official Under Scrutiny
description: The New York City Department of Investigation is looking into whether the chairman of the Health and Hospitals Corporation, Richard T. Roberts, spent public money improperly two years ago when he was leading the board of another public corporation, officials said yesterday. Mr. Roberts came under scrutiny after The Village Voice reported that as chairman of the Housing Development Corporation he had charged $25,000 to an agency credit card for meals, a trip to Germany and a visit to a New Orleans strip club. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Mr. Roberts should remain in his post until the inquiry is complete. A spokesman for Mr. Roberts said that he would not comment because of the investigation. Michael Cooper (NYT)
