description: One man walked out of the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem before dawn this morning, signaling the beginning of the end of a five-week siege that imprisoned about 150 people, including Palestinian gunmen, priests and nuns, with little food or water.

The wooden pews are splintered, the statue of Jesus smashed to pieces. The floor is covered with blood and maggots, evidence of the worst loss of civilian life in a single day in Colombia's seemingly endless civil conflict.

The program, overseen by the Coast Guard, is already in place in Maine, Illinois and Louisiana.

title: 422 Saves Take Toll on a Left Arm

He was about to throw the most important pitch of his endless career to Barry Bonds and Franco did not want to fire a fastball. Franco wanted to throw a changeup. A true closer knows that he should never lose with his second-best pitch.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Denmark: Carlsberg Plans Buyback
description: Carlsberg A.S., which owns 60 percent of the Danish brewing giant, Carlsberg, has announced a share buyback of $120 million and reported an increase in first-quarter profits to 439 million kroner ($54 million) up from 144 million kroner ($17.7 million) a year earlier. The company said it expected profits to rise 15 percent in 2002 rather than an earlier forecast of 10 percent to 12 percent. The improved outlook reflects booming sales in Eastern Europe, which surged 74 percent. Desmond Butler (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUCOIN, KEVYN
description: AUCOIN-Kevyn. The Board of Directors and staff of the American Foundation for AIDS Research (amfAR) mourn the loss of our cherished friend and longtime volunteer and supporter Kevin Aucoin. A preeminent master of makeup artistry, Kevyn was celebrated for his uniquely understated and creative style. As an activist, Kevyn also searched for ways to exert powerful, transformative change. We salute his steadfast commitment to fighting intolerance and injustice on all fronts and are grateful for his spirited work on behalf of AIDS research and his generous support of amfAR over the years. We fondly remember Kevyn's great personal warmth and exuberant approach to life, as we extend our heartfelt condolences to his partner Jeremy Antunes and to his entire family. Mathilde Krim, Ph.D., Founding Chair and Chairman of the Board Jerome J. Radwin, CEO American Foundation for AIDS Research

title: Hall's Inductees Include Olympians
description: Summer Sanders, Jill Sterkel and Mel Stewart, Americans who won Olympic gold medals, will be inducted Saturday night into the International Swimming Hall of Fame in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Sanders swam the butterfly and the individual medley, Sterkel swam freestyle sprints and Stewart swam the butterfly.

title: After Shootings, Germany Seeks to Ban Violent Computer Games
description: Responding to the deaths of 16 people in a school shooting last month in Erfurt, the German government has said it wants to give regulators the right to ban violent computer games. The proposal has been added to a long-planned youth protection bill and follows announcement of a plan to toughen gun-control laws approved just before the killings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROLL, DR. FREDERIC.
description: ROLL-Dr. Frederic. April 29, 2002. Husband of Christine (nee Opolos) of Philadelphia. Relatives and friends are invited to memorial services Monday, May 13, 12 noon, the Community Room at the Philadelphian, 2401 Pennsylvania Avenue, Philadelphia. Interment private. Joseph Levine and Son.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Teenager Faces Murder Charge
description: Detectives in Brooklyn have charged a 16-year-old in the killing last month of a man outside a liquor store, the police said yesterday. An off-duty City Correction Department captain was also wounded in the episode on April 29 outside the store at the corner of Halsey Street and Reed Avenue in the Stuyvesant Heights section of Brooklyn, the police said. The 16-year-old, DeJuan Brown of 11 Kingston Avenue, was charged Tuesday with second-degree murder in the death of Darryl Jones, 35. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Rumsfeld Sets Up Showdown Over Weapon
description: Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld set the stage today for a Capitol Hill showdown with the formal announcement that he would ask Congress to cancel the $11 billion artillery system known as the Crusader.

description: For the second consecutive year, Connecticut lawmakers have been forced to extend their annual legislative session, because of an impasse between Democrats, who control the Legislature, and John G. Rowland, the Republican governor, over how to spend a $500 million increase in the state budget.

title: Sehorn Works to Regain His Health and His Form
description: The Giants' huddle would break, cornerback Jason Sehorn would fan out to take his position across the line of scrimmage from the wide receiver he was assigned to cover. Gradually, as last season progressed, the distance between Sehorn and the receivers widened before the snap of the ball.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Agency.com, New York, was reorganized into two operating divisions, to be headed by two top executives. Don Scales, president for the Western region, was promoted to chief executive for North America, and Eben Lenderking, president for Europe, was promoted to chief executive for Europe. They will continue to report to Chan Suh, chairman and chief executive at Agency.com, which is majority-owned by Seneca Investments.

description: In today's risk-averse investing climate, it is hard to conceive that a cluster of debt-ridden, recently bankrupt companies could come together and make a wildly successful debut on Wall Street.

description: ''I gave my orders and directions to all the Palestinian security forces to confront and prevent all terror attacks.''

title: Suicide Planner Expresses Joy Over His Missions
description: The slight, bearded Palestinian prisoner, dressed in a tan shirt and sweat pants, spoke evenly about how he had sent suicidal attackers to kill Israelis, recalling his satisfaction when their missions were accomplished.

title: A Shapely Home For Chips and Dips
description: From the housewares company Wovo and its consultants at Smart Design comes a sculptural hors d'oeuvres server in bright red, blue or white. Created by the same people who came up with those ergonomic Oxo kitchen utensils, the 8 1/2-by-17-inch Twist Bowl is made of indestructible plastic and at $13 reflects Wovo's mission to bring good design to inexpensive everyday products. The idea for the single twist occurred to Scott Henderson, Smart Design's director of industrial design, while he was playing with modeling clay. Mr. Henderson conveyed the whimsy of his discovery by giving the server, rendered using 3-D computer software, a ribbonlike asymmetry. The Twist Bowl will be at Bloomingdale's in a few weeks, at the MoMA Design Store and Crate & Barrel this summer, and at Bed Bath & Beyond come fall. PILAR GUZMAN

title: Euro RSCG Partner Is Stepping Down
description: Jon White, a founding partner at the agency now known as Euro RSCG Tatham Partners Salt Lake City, is retiring, the agency said, to spend more time with his family. No successor is being named.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 18 about the plan for a deposition by Cardinal Bernard F. Law of Boston in a sexual abuse lawsuit referred incorrectly to its unusualness. (The error also occurred in an article on the subject on Tuesday.) Other American cardinals have indeed given sworn statements in legal cases; Cardinal Law is not the first.

title: Too Early To Panic, But Lakers Are Shaky
description: During the regular season, when the Los Angeles Lakers, the two-time defending N.B.A. champions, displayed a surprising tendency to come up short against some of the league's weaker teams, there was no reason for them to panic.

title: Dividing And Conquering
description: SOMETIMES a room -- whether a loft, a cramped studio or an expansive suburban den -- is called upon to do double duty. Adding doors or walls can block out light and air. Lightweight fabric panels, however, are a flexible, decorative way to provide a private corner of calm.

title: White House Proposes New View of Education Law to Encourage Single-Sex Schools
description: The Bush administration is planning to reinterpret the nation's education law to encourage the creation of single-sex public schools, which had been largely denied federal financing under 30 years of Republican and Democratic administrations. The schools had also been open to discrimination lawsuits under the statute's current interpretation.

title: Seeking a Higher Authority
description: The most assertive aspect of book publishing these days seems to be the selling of the incorporeal: connectedness to God, wellness, perfection of the spirit. This wave has been building for a while now, but two recent events showed that it has become a tsunami.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Trial To Proceed
description: A federal judge in Northern California yesterday denied two motions to dismiss the prosecution of a Russian software company charged with violating a digital copyright law, clearing the way for a trial. Judge Ronald M. Whyte ruled that the Digital Millennium Copyright Act of 1998 is neither unconstitutionally vague nor a violation of free speech, as lawyers for the company, ElcomSoft, had argued. The federal government has charged ElcomSoft with violating the act for selling a program that allowed people to disable encryption software from Adobe Systems that is used to protect electronic books. Lawyers for ElcomSoft, which faces one charge of conspiracy and four charges of trafficking in technology for use in copyright circumvention, are to appear in court on May 20 to set a trial date. The case drew attention after an ElcomSoft employee, Dmitry Sklyarov, was arrested at a computer hackers convention in July. The government has since dropped its case against him in exchange for his testimony. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Political Memo; Party Chiefs Back McCall Over Cuomo In Primary
description: H. Carl McCall, a Democratic candidate for governor, walked up the steps of City Hall this week to present the latest elected officials who are supporting his candidacy: all four Democratic borough presidents from New York City. By the count of Mr. McCall's campaign -- and it is keeping count -- he has by last night been endorsed by more than 450 New York State mayors, City Council members, county executives, United States representatives and members of the Assembly and Senate.

Visiting hours at the Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Avenue, Pelham, NY, on Thursday from 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Catharine's Church, Pelham, on Friday at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory to United Way of Westchester, 336 Central Park Avenue, White Plains, New York 10606.

title: The Modern Use of Ancient Lies
description: As Jews view the demonic images of themselves that are circulating in the Middle East today, they have a sickening sense of dj vu. The strain of anti-Semitism that has taken hold in the Arab world, particularly since Sept. 11, is especially hateful. When Western commentators take note of this phenomenon they tend to ascribe it to a ''medieval mentality'' in the Muslim world. Yet a look at the anti-Semitic imagery sweeping much of the Arab world shows something quite different.

title: Excerpts From Cardinal Law's Deposition in a Sex Abuse Suit
description: Following are excerpts from Cardinal Bernard F. Law's deposition yesterday in Superior Court in Boston in a lawsuit by 86 people who said they had been sexually abused by a Roman Catholic priest, the Rev. John J. Geoghan, as released by the court reporter. A full transcript is available at nytimes.com/national.

title: 9/11, a Man Went to Work. His Fate Is a Mystery.
description: Juan Lafuente, a laconic Cuban immigrant, lived in the shadow of his prominent wife, Colette, mayor of the city of Poughkeepsie. Friends remember him as a shy creature of habit, a man who made repairs around the house, mowed the lawn, cared for the old Volvo and was devoted to his four grown daughters.

Paid Notice: Deaths  KEEGAN, ROBERT E.
description: KEEGAN-Robert E. Of the Bronx, died on May 8, 2002. Robert was a former Secretary of the Committee on Character & Fitness, Appellate Division First Department. He is survived by his beloved wife, Yvonne; his children, Gary, Glenn, and Nancy; and grandchildren Stacy, Zachary, and Morgan. Visiting will be at the Flynn Memorial Home, Yonkers, NY, on Friday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass, St. Barnabas Church, Bronx, Saturday at 9:45am. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne NY.

title: ANALYST'S REPORT SENDS SHARES OF EDISON DOWN 40%
description: Stock in Edison Schools Inc., the operator of public schools, fell 40 percent yesterday after an analyst downgraded the stock. The analyst, Mark Marostica at U.S. Bancorp Piper Jaffray, said he expected the shares to trade at $3 each. His previous 12-month forecast was $32. Edison's shares fell $1.48, to $2.22. Shares of Edison, based in New York, had fallen 71 percent since the company was selected last month to run 20 of Philadelphia's worst-performing schools, fewer than half the number sought. Officials from Edison could not be reached for comment. The company, which has been losing money, is scheduled to release its earnings next week.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Rebels' Cease-Fire Rejected
description: After a week of intense fighting between Maoist rebels and government security forces in Maoist strongholds, the rebel leader, Pushpa Kamal Dahal, declared a monthlong cease-fire, but Prime Minister Sher Bahadur Deuba promptly rejected it, saying the Maoists betrayed him last year when they broke off peace talks. ''Unless they lay down their arms and renounce violence, we can't trust them anymore,'' Mr. Deuba told CNN. He is in the United States seeking military aid to help crush the insurgency.

title: Accidents (or Medals) Galore, Just Waiting to Happen
description: The very end of the credits for ''ESPN's Ultimate X'' gives special thanks to Michael Bay and Jerry Bruckheimer, the director and producer responsible for ''Pearl Harbor,'' ''Armageddon'' and ''The Rock.'' They probably wish they had filmed those movies in the eight-miles-high style of this Imax sports documentary. Mr. Bay might well be thanked here, since much of the crew also worked on ''Pearl Harbor,'' though he has shot his share of television commercials filled with the white-knuckled athleticism of X-Games.

title: From Old Masters to Modern Masters
description: The Seventh Regiment Armory was built to hold tanks, not old master paintings. But this shabby-genteel Park Avenue hulk has long been home to the city's top art fairs and was much missed when claimed for use by the National Guard after Sept. 11. Scheduled events had to scramble for new quarters, with some less than happy results, including a Winter Antiques Show that looked hectic and anemic at the New York Hilton. But all's well now. The armory is available again, and one of its star attractions, the International Fine Art Fair, is right where it should be this spring.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: ''American Psycho'' was, among other things, a wicked cinematic catalog of next-wave Manhattan restaurants. Too bad it came too soon to include industry(food). The name, all lower case and fused with parentheses, is militantly anti-sensual. The decorating scheme suggests an Adirondacks camp as seen through the lens of madness. Ramps leading to a boathouselike back dining room and a lower-level dining room that feels like a pit, add to the general sense of dislocation.

title: Taiwan's Leader Proposes a Delegation as an Overture to China
description: In an unexpected peace overture to Beijing, President Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan proposed on Thursday to send an informal delegation from his ruling Democratic Progressive Party to China late this summer.

title: When Will New York Correct Its Mistake?
description: This week marks the beginning of the 30th year of the injustice in New York State's penal system from the enactment of the Rockefeller drug laws. These laws have been roundly criticized as ineffective and wasteful. Ineffective because they have done little to stem the flow of drugs into our communities, wasteful because they are responsible for the warehousing of thousands of New Yorkers in expensive prison cells when community-based drug treatment would serve them better.

title: One City Reading One Book? Not if the City Is New York
description: A campaign to persuade the citizens of New York to read the same book all at once has dissolved amid a split between factions of its organizing committee over which book to recommend.

title: Kings Put Mavericks Away With Dominant 4th Quarter
description: Bulging leads came and went, rolling by like tumbleweeds in a dust storm. If Chris Webber and Doug Christie learned anything about the Dallas Mavericks this week, they knew they would get up from the dirt and fire back.

title: Gay Pastor's History of Abuse Shocks a South Dakota City
description: Though it was never meant to be a secret, the Metropolitan Community Church of the Black Hills, which serves a gay and lesbian congregation, existed in relative obscurity in this community of 60,000.

title: Making It All Up As She Goes Along
description: Which of us hasn't been suckered by a fantasist spouting the sort of tantalizing tales of globe-hopping adventure that the title character of the British comedy ''Janice Beard'' dishes out to anyone who will listen? A young Scottish woman who moves to London in hopes of making enough money to pay for the treatment of her seriously agoraphobic mother, Janice claims to have lived everywhere and done everything, although she has actually gone nowhere and done nothing.

title: Bush Wins Latest Round in Legal Battle on Civil Rights Panel
description: A three-judge appeals court panel ruled unanimously today that President Bush had properly appointed a new member to United States Civil Rights Commission.

title: Back to Buff the Tarnish Off the Finance Dept.
description: FOR a shy gal from Brooklyn who inherited a sizzling scandal along with the expansive office that is the province of New York City's finance commissioner (and a favored locale of ''Law & Order'' episodes), Martha E. Stark projects her fair share of extroverted poise. Her bone-rattling handshake is beyond robust; her teeth and dimple flash like neon, no lawyerish equivocation here. This must be how a person with a crush on her job behaves.

description: ASIA NEPAL: REBELS' CEASE-FIRE REJECTED After a week of intense fighting between Maoist rebels and government security forces in Maoist strongholds, the rebel leader, Pushpa Kamal Dahal, declared a monthlong cease-fire, but Prime Minister Sher Bahadur Deuba promptly rejected it, saying the Maoists betrayed him last year when they broke off peace talks. description: Doughnuts may not be quite as American as, say, apple pie, but they come close enough to make Samir Nasier, a Saudi fast-food king, nervous.

title: Girl, 15, Is Raped at School
description: A 16-year-old boy was arrested yesterday and charged with raping a 15-year-old girl in a stairwell of Thomas Jefferson High School in the East New York section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOHF, KENNETH A.
description: LOHF-Kenneth A., 77. On May 9, 2002 after a brief illness. He is survived by his companion of many years, Paul Palmer, and three nephews, Gerald K. Freitag, Ronald Freitag and Donald J. Freitag, of Franklin, Wisconsin. Director for 25 years of Columbia University Rare Book and Manuscript Library; President of the Grolier Club 1990-1994 and member since 1961; long time Fellow and Patron of the Morgan Library; vestry member of St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue and Chairman of the St. Thomas Choir School Committee; supporter and board member of numerous other cultural organizations and noted collector of books and works of art and a much published poet. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Nissan Turns Attention to Its Vehicles
description: Having taken Nissan Motor from near bankruptcy to record profits in three years, the company's president, Carlos Ghosn, laid out a strategic plan for the company today that he said would elevate it ''from a good company to a great company.''

title: I.B.M. Likely To Eliminate 9,000 Jobs
description: Reflecting the continued weakness in technology spending and shifts in its mix of businesses, I.B.M. plans to trim its payroll by roughly 9,000 workers by the middle of this year, an industry executive close to the company said yesterday.

title: With Ellington, Camera in Hand
description: In the 1960's the filmmaker Robert Drew was considering various jazz figures as prospective subjects for a documentary. Duke Ellington was a possibility, as were Dave Brubeck, Louis Armstrong and Count Basie. "There was no question Ellington was the strongest of them," Mr. Drew said this week. "Just by talking to him, I knew the man would come through."

title: A Bittersweet Homecoming
description: BETHLEHEM, West Bank, May 10 — Heading home at last after 39 days under siege in the Church of the Nativity, Salah Ajarma bought a bagful of candy and stopped first at the house of a neighbor who had been expelled from the church to Gaza.

title: Legislators Parry Over Special Session's Agenda
description: Just a few hours after Connecticut lawmakers wrapped up their annual session at midnight, party leaders were back in battle mode today, arguing about the scope and specifics of the special session that will be needed to close a $350 million deficit and adopt a budget by a June 30 deadline.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Ruling May Doom Regulation On Questioning Police Officers
description: A much-criticized Police Department regulation that bars for two days the interrogation of officers suspected of misconduct can no longer be negotiated into the police union's contract with the city, a state hearing officer has ruled. Police officials said yesterday that they planned to use the ruling to eliminate the regulation.

title: British Judge Orders Extradition of an Al Qaeda Suspect to U.S.
description: LONDON, May 10  A British judge ruled today that an Algerian accused of being the leader of a London-based Al Qaeda cell and of plotting with Osama bin Laden to blow up Los Angeles International Airport on the eve of the millennium celebrations should be extradited to the United States.

description: Howard Merrill, a writer for radio and television who began his career as a child film actor and later produced a play on Broadway, died on April 20 at a hospital in Los Angeles, his family said. He was 85 and lived in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: EUROPE BELGIUM: INQUIRY IN KILLING OF IMMIGRANTS Officials will investigate whether the police responded quickly enough to the murder of an immigrant couple, a government spokesman said. Hendrik Vejt, a 79-year-old Belgian known locally for his racist views, died in a gunfight with the police on Tuesday after killing a Moroccan couple who lived in a neighboring apartment in the Schaerbeek district of Brussels. Late Wednesday, the police clashed in Schaerbeek with about 150 youths of Moroccan origin.    (Reuters)

title: Japan Protests China's Arrest Of Koreans At Consulate
description: With television relaying images of Chinese police officers dragging five North Korean refugees from inside a Japanese Consulate compound in China, Japan protested strongly today, seeking to head off a nationalist reaction against its powerful neighbor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONGIOVANNI, ANN
description: BONGIOVANNI-Ann. It is with deep regret that my friend and fellow traveler, Rosemary Paparo has lost her dear mother, Ann Bongiovanni. I know she was always in Rosemary's heart. With sincere sympathy I extend my heartfelt condolences to Rosemary's brother Anthony, sisters Linda, Janet, Anita and Ann Marie, and to her father Anthony. Fondly, Norman Buchbinder

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Couple Donates U.S. Grant Home
description: After years of restoration, the boyhood home of Ulysses S. Grant in Georgetown has been donated to the Ohio Historical Society by John Ruthven, a wildlife artist, and his wife, Judy, a Grant enthusiast. The one-and-a-half-story brick house was built by Grant's father from 1823 to 1828.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Morris Shamos, a nuclear physicist and science educator, misstated the year that his book ''Great Experiments in Physics'' was first published. It was 1959, not 1995.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Jackson Township: Tiger Preserve
description: The State of New York has told the owner of a tiger preserve in New Jersey that she may not, after all, move her 24 big cats to a farm in Orange County, N.Y. Officials with New York's Department of Environmental Conservation had granted a license to allow Joan Byron-Marasek, known as the Tiger Lady because of her preserve in Jackson Township, N.J., to move her operation to their state. Apparently, New York officials were unaware that Ms. Byron-Marasek has been waging a long and highly publicized battle with New Jersey state wildlife officials, who had won a court decision in 2001 to shut her preserve down. New York officials said Ms. Byron-Marasek had provided them with ''materially false or inaccurate statements.'' On Wednesday, Ms. Byron-Marasek and New Jersey officials are due in State Superior Court in Toms River for a judge to decide on a plan to get the tigers out of the state. Maria Newman (NYT)

title: Bronx G.O.P. Leader Enters Not Guilty Plea In City Bribery Case
description: Facing a 64-page, 25-count indictment, State Senator Guy J. Velella of the Bronx pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that he took bribes in exchange for using his influence to help obtain funding for public works projects.

title: The Big City; Puzzling Out The Logic In Living Wage
description: PEOPLE who call themselves advocates for the poor are all for reducing the poverty rate in New York City, but it's not clear how they want to do it. Do they want the poor to climb the ladder to higher-paying jobs? Or would they rather reduce the poverty rate by keeping poor people out of town?

title: Companies Trim Health Benefits For Many Retirees as Costs Surge
description: Hundreds of thousands of retired workers who used to have generous health benefits from large companies are digging deeper into their own pockets this year. Surging inflation in medical costs is draining hundreds of millions of dollars from corporate profits, and many large employers are responding by cutting back on health care benefits for retirees or requiring them to pay more for coverage.

title: Getting to College, Without Stress
description: To the Editor:

title: Diplomats Expect Conviction in Pearl Case
description: The Bush administration is confident that Ahmed Omar Sheikh, who is on trial here for the abduction and murder of the American journalist Daniel Pearl, will be convicted and executed, and is therefore not demanding that he be extradited to the United States, according to Pakistani officials and Western diplomats.

title: DECLINE IN GAP'S SALES IS SMALLER THAN EXPECTED
description: Gap Inc. said yesterday that sales at its stores open at least a year fell 24 percent in April, a smaller decline than expected, and that it expected to report a small profit in its most recent quarter. Gap, the casual-clothing chain, said sales for the four weeks ended May 4 fell 17 percent, to $962 million, from $1.2 billion a year earlier. Wall Street analysts had expected a drop of 30.2 percent. Sales at stores open at least a year fell 26 percent at Gap's domestic division, 21 percent at its international division, 13 percent at Banana Republic and 27 percent at Old Navy. The company said it expected to post a profit of 2 to 3 cents a share in the quarter, which ended Saturday.

title: The War On Terror Flounders
description: To understand why America's war on terrorism is beginning to sputter, infiltrate the Bush administration's Bat Cave at the intersection of Intelligence Way and Cryptological Court (no, I'm not making this up) at a Navy base here. This is the brand-new homeland defense center from which America will respond to anthrax, smallpox, nuclear attack, multiple hijackings or other shoes still to drop.

description: Executives in London and New York are heading new agencies.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: XBox Developers Plan Games Venture
description: Two software programmers who left Microsoft after spearheading the introduction of its Xbox video game console have reunited in a start-up games company. Seamus Blackley and Kevin Bachus plan to introduce today their new venture, the Capital Entertainment Group, which will function much like a Hollywood film producer for early-stage game projects. The company, based in Seattle, is raising more than $40 million from investors like the Durlacher Corporation to finance creative games ''that wouldn't otherwise get made,'' said Mr. Blackley, the company's vice president for development. Capital Entertainment will advise game developers, then seek marketing and distribution contracts with publishers. It will focus on games for the Xbox, he said, but will take on projects for any console or the personal computer. The company plans to announce its first development partnership today, with the publisher Sega of America. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: A Big, Bad Subconscious Lurks in a Dark Forest
description: At first ''Blackwoods,'' a supernatural thriller crammed with slow-motion photography, garish blue-tinted flashbacks and other special effects, appears to be a cut-and-dried low-rent horror film about a nice young man and his girlfriend whose trip to the country turns into a nightmare.

title: Hurricanes Save Their Best for Last
description: ''The ghosts are back,'' the Montreal Canadiens' owner, George Gillett, giddily proclaimed earlier this week.

title: I.N.S. Bolsters Efforts to Track Foreign Students in America
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service will begin using the Internet to keep better track of foreign students who are studying in the United States, Attorney General John Ashcroft announced today.

title: Gates to Bankroll Nutrition Project
description: Declaring ''market-based capitalism'' to be insufficient to improve the lives of poor children worldwide, Bill Gates, the chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, pledged today to bankroll the bulk of a $70 million effort to combat malnutrition.

title: Poultry Plants to Pay Workers $10 Million in Compensation
description: The Labor Department announced a $10 million settlement with Perdue Farms yesterday over the company's failure to pay poultry workers for time spent putting on and removing clothes and protective gear.

title: Death Penalty Is Suspended In Maryland
description: Citing ''reasonable questions'' about the fairness of Maryland's death penalty, Gov. Parris N. Glendening ordered a moratorium on executions yesterday until a special study is completed into whether minority felons are unjustly singled out for capital punishment.

title: Spaghetti Suppleness, Neo-Dada and a Toast in a Showcase of New Works
description: The showcase of new choreography that New York City Ballet calls its Diamond Project offered this season's first round of premieres on Wednesday night, and just when one expected the expected, the opening shot included a ballet with a creative difference.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COREN, HELEN S.
description: COREN-Helen S. Beloved wife of Dr. Adrian Coren. Dear mother of Dr. Seth and Jennie Coren, Kenneth Coren and Bonnie Coren. Adored grandmother of Michael and Marissa. Services today 10 AM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

description: Auction Victims Still Waiting

description: Behind the wooden gate, past the skittering dog, inside the rambling old house, plastered on the door of Nadine Gordimer's office is an African National Congress poster that proclaims, ''Freedom Now!''

title: Six Killed in Train Derailment in Britain
description: LONDON, May 10  Six people died and six were critically injured today when a passenger train traveling 100 miles an hour jumped the tracks at Potters Bar, a commuter belt town 10 minutes north of London, smashed into an elevated station platform and broke up.

title: Arafat Is to Blame
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Panels to Investigate Pricing Of Energy in California's Crisis
description: Two Senate committees moved today to investigate price manipulation in the California energy market, as lawmakers prepare to hear testimony from the authors of internal Enron memorandums that describe how the company manipulated electricity prices during the California energy crisis of 2000-2001.

title: Hallmark now has hearts and flowers and hopes that a print campaign will sell its online bouquets.
description: HALLMARK CARDS is offering a special gift suggestion for Mother's Day this Sunday: flowers that speak words of endearment.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: MSN Messenger Flaw Is Identified
description: Microsoft said a security flaw in some versions of its MSN Messenger program for exchanging messages over the Internet could enable a hacker to take over a user's computer. MSN Messenger had 23.4 million users for September, according to a study by the market research firm Jupiter Media Metrix, making it the No. 2 such program. A similar program that comes installed with Microsoft's newest version of Windows does not have the flaw, according to a Microsoft security alert. A software patch to fix the flaw can be found at www.microsoft.com/downloads.

title: Cardinal Law in Rome
description: To the Editor:

title: Students, Especially 12th Graders, Do Poorly on History Tests
description: At a time when ancient cultures and conflicts are increasing American involvement around the world, American students show a poor command of history, according to the results of a history exam given to a sample of students by the federal government and released here today.

title: How Arafat Fits Into the Arab World
description: As the prospect of an international conference on the Arab-Israeli dispute becomes increasingly likely, both the Bush administration and the government of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon face coming to terms with a Palestinian leader they can neither abide nor avoid. What is it about Yasir Arafat that makes him so troubling to the United States and Israel? In fact, the problem is not the man himself, as Mr. Sharon and President Bush seem to think, but the political position of the Palestinians in the Arab world today.

title: Showing at the TriBeCa Film Festival
description: The TriBeCa Film Festival, featuring screenings of new and classic films, panel discussions and other special events, runs through Sunday at various locations. Films are grouped according to categories that include narrative, documentary and feature films, short films and children's films. There is also a 9/11 program and a selection of classic films set in New York that have been selected by the director Martin Scorsese. Among the special screenings is George Lucas's ''Star Wars: Episode II -- Attack of the Clones'' on Sunday. About 15 countries are represented at the festival; all foreign-language films have English subtitles. Tickets range from $10 for a single screening to $25 for a panel discussion to $2,500 for an all-inclusive pass. Some screenings, including both ''Star Wars'' showings, are sold out, but returns may be available. Tickets: (212) 307-7171 (Ticketmaster); Information: (866) 941-3378 and (212) 941-2383; tickets and information: www.tribecafilmfestival.org. Here are locations and special-event and feature-film highlights. Unless noted, screenings are at the United Artists Battery Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARAC, EVELYN C.
description: ARAC-Evelyn C., 95. Of Canton, Massachusetts, formerly of Brookline, Newton and New York City, Wednesday, May 8, 2002, at home. Wife of the late Benjamin Arac, mother of Jonathan Arac of New York City and Elizabeth A. Beane, M.D. of Hingham, MA. Grandmother of Daniel M. Beane of Hingham, Rachel A. Beane of New York City, and Adam D. Beane of Providence, R.I. Sister of the late Irving Charm. Memorials to Orchard Cove Scholarship Fund, 1 Del Pond Drive, Canton, MA. 02021, Attn: Arnold Weiner.

title: Congress Is Warned Not to Save a Weapons System
description: The White House warned Congress today not to block Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld's efforts to cancel an $11 billion artillery system known as the Crusader, even as the House prepared to pass legislation containing $475 million for the system.

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights. ++ means discounted tickets were at the booth for last Friday night only. +++ means discounted tickets were at the booth for performances last Saturday night only.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LESCHER, MARY CANTWELL
description: LESCHER-Mary Cantwell. May 10, 1930 to February 1, 2000. Mom, on your birthday with all our love. Margaret, Jon, and Anna

title: Mets Lose Their Fifth Straight And Drop Out of First Place
description: Pedro Astacio has been the Mets' most successful pitcher this season, commanding the plate and giving the team another ace to go along with Al Leiter. And last night, Astacio was not about to back down from Barry Bonds, the San Francisco Giants' slugger who had slumbered through this series.

title: Images From a Decade Of Exciting Hard News
description: The decade of the 1950's -- often thought of as a time of conformity, conservatism and cold war saber rattling -- is generally not considered the most visually exciting American era. Not when stacked up against, say, the war-torn 1940's or the youthquaking 1960's.

title: Magloire Gives Scott His Words on a Plate
description: The statement was true but harsh, and tonight it came back to haunt Coach Byron Scott and his Nets. Before Game 2, Scott said the Charlotte Hornets' eagerness and excitement about Jamaal Magloire's return from a Game 1 suspension was excessive.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Eric Bindelglass, chief operating officer at Premier Retail Networks, San Francisco, was promoted to president, succeeding Charles Nooney, who was promoted to chief executive. Also, Bill Collier was named vice president for regional advertising sales; he had been director for strategy and business development at SmartSource iGroup, New York, a division of the News America Marketing unit of the News Corporation.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Deal In Sex-Abuse Case
description: A 19-year-old woman who tried to kill herself in a suicide pact with her husband last month is expected to plead no contest to third-degree criminal sexual conduct, her lawyer and prosecutors said. The woman, Jennifer Holey, is charged with first-degree criminal sexual conduct for aiding her husband, Patrick Holey, 19, in the rape of a 14-year-old girl on April 1. On April 9, the couple, who knew they were under investigation, went to an abandoned farmhouse and took painkillers that killed Mr. Holey. Mrs. Holey's mother-in-law, Kathleen K. Holey, who the authorities say drove the couple to the farmhouse and gave them the drugs, is charged with two counts of assisted suicide. John W. Fountain (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAVIT, BUMA
description: SHAVIT-Buma. Passed away May 8, 2002, in Tel Aviv, Israel. A prominent industrialist and political figure, former Chairman of ElAl Airlines and the Israel Manufacturers Association; an early leader in the development of the State of Israel Bonds in the United States. Our beloved cousin and devoted family member, a man larger than life, who lived every day to the fullest will be sorely missed by the many who loved and admired him. Caren and Amnon Barness, and family

title: E*Trade Chief Accepts A Cut in Compensation
description: Responding to criticism from investors, the chief executive of the E*Trade Group said yesterday that he would forfeit about $21 million of his pay from 2001 and accept no base salary for the next two years.

title: REVLON REPORTS ANOTHER LOSS, THOUGH A NARROWER ONE
description: Revlon, the cosmetics maker controlled by the financier Ronald O. Perelman, said that its first-quarter loss narrowed through cost cuts, but that sales might continue to decline this quarter. The loss shrank to $46.1 million, or 88 cents a share, from $46.5 million, or 89 cents, a year earlier. It was the company's 14th consecutive quarterly loss. Sales fell 12 percent, to $275.4 million. North American sales, which make up three-quarters of Revlon's total, fell 7.6 percent last quarter. International sales fell 13.5 percent. Revlon's share of the nation's cosmetics business fell to 22 percent at the end of the quarter from 24 percent a year earlier, said ACNielsen, the research company.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: A Fender Bender For Janet Reno
description: Janet Reno, a Democratic candidate for governor and former United States attorney general, was involved in a minor traffic accident when another driver collided with her beloved red pickup truck near her home in a Miami suburb, her campaign office said. ''It was a very minor fender bender,'' Nichole Harburger, a campaign spokeswoman, said. ''I emphasize minor.'' The Miami-Dade police said there had been no injuries, and no damage to Ms. Reno's truck. The other vehicle sustained about $100 in damage, the police said. The officer on the scene made no decision on who was at fault. Dana Canedy (NYT)

title: An Injured and Emotional Franco Shows There Is Crying in Baseball
description: John Franco's brown eyes flooded with tears, his chirping voice quivered and he shook his head in resignation. It was happening. Franco lost the hold on his emotions on the fifth question of a news conference yesterday as he struggled to explain how J. J., his 10-year-old son, asked him whether playing catch together on Tuesday had caused Franco's devastating left elbow injury.

title: Dan Devine, Football Coach, Is Dead at 77
description: Dan Devine, a head football coach for 22 years at three colleges and for four tumultuous years with the Green Bay Packers, died yesterday at his home in Phoenix. He was 77.

title: Getting to College, Without Stress
description: To the Editor:

title: Music Group's Stock Falters On Its First Day of Trading
description: The shares of the HMV Group made a wobbly debut on the London stock market today, falling 7 percent in their first day of trading and undermining the possibility of a recovery in the market for initial public stock offerings.

title: 'Hair Stories'
description: Adam Baumgold Gallery

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Foundry Reports A Surge In Orders
description: Shares in Foundry Networks Inc. of San Jose, Calif., the maker of computer network switches and routers, rose 57 cents, or 10.1 percent, to $6.20 yesterday, after Tim Heffner, the company's chief financial officer, said there were signs that demand for the company's products had picked up. Speaking at a financial conference, Mr. Heffner said orders in April were ''the strongest we'd seen for the first month of any quarter in the past 18 months.'' The strong monthly performance should help Foundry post higher second-quarter revenue than the first quarter's $62.4 million, he said. Two analysts at Frost Securities Inc. upgraded the company to buy from market perform. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Executives Take On New Assignments
description: Executives in London and New York are heading new agencies.

title: U.S. Action on Iraq Slowed by Rift Over Whom to Support
description: Despite repeated vows by President Bush to force Saddam Hussein from power, Bush administration officials are still at odds over which Iraqi opposition groups the United States should support, American officials and Iraqi opposition leaders say.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Cable Merger Planned
description: The Spanish telecommunications company Telefnica plans to merge its money-losing digital television platform, Via Digital, with its only rival, Canal Satellite Digital, which is owned by Sogecable. The deal, which is sure to face the scrutiny of regulators with the European Union and at home in Spain, would create a monopoly with 2.5 million clients and revenue of 1.3 billion euros a year. If approved, the merger would give Telefnica, the Spanish media group Prisa and Canal Plus of France 23 percent stakes in Sogecable, the sole Spanish company with the ability to deliver Hollywood movies and sports events, including the domestic soccer league, to subscribers.

title: Rivera Sets a Yankee Record With His 225th Save, but Not Without a Scare
description: Mariano Rivera became the Yankees' career saves leader tonight, closing out a 3-1 victory and a three-game sweep of the Tampa Bay Devil Rays. He kept the game ball as a souvenir, threw as hard as 96 miles an hour and broke a bat or two.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Language Requirement
description: In a review of graduation requirements, the state Board of Education is considering eliminating the requirement that all high school students study a foreign language for two years. Joseph Colombo, the superintendent of the Middlesex Vocational and Technical High Schools, said he appealed to the board because the prerequisite unfairly burdened vocational schools. Changes to the state requirements are not likely to occur before November, said a spokesman for the State Department of Education. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WANG, THOMAS KE, LIANG
description: WANG-Thomas Ke-Liang. On May 9, 2002. Beloved husband of En-Ming. Loving father of George H., Aveline and Johnny. Grandfather of Brian and Matthew. Brother of Ke-Ming. Reposing Neufeld Funeral Home, 88-04 43 Ave, Elmhurst NY, Saturday, May 11, 2002, 9AM-11AM. Services 11AM. Burial Kensico Cemetery.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mount Pleasant: Gun Charge
description: A resident of the Pleasantville Cottage School, a treatment center for troubled foster children in Mount Pleasant, N.Y., has been charged with criminal possession of a weapon, a felony, the Westchester County district attorney, Jeanine F. Pirro, announced yesterday. The defendant, Theodore Johnson, 18, was arrested at a nearby train station on Monday after the police got a tip from someone at the school. The authorities said Mr. Johnson was carrying a loaded 9-millimeter semiautomatic pistol. In February, the school was the scene of a brutal attack on a counselor; eight girls ranging in age from 14 to 16 have been charged with attempted murder in the assault. Lisa W. Foderaro (NYT)

title: Barney's Ancestors Star In Their Own Soap Opera
description: The notion of turning James Gurney's books about Dinotopia into a film must have been irresistible. In words and lovingly precise illustrations, he has imagined an island paradise where people, dressed in outfits of olden times, live in blissful harmony with kindly, intelligent dinosaurs. It's a cinematic natural, a world where ''Jurassic Park'' meets ''The Wizard of Oz.'' Obviously you would need a few real-life wizards to create special effects, sets and costumes to bring this world to life. But you'd also need to add some sort of narrative structure to make the whole thing work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANGER, EDWINA CAMPBELL
description: SANGER-Edwina Campbell, M.D. 92. Of Somers and Fishers Island, NY, on May 9, 2002. Wife of the late Grant Sanger, M.D. Mother of Michael, Alexander, Morgan and Anne, and of the late Peter and Stephen. A memorial service will be held at St. Matthew's Church, Katonah, New York, on Thursday, May 23rd, at 10 A.M. Graveside service to follow at Fishers Island Cemetery at 4:30 P.M.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This crime today was committed by scum who hold nothing sacred.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Nuha Khouri, a Palestinian who spent 15 years in the United States before returning to the West Bank to help build an independent state, misspelled the name of a Michigan town where her father opened the White Feather Inn and Restaurant when he brought the family from Bethlehem. It was Pinconning, not Piconning.

title: Factory Jobs, Then Workers, Leaving Poorest Southern Areas
description: This old farming and factory town in the rural South Carolina lowlands still has its charms, but they are lost on Sonya Alston, 22. She is planning to move to Charlotte, N.C., any day now.

title: Ex-F.B.I. Agent Sentenced to Life in Prison for Spying
description: Robert P. Hanssen, the former F.B.I. agent who confessed to selling secrets to Moscow, was sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole today by a federal judge in Alexandria, Va.

title: Joel B. Leff, 67, Co-Founder Of Investment Management Firm
description: Joel B. Leff, a founder and co-chairman of the investment management firm Forstmann-Leff Associates, died at his Manhattan home on Tuesday. He was 67 years old and had suffered from cancer.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Opposition Names Candidate
description: Lee Joi Chang, leader of the opposition Grand National Party, won the party's nomination for the presidential election in December after capturing 68 percent of the votes in primaries. Mr. Lee, who narrowly lost to Kim Dae Jung in 1997, promised ''a new clean government for Korea'' if elected. Noh Muu Hyun, the candidate of Mr. Kim's Millennium Democratic Party, leads in polls but has been slipping as scandals have rocked the government. Mr. Kim is barred by the Constitution from running for a second term. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUPPERT, MELITA
description: HUPPERT-Melita. Serenely, May 9, 2002 after a brief illness. Native of Krakow, Poland, law graduate, Jagellonian University, Holocaust survivor. She is recalled with everlasting and profound affection by her husband of 63 years, Victor, her daughter Frances, son Arthur, niece Elizabeth Kujawski, son-inlaw Jeffrey Fishman, daughter-inlaw Miriam Field, Grandchildren Dana and Casey Fishman, Cayla and David Huppert, great nieces Melissa and Stephanie Kujawski and innumerable others. She uplifts and lives on within all who knew and love her. Service Friday 1 P.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the 92nd Street ''Y'' New York City.

title: British Report a Taliban-Qaeda Arms Cache
description: The Royal Marines announced today that British troops had found a major arms cache in caves in Paktika Province, where they have been conducting a sweep for the past 10 days.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Drug Law Reform: A New Vocabulary
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Insurer Is Leaving Many Doctors Scrambling
description: After 25 years of providing insurance against suits for medical malpractice, the company that insured nearly 40 percent of New Jersey's doctors is shutting its doors, leaving the doctors scrambling for coverage just as other insurers are getting out of the business or cutting back.

title: A Profusion of Painting, Very Much Alive
description: THE idea that painting is dead is more pass than ever, judging from the medium's dominance in New York City's commercial galleries this weekend. Perhaps it is taking its revenge on museums that have been mostly otherwise engaged this season. Maybe dealers have put their best (selling) feet forward for the annual rite of spring auctions. But let's not quibble. There's too much to be seen.

title: Dawn at Grand Army Plaza: One Brooklyn Rooster, to Go
description: Behind a chain-link fence in the lush green crescent known as Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn, a four-note cry pierces the softness of dawn.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Drinking Policy Toughened
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly issued a new policy yesterday that toughens the sanctions for officers who drink and drive so that those involved in serious automobile accidents would almost certainly be dismissed. Officers found to be unfit for duty because they were driving while intoxicated and caused someone serious physical injury would be fired ''absent exigent circumstances,'' the policy said. Officers who admit to driving while intoxicated in incidents in which there is no serious physical injury, will be placed on probation for a year and be subject to random Breathalyzer tests. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK BROOKLYN: PORNOGRAPHER SENTENCED

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hynix To Break Up
description: Hynix Semiconductor yielded to government pressure and agreed to break up the company after rejecting a deal last week for Micron Technology to take over its memory-chip plants. Confronted with a threat by creditors to declare the company bankrupt, Hynix directors endorsed a proposal to break off the units that make products other than memory chips and sell them separately from the rest of the company. The board surrendered after Korea's two most powerful finance officials, the finance minister and the chairman of the Financial Supervisory Commission, said there was no way to salvage the company other than to sell it off. The chairman of the supervisory commission promised to press for a declaration of bankruptcy. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: For the Residents of Roosevelt, A Primer on the State Takeover
description: The state's top education official swooped into this Nassau County hamlet today to lay out plans for improving its school system, the first in New York's history to be taken over by the state.

title: Regulate Casinos Fairly
description: To the Editor:

title: Andersen Lawyer Accuses Prosecutors of Misconduct
description: A lawyer for Arthur Andersen accused prosecutors today of trying to intimidate at least three witnesses, and said he would submit an immediate request to the Justice Department for an investigation.

title: Kicking Up Cosmic Dust
description: AFTER sitting through ''Star Wars: Episode II -- Attack of the Clones,'' I'm tempted to quote an evergreen Public Enemy song: don't believe the hype. But really, belief is beside the point. The promotional machinery around the ''Star Wars'' franchise exists beyond fervor or skepticism; it is a fact of life. When the fifth installment in George Lucas's pop-Wagnerian cycle opens nationally on Thursday (after being shown at the first TriBeCa Film Festival on Sunday afternoon), the event will have all the spontaneity and surprise of an election day in the old Soviet Union.

title: 'Left vs. Right' -- 'Expressionist Propaganda Posters of the Early Weimar Era'
description: Ubu Gallery

title: U.N. Forum Stalls on Sex Education and Abortion Rights
description: Differences over abortion and sex education continued to distance the Bush administration from many of the other delegates to a General Assembly Special Session on Children today, complicating efforts to draft a final declaration due on Friday.

title: Smallpox Vaccine Knowledge Found Lacking
description: Doctors and the public poorly understand the dangers of the smallpox vaccine and need to be better informed if vaccinations are to be reintroduced after an absence of 30 years, federal health officials and infectious disease experts said here today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 19 about the sexual abuse scandals in the Roman Catholic Church misstated the background of Tom Caldarola, a psychotherapist in San Francisco who said he had struggled with staying true to religious vows. He was a Jesuit seminarian, but he was never ordained.

title: 'European Sculpture'
description: Daniel Katz at Dickinson Roundell

title: White House and Senate in Trade Accord
description: Senate leaders and the White House reached agreement today on a broad trade package that includes subsidized health insurance for American workers who are displaced by foreign competition, clearing the way for Senate approval as early as next week of new trade negotiating authority sought by President Bush.

title: House Panel Adds $200 Million for Israel to an Emergency Bill
description: After denouncing the Office of Management and Budget as uncooperative, the House Appropriations Committee today voted to add $200 million for Israel to a $29.4 billion measure for homeland security and military spending. The Bush administration had not sought the aid to Israel.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 30 about a Roman Catholic Church program in New Hampshire intended to prevent and detect sexual abuse misidentified as priests two people in instructional videotapes. A man who said he had molested 500 girls was the owner of a roller-skating rink, and another man, reported to have abused a 10-year-old boy, was a camp counselor.

title: Chic to Chic on South Beach
description: JUST a few blocks from each other in South Beach, the ultra-hip Delano (1685 Collins Avenue, Miami Beach; 305-672-2000) and elegant Shore Club (1901 Collins Avenue; 305-695-3100), are engaged in a classic hotel rivalry these days: the trend-setting pioneer vs. the buzz-generating newcomer. How do they stack up? MARY BILLARD

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel To Make Pentiums In China
description: The Intel Corporation said it would expand an existing plant in Shanghai to assemble and test Pentium 4 microprocessors. The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it expected to spend $100 million on the expansion, out of a planned $500 million investment it has already announced it will use to set up operations in China. Intel said it expected the new plant to be finished by the end of the year, with commercial shipments to begin in the first half of next year. By 2004, the company aims to employ 3,000 people in Shanghai, compared with about 1,300 now.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in some editions yesterday with the obituary of Louis C. Wyman, a longtime Republican representative from New Hampshire, misstated the number of terms he served. It was 5, not 20.

title: INSIDE
description: Tax Maneuver Approved

title: Number of Global Polio Cases Hit Its Lowest Point Last Year
description: The number of polio cases worldwide dropped to its lowest recorded point last year, but the campaign to eradicate the virus could be undermined by regional conflict and a funding shortfall, the World Health Organization has warned.

title: The Cardinal and Sin
description: Americans have become depressingly familiar with the sight of great men and women dragged before a judge or grand jury and answering questions with an eye to the finer nuances of law rather than the grand moral questions of social justice. On Wednesday Cardinal Bernard Law of Boston became the latest, and his answers in a court-ordered deposition were more befitting a businessman trying to dodge an insider-trading suit than one of the nation's highest-ranking churchmen.

title: Israeli Soldier Just Wants To Go Home
description: Nisan, 19, stood on the other side of the makeshift barricade of Israeli-blue metal stands and barbed wire, leaning his helmeted head against the wall, listening to the women in head scarves. They were begging to be allowed to see their sons and relatives, still besieged in the Church of the Nativity, but part of the group of wanted Palestinian gunmen who are supposed to go into exile in Gaza or abroad.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: Trainers Promise Tyson of Old
description: Stacey McKinley, a longtime assistant trainer in Mike Tyson's corner, said yesterday that Tyson recently told him: ''I quit fighting 10 years ago. Now, against this guy, I'm ready to go again.''

title: The Eldorado Sips Its Last Tanker of Gas
description: THE final Cadillac Eldorado rolled off the assembly line last month in Lansing, Mich., an alpine white car destined for the company's museum.

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST

title: Finding The Big Sky, Close to Manhattan
description: UTTER the words Delaware County at a party in Manhattan and you will likely get one of two very different reactions. People will either raise their eyebrows knowingly, and indicate they would prefer that their fellow New Yorkers never discover it. Or they will give the more typical response and ask, where's Delaware County?

title: Teams to Focus on Repeat Domestic Abuse
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced a pilot program yesterday under which teams of workers from a number of city agencies would be assigned to help curb domestic violence in two police precincts, one in the Bronx and another in Brooklyn.

title: Thank Heaven for Roz Sternlieb
description: After holding their breath for months, high school seniors all over the country have finally received the good or bad news from the colleges to which they applied last winter. In a three-part series this week, Jane Gross of The Times painted a sensitive portrait of the nerve-racking quest for college admission as told through the lives of three New York City students from different backgrounds but with compelling stories that made them all easy to root for. The other stars of the articles were the guidance counselors who ushered them through the application process.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Rates Held Steady
description: The monetary policy committee of the Bank of England voted yesterday to keep interest rates at 4 percent, joining the United States Federal Reserve and the European Central Bank in their decisions to keep rates even until the economic recovery gains strength. Britain's economy grew at the slowest pace in a decade in the first quarter. Consumer spending, accounting for about two-thirds of the gross domestic product, has compensated for one of the worst slides in factory production in decades. If the economic recovery continues to gather steam, a rate increase is still possible later in the year, analysts said. The Bank of England last reduced rates on Nov. 8, by half a percentage point, after six reductions earlier in 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCARTHY, JOHN V.
description: McCARTHY-John V. May 7, 2002. Founder and President of John V. McCarthy & Assoc. Beloved husband of Catherine ''Cay''. Dear father of Mary, Thomas (Frances Day), Catherine, Theresa, Susan Wiggin (David), John V. Jr., Margaret Froehlke (Dr. Robert), Anne, Patrick (Christine Obregon), Jane Roberts (William), Carol and the late Daniel. Palmer Jr; James and Maisie DiStanislao; Margaret and Catherine Wiggin; Elizabeth, Alex, Brennan & Sarah Froehlke; Sean and Matthew McCarthy; Emily, Claire and Andrew Roberts. Memorial Tributes to Gesu Church. For information and full obituary: www.desmondfuneralhome.com

title: Prosecution Witness Disputes Skakel's Alibi
description: A prosecution witness today disputed Michael C. Skakel's alibi on the night Martha Moxley was killed in 1975, testifying that Mr. Skakel had not gone with two of his brothers to a cousin's home. The defense has insisted that Mr. Skakel was watching television at the cousin's home at the time Miss Moxley was being bludgeoned in her family's yard.

title: Pavarotti and Borrowed Time
description: No one should have been surprised that Luciano Pavarotti withdrew from his scheduled appearance as Mario Cavaradossi in ''Tosca'' at the Metropolitan Opera on Wednesday night, just 90 minutes before the performance was to begin. The reason given was that Mr. Pavarotti, the superstar tenor, had come down with influenza.

title: City's Budget Gap Could Top $6 Billion, Comptroller Says
description: New York City's budget shortfall could top $6 billion, which would make it more than a billion dollars worse than Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg projected, according to a report issued yesterday by Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr.

title: Bankruptcy Talks Collapse on Abortion Issue
description: Congressional negotiators said today that talks intended to forge a compromise bill to overhaul the nation's bankruptcy system had broken down in a dispute over a provision on abortion rights, with the two leaders of the talks blaming each other in unusually personal terms.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Governor Criticized For Ads
description: A government watchdog group criticized Gov. John G. Rowland yesterday for allowing state tourism officials to spend millions of taxpayer dollars since 1999 to produce television ads featuring Mr. Rowland. Common Cause Connecticut said the Department of Economic and Community Development spent $2.5 million in public funds from 1999 to 2001 for ads promoting the state and featuring Mr. Rowland, who is up for re-election in November. Chris Cooper, Mr. Rowland's press secretary, said tourism officials asked the governor to appear in the ads, which Mr. Cooper said had helped increase tourism. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Chelo Gonzlez Amezcua
description: Cavin-Morris Gallery

title: National Briefing | Washington: A Very Tall Zone Of Privacy
description: The debate over patient privacy took a new turn this week with a dispute over the medical records of Ryma, a 17-year-old giraffe who died in February at the National Zoo. When The Washington Post asked for a pathology report, the zoo released only a summary. The zoo director, Lucy Spelman, explained that doctor-patient confidentiality ''in principle'' applies to animals, the newspaper said. While animal rights activists and defenders of the First Amendment protested the decision, a zoo spokesman noted that in addition to the summary, The Post received a two-hour interview with the chief pathologist. The cause of death? Digestive illness. Sheryl Gay Stolberg (NYT)

title: Fed Releases March 19 Minutes
description: Federal Reserve officials saw ''strong evidence'' that the economy was recovering from recession at their March 19 policy meeting and sent a signal to investors that interest rates would have to rise at some point, minutes of the meeting showed today.

title: Sweatshops Under the American Flag
description: Last month a court in American Samoa ordered a garment factory to pay $3.5 million to 270 workers from China and Vietnam. The court described workers cheated of wages, beaten and deprived of food, something that should never have occurred anywhere, much less on American territory. But while the exploitation in the Daewoosa factory was egregious, it is not isolated. On Saipan, the largest island of the American Commonwealth of the Northern Marianas, federal investigators have documented mistreatment of workers.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DELPHI, Troy, Mich., the world's largest maker of automotive parts, said it had won a five-year, $60 million contract to provide systems that control air and fuel flow in motorcycle engines to Chongqing Zongsheng Motorcycle Group, China.

title: Order a Backyard Luau (Pig Included)
description: NOT everyone can have a home in Hawaii, but there are a lot of ways to bring Hawaii to your home.

title: Smoking Fat Boy
description: An old joke: A farmer hears suspicious noises in his henhouse. ''Who's there?'' he calls out. ''Nobody here but us chickens,'' replies the thief. Satisfied, the farmer goes back to bed.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Mitchell Estate Settles 'Gone With the Wind' Suit
description: The estate of Margaret Mitchell agreed yesterday to settle its copyright infringement lawsuit against the Houghton Mifflin Company over the publication of ''The Wind Done Gone,'' a first novel by the writer Alice Randall that is set on the same plantation as Miss Mitchell's best seller ''Gone With the Wind'' but told from the perspective of a slave.

title: During Testimony on Uprising at Attica, Ex-Guards Recall Days of Siege and Days of Horror
description: The day before the Attica uprising, an inmate quietly told Dean Wright to call in sick the next morning. He was sick, with a cold, but he reported to the prison anyway. ''I went to work because that's my job,'' Mr. Wright said yesterday during the first of two days of state hearings to let former guards and their families talk about their experiences during the 1971 riot -- a tale that many say has been told only from the perspective of inmates.

title: The Power of Education
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: Charges In A '68 Bias Killing
description: A 70-year-old man is being held without bail for the 1968 murder of a 21-year-old black woman who was selling items door to door in Martinsville, then a Ku Klux Klan stronghold. The man, Kenneth C. Richmond, is accused of stabbing the woman, Carol Jenkins, with a screwdriver on a roadside, while his 7-year-old daughter watched. Last December, according to court records, the daughter told the police that Mr. Richmond had given her $7 to keep the crime secret from her mother. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: In Hawaii, an Oasis For the Ultra Rich
description: LAURENCE BLICKMAN, a businessman from the San Francisco Bay Area, is so enamored of Hawaii's Big Island that one day on impulse, he snapped up a house for a friend.

title: Spring Hikes: First Blisters, Then the Bliss
description: MY husband and I are standing on a narrow, green jut of land deep within the Wild Rivers Recreation Area north of Taos, watching storm clouds scud overhead. They are the exact shade and oddshapes of bruises. They are also a surprise, since the Southwest is experiencing drought, and until 10 minutes ago, the sky had been a cloudless, infinite Yves Klein blue.

title: Where Trains Rolled, Bicyclists Now Roam
description: IT was already past 10 a.m., and we were going nowhere fast. The bikes were still strapped to our car, parked outside the Village Diner in Millerton, N.Y., and my husband, Steve, and I were stuck in a vinyl booth with two kids who were taking their time over breakfast. While Hannah accidentally flipped her blueberry pancake onto my lap and Daniel dumped salt on his, I gazed out the window at a Lycra-clad couple speeding toward the entrance to the Harlem Valley Rail Trail, their racing bikes glinting in the sun. They leaned into the turn, swooped onto the path created on the bed of the old New York and Harlem Railroad, and disappeared into the lush greenery. I was itching to follow them.

title: Interrupted By Alarm, He Plays On With Grace
description: During Houston Person's opening set on Tuesday night at the Jazz Standard, the smoke alarm went off, triggered by a problem in the restaurant upstairs, Blue Smoke. It was activated by a minor problem with an air-conditioner, but the club demonstrated its full-metal alarm system: strong lights blinked, and a loud, electronic warning chirp started its rhythmic cycle.

title: Phillies' Affiliate Looking to Improve
description: The Lakewood (N.J.) BlueClaws did everything right off the field last year in their first season. Their fan-friendly $20 million stadium, strong community relations and even their cute logo went into drawing 482,206 fans to GPU Park (renamed FirstEnergy Park this year because of a corporate merger).

title: Atrocities Against Israelis Seem Also Aimed at Arafat
description: The suicide bombing this week at a pool hall and slot-machine parlor near Tel Aviv, was aimed not only at Israelis but also at the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, whose credibility as a peacemaker was further tarnished, Palestinian officials and analysts say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROTMAN, ANITA (NEE HAIUNGS)
description: BROTMAN-Anita (nee Haiungs). On May 8, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Buddy. Loving mother of Beth and Harlan Sugerman and David Brotman and Karen Stevens. Cherished grandmother of Alex and Jessie. Dearest sister of Helen and her husband Tom. Fond sister-in-law of Pauline and devoted aunt. description: CALDERWOOD-Stanford. Of Belmont on May 9th, 2002, at 81. Former President of WGBH-TV in Boston and Executive Vice President of Polaroid Corporation. Beloved husband of Norma Jean Calderwood. Funeral services are private at the request of the family. Late World War II Navy veteran who was aboard the USS Braine and USS Minneapolis. title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Elizabeth: Arrest In Doctor's Death
description: A man who leads an Irvington-based youth gang has been charged in the March 1 shooting death of a New York oncologist outside a hotel near Newark International Airport. The man, Fedner Pierre Louis, 18, of Irvington, was charged with the murder and armed robbery of Dr. Jeffrey Perchick. The authorities said the gun used in the killing had been stolen from its legal owner in North Carolina on Dec. 2, 2000, then transported to New Jersey, where it eventually fell to Mr. Louis. Mr. Louis was ordered held yesterday in $750,000 bail. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: More Worry Over Loans By Big Banks In China
description: Financial experts are expressing grave worries about the solvency of China's banking system, which may have a bad-loan problem several times as bad as Japan's.

title: Rangers Lean to Brooks As Robinson Steps Away
description: Herb Brooks has emerged as the front-runner in the Rangers' search for a head coach, two National Hockey League officials said, and Larry Robinson formally withdrew from consideration for the job yesterday.

title: Building Arms for the Wrong War
description: The Crusader, a self-propelled, high-tech cannon planned for delivery in 2008, is the most advanced artillery system in the world. It can shoot 10 shells a minute at targets more than 30 miles away on battlefields where American air power is limited by advanced antiaircraft weapons. If the Army were still facing the Soviet Union across Central Europe or contemplating battle against a similar military power in the coming decade, the Crusader would be indispensable.

title: Tax Receipts Fall Far Short Of Predictions
description: The Congressional Budget Office said today that tax receipts this fiscal year through April were $75 billion below its projections, ensuring that the federal budget deficit would be far larger than anticipated.

title: N.F.L. to Test Players for the Stimulant Ephedra
description: The National Football League will become the first professional sports league to test for the stimulant ephedra with a testing program to begin July 1, league and union officials say.

title: When the Tough Get Glowing: The Car as Light Show
description: ''THAT car is sick,'' the young man said, leaning over a police barrier in front of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. Although a purplish radioactive glow was seeping out from underneath the vehicle in question, a silver Nissan Frontier pickup, the spectator's word choice was intended as high praise. As a slang compliment among young car customizers, ''sick'' is right up there with ''off the hook.''

title: Newark's Competing Visions of Itself; Reborn or Struggling? Each View Is Reflected by a Mayoral Candidate
description: If this hard-luck city had a slogan it would be a single word: renaissance.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Nuha Khouri, a Palestinian who spent 15 years in the United States before returning to the West Bank to help build an independent state, misspelled the name of a Michigan town where her father opened the White Feather Inn and Restaurant when he brought the family from Bethlehem. It was Pinconning, not Piconning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GETRAER, JOSEPH L.
description: GETRAER-Joseph L. We are deeply saddened by the untimely loss of our good friend and partner with whom we shared so many wonderful times. He will always be fondly remembered and sorely missed. Cooki and Joel Yunis

title: Looking to Elections, Bush Plays Up Domestic Issues
description: It was only in January that Karl Rove, President Bush's chief political strategist, was telling Republican operatives to trumpet the administration's handling of the war on terrorism as a major selling point in the November midterm elections.
