title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Contract Settled
description: The union representing 800 registered nurses at St. Vincent Catholic Medical Centers announced yesterday that the nurses had ratified a new three-year contract. The union, the New York State Nurses Association, said the agreement would raise salaries by 3 percent annually, increasing the base salary to $62,114 by the contract's end. The union said the agreement called for stricter staffing guidelines in the emergency department and the cancer center. The accord also gives full-time nurses the right to refuse forced overtime three times every six months. The nurses' old contract expired Feb. 15. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: At Spring Art Auctions, a Second Strong Night
description: Sotheby's held a strong sale of Impressionist and modern art on Wednesday night, with a Cézanne still life bringing $16.7 million, a Degas pastel being snapped up for $16.5 million and a Giacometti bust selling for $13.7 million. Yet the atmosphere there felt less buoyant than it did at Christie's sale the night before, even though the Christie's results weren't as good.

title: People
description: * Dave Robinson, general manager at the T&O Group, Irvine, Calif., was promoted to president, succeeding Stephen E. O'Leary, who was promoted to the new post of chairman.

title: Rivals Offer Plans to Fix Adult Homes
description: The two Democratic candidates for governor presented plans yesterday to overhaul the state's system of adult homes for the mentally ill, saying that conditions at the homes had deteriorated to scandalous levels.

title: Accounts
description: * Patio.com, Stamford, Conn., to Mark Stevens & Company, Purchase, N.Y., as agency of record to introduce a corporate communications program for the online and offline retailer of patio furniture. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $8 million.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Man Convicted In Killings
description: A man whose DNA tied him to the murders of three young women in Westchester County was convicted yesterday of second-degree murder. Patrick Baxter, 33, could be sentenced to 75 years to life for the murders, which took place in 1987, 1988 and 1990. The three women were also sexually assaulted. Until the DNA tests, no one thought that the killings were committed by the same person because the victims were different ages and races and their deaths occurred in different locations. David W. Chen (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMAREST, DANIEL A.
description: DEMAREST-Daniel A. On May 3, 2002, of lung cancer. Lawyer and trustee. Retired partner of the former law firms of Beekman & Bogue and Gaston & Snow, he specialized in corporate and securities law. He graduated from St. George's School in Newport, RI in 1942, served in the U.S. Army 194346, graduated from Harvard College in 1948 and Harvard Law School in 1951. At the time of his death, he was a Trustee of The Lachaise Foundation, a Director of The Bay Foundation and a Director of The Josephine Bay Paul and C. Michael Paul Foundation, and was a longtime member of The Knickerbocker Club and The Holland Society. Survivors include his sister, Rosemary R. Demarest of New York City, and his nephew, David R. Demarest of San Anselmo, CA. Donations in memory of Daniel Demarest may be made to The Juilliard School, attn: Development Office, 60 Lincoln Center Plaza, New York, NY 10023-6588, or to Cabrini Hospice, attn: Ms. Mary Cooke, Director, 227 East 19th Street, New York, New York 10003-2693. Funeral services will be held on Saturday, May 11, 2002 at 11 A.M. at The Church of the Heavenly Rest, Two East 90th Street, New York City.

description: Israel had tanks moving toward the Gaza Strip today as it prepared to retaliate for a Palestinian suicide attack that killed 15 Israelis south of Tel Aviv three days ago.

title: Stanley Hails Bermuda Vote, But Employees Cry Deception
description: Stanley Works said today that its shareholders had approved by the thinnest of margins its proposal to become a Bermuda company, but employees and retirees contested the outcome and said managers had misled them about how millions of votes would be counted.

title: Molder and Durant Share the Lead
description: May has become one of Bryce Molder's favorite months.

title: With Warning on Enron, a Celebrity Is Born
description: The nightclub sparkled under a strobe light, as dancers gyrated to ''Play That Funky Music'' and Court TV's guest of honor, Sherron S. Watkins, sipped wine from a glow-in-the-dark glass. The music stopped so Ms. Watkins could accept the cable channel's Scales of Justice award.

title: Reimagining A Downtown
description: For urban planners and elected officials, the destruction of the World Trade Center has provided an almost unfathomable opportunity to reconsider and reshape the future of one of the most distinctive neighborhoods in the world: 16 acres of land in the heart of downtown Manhattan.

title: Residential Real Estate; Once Again In Brooklyn, Living Space Over Stores
description: They are reminiscent of another time: eight buildings on Mermaid Avenue in Brooklyn, each with two apartments and street-level store space so owners can live, work and rent out an apartment all in the same place. But the buildings are also part of a contemporary city strategy to improve neighborhoods.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Figures Show Playstation's Strength
description: Sony's video game division said yesterday that it had shipped 30 million PlayStation 2 consoles since the system's introduction in October 2000, highlighting the challenges facing its rivals, Nintendo and Microsoft, in trying to unseat Sony. Nintendo said yesterday that it had shipped 12 million of its GameCube consoles, which cost less and are popular among younger children. The PlayStation 2's installed base is largest in North America, where there are 11.3 million, followed by Japan, with 9.9 million, and Europe, with 8.8 million. Sony has shipped four million PlayStation 2's in the last three months alone, matching Microsoft's most optimistic shipment estimates for its Xbox during the company's entire fiscal year, which ends June 30. The Xbox, which hit the market in November, has sold well in North America but struggled in Europe and especially in Japan. Earlier this week, Microsoft said recent price cuts had lifted Xbox sales in Europe, but it released no sales figures.

title: Beauty in the Eye Of the Key Holder
description: IN April, casual strollers along Park Avenue near 38th Street in Manhattan found themselves stopping to press their faces to the glass wall of Scandinavia House, a showcase for art and designs from Sweden, Norway and Denmark. What they saw, for the first time, was Saab's futuristic 9X concept vehicle, on display inside.

title: Party Leaders Clash in Capitol Over Pace of Filling Judgeships
description: Democrats and Republicans in the Senate held competing news conferences today and produced conflicting statistics as each side battled to demonstrate that the other was behaving abominably in considering candidates for the federal bench.

title: ABC SPOKESWOMAN TO OVERSEE DISNEY COMMUNICATIONS
description: Zenia Mucha, the spokeswoman for the ABC Broadcast Group and ABC Television Network divisions of the Walt Disney Company, was named the head of communications for Disney yesterday. She will succeed John Dreyer, who has held that position since 1992. Mr. Dreyer will continue to work for Disney as a consultant, the company said. Ms. Mucha, 45, is a former senior policy adviser to Gov. George E. Pataki of New York. She began working as the chief spokeswoman for ABC in February 2001. In her new post she will be in charge of communications for all of the company's divisions. Jim Rutenberg (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, FRANKLIN M.
description: ROGERS-Franklin M. Passed on to eternal life. Born in Irvington, NJ, graduate of Seton Hall University in 1941. A W.W. II naval officer aboard the USS Taylor & PT Boat Squadron Commander in South Pacific, fighting in Guadalcanal, New Guinea, and providing escort for General MacArthur's return to the Philippines. Later a jewelry executive, rose to VP of Bulova Watch Company. Predeceased by his mother, father, sister, Agnes, Matthew and Marion. Survived by his children, Randall, Kevin, Richard and Judith, five grandchildren and three great grandchildren. A dedicated and loving father who will be missed.

title: National Briefing | South: Kentucky: Sheriff Halts Primaries
description: Suspicious about a large early ballot turnout, Sheriff Ed Jordan of Clay County has shut down the voting machines in his Appalachian district, angering a crowd of constituents who were lined up to vote in advance of the May 28 primary. ''Buying votes is what they are doing,'' Sheriff Jordan said. He admitted he had no evidence and no suspects, just a suspicion after an unusually high turnout of 269 early voters for the multioffice primary. The state attorney general's office said it would investigate.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Gurkhas Sue For Equal Treatment
description: Former soldiers in Nepal's Gurkha forces, which have served in the British Army for almost two centuries, charged Britain with unfair treatment and career discrimination and are seeking $2.9 billion in compensation. The Gurkhas, famed as fearless fighters, said they were paid less than other British soldiers and had far smaller pensions, less prospects of promotion, worse layoff terms and slim chances of obtaining British residency. Heading their legal team is Cherie Booth, the wife of Prime Minister Tony Blair, who is a leading employment rights lawyer.

description: REIF-Roslyn. On May 5, 2002. In San Diego, Calif. Best friend, wise sage, we will miss you so much. Phyllis and Woody Federman

title: Decorators Find Treasure In Their Bins
description: What would happen if the world's greatest decorators got together for a fancy tag sale? Well, that's basically what is happening at Sotheby's in New York on May 17 and 18. Last July Sotheby's asked 140 well-known interior designers if they wanted to consign any antiques or items in inventory for a sale. The 50 who responded are now selling 710 lots, some commissioned for famous people like Yves Saint Laurent, others designed by 20th-century legends like Billy Baldwin, Van Day Truex, Renzo Mongiardino, Andr Arbus and Gio Ponti.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCKOWITZ, MURRAY
description: ROCKOWITZ-Murray. The Solomon Schechter School of Westchester notes with sorrow the death of Murray Rockowitz, father of our esteemed Trustee, Noah Rockowitz. Dubin, Vice Chairman Dr. Elliot Spiegel, Headmaster

title: This Side of Heaven, Please, in the Village
description: Three-quarters of the way down on the left. On the same side of the street as the Weathermen-bombing house. Beyond the place where Oscar Wilde stayed after his American tour. Before the cemetery but after Cynthia Harris's lush window boxes. That's it just there: the tall brown brick building looming shabbily over all the Greek Revival town houses. Home. My home. Or one of them, anyway.

description: O'CONNOR-Margaret C. Of Babylon, formerly of Elmhurst in her 92nd year. Passed away on May 8, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Louis O'Connor. Loving mother of Helen, Barbara, Alice, Mary, Leonard, John, Arlene and Robert. Cherished grandmother of all her grandchildren and great grandchildren. We truly love you and you will be missed. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Joseph's RC Church, Babylon Village at 10:45AM Saturday, May 11. Interment following at St. John Cemetery in Middle Village, Queens.

title: The Next Chrebet? From Hofstra to Jets
description: Doug Shanahan noticed a subtle change when he arrived at the Jets' complex for the second day of their recent minicamp. He was in for a tryout, and still sleeping in his old Hofstra dorm room instead of in the hotel where the Jets put up everyone else, and suddenly the coaches knew his name.

title: The New Kid Struggles to Make a Bad Impression
description: ''The New Guy,'' a bad-taste comedy with a heart, should have a condition appended to its PG-13 rating: be careful not to visit the concession stand before the picture starts. Early on, Diz, a high school senior, catches the principal in the bathroom with what could be best described as a stall cam. Not only is this a set piece, but it's, sigh, also a crucial plot point.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Pirelli Posts A Loss
description: Pirelli, a leading maker of fiber optic cable, posted a second consecutive quarterly loss as a recession in the United States hurt its sales. Pirelli lost 37 million euros ($33.5 million) in the first quarter, down from a profit of 149 million euros a year earlier. Sales of energy cable fell, and sales of tires rose slightly. The chairman of Pirelli, Marco Tronchetti Provera, said he expected earnings before interest, taxes and one-time items to rise an average of 25 percent a year through 2004. Mr. Provera also said that a recovery in the telecommunications sector was unlikely this year and that the company had cut costs by 200 million euros this year.

title: Liberty Meets Old Rival for Tuneup
description: Liberty Coach Richie Adubato said he was not thinking so much about winning the team's first preseason game against the Mystics tonight in Washington. He was more concerned with seeing how well the 15 players on his training camp roster would compete in a game.

title: Credit Rating Of WorldCom Is Cut to Junk
description: WorldCom's credit rating was cut below investment grade yesterday by Moody's Investors Service, but the company narrowly averted a cash squeeze by securing a waiver from its lenders that allows it to have access to an important borrowing program.

title: Life of a Man Who Helped Define Cool
description: DEEP IN A DREAM

title: To Fix the Audit Mess, Rotate the Auditors
description: THERE is nothing like a second set of eyes when it comes to spotting problems. And that sounds very bad to someone who would prefer that the problems not be spotted.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Automotive Profits
description: Hyundai Motor, South Korea's dominant motor vehicle manufacturer, posted a profit of $457 million for the first three months of this year. The company attributed the profit to the rising popularity of sports utility vehicles and the country's prosperity. Another factor was the competitiveness of Korean exports as a result of the drop in value of the won against major foreign currencies. Hyundai Mobis, a major parts manufacturer and mainstay of the Hyundai automotive group, said it netted $84 million in the first quarter. Sangyong Motor, a small company in the hands of creditors, reported a net profit of $32.5 million from January through March, in contrast to a $3 million loss in the first quarter of 2001. Don Kirk(NYT)

title: New Data on Unemployment Question Health of Labor Market
description: Worker claims for jobless benefits fell less than expected last week, and the number of Americans collecting aid rose to a 19-year high, government figures showed today, suggesting that the labor market is not improving rapidly as the economy recovers.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Motorola Wins Round In Turkish Dispute
description: A federal judge in New York yesterday ordered members of a wealthy Turkish family to turn over stock in Telsim Mobil, Turkey's second-largest mobile phone company, and imposed a freeze on related assets. The ruling by Federal District Judge Jed S. Rakoff was hailed by Motorola and by Nokia, which had sought the order after filing a lawsuit charging members of the Uzan family and codefendants with illegally appropriating about $3 billion that had been lent to the family, with Telsim stock as collateral. The shares amounted to a 66 percent stake in Telsim for Motorola and 7 percent for Nokia. According to the lawsuit, the Uzans arranged for Telsim to triple the outstanding shares and then stripped the foreign companies' shrunken holdings of voting rights. No trial date in the lawsuit has been set. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

In a report delivered last month, Ulster's police ombudsman, Nuala O'Loan, said an Irish policeman had not told Northern Irish counterparts about potential terrorist activity by dissident republican paramilitaries. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Pornographer Sentenced
description: The pornographer Al Goldstein was sentenced yesterday to 60 days in jail and three years' probation for harassing his former secretary last year. Mr. Goldstein, 66, the publisher of Screw magazine, was convicted in February of six counts of harassment for vicious comments he made by phone and through the mail to the secretary after she quit her job. Mr. Goldstein's lawyers asked the Criminal Court judge, Danny K. Chun, to delay the start of the sentence pending an appeal, having already told the judge that Mr. Goldstein was ''a medical time bomb'' who has diabetes, hypertension, and sleep apnea. After the judge rejected the request, Mr. Goldstein complained of chest pains and was taken to Long Island College Hospital, where he was being held overnight for observation. An appeal of Judge Chun's decision not to delay the sentence is to be heard today. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Latvia: Language Law Dropped
description: Parliament voted 67-to-13 to drop a language requirement that hindered ethnic Russians in the former Soviet republic from running for political office. NATO and the European Union had demanded the change, which lawmakers hope will smooth the way to an invitation to join the defense alliance. Russian speakers make up one-third of Latvia's 2.4 million population. The law had required candidates running in national and local elections to prove their fluency in Latvian. Now they will be required only to give a self-evaluation of their language skills.

title: Analysis May Yield Clues To Origins of Anthrax Mail
description: Researchers said yesterday that they had found subtle differences among samples of the same anthrax strain, increasing hopes of identifying the laboratory that might have been the source of the microbes used in last fall's anthrax mailings.

title: Bomb Blast at a Crowded Parade Kills at Least 34 in Russian Town
description: A powerful bomb stuffed with bolts and nails and hidden in roadside bushes ripped through a military parade today in southwest Russia commemorating the end of World War II. At least 34 people died, including at least 12 children, and Russian news services said another 130 were hospitalized.

title: Visionaries Dare to Take the Catwalk
description: I've been a New Yorker for almost 30 years, and I've walked all over this great city on a high wire. I did it illegally at first -- at 1,350 feet, between the twin towers of the World Trade Center, in 1974. Then officially: over Belvedere Lake in Central Park; across Amsterdam Avenue, 16 stories in the air, to the unfinished south tower of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine; and later, on several occasions, inside the nave. I've walked from wing to wing above the entrance courtyard of the Museum of the City of New York and from roof to roof between the buildings of Lincoln Center, over the fountain. I've danced on a high wire under the celestial vault of Grand Central Station and in the Rose Center for Earth and Space at the American Museum of Natural History. Just last weekend, I walked 50 feet in the air between two distant columns in the Crystal Palace at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. Believe me when I say that New York City hides many treasures in high places, some of them visible only from a bird's-eye view.

title: 36 Hours | Athens, Ga.
description: IT is called the Classic City because of its name and its neo-Classical-style buildings, but Athens, Ga., might as well be known as Live Music Central. Home to 30,000 University of Georgia students, who make up a third of the town's population, and a healthy contingent of artistic-minded residents, Athens has always been something of a cultural haven. Its reputation as a cutting-edge music scene took off in the early 1980's after two homegrown bands, R.E.M. and the B-52's, hit the big time. The town has produced waves of fresh local acts and a growing number of live music sites since. Even if the music is not to your taste, the stately homes, lovely university campus, eclectic restaurants and sleepy Southern atmosphere provide plenty of other reasons to spend a few days in Athens. A trusty guide is Flagpole Magazine, a free weekly that lists restaurants, bars, clubs and, of course, live music. ABBY GOODNOUGH

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Suit To Revoke Citizenship
description: The Justice Department filed a civil suit in federal court in Brooklyn yesterday, seeking to revoke the citizenship of a Queens man who it contends was an armed guard at a Nazi slave labor camp during World War II. The complaint said Jakiw Palij, 78, was a guard at the Trawniki camp in Nazi-occupied Poland at a time when 6,000 Jewish prisoners were shot to death. The complaint said he misrepresented his wartime activities when he applied for admission to the United States in 1949. Since 1979, according to the Justice Department, 54 people have been removed from the United States based on evidence that they assisted in the Holocaust and more than 160 remain under investigation. Through a secretary, Mr. Palij's lawyer, Ivars Berzins, declined to comment. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing
description: HARDWARE FIGURES SHOW PLAYSTATION'S STRENGTH Sony's video game division said yesterday that it had shipped 30 million PlayStation 2 consoles since the system's introduction in October 2000, highlighting the challenges facing its rivals, Nintendo and Microsoft , in trying to unseat Sony. Nintendo said yesterday that it had shipped 12 million of its GameCube consoles, which cost less and are popular among younger children. The PlayStation 2's installed base is largest in North America, where there are 11.3 million, followed by Japan, with 9.9 million, and Europe, with 8.8 million. Sony has shipped four million PlayStation 2's in the last three months alone, matching Microsoft's most optimistic shipment estimates for its Xbox during the company's entire fiscal year, which ends June 30. The Xbox, which hit the market in November, has sold well in North America but struggled in Europe and especially in Japan. Earlier this week, Microsoft said recent price cuts had lifted Xbox sales in Europe, but it released no sales figures. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Two Key Governing Groups Agree to Limits on Drivers
description: The United States Golf Association and the Royal & Ancient Golf Club announced today that they had reached an agreement on the rules governing the springlike effect in drivers. title: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Too Much Democracy
description: Democracy may be getting out of hand in Vietnam, the Communist Party leader, Nong Duc Manh, said. Calling for a curb on public protests at government buildings, he said people should confine their complaints to proper government channels. ''The fact that people gather with placards is abnormal,'' he said. ''Our democracy is in many cases excessive.'' Seth Mydans (NYT)

description: For years the Energy Department has promised to clean nearly all the radioactivity out of bomb wastes here that are to be secured in giant concrete blocks. title: GENERAL ELECTRIC TO BUY DRUCK FOR $335 MILLION
description: General Electric said it had agreed to buy Druck Holdings, a British maker of electrical measuring instruments, for 229 million ($335 million). G.E. offered 3.50 for each Druck share. The offer represents a premium of 17.3 percent over the closing price of Druck shares on May 8, the day before Druck said it was in talks that might lead to an offer for the company. The acquisition will expand the presence of GE Industrial Systems, based in Plainville, Conn., in the electrical measuring devices market for a wide range of industries, including aircraft and oil. Druck shares rose 1.2 percent, to 3.48. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Uganda: Political Restrictions Eased
description: Parliament passed a bill easing restrictions on political parties but some lawmakers walked out because, they said, the changes did not do enough to end one-party rule. President Yoweri Museveni, who took power in 1986, has restricted rival parties, saying they foster ethnic strife. The new law allows parties to operate but forbids them from holding meetings or canvassing for support outside the capital. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | North America: Canada: Jobless Rate Declines
description: Canada's unemployment rate fell to a five-month low of 7.6 percent in April because of a surge in full-time jobs that heightened expectations that interest rates would continue to rise faster than those in the United States. The economy created a net 36,600 jobs, all of them higher-paying full-time positions, as retailers, transportation companies and builders hired people to keep up with demand, Statistics Canada said.

title: Doom Chases Lust, but With Loveliness
description: The titillating eerieness of impending doom is exploited so gorgeously in ''Vienna: Lusthaus (Revisited)'' that you can understand how civilizations become complicit in their own demise. A reprise of Martha Clarke's 1986 theater piece, this seamless amalgam of dance, music and drama is set before World War I in Vienna, where Freud and Hitler overlapped, which it presents in a delicately surreal fashion as a hothouse of sensuality and incipient Nazism. The show opened on Wednesday at the New York Theater Workshop as a replacement for ''Far Away,'' a play by Caryl Churchill that has been postponed until the fall.

title: National Briefing | New England: 4 States Want Fishing Bans Revisited
description: The states of New Hampshire, Maine, Massachusetts and Rhode Island have filed a motion asking a federal judge to reconsider a ruling that imposed what many believe to be the strictest restrictions ever placed on the fishing industry in the region. Two weeks ago, Judge Gladys Kessler of Federal District Court, seeking to stop overfishing off New England, closed parts of the Gulf of Maine and ordered sharp reductions in the number of days fisherman are allowed to fish. The ruling went beyond a negotiated settlement reached in April by fishermen, environmental groups and federal regulators. Fishermen say it will cripple their industry. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: A Father And a Son Harmonize
description: ''Signs, Games and Messages,'' an abundant three-week festival here at the South Bank Center, devoted to the minuscule, painstaking art of the Hungarian composer Gyorgy Kurtag, has established the strength of his music within a powerful context. Contemporaries important to him have been included in the programming: Luigi Nono, Karlheinz Stockhausen and his compatriot and student ally Gyorgy Ligeti. So have imposing forebears -- Schubert, Schumann, Mozart, Beethoven, Bartok -- with no need for apologies on behalf of the present. Mr. Kurtag's music does what music has always done: it expresses itself decisively, fascinates, exposes something very private in a public forum, opens a new world.

title: Sports of The Times; A Tortuous Journey To Detroit
description: ABOUT four years ago, Ben Wallace decided that he'd be different. At a time when many players in the N.B.A. were sporting the bald look, Wallace decided to let his hair grow. And grow. And grow. He made a bet with Chris Webber, then his teammate in Washington, to see which of them would be the first to cut his hair. Webber relented, and Wallace's wild Afro has become his signature. His flowing, Dr. J-like Afro adds four inches to his 6-foot-9 frame, making him a sort of 7-footer.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Sale
description: Goldman, Sachs will be the major adviser in another effort by Seoul to sell SeoulBank, which it acquired in 1997. The Korea Deposit Insurance Corporation, the government entity that owns SeoulBank, has failed in previous attempts to sell the bank, kept alive by cash infusions totaling $4 billion. Goldman is expected to advise on selling SeoulBank to foreign interests while Samsung Securities will focus on selling it to a Korean buyer. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: BERKSHIRE PROFITS RISE ON HIGHER INSURANCE PRICES
description: Berkshire Hathaway said first-quarter profit rose 51 percent as it raised prices at its insurance businesses. Net income rose to $916 million, or $598 a share, from $606 million, or $397, a year earlier. Profit per share excluding gains from the sale of securities was $534, compared with estimates of $446.50 in a survey by Thomson Financial/First Call. Investment gains fell to $98 million from $144 million a year earlier. Berkshire's insurance operations, including the General Re Corporation, the third largest reinsurer, and the Geico Corporation, the car insurer, posted a $20 million underwriting profit in the first quarter as they raised prices and had lower-than-expected claims. General Re's $88 million underwriting loss narrowed from $126 million. Berkshire had underwriting losses of more than $3 billion since paying $17 billion for General Re in December 1998.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Loss At Softbank
description: The Internet investor Softbank lost money on a net basis for the first time as the value of its portfolio fell and it spent heavily to roll out its broadband business. The company lost 88.76 billion yen ($691 million) in the year that ended March 31 even though revenue increased 2.1 percent. Stung by losses in technology-driven companies, Softbank set up a subsidiary, Yahoo BB, which offers cheap high-speed Internet access. The service has bolstered cash flow, but still requires heavy investment in equipment and research. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOUFFMAN, MOLLY L.
description: KOUFFMAN-Molly L. Conviser. May 8, 2002. Graveside service Monday, May 13, 1 PM at Knollwood Park Cemetery. Donations to the American Lung Association. Gutterman's, Inc. 718-284-1500.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the On Stage and Off column in Weekend yesterday about the Tony Award race for best musical misstated the role of Dodger Theatricals in a nonunion tour by ''The Music Man.'' Dodger was the lead producer of the Broadway production that preceded the tour, but did not mount the tour itself. The producer of the nonunion tour is Big League Theatricals.

title: Graduation Speakers With 9/11 Ties Are in Vogue
description: As this year's college seniors prepare to find their way in a world indelibly changed by the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, a new category of commencement speaker is emerging: those who symbolized the bravery and heroics of that day.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of horse farms for sale in the Escapes section on April 26 misstated the location of Collegeville, Pa. It is 25 miles northwest of Philadelphia, not 25 minutes northeast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALDERWOOD, STANFORD
description: CALDERWOOD-Stanford. Of Belmont on May 9th, 2002, at 81. Former President of WGBH-TV in Boston and Executive Vice President of Polaroid Corporation. Beloved husband of Norma Jean Calderwood. Funeral services are private at the request of the family. Late World War II Navy veteran who was aboard the USS Braine and USS Minneapolis. For further information, please call the J.S. Waterman & Sons-EastmanWaring, phone: 617-536-4110.

title: Goodbye, National Guard; Hello, Local Police Officers
description: The occupation ended at midnight today.

title: Shares of Mobile Phone Company Plunge
description: Shares in the Western Wireless Corporation, the mobile phone company, fell 41 percent today after it said it lost customers in the first quarter. The shares fell $2.33, to $3.35 a share, on Nasdaq.

title: Clinton Dismisses Notion of Doing A TV Show Now
description: Bill Clinton does not expect to become the host of a television show anytime soon, and in a radio interview broadcast yesterday he called reports that he was considering doing so blown out of proportion.

title: Religion Journal; A Chastened Singer Returns to Christian Basics
description: In 1976, an unknown 15-year-old Nashville girl named Amy Grant signed with Myrrh Records, an upstart record label, which released her surprisingly successful debut the next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATTERSON, GEORGE EDWARD
description: PATTERSON-George Edward. At Columbia, MD. Formerly of East Rockaway. Beloved husband of Jean. Devoted father of Robert and Brian and the late Anne Clark and Joan Patterson. Also survived by six grandchildren. Fond brother of William. Former Community Superintendent of schools in New York City. Reposing at the Perry Funeral Home, Inc. 118 Union Ave., Lynbrook. Mass will be offered at St. Raymond's RC Church, Monday at 9:45am. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Profit At Daewoo
description: Daewoo Motor posted an operating profit of $20 million for the first four months of this year, reversing a loss of $30 million in the period a year earlier. The operating profit excludes interest and taxes. The company, Korea's third-largest vehicle maker after Hyundai and its affiliate, Kia, sold 147,500 vehicles in the period, which ended April 30, and forecast sales of 610,000 vehicles for the year, up 31 percent from last year. Daewoo, which was going through bankruptcy proceedings, agreed last week to be taken over by General Motors, which is forming a new Korean carmaker that will be called GM Daewoo Auto and Technology. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Woman on Curb Is Killed by Truck
description: A 34-year-old woman was killed by a truck yesterday in the Bronx as she stood on a curb waiting to cross a street near Co-Op City, the authorities said.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Purchase Will Expand Big Sur
description: Conservation groups have bought a 10-mile stretch of undeveloped land on the northern end of Big Sur. The nearly 10,000-acre tract was acquired by the Nature Conservancy and the Big Sur Land Trust from Craig McCaw, the cellular entrepreneur, for about $38 million. It will complete a 70-mile wildlife corridor. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: Nanny's Love Repaid in Halls of Justice; Woman Wins Adoption Battle With Help of One of Her Charges
description: They would sit together in a Manhattan kitchen over cups of milky tea, the impossible little boy and his ever-patient nanny, Louise Brown. Her calming presence amid his tantrums was one of the boy's earliest memories. Often, his parents recall, she held him until he quieted, talking in rhythms passed down through the generations from African slaves in the rural North Carolina of her birth.

title: Confessions of Isolation Played in a 1960's Mode
description: Belle and Sebastian

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: 'Do Not Call' Measure Passes
description: Residents will soon be able to shield themselves from some telemarketers by putting themselves on a do-not-call list at the Department of Commerce. Lawmakers, who had rejected similar ideas over the past three years, voted overwhelmingly to join 28 other states with similar blocking programs. Politicians and nonprofit groups are exempt. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: First Woman Executed Since 1957
description: Lynda Lyon Block, 54, who was convicted of killing a police officer in 1993, was put to death in the electric chair at Holman Prison in Atmore. She and her common-law husband, George Sibley, were both sentenced to death for murdering Sgt. Roger Lamar Motley Jr. of Opelika, whom they encountered while they were fleeing Florida to avoid being sentenced for assault convictions. A date for Mr. Sibley's execution has not been set. Ms. Block, the first woman to die in Alabama's electric chair since 1957, could be the last; a state law passed in April made lethal injection the normal method of execution. David M. Halbfinger (NYT)

title: Atlas Air Says Loss Widened in Quarter
description: Atlas Air Worldwide Holdings Inc., the largest handler of freight for other airlines, said its loss widened to $6.7 million in the first quarter as shipping declined.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column on Thursday about a warning from the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education that Yale University general surgery residents were working too many hours misidentified the institution that could lose its accreditation as a result. It is Yale-New Haven Hospital, the teaching hospital affiliated with the Yale School of Medicine, not the school itself.

title: A Man Who Would Shake Up Science; Physicist Says He's Explained The Way Nature Operates
description: Some images on the back jacket of Stephen Wolfram's 1,197-page tome, ''A New Kind of Science,'' are familiar: a splash of liquid, jets of gas, sea anemone, ancient mosaics and mollusk shells. But others become understandable only after working through ideas in this much-awaited book: spindly sketches of leaves and snowflakes, a baroque lacework of light, schematic diagrams that waver under the gaze.

title: Torre Offers Support to Johnson
description: MINNEAPOLIS, May 10  The lineup card does not show it, but Yankees Manager Joe Torre insists he still has confidence in Nick Johnson, the struggling rookie.

title: Cuomo Is Richest of Major-Party Candidates
description: Andrew M. Cuomo appears to be the richest major-party candidate running for governor of New York, according to tax returns he made available to reporters yesterday. He certainly had the most lucrative job last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRLICH, MARJORIE GLAUBACH
description: EHRLICH - Marjorie Glaubach. Born April 1st, 1926. Died May 9th, 2002. Beloved wife of Irving, mother of Debbie Fox and Gwen Mergian & grandmother of Nina & Nathan. Service at I.J. Morris, Inc., Hempstead, NY, Sunday, 1 P.M.

title: Paper Fights Subpoena Of Journalist By U.N. Court
description: Lawyers for The Washington Post today challenged a subpoena served by the United Nations war crimes tribunal on a former reporter for the newspaper, arguing that journalists who work in conflict zones should not be required to give testimony unless absolutely vital because it could hamper their work and endanger their lives.

title: Afghanistan Maps for Pilots Were Delayed by Foul-Ups
description: Thousands of new satellite photographs of Afghanistan lay idly in storage at the height of the American military campaign last fall, as technological and then bureaucratic failings kept them out of the hands of Air Force pilots desperate for more accurate maps of the remote country, industry and military officials say.

title: Skakel Trial Testimony Deepens Mystery
description: The investigators who have led the inquiry into the 1975 killing of Martha Moxley since the state reopened the case in 1991 flatly contradicted each other on the witness stand today as prosecutors and defense lawyers in the murder trial of Michael C. Skakel argued over whether another man had ever confessed to the crime.

title: Bach's Test of Violin Limits
description: Simply as a structural matter, the violin is best suited to producing a single melodic line. It can be a soaring one, or it can evoke anything from quiet, lilting introspection to daredevil virtuosity. But it is not really made for counterpoint, chordal writing and melodies fully supported by built-in accompaniments. In asking violinists to do all these things in his extraordinary Sonatas and Partitas for Unaccompanied Violin, Bach demanded that they bend the instrument to their will and his.

title: More Pork, Please
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Give Arafat Another Chance?
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctors Are Cautioned Not to Give a Type of Plasma to Liver Patients
description: Doctors have been warned to avoid giving a type of blood plasma called PlasSD or SD plasma to people who have severe liver disease or who are receiving liver transplants, the Food and Drug Administration has said.

title: Leading a Russia in Transition
description: One factor in Russia's transition from dictatorship to democracy has been the capacity of its recent leaders to break with their own pasts. Once Mikhail Gorbachev made it to the top of the Soviet system, he moved to repudiate its reliance on lies and brute force, setting the stage for the end of the empire and of the cold war. Boris Yeltsin, who rose to the Politburo by carrying out its orders, spent his presidency doing battle against the remnants of the Communist Party. Vladimir Putin, a former K.G.B. officer who almost everyone believed would be hopelessly out of his depth as Mr. Yeltsin's successor, has remained popular at home while accelerating Russia's alignment with the West.

title: Valentine Tries to Take Blame for This Loss
description: Like all the Mets, Manager Bobby Valentine has somehow maintained an upbeat attitude over the past week. He and the team have clung to the Mets' winning record and their standing in the division despite the lack of performance from most of the roster.

title: Officials to Speed Start of New Student Visa Tracking System
description: Facing growing evidence of fraud in student visas and disarray in the nation's immigration service since Sept. 11, Bush administration officials said today that they were hastening the start-up of a vast computerized system for tracking foreign students attending thousands of educational institutions.

title: Tournament Berth At Stake for U.S.
description: A place in the first FIFA under-19 women's world championships will be determined tonight in Trinidad and Tobago when the United States plays Costa Rica. The United States will advance to this summer's finals in Canada with either a victory or a draw.

title: Amid Atlanta's Newness, a Familiar Face
description: The Atlanta Falcons have a new owner (Arthur Blank), a new minority owner (Joe Gibbs), a new adviser (Bobby Beathard), a new starting quarterback (Michael Vick), a new free-agent linebacker (John Thierry), a new free-agent running back (Warrick Dunn) and a new rookie running back (T. J. Duckett), and they are expected to hire a new chief administrative officer specializing in finance.

title: Maine at Front Line in Fight Over the High Cost of Drugs
description: The anxiety, the sense of grievance and most of all the anger fill the meeting room at a residence for the elderly in Augusta, Me. It is another day on the barricades in Maine, where the political rebellion against the soaring cost of prescription drugs, now brewing around the country, may be at its peak.

title: Nets Plan for the Possibility Of Playing Without Kidd
description: With his left eye watching his step, Jason Kidd walked purposefully through the hotel lobby to a team film session this evening, holding an ice bag to the right eye that had been swollen shut virtually since dawn.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Classical Music and Dance Guide in Weekend yesterday misstated the starting time for a concert today by the Russian Chamber Chorus of New York at St. Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue at 54th Street, in Manhattan. It is 3 p.m., not 8 p.m.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BILUS, HARRIET (NEE LAZARUS)
description: BILUS-Harriet (nee Lazarus). Of Bloomfield, New Jersey, on May 10th, 2002. Beloved wife of 54 years of Herbert Bilus. Cherished daughter of the late Mannis and Florence Lazarus. Devoted mother of Jane Bilus Gould (Ken), Patricia Bilus Lager (Martin) of White Plains, NY, and Frann Bilus and Rick Feldman of Andover, MA. Dear sister of Natalie Warshay of Bayonne, N.J. Loving grandmother of Elizabeth and Caroline Gould, Karen and David Lager, and Zachary and Noah Feldman. Services will be Sunday, May 12, 1:30 P.M. at Temple Ner Tamid, 936 Broad Street, Bloomfield, NJ. For information, Jewish Memorial Chapel, 973-779-3048.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: El Nio Still Expected
description: The warming tropical Pacific Ocean is still on track to produce El Nio for the first time in four years by the end of 2002, the National Centers for Climate Prediction said this week. But the warming pattern is likely to be ''considerably weaker'' than the potent episode of 1997 and 1998, which seared southern Asia. That El Nio was the worst of the 20th century, helping lift the average global temperature to record highs. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: Bail Is Reduced For Boston Priest
description: A Massachusetts judge reduced bail today for the Rev. Paul Shanley, the Roman Catholic priest accused of child rape, to $300,000 from $750,000. But a person close to the case said Father Shanley did not have the resources to make even the reduced bail and would most likely remain in jail.

title: Competing Firm Openly Woos Andersen Partners
description: A battle over who would have their pick of Arthur Andersen accountants intensified yesterday as one accounting firm sent a mass e-mail memo seeking to woo Andersen partners.

title: In Church of Nativity, the Refuse of a Siege
description: Between columns of amber marble, darkened by age and burnished by worshipers, the occupiers had laid grubby mattresses and brown blankets, tangled and rumpled. At the low entrance, called the Door of Humility, the air was acrid with urine. Under the high wooden vaulted ceiling, empty sardine tins dripped oil among spilled votive candles.

title: Toronto's Mondesi on Market
description: MINNEAPOLIS, May 10 — Some Yankees officials would rather wait to let the trade market sort itself out before acting to acquire an outfielder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHARD, ILSE
description: RICHARD-Ilse. Age 86. Beloved wife of the late Simon. Devoted mother of Dorothy and Raphael Block. Adored grandmother of David and Joel. Loving great-grandmother. Dear sister of Lora Gottlieb and Franzi Mayer. Services Sunday 9am ''Sinai Chapels'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: No Big Deal, but Some Dorm Rooms Have Gone Coed
description: First came coeducational colleges, then dorms, then bathrooms. Now, on a few campuses, there are coeducational rooms.

title: When Origin Becomes a Competitive Issue
description: Navin Bhatt goes by the name Nick because it sounds more American. The short version of Nick Bhatt's American life goes like this: He saved some money -- not a lot of money -- and bought a motel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, BARBARA H.
description: BECKER-Barbara H. Of Short Hills, NJ, on Friday, May 10, 2002. Beloved wife of Frederic K. Becker. Loving mother of Richard, Martin, Mary Becker Kleinstein and Jonathan Kleinstein. Cherished grandmother of Molly and Ella Kleinstein. Dear sister of Lois and Raymond Ross. Adored sister-in-law of Marjorie and William Becker. Services will be held at Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 1025 South Orange Ave., Short Hills, NJ, Sunday, 12:30 PM. For information, please call Bernheim Apter Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel (800) 938-6372.

title: Met Is Ready if Pavarotti Isn't
description: With an ailing Luciano Pavarotti cooking up vast quantities of chicken soup and still undecided whether to take the stage for what might be his last Metropolitan Opera performance tonight, the Met yesterday plucked a possible young replacement from Milan and flew him to New York on a Concorde.

title: A Pakistani Dancer and Her Life Underground
description: FOR the well-dressed, well-heeled and well-bred of the Horticultural Society of Pakistan, it was an unusually daring event, even risqu. Organizers had obtained a rare government permit and admission was tightly controlled.

title: Cuomo's Call for Novello's Resignation Criticized
description: Hispanic lawmakers, both Democratic and Republican, had strong words yesterday for Andrew M. Cuomo, a Democratic candidate for governor, after he called for the resignation of Dr. Antonia C. Novello, the state health commissioner, on Thursday.

title: Thai Premier Offers Compromise of Sorts on Pipeline Dispute
description: Caught between impatient energy companies and neighboring nations on the one hand, and angry environmentalists and local villagers on the other, Thailand's prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, today announced his long-awaited solution to a dispute over a planned $700 million natural gas pipeline across southern Thailand.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Warning To China
description: Officials stepped up their criticism of China over an episode this week in which Chinese policemen entered the grounds of a Japanese Consulate in pursuit of five North Korean asylum seekers, knocking over a 2-year-old girl, wrestling her mother into submission and dragging away her pregnant aunt. Foreign Minister Yoriko Kawaguchi demanded the immediate release of the North Koreans and warned that the incident could damage relations between China and Japan James Brooke (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAND, MIRIAM
description: BRAND-Miriam. On May 10, 2002. Beloved mother of Marilyn and Ralph, Sol and Yaffa, Ruth and Richard, Josh and Brooks. She was the devoted grandmother of Rob and Amparo, Donna, Michal, Aila, Arnon, Jessica, Erika, Sam and David. She was predeceased by her husband, Jack, almost eight years ago and was the sole surviving member of her six siblings and other relatives, most of whom died in the Holocaust. We will always remember her for her fierce determination, angelic spirit and love of family. May she rest in peace. Funeral will be held on Tuesday May 14th.

title: Retailers' Pacts For Cash Back From Suppliers Draw Attention
description: When Kmart announced that it might have to restate earnings for at least part of last year, after an inquiry into internal accounting problems, it drew attention to a widespread practice in the retail business that everyone seems to know about, but almost no one wants to discuss.

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Permanent Shark Warnings
description: The state will place its first permanent shark warnings at a popular Maui snorkeling site in about a month, Deborah Ward, spokeswoman for the Department of Land and Natural Resources, said. Seven or eight signs will be posted along a one-mile stretch near Olowalu beach in the West Maui resort area, where two shark attacks have occurred in the last 19 months. Hawaii averages three or four shark attacks annually, the department said. Michele Kayal (NYT)

title: Enron's Lessons for the Energy Market
description: This week the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission released internal memos it had obtained from Enron detailing an edifice of corrupt practices Enron used to profit from artificial shortages it created in the California energy market.

title: Stanley Voids Bermuda Vote And Promises To Try Again
description: Stanley Works threw out a contested shareholders vote today that would have allowed it to become a Bermuda company and said that it would schedule a new vote.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOHF, KENNETH A.
description: LOHF-Kenneth A. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the loss of a respected member of the Museum's Trustee Committee on Museum, Library, and Research as well as its Library Council. Mr. Lohf, who was a distinguished librarian, scholar and author, will be deeply missed by all of his friends at the Museum and by the many other institutions who had the benefit of his involvement. Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Agnes Gund, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, NY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNLAP, JOHN
description: DUNLAP-John, 46. Sales Executive for Penthouse Magazine and other general media publications, died May 10 at the Cabrini Medical Center after a long battle with AIDS and cancer. In addition to his position at Penthouse, John also tried his hand at various other ventures including selling high-end cosmetics out of the guest bathroom of his Manhattan apartment, giving massages in the dining room and experimenting with aromatherapy. Although he collected thousands of religious tomes, his favorite book appeared to be the PDR. In addition to his fondness for pharmaceuticals, he also fancied himself an expert in canine nutrition. He is survived by his sister Nina of Syracuse, NY, his brother Raymond of Atlanta, his aunt Lucy of Rochester, and dozens of friends from coast to coast who are convinced they will never meet another person quite like John. Funeral services at the Holy Protection of the Mother of God located at 2637 12th St., Astoria, Saturday, at 12 noon. Interment to follow in Baltimore on Tuesday at the Greek Orthodox Cemetery.

title: Yanks Enjoy Room-Service Pitching
description: If Derek Jeter placed any importance on statistics, he would have looked forward to the Yankees' last two games. He has always devoured the opposing starting pitchers.

title: Signaling Shift, City Reassigns Work Program To Jobs Agency
description: The city's employment commissioner told City Council yesterday that her department would take over a federal work force program from the city's welfare agency, underscoring a shift from the Giuliani administration's workfare policy.

title: Demotion Pays Off for Young Goaltender
description: Rick DiPietro was blindsided. For someone who was pretty good at covering all the angles and anticipating shots from anywhere, he never saw the demotion coming. That, he said, was probably the worst part.

title: ISRAEL'S MILITARY RETHINKING ACTION IN THE GAZA STRIP
description: The Israeli government appeared today to be moving toward a targeted, limited military operation in the Gaza Strip as its troops pulled out of Bethlehem, marking the end of the long, tortuous siege at the Church of the Nativity.

title: New Jersey Ponders the Legalities of Borrowing to Cover a $1 Billion Shortfall
description: New Jersey's budget crisis has grown so acute that the state may have to borrow as much as $1 billion to cover a cash-flow shortage between now and June 30, the end of the fiscal year, administration officials said today.

title: ARCELOR OF LUXEMBOURG SEEKS TO EXPAND IN STEEL IN U.S.
description: Arcelor, the world's largest steel maker, based in Luxembourg, said it was in talks with domestic steel producers to expand in the United States. One company, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, confirmed that it had talked to a potential buyer, which it did not identify, about selling one of its biggest mills, Burns Harbor, on Lake Michigan outside Chicago. Arcelor supplies one in three European cars and generates 12 percent of its sales in North America. Opened in 1962 to serve the auto, machine and appliance makers in the Midwest, Burns Harbor can produce 4.4 million tons of steel a year.

title: Struggling Hampton Ready to Hear Boos at Shea
description: Mike Hampton was not surprised by the boos that accompanied him to the mound when he made his return to Shea Stadium last August, less than a year after helping the Mets reach the World Series. Hampton was bombarded first by fans and then by the Mets, who knocked him out of the game.

title: Cardinal Law Wins A Delay in Release Of New Transcripts
description: On the second day of the deposition of Cardinal Bernard F. Law of Boston, a judge granted a request by archdiocesan lawyers today and ruled that further transcripts of the questioning could not be released until the cardinal had a chance to review and amend the transcripts.

title: INSIDE
description: Tracking Foreign Students

title: F.B.I. Agent Suing Bureau For Barring Book on Terror
description: An F.B.I. agent has sued the bureau for refusing to let him publish a book about what he says were botched efforts to investigate fund-raising by Hamas and other militant Islamic networks in the United States in the 1990's.

title: Possibility Of Big Spinoff Seen at Sony
description: The Sony Corporation said yesterday that its entertainment businesses, including hit movies like ''Spider-Man,'' were worth $14 billion to $19 billion, prompting speculation that the company planned to sell stock in them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOTO, JOSEPH R.
description: TOTO-Joseph R. Of Rye, NY and formerly of Croton-on-Hudson, NY died on May 9, 2002. He was 64. Mr. Toto until recently was a Creative Director and Senior Vice President at the D'Arcy Advertising Agency in New York City. He is survived by his wife Maria, his two children Michael Toto of Washington DC and Melissa Toto Purdon of Marietta, GA. Also survived by his sister Joyce of Queens, NY and brother Michael of Edison, NJ. Family will receive friends on Sunday from 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM at Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY. Mass of Christian Burial is Monday 11 AM at Resurrection Church in Rye. Interment will follow, Bethel Cemetery, Croton-on-Hudson, NY.

title: Panel Members Accuse FIFA's President of Misconduct
description: The struggle for control of FIFA, soccer's governing body, intensified yesterday when 11 members of the organization's executive committee initiated legal proceedings against their president, Joseph (Sepp) Blatter.

title: Rangers' Staff Meets to Discuss New Coach
description: The Rangers are scheduled to begin their annual organizational meetings on Monday at Glen Sather's home in La Quinta, Calif. The major topic, apparently, will be who Sather, the team's president and general manager, should select as the team's head coach.

title: Prosecutor Dismisses Twists in Murder Case
description: Twelve years after Lamont Branch was convicted of a murder he says he did not commit, a Brooklyn prosecutor told a judge yesterday that Mr. Branch's conviction should stand.

title: The Booing of Wolfowitz
description: Like many other Jews, I am perhaps all too willing to believe that the entire world is anti-Semitic. The Palestinians, certainly. Much of Europe, starting with the French -- and not just the Le Pen 18 percent but anyone who believed Jacques Chirac when he declared ''there is no anti-Semitism in France'' while synagogues burned. Then there are the Muslims from Jordan to Iran who, as Susan Sachs of The Times reported, offer that perennial wellspring of hatred, ''Protocols of the Elders of Zion,'' as a gift-shop keepsake at five-star hotels.

title: Illegal Immigrants: There's a Law
description: To the Editor:

title: The Wild, Wild West, and Basketball, Too
description: Mark Cuban, the 43-year-old owner of the Dallas Mavericks, and Joe Maloof, 46, the co-owner of the Sacramento Kings, teamed up for some brainless chitchat with a Dallas radio host on Thursday. Joe's brother, Gavin, 45, was supposed to take part in the pregame hype. But he had had a rough night.

title: DNA Tests Show Girl's Body Is Not That of Miami Child
description: The little girls share the sad fate of a childhood stolen but not a crescent-shaped birthmark, palm prints or, the authorities confirmed today, DNA.

title: Judge Denies Andersen Access to Notes
description: A federal judge ruled today that Arthur Andersen could not have access to notes taken by the lawyers for the chief witness against the firm in its obstruction of justice trial.

title: Strikers at Insurer Aim to Keep Free Benefits
description: Group Health Inc., the Manhattan-based health insurer, has long had a reputation as a paternalistic employer because of its tradition of giving its workers health coverage requiring no out-of-pocket expenses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, HELEN
description: JAFFE-Helen. On May 8, 2002. Wife of the late Henry. Loving mother of James Alan and the late Thomas. Devoted mother-inlaw of Ellin. Dear grandmother of Douglas, Phillip, Neil and great grandmother of Hannah, Grayson and Nathaniel. Service Sunday 11:00 a.m. at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Housing Opportunities
description: To the Editor:

title: BANK OF MONTREAL TO BUY A MORGAN STANLEY UNIT
description: The Bank of Montreal agreed to buy Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company's discount brokerage business for $106 million to expand in online trading. The transaction will increase Bank of Montreal's brokerage assets under administration by 23 percent, to $38 billion, and the number of accounts by 150,000, to about one million, said Ian Blair, a spokesman for the bank. In February, Bank of Montreal bought CSFBdirect, the online brokerage unit of Credit Suisse First Boston, for about $540 million. Morgan Stanley, which is based in New York, will focus on customers who use its 14,000 financial advisers. Bank of Montreal, based in Toronto, will merge the Morgan Stanley clients with CSFBdirect's into Harrisdirect.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: LOSS AT SOFTBANK The Internet investor Soft- bank lost money on a net basis for the first time as the value of its portfolio fell and it spent heavily to roll out its broadband business. The company lost 88.76 billion yen ($691 million) in the year that ended March 31 even though revenue increased 2.1 percent. Stung by losses in technology-driven companies, Softbank set up a subsidiary, Yahoo BB, which offers cheap high-speed Internet access. The service has bolstered cash flow, but still requires heavy investment in equipment and research.   Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Mothers Are the Wind Beneath Their Wings
description: When Mary Mazzio acted in a school play, became a cheerleader or rowed doubles in the 1992 Summer Olympics, she said her mother was always referred to as ''Mary Mazzio's mother.''

title: Producer Prices Tumbled Unexpectedly in April
description: Producer prices fell unexpectedly in April as food costs showed the biggest decline in almost three decades and sluggish demand made it harder for companies to charge more, the government reported today.

title: The Deepening Anthrax Mystery
description: It has been seven months since the anthrax attacks claimed their first victims, yet investigators seem no closer to finding the culprit than they were at the beginning. There was encouraging news this week that genetic analysis of the anthrax might prove a useful investigative tool, but for now the goal of identifying where the anthrax came from and who might have sent it through the mails remains as elusive as ever.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Pay TV Loss Narrows
description: The British Sky Broadcasting Group, the pay television company controlled by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, said it narrowed its third-quarter loss to 30.8 million ($45 million), or 1.6 pence a share, compared with 111.1 million, or 6 pence a share, a year earlier. British Sky Broadcasting said it added 171,000 subscribers in the quarter that ended March 31, bringing the total to 5.9 million.

title: Army Liaison Who Lobbied Congress for Weapon Resigns
description: The Army said today that it had accepted the resignation of a midlevel official who aggressively lobbied Congress to support an $11 billion artillery system that Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld had vowed to cancel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANGER, EDWINA CAMPBELL, M.D.

title: Math Teachers Who Almost Took Math
description: In January a young woman came to my office in search of an appropriate math course to qualify her for certification as a mathematics teacher. She was armed with a New York State Education Department form that indicated she was just one course short of meeting the math teacher requirements. Yet she had only one mathematics course -- pre-calculus -- on her college transcript. How could this be? The answer is that New York State credits courses for math certification that are really not math courses. I have seen accounting, finance, economics and engineering courses credited toward the math requirement.

The case could pose a constitutional test of whether Hong Kong's Public Order Ordinance complies with Hong Kong's Basic Law, which protects freedom of assembly. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: EBAY TO PAY AOL LESS IN AMENDED COMMISSION AGREEMENT
description: EBay said it would pay less to AOL Time Warner after renegotiating an advertising sales and marketing agreement last month. EBay will pay a maximum of $15 million in the agreement's first renewal year, rather than the $18.8 million it was to have paid in the period, which ends March 23, 2004, the company said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. AOL provides online advertising and marketing services for eBay. EBay is a provider of online trading services on AOL sites, and the companies have a co-branded Web site. The companies adjusted the commission structure for advertising sales and shortened the term of the agreement to March 31, 2003, from its previous termination at the end of next year. EBay will pay $10 million if the contract is extended for the year ending March 23, 2005.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank Downgraded
description: Standard & Poor's reduced Deutsche Bank's credit rating, another blow for the bank, Germany's biggest, at a time when its stock price is slumping and its executives are worried that the bank could fall victim to unwanted takeover attempts. Standard & Poor's dropped its rating on Deutsche to AA- from AA. It cited the bank's weakness in retail banking, stemming from overcrowding and low profits in the German market, as well as weakness in the world's security markets. Today's action follows similar downgrades at Germany's other big banks. Deutsche Bank has repeatedly failed to merge its retail banking network with those of a rival, a move that would make it easier to eliminate bank branches. Josef Ackermann, above, who will take over as chief executive later this month, has vowed to cut costs by 2 billion euros, sell off holdings in other companies and buy back some of its own shares. Standard & Poor's also reduced its rating on the Credit Suisse Group of Switzerland.

title: Time to Draw the Line

There are feints and dodges, with public maps brandished by the state's political leaders while the real cartography goes on behind closed doors. The self-protection and sneaky gamesmanship are beyond tiresome.

title: Editorial Observer; Old Personal Computers Never Die; They Just Fade Into Deep Storage
description: As a high school senior in the fall of 1983, I was in awe of Michael Jackson and Morris Miller. Michael had just come out with his ''Thriller'' video; my friend Morris owned a computer. In his very own bedroom, Morris had a Kaypro to administer his life and to churn out what we digital have-nots assumed could only have been flawless English papers. Never before, it seemed, had such formidable technology been mustered for such prosaic ends. Most astonishing, his Kaypro was portable. When he'd lovingly pack it in its steel traveling case, the thing weighed in at a nimble 30 pounds.

''They say [on Fox], 'We report, you decide,' but it's biased -- they decide before us,'' she said. ''They say there is no spin, but I get dizzy looking at it. I also get upset when they invite on Muslims and just insult them.''

title: EMISSIONS-TESTING ULTIMATUM
description: Governor McGreevey last week told the company that installed and operates the state's vehicle inspection system that it will have to reduce the amount it is charging New Jersey or risk losing its contract entirely. The system has been under scrutiny since its unveiling in 1999, when testing machines froze in cold weather. Investigations revealed that Parsons Infrastructure and Technology Group, the sole bidder for the state contract, had numerous connections within the Whitman administration before obtaining the contract. An audit released last week recommended renegotiating the $26 per inspection that Parsons is paid. In case negotiations fail, Governor McGreevey said, he was starting to look for another company to run the system. Karen DeMasters

title: Most Influential? It's Mom

Fifty-seven percent of the 411 executives from Fortune 1,000 companies who were asked that question last month said it was their mothers, versus 36 percent who cited their fathers and 7 percent their bosses, according to survey results released last week by Christian & Timbers, an executive search firm.

title: Gathers That Flatter
description: Short, puffy sleeves may be the rage, but their tightly gathered construction is unforgiving to women with less than perfectly shaped arms. This summer, designers are giving flabby triceps a break, shifting those unflattering sleeve gathers to more flattering locations, like plackets, dcolletage and back yokes. Michael Stars's sleeveless T-shirt ($40, above right) is gathered on a diagonal, while Catherine Malandrino's cotton blouse ($238, above left) sports a double set of gathers straight up the center placket, for a reversed-ruching effect (both at Henri Bendel). J. Crew prettifies the polo shirt with delicate detail along the front and back yokes ($24); Deesh's grosgrain-trimmed tanks have a tiny fan of gathers at the breastbone ($50 at Olive & Bette's). Rebecca Taylor's peasant tops are gently gathered at the dcolletage ($138 at Bergdorf Goodman).

title: 'Unless'
description: It happens that I am going through a period of great unhappiness and loss just now. All my life I've heard people speak of finding themselves in acute pain, bankrupt in spirit and body, but I've never understood what they meant. To lose. To have lost. I believed these visitations of darkness lasted only a few minutes or hours and that these saddened people, in between bouts, were occupied, as we all were, with the useful monotony of happiness. But happiness is not what I thought. Happiness is the lucky pane of glass you carry in your head. It takes all your cunning just to hang on to it, and once it's smashed you have to move into a different sort of life.

title: Seville's Siren Song

title: FOOTNOTES
description: 1. The man who captured Alanis in all her picturesque guises is the photographer Michael Elins, a Chicago native who has been in L.A. since the Bears won the Super Bowl in 1986. Originally an illustrator -- he worked on the ''Lord of the Rings'' movie poster -- Elins began blending painting and photography on computers, later figuring out how to animate his photos on the Internet. Elins says he flipped when he heard Alanis's ''Precious Illusions,'' the second single due to be released from ''Under Rug Swept.'' From that, he drew on visual inspirations, like paintings by the surrealist Frida Kahlo. ''Her paintings were her narrative, just like Alanis's life story can be understood through her lyrics.'' Ed Ruscha inspired him, too. ''He was all about words, pictures and words that became a novel without a plot, an implied narrative.'' And his third source was Marcel Duchamp's mustachioed Mona Lisa: ''It's about tweaking people; part of Alanis wants to startle, to make people think.''

title: 'The Dive From Clausen's Pier'
description: When something terrible happens to someone else, people often use the word "unbearable." Living through a child's death, a spouse's, enduring some other kind of permanent loss–it's unbearable, it's too awful to be borne, and the person or people to whom it's happened take on a kind of horrible glow in your mind, because they are in fact bearing it, or trying to: doing the thing that it's impossible to do. The glow can be blinding at first–it can be all you see–and although it diminishes as years pass it never goes out entirely, so that late some night when you are wandering the back pathways of your mind you may stop at the sudden sight of someone up ahead, signaling even now with a faint but terrible light.

Mr. Rumsfeld wants to plow $475 million earmarked for the program in 2003 into new technologies, but Congressional supporters say the mobile 155-millimeter howitzer is needed to replace a 40-year-old system. The Crusader is made by a unit of the Carlyle Group, where Frank C. Carlucci, a former secretary of defense, is president, and former President George Bush is a senior adviser. Eric Schmitt

title: Faltering on the Home Front

It's not too late to turn the Office of Homeland Security into a powerhouse, but Mr. Ridge and his patron, President Bush, will have to break some china and insist that Washington's balkanized bureaucracy follow the lead of the White House.

(Cantankerous Aunt Edna eventually expires and is tied to the luggage rack, for instance.) But today the family vacation is making a roaring comeback. In the past year, 37 percent of leisure travelers took trips with their kids, compared with only 26 percent two years earlier, according to a survey by the marketing firm Yesawich, Pepperdine & Brown.

title: QUICK BITE/New Brunswick; When a Cooked Goose Was a Good Thing
description: They didn't cook quiche for company 140 years ago, at least not in New Jersey. Roast goose was more like it. There is a recipe for goose in ''The Housewives Pocket Companion, Dime Cookbook Embodying What is Most Economical, Most Practical, Most Excellent'' by Mrs. Victor, published in Newark in 1859. How about okra soup and oyster patties? The recipes are in ''Choice Recipes Compiled by Ladies of Elizabeth New Jersey,'' published in 1881. More recently, the New Vernon Volunteer Fire Department put a recipe for Holiday Mashed Potatoes made with cream cheese in ''Burnt Offerings'' (1993). These cookbooks are part of the Sinclair Jerseyana Cookbook Collection at the Archibald S. Alexander Library of Rutgers in New Brunswick. The collection includes more than 500 cookbooks going back to the 19th century compiled by organizations like churches, hospital auxiliaries, libraries, the Daughters of the American Revolution, Junior Leagues, schools, bridge clubs and Red Cross chapters. The library is are still collecting cookbooks, according to Bonita Craft Grant, the New Jersey bibliographer, who notes that preserving cookbooks can be a challenge because of all the food stains. As someone identified only as Lucille, one of the Elizabeth ladies, rhymed, ''We may live without poetry, music and art, We may live without conscience and live without heart, We may live without friends, We may live without books, But civilized man can't live without cooks.'' Margo Nash

title: Dig It
description: For about 300 years, Murray Street was a street. Then, last winter, after the World Trade Center went down, it was dug up and turned into a hole. Not a little hole. Not a hole with a few flags and two or three workers and a blinking yellow light. The hole that was Murray Street was a crumbling and steaming and wooden-plank-reinforced earthen gash, which, if it weren't lying sideways across the border of TriBeCa and the financial district, would have been about 100 stories tall. In January, on a cold, clear morning, just after the underground version of Murray Street had been opened up, Mike Redes, a project manager for Empire City Subway, a Verizon-owned company that maintains utilities under the street, was standing on a single-family-home-size plot of subterranean real estate in which Murray Street meets Church Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALTER, BARBARA CLARE, M.D.
description: WALTER-Barbara Clare, M.D. Of Los Angelas, CA, who grew up and was educated in New York City, died on May 3, 2002. Born in Jamaica, West Indes, August 5, 1946, she earned an MSW at Columbia University 1971, and an M.D. at Mt. Sinai School of Medicine 1978. Completed a residency at Kaiser Foundation Hospital 1979. Post doctural residency in anesthesiology at UCLA 1982, and was Board Certified and practiced in Los Angeles and surrounding areas for 20 years. Barbara was active in community and social activities, as well as being a cornerstone in her extended family. She was an inspiration to all who knew her and she will be sorely missed by family and friends. She is survived by her mother Winnifred, sisters Moira, Dawn and Vanessa, brother Colbert, niece Ivana, nephew Hugh, her canine children Tasha and Mercedes, and numerous other relatives and friends. Barbara will be cremated and scattered off the coast of Redondo Beach, CA. Memorial services will be held in Los Angeles, Fort Lauderdale and New York City. For those wishing to express condolences the family requests you make a donation to a charity of your choice in Barbara's name.

title: Editorial Observer; The Constitution Does Not Protect Spamming
description: There's a new television commercial that pulls viewers in with a flurry of poignant phrases: ''I love you'' . . . ''I felt the baby move'' . . . ''It's benign.'' The voice-over is a salute to free speech. ''All words are created equal,'' it says. ''The power to use them is our right as humans.'' Has the First Amendment gone out and gotten itself an advertising strategy? Not quite. The ad is for a phone company. The freedom it celebrates is in a calling plan that says ''local and long distance calls are unlimited.'' Not exactly what James Madison had in mind when he gave the First Amendment top billing in the Bill of Rights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSTROVE, LESTER L. M.D., F.A.C.S.
description: OSTROVE - Lester L. M.D., F.A.C.S., May 4, 2002. Inspiration to three generations of family, friends and colleagues for his integrity, steadfastness, generosity of spirit and love of learning. Born July 4, 1913. Served as flight surgeon in WW II. Practiced general surgery at Lincoln Hospital; Bronx-Lebanon Hospital, where he was President of Medical Board; and St. Barnabas Hospital, where he was Director of Surgery. Served as President of the Bronx Chapter of the American College of Surgeons and was Clinical Assistant Professor of Surgery at Albert Einstein College of Medicine. In 1975 he was honored by the United Jewish Appeal for his service to the organization. In retirement, he continued to serve the medical community in various capacities. Well into his eighties, he was a force to be reckoned with on the fairways of Alpine CC. He is survived by his wife Kate, a daughter Sue Ann Heller, and grandaughters Samantha and Alison Heller; son-in-law, Charles Heller, and two grandsons-in-law, Raj Bhattacharrya and Glen W. Roberts II; and a brother Bert Ostrove. His nieces and nephews will also miss his love and wisdom. He was devoted to his family and much loved and respected by all who knew him.

title: 'Interesting Women'

The phone could be trilling its electronic morsel of Mozart or Bacharach in a big vulgar villa with guard dogs and closed-circuit cameras on the bosky shores of Lake Como. Or in an overpriced hotel suite in Portofino. Or why not in the Aeolian Islands, or on Ischia, or Sardinia? It’s late September, and all over the Mediterranean the yachts of politicians and arms manufacturers and pan-Slavic gangsters are still snuggled side by side in the indulgent golden light of harbors where the calendars of the toiling masses mean nothing. The truth is that the phone could be ringing anywhere in the world where there are rich men.
