title: RABBI MURDER RETRIAL
description: The retrial of Fred Neulander, the Cherry Hill rabbi accused of ordering the murder of his wife in 1994, will probably be moved to Freehold in Monmouth County, a court spokesman said last week. Judge Linda Baxter of Camden County Superior Court has agreed to move the trial away Cherry Hill, because of publicity in the Philadelphia media market surrounding the first trial, which ended in a mistrial with a hung jury in November. Judge Baxter will hold a hearing on Friday on requests to move the retrial, but a Monmouth County court spokesman said Freehold was the likely choice for the trial, is scheduled to begin in late summer or the fall. Robert Strauss

title: California, Here We Come: Scientists Warn of Earthquakes Here
description: Now that New Yorkers have faced and conquered fear, seismologists are ready to talk. The next disaster, they want you to know, may not be a terrorist attack, but an old-fashioned earthquake. The last big one had its epicenter off Coney Island on Aug. 10, 1884. Estimated at 5.2 on the Richter scale, it toppled hundreds of chimneys in the city. An equivalent tremor off Coney Island today could cause $750 million in damage in Manhattan alone.

title: Franco Faces Big Decision
description: John Franco will travel with the Mets tonight to Los Angeles, where he will meet with his agents to make decisions about the surgery to repair the torn medial collateral ligament and torn flexor tendon in his left elbow. Franco said Frank Jobe and Lewis Yocum, who are based in California, and James Andrews, who is in Alabama, are the orthopedists he is considering seeing for second opinions.

description: Joseph Bonanno, who founded one of the nation's most enduring Mafia families and rose to the pinnacle of organized crime in America, died yesterday in Tucson, where he had been living for many years. He was 97.

title: Mourning My Miscarriage
description: There is another shrine, called Suitengu, that complements the temple Orenstein visited. Suitengu is situated in a northeastern Tokyo neighborhood called Ningyocho, or Doll Town, which is full of small maternity and toy shops. The shrine is dedicated to the safety of mother and child in pregnancy and childbirth. This shrine and Zozo-ji, the temple described in the article, reflect a Japanese sensibility that spiritualizes the perils and losses associated with pregnancy -- whether merely feared, actually encountered or happily averted.

title: Karlovy Vary
description: To the Editor: I was reminded by ''A Spa Slacker in Karlovy Vary'' (April 21) of the time in the mid-1990's when my wife, son and I were invited to a concert of Johann Strauss music at the Hollywood Bowl. After the customary alfresco dinner of things with sprouts and bottles of merlot, the audience was treated to a concert so tongue-in-cheek that during the ''hunters polka,'' the fur coat-clad conductor fired a toy rifle into the air, bringing down a brace of rubber chickens. Hilarious.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNOFSKY, ARTHUR M.
description: KUNOFSKY-Arthur M. Of New York, New York, on May 10, 2002, at age 64. Beloved husband of Rita Robbins Kunofsky, son of Helen Kunofsky and the late Herman Kunofsky, father of Glen and Harris Kunofsky, and sister of Shirley Vituli. His dear nieces and nephews, and dozens of other family members and friends also survive him. To Arthur, his family was everything, although his affinity for all people was apparent to all who knew or encountered him. Arthur's renowned sense of humor and ability to enjoy the simplest pleasures in life, even throughout his illness, made the world a better place. We will all miss him terribly. May he rest in peace. Arthur was raised in Brooklyn, and served as the Principal of IS 180, in the Bronx, until 1990. Funeral service at 9:30 AM, Sunday, May 12th at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Arthur's memory to the Aplastic Anemia & MDS International Foundation, Inc, PO Box 613, Annapolis, MD 21404 or www.aamds.org.

title: OPEC Ministers Signal That Group Has No Plan to Lift Oil Output
description: Two OPEC ministers said today that oil supplies were adequate, indicating they had no plan to raise production to stem the 33 percent surge in prices so far this year.

title: ENRON'S NAME GAMES
description: Fat Boy. Death Star. Get Shorty. These were the cocky nicknames Enron traders gave their strategies to manipulate California's electricity prices in 2000 and 2001, when the company was riding high, exploiting weaknesses in the state's deregulated electricity market. Enron has collapsed, but California officials hope internal e-mail messages about its trading games will help them persuade regulators and juries that Enron and other energy traders should return some of the profits they made at California's expense during its yearlong energy crisis. Joseph Kahn

title: Assembling Collections From All Temperatures
description: THE current exhibition at Real Art Ways in Hartford puts the spotlight on four private collections of contemporary art in Connecticut. Its title, ''Acquiring Taste,'' is intriguing because it might mean that we viewers might acquire taste while surveying the art objects. Or the show might be a record of how the collectors came to know what they like.

title: McEwing's One Swing Ends Gloom For Mets
description: Joe McEwing was expecting a fastball from Mike Hampton with two Mets on base and two outs in the sixth inning because he always expects fastballs and then adjusts to whatever is thrown. Hampton threw a fastball because he wanted to bury McEwing, continue breezing past the sluggish Mets and keep suppressing the boos that had reverberated throughout Shea Stadium.

title: Admitting To Mixed Feelings About Motherhood
description: SINCE its publication last fall, Naomi Wolf's ''Misconceptions: Truth, Lies and the Unexpected on the Journey to Motherhood'' has become a staple of baby shower gift baskets. Ms. Wolf, who has made a career of turning her rites of passage into social critiques, details the difficulties of her second pregnancy, the lack of support for new mothers and the toll that parenthood takes on couples. The book, which rejects the conventional, nurturing tone of popular baby advice books, is one of several published recently that challenge the prevailing image of this second Sunday in May -- of motherhood as Hallmark card.

title: Who Was Responsible for Elizabeth Shin?
description: I was struck by how greatly the university administrators relied on Elizabeth Shin's classmates to care for her. It seems that they were more willing to burden her dorm mates and friends than her own parents, who should have been made aware of her illness and the necessity for immediate medical treatment. Had the fire that Shin set injured or killed those around her, M.I.T. would now be facing greater legal liabilities.

title: Who Was Responsible for Elizabeth Shin?
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology may have erred in its responsibility to Elizabeth Shin's parents; the court will decide that. A lack is achingly apparent in the school's inadequate provision of mental-health care to this troubled girl. With Shin's history of self-mutilation and suicidal ideation, a clear plan for killing herself and downward-spiraling thoughts of worthlessness, all steeping in the pressure keg that is M.I.T., no practitioner should have sent her back to her dorm room. M.I.T. may need a court order to change the way it keeps parents informed; it should not wait to upgrade its mental-health staff.

title: 'Tonight at Noon'
description: Imet Charles Mingus shortly before midnight in July 1964. I'd gone down to the Five Spot, a jazz club in lower Manhattan, because the producer of a film I was acting in had commissioned a jazz soundtrack from saxophonist Ornette Coleman–at least he thought he had commissioned a soundtrack–and my friend Sam Edwards, who was working on the film, suggested I check out the scene. I didn't know the first thing about jazz. Sam warned me I was not with it, especially for someone in New York, but added in his usual upbeat fashion that anyone could learn. Members of the cast had given me an Ornette Coleman album called Something Else , and I had listened over and over to a Miles Davis record called Miles Ahead , because the director of the film had played it over and over in the apartment where we were shooting during the long intervals between takes. That was the extent of my baptism into the music.

title: Death by Drowning
description: Last August I spent a couple of days with a group of friends in the small town of Yusufeli, in Turkey's remote northeast. I didn't realize at the time that this might be my last chance to do so. Yusufeli has a rough and ready air, and the hotels are spartan, but with its beer gardens and restaurants suspended above the raging waters of the Barhal River, it has a certain raffish charm. In the last two decades it has become increasingly popular with foreign visitors. Numbers have tripled, and with good reason: the surrounding landscape of soaring mountains, alpine meadows and sheer-sided canyons is spectacular. It is also completely unspoiled, and scattered with magnificent Georgian churches, built mostly in the 10th century by the princes of Tayk-Tao. If you want to see the churches, go trekking in the mountains or rafting on the rivers, you have to stay in Yusufeli, a minimum of three hours from Istanbul by plane and bus.

title: The Mother's Day Instinct
description: All last week, small classified ads appeared in local papers across the country, each a public testimonial wishing mom a happy Mother's Day in a few lines of black ink. A sudden spring of blossoms came to flower shops across the country, too, and made its way, this morning, into the hands of women everywhere. The greeting card industry went into overdrive so even the most inexpressive but grateful of grown-up children would have a way to put in words how they felt. The phone lines and wireless connections will be jammed today with filial good wishes, calls placed for the sole purpose of hearing the most familiar voice in the world on the other end of the line.

title: CARDINAL LAW TESTIFIES
description: Cardinal Bernard F. Law, the Boston archbishop, answered questions under oath for the first time about the case that set off the sex abuse scandal rocking the Roman Catholic Church. Ordered to testify by a judge who feared that the cardinal could be transferred to the Vatican at any time, Cardinal Law said he delegated most decisions about the pedophile priest John J. Geoghan and did not recall most crucial details about his first involvement with the case, including letters written in 1984 by a bishop and the aunt of seven Geoghan victims warning him of Father Geoghan's past sexual abuse. Cardinal Law transferred the priest to a parish in which he is accused of molesting scores of children. Pam Belluck

title: Baby Talk
description: I keep trying to find an analogy for the kind of April Ashanti Douglas had, but there really isn't one. On April 2, her debut album, ''Ashanti,'' opened at No.1 on the Billboard 200 and R&B/hip-hop charts. In a week it sold more than a half million copies. No ''first-time female artist'' had ever done that. Meanwhile, three singles featuring Ashanti, who is 21 and comes from Glen Cove, N.Y., were entering the Top 10 of the Billboard Hot 100 at the same time. Only the Beatles had ever done that. Let's face it. If you're still at an age where love pangs get in the way of your homework, this is an Ashanti spring.

title: U.N. ON CHILDREN
description: At a special session of the U.N. General Assembly, delegates from 180 countries forged a broad consensus on issues ranging from exploitative child labor and AIDS prevention to the impact of armed conflict on children. But there were fractious debates over sex. In the end, the Bush administration, the Vatican and some Islamic states lost their effort to remove references to abortion among reproductive health services for teenagers and to promote sexual abstinence. But the European Union lost, too: the final document contains no bars against the use of capital punishment against minors. Somini Sengupta

title: Where Earhart, not Lindbergh, Is the Hero
description: BOZENA SYSKA, a graphic designer, packed her 2-year-old daughter, Daria, into her car seat and her mutt, Czarna, on the back seat of her single-engine Piper Cherokee Warrior as if they were going to the park. Then she climbed into the cockpit, taxied down the runway at Brookhaven Calabro Airport and took off. She soared into the sky, reaching 2,000 feet, then swooped around and headed back in for a landing, aiming for wide line drawn across the 4,200-foot runway. Landing way past it, she taxied back in line again for takeoff. Like a child taking another whirl on a merry-go-round to grab the brass ring, she looped the airport and tried to land on the line again.

title: The Heat Doing Things To the Heart
description: IT'S a standard summer scene in the city. Only the little things change. In 1944, in Fritz Lang's ''Woman in the Window,'' Edward G. Robinson is a professor at Gotham College. He lectures on the degrees of homicide, with a handkerchief peeping just so from his breast pocket. Then, next morning, he puts his wife and two children on the train for Maine. (It would be wrong to omit that his son, a pretty little boy, is Robert Blake -- likely to spend much of this summer in jail awaiting trial.) Robinson tells his family that he'll be thinking of them: ''Every second of the day. Every minute of the night.'' And the late June warmth falls kindly on his fond lies.

title: Andrea Foreman, Steven Kline
description: Andrea Lyn Foreman, a daughter of Sandra Foreman and Dr. Spencer Foreman of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Steven Paul Kline, a son of Sharon Adams of Mahwah, N.J., and Dick Kline of Los Angeles. Rabbi Mordecai Genn officiated at the Pierre.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the alcoholic beverage market in India referred incorrectly to a 10 percent annual growth rate. That is the rate of increase in the country's alcoholic beverage consumption, according to the All India Distillers Association. It is not India's annual population growth rate, which is 1.93 percent.

title: Writing in Circles To Arrive at the Truth
description: HAVE you ever noticed how politeness and prurience tend to warp intimate conversations? Have you noticed how in families everybody talks to the sister with the drinking problem about everything but her drinking problem and to the gay brother about everything but being gay, and yet those subjects keep leaking to the surface anyway?

title: POSTINGS: Top 4 Floors in Chelsea to Be Above the Adjacent Structure; Condo Shaped Like Inverted L
description: At first glance it might seem as if it's going to be one building, but it's really two. The one on the left is a new nine-story condominium going up at 211 West 18th Street in Chelsea -- and its upper four floors hang over and are attached to the adjacent old five-story commercial building.

title: Kathryn Whipple, Mark Raimy
description: Kathryn Elizabeth Whipple, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce R. Whipple of West Pittston, Pa., was married yesterday to Mark Harvey Raimy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce H. Raimy of Erie, Pa. The Rev. William Bergen performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: A Professor's 800 Pieces of Islam
description: WHEN he was 12, Maan Madina collected grasshoppers while on vacation with his family in the Golan Heights, which was then in Syria, about an hour's drive from his home in Damascus. ''There was an infestation of them and I cannot remember how many different types I found in the scores I kept,'' he said. ''But I didn't know how to preserve them dead or alive. So, several days later when they began to smell, my mother threw them out.''

title: As Rates Rise, Some Municipal Bonds Keep Their Luster
description: ALTHOUGH interest rates rose last week and are expected to move higher as the economy recovers, there are still some bonds ripe for the picking by cautious investors in the municipal market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, PATRICK
description: PORTER-Patrick. Died on May 9, 2002 in New York City. The many friends of Patrick Porter mourn his loss. As a member of the British Army's invading force, he landed on Normandy Beach on DDay. An extraordinarily creative fashion designer and former Professor of Design at the Pratt Institute. He is survived by his companion, Charles B. Selden. Condolences in the form of charitable contributions may be made to Doctors Without Borders, Box 94, Tom's River, N.J. 08754.

title: Trials Test the Faith of Rwandans
description: Every day, it is the mass spilling of blood that dominates the debates in the rambling courthouse of Arusha, a town in Tanzania. Always the questions are grave, but sometimes they weigh more heavily, as they do now.

title: Molire's 'Don Juan,' Skillfully Reconstructed
description: WHO wrote ''Don Juan,'' the new old play at the McCarter Theater? The answer would seem to be Molire, but you don't have to believe what the program says.

title: Elizabeth Bolton, James Huang
description: Elizabeth Byrne Bolton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis X. Bolton of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to James Huang, a son of Dr. Mona Huang of East Windsor, N.J., and the late Dr. Chen-Ya Huang. Msgr. Joseph Nagle performed the ceremony at St. Saviour Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn.

title: Habitats/Bank Street in Greenwich Village; Making Small Apartment Seem as if It's Larger
description: FOR certain kinds of New Yorkers, there is no style of housing more appealing than the loft. They picture a high-ceilinged, wide-open space, an urban version of the frontier, with a sense of limitless possibility.

title: Carla Madeira, Frank Pellegrino Jr.
description: Carla Madeira and Frank Pellegrino Jr. were married yesterday by the Rev. Fanny Erickson, a United Church of Christ minister, at Riverside Church in New York.

title: Year by Year, The Summer's Biggest
description: Summer movies used to be movies set in the summer, or movies that happened to open between June ad September. But in 1975, that all changed. Steven Spielberg's ''Jaws'' took a huge bite of the audience. Hollywood was on to something, epic-size action, and the summer blockbuster was born. Here are some past blockbusters, their directors and the domestic box-office gross for the initial release. BEN SISARIO

title: Poland's Heritage
description: To the Editor:

title: Let's Dance
Out of the Ruins, A Career Emerges
description: BEFORE Sept. 11, David Margules had never taken a professional photograph.

title: The Stars Come Out for a Jazzman on a Journey
description: SHAKESPEARE never played the blues, but he definitely understood the making of a career: ripeness is all. Bill Charlap has been on the scene since the late 80's, and his youthful tours of duty with Gerry Mulligan and Phil Woods long ago made it clear that he was a pianist worth watching. Still, it has been only in the last year or so that Mr. Charlap, 35, has come into his own as a star in the making.

title: Corrections
description: The Choice Tables column on April 28, about Hanoi, misstated the pronunciation for pho, the noodle soup served at storefronts. It is fuh, not feh.

title: Who Was Responsible for Elizabeth Shin?
description: Elizabeth Shin's parents knew she had been admitted to a mental hospital but did not ensure that she had follow-up care. Many at M.I.T. tried to help Shin, and clearly help was readily available. Her death might have been a tragic accident, a cry for release from outrageous demands, including her own, or an intentional suicide; we will never know. Nevertheless, she took this action by herself, and no one else can be held accountable.

title: Irony Maiden
description: ''The truth is messy, incoherent, aimless, boring, absurd. The truth does not make a good story; that's why we have art.'' Janet Malcolm

title: A Diploma for the Ages
description: AFTER 170 seniors gather in Kenny Memorial Stadium on campus next Sunday to hear Anne Mulcahy, '74, chairwoman of the board and chief executive officer of Xerox Corporation, give the commencement address, they will be the last class to receive Marymount College degrees. Effective July 1, Marymount, the women's liberal arts college in Tarrytown, will merge with Fordham University and degrees will be awarded by Marymount College of Fordham University.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 21 about Florida's place in the national culture referred incorrectly to the standoff between Branch Davidians and the F.B.I. in Waco, Tex., which occurred during the tenure of Janet Reno as attorney general of the United States and is getting new attention in light of her campaign for the Florida governorship. The investigation of the standoff led by former Senator John Danforth was independent, not Congressional. According to the Danforth report, the Branch Davidians were responsible for the fire inside their compound; it was not started by the F.B.I. The number of Branch Davidians who died was about 80, not 75, including more than 20 children, not 25. The previous office held by Reno was state attorney for Dade County, Fla., not state attorney general.

title: Sports of The Times; Bonds, the Babe and the All-Time Hitters
description: WITH every Barry Bonds home run, the question becomes more intriguing: where will he eventually rank on baseball's all-time list of great players?

title: Bernie Mac Smacks A Nerve
description: The Glamour Nail Salon is in a suburban strip mall 20 minutes outside Chicago. On this gray April afternoon, the clients are respectable, churchgoing black women of a certain age; they sit at the buffing stations, wearing sweat pants, reading Ebony and chatting quietly about their kids. Swinging open the glass door, Bernie Mac (n McCullough) disrupts this female sanctuary with characteristic brio: ''Whassup, you squares!''

title: Sequels? Sure. But Godard, Too.
description: THE Jedi knights are back. So are the under-age spies, the small-town serial killer, the talking mouse, the mod 60's agent with bad teeth and a pair of men who look great in black. Otherwise it looks like a catchall season, maybe because so much has happened since Americans last settled in for something as frivolous as a new batch of summer movies.

title: Is It Our Right to Own Guns?
description: To the Editor:

title: Newark Race's Contrasts Extend to the Volunteers
description: They are passionate political zealots devoted to charismatic and ambitious men. They thrive on coffee and junk food. They get by on four hours' sleep. And when it comes to their candidate, they are prone to hyperbole and hubris.

title: China's Surgical Craze
description: To the Editor:

title: Heading Downtown for Bargains and Dim Sum
description: TWO years ago, bottom-fishing for cheap hotel rooms in New York City, I found it was possible to stay comfortably, if not luxuriously, for less than $120 a night. With the city's hotels seeing a downturn in business recently, I decided to revisit the bottom end, this time with a twist, staying only in hotels below Houston Street. I thought that downtown hotels would have reduced prices further to attract customers. But I also wanted to remain below Houston Street because this is the part of New York where my inner traveler feels most content.

title: Lies From the Heart
description: The Chinese filmmaker Zhang Yimou has two styles -- one for the studio, where he creates lush, carefully lighted period melodramas like ''Raise the Red Lantern'' and ''To Live,'' and another for the street, where he allows his camera to discover, free of any apparent artifice, pointed comic fables about life in contemporary China like ''Not One Less'' and ''The Story of Qiu Ju.''

title: Commercial Property/Connecticut; Finding a Strong Niche in Central Fairfield County
description: IN 1983, Carl Kuehner III and his brother Paul, both still in school, began working in the family's company, Building and Land Technology, by upgrading and selling 10 homes in an existing New Canaan development. Since then, after branching out on their own, the brothers have completed ventures worth more than $1 billion as developers, builders, historic redevelopers, buyers, sellers or marketers of land in 6 office parks, 8 apartment complexes, 16 single family subdivisions, 13 common-interest communities run by boards of residents and 8 adaptive reuse projects.

title: Hotel Hideaway
description: FINALLY, after weeks and weeks of telling about only ''good'' restaurants, I'm delighted to report on Chez Catherine, where the food is excellent, the atmosphere elegant and the service is almost as good.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: JOHN HENRY DAYS, by Colson Whitehead. (Anchor, $14.) This novel, chosen by the editors of the Book Review as one of the best books of 2001, tells two tales -- that of the legendary ''steel-driving man'' John Henry and that of J. Sutter, a black freelance journalist and avid junketeer whose interior crisis of manhood is played out against a backdrop of today's pop-crazed consumer society and the publicity machine that fuels it. The result is a ''funny and wise and sumptuously written'' tale, Jonathan Franzen wrote in these pages.

title: Ventura's Homer Gives Yankees Fifth Straight Victory
description: Somewhere, there must be videotape of Robin Ventura facing American League pitchers like Eddie Guardado. But it would be mostly old footage, from Ventura's days with the Chicago White Sox, and the Yankees do not have it. So when Ventura needs to study a pitcher, even if he has faced him before, he watches tapes of Tino Martinez and Paul O'Neill, left-handed hitters who used to play for the Yankees.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Renewing Friendships For a Fourth Summer
description: WHEN Brandi Moses visits Elizabeth and Rodd Berro in the summer, she gets to mingle with three generations: Mr. Berro, a money manager, 43, his wife, a pediatric nurse, 37, their children, Kelsey, 8, and Zachary, 6. And there is also Nathan Berro, 80, Mr. Berro's father, who lives in his own wing of the family's redwood house here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, NATALIE F.
description: ROTH-Natalie F. Age 84, on May 11, 2002. Wife of the late Norman H. Roth. Mother of Stephen H. Roth, Dr. Barbara Roth-Marsh and Dorothy Scholz. Grandmother of David and Serena Roth and Joshua and Lauren Scholz. Services Monday, 10:30 AM, at ''Wien & Wien,'' 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ. Contributions may be made to Temple Beth El, Kennedy Boulevard, Jersey City, NJ.

title: Bush Beans, Short in Stature but High in Flavor
description: WHEN it comes to string beans, the question facing vegetable gardeners is not when but which. When is dictated by nature, and at my house in central New Jersey that time is now because the soil has warmed up and temperatures are no longer freezing.

title: WITHOUT U.S.
description: For those who depict the Bush administration as eager to shun multilateral arrangements, the State Department provided fresh evidence when it announced that the U.S. was withdrawing its signature from the treaty creating an International Criminal Court. Officials said the treaty would give too much power to an unaccountable international prosecutor who could initiate capricious cases against U.S. policymakers and soldiers. The administration also said it would not cooperate in any way with the court, set to begin operation soon in The Hague. Neil A. Lewis

title: There Is Nothing Funny About This Image
description: HE was still every inch the childlike kidder in need of Ritalin, the warp-drive banterer of a thousand voices, the sweaty satirist scathingly on top of the day's events.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BADER, NATHAN
description: BADER-Nathan. Daddy, two years ago today. I miss you so much. Goodnight, sweet Prince. All my love, Ann

title: Robin Reitzes, Adam Kern
description: Robin Elizabeth Reitzes, the daughter of Bobbi and Robert Reitzes of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married last evening to Adam Samuel Kern, a son of Marjorie Malina-Kern and Joel Kern, also of Chappaqua. Rabbi Eric Siroka officiated at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: A Temple of Fashion
description: As department stores furiously specialize with in-house boutiques, Leah Forester (seated) and Heather Rich are taking a macro approach with Decollage, a style world version of a general store. Decollage, in a town house on Eighth Avenue at West 12th Street, is store, art gallery, coffeehouse and party space.

title: For Ad Agencies, a Year of Ups and Downs
description: CLOSE to 700 advertising executives and their clients are expected to turn out on Tuesday evening, when the Long Island Advertising Club holds its 29th annual Best of Long Island awards gala at the Vanderbilt in Plainview.

title: In Brief
description: THE ROCKAWAYS

title: Making the 'Easy' Jump From Hip-Hop to Screen
description: IN 1997, the Notorious B.I.G. insulted his fellow rappers by claiming that their tough talk was mere play-acting. They ''deserve Oscars,'' he sneered. Five years later, Will Smith was nominated for an Academy Award in ''Ali,'' nearly turning B.I.G.'s insult into a prophecy. Mr. Smith lost to Denzel Washington, who was recognized for his performance in ''Training Day,'' a film that featured supporting performances by Snoop Dogg and Dr. Dre.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, MICHAEL
description: O'CONNOR-Michael. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Michael O'Connor, with The Times from 1962 until retiring in 1993.

title: A Tale of Requited Love: A Man and a Pipe Organ
description: This is a love story about a man and a pipe organ.

title: Investing; Where Telecom Bargain Hunters Turn
description: IT has been two months since Ivan G. Seidenberg, the chief executive of Verizon Communications, mused at an investment conference that his company might bid for WorldCom ''for the fun of it'' if the stock price of that long-distance and Internet carrier continued falling.

title: Will Wall Street Become a Regular at the Courthouse?
description: BROKERAGE firms' stocks have been battered since Eliot L. Spitzer, the New York attorney general, released documents showing how alarmingly symbiotic the relationship was between Merrill Lynch's research and investment banking departments in recent years. Assuming that more damaging revelations are coming, investors have driven down the American Stock Exchange Securities Broker/Dealer index of 12 publicly traded securities firms by 12 percent in just the last month or so.

title: Marching as to War
description: THE NEXT CHRISTENDOM

title: Private Sector; Now It's a Parisian in America
description: Serge Weinberg, the chief executive of Pinault-Printemps-Redoute, the French retail and luxury-goods conglomerate, said he had high regard for some American competitors -- notably Wal-Mart Stores and Home Depot. But in a visit last week to New York, where he met with financial journalists, Mr. Weinberg said there were certain American business practices that he could not understand -- like executive pay. For many American executives, he said, it seems that ''money is the ultimate goal.'' But, he added, ''I'm not putting a judgment on it; it's just different.'' In Europe, where executive pay is modest by American standards, there is little public disclosure about the salaries and bonuses of corporate leaders, although that is slowly changing.

title: Guilt Trip
description: THE DIVE FROM CLAUSEN'S PIER

title: Shanahan And Wings Eliminate The Blues
description: Despite a damaged knee that may require surgery, Steve Yzerman, the team captain, leads the Detroit Red Wings in playoff scoring with 13 points. So the St. Louis Blues made him a target in the Western Conference semifinals of the Stanley Cup playoffs. That was their mistake, as they learned again today when the Wings eliminated them with a 4-0 victory in Game 5 of the four-of-seven-game series at Joe Louis Arena.

title: In the Eye of One Beholder, Only Beauty
description: EVENTS in the beauty world -- that comfy, familiar haven of lip glosses and blushers -- rarely have any wide-reaching reverberations. But last Tuesday, when the makeup artist Kevyn Aucoin died of a rare pituitary condition at age 40, the news resonated beyond cosmetics counters and out into the larger bailiwick of style. The beauty industry had lost a star.

title: Letters: Layne Stanley
description: Be Slow to Judge

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIROKA, HAROLD
description: SIROKA-Harold. On May 10, 2002. Beloved husband of Shirley for 54 years, devoted father of Roberta Siroka and Steven Strauss, Martin and Susan Siroka, Dr. Peter and Cathy Siroka, and Madeline and Howard Cohen. Dear brother of Pearl Hager, Miriam Wexler, and Meyer Siroka. Loving grandfather of Peter, Alex, Matthew, Michael and Gabrielle. Proud Marine Corps veteran of World War II. Pop, we will miss your strength and your smile. Services Monday, 1 PM, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: The Newest Wrinkle In a Not So New Rivalry
description: When The New York Blade News, a gay newspaper, hit the streets five years ago, its rival played the gay card.

title: Neeta Sharma, Alfred Ogden III
description: Dr. Neeta Sharma, a daughter of Dr. Usha Sharma and Dr. Madho K. Sharma of Edison, N.J., was married at her parents' house yesterday to Dr. Alfred Trecartin Ogden III, the son of Patricia P. McGrath and Mr. Ogden II, both of New York. Pandit Anand Mohan performed the Hindu ceremony.

title: The Botox Party Arrives on the Island
description: MARY BROOK had an idea. What better way, the Greenvale spa owner reasoned, to generate a little business and celebrate the Food and Drug Administration's recent approval of botulinum toxin type A, otherwise known as Botox, than with a party? Something like a Tupperware party, but with injections.

title: Broken Windows Or Broken Promises?
description: ON June 12, 1996, the police arrested John Royster, one day after the slaying of Evelyn Alvarez, a beloved Park Avenue dry cleaner.

title: Maiden Voyage: Child on a Business Trip
description: NEXT weekend, I will bring my 11-year-old son along on a business trip. I've been spending the better part of this month traveling the country promoting my new book, a trip suffused with the discomfiting irony that while I'm out talking about the balance between life and work, my sons are both back home. I miss them like crazy, and they surely miss me, so having Evan along in Washington for three days will be a comfort.

title: On Slightly Less Lush Streets, The Flower-Mad Find Ways to Cope
description: It is spring, but the flowers that typically grace the tree beds and vest-pocket parks of the East Side have not sprung. The thirsty blossoms that used to roll through the neighborhood this time of year have been relegated to a damper past.

title: Street Kids
description: Since I work near a museum, I often encounter parents restraining young children from crossing the street until the walk signal appears. Ordinarily I'd freely cross against the light if no cars were coming, but I'm concerned that my doing so might undermine the parents' laudable efforts to teach their children safety. Should I refrain from setting a bad example? Theodore Hong, London

title: An Instructor in How to See
description: ''The covers of a book are like a roof and four walls. What is to happen next will take place within the four walls of the story. And this is possible because the story's voice makes everything its own.'' John Berger, from ''Selected Essays''

title: 2 Teenagers Charged In Suspect's Beating
description: Two teenagers who responded to the screams of a woman who had just been robbed in the Bronx have been charged with beating the woman's assailant, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KEVLES, MICHAEL DAVID
description: KEVLES-Michael David. Difficult years have passed since the loss of our beloved son. We thank and appreciate your support in aiding us to endure these trying times.

title: Paint It Forward
description: It has been four decades since the French New Wave was new, but now, at 82, one of its pioneers, Eric Rohmer, has gone digital.

title: Personal Business; As Salary Grows, So Does a Gender Gap
description: WOMEN may be bringing home larger paychecks, but when it comes to earning the really serious money -- wages of $1 million or more -- men far outnumber them, as they did a generation ago.

title: Hardcover Business Best Sellers
description: This

title: DUTCH POLITICIAN KILLED
description: Pim Fortuyn, a gay right-wing populist who stood out in the gray political world of the Netherlands, was killed by a gunman as he left a radio station after an interview. Mr. Fortuyn, 54, a former sociology professor with a strong anti-immigrant message, was a leading candidate in national elections set for this Wednesday.

title: Israeli Troops Standing By on the Outskirts of Gaza
description: Israeli troops continued to loom outside the Gaza Strip today though a Saudi envoy spoke of a ''ray of hope'' in Washington's revived peace efforts.

title: TUITION INCREASES AND AUDITS
description: Governor McGreevey last week warned college officials that any school raising its tuition by more than 10 percent would be subject to an audit by the state Commission on Higher Education. State aid to colleges was reduced an average of 5 percent this year, but not enough to justify the large tuition increases some schools are considering, he said. Wendy Ginsberg

title: Worthwhile Dining by Careful Choices
description: HOW did I like Tower & Main in Roslyn? I loved it and I hated it. There have been good, bad and in-between restaurants at 8 Tower Place (516-484-4518). Tower & Main is all three. Its efforts are up, down and all around the culinary map. If the kitchen could always turn out dishes as good as its successes, this place, with its economical prices and striking view of Roslyn Park Pond, would be a find. But it can't. At least it didn't during my two visits. Descriptives like erratic, uneven and careless passed through my mind as I ate. From the beginning, contradictions and inconsistencies were the norm.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Carroll Gardens; Area of Gardens and 19th-Century Charm
description: A CENTURY ago, Carroll Gardens was a working-class neighborhood in Brooklyn, home to thousands of Irish immigrants. In the decades before World War II, the Irish moved out and first-generation Italians moved in.

title: A Few Bumps on the Way to a Pampered Pig
description: ''I DOUBT if this wild pig ever set a trotter outside a comfy pen, let alone in a forest.'' This comment by a friend during our dinner at the Boxing Horse Bistro in Lakeville was prompted by a bite of the best pork I have ever eaten, bar none. Billed as ''fire-grilled tenderloin of wild pig,'' the pork was cooked just to the pink stage and was tender, with a texture so fine grained it was almost buttery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCKOWITZ, MURRAY
description: ROCKOWITZ-Murray. Of Ardsley-on-Hudson, NY, on May 8, 2002 in Jerusalem, Israel. Beloved husband of Anna Cohen Rockowitz. Loving father of Noah and Eli, father-in-law of Julie and Naomi. Cherished grandfather of Shira, Deena, Leora, Dahlia, Avital, Yoav and Alon. Retired Chairman of the Board of Examiners of the NYC Board of Education, noted author and lifelong Zionist. WWII Commanding Officer of Air Corps Radio Manila. A man of outstanding accomplishments, unswerving principles and great humility who will be sorely missed. Services at 9:15am today, Sunday, at Westchester Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W. Broad St, Mt. Vernon.

title: Word for Word / All Together Now; Tone-Deaf Corporations In Search of the Perfect Pitch
description: IT'S at least arguable that America's only true indigenous art form is industrial music, the anthems and mini-musical productions that corporations commission to impress clients and bludgeon sales forces into action. After all, people in other countries have mastered jazz, rap and gospel. Nobody on another continent has yet achieved the delicate balance of peppiness, boosterism and dementia that industrial music demands.

title: BLOOD EDGES HUDDLE IN 1,600
description: Nicole Blood, a 14-year-old eighth grader from Saratoga Springs, N.Y., upset Molly Huddle, a senior at Notre Dame High School in Elmira, N.Y., in the girls' 1,600-meter run yesterday at the Loucks Games at White Plains High School.

title: Saturday Stays
description: To the Editor: Your chart on lowest air fares (Travel Advisory, April 21) listed New York to San Diego for $337 restricted or $2,386 unrestricted. This is an extreme, but not untypical example of the huge variations that are essentially based on whether there's a Saturday night stay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARR, CHARLES NOELL
description: CARR-Charles Noell, 73 years old. Of the United Methodist Retirement Community, Winston-Salem NC, was born in Durham, NC, May 25, 1928 to Austin Heaton Carr and Laura Noell Carr Chapman. He was a graduate of Harvard University, Cambridge, MA., and the Arts Students League in NYC. He served as a lieutenant in the U.S. Air Force. He resided in New York City for over 30 years where he was a professional painter in various media. Mr. Carr is survived by three children: Roby Campbell Carr, Houston, TX., Margaret Noel Carr, Anchorage, AK, and Charles Noell Carr, Jr., Fairfield, CT., a brother Austin H. Carr, Jr., Winston-Salem, NC; a niece Laura Noell Carr, Winston-Salem, NC., nephew Donnel B. Carr, Trucker, CA., and a grand nephew and a grand niece, of Trucker, CA. Burial will be in the Carr Family Plot at Maplewood Cemetery, Durham, NC., following a graveside service at 11:00 A.M. May 13, 2002. The family asks that in lieu of flowers, memorials be made to: The American Diabetes Association, Memorial Program-ncc, P.O. Box 2680, North Canton, OH., 44720 (www.diabetes.org)

description: To the Editor:

description: THE COMPANY

title: The Odd Couple
description: TEN minutes before the cameras begin to roll, the two former governors are huddled like unflappable executives debriefing each other before a board meeting.

title: Poet of the Ages
description: Q: People are going to Mary Zimmerman's adaptation of ''Metamorphoses'' in droves, and now your play has just opened. Why do you think we're drawn to classics right now?

description: To the Editor:

title: A Mayor's Recollections Of an Unforgettable Day
description: ''We were into something different than any of us had ever prepared for, or any of us had thought we would live through. I realized I was in some kind of horrible, awful, horrific human experience.''

description: FUNNYMEN

title: Monaco
description: It had been 30 years since i had heard it, surely the most sublime noise to enter the ear of sporting man. It came first as my wife, Jane, and I descended the narrow, winding streets of Monaco on an azure morning in late May last year. We were in an open-topped Renault Mgane rental car picked up the previous evening at the Cannes-Nice airport, some 12 miles along the coast. The traffic was backed up beside a sidewalk bistro, and the scent of freshly brewed caf filtre was wafting into the road. Beside us, a procession of casual style, of handsome men and striking women, was walking briskly down toward the port, raising my sense of frustrated urgency.

title: Introduction
description: The cover article on a student's suicide at M.I.T. drew mail from scores of readers who were critical in equal measure of the school, the therapists, the parents -- even (to a lesser degree) the victim. Others said our warts-and-all appraisal of Florida was accurate, but few regretted moving there.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the Cannes International Film Festival misspelled the surname of the director of the closing offering, ''And Now . . . Ladies and Gentlemen.'' He is Claude Lelouch, not Lelouche. The article also misidentified the actor who stars as an acute schizophrenic in ''Spider.'' He is Ralph Fiennes; Gabriel Byrne plays a supporting role.

title: Black Jockeys: An Addendum
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Among the World's Homeless Is Art
description: MUCH has been said recently about the rights and wrongs of art being removed during wars from one owner or country to another. Yet the long history of such appropriations is rarely mentioned. It may be that Rome's pillage of Corinth in 146 B.C., or Venice's of Constantinople in 1204, now seem irrelevant because the spoils cannot be identified or because they have come to be associated with their new home. (The four horses of St. Mark's is a case in point). But even when we know the fate of the booty, we accept the outcome after enough time has passed: in the long run, art has no permanent home.

Survived by Esther, adoring and devoted wife of 57 years; children Jeffrey and wife Gale, Lynne Grusby and husband Alan, and Marsha Satuloff; beloved sister Josephine Steiner; grandchildren Jill and Steve Sanko, Mara Steiner, Jennifer Grusby and Samuel Steiner; nieces and nephews Norman, Jonathan, Amalia, Phillip, Felicia, Ken, Jeff, Abigail, Sidney and Jordanna.

title: Insides Out
description: Shelley Jackson's bizarre, often marvelous story collection, THE MELANCHOLY OF ANATOMY (Anchor, paper, $12), is a surreal satire of Robert Burton's classic ''Anatomy of Melancholy,'' divided by headings -- Choleric,'' ''Melancholic,'' ''Phlegmatic'' and ''Sanguine'' -- drawn from that eccentric 17th-century treatise on the four corporeal humors (among other subjects). Throughout, Jackson takes deep-rooted anxieties about the body's capacious growths, secretions and desires and spins them into wry, absurdist fantasies. In an early story, ''Egg,'' the 36-year-old narrator happens upon a mysterious egg -- one that possesses the characteristics of an actual egg, an infant and the Blob, and which she instinctively guards. She also reads up on its lore (''The egg is manifold: called divine, it can be sliced thin and made into very passable sandwiches''), watches it grow larger than her bedroom window and allows it, for a while, to take over her life. Most of the 13 stories here hinge on a bodily fluid or part that is externalized and exaggerated almost -- but not quite -- beyond recognition: a large fetus floats through a town like a balloon, performing tasks like helping out with the groceries; cancer grows as a buoyant, springy, branching red tree; sperm the size of Great Danes annoy the citizenry with their constant capers and horseplay. The effect of Jackson's visceral, inventive details can be gorgeous, or utterly grotesque -- as in ''Phlegm,'' which presents a world wherein the disgusting stuff is used as a social lubricant. As Jackson imagines physiology's power to shape the self, each story's strange internal logic takes on a life of its own. Megan Harlan

title: ARMS AND THE MAN

Now, in footnotes to two briefs, he has put the Supreme Court on notice that this is also the government's position. The new position reverses decades of federal policy and indirectly challenges the court to revisit a 1939 precedent that treated the Constitution as protecting only the states' collective right to maintain militias. Walls will have to be torn down and new conveyor belts installed so bags can be moved through the machines. The Port Authority said the project is six to seven months from completion. John Holl

title: Am I My Brother's Keeper?

His stomach roiled. It would be easier, he reasoned, not to do it, and it would probably be best. But then he envisioned the priest in question rounding a corner the following morning without any knowledge that his name had hit the newspaper and facing a television camera he never saw coming. He imagined the man's humiliation. And he was not sure he could bear the thought of it.

title: Keeping a Finger On China's Pulse

For more than a decade before he opened his chocolate shop on Water Street in Brooklyn, Mr. Torres was the pastry chef at Le Cirque. There he was famous for a molten chocolate fondant that arrived under a lacy dome made of spun sugar so transparent it looked like icicles. All day long Mr. Torres toys with rivers of melted chocolate in a sure, lighthearted way. He nibbles. He tastes. He is not fat, but neither is he skinny. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACGREGOR, FRANCES COOKE
description: MACGREGOR-Frances Cooke. With apologies for the delay to her friends and colleagues, it is with regret that we advise that Frances Cooke Macgregor, an expert on the psychological effects of facial deformities, died on Christmas Eve (2001) at her retirement home in Carmel, California. She was 95 and died of congestive heart failure. She was a renowned social scientist whose research and writing on the social and psychological significance of facial differences was the first acknowledgement of disfigurement as a disability. Her publications document 40 years of research. Mrs. Macgregor was born in Portland, Oregon, but grew up in San Rafael, California and earned a bachelor's degree in economics from the University of California at Berkeley in 1927. She moved to Massachusetts several years later and in 1933 married the late Gordon Macgregor, an anthropologist for the U.S. Bureau of Indian Affairs. They later divorced. While they were married, the Macgregors visited Indian reservations around the country. A professional photographer at the time, Mrs. Macgregor took pictures that captured daily life on the reservations. Those photographs, published in 1941 in a book entitled, ''Twentieth Century Indians'', helped prompt Congress to devote more money to Indian reservations. Other pictures Mrs. Macgregor took over the course of a year in the small Massachusetts town of Hingham, were also published in 1941 in a book called, ''This Is America'', with text written by her friend, former first lady Eleanor Roosevelt. In the 1940's, Mrs. Macgregor moved to New York City and did graduate work in anthropology at Columbia University under Dr. Margaret Mead. Mrs. Macgregor obtained her master's degree in sociology at the University of Missouri in 1947. Her work on facial disfigurement began during World War II while photographing patients at the Ellis Fischel Cancer State Hospital in Columbia, Missouri. Shortly after the war, she met plastic surgeon Dr. John Marquis Converse, who helped repair the shattered and burned faces of French and English pilots. His specialty coincided with her interest in social and psychological ramifications of facial disfigurement. Dr. Converse accepted her suggestion to conduct an exploratory study of his patients. At that time, the existing literature on physical disabilities was limited almost entirely to functional impairments: the loss of a leg, blindness, deafness and so on, and the problems of physical rehabilitation. As for those whose faces happen to deviate from the norm, there was and is, a special irony with which they must contend. Their problems have their roots in the inextricable relationship of the face to the person and its role in human relations. Moreover, it is a situation made even worse in a society whose frenetic efforts to look young and beautiful makes looking different a social stigma-a stigma that has the potential for social and psychological death. Her work led to the World Health Organization adding facial disfigurement to its list of disabilities. In 1951 The Society for the Rehabilitation of the Facially Disfigured was established. Now known as The National Foundation for Facial Reconstruction, the Foundation helps fund the work of the Institute of Reconstructive Plastic Surgery at New York University Medical Center. Mrs. Macgregor remained in close touch with Dr. Joseph G. McCarthy, who became Director of the Institute following the death of Dr. Converse in 1981. The innovative streak in Macgregor drew the attention of the Russell Sage Foundation where she did a threeyear study at the New York Hospital, Cornell University School of Nursing in order to introduce social science into the education of nurses. She published a textbook, ''Social Science in Nursing; Applications for the Improvement of Patient Care'' (Russell Sage Foundation, New York, 1960). She became a full professor teaching at Cornell University Medical and Nursing School from 1954 to 1968 then rejoined the Institute of Reconstructive Plastic Surgery at NYU Medical Center. In 1991, Macgregor moved from New York City to Carmel, California. She continued her consultancies adding legal clients as well as medical colleagues and patients. Magregor's last research efforts focused on iatrogenic illness. Years before it was frontpage news in the New York Times (Sunday, December 19, 1999), she wanted her philanthropic funds to go to studying medical errors caused by physicians and other health professionals. On the same page as the continuation of The New York Times article of December 19, 1999, ''Breaking Down Medicine's Culture of Silence'', the Institute of Medicine estimated that between 44,000 and 98,000 Americans die each year as a result of medical errors. Macgregor had already contributed to studies by the Institute of Medicine and also the Harvard Medical School in her name through the aegis of The Commonwealth Fund. She has left her estate to The Commonwealth Fund who will administer the Frances Cooke Macgregor Awards for further study of iatrogenic illness. At a private ceremony on January 4, 2002, Frances Cooke Macgregor was buried at the family burial plot beside her father, mother, brother and nephew at the Mt. Tamalpais Cemetery in San Rafael, California.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WISNICKI, LORRAINE JUSTMAN
description: WISNICKI-Lorraine Justman, 77. Of Flushing, NY, passed away on March 9, 2002. She remains adored by her husband Joseph of 55 years. Children Susan and Jeffrey, daughter-in-law Rebecca, and grandsons, Justin and Brandon, cherish her memory. She left this world less than two days after Brandon was safely brought into it. A survivor of the Holocaust, she distinguished herself with a lifetime of courage and accomplishment. As a teenager in the Warsaw Ghetto, she worked with the heroic Dr. Janusz Korczak at his Orphanage writing and organizing plays for his little orphans. She never stopped writing since. After the War, she helped organize the Jewish Committee in Innsbruck to support and assist the survivors. She became a dedicated voice for remembrance of the Holocaust. Her work has included volumes on Dr. Korczak, of poetry, Holocaust stories and a compelling autobiography. A member of Hadassah, she was also actively involved in many Survivor organizations and societies. As she herself wrote, '' I try to tell the story the way it happened...because it should live in our memories and hearts as long as the world exists.''

The instruction manuals were incomprehensible, and the help-lines were staffed by geeks from another planet. There were no ''Dummies'' books for people like me, and no courses for beginners. We learned by trial and error, just the way we learned about sex. As with sex, we were never properly trained in the authorized procedures and the neatest shortcuts. Every computer was a ticking bomb. Would it actually explode? Would it just go blank? Would it delete thousands of pages of data because of a single careless keystroke? Typewriting was never like this.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDWASSER, MARTIN
description: GOLDWASSER-Martin. Formerly of Brooklyn Heights, passed away May 3, 2002 at age 95. He is survived by his wife Elizabeth S. Teter, son Hank, daughter Janet, grandchildren Jonathan, Missy Carvin and Douglass Dowty, and a sister, Esther Natt. He was preceded in death by his first wife, Paula Neumann in 1983, after 49 years of marriage. Martin graduated from Erasmus High School in Brooklyn, earned his Bachelor of Science degree from City College, and his D.D.S. from New York University. He was a skilled & caring dentist, who over half a century, saw the children and the grandchildren of his first patients come to him for treatment in his practices in Manhattan and Brooklyn. Dr. Goldwasser gave of himself to others, volunteering many hours over the years at dental clinics in Brooklyn. He was a lifelong pacifist and Conscientious Objector, doing alternative service in state mental hospitals in Maryland during World War II. In later years, he spent many hours counseling young men about peaceful alternatives to military service in his work with the Metropolitan Board for Conscientious Objectors. His hobbies included stamp collecting, bird watching, and bicycling. He lived a full life, and will be remembered with love by us all. A memorial service will be held in June. Contact Hank Goldwasser at (914) 347-6672 after June 1 for details.

title: ON TRIAL IN HOUSTON
description: In its first week at bat in its obstruction-of-justice trial, Arthur Andersen racked up a lot of strikes. First, a judge ruled that a series of accounting scandals at the firm could be presented to the jury as motive for its destruction of Enron documents. Then the judge denied the firm access to notes of earlier statements by the government's chief witness. And an Andersen partner admitted to erasing Enron e-mail messages just before the firm became aware of an informal investigation. Still, Andersen got a few hits, like admissions from some of its partners, called as government witnesses, that they had never been told to destroy documents to keep them from investigators. Kurt Eichenwald

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: A Letter From Pavarotti
description: A day after backing out of his eagerly anticipated, season-closing performance of ''Tosca'' at the Metropolitan Opera because of a stubborn dose of the flu, Luciano Pavarotti released an open letter to his fans yesterday that explained his decision, and offered no apology. ''A proper vocal condition is the basic rule for any singing performance,'' the letter said, ''without it, no matter how much willingness, talent, discipline or passion there is, it is simply impossible to offer the public the performance for which they have paid.'' On Saturday night, the young tenor Salvatore Licitra replaced Mr. Pavarotti in the role of Mario Cavaradossi. [Critic's Notebook, The Arts, Page E1.] ''The media seems to imply that the New York opera public will not forgive my cancellation,'' Mr. Pavarotti's letter concluded. ''But forgiveness assumes that one has made a mistake; no matter how much I regret with a passion not being able to sing at the Met on this occasion, catching the flu was certainly not a willful mistake I made.'' Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Museum's Cyberpeeping Artwork Has Its Plug Pulled
description: An Internet-based artwork in an exhibition at the New Museum of Contemporary Art was taken offline on Friday because the work was conducting surveillance of outside computers. It is not clear yet who is responsible for the blacking out -- the artists, the museum or its Internet service provider -- but the action illuminates the work's central theme: the tension between public and private control of the Internet. The shutdown also shows how cyberspace's gray areas can enshroud museums as they embrace the evolving medium.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: A Push To Improve Nuclear Detection Devices
description: Terrorists could easily smuggle a nuclear bomb through the country's ports and across its borders, Senator Charles E. Schumer said yesterday while announcing a bill intended to improve nuclear detection devices. The bill, which the senator plans to submit to Congress this week, includes $250 million to develop more sensitive detectors and upgrade computer monitoring of shipments around the world. The devices would be installed at toll booths and on cranes loading cargo into ships, Mr. Schumer said. ''Even if we inspect every container but don't have the detecting devices, we'll lose,'' he said. The cost of providing the equipment for the entire country was unclear, the senator said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Slip, Fall, Collect
description: As the city struggles to close a $5 billion budget gap without cutting into essential services, one area of spending makes a particularly tempting target: the half-billion dollars the city paid out last year to people who sued it. Mayor Michael Bloomberg is campaigning, both in the City Council and in Albany, for changes in the law that would make the city less vulnerable to costly damage awards. He is hardly the first mayor to wage this fight, but he is right to try, and the City Council, the State Legislature and the governor should support his efforts.

title: Instead of a Swan Song, A Warbler's Ardent Debut
description: So, as the whole world must know by now, Luciano Pavarotti did not appear in the Metropolitan Opera's season-closing performance of Puccini's ''Tosca'' on Saturday night. Instead, Mr. Pavarotti, the 66-year-old tenor, remained in his Central Park South apartment downing chicken soup, fighting the flu that he said had forced him to withdraw from Wednesday's performance and, one can only hope, ruing the advice he was given to take on these performances in the first place.

title: Powell and Russian Official Say Arms Accord Is Likely

In response, Lincoln Center has refused to assure the family that the Avery Fisher name will continue if the hall that is home to the New York Philharmonic is reconstructed.

title: Likud Vote on Palestinian State Is Not Seen as Dramatic Change

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: A LETTER FROM PAVAROTTI A day after backing out of his eagerly anticipated, season-closing performance of "Tosca" at the Metropolitan Opera because of a stubborn dose of the flu, Luciano Pavarotti released an open letter to his fans yesterday that explained his decision, and offered no apology. "A proper vocal condition is the basic rule for any singing performance," the letter said, "without it, no matter how much willingness, talent, discipline or passion there is, it is simply impossible to offer the public the performance for which they have paid." On Saturday night, the young tenor Salvatore Licitra replaced Mr. Pavarotti in the role of Mario Cavaradossi. [Critic's Notebook, The Arts, Page E1.] "The media seems to imply that the New York opera public will not forgive my cancellation," Mr. Pavarotti's letter concluded. "But forgiveness assumes that one has made a mistake; no matter how much I regret with a passion not being able to sing at the Met on this occasion, catching the flu was certainly not a willful mistake I made."

title: Security Company Reconsidering Takeover
description: Securitas A.B., the Swedish maker of security systems, will decide this week whether to proceed with a $3 billion takeover of Chubb, a British rival, people close to the companies said today.

title: Don't Get Angry. He's Kidding. Seriously.
description: The invitation to his opening looked innocent enough: a photograph of a pigeon perched on a ledge overlooking the rooftops of Manhattan. Those familiar with the work of Maurizio Cattelan, the Italian Neo-Conceptual artist, might well have assumed the exhibition would feature some of his latest animal pieces. Perhaps a new twist on his horse hanging from a ceiling or a variation on the ostrich with its head in the ground or another play on ''Cheap to Feed,'' the dead dog curled up in a chair taking a nap.

title: Bush Quietly Signs Farm Bill Despite Big Rise in Subsidies
description: CHICAGO, May 13  President Bush today reversed six years of Republican efforts to wean farmers of huge Federal subsidies, signing into law a bill that increases those federal payments by at least $83 billion over the next 10 years, even as the United States urges Europe and Asian nations to reduce their own market-distorting payments to farmers.

title: A Man Who Stole the Roses
description: With his platinum mop-top, red Jaguar and barbed tongue, Bob Baffert has rarely been able to fade into the background of the backside of a racetrack. He has always been more frat boy than farmhand, more camera ready than camera shy. But somehow, for the two weeks before the first Saturday in May, Baffert transformed himself into the invisible trainer in order to perpetrate one of the most delicious thefts in racing history: he and his colt War Emblem stole the 128th running of the Kentucky Derby.

title: REBUFFING SHARON, PARTY REPUDIATES PALESTINIAN STATE

The excitment and stimulation you brought to all you knew and a loving concern to those with whom you were close. Your generosity, your honesty, with yourself as well as others. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Suspect Escapes, Briefly
description: A suspect escaped from police custody on Saturday night but was recaptured at her home about three hours later, the police said. The woman, Delores A. Carpino, 43, who had been arrested on drug charges, escaped about 10:30 p.m. after she was driven in a police van to Bronx Central Booking along with 20 other prisoners, the police said. She slipped out of her handcuffs and blended into a crowd of pedestrians who were passing by as the prisoners were escorted from the van to the central booking building, the police said. Ms. Carpino was recaptured about 1:15 a.m. yesterday after she took a cab to her home in Morris Park, the police said. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Suspect In Attacks Is Identified Through DNA
description: A suspect in 16 sexual attacks in the city who fled from a police interrogation room in the Bronx last Monday has been positively identified through DNA tests, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly has said. The man, Jose Santiago, 33, remains on the loose, the police said. Mr. Santiago, who also uses the names Raul Luis Acosta and Lito Acosta, was linked to 15 of the attacks through a match of DNA samples recovered at 15 of the crime scenes and a saliva sample he provided to detectives before he escaped from the Bronx Special Victims Squad on May 6. The attacks on women and young girls occurred between March 5, 1997, and Feb. 26 of this year, the police said. Anyone with information is asked to call the police at a (800) 577-TIPS. Al Baker (NYT)

title: A Bad Law's Birthday
description: Last week marked the 130th anniversary of a destructive relic known as the General Mining Law of 1872. The event went unheralded by both the environmental community, which hates the law, and the mining industry, which loves the law but would be happy if nobody noticed it. Nevertheless, a few adventurous members of Congress have now embarked on the first serious effort since 1994 to rewrite the law, which has done more than any other statute to foul the country's rivers and streams. The effort is being spearheaded by Representatives Nick Rahall II, Democrat of West Virginia, and Christopher Shays, Republican of Connecticut. The Bush administration has also suggested reforms. They are not strong enough to correct the law's bias toward industry and against nature. The Rahall approach is superior.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Online Ads Increase, Report Says

The study, by the AdRelevance unit of Nielsen/NetRatings, found that traditional advertisers like Columbia House, Nestl and the federal government led the list of top media buyers. Nielsen/NetRatings found that online advertising fell to a low of 52,530 ads in January 2002 but rebounded recently. The 69,838 ads in April reflected a 9 percent increase over January 2001. Charles Buchwalter, vice president for media research at NetRatings, said the adoption of the online medium by blue-chip companies appeared to be accelerating.

description: While Dave Tippett was interviewing yesterday for the Rangers' head-coaching position, Ken Hitchock appeared to be close to an agreement to become the Philadelphia Flyers' new coach.

title: The Cable Guys
description: The Seattle Mariners have 26 victories this season, but none of them include their local ratings triumphs in prime time over dramas and comedies like ''West Wing,'' ''Frasier'' (the Seattle radio shrink who would not know where Safeco Field is) and ''Survivor.''

title: AVAYA TO EXPAND ITS NETWORK SERVICES BUSINESS
description: Avaya, a maker of office communications equipment, said yesterday that it would expand its network services business as customers cut spending on telecommunications equipment. The company, based in Basking Ridge, N.J., will form a sales team to focus on network maintenance and other services, Avaya said. The company had emphasized selling services primarily to customers that bought its equipment. Avaya, formerly part of Lucent Technologies Inc., is trying to increase revenue from the services business after declining sales of phone equipment hurt results. The market for the services business is forecast to grow to more than $82 billion in 2005 from $51 billion this year, Avaya said.

title: Minister Says India Won't Attack Pakistan
description: Even as an American official arrived here on a mission to defuse the tensions that have lingered between nuclear-armed India and Pakistan, India's defense minister, George Fernandes, said in an interview today that India had no plans to launch such a military attack over the next few months even if severely provoked.

title: Sears to Buy Lands' End In a Deal That Unites Pants and Power Drills
description: Trying to build up its much-maligned softer side, Sears, Roebuck & Company announced yesterday that it would pay $1.9 billion in cash to buy Lands' End, the mail-order retailer, adding well-known fleecy jackets, khaki pants, oxford shirts and other staples to its lineup of washing machines, power drills and automotive products.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the suspension of executions in Maryland misstated the events leading to it. Gov. Parris N. Glendening made the decision independently, to await the completion of a state study on capital punishment; he did not base his decision on a request by Lt. Gov. Kathleen Kennedy Townsend. According to the offices of both officials, Ms. Townsend, a candidate to succeed Mr. Glendening, discussed the idea with him, then endorsed it in advance of his announcement.

title: G.O.P. Proposes Block Grants To States for Feeding the Poor
description: Five states could eliminate the food stamp program and receive lump sums of federal money to feed poor people in any way they wanted under a new provision of the welfare bill coming to a vote this week in the House of Representatives.

title: Bush Signs Bill to Tighten Security at Nation's Borders
description: Saying "we must know who is coming into our country and why they're coming," President Bush signed legislation today to improve the security of American borders and to toughen enforcement of immigration laws.

title: NBC is adding only five shows to its prime-time fall lineup, and moving the successful ''Scrubs.''
description: TRYING to capitalize on a dominant lead in the prime-time television ratings, NBC announced a program schedule for the fall yesterday that will add only five shows to its lineup. And, in what is sure to be its most-scrutinized move, the network placed this year's most successful new comedy, ''Scrubs,'' in the Thursday time slot behind the soon-to-be-departing ''Friends.''

title: Lawyers for Lindh Ask Court To Dismiss Several Charges
description: Lawyers for John Walker Lindh, the Californian accused of fighting for the Taliban, today sought the dismissal of 5 of the 10 counts against him.

title: Drossin Is Surging To Forefront
description: For a decade, since injuries started closing down the long and glorious career of Mary Decker Slaney, the United States has been searching for a female distance runner who could compete with the world's best. She seems to have arrived in Deena Drossin, a 29-year-old University of Arkansas graduate.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Confidence Rises
description: Australian business confidence rose to its highest level in eight years in April, signaling that the economy is picking up and that the Reserve Bank of Australia may raise interest rates faster than expected. National Australia Bank's closely watched index of business confidence rose 5.8 points, to 20.6 points, the highest level since 1994.

title: Mexico Now Appears to Be Developing the Politics of Stalemate
description: Mexico used to be a one-party country. Now it is a place where no majority rules, and no politician -- particularly President Vicente Fox -- controls a coalition capable of changing the way things work.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Scientology Plaintiff Wins $8.6 Million
description: The Church of Scientology will pay more than $8.6 million to a 53-year-old former member who sued it more than 20 years ago asserting that church tactics caused him to develop bipolar disorder and contemplate suicide. A jury awarded the former member, Lawrence Wollersheim of Nevada, $30 million in 1986, but the amount was reduced to $2.5 million in 1994 by the United States Supreme Court. The final payment of $8,674,843 was reached by combining the $2.5 million reduced settlement with 10 percent compounded interest over the years. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Boy Dies After Fall From Roof
description: A 12-year-old Bronx boy who was playing with friends Sunday night on the roof of a four-story building near his home accidentally fell to the ground and was killed, the police said yesterday. The boy, Sucre Baez, was with four friends on the rooftop at 1528 Leland Avenue about 8:45 p.m. when he dropped 50 feet to an alleyway between the two buildings, the police said. He was pronounced dead at Jacobi Medical Center at 12:30 a.m. yesterday, the police said. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Carter and Powell Cast Doubt on Bioarms in Cuba
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that Bush administration officials who briefed him before his trip to Cuba never mentioned any concerns about Cuban involvement in developing biological weapons.

description: Europeans have been eating Quorn -- Quorn nuggets, Quorn cutlets, Quorn patties -- for 16 years. And, yes, many say it tastes like chicken.

description: The New York City Ballet has come up with some gorgeous dancing this season. There is a way to fool an audience that has remained loyal to the company for decades, and when it roared after recent performances of George Balanchine's ''Stravinsky Violin Concerto'' it rightly singled out Nikolaj Hubbe, powerfully carving his way through space: a passionate dancer.

description: PINE-Florence. ''A Grand Dame''. title: Treaty Offers Pentagon New Flexibility for New Set of Nuclear Priorities
description: There is a reason the nuclear arms treaty President Bush plans to sign at the coming Moscow summit meeting is only three pages long. It is intended to provide maximum flexibility to the Pentagon.

title: In Spiders, Itsy Bitsy Gets the Girl
description: In the battle for mates, it is the largest males of the animal kingdom that tend to dominate, facing down competitors with their towering height and great girth. But scientists have discovered one battle that conveys the advantage to the teeny-tiny male: the battle with gravity.

title: Girl, 9, Dies From Injuries In 4-Story Fall
description: A 9-year-old deaf and blind girl died this afternoon from her injuries a day after she plunged four stories from the window of an apartment where the police said she had been left home alone, tied to a bathroom radiator.

description: American Special Operations forces killed five people suspected of being fighters for Al Qaeda or the Taliban and captured 32 others in a night raid in southern Afghanistan on Sunday, military officials said today.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Rail Crash Cause
description: Officials said a train derailment that killed seven people last week was caused by problems in track repaired late last year and inspected the day before the accident. Speaking to Parliament, the transportation secretary, Stephen Byers, said two missing nuts from the points system -- the mechanism that enables trains to change tracks -- had caused the rear car of the train to derail. About 70 people were injured in the accident, which took place at Potters Bar, north of London. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Lupus Death Toll Increases
description: The number of deaths in America from lupus has risen sharply in recent years, particularly among middle-aged black women, according to a report released this month by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

description: The wave of serious injuries that has struck World Cup powers like Italy, Germany and England has now also affected the lineup of the United States.

Fox created a medical research foundation that is already renowned for its fast-paced disbursements to scientists. Since April of last year, the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research has given out nearly $17 million to help finance 57 studies.

description: If Sears, Roebuck's planned acquisition of the catalog and Internet retailer Lands' End goes as planned, analysts say, the e-commerce operations of both companies, already among the leaders in their respective online categories, may benefit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUPP, STUART RUSSELL
description: HUPP-Stuart Russell, 80. Of New York City, died May 11, 2002. He was the son of the late Mrs. Rand Lewis Hupp, and the late William F. Mr. Hupp, who retired from IBM, was formerly with the CIA in Europe, and was a combat veteran of World War II. He was a member of Saint Thomas Episcopal Church in New York City. title: A Dutch Radical's Message to Europe
description: The death of Pim Fortuyn, assassinated last week as he campaigned for prime minister, leaves the Netherlands -- in fact, all of Europe -- with many uncomfortable questions. The most serious, of course, is how someone could be killed for his political beliefs; the Netherlands had long thought itself beyond such violence. Other questions, however, are more easily answered.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Kansas: Ban On Cockfighting
description: Legislators voted to make it a misdemeanor to stage battles between roosters, train the birds to fight or watch such an event. Cockfighting was already illegal in Kansas under animal-cruelty laws but the state had no specific statutes on it. Cockfighting is legal only in Oklahoma, New Mexico and Louisiana. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Crown Heights Ruling
description: A Brooklyn federal judge delayed setting a date yesterday for a new trial in the Crown Heights case because the remaining defendant, Lemrick Nelson Jr., has asked the United States Supreme Court to review the case. The convictions of Mr. Nelson, 27, and Charles Price, 48, were overturned in January by a federal appeals court, which ruled that the jury had been chosen improperly. Mr. Price has pleaded guilty, but Mr. Nelson has asked the Supreme Court for a broader ruling that civil rights laws were applied improperly to charges that he killed a Hasidic scholar, Yankel Rosenbaum, during violence between blacks and Orthodox Jews in 1991.
