Responding to concerns about the case of Rilya Wilson, a 5-year-old who disappeared while in the care of the Department of Children and Families, lawmakers also made it a felony for any state employee to falsify or destroy public records dealing with children under the state's supervision. Gary Fineout (NYT)

title: Sifting the Last Tons of Sept. 11 Debris
description: At the other place, the place called The Hill, things are winding down. Workers are decontaminating the barges, towing away equipment, spraying the ground with a gray concrete sealant. Soon, the makeshift village of sorrowful duty that sits on a remote landfill will exist only in the memory of a few.

description: Colorize your diet. That is the latest advice from nutrition experts who have studied the health-promoting properties of the vast spectrum of colorful fruits and vegetables now available throughout the country.

title: A Sikh in Pinstripes Works With Irony of Unknown Depth
description: By the time Tjinder Singh took the stage at Irving Plaza on Thursday night, his band, Cornershop, had already been playing for a few minutes. In his pinstripe jacket, Mr. Singh looked like an actor who had wandered into the wrong movie, and even when he started singing, his expression never changed. It was a diffident performance by a diffident band that has worked hard to avoid becoming a world-music act.

title: Kabul Journal; In the Afghan Capital, Rents Go Through the Roof

title: 'Watery Graves' Was No Figure Of Speech; A Receding City Reservoir Reveals a Turbulent Past
description: It is the Catskills' own Atlantis: a dozen bucolic hamlets swallowed up almost a century ago in New York City's desperate desire for water. Hundreds of houses were dismantled or burned, 2,000 people were forced out and an even greater number of graves were disinterred so the land could be flooded.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Friday about companies that are cutting back health benefits for retirees or requiring them to pay more for coverage misstated the policy at AT&T. Employees outside union jurisdiction who began paying monthly premiums this year were those who retired after March 1, 1990, not those who were hired after that date.

title: Nets Assistant Draws Interest
description: Although Denver General Manager Kiki Vandeweghe would not comment today, the Nuggets are believed to have requested permission from the Nets to speak with Eddie Jordan about their head-coaching job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, MOLLIE
description: ABRAMS-Mollie. The Officers, Trustees, Clergy and Members of Park Avenue Synagogue mourn the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend to the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Geoffrey J. Colvin, Ch. of the Bd Paul S. Schreiber, President

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Acquisition Called Off
description: Securitas, the Swedish maker of security systems, said it called off talks to acquire Chubb, a British rival. Chubb shares rose 15 percent on Friday after it said it was in discussions with Securitas, making the company more expensive to acquire. The same day, Securitas shares declined sharply, reducing the value of its all-stock offer. Yesterday, the share price movements reversed, with Securitas shares gaining 7.3 percent, to 198.5 kroner ($19.43). Chubb shares tumbled 14 percent, to 1.80 ($2.63).

title: Phone Start-Ups Win the Latest Round in Court
description: The Supreme Court handed a huge victory to start-up telephone companies today by broadly affirming rules that permit them to lease equipment from the largest phone companies at relatively low costs.

title: 7 World Trade Is Envisioned As a Gateway
description: Providing the first public glimpse of plans to replace the destroyed 7 World Trade Center, architects for Larry A. Silverstein said yesterday that the new building would be a transparent, ''light-emanating shaft'' designed as a gateway to the planned World Trade Center memorial and other buildings that are expected to be built there.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Detective Testifies
description: A detective testified during a pretrial hearing yesterday that a man accused of murder admitted he killed his girlfriend and two of her children. That admission, said the detective, William Craft, came after the suspect, Dennis Alvarez Hernandez, 23, learned that a third child, who survived the attack, pointed him out as the family's attacker. The hearing was held to decide the admissibility of evidence against Mr. Hernandez. He is accused of fatally stabbing his girlfriend, Patricia Torres, 28; William Santiago, 7; and Ashley Dominguez, 4; and of wounding Vincent Santiago, 9, in the family's Yonkers apartment on Sept. 3, 2000. If convicted, Mr. Hernandez could be sentenced to death. His is the first death-penalty case in Westchester County since the state reinstated capital punishment. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Argentine Foundation Keeps Crumbling
description: With Argentina's foreign currency reserves dwindling and its ability to borrow abroad blocked by past defaults, its government is facing a desperate cash squeeze and is asking the World Bank to let it put off repaying $800 million in loans that come due this week, President Eduardo Duhalde said today.

title: Rights Panel Plans Fight
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights announced today that it planned to ask the Supreme Court to overturn a court decision seating a Bush administration appointee on the panel.

description: Yasir Arafat left Ramallah today for the first time in more than five months, visiting three other West Bank cities ravaged in Israeli military sweeps.

title: U.S. to Review Diplomacy in Chvez Crisis
description: The State Department inspector general will review actions by American diplomats related to the attempted ouster last month of President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela, a senior official said over the weekend.

title: In Fight Over Turf In Montana Valley, It's Man vs. Grizzly
description: Using rubber bullets, flying beanbags and Finnish bear dogs, Tim Manley, a Montana wildlife conflict specialist, teaches grizzlies to associate the outskirts of this resort town with unpleasantness and pain.

title: More Glum News For Magazine Ads
description: Despite signs of economic recovery, magazine advertising pages continued to decline in April, according to data released by the Publishers Information Bureau.

title: Newark Arena Financial Plan Is a Mix of Old and New Ideas
description: The financial partnership between the state and the owners of the New Jersey Nets and Devils to build a $355 million arena in Newark is a mix of the familiar and the novel: It cobbles together several old proposals by the teams and state officials, as well as new features that some critics say violate the State Constitution and may undermine pledges that taxpayers will not be put at risk.

Alpern, a senior editor.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Handspring Offers Wireless E-mail
description: Handspring, a maker of hand-held computers, has released Treo Mail, a wireless e-mail service intended for its Treo communicators. Analysts expect wireless organizers to spur the next wave of hand-held buying. But while the Treo, with its integration of cellphone and organizer functions, has been well reviewed, demand has been lackluster. The company has sold 47,000 units, most to retail stores and distributors; only 13,000 are in the hands of consumers. Hoping to increase demand, Handspring is offering $100 rebates to customers who trade in their cellphones or hand-held computers. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

description: JERUSALEM, May 14  Calling Yasir Arafat's Palestinian Authority a "rotten and dictatorial regime of terror," Prime Minister Ariel Sharon said today that Israel would not enter any peace negotiations until it could sit down with a "different Authority."

title: Judge Rejects Perelman Deal To End Dispute on Stock Sale
description: A Delaware judge rejected a settlement yesterday that allowed the financier Ronald O. Perelman to keep the money he received when he arranged for one company he controlled to pay him more than four times the market price for stock he owned in another company.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: State Workers Working More
description: State employees have steadily increased overtime hours over the past decade, as the number of workers on the state payroll has shrunk. The amount paid in time-and-a-half wages more than doubled to more than $46 million last year, from slightly more than $20 million in 1992, state officials said, and more than $191 million in the past five years. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Airline Posts Loss
description: Switzerland's new airline, Swiss, posted a first-quarter loss of $118 million, a better result than expected, and forecast its 2002 loss would be less than budgeted. Swiss, which replaced Swissair, said its second-quarter loss would be larger as it expanded its intercontinental business. Swiss's shareholders meeting yesterday also approved the change in the company's name from Crossair to Swiss International Air Lines Ltd. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: No Toll Increase
description: Lawmakers ruled out a toll increase on some of New Jersey's busiest roadways yesterday, saying the highway authorities might have to reduce construction projects if there is to be enough money to repay the $300 million bond used to build the E-ZPass toll collection system. In 1999, MFS Network Technologies won a $500 million contract to build E-ZPass, which was to be financed primarily through fines collected from toll cheats. But collections have fallen far short of estimates. Assemblyman John S. Wisniewski, chairman of the Transportation Committee, said that the New Jersey Turnpike Authority would not be allowed to default on the bonds.

title: Mideast Bombast and Diplomacy
description: Sometimes good news in the Middle East is a matter of what has not happened. In recent days, despite massing its troops and vowing retaliation for a suicide bombing last week, Israel chose not to invade the Gaza Strip. And Yasir Arafat, leaving Ramallah yesterday for the first time in five months, did not call for more ''martyrs.''

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Priceline Expands Offerings
description: In an effort to expand its inventory and compete with online rivals, Priceline.com has extended its name-your-own-price offerings to vacation packages that consumers can customize. Priceline will permit customers to choose their destination, departure and return dates and the number of hotel rooms needed. It will return a list of rooms available and the customer can choose a hotel and enter a bid for the package, including airfare. If the bid is accepted, Priceline arranges air transportation with one of its airline partners.

description: UNITED NATIONS, May 14  The United Nations Security Council unanimously approved a resolution this morning that would allow a vast array of goods to be ferried into Iraq while setting aside those items that may be put to military use.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Boy From Thailand To Get Special Visa
description: A 4-year-old boy from Thailand who was used in a scheme to smuggle prostitutes into the United States will receive a special visa allowing him to remain in this country for now, Justice Department officials said. The move brings the boy, Phanupong Khaisri, a step closer to remaining permanently with a family that wants to adopt him. Government officials initially denied asylum to the boy, who was severely malnourished when he entered the country in April 2000 and was later found to have H.I.V. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: Baruch to Add 42 Professors And a Dean to Lead Them
description: Baruch College, which is making a strong effort to push its graduate business program into the ranks of the nation's top-ranked business schools, announced yesterday the appointment of a new dean and plans for hiring 42 new full-time faculty members.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Telecom Profit Rises
description: Telefnica Mviles, the leading cellphone operator in Spain, announced an 85 percent rise in first-quarter net profit, to 287 million euros ($262 million) on a pro forma basis, despite losses from its European start-ups and costs caused by devaluation in Argentina. Strong growth in Spain and Brazil helped revenue rise 16.6 percent, to 2.26 billion euros, while earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization rose 22 percent, to 916.6 million euros. Operating costs were steady at 61 percent of revenue.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: BENEFITS FOR THE ELDERLY Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday inaugurated QuickCheck, a computer-based benefit-application system for the elderly developed by the city's Department for the Aging and the Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications. Under the system, people can use a computer to find out which benefit programs are administered by which city agencies, figure out which ones they qualify for, and then enroll. Caseworkers will be able to go to people's homes with laptops. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

Donations may be given to the Diabetes Foundation of Palm Beach, Florida.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: RAIL CRASH CAUSE Officials said a train derailment that killed seven people last week was caused by problems in track repaired late last year and inspected the day before the accident. Speaking to Parliament, the transportation secretary, Stephen Byers, said two missing nuts from the points system — the mechanism that enables trains to change tracks — had caused the rear car of the train to derail. About 70 people were injured in the accident, which took place at Potters Bar, north of London.    Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: An Atomic Bomb, a Zeppelin, a Warning About Genetic Manipulation
description: ''Three Tales,'' the big new live-music video by Steve Reich and Beryl Korot that had its world premiere here Sunday night in the Museumsquartier at the Vienna Festival, is going to excite a lot of controversy. These two artists did that with ''The Cave,'' which started out in the same place nine years ago and considered the common ancestry of Judaism and Islam. But where ''The Cave'' researched roots, ''Three Tales'' examines destinations. And where ''The Cave'' reached a bright American optimism in its finale, ''Three Tales'' mounts to a clamor of warning.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Tourism Chief Named
description: Jonathan M. Tisch, chairman and chief executive of Loews Hotels, was appointed chairman of the city's convention and visitor's bureau, NYC & Company, yesterday. Mr. Tisch, who is also the chairman of the National Business Roundtable, a group that promotes tourism, replaces Tim Zagat, the president of Zagat Surveys, which reviews restaurants in New York City and other places. While Mr. Zagat and NYC & Company's president and chief executive, Cristyne L. Nicholas, are credited with helping the New York tourism industry recover after the Sept. 11 attack, Mr. Tisch has lobbied in Washington for the industries. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: In hot housing markets, signs of overheating
description: LONDON:  The housing market has heated up to such a fevered state here that home-hunters are resorting to unorthodox approaches. A few weeks ago, one of them wrote a letter to every resident of Inglebert Street, a modest stretch of row houses in the Clerkenwell neighborhood where two-bedroom apartments can fetch more than 300,000 ($440,000).

title: Savings in Santa Monica
description: Through June, the 63-suite Hotel Oceana in Santa Monica, Calif., is charging $250 for pool-view accommodations to $565 a night for a two-bedroom suite, savings of up to 34 percent. Rooms have Italian linens, and amenities include a heated pool. The hotel is near the ocean, shopping and restaurants. A two-night stay is required and availability is limited. Information: (800) 777-0758 or www.hoteloceana.com .

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Lucent Allots Shares For Agere
description: Lucent Technologies, the telecommunications equipment maker, has decided how to distribute the shares in the spinoff of its remaining 58 percent stake in the chip maker Agere Systems of Allentown, Pa. Lucent said it would issue one share of Agere Class A common stock for every 92.768991 shares of Lucent common stock, and one Agere Class B common share for every 3.779818 shares of Lucent common stock. The shares will be distributed on June 1 to stockholders of record as of May 3. Agere wants to split so it can sell more parts to companies that may have been reluctant to award contracts to the unit of a rival.

title: Have It Your Way (but Hold the Garlic Powder)
description: Quorn's greatest virtue is its blandness. Like tofu or wheat gluten, it serves primarily as a vehicle for whatever flavors and textures are imparted through cooking. Put tofu in the hands of a skilled Sichuan chef and, with the addition of a little pork, chili, Sichuan pepper, garlic and oil, you might have a masterpiece.

title: Not Even a Whimper
description: Luciano Pavarotti's farewell to the Metropolitan Opera should not have gone like this. On Saturday night Mr. Pavarotti withdrew at the last hour, and after much vacillation, from performing in ''Tosca'' at the Met's season-end gala. He had done the same on Wednesday night, citing illness. A sense of inevitability and self-exculpation was in the air for several days, as everyone associated with scheduling Mr. Pavarotti tried to acknowledge that events had slipped out of their control. Mr. Pavarotti was the chief self-exculpator. ''A proper vocal condition is the basic rule for any singing performance,'' he wrote in a public letter explaining his decision, and ''without it, no matter how much willingness, talent, discipline or passion there is, it is simply impossible to offer the public the performance for which they have paid.'' It has been some time, however, since Mr. Pavarotti was in proper vocal condition; proper, that is, for a full operatic performance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATZKIN, ROSE ELLIS. HADASSAH
description: MATZKIN-Rose Ellis. Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, announces with great sadness the death of its 15th National President, who served 1972-1976. During her tenure, Hadassah University Hospital on Mt. Scopus was reopened and Kibbutz Ketura was founded in the Arava. A lifelong Zionist, she served in numerous capacities within Hadassah and the Zionist world, holding many portfolios and offices. A member of President Ford's Task Force on Women, she was also an honorary life member of the Board of Governors of the Hebrew University. She got her start with Hadassah as the president of the Waterbury Chapter and served as president of the Connecticut Region. A gracious presence and powerful orator, she will be missed by countless devoted Hadassah friends and admirers. Predeceased by her beloved husband, Dr. Max Matzkin, she leaves behind children, Dr. Michael Matzkin and Hannah Lavine, their spouses, four granddaughters and two great grandchildren. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Bonnie Lipton National President

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sun Executive Joins Netezza Board
description: Edward J. Zander, the retiring president and chief operating officer of Sun Microsystems, will join the board of Netezza, a start-up company that makes computers. Netezza, based in Framingham, Mass., plans to ship its first data-serving computers in two or three months. The computers will be used for analyzing marketing and customer data. Mr. Zander, above, the No. 2 executive at Sun, said earlier this month that he would retire from Sun on July 1 and would consider becoming chief executive of another company. He could not be reached for comment yesterday, but Jit Saxena, the chief executive of Netezza, said there were no plans for Mr. Zander to take the company's helm. ''It's just a coincidence,'' Mr. Saxena said, ''that we announced this thing when he was just leaving Sun.'' Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Immigrant Amnesty Campaign
description: Several dozen community organizations, religious groups and labor unions plan to announce a nationwide campaign today to collect a million postcards that urge President Bush and members of Congress to change immigration laws to grant amnesty to many illegal immigrants. Groups in 30 cities, including New York, Los Angeles, Chicago and Miami, will participate in the campaign. Among the groups sponsoring the drive are the New York Immigration Coalition, the Bronx Spanish Evangelical Church, Make the Road by Walking, the Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now, and Local 32B-32J of the Service Employees International Union. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

description: With more than two decades of fighting seemingly at an end, the Angolan government is facing new pressures to account for its enormous oil revenue and to devote more of its resources to rebuilding this war-shattered country.

title: Victim's Father May Be Given Spot on Rebuilding Committee
description: Gov. George E. Pataki is expected today to appoint the father of a financial analyst who was killed in the attack on the World Trade Center to the board of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, a state official said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about an Indian-American motel owner in Winslow, Ariz., and a competitor, who advertises her own motel as ''American owned and operated,'' referred incorrectly to 17,000 United States hotels and motels whose owners are of Asian descent and misattributed the information in some copies. The businesses are owned by members of the Asian American Hotel Owners Association, not by Indians. The figure is the estimate of the association, not of its chairman, Mike Amin.

title: Latest Energy Deal in Canada Is a Plan to Acquire Rio Alto
description: Continuing a flurry of consolidation in western Canada's energy industry, Rio Alto Exploration said today that it had agreed to be acquired by Canadian Natural Resources for 1.43 billion Canadian dollars ($918 million) in cash and stock after Rio Alto spins off its Latin American operations to its shareholders.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Advertising Age, part of Crain Communications, named the winners of its annual Best Awards competition, for ads created during 2001. The winner of the Best of Show award, by a unanimous vote, was the popular "Freestyle" commercial for Nike basketball shoes by Wieden & Kennedy, Portland, Ore. Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, San Francisco, part of the Omnicom Group, received two awards and two commendations; Arnold Worldwide, Boston, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners division of Havas Advertising, received one award and three commendations; and the New York office of Bartle Bogle Hegarty, which is 49 percent owned by the Bcom3 Group, received two awards. In a special category to honor ads relating to Sept. 11, the winner was the "New York miracle: campaign to promote tourism for New York City, created by the New York office of BBDO Worldwide, part of Omnicom.

title: The Great Evasion
description: Last week Stanley Works, a Connecticut tool company, postponed its plan to evade taxes by incorporating itself in Bermuda. The decision reflected pressure from the White House, which denounced the move as unpatriotic in a time of national emergency.

title: Off the Reservation, Onto the Dealer's Lot
description: Frontier Ford, a nondescript dealership with a few rows of cars lined up in its lot in this small central Mississippi town, does not look like much of a competitive threat.

description: Michael J. Fox's celebrity can do more than raise money for Parkinson's research. It may also help open an avenue of research that scientists have long wanted to explore.

title: A New Jersey Senate Candidate Lists $3 Million From Dividends
description: Douglas R. Forrester, a candidate for the Republican nomination for the United State Senate, has used at least $3 million in dividends from his company to pay for his campaign, he reported today in documents required under Senate ethics rules.

description: Marc Smirnoff has been kicked out of parties, cussed out behind his back and branded a carpetbagger on the walls of restaurant bathrooms all over this town of 12,000.

description: LOS ANGELES, May 13 -- The Mets hoped a weekend of meetings, soggy weather and bad baseball had been left behind in New York. But jet lag does little to cure the hitting woes.

description: Today is Election Day. Polls will open at 6 a.m. and close at 8 p.m. for non-partisan, municipal elections in Essex County and other selected municipalities in New Jersey.

title: Russia Sees Pact's Virtue As Closer Ties With the West
description: The wholesale reduction of strategic nuclear weapons announced today may help sustain the slow-motion momentum of Russia's realignment toward the West, and it may give the architect of that realignment, President Vladimir V. Putin, a marginal political lift at home.

title: Pulling Russia Closer
description: The strategic arms reductions that the United States and Russia announced today represent radical cutbacks impossible to even ponder during the cold war, despite the warhead storage issues that remain.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Killed By Truck
description: An 87-year-old Manhattan man was killed yesterday when a garbage truck hit him, in what at first appeared to be a hit-and-run accident, the police said. The truck struck the man, Mee Sun Jung of Henry Street, at the intersection of Chrystie and Grand Streets about 7:45 a.m., and drove away. The man was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center, where he died. A witness said that the truck belonged to Gotham Recycling Resources in Newark. The police called the company, and the driver returned to the scene. No charges were filed, Officer Louis Camacho said. The police said the incident was being considered an accident. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Giants Complete Office Reshuffling
description: The Giants completed the restructuring of much of their player personnel department yesterday, naming Ken Sternfeld to be the team's assistant director of pro personnel. He replaces Jerry Reese, who was named director of college player personnel earlier this month.

title: Diplomacy vs. Family
description: To the Editor:

title: Aspirin's Added Benefits to Heart
description: Aspirin may help prevent heart disease in more ways than was thought, according to a study released yesterday in the journal Circulation.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on April 26 about Col. William E. Barber of the Marines, who won the Medal of Honor for his leadership at the Battle of the Chosin Reservoir in Korea, in 1950, referred incompletely to the outcome. Although an overwhelming Chinese force ultimately drove the much smaller American one from the field, the Marines, and some historians, describe the American action as a series of tactical victories in the course of a fighting withdrawal or retreat, not one of the worst defeats in Marine Corps history.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Study Questions H.M.O. Decisions
description: A new study in Texas has concluded that patients are being improperly denied medical care by health maintenance organizations, particularly on initial claims for mental health treatment. The report by Consumers Union, which reviewed 263 appeals heard by the State Department of Insurance from March to September 2001, found that 70 percent of cases in which the H.M.O. rejected providing coverage related to mental illness were overturned when appealed to an independent reviewer. A spokeswoman for the Texas Association of Health Plans attributed the higher rate of overturned denials to the complexities of mental illness. Jim Yardley (NYT)

title: Open Hearings Sought for Terror Detainees
description: Even a case-by-case process of determining whether immigration hearings for post-Sept. 11 detainees should be kept secret could jeopardize the terrorism investigation, lawyers for the federal government argued today as they battled a lawsuit over whether to open the hearings to the press.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: No Mayor For Plymouth
description: Voters in Plymouth rejected a plan to replace their nearly 400-year-old form of government by annual town meeting with a mayor and town council system. On Saturday, 35 percent of Plymouth's registered voters went to the polls, twice the normal turnout, with 7,196 against the proposal to 4,388 in favor. Supporters of the mayoral plan contended that the town-meeting system could not cope with Plymouth's rapid growth. But in a town that dates to 1620, when it was settled by the Pilgrims, tradition triumphed. Fox Butterfield (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUS, HERMAN I.
description: KRAUS-Herman I. The Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member, Herman I. Kraus. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Samuel Wasserman, President

title: Clinical Trial for Oral Form of Drug Fails
description: A new approach that would allow drugs that must now be injected to be taken orally instead has failed in its first significant clinical trial, a spokeswoman for the company that developed the technology said last night.

Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Service Thursday, May 16, 9:30 AM at the chapel of Frank E. Campbell.

title: Competing Claims in Trial In Killings Above a Deli
description: One man says he was not even there on the evening last May when three people were killed and two others wounded during a botched robbery of a marijuana dealer in an apartment above the Carnegie Delicatessen. The other man says he was forced to join the robbery and killed only one person, by accident. The prosecutors say both men are lying.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: INDIANA: STATE WORKERS WORKING MORE State employees have steadily increased overtime hours over the past decade, as the number of workers on the state payroll has shrunk. The amount paid in time-and-a-half wages more than doubled to more than $46 million last year, from slightly more than $20 million in 1992, state officials said, and more than $191 million in the past five years.    Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOOSLI, DEMETRIA
description: LOOSLI-Demetria. Mrs. Demetria Loosli of Plainfield, New Jersey passed away peacefully in her sleep at the age of 86 on Sunday, May 12, 2002. She was the widow of the late Mr. Alden Loosli and is survived by two daughters, Louise Petz of New York City and Lisle Bradley of Boulder, CO, two sons, Ben of Chambersburg, PA., and Richard of Plainfield, eight grandchildren and one great grandchild. Services will be held at 10:00 A.M. on Wednesday, May 15, 2002 at Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church, 716 Watchung Avenue, Plainfield, New Jersey. Callers will be received from 7 to 9 P.M., on Tuesday, May 14, 2002 at Higgins Funeral Home, 209 West 8th Street, Plainfield, N.J. 07060. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Mrs. Loosli's memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Truckers To Watch For Terrorists
description: The nation's trucking industry has offered to train its three million drivers to keep close watch on potential terrorist targets like bridges, tunnels, ports and large commercial facilities. A coalition of industry organizations, the Trucking Security Working Group, said drivers would be given a toll-free number to call should they spot any suspicious activity. B. Drummond Ayres Jr. (NYT)

title: Cuban Dissidents Put Hope in a Petition and Jimmy Carter
description: Oswaldo Paya is a Cuban radical. But he is not among the hoarse-throated, flag-waving masses that cheer President Fidel Castro. He is radical because he has asked openly for democracy.

description: A court-appointed expert proposed new Congressional boundaries for New York today that would eliminate two upstate districts but none in the New York City area.

title: Kelly Says Police May Be Cut To Lowest Level in a Decade
description: The Police Department will shrink to its smallest size in nearly a decade by December if Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has to put his contingency budget plan in place, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: METAL STRIKE TALKS SET German metalworkers and their employers agreed to resume contract negotiations on Wednesday as one-day strikes spread to the state of Brandenburg and Berlin and those in the state of Baden-Wurttemberg moved into a second week. According to the union IG Metall, more than 100,000 workers joined last week's action and this week they called on 130,000 workers at 135 plants in both regions to take part in the one-day strikes. A union spokesman said the strikes would continue until a deal was reached. The union is demanding wage increases of 6.5 percent and the employers are offering 3.3 percent.

title: American Views of the Mideast Conflict
description: Congress's overwhelming backing of Israel's use of force in the West Bank is reflective of the politics of Washington, but it runs counter to the tone of American public opinion about the crisis in the Middle East. Americans are and consistently have been more sympathetic to Israelis than to the Palestinians, and that feeling was reinforced by the attacks on Sept. 11 and the suicide bombings in Israel this spring. But average Americans see shades of gray in the Middle East conflict, and their sympathies notwithstanding, they favor a neutral role for the United States.

title: New Yorker Is Suspected of Aiding Killers of Anti-Taliban Leader
description: A Staten Island man indicted on charges related to terrorism is also suspected of helping prepare a letter of introduction used last year by two men who killed Ahmed Shah Massoud, the commander of the anti-Taliban forces in northern Afghanistan, an official said yesterday.

title: In Hong Kong
description: Hong Kong is still woozy from its second economic slowdown in four years, but there are signs of revival. Tourism is booming, the stock market has stabilized and the real estate market -- Hong Kong's lifeline -- is alive again. In a sign the former British colony has not lost its hubris, it is building two of Asia's tallest skyscrapers on either side of Victoria Harbor, an 88-story monolith to house the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and a 102-story headquarters for the mass transit system.

title: Franco Opts For Surgery In Attempt To Return
description: Mets reliever John Franco, hoping to prolong a career that has brought him to No. 2 on the major league saves list, said today that he would undergo surgery here Wednesday afternoon to repair ligament and tendon damage in his pitching elbow.

title: Critic's Notebook; Carnegie Hall vs. the Kimmel Center
description: When the Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts in Philadelphia opened in December, work on Verizon Hall, the new 2,500-seat home of the Philadelphia Orchestra, the largest component of the center, was barely complete. With its unusual shape, somewhat like a cello, its airy ambience, beautiful wood paneling and velour seat covers, Verizon Hall immediately felt like an inviting space to hear a concert. But you were reluctant to place your hand on a railing for fear of getting smudged with wet varnish. The air-conditioning system was stuck on high, and the hall was freezing.

title: Skakel Tutor, Once a Suspect, Says His Admission in the Moxley Killing Was Wrong
description: The judge in the murder trial of Michael C. Skakel allowed jurors to hear conflicting and confusing testimony today from another longtime suspect about whether he had ever confessed to the crime.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Insurer's Revenue Rises
description: Europe's secondbiggest insurer, AXA, said first-quarter revenue rose 2.5 percent, to 21.12 billion euros ($19.3 billion) from 20.6 billion euros a year earlier. Revenue from its biggest business, life insurance and pensions, fell 1.8 percent, while asset management revenue gained 4.5 percent. Last year, AXA's revenue rose 2.1 percent, the smallest gain in seven years. Its chief executive, Henri de Castries, is taking steps to cut costs by 600 million euros; he eliminated 530 positions in the United States and has hinted at cutting as many as 300 more in Britain. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: NORTEL TO SELL ABOUT $2.5 BILLION IN SECURITIES
description: Nortel Networks, a maker of telephone equipment, will file to sell as much as $2.5 billion of securities. Nortel, which lost $25.6 billion in the last year and had its credit rating cut to junk status, is increasing the amount it may raise by $1.5 billion as demand for its equipment slumps. Analysts said the filing was an indication that the company could not count on sales to rebound soon. Nortel may sell securities that can be converted into stock, rather than bonds, they said. The junk rating, issued last month, set off a bank-line provision that gives creditors title to Nortel's assets in the event of bankruptcy. That means that any new bonds will not be backed by assets, analysts said. Nortel, which is based in Brampton, Ontario, said the sale of securities might include common and preferred shares, along with debt and warrants to purchase equity or debt.

title: Vodafone Selects J. Walter Thompson
description: The Vodafone Group in Newbury, England, yesterday named J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group, as the first worldwide agency to handle its account as the company moves to a single mobile telephone brand. Total spending was estimated at more than $120 million.

description: In the Case of the Purloined Panels, Robert Hickman trusts nobody.

title: At Least 30 Killed in Kashmir by Suspected Islamic Militants
description: NEW DELHI, May 14  In one of the deadliest terrorist attacks India has witnessed in recent years, three heavily armed men disguised in army fatigues killed 30 people today and wounded 48 in wild sprays of automatic gunfire on the outskirts of Jammu, the winter capital of the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir.

title: Moon's Dust Hides a Throbbing Heart
description: It takes two and a half seconds for a laser beam to flash from Earth to the Moon and back again. But it has taken 33 years of doing such experiments for scientists to glimpse what may be the Moon's greatest secret: that far beneath its cold craters and rocky landscape lies a heart that is warm and yielding. The discovery, if confirmed, could boost a theory that the Moon was born in the aftermath of a violent collision between early Earth and a speeding cosmic wanderer.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Utility's Profit Is Up
description: The Korea Electric Power Corporation said its profit in the first quarter rose 91 percent, to $616.1 million, over the year-earlier quarter. Analysts attributed the gain, which was better than expected, to a 9.6 percent increase in electricity use along with lower fuel prices. The company appears to have emerged unscathed from a 38-day strike, which ended April 4, by workers protesting plans by the government to sell its thermal power operations. The strike forced the government to delay the sale of the company's 30 percent stake in Powercomm, which produces fiber optic cables, from February to June.

title: NATO Countries Approve Pact Giving Russia Role of a Partner
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, May 14 - More than 50 years after its founding and a decade after the end of the cold war, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization approved an agreement today accepting Russia, the former enemy it was formed to fight, into a new partnership with the allies on terrorism, arms control and international crisis management in a post-Sept. 11 world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITEMAN, DR. HAROLD BARTLETT, JR.
description: WHITEMAN-Dr. Harold Bartlett, Jr., 82. Died May 6, 2002 at his home in Nashville, TN. Dr. Whiteman was born on April 22, 1920, son of Emma Anderson Whiteman & Harold Barlett Whiteman. He attended the Taft School in Watertown, CT., and Yale College in New Haven, CT. where he was a member of Phi Beta Kappa and captain of the 1940 varsity football team. He served in the military during World War II in Africa. He received his M.A. in political science from Vanderbilt in 1950, and his Ph.D. in International Relations from Yale University in 1958. Dr. Whiteman was married in July of 1946 to the former Edith Uhler Davis of Nashville. He served as a mathematics instructor at Taft from 1946-1947 and a Teaching Fellow at Vanderbilt from 1947-1948. He served Yale University as Dean of the Freshman Year from 1948-1964. He was named as Assistant to the President of New York University in NYC in 1964 and he served there until 1971 as Vice Chancellor for Student Affairs. In 1971 Dr. Whiteman was named President of Sweet Briar College, a womens' college in Amherst County, Virginia. He served there until his retirement in 1983. Dr. Whiteman served on many committees and and boards during his notable career, including the board of the Berkeley Divinity School at Yale, the Virginia Foundation of Independent Colleges, and the English Speaking Union. Outside of his academic achievements, Dr. Whiteman spent many days sailing the waters of New England and Martha's Vineyard, where his family maintains a summer home. He is survived by his wife, Edith Uhler Davis Whiteman; three children, Harold Bartlett Whiteman III of Lookout Mountain, GA, Maclin Davis Whiteman of Nashville, and Priscilla Whiteman Kellert of New Haven, CT.; three grandchildren, three step grandchildren and one step-great grandchild.

title: Hurricanes Oust Canadiens With 5-Goal First Period
description: They were first called the New England Whalers, then the Hartford Whalers. Their homes were in Boston, Springfield, Mass., and Hartford. They have played in the World Hockey Association and the National Hockey League. Recently, they have been based in two cities in North Carolina. For 30 years, they were everywhere and nowhere, a nomad team and a no-man's team. Yes, Gordie Howe played for them, but so did hundreds of guys few fans ever heard of.

description: Markus J. Granziol, the chairman of UBS Warburg, the global investment banking arm of UBS of Switzerland, is expected to announce his resignation today, a person close to the bank said.

description: The vote by Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's political party against the establishment of any independent Palestinian state may limit his room for maneuver but will not tie his hands, Israeli politicians and political analysts said today.

title: How to Create A Film Festival In Just 4 Months
description: The resounding success of the first TriBeCa Film Festival proved that, as one of its founders, Martin Scorsese, said in his opening address at the award ceremony on Sunday, ''a major film festival, pulled together in four months,'' can be made to happen. All that's required is hard work, intriguing programming, a phalanx of volunteers doing a great job of managing the audiences, and several million dollars of seed money from American Express.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Kosovo: Convictions In Serbs' Killings

Since the 1999 war, Serbs have complained that revenge killings against them have been all but ignored. Last Friday, a court convicted a German who fought aside ethnic Albanian rebels for his role in a bomb attack last year in which a Serb was killed. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Shares In Broadcaster Are Sold
description: Deutsche Bank said it was offering to sell 250 million shares in the pay-TV broadcaster British Sky Broadcasting, part of the 22 percent in BskyB held by the troubled French media giant Vivendi Universal. Vivendi deposited the shares with Deutsche Bank late last year along with 150 million others that make up its stake. Vivendi's move was seen as an effort to placate credit agencies worried about its $15.4 billion debt. The sale, worth $2.4 billion, pushed Vivendi's shares up by over 5 percent after months of declines. BskyB shares first fell then rose by about 1 percent. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Reviewing New Opera? Not Quite
description: For six late afternoons over the last two weeks, the New York City Opera has been hard at work, but not at Lincoln Center. No, the company didn't pack up and sneak off the center's campus, fulfilling its threat to relocate away from its squabbling, hostile constituents.

title: To the Trade, and Now to You
description: Piccinini Brothers, a Ninth Avenue meat purveyor since 1922, has a sleek new retail offshoot: Tartare, 653 Ninth Avenue (46th Street). Owned by Paul Vaccari, whose grandfather was a Piccinini founder, and his wife, Sylvie, the store offers both fresh meat and prepared foods. The small shop has an invitingly open glass facade; inside, display cases hold platters of delicious-looking meats, until now sold by Piccinini only to restaurants. Some of the meat has been stuffed and seasoned and is ready to cook. There are side dishes, some seafood and even desserts. The chef, Lea Forant, also makes sauces, stocks and glazes. Chickens, loins of pork and other meats turn on a French rotisserie. Wednesday's specials are steak au poivre cooked or ready for the pan ($32 and $28 a pound), along with potato gratin ($9.50 a pound) and spinach with garlic ($5.95 a pound); tomorrow's include herb-crusted rack of lamb ($19 a pound, cooked). A roast beef dinner will be available on Sunday ($18 a pound with side dishes at $3.95 to $8.95 a pound). The shop will deliver free in a 25-block radius on the West Side and for cab fare elsewhere.

title: Priceline Cuts Ties With Hill, Holliday
description: Priceline.com said yesterday that it had ended its relationship with Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston after almost three years. Priceline, the online seller of discount travel services like airline tickets, will handle its own advertising. Last year, it spent about $40 million on advertising, according to the CMR division of Taylor Nelson Sofres.

title: On Day of Big Fund-Raiser, White House Is Attacked as 9/11 Marketer
description: The Republican Party raised a record $30 million at a black-tie gala tonight from major corporations with issues before the government, but the White House spent most of the day engulfed in a separate fund-raising dispute over a picture taken on Sept. 11.

title: Stock Option Windfall for Comcast Official
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (Bloomberg News)  Ralph Roberts, the chairman of the Comcast Corporation , generated about $32.7 million of paper profits through the exercise of company stock options last month.

title: Video of Death Of Journalist Is Seen in Court In Pakistan
description: A video showing the beheading of the American journalist Daniel Pearl was shown in a Pakistani court today in the trial of four men accused of the murder.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: ISUZU RAISES LOSS FORECAST The automaker Isuzu Motors has raised its forecast for an expected loss in the fiscal year that ended March 31 as truck sales slumped. Isuzu, which is 49 percent owned by General Motors , expects to lose 43 billion yen ($335 million) even though it benefited from cost cutting and a weaker yen. The company raised the figure from a loss of 25 billion yen that it forecast in November. Isuzu cut its debt by 30 percent but still has 740 billion yen ($5.8 billion) in obligations, an amount analysts say is too high, given its sales. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: MOVIE CRAZY : Cannes, Hollywood... Bollywood & the world
description: CANNES  The Cannes Festival at this flashy little beach resort is striving to revamp its legendary frosty image and stave off grumbles from foreign guests, and the Hollywood contingent  so desired, yet so feared.

title: Yearning to Teach Math
description: To the Editor:

title: Neil Diamond Carries a Tune for N.Y.U.
description: L. JAY OLIVA, New York University's departing president, who loves to sing and dance as much as he loves being a college president, was looking for a way to go out with a bang at his final commencement ceremony this week. He asked NEIL DIAMOND, an N.Y.U. alumnus, if he would write a song for the university. He did. ''It's not a new alma mater,'' Mr. Oliva said, explaining that the alumni would never forgive such a move. ''But you have got to keep adding,'' he said. ''It's like having 'God Bless America' and 'The Star Spangled Banner.' ''

title: Downtown Families Eligible for More Housing Aid
description: Families living in Chinatown and Little Italy will be eligible for housing assistance grants of up to $750 more than previously proposed under a revised plan that is expected to be announced today, state officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IMPERATO, FRANK
description: IMPERATO-Frank. Born November 11, 1960. Died May 13, 2002. With deep sorrow and affection, we mourn the passing of our brother and dear friend. Frank brought a sense of drama, comedy and passion to everything and everyone he touched. He will always be remembered because he was truly unforgettable. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave on Wed & Thurs. 212-288-3500 Albert Imperato Mitchell & Patti Grabow Suzanne & Mike Gerla Lisa & Tom Karach Tom Herman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OPOLINSKY, STANLEY
description: OPOLINSKY-Stanley, of Boca Raton, FL, age 74. Thank you for our beautiful children and grandchildren and for sharing them with me. Rest easy. Love, Dorothy Widder

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Protecting Landmarks
description: United States Representatives Carolyn B. Maloney and Jerrold Nadler, both Democrats, have introduced legislation that would permanently protect the status of two historical sites on Governors Island that President Bill Clinton had named national monuments before he left office, they said yesterday. But since President Bush has agreed to sell the island to New York for a nominal sum, officials said, his administration has questioned the validity of the designations of Castle Williams and Fort Jay. The legislation, if passed by Congress, would retain that status for the sites and require the federal government to maintain them, regardless of how the rest of the island, planned as a campus for the City University of New York, is developed. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Our Towns; A New Tale Of 2 Cities, But Both Are Newark
description: MONDAY night's rain had cut attendance at Sharpe James's pre-election rally to 200, from the planned 2,000. There was extra food and an extra-loud band, and anxiety rippled through the paltry crowd in the cavernous bus garage that had been cleared out for the event. ''I'm surprised there's not more people,'' one woman said nervously.

title: Dear I.R.S.: Forward to Bermuda
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Counterterrorism Hot Line
description: The New York Police Department announced yesterday the creation of a new phone line for information about suspected terrorist activity and encouraged anyone who had suspicions or knowledge of terrorist activity to call. The number, (718) 615-7040, was established by the counterterrorism bureau and is staffed continuously, the police said. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: News Corp. Reports a Loss, but Its Shares Soar
description: The News Corporation of Australia reported strong quarterly results from many of its core media operations yesterday, even as a soured outside investment caused it to report a $4 billion loss.

title: Completing an Offbeat Trifecta on Clinton Street
description: ALIAS, which opened several months ago on the Lower East Side, serves seared pork loin with sauerkraut. Its duck confit comes with black-eyed peas, its ceviche with roasted pumpkin seed oil. It cures its own sable and offers its own pickle plate.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Air Testing After Sept. 11 Attack Is Both Perplexing and Reassuring
description: The ground-level atmosphere of Lower Manhattan has become one of the most intensely studied and sampled environments on the planet. Air monitors have been hung from trees and strapped to the belts of truck drivers. At least 11,000 people who worked at ground zero have had chest X-rays. Thousands more have been interviewed by researchers. What has been learned, scientists say, will have a far-reaching effect on urban disasters in the future.

title: New Dean at C.C.N.Y.
description: The City College of New York named ALFRED S. POSAMENTIER as dean of its school of education recently; he had been the interim dean since 1999. In recent years, the school and the college have worked to increase the number of C.C.N.Y. graduates who pass the state's teacher certification exams, and Dr. Posamentier said he hoped to raise that number still further. A graduate of Hunter College, he received a master's degree from City College and a Ph.D. in mathematics education from Fordham University. Karen W. Arenson

title: Prosecutors Try to Recreate Birmingham's '63 Nightmare
description: Prosecutors led the jury today on a nightmare journey of crumpled church walls, shattered stained glass and murdered children and tried to bind a now-old white supremacist to that terror with a white Klansman's robe and a 38-year-old clip of black-and-white film.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the difficulty of dismantling the Maine Yankee nuclear power plant misstated the name of an environmental education institution a mile away. It is the Chewonki Foundation, not Chewonski.

title: Racing Dead Horses. Dental Torture. The Usual.
description: The scaly spire of the Chrysler Building in New York City is the summit of all dreams in ''Cremaster 3,'' the centerpiece of Matthew Barney's deliriously esoteric five-part epic cycle exploring artistic creation and destruction. Images of that spire, poking through clouds like the needled head of a giant swordfish jabbing into heaven, recur throughout this three-hour movie, which opens today at the Film Forum.

title: Lakers Stick to Script And Eliminate the Spurs
description: It was another sluggish start for the Los Angeles Lakers, but another superb finish, sending the two-time defending N.B.A. champions into a much-anticipated duel with the Sacramento Kings in the Western Conference finals. The Lakers defeated the San Antonio Spurs, 93-87, tonight before 18,997 at the Staples Center to capture the four-of-seven-game series in five games.

title: Ballet Theater Gives an Overture to Its Season
description: American Ballet Theater opened its eight-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday night with one of its best gala benefits. It was a shrewdly paced, straightforward evening, filled mainly with excerpts but not tidbits, and even the usual thanks to donors were kept to a minimum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACK, THEODIES (TED)
description: BLACK-Theodies (Ted). Departed this life on Sunday, May 12. Father of Dorothy, Anita and Babette. Grandfather of five. Great-grandfather of nine. Retired employee of UAW, State of Illinois. Active with the Illinois Judicial Council, CBTU and South Central Services, Inc. For information call Griffin Funeral Home (312-842-3232).

title: New Dean at Woodrow Wilson School
description: Princeton University named ANNE-MARIE SLAUGHTER, a professor at both Harvard Law School and the John F. Kennedy School of Government, as the next dean of the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs yesterday. SHIRLEY M. TILGHMAN, Princeton's president, said Ms. Slaughter's "deep background in international affairs" and "interdisciplinary approach" were factors in her selection as dean. Ms. Slaughter, a 1980 Princeton graduate, earned a master's degree and a doctorate in international relations from Oxford University and a law degree from Harvard. Her teaching and research have focused on global governance, the politics of international tribunals and interdisciplinary analyses of international legal issues. She will hold faculty positions both at Woodrow Wilson and in Princeton's department of politics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PITTMAN, HOWARD
description: PITTMAN-Howard. With deep sorrow and affection, we mourn the passing of our dear friend, Howard. Howard was ''one in a million'',''a mench'', always with kindness in his heart and a smile on his face. He will always be remembered. We extend our sincerest condolences and sympathy to Millie and the entire family. Roslyn and Robert Smith

title: California Governor Seeking Tax Increase to Cut Shortfall
description: After months of saying he had no intention of raising taxes, Gov. Gray Davis announced a revised budget today to reduce a $23.6 billion shortfall with the help of far-reaching spending cuts and tax increases.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Congressman Says He Leaked Tape
description: After years of speculation, Representative Jim McDermott, Democrat of Washington, has said he leaked to reporters a taped cellphone conversation that embarrassed Newt Gingrich, who was then the House speaker. In the 1996 conversation, recorded by a Florida couple who gave the tape to Mr. McDermott, Mr. Gingrich discussed with other House Republican leaders how to deal with a finding against him by the ethics-committee. Mr. McDermott's admission that he let reporters hear the tape came in court filings in a lawsuit against him by Representative John A. Boehner, an Ohio Republican who was also taped. Blaine Harden (NYT)

title: Senate Votes To Break Up Trade Pacts
description: The Senate scorned the threat of a Bush administration veto today, voting to amend trade legislation to permit separate votes on any provisions of new agreements that could weaken existing antidumping laws.

title: Vivendi walks tightrope with balance sheet
description: PARIS:  Bowing to pressure from credit ratings agencies to reduce debt and improve transparency, Vivendi Universal on Tuesday agreed to the early settlement of a financing arrangement with Deutsche Bank that could have exposed the media company to billions of dollars in off-balance sheet risks.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Elizabeth: Teenagers Admit Sex Assault
description: Two teenage boys, both students at Scotch Plains-Fanwood High School in Scotch Plains, have admitted to their involvement in a gang-sex assault on a 13-year-old girl. In separate hearings in Superior Court, the two, Mark Russell, 17, and Jesus Gonzalez, 16, confessed that they were among the five boys who forced the girl to perform sex acts on them near Park Creek Middle School on Jan. 2. Both Mr. Russell and Mr. Gonzalez will be sentenced as adults. If the judge finds them guilty of aggravated sexual assault based on the confessions, they could face up to 18 years in prison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAFIAS, TINA
description: VAFIAS-Tina. Of Hampton Bays, NY on May 14, 2002. Beloved wife of Constantine. Loving daughter of Mary Zagoreos. Cherished mother of George-Jonathon and Cynthia Vafias; Melissa Caye Vafias, and Drew Robustelli. Dear sister of Aglaia Zagoreos. Reposing Thursday 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 PM at the Ralph Aievoli & Son Funeral Home, Inc. 1275 65th St., Brooklyn, NY and Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the Brockett Funeral Home, Inc. 203 Hampton Road. Southampton, NY. Funeral Service Sat. 12:30 PM at the Greek Orthodox Church of the Hamptons, Southampton, New York. Interment in Southampton Cemetery. In lieu of flowers memorial donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital, or the Greek Orthodox Church of the Hamptons would be appreciated.

title: Priceline Cuts Ties With Hill, Holliday
description: Priceline.com said yesterday that it had ended its relationship with Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston after almost three years. Priceline, the online seller of discount travel services like airline tickets, will handle its own advertising. Last year, it spent about $40 million on advertising, according to the CMR division of Taylor Nelson Sofres.

title: National Briefing: Northwest
description: IDAHO: REVISITING TERM LIMITS Three months after the Legislature repealed a law setting term limits for state and local officials, a group has collected enough signatures to put the issue on the ballot a second time. In 1994, voters approved the first measure, but lawmakers invalidated it in February, saying it drove out experienced officials. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Suit Says Company Promoted Drug in Exam Rooms
description: Newly unsealed court documents reveal that some physicians, in exchange for money, have allowed pharmaceutical sales representatives into their examining rooms to meet with patients, review medical charts and recommend what medicines to prescribe.

title: As Civil Rights Battles Recede, Generational Fights Replace Them
description: Thirty-five years ago, this striving city still digging itself out of the rubble of riot -- played host to one of the first national conferences on black power. The theme of the conference was simple: energizing a sometimes passive electorate and positioning black candidates to run for elective offices dominated by a white establishment.

title: Squeezing Big Ideas Into Small Packages
description: Is there any setting for a play more hackneyed than a school reunion? At the start of ''Reunions,'' Billy Aronson's one-act play at the Ensemble Studio Theater, three recognizable types -- a single career woman, a pregnant wife and a perennially ignorable nerd -- begin trading their apt and ordinary life stories around the punch table, and in the audience your eyes blink from the dust being blown off this antique clich, and your heart sinks in disbelief.

title: Being Rich Is Grand; Getting Old Is Getting Old
description: GONE are the days when Hope Gimbel Solinger rode to the hounds. She is 87, the circulation in her legs so bad that it hurts her to put on her socks -- wait, here among the Picassos and Giacomettis and the Lger in her Upper East Side apartment, she'll pull down a sock to show you the rough skin and discoloration.

title: Retirees' Health Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: Europe Lists U.S. Products It Intends To Sanction
description: The European Commission told the World Trade Organization today which American products it intends to single out for sanctions in retaliation for the protective steel tariffs of up to 30 percent that the Bush administration imposed on imported steel in March.

title: THE CHEF
description: I AM not a chocolate lover, and carefully executed fancy individual desserts are not for me. Give me a big piece of homey cake, something like pound cake, and I'm happy.

title: High Pitch To Jeter Stirs Yanks
description: A wild outing by Tampa Bay reliever Jesus Colome resulted in both benches and bullpens emptying during the Yankees' six-run eighth inning last night in their 10-3 victory over the Devil Rays at Yankee Stadium.

title: Excerpts From Ruling on Admissions
description: Following are excerpts from the 5-to-4 ruling yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit in a case involving the admissions policy for the University of Michigan Law School. Boyce F. Martin Jr., the chief circuit judge, wrote the majority opinion; Judge Danny J. Boggs wrote the dissent. A complete version is available at The New York Times on the Web: nytimes.com.

title: Evidence in Skakel Trial Shows Ex-Tutor Denied Killing in 1992
description: In a conversation secretly recorded by investigators in 1992, Kenneth W. Littleton, a longtime suspect in the 1975 killing of Martha Moxley, emphatically denied to his ex-wife that he had committed the crime, even as she repeatedly sought to convince him that he had confessed to her during psychotic episodes in the 1980's and 90's.

title: A Century's Worth of Life in Limerick
description: Characters and incident abound in ''Pigtown.'' What is lacking in this impressionistic tour of Limerick, Ireland, in the 20th century is consistent life.

title: Toronto Is Rough and Ready for Next Round
description: The Toronto Maple Leafs are not a pretty team, but they are a gritty team. They have been battered by injuries and they have inflicted a few on their opponents, too. They do not always abide by the rules, yet they complain to the referees more than most teams.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Segregating Asylum Seekers
description: In its latest effort to deal with the growing numbers of migrants in urban areas, the government announced plans to build three centers to house new arrivals whose asylum applications are being processed. The centers, each to hold about 750 people, would be built in Worcestershire, Nottinghamshire and Oxfordshire, and would have on-site services like schools. Community groups oppose the plans, as do advocacy groups, which warn that they will create even more tension between Britons and asylum seekers. Almost 72,000 people applied for asylum in Britain last year. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, ALICE
description: MARCUS-Alice, 87. Formerly of New York City, died on Sunday, May 12. Her husband Abraham Marcus preceded her in death. She is survived by her son Robert & wife Glynda, four grandchildren and one great grandchild. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the San Antonio Jewish Community Center, 12500 N.W. Military Highway, Suite 275, San Antonio, Texas 78231.

title: For Those With the Craving, a Most Chocolaty Spot
description: Spicy brownies, fat cookies, chocolate clusters with either peanut butter or strawberry shortcake centers, dessert sauces, truffle lollipops, chocolate bars and assorted truffles fill the shelves at the bright new Chocolate Bar, 48 Eighth Avenue (Jane Street). The owners, Alison Nelson and Matt Lewis, below, carry only the work of New York bakers and chocolatiers, including Jacques Torres, Garrison Confections, Sweet Bliss and Lunchbox. The shop also sells coffee (48 cents a cup this month), iced chocolate drinks and chocolate-flavored teas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAYLE, PHYLLIS JOAN
description: CAYLE-Phyllis Joan. 1927-2002. Loving mother of Tracy Romano and husband James and Dr. Jonathan Cayle (Capt. U.S.N.) and wife Monique. Grandmother of Lindsay and Jessica Romano. Service Wednesday, 10:30 AM, at I.J. Morris Funeral Home, 516486-2500. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to AABR, 718321-3800.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: REBELS BLAMED FOR BOMBINGS The chief prosecutor's office said an inquiry had found "definitive proof" that separatists from Chechnya, not Kremlin intelligence agents, masterminded apartment-house bombings in 1999 that killed more than 300 Russians and led to full-scale war in Chechnya. The Interfax news service said the deputy general prosecutor, Valery Kalmogorov, also upheld the domestic intelligence agency's assertion that so-called bombs the agency admitted placing in a building in Ryazan were in fact sacks of sugar, part of a training exercise. Kremlin opponents, led by the London-based Russian financier Boris Berezovsky, say the bombings were a government plot.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Insurer Names Executive
description: Zurich Financial Services named a new chief executive, James Schiro, left, ending the era of his predecessor, Rolf Hppi. Mr. Schiro, formerly the chief executive of PricewaterhouseCoopers, joined the company two months ago in charge of group finances. He must address the insurer's sagging earnings, after a decade of expansion. Mr. Hppi lost investor confidence with overly optimistic earnings forecasts. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAAS, MICHAEL
description: MAAS-Michael. Of Westhampton Beach, NY. On May 12, 2002 at the age of 70. Beloved husband of Jane Maas, loving father of Katherine and Jennifer Maas, adoring grandfather of Jenna Maas. Brother of the late Peter. A Fellow of the American Institute of Architects and a member of its national Board of Directors, he was former managing partner of HLW International. He graduated from Renssalaer Polytechnic Institute in 1954 and served for three years in the United States Marine Corps. Among the many projects whose design teams he led were the world headquarters for Chemical Bank, corporate headquarters for the U.S. Trust Company, and buildings for Travelers, Jaguar, the U.S. Army War College and the School of Public Health at Harvard University. He served as president of the Fifth Avenue Association, received the Silver Beaver Award from the Boy Scouts and an honorary Doctor of Laws degree from St. John's University. Funeral mass on Friday, May 17 at 10:30 A.M. at St. Thomas More, 65 East 89th Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Architectural Foundation, 1735 New York Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20006.

title: Technology Briefing
description: SOFTWARE

title: Debt Limit Must Be Raised, Administration Tells Congress
description: The Bush administration warned Congress today that it was running out of time to raise the legal limit on the national debt, saying the Treasury Department would have to begin using financial gimmicks in the next few days to keep the government solvent.

title: Shea Needs $11 Million in Repairs, Engineering Report Says
description: Shea Stadium, the aging home of the Mets, requires at least $11 million in structural, electrical, mechanical and plumbing repairs, according to a city engineering report.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SATT, JACK
description: SATT-Jack. Congregation Kneseth Israel, Far Rockaway, NY, mourns the passing of our esteemed member and extends condolences to the entire family. Tzvi Flaum, Rabbi Ralph Pelcovitz, Rabbi Emeritus Jeffrey Sinensky, President
