description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERT, IRVING
description: ALBERT-Irving, 80. Died suddenly on May 13, 2002 at home. Born in Poland, came to the United States in 1938. An honored union organizer and committed leftist. He served in the U.S. Armed Forces in the invasion of North Africa, landed in Anzio and marched to Rome. Supported many Jewish causes. And was an Alaskan entrepreneur. Husband of Alicia and the late Dorothy, father of Marc and David, father-in-law of Orna, adoring grandfather of Ben, and relentless competitor at pinochle. Service Sunday, May 19, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The family will at home this week.

title: Circuit City Changes Finance Disclosure
description: The Circuit City Group said today that it would begin disclosing profit related to the finance operations of its electronics chain Circuit City and its CarMax Group in quarterly and annual statements.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: 'Religious Terrorist' Killed
description: The police killed one of the country's most wanted men, accused of complicity in the killing of more than 100 Shiite Muslims, during a gunfight in the remote eastern town of Multan, police officials said. They said the man, Riaz Basra, was killed with three associates after attacking a Shiite Muslim cleric's house. They called Mr. Basra, the leader of an outlawed Sunni Muslim group, a religious terrorist and one of the worst killers in the violence between Sunnis and Shiites. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAREY, EDWARD M.
description: CAREY-Edward M. To the eldest of our generation, you showed us determination, style, perserverance and wit. Thank you for all you have done. Love, your brother, Governor Hugh L. Carey

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: 4 Charged With Defrauding Banks of Over $600 Million

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARFUNKEL, DORIS (NEE BROOKS)
description: GARFUNKEL - Doris (nee Brooks). On May 14, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Milton. Devoted mother of Steven, his wife Marilyn & Bruce & his wife Jeannie. Cherished grandmother of Meredith, Allison, Adam and Hana. Adored sister of Juliet Warshauer. Loving aunt of Nancy Mendel and Robert Warshauer. Fond great aunt of Erica, David, Lauren and Melissa. In lieu of flowers donations can be made in her name to City Meals on Wheels, 355 Lexington Avenue, New York, New York 10017. Private graveside services. She will remain in our hearts forever.

title: White House On Autocrats: Malaysian S, Cuban No
description: President Bush today continued the rehabilitation of Asia's longest-serving leader, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia, welcoming him to the Oval Office and calling him an ally in the war on terror. At the same time, Mr. Bush toned down Washington's long-running complaints about Dr. Mahathir's sometimes brutal suppression of dissent.

title: U.P.S. Strike Vote Is Set
description: United Parcel Service workers represented by the Teamsters will vote this weekend on giving their leaders authority to call a strike if necessary, as the union tries to speed up contract talks.

title: Corrections
description: A brief sports report yesterday about an information booklet produced by MasterCard for people traveling to the World Cup soccer tournament misstated the telephone number for requests. It is (800) 229-4758.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOOSLI, DEMETRIA
description: LOOSLI-Demetria. Mrs. Demetria Loosli of Plainfield, New Jersey passed away peacefully in her sleep at the age of 86 on Sunday, May 12, 2002. She was the widow of the late Mr. Alden Loosli and is survived by two daughters, Louise Petz of New York City and Lisle Bradley of Boulder, CO, two sons, Ben of Chambersburg, PA., and Richard of Plainfield, eight grandchildren and one great grandchild. Services will be held at 10:00 A.M. on Wednesday, May 15, 2002 at Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church, 716 Watchung Avenue, Plainfield, New Jersey. Callers will be received from 7 to 9 P.M., on Tuesday, May 14, 2002 at Higgins Funeral Home, 209 West 8th Street, Plainfield, N.J. 07060. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Mrs. Loosli's memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: INSIDE
description: Affirmative Action Upheld

title: TWO COMPANIES DECIDE TO REINCORPORATE IN BERMUDA
description: Shareholders of two companies, a financial services holding company and a hardware manufacturer, have approved measures to reincorporate in Bermuda. The two companies are the Leucadia National Corporation of New York, a holding company with units in life insurance, banking and lending, and Cooper Industries of Houston, which makes Crescent wrenches, among other tools and electrical products. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Leucadia said it has no immediate plans to complete the move to Bermuda because such a transaction would be treated as a sale of assets and the company would incur a tax liability of about $315 million. Cooper industries expects to follow up and reincorporate in Bermuda by May 21. The company said its worldwide tax rate there should decline from 32 percent of profits to as low as 20 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ELI
description: COHEN-Eli. On May 14, 2002, of Manhasset, LI. Beloved husband of Marilyn. Devoted father of Lorrie and Michael Cohen and Jill and Eddie Lumish. Brother of Jack Kogen. Loving grandfather of Daryn, Jamie, Josh, Perri, Jordan and Dean. Services Thursday, 12 Noon, at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: Law Requires Tracking Beer Kegs
description: Legislators have approved a new law requiring retailers to track sales of beer kegs using tags that identify the buyers. Sponsors of the law, which takes effect next year, said it would help cut under-age drinking; if kegs turn up at parties frequented by minors, the police can find out who supplied them. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORSACK, LESLEY MARIE (NEE SCHULTHEIS)
description: BORSACK-Lesley Marie (nee Schultheis) of Montague, NJ and Manhasset, LI was tragically taken from us on May 8, 2002 at the young age of 44 in the prime of her life. Loving and adored wife of Ronald Borsack. Beloved, adored and devoted mother of her two sunshine's Zachary and Valyrea. Loving daughter of Anne Schultheis and cherished sister of George, Hilary, Jennifer and John. Leslie Marie is now with her beloved father Daniel who passed away May 16, 2000. She will be greatly, sadly and deeply missed by all who knew her and the many lives she touched with love.

title: Cooking Like a 3-Star Chef In Your Own Home (Almost)
description: IT looks pretty straightforward, and for Harold Moore, the 29-year-old chef at Montrachet in TriBeCa, it is. Take a dry-aged sirloin and saut it. Serve the meat on a bed of shallots in a red wine reduction sauce, with sauted chanterelle mushrooms, a few haricots verts and some carrots.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Bush Signs Border-Security Measure
description: President Bush signed legislation to improve border security and to toughen enforcement of immigration laws. The legislation provides for more immigration investigators, directs colleges and universities to use the Internet to track foreign students and requires foreign visitors to carry visas that include biometric identifiers like fingerprints. Carla Baranauckas (NYT)

title: Residents Are on Edge for Mayoral Election, but They Resist Going Over It
description: NEWARK, May 14  There were a few isolated shenanigans, officials said  police officers telling people how to vote, offers of post-voting snacks supplied by a candidate  and plenty of partisan name-calling. But by and large, the fears of widespread misconduct that drew federal monitors to oversee the re-election of Mayor Sharpe James today were not borne out.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Columbus Circle Sushi

title: A Yankee's Superheroes
description: Wherever Enrique Wilson goes, the Protector of the Earth watches over him. At Yankee Stadium, he is there. At Tropicana Field or the Metrodome, he is there.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Idaho: Revisiting Term Limits
description: Three months after the Legislature repealed a law setting term limits for state and local officials, a group has collected enough signatures to put the issue on the ballot a second time. In 1994, voters approved the first measure, but lawmakers invalidated it in February, saying it drove out experienced officials. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Dollar Mare, Dream Colt
description: War Emblem and Magic Weisner are both running Saturday in the Preakness Stakes, the middle jewel of the Triple Crown, which is where the similarities start and end. War Emblem's Kentucky Derby victory proved that the money of a Saudi prince and the might of one of the nation's most successful stables can be a tough combination to beat.

title: On Eve of Vote, Dutch Weigh Impact of the Assassination
description: Murder has not been a feature of the tranquil political stage of the Netherlands since World War II, and as the country prepares to vote Wednesday in national elections, it appears gripped by doubts over how to cope with the shooting of the campaign's most famous candidate.

title: KEY ENERGY SERVICES TO BUY RIVAL FOR $185 MILLION
description: Key Energy Services Inc., the oil well-service company, agreed to buy a closely held rival, Q Services Inc. of Houston, for $185 million in stock to expand in the Gulf Coast. Key Energy will also assume $80 million in debt. Key Energy, based in Houston, expects to save $10 million a year with the transaction. It will raise the number of its oilfield-service vehicles by a quarter to 2,050.

title: Modesto Journal; Verily, but a Bit Tardily, the Auto Junkman Cometh
description: For those who like their classic cars shiny and their rock 'n' roll snappy, Modesto conjures up images of dudes cruising the streets and chasing girls on steamy summer nights, a world lovingly brought to the screen by George Lucas, a native son, in ''American Graffiti.''

title: CARTER ADDRESSES THE CUBAN NATION AND URGES REFORM
description: Former President Jimmy Carter, in an address to the Cuban people broadcast live on television across the nation, called on President Fidel Castro tonight to allow a referendum to bring broad reforms in political rights and castigated the socialist system for denying basic freedoms.

title: CLINTON HIGH WINS ANOTHER TITLE
description: DeWitt Clinton High School, led by double winner Ramon Guzman, captured its 14th straight Bronx Public Schools Athletic League boys outdoor championship yesterday on its home field. The Governors had 204 points to 83 for Truman and 73 for Evander Childs.

title: Bail Is Denied for Sect Leader Accused of Molesting Children
description: The leader of a black religious sect based in an isolated rural Georgia compound was denied bail today after federal prosecutors said he had molested dozens of children in the last decade.

title: Ramapo College Gets Interim Provost
description: EDWARD CODY, a professor of history and American studies at Ramapo College in Mahwah, N.J., will become the college's interim provost and vice president for academic affairs on Aug. 1. Dr. Cody, who has been an associate dean at the college and drafted the school's mission statement, has been a member of Ramapo's faculty since 1971. Stephanie Rosenbloom

title: Sports of The Times; The Picture Worth Lewis's Words
description: UNTIL the bell rings on June 8 in Memphis, the hype for the big fight is really just a talk show bouncing back and forth across the 5,000 miles from where Lennox Lewis is preening here in the Poconos to where Mike Tyson is prowling in Hawaii. But now there's a picture worth all of Lewis's words, allegedly a picture of the leg bite that altered the heavyweight champion's view of Tyson.

title: Survivors' Call for Help Is Heard In Killings Over Carnegie Deli
description: The voice on the recording sounding shaky, frightened and desperate: ''A bunch of us have been shot!'' a man screamed. ''I'm bleeding out of the side of my head and I'm losing a lot of blood. Please, God!'' he cried, later adding: ''They came in, they broke in and they had guns.''

title: Hot housing markets show signs of overheating
description: LONDON:  The housing market has heated up to such a fevered state here that home-hunters are resorting to unorthodox approaches. A few weeks ago, one of them wrote a letter to every resident of Inglebert Street, a modest stretch of row houses in the Clerkenwell neighborhood where two-bedroom apartments can fetch more than 300,000 ($440,000).

title: Contemporary-Art Auction Sets Records for 15 Artists
description: ''Who wants to die with money in the stock market when you can have Rothkos on your walls?'' a collector asked as he was leaving Christie's sale of postwar and contemporary art last night.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Apple To Offer Server Computer
description: The Apple Computer chairman, Steven P. Jobs, said the company would re-enter the corporate computing market next month with a pizza-box-size machine designed for data centers. Apple is trying to capitalize on the popularity of its Macintosh OS X Unix operating system, which Mr. Jobs developed at Next Computer and then sold to Apple in 1996. The new rack-mounted Xserve computer will be priced at $2,999 to $6,500 and will come with as much as 480 gigabytes of storage and a high-speed network connection. Such computers have become a standard in corporate computing centers for applications that range from file storage and printer management to Web servers as well as database and scientific computing. Mr. Jobs said Apple's strategy in entering an intensely competitive computing market dominated by giant, well-established companies would be to focus initially on the company's strongest markets: education, creative services, biotechnology and video. John Markoff (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: SHARES IN BROADCASTER ARE SOLD Deutsche Bank said it was offering to sell 250 million shares in the pay-TV broadcaster British Sky Broadcasting , part of the 22 percent in BskyB held by the troubled French media giant Vivendi Universal . Vivendi deposited the shares with Deutsche Bank late last year along with 150 million others that make up its stake. Vivendi's move was seen as an effort to placate credit agencies worried about its $15.4 billion debt. The sale, worth $2.4 billion, pushed Vivendi's shares up by over 5 percent after months of declines. BskyB shares first fell then rose by about 1 percent. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Mayor Sees Bigger Public-Private Partnerships
description: In a sharp departure from the policies of his predecessor, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced several initiatives yesterday that are intended to encourage business improvement districts to play a bigger role in the city's economic growth.

title: Blatter Denies All Charges Coming From Within FIFA
description: With the start of the World Cup a little more than two weeks away, the president of FIFA, soccer's world governing body, today denied charges from within his own organization that he was a strongman and a crook.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NELSON, DORIS SIEGEL
description: NELSON-Doris Siegel. In loving memory of our dearest mother, grandmother and mother-in-law who remains always in our thoughts. Elizabeth, Margery, Jonathan, Karen, Amy, Andrea, Meredith, Laurie, Bil

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Isuzu Raises Loss Forecast
description: The automaker Isuzu Motors has raised its forecast for an expected loss in the fiscal year that ended March 31 as truck sales slumped. Isuzu, which is 49 percent owned by General Motors, expects to lose 43 billion yen ($335 million) even though it benefited from cost cutting and a weaker yen. The company raised the figure from a loss of 25 billion yen that it forecast in November. Isuzu cut its debt by 30 percent but still has 740 billion yen ($5.8 billion) in obligations, an amount analysts say is too high, given its sales. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: 96-Year-Old Synagogue Is Gutted in Fire in Queens
description: A 96-year-old seaside synagogue that stood as a faded reminder of the heyday of the Rockaways as a summer resort was gutted by fire yesterday, less than a decade after it had survived two arson attempts.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Dead Singer's Parents File Suit
description: The parents of the singer Aaliyah have filed a lawsuit charging Virgin Records, several production companies and Blackhawk International Airways with negligence in connection with the plane crash in the Bahamas that killed her and eight members of her entourage last August. The suit, filed in Los Angeles Superior Court, contends the companies knew that the pilot was inexperienced and that the 10-seat Cessna 402-B was overloaded and incapable of safe flight. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: SBC To Cut 5,000 Jobs
description: The big local telephone company SBC Communications Inc. will eliminate 5,000 jobs, or 2.6 percent of its work force, this quarter. Jobs will be cut in 13 states and include management and nonmanagement employees who do not directly serve customers, SBC said. The company pared 4,000 jobs in the first quarter and said last month that it would cut 4,000 more this year.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: School Cleaner Accused Of Abuse
description: A man who worked as a custodial cleaner at a Brooklyn middle school has been arrested and charged with sexually abusing a 10-year-old girl while she was in a gym class earlier this month, the police said. The custodian, Angel Rodriguez, 34, of Brooklyn, is accused of attacking the girl at 2:30 p.m. on May 6 at Public School 198, on Farragut Road in the East Flatbush neighborhood. He was charged on Monday with one count of first-degree sexual abuse, the police said. The girl first reported the incident to school authorities on Monday, and they called the police. Mr. Rodriguez, who has worked at the school as a helper to its custodian for the last 10 years, has been suspended without pay, said Margie Feinberg, a spokeswoman for Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy. Al Baker (NYT)

title: CALENDER
description: Korean Festival at the U.N.

title: Trading Dispute Is Shrouded in Accusations of Bias
description: Youssef Fakih attached a tape recorder to the telephone and pressed the record button before dialing his stockbroker.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Fuel-Cell Research Pact
description: Honda Motor and Plug Power, a fuel-cell maker in Latham, N.Y., said they would study the possibility of developing dual-purpose Plug Power fuel cells that could provide household heat and power while producing the hydrogen needed to replenish fuel cells in hydrogen-powered cars Honda hopes to market later this decade. The fuel cells would consume natural gas, which is already readily available to many homeowners. The research agreement points to one of the auto industry's many efforts to develop the hydrogen-distribution infrastructure needed to migrate from gasoline-powered vehicles to designs based on fuel cells, which could be more efficient and environmentally benign. Plug Power shares rose 5.8 percent, to $10.63. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Cyprus: Annan Pushes Reunification
description: Kofi Annan, the first United Nations secretary general to visit Cyprus in 23 years, tried to jump-start flagging reunification talks between the rival Greek and Turkish communities. Cyprus has been divided since a Turkish invasion in 1974, with the internationally recognized Greek Cypriot government controlling about two-thirds of it. The prospect of European Union membership has prompted fresh efforts for a solution. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T Sets Separate Votes On Cable Deal
description: AT&T said its shareholders would vote separately on the sale of its broadband unit to Comcast and the proposed management structure for the company that will be created by the merger, which has been tentatively set by the AT&T board and Comcast officials. For the agreement to be completed, AT&T officials said, shareholders must approve both measures at the company's annual meeting in Charleston, S.C. in July. The combined company, to be called the AT&T Comcast Corporation, will be the nation's largest cable television company. Shareholders of Comcast, based in Philadelphia, are scheduled to vote on the $72 billion deal in June. AT&T officials said allowing shareholders to vote on both matters will expedite the process. The agreement requires antitrust clearance from the Justice Department and the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Fox Official Derides Huge Rights Fees
description: Peter Chernin, the president of News Corp., the parent company of Fox Sports, said yesterday that the rationale no longer exists for the company to pay huge rights fees in the future to the National Football League.

title: Applications for Urban Teaching Jobs Rise
description: Teach for America, the nonprofit group that places new college graduates in urban schools after a summer of training, received 14,000 applications this year -- nearly three times the number it received last year. Interest was especially high at Yale, where 7 percent of the senior class applied to participate in the two-year program, and at Spelman College in Atlanta, where 14 percent of seniors applied. Ninety-four Yale seniors applied, 44 have been accepted so far and 27 have made commitments to the program. At Spelman, 64 seniors applied, 23 have been accepted and 21 have signed on. Abby Goodnough

title: Finding New Lives in a Writer's Death
description: THE CITY OF YOUR FINAL DESTINATION

title: Dear I.R.S.: Forward to Bermuda
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Flextronics To Make Casio Products
description: Flextronics International, the No. 2 contract manufacturer of electronic components, and Casio Computer announced a three-year, $1.5 billion manufacturing agreement. The deal, which calls for Flextronics to make a variety of Casio products, includes the purchase of a Casio factory in Malaysia and extensive use of another in Japan. Casio, perhaps best known for its digital watches and calculators, will hand over production at the two plants by the end of July. Flextronics, which makes electronic components for companies like Xerox and Microsoft, will use the Japanese factory as its center for repair, logistics and distribution services. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: U.N. Broadens List of Products Iraq Can Import
description: The Security Council unanimously approved a resolution today overhauling its economic sanctions against Iraq, with the goal of dampening their impact on civilians while keeping pressure on Saddam Hussein.

title: MTV PRESIDENT BRIAN GRADEN IS PICKED TO HEAD VH1
description: Brian Graden, president of entertainment for MTV, has added the same duties at sister cable network VH1, parent company Viacom announced yesterday. The move was expected, as former MTV chief Judy McGrath had been named to run all the MTV-related music networks. Executives are hoping Mr. Graden can bring to VH1 some of the success MTV has had, most notably with ''The Osbournes.'' Mr. Graden succeeds Fred Graver, who will become an independent producer and is expected to contribute projects to VH1. Jim Rutenberg (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'KEEFFE, ESTHER BURGER
description: O'KEEFFE-Esther Burger. Palm Beach philanthropist has died from complications following a stroke. A longtime Palm Beach resident, Mrs. O'Keeffe was born in St. Joseph, Missouri. She attended Washington University in St. Louis and the Kansas City Art Institute, where she studied portrait painting under the instruction of Thomas Hart Benton. Excelling as a portrait artist, Mrs. O'Keeffe worked extensively in Kansas City, Los Angeles and New York City. Mrs. O'Keeffe made many philantropic gifts locally including gifts to St. Mary's Hospital, Good Samaritan Hospital, The Norton Museum of Art, The Society of the Four Arts and the American Heart Association. Mrs. O'Keeffe has also made philanthropic gifts to the Massachusetts General Hospital and the Cape Cod Hospital in Massachusetts, and she is a Founding Donor of the Georgia O'Keeffe Museum in Santa Fe, New Mexico. Mrs. O'Keeffe was a member of the Bath and Tennis Club, the Everglades Club and the Beach Club in Palm Beach, the Kansas City Country Club (MO), the Metropolitan Club and the River Club (NYC), Bloomingrove Hunting and Fishing Club (PA), the Wianno Club (MA), and the Eldorado Club (CA). She is survived by her husband Dr. Arthur O'Keeffe and four children, Arthur, Brian, Clare and Daniel. Private family services have been held. Memorial donations may be made to the Noreen McKeen Residence.

title: Union Asks Better Cleaning of Fire Trucks
description: Officials of the union that represents New York City firefighters said yesterday that the Fire Department has done an inadequate job of cleaning trucks that might have been exposed to toxic substances when the World Trade Center collapsed.

title: 3 High Schools For Students Who Excel
description: The Board of Education will open three selective high schools in September on campuses of the City University of New York, expanding the slots for strong students who do not make it into the Bronx High School of Science or the other two competitive science schools.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOHN, EDWARD
description: SOHN-Edward. Beth El Synagogue of New Rochelle mourns the passing of our Honorary Trustee and expresses heartfelt condolences to the family. Melvin N. Sirner, Rabbi Bertram S. Schwarz, President

title: Edison Schools In Settlement With S.E.C.
description: Edison Schools, the nation's largest commercial operator of public schools and a pioneer in the field of for-profit school management, provided inaccurate information about its past revenue and maintained inadequate financial controls, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday.

title: A New Firehouse in Queens Would Include Paramedics
description: New York City has embarked on a plan to change the traditions of its firehouses into something similar to the model used in other cities, where firefighters and paramedics share quarters.

title: You Never Forget Your First Computer
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Afghan Army Takes Shape, With G.I.'s as Trainers
description: American Green Berets today began training the first soldiers of a new Afghan national army -- the approach to policing Afghanistan that the Bush administration prefers to beefing up the international security forces.

title: One City, One Book, Zero Chance
description: FOR a city that fancies itself the capital of the world -- king of the hill, top of the heap, A-No. 1 and all that -- New York can be disappointingly unoriginal. Think of school vouchers, welfare revision and mayoral control over education, to name but a few issues. With each, the debate is basically whether to imitate innovations begun or embellished elsewhere.

title: Former Nassau Official Charged In Illegal Tax Reductions Case
description: A former Nassau County official was charged today with granting illegal property tax reductions to friends, political associates and business clients, defrauding the county and some school districts out of about $19,000, the authorities said.

title: Faster Charity
description: The burgeoning federal deficit, coupled with new spending for defense and homeland security, will soon put health care, education and other social programs in a serious squeeze. Yet this crunch can be eased if America's richest nonprofit groups distributed more of their money now instead of saving for the future. They could provide America with some $20 billion more a year to spend on urgent social needs.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Cuts Xbox Price
description: Escalating the hard-nosed price war in the video game industry, Microsoft is to announce today that it will cut the price of its Xbox console in North America by a third, to $199 from $299. It already costs Microsoft more than $299 to make each Xbox. Yesterday, Microsoft's rival console maker, Sony, cut the price of its PlayStation 2 by $100, to $199. Sony says it expects the PlayStation 2, which has been on the market a year longer than the Xbox and shipped about 10 times as many units, to soon be profitable at the new price. Microsoft had planned to announce a price cut next week at the Electronic Entertainment Expo, an annual industry trade show in Los Angeles, but acted instead after Sony's announcement. A third maker of video game consoles, Nintendo, said yesterday that it had no plans to lower the North American price of its $199 GameCube system. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFF, JOEL
description: LEFF-Joel. With deep sorrow and affection, we mourn the passing of our dear friend and co-founder. Joel brought remarkable wisdom, energy and good humor to everything and everyone he touched. He will always be remembered. We extend our sincere condolences and sympathy to his family and friends. Forstmann-Leff Associates, LLC

title: Bloomberg and Silver Differ Over Control of the Schools
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's attempt to win control of the New York City school system suffered a setback yesterday when he and Sheldon Silver, the speaker of the State Assembly, squabbled over the terms of an agreement, officials with knowledge of their conversation said.

title: Hewlett-Packard's Profit Rises Despite Weak Sales
description: Hewlett-Packard yesterday reported higher profits in its second quarter despite weak revenues amid sluggish corporate spending on computer technology. And the company delivered a sober outlook for the remainder of the year, saying it was ''not counting on a meaningful improvement'' in technology spending until 2003.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Nebraska: Judge Orders River Water  Released
description: In the latest round of a regional wrestling match over the Missouri River, Judge Laurie Smith Camp of Federal District Court in Omaha has ordered the Army Corps of Engineers to release water to float barges in the lower river. Northern states along the river want to keep water in reservoirs for recreation. States farther south insist they are entitled to a guaranteed flow for navigation and industry. Blaine Harden (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Utility Chief Is Selected
description: Italy's state-controlled electric power utility Enel removed Franco Tato as chief executive and name Paolo Scaroni, chief executive of the glass maker Pilkington of Britain, to succeed him. Mr. Scaroni, 55, is credited with doubling profit margins in five years at Pilkington but has no experience in the power business. Enel's stock has lost more than 20 percent of its value since it was first sold more than two years ago. Enel shares rose 2.3 percent, and Pilkington stock slid 5.5 percent. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Joseph L. Steiner, 95, a Founder Of a Well-Known Toy Maker
description: Joseph Lowenbach Steiner, a co-founder of the company that made toys like the Bubble Rocket and the Easy-Bake Oven, died on Saturday at a hospital in a suburb of Cincinnati. He was 95.

title: UBS Quarterly Income Falls, But Results Beat Expectations
description: The Swiss banking giant UBS announced better-than-expected first-quarter results today and said it would reshuffle its executive ranks to shore up its growth in the United States.

title: Admiring Portrait Of a Famous Temptation
description: The ice cream sundae was invented in Ithaca, N.Y., in 1892, said Michael Turback, the sundae historian who wrote ''A Month of Sundaes'' (Red Rock Press, $19.95). Mr. Turback, a former Ithaca restaurateur, weaves together sundae history, regional styles, folklore and trivia. The new book includes a seven-page chart that gives formulas for 25 sundaes and lists their place of origin. Recipes range from a simple Philadelphia vanilla ice cream (eggless, unlike the French variety) to a baroque hot fudge, ice cream and cinnamon-raisin bagel concoction.

title: Turmoil at Napster Moves the Service Closer to the Day The Music Dies
description: The chief executive of Napster, its founder and several of its top executives resigned today, a move that may foreshadow the imminent bankruptcy of a service that became synonymous with the free exchange of music online.

title: Aide Defends Egan's Action In Priest Case
description: The Archdiocese of New York issued a detailed defense yesterday of Cardinal Edward M. Egan's actions regarding a priest in Connecticut who had been accused of sexually abusing minors in the 1960's.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: James Wins 5th Term in Newark as Challenger Is Rebuffed
description: Sharpe James became the first mayor in Newark's history to win a fifth term tonight, staving off a fierce challenge from Councilman Cory Booker and cementing his reputation as one of New Jersey's most formidable politicians.

title: Nine Are Indicted in Investment Fraud Case
description: Federal prosecutors turned the tables yesterday on two men who blew the whistle when $100 million vanished from a foreign currency trading firm after the World Trade Center collapsed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, PAUL
description: SINGER-Paul. On May 12, 2002. Beloved brother of Eric. Loving father of Lily. You were just the best. Memorial service Sunday May 19 at 11 A.M. at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINGSLEY, ORA R.
description: KINGSLEY-Ora R. The Department of Otolaryngology/Head & Neck Surgery of Columbia University notes with sorrow the loss of our friend and benefactor, Ora Kingsley. We extend condolences to her daughter and son-in-law, Dr. Ora Smith and Dr. Howard Smith and their family.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Boy Dies Of Head Injuries
description: A 3-year-old boy died yesterday of injuries that were reported to the police on Saturday, and his mother's boyfriend has been charged in the case. The boy, Anthony Rivera of Maple Street in Wingate, was taken to Kings County Hospital Center in critical condition late Saturday night, having suffered serious head trauma, the police said. He died just before 5:30 p.m. yesterday. The mother's boyfriend, Jean Henry, 21, told the police that he had found the boy unconscious at home. Mr. Henry, of 183 Street in Queens, was arrested Saturday. He is expected to be charged with murder today, a spokesman for the Brookyn district attorney's office said. The police did not know where the mother was at the time the boy was injured. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: U.S. Expects Russian Help To Stem Nuclear Weapons
description: The United States expects Russia to join it in a high-priority effort to control the spread of weapons of mass destruction, now that deep cuts in their own nuclear arsenals are assured, a senior Bush administration official said here today.

title: EnCana Cites 'Round-Trip' Trades by Unit
description: EnCana, Canada's biggest natural-gas producer, said today that 8 percent of the gas trades conducted by a Houston subsidiary last year were made at no profit with Reliant Resources to increase volumes.

title: Warehouse Vacancy Rates Are Up as Rents Fall
description: Out on the western edge of St. Cloud, Minn., there is a 1.1 million-square-foot box, put there in part because the city is not much farther from any one big coastal American city than from any other. It was built for the single purpose of gathering baseball bats and sofas and coffee makers and all manner of goods together in one place, where they could be packaged into made-to-order bundles and sent out to the homes of customers.

title: James McFarland, 90, Executive Who Diversified General Mills
description: James P. McFarland, who led General Mills through a period of robust growth before retiring in 1977, died on Friday at his home in Wayzata, Minn., a suburb of Minneapolis. He was 90.

title: New crop of young filmmakers makes a splash in U.S. : French take cue from Hollywood
description: LOS ANGELES  The first time the French director Laurent Cantet brought a film, "Human Resources" (Ressources humaines), to the United States two years ago, he won a handful of reviews  belated, if mostly positive, notices for his drama about unemployment.

title: Picking the Best Student Body
description: Americans who cherish the nation's diversity have been alarmed in recent years by efforts to restrict the consideration of race in public university admissions policies. Conflicting decisions by various federal courts will eventually force the Supreme Court to clarify this issue. But for the time being, at least, a new ruling by the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals has shown that carefully tailored policies that avoid quotas can still include race as one factor among many in the admissions equation.

title: ABC is returning to its roots to reverse a ratings decline.
description: THE ABC network, which had a precipitous decline in its prime-time ratings this season, will try to start the long climb back by returning to its roots this fall as a family-oriented network.

title: It's Time For Thai
description: Of the flavors most closely associated with Thai cooking, several stand out: nam pla, the salty, fermented fish sauce; coconut milk; lime and sugar, which provide the sour-and-sweet essential to the cuisine; and chili. Combine these ingredients with meat, fish or poultry, and you will have a dish that is recognizably Thai.

title: Man Is Held in Shooting of Priest He Accused of Abuse
description: A suspended Roman Catholic priest was shot and seriously wounded outside his home here by a man who told the police he had been sexually abused by the priest nine years ago, the authorities reported today.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: BCE Executive Is Named
description: BCE Emergis, 65 percent owned by communications group BCE Inc. of Montreal, has named Pierre Blouin as chief executive, succeeding Brian Edwards. The move comes less than a month after Michael Sabia took over as BCE's chief executive. First-quarter revenues and earnings at BCE Emergis, which provides e-commerce services to the health-care and financial services sectors, were well below market expectations, and the stock has lost more than three-quarters of its value since January. The company announced a 20 percent cut in its work force last month. But Mr. Sabia described BCE Emergis as an important company for BCE. Mr. Blouin was previously chief executive of Bell Mobility, BCE's mobile communications unit. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: They Do a Whole Lot More Than Croak on Lily Pads
description: The pale green and yellow frogs are back, squatting unblinking on the stage before beginning to hop and jump. So are the huge alligators with their red eyes that glow fiercely in the dark, along with the cat in the enormous paper bag and the phosphorescent strings. The penguins have returned, too, to play their not entirely sporting but nevertheless funny game of musical chairs.

title: Shares Rally After Unexpectedly Healthy Retail Sales
description: Stock prices rallied for a second consecutive session yesterday, pushed higher by a retail sales report that was stronger than expected, bullish comments on Intel and healthy first-quarter earnings gains at Wal-Mart Stores and J. C. Penney.

title: Computer Associates Says U.S. Is Seeking Data on Accounting
description: Computer Associates said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had issued formal demands for information to third parties as part of a civil and criminal investigation into the company's accounting practices.

title: Four Men Are Charged With $600 Million Bank Fraud Linked to Metal Trading
description: Four New Jersey men were charged yesterday with defrauding banks of more than $600 million through an international scheme to secure loans for illusory metal-trading deals, federal authorities said.

title: New York's Best Espresso?
description: I AM not a fanatic about espresso. To begin with, I drink more tea than coffee, and at the end of a meal I almost always order a plain American-style coffee. Still, about once a week the urge for an espresso made the Italian way hits hard. Like a vague tingling in the sinuses that develops into a 90-megaton sneeze, this little hankering cannot be ignored. It's a want that becomes a need. And there's the problem. It is almost impossible to get a decent cup of espresso in New York.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: NTT Posts Record Loss
description: The telecommunications company, Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, posted a record loss for a year by a nonfinancial company in Japan because of costs associated with restructuring and write-downs on its overseas investments. In all, Nippon lost 812.1 billion yen ($6.4 billion) even though sales rose 2.3 percent, mostly because of its mobile-phone unit, DoCoMo, which itself lost money on investments in KPN Mobile, AT&T Wireless and other carriers. For the current year, N.T.T. expects a profit of 361 billion yen. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Realizing a Mistake, in the Flesh

title: List Clients, McCall Says, Using a Mario Cuomo Tactic
description: Taking a lesson from a campaign by Mario M. Cuomo when he ran for governor 16 years ago, H. Carl McCall yesterday called on his opponent in the Democratic gubernatorial primary -- Mr. Cuomo's oldest son, Andrew -- to release a list of clients he is representing as a private lawyer in New York.

title: Hugh Hicks, 79, Prodigious Collector of Light Bulbs, Dies
description: Dr. Hugh Francis Hicks, a dentist whose fascination with light bulbs is said to have begun when his mother tossed one into his crib and culminated in his owning 60,000 bulbs, died on May 7 in Baltimore. He was 79.

title: New Dean at Woodrow Wilson School
description: Princeton University named ANNE-MARIE SLAUGHTER, left, a professor at both Harvard Law School and the John F. Kennedy School of Government, as the next dean of the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs yesterday. SHIRLEY M. TILGHMAN, Princeton's president, said Ms. Slaughter's ''deep background in international affairs'' and ''interdisciplinary approach'' were factors in her selection as dean. Ms. Slaughter, a 1980 Princeton graduate, earned a master's degree and a doctorate in international relations from Oxford University and a law degree from Harvard. Her teaching and research have focused on global governance, the politics of international tribunals and interdisciplinary analyses of international legal issues. She will hold faculty positions both at Woodrow Wilson and in Princeton's department of politics.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the family of Avery Fisher, which seeks to ensure that his name will remain on the concert hall used by the New York Philharmonic, misstated the year that the Avery Fisher Artist Program was founded and gave outdated figures for the size of its grants. The program was established in 1974, not 1976. Since then, prizes to young musicians have risen to $50,000 from $25,000, and career grants to emerging artists have risen to $15,000 from $10,000.

title: High School Jazz Awards
description: Seattle high school bands won the top two places in Jazz at Lincoln Center's seventh annual Essentially Ellington High School Jazz Band & Competition. The winner was Roosevelt High School, followed by Garfield High School. Taking third place was the New World School of the Arts from Miami. The three schools were among 15 finalists; 149 bands around the country competed for trophies and cash awards over the weekend at Lincoln Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELIGMAN, PAUL
description: SELIGMAN-Paul. On May 13, 2002, at age 77. Photojournalist. Author of ''Debuts & Farewells: A Two-Decade Photographic Chronicle of the Metropolitan Opera'' (Knopf). His work is in the permanent collections of the Museum of Modern Art and the Brooklyn Museum. He exhibited in numerous one-man and group shows. His photos have been published by Life, Time, Newsweek, Vanity Fair, The New York Times, Doubleday & MOMA/Abrams. His work also appeared on WOR-TV News. Most recent New York exhibits were ''Maria Callas: 40th Anniversary'' in 1996 and ''The New School: the Sixties and Seventies'' in January 2001. He is survived by his sister Miriam Lewis, sister-inlaw Shirley Seligman, nieces and nephews Susan Lewis, Lori Lewis, Howard and Hitomi Seligman and Dr. Stephen Seligman and Dr. Mary Amsler Seligman, greatnieces Hana and Molly Seligman, and dear friend Elinor Alpern. Services will be private.

title: Freetown Journal; Where Battered People Find Wholeness in a Ballot
description: A wounded nation came out today to choose a president and legislators in elections that are expected to reinforce a five-month-old peace in this West African country and signal the withdrawal of the largest United Nations peacekeeping force.

title: Kaiser Aluminum's Lockout Leads to Record Back-Pay Award
description: An administrative law judge for the National Labor Relations Board has ordered that the Kaiser Aluminum Corporation provide back pay to 2,900 workers whom it locked out in the aftermath of a strike. The workers' union estimates the total amount at no less than $180 million, a sum that federal officials say would be by far the largest back-pay award in the labor board's 67-year history.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about competition among weekly newsmagazines misstated the period for the percentage change in advertising pages this year for Newsweek, Time and U.S. News & World Report, and misstated the change for U.S. News. The figures for ad pages were through April, compared with the period a year earlier, not the first quarter. According to the Publishers Information Bureau, ad pages for U.S. News were down 9.8 percent, not up 9.8 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, ANITA
description: SHAPIRO-Anita. May 14, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Arthur Shapiro. Loving sister of Miriam Zeiler & the late Gelta Rubin. Also survived by numerous nieces and nephews. Service Thursday, May 16, at 1:30 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St.

title: Rent Report Cites Signs of Rebound, Even Downtown
description: The amount of retail space available in Manhattan declined slightly from the end of September to the end of March, to 11.2 million square feet from 11.3 million, while the overall average rent being asked per square foot increased by $3, to $87 a square foot a year from $84, a Real Estate Board of New York survey shows.

title: Small-Fry Artichokes Charm Chefs
description: FOR all that is unchanging in the routines of any harvest, there is something different about artichoke season this year. Here in the artichoke capital of the world, there is an effort to advance the cause of the little guy: the baby artichoke.

title: Pair Killed by Train Had Drug Problems, Family Says
description: Theresa LaMarca and Damien J. Connors walked off a train platform here on Monday afternoon, crossed one set of tracks, squatted down on a second set, embraced, then waited for a train that was speeding toward them. The train, the Amtrak No. 650 on its way from Harrisburg, Pa., to New York City, killed them instantly.

title: U.S. Regulators Are Requiring Full Details Of Energy Sales
description: A new rule adopted by federal regulators will force electricity traders to report individual transactions in detail beginning in July, preventing them from concealing the sort of fake ''round-trip'' trades that have allowed large energy producers to inflate their volumes and revenue, regulators say.

title: Recipe: Vanilla Pots de Crme
description: Time: About an hour

title: Rewriting History in Reykjavik
description: One of the iconic images of the cold war is of a grimacing Ronald Reagan bidding farewell to Mikhail Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, after the collapse of their summit conference in Reykjavik in October 1986. Yesterday the Icelandic capital was the scene of a very different moment, as the North Atlantic Treaty Organization welcomed Russia into a new partnership that Mr. Reagan and Mr. Gorbachev could not have imagined on that afternoon nearly 16 years ago. In the wake of Monday's nuclear arms reduction agreement between Washington and Moscow, the NATO action makes plain that a constructive and potentially historic new era has begun in relations between Russia and the West.

title: Torre Says Clemens Is Above His Own High Standard
description: Yankees Manager Joe Torre made a startling statement after watching Roger Clemens bull through the Tampa Bay Devil Rays' lineup at Yankee Stadium last night.

The continuations of three articles were affected -- one about capital improvements at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, another about the high cost of lawn service on the Island and a column offering tips for prospective buyers of apartments under construction. title: A Visual Arts Library That's Out of the Box; Design Chosen for Building in Brooklyn
description: The Brooklyn Public Library has picked a leading Mexican architect to design its Visual and Performing Arts Library as a luminous, spectral speedboat floating at anchor in front of the Brooklyn Academy of Music and the Williamsburgh Savings Bank tower, poised to sail down Flatbush Avenue.

title: U.S. Plans to End Exemption of California Farmers From Air Pollution Standards
description: Under pressure from a lawsuit, the Environmental Protection Agency agreed today to end an exemption that California farmers enjoyed from the Clean Air Act, a step that could have a major impact on some of the most polluted regions of the country.

title: Footlights
description: Adieu

title: KPMG Chief Alters View of Meeting
description: The chief executive of KPMG backpedalled today after finding himself publicly contradicting his top regulator, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, over a sensitive fraud investigation.

title: Gitlin Moves to Columbia
description: TODD GITLIN, a sociologist who writes widely about politics, culture and the media, is jumping from New York University to Columbia, where he will join the sociology department and the journalism school. Dr. Gitlin, 59, who was an undergraduate at Harvard, earned his master's degree at the University of Michigan (where he was president of Students for a Democratic Society) and a Ph.D. from the University of California at Berkeley. He said yesterday that he was drawn to Columbia for two reasons: the ''top-of-the-line students'' at Columbia and Barnard, and Columbia's four-year-old Ph.D. program in communications. Karen W. Arenson

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I want the people of the United States and Cuba to share more than a love of baseball and wonderful

title: Pinot Noir, the Russian River's Gold Rush
description: BACK in the late 1960's, a former airline pilot named Joe Swan began making wine for himself and his family at his home in Forestville, in central Sonoma County. What he didn't use himself, he sold off. Joe liked zinfandel, but he really loved pinot noir.

title: Adding Love To the Pies' Time-Tested Recipe
description: Why, Mrs. Lovett you're, you're beautiful!

title: Bush Plans to Tighten Sanctions on Cuba, Not Ease Them
description: While Jimmy Carter called for easing sanctions against Cuba, President Bush said today that he would hew to a tough line when he speaks Monday on his policy toward Cuba.

title: Fry That Twinkie, but Hold the Chips
description: WHAT do you do if you are young, bored and working the deep-fryer in a fish and chips shop? Fry everything you can get your hands on, of course.

title: Astacio's Complete Game Means Mets Need Nothing Extra
description: The Mets' high-powered and highly paid offense can barely squeak out a run, so when it scored twice for Pedro Astacio tonight, Manager Bobby Valentine was not about to tinker with a good thing. Astacio had thrown 104 pitches when he was due to lead off the top of the ninth inning. Scott Strickland, closer for the day, was warming up, but Valentine let Astacio bat for himself, as much a reward for another powerful outing as an admission that he did not have much on the bench.

title: Shoulder Injury Sidelines Valentin
description: The Mets learned today that the reserve infielder John Valentin, one of their best hitters over the past few weeks, has a partly torn rotator cuff that will land him on the disabled list and cause him to miss more than two weeks.

title: Sharon Makes Palestinian Reforms a Condition for Talks
description: Calling Yasir Arafat's Palestinian Authority a ''rotten and dictatorial regime of terror,'' Prime Minister Ariel Sharon said today that Israel would not enter any peace negotiations until it could sit down with a ''different Authority.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, BROWN, FRANCES
description: KAUFMAN - BROWN - Frances. Beth El Synagogue of New Rochelle mourns the passing of the dear mother of our Honorary President Richard Kaufman. Heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Melvin N. Sirner, Rabbi Bertram S. Schwarz, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, LAURA S.
description: JOHNSON-Laura S. May 12, 2002. Beloved wife of the late F. Raymond Johnson, former President of Saks Fifth Avenue, NYC. Loving stepmother of Patrick Johnson. Loving aunt of Nicole and Gerard Krausz. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her and will never be forgotten. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Service Thursday, May 16, 9:30 AM at the chapel of Frank E. Campbell.

title: North Koreans Who Defected In North China Reach Seoul
description: Three North Korean defectors who had climbed over the wall of a United States Consulate in northeastern China arrived here today, joining about 30 others who have escaped recently through China by finding refuge in diplomatic buildings.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DANIEL, ELSA MUSLINER
description: DANIEL-Elsa Musliner. Left us five years ago. Remembered for her inquisitive mind and dedication to ethical principles and philanthropy, as well as her love and devotion for friends and family.

title: Ferrari Team's Victory Leaves a Bitter Taste
description: PARIS, May 14  Until the last seconds of the Austrian Grand Prix on Sunday, it looked as if the Ferrari team was the epitome of modern Formula One greatness.

title: National Briefing | Labor: Judge Grants Class Status To Workers
description: A federal judge in the Northern Marianas Islands has granted class certification to more than 30,000 workers in a lawsuit asserting that 28 apparel factories on Saipan maintained sweatshop conditions. Judge Alex R. Munson of Federal District Court also gave preliminary approval to a settlement in which 19 defendants agreed to pay more than $8 million and to ensure that the factories comply with a model code of conduct. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: W. A. Rosenblith, 88, Catalyst In Combining Scientific Fields
description: Walter A. Rosenblith, one of the first scientists to use computer models to emulate the behavior of the human brain, died on May 1 in Miami Beach. He was 88.

title: Corrrections
description: An article yesterday about the difficulty of dismantling the Maine Yankee nuclear power plant misstated the name of an environmental education institution a mile away. It is the Chewonki Foundation, not Chewonski.

description: Let me get this straight.

title: PRE-ATTACK MEMO CITED BIN LADEN
description: The classified memorandum written by an F.B.I. agent in Phoenix last summer urging bureau headquarters to investigate Middle Eastern men enrolled in American flight schools also cited Osama bin Laden by name and suggested that his followers could use the schools to train for terror operations, government officials said for the first time today.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: Rabbi Requests Jail Transfer
description: A Cherry Hill rabbi accused of contracting his wife's murder could be moved from the Camden County Jail to the Burlington County Jail on Friday. Michael E. Riley, the lawyer for the rabbi, Fred J. Neulander, left, asked yesterday for the move so that his client would be closer to his Mount Holly office in Burlington County. Mr. Neulander's first trial ended when the jury could not reach a conclusion. Judge Linda Baxter of Superior Court, who presided over the first trial, will hold a hearing on Friday about Mr. Riley's request. She could also rule on the site for the retrial. Mr. Neulander, 60, has been in Camden County Jail since his June 2000 arrest. He is accused of arranging his wife's fatal beating in 1994.

title: Lesson No. 1: Stay Away From That Couple
description: A distinguished man of letters arrives at the home of eager, dithering strangers and becomes unhappily ensconced in a spare room. No, not ''The Man Who Came to Dinner,'' nothing so benign or gently teasing. Instead of the houseguest tormenting the house, the circumstances are reversed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILORENZO, JEANNETTE
description: DILORENZO - Jeannette. We mourn the death of Jeannette DiLorenzo, Chapter leader, United Federation of Teachers, Retired Teachers Program and beloved colleague and friend. Our sympathies to her family, staff and members of UFT. We honor her memory. Pat and Rose for the staff of the Brookdale Center on Aging/ Hunter College

title: Bernadette Peters and Gregory Hines to Be Tony Hosts
description: Less than three weeks before the June 2 ceremony, organizers of the Tony Awards said yesterday that Bernadette Peters and Gregory Hines would be the hosts of the show. They have formidable Broadway pedigrees but questionable television drawing power.

title: Israeli Soldiers' Refusal
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Did Standard & Poor's make a mistake by removing WorldCom from the 500?
description: WORLDCOM has plenty of problems, and well-publicized ones. But does it really deserve to be exiled from the Standard & Poor's 500?

title: Recipe: Steamed Broccoli With Beurre Noisette
description: Time: 30 minutes

title: Gunmen Kill 30, Including 10 Children, in Kashmir
description: In one of the deadliest attacks India has witnessed in recent years, three men disguised in army fatigues killed 30 people today and wounded 48 with sprays of automatic gunfire in the state of Jammu and Kashmir, which both India and Pakistan claim.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Rebels Blamed For Bombings
description: The chief prosecutor's office said an inquiry had found ''definitive proof'' that separatists from Chechnya, not Kremlin intelligence agents, masterminded apartment-house bombings in 1999 that killed more than 300 Russians and led to full-scale war in Chechnya. The Interfax news service said the deputy general prosecutor, Valery Kalmogorov, also upheld the domestic intelligence agency's assertion that so-called bombs the agency admitted placing in a building in Ryazan were in fact sacks of sugar, part of a training exercise. Kremlin opponents, led by the London-based Russian financier Boris Berezovsky, say the bombings were a government plot. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Cloning Company Misspent U.S. Grants, Auditors Say; It Will Repay
description: A biotechnology company whose assertions that it is trying to clone human embryos has created a stir in Congress misspent nearly $150,000 in government grants, an audit by federal health inspectors has found. The company, Advanced Cell Technology of Worcester, Mass., has been ordered to repay the money.

title: Lukas Puts Second Colt In Preakness
description: Table Limit, a recent allowance winner at Keeneland, will start in the Preakness at Pimlico on Saturday, his trainer, D. Wayne Lukas, has confirmed.

title: Nets Are Approaching Game 5 As Their Next Steppingstone
description: On the brink of team history, advancing to the Eastern Conference finals, the Nets today could almost taste the opportunity tantalizing them.

title: A Canvas of Contrasts, in One Little Bite
description: AN amuse-bouche that lives up to its promise is at La Caravelle this season. Like only a few of the gifts from the chef that have become a fine dining routine at restaurants around the country, this one is an elaborate miniature, a single delicious bite.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRK, KATHERINE
description: KIRK-Katherine. She was suddenly taken from us at the young age of 45. Beautiful, beloved and devoted mother to Laurence and Max Altschuler, and mourned by their father Lane Altschuler. Cherished by parents Herbert and Betty Kirk, sister Melanie Louis and in-laws Paul and Antonia Miner. All who knew her will treasure her memory. Services Friday, May 17 at 11AM at the Church of the Incarnation on Madison Avenue and 35th St. A reception will follow.

title: Nine Wars Too Many
description: If I were making a movie of the Arab-Israeli conflict today I would call it ''Ten Wars and a Funeral.'' Because the biggest problem in resolving this conflict is that there are at least 10 different wars being fought over Israel-Palestine, and we need to reduce them to just one to have any chance of making peace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPECHT, MARGARET
description: SPECHT-Margaret. Eighty-four, of Saddle Brook, NJ on February 18. She was a buyer for NYU and Brentano Books. Memorial service Saturday, May 18, 11AM at St. Mary's RC Church, Passaic. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Saddle Brook Library. Aloia Funeral Home, Garfield, NJ (973-340-7077).

title: Pairing: A Natural Partner for a Versatile Wine
description: PINOT NOIR may be the most food-friendly grape varietal around. It pairs as easily with a roasted chicken as it does with a cheese course, sauted skate or pt.

title: National Briefing: Northwest
description: NEBRASKA: JUDGE ORDERS RIVER WATER RELEASED In the latest round of a regional wrestling match over the Missouri River, Judge Laurie Smith Camp of Federal District Court in Omaha has ordered the Army Corps of Engineers to release water to float barges in the lower river. Northern states along the river want to keep water in reservoirs for recreation. States farther south insist they are entitled to a guaranteed flow for navigation and industry.

title: For China's Wealthy, All but Fruited Plain
description: Li Qinfu, snapping his fingers to emphasize the points he is making, races his purple Lamborghini toward what looks like the United States Capitol rising above the canola fields south of Shanghai.

title: NATO STRIKES DEAL TO ACCEPT RUSSIA IN A PARTNERSHIP
description: More than 50 years after its founding and a decade after the end of the cold war, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization approved an agreement today accepting Russia, the former enemy it was formed to fight, into a new partnership with the allies on terrorism, arms control and international crisis management in a post-Sept. 11 world.

title: Half of New Teachers Lack Certificates, Data Say
description: When the New York City Board of Education announced last fall that it had hired nearly 8,000 teachers for this school year -- more than the teaching staff of Yonkers or Buffalo -- it was hard to picture anything more specific than a swarm of nameless, faceless recruits descending on the city's 1,100 schools.

title: Benitez's Boo-Boo
description: Armando Benitez did what every mother tells her child to avoid. He left his finger in the crack of a door. Benitez was leaving the Mets' clubhouse on Friday night when he paused at the doorway, leaving his fingers on the door frame. Someone went by and let the door close. Benitez pulled his hand out in time to avoid severe damage, and X-rays showed no fractures, but he still had a swollen index finger and a callus.

title: PPG SETTLES ASBESTOS CLAIMS FOR $2.7 BILLION
description: PPG Industries has settled asbestos injury claims for $2.7 billion and will take a charge against earnings of about $500 million, the company said yesterday. The settlement will be paid over the next 21 years by the manufacturing company and at least three-dozen insurers, including the Travelers Property and Casualty Corporation, the company said. Raymond W. LeBoeuf, PPG's chief executive officer, said most of the asbestos claims were the result of the company's 50 percent ownership position in Pittsburgh Corning, a joint venture with Corning Inc., a company that made asbestos pipe insulation before it filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in April 2000.

title: A Strike Date Is Discussed As Talks Lag In Baseball
description: It's beginning to look a lot like 1994. Baseball's labor situation, that is.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the difficulty of dismantling the Maine Yankee nuclear power plant misstated the name of an environmental education institution a mile away. It is the Chewonki Foundation, not Chewonski.

title: A Very American Movie
description: Summer of 2002, and George Lucas has once again roused himself to deliver another installment of ''Star Wars.'' This is space opera, a form of science fiction that engulfs and devours every rival mode of pulp entertainment. ''Star Wars'' is women's romance, action-adventure, a Western, a mystery, horror, fantasy and occultism -- all at once. It's a mongrel host of alien traditions under one sleek industrial facade. You just can't get more American.

title: Daewoo Leaves Foreign Plants Adrift
description: There is a conspicuously empty space on the wall of the president's office at Daewoo-FSO Motor here, where a portrait of the Daewoo Group's founder and former chairman, Kim Woo Choong, once held pride of place.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: Park Service Changes  Its Plans
description: The National Park Service has agreed to modify plans for the new Liberty Bell Center at Independence National Historical Park in Philadelphia to reflect more fully the role of slavery in the nation's origins. The center will be situated over part of the mansion where George Washington lived with his slaves during most of his presidency. Dinitia Smith (NYT)

title: Two Scoops Of Flavor
description: What do you do when you crave two flavors of homemade ice cream but your ice cream maker allows you to make only one? Cuisinart's Flavor Duo is the answer. Unlike home machines that come with a single canister to freeze, it has two, each holding one quart. The Flavor Duo can also be used with a single canister. Either way, you turn on the machine and pour the chilled mixtures through the openings in the canister lids. After about a half hour, fresh ice cream, frozen yogurt or sorbet is ready. The only question is whether your freezer has room for two canisters, and your cupboards space for the somewhat bulky base. The machine, in white or stainless steel, is $94.98 at Zabar's and $99.95 at Williams-Sonoma.

title: Corrections
description: A review of the Dance Theater of Harlem on Monday misidentified the royal visitor from Monaco in the audience at the Apollo Theater on Friday night. He was Prince Albert. (Prince Rainier is his father.)

title: Rodeo's Breakthrough Star Retires at 32
description: In this golden age of sports on television, rodeo has, if anything, become even more obscure, falling behind as newer entries like skateboading elbow their way into the lineup. It is an impossible sport to follow, even for the determined. There are 700 rodeos a year, in every nook and cranny of the country. About 1,200 cowboys compete in them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORMAN, HELEN
description: FORMAN-Helen. On May 13, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Nathan, loving mother of Milton and Eunice, Roslyn and Harry Weinrauch, adoring grandmother of Daniel, Bill and David Forman, Michael, Susanne and James Weinrauch, great-grandmother of nine. Service Wednesday 1 PM, at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam

description: Time: 30 minutes

title: Census Shows Bigger Houses And Incomes, but Not for All
description: The celebrated prosperity of the 1990's brought a surge in the size and values of homes and in family incomes, according to new Census Bureau statistics covering 13 states, including California, Illinois, Indiana, Washington and Wisconsin. Many more Americans earned college and graduate degrees, and the incomes of the elderly jumped about 60 percent.

title: Challenger's Victory in Hospital Union Election Is Upheld
description: James Butler, the president of the union local representing 7,500 municipal hospital workers in New York City, lost his bid to remain in office yesterday when the local's parent union rejected his challenge to the results of a February election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, EVELYN (NEE BAG)
description: LEVIN-Evelyn (nee Bag), May 14, 2002. Beloved wife of Monte, devoted and loving mother of Marjorie and Joe Gerena, Robert and Marci. Adoring grandmother of Alexis Katz and Jane Levin and dear sister of Lillian Sustick. A woman of charm and elegance who will be deeply missed. Contributions to the Alzheimers Association. Services Thursday, May 16 at 11:30 A.M., The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Abortion Clinic Wins a Round In a Fight Over Its New Home
description: A clinic that performs abortions mostly for low-income women won an important if technical victory this evening in its efforts to relocate after the city's Zoning Board of Appeals refused to hear a last-ditch argument against the move by two Democrats on the City Council.

title: One Woman's Showdown With the Food Industry
description: IN ''Food Politics,'' Marion Nestle's telling book on the food industry's influence on nutrition and health, she asserts that one of the ways the industry intimidates its critics is by suing them.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: The Advertising Council, New York, elected 13 members to its board. They are: Ron Askew, senior vice president for marketing at Coors Brewing, part of the Adolph Coors Company; Carole Black, president and chief executive at Lifetime Television Network, a joint venture of the Hearst Corporation and the Walt Disney Company; Daniel Dillon, president and chief executive at Welch Foods; Phil Dusenberry, chairman at BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group; Steven T. Florio, president and chief executive at Condé Nast Publications, part of Advance Publications; Christopher Fraleigh, executive director for corporate advertising at the General Motors Corporation; Marty Franks, executive vice president at CBS Television, owned by Viacom; Bruce Gordon, president for the retail markets group at Verizon Communications; Steve Howe, vice president at Dow Jones & Company; Jerry Judge, chief executive at Lowe & Partners Worldwide, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies; Stephen Lacy, president at the Meredith Publishing Group unit of the Meredith Corporation; Stone Roberts, chairman and chief executive at Gotham, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of Interpublic; and Jim Speros, chief marketing officer at the United States operations of Ernst & Young.

title: Californian Who Protests Taxes Is Jailed After Audit Hearing
description: Al Thompson, a California business owner who says the income tax laws are a hoax, was jailed yesterday by a state judge for refusing to cooperate with a state tax audit.

title: Court Says Law School May Consider Race in Admissions
description: A federal appeals court ruled yesterday that the Constitution permits colleges and graduate schools to seek a ''critical mass'' of black and Hispanic students in assembling their entering classes each year, as long as those rough targets do not harden into precise quotas.

title: Senecas Vote to Approve Plans for 2 Casinos
description: Members of the Seneca Nation of Indians in western New York voted 1,077 to 976 today in favor of two proposed casinos for Buffalo and Niagara Falls, and the hundreds of millions of dollars they are expected to bring.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Environmental Concerns At School
description: Board of Education officials are to meet this morning with parents and teachers at Public School 65 in Ozone Park to discuss concerns about potential environmental hazards. The school is housed in a former airplane parts factory, and teachers have complained about air quality, said Catie Marshall, a board spokeswoman. In January, the State Department of Environmental Conservation decided that contaminated groundwater below a nearby building posed ''a significant threat to the public health'' and might need to be cleaned up, said Jennifer Post, a department spokeswoman. The groundwater flows in the school's direction, Ms. Post said, adding that the state's findings were not urgent enough to require immediate action. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: Fiat Reports Loss and Will Sell Shares in Ferrari Unit
description: Fiat said today that its struggling automobile division dragged it into a second consecutive quarterly loss and that it would sell shares in its Ferrari sports car unit to reduce debt.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Rebels Accused In Officers' Deaths
description: The government in the southern state of Guerrero said members of an armed leftist group had killed two police officers in a shootout at a rural water treatment plant 95 miles east of Acapulco. They said the attack had been carried out by members of the People's Revolutionary Army, a group that fought several intense battles with the Mexican Army in 1996 and 1997 but was believed to have splintered in recent years. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Wednesday about the endurance of steak as Argentina's national dish even in difficult economic times misstated the term for a cut of sirloin with a shape reminiscent of a gun. It is cuarto pistola, not corta de pistola.

title: A Fennel That's Little But Long On Licorice Flavor
description: Baby vegetables can be too precious for their own good, adorable but underdeveloped in flavor. This isn't so with fennel. Baby fennel has an intense licorice sweetness that is very appealing, and the trimmed bulbs can be quartered with ease and tossed with a dressing for salad, or blanched and sauted for a pasta sauce. The organic fennel, above, sold by Fairway markets for $1.49 a pound, is actually toddler-size, with bulbs about as big as lemons. Still, the stems are tender enough to poach and marinate in a vinaigrette. The fennel will be available for another month.

title: Early Warning: There May Be None for Next Rate Increase
description: Federal Reserve policy makers do not like surprises, but they may be cooking up one for for analysts and investors who do not read Fed tea leaves closely.

title: A Surprise From Senator Clinton
description: When President Bill Clinton worked with Republicans to ''end welfare as we know it'' six years ago, there was speculation that Hillary Rodham Clinton was a silent critic. But whatever her views then, Mrs. Clinton now favors a tougher policy. To the surprise of many, New York's junior senator has decided to side with President Bush and others advocating punitive new work requirements in legislation to be voted on this week in the House.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Ruling In Killing By Colonel
description: An army colonel who admitted strangling an 18-year-old Chechen woman two years ago suffered from shell shock and shrapnel wounds to the head and was insane at the time of the crime, military psychiatrists concluded. The ruling, disclosed by prosecutors, probably means that Col. Yuri Budanov will be freed from custody and given court-ordered medical treatment, officials said. Colonel Budanov has said he suspected that the woman, whom he seized from her father's home, was a sniper and that he has no memory of the killing. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Corrections

The continuations of three articles were affected -- one about capital improvements at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, another about the high cost of lawn service on the Island and a column offering tips for prospective buyers of apartments under construction. The articles may be read online today at nytimes.com/corrections.html. They may also be requested from Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; telephone (212) 556-1992. E-mail: quality@nytimes.com. title: F.D.A. Backs Cancer Drug
description: The biotechnology companies, Genentech and OSI Pharmaceuticals said today that the Food and Drug Administration had designated the cancer treatment Tarceva as a fast-track product to expedite its review.

Gotimer, Marion Dupper, Monsignor James E. Gotimer & George T. Gotimer. Also survived by many devoted nieces, nephews & cousins. Reposing at the Convent of Mary the Queen, 35 Vark Street, Yonkers, NY on Wednesday, 1-8 P.M. Funeral Mass Thursday, 10:30 A.M. at the convent. Interment to follow at St. Joseph's Cemetery, Yonkers, NY. title: Asian Touches, Orchestrated in Jazzy Riffs
description: THE Lotus that most New Yorkers know is a nightclub and lounge that comes alive in the late evening hours. It has a velvet rope and a man with a guest list whose job is to break the bad news to the 99.9 percent of the human race not on it. Everything I know about the first Lotus I read in the gossip columns.
