title: A Bride's First Vow: My Feast Won't Be Dull
description: MY wedding guests have probably been served salmon at countless prior nuptials. And to our utter disbelief, my fianc and I are considering serving it to them again when we get married in October.

title: Unmemorable Theater Moments, Gone but Not Forgotten
description: In films and on television there are outtakes, either unnecessary scenes or fumblings in performance. These clips are filed away and sometimes they return in retrospectives, where they are greeted by laughter. In contrast, in the theater, once a scene is cut -- in rehearsal or an out-of-town tryout -- it generally disappears into a playwright's trunk. Occasionally, in a revival of a musical, a song might be restored or it might be shifted to another show by the same composer. For the most part, however, such scenes and songs become archival history.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Ex-General Convicted In Nuclear Case
description: A retired general was convicted of disclosing classified information related to Israel's nuclear program but cleared of charges that he intended to harm state security. Brig. Gen. Yitzhak Yaakov, 76, who also has American citizenship, was head of weapons development for the military for a decade. The conviction, which carries a sentence of up to 15 years, cited unpublished manuscripts of a memoir and novel that Mr. Yaakov sent to publishers in the United States. He was arrested last year after giving interviews to an Israeli reporter, whose article was banned by the military censor. Joel Greenberg (NYT)

title: Papers Show Officials Knew Of Priest's Troubles in 1991
description: Officials in the Boston Archdiocese were told in 1991 that the Rev. Paul R. Shanley had serious psychiatric problems, two years before they informed church officials in California, where Father Shanley was serving as a pastor, according to psychiatric and medical records released today.

title: After Having Lived His Dream, Ramos Says It's Time to Move On
description: Tab Ramos and his wife, Amy, needed a few seconds to usher their children, Alex, 5, and Kristen, 3, to their seats in the Board Room at St. Benedict's Prep.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LILIEN, HELEN H.
description: LILIEN-Helen H. Dear sister, gone these fifty-three years and ofttimes there are tears. Spiritually, you were compassionate, loving and caring of all living kind and your physical beauty is always brought to mind. Herbert

title: Court Lacks Last Word In Aid to Religious Schools
description: THE Supreme Court will soon decide if public money can pay for tuition at private religious schools. Advocates and opponents of vouchers await the ruling with great excitement or dread. But the decision may be less important than they think.

title: Andersen Auditors Knew About Federal Inquiry, Records at Trial Show
description: Auditors with Arthur Andersen billed Enron about $720,000 for dealing with a federal inquiry into its finances at the same time they were destroying boxes of documents related to the company, according to records and testimony presented today at the firm's trial on a charge of obstruction of justice.

title: To the Trade, And Now to You
description: Piccinini Brothers, a Ninth Avenue meat purveyor since 1922, has a sleek new retail offshoot: Tartare, 653 Ninth Avenue (46th Street). Owned by Paul Vaccari, whose grandfather was a Piccinini founder, and his wife, Sylvie, the store offers both fresh meat and prepared foods. The small shop has an invitingly open glass facade; inside, display cases hold platters of delicious-looking meats, until now sold by Piccinini only to restaurants. Some of the meat has been stuffed and seasoned and is ready to cook. There are side dishes, some seafood and even desserts. The chef, Lea Forant, right, also makes sauces, stocks and glazes. Chickens, loins of pork and other meats turn on a French rotisserie. Today's specials are steak au poivre cooked or ready for the pan ($32 and $28 a pound), along with potato gratin ($9.50 a pound) and spinach with garlic ($5.95 a pound); tomorrow's include herb-crusted rack of lamb ($19 a pound, cooked). A roast beef dinner will be available on Sunday ($18 a pound with side dishes at $3.95 to $8.95 a pound). The shop will deliver free in a 25-block radius on the West Side and for cab fare elsewhere.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANSPACH, ERNST
description: ANSPACH-Ernst. The members, officers and staff of Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church give thanks to God for the life and ministry of their beloved member Ernst Anspach, who died in his home in New York City, April 27, 2002, at the age of 89, and extend our sympathies and prayers to his wife, Ruth; their children, Gretel and David, as well as the many others for whom Ernst was counselor, advocate and friend. Dr. Anspach served Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church as Ruling Elder and Trustee for more than thirty years. ''Well done, good and faithful servant! Enter the joy of your Lord.'' Memorial Service, Friday, May 17, 11 AM, at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, New York City. Contributions in Dr. Anspach's memory mory may be made to the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

description: The possibilities opened up by the availability of relatively inexpensive, highly compact digital video cameras are just beginning to be explored. For documentary makers in particular, the new technology points the way toward a new aesthetic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN ALSTYNE, JANET G.
description: VAN ALSTYNE-Janet G. The Board of Trustees of Englewood Hospital and Medical Center records with sorrow the passing of Janet Graham Van Alstyne who served our Medical Center for more than half a century as a trustee, volunteer and fund-raiser. Mrs. Van Alstyne's good deeds will serve as a lasting memorial to her long and distinguished life. Our condolences go out to her daughters Joan, Keats and Ellen, and the other members of her family. Andrew F. Durkin, Chairman Daniel A. Kane, President

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Automotive Stake To Be Sold
description: India has agreed to sell part of its stake in the country's largest carmaker, Maruti Udyog, to the company's venture partner, the Suzuki Motor Corporation of Japan, as it moves ahead with efforts to sell government-held assets. The government will reduce its stake in Maruti to 45.5 percent from 49.7 percent through the sale. Suzuki will pay 4 billion rupees ($85 million) and raise its ownership to 54.2 percent. The government plans to divest the rest of its stake by selling shares to the public over the next two years. Maruti, which is run by Suzuki, controls about two-thirds of the Indian market. Saritha Rai (NYT)

World Briefing: Asia
description: REGIONAL ANTITERROR EFFORT Defense ministers from Russia, China and three central Asian nations decided to pool their efforts to combat terrorism, extremism and separatist movements, saying they posed a threat to the entire region. The countries, which formed the Shanghai Cooperation Organization last year to discuss security issues, all face either internal extremist or separatist movements, led by Russia's long-running war in Chechnya, or fear infiltration by terrorist groups after the defeat of the Taliban in Afghanistan. Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan joined Russia and China in the move; the sixth member, Uzbekistan, boycotted the meeting, apparently to protest Russia's formation of military alliances with other nearby nations.

title: Talk About Retro: A Return to the Bronze Age
description: WHEN the Long Island architect Peter Bentel was working on the design for Tom Colicchio's restaurant Craft, his first thought, he said, was to use silvery tones for the metal accents, like the bathroom sinks and front-door handles.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: West Virginia: Voters Reject Sunday Hunting
description: Voters in a county-by-county referendum overwhelmingly chose not to allow hunting on Sundays. Residents voted on hunting for turkey, squirrel and other game seven days a week or just Monday through Saturday. In all 32 counties with early results, the balloting was lopsidedly against hunting on Sunday. Sam Dillon (NYT)

title: Richter and Warhol Rule at Contemporary-Art Sale
description: Generally taste and fashion move the market for contemporary art, but two artists' retrospectives and the arrival of a long-awaited catalogue raisonn drove the bidding for 7 of the top 10 works auctioned last night at Sotheby's.

Watkins, the Enron vice president who warned the chairman of problems with its accounting practices, referred incorrectly to criticism of her by a lawyer for Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former Enron chief executive. The lawyer, Bruce Hiler, who suggested that the memo was more damage control than whistle-blowing, made his comments after a Congressional hearing on Enron, not during testimony.

title: Witness Suggests Skakel Killed Friend While Drunk
description: After a week of testimony that focused mostly on earlier suspects, state prosecutors began to build their case against Michael C. Skakel today, calling to the witness stand a neighbor and close friend of the Skakel family who raised the possibility that Mr. Skakel killed Martha Moxley but was so drunk that he could not remember the crime.

title: Blair Says Merrie Olde England Indeed Needs Shiny New Euro
description: Edging closer to an outright endorsement of joining Europe's single currency, Prime Minister Tony Blair said tonight that it would be a ''betrayal of our national interest'' if Britons chose to remain apart from the new money for political reasons alone.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: MAZDA RAISES OUTLOOK Japan's fifth-largest automaker, the Mazda Motor Corporation, said it expected profit to double this year, helped by revived sales in Japan and Europe. The company, which is based in Hiroshima and is one-third owned by the Ford Motor Company , forecasts a profit of 20 billion yen ($155.6 million) in the year ending March 31, 2003, or 127 percent more than this year. Mazda expects sales to rise 8 percent. The company also expects to trim outstanding debt by 7.5 percent and cut capital spending 15 percent. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: SMITHS GROUP MAY BID ON TRW AERONAUTICAL UNIT
description: The Smiths Group, a maker of airplane controls and cockpit displays, signed a confidentiality agreement with TRW that could lead to a bid for TRW's aeronautical unit. Smiths, based in London, is interested in the unit's actuation and power-management businesses, said Keith Butler-Wheelhouse, the chief executive. He declined to comment on whether Smiths had made a bid. The unit may bring as much as $1.5 billion, analysts said. TRW, based in Cleveland, wants to sell the unit as part of a plan to break up the company to improve shareholder value. Northrop Grumman, which made a hostile $12.2 billion offer for TRW, has also agreed to a confidential review of the company's finances.

title: A Race to Vote On a Budget In Albany
description: Operating in closed meetings, state lawmakers today began absorbing details of the gargantuan budget bills negotiated by their leaders. The legislators, juggling dozens of dollar figures largely in their heads, were to begin voting on the bills Thursday morning.

title: BUSH WAS WARNED BIN LADEN WANTED TO HIJACK PLANES
description: The White House said tonight that President Bush had been warned by American intelligence agencies in early August that Osama bin Laden was seeking to hijack aircraft but that the warnings did not contemplate the possibility that the hijackers would turn the planes into guided missiles for a terrorist attack.

title: Enron Traded Amid Doubts, Senate Is Told
description: Enron lawyers alerted senior company executives in October 2000 to trading strategies that Enron was using in the California electricity market, and concluded in December 2000 that the tactics were ''potentially criminal.'' Only then did the company order the maneuvers stopped, according to Senate testimony today.

title: Alas, No Swan Song
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Chief Named At AOL Interactive
description: America Online, a part of AOL Time Warner, said yesterday that James Bankoff would become chief of its AOL Interactive Services unit, where he will lead development and management of AOL online products and services. Mr. Bankoff was president of the AOL Web Properties Group and vice president for strategy and operations for the AOL brand. Joel Davidson, executive vice president and chief operating officer of the Web Properties Group, will succeed Mr. Bankoff in overseeing the group.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qwest Fined Over Network Access
description: Qwest Communications International said yesterday that it would appeal a $900,000 fine assessed by the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission for denying requests by AT&T to perform tests on Qwest's network. AT&T wanted the tests to help it assess the costs of competing with Qwest to sell local phone service in Minnesota. Qwest eventually permitted the tests after AT&T filed a complaint accusing it of anticompetitive behavior. Qwest told the commission it had resisted because AT&T had no intention of using the data to offer local phone service. AT&T's actual goal, Qwest said, was gathering information AT&T might use to fight Qwest's efforts to sell long-distance service in the state. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Growth Estimate Raised
description: The Bank of England raised its estimate of Britain's likely economic growth rate, setting off speculation that interest rates will rise later in the year. The bank said the annual growth rate would expand to about 3 percent by the beginning of 2003. In February, the bank's forecast was a 2.4 percent annual growth rate in the same period. Faster growth will mean that inflation will reach the bank's 2.5 percent target sooner than forecast. Economists say rates could begin to rise in August, taking the benchmark interest rate from 4 to 4.5 percent by the end of 2002.

title: Learning From Diversity
description: On Tuesday, the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the University of Michigan Law School's admissions policy, in which race is one of the many factors that can influence a decision. The ruling leaves in place a policy that is as cautious a form of affirmative action as one may find in higher education.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Iowa: Students Win Ban On Lord's Prayer
description: Two students at a high school in Woodbine have won a court challenge to stop the singing of the Lord's Prayer at their commencement, a compulsory school tradition for 30 years. Judge Charles R. Wolle of Federal District Court in Des Moines ruled that the principal effect of having the high school choir sing the prayer was ''to advance the Christian religion.'' School officials said although they disagreed with the ruling, they would enforce it on graduation day. Laurie Goodstein (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Mitsubishi's Profit Falls
description: Japan's largest trading company, the Mitsubishi Corporation, said profit fell 35 percent because of a decline in the value of its investments. The company earned 60 billion yen ($466.9 million) in the year that ended in March as sales fell 5.5 percent. The company was hit particularly by its 30 percent stake in Lawson Inc., Japan's second-largest convenience store chain. Mitsubishi said in April that it would probably take a loss of 31 billion yen this fiscal year to write down the value of its Lawson investment. Still, Mitsubishi said that it expected profit to rise 42 percent this year.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Court Voids Law On Same-Sex Soliciting
description: Unanimously, the State Supreme Court struck down a law that bars same-sex solicitation, saying it violated free-speech and equal-protection rights. The ruling called the law an illegal restriction on speech, and a concurring opinion said it unfairly treated people who seek homosexual activity differently from people who seek heterosexual activity. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: H&R BLOCK INC., -- Kansas City, Mo., a tax preparer, said it had filed for a federal bank charter to allow the company to offer savings accounts to its clients and enable its Option One Mortgage Corporation unit to use the deposits for lending.

title: Vote on Tax Bill Blocked in House
description: WASHINGTON, May 15  Republicans in the House of Representatives are blocking an attempt by Democrats to force a vote on a measure that would prevent companies from avoiding income taxes by reincorporating in Bermuda and other offshore tax havens.

title: Rescue Efforts Lift Poets' Voices From Fraying Tapes
description: The melodic voice of Marianne Moore echoed from a reel-to-reel tape recorder at the American Poetry Archives here on a recent morning. She was reading her poems to an enthusiastic audience in 1957, and the tape offered delights quite different from those that come from reading a printed page.

description: THE reason I dislike the word ''mommy,'' I told the dog, is because that whiny second syllable robs ''mom'' of its dignity.

title: Wal-Mart Is Seeking Approval to Buy a California Bank
description: Wal-Mart is seeking regulatory approval to buy a tiny California bank, saying it hopes a banking license will lower its processing costs for certain transactions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILLET, FRANCIS WARRINGTON, JR
description: GILLET-Francis Warrington, Jr, of Palm Beach, Florida, died peacefully on May 13, 2002 of heart related complications. Born in Baltimore, Maryland on July 17, 1930, he was the son of Francis Warrington Gillet, Sr. and Louise Warfield Harris Gillet. He is survived by his wife, Elesabeth Ingalls Gillet; daughter Suzy Gillet Chewning; son, F. Warrington Gillet, III; grandchildren, Blair Chewning, Elinor Chewning, William Chewning, III, F. Warrington Gillet, IV; and first cousin, Sherlock Gillet and his wife Iva of Glyndon, Maryland. Mr. Gillet was a graduate of Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, Maryland, and served in the military as a First Lieutenant, Infantry. Following his military career, he worked along side his father at Hiram Walker Incorporated and later as a broker agent with Sotheby's, Palm Beach. Mr. Gillet was an avid cook and outdoorsman. He spent the summer in Maine, and the balance of the year between New York City and Palm Beach. He attended and contributed to numerous charity events. Mr. Gillet was President of the Game Conservancy-USA and was a member of the Everglades Club, The Bath & Tennis Club, The Sailfish Club of Florida, as well as other clubs in Palm Beach, New York, and London. A Memorial Service will be held at 11:30 AM on Thursday, May 16, 2002 at Bethesda-By-The-Sea Episcopal Church, Palm Beach, Florida. A Graveside Service will be held at 1:00 PM on Friday, May 17, 2002 at St. John's Episcopal Church Cemetery, Glyndon, Maryland, with Rev. Patrick O'Neill, officiating. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Mr. Gillet's memory to either: The New Hope Charities, Inc, 626 North Dixie Highway, West Palm Beach, Florida 33401; or St. John's Episcopal Church, 3738 Butler Road, Glyndon, Maryland 21070.

With playoff victories included, they won 13 games in each of three seasons, not 13 games over all. They won 57 games over the five seasons.

title: Chief Executive Resigns Position As Adelphia Expands Inquiry
description: Underscoring the breadth of the crisis facing Adelphia Communications, the company said yesterday that its founder and chief executive, John J. Rigas, had resigned and that it was conducting an investigation into issues raised during the preparation of its 2001 financial statements.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Kansas: Parents Want Superintendent Fired
description: Parents in Piper are circulating petitions demanding the ouster of the school superintendent, Dr. Michael O. Rooney, who ordered a biology teacher not to fail 28 students who plagiarized their work for a botany project in the fall. The group, Parents Involved in Education, is also collecting signatures to recall three of the seven board members of the 1,300-student district. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKER, SAMUEL D.
description: BAKER-Samuel D. Of Staten Island on May 14, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Minna. Loving father of William and Robert and father-in-law of Muriel. Dear brother of Larae Moody. Devoted grandfather of Daniel, Brian, Abbey and Drs. Seth and Mary Baker and great grandfather of Alexandra, David, Andrew and Merideth Baker. Services held Thursday, May 16, Congregation Ahavath Israel, SI, NY. Interment United Hebrew Cemtery, S.I. NY. Bedell-Pizzo Funeral Home, S.I.

title: A Little Bit of This, a Little of That
description: The best of more than 1,000 entries in an annual pottery competition in Lincoln, Calif., 30 miles northeast of Sacramento, include a porcelain window made in honor of the artist's blind grandfather, and functional wares, like the Crazy Rhythms bowls, right, by Katharine Gotham. The works of the 73 winners of the contest, held by Lincoln Arts, will be shown (and are for sale) through May 26 at the offices of Gladding McBean, a maker of terra cotta for restoration projects, including one at the School of the Future in Manhattan. The bowls have been sold; for information on other pieces: (916) 645-9713 or www.lincolnarts.org.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: A Poke At U.N.
description: Prime Minister Hun Sen suggested that the United Nations had pulled out of talks with Cambodia on setting up a trial of former Khmer Rouge leaders because it wanted to avoid embarrassment. He based his gibe on a historical reality. The United Nations continued to recognize the brutal Communist movement throughout its reign of terror from 1975 to 1979, and then for the following decade as it fought a guerrilla war against the government that had ousted it. In February the United Nations ended talks with Cambodia over the shape of an international tribunal, saying Mr. Hun Sen's government was refusing to meet international standards of justice. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Relentless Exhibitionism Becomes a Life's Work
description: ''I use everything as a mirror,'' the German pop star Nina Hagen declares near the end of Peter Sempel's chaotic, murky, confrontational documentary portrait, ''Nina Hagen = Punk + Glory,'' which opened yesterday at the Anthology Film Archives. She isn't exaggerating. Her relentless exhibitionism (she boasts of having once masturbated on an Austrian television show) makes Madonna's most flamboyant ploys for attention seem demure.

title: A Drummer Boy Is Gone, and He Didn't March Off
description: The drummer boy is AWOL from the Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx.

title: Reno, Whose Eventful Life Is a One-Woman Show
description: THIS must be the right place. The name on the doorbell says Reno, and chaos is in progress: a wild-eyed, barking dog with a stand-up hairdo straight from the Don King handbook has just come hurtling down the stairs of a TriBeCa loft, followed by a middle-aged woman with similar eyes and hairdo (though hers is spiked with beauty parlor highlights). No leash laws for this dog.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: TEXAS: VICTIM'S MOTHER PLEADS FOR KILLER The mother of a convenience store clerk stabbed to death in 1993 in Corpus Christi has asked the state Board of Pardons and Paroles to spare the life of her son's killer. The woman, Lana Norris, said Johnny Joe Martinez, convicted of murdering her son Clay Peterson, had repented. Ms. Norris made the request after spending more than four hours with Mr. Martinez, 29, in a prison mediation program. He is scheduled to be executed on Wednesday. Jim Yardley (NYT)

title: Playoffs Chug Along and Stir Memories
description: When the National Hockey League had only six teams and they all traveled by railroad, rivals sometimes shared trains. In a recent book called ''The Glory of Their Game,'' the Detroit hero Gordie Howe recalled, a bit vaguely, how ''one of our guys got into a fight with Dickie Moore'' as Moore, a Montreal player, walked to the breakfast car.

title: Transcript of Gephardt's News Conference
description: Following is a transcript of a news conference today by the House Democratic Leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, in Washington. as distributed by his office:

title: Campaign Reform's Slow Arrival
description: Cockeyed optimists who were hoping that the nation's new campaign finance reform law would remove the influence of big-money donors overnight should have been brought down to earth on Tuesday when President Bush played host at a record-breaking $30 million fund-raiser. The reforms, alas, do not even take effect until after November -- but it would be nice if some party decided to abide by their spirit this election cycle.

title: National Briefing: Plains
description: KANSAS: PARENTS WANT SUPERINTENDENT FIRED Parents in Piper are circulating petitions demanding the ouster of the school superintendent, Dr. Michael O. Rooney, who ordered a biology teacher not to fail 28 students who plagiarized their work for a botany project in the fall. The group, Parents Involved in Education, is also collecting signatures to recall three of the seven board members of the 1,300-student district.

title: For the Giant of a Hotel Guest, and Others
description: Andr Balazs's Downtown L.A. Standard hotel is anything but standard issue. Originally the headquarters for Superior Oil, the 1956 building, facade intact, now has a tongue-in-cheek corporate interior by Koning Eizenberg Architecture and Shawn Hausman, a film production designer. It is in the financial district and offers cheeky design, like 21 rooms with beds and baths big enough for basketball players at the nearby Staples Center; oversize bathrooms have a giant black rubber foot, left, by Gaetano Pesce. Stripes and matching lampshade enliven another room, below. The hotel, with rooms as low as $95, is at 550 South Flower Street; (213) 892-8080.

title: Patching Together Help as Doctors' Insurance Unravels
description: With thousands of New Jersey doctors struggling to find insurance against medical malpractice lawsuits, at least four groups are trying to start new companies to provide coverage.

title: Mayor's Welfare Plan Embraces Job Training
description: Departing significantly from the welfare policies of his predecessor, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday that his administration planned to provide extensive job training, child care and other programs to help welfare recipients find and hold jobs.

title: West Bank Damages Put at $361 Million
description: Israel's recent military offensive in the West Bank caused physical damage estimated at $361 million, according to an assessment issued here today by international donors who are mobilizing to finance reconstruction. By comparison, the first 15 months of Israeli-Palestinian fighting, which erupted in September 2000, caused an estimated $305 million in damage.

title: Alas, a Swan Song Without the Song
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOGEN, SAMUEL A.
description: BOGEN-Samuel A. Of Port Washington, NY, died Tuesday at age 89. A memorial service will take place Sunday, May 19, 1:30 PM at The Landmark (formerly Main Street School), 232 Main Street, Port Washington.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Tough Maidenhair

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, DAISY (THERESA)
description: MARKS-Daisy (Theresa). On May 12, 2002, at age 94. Beloved wife of the late Duke Marks. She is survived by sons, Walter, and his wife, Joan, Peter and his wife, Jean, and three grandchildren, Benjamin, his wife, Elizabeth Morrison, Annie and Sam, and greatgranddaughter, Sophia Morrison Marks. Services will be private. Contributions in Daisy's memory may be made to Jacob Perlow Hospice, Beth Israel Medical Ctr. 1st Ave at 16th St, NY, NY 10003.

title: When Worship Gets Wired
description: LIVE full-color images from cameras placed around the room started to appear on the wall-mounted projection screens, and the crowd began to quiet down in anticipation. The room was full of sleek video and audio gear and illuminated by theatrical lighting equipment, but the event was not a stage production, a sports event or a television-show taping.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the celebrity status of Sherron S. Watkins, the Enron vice president who warned the chairman of problems with its accounting practices, referred incorrectly to criticism of her by a lawyer for Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former Enron chief executive. The lawyer, Bruce Hiler, who suggested that the memo was more damage control than whistle-blowing, made his comments after a Congressional hearing on Enron, not during testimony.

title: Japan and China Intensify Dispute Over Korean Asylum Seekers
description: A diplomatic dispute between China and Japan escalated today over the case of a North Korean family that sought political asylum in a Japanese consulate last week.

title: Church Erred on Abuses, Boston College Leader Says
description: The president of Boston College, Boston's most prestigious institution of Roman Catholic education, said today that the Catholic hierarchy had ''badly mishandled'' the cases of sexually abusive priests and that he felt betrayed by how the church had kept the problem a secret while letting the priests continue working in parishes.

title: Protecting Internet Speech
description: Although the Supreme Court may have given new life to the Child Online Protection Act this week, the ruling suggests that the court remains deeply concerned about free speech online. We hope that Congress's misguided attempt to regulate online pornography and other Internet material will ultimately be struck down on First Amendment grounds.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Nebraska: Record Low Turnout
description: Election officials say apathy and a lack of contested elections caused a record low voter turnout. About 200,000 people, 20 percent of registered voters, went to the polls for the primary on Tuesday, far below the previous record of 36 percent, in 1998. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Judge's Drug Use at Issue in 2 Death Sentences
description: The judge bought marijuana by mail. He paid with a cashier's check, and he used the office stationery. The envelope bore a handsome imprint: ''Philip Marquardt, Superior Court Judge, Phoenix, Arizona.''

title: A Scandinavian Sampler, the Century Undecided
description: Postulating a national style in music is as useful, and as limiting, as postulating a national style of dress, manners or cuisine: it lays out guidelines that can degenerate into stereotype. On the evidence of the Scandinavian program Leon Botstein and the American Symphony Orchestra played at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday evening, the music of Denmark, Sweden and Finland fits right in with one's general image of these Northern realms: cool, craggy, organic.

title: CALENDER
description: Furniture Fashions

title: U.S. and Israel Disagree On West Bank Security
description: A senior Israeli military official said today that there was no point in America's undertaking a diplomatic mission to rebuild the Palestinian security force while Yasir Arafat was in charge and that Israel needed to retain responsibility for security in the occupied territories.

title: Sports of The Times; New-Look Nets Belong In Newark
description: WITH one, possibly two more rounds of playoffs to go, we're running out of superlatives to describe Jason Kidd.

title: National Security Adviser's Press Briefing
description: Following is the transcipt of the press briefing given by National Security Adviser Condoleeza Rice on Thursday afternoon, as recorded by the White House.

title: Nets Reach Another Milestone
description: Seven months ago, Jason Kidd proclaimed the improbable. He told his new teammates that the Nets would win 40 games.

title: When the Grim Reaper Calls, The Computer Goes Into Action
description: If you're looking for peace of mind in the afterlife, life insurance and estate planning may pale in comparison with getting one last crack at your keyboard from beyond the grave.

title: Andersen Partner Says He Came to Accept Guilt
description: David B. Duncan, the former partner with Arthur Andersen who pleaded guilty last month to obstruction of justice, testified today about the months of anguish he experienced during his gradual shift from a certainty in his own innocence to his eventual belief that he had committed a crime by destroying thousands of records related to Enron.

title: From TV Advertisers, Thumbs Up and Down
description: In an annual bicoastal courtship that ends today, Hollywood came to New York this week with a product to sell to advertisers: next season's television programs. Network executives arrived seeking big scores, and they scurried to put together the most appealing schedules.

title: Albany Bill Would Define a Fetus as a Person in Cases of Assault
description: After an emotional and divisive debate today, the State Senate passed a bill that would define a fetus as a person in cases of assault and homicide.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Hackers' Equipment Confiscated
description: Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation have confiscated computer equipment from two young men who are suspected of hacking into government and business Web sites in the name of patriotism and computer security. A group calling itself the Deceptive Duo has hacked into government computer systems and defaced Web pages with patriotic essays, data from other hacked systems and demands that the operators of the sites tighten security. Federal agents served a search warrant on Monday on Robert Lyttle, 18, above, who goes by the online name Pimpshiz and lives in California, and who is already on probation for a string of Web site defacements protesting the shutdown of the Napster free music service. The other person served with a search warrant, who uses the online name The-Rev, lives in Florida. Neither has been arrested. In January, Mr. Lyttle published an article on the Web site of Sub Seven Software, a security company, in which he wrote, ''If it weren't for hackers there would be no sense of insecurity, and therefore no drive to create stronger security.''

title: Bluetooth, the Wireless Matchmaker, Tries Again
description: THIS week, in my very own home, I performed three technological feats so advanced, so miraculous, that you may find this account difficult to believe. First -- brace yourself -- I sent a document from a computer to an inkjet printer. Second -- are you sitting down? -- I copied a file from one computer to another. Finally -- and here's where it gets truly crazy -- I synchronized a Palm organizer with a laptop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IMPERATO, FRANK
description: IMPERATO-Frank. Born November 11, 1960. Died May 13, 2002. With deep sorrow and affection, we mourn the passing of our brother and dear friend. Frank brought a sense of drama, comedy and passion to everything and everyone he touched. He will always be remembered because he was truly unforgettable. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave on Wed & Thurs. 212-288-3500 Albert Imperato Mitchell & Patti Grabow Suzanne & Mike Gerla Lisa & Tom Karach Tom Herman

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit in Cincinnati upholding the admissions policies of the University of Michigan Law School misidentified the president who appointed the chief judge, Boyce F. Martin Jr. He was Jimmy Carter, not Bill Clinton.

title: After Years of High Life, Swindler Pleads Guilty
description: An eccentric Greenwich playboy who became an international fugitive after stealing a fortune in an insurance scheme pleaded guilty here today to 23 federal counts of racketeering and wire and securities fraud.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERT, IRVING
description: ALBERT-Irving, 80. Died suddenly on May 13, 2002 at home. Born in Poland, came to the United States in 1938. An honored union organizer and committed leftist. He served in the U.S. Armed Forces in the invasion of North Africa, landed in Anzio and marched to Rome. Supported many Jewish causes. And was an Alaskan entrepreneur. Husband of Alicia and the late Dorothy, father of Marc and David, father-in-law of Orna, adoring grandfather of Ben, and relentless competitor at pinochle. Service Sunday, May 19, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The family will be at home this week.

title: Board Details Plans to Alter College Exam
description: Representatives of the College Board laid out for officials of the University of California today the changes they proposed in the company's main college admission test taken by hundreds of thousands of the nation's high school students. The revamping includes the addition of a writing component and an increase in the number of years of mathematics covered.

title: Muslims and Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: CBS News Criticized for Showing Part of Video of Slain Reporter
description: A cable news program yesterday echoed the State and Justice Departments in expressing dismay at the CBS News decision to use about 15 seconds of the kidnappers' images of Daniel Pearl, alive and in captivity.

title: Albany's $90 Billion Budget Plan
description: TAX INCREASES The budget authorizes New York City to raise its cigarette tax, now 8 cents a pack, to $1.50. That would generate several hundred million dollars a year, though the city would be forced to share some of that revenue with the state. The state raised its own cigarette tax to $1.50 from $1.11 earlier this year. The budget also extends the state tax to other tobacco products, like chewing tobacco.

title: Market Place; WorldCom eases cash concerns by tapping a $2.65 billion credit line.
description: WORLDCOM said yesterday that it would tap a $2.65 billion credit line in a move that temporarily eases concern over access to cash as it advances its efforts to obtain more financing.

title: Dire Budget Warnings
description: The cries of distress are coming in from across the city.

title: A Modern Workplace, All Light, Warmth and Motion
description: Jay Chiat, who died last month at the age of 70, was a co-founder of Chiat/Day, best known for designing memorable ad campaigns for Apple computers, Nike sneakers and Energizer bunnies -- er, batteries. But he once described himself as a frustrated architect, and he treated his firm's work spaces as architectural adventures. Mr. Chiat hired Frank Gehry to design two avant-garde office spaces for the agency in Los Angeles. And though he sold his interest in the firm, now called TBWA/Chiat/Day, in 1995, his inspiration lived on.

title: Indonesia Plans to Sell 11% Stake in Overseas Telephone Company
description: P>

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEBAUN, MARY
description: DeBAUN-Mary. Beloved wife of the late Clinton DeBaun, loving mother of the late Louise von Arentschildt, cherished grandmother of Anne Dawson and Charles von Arentschildt and doting great grandmother to Charles T. von Arentschildt and Charles and Henry Dawson passed away peacefully in her sleep on May 13, 2002 at the age of 94. She will be dearly missed by all that knew and loved her. Contributions in her memory may be made to your favorite charity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUSH, GRAHAM M. JR.
description: BRUSH-Graham M. Jr., 78, of Warren, CT, on May 14, 2002. Husband of Katharine Van R. Brush, father of Graham M. Brush III and Jonathan H. Brush, brother of Donald K. Brush, grandfather of Patrick and Keelan. No services. Donations in his memory may be made to Eden Institute, 14 Logan Drive, Princeton, NJ 08540.

title: Players Take Note of Balanced Celtics
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 15  The Nets know that the Boston Celtics await them  if they don't squander a three-games-to-one lead over the Charlotte Hornets.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Guerrilla Leader Released
description: The province's most prominent Protestant paramilitary leader, Johnny Adair, was paroled from prison and greeted by hundreds of cheering supporters and a Champagne reception at his Belfast home. Mr. Adair, 38, began a 16-year sentence in 1994 but was released under a general amnesty in the 1998 peace accord before being jailed again for continued paramilitary activity. Under his leadership, the Ulster Defense Association is believed to have killed 20 Roman Catholic civilians. The police said they would put him under round-the-clock surveillance. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, EVELYN
description: LEVIN-Evelyn. Temple Beth Sholom, Roslyn Heights, NY mourns the passing of Evelyn Levin, wife of Past-President Monte Levin. Our heartfelt condolences to the family. Alan B. Lucas, Rabbi Dr. Rose Schecter, President

title: Healthy Morariu Expects to Return to Court
description: Dr. Albin Morariu had delivered difficult diagnoses before, but when the blood work had his daughter's name on it, when the test results belied her image as a fit, young tennis pro, all medical detachment was lost.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Rebels Avenge A Leader's Death
description: A Web site run by Chechen separatists said rebels had executed the man who poisoned the rebel leader Khattab, an Arab warlord who was reportedly killed on March 19. Russia's domestic intelligence agency, the F.S.B., announced last month that it had spent a year manipulating divisions among the rebels and had provoked the killing of Khattab, who led Islamic militants against Russian forces in Chechyna. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Sinn Fein Alters Appeal To Expand Its Influence
description: As an Irish Republican Army guerrilla in the 1980's, Martin Ferris tried to smuggle weapons into County Kerry and spent 10 years in prison for it. As a candidate for Sinn Fein, the I.R.A.'s political party, he is now campaigning to spend the next five years in Dublin's Parliament.

title: The Pimlico 13
description: Four survivors of the Kentucky Derby, including the winner, and nine fresh horses will contend in the 127th running of the Preakness Stakes on Saturday. The selections were made in order of preference by Joe Drape; the morning line was provided by Frank Carulli, the oddsmaker at Pimlico Race Course.

title: Journey to Havana
description: Considering how hard the United States and Cuba have worked to torment one another over the last four decades, it was startling the other day to see Jimmy Carter in short sleeves and a baseball cap tossing the ceremonial first pitch at a game in Havana. Mr. Carter's visit to Cuba this week doesn't mean relations with Havana are about to come out of the ice age, but his trip has shown why it makes far more sense to engage in an open dialogue with Mr. Castro and his nation than to shun them as ideological lepers. It is a shame that President Bush still seems to think that preventing American trade and ideas from crossing the Straits of Florida will loosen Mr. Castro's grip on power.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: MISSOURI: PROPOSED BAN ON PHOTOS IN BARNS Photographers who take pictures of animals in barns or breeding and research centers without the owners' permission would face a $1,000 fine and a year in jail under proposed legislation. The sponsor, Representative Ken Legan, Republican of Halfway, said it was aimed at undercover reporters and others who took photographs or made videotapes to be used in a "derogatory manner." Mr. Legan, a cattle farmer, said hog farmers had urged him to sponsor the bill after unflattering reports about their operations.

title: Hip-Hop Head-Spinning, But With a French Twist
description: The dancers in Compagnie Kfig, a dazzling and experimental French hip-hop troupe, can spin on their heads and lock into robotic moves like the best street virtuosos.

title: Man Says Dead Girls' Photo Led Him to Become Informer
description: Mitchell Burns, white haired at 75, said he used to be a believer in the Ku Klux Klan, back when talk of integration here had people lining up to join. But then a man from the federal government showed him pictures of four dead girls, and he changed his mind.

title: Economic Scene; The muscle-bound dollar, a pillar of the strong American expansion during the last decade, may have turned into an Achilles' heel.
description: THE dollar has long been the wild card in the economic outlook. Its surprising strength in the 1990's helped keep inflation in check by reducing import prices. A high dollar also attracted hundreds of billions of dollars in investment to compensate for the low savings rate among Americans. And while the dollar rose more than 40 percent since 1995, the gross domestic product kept growing strongly, anyway. The high dollar greatly raised world prices for the nation's manufacturing exports, but record trade deficits only partly offset other fast-growing components of G.D.P.

title: National Briefing: South
description: FLORIDA: LAW BANS FAKE CHILD-CUSTODY PAPERS Gov. Jeb Bush signed into law a bill that makes the falsification of documents related to child custody a felony. The move was prompted by the case of Rilya Wilson, 5, who has been missing for 16 months despite being under state protection. Department of Children and Families officials said they did not know about the disappearance because a caseworker filed false documents.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 30 about a survey sent by the White House to top administration officials, seeking information on their contacts with the Enron Corporation, misspelled the surname of a spokesman who said the administration would cooperate with reasonable requests from Congress for information. He is Scott McClellan, not McLellan.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Disappointing Forecast At LVMH
description: The world's largest maker of luxury goods, LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton, said profit would probably grow by more than 10 percent this year, a figure that is less than investors expected. LVMH made a similar forecast last year, but had to reduce the target three times after the Sept. 11 attacks. The chairman. Bernard Arnault, told shareholders yesterday that he expected a ''substantial rebound'' after the company's second-half loss in 2001. Shares in LVMH fell 60 cents, or 1 percent, to 59.15 euros. In the first quarter this fiscal year, revenue rose 8 percent, helped by the sales of luxury goods and Champagne. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Monitors That Can Kick The Brightness Up a Notch
description: A conventional cathode-ray-tube monitor is something of a dim bulb. It can't match a liquid-crystal display in brightness, and because of the demands of high resolution it is dimmer than a standard television set, even though it uses the same technology.

title: 'Ha-Ha, I'm in Hawaii': Automatic E-Mail Replies
description: Q. How do I set up an automatic reply to tell people who e-mail me that I will not be answering my mail while I am on vacation?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, ARNOLD
description: LEVY-Arnold. On Tuesday, May 14, 2002, of Washington, DC. Beloved husband of Clarice Leiner Levy. Devoted father of Joan Layton (William) Furth, Andrew Harris Levy (Tovah Feldshuh), Laurie Levy (Yves Gerard) Issembert. Cherished grandfather of Elisabeth Layton (Louis Jacobson), Julie Layton, G. Brandon Levy, Amanda Claire Levy, Matthew Levy Issembert, Valerie Levy Issembert. Funeral service today, May 16th at 10:30AM at Washington Hebrew Congregation. Family will be sitting Shiva Saturday sundown through Sunday evening at the residence of Clarice Levy. In lieu of flowers, expressions of sympathy in his name may be made to the American Jewish Committee, Washington Hebrew Congregation, or the charity of your choice.

title: Playoffs At Risk If Players Strike
description: Baseball players have struck at the start of the season, and they have struck during the season. They have also struck before the season, during spring training. Now they are discussing the possibility of striking after the season -- at the outset of the playoffs.

title: Maida Abrams, 63, Dutch-Art Collector and Advocate for the Disabled
description: Maida Stocker Abrams, a prominent collector of Dutch art and an advocate for the disabled, died last Thursday in Boston. She was 63 and lived in Newton, Mass.

title: Sam Walton, 59, Jets Tackle Who Wound Up Homeless
description: Sam Walton, who as a rookie started every regular-season game at right tackle during the New York Jets' Super Bowl season of 1968, but who ended up a homeless vagrant, was found dead in a vacant apartment in Memphis on Sunday night, the police said. He was 59.

description: Wal-Mart Seeks Approval To Buy a California Bank

description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Couple Remain In Jail In Girl's Death
description: A couple are being held in lieu of $500,000 bail in connection with the fatal plunge of a 9-year-old deaf and blind girl from a third-story apartment in Chicago. The girl's mother, Sundas Balwa, 33, and her partner, Shakir al-Shahien, 37, face charges of endangering the life of a child, a misdemeanor. Ms. Balwa also is accused of criminal negligence of a disabled person, a felony. The police said the girl, Parwin Husan, had been tied to a radiator and was apparently left alone, broke free and jumped or fell out the window. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Trying to Get Beyond the Role of the Maid; Hispanic Actors Are Seen as Underrepresented, With the Exception of One Part
description: Lupe Ontiveros's idea of a plum role is a Hispanic heroine, someone like the union organizer Dolores Huerta, a founder of the United Farm Workers, or perhaps the 17th-century Mexican poet and nun Sor Juana Ins de la Cruz, often viewed as the first feminist of the Americas.

title: Time to Hop, in a Lindy Kind of Way
description: Janice Wilson envisioned a gleaming career as a corporate lawyer when she entered the Columbia University School of Law in 1995. But fate intervened when Ms. Wilson happened to see a performance by a venerable Lindy Hopper named Dawn Hampton, who had danced at Savoy Ballroom in Harlem many decades earlier; Ms. Wilson fell in love with the popular dance forms of the swing era. And so the American Institute of Vernacular Jazz Dance was born, and with it the free Harlem Jazz Dance Festival, which will spread out this weekend over Marcus Garvey Park at 124th Street near Mount Morris Park West in Harlem.

title: War Emblem Getting No Respect for Preakness
description: Two weeks ago, there was widespread confusion about which 3-year-old might win the Kentucky Derby. But as the post positions were drawn today for the 127th running of the Preakness Stakes, there was finally a consensus: hardly anyone associated with the race believes that War Emblem can run away with the second leg of thoroughbred racing's Triple Crown.

description: The Man Behind Tony?

title: PFIZER SAYS PRICING OF LIPITOR FACES WIDER U.S. INQUIRY
description: Pfizer Inc. said the Justice Department was investigating the price of its cholesterol drug Lipitor from 1998 through 2001. Pfizer, based in New York, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that the Justice Department was examining whether grants to health plans and pharmacy-benefit managers should qualify as rebates. That would entitle the government to a bigger discount on the drug under best-price rules for Medicaid. Pfizer disclosed in March that the Justice Department was investigating Lipitor prices for 1998 through 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATZKIN, ROSE
description: MATZKIN-Rose. The World Confederation of United Zionists mourn the death of Rose Matzkin, former National President of Hadassah, and longtime leader in The Executive of The Confederation. We honor her memory. Marlene Post Kalman Sultanik Co-Presidents

title: A Brooding Introvert, Awakened by Passion
description: American Ballet Theater worked a miracle on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. It gave an absolutely electrifying performance of a choreographically uneven work: John Cranko's ''Onegin.''

title: House Republicans Press Senate on Cloning
description: As the Senate considers legislation to restrict human cloning, Republicans in the House of Representatives today tried to rally opposition to the research. They produced a memorandum from the Justice Department saying any legislation short of a ban would be difficult to enforce and heard from a scientist who vowed to clone a baby this year.

title: The Long Goodbye
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Economy Shrinks
description: New York City's economy continued to shrink in the first quarter of 2002, and personal income tax payments plunged, according to data released yesterday by William C. Thompson Jr., the city comptroller. The gross city product, a measure of the overall economy, dropped by 2.6 percent, even as a similar measure of the national economy, the gross domestic product, grew by 5.8 percent. Personal income tax payments, which the comptroller's office uses as a guideline to measure New Yorkers' income, fell by 20 percent from last year. Included was a 12 percent drop in withholding taxes and a 38.9 percent drop in estimated tax payments. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: The Economics of Ink
description: To the Editor:

title: Aid Meant For the Hungry
description: Hunger still threatens millions in North Korea, and one symptom of the harsh conditions is the desperation of North Korean refugees trying in the past few days to elude Chinese police and seek asylum at American and Japanese consulates in China. As the Bush administration prepares to restart talks with North Korea, food, as well as weapons and troops, should be on the agenda. Despite the tense relationship between the two countries, the United States is the leading donor of food to North Korea, which cannot feed its 22 million people. American negotiators should insist on assurances that this aid is reaching those most in need.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Crackdown In The Wild Northwest
description: Officials have banned the display of arms in the semi-autonomous northwestern tribal areas bordering Afghanistan, local officials said. The ban comes as the United States is pressing Pakistan to step up policing of the border area while American and Pakistani troops hunt for Taliban and Qaeda fugitives in the area. ''The idea behind stopping the open display of arms is to control the law and order situation,'' a local administrator said. Howard W. French (NYT)

description: INTERNET

title: Metal as Warm As Brandy
description: ''WINTER looms large in the Canadian imagination,'' said Brigitte Shim, an architect whose buildings, with their layering of warm materials and graceful blending with the landscape, are helping to put this city on the design map.

description: KLAPHOLTZ-Anne. March 22, 1902 to May 16, 1994. Remembered. Francene

title: Dutch Veer to Right After Candidate's Killing
description: Dutch politics took a startling swing to the right in parliamentary elections as followers of the slain populist Pim Fortuyn turned out in force today to push his anti-immigrant and law-and-order agenda.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Prison Term For Editor
description: The editor of a leading pro-reform newspaper has been sentenced to six months in prison on charges of spreading anti-government information and insulting the authorities. Mohsen Mirdamadi, who is also the head of Parliament's foreign and national security commission, was banned from press activities for four years and his newspaper, Norouz, will be shut for six months. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: CBS adds seven new series and tries to make a dent in NBC's dominance at 10 p.m.
description: EXPRESSING confidence about an improving competitive position, even among young viewers once considered beyond its reach, CBS announced a fall schedule yesterday tailored to attack some strongholds of the ratings leader, NBC.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Victim's Mother Pleads For Killer
description: The mother of a convenience store clerk stabbed to death in 1993 in Corpus Christi has asked the state Board of Pardons and Paroles to spare the life of her son's killer. The woman, Lana Norris, said Johnny Joe Martinez, convicted of murdering her son Clay Peterson, had repented. Ms. Norris made the request after spending more than four hours with Mr. Martinez, 29, in a prison mediation program. He is scheduled to be executed on Wednesday. Jim Yardley (NYT)

title: U.S. India-Pakistan Mission Fails to Ease the Standoff
description: A senior American diplomat ended a two-day visit to India and Pakistan today aimed at reducing the military standoff between the nuclear-armed rivals but reported little sign of progress, saying ''this is not the work of one trip.''
