title: Q&A / Takashi Asai : How to escape Japan's next crisis
description: In the early 1990s, Takashi Asai, a financial reporter at Mainichi Shimbun, a Japanese daily, published a series of books warning of the coming disaster in which banks would face a crisis, prices would fall and life-time employment would crumble. At the time, they were not taken seriously. Today they read like a recounting of the economic events of the past decade in Japan. In 1996, Asai started a publishing enterprise, Daini-kaientai, which, among other things, issues financial newsletters to wealthy individual investors. He also runs an investors' club. His fans like his no-holds-barred critique of government policy and his bold counsel on how to defend one's wealth, including suggestions that people move to New Zealand. Asai believes the Japanese economy will probably collapse within a few years, possibly as early as next year, and that the government's assurances that it can never go bankrupt should not be accepted. He discussed ways that individuals can protect their assets with Miki Tanikawa.

title: Panel Wants to Toughen Edison School Contracts
description: The state commission overseeing the Philadelphia public school system today reaffirmed its plans to cede management of 20 low-performing schools to Edison Schools Inc., but said it would build safeguards into its contracts with the company to limit any academic disruptions at those schools should Edison's financial condition worsen.

title: German Metalworkers' Union Wins Higher Wages
description: After nearly two weeks of one-day strikes at scores of companies, Germany's giant metalworkers' union reached a deal with industry that will increase wages by 4 percent this year.

title: Devil Rays Send Colome to Minors
description: One day after nearly instigating a bench-clearing brawl with his wildness, the hard-throwing Tampa Bay right-hander Jess Colome was optioned yesterday to the Devil Rays' Class AAA affiliate in Durham, N.C.

title: CURTIS BOYS AND GIRLS WIN
description: Curtis captured the girls' and boys' titles yesterday in the Staten Island Public Schools Athletic League outdoor borough championships at Tottenville High School. The girls won with 186 points and the boys retained their crown with 244.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MURPHY, NEIL J.
description: MURPHY-Neil J. 5/16/51-7/14/00. Dearest Son, Happy Birthday. You will always be in our thoughts and prayers. Neil, the marine's son, SEMPER FI. Mom, Dad, John Keith, Colin, Joanmarie & Eilee

title: In Newark, Newcomer's Allure Can't Topple Local Favorite
description: He was outspent by half a million dollars. He lagged in the latest polls by as many six percentage points. And perhaps most galling of all, Sharpe James -- for 32 years a fixture in politics here -- was cast by his opponent as a machine-backed dinosaur who had failed the city by ignoring the common folk as he brought better times to the downtown area.

title: U.S. and Europe Investigating Online Currency Trade Venture
description: The Justice Department and the European Commission said today that they were looking into an online currency trading venture run by some of the world's largest banks for possible anticompetitive behavior.

title: Power Giants Have Trouble Raising Cash For Plants
description: Accused of accounting chicanery and illegally inflating power prices, companies that generate much of the nation's electricity have lost the confidence of investors. For the moment, they are finding it nearly impossible to raise money for new plants, raising the risk of future power shortages, industry experts say.

title: National Briefing
description: SOUTHWEST

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fire Chief's Remains Identified
description: The remains of Deputy Chief Raymond M. Downey, the New York City fire commander who was a nationally known expert on rescue operations, have been identified, eight months after he disappeared in the collapse of the World Trade Center. Chief Downey, a firefighter for 39 years, was identified through DNA analysis, according to the city medical examiner's office. As the head of Special Operations Command, Chief Downey directed rescue operations at collapsed buildings. Asked once why he searched so long for remains of the presumed dead, he cited the families left behind. ''The only way you can relieve some of their sorrow,'' he said, ''is to successfully recover the bodies of the people they loved.''

title: Egan Says Claims of Abuse Will Go Right to Prosecutors
description: Under pressure from prosecutors, Cardinal Edward M. Egan announced yet another policy change yesterday regarding priests who abuse minors, promising to pass on allegations of abuse directly to district attorneys.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Bid For Retailer's Shares
description: The British retailer Kingfisher said it offered $4.6 billion for the 45 percent of the French home improvement giant Castorama Dubois that it does not already own. Castorama rejected the offer as insufficient, and investors bid Castorama's stock up, expecting a higher offer. Kingfisher also said that it would spin off its Comet electrical goods chain and issue stock worth $2.9 billion to pay for the moves, and that its chief executive, Geoffrey Mulcahy, would step down. Investors have blamed Mr. Mulcahy for a two-thirds slump in Kingfisher's share price since 1999. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITTEN, MARVIN
description: WHITTEN-Marvin. Formerly of Baldwin, NY, died May 15, 2002 in Sarasota, FL. He was 81. Adoring husband of Elsbeth, beloved father of Donald, dear brother of Laurette, and cherished friend to many. Donations in his memory may be made to the Parkinson's Foundation or a charity of your choice.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Auditor Quits Chip Maker's Account
description: Applied Digital Systems, a technology company that is known for its skin-embeddable Verichip device, announced yesterday that its auditor had quit over an accounting dispute. The firm, Grant Thornton, said a noncash $14 million expense from the acquisition of Medical Accounting Systems should be recorded as a one-time charge. This would result in a loss for the company in the first quarter. Applied Digital says that the charge should be spread over time, and it is asking the Securities and Exchange Commission for a ruling on the question. Like many technology companies, Applied Digital has experienced stock price gyrations over the last two years, dropping from a high of $15 in January 2000 to under 50 cents in March. The shares have rebounded to as much as $2.40 as the Verichip has headed toward market, but they dropped 25 cents, or 17.6 percent, to $1.17, after yesterday's announcement.

title: Budget Office Reports Deficit Is Understated
description: New York City's money shortage is so severe that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's worst-case plan for $500 million in contingency budget cuts may not be enough to balance the budget, the city's Independent Budget Office warned yesterday.

title: Family Politics Shift to the Keyboard
description: IN a promotional mailing, EarthLink, the Internet service provider, called it ''the Harris family problem'': ''Lisa wants to use the phone. Bobby wants to download MP3's. Mom and Dad are going crazy.''

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Detective Critically Injured
description: A veteran police detective driving to work was critically injured yesterday when a steel plate cut through her windshield and struck her in the head, officials said. The detective, Jeanine Farrell, 41, was struck about 6:30 a.m. as she drove west to the Brooklyn Battery Tunnel, the police said. The steel plate, which an official said measured about 12 inches by 18 inches, either fell off a westbound truck or was kicked up from the roadway by a car in front of hers, the police said. The detective, an 18-year veteran of the department, suffered a broken jaw, facial lacerations and a brain contusion, the police said. She was reported in critical but stable condition at Lutheran Hospital. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Drug Shares and Hewlett Drag Down S.& P. and Dow
description: The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell yesterday, led by drug shares, after Abbott Laboratories said that a plant failed inspection and Schering-Plough said that it was being investigated by the Food and Drug Administration.

title: COMPUTER ASSOCIATES NAMES LEAD DIRECTOR FOR BOARD
description: A spokesman for Computer Associates, the software company co-founded by Charles B. Wang, confirmed last night that Lewis Ranieri, one of its directors and the former vice chairman of Salomon Brothers, had been named by the board to be lead director. In that position, Mr. Ranieri will represent the independent directors on the board, speaking on their behalf to outsiders and conducting any separate meetings they may hold apart from the full board, which is led by Mr. Wang as chairman. The board also gave the chairmanship of its audit committee to the director Walter Schuetze, the former chief accountant at the Securities and Exchange Commission. The S.E.C. is among several agencies that are investigating whether Computer Associates inflated its earnings in the late 1990's as part of a plan to enrich Mr. Wang and other senior executives. Diana B. Henriques (NYT)

title: Another Plot Against Tough Sheriff, With a Twist
description: As threats against him go, Sheriff Joe Arpaio of Maricopa County said, this one was strictly routine. So three men wanted him dead. Big deal. After all, Mr. Arpaio calls himself, ''America's toughest sheriff,'' a lawman despised by criminals for an uncompromising style of incarceration that includes chain gangs, cheap food, no smoking and no television.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Man Sentenced In 2 Killings
description: A Bronx man who strangled his girlfriend's mother and father and dumped their bodies in the East River was sentenced yesterday to two consecutive terms of 15 years to life in prison. The man, Eric Louissaint, 21, pleaded guilty last month to two counts of second-degree murder for killing Stephen Leung, 55, and his wife, Chilin, 41, in their East Harlem apartment in November 2000. The victims' daughter, Connie Leung, who was 17 at the time of the murders, was also charged and is awaiting trial. Police officials have said that race was a factor in the killings: the Leungs, who were immigrants from Hong Kong, were upset that their daughter was dating Mr. Louissaint, who is black. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Vote Set Today on Mexican Rail Merger
description: Mexican authorities are set to vote Thursday on a proposed railroad merger that would unite the country's second- and third-largest railways into one company with nationwide reach.

title: Kimberly Miles, 33, Recipient In a Rare Lung Transplant
description: Kimberly Miles, recipient of a lung transplant in November 2000 in an unusual operation in which her sister and a friend donated parts of their lungs, died on Monday in Minneapolis. She was 33.

title: Outbreak of Hospital Infection Is Tied to Worker's Drug Abuse
description: A string of mysterious infections at a hospital from 1998 to 1999 were traced to a most unexpected source, doctors are reporting today: a respiratory therapist who is suspected of having used a needle and syringe to steal a narcotic from the bags of intravenous medicine that were hanging by the bedsides of critically ill patients. The therapist is believed to have contaminated the medications while tapping into them.

title: Car Crashes At Restaurant And Kills 3 Employees
description: Three employees of a McDonald'swere killed early yesterday morning when a speeding car smashed through a restaurant branch in Mount Ephraim, N.J., a suburb southeast of Philadelphia, the authorities said. The driver and another employee were injured.

title: It's a Boulder, All Right, But Was It Once a Border?; Marker Lost to History Is Found (Maybe)
description: If only this were a simple story about a rock, the happy tale of a 10,000-year-old New York City artifact that is finally, in 2002, getting its proper due.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Summit Bombing Foiled, Police Say
description: The Basque separatist group E.T.A. planned to bomb a summit meeting of leaders from the European Union and Latin America this weekend, the police said. Two E.T.A. members were arrested in Madrid on Tuesday, and the police said they had found nearly 90 pounds of explosives ready for use in a car bomb and 400 pounds in an apartment. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: The Lightning-Rod Amendment
description: To the Editor:

title: Four Jets Begin Preliminary Talks
description: The Jets have begun preliminary talks with the agents for four veteran players who are entering the final years of their contracts.

title: 3 Ex-Chiefs Discover Perils Of Borrowing and Believing
description: They were among the corporate elite, three chief executives who made millions and were the leading citizens of their communities. Now they find themselves out of work and hundreds of millions of dollars in debt -- all because they were wrongly confident that their companies would never falter. Perhaps they should be known as the borrowing believers.

title: Cuomo Faults Pace of Downtown Recovery
description: Andrew M. Cuomo criticized the pace and management of the effort to rebuild Lower Manhattan yesterday, and said the governor should take control to end bickering among rival state agencies.

title: Desperately Seeking A Devil Rays Fan
description: The search for a particular species at Yankee Stadium yesterday focused on finding a person who was loyal, self-deprecating, brave, depressed and a bit zany. That description would seemingly fit a fan of the endlessly downtrodden Tampa Bay Devil Rays, especially if he or she had the temerity to wear the familiar green, blue, black and white colors in the Bronx.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: New Lottery Proposal
description: Less than three years after voters rejected a lottery for education, Gov. Donald Siegelman proposed another one, saying it was needed to finance the school system while avoiding tax increases. The governor, a Democrat running for re-election, won on a platform that endorsed instituting a lottery in 1998. But when the gambling measure failed, the state struggled to balance its budget. Mr. Siegelman's political opponents and religious leaders promised to fight the new proposal. David Firestone (NYT)

title: Showrooms Jump to Melrose Place
description: Furniture showrooms used to be concentrated in the Pacific Design Center, a soulless mall in West Hollywood. Now, Melrose Place is becoming a place to go, as showrooms for professional decorators move there and reopen as boutiques.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERNEV, BEATRICE LEVIN
description: CHERNEV - Beatrice Levin. Passed away at home on May 15, 2002. She was the beloved wife of Bernard her devoted husband of 52 years who predeceased her. She is survived by daughters and sons-in-law Nancy and Jeffrey Weissman, Wendy and Dr. Stuart Breiterman, JoAnne Adlerstein and Lee Adlerstein, dear friend Seymour L. Goldstein, sister Pearl Bell, eight grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Services are today, 10:30 A.M. at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: It's D'Amico's Turn to Toss a Two-Hitter, and Mets Win Again
description: The Mets do not score many runs, so pitchers make do with what they get. They needed a shutout to win Tuesday night and another one tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAAS, MICHAEL
description: MAAS-Michael. On May 12, 2002, at the age of 70. Funeral Mass on Friday, May 17, at 10:30 A.M., at St. Thomas More, 65 East 89th Street.

title: Schering-Plough Says F.D.A. Investigation May Focus on Some of Its Products
description: Federal authorities are conducting a criminal investigation that may focus on one or more products made by Schering-Plough, the company said yesterday in a financial report.

title: Novelists Court The Braces Set
description: Two of the most widely anticipated children's books that will be out there this fall have been written not by traditional children's novel writers (or even by writers who unwittingly produce juvenile work), but by authors known for their popular and acclaimed adult books.

title: Drugs, Terror and Tuna: How Goals Clash
description: This industrial city on the southern coast of Mindanao Island illustrates how America's various strategic aims in the wars on drugs and terrorism can clash, alienating important allies engaged in battling terrorism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHAN, BERTRAM
description: KAHAN-Bertram. On May 14, 2002. Beloved husband of Evelyn. Devoted father of Marvin, Gerald and Edward. Father-in-law of Lynn and Nancy. Cherished grandfather of Robin, Adam, Jodi and Jill. Loving great-grandfather of Alex, Remi, Libby and Hannah Rose. Services Thursday 1:00pm at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Devil Rays Jump on Hernndez and Hold On
description: Manager Joe Torre said Orlando Hernndez experienced stiffness in his upper back in last night's game at Yankee Stadium. A defiant Hernndez vigorously countered, ''There is nothing,'' when questioned about his back's condition after the game.

title: Merrill Conflict-of-Interest Hearing Rescheduled
description: Merrill Lynch got another reprieve yesterday when a court hearing to schedule testimony by stock analysts and executives of the firm was postponed for a second time.

title: Warrant Issued for Eye Doctor Who Operated on Mentally Ill
description: Federal authorities have obtained an arrest warrant for an ophthalmologist they suspect of performing unnecessary eye surgery on mentally ill residents of adult homes in New York City, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRYE, JOHN HOWARD ''JUNIE''
description: FRYE-John Howard ''Junie'' Frye, Jr, 86. Beloved husband of Claire A. Frye, father to June F. Johnston and her husband J. Lawrence, brother to Rosamond F. Smith, grandfather to Mark Johnston & his wife Stella Hetelekidis, MD, Marley LeBeau and her husband Michael, great-grandfather to Alex, Adam and Laura Johnston and Madeline LeBeau. Stepfather to Stephen Varano, Andrea Varano and Jennifer Baraldi. Visitation 4-8 PM Friday at the Bibber Memorial Chapel, Wells, ME. Funeral 11 AM Saturday at Chapel of Harmony Grove Cemetery, Salem, MA. Donations to Lockie Weir Memorial Fund, c/o Florence Duffy, Sherbrooke, Nova Scotia, BOJ 3CO, or St. Mary's River Association, PO Box 179, Sherbrooke, Nova Scotia, BOJ 3CO.

title: Grand Jury Hears Testimony Alleging Sex Abuse by Priest
description: At least six men who say they were abused by the same priest testified about their experiences this week before a special grand jury formed to examine how the Diocese of Rockville Centre has handled abuse allegations.

title: Summer Rates in Grenada
description: The Spice Island Beach Resort, a 66-room hotel on Grand Anse Beach in Grenada, is following the lead of most other Caribbean resorts by dropping prices for the summer. All-inclusive rates (three meals a day, afternoon tea, non-motorized watersports) start at $470 a night per person, based on double occupancy, through Dec. 14, about $100 less than in high season. Some rooms have private pools, and there is a spa on the grounds. Call (800) 223-9815 or visit www.spicebeacresort.com .

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Serbs Surrender To Tribunal
description: Two Serbs indicted on war crimes charges flew to The Hague to face the United Nations tribunal. Milan Martic, 56, the former president of the rebel Serb Republic of Krajina in Croatia, is accused of ordering attacks on the Croatian capital, Zagreb, in which seven people were killed in 1995. Mile Mrksic, 54, is a former Yugoslav Army general whose forces attacked the town of Vukovar in Croatia in 1991 and killed some 250 people, many of them civilians, at a hospital. Five people have turned themselves in since Yugoslavia, under heavy pressure from Western nations, agreed last month to cooperate more fully with the tribunal. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Regional Antiterror Effort
description: Defense ministers from Russia, China and three central Asian nations decided to pool their efforts to combat terrorism, extremism and separatist movements, saying they posed a threat to the entire region. The countries, which formed the Shanghai Cooperation Organization last year to discuss security issues, all face either internal extremist or separatist movements, led by Russia's long-running war in Chechnya, or fear infiltration by terrorist groups after the defeat of the Taliban in Afghanistan. Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan joined Russia and China in the move; the sixth member, Uzbekistan, boycotted the meeting, apparently to protest Russia's formation of military alliances with other nearby nations. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: ADMITTING ERRORS, ARAFAT PROMISES WAVE OF REFORM
description: Yasir Arafat responded today to growing Palestinian and international pressure for reform by acknowledging mistakes and promising changes to his administration and new elections, though he presented scant details.

title: The But-What-if Factor
description: The Senate agrees with the House that cloning to make a human baby should be outlawed before such a new chapter in ''Frankenstein'' begins. At issue, however, is a related proposal to ban therapeutic cloning -- the creation of cells that the body will not reject -- to repair organs and combat disease.

title: Doctor Hints That Hingis May Retire Early
description: The path of Martina Hingis's plunge in the ranking has contained a series of strange side trips over the past year, including the trial of her stalker in Miami, the filing of a $40 million lawsuit in Manhattan against an Italian shoe manufacturer and a season-ending injury that defied her reputation for durability.

title: Broad Tax Sought on Music Storage in Canada
description: IN the United States, the recording industry has dealt with music copying mostly through legal action and the development of anti-copying technology. In Canada, however, the industry is going after cash.

title: A Long Shot Is Better Than No Shot at All
description: After the jubilation ended on Monday night and the chants of ''Beat L.A.!'' subsided, Chris Webber tried to put his team's impressive series-clinching victory over the Dallas Mavericks in the Western Conference semifinals into perspective.

title: Spy's Wife Speaks, After Taking a Lie Test
description: In the 15 months since her husband's arrest as a Russian spy, Bonnie Hanssen has struggled to maintain her public silence in the face of a torrent of disclosures about her life with a man she thought she knew.

title: Metro Matters; At Reservoir, An Ugly Fence May Soon Fall
description: IT is easy to hate, hard to change. There have been money problems and jurisdictional problems, bureaucratic barriers and the greatest barrier of all, inertia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAREY, EDWARD M.
description: CAREY-Edward M. To the eldest of our generation, you showed us determination, style, perserverance and wit. Thank you for all you have done. Love, your brother, Governor Hugh L. Carey

title: Kmart Reports $2.42 Billion Annual Loss
description: Confirming that shoppers and shareholders had witnessed its worst performance on record, the Kmart Corporation announced yesterday that it lost $2.42 billion, or $4.89 a share, last year because of strategic mistakes and the keen competition in the discount retail business.

title: Big Korean Chip Maker Fires Top Executives and Salomon
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 16  Hynix Semiconductor fired about one-third of its 60 senior executives today and discharged Salomon Smith Barney, the American investment firm that had helped to engineer the ill-fated deal to sell the company's memory-chip plants to Micron Technology .

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BID FOR RETAILER'S SHARES The British retailer Kingfisher said it offered $4.6 billion for the 45 percent of the French home improvement giant Castorama Dubois that it does not already own. Castorama rejected the offer as insufficient, and investors bid Castorama's stock up, expecting a higher offer. Kingfisher also said that it would spin off its Comet electrical goods chain and issue stock worth $2.9 billion to pay for the moves, and that its chief executive, Geoffrey Mulcahy, would step down. Investors have blamed Mr. Mulcahy for a two-thirds slump in Kingfisher's share price since 1999. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ELI
description: COHEN-Eli. It is with deep sorrow and regret that we mourn the untimely passing of our friend and esteemed partner, Eli Cohen. From his start in the firm in 1958 until his retirement in September 2000, Eli spent his entire professional career at the firm. With that came a keen business sense and remarkable vision. As Co-Managing Partner from 1992 to 2000, Eli's leadership and guidance is considered a tremendous factor in making the firm the success it is today. Known as ''Flash'' because of his ability to get a job done quickly, Eli's energy was an infectious force felt by all. He was not only our business partner but a cherished friend whose intellect and good humor will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Marilyn, his daughters Jill and Laurie, their husbands Eddie and Michael and his adored grandchildren. We will all miss you. The Partners and Staff of Anchin, Block & Anchin, LLP

title: Lakers Back in a Familiar Place
description: LOS ANGELES, May 15  Trailing the San Antonio Spurs by 12 points late in the second quarter Tuesday night, the Los Angeles Lakers were in a familiar spot in this year's playoffs, struggling to discover their rhythm.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Enron Partners Argue for Removal of Law Firm
description: With billions at stake and bitterness in the air, a group of Enron's business partners argued yesterday for the removal of Milbank Tweed Hadley & McCloy as counsel to the Enron creditors committee, claiming that conflicts of interest prevented Milbank from fairly representing the concerns of everyone owed money by Enron.

title: Worlds Old and New Meld in a Dream State
description: H. T. Chen has managed over the years to blend traditional Chinese dance and Western modern dance in ways that allow the traditional to retain its identity. A perfect example is "The Dream," a new work presented by H. T. Chen & Dancers on Saturday night at the Mulberry Street Theater.

title: Credit Suisse's First Quarter Shows Steep Drop in Earnings
description: Struggling to right its high-cost American investment banking arm and to cope with declining revenue in its once-steadfast insurance business, the Credit Suisse Group reported sharply lower net income for the first quarter of 2002 today and said it was ''cautious in its outlook'' for the rest of the year.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Princeton: Psychic Accused In Swindle
description: A psychic is accused of swindling a Plainsboro woman out of $183,000 in cash and jewelery. The psychic, Christine Evans, 32, persuaded the victim, 47, that she was possessed by an evil spirit from the 1800's, said Capt. Anthony V. Federico of the Princeton Borough Police Department. To rid herself of the spirit, the victim was told during various meetings to give the money and jewels to Ms. Evans, who then kept them, Captain Federico said. Ms. Evans was arrested on Monday and is being held at Mercer County Jail in $150,000 bail.

title: The Lightning-Rod Amendment
description: To the Editor:

title: For Your Big Graphics Files, A Wireless Speed Demon
description: Given that even high-speed household Internet connections do not exploit the full speed of the wireless networking standard known as 802.11b, or Wi-Fi, offering something almost five times faster seems a bit unnecessary. But Bradley Morse, vice president for marketing at D-Link, a maker of networking products, insists that there is a place for 54 megabit-per-second wireless networking. In fact, he said, ''54 megs is just the beginning.''

title: Diplomatic Memo; A Wider Atlantic: Europe Sees a Grotesque U.S.
description: To travel on this side of the Atlantic with Secretary of State Colin L. Powell is to catch a brief glimpse of a parallel universe: the heedless, insular, bellicose, unilateralist America seen by many European eyes.

title: Douglas Pike, Vietnam Expert, Dies at 77
description: Douglas Pike, who arrived in Vietnam as a government information officer the same month the Vietcong were formed and spent the rest of his life explaining the war in eight books and scores of articles, died on Monday at a hospital in Lubbock, Tex. He was 77.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHON, JOSEPH P.
description: MAHON-Joseph P. On May 15, 2002. Beloved husband of Connie (nee Giannone). Loving father of Linda Pasternack, Gary, Patrick, & Laura Marzella. Dear brother of Eugene, and Anna McHenry. Cherished grandfather of seven. Funeral on Friday, 9:30AM. from the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Rd, Bklyn. Mass of Christian Burial 10:30 AM St. Thomas Aquinas RC Church. Entombment Pinelawn Memorial Park. Visiting Thursday 2-5 and 7-10 P.M.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I think people feel betrayed. I do.''

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: FIRE CHIEF'S REMAINS IDENTIFIED The remains of Deputy Chief Raymond M. Downey, the New York City fire commander who was a nationally known expert on rescue operations, have been identified, eight months after he disappeared in the collapse of the World Trade Center. Chief Downey, a firefighter for 39 years, was identified through DNA analysis, according to the city medical examiner's office. As the head of Special Operations Command, Chief Downey directed rescue operations at collapsed buildings. Asked once why he searched so long for remains of the presumed dead, he cited the families left behind. "The only way you can relieve some of their sorrow," he said, "is to successfully recover the bodies of the people they loved."

description: In the shadow of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, when financial markets around the world were reeling, six private banks opened their doors in Spain's southern city of Seville.

title: William Morris And the Soul of Design
description: William Morris, a Socialist who created wallpapers and fabrics for some of the most fashionable homes in England, reviled the mass production of the 19th century and believed design should elevate the spirit. The Huntington Library in San Marino, near Los Angeles, is honoring his vision in a show, ''William Morris: Creating the Useful and the Beautiful,'' through Sept. 22. One display has wallpaper, above, by J. H. Dearle, one of Morris's designers. Information: (626) 405-2100.

description: The floor creaks,

title: Lindh Wants Charge Dropped Using Justice Dept. Argument
description: Lawyers for John Walker Lindh, the Californian accused of fighting with the Taliban, sought today to dismiss a firearms charge against him based in part on the Justice Department's new interpretation of the Second Amendment.

description: Defending Dot-Com U.

title: Newark Re-elects Mayor James
description: By winning his fifth term as mayor of Newark, and besting a strong young challenger, Sharpe James has proved how formidable his political skills are. His victory demonstrated that his support extends beyond his loyal backers in the unions, the city work force and the Democratic establishment. But the election also made clear that many people in Newark feel that the mayor's much-touted Newark Renaissance has not reached their neighborhoods. To secure his legacy, Mr. James must tend to those concerns, and the 25,000 voters who stood with his opponent, Cory Booker.

title: Town Rallies to Save Its Grocery and Its Vitality
description: The brick arches outside Price's Supermarket are still charred at the edges. But the glow of fluorescent light inside this town's only grocery store, which burned more than a year ago, and the flow of traffic on Gage Street said the store that this community of 800 rallied to rebuild was again open for business.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: INTEGRA LEADS THEFT TOTALS The Acura Integra , refashioned this year as the RSX, is stolen eight times more often than the average car in the 1999 and 2000 model years, according to a report by the Highway Loss Data Institute, an insurer-financed group. Based on insurance claims, the Honda-made Integra coupes and small sedans are also two and a half times more likely to be stolen than the second-ranking car, the Jeep Wrangler. Another Jeep, the Cherokee, was third. Peter T. Kilborn (NYT)

title: Castro's Door: Both Open and Closed
description: With President Fidel Castro sitting in the front row, Jimmy Carter chastised him Tuesday night about the failure of the Communist system to respect political rights. The Cuban nation watched on uncensored television. Mr. Castro said nothing.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on May 7 about women who bear children without assistance referred imprecisely to a method called Lotus birth. In it, the umbilical cord stays attached to the baby and to the placenta -- but not to the mother -- until it falls off spontaneously.

title: Group Says Agency Is Needed To Replace Elections Panel
description: Calling the Federal Election Commission a ''failed agency'' designed by Congress to be ineffective, a group of campaign watchdogs today proposed replacing it with an independent agency headed by a single administrator.

title: Defending Dot-Com U.
description: To the Editor:

title: Pamper Your Pixels: Making the Most of the Monitor
description: IT is one of the paradoxes of the computer age that the object that users spend the most time looking at, the monitor, is often the most overlooked.

title: Russian Blunder Lets Americans Win
description: A remarkable stretch drive in the final session of the Cavendish Pairs in Las Vegas on Sunday gave a victory to Steve Weinstein and Bobby Levin. They moved from 15th to first in the field of 60 and repeated their 1999 victory. Weinstein has now won four times in 10 years, which is astonishing. No other player in the 28-year history of this world-class event has won more than twice.

title: A.I.G. Shares Dip As Chief Seeks To Cheer Holders

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RONDELL, THOMAS
description: RONDELL-Thomas. September 16, 1933-May 11, 2002. In Palo Alto on May 11, 2002 Tom passed away after a courageous battle with pancreatic cancer. He was 68 years young. Tom was a native of New York City and had lived in Northern California since 1966, most recently in Mountain View. A loving and supportive father with a great sense of humor, Tom is survived by his daughters, Lexi Rhorer and Gabi Rondell, his sonin-law, Trent Rhorer, and grandson, Jordan Thomas Rhorer. Tom is also survived by his loving companion, Jo Chisolm of Santa Cruz, his daughters' mother, Joan Sperans, and his daughter Gabi's boyfriend, Riaz Shivji. A public relations professional for over forty years, Tom was passionate about spending time with his daughters, their friends and family, his girlfriend Jo and his friends. He was also crazy about and a devoted fan of Stanford tennis and the San Francisco Giants baseball and attended as many sporting events as possible. For the past several years Tom volunteered for the Stanford men's tennis team. Most of all Tom loved befriending people. He will be greatly missed by his friends and family. In lieu of sending flowers please make donations to the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network Community (PanCAN) at P.O. Box 1010, Torrance, CA 90505 (www.pancan.com) or to the Stanford Tennis Team in memory of Tom Rondell. Checks should be made payable to Stanford University and sent to Men's Tennis Office, Dept of Athletics, Stanford, CA, 94305-6150. A service and reception celebrating Tom's life will be held on Saturday, May 18th at 2 P.M. at the home of his dear friends, Dr. and Mrs. George Waltuch, at 12675 La Cresta Drive in Los Altos Hills.

description: New York University said yesterday that the federal government had agreed to cover some of the expenses incurred from the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. Ms. Schiller, 40, had been senior vice president for CNN Productions in Atlanta, the long-form programming division at CNN, part of AOL Time Warner. Ms. Schiller will start in early summer.

description: After years of struggling with obscurity and financial problems, the Southwest Museum, one of the country's finest collections of American Indian artifacts, is on the verge of announcing a broad but disputed financial partnership with a local Indian tribe.

description: The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation approved a $350 million expansion of grant programs yesterday to encourage businesses to stay in downtown Manhattan or move there, raising the total available for those programs to more than $1 billion.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Synogogue Fire Ruled Accidental
description: Fire officials said yesterday that a blaze on Tuesday that gutted a 96-year-old synagogue in the Rockaways was caused by faulty basement wiring. The fire was initially called suspicious because the synogogue, Congregation Derech Emunoh, at 199 Beach 67th Street, had been the target of an arsonist twice in the 1990's. The two-story frame building was rebuilt after the previous fires, but the authorities said the extensive damage on Tuesday might preclude rebuilding. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: THE HAGUE: SERBS SURRENDER TO TRIBUNAL Two Serbs indicted on war crimes charges flew to The Hague to face the United Nations tribunal. Milan Martic, 56, the former president of the rebel Serb Republic of Krajina in Croatia, is accused of ordering attacks on the Croatian capital, Zagreb, in which seven people were killed in 1995. Mile Mrksic, 54, is a former Yugoslav Army general whose forces attacked the town of Vukovar in Croatia in 1991 and killed some 250 people, many of them civilians, at a hospital. Five people have turned themselves in since Yugoslavia, under heavy pressure from Western nations, agreed last month to cooperate more fully with the tribunal. Ian Fisher (NYT)

Bankers have stopped letting KPNQwest draw on a 525 million euro ($477 million) credit line, which is needed ''to meet its funding requirements for all of 2002,'' the company said. title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Stratford: Former Town Official Is Fined
description: The Connecticut Elections Enforcement Commission determined yesterday that Michael Singh, the former town council majority leader, was not a United States citizen when he registered to vote in 1999 and when he was elected last November. The commission has levied fines of $4,000 for violations of state election law. Mr. Singh, 35, who represented the town's most populous district, which is overwhelmingly black and Hispanic, signed an agreement yesterday conceding that he was not a citizen and agreeing to pay the fines. Mr. Singh resigned last month after doubts were raised about his citizenship. He was born in Jamaica and was brought to the United States when he was 1, and has stated that he believed he was a citizen.

All fares that are now sold on Orbitz, which is owned by five major airlines, will become available on the proprietary computerized reservations systems used by travel agents. Travel agents have charged Orbitz with anticompetitive practices, as have online booking sites that compete with Orbitz. The Justice Department is currently investigating those complaints. The purchase by the Marsico group, a unit of Bank of America, was worth about $450 million, according to Bigdough.com, which tracks securities filings. The purchase makes G.M., which was previously not held by Mr. Marsico's group, one of its top 10 holdings. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAININ, DR. PHILIP.
description: KRAININ-Dr. Philip. Passed away on May 14, 2002, just two weeks shy of his hundredth birthday. Dr. Krainin spent his last years near his daughter in Bethesda, MD. He died after a long illness. He had spent his earlier retirement years in Naples, ME and Boca Raton, FL. He was born in Manhattan and practiced medicine there for many years. Dr. Krainin attended Columbia University and graduated from New York University School of Medicine. He was a founding member of the American Euthanasia Society. He became a Fellow of the American College of Physicians. Among his published articles was an early report of the dangers of butizolidine to the kidney. Dr. Krainin served as President of the Medical Board of Jewish Memorial Hospital in Manhattan. During World War II, Dr. Krainin served as Lt. Commander in Saipan and later was Chief of the US Naval Hospital in Newport, RI. He was discharged as a Commander. A ceremony with burial of his ashes will be held at Arlington National Cemetery. Dr. Krainin, whose wife Stella (Ornstein) passed away nine years ago leaves two children: Stefanie Greene, M.D. of Cabin John, MD, and James M. Krainin, M.D. of Sharon, MA, as well as five grandchildren and one great-granddaughter. Donations in his memory may be made to the Naples Scholarship Fund, Town Hall, Naples, ME 04055. Those interested in information regarding future memorial ceremony, contact James Krainin, M.D., 470 Washington Street, Norwood, MA 02062.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: Electric Workers On Strike
description: Hundreds of electric company employees went on strike yesterday morning after negotiations between the electric company, United Illuminating, and the union, Local 410-1 of the Utility Workers Union of America, failed. The union represents 360 meter readers, customer service representatives and repair technicians, whose contract expired Wednesday. The union is demanding a raise of $3 to $4 per hour, which its president, Jimmie Murray, said would make their salaries equal to those of utility workers elsewhere in the country. But many union leaders said they left the meeting more confused than combative, still unsure of exactly what concessions the executives wanted.

title: Reinventing the Palestinian Authority
description: It would have been comical had it not been so tragic. There was Yasir Arafat in Ramallah on Wednesday lecturing the Palestinian legislature on the need to make the Palestinian Authority more democratic, accountable and transparent. Here was the man who had spent six years marginalizing the very group he was addressing -- who had never signed the Basic Law passed by the legislature that established a separation of powers -- demanding ''firmer bases of democracy, rule of law, independent judiciary.''

title: Charles M. Rick, 87, Botanist; Helped Create Tastier Tomatoes
description: Dr. Charles M. Rick, whose encyclopedic knowledge of the evolution and genetics of the tomato enabled him and other botanists to produce healthier and tastier tomatoes through crossbreeding, died on May 5 in Davis, Calif., where he was a professor emeritus at the University of California. He was 87.

title: Party Organ In Cuba Prints Speech By Carter
description: In a highly unusual gesture of openness, the official newspaper of the Communist Party today published the uncensored text of former President Jimmy Carter's speech Tuesday in which he bluntly criticized Cuba's government for denying basic freedoms and endorsed a referendum to improve rights.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Making Posthumous Amends
description: Ten years after the death of Marlene Dietrich, the Berlin government made the movie legend an honorary citizen of the capital, where she was born in 1901 and is buried. ''This honor comes late, perhaps some would say too late,'' Mayor Klaus Wowereit said when presenting the citizenship certificate to Dietrich's grandson Peter Riva. Dietrich left Germany in 1930 and later became an an American citizen, criticizing the Nazis and entertaining United States troops in World War II. After a hostile reception in Berlin in 1960 by Germans who considered her a traitor, she vowed not to return to the city before she died.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MITTLEMAN, ALBERT AND BLANCHE
description: MITTLEMAN-Albert and Blanche 1962-2002 In loving memory Daughters Laraine and Shelly Grandchildren Adam, Gabriel, Michael and Sasha.

title: Harold Stevenson
description: Mitchell Algus Gallery

title: Williamsburg Journal; Where the Past Lives, Undisturbed by the Present
description: The word came back from the future, as it were, to the African-American character interpreters who portray slaves anguishing over freedom in the year 1774 here in the busy, history-steeped tourist mecca of modern Colonial Williamsburg:

title: On Crossing the Strait to Cuba
description: To the Editor:

title: BANK OF IRELAND ACQUIRES 61% OF FUND MANAGER IRIDIAN
description: The Bank of Ireland said yesterday that its asset management arm had bought 61 percent of Iridian Asset Management, a fund manager in Connecticut, for $177 million, and predicted a handful of similar niche acquisitions to increase its presence in United States and British equities. The news came as the bank reported its 10th consecutive year of record annual profit, with 1.12 billion euros ($1.02 billion) before tax and exceptional items for the year that ended March 31. The increase, 3.7 percent, was principally a result of a strong performance from its retail banking operations. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: ST. PAUL COS. DISCLOSES ASBESTOS LIABILITY
description: The St. Paul Companies, a leading business insurer, said yesterday that it could face a substantial claim from an asbestos distributor and installer. The claim is from Western MacArthur, which acquired some assets of a St. Paul policyholder, Western Asbestos, a seller of products containing asbestos in the 1950's and early 1960's. St. Paul made the disclosure in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. Mark Hamel, a St. Paul spokesman, said the disclosure was prudent given bigger-than-expected asbestos claims in recent years, ''and our belief that this is our most significant known asbestos exposure.'' St. Paul did not estimate its potential liability. Its shares fell 88 cents, to $46.30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHNEIDER, SIDNEY
description: SHNEIDER-Sidney. The Board of Governors and members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Sidney Shneider. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Suzanne, and their family. Richard R. Bornstein, President Leon Fassler, Secretary

title: The Blame Game
description: The story line of the Sept. 11 terror attacks would unquestionably be a lot tidier if we knew that President Bush had been warned about possible strikes and done nothing to prevent them. That's why Washington is buzzing about the disclosure that the Central Intelligence Agency told Mr. Bush early last August that Osama bin Laden might try to hijack airplanes. But tragedies of the magnitude of Sept. 11 are rarely so neatly explained. Until someone produces evidence that the Bush administration received and ignored information pointing directly to the suicide hijackings, the country will have to live with the much messier and no less disturbing fact that the government as a whole dropped the ball and even now is not doing nearly enough to ensure that it doesn't happen again.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Airport Screening Test Scores 90%
description: Security systems that compare the faces of travelers and airport employees to previously recorded images successfully identified test subjects more than 90 percent of the time in a three-month experiment at Logan Airport in Boston, according to two manufacturers of the face recognition equipment. The two companies, Viisage Technology and Visionics, make competing systems. They have not yet received a final report on the tests, which were just one element of security research at the airport. While demonstrating the potential of the technology, such results suggest that substantial numbers of dangerous travelers could elude facial recognition equipment at an airport the size of Logan, which serves 26 million travelers annually. Separately, Viisage announced a contract to install equipment capable of screening all travelers at the airport in Manchester, N.H. Terms were not disclosed. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Democrats Say Bush Must Give Full Disclosure
description: After months of unstinting support for President Bush's handling of the war on terror, leading Congressional Democrats changed course today and demanded full disclosure of what Mr. Bush was told last summer about the danger of terrorist hijackings. They also called for a broad public inquiry into what the government knew before Sept. 11.

title: Going Back: History Before the Tourists
description: EACH year, more than a million tourists descend on Colonial Williamsburg (many on the Memorial Day weekend), where they often encounter a theme-park environment of crowds, intricate admissions and package plans, eerily pristine ''Colonial'' show places (two of which were built in the mid-20th century), legions of re-enactors in period costumes and, of course, gift shops.

title: In Wake of Assessment Scandal, Panel Urges Changes in System
description: A state panel looking into the scandal in which many of the city's tax assessors were accused of taking bribes is to recommend increased education and training for assessors, more scrutiny of their finances and the creation of an independent office responsible for certifying their work.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Conviction In Kidnapping
description: A Mercer County jury convicted Eli Bethea, 26, on Wednesday, of kidnapping and torturing Jerome Garrison, 34, over an unpaid debt on Jan. 27, 2001. Prosecutors alleged that Mr. Bethea and a second defendant, Emanuel Ross, 27, forced the victim to undress, bound him with duct tape, poured hot water on him and burned him with a hot metal hanger. Mr. Ross is to stand trial on similar charges later this year.

title: House Passes a Welfare Bill With Stricter Rules on Work
description: The House voted today to impose stricter work requirements on welfare recipients as part of a Republican plan to extend the change in social policy brought about by the 1996 welfare law.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Digital Offering Gets Poor Reception
description: Shares of Verint Systems, a maker of digital security components and systems, fell 11.8 percent in their first day of trading. The stock closed at $14.49, down $1.51 from the $16 initial offering price for 4.5 million shares. Verint is a unit of Comverse Technology of Woodbury, N.Y.; Comverse will retain about 80 percent after the offering. Verint had a net loss of $4.6 million on $131.2 million in revenue for its latest fiscal year. Marcin Skomial (NYT)

title: Treasury Dept. Faces Suit by Minority Agents
description: In what could become one of the largest class-action suits against the federal government, black and Hispanic special agents from three agencies are joining forces to file a consolidated discrimination case against the Department of the Treasury.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Not Political Boss. Just Boss.

title: Schwab Begins Grading Stocks on a Curve
description: Amid the uproar over the conflicts of interest at traditional brokerage firms, the Charles Schwab Corporation has begun rating stocks as part of its gradual move toward advising investors.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank's Profit Falls
description: France's third-largest bank, Socit Gnrale S.A., posted a 24 percent decline in first-quarter profit from a year earlier, falling short of analysts' predictions. Net income fell to 511 million euros ($466 million) from 677 million euros in 2001. The bank attributed the decline to an increase in provisions at its corporate and investment banking division; in the fourth quarter last year, Socit Gnrale increased provisions by 78 percent, to 448 million euros, partly to cover loans made to Enron and Argentina. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Lieberman to Seek Subpoena on White House's Enron Contacts
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  Democratic Senator Joseph I. Lieberman said today that he will seek to subpoena the White House about its contacts with the bankrupt but once-politically influential energy trader.

title: Residential Real Estate; TriBeCa Is Priciest Neighborhood
description: A ZIP-code by ZIP-code analysis of the New York real estate market shows that TriBeCa, with its apartments converted from expansive lofts, was the highest priced residential neighborhood in Manhattan last year. Apartments there were on average about 50 percent more expensive than those in the neighborhood that might have seemed like the obvious choice, the Upper East Side.

title: The Big City; Waterfront Could Still Be a Contender
description: IF you wanted an analysis of New York's decrepit waterfront, on Wednesday you had a choice. You could either listen to the governor of New Jersey deliver the keynote address at the Waterfront 2002 Conference, or you could go cruising on a catboat with William Kornblum.

title: Grilling Utensils That Flip, Baste and Take the Heat
description: IF you are already among the 89 percent of American households that grill outdoors, you undoubtedly have the basic gas, charcoal or wood-burning heat source. What you may not have is the essential backup equipment for great grilling this summer.

title: Mixing Operatic Tradition With Irony and High Jinks
description: I'm not sure there has previously been such a genre as ironic opera, but there is now. In ''The Sandman,'' the mischievous and boldly eccentric Target Margin Theater has produced an arch musical treatment of the supernatural E. T. A. Hoffmann tale about an unfortunate scholar, his horrifying memories and ill-advised romantic urges.

title: National Briefing | Education And Science: $41.5 Billion For Construction
description: Educational institutions spent a record $41.5 billion on construction last year, according to a survey by the trade magazine, American School and University. With $26.8 billion spent on elementary and secondary schools and $14.7 billion on construction by colleges and universities, the magazine forecast that the educational construction boom would remain strong. Diana Jean Schemo (NYT)

title: Getting There: How to Beat the Traffic Blues
description: SUDDENLY, it is at least possible to imagine summer. You have bought or rented or borrowed your way into the perfect weekend home, and you cannot wait to start showing up at the office on Friday mornings in Bermuda shorts and sandals.

title: INSIDE
description: Priest an Apparent Suicide

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Technology Briefing column of Business Day yesterday about an accounting dispute between a company that makes a skin-embedded computer chip and its auditor, Grant Thornton, misstated the company's name. It is Applied Digital Solutions, not Systems.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Mobile Phone Expansion
description: China Mobile, the main cellular phone operator in coastal China, said it would pay $10.2 billion to China's state-owned national phone company to buy the cellular phone operations in eight provinces in central and western China. The deal will add 20.9 million subscribers to the 69.6 million that China Mobile already has. China Mobile will raise part of the money for the deal by selling $750 million worth of its shares to the Vodafone Group, which increases its stake in China Mobile to 3.27 percent from 2.18 percent. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: For Patients, Welcome Relief From 4 Bare Walls
description: When friends knocked on the door of his hospital room, the young man said, he looked at the photograph of a bright hallway that hung on his wall, and he felt as if he were inviting people into his home.

title: Still Scraping for Runs, Mets Win Third Straight
description: Perhaps every team and all games on the West Coast are like this one, because for three days the Mets have been repeating themselves. Their offense scrapes for runs while their starting pitcher shuts down the opponent.

title: Dutch Rightists Replace Assassinated Leader
description: The party of the slain populist politician Pim Fortuyn elected a former Defense Ministry spokesman today to replace Mr. Fortuyn as its leader. An unusually strong showing carried the party to second place in parliamentary elections on Wednesday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Unemployment Inches Up
description: New York City's jobless rate continued to climb in April, rising to 7.7 percent from 7.5 percent in March, the New York State Department of Labor announced yesterday. The unemployment rate in the city has risen by 2.4 percentage points since March 2001, and is now the highest since November 1998. Excluding the city and its suburbs, New York State's unemployment rate edged up to 5 percent from 4.9 percent. Both the city and state increases were smaller than the national rate, which climbed 0.3 percentage points in April, to 6 percent.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about changes in welfare policy under the Bloomberg administration misstated the city's share of public assistance spending under the federal welfare law. It is 25 percent, not zero.

title: State Will Require Coverage Of Treatment for Infertility
description: The Legislature and the governor acted today to require health insurance plans to cover most infertility treatments, bringing an abrupt, surprising end to three years of wrangling.

title: A Wrap That's Almost Human
description: DESIGN is us and always has been: it is made by and for humans, and it mirrors human needs and capacities. But these days design is more us than ever, thanks to digital technology, astounding synthetic materials and postmodern miracles like cloning and genetic engineering. The distance between the animate and inanimate diminishes daily. This is a situation as scary as it is wondrous, as is demonstrated by ''Skin: Surface, Substance and Design,'' a tantalizing yet deficient exhibition at Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum of the Smithsonian Institution.

title: Basking Comes in Bulk, Too
description: NO matter where I have lived in Manhattan, there has always been at least one 24-hour deli within a block of my apartment. This means I have never stocked up on household basics that could clutter my always-too-small apartments. That is why I buy paper towels and toilet paper one roll at a time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARSON, DR. PAUL DAVID, AIA.
description: PEARSON-Dr. Paul David, AIA. Professor, City College School of Architecture, May 8, from fall at construction site, Chappaqua, NY. Survived by son, Paul Chris Pearson, grandson Adam Cody Pearson, and sister Kathryn Korematsu. Predeceased by son David Brian Pearson. Funeral services May 20, 10 AM Riverside Church.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Monday described opposition by historic preservationists to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to transform the newly renovated Tweed Courthouse into an office and school. It included a quotation from Peg Breen, a preservationist who questioned whether New York City's building codes would allow alterations for that purpose. While Ms. Breen was correctly identified as president of the New York Landmarks Conservancy, the article should also have noted that she serves on the board of the Museum of the City of New York, which had previously planned to move into the Tweed building.

title: Designing For the Camera
description: Gilbert Adrian, whose Hollywood costumes for Greta Garbo, Katharine Hepburn and Joan Crawford brought him fame, is the subject of the Costume Institute's new show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. ''Adrian: American Glamour'' explores both his costumes for MGM and his career in fashion, which included an interest in animal motifs, reflected in this 1945 dinner dress, left. The retrospective depicts Adrian as a quintessential 20th-century American designer.

title: Poet of Involvement: Surveying the Career of a Dramatic Draftsman
description: Unlike Watteau, Fragonard and Boucher, Jean-Baptiste Greuze (1725-1805) does not have a name that rings bells. At one time he was dismissed, unseen, as grossly sentimental. Yet as a dramatist in painting he stands very high, and as a draftsman he stands higher still.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about the dispute stemming from memoirs by James J. Cramer, the former hedge fund manager, and Nicholas W. Maier, a former employee, omitted a response from Mr. Cramer about accusations made by Mr. Maier in his book ''Trading With the Enemy.'' Mr. Maier contended that Mr. Cramer learned in advance about reports planned by two CNBC reporters -- Maria Bartiromo and David Faber -- and traded on that information. Mr. Cramer has said he never learned about the reports in advance. A spokeswoman for CNBC has also denied the accusations.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about plans by Orbitz, the online travel-booking site, misstated the way its fares would be made available to travel agents. The company will use a separate software system, not the computer reservations systems used by agents.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Ithaca: Union Drive At Cornell
description: Cornell University students petitioned the National Labor Relations Board this week for permission to unionize a broad range of students, including graduate teaching and research assistants and undergraduates in similar positions. Cornell officials expressed ''grave concern'' about designating such assistants as employees under the National Labor Relations Act but said they respected the students' right to seek permission to unionize. The student organizers are affiliated with the United Automobile Workers. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: From a Simple Thought, A Collection Grows
description: I MET my first two egg coddlers three years ago in the large antiques and flea market at 25th Street and the Avenue of the Americas. Now, I have 82.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dell's Financial Results Slightly Beat Expectations

title: Notes From Charleston; The Fight for the Soul of Coal Country
description: At the edge of Madison, a small southern West Virginia town once populated largely by miners and mine owners, a large sign proudly informs visitors they have entered ''the gateway to the West Virginia coal fields.''

description: Rebecca Raub is more straightforward and prescient than most people twice, or even 10 times, her age, which is 7. Here is the letter she wrote in February to President Bush:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Forests May Be Sold
description: Stora Enso, the Finnish paper manufacturer, said it might sell forests in Sweden, Finland and the United States worth as much as $2.25 billion. The trees cover 27,600 square kilometers, an area about the size of Belgium. Finnish forests worth about 500 million euros will be placed in a separate company to be named Tornator, before a majority stake is sold later this year, the company said. Holdings in the United States will be offered to private investors, and the company is currently investigating its forests in Sweden. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: 13,000 Credit Reports Stolen by Hackers
description: Hackers posing as employees of the Ford Motor Credit Company have in recent months harvested a trove of 13,000 credit reports -- a virtual one-stop shop for fraud and identity theft -- with data on consumers in affluent neighborhoods across the country.

title: Worker Dies in Collapse on Upper East Side
description: One construction worker was killed and at least five others were seriously injured yesterday when part of a 92-year-old building being renovated on the Upper East Side collapsed, the authorities said.

title: With Folk Medicine on Rise, Health Group Is Monitoring
description: Assigning itself a Herculean task, the World Health Organization took the first step today toward becoming the global watchdog over unconventional medicine.

title: Energy Trades Echoed In Broadband Market
description: Big energy trading companies engaged in scores of transactions aimed at creating the appearance of activity as they tried to build a market for trading high-speed communications capacity, according to records and interviews with former employees and executives at the companies.

title: Drug Makers And F.D.A. Fighting Hard Over Quality
description: Major drug makers and federal regulators are increasingly squaring off over problems at factories that could affect the quality of medicines being produced.

title: At AOL, Parting Without the Sweet Sorrow
description: After AOL Time Warner's annual meeting yesterday, Richard D. Parsons told reporters that the shareholders who gathered at the Apollo Theater in Harlem had been ''more gracious and respectful than I had anticipated.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FINNEGAN, LAWRENCE J. JR.
description: FINNEGAN-Lawrence J. Jr. Dear Larry, 3 years in heaven and although my world has changed, my love for you remains the same. You are forever in my heart and will always be a part of my soul. I miss you and miss us. With love and devotion, Jackie

title: Out of Horror, Visions of a Place Reborn
description: To the Editor:

title: Many Advise, Mr. President, but You Decide
description: Exuberant in the Oval Office on the night of his 1965 inauguration, soon after he was elected president by a huge majority, Lyndon B. Johnson puts his arms out and swirls an imaginary dance partner around the room. ''The Great Society is my beautiful woman and I'm taking her by the arm,'' he crows. He is captured with startling likeness by Michael Gambon, whose long, lined face seems to become Johnson's, a feat of acting that goes beyond makeup and prosthetic ears.

title: Prosecutors Oppose Judge In Ruling on Death Penalty
description: Prosecutors made a last effort yesterday to dissuade a judge from following through on his plan to declare the federal death penalty unconstitutional, arguing that he was relying on flawed reasoning and questionable research.

title: HBO-Showtime Team Using Experienced Reporter to Cover Tyson Bout
description: Upon being named the reporter for HBO and Showtime's production of the coming Mike Tyson-Lennox Lewis fight, Jim Gray reflected yesterday on an interview he did on NBC's ''Dateline'' program in early 1999 when Tyson threatened, under certain conditions that Gray would find difficult to fulfill, to kill him.

title: 'The Founding Five'
description: David Findlay Jr. Contemporary

title: Meteor May Have Started Dinosaur Era
description: The age of dinosaurs, which ended with the cataclysmic bang of a meteor impact 65 million years ago, may also have begun with one.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Man Charged With Rape
description: A man was arrested yesterday after a woman who had just been raped followed him in a taxicab and flagged down an ambulance crew who radioed the police, the authorities said. The man, identified as Shawn Davis, 34, of Morris Heights, has been charged with rape, the police said. The woman, who is 33, was walking in front of 1539 Nelson Avenue about 12:30 a.m. when she was forced to the rear of the building and raped, the police said. The woman hailed a cab and had the driver follow the man as he walked down the street, they said. The cab pulled beside an ambulance and workers alerted the police. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Irish Voters Appear Ready to Re-elect Prime Minister
description: The campaign to decide who will lead Ireland ended today with no evidence that opposition parties had persuaded voters to deny re-election to Prime Minister Bertie Ahern, who has presided over the biggest economic boom in the country's history.

title: For a Family, a House With History and Walls That Seem to Speak
description: WHO -- Michael and Lisa Richard and their six children.

title: Airlines Report Hearing Only Vague Caution
description: The two airlines whose planes were hijacked on Sept. 11 said today that they had received only general, vague warnings of terrorism last summer and nothing that would have prompted them to make major changes in their operations.

title: Nets Receive 2nd-Highest Rating
description: The Nets' victory over Charlotte in Game 5 of the Eastern Division semifinals on Thursday generated a 3.68 cable rating on Fox Sports New York, and was watched in part by 268,679 local television households.

title: Excerpts From National Security Adviser's Statement
description: Following are excerpts from the statement of Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser, at a news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times. The complete transcript is online at nytimes.com/politics.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about a successful effort by the author David Baldacci to halt the publication of an anthology of mystery stories, with a cover resembling the one on a novel of his, referred incorrectly to courts' ability to block books. While injunctions can be issued for copyright violations, they cannot be issued for libel.

title: Slater Bradley -- 'Unknown Pleasures'
description: Team Gallery

title: Utility Board Votes to Restart a Nuclear Reactor in Alabama That Has Been Idle Since 1985
description: The board of the Tennessee Valley Authority voted today to spend $1.7 billion to restart a troubled nuclear reactor at its Browns Ferry plant in northern Alabama, a decision that could produce the first substantial increase in the nation's nuclear-generating capacity in more than a decade.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Tug the Ear, Do a Show

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Some chefs make so powerful a first impression that an encore becomes almost impossible. Jonathan Waxman surely knows the problem. In the mid-1980's he swept New York off its feet with Jams, an inspired interpretation of California cuisine. In recent years, however, Mr. Waxman has bounced from one project to another, never seeming to get a foothold. Washington Park may change all that.

title: Betting on the Luxury Goods Market
description: Is the luxury goods market turning around? Patrizio Bertelli is betting on it.

title: Stephanie Blythe
description: Alice Tully Hall

title: Police Are Led to Body Said to Be Pearl's
description: A Pakistani police official told The Associated Press yesterday that three new suspects in the murder of Daniel Pearl, the Wall Street Journal reporter, had led police to a grave where they said he was buried. But, the report said, tests had not established the identity of the remains found in the grave, in a field near a poor neighborhood at the western edge of Karachi.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Technology Briefing
description: SOFTWARE

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: KELLWOOD, St. Louis, a maker of women's clothing, agreed to buy Gerber Childrenswear, Greenville, S.C., for about $135 million in cash and stock to gain lines of infant and toddler clothing and athletic socks.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Ex-Teacher Faces Rape Charges
description: A former New York City public school teacher was arrested in Oklahoma yesterday and charged with raping a 16-year-old student, the police said. The former teacher, Josner Bueno, 31, of Jackson Heights, was arrested by detectives from the Queens Special Victims Squad around 2 p.m. He is accused of raping the student twice, once at Newton High School in Elmhurst in December and once near Forest Park in March, said Detective Cheryl Cox. Mr. Bueno resigned from his job before leaving for an Oklahoma military base, where he is a reservist, said Kevin Ortiz, a spokesman for the Board of Education. Mr. Ortiz did not know when he left or what classes he taught. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Asbestos Limit Overruled
description: The House of Lords, England's highest court, overturned a previous ruling that barred people from collecting compensation for asbestos-related illness if they were exposed to the material by more than one employer. Lord Bingham of Cornhill, who led a five-member panel for the court, said that the previous ruling by the Court of Appeal had been unanimously overturned. The ruling could expose insurers to billions of pounds in additional claims for respiratory illness and cancer that has been linked to asbestos. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Pakistani Police Unearth a Body Thought to Be Slain Reporter's
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 17  Pakistani authorities said today that they had unearthed the remains of a man believed to be Daniel Pearl, the kidnapped and slain Wall Street Journal reporter.

title: Fred Hersch
description: Village Vanguard

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: NEC Plans Spinoff
description: Under pressure from low-cost com petitors abroad, the NEC Corporation said it would spin off its nonmemory semiconductor business in October. The new company will make system chips, general semiconductors and some devices. NEC, Japan's second-largest chip maker, expects the new business to have sales of $5.5 billion. NEC plans to offer shares in the new company, although no date was set. In New York, NEC's American depository receipts rose 4.1 percent, to $7.64. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APOSTOLAKIS, ANN
description: APOSTOLAKIS-Ann. On May 15, 2002. Beloved wife of the late John. Devoted mother of James Apostolakis and the late George Apostle. Cherished grandmother of Lisa Coleman, John and Jeffrey Apostle and great grandmother of Charles and Ann Coleman, George and Mary Jane Apostle. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Monday, May 20, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Service Tuesday, May 21, 12 noon at the Greek Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 E. 74th St., NYC.

title: Indictments Reach Madison Avenue
description: A federal grand jury has handed up indictments in a continuing investigation of the print-production industry and advertising agencies.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Oil Executive Turns Water Seller
description: T. Boone Pickens, the oil executive and corporate raider, has received permission to sell billions of gallons of water from an underground aquifer in the Texas Panhandle. After a series of lawsuits, Mr. Pickens's Mesa Water Inc. has been granted a permit by the Panhandle Groundwater Conservation District to pump water from the Ogallala aquifer. Mr. Pickens has negotiated with parched municipalities, including San Antonio, El Paso and Fort Worth, about shipping them water via a pipeline. Opponents said the project could endanger the Ogallala, a major water source for the Panhandle. Jim Yardley (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Times Square Tower Sold
description: The Times Square building that is the headquarters of the media giant Viacom has been acquired by the S. L. Green real estate investment trust of New York and a Canadian partner for $483 million. The building, at 1515 Broadway between 44th and 45th Streets, is a 1.75-million-square-foot, 54-story office tower. The purchase is one of the first major Manhattan office building transactions since Sept. 11. John Holusha (NYT)

title: SERIES OF WARNINGS
description: Foreboding grew in the months before the Sept. 11 attacks, as President Bush and his national security aides studied intelligence reports hinting that terrorists could be plotting a major attack, Mr. Bush's national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, said today.

title: Not Married? Sorry, You're Not a Man
description: ''Late Marriage'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 6; the full text is available at nytimes.com/movies. The film, in Hebrew and Georgian with subtitles, opens today in Manhattan.

title: Cars to Hang on a Wall
description: EXOTIC, rare automobiles have come to Rockefeller Center, where Christie's will auction 51 such cars tomorrow at 2 p.m.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAAS, MICHAEL
description: MAAS-Michael. On May 12, 2002, at the age of 70. Funeral Mass on Friday, May 17, at 10:30 A.M., at St. Thomas More, 65 East 89th Street.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: College Dormitory Sale Considered
description: Faced with a $1.7 billion deficit over two years, the Legislature is considering a proposal to sell state college dormitories to for-profit groups. By one estimate, such a sale could raise $750 million. Gov. Bob Taft said he opposed the sale of the dormitories, or anything else that would lead to higher tuitions and student fees.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Black Squatters Face Eviction
description: The government said it would begin evicting thousands of black squatters from white-owned farms that are not scheduled to be be acquired under a land redistribution program. Foreign diplomats and regional leaders have been urging the government to take the step for months. Officials say they would start by evicting about 12,000 families from farms in the southern part of the country, a move that was welcomed by white farmers.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: BRAZIL: POLICE CHIEF CONVICTED IN PEASANTS' DEATHS In a landmark verdict decided by a 4-3 vote, a jury found the commander of a state police contingent guilty of murder in connection with the killing of 19 landless peasants during a 1996 confrontation in the Amazon and sentenced him to 228 years in prison. A trial in 1999 had absolved Col. Mario Colares Pantoja and two other senior officers of all charges but that verdict was overturned because of procedural irregularities. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Debate on Human Cloning Turns to Patents
description: The University of Missouri has received a patent that some lawyers say could cover human cloning, potentially violating a longstanding taboo against the patenting of humans.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Discount Airlines Merge
description: The low-cost airline EasyJet said it had agreed to buy a rival, Go Fly, for the equivalent of $545 million to overtake Ryanair of Ireland as Europe's biggest discount airline. Shares in EasyJet, which is based in London, rose 10 percent, to 504 pence. Ray Webster, EasyJet's chief executive, said that the acquisition would help Easyjet with its plans for expansion. Go Fly was initially a subsidiary of British Airways, which sold the operation last June for $154 million to the venture capital fund 3i and the airline's management. Alan Cowell (NYT)
