title: Wells Leads Yankees Over Inept Devil Rays
description: For the next 70 days, the Yankees do not play the Tampa Bay Devil Rays at all. For 70 long, much more taxing days, there will be no Ryan Rupe, no Felix Escalona and no more games like last night's, in which the disparity between the teams could not have been more obvious.

title: NSB HOLDING IS BUYING LIBERTY BANCORP FOR $34.5 MILLION
description: The NSB Holding Corporation, the parent of Northfield Savings Bank, is acquiring Liberty Bancorp for about $34.5 million in cash, the companies said yesterday. NSB will pay $26.50 a share to holders of Liberty Bancorp's common stock, 45 percent higher than Liberty's closing price Wednesday. Liberty operates banks in Middlesex and Union Counties in New Jersey. Under the agreement, Liberty Bank will operate as a division of Northfield Savings Bank. Northfield operates 11 branches on Staten Island.

title: U.N. Warns That Many Children, Rich and Poor, Are Obese
description: Obesity among children is becoming a global epidemic and the problem must be tackled at its junk-food roots, health experts say.

title: Defense Sees New Problem In Account By Louima
description: Defense lawyers in the coming retrial of Charles Schwarz, the former police officer charged with assisting in the 1997 torture of Abner Louima, said yesterday that they had received new information from prosecutors that raised new questions about Mr. Louima's version of events.

title: Pressure on Arafat Now Comes From Within
description: Under increased internal and international pressure to reform the Palestinian Authority and put an end to suicide bombings, Yasir Arafat conceded this week that he has made mistakes and promised to institute change. ''We are in a great need to review our policies in order to rectify and correct our march toward national independence,'' he said. He also repeated his opposition to attacks on Israeli civilians, saying, ''These operations do not serve our interests.'' The words sound constructive, but advocates of reform will remain skeptical of Mr. Arafat's genuine commitment to transparency, accountability and power sharing.

title: Rose Ellis Matzkin -- Hadassah Leader, 88
description: Rose Ellis Matzkin, national president of Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization of America, from 1972 to 1976, died on Monday in a hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. She was 88.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Ex-General Pleads Not Guilty
description: A former Yugoslav Army general pleaded not guilty to charges that his troops killed more than 200 patients and hospital workers in 1991 in Vukovar after the Croatian town fell to his forces. Mile Mrksic surrendered to the United Nations war crimes tribunal on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDSMAN, IRVING
description: LANDSMAN-Irving. 94. On May 12 of Long Beach, New York. Noted attorney, valuation expert, entrepreneur, teacher, author, civic leader, equestrian, swimmer, and track athlete. Strength, courage and drive be his forever. Interment at Mt. description: JERUSALEM, May 17  Only hours after two of his top aides said he was ready to run for election within six months, Yasir Arafat said today that Palestinians could not hold elections until Israeli forces pulled back from the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Councilman Rebuffs Levy
description: A Bronx City Council member asked Chancellor Harold O. Levy yesterday to rescind his plan to have five relatively successful New York City school districts give management, financial and instructional advice to nine of their less successful counterparts. The councilman, G. Oliver Koppell, above, said he did not think the school district he represents, District 10 in the northwest Bronx, could become a consultant to other districts without hurting its own programs and students. Mr. Levy announced the plan to have five strong districts help nine weak ones -- for a fee of $250,000 for each district helped -- on Wednesday. Mr. Levy added yesterday that he had consulted with all of the superintendents in advance and had been assured that each would be able to help the others without shortchanging their own students.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Warning About Con Men
description: The police released a photograph yesterday of one of two men who they say impersonate police detectives and try to trick elderly men into handing over cash. The two men have tried to swindle five men, ages 75 to 88, across the city since March 8, the police said. They succeeded twice, robbing one man of $47,000 and another of $780 in rent money. One of the suspects, identified as Jimmy Davis, 42, above, and another man approach the elderly men, present white police badges and say they are looking for a fugitive named Sullivan, the police said. They said the men insist that Sullivan is hiding in the victim's apartment and has stashed money there, and if the victim does not give them cash, they will get a search warrant. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Surviving Stabbing, Becoming a Star
description: The Nets outlasted Indiana's Reggie Miller and wore down Charlotte's Baron Davis. Now they must overcome Boston's Paul Pierce, the superstar swingman who destroyed them during the regular season with slick moves in the lane, short jumpers over exasperated defenders and a barrage of 3-pointers.

title: Sharon Monsky, 48, Leader In Fight Against Rare Illness
description: Sharon L. Monsky, a scleroderma sufferer who founded an organization that raised millions of dollars to look for a cure for the disease, died on Saturday in Santa Barbara, Calif. She was 48 and lived in Santa Barbara.

title: Southern Suites
description: All SpringHill Suites by Marriott in Florida, Georgia, Tennessee and Alabama are offering a discount of $10 a night to repeat guests through Sept. 30. Guests must stay at a participating SpringHill Suites and ask for a discount coupon for a future stay. Reservations: (888) 287-9400 or online at www.springhillsuites.com .

title: New York's Wildest Love Affairs
description: It's springtime again, and the curious mating habits of New Yorkers can be observed all over town. Singles are adding their personal profiles to Match.com, lining up for Speed Dating and taking classes on how to flirt. There are also the usual preparations for June weddings as betrothed couples endure last-minute fittings, Jack-and-Jill showers and nervous future in-laws. It's all so familiar. So Homo sapiens.

title: Schools for Sale
description: It is no secret the public schools are strapped for cash, but they would be making a Faustian bargain if, as Schools Chancellor Harold Levy is urging, they allow advertising on school grounds. Even in difficult economic times, children should not have to be bombarded with pitches from Nike and Coca-Cola in order to get a decent education.

title: Goodbye to Ally and Scully and Mulder at Fox. Hello to Mr. Grubb and John Doe.
description: COMING off a season of ratings setbacks and needing to find hits to replace two departing signature shows -- ''Ally McBeal'' and ''The X-Files '' -- the Fox network announced a new prime-time lineup yesterday that was filled with changes.

title: Getaways for a Holiday Weekend
description: STILL haven't made plans for Memorial Day? Then consider the following options. All are for the weekend of May 24-27, and these transportation and hotel deals were available yesterday afternoon at major travel and airline Web sites. Airfares are based on a seven-day advance purchase, leaving Friday and returning Monday. Hotel rates are for each night, with a maximum occupancy of four people.

description: Brian Cashman practically sighed when he was asked about how the Yankees plan to fill the manager's job at Class AAA Columbus after Brian Butterfield was fired yesterday. ''It's a thin market,'' said Cashman, the Yankees' general manager.

title: On Giants, New Faces And a New Identity
description: The Giants have come and gone from their stadium in recent days, some choosing early mornings and others late mornings for their off-season workouts. They crisscross one another like cars on a freeway, but in this instance, the destinations are the same: to get back to winning.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Montenegro: Voters Back Leader's Party
description: Voters torn over whether to seek independence from Yugoslavia threw their support behind the party of President Milo Djukanovic in local elections. They thus appeared to grant a grudging endorsement to the creation of a new combined state to replace Yugoslavia, called Serbia and Montenegro. The elections for local councils were viewed largely as a referendum on Mr. Djukanovic, who outraged many in the tiny Balkan republic earlier this year by dropping his support for immediate independence in favor of a recast union with Serbia for at least three years. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Arafat Willing To Face Voters, His Aides Say
description: As Palestinian legislators prepared to challenge Yasir Arafat by presenting detailed proposals to curtail his power, replace his ministers and hold elections by early next year, two of his top aides said tonight that he was willing to run for election within six months.

description: A federal appeals court in California ruled yesterday that organizations that distributed Old West-style wanted posters identifying doctors who provided abortions had illegally threatened them, and it upheld a jury verdict against the organizations.

title: Police Dept. Reports Jump In Applicants
description: The number of applicants to take the exam to become a city police officer has risen to more than 35,000, nearly three times as many as applied for last June's exam. The Police Department attributes the sharp rise in part to a new system that allows applicants to register on the Internet.

title: Big Charter School in Boston Breaks Its Ties With Edison
description: One of the nation's largest charter schools has canceled its contract with Edison Schools Inc., delivering another shock to the biggest for-profit operator of public schools at its time of severe financial setbacks.

title: Jockey Is Speaking Language of Success
description: Victor Espinoza has always had that Dr. Dolittle quality inherent in top-flight jockeys. He can communicate with racehorses. It is their two-legged trainers he sometimes has a fuzzy connection with. Fortunately for Espinoza on the morning of the Kentucky Derby, the trainer Bob Baffert knew enough Spanish, and Espinoza, a native of Mexico, was able to tune in to enough English to make their pre-race skull session worthwhile.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, CHARLES S.
description: STRAUSS-Charles S., 88. Of Larchmont, died on May 15 due to complications in the last few months. He was born December 31, 1913 in Haverhill, MA. to Ansel and Helen Strauss. He spent his youth in Pelham, New York. He graduated from Andover in 1931 and Yale in 1935. Charlie served as a First Sergeant in World War II. After the war he worked for M. Lowenstein & Sons until his retirement. Charlie was predeceased by his beloved wife, Margaret Levi Strauss and his loving daughter, Leyae Strauss and his brother John Strauss. He is survived by his loving family: daughter, Barbara Strauss, his son and daughter-inlaw, Chick and Sherry Strauss, his three grandchildren Emily, Hannah and Noah Strauss, and by his brother and sister-in-law, Peter and Barbara Strauss, and their children, John, Eileen and Sally Strauss. A memorial service will be held at Congregation Emanuel of Westchester on Thursday, May 23, at 2 PM, the Temple of which he was a past president. Donations in his memory may be sent to Yale, Andover, Congregation Emanuel of Westchester, or a charity of your choice. Charlie was an avid Quaker Ridge golfer, bridge player, story teller and a caring and supportive friend. We're left with fond memories. He will be missed by all.

She lived a long & creative life & devoted herself passionately to her children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. She had boundless enthusiasm for life, family and friendship. She will be greatly, sadly and deeply missed by all who knew her and the many lives she touched. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENWASSER, ROBERT
description: ROSENWASSER-Robert. Passed away on May 16, 2002, after a long and dreadful illness. Dearest husband of Dorothy, devoted father of Carol Harris & Marsha and Tim Schaffner, stepfather of Jonathan and Terrence Paret, loving grandfather of Debby and Will Gans and Dan and Rivka Bushell, greatgrandfather of Malky Bushell, brother of Sidney Rosenwasser. Robert Rosenwasser was the founder and President of Rosenwasser Grossman Consulting Engineers. He was a distinguished engineer with a long career who received numerous awards in structural engineering. He was acclaimed for his many contributions to the NYC skyline. Robert Rosenwasser was a graduate of the City College of New York. He was a member of Chi Epsilon, the National Civil Engineering honor fraternity, and was a Fellow of the American Concrete Institute. He was honored by the Concrete Industry Board of New York, which presented him with its Leader of Industry Award. He wrote several articles on various aspects of building design, construction and economics. Services will be held Sunday, May 19, 2002, at 1:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave at 81st St. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Departments of Immunology and Neurology at Mt. Sinai Hospital, 5 East 98th Street, New York 10029.

description: AS Memorial Day nears, families that use the long weekend to open their summer cottages are getting ready, calling and sending e-mails back and forth. Some of them are continuing long family traditions, making plans to meet for ritualistic openings, airing out stale rooms, chasing bats from chimneys, and running orangy-brown water until it is clear.

description: Chancellor Gerhard Schrder may have a mousy head of hair, but the color is completely natural, says the man who knows for sure.

title: Living the Music: Brazilians and Americans Exchange Traditions
description: I love taking the sound of jazz all over the world. And generally speaking, people everywhere are friendly toward musicians, because we represent a good time. Of all that the road has to offer, I most enjoy the accidental meetings with great musicians right in their hometowns.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Strategy Rebuffed
description: The federal judge overseeing the Microsoft trial appeared unreceptive yesterday to Microsoft's efforts to convince her that nine states have no right to seek antitrust penalties on the company beyond a settlement already reached with the Justice Department. Microsoft argues that California, Iowa and the other states do not have the standing to ask for restrictions that would apply to Microsoft's business practices nationwide. But Federal Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly noted that the appeals court that upheld Microsoft's antitrust violations last year was well aware that the original suit was brought by the federal government along with a coalition of states. If the court had believed the states lacked standing, she said, the judges ''certainly would have said so.'' The judge's comments suggested she would not dismiss the case on those grounds, but she did ask whether she owed ''some amount of deference'' to the Justice Department's less stringent proposal. Amy Harmon (NYT)

title: Home Building Was Off in April
description: The construction of new homes fell in April to the lowest level in six months and the number of workers seeking unemployment benefits rose unexpectedly last week, two reports released today showed, pointing to a moderating economic expansion.

title: The League Asks If O'Neal Is Too Much of a Good Thing
description: Bill Hill has a purple-tinted goatee, a wife with a broken cowbell and one wish from his courtside seat in Sacramento: He hopes Shaquille O'Neal's arthritic big toe ''gets worse.''

title: LABOR TALKS AT HERSHEY STALL OVER HEALTH BENEFITS
description: Federally mediated contract talks between Hershey Foods and the union representing 3,000 striking workers broke down yesterday over health care benefits. Two Hershey candy plants have been shut as a result of the strike, which began April 26. The workers' contract expired Nov. 4. The company's latest proposal met the union's request for wage increases and provided for retroactive compensation in the form of a signing bonus. But the proposal asked that employees share the cost of health care, though at a lower level than previously suggested. Union officials said nearly 87 percent of the workers had voted against higher co-payments.

description: THERE'S more to that glow on Emil Wilbekin's cinnamon-hued face than a week just spent at a chic boutique hotel in San Juan, Puerto Rico. He's the editor in chief of Vibe, the urban music magazine, whose job it is to keep tabs on the cutting edge.

title: Trading Musical Traditions
description: This weekend Jazz at Lincoln Center will celebrate the integration of aspects of Brazilian music with jazz. On hand will be two Brazilian musicians, the percussionist Cyro Baptista (above) and the guitarist Romero Lubambo.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BELGIUM: EUTHANASIA LAW APPROVED Parliament adopted a law legalizing euthanasia in some cases, making Belgium the second country after the Netherlands to allow doctors to kill patients under specific circumstances. The bill was adopted by 86-51 with 10 abstentions and is expected to come into force within three months. Under the law, a doctor who ends a patient's life will not be guilty of a crime if the patient is terminally ill, in "constant and unbearable" physical or psychological pain and has made the decision himself.

title: National Briefing | Plains: North Dakota: Tribe Loses Land-Sale Case
description: The State Supreme Court ruled that the state can force an Indian tribe to sell land containing burial grounds to build a dam on the Maple River. The Turtle Mountain Band of Chippewa Indians bought a 1.43-acre tract in 2000, and the land is not part of a reservation. The court ruled the tribe could thus not invoke sovereign immunity in opposing the state's action. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Senator Clinton's Speech on Sept. 11 Intelligence
description: Following is a speech by Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in the Senate on Thursday, as recorded by The Congressional Record.

title: 36 Hours | Newport, R.I.
description: EACH summer, two million tourists shuffle their way through Newport's Gilded Age monuments, the lumbering white elephants (or are they gaga and overdressed maiden aunts?) perched hip to hip on the city's glittering rocky coastline. You too can explore America's insatiable appetite for . . . darn nearly everything here, and ponder the freakishness of the wealthy. Glut your senses by driving down Newport's main drag, otherwise known as Bellevue Avenue, a weird bazaar of architectural expression that includes more Versailles references than is probably healthy. If you continue along Ocean Drive, you will note attempts by contemporary architects to be this century's Stanford White (and that is not necessarily a good thing). It is prudent to plan a visit now, before the city is overwhelmed by visitors in search of more earthly stimulants, like fudge, booze or T-shirts. PENELOPE GREEN

title: Archdiocese Vows to Report Abuse Sooner
description: The head of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Hartford agreed yesterday under pressure from Connecticut officials to start using a state child-abuse line to immediately report any accusations of sexual abuse involving priests and minors.

title: America's Poor Standards
description: On Tuesday Standard & Poor's, the private bond rating agency, announced that it would do something unprecedented: It will try to impose accounting standards substantially stricter than those required by the federal government. Instead of taking corporate reports at face value, S.&P. will correct the numbers to eliminate what it considers the inappropriate treatment of ''one-time'' expenses, pension fund earnings and, above all, stock options -- a major part of executive compensation that, according to federal standards, somehow isn't a business expense. S.&P.'s estimate of ''core earnings'' for the 500 largest companies slashes reported profits by an astonishing 25 percent.

title: A Leftist Surges in Brazil's Turbulent Presidential Election
description: With corruption accusations throwing the Brazilian presidential race into turmoil, polls are showing the left-wing opposition challenger, Luiz Incio da Silva, charging ahead of the chosen candidate of President Fernando Henrique Cardoso.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Keeping Drug Needles Off Streets
description: In an effort to keep hypodermic needles off the streets and out of public garbage cans, officials in Santa Cruz have approved a plan to install needle disposal boxes on a trial basis at sites like public restrooms near the beach. The move comes after park and recreation workers were stuck by needles seven times in the past five years. The boxes cost about $75 each and use disposable liners to help workers avoid coming in contact with the needles, assumed to have been employed for illegal drug use. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERT, IRVING
description: ALBERT-Irving, 80. Died suddenly on May 13, 2002 at home. Born in Poland, came to the United States in 1938. An honored union organizer and committed leftist. He served in the U.S. Armed Forces in the invasion of North Africa, landed in Anzio and marched to Rome. Supported many Jewish causes. And was an Alaskan entrepreneur. Husband of Alicia and the late Dorothy, father of Marc and David, father-in-law of Orna, adoring grandfather of Ben, and relentless competitor at pinochle. Service Sunday, May 19, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The family will be at home this week.

title: Martha Argerich, Gidon Kremer and Mischa Maisky
description: Carnegie Hall

title: Adrian, Whose Elegant Styles Were Movie Scene-Stealers
description: Although Gilbert Adrian (1903-1959) never appeared in a movie, he was one of the great Hollywood stars. As a designer of surpassing ability on the Metro Goldwyn Mayer talent team, he dressed Katharine Hepburn, Joan Crawford, Greta Garbo, Norma Shearer, Judy Garland and others for some of their most memorable film roles before setting out on his own to become a leading style maker in the American fashion industry.

title: Report Finds Bias in Nassau Jobs
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., May 16  Minority workers make up more than a third of Nassau County's social services staff, but nearly all their bosses are white, according to a new report that alleges bias in promotions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINER, CHARLES
description: REINER-Charles. On May 15, 2002. With profound sadness and an overwhelming sense of loss, his devoted family and friends mourn his untimely passing after a brief illness. Born in NYC 1946 and raised in Great Neck, NY, he made his homes in Larchmont, NY and West Otis, MA. The son of Norma and the late Jules Reiner, he was an adoring father to Alysia Reiner (daughter of Gail), Katharine (daughter of Terry), and loving father (in-law) of David Basche. He was the older brother of Elizabeth (Paul) and Barry (Andrea) and beloved uncle to Douglas, Benjamin, Allison and Lauren and adored nephew of Joy and Myles Eiten and fond cousin to their children Jonathan (Amy), Emily (Itzhak), Daniel and David (Meg). After obtaining his Ph.D. in Clinical Psychology, he was in private practice for several years. He then founded Vector Strategic Resources, a major national management consulting firm. His associates agree he was able to see the future no matter how confused the present, and engaged his clients in striving for the art of the possible. He was masterful in creating visions for businesses that clients found both inspiring and practical. His company's mission was, above all else ''Make a difference; have fun.'' Reiner was a film enthusiast who started Preferred Films, Ltd, which produced several independent features. His love of the arts, as participant and benefactor was second only to his love of family and friends, for whom he will always remain a beacon. The family is grateful to all those who have been so supportive during this most difficult time. Services Sunday 10 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in his memory can be made and payable to Tanglewood-for the Jules C. Reimer Violin Prize-c/o Boston Symphony Orchestra 301 Massachusetts Ave.,Boston, MA 02115.

title: Jos Lutzenberger, Brazilian Environmentalist, Dies at 75
description: Jos Lutzenberger, one of the principal founders and most outspoken advocates of the environmental movement in Brazil, died Tuesday in Prto Alegre. He was 75.

title: His Actions Are Evil but He Can't Stop
description: ''The Believer'' was shown on Showtime on March 17, 2002. Following are excerpts from Julie Salamon's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 16; the full text is available as a link within this review at nytimes.com/movies. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: Indonesia Plans to Sell Part Of Its Overseas Phone Unit
description: Indonesia's cash-short government said today that it would sell roughly one-ninth of the country's dominant overseas telephone operator, seizing on improving economic tides to push forward its often unpopular privatization program.

title: Gina Magid
description: Feature

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Implant Settlement
description: Sulzer Medica, the Swiss orthopedics maker, said that all but 120 patients who received faulty hip or knee implants had accepted its settlement offer. The acceptance of the settlement, which totals about $1 billion, by about 99 percent of those who had brought suit raised the Zurich company's hope that it can avoid bankruptcy. Analysts had been expecting a higher number of the estimated 30,000 affected to opt out of the settlement. Sulzer reported a 52 percent rise in its first-quarter profit despite another product alert recently when a heart valve tester failed during surgery in Britain. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Peter Pan Meets Another Lost Boy
description: Its title notwithstanding, Paul and Chris Weitz's adaptation of Nick Hornby's breezy, heartfelt novel ''About a Boy'' is really about two boys. One is a 12-year-old social misfit named Marcus (Nicholas Hoult), who is struggling to grow up amid the torments of school, where he is easy prey for bullies, and home, where his mother (Toni Collette) spends much of her time weeping on the couch. The other is 38-year-old Will Freeman (Hugh Grant), who is doing everything in his power to avoid growing up.

title: Wosene Worke Kosrof
description: Skoto Gallery

title: Cerebral Abstraction And Lyrical Waltzes
description: Age triumphed over relative youth, unsurprisingly enough, when the New York City Ballet presented a Diamond Project revival by Kevin O'Day and repertory staples by Jerome Robbins and George Balanchine on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about the dispute stemming from memoirs by James J. Cramer, the former hedge fund manager, and Nicholas W. Maier, a former employee, omitted a response from Mr. Cramer about accusations made by Mr. Maier in his book "Trading With the Enemy." Mr. Maier contended that Mr. Cramer learned in advance about reports planned by two CNBC reporters  Maria Bartiromo and David Faber  and traded on that information. Mr. Cramer has said he never learned about the reports in advance. A spokeswoman for CNBC has also denied the accusations.

title: Senator Prevents Action on Online Privacy Bill
description: Senator Trent Lott, the minority leader, forced the Senate Commerce Committee to adjourn this morning as it was on the verge of adopting an online privacy bill.

title: Budget in Albany Has Few Cuts But Relies on One-Time Revenue
description: While states around the country are reducing spending, New York lawmakers today approved an $89.6 billion budget that sidesteps cuts in services by relying heavily on one-time revenues and nearly exhausting the state's reserves.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Arrest After Kashmir Attack
description: The Pakistani police arrested Hafiz Muhammad Saeed, founder of a banned Islamic group, who was already jailed and released in recent months and whose organization is suspected of mounting an attack on Tuesday in Indian-controlled Kashmir that killed 34 people. The authorities said Mr. Saeed was picked up by a heavily armed police brigade as he was entering Islamabad, the capital, by road from Lahore to attend a religious conference. Indian authorities also blamed his outlawed group, Lashkar-e-Taiba, for an attack on Parliament in December. Howard French (NYT)

title: 6 Stricken by Mysterious Illness in Yonkers
description: Two people were critically ill and four others were hospitalized after they became sick in an apartment building in Yonkers last night in what Mayor John D. Spencer said could be a case of cyanide poisoning.

title: Russia and China Called Top Business Bribers
description: When more than 800 business experts in 15 emerging-market countries were asked recently to identify the most flagrant bribe-payers in richer nations seeking contracts, Russian and Chinese companies emerged at the top of the list, according to a report this week from Transparency International, an independent anticorruption organization.

title: UAL SHAREHOLDERS APPROVE PLAN FOR EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Shareholders of the UAL Corporation approved nonbinding proposals yesterday to separate the jobs of the chairman and the chief executive and to tie executive pay to rebuilding its United Airlines unit. The two measures and a third that would give shareholders a vote on airline acquisitions were passed despite the opposition of the directors. The proposals won more than 60 percent of votes from workers, who own 55 percent of UAL. UAL had a record $2.1 billion loss last year as it cut jobs and flights after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and carried fewer business travelers because of the recession. Shares of UAL fell 20 cents, to $11.89, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Post-9/11, Questions About Security at Electric Plants
description: Rose Marie Poveromo never thought much about security at the five power plants near her home in Astoria Heights, Queens. Instead, she focused on things like whether the tiny particles coming out of the plants caused cancer and made people sick.

title: The Church's Logic
description: To the Editor:

title: Medaglia d'Oro Is a Dangerous Favorite
description: The past performances of the Preakness contenders tell one story. On paper, Medaglia d'Oro was a soundly beaten fourth in the Kentucky Derby, which would seem to indicate he will have problems against the Derby winner, War Emblem, on Saturday.

title: Democrats Say Bush Must Give Full Disclosure
description: WASHINGTON, May 16  After months of unstinting support for President Bush's handling of the war on terror, leading Congressional Democrats changed course today and demanded full disclosure of what Mr. Bush was told last summer about the danger of terrorist hijackings. They also called for a broad public inquiry into what the government knew before Sept. 11.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: MOBILE PHONE EXPANSION China Mobile , the main cellular phone operator in coastal China, said it would pay $10.2 billion to China's state-owned national phone company to buy the cellular phone operations in eight provinces in central and western China. The deal will add 20.9 million subscribers to the 69.6 million that China Mobile already has. China Mobile will raise part of the money for the deal by selling $750 million worth of its shares to the Vodafone Group , which increases its stake in China Mobile to 3.27 percent from 2.18 percent.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about arguments over a course on Palestinian poetry at the University of California at Berkeley referred incorrectly to an earlier campus conflict over the Middle East -- a protest last month that called on the university to divest itself of stock in corporations that do business with Israel. After protesters surged into a building, the police locked some doors to keep others out. The demonstrators did not chain the doors shut.

title: Forest Service to Recommend Opening Alaska Forest Area
description: In its first major decision on wilderness protection, the Bush administration plans to recommend that nine million acres of the Tongass National Forest in Alaska be opened for logging, mining and road building, while 1.4 million acres of the state's Chugach National Forest receive the highest designation of protection.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILORENZO, JEANNETTE B.
description: DiLORENZO-Jeannette B. On May 14, 2002. Wife of the late John, beloved sister of Blanche and the late Philip. Leader of the UFT/RTC, trade unionist and political activist. Services Monday, May 20th at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th street and Amsterdam Avenue. Visiting from 10 AM. Service at 11:45 AM. Contributions may be made to the Jewish Labor Committee, Holocaust Museum, Brooklyn College Fund, American Red Cross.

title: State Budget Passage Leaves Questions for City Finances
description: The approval of the state budget today left New York City with question marks on its balance sheet. A list of requests from the Bloomberg administration, including permission to raise the city's cigarette tax to $1.50 from 8 cents and refinance its pension plans, were left largely unaddressed, even as lawmakers promised that some of the measures would be granted in a separate bill early next week.

description: Julio Gonzalez

title: Xavier Montsalvatge, 90; Composer and Music Critic
description: Xavier Montsalvatge, a Spanish composer and music critic best known for the lush, Neo-Romantic works he composed in the 1940's and 1950's, died on May 7 at his home in Barcelona. He was 90.

title: UPN Keeps Its Focus on Youth, So Its Leader Talks the Talk
description: Not too long ago, the CBS Television president, Leslie Moonves, was known as the head of the network with the oldest audience in television. But now that he also oversees UPN, the youthful sister network of CBS, Mr. Moonves has taken to peppering his speech with street lingo and extolling the virtues of the 18- to 34-year-old television audience.

title: Your Stolen Art? I Threw Them Away, Dear
description: For years Stphane Breitwieser, a youthful-looking Frenchman, traveled through Europe working as a waiter, and in his off hours visited out-of-the-way museums where he looked for opportunities to walk off with what he liked. He stashed stolen oil paintings, rare musical instruments and other art objects in his private collection in his mother's home in Mulhouse, in eastern France, investigators said.

description: Martha Argerich, Gidon Kremer and Mischa Maisky

title: NO HINT OF SEPT. 11 IN REPORT IN AUGUST, WHITE HOUSE SAYS, BUT CONGRESS SEEKS INQUIRY
description: Confronting a political uproar over its disclosure that President Bush was cautioned last August that Osama bin Laden might be planning a hijacking, the White House said today that the assessment was in a C.I.A. analysis that was not based on specific intelligence of any pending attack.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Police Chief Convicted In Peasants' Deaths
description: In a landmark verdict decided by a 4-3 vote, a jury found the commander of a state police contingent guilty of murder in connection with the killing of 19 landless peasants during a 1996 confrontation in the Amazon and sentenced him to 228 years in prison. A trial in 1999 had absolved Col. Mario Colares Pantoja and two other senior officers of all charges but that verdict was overturned because of procedural irregularities.

description: Artemis Greenberg Van Doren

title: Adelphia Fails to Make Note Payment
description: Adelphia Communications failed to make a crucial payment to a creditor yesterday and appears to be in violation of some bond and bank loan agreements, putting the company in perilous financial condition.

title: Williams Wary About Next Season
description: The last time the Maryland men's basketball team played was April 1, when it won the N.C.A.A. championship. Coach Gary Williams is not sure what the team can do for an encore, not with four starters leaving.

description: To the Editor:

title: F.B.I. Is Investigating Kmart For Possible Criminal Violations
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation, working with the United States attorney in Detroit, said yesterday that it was examining Kmart's records to determine whether any of the company's activities warranted criminal charges.

title: National Briefing | Education And Science: Jupiter Regains Moon Lead
description: Jupiter is once again the planet with the most known moons. Astronomers at the University of Hawaii announced the discovery of 11 new moons, bringing Jupiter's total to 39, which overtakes Saturn's 30. The new moons, which were estimated to be from 1 to 2.5 miles in diameter, travel in distant, tilted elliptical orbits around Jupiter, suggesting that they had been passing bodies that were captured by the planet's gravity. The observations were made using the 12-inch Canada-France-Hawaii telescope at Mauna Kea on the main island, Hawaii, in December, then confirmed by observations with a second telescope in the months that followed. In July, astronomers announced the discovery of 12 new moons around Saturn, which briefly made that planet the leader in moons.

title: Commencement; Uniforms Take Honored Place at N.Y.U.
description: Much about New York University's commencement ceremony yesterday was steeped in familiar ritual: a senior faculty member passed the school's silver torch to the youngest graduate, beach balls bounced through the sea of violet robes and trumpets rang out from the top of the Washington Square arch.

title: National Briefing | West: Alaska: Captain In Valdez Spill Pays Debt
description: The ship captain responsible for the country's worst oil spill finished paying his debt to the State of Alaska with a $50,000 check. The restitution was part of a sentence issued in 1990 after a jury convicted the captain of the Exxon Valdez, Joseph J. Hazelwood, for the negligent discharge of oil after the tanker ran aground in 1989. The spill spewed 11 million gallons of crude oil into Prince William Sound and marred 1,500 miles of coastline. The sentence called for probation, the restitution and 1,000 hours of community service, which he completed last summer. Douglas Jehl (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Insurer's Profit Rises
description: First-quarter profit at Allianz, an insurance company based in Munich, rose to 1.9 billion euros ($1.7 billion) from 705 million euros the previous year, the company said. Its results were helped by gains of 2.3 billion euros from the sale of shares in the Vodafone Group and in Munich Re and from a change in German tax law that made the sales tax free. The results included losses of 108 million euros from its banking unit, Dresdner Bank. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Congress Meets An I.M.F. Demand
description: After five months of debate, Congress has approved changes in a bankruptcy law that the International Monetary Fund had been demanding as a condition for resuming financial aid. The changes, sought by President Eduardo Duhalde, allow foreign investors to take over local companies and revoke other provisions said to favor debtors over creditors. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Pena Flowers While Henson Wilts
description: Not everything the Yankees touch turns to gold. At least not instantly.

description: Untitled, Yes; Neglected, No

title: Aides Say Pope Would Resign If Unfit to Work
description: An increasingly infirm Pope John Paul II turns 82 on Saturday, and two cardinals close to him have said they believe that he would step down if he were no longer able to function in the job.

title: N.C.A.A. Quarterfinals To Be Played at Hofstra
description: The N.C.A.A. Division I men's lacrosse tournament comes to the metropolitan New York area tomorrow with games involving Princeton, the defending champion, and Syracuse, last year's runner-up.

title: Fed Proposes Charging Banks Higher Rate for Direct Loans
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  The Federal Reserve proposed a substantial change today in its system of lending directly to commercial banks, saying it wants to increase the interest rate it charges on emergency overnight loans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, MARY JUDITH, M.D., M.P.H.
description: MURPHY-Mary Judith, M.D., M.P.H. On May 16, 2002. Born on July 23, 1943 in New York City, daughter of Francis X. & Margaret (nee McNally) Murphy. Graduate of College of Mt. St. Vincent, NY Medical College and Columbia University. A loving mother, wife & pediatrician, she was a member of the faculty at Columbia University until she pursued a career in the pharmaceutical industry with Pfizer. Mary Judith was an expert on childhood infectious diseases and a Fellow of the American Academy of Pediatrics. Surviving: husband, Dr. Joseph H. Graziano, Hastings - on - Hudson; daughter, Caitlin Judith Graziano; sisters Kathleen Murphy Mallinger of San Diego, CA, Anne Murphy, M.D. Baltimore, MD, brothers Francis X., Jr. of Philadelphia, PA, Christopher of Lakewood, CO, Timothy of Silver Springs, MD; Joe's children Michelle McCarthy and Joseph N. Graziano, M.D. Funeral service 1PM Saturday at EdwardsDowdle Funeral Home 64 Ashford Avenue (exit 17 Saw Mill) Dobbs Ferry, NY. Visiting Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Contributions to Friends of Children's Fund at American Academy of Pediatrics, 38367 Eagle Way, Chicago, IL 60678-1383.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Catholic Hospital Acted Legally In Firing Evangelical
description: The State Supreme Court ruled that a Roman Catholic hospital was free to fire a file clerk for what the hospital called objectionable speech by the clerk about his evangelical Christian faith. The court held that the ability of a religious employer to control religious speech in the workplace was important to its mission and that courts should not become entangled in deciding what is appropriate religious speech. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Korea Frets Over Animal Disease as World Cup Approaches
description: The Agricultural Ministry intensified its search today for signs of foot and mouth disease on farms throughout the country after President Kim Dae Jung expressed concern that an outbreak of the disease would reduce attendance at the World Cup soccer tournament that begins here this month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRABOWSKI, BENJAMIN
description: GRABOWSKI-Benjamin. On April 30, 2002, former New York Times employee Benjamin Grabowski passed away at his home at 5036 Abagail Drive in Springhill, Florida. Mr. Grabowski is survived by his wife Ann of 41 years and his two step sons Sal and Michael. Mr. Grabowski was employed in the production advertising area. He would have been 82 on his next birthday.

title: Another Snag For ImClone And Its Drug For Cancer
description: In another potential blow to ImClone Systems, the company with the European rights to ImClone's cancer drug, Erbitux, has decided not to modify its clinical trial in some ways that ImClone believed would help the drug win approval in the United States, a spokesman for the European partner, Merck of Germany, said yesterday.

title: Witnesses Say Ex-Klansman Boasted of Church Bombing
description: Willadean Brogdon, who once left her then husband in a cloud of dust on the side of the road in Mount Olive, Ala., and could never be called an impartial witness, said she heard him say on several occasions that he planted the bomb that killed four girls at the 16th Street Baptist Church.

title: Cardinal in Los Angeles Says He Let Abuser Remain a Priest
description: Cardinal Roger M. Mahony, who has maintained that he dealt firmly with any sexual abuse accusations against priests here in his archdiocese, has now acknowledged that he allowed one to remain in the ministry after that priest told him in 1986 that he had molested some boys.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the first and second days of Shavuot, the Jewish Feast of Weeks, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Telecom Profit Is Up
description: Japan's second-largest telecommunications carrier, the KDDI Corporation, said spending cuts helped increase its profit 30 percent in the six months to March 2002. The company earned 6.3 billion yen ($49.1 million) during the period even though sales slowed 2.8 percent. KDDI's ''au'' mobile phones face stiff competition from NTT DoCoMo Inc. and the J-Phone Company, which is owned by the Vodafone Group of Britain. KDDI's mobile phone unit lost 59 billion yen last year, but its recently released third-generation phone service is expected to help restore profits this year. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: State Dept. Report Investigating Arafat's Links to Terror Is at Odds With Israeli Claims
description: A new State Department report has found ''no conclusive evidence'' that Yasir Arafat or other senior Palestinian leaders planned or approved specific terrorist attacks on Israel in the six months that ended in December, an assertion sharply at odds with recent Israeli claims.

description: PLAPINGER-Rea. Of New York, died on May 12, 2002, in Ashland, Oregon. No services are planned.

title: Insulting the Tongass
description: The administration has flunked the first big test of its pledge to protect roadless areas of the national forest system from logging and other commercial development. It decided yesterday to leave fragile parts of Alaska's Tongass National Forest unprotected. This is unsettling news for the future of President Bill Clinton's roadless policy and for the old-growth trees of the Tongass, a splendid forest of talismanic significance for environmentalists.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Rail Merger Blocked
description: A regulatory panel voted to block the merger of Mexico's second-largest and third-largest railways on antitrust grounds. Grupo Mxico, which had sought to unite its Ferrocarril Mexicano line with the nation's southern line, Ferrocarril del Sureste, said that it would appeal the decision and might ask a court to issue an injunction allowing the deal to proceed. The plan was opposed by the country's largest railroad, Transportacin Ferroviaria Mexicana. Graham Gori (NYT)

title: Newest MetroStar Faces His Old Team
description: Tonight's game against D.C. United will be something of a homecoming for new MetroStars midfielder, Mark Lisi, who came to the team last week along with defender Craig Zaidie in exchange for midfielder Petter Villegas and defender Orlando Perez. With the MetroStars' Clint Mathis playing for the United States national team for the next few weeks, the team added Lisi to add some punch to its midfield and ignite the offense.

description: Kenyon Martin listened to the talk and just shrugged his shoulders.

While the auction catalog costs $40, there is no charge to view the cars, on display until noon today.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about plans by a maker of medical devices to split its stock 2 for 1 misstated the company's name. It is St. Jude Medical Inc., not Medical Center.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Navy Ship Reports Early For Reef Duty
description: A 510-foot Navy ship that was supposed to be scuttled with explosives to create a giant artificial reef sank on its own off the Keys, sending workers scrambling to get off. The 46-year-old ship, the Spiegel Grove, started going down as workers prepared to blow holes in it. A tugboat had to carry the workers to safety. The ship ended up upside down in about 160 feet of water, its bow sticking out of the sea. The Spiegel Grove was to be the largest vessel ever deliberately sunk to create an artificial reef, intended as a nursery for fish and a playground for snorkelers and scuba divers. Dana Canedy (NYT)

description: The White House began an aggressive attack on Democrats in Congress today as President Bush tried to contain the political fury over a warning he received last August that Osama bin Laden might be planning a hijacking.

description: The White House learned in February 2001 that Osama bin Laden had discussed hijacking a Pakistani airliner with the son of Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman at a meeting earlier that year in Afghanistan, according to current and former administration officials.

title: Preakness Forecast: War Emblem Can Expect No Breeze

But if you believe the trainers of the colts in Saturday's 127th running of the Preakness Stakes, the first quarter-mile is where the second leg of the Triple Crown is going to be won or lost.

description: The Treasury Department urged Congress tonight to stop companies from using offshore shelters to avoid United States income taxes but warned that the problem could not be solved by legislation that simply outlawed overseas tax havens.
