title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Bridgeport: Economic Council
description: Gov. John G. Rowland appointed 10 city business leaders yesterday to a council created to promote economic development in the city in the wake of Mayor Joseph P. Ganim's indictment on federal racketeering, bribery and extortion charges. At a news conference here, the governor said he wanted to re-establish the state's partnership with the city and make a ''fresh start'' by using the experience and connection of the council to bring business to Bridgeport.

title: Mayor Finds More Limits To Control Of Schools
description: For several months now, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has been trying to wrest control of the New York City school system, first by seeking to abolish the Board of Education, then, when that failed, by demanding that he be able to appoint a majority of its members.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENWASSER, ROBERT
description: ROSENWASSER-Robert. Passed away on May 16, 2002, after a long and dreadful illness. Dearest husband of Dorothy, devoted father of Carol Harris & Marsha and Tim Schaffner, stepfather of Jonathan Peret and Terrence and Joanne Paret, loving grandfather of Debby and Will Gans and Dan and Rivka Bushell, great-grandfather of Malky Bushell, brother of Sidney Rosenwasser. Robert Rosenwasser was the founder and President of Rosenwasser Grossman Consulting Engineers. He was a distinguished engineer with a long career who received numerous awards in structural engineering. He was acclaimed for his many contributions to the NYC skyline. Robert Rosenwasser was a graduate of the City College of New York. He was a member of Chi Epsilon, the National Civil Engineering honor fraternity, and was a Fellow of the American Concrete Institute. He was honored by the Concrete Industry Board of New York, which presented him with its Leader of Industry Award. He wrote several articles on various aspects of building design, construction and economics. Services will be held Sunday, May 19, 2002, at 1:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave at 81st St. Shiva will be observed directly following the service, Sunday, May 19, at the Rosenwasser residence. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Departments of Immunology and Neurology at Mt. Sinai Hospital, 5 East 98th Street, New York 10029.

title: U.S. Injuries Are Not Serious
description: The United States soccer team received encouraging news yesterday after several players were injured during Thursday's 5-0 victory over Jamaica at Giants Stadium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONSON, SIDNEY
description: ARONSON-Sidney. On May 5, 2002. Beloved husband of Letty. Loving father of Christopher, Erika and Alexa. Adoring grandfather of Katherine and Ethan. He will be missed by his family and friends. Service Sunday 3pm at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in his memory may be made to New Yorkers for Children, 200 Park Ave, Ste. 4503, NY, NY 10166.

title: Carter Urges Bush to Reject Plan to Aid Cuba Dissidents
description: As the Bush administration prepares to announce a more aggressive policy against President Fidel Castro that could include channeling resources to dissidents, former President Jimmy Carter strongly warned today that such a move would be counterproductive.

title: Lives Lost and the Renewal of Downtown
description: I am one of the lucky ones. The remains of my husband, Neil Levin, were found under the rubble that was once Tower One. Two-thirds of those who lost family at the World Trade Center on Sept. 11 may never be able to bury their loved ones. New York's experience is not like that of Oklahoma City, where victims of terrorism were recovered and laid to rest. What survivors here need and expect from the trade center site -- once the rubble is finally cleared and the search ended within the next month -- is very different. This is a burial ground, not just a location for a future national memorial.

title: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: Trade Pact Spans Atlantic
description: Chile and the European Union have concluded an agreement that will free more than $7 billion in trade between the two, the first deal of its kind between Europe and South America. ''Today the dreams of 15 million Chileans are with us, and also the hopes of all Latin America,'' the president of Chile, Ricardo Lagos, said at a meeting of leaders of the European Union, Latin America and the Caribbean. The host, Prime Minister Jos Maria Aznar of Spain, hailed the agreement as a ''landmark in European foreign policy.'' The union is negotiating a similar deal with the Mercosur block of Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Where There Wasn't a Will, He Found a Way
description: He liked fast cars and attractive women, and if those passions did not make Mel Spillman unique among men, the cars, at least, seemed beyond the limits of his salary. Yet he would arrive at his $33,000-a-year job as a court clerk driving a Mercedes-Benz or a Ferrari.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Fox Promises Water For U.S.
description: President Vicente Fox said Mexico would pay a debt of billions of gallons of water it owes to the United States under a 1944 treaty. Much of the water has been diverted before reaching the Rio Grande by officials in Chihuahua, south of Texas. This has deprived farmers in Texas and Mexico's Tamaulipas. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: AERONAUTIC CONCERN HAS LOSS The European Aeronautic, Defense and Space Company posted a first-quarter net loss as its Airbus unit delivered fewer planes, and new orders fell 80 percent after Sept. 11 . The company said it had a net loss of 25 million euros ($21.2 million) in contrast to profit of 1.67 billion euros a year earlier. Sales rose 2 percent.   (Bloomberg News)

title: A Beautiful Friendship
description: Thanks to some dogged diplomacy and a little skillful spin, two once implacable foes this week achieved a surprising, if temporary, rapprochement.

title: Early Warning Was Still Too Late
description: After learning last summer that Al Qaeda might resort to airplane hijackings, did President Bush and his advisers do enough to prevent possible terrorist actions like those of Sept. 11? This question must be answered, and soon -- not for partisan political purposes, but to ensure that the United States is doing everything possible to prevent future terrorist attacks.

title: Tokyo Sees End of Recession, But Others Are Not So Sure
description: Japan's government signaled today that it believed that the country's third recession in the last decade had ended, joining a growing band of optimistic forecasters in the private sector. But many experts suspect that the government's outlook is born more of political pragmatism than economic analysis.

title: National Briefing
description: SOUTHWEST

title: Corrections
description: Apage from last Saturday's issue was reprinted inadvertently in some Florida copies on Monday in place of the correct Page A5. The omitted material was a full-page advertisement, which may be obtained from Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; telephone (212) 556-1992. E-mail: quality@nytimes.com. (Include a postal address.)

title: After Accused Priest's Suicide, Shock and Second Thoughts
description: He spent most of his 37-year career as a Roman Catholic priest here in one of the wealthiest regions of the nation, yet he seemed most content during his two years in a remote Peruvian mountain village.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINER, CHARLES
description: REINER-Charles, on May 15, 2002. With profound sadness and an overwhelming sense of loss, his devoted family and friends mourn his untimely passing after a brief illness. Services Sunday 10 A.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: MERRILL TO QUIT ONLINE JOINT VENTURE WITH HSBC
description: Merrill Lynch said yesterday that it was quitting an unprofitable two-year-old online brokerage joint venture with HSBC Holdings to save money. HSBC, a European bank, said it would take over the venture, which serves customers in Britain, Canada and Australia. Merrill said it had spent $200 million on the project.

title: Chancellor's Hair Color Is Now Ward of the Court
description: Gerhard Schrder, the German chancellor, won a legal victory today in his campaign to quash news reports that he dyes his hair. But even before he could celebrate, the advertising industry gave Mr. Schrder entirely new grounds for hair rage.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Buffalo: Union Members Indicted
description: Federal prosecutors unsealed a seven-count indictment against 14 members of Laborers Local 91, based in Niagara Falls, yesterday, charging the defendants with racketeering, extortion and conspiracy. Michael A. Battle, the United States attorney, said the defendants, who included the leaders of the largest construction trades union in Niagara County, repeatedly threatened employers and union and nonunion workers. ''It's a throwback to the Stone Age of operating labor unions,'' said Peter J. Ahearn, special agent in charge of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Buffalo office.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: E.ON May Sell Degussa Stake
description: Germany's biggest utility, E.ON, is in negotiations that may give control of Degussa, the specialty chemical maker, to RAG, a European coal company, E.ON's co-chief executive, Wilhelm Simson, said at the company's annual meeting. E.ON owns 64.5 percent of Degussa and Mr. Simson is also the head of Degussa's supervisory board. E.ON agreed to sell its nonenergy holdings to win regulatory approval for an acquisition. RAG could combine Degussa with its own chemicals unit, Ruetgers.

title: Albany's 'Miracle' Budget
description: After New York State's legislators adopted their $90 billion budget this week, one leader lovingly called it a ''miracle.'' If a miracle is something that may be too good to be true, then he's right. This budget is designed to do one thing well -- re-elect incumbents this fall. It is full of apparent good news, especially for New York City, while under the press releases are signs of financial trouble.

title: Russia Will Gradually End Restrictions on Oil Exports
description: Russia said today that it would stop holding down its oil exports and let them rise to former levels over the next two months.

title: A.P. RANDOLPH WINS
description: A.P. Randolph easily won the Manhattan Girls Public Schools Athletic League borough title with the help of Angelica Reed, who the long jump and the high jump in action at Dewitt Clinton High School in the Bronx. Reed also finished second in the 100-meter hurdles. Serena Sappleton, Randolph's middle distance standout, won the 1,500 meters and 400 intermediate hurdles events. Murray Burgtraum was second in the final standing with 165 points.

title: MAKER OF DISPOSABLE PLATES AND CUPS TAKES GREEN TURN
description: Sweetheart Cup, a leading manufacturer of disposable packaging and food service items, and Earthshell, a developer of biodegradable materials, said yesterday that Sweetheart intended to manufacture and sell containers, cups, plates and bowls from Earthshell's materials in North America. Sweetheart is based in Owings Mills, Md. Earthshell is based in Santa Barbara, Calif. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: The Pimlico 13
description: Four survivors of the Kentucky Derby, including the winner, and nine fresh horses will contend in the 127th running of the Preakness Stakes today. The selections were listed in order of preference by Joe Drape; the morning line was provided by Frank Carulli, the oddsmaker at Pimlico Race Course.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Peace Talks Set For June
description: A senior aide to the prime minister said talks between the government and separatist ethnic Tamil rebels were expected to begin in June in Thailand. Bradman Weerakoon also said the government would have to lift the ban on the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam if talks were to happen. Both sides signed a cease-fire in February, and Norway has been trying to broker the talks. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERT, IRVING
description: ALBERT-Irving, 80. Died suddenly on May 13, 2002 at home. Born in Poland, came to the United States in 1938. An honored union organizer and committed leftist. He served in the U.S. Armed Forces in the invasion of North Africa, landed in Anzio and marched to Rome. Supported many Jewish causes. And was an Alaskan entrepreneur. Husband of Alicia and the late Dorothy, father of Marc and David, father-in-law of Orna, adoring grandfather of Ben, and relentless competitor at pinochle. Service Sunday, May 19, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The family will be at home this week.

title: Louima's Credibility at Issue in Hearings
description: A federal judge ruled yesterday that prosecutors improperly kept information from defense lawyers in the Abner Louima case, saying it raised questions about Mr. Louima's account of how many police officers were present when he was attacked in 1997.

title: Kenneth A. Lohf, 77, Librarian for Rare Books at Columbia
description: Kenneth A. Lohf, a Columbia University librarian who in a quarter century more than doubled the university's collection of rare books and manuscripts, died on May 9 at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 77 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Before The Word, Perhaps The Wink?; Some Language Experts Think Humans Spoke First With Gestures
description: ''What a hairy back!'' was Lily Tomlin's candidate for the first human sentence. But whatever the content of that original remark, if Michael C. Corballis is correct, it was expressed in gestures, not words.

title: 1,000 British Marines Join Australians in Firefight With Suspected Taliban
description: Nearly 1,000 British marines were airlifted this morning to a rugged corner of eastern Afghanistan where an Australian Special Forces patrol had come under heavy fire on Thursday afternoon from suspected Taliban fighters, American and British officials said today.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: LEAVING MUSEUM BOARD Peg Breen, the president of the New York Landmarks Conservancy who also served on the board of the Museum of the City of New York for a year and a half, has resigned from the museum's board. The museum directors had wanted to move into the Tweed Courthouse, an idea that was supported by the conservancy but rebuffed by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. "My primary duty is to the Landmarks Conservancy," Ms. Breen said yesterday. "And there are going to be times when we diverge on things. I just wanted to be very clear that I am speaking for the conservancy."

title: 6 Days in Jail Broke Him, Freed Pornographer Says
description: Just before the pornographer Al Goldstein was sentenced to 60 days in jail this month for harassing his former secretary, he delivered a stirring speech in which he claimed the mantle of First Amendment martyr. ''Jail means nothing to me,'' Mr. Goldstein thundered, ''because freedom means so much to me.''

title: Flight Crews' Reaction Mixed On a Lack of Pre-9/11 Alerts
description: Some pilots and flight attendants are criticizing airlines for not passing on to flight crews general warnings of terrorist threats that the federal government gave to the carriers before Sept. 11. But others say such vague warnings are useless and would have made little difference in the way they went about their daily routine.

title: Hoteliers and Bias
description: To the Editor:

title: Andersen Team Challenges Intent in Shredding
description: Arthur Andersen's defense team had its best day in court since the beginning of the firm's trial, challenging the chief prosecution witness today on whether he intended to impede a federal investigation through the destruction of documents related to Enron.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Fine Or Jail For Sprinkling With Intent
description: Because of a statewide drought, two towns have amended their water restrictions and increased penalties. In Parachute, people who water lawns during restricted times could face a fine of up to $1,000 or a year in jail. In nearby Silt, people who use water for irrigation or other reasons in yards can be fined $1,000 or spend 90 days in jail. Officials in both towns said that it was unlikely anyone would serve time for excessive watering of their grass but that warnings and subsequent fines would be enforced. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: District Council 37 Leaders Order Audit of Benefits Fund
description: The new leaders of District Council 37, New York City's largest municipal union, said yesterday that they had ordered a thorough audit of the union's benefits fund, which will receive $206 million from the city this year.

title: Abdur-Rahim Wins Decathlon at IC4A
description: Mustafa Abdur-Rahim, a Dartmouth sophomore from Brookline, Mass., posted four personal-best performances and totaled 7,171 points to win the decathlon in the 126th annual Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletics men's track and field championships at Princeton's Weaver Stadium.

title: Youths Dreamed of Adventure, But Settled for Killing a Couple
description: The two Vermont teenagers who pleaded guilty to killing two Dartmouth College professors envisioned themselves as explorers but decided on a life of crime after concluding that every place had been explored, according to transcripts of prosecutors' interviews with one of them.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ENBRIDGE ENERGY PARTNERS, Houston, a transporter of oil and gas to refineries, said it would buy assets for $929 million from Enbridge, Calgary, Alberta, a pipeline company.

title: Embracing The Auteurs At Cannes
description: This year's Cannes International Film Festival is, as always, an embrace of auteurs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, JOHN CHABOT
description: SMITH-John Chabot. On May 16, 2002. Author. Former White House, and W.W. II correspondent for The NY Herald Tribune, and retired writing teacher. Loving husband of the late Betty McCarthy Smith. Devoted father of Michael Smith, and the late Betsy Falk. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 11:30 AM at St. Saviour Church, Park Slope. Interment at Green-wood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers please make donations in John's name to Veritas Therapeutic Community, 912 Amsterdam Ave., New York, New York 10025.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Egyptian Sought By U.S. Is Freed
description: An Egyptian facing possible extradition to the United States on charges of financing Al Qaeda was freed on $22,000 bail and told to return to court on May 31. The action came the day after Yassir al-Sirri, 39, was cleared by another court of conspiring in the murder of Ahmed Shah Massoud, the anti-Taliban Afghan guerrilla leader, shortly before Sept. 11. He was immediately rearrested on a United States warrant seeking his extradition. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Curb the Endless Ringing of the Telemarketers
description: It happened again the other night: I was bottle-feeding the baby when the phone rang, just out of reach. I put the baby down -- he immediately started to squawk -- rose from my chair and picked up the receiver. The caller wasn't my wife saying when she'd be home or my editor wondering when I'd file. It was a tape-recorded message from a local window dealer offering a free estimate. By the time I had hung up, my little boy was in a full-blown cry.

title: Dr. Frankenstein on the Hill
description: House Republicans called in a latter-day Dr. Frankenstein this week in an absurd attempt to stampede the Senate into passing a ban on all human cloning, even that intended for the most beneficial purposes. The witness was Dr. Panayiotis Zavos, one of a small band of scientists who have been titillating and terrifying anyone who will listen by proclaiming that they will soon produce the world's first cloned human baby. The very thought, House Republicans hope, may push Congress to impose a ban on all human cloning lest the dreaded deed happen here instead of abroad.

title: A Triple Play Is Grand
description: The Mets spent most of the first seven weeks of the season wondering when they would start resembling the team that was assembled over the winter. Where was the infield that boasted three potential Gold Glove winners? Where was the offense? Where was the excitement?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEPLER, MORTON M. MD.
description: LEPLER-Morton M. MD. Age 94. Of Lenox, Mass. Died Wednesday, May 15, 2002 at his home. Husband of the late Gertrude (Fine) Lepler. Survivors include two sons, Harold Lepler of Brewster, N.Y. and Edward Lepler of San Francisco, Calif. Funeral Service Sunday, May 19, 1PM at Riverdale Temple, 4545 Independence Ave, Bronx. Interment King David Cemetery, Putnam Valley, N.Y. Beecher Funeral Home, 1 Putnam Ave, Brewster New York, phone 845-279-3615.

title: Senate Democrats Escalate Efforts to Get White House To Disclose Enron Contacts
description: Senate Democrats investigating the collapse of Enron are turning up the heat on the White House, with Senator Joseph I. Lieberman saying today that he plans to subpoena the Bush administration about its contacts with the company, which was once highly influential politically.

title: Beliefs; In four pages, Al Franken ranks world religions and explains the thousand faces of God.
description: No one would ever confuse ''Oh, the Things I Know!'' by Al Franken, Ph.D. (Hon.), with the heavy tomes occasionally discussed in this column. ''Oh, the Things I Know!'' is definitely a light book, nine ounces, in fact, by the scale closest at hand.

title: Scott Not Afraid to Be Walking Bulletin Board
description: Many coaches scour the news clippings searching for an inflammatory comment, an item to pin on the bulletin board that can motivate their players. Nets Coach Byron Scott prefers to create his own stir, handing out incendiary comments for other teams to cling to and for his own players to defend.

title: Joe Black, Pitching Pioneer for the Dodgers, Dies at 78
description: Joe Black, the Brooklyn Dodgers pitcher who was the National League rookie of the year in 1952, the year he also became the first African-American to win a World Series game, died yesterday in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 78.

title: Contaminated Food Sickened Six in Yonkers, Officials Say
description: After considering everything from cyanide poisoning to bioterrorism, officials here say that six residents who became violently ill Thursday night appear to have suffered from food contamination.

title: Into the Valley of the Shadow Rode the Obedient Declarer
description: Whether it is ever proper to disobey an order from a superior officer is often argued, especially when obedience leads to disaster. It is easier at the bridge table, but even then players are often too obedient.

title: The Chief of a Record Label Joins the Hip-Hop Subgenre He Helped Create
description: El-P is the biggest star in a hip-hop subgenre that he helped create, revered by an audience that likes its beats noisy and its verse free. His performance at the Bowery Ballroom on Monday was a party in his honor, celebrating his first solo album, "Fantastic Damage," which was released the next day by the label he runs, Definitive Jux.

title: Masur in His Waning Moments, With a Smile and a Wave to the Past
description: Kurt Masur's neatly orchestrated withdrawal from the New York Philharmonic took its historical turn on Thursday night. A music director in his waning moments was conducting the music of former music directors: before intermission, Leonard Bernstein's Serenade for Strings, Harp and Percussion; after intermission, the Mahler First Symphony.

title: Bagwell Leads Astros To Sixth Straight Victory
description: Jeff Bagwell hit a three-run homer, and the Houston Astros extended their winning streak to a season-high six games last night with a 7-4 victory over the visiting Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: Pakistan Says Body Is Likely to Be Pearl's
description: The Pakistani authorities said today that they had unearthed the remains of someone believed to be the Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl, who was kidnapped on Jan. 23 and later killed.

title: Europe 'Is Rubbing Its Eyes' at the Ascent of the Right
description: With the rise of the right in the Netherlands after elections this week, it is more clear than ever that Europe's political landscape is being dramatically redrawn.

title: Excerpts From Senator Clinton's Speech
description: Following are excerpts from a speech by Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in the Senate on Thursday, as recorded by The Congressional Record. A complete transcript is online at nytimes.com/politics.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Kansas: Raising Sales And Cigarette Taxes
description: Lawmakers approved a $255.7 million tax increase to help balance the state's budget. The bill would increase the sales tax to 5.3 percent from 4.9 percent beginning this summer, but the tax would drop to 5 percent in 2005. Legislators also agreed to raise the tax on cigarettes to 70 cents from 24 cents starting July 1. It will rise again in 2003, to 79 cents. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Mississippi Weighing Choctaw License
description: The Mississippi Motor Vehicle Commission failed to reach a decision on whether the state's band of Choctaw Indians could keep a license to operate a small Ford Motor dealership in Carthage, in the central part of the state.

title: Smarter Sanctions on Iraq
description: Visitors to Baghdad are quickly herded to the Saddam Hussein Children's Hospital for a look at what Iraqis say is the result of international trade sanctions -- sick and undernourished infants. Unicef says that in much of the country Iraqi children under age 5 are dying at more than twice the rate they did a decade ago. It's a heart-rending sight, as are the dilapidated cars and crumbling homes in a society that a generation ago enjoyed standards of living and welfare comparable to much of Europe.

title: A Prince's Passion Finally Pays Off
description: The first time Prince Ahmed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia went to see a man about a horse, it was in the early 1980's and he was studying comparative culture at the University of California-Irvine. He made an appointment to meet a trainer, Richard Mulhall, at a farm to view a gray stallion named Jumping Hill, never mentioning that he was a member of his country's royal family.

title: Trump Cancels Bond Sale, Calling Rates Too High
description: Failing to entice the financial markets, Donald J. Trump canceled a $470 million sale of bonds for his casinos yesterday because investors were demanding such high interest rates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, FLORENCE BLOOM
description: EISENBERG - Florence Bloom, peacefully on Friday, May 17, 2002, beloved wife of the late Bernard C. Eisenberg, formerly of White Meadow Lake and Teaneck, NJ. Much loved by her children Edward Eisenberg, Stephen Eisenberg, Marian E. Dunn and Lisa Macchi and their spouses. Loving grandmother of Roark Dunn, Darin Dunn, Ryan Dunn Jacob, Glenn, Leigh, and Gregg Eisenberg, Melissa Sodowick and Amanda Macchi. Great-grandmother of Ariel, Leah, Truman and Julia. A beloved Aunt of many. She was a gracious and wonderful lady, cherished by us all. Services are 12 noon, Sunday at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel W-150 Route 4 East, Paramus, NJ.

title: Anderson Revives His Game in Boston
description: The epiphany came late last season, when Kenny Anderson was rehabilitating his sprained right ankle and heard the whisper about his demise as a player. Afraid that the Boston Celtics might trade him or, worse, bench him, Anderson decided to change his approach to basketball.

title: Witness Offers a Motive at Skakel Trial
description: A former classmate of Michael C. Skakel testified today that Mr. Skakel felt that ''his brother stole his girlfriend,'' offering jurors a possible motive for the 1975 killing of Martha Moxley. The classmate, Elizabeth Arnold, said that she never heard Mr. Skakel confess but that ''he was very upset because he didn't know whether he had killed this girl.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Looking For A Mandate
description: Voters chose the 166 members of Parliament in an election that appeared certain to return Prime Minister Bertie Ahern, left, to office, possibly with a majority that would produce the first single-party government in 25 years. Contesting an Irish election more vigorously than it ever had before, Sinn Fein, the political arm of the Irish Republican Army, hoped to add as many as four seats to the one it gained in 1997. Most of the votes will be counted today, with results expected by evening. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Why America Slept: The Furor Over Sept. 11
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Deadly Attacks Show Signs of a Qaeda Revival
description: French and German investigators said today that they were nearly certain that recent car bombings in Tunisia and Pakistan that killed 31 people were the work of Al Qaeda cells that have reactivated themselves since the American war in Afghanistan.

title: Survivor of '63 Bomb Recalls Glass Shards and a Sister Lost
description: Sarah Collins Rudolph, even with one eye of glass, can still see the morning of Sept. 15, 1963, can see it sharp and clear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, CHARLES
description: STRAUSS-Charles. The Board of Directors and Members of the Quaker Ridge Golf Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Charles Strauss, whose many years of friendship, kindness & enthusiastic spirit will always be remembered. We send our sincere condolences to his family. Beth Z. Post, President Roger H. Tulcin, Secretar

title: Why America Slept: The Furor Over Sept. 11
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Dictator's Daughter Forms Party
description: Park Geun Hye, the daughter of the country's former dictator Park Chung Hee, was appointed yesterday to lead a party she has formed, and many analysts expect her to be a candidate in the December presidential election. Ms. Park said the Korean Coalition for the Future would name a candidate to succeed Kim Dae Jung, who under the Constitution cannot seek a second term. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: McCall Issues Budget Warning
description: Even if New York City gets all of the assistance it has requested from Albany, Washington and the city's labor unions, it could still face a shortfall of $1 billion in the next fiscal year, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall warned yesterday. The gap could reach $2 billion without the requested assistance, according to Mr. McCall's review of the city's four-year financial plan. ''With tax revenues coming up short and the economic recovery proceeding slowly, the reality is harsh,'' said Mr. McCall, a Democratic candidate for governor. On Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's weekly radio program yesterday, the mayor said: ''Even if we have a reasonably robust improvement in the economy, the tax revenues aren't going to be enough. We're going to have to make some very hard choices next year.'' Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Kronos Quartet Gathers All the Music of Mexico
description: An opening chord sounded like a fanfare when the Kronos Quartet started its second show on Thursday night at Joe's Pub. That was only appropriate, since the string quartet was playing a version of ''El Sinaloense'' based on the version by El Recodo, a Mexican brass band from the state of Sinaloa. In its continuing quest to play every musical style, Kronos has just released an album, ''Nuevo'' (Nonesuch), that's an idiosyncratic anthology of Mexican compositions: classical, rural, television themes, romantic ballads, warped easy listening, alternative rock. It played most of the album's selections on Thursday, in an extremely rare cabaret engagement that continues through tonight.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: Rabbi Trial Is Moved
description: The retrial of the Cherry Hill rabbi accused of contracting for his wife's murder was moved to Monmouth County yesterday. At a hearing yesterday, Judge Linda G. Baxter of State Superior Court said she chose the new venue because it had similar demographics to Camden County, where the first trial attracted considerable media coverage and ended in November 2001 with a split verdict. The rabbi, Fred J. Neulander, who prosecutors say arranged the fatal beating of his wife in 1994 so he could continue his affair with a Philadelphia talk radio host, could face the death penalty if convicted.

title: Patting a Back Can Be Painful If It's Yours
description: ORTHOPEDISTS in Albany must have worked overtime yesterday. There had to have been a lot of sprained arms, considering how hard politicians in the state capital patted themselves on the back for approving a budget.

title: Police Kill Drug Suspect in Raid, Saying He Charged at Troopers
description: A New York State Police trooper fatally shot a man who charged at officers as they stormed his bedroom during a drug raid early yesterday on the East End of Long Island, the police said.

title: Vanishing Act: Whitman Stays Far From Home In New Jersey
description: Where's Christie?

title: Allstate Said To Coerce Life Agents
description: A federal agency has concluded that the Allstate Insurance Company was illegally discriminating against about 650 life insurance agents even as it was negotiating to settle similar charges involving thousands of agents who sell auto and home insurance, several agents and the company disclosed yesterday.

title: Ford Is Said To Reappoint Ex-Executive
description: The Ford Motor Company, seeking to bolster its credibility on Wall Street, is set to elevate another experienced executive, this time from its past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDING, MELVILLE J.
description: GOLDING-Melville J., 82. Of Tucson, died May 17, 2002. Beloved husband of Rita Golding. Devoted father of Lance Golding (Debbi) of Nevada, Gary Golding (Jani) of Connecticut, Stacy Golding of California and Matthew Golding of California. Dear brother of Lawrence Golding of Florida. Loving grandfather of Austin, Wyatt, Carly, Johanna, Kira and Hannah. Services to be held 3 PM on May 20, 2002 at Evergreen Mortuary in Tucson, AZ. Interment to follow in the Congregation Anshei Israel, Section of Evergreen Cemetery, N. Oracle & W. Miracle Mile. Memorial contributions may be made to The Arizona Cancer Center, attention Dr. Thomas Miller, University of Arizona Health Sciences Center, Tucson, AZ 85724 or to Congregation Anshei Israel, 5550 East 5th Street, Tucson, AZ 85711.

title: F.B.I.'s Anthrax Inquiry
description: To the Editor:

title: Why America Slept: The Furor Over Sept. 11
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, JACK
description: ALTMAN-Jack. 87. Passed away May 17, 2002. A devoted husband and father, Jack cherished family above all else. For over 60 years, he worked as a journeyman plumber. Among the many structures that bear his signature is the Technology Building at CCNY built in the 1960s. He excelled in handball and swimming in his early years. In his later years, he was very involved in his synagogue. He was married for over forty years to the late Sarah. He is survived by his children Anita and Stan, daughterin-law Claire, grandchildren Sascha, Jeffrey and David, sisters Etta and Esta and brother Bob. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, May 19th at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (near 91st Street) at 11 A.M. Contributions can be made to the Jack and Sarah Fund at FJC, 130 East 59 Street, New York, New York 10022.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about trades made by energy companies as they sought to develop a market in high-speed communications capacity misidentified one company. It is the El Paso Corporation, not El Paso Energy Partners, a limited partnership with ties to El Paso.

title: Cablevision Given More Time by Judge
description: A federal district judge has granted Cablevision extra time to respond to the YES network's lawsuit alleging that the cable operator has violated antitrust laws by refusing to carry the new network.

title: A First Work With Hot and Cool Spices
description: In the Diamond Project, the showcase of new works presented intermittently over the years by the New York City Ballet, the company becomes an equal opportunity employer for novice and seasoned choreographer alike.

title: Rain Keeps Up in Water-Logged Midwest
description: Residents across Illinois, Indiana and Missouri braced for more flooding today as scattered showers continued. Even so, there was hope that sandbags would prevail against overflowing rivers that were already blamed for nine deaths in the past two weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, CAROL RAE
description: SMITH-Carol Rae. Beloved wife of Park B. Smith, was born into eternal life on May 16, 2002 while at their home in Lakeville, CT. Carol was born September 9, 1950 in Minneapolis, MN. She is survived by her devoted husband, Park B. Smith of New York City, NY, and Lakeville, CT; her parents, Richard Locken and Betty Rodriguez, & her sisters Marla, Janet, Nancy and brother David Locken, of Minneapolis, MN; and the Park and Terry Smith, and the Jim and Patty White families of Warren, NJ. As Co-Chair of Park B. Smith, Inc., of New York City, Carol's standard of excellence, attention to detail, and the ability to address issues head-on were essential to the growth of the company. Her legacy continues to inspire and guide those at PBS, Inc. Not only did Carol desire the success of the company, but also the personal growth and success of the many employees for whom she cared. Carol was intimately involved in all aspects of Park B. Smith, Inc., including operations, systems, finance and design. Not one facet of the business has gone untouched by Carol's intelligence and capability. Tough and demanding of herself as well as the others with whom she worked, Carol inspired all who knew her. She was not only a leader of the company, she was an integral part of the company, and will be greatly missed. As a team, Carol and her husband Park B. Smith built a company that exemplifies excellence, creativity, and excitement within the home furnishings industry. The foundation that Carol and Park built is based on loyalty, trust, and integrity. It is a solid foundation which bodes well for the present and future growth of PBS, Inc. Carol, also affectionately known as ''Toots,'' was a cherished wife, sister, daughter, aunt, grandmother and friend. Her never-ending smile, loving ways, and concern and love for others will be remembered. Carol lived with dignity, elegance, and quiet strength. We will miss her very much. May her memory live in our hearts. Friends may visit Sunday, May 19, 2002 from 2:00-5:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, Madison Avenue at 81 St., NYC, NY. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Monday, May 20, 2002, at 10:00 AM at St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington and 66 St., NYC, NY. A private family burial will follow in Salisbury, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations in Carol's name may be sent to The World Wildlife Fund, 1250 24 St., NW, PO Box 97180, Washington, D.C. 20090. (www.worldwildlife.org). The Smith, Locken and White Families

title: Rangers Start Over In Pursuit of Coach
description: A candidate's change of heart -- about the Rangers and about coaching -- has forced Glen Sather back to the drawing board.

title: Rivals Emphasize Team Over Individual Matchups
description: When someone asked Patrick Roy today about his matchup in goal against Dominik Hasek in the N.H.L.'s Western Conference finals, Roy's blue eyes flashed, his voice rose and his tense body language suggested that he meant what he was about to say.

title: Suit Over Remote-Control Train Devices
description: The Union Pacific Corporatoin's rail unit has been sued by the locomotive engineers union, which claimed ''a serious safety threat'' from use of remote-control equipment to move trains in freight yards.

title: Cultural Soul-Searching: In 50 Years It's Emigrated Back to Europe
description: One participant spoke of the ''growing isolation'' of the United States in the midst of its vast power and of ''the hostility which is directed against it.'' Another described the cultural ''leveling'' taking place because of American influence, a leveling that ''the whole world is bound to endure.'' A third complained about the ''regimentation of thought'' in the United States that was stifling dissent. ''Materialism,'' ''hollowness,'' cultural ''idiocy,'' political ''immaturity'' -- accusations were made and defenses offered, diagnoses proclaimed and protocols recommended.

title: Jeter Waiting to Click at the Plate
description: Derek Jeter is curious about the time the Nets play the Boston Celtics tomorrow because he hopes to get to Continental Arena after the Yankees' game against the Minnesota Twins. When Jeter was told the basketball game tips off at 5:30 p.m., he quickly told Rondell White that they might have a chance to motor from the Bronx to East Rutherford, N.J., if the Yankees' game were to end promptly.

title: Surgery Will Force Hingis to Miss French Open, but She Plans to Return
description: Players with lumberjack strokes have worn down Martina Hingis's calculating game over the years, but she managed to maintain her top ranking in women's tennis with the attendance record of an A student on the pro tour.

title: Why America Slept: The Furor Over Sept. 11
description: To the Editor:

title: Why America Slept: The Furor Over Sept. 11
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Salinas Investigation Ends
description: A judge in Geneva has ended an inquiry into accusations that Ral Salinas, the brother of former President Carlos Salinas of Mexico, laundered $130 million in bribes from drug traffickers through Swiss bank accounts. The money will remain frozen until its source can be established. The judge, Paul Perraudin, said he had asked Swiss prosecutors to forward the dossier to Mexico. Ral Salinas is serving 27 1/2 years there for murder Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Baffert Wins Big Races, Not Admirers
description: MOST big races are laced with anticipation and uncertainty. The 127th running of the Preakness has an unusual undercurrent of resentment, an undercurrent that goes deeper than simply wanting one horse to beat another. There's a hint of Great White Hope-ism that takes place when people feel a collective sense that a way of life or entitlement is being threatened.

title: Fired Official Is Critical Of County Plan For Emergency
description: The former deputy director of emergency preparedness for Westchester County said today that his dismissal this week was unfair and that it was a result of his attempts to design a new evacuation plan for the county that was good for more than show.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: School Assault Investigated
description: A 13-year-old boy was arrested yesterday afternoon at Middle School 72 in Springfield Gardens as a suspect in a sexual assault that occurred in the school, the police said. On Thursday, an 11-year-old girl was forced into a classroom closet by the boy and a 12-year-old boy, and was sodomized, the police said. The incident was reported yesterday shortly after 1 p.m. The boy was arrested around 2 p.m., and charges are pending, said Detective Gary Cillo. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Bertelsmann, in a Reversal, Agrees to Acquire Napster
description: In a startling reversal, Bertelsmann, the German media giant, agreed yesterday to acquire the assets of the languishing Napster Inc. for $8 million.

title: Taxi Driver Rescues Stolen Marble Drummer Boy
description: The Drummer Boy is on his way back to -- one hopes -- his final resting place, Woodlawn Cemetery, thanks to an observant taxi driver stuck in traffic.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Aeronautic Concern Has Loss
description: The European Aeronautic, Defense and Space Company posted a first-quarter net loss as its Airbus unit delivered fewer planes, and new orders fell 80 percent after Sept. 11 . The company said it had a net loss of 25 million euros ($21.2 million) in contrast to profit of 1.67 billion euros a year earlier. Sales rose 2 percent.

title: New Questions Are Turning Up In the Inquiry Into Adelphia
description: Investigations into accounting problems at Adelphia Communications are turning up a far broader number of questionable transactions between the company and its controlling family than had been apparent at first, an executive close to the situation said yesterday.

title: Cyclones Fans Sweep Up Tickets
description: After an inaugural season in which they set an attendance record for the Class A New York-Penn League and won a share of the league championship, the Brooklyn Cyclones have sold 97 percent of the tickets for their second season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILORENZO, JEANNETTE B.
description: DiLORENZO-Jeannette B. On May 14, 2002. Wife of the late John, beloved sister of Blanche and the late Philip. Leader of the UFT/RTC, trade unionist and political activist. Services Monday, May 20th at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th street and Amsterdam Avenue. Visiting from 10 AM. Service at 11:45 AM. Contributions may be made to the Jewish Labor Committee, Holocaust Museum, Brooklyn College Fund, American Red Cross.

title: Resentments as Workers Strike in a Town Built on Chocolate
description: This town's reputation as ''the sweetest place on earth'' has taken a beating since 2,700 workers went on strike three weeks ago, shutting down two factories that make Hershey's Kisses, Mr. Goodbar and other candies.

title: Kings to Confront Lakers Demons Again
description: Less than a week ago, the San Antonio Spurs were in fairly good shape. They had a 10-point lead with five minutes left and were maybe two defensive stops from evening their playoff series with the Los Angeles Lakers at two games each. With Shaquille O'Neal hurting and Kobe Bryant missing everything from the perimeter, a four-of-seven-game conference semifinal series was about to become two out of three, and the Spurs had already taken one game in Los Angeles.

title: Free Checkups for Ground Zero Workers
description: The occupational health center of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine in Manhattan will begin offering free health examinations this summer -- at federal government expense -- to thousands of people who worked or volunteered at ground zero.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, MARY JUDITH, M.D.
description: MURPHY-Mary Judith, M.D., M.P.H. The faculty, students, alumni and staff of Columbia's Mailman School of Public Health deeply mourn the passing of Mary Judith Murphy, loving wife of our dedicated & distinguished faculty member, and longtime head of the Department of Environmental Health Sciences, Joseph H. Graziano. Pediatrician and expert on childhood infectious diseases, Mary also enjoyed a career in the pharmaceutical industry. To Joe, their daughter, Caitlin, and his children, Michele and Joseph, and the Murphy family, we extend our deepest sympathy. Allan Rosenfield, M.D. Dean

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDIS, MORRIS B.
description: LANDIS-Morris B. Of Highland Park, NJ and Aventura, FL. Beloved husband of Raye nee Rosenbaum. Devoted father of Mark, Alan, Diana, Ilene, Mitchell and Tefera. Father-in-law of Carolyn, Linda, Jeffrey and Linda Jean. Dear brother of Alex and Sam. Loving grandfather of 12 grandchildren and 2 great-grandchildren. Dad, Grandpa, Meish, Uncle Morris, ''The Producer''. Always a trendsetter, with a healthy diet and exercise, always years ahead of his time, the eternal overflowing optimist. Now at his passing, years ahead of his time. We will all miss our greatest cheerleader and supporter. We hope throughout our lives and those of future generations that Dad's very special being will live on. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Central New Jersey Jewish Home for the Aged, 732-873-2000 or to the Israel Emergency Fund of the UJA Federation, 212-980-1000. Services were held. For information ''Wein & Wein'', 800-322-0533.

title: Too Much Basketball?
description: Jason Kidd is questioning his plans to play in the world basketball championships. ''Come June, we're going to have to make a decision -- it's going to be an issue,'' he said.

title: Japan, Joining Europeans, Plans To Impose Steel Duties on U.S.
description: Joining forces with the European Union, Japan announced today that it would impose 100 percent duties on some imports of American steel next month.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Dissident Meets Party Members
description: Testing her new freedom for the first time since being released from house arrest by the military government on May 6, the pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi drove unobstructed to a suburb of the capital, Yangon, to meet with members of her party, the National League for Democracy. The last time she tried such a trip, in September 2000, she was stopped and her house arrest began. She told 500 cheering residents: ''The N.L.D. is working for the welfare of everyone in the country, not for the N.L.D. alone. Don't support me without knowing what we are doing.'' Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: As a New TV Deal Looms, The Nets' Picture Is Bright
description: As a basketball team or a business, the Nets have seldom been mistaken for a model to live by.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Caterer Lowers Outlook
description: The catering company Sodexho Alliance said it expected profitability to decline because corporate demand for the nonessential services it provides has fallen. Profit before interest, tax and amortization will narrow to 4.7 percent of sales in the 12 months ending Aug. 31, down from 4.9 percent a year earlier, executives said at a news conference. The report set off a 4.9 percent, or 2 euro, decline in the company's stock price, which closed at 38.65 euros.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Bioterror Powers
description: To enhance state control after a terrorist biological emergency, the Legislature voted to give the governor more authority over medical examinations, quarantines and access to medical records without court approval. The measure, which passed 45 to 10 in the House and 29 to 0 in the Senate, came in response to the Sept. 11 attacks and would apply when officials believe that an outbreak of illness has been caused by an attack. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: What's the Ostrich For? Politics; Budget Protests Use Street Theater and Star Powers
description: The piercing whistle by an AIDS protester being arrested outside Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's famous bullpen-style office. Schoolchildren delivering boxes of letters to City Hall complaining about the loss of teachers and programs to budget cuts. A woman parading around in an ostrich suit, calling herself the Bloombird, asking the mayor to consider tax increases instead of some budget cuts.

title: Arafat at Camp David, and Today
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Yeshiva Labor Settlement
description: The union representing 400 workers at three Yeshiva University campuses announced yesterday that it had reached a tentative contract settlement. The workers, who belong to 1199/S.E.I.U., went on a three-day strike earlier this month, but returned to work when negotiations resumed with a federal mediator. Under the proposed 46-month agreement, Yeshiva's clerical, housekeeping, maintenance, dietary and social workers would receive wage increases of 11.6 percent. They work at Yeshiva's main campus, at the Stern College for Women and at the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law. A ratification vote is set for Tuesday. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Cardinal Describes Ouster Of Priest Sued Over Abuse
description: The Archdiocese of New York issued an unusual statement yesterday describing how, within weeks of becoming bishop of Bridgeport, Conn., in 1988, Cardinal Edward M. Egan settled a lawsuit over an abusive priest and arranged for his permanent removal from the priesthood.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Schering-Plough Agrees To Pay $500 Million Fine

title: F.B.I. Knew for Years About Terror Pilot Training
description: The F.B.I. had been aware for several years that Osama bin Laden and his terrorist network were training pilots in the United States and elsewhere around the world, according to court records and interviews at flight schools and with federal law enforcement officials.

title: Arafat at Camp David, and Today
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Escapes section yesterday with an article about the ritual of seasonal reopening at family summer cottages misattributed the Latin phrase on a signboard, ''Ille terrarum mihi praeter omnes angulus ridet'' (''This corner of the earth pleases me more than any other''). It is from Horace, not Homer.

title: G.O.P. Fights Proposed Rules on Auditors
description: Republicans led by Senator Phil Gramm of Texas and the accounting industry's trade group are working to kill a Democratic measure that would impose new rules on auditors, companies and investment banks in the wake of Enron's collapse.

title: Why America Slept: The Furor Over Sept. 11
description: To the Editor:

title: Before Scheduling Elections, Arafat Demands Israeli Pullback
description: Only hours after two of his top aides said he was ready to run for election within six months, Yasir Arafat said today that Palestinians could not hold elections until Israeli forces pulled back from the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Democrats Raise Questions Over Remarks on Warnings
description: Some Congressional Democratic leaders and party strategists raised concerns today about remarks made by senior Bush administration officials last fall that they had received no warnings about the type of terrorist attacks that occurred on Sept. 11.

title: Mayor Drops Incinerator Plan
description: The use of high-tech incinerators to help solve the city's mounting trash disposal problems is unlikely, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday, backing away from the administration's earlier stance.

title: Judge Skeptical of a Microsoft Remedy
description: The judge overseeing the Microsoft trial appeared highly skeptical today of a proposal made by nine states on how to enforce the tough antitrust restrictions they are seeking.

title: INSIDE
description: Bias Claims at Allstate

title: A Vatican Lawyer Says Bishops Should Not Reveal Abuse Claims
description: An influential canon lawyer at the Vatican has written an article to be published today in a Vatican-approved Jesuit journal saying that Roman Catholic bishops should not turn over allegations or records of sexual abuse by priests to the civil authorities.

title: Boston Panel Wants Bigger Lay Role in Crisis
description: A panel created by Cardinal Bernard F. Law to help address the sexual abuse crisis in the Boston Archdiocese recommended today that lay people play a greater role in investigating accusations of abuse, counseling victims, starting prevention and education programs in parishes and monitoring how sexually abusive members of the clergy are treated.

title: Roosevelt Island Tram May Start Carrying Ads
description: It's a New York vista: the red Roosevelt Island aerial tramway soars across the East River above the New York skyline, above the boats on the water and the graceful split-level Queensboro Bridge.

title: Bill Peet, 87, Disney Artist And Children's Book Author
description: Bill Peet, an illustrator, screenwriter and children's book author almost as well known for his tempestuous, 27-year relationship with Walt Disney as for the cartoon characters he created, died last Saturday at his home in Studio City, Calif. He was 87.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an entry in the Memo Pad column of the Business Travel page on Tuesday referred incompletely to agreements reached by Expedia, the online booking site, to carry airlines' Internet-only fares. The fares will be available only occasionally. Because of an editing error, the entry also misstated Expedia's means of disclosing the agreements. It acknowledged them in an interview; it did not not make an announcement.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Senate Panel Approves E-Privacy
description: The Senate Commerce Committee approved privacy legislation to require Internet service providers, online service providers and Web sites to obtain customers' permission before disclosing or selling sensitive personal information. Such items include a Social Security number or information about religion, ethnicity, sexual orientation, finances or health. The bill was supported by 12 Democrats and 3 Republicans and opposed by 8 Republicans.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Leaving Museum Board
description: Peg Breen, the president of the New York Landmarks Conservancy who also served on the board of the Museum of the City of New York for a year and a half, has resigned from the museum's board. The museum directors had wanted to move into the Tweed Courthouse, an idea that was supported by the conservancy but rebuffed by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. ''My primary duty is to the Landmarks Conservancy,'' Ms. Breen said yesterday. ''And there are going to be times when we diverge on things. I just wanted to be very clear that I am speaking for the conservancy.'' Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Rookie Officer Is Wounded By a Gunman In Brooklyn
description: A rookie police officer in uniform was shot twice in the arm early yesterday in Brooklyn by a gunman who opened fire on her and four other newly minted officers from behind as they walked down a Flatbush street, police officials said.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday about the scene at the TriBeCa Film Festival misspelled the surname of an artist who was painting the face of a movie fan. The artist, who uses the clown name LOL, is Camille Czarnecki, not Zarnecki.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on May 8 about ways in which the Massachusetts charitable immunity law might be used by the Catholic Church to fight lawsuits over sexual abuse referred imprecisely to a comment by a judge who declined to apply the law in a case involving experiments at Massachusetts General Hospital. The judge said, ''One need not invoke the specter of the war crime trials of 20 Nazi physicians to make the point'' that calling human experiments research does not make them charitable acts. He did not compare the hospital's experiments to those of Nazi doctors.

title: Knicks' Layden Looks For a Lucky Number
description: Scott Layden seems unusually excited for a man whose high-profile basketball team missed the playoffs for the first time in 15 years. One would expect trips to China and Italy to be stimulating, but Layden, the Knicks' president and general manager, attributed his enthusiasm to tomorrow's N.B.A. draft lottery.

title: After a Long Night, Giambi's Slam Saves the Yanks
description: The rain was falling harder and harder and the Yankees were two outs away from losing a game they surely expected to win. Mike Mussina almost always defeats the Minnesota Twins, but he inexplicably let a five-run bulge evaporate and then the Yankees wasted numerous opportunities and found themselves trailing by three runs in the 14th inning.

title: U.S. Fails in U.N. to Exempt Peacekeepers From New Court
description: In a harbinger of coming clashes over the new international war crimes tribunal, the United States failed today in an effort to safeguard United Nations peacekeepers from prosecution by international tribunals.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: 1,000 Fans Barred From World Cup
description: The police said that more than 1,000 soccer fans with records of violence or suspected of being hooligans had been barred from leaving the country to attend the World Cup soccer tournament in Japan and South Korea, which starts on May 31. The fans were ordered to surrender their passports and will not get them back until the tournament ends. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: For Fall, TV Looks Back, And Back
description: Over four days this week, the television networks went through an annual ritual called the upfronts, in which they took over Carnegie Hall, Radio City and other prime New York locations to announce their fall schedules and lure advertisers to buy spots early. As always, there were jokey performances, circuslike parties where media buyers lined up to be photographed with stars, and unrelenting hype for shows that try to reflect the national mood.

title: This Isn't a Kickoff Talk, Torricelli Says
description: He said it was not a campaign kickoff, but Senator Robert G. Torricelli opened his re-election headquarters here with a stump speech that showed he was off and running as he promoted his accomplishments in Congress and ignored the three Republicans who want to be his opponent in November.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''From a canonical point of view, the bishop or religious superior is neither morally nor legally responsible for a criminal act committed by one of his clerics.''

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: EGYPTIAN SOUGHT BY U.S. IS FREED An Egyptian facing possible extradition to the United States on charges of financing Al Qaeda was freed on $22,000 bail and told to return to court on May 31. The action came the day after Yassir al-Sirri, 39, was cleared by another court of conspiring in the murder of Ahmed Shah Massoud, the anti-Taliban Afghan guerrilla leader, shortly before Sept. 11. He was immediately rearrested on a United States warrant seeking his extradition. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, ESTHER
description: BROWN-Esther. On May 16, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Mac. Loving mother of Stephen and Linda and Harvey & Barbara. Dear grandmother of Allison, Jennifer, Jason and Andrew, great grandmother of Zack, Jake, Ryan, Ike and Jack.

title: The Insights of Surveying Musicals From 1951
description: With its bright and breezy survey of songs from the Broadway musicals of 1951 on Monday evening at Town Hall, the fledgling series Broadway by the Year proved once again it is the Little Series That Could. There is something intrinsically fascinating about sorting through artifacts of popular culture created more or less simultaneously. And in the songs from "The King and I" and "Paint Your Wagon," the two most famous musicals to open that year, you could discern a formal chill in the air. Anti-Communist paranoia was gathering momentum in the country at the same time that television had begun to erode the movie and theatergoing audience.

title: A New Director Is Appointed At Hale House
description: A former assistant secretary of education who has served as the chief financial officer of several large institutions has been named executive director of Hale House, the children's shelter in Harlem, an official announced yesterday.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the second day of Shavuot, the Jewish Feast of Weeks, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Fed Wants to Raise Interest Rate on Its Direct Loans to Banks
description: The Federal Reserve proposed a substantial change today in its system of lending directly to banks, saying it wants to increase the interest rate it charges on emergency overnight loans.

title: Drug Maker to Pay $500 Million Fine For Factory Lapses
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to pay $500 million to the federal government because of its repeated failure over the years to fix problems in manufacturing dozens of drugs at four of its factories.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Why America Slept: The Furor Over Sept. 11
description: To the Editor:

title: Kidd Criticizes Suns
description: Jason Kidd, traded from Phoenix for Stephon Marbury in the off-season, had been quiet recently about proving Suns executives wrong. But he has clearly not forgotten their claim that he could not lead a team past the second round in the playoffs. With a wry smile and strong words, Kidd criticized the Suns' owner, Jerry Colangelo, and president, Bryan Colangelo.

title: Pea, Not Henson, Blossoms In the Outfield for the Reds
description: Not everything the Yankees touch turns to gold. At least not instantly.

title: Lower Manhattan Retailers Still Suffer Without Foot Traffic
description: Pasquale Di Tillio says his pizzeria on Cortlandt Street, half a block from the World Trade Center site, is doing about a third of the business it did before the terrorist attack eight months ago.

title: Corrections
description: A chronology chart yesterday with an article about intelligence warnings of terrorist threats before Sept. 11 misstated the date of a worldwide caution issued by the State Department. It was June 22, not 26.

title: Lake Balapan's Legacy
Can This Tavern Get Its Groove Back?
description: OPENING a restaurant in the dead of winter on Martha's Vineyard sounds foolhardy. But in the beginning, the restaurant, Black Dog Tavern, had modest goals. It wanted to give islanders a warm place to come into from the cold. It didn't imagine selling tourists clam chowder by the gallon and bagfuls of T-shirts and baseball caps.

title: Welcome Back, Little TV Friend
description: IT was 8:30 on a recent Monday night, and Jerry Seinfeld's live comedy show at the Beacon Theater was already a half-hour late.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOOKER, CHARLES
description: LOOKER-Charles. The Board of Directors of the Musicians Foundation mourn the passing of Charles Looker, a devoted friend and supporter of musicians. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family and friends. Anne Bigelow Stern, President Hans Tausig, Vice President

title: Samantha Stein, Rodger Wells II
description: Samantha Lee Stein, a daughter of Linda Stein and Seymour Stein, both of New York, is to be married today to Rodger Paul Wells II, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wells of Dubois, Pa. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel is to officiate at Cipriani 42nd Street in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDES, PEGGY HAPPACH
description: LANDES-Peggy Happach. May 16, 2002. Devoted mother to Hayley, beloved wife of Tom. Her energy, determination and courage inspired many. Her beautiful heart will never be forgotten. Friends may call Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. Funeral Mass on Tuesday at 10:30 AM, at St. Ignatius Church, Park Ave at 84th Street.

title: Death Remains
description: To the Editor:

title: Laura Iverson, William Burg
description: Laura McMillan Iverson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Iverson of New York, was married yesterday to William Peter Burg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Peter Burg of Stow, Ohio. The Rev. Dr. Fred R. Anderson performed the ceremony at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Did You Hear About Doc Ogden?
description: Having experienced a tragic childbirth myself, in which medical intervention at a critical moment might have prevented severe neurological impairment in my son, I read Michael Winerip's article (May 5) with intense interest. That no one is depicted as a villain, and that everyone is shown to be so painfully human, did justice to the story.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS IN BRIEF
description: GREEN BOY

title: INSIDE
description: Defense Opens in Bombing

title: The World; Just Try to Imagine A Palestinian Democracy
description: REFORM of Yasir Arafat's Palestinian Authority is suddenly dominating the diplomacy for Middle East peace, and as is so often true of this suffocating conflict, the debate is already narrowing to self-serving questions: Is Mr. Arafat speaking of reform simply to sustain his power? Is Ariel Sharon, Israel's prime minister, calling for reform just to postpone peace talks? Will the Bush administration settle for cosmetic change to appease Arab states?

title: Harking Back To the Time the War Was Over There
description: It caused a bit of a stir, but no one seems to have any clue who posted the billboard reading ''Jihad Is Over! (If You Want It)'' on East 14th Street.

title: Did Somebody Say Recovery? (Shhh.)
description: IS it just a case of spring fever -- or is economic recovery in the air?

title: A Yiddish Star
description: To the Editor:

title: Putting the 'Mr.' in Soft Ice Cream
description: IT was coming up on St. Patrick's Day in 1956 and Jim and Bill Conway, brothers who were sons of the auld sod, were looking for a way to celebrate.

title: The Pursuit of Quality (Vacation) Time
description: It's nearly summer, and two out of every three Americans are planning vacations, many with families and budgets in mind.

title: What Makes a Campus Diverse?
description: To the Editor:

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: May 19, 2002
description: Weeks

title: When It Seems Like More Than a Dozen Nights
description: IF it isn't one ''Twelfth Night,'' it's another. Overflowing with romantic longing and antic humor, Shakespeare's 400-year-old comedy is an eternal ode to love unbound by logic or sexual preference. Sublimely lacking in rationality, it inspires loony, dreamy interpretations, in our time, it seems, more than ever.

title: Grizzlies at Risk
description: Grizzly bears need all the friends they can get. The grizzly is a federally protected species whose recovery is nonetheless under relentless pressure from suburban development and from politicians who covet the bears' habitat for its timber and natural gas. It was thus reassuring to read Blaine Harden's charming story in The Times last week about Tim Manley, a Montana ''wildlife conflict specialist'' who is teaching grizzlies and people how to coexist. Essentially that means persuading the bears to stay clear of humans, rather than the other way around. But for the moment, at least in northern Montana, it has inspired a truce in the battle between a soaring population of people and a recovering population of grizzlies.

title: Few Are Switching? It's No Surprise
description: Regulators and legislators should not be surprised at the failure of Connecticut's residential consumers to exercise their option to choose other suppliers of electricity (''More Customers Switch Electric Service,'' May 5.). When they deregulated electricity at the retail level, legislators and regulators frustrated the proper operation of the laws of supply and demand. In order to make deregulation palatable to a skeptical public, the legislature mandated a 10 percent cut in the retail price of electricity and obligated incumbent companies to provide electricity at this artificially low price for several years. The would-be competitors, who all promised robust competition, discovered that they could not price retail power below this artificial ceiling and still make adequate profits.

title: Sweet Mike
description: Sometime around 1985, I first saw Michael Gerard Tyson, flickering on a television screen in a Manhattan bar. I nearly dumped my beer. The young Tyson was developing a reputation as a brutal street brawler. But the boxer I saw was a fistic Mozart. He had a way of changing the levels and angles of his blows, knowing, as the best boxers do, that it is the punch your opponent does not see, and thus cannot roll with, that knocks him out. There are a number of points on the face -- the chin and a couple of inches to either side -- that are expressways to the brain. Hit them just right, and what some fighters term the black lights flip on. Tyson could turn the switch with glancing blows, even to the forehead. His signature riff was an exotic combination of punches that Teddy Atlas, one of his early trainers, claims he passed on to Tyson from watching Roberto Duran. After jabbing through the danger zone and getting his head near his opponent's chest, Tyson would take a short step and weave to his right, fire a short right below the elbow, reload and snap a right uppercut up the middle. The uppercut would jerk his opponent's head above his guard, rendering it a perfect target for the coup de grce, the left hook.

title: Resigned To Another Blockbuster
description: IN 1980, Pauline Kael published an essay in The New Yorker called ''Why Are Movies So Bad? or, The Numbers,'' in which she castigated Hollywood studios, most of which had been swallowed up by conglomerates in the previous decade, for bombarding the movie-loving public with tame, derivative and mediocre movies. Rereading the piece today (it is reprinted in Kael's career-spanning collection ''For Keeps''), one is struck by its timeliness. Only the names of the movies and the numbers themselves seem dated. Since then, production costs and box office expectations have spiraled ever upward. When Kael mentions $14 million or $15 million budgets, you must remember that that was a lot of money back then. Recent movies like ''Spider-Man,'' ''Pearl Harbor'' and ''Star Wars: Episode II -- Attack of the Clones'' cost nearly 10 times as much.

But instead of golf, tennis or the other pastimes of privileged people, they chose what they knew best. Francis Ford Coppola and his relatives acted, wrote and, of course, directed, mounting a series of plays in a converted barn. description: In most ways, old man Whitelaw's funeral was just another scene in the family's life. Paul Crusoe, estranged from Whitelaw's daughter Evelyn, a strong young woman with black hair that hung straight to her collar, was led to his mother-in-law's sitting room by Evelyn herself. Mrs. Whitelaw, who could act as oblivious as someone nearly blind, sat with Evelyn's sister, Natalie, whom Paul viewed as a high-strung, nasty girl who once caused all his problems and who for her part despised him unstintingly. On the side table was a Stockman's Journal and a CPR handbook. Natalie smoked and looked at Paul over her raised cigarette. The red hair was certainly not genuine.

title: Local E.M.T.'s Form Backbone in Emergencies
description: To the Editor:Your article ''The 911 Call'' (May 5) , does a disservice to the volunteers who administer the county's emergency medical system. The article irresponsibly creates a sense of panic, suggesting that anyone who does not receive a STAT helicopter ride to the hospital is getting substandard care. This is not the case. In fact, that situation is very much the exception; the vast majority of calls are appropriately handled by a ride to the nearest hospital in a local volunteer-staffed ambulance, with or without a well-trained paramedic on board, depending on the severity of the situation.

title: Amenities Proliferate on Board
description: IF all goes according to Rick Sasso's plan, next weekend will be a whirlwind of fabric swatches and measuring tapes aboard Holland America's Rotterdam. There, in a lounge, he will be setting up his first on-board custom tailoring shop, where passengers can leaf through a catalog of designs, massage racks of Egyptian cotton and Chinese silk, have their measurements taken and buy luxury clothing made to order.

title: Kimberly McCreight, Anthony Prentice
description: Kimberly Elizabeth McCreight, a daughter of Diane R. Dohm of Washington Crossing, Pa., and John A. McCreight of New Canaan, Conn., was married last evening to Anthony Ian Prentice, a son of Clare and Martin Prentice of Morristown, N.J. Gail Saunders, a minister of the Madonna Ministry, officiated at Studio 450 in New York.

title: You Read Your Book and I'll Read Mine
description: In Thomas Mann's novel ''The Magic Mountain,'' Hans Castorp, a young bourgeois about to embark on a conventional career, visits an Alpine sanitarium for tuberculosis patients, becomes infatuated with one of them and is conveniently discovered to have a spot on one of his own lungs. He gets to spend the next several years as her fellow inmate. At the sanitarium Hans experiences an astonishing awakening. His infatuation inspires a craving for knowledge -- about art (his inamorata has posed for paintings), anatomy (her diseased one in particular), chemistry (disease again), consciousness, botany, the passage of time and the biological mystery of life, to name just a few of the topics his desire leads him to. Each book he reads functions as a fetish object: it magically ushers him into the presence of his beloved. Drifting off to sleep over a work on pathology, Hans ''beheld the image of life, its voluptuous limbs, its flesh-borne beauty,'' Mann writes. ''She bent toward him, bent down to him, over him, he sensed her organic aroma, sensed the lacelike pounding of her heart.''

title: For Militant, No Glorified End, but Death in the Dust
description: For the nation's most feared Islamic militant, no glory was waiting at the end of the road. He was killed in a late-night shootout in this dusty farm village in the blistering plains of south Punjab.

title: Ideas & Trends: Gotcha!; One Cheer for Politics as Usual
description: THAT old question is back, the one made famous by former Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. during Watergate. What the country needed to find out, they said, was, ''What did President Bush know, and when did he know it?''

title: Measuring Civility by the Teaspoon
description: SERENA BASS, caterer to the stars -- Steven Meisel, Brooke Hayward, Grace Coddington -- and an owner of Serena, the sultry red and black lounge at the Chelsea Hotel, was 14 when she met 24-year-old David Shaffer, 16 when they started dating and 18 when he took her from London to Johannesburg to meet his family. (They married two years later, in 1966.) In his parents' home, she had a kind of epiphany.

title: Fewer Jobs, but Better Benefits
description: While many big companies eliminated jobs during the recession, they generally did not cut employee benefits, a recent study shows. In fact, most programs offered by the 945 major companies studied nationwide grew modestly over the last year, according to the survey results, which were released last week.

title: Laura Johnson, Exuberant Social Figure and Quiet Philanthropist, Dies
description: Laura Johnson, a flamboyant New York social figure who reveled in personal publicity but refused to have her many philanthropies made public, died May 12 at her home in Manhattan. She was believed to be in her late 80's, but although she celebrated her birth date, July 17, her birth year remained a mystery even to those closest to her.

title: Raging, Softly, Against the Fame Machine
description: LIAM NEESON doesn't like autograph hounds. At 6-foot-4, with his large, strong hands and broad, handsome face, he exudes a kind of bruised quality, like a gentle giant. This reticent actor loves his work but hates selling himself. So he has arranged to sit for an interview late in the afternoon at a favorite West Side restaurant in hopes that the place will be empty and he won't be accosted by fans.
