title: High Notes, Jersey Roots
description: Does Frankie still have his falsetto? ''Yes,'' says the early rock 'n roll singer Frankie Valli, who will bring his stage show and old hits like ''Sherry'' and ''Dawn'' to the Trump Plaza in Atlantic City on May 24-26. Mr. Valli began singing with friends on street corners outside Steven Crane Village, the Newark housing project where he lived, and later migrated to West Orange, Nutley, Fort Lee and finally, Englewood. Six years ago he moved to California, but now he wants to return. ''I've had a love affair with New Jersey and New York just about all my life,'' he said. ''I live in California mainly because I have little children. You have to live someplace, and they wanted to live in California. But I want to go back. It's all about roots, you know what I mean?'' As for Sherry and Dawn, were there real people in Newark who inspired the lyrics? Mr. Valli confessed that there were not. ''I think the inspiration came out of wanting to be successful and make something out of yourself and wanting to be different.'' Margo Nash

title: Former Kraft Foods Building Reopens With a New Look
description: Cohen Brothers Realty Corporation of Manhattan held a grand opening on Thursday of 333 Westchester Avenue in White Plains, the 39-acre former headquarters of Kraft Foods. The $90 million renovation of the 50-year-old, 632,000-square-foot office complex has involved converting the structure, which is about a mile from the central business district of the city, into a multitenant building. To accomplish that, Cohen Brothers, which acquired the property in 1998 for $25 million, hired Philip Johnson's firm as architects and redesigned and remarketed the complex as four separate buildings. Under the new design, which can accommodate tenants who need as little as 2,500 square feet, each building is entered through a towering entry with its own distinctive color.

title: Where Corn Dogs Meet Foie Gras
description: Corn dogs, a staple of beach concession stands and state fairs, have made it to New York restaurant menus, but in a diminutive, fancier form. At 55 Wall in the Regent Wall Street hotel, mini corn dogs are wrapped in a subway map, right, and spread with molasses mustard ($11). Virgil's Barbecue (152 West 44th Street) offers cocktail-size beef franks dipped in hush puppy batter, garnished with smoked poblano mustard ($7.95). At the Star Room on Montauk Highway in Wainscott, N.Y., sweet baby corn dogs appear on the children's and the catering menus, studded with corn picked from Long Island's East End ($9 for four). And District, 130 West 46th Street, does away with the frankfurter element completely, fashioning cornmeal-encrusted ''pops'' out of foie gras and serving them with cherries jubilee sauce and pickled onions ($20 for three). Of course, while the scaled-down dogs may seem more chic, everyone knows that a miniature corn dog is really just a modified pig in a blanket.

title: Young Feet in Old Sneakers
description: The popularity of retro sneakers has spread to the children's department, where the makers are offering junior editions of vintage designs. New Balance's Heritage line runs from toddlers to teenagers with its new Heritage running shoe in gray or blue suede (far left, $38 at New Balance stores). Nike's preschool Air Force 1 (near left) is a leather version of the original high-top sneaker in black or white ($45 at Transit, 665 Broadway, near Bond Street; 212-358-8726; www.transitnyc.com). Field Day sneakers by Keds mimic the shape of old-time basketball low-tops in white leather with navy piping ($29.99 at www.keds.com). And Kids Footlocker carries Reebok's Little Kids Classic editions in lightweight black or white leather ($35.99), as well as the familiar white Adidas Little Superstars sneaker (center), with its shell toe and three trademark stripes in black, gray or white ($44.99). The best part of this dash down memory lane is no cartoon characters on the laces and no tread soles with blinking lights.

title: Pig-Lit
description: IS New York too fractious to have all its citizens read the same book? A committee of librarians, booksellers and educators recently deadlocked over two finalists, Chang-Rae Lee's novel ''Native Speaker'' and James McBride's memoir ''The Color of Water,'' although one faction, the New York Women's Agenda, is going ahead with the McBride book.

title: What Makes a Campus Diverse?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAU, RICHARD
description: GRAU-Richard. May 7, 2002. He was fearless, legendarily generous, unequivocally devoted to his family, loyal to friends, movie-star handsome, elegant, funny, smart, street-smart, strong, possessed of the most refined instincts, endlessly energetic, a terrific father to young children, the best companion as we grew older, proud, honorable, unselfish, unself-conscious, humble, sweet, respectful, loving, sensitive, tender, intrepid, courageous, sterling. Full of grace - in all senses of the word. He set the bar. He gave us everything, and in return he was the center of our world. He recognized in Mom a lifetime companion who shared his unimpeachable values, and was able to create so much for his family out of determination, hard work, devotion, and love. What will see us through these difficult days is our awareness that he knew how we cherished him - always, all the time. And that nourished him, and us, over the years, as it will forever. He was - is - without compare, without equal. And we are so lucky to have had him, to have all that he gave to those he loved. His grace will burn brightly, incandescently, eternally - a beacon in dark times, a light to strive toward. How much we will miss him is far beyond the reach of words.

title: PrivateSector; Gracefully Tiptoeing Between Star Acts
description: It may be hard to think of a banker as a man of dance, but William B. Harrison Jr., chief executive of J. P. Morgan Chase, was honored last week for the 14 years he has been supporting the National Dance Institute, which teaches children in the New York City area. The problem for Mr. Harrison was that he arrived onstage after a crowd-pleasing performance at Lincoln Center by a talented group of students under the direction of the institute's choreographer, Jacques d'Amboise. Worse, Mr. Harrison was to speak before Whoopi Goldberg, who was also honored.

title: Railway.Coms Within Europe
description: ONE of the most nail-biting travel experiences I have had was flying by myself to Italy as a junior in college, embarking on a semester abroad. I was on a different flight than the rest of my classmates, which meant I had to get myself from the Milan airport to an address in Florence with little information about the trains in between.

description: FEINSTONE-Emanuel, 96 years young, a ''tough cookie'' with a passion for living and life-cigars, Canadian Club, country club''he did it his way.'' He left us heartbroken on May 12th, 2002. We love you, husband, father, grandfather, great grandfather.

description: Suzanne Marian Sims, the daughter of Janie and Nelson Sims of Key Largo, Fla., was married there yesterday to Andrew Robinson Hough, a son of Rosemary and Richard Hough of Roanoke, Va. The Rev. Clair E. Berry, a Disciples of Christ minister, officiated in the chapel of the Ocean Reef Club.

description: Rose Farley, a reporter for The Dallas Observer, thought she would have a little fun with a decision by a judge to jail a seventh grader for five days in 1999 because he had read a graphic Halloween story to his class, for extra credit.

description: Known for reaching high decibels, the crowd at Arco Arena was as loud as ever today as its beloved Kings were introduced. The franchise came to Sacramento in 1985 and the city was playing host to its first appearance in the Western Conference finals.

description: NORTH CASTLE, the sprawling 27-square-mile township that embraces urban North White Plains, suburban Armonk and the Vermont-like rural East End of Banksville, has a reputation for being McMansion-friendly.

title: May 12-18: NATIONAL; CLONING PATENT
description: The University of Missouri received a patent a year ago for a process to clone pigs, but it may also cover humans, according to a Washington group opposed to human cloning. The International Center for Technology Assessment, which has long opposed the patenting of living things, pointed out that the patent applies to mammals, without excepting humans. Senator Sam Brownback, a leading cloning opponent, said he would introduce a bill to outlaw patenting of human beings, which he called ''akin to slavery.'' The U.S. Patent and Trademark Office said it had not changed its policy, which is not to grant patents on humans. Andrew Pollack

description: DR. ANA SILBERT and Dr. Joel Silbert had a house in Ardsley, a small town in Westchester County, but they didn't fall in love with the homeowning life. He found it similar to a cartoon he once saw, where every corner of the house was calling out, fix me, patch me.

title: Jolts of Anxiety
description: I am a recent recipient of a defibrillator. While I certainly value the lifesaving aspects of this technology, I believe that the emotional implications for patients should also be addressed. I have already had numerous ''jolts'' and can attest to Lorraine Flood's experience with the device.

title: Corrections
description: A biographical sketch on Sept. 24 about a World Trade Center victim, Catherine L. LoGuidice, an assistant bond trader at Cantor Fitzgerald who spent weekends helping at a veterinary hospital, misidentified an illness her grandfather had and her role during it. He had a stroke, not cancer. She drove him to physical therapy; she did not take care of him. A family member notified The Times of the errors in January, but this correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: May 12-18: NATIONAL; NO THERE THERE
description: Shares of some of the nation's biggest energy trading companies fell sharply after several of them admitted to engaging in bogus trades in the electricity market to inflate revenues and market share, a week after Dynegy admitted to the same. Top executives in the trading divisions of Reliant Resources and CMS Energy resigned. The companies apologized for the sham transactions and said they would have to restate some of their financial reports. Trading records from 2000 and 2001 also suggest that several energy traders -- Reliant, Enron, Aquila and the El Paso Corporation -- engaged in scores of transactions aimed at creating the appearance of more robust activity in the fledgling market in the trading of high-speed communications capacity. All four deny they did so. David Barboza

title: Teenage Pied Pipers Turn Pages
description: IT'S a Thursday afternoon and a steady stream of elementary schoolchildren troops into the community room of the Huguenot Children's Library here. Each one tries to be the first to greet the two teenagers who are there to meet them. They are meeting for their biweekly book discussion group, but as with most such groups, a certain amount of socializing has to take place first.

Trash is collected in the backyard to keep unsightly cans off the curb. No parking is allowed on the street overnight. Front-yard fences are forbidden. So is any fence over four feet high. Except certain fences on corner lots, which cannot exceed 30 inches.

description: I'M a sucker for trains. So after I moved to Oslo three years ago, it was only a matter of time before I took the trip my Norwegian friends kept telling me I had to take -- the roughly seven-hour railway journey across Norway's mountainous midriff to Bergen, on the North Sea coast.

title: Commercial Property; Downtown, a Menu of Incentives
description: TO help revive the downtown office market in the wake of the Sept. 11 attack, a complex set of federal, state and city incentives -- cash allowances and tax breaks -- are being offered to businesses that renew leases or move into the area. The incentives, together with rents that have gone down since the attack, have reduced the cost of office space to the point where it is 40 to 45 percent less than in Midtown, rather than the traditional 20 to 25 percent, according to real estate executives.

title: Jolts of Anxiety
description: Sandeep Jauhar (May 5) does an excellent job of describing the harrowing experience of one patient who suffered multiple defibrillator shocks and the psychological trauma that ensued. But as an electrophysiologist who has implanted hundreds of these devices, I believe the article has reported on only one extreme and not the other, at the expense of the truth in the middle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIED, GEORGE
description: FRIED-George. Former principal of P.S. 122, Queens. Beloved husband of Gertrude and the late Doris. Devoted father of Lucy Koster and Alice Baker and stepfather of Edward Neidich. Cherished grandfather of Christopher and Kevin Koster, David Baker and Carolyn Baker Ringel; and great-grandfather of Jessica. Chartreuse, that jolting color fad of the 1980's, has re-emerged this season in the more palatable shade of citron yellow, midway between lemon and lime. Missoni makes a citron one-piece bathing suit ($170) and also pairs the neon-bright tone with turquoise and gray in a handbag ($900 at Missoni boutiques). Gucci saturates a washed-cotton Western-style shirt with the color ($395), while Edmundo Castillo uses it for a pair of pumps ($350 at Jeffrey New York). And Chlo's entry (not shown) is a V-neck T-shirt that ties at the hip, ''Flashdance'' style ($195).

description: ALBERT-Irving. 80. Died suddenly on May 13, 2002, at home. Born in Poland, came to the United States in 1938. An honored union organizer and committed leftist, he served in the U.S. Armed Forces in the invasion of North Africa, landed in Anzio and marched to Rome, supported many Jewish causes, and was an Alaskan entrepreneur. Husband of Alicia and the late Dorothy, father of Marc and David, father-in-law of Orna, adoring grandfather of Ben, and relentless competitor at pinochle. Service Sunday, May 19, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The family will be at home this week.

title: Susanna Felleman, Erik Feig

title: A Fruity Kick For Brunch
description: Wild Horse's appetitewhetting 2001 malvasia bianca from Monterey, on the Central Coast of California, is an ideal Sunday brunch white. Made from an ancient Mediterranean grape, the wine delivers a bold, almost shocking, grapefruit-and-kiwi kick that sticks around for minutes. It's wonderful with Pacific Rim cuisine. West Side Wine, 481 Columbus Avenue (83rd Street), charges $15. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

Gilmore International Keyboard Festival here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUPP, STUART RUSSELL
description: HUPP-Stuart Russell, 80. Of New York City, died May 11, 2002. He was the son of the late Mrs. Rand Lewis Hupp, and the late William F. Hupp. He is survived by a sisterin-law, Mrs. Stamford Gray Hupp, a nephew, Ronald Hupp, a niece, Mrs. Denise Pietrucha, as well as two great nephews and a great niece. Mr. Hupp, who retired from IBM, was formerly with the CIA in Europe, and was a combat veteran of World War II. He was a member of Saint Thomas Episcopal Church in New York City. Funeral services will be held Thursday, May 16, at 11:30 A.M. in The Ford Memorial Home, 234 West Washington Ave, Washington, NJ. Interment will follow in Spruce Run Cemetery in Glen Gardner, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDIS, MORRIS B.
description: LANDIS-Morris B. Of Highland Park, NJ and Aventura, FL. Beloved husband of Raye nee Rosenbaum. Devoted father of Mark, Alan, Diana, Ilene, Mitchell and Tefera. Father-in-law of Carolyn, Linda, Jeffrey and Linda Jean. Dear brother of Alex and Sam. Loving grandfather of 12 grandchildren and 2 great-grandchildren. Dad, Grandpa, Meish, Uncle Morris, ''The Producer''. Always a trendsetter, with a healthy diet and exercise, always years ahead of his time, the eternal overflowing optimist. Now at his passing, years ahead of his time. We will all miss our greatest cheerleader and supporter. We hope throughout our lives and those of future generations that Dad's very special being will live on. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Central New Jersey Jewish Home for the Aged, 732-873-2000 or to the Israel Emergency Fund of the UJA Federation, 212-980-1000. Services were held. For information ''Wein & Wein'', 800-322-0533.

title: The Politics Of Security
description: The ferocity of the White House counterattack this week, when confronted by criticism that President Bush and his top advisers knew more than the public about hijacking threats before Sept. 11, is a sure sign that they recognize the political danger should Democrats press the issue through the coming election campaign.

title: Life Without Parole?
description: At the parole office on West 40th Street in Manhattan, Tuesdays are always busy. Parolees begin lining up on the sidewalk at 8 a.m., 20 minutes before the front door opens. By 8:30, most of the 80 seats in the waiting room are filled. Men greet each other by slapping palms, and the noise level rises throughout the morning. ''A criminal social club,'' a supervisor mutters, surveying the scene with a 9-millimeter pistol hidden beneath his jacket.

Instead, Mr. Cohen, 37, is an in-house disc jockey at the Virgin Megastore in Union Square in Manhattan. (''Brother Mike'' is his D.J. name.) He's quite content.

title: Horticultural Feast at a Rhode Island Estate
description: ESTATE gardens can be a yawn: acres of lawn rolling down from an English-style mansion, garden "rooms" rolling out from the south side of the house. And somewhere, a walled rose garden.

title: Love Your Hat
description: ''I'm from Queens,'' the singer-actress christeni melendez, opposite, told Robert Burck, aka the naked cowboy. He responded, ''Is that a play on words?'' She wears Bill Blass's silk embroidered dress, $10,500. At Bergdorf Goodman. Necklaces: Kenneth Jay Lane. Earrings and bracelet: Swarovski. Shoes: Sergio Rossi. title: Hwa-Shih Lee, Reginald Tucker
description: Hwa-Shih Lee, a daughter of Chin and Ting Lee of Diamond Bar, Calif., is to be married today to Reginald Donnell Tucker, the son of Janet L. Tucker and the stepson of Samuel W. Jones of Hamden, Conn. The Rev. Jeffrey B. Kearney, a Baptist minister, is to perform the ceremony at Dish of Salt, a New York restaurant.

title: Country Dwellers One Might Invite Home
description: CLOISTERED in our suburban gardens, encircled by impatiens and bounded by well-tended lawns, we can easily forget about the common milkweed (Asclepias syraica). Out of sight and out of mind, it is commonly found in rural areas, keeping company with the likes of wild chicory, daisy fleabane and Queen Anne's lace. A few related species, like the flashy butterfly weed (Asclepias tuberosa), have caught the public's fancy, but somehow milkweed has never been able to overcome its country cousin status in the community of garden plants.

description: LIFE'S WORK

title: A Master Passes On Ashton's Mastery
description: AMERICAN Ballet Theater will present the company premieres of ''The Dream'' on Friday and ''La Fille Mal Garde'' on May 31 at the Metropolitan Opera House. Created for the Royal Ballet, the two classics are signature works by Sir Frederick Ashton, a choreographer who in many ways defined English ballet in the 20th century.

title: Estes's Outing Not Wasted This Time
description: Five days ago, Shawn Estes walked off the mound after producing another well-pitched game. He settled down to watch what the Mets would do after they rallied to tie the score. And he waited.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIGAL, HARRIET F.
description: SIGAL-Harriet F. On May 3, 2002 in Sarasota, FL. Concert and operatic mezzo-soprano. High school choral director and music teacher in New York City schools. Beloved wife of the late Alvin I. Sigal. She will be deeply missed by her children Leah and husband Mark Spitzer, Joshua & partner Howard Haskin, Melanie and husband Douglas Gordin, & grandchildren Rebecca, Max, Jacob, Zoe, and Isaac. Remembered by many for her devotion, excellence as a performer and teacher, unique spirit, and volunteer work. Private family memorial service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, RUTH E.
description: ROSENBERG-Ruth E. Age 87, passed away May 10, in her Manhattan apartment. Ruth enjoyed a long and respected career as an executive secretary at the headquarters of one of the nation's largest textile companies. She was a native New Yorker who loved the City, and would think of living nowhere else. She had a New Yorker's dry and wry wit, and an unfailing sense of style and taste. Ruth and her late husband, Murray, loved discovering restaurants. On Sundays, driving with them to dinner, you never knew where you were going to end up, only that you'd be laughing all the way. Burial will be private. Anyone wishing to share memories can contact her nephew Andy Safir, at 3800 Carbo Court, La Mesa, CA 91941.

title: Bridge for Sale In Brooklyn
description: THE Internet boom may be over, but the New Economy hype machine lives on, as can be seen in a recent memorandum from Andrew Filipowski, the chairman of Divine Inc., to his employees.

title: Genetic Tests Abound. Why Won't Insurers Pay?
description: LAST month, J. Craig Venter, the former president and founder of Celera Genomics, caused a stir in scientific circles by revealing that he had used his own DNA in the company's successful effort to unravel the human genome. The DNA was supposed to have come exclusively from anonymous donors. But protocol aside, it is easy to understand why Mr. Venter might have made himself a guinea pig: Your genetic code offers important clues to your future health and well-being.

title: Suppose They Gave a Party And Served on Majolica?

title: PrivateSector; Adding a Talk-Show Spritz To Coke's Annual Mixer
description: Among the annual shareholder meetings this season, the Coca-Cola Company's fiesta in New York last month stands out. Many companies chose to be circumspect about their get-togethers, citing cost and security concerns this year, said Patrick McGurn, vice president of Institutional Shareholder Services, which tracks the meetings. But Coke executives brought in Jon Bon Jovi, Wynton Marsalis, Cal Ripken Jr., Muhammad Ali and other celebrities to help tout the virtues of owning shares in Coca-Cola.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.

title: May 12-18: INTERNATIONAL; CARTER IN CUBA
description: Jimmy Carter took in a baseball game during his five-day visit to Cuba, the first by a former or sitting U.S. president since Fidel Castro took power. But he had already been playing hardball. In a speech broadcast live on state-run television and radio -- and delivered before Mr. Castro -- Mr. Carter said that the Cuban revolution had failed to protect human rights and endorsed a referendum seeking greater freedoms. Mr. Castro, however, got what he wanted when Mr. Carter called for an end to the trade embargo. But the Bush administration is expected to announce a tougher Cuba policy Monday. David Gonzalez

title: Princeton and Syracuse Reach Familiar Place
description: Somehow, Princeton always seems to win its close games in the N.C.A.A. men's lacrosse tournament. It won its four previous N.C.A.A. games, including last year's final, by one goal. Of its 11 previous N.C.A.A. games decided by one goal, it won them all.

title: An Accidental Gardener Dresses the Part
description: A SWIPE at my wind-blown hair with a mud-caked glove has left me feeling like Scarlett O'Hara with a fistful of Tara's red earth. As God is my witness, I'll never plant impatiens in direct sunlight again.

title: Morris Park Journal; Are These Ladies Game to Keep Playing? Bingo!
description: They take their bingo seriously at the Morris Park Senior Center. They play the inner square, the outer square, the X, the T, the entire board -- 24 games in 90 minutes, plus a short half-hour break for lunch.

He was on a 1965 F.B.I. suspect list, along with two men who were eventually convicted, one in 1977, and one last year. But J. title: Other People's Money

But if Mr. James's victory highlighted the primacy of incumbency -- the mayor was backed by every important union and Democrat in the state -- it also showed that many urban blacks remain wary of candidates perceived as outsiders. His plan is to make himself a court favorite, so he can gain access to Louis XVI and persuade him to finance a drainage project back home (Ponceludon is a very unselfish lord. This is not for him, but for the health of the local peasants.) Life being what it is, Ponceludon also finds love (with a virginal young thing who goes diving in her spare time) and sex (with an outspoken, slightly older countess. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENWASSER, ROBERT
description: ROSENWASSER-Robert. Passed away on May 16, 2002, after a long and dreadful illness. Dearest husband of Dorothy, devoted father of Carol Harris & Marsha and Tim Schaffner, stepfather of Jonathan Paret & Terrence and Joanne Paret, loving grandfather of Debby and Will Gans and Dan and Rivka Bushell, great-grandfather of Malky Bushell, brother of Sidney Rosenwasser. Robert Rosenwasser was the founder and President of Rosenwasser Grossman Consulting Engineers. He was a distinguished engineer with a long career who received numerous awards in structural engineering. He was acclaimed for his many contributions to the NYC skyline. Robert Rosenwasser was a graduate of the City College of New York. He was a member of Chi Epsilon, the National Civil Engineering honor fraternity, and was a Fellow of the American Concrete Institute. He was honored by the Concrete Industry Board of New York, which presented him with its Leader of Industry Award. He wrote several articles on various aspects of building design, construction and economics. Services will be held Sunday, May 19, 2002, at 1:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave at 81st St. Shiva will be observed directly following the service, Sunday, May 19, at the Rosenwasser residence. title: Windswept Freedom on Two Fast Wheels
description: IN its twilight years in the early 1960's, Steeplechase Park in Coney Island was my childhood summer playground. I learned to swim in the saltwater pool and screamed with feigned fright on the giant roller coaster. But my most thrilling memories are of the Steeplechase horses. These fantastic wooden steeds sped on electric rails around a half-mile ''race course'' on top of the amusement pavilion. I always had to ride the horse on the inside rail: He went the fastest, and the rush of the wind on my little face was exhilarating. When Steeplechase Park closed in 1964, a piece of my childhood went with it.

title: Pushing the Limit

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, CHARLES S.
description: STRAUSS-Charles S., 88. Of Larchmont, died on May 15 due to complications in the last few months. He was born December 31, 1913 in Haverhill, MA. to Ansel and Helen Strauss. He spent his youth in Pelham, New York. He graduated from Andover in 1931 and Yale in 1935. Charlie served as a First Sergeant in World War II. After the war he worked for M. Lowenstein & Sons until his retirement. Charlie was predeceased by his beloved wife, Margaret Levi Strauss and his loving daughter, Leyae Strauss and his brother John Strauss. He is survived by his loving family: daughter, Barbara Strauss, his son and daughter-inlaw, Chick and Sherry Strauss, his three grandchildren Emily, Hannah and Noah Strauss, and by his brother and sister-in-law, Peter and Barbara Strauss, and their children, John, Eileen and Sally Strauss. A memorial service will be held at Congregation Emanuel of Westchester on Thursday, May 23, at 2 PM, the Temple of which he was a past president. Donations in his memory may be sent to Yale, Andover, Congregation Emanuel of Westchester, or a charity of your choice. Charlie was an avid Quaker Ridge golfer, bridge player, story teller and a caring and supportive friend. We're left with fond memories. He will be missed by all.

title: When the Outs Got In
description: In a parable by Kafka, wild beasts break into a temple and disrupt the act of worship again and again, until the ritual is modified to incorporate their visits. For the literary scholar Morris Dickstein's purposes, the leopards are the newer, more cosmopolitan writers -- black, beatnik, Jewish, homosexual -- who exploded upon the artificially unified temple of American letters at the end of World War II. Dickstein's study LEOPARDS IN THE TEMPLE: The Transformation of American Fiction, 1945-1970 (Harvard University, paper, $15.95) begins with the war novels of Norman Mailer, Joseph Heller and James Jones, then takes a sharp turn inward with Chester B. Himes and Saul Bellow. He prefers Paul Bowles and Tennessee Williams (especially Williams's ''neglected but wonderful'' short stories) to Truman Capote, ''a fashionable tourist in the lower depths.'' As Dickstein's study moves forward, its central irony only deepens: the more prosperous and outwardly peaceful the nation, the more existentially anxious its writers seem to become. The best writing from the 1950's, as Dickstein says, has an undertone of hysteria, a desperate pathos, a sense of entrapment, a mournful sense of fear and loss. Dickstein particularly values Bernard Malamud's books ''The Assistant'' and ''The Magic Barrel.'' But he is also good on Vladimir Nabokov, whose ''Lolita'' he impishly reads as a sort of pre-emptive ''sendup'' of Jack Kerouac's ''On the Road,'' with Humbert Humbert as an advance parody of the priapic Dean Moriarty and ''a phantasmagoric landscape of cultural kitsch and inward fixation'' standing in for the pointless, illusory freedom of Sal Paradise. title: 'The Making of a Philosopher'
description: Iwas born in 1950, five years after the end of World War II, in West Hartlepool, county Durham, a small mining town in the northeast of England. The hospital in which I was born was a converted workhouse, or homeless shelter as it would be known today. My mother was twenty years old, my father twenty-six, and I was their first child. Both my grandfathers — whose names were both Joseph, like my father's — were coal miners, as were all of my uncles except one, who was a carpenter and bricklayer. Life expectancy among miners was low, and both my grandfathers died young from work-related diseases. Everyone in my family was short and wiry. My paternal grandfather was known in the mine as "Joe the Agitator" because of his activities in fighting for improved working conditions; he eventually became secretary of the local miners' union, and read Karl Marx and Rudyard Kipling in his spare time. He was a kindly, clipped man, not much given to conversation, devoted to his Woodbine smokes. I never remember a time when my tiny, shrill-voiced, constantly cussing grandmother had any teeth; she chewed meat with her gums. She said "thee" and "thou" (pronounced thoo ) as part of ordinary speech, as in "thee knaas Jack Ridley" (meaning "you know Jack Ridley"). Of a blunt knife she would say "I could ride bare-arsed to London on this" and give out a throaty, high-pitched cackle. I have no recollection of my maternal grandfather, though his widow is still miraculously alive at ninety. My father left school at fourteen and went "down the pit," his first job being to pick stones out of the coal as it was shunted by on a massive belt contraption. But he quickly escaped this form of premature burial by going to night school and learning the building trade. He was sufficiently proficient at this to become general manager of a small building company while still in his twenties, and he made his career as manager of various branches of the building department of the co-op in different parts of England. He retired early and now has a second career as a painter, mainly of scenes from the mining towns in which he grew up. Some of his work is in the historical record of the art gallery that serves the area his paintings record. Both my brothers, Keith and Martin, are artists too, though I was never very strong in that department.

Our 1990 census figures show that there are 175,000 residents who are 60 years of age or older or that, one out of every five of our residents are seniors. Nearly half of this group relies on Social Security as their only income. Some 50,000 people in this group have incomes of $15,000 or less annually. Eighty percent are women who live alone. It is estimated that the elderly population will increase by 30 percent over the next 20 years.

title: Intersecting Flight Paths, 75 Years Apart
description: ON May 1, Erik Lindbergh, grandson of the man who made history by flying solo nonstop from New York to Paris, headed his Lancair Columbia 300 single-engine aircraft over St. John's, Newfoundland, and out into the ocean. Hours earlier he had left New York for Paris following roughly the same Great Circle route that Charles Lindbergh had taken 75 years ago tomorrow. Beneath him the cloud cover had broken. ''It was sublime, very beautiful,'' he said. Two hours later dusk became total darkness. ''About that time I lost all communication with air traffic control, and I could tell my computer wasn't sending position reports,'' he said.

title: The Weight of an Anchor
description: It can't be fun to be told repeatedly that you are obsolete, dying, soon to be relegated to TV's Hall of Fame like such other once ubiquitous but now half-forgotten golden oldies as ''Kukla, Fran & Ollie.'' So pity, at least for a moment, the plight of three of the most widely known and highly paid stars in the vast American information firmament: the network news anchormen. Their nightly newscasts, which collectively commanded 84 percent of the viewing audience in 1981, now attract only 43 percent of the pie. Those Americans who do tune in, with a median age ranging from 56 (NBC) to 60 (CBS), are regarded as a step or two from the grave by the youth-centric standards of a medium that worships the 18-24 demographic. Whatever the news each night on NBC's ''Nightly News,'' CBS's ''Evening News'' and ABC's ''World News Tonight,'' the commercials on the three broadcasts amount to a grim virtual tour of a medicine cabinet largely for the aging, the infirm, the impotent and the incontinent: Plavix, Pepcid, Nexium, Ditropan, Caltrate, Viagra and Depends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRYAN, ROBERT F.
description: BRYAN-Robert F. Of Delray Beach, Florida, formerly of Rye, NY. On May 16, at the age of 89, due to complications from Parkinson's Disease. A graduate of Oberlin College, Phi Beta Kappa, in 1934, he earned a Ph.D. in Economics from Yale University in 1939 having been an instructor at both Yale and Princeton Universities. He was an economist with Lionel D. Edie & Co. from 1939-1948 except during W.W. II, 1941-42, when he was with the OPA. In 1948 he joined J.H. Whitney & Co. becoming a partner in 1951. From 1959-69 he was a financial vice-president, treasurer and director of Whitney Communications Corp. and from 1967-69 a partner in Whitcom Investment Co. He was a member of the executive committee of the Yale Graduate School Council 1969-73 and a Trustee of Oberlin College 1960-70. He was predeceased by his wife, Dorothy Darr Bryan, in 1979 and his wife, Gertrude G. Bryan in 1999. His first wife, Elaine Norwood Bennett, who is also the mother of his two daughters, survives him as does his oldest daughter, Diane Bryan Lyon, of New York City. His younger daughter, Barbara Bryan Bardo, passed away in 1992. He is also survived by three granddaughters, Cecil Lyon Sanford and Wendy Lyon McCammon both of Miami, Florida, Michelle Bowen Kowalski of Berkeley, California and one grandson, Robert Bryan Bowen of Petaluma, CA. as well as four great-grandchildren. Burial will be in Greenwood-Union Cemetery, Rye, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, CAROL RAE
description: SMITH-Carol Rae. Beloved wife of Park B. Smith, was born into eternal life on May 16, 2002 while at their home in Lakeville, CT. Carol was born September 9, 1950 in Minneapolis, MN. She is survived by her devoted husband, Park B. Smith of New York City, NY, and Lakeville, CT; her parents, Richard Locken and Betty Rodriguez, & her sisters Marla, Janet, Nancy and brother David Locken, of Minneapolis, MN; and the Park and Terry Smith, and the Jim and Patty White families of Warren, NJ. As Co-Chair of Park B. Smith, Inc., of New York City, Carol's standard of excellence, attention to detail, and the ability to address issues head-on were essential to the growth of the company. Her legacy continues to inspire and guide those at PBS, Inc. Not only did Carol desire the success of the company, but also the personal growth and success of the many employees for whom she cared. Carol was intimately involved in all aspects of Park B. Smith, Inc., including operations, systems, finance and design. Not one facet of the business has gone untouched by Carol's intelligence and capability. Tough and demanding of herself as well as the others with whom she worked, Carol inspired all who knew her. She was not only a leader of the company, she was an integral part of the company, and will be greatly missed. As a team, Carol and her husband Park B. Smith built a company that exemplifies excellence, creativity, and excitement within the home furnishings industry. The foundation that Carol and Park built is based on loyalty, trust, and integrity. It is a solid foundation which bodes well for the present and future growth of PBS, Inc. Carol, also affectionately known as ''Toots,'' was a cherished wife, sister, daughter, aunt, grandmother and friend. Her never-ending smile, loving ways, and concern and love for others will be remembered. Carol lived with dignity, elegance, and quiet strength. We will miss her very much. May her memory live in our hearts. Friends may visit Sunday, May 19, 2002 from 2:00-5:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, Madison Avenue at 81 St., NYC, NY. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Monday, May 20, 2002, at 10:00 AM at St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington and 66 St., NYC, NY. A private family burial will follow in Salisbury, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations in Carol's name may be sent to The World Wildlife Fund, 1250 24 St., NW, PO Box 97180, Washington, D.C. 20090. (www.worldwildlife.org). The Smith, Locken and White Families

Constantine Mathews of Stamford, Conn. The Very Rev. description: AT some point Monday, the Democratic Republic of East Timor will be born as an independent and sovereign country just like all the member states of the United Nations and also Switzerland, which is not in the United Nations. But that is another story.

title: Priceline.com Adds Vacation Packages
description: Priceline.com has been something of a boon to travelers who are looking for bargain air fares, hotels and car rentals, provided they can live with some uncertainty, like not knowing what airline or hotel they'll be using. Now, the company is expanding into the realm of vacation packages, without some of the uncertainty.

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: The World: Past as Prologue; The Politics of Assassination
description: THE assassination of the right-wing Dutch politician Pim Fortuyn, just one week before the party that bears his name won a dramatic victory in a national election and prepares to enter a center-right coalition government, is a stark reminder that political murder has played an important part in modern European history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSCOW, ELSA MOOLTEN
description: MOSCOW-Elsa Moolten. 88. On May 13, 2002. Of NYC; formerly of San Diego and Rockville Centre, NY. Devoted mother of Jon Moscow and Judith Moscow Warren. Grandmother of David and Lev. Mother-in-law of Patricia Sterner. A strong, independent woman, Elsa shared with and learned from the world. We will miss you. Friends may Email jmoscow01@ aol.com or write Jon at Amber CS, 310 Lenox Ave, NYC 10027. Contributions in Elsa's name may be made to Barnard College or Jewish Home & Hospital in Bronx.

title: United's Lame-Duck Chief May Have to Move Fast
description: JOHN W. CREIGHTON JR. descended into the bowels of O'Hare International Airport on his first night on the job. He looked around like a newly crowned king among his subjects. United Airlines pilots came and went. Flight attendants wheeled their carry-on bags.

title: Carry On Nail Files, But Not Corkscrews
description: In an effort to speed up security checkpoints at airports and alleviate passenger confusion, the new Transportation Security Administration has issued an updated list of what items may and may not be included in carry-on luggage.

title: Sports of The Times; For Legions of Pitino Haters, the Recovery of the Celtics Is Sweet
description: OUR first caller on the subject of the captivating renaissance of the Boston Celtics under Jim O'Brien after Rick Pitino is a familiar voice but one that we have not heard from in years, Al from Phoenix.

title: Mom's World, Explained
description: MY first name is a combination of an Indian word meaning ''lotus'' and the name of a symbol connoting everything that's good, beautiful or prosperous. I get a lot of questions about my married name. People ask whether they should be afraid of me.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHESTER, DAVID J.
description: CHESTER-David J. Banker and musician, died May 17, 2002, at age 52. Beloved husband of Andie (Andrea). Loving father of Jennifer Kilgallen and David Jr. Dear brother of Sam. Devoted son of the late Jack and Rose. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Sunday and Monday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM, with service Tuesday, 9:30 AM. Interment to follow at Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Poetry in Motion?
description: TAKING THE TRAIN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARNETT, ALAN
description: GARNETT-Alan. La Coquille of Westhampton Beach, Inc, records with sorrow the passing of member Alan Garnett. Condolences to his wife Margo. The Board of Directors La Coquille of Westhampton Beach, Inc.

title: May 12-18
description: LANDMARK MOMENT The metaphor of choice was funeral (for the cold war). But two new agreements cementing Russia's rapprochement with the West felt as much like a wedding (which Secretary of State Colin L. Powell acknowledged no one has yet found "a new neon sign" to describe). Within 24 hours, Washington and Moscow announced a treaty to cut nuclear warheads by two-thirds, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization formally invited Vladimir V. Putin's Russia into a junior partnership with the military alliance that was formed to defend Europe from the Soviet threat. The arms treaty amounts to three pages, incorporating separate pledges by each side. The new NATO agreement pledges cooperation with Russia on issues like terrorism, civil disasters and nonproliferation, but reserves decisions on use of force for the alliance's members.

title: A Mystery Deepens in Mystic After a Beloved Teacher Dies
description: TWO weeks ago, a 7-year-old boy walked into a newsstand in Stonington and told the owner, Tom Rezendes, that his mother had sent him to buy a newspaper.

title: 'The City of Your Final Destination'
description: September 13, 1995

title: Simply Radiant
description: Clothes with a rich shimmer, tissue-thin brocades and lams, most often associated with winter, are here for spring and summer. What has happened is that these brocades are being made lightweight, cut in simple shapes and separates, with the fabric speaking loudest. Gold and ivory stretch brocade dresses, like the four below, reflect a contemporary look for the sleek body and are being worn to dinner parties. A day suit suggesting a pajama top, and worn with a box-pleat skirt (left and far right), are favorites. A most interesting mix is bronze and gold, with an insert of terra cotta (group of three below right). All these gossamer clothes have one thing in common: they're by Prada.

title: Corrections
description: Abiographical sketch on Sept. 24 about a World Trade Center victim, Catherine L. LoGuidice, an assistant bond trader at Cantor Fitzgerald who spent weekends helping at a veterinary hospital, misidentified an illness her grandfather had and her role during it. He had a stroke, not cancer. She drove him to physical therapy; she did not take care of him. A family member notified The Times of the errors in January, but this correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, CAROL
description: SMITH-Carol. We extend our heartfelt condolences to our President Park Smith on the passing of his beloved wife. The Board of Directors of the Home Fashion Products Association

title: Deirdre Carraher, Richard Latour
description: Deirdre Ann Carraher, the daughter of Elaine Y. Carraher and Glenn F. Carraher of Seekonk, Mass., was married on Friday to Richard Latour, a son of Theresa and Guy Latour of Ottawa. The Rev. Joseph A. Cogo, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Pompei Church in New York.

title: Amazon II: Will This Smile Last?
description: JEFF BEZOS is feeling a tad cocky lately. That might seem like a dog-bites-man observation for the founder of Amazon.com, a man so obsessed with brain power that he started a science-and-literature summer school for children after his freshman year at Princeton and once hired only college graduates to staff the customer-service phone lines at his company.

title: A Wagner More Intimate Than Heroic
description: HOW big does Wagner have to be in order to be great? The question is posed by the Eos Orchestra, which presents ''The Rhinegold'' on Thursday and Saturday at the New York Society for Ethical Culture. Conducting the imposing prologue to the ''Ring'' cycle, in an English-language production staged by Christopher Alden, Jonathan Sheffer will have before him not the original immense forces but just 18 or so players, performing an arrangement of the score by the British composer Jonathan Dove. Here, for once, is chamber Wagner.

title: If You Don't Like the Weather, Keep Surfing
description: LAST month, Karen Persichilli Keogh, who works in Manhattan directing Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's New York operations, was scheduled to attend a 4 p.m. memorial service in Boston with her husband. Since Delta's shuttle from La Guardia to Logan flies every hour, the big question Ms. Keogh faced as she packed was whether to leave the office by midmorning and face a mountain of work on Monday, or leave later and risk missing the service.

title: Warren Brandt, 84, a Painter In a Style of Domestic Warmth
description: Warren Brandt, a painter whose dalliance with Abstract Expressionism gave way to a style of realism and domestic warmth, died May 5 in Sykesville, Md., his family said. He was 84 and lived in New York City.

title: Topaza Watkins, Alfred Edmond Jr.
description: Topaza Letrice Watkins, an executive recruiter, and Alfred Adam Edmond Jr., the editor in chief of Black Enterprise magazine, are to be married today in Nashville. The Rev. Eddie L. Long, a Baptist minister, is to officiate at the Gaylord Opryland Hotel Resort and Convention Center.

title: Jolts of Anxiety
description: I have a defibrillator and am familiar with the panic attacks Lorraine Flood describes; I have taken Ativan and attended support groups to deal with those symptoms. There was a time when I, too, saw my life largely focused on avoiding defibrillator shocks.

title: Who Really Needs a Golden Thingy?
description: ONE Monday morning late last December in Los Angeles, I found myself waking early. It was 6 a.m. in L.A., 9 a.m. in New York. Today the nominees for the Golden Globes would be announced. There had been speculation that I would receive a nomination for my performance in the film ''L.I.E.'' So I sat in my office, quietly, uneasily trying to think of something -- anything -- else. But the Globes were tolling away at the back of my preoccupied gray matter.

title: Getting Epidermal When It's Thermal
description: YOUR office mates are in short sleeves. Your mail carrier is in shorts. Your dog is shedding its fur. The sartorial signals are unmistakable. It's time for the annual strip-down that spells summer.

title: Horticultural Feast at a Rhode Island Estate
description: ESTATE gardens can be a yawn: acres of lawn rolling down from an English-style mansion, garden ''rooms'' rolling out from the south side of the house. And somewhere, a walled rose garden.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: WINNING SOUNDS LIKE THIS

title: Dr. Levine's Dilemma
description: Primary-care medicine needs more physicians like Jim Levine, but he is being forced out by the intolerable demands of managed care (Devin Friedman, May 5). Why should Levine have to care for 4,000 patients ''faster than some people run'' until he burns out, when he could care for 300 patients and have some time left for himself?

title: Giambi Adds His Name To Yankee Record Book
description: After 5 hours 45 minutes of baseball, the last four hours or so played in a misty rain, the Yankees had another chance to redeem themselves on the Friday night that became a Saturday morning. It was a night and a morning filled with drama, missed opportunities, more suspense and more botched chances.

title: To Hold, Not to Have
description: AS tourists -- people for whom travel is possible simply because we pay for the experience -- we are lulled into a global garage sale mentality. In Japan, where I live part-time, I find myself bargaining with flea market vendors over items that should be displayed in museums. Antique kimono? How much do you want? Edo period Shinto scroll? Would you take any less for that? I've seen this scene repeated, with minute variations, around the world. Whether rattling 19th-century tea sets at a Tokyo bazaar, sifting through Roman coins in the Old City of Jerusalem or haggling down fabrics vendors in Aix-en-Provence, it is axiomatic that, as travelers, we can partake in the cultural riches around us by purchasing them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGUIRE, GEORGE WILLIAM
description: McGUIRE-George William. 74, passed away at his home on May 1, 2002. He was born in Brooklyn, NY, served in the U.S. Navy and graduated from New York University. He had a long and distinguished career in advertising, including positions with DuPont, Grey Advertising and Peterson Publishing, was President of Grey, Lyon and King, and partner in the executive search firm of Lucas, Berger, McGuire and O'Brien. Mr. McGuire was a lifelong supporter of various charities. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in George McGuire's name to Soft Tissue Sarcoma Research at Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

title: What's in An Award? He'll Tell You
description: WHEN Frank DiBella watches the Tony Awards show on television, he always gets nervous after winners are announced. He knows they will be presented with their awards.

title: Edginess
description: BLUES FOR CANNIBALS

title: Pair Charged in Killing of 7 In a 1993 Restaurant Robbery
description: Nearly 10 years after one of the worst massacres in the state's history, two men were charged today with seven counts of murder while committing armed robbery in 1993 at a fast-food restaurant in this village 30 miles northwest of Chicago.

title: London
description: With its long lazy days and short sweet nights, summer is always a special time in London. This summer holds even more promise than usual, because Queen Elizabeth II is celebrating her Golden Jubilee, marking the 50th anniversary of her ascension to the throne on Feb. 2, 1952.

title: PrivateSector; Harsh Lessons for Russian Oilman
description: VAGIT ALEKPEROV gathered a group of analysts and bankers at the headquarters of Lukoil, the giant oil company of which he is chief executive, to lay out an ambitious corporate overhaul plan to reinvigorate its sluggish shares.

title: Away From It All on the Delaware
description: THE story of the Delaware River is often told in terms of transportation and commerce. But there is another story to tell about the history of recreation along the river and how Americans learned the art of chilling out along the Delaware.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Strip Centers Are Turning to Nonretail Tenants
description: IN attempting to stave off high vacancy rates, strip shopping centers in Suffolk County, which proliferate along its most traveled roads, are changing their appearance. Many of the strips, which average 15,000 square feet, have had to look for nonretail tenants to survive.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Browsing in Private Gardens

title: Denise Gottlieb, Steven Gordon
description: Denise Michele Gottlieb, the daughter of Regina T. Kratt of Garden City, N.Y., and the late Robert S. Gottlieb, was married on Friday to Steven Matthew Gordon, a son of Lois Gordon and William Gordon of Los Angeles. Msgr. James Lisante officiated at the Garden City Hotel, with Rabbi Allen Block taking part in the ceremony.

title: Hints of Cruel Fate for American Lost in Chile
description: The vacationing hiker spent the night under the summer stars, his only companion a local herdsman. The next morning, the traveler, an American mathematics professor named Boris Weisfeiler, made his way toward a spot where two rivers converged, hoping to wade across.

title: Chirac, a Victory in Hand, Sets His Sights on Another
description: Last weekend, a furious President Jacques Chirac stormed out of a soccer stadium here after a few fans greeted the French national anthem, the Marseillaise, with whistles and jeers.

title: The Wild Ones
description: For those who worship in the salmon's nave instead of some other deity's, the next few months are Christmas, Easter, Hanukkah, Ramadan, Boun That Luang, Kwanzaa and Stick Day rolled into one blissful season. The wild ones are coming. In fact, some are already here.

title: Still Connecting When It Counts, Yanks Back Lilly's Strong Start
description: Ted Lilly and Randy Choate were waiting for a car service outside their Midtown apartment at about 10:30 yesterday morning. Like any casual Yankee fan catching a ride to work with a friend, Lilly asked Choate who had won the night before.

title: Sports of The Times; A Strike Date of Oct. 1 Insults Every Fan
description: IN what is both a new high for arrogance and a new low in labor relations, October is again in jeopardy of being torn off baseball's calendar.

title: Face to Face With Ugliness
description: IT is a scene with the potential to inspire inappropriate guffaws or just shocked silence: a confession of adultery, complete with wounded wife and contrite husband. Except, in this case, the other woman is a member of another species.

title: Defense Remains a Problem For the Last-Place Power
description: Defense has been the biggest problem for the New York Power, which has won once in six games.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; A Bond Formed in His Youth Still Shapes His Life
description: On a platform at Pennsylvania Station in 1960, 8-year-old James Peterson waited in the stifling summer heat with his mother. From the inner city, he was bound for a two-week vacation in the country. As the train left, the scared boy peered out the window and watched the concrete landscape morph into green pastures speckled with grazing farm animals.

title: Verizon Lays Ma Bell to Rest With a Very Visible Swoosh
description: The Manhattan skyline has a new logo, but viewers from Manhattan and Brooklyn are not buying it.

title: Study Finds Quitting Smoking Helps Odds for Cancer Patients
description: Stopping smoking even after lung cancer develops -- can lengthen patient survival, a Canadian study has found.

title: Art Listings
description: Museums/Institutions

title: How to Deal With Water In Basement
description: FOR most homeowners, keeping water out of the house involves making sure that the roof, windows and doors are in good repair and hold the elements at bay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, JOHN CHABOT
description: SMITH-John Chabot. On May 16, 2002. Author. Former White House, and W.W. II correspondent for The NY Herald Tribune, and retired writing teacher. Loving husband of the late Betty McCarthy Smith. Devoted father of Michael Smith, and the late Betsy Falk. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 11:30 AM at St. Saviour Church, Park Slope. Interment at Green-wood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers please make donations in John's name to Veritas Therapeutic Community, 912 Amsterdam Ave., New York, New York 10025.

title: Playing Through
description: Rainy nights I have flashbacks, because it happened on a rainy night. It's been four years since Rayshawn, Danny, Keshon and I were shot and became the poster boys of racial profiling. Shot while traveling to a college-basketball tryout in Durham, N.C., the mecca of basketball. Shot -- just when I was ready for the big boys.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 34 of The Times Magazine today about the state of network news misspells the surname of a CBS News producer who has commented on the Sept. 11 coverage by anchors of all networks. He is Al Ortiz, not Artiz.

title: The War Finally Ends For an Image of Evil
description: IF President Bush visits the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg as expected on Saturday, during a three-day trip to Russian, he might consider comparing his ideas about the nature of evil to a particularly vivid version that dates back nearly 700 years. On view are 14th-century panels from what may be the only stained-glass window wholly dedicated to the life and times of the Antichrist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINMAN, LUDWIG (LOU)
description: WEINMAN-Ludwig (Lou). June 2nd, 1914 to May 15, 2002. Beloved husband of Ilsa. Loving father of Ken and father-in-law of Joanne. Services today, 1 P.M. graveside at Mount Hebron Cemetery. For information, contact Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 718-263-7600.

title: In the Region/Westchester; Builders Are Moving to Fill Demand for Lab Space
description: IN response to a growing demand for biomedical laboratory space in Westchester County, a 30-year-old, 700,000-square-foot research park in Greenburgh and Mount Pleasant is planning to expand by as much at 570,000 square feet.

title: 75 Years Later, the Memory Lingers
description: FOURTEEN years ago, a plan to reunite witnesses to Charles A. Lindbergh's celebrated trans-Atlantic takeoff went somewhat awry. About 125 people called, claiming they observed the May 20, 1927, takeoff from a muddy Roosevelt Field runway.

title: A Smaller Garage Still Looms Large to Some
description: In February, Glenwood Management Corporation started planning a 180-space parking garage beneath its planned apartment tower on Broadway, at West 64th Street. It aimed to cater to shoppers and Lincoln Center audiences, but neighbors complained that the garage would clog already congested streets. The garage entrance was not pretty, either, they said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, MINNIE P.
description: WEINER-Minnie P. Of Kingston, NY, on May 16, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Theodore. Devoted mother of Phyllis Goldman and her husband, Alan. Cherished grandmother of Bruce and Linda, Michael and Karen, Terri and Robert. Proud great grandmother of Nina, Emily, Julia, Sam, Alanna, Jackson and Jason. She touched our lives deeply and we will miss her. Shiva at Phyllis's home Monday through Thursday evenings.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KRAMER, ALAN D.
description: KRAMER-Alan D. May 19, 2000. Missing you and the good times. Love, Joyce and Irving

title: In 5 Seconds or Less, What Brings You Here?
description: There are courses for speed reading, but speed interviewing? In a tough job market, maybe there should be.

title: Taking the Heat Off Cooking
description: ITALIANS know how to wake up a person's appetite. Most often, when you walk into an Italian restaurant, the first thing you see is a tantalizing spread of antipasti laid out by the front door: cold meats and sausages, glistening salads and platters of grilled vegetables, all of which inevitably guarantee an extra 10 bucks per person on the bill.

title: In Bad Times, It's Easier to Blame
description: IN ''The Grapes of Wrath,'' John Steinbeck paints the scene of a farmer, carrying a shotgun, approaching the driver of a tractor that is demolishing his home. After the driver explains that a bank in Oklahoma City has instructed him to do the deed, the farmer exclaims in frustration, ''Who can we shoot?''

title: These Buds For You, Bub
description: Men who like colors can have a field day this summer: the season's sportswear racks are abloom with the delicate floral prints made popular by Liberty of London in the 1930's. For those who crave a certain order to their splendor in the grass, Theory offers bright turquoise shirts ($165), bottom right, with matching pants ($195, both at Saks Fifth Avenue), while Miu Miu makes earth-tone flowered blazers, top right, and ''executive pouches'' ($550 for the blazers and $130 and $150 for the bags at Miu Miu Los Angeles, 323-651-0072). Marc Jacobs takes a soft approach by planting baby-blue tulips on crisp white oxfords ($330 at Marc Jacobs). On the brighter side, T-shirts, polos and button-down dress shirts by Custo Barcelona ($45 to $85 at Neiman Marcus) are a riot of color in yellow, blue and red. And for a funkier take on this season's inner botanist, Tracy Feith makes aqua, pink, blue or lavender safari shirts with two front pockets ($195 to $250 at Tracy Feith in SoHo).

title: It's Not Your Mom's Prom
description: SHANTELLE GARRIS has been looking forward to the prom since she came to Mount Vernon High School in 10th grade. Now a senior, Shantelle, 18, said she is most excited about getting dressed, a process for which she thinks she'll need a good part of the day.

title: Weekend Rains Are Still Only a Drop in the Reservoir
description: Heavy rains that pounded the metropolitan area early yesterday soaked the ground for the second time in a week, bringing runoffs to depleted reservoirs and a lush sheen to lawns, parks and woodlands. But to a profoundly parched region, the downpours were little more than an impressive illusion.

title: BEST SELLERS: May 19, 2002
description: Weeks

title: Our Man in Arizona
description: He hasn't been featured in any of the flinty-eyed, lantern-jawed photo shoots where the Bush team preened as war heroes. Annie Leibovitz has never laid eyes on him.

title: That Dame in the Clogs Is No Lady
description: AT Kirk Peterson's last performance with American Ballet Theater, in 1980, he led the company in Balanchine's ''Theme and Variations,'' dressed in the tights and velvet doublet of the premier danseur. For his comeback on May 31, Mr. Peterson, 52, will make his debut as the Widow Simone in Ballet Theater's premiere of Sir Frederick Ashton's ''Fille Mal Garde,'' wearing a frock and a bonnet.

title: Children's Book Illustrations
description: A selection of 9 illustrations from new books for young readers features the work of D. B. Johnson, Andrew Glass and Peter Ss.

title: Wage Pact Reached By German Workers
description: German metal workers in the Berlin and Brandenburg region adopted a wage accord reached today in the southern state of Baden-Wrttemberg, suggesting a series of strikes are close to an end.

title: Sticking To Basics, Nets Make Statement
description: It will never wind up in a sneaker commercial. There was no hang time, no long-range accuracy, and admittedly no funk. It was fundamental. And it was crucial.

title: Cheney Rejects Broader Access To Terror Brief
description: Vice President Dick Cheney said today that he would advise President Bush not to turn over to Congress the August intelligence briefing that warned that terrorists were interested in hijacking airplanes, and he insisted that the investigation into Sept. 11 should be handled by the Congressional intelligence committees, not an independent commission.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Urging Young to Buckle Up, Officials Try Switch in Tactics
description: Forget warning young drivers that driving without a seat belt can kill them. Those who still do not buckle up, safety officials say, are more likely to be moved by a threat that scares them more than death: a traffic ticket.

title: C.H.S.A.A. GIRLS RETAIN TITLE
description: St. Joseph by-the-Sea High School successfully defended its team title yesterday in the New York sectional girls' championships of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association at the winners' field on Staten Island. In the Brooklyn-Queens C.H.S.A.A. title meet, at the same site, Bishop Loughlin of Brooklyn was victorious.

title: Wisconsin Upsets Harvard For Title in Eastern Sprints
description: Fifty-six years after winning the inaugural Eastern Sprint Championship, Wisconsin finally won its second title today with a commanding performance against undefeated Harvard, the heavy favorite.

title: In Bid to Improve Nutrition, Schools Expel Soda and Chips
description: It is lunchtime at Fremont High, in one of the largest school districts in the nation to enact a systemwide ban on junk food. The cafeteria is offering a mystery meat wrapped in a tortilla, with fruit on the side, but it is no draw for Nicole Talbott, a student who is headed across the street to a small market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, JAMES R.
description: ROSS-James R. At age 22, on May 17, 2002. Beloved son of Gerald and Diana Ross. Brother of Margaret. Funeral services Wednesday, May 22, 10 AM, at Christ St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, 120 West 69th Street, New York, NY 10023, telephone 212-787-2755. The family will be receiving at the Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street, Tuesday evening, 7 to 9 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in James's memory to Canisius College, ROTC Endowment Fund or to Christ St. Stephen's Episcopal Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILORENZO, JEANNETTE B.
description: DiLORENZO-Jeannette B. The United Federation of Teachers Jewish Heritage Committee/Jewish Labor Committee Educators Chapter, deeply mourns the passing of our friend, colleague, and founder. Jeannette was a very special person. She will always be remembered for her leadership and for her dedication to education, trade unionism, human rights, and the State of Israel. We send our sympathy to her sister Blanche. Joel H. Shiller, Chairperson

title: A Great Run, an Imperfect Horse
description: War Emblem proved he is a remarkable horse with his performance here in the second leg of the Triple Crown, a victory made all the more impressive because he was forced to change his front-running style and gut out a three-quarter-length victory. Bob Baffert is as sharp a trainer as they come and has won the Kentucky Derby twice, the Preakness four times and the Belmont Stakes once over the past six years to stop any argument before it even starts.

title: Clemens Overpowers Twins With 13 Strikeouts
description: Roger Clemens's 125th and final pitch at Yankee Stadium yesterday afternoon may have been the best in an eight-inning performance his catcher, Jorge Posada, called Clemens's most dominating of the season.

title: Cheney Expects More Terror for U.S.
description: Vice President Dick Cheney said today that he considered another major attack by Al Qaeda against the United States to be ''almost certain.''

title: ImClone Cancer Drug Fails In a Test Against a Placebo
description: ImClone Systems' cancer drug Erbitux has failed the first clinical trial in which it was compared with a placebo, doctors conducting the trials said here today.

title: Cheers in the Meadowlands, And They're Not for the Giants
description: Sean Gatesy remembers when New Jersey Nets fans were so few that they were forced to sit on one side of the arena to give the appearance of a crowd. That was not long ago, he recalled, admitting that until this season he never believed his favorite team would be so close to a championship.

title: Artist Depicts the Bill of Rights in a World Out of Joint
description: ''I like art that gives you a reality fix,'' says Richard Minsky. A reality he treasures is the Bill of Rights, so Mr. Minsky, 55, a Greenwich Village artist and professional bookbinder, has found a way to exemplify the first 10 amendments to the Constitution as artworks.

title: Not Bad, Clones, But Watch Spidey's Legs
description: ''Star Wars: Episode 2 Attack of the Clones'' sold an estimated $116.3 million worth of tickets in its first four days in theaters, an impressive opening for any film, but one, it must be said, that did not quite match the $115 million that ''Spider-Man'' made in just three days two weeks ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUTSCH, ARTHUR LEO
description: DEUTSCH-Arthur Leo. On May 19, 2002. Beloved husband of Beulah. Loving father of Michael, Peter and father-in-law of Lori. Cherished grandfather to Caitlin, Marianna, Christina, Rory, Jonathan and Daniellie. Loving brother of Shirley Peters and Ethel Deutsch. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIRINSKY, RICHARD W. SR.
description: ZIRINSKY-Richard W. Sr. 86, died suddenly in South Hampton, Saturday, May 18. He was a lifelong resident of New York City, where for more than fifty years, he was a prominent and highly respected real estate owner, builder and developer. He was also a most beloved husband, father, brother and grandfather. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Cynthia Zirinsky, a daughter, Susan Zirinsky of New York City, and a son, Richard W. Zirinsky Jr. of Sag Harbor, NY. His daughter Barbara Faden predeceased him. He also has two grandchildren, Cynthia Deutsch and Zoe Peyronnin, both of New York City. One brother Daniel Zirinsky surives him. His brother Ralph Zirinsky and his sister Betty Zirinsky predeceased him. Richard Zirinsky was born on October 20, 1915, in Brooklyn, NY. He graduated from Syracuse University in 1938 with a degree in business administration. He was a member of the Sigma Alpha Mu Fraternity. In WWII he served in the United States Navy, rising to the rank of Lieutenant J.G. and served in the Pacific on the USS Edwards as a communications officer. Following the war he, his brothers and a cousin, the late Lawrence Zirinsky, invested and built numerous industrial real estate properties in Brooklyn and Long Island City. In 1959, Richard and Lawrence teamed up to build Gracie Square Hospital in New York City, one of the largest private psychiatric hospitals in the United States. He later became the sole owner and ran the hospital with his wife until 1992, when New York Hospital acquired it. Richard was also a Trustee of the New York Institute of Technology, Old Westbury, NY, where he played a major role in that school's exspansion and received an honorary doctoral degree. He served on the Board of the Kildonan School for Dyslexic Children and he was on the Board of the Parkinson Disease Foundation at New York's Prestyberian Hospital. Visitation will be Tuesday, May 21, from 7-9 PM, at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 81st St and Madison Ave, in New York City. The funeral service will take place at 11 AM, Wednesday, May 22, at Temple Emanu-El at 5th Avenue and 65th St, NY, NY. The burial will follow at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Donations in his name can be made to The Barbara Zirinsky Fund at Beth Israel Hospital, NY, NY 10003; or the Parkinson Disease Foundation, New York Presbyterian Hospital, NY, NY 10032.

title: Running Away
description: The 320-passenger Paul Gauguin, which sails Tahiti and nearby islands, is including round-trip economy air fare from 82 North American cities, including New York, on seven-night departures June 8 and 22. Ports of call include Raiatea, Tahaa, Bora-Bora and Moorea. Prices per person, based on double occupancy, start at $2,895. For more information: (866) 213-1272 or on the Web at www.rssc.com .

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Receive Antiterrorism Training In Israel
description: The New York Police Department has sent a team of investigators to Israel for training on how to detect suicide bombers and prevent them from carrying out attacks here. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that the department must be prepared for myriad terrorist threats, including suicide bombings like the one yesterday at an open-air market in Netanya, Israel. The training in Israel, first reoprted yesterday in The Daily News, is the latest effort by the police to prepare for terrorist attacks, and to seek to prevent them. Mr. Kelly announced recently that he would send 30 of his executive staff members to the Naval War College in Newport, R.I., to study mock disasters. Last month, he assigned investigators to work full time at F.B.I. headquarters in Washington. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: CAMDEN: DRUG RING ARRESTS The police say they have broken up a drug ring that controlled five of the city's most notorious open-air drug markets and netted nearly $600,000 a month selling heroin and cocaine. The Camden County prosecutor, Lee Solomon, said 10 people were arrested after a six-month undercover investigation by federal, state and local law enforcement agencies. Those arrested were being held in federal custody, and additional arrests were expected. Mr. Solomon said the ring distributed up to 10 kilograms of heroin and 6 kilograms of cocaine each month. The open-air markets operated in downtown Camden and in Vineland in Cumberland County. The authorities identified the Camden ringleader as Jose Fonseca, 44, who was charged with multiple counts of drug trafficking. (AP)

title: U.S. Attitudes Altered Little By Sept. 11, Pollsters Say
description: Authorities on public opinion meeting here this weekend expressed doubt that the attacks of Sept. 11 had led to fundamental changes in American attitudes.

title: Adelphia Is Said to Plan Disclosures of Dealings
description: Adelphia Communications, the beleaguered cable operator, plans to disclose the details of its dealings with the Rigas family, which controls the company, people briefed on the plan said yesterday. The disclosures are aimed at regaining the support of regulators and creditors in an effort to avoid being delisted by Nasdaq, a step that could lead to bankruptcy.

title: In Los Angeles, Return to Roots Loses Readers For Newspaper
description: In a poignant tale from ''The Martian Chronicles,'' Ray Bradbury's 1950 collection of science fiction loosely rooted in the history of Southern California, a Martian fulfills the wishes of humans it encounters by taking the form of someone they have lost. When the Martian stays with one couple, its skill is a virtue. Exposed to too many people, it remakes itself over and over, dying in an agony of multiple identities.

title: When Inspiration Stared Stoically From an Old Photograph
description: Thirty-five years ago, in suburban Los Angeles, my grandfather showed me a photograph he had taken in Alaska in 1915. It was a picture of a native woman smoking a pipe. He said her name was Six-Mile Mary, and she stood alone in a bleak landscape, somewhere outside the new town of Anchorage. There was no house behind her, no man or child beside her, no dog, no horse, no campsite, no tree.

title: Metro Matters; Portraits Of Trauma, Beyond 9/11
description: IN a corridor of a school on the edge of Chinatown, one wall is devoted to self-portraits sketched by fifth graders. Thirty of the 35 faces are pictures of profound sadness, of vacant eyes and downturned mouths.

title: A Nation Is Born
description: The country of East Timor, now just hours old, is a child of adversity, born of bloodshed and destruction. Independent for the first time in nearly 500 years, East Timor is small and vulnerable, one of the 20 poorest nations of the world, relying on the kindness of strangers who in the past have treated it roughly. Yet the midnight ceremony -- in which a United Nations transitional administration turned over power to the Timorese -- was a joyous and optimistic occasion. Indeed, there is reason to think that with concerted international help East Timor can succeed despite its many disadvantages.

title: Foreclosed property is auctioned off : Japanese rush in to housing bazaar
description: TOKYO  Japan's economy remains stalled in a deep recession and the piles of bad loans, emblem of the country's economic ills, see little sign of dwindling, as policymakers dither over a decision to drastically overhaul the nation's dysfunctional economy.

title: MediaTalk; Try This Obscure Book, Not That Best Seller
description: Like many little-known authors, Janis Jaquith often wishes that some of the people buying best sellers would pick up her book instead. Now the online retailer Amazon.com is giving her a chance to express those feelings.

description: A drug that blocks the flow of blood to tumors significantly slowed the worsening of cancer, scientists reported here today.

title: Kidd Was There for Nets
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  JASON KIDD was in New Jersey last night performing those same old humdrum-as-brushing-your-teeth miracles. It's like thinking it's impossible for one of those high-wire fliers in the Cirque du Soleil to complete that fourth somersault in midair and still be caught by another high flier, but he is snatched in the last moments, seemingly by the fingertips. Once again. Yawn.

title: What 'Friends' Has Going for It . . .; . . . That 'Ally McBeal' and 'The X-Files' Didn't Have
description: In the life of a long-running series there are a few unmistakable signs of desperation: a wedding, a baby's birth, a season-ending cliffhanger. But when Rachel gave birth to her and Ross's baby on the season finale of ''Friends'' Thursday, in an episode that ended with a cliffhanging marriage proposal, the series got the second-highest ratings in its history (beaten only by an episode that followed the Super Bowl). Heading into its ninth and most likely final season this fall, ''Friends'' has taken every clich from the ''very special episode'' handbook and through some alchemy of good writing and performing turned hackneyed ideas into funny, energetic, fresh shows.

title: Born of Hell, Lost After Inferno; Rodin Work From Trade Center Survived, and Vanished

Siemens in turn will get a stake of nearly 10 percent in Juniper. Unisphere, which is based in Westford, Mass., was started by Siemens in 1999 by combining three United States start-ups. Shares in Juniper ended the day down 31 cents, or 3.1 percent, to close at $9.54. Andrew Zipern (NYT)
