title: Rocking the Meadowlands
description: The New Jersey Nets basketball team started this season playing in a half-empty arena in the Meadowlands before fans who expected so little that they seemed hesitant to even cheer. The arena began to fill up as the Nets surged through the season. It was jam-packed and rocking this week when the team, in the Eastern Conference finals for the first time in its history, bulled its way past the Boston Celtics to take the first game of this series. The process that took the Nets from doormat to juggernaut offers lessons for the venerable but ailing New York Knicks, who failed to make the playoffs after a dismal season that sent basketball fans streaming across the Hudson River into New Jersey.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Stabbing Follows Abuse Report
description: A Jamaica woman stabbed her husband in the legs and back after her daughter said he had sexually abused her, the authorities said yesterday. The woman, Sharon Wheeler-Carter, 37, has been charged with second-degree assault while her husband, Wayne Carter, 49, faces sexual abuse charges, the police said. Mr. Carter was in stable condition yesterday at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center. On Sunday, Ms. Wheeler-Carter's daughter, 12, told her that Mr. Carter, her stepfather, abused her the day before, the police said. Ms. Wheeler-Carter then set upon her husband with a knife, they said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

For every ''Dennis Cleveland,'' the innovative television talk show opera by Mikel Rouse, there are five ''Great Gatsbys'': operas, that is, that follow the time-honored formula of constructing arias, ensembles and instrumental interludes around a conventional narrative and inflating the whole thing onto a suitably grand scale. Opera is an old-fashioned form, runs the conventional wisdom, and approaches to it remain, generally, old-fashioned.

The trades he described as ''not inherently bad things'' were speculative trades -- bets on the direction of prices in the future -- not wash trades.

title: In Baltimore
description: The hub of Baltimore's insurance and financial industries stands cheek by jowl with the engines of the city's other top commercial endeavor: tourism. The juxtaposition provides a near seamless transition between work and play (the headquarters of the Legg Mason investment firm are just a few blocks from Camden Yards). Yet it also gives much of downtown an air of amusement-park frivolity. Baltimore's compactness makes it easily navigable on foot or by short taxi rides.

title: F.B.I. Warns of Possible Threats to New York Landmarks
description: Law enforcement officials said today that they have received information about general threats that point to the possibility of future terrorist attacks in New York City - with landmarks like the Brooklyn Bridge and the Statue of Liberty among the potential targets.

title: Politics and a National Tragedy
description: To the Editor:

title: Tunnel Vision; A Subway Interrupted Awaits Its Imminent Resurgence
description: On Thursday of next week, a bugler will play taps and mourners will carry a stretcher, covered with a flag, from the depths of the pit at ground zero. With that, the recovery will officially end and the rebuilding of a large part of an impatient city will begin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIRINSKY, RICHARD W. SR.
description: ZIRINSKY-Richard W. Sr. 86, died suddenly in South Hampton, Saturday, May 18. He was a lifelong resident of New York City, where for more than fifty years, he was a prominent and highly respected real estate owner, builder and developer. He was also a most beloved husband, father, brother and grandfather. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Cynthia Zirinsky, a daughter, Susan Zirinsky of New York City, and a son, Richard W. Zirinsky Jr. of Sag Harbor, NY. His daughter Barbara Faden predeceased him. He also has two grandchildren, Cynthia Deutsch and Zoe Peyronnin, both of New York City. One brother Daniel Zirinsky surives him. His brother Ralph Zirinsky and his sister Betty Zirinsky predeceased him. Richard Zirinsky was born on October 20, 1915, in Brooklyn, NY. He graduated from Syracuse University in 1938 with a degree in business administration. He was a member of the Sigma Alpha Mu Fraternity. In WWII he served in the United States Navy, rising to the rank of Lieutenant J.G. and served in the Pacific on the USS Edwards as a communications officer. Following the war he, his brothers and a cousin, the late Lawrence Zirinsky, invested and built numerous industrial real estate properties in Brooklyn and Long Island City. In 1959, Richard and Lawrence teamed up to build Gracie Square Hospital in New York City, one of the largest private psychiatric hospitals in the United States. He later became the sole owner and ran the hospital with his wife until 1992, when New York Hospital acquired it. Richard was also a Trustee of the New York Institute of Technology, Old Westbury, NY, where he played a major role in that school's exspansion and received an honorary doctoral degree. He served on the Board of the Kildonan School for Dyslexic Children and he was on the Board of the Parkinson Disease Foundation at New York's Prestyberian Hospital. Visitation will be Tuesday, May 21, from 7-9 PM, at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 81st St and Madison Ave, in New York City. The funeral service will take place at 11 AM, Wednesday, May 22, at Temple Emanu-El at 5th Avenue and 65th St, NY, NY. The burial will follow at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Donations in his name can be made to The Barbara Zirinsky Fund at Beth Israel Hospital, NY, NY 10003; or the Parkinson Disease Foundation, New York Presbyterian Hospital, NY, NY 10032.

title: An Electricity Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Runner's High? Endorphins? Fiction, Some Scientists Say
description: Dr. Richard Friedman, a psychopharmacologist at Weill Medical College of Cornell University, had a runner's high -- once.

title: Divers Discover Maya Relics In Caves That Became Rivers
description: Nearly 100 feet beneath the Yucatn Peninsula in southern Mexico, cave divers are mapping the world's longest underground river. More important, they are unraveling the mysteries of a fragile ecosystem that may be destroyed before it is fully understood.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: New Penalties For Insurers
description: Insurance companies will face heavy penalties if they do not pay claims in 45 days, under a new state law. The legislation applies to so-called clean claims, cases where all necessary information has been submitted. A 12 percent interest rate will apply to delayed clean claims. Unjustified delays by insurers are also punishable by fines of up to $10,000. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Touring for a Cult Album 25 Years After Its First Release
description: Gary Wilson

title: In Albany, Bill Would Give School Control to Bloomberg
description: The Republican-led State Senate leapt into the increasingly tense debate over who should run New York City's schools, announcing it would vote as soon as today on a bill to grant Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg control of the system.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Laws on Sex Offender Lists to Get Further Look
description: The Supreme Court today substantially broadened its review of laws under which states keep the public informed of the whereabouts of convicted sex offenders who have been released from prison.

title: KMART SPENT UP TO $1 BILLION ON CLOSING OF STORES
description: The Kmart Corporation spent as much as $1.05 billion in the first quarter to prepare to close hundreds of stores, according to a regulatory filing. Kmart spent $600 million to $800 million in the quarter ended May 1 for the planned closing of 283 stores, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Kmart had an additional $250 million in expenses from discounting merchandise sold at going-out-of-business sales. Kmart, based in Troy, Mich., began closing stores on Sunday. The company, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in January, plans to close 13 percent of its 2,114 sites.

title: Forsberg Saves Roy and Game, for a Change
description: Patrick Roy was the winning goalie tonight, but the Colorado Avalanche beat the Detroit Red Wings because they survived his mistakes. They won by 4-3 to even the Western Conference finals at one victory each because Chris Drury scored in overtime and Peter Forsberg was the best player on the ice at Joe Louis Arena.

title: Walter Lord, Author of Historical Books, Including 'A Night to Remember,' Dies at 84
description: Walter Lord, the narrative historian whose books -- most notably ''A Night to Remember,'' a riveting account of the sinking of the Titanic -- were characterized by intensive research and exhaustive interviews, died on Sunday at his Manhattan apartment. He was 84.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOTT, HANSEN, PEGGY
description: SCOTT-HANSEN-Peggy, left us peacefully on May 18, 2002, at White Plains, NY. Widow of Oyvind Scott-Hansen, Ambassador of Norway, she will be remembered lovingly by her children, Andreas, Peter and Linda, her seven grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. Services will be private.

title: Scully and Mulder Reunited for the Truth, and a Kiss
description: The television series that turned paranoid distrust of the government into a pop phenomenon ended just when paranoia might seem like a smart response to current events. But with a platitudinous final episode that was more of a tease than a conclusion, ''The X-Files'' wrapped up looking more dutiful than relevant, an acknowledgment that the show's lucrative future lies in its past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLASKOW, JEROME
description: PLASKOW-Jerome. On May 19, 2002. Beloved husband of Elaine. Loving father of Judith and Harriet and grandfather of Alex. Services Wednesday, 2PM, at Sinai Chapel, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Flushing.

title: When a Business Trip Becomes a Family Affair
description: On a recent business trip to New York, Duncan Christy wandered through the South Street Seaport and spent an afternoon on Ellis Island. He even admitted to skipping down the city streets.

title: Sharon Ejects Party From Israeli Cabinet
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel fired ministers from the rigorously Orthodox Shas Party from his cabinet after they voted against an emergency economic package in Parliament.

title: A CONVERSATION WITH/Hugh Gusterson; Finding Rich Fodder In Nuclear Scientists
description: Say the word ''anthropologist'' and images of Margaret Mead in Samoa or Bronislaw Malinowski among the Trobriand Islanders may spring to mind. But for Dr. Hugh Gusterson, 43, a professor of anthropology at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the intensive scrutiny of scientific investigation is applied not to island natives but to mostly affluent white men with ''Ph.D.'' affixed to their names.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Broadcaster Declines Share Buyback
description: The British satellite-television company, British Sky Broadcasting Group, controlled by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, said that its attempt to exercise a put option, which would force the insolvent KirchpayTV to buy back BSkyB's 22 percent stake for $1.5 billion was rejected. Various parts of the Kirch empire including KirchMedia and KirchpayTV have filed for bankruptcy protection. Kirch said the conditions requiring it to accept an early use of the put option had not been met. Desmond Butler (NYT)

title: New Jellyfish Problem Means Jellyfish Are Not the Only Problem
description: When Robert King climbed back on the boat after snorkeling off the Great Barrier Reef here on March 31, he knew something was wrong. ''I don't feel so good,'' he said, rubbing his chest.

title: Man and Craft Were One, As a New Age Began
description: A man seized by a memory of the boy who built model airplanes, the dreamy whiff of glue and banana oil lingering in imagination, casts an appraising eye over the well-made fuselage and wing. With more ambition and a bigger X-acto knife -- also something sturdier than balsa wood -- he just might have constructed the airplane he sees hanging from the ceiling of the National Air and Space Museum in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BROWNSTEIN, NOAH J.
description: BROWNSTEIN-Noah J. 5/21/52 to 8/1/92. Happy 50th Birthday, Our Guardian Angel. We'll celebrate by kissing and talking to all of your pictures. Hugs and kisses, Mom and Dad

title: MAKER OF HEFTY BAGS AGREES TO BUY PACKAGING COMPANY
description: The Pactiv Corporation, the maker of Hefty plastic freezer bags, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Winkler Forming for about $72.5 million to expand its wholesale bakery, confectionery and fresh-produce packaging business. Winkler, which is closely held, has manufacturing plants in Santa Fe Springs, Calif., and Bridgeview, Ill., Pactiv said. Winkler had about $50 million in sales in the last 12 months. Pactiv is based in Lake Forest, Ill.

title: Woods Beats Montgomerie In a Playoff
description: Tiger Woods defeated Colin Montgomerie of Scotland in a three-hole playoff today to win the European PGA Tour's Deutsche Bank-SAP Open at the St. Leon-Rot Course.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPAISMAN, ZYPORA
description: SPAISMAN-Zypora. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Spaisman, and loving mother of Ben A. Spaisman and daughter-in-law Sally A. Spaisman and devoted grandmother of Erica and Elliot Spaisman. Born in Lublin, Poland, she came to this country as WW II refugee having spent time in Russia during the war, and in Poland, France, and Canada thereafter. Award winning actress and star of the Yiddish Theater for over 40 years, was an active patron and supporter of Yiddish culture her entire life. The services will be help on Wednesday May 22nd 12 noon at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., New York, NY.

title: More Acidic Than Vinegar, River Teems With Tiny Life
description: Biological diversity is normally associated with pristine tropical rain forests or coral reefs, not rivers laden with heavy metals and so acidic they bear a pH of 2, halfway between vinegar and stomach acid.

title: H.I.V. Patients Try to Remedy Gaunt Appearance
description: Like many people taking drugs to combat H.I.V., Steven Hodges, a former hairdresser here, noticed a few years ago that he was becoming gaunt and hollow-cheeked even though he still felt healthy.

title: Sweet Satisfaction in the Songs of the Wild
description: This is the season when the natural world explodes with song as birds return from wintering areas ready for another breeding season, singing profusely at dawn and dusk.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Gazprom Endorses Auditor
description: Gazprom's board recommended PricewaterhouseCoopers continue as auditor, ignoring shareholder criticism that the accounting firm failed to reveal billions of dollars of losses at Gazprom, the world's largest gas producer. Shareholders vote on the board's recommendation June 28. Gazprom's minority shareholders have said Pricewaterhouse failed to reveal financial damage incurred by the company during transfers of Gazprom's assets to Itera Holding, a Russian gas company. In another move, Gazprom's chairman, Rem Vyakhirev, above, who was fired as chief executive a year ago, will resign from the board, the company said.

title: Camby Cleared to Work Out
description: After their hopes of obtaining their center of the future, Yao Ming, were all but dashed at Sunday's National Basketball Association draft lottery, the Knicks received good news yesterday concerning their center of the present, Marcus Camby: he is back to full health.

title: MEMO PAD
description: No Ticket Needed For Airport Clubs

title: Superheroes for Adults
description: To the Editor:

title: On Guard Against Allergens
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Maui And Kauai Poverty Increases
description: Poverty increased nearly 70 percent on Maui and Kauai, 2000 Census figures show. That made the two counties on the two islands the hardest hit in the state, with 10.5 percent of their residents officially poor. Statewide, poverty increased 43 percent, with 10.7 percent of the total population, or 126,154 people, in poverty. Michele Kayal (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENWASSER, ROBERT
description: ROSENWASSER - Robert. Our deepest condolences to the family of Robert Rosenwasser for their immeasurable loss. He will be greatly missed by those who had the privilege of knowing this fine human being. Costas, Kondylis & Partners

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: MICHIGAN: NEW PENALTIES FOR INSURERS Insurance companies will face heavy penalties if they do not pay claims in 45 days, under a new state law. The legislation applies to so-called clean claims, cases where all necessary information has been submitted. A 12 percent interest rate will apply to delayed clean claims. Unjustified delays by insurers are also punishable by fines of up to $10,000. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Tensions Mount Over Kashmir as Separatist Leader Is Killed
description: NEW DELHI, May 21  Abdul Ghani Lone, a moderate Kashmiri separatist leader, was assassinated today in the city of Srinagar, a killing that the governments of India and Pakistan immediately charged each other with, bringing the already tense region a few steps closer to war.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I see people are still buying cars, still making home improvements. Things can't be that bad if so many people are driving these big, fancy S.U.V.'s.''

title: Following God Abroad
description: Guess what was on the recent cover of the magazine published by Campus Crusade for Christ.

title: Politics and a National Tragedy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASTORELLE, DOMINIC JOSEPH JR., M.D.
description: PASTORELLE-Dominic Joseph Jr., M.D., of Mystic, and North Hutchinson Island, FL. formerly of White Plains, NY, died Sunday, May 19, at the Groton Regency after a courageous battle with a brain tumor. He was born in White Plains, NY, son of Dominic and Marguerite Xavier Pastorelle. Dr. Pastorelle was a three year graduate of Fordham University and received his medical degree from New York University College of Medicine. He completed his internship and surgical residency at Bellevue Hospital and New York University Hospital in New York City. He was an instructor in surgery at NYU and attending surgeon at NYU Hospital and St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains, NY. From 1959 to 1981 Dr. Pastorelle maintained a surgical practice in White Plains, NY. From 1981 to 1988 he was on active duty with the Navy, serving as Director of Surgical Services at the Submarine Base Hospital in Groton. He was a Diplomate of the American Board of Surgery and a member of numerous professional organizations. He is survived by his wife, the former Vicki Tonna; one daughter, Veronica LaVista of Flemington, NJ; two sons, D.J. ''Dee'' Pastorelle of White Plains, NY, John Pastorelle of South Glastonbury, CT; three brothers, Francis Pastorelle of Homewood, IL, Peter J. Pastorelle of Mt. Kisco, NY, H. John Pastorelle of White Plains, NY; and eight grandchildren. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Thursday, May 23, at 10:30 AM at St. Patrick Church in Mystic, followed by military honors in the Church garden. Burial will be private. Relatives and friends may call at the Mystic Funeral Home, Route 1, Mystic, on Wednesday, 5-8 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, 501 St. Jude Place, Memphis, TN 38105-1905.

title: Metromedia Fiber Files for Bankruptcy
description: Metromedia Fiber Network Inc., a telecommunications company backed by the billionaire investor John W. Kluge, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday after failing to win enough customers for its ambitious plan to sell fast Internet service in urban areas.

title: Chamber Players Who Leap Among Periods and Styles
description: The Elastic Band is a group of freelance chamber players who have joined forces for programs that cross freely among periods and styles that are usually regarded as incompatible. For its performance at Merkin Concert Hall last Tuesday afternoon, for example, the band began with a group of works by Gesualdo, the eccentric Renaissance madrigal composer, and made their way to Mahler (both Gustav and Alma) and Kurt Weill. By any historical or stylistic measure that's a vast distance, and it's a difficult voyage to make with any coherence. Not surprisingly, parts of the program worked better than others.

title: Politics and a National Tragedy
description: To the Editor:

title: Investors Start to Take New Look at Vivendi
description: Investors who have stuck with Vivendi Universal, the water utility turned media conglomerate, say they like each of its businesses, even if they feel uncomfortable with the ability of its embattled chief executive, Jean-Marie Messier, to weld them into a solid, consistently profitable whole.

title: Man Held in a Charity Fraud
description: A Queens man was arrested yesterday and charged with defrauding scores of New York businesses and individuals of more than $400,000 by soliciting donations for a charity that he said benefited the families of slain police officers, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GASPARINETTI, LUIGI
description: GASPARINETTI-Luigi. The Board of Trustees and staff of WLIW21 mourn the untimely passing of our esteemed Board Member, Luigi Gasparinetti on May 16, 2002. Luigi was a dedicated member of our Board and a generous contributor of both time and money in support of our mission of bringing the finest quality public television to our audience. His vision, energy and commitment will be sorely missed. Our sincere condolences to his family.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sinkhole Spurs Street Closing
description: Riverside Drive is expected to be closed in both directions between 135th Street and 145th Street for the next three or four days, after a 4-foot-by-4-foot sinkhole opened up in the drive near 142nd Street, the police said. The sinkhole opened into a 20-foot-wide hole beneath the street level. The City Department of Environmental Protection was on the scene of the collapse, which occurred around 6:15 p.m. yesterday.

title: A Closer Look at Soy and Babies
description: A new study raises the possibility that soy-based infant formulas, which account for one-fourth of all the formula used in the United States, may weaken babies' immune systems.

title: A Reminder That AIDS Still Causes Remorse
description: In ''A Letter From Ethel Kennedy,'' the semi-insider jokes get the laughs. There are references to Kevin Spacey, Elaine Stritch, Wendy Wasserstein, Jerome Robbins and ''All About Eve.'' (How, one character wonders, do you talk to a person who has seen it only once?) The humor is fairly contemporary; the situation isn't.

title: Front Row
description: Yesterday marked the end of a three-day event in the eastern stretches of Chelsea -- one known to about the same number of New Yorkers as those who have never experienced an extended wait for a subway. The event, a trade show called Visual New York, occurs twice a year, in May and December. It draws window dressers from around the country to the showrooms of mannequin makers who are promoting new models of their Space Needle-tall fiberglass and resin mock beings.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Incentive To Submit Rape Kits
description: The state will pay police departments $100 for each rape evidence kit forwarded from evidence rooms to a laboratory for testing in cases where there is no suspect. The Cleveland department, the first to participate, has 650 kits stored in its evidence room. Rape kits, which often have semen and other forensic evidence, can sit idle for years until the police find suspects. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: PRESCRIPTION MANAGER RAISES PROFIT FORECAST FOR YEAR
description: The MIM Corporation, which manages prescription drug benefits for insurance companies and health care providers, yesterday raised its profit forecast for this year, citing a better tax rate and improvements in operations. MIM said it expected profit of 90 cents a share, up from an earlier estimate of 86 cents before a 3-cent gain reported in the first quarter. The company, which is based in Elmsford, N.Y., said it expected sales of $620 million this year, a 36 percent increase from $456.7 million in 2001. MIM's stock rose $2.58, or 26 percent, to $12.46 a share.

title: Once-Invisible Sperm Donors Get to Meet the Family
description: In the early 80's, Bob, who was a student at the time, decided to donate sperm to a sperm bank. He needed the money, but he also thought it would be nice to help a couple who wanted a child but could not conceive. He signed a waiver and was promised anonymity. He assumed that was that.

title: Sharon Ejects Orthodox Party, Cutting Coalition's Edge
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon fired ministers from the rigorously Orthodox Shas Party from his cabinet tonight after they voted against an emergency economic package in Parliament. Mr. Sharon's action significantly narrowed his government's political base and raised the possibility of early elections.

title: EMBARGO REMAINS UNTIL CUBA ALTERS POLICY, BUSH SAYS
description: President Bush, in a speech harshly critical of Fidel Castro, said today that he would not lift a trade embargo against Cuba without substantial movement toward democracy there.

title: QUANTA SERVICES AND AQUILA SETTLE PROXY FIGHT
description: Quanta Services, which installs power and telephone lines, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement that would end a hostile bid by Aquila, the energy trader that is its largest shareholder, to control Quanta's board. Under the deal, Aquila will end its proxy contest for control of the board and will withdraw all litigation and arbitration, Quanta said. Aquila also agreed not to buy Quanta's shares on the open market or begin another fight for control of the board. Aquila, which is based in Kansas City, will have three seats on Quanta's 10-member board and can designate one of four independent directors, Quanta said. As part of the settlement, Quanta will reinstate its stock-repurchase program.

title: Trenton Tries to Avert Layoffs With Early-Retirement Bill
description: With Gov. James E. McGreevey warning that New Jersey may be forced to lay off thousands of state workers, the General Assembly today overwhelmingly passed an early retirement plan that the governor said was necessary to avert the layoffs.

title: 4th Guilty Plea In Sewer Deals In New Jersey
description: Stretching nearly the length of the the state, a corruption investigation involving municipal sewer contracts led to its fourth guilty plea today, by Camden's former public utilities director.

title: Hotel Discount in Manhattan
description: The Mark, a hotel on 25 East 77th Street in Manhattan, is offering special rates of $349 a night Sunday to Thursday and $339 Friday and Saturday until Sept. 30. These prices, good for two people, include daily breakfast and a late check-out. Taxes and service charges are extra and the rates are subject to availability. For reservations: (800) 223-1588 or www.mandarinoriental.com .

title: The Big City; Boss Tweed Would Agree: Unload It
description: THE Tweed Courthouse has become a white elephant for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, but there's a graceful way for him to unload it. Put it on the market.

title: Trying to Add Light to the Heat on Indian Point
description: THERE are times, Sandy Galef tells her constituents, when ''one issue overrides all others,'' and since Sept. 11, the Indian Point nuclear power complex is that issue in the 90th Assembly District in the northwest corner of Westchester County.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nissan Posts a Profit
description: Helped by cost-cutting and the weakness of Japan's currency, the Nissan Motor Company earned 372 billion yen ($2.95 billion) in the year that ended March 31. The automaker, which was near bankruptcy in 1998, has also cut its debt sharply and increased its operating margins. The company, which is 44.4 percent owned by Renault S.A., expects its profit to rise another 2.2 percent this year and sales to increase 4.9 percent. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Chrysler Warns About Sales in Canada
description: The Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler has started notifying dealers that it will stop honoring warranties for the 2003 model year on new cars and trucks bought in Canada for use in the United States because the sales reduce the automaker's profit.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a passage was misplaced on Sunday in an article in the City section about a reunion of people who grew up in Vinegar Hill, Brooklyn. A correct version may be read online at nytimes.com/thecity. It may also be requested from Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; telephone (212) 556-1992. E-mail: quality@nytimes.com. (Include a postal address.)

title: Villagers Flee As Fighting In Kashmir Is Unabated
description: Intense Indian-Pakistani artillery barrages persisted today for the fourth day, sending thousands of villagers in Kashmir fleeing for safety as fears of even fiercer fighting deepened.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Airline Posts Loss
description: British Airways posted a pretax loss in the fourth quarter of 2001 of 85 million ($124 million), compared with a loss of 65 million a year earlier. For all of 2001, the company lost 200 million before taxes, compared with a 150 million pretax loss in 2000. British Airways has been struggling to reposition itself, a process made more difficult after Sept. 11. Passenger capacity for the year declined 12.4 percent, the company said. Rod Eddington, the chief executive of British Airways, has recently come under criticism for some of his strategy, for instance, his decision last year to sell Go Fly, a budget airline to the venture capital firm 3i. 3i recently sold Go Fly to EasyJet for $545 million. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, HARRIS WOLF
description: DAVIS-Harris Wolf. May 17, 2002. Beloved husband of Judith Davis; dear father of Shari Davis; our dear brother, brother-in-law, uncle and friend. Mr. Davis was part of the New York City Opera for 39 years and was on the Board of Governors of the American Guild of Musical Artists (AGMA) for 36 years. Mr. Davis was the President of the Baltic-Butler Block Association and he was an elected official for the Liberal Party of Assemblymen in 2001. Mr. Davis was very active as a volunteer in the community and in the music world, and was also an avid NY Yankees fan. Graveside service Tuesday, May 21, at 12 noon, at B'nai Amoona Cemetery, 930 North and South Rd., St. Louis, MO. Memorial contributions preferred to AGMA Relief Fund, 1430 Broadway, 14th floor, NYC 10018.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDIS, MORRIS B.
description: LANDIS-Morris B. Of Highland Park, NJ and Aventura, FL. Beloved husband of Raye nee Rosenbaum. Devoted father of Mark, Alan, Diana, Ilene, Mitchell and Tefera. Father-in-law of Carolyn, Linda, Jeffrey and Linda Jean. Dear brother of Alex and Sam. Loving grandfather of 12 grandchildren and 2 great-grandchildren. Dad, Grandpa, Meish, Uncle Morris, ''The Producer''. Always a trendsetter, with a healthy diet and exercise, always years ahead of his time, the eternal overflowing optimist. Now at his passing, years ahead of his time. We will all miss our greatest cheerleader and supporter. We hope throughout our lives and those of future generations that Dad's very special being will live on. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Central New Jersey Jewish Home for the Aged, 732-873-2000 or to the Israel Emergency Fund of the UJA Federation, 212-980-1000. Services were held. For information ''Wein & Wein'', 800-322-0533.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Aiming For The Moon
description: China aims to put a man in orbit by 2005 and then place astronauts on the moon by 2010, according to a report in the official China Daily that included the most precise target dates yet for the country's ambitious space program. Twelve astronauts are in intensive training, the report said. ''China is expected to complete its first exploration of the moon in 2010 and we will establish a base on the moon as we did in the South Pole and the North Pole,'' said Ouyang Ziyuan, chief scientist in the moon program. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: Wines of the Week
description: Summer is right around the corner so now is the time to stock up on affordable warm-weather wines.

title: Yes, It's Arafat's Fault
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALSTEAD, CAROL P.
description: HALSTEAD-Carol P., 60. On May 18, 2002, at home in Manhattan with daughters Heather and Hilary and husband Clark at her bedside. Beloved by her family and many friends for her unfailingly brilliant energy and love that touched the hearts of all who were privileged to know her. She was an adventurer, an educator, a mentor, an entrepreneur, and advisor to college presidents, a soulmate, a mother, and much more. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Carol's special passion, Reach the World (www.reachtheworld.org), a nonprofit educational foundation founded by her daughter, Heather, or the Carcinoid Cancer Foundation (www.carcinoid.org). A memorial service will be held at All Souls Church, Lexington Avenue and 80th Street, on June 18th at 11:00 AM.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: State Takes Over Three Banks
description: Fearing an aggravation of the country's financial crisis, the Central Bank has ordered the state-owned Banco de la Nacin to assume control of three small provincial banks temporarily after their French owner decided to abandon them. Having already written off its investment after a loss of more than $300 million, Crdit Agricole, the largest bank in France, said that it would suspend operations rather than inject additional capital into the three, Banco Bisel, Banco de Entre Rios and Banco Suquia, to comply with Argentine government deposit requirements. A government spokesman said the government hoped to sell the banks, which play an important role in financing Argentine exports of grains to private investors, but acknowledged that there were no immediate candidates. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Harry L. Sears, 82, Politician And Courier for Vesco Cash
description: Harry L. Sears, a lawyer and New Jersey Republican legislative leader who delivered a briefcase holding $200,000 in $50 and $100 bills from the financier Robert Vesco to President Richard M. Nixon's re-election campaign in 1972, died on Friday in Denville, N.J. He was 82 and lived in Mount Arlington, N.J.

title: Merrill Lynch to Pay $100 Million to Settle Analyst Charges
description: Merrill Lynch & Company will pay a $100 million civil penalty under a wide-ranging agreement settling charges that the company misled investors with "tainted" stock research, the New York State attorney general's office said today.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: JUNIPER TO BUY SIEMENS UNIT Juniper Networks Inc. , the No. 2 maker of equipment that directs Internet traffic, said yesterday that it would buy the Unisphere Networks Inc. unit of Siemens A.G. for about $740 million in cash and stock. Siemens in turn will get a stake of nearly 10 percent in Juniper. Unisphere, which is based in Westford, Mass., was started by Siemens in 1999 by combining three United States start-ups. Shares in Juniper ended the day down 31 cents, or 3.1 percent, to close at $9.54.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Profit For Suzuki
description: Japan's largest maker of compact cars, the Suzuki Motor Corporation, said its profit rose 10.6 percent, to 22.4 billion yen ($178 million) last fiscal year, helped by lower costs and rising productivity. The company said sales rose 4.2 percent, aided by strong demand for its motorcycles. Suzuki expects its profit to increase 34 percent in the fiscal year that began on April 1. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Forecast For 6 To 8 Hurricanes
description: The Atlantic hurricane season this year is quite likely to produce 9 to 13 named tropical storms, with 6 to 8 developing into hurricanes, federal weather forecasters said. That would make the season, which runs from June 1 to Nov. 30, average or slightly above average, said meteorologists at the National Hurricane Center in Miami. American shores have not been hit by a hurricane since 1999. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: In Folding Proteins, Clues to Many Diseases
description: Consider the consequences of a garbage strike. Trash accumulates, streets are clogged and daily life is disrupted. Eventually, things can come to a standstill.

title: City Board Recommends Rent Increases Of 2% and 4%
description: The New York City Rent Guidelines Board, rejecting calls for the first rent rollback on rent-stabilized apartments, last night recommended increases of 2 percent on one-year leases and 4 percent on two-year leases.

title: INSIDE
description: Arafat's Leadership Tested

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: Officials Drop 4 Abuse Charges
description: Four of seven felony charges were dropped as jury selection began in the child abuse trial of a school administrator who forced students to stand in manure pits as punishment. Prosecutors did not explain why they were reducing the counts in the case against the administrator, Charles Robert Patchin. Mr. Patchin is accused of having ''knowingly inflicted cruel and inhuman punishment'' on three children last year at the Heartland Christian Academy in northeastern Missouri. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Help the Philippines
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, MIRIAM SILVERSTEIN
description: SOLOMON-Miriam Silverstein. Age 86. Died at home on May 20, 2002. Wife of the late Dr. Nathaniel Solomon. Survived by a sister Charlotte Levy, daughter Shelah Hardy and three grandchildren. Services at Schwartz Bros., 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills Wednesday, May 22nd, 12:30PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERRY, IRENE KLOSK
description: PERRY-Irene Klosk. May 19 after 96 years of unending selfless devotion to her family. Constant friend and wife of Allan for their 63 years until his death. Her indomitable spirit was a paradigm for all who knew her. Mother of Lynn, Jane, and Andrew. Grandmother of Stacy, Jennifer, Ross, Caroline, Alexander. Great-grandmother of Evan. Services Private.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hamilton: Colgate Names President
description: Colgate University named Rebecca S. Chopp, the dean of the Yale University Divinity School, as its next president yesterday. She will take office on July 1. Dr. Chopp, left, whose specialty is religion and American culture, earned a bachelor's degree at Kansas Wesleyan University, a master's degree in divinity from St. Paul School of Theology and a Ph.D. from the University of Chicago Divinity School. She was provost and executive vice president for academic affairs at Emory University before moving to Yale. Colgate's former president, Charles H. Karelis, resigned in June 2001 after less than two years in the post. Jane L. Pinchin, Colgate's provost and dean of the faculty, has served as interim president. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: CROWDED FIELD FOR PARLIAMENT RACE The Interior Ministry said 8,633 people declared their candidacy in elections for 577 seats in the National Assembly by the midnight Sunday deadline, one-third more than in the last legislative elections five years ago. Two rounds of voting, on June 9 and 16, will determine the shape of the next government, and the record number of candidates could erode support for a majority behind President Jacques Chirac, who was re-elected this month in a landslide over the far-right leader Jean-Marie Le Pen. Mr. Le Pen's movement, the National Front, is running candidates for at least 563 seats, threatening to siphon support from Mr. Chirac's conservative Rally for the Republic party. The Socialists, too, face uncertainty from two Trotskyite splinter parties.

title: Bell Labs Forms Panel to Study Claims of Research Misconduct
description: Responding to accusations of scientific misconduct, Lucent Technologies' Bell Laboratories has formed a panel to examine the validity of some recent impressive experiments, including a claim last fall that it created a transistor in which the electronic switch consists of a single molecule.

title: No Gains From a Clean Home
description: Researchers in Britain say they have found no evidence that cleaning, even heavy housework, causes women between the ages 60 and 79 to lose weight.

title: Chefs Joining Boycott in Effort to Save Imperiled Sea Bass
description: On the menu it is called Chilean sea bass, and it is prized for its mild flavor and firm, milk-white flesh. In the Antarctic waters where it swims, its name is Patagonian toothfish. It has a natural antifreeze in its blood, and it can live 50 years and grow to the size of a linebacker.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Dousing Beach Barbecues
description: Barbecue parties on the beach in some parts of Southern California will be a bit darker and chillier this summer. Because of tight budgets in Orange County, more than 800 fire pits will be closed on state beaches after the Fourth of July. With a 15 percent to 20 percent reduction in the number of lifeguards at the beaches, the authorities said, it will be impossible to keep the pits safe by removing hot coals and items like nails and coat hangers. Concerns about air pollution also played a role in the decision to close the pits. Just a handful of the city beaches in Orange County will be openin gup their pits. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: Guides to Help Revive The Sexually Inactive
description: ''Getting the Sex You Want: A Woman's Guide to Becoming Proud, Passionate and Pleased in Bed,'' by Dr. Sandra Leiblum and Judith Sachs, Crown, $23.95.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Boy Charged With Sex Assault
description: A 14-year-old boy was arrested yesterday afternoon on charges that he forced a female classmate into a stairwell in a school in Corona and made her perform a sex act on him, the authorities said. He has been charged with first-degree sodomy and endangering the welfare of a minor. The girl, 12, told investigators yesterday that the boy had forced her into a stairwell at Intermediate School 61, 98-50 50th Avenue, around 1:30 p.m. Friday, the police said. A spokesman for the city's Board of Education, Kevin B. Ortiz, said school officials were investigating the allegations against the boy and would decide today what disciplinary action to take. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: 2 Say Skakel Told of Being At Crime Scene
description: Two witnesses testified today that Michael C. Skakel who is on trial charged with murder -- admitted in separate conversations in 1987 and 1991 that he was in a tree on the Moxley property on the night of Oct. 30, 1975, putting him at the scene where his friend Martha Moxley was bludgeoned to death.

title: Corrections
description: A music listing in Arts & Leisure on Sunday for the Young Concert Artists Irene Diamond Concert tomorrow night misstated the location. It is Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center, not the 92nd Street Y.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: New Foot-And-Mouth Cases
description: The Agriculture Ministry began slaughtering another 13,000 pigs after finding four new cases of foot-and-mouth disease on farms about 60 miles south of Seoul. The government has assigned an extra 2,500 quarantine officers, soldiers and police officers to try to contain the disease before the opening of the World Cup soccer tournament in Seoul on May 31. The disease does not threaten people, but they are able to carry it on their clothing. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITKIN, RADOVIC, DR.
description: WITKIN-RADOVIC-Dr. Mildred Hope Fisher. Deep condolences honoring my lifelong and devoted friend Dr. Mildred Hope Fisher Witkin-Radovic for her loving friendship enduring for over half a century since our college Freshman years. Dr. Sylvia Herz, Hollywood, Fla

title: Alexopoulos Bows Out With Two Balanchine Works
description: Blessed with a natural glamour that fills the stage, Helene Alexopoulos's dancing in the New York City Ballet has been a study in contrasts. At her most subdued, she radiates a compelling sense of mystery. At her most dramatic, she moves boldly, even brazenly, exuding passion with either humor or sensuality.

title: Flushing Out a Hidden Ailment
description: Thousands of people could be steered toward treatment for depression if their regular doctors took a few moments to ask them two simple questions, a study reported yesterday.

title: Executive Leaves Retirement to Help Ford
description: The Ford Motor Company announced today a management shuffle that included bringing back a retired executive to reprise his role as chief financial officer.

title: Politics and a National Tragedy
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets' Jefferson: Cool, Cocky And Confident
description: To Richard Jefferson, his soaring alley-oop dunk Sunday night rattled the backboard but did not shake his world. His baseline reverse jam over Boston's Paul Pierce and Antoine Walker seemed like child's play to him.

title: Cast Adrift After Siege, Bethlehem Exiles Grieve
description: The Palestinian fighters arrived here from Bethlehem to cheering crowds, hot meals and bursts of celebratory gunfire.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Finland: Forklift Maker Rejects Bid
description: Partek Oyj, a Finnish maker of forklifts, rejected a 750 million euro ($691 million) bid from Kone Oyj, the world's biggest escalator company. Partek said that it was in talks with KCI Konecranes, a crane manufacturer, which was spun off from Kone in 1993. Kone, which said it would not increase its bid, has offered to buy the Finnish government's 30 percent stake in Partek. Finland is said to support the deal. Desmond Butler (NYT)

title: Tough Policies on Priests Prompt Some Dissension in the Pews
description: American Catholic bishops are scheduled to gather here next month to debate a tough new policy on sexual abuse, but many dioceses around the nation have already carried out what amount to zero-tolerance rules, swiftly removing accused priests and dealing harshly with clergy members who fail to adopt guidelines on preventing abuse.

title: Big Shareholder Mounts Attack On Energy Industry Accounting
description: In a further sign of the tensions roiling the energy industry, one of the largest shareholders of the El Paso Corporation attacked the company at its annual meeting today, calling for it to overhaul its accounting practices and change the way it does business.

title: Donkeys and Elephants Inject Politics Into Art
description: When the District of Columbia last month displayed an arts project with dozens of sculptures of donkeys and elephants to be exhibited throughout the city, it was meant to be a whimsical and trouble-free civic venture.

title: Met Bullpen Finds Way To Get the Job Done
description: John Franco has accompanied the Mets for all but one day this season: last Wednesday, when he had a 110-minute operation to replace the torn ligament and reattach the flexor tendon in his left elbow. A still-groggy Franco joined the team the next day in San Diego and has attended every game since.

title: Harvick Drives Nascar Crazy Like No One Else
description: More than a year has passed since Kevin Harvick showed up on the Nascar Winston Cup scene and became the sport's new boy wonder.

title: Mending Of Hearts And Minds
description: A fellow psychiatrist once told me an anecdote I have never forgotten. He was at a conference about depression in developing countries. The essence of the lectures was that people in those areas commonly expressed depression as physical symptoms. They ''somaticize'' their depression, to use the medical parlance, complaining of malaise, stomachaches, dizziness and other symptoms that are hard to pin down.

title: U.S. Defends the Withholding Of Jailed Immigrants' Names
description: Justice Department lawyers, defending the federal government's refusal to identify the 1,200 foreign Muslims arrested after Sept. 11, said today that public disclosure would undermine counterterrorism efforts and put the detainees at risk of attack from angry Americans as well as terrorists.

title: Online Travel Booking Site Files for Public Stock Sale
description: Orbitz Inc., the Internet travel booking site owned by the country's five largest airlines, filed for an initial stock offering yesterday that is intended to raise $125 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEPPER, SUSAN ELLEN
description: TEPPER-Susan Ellen, 58, on May 15, 2002. Daughter of Allen and Pauline Shatsky. Mother of Daniel Tepper and grandmother of James Tepper.

title: No Talk of Total Control From Scott or His Team
description: Nets Coach Byron Scott was not about to repeat his bold claim from the Charlotte series that a victory in Game 2 would be akin to ''total control.''

title: Twellman Not Surprised By His Resurgence in U.S.
description: When it acquired MAMADOU DIALLO and ALEX PINEDA CHACON in Major League Soccer's dispersal draft, the New England Revolution thought it was receiving a quick infusion of offense. Think again.

title: Selection Of Consultant In Rebuilding Is Questioned
description: A committee working on the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan and the World Trade Center site has recommended that a prominent architectural firm, Beyer Blinder Belle, be selected as the urban planning consultant to work with state and city officials on the redevelopment, officials involved in the planning process said yesterday.

title: Death of a Paleontologist
description: Perhaps the only person who was really prepared for Stephen Jay Gould's death was Mr. Gould himself. Twenty years ago the scientist, who died yesterday at the age of 60, had a life-threatening bout of cancer. Many readers will remember the way he wrote about that episode, not only for its personal candor but also for the fact that he found comfort in a statistical analysis of his chances of survival. It was wholly in keeping with the tenor of Mr. Gould's character that he could turn an understanding of statistics into a toehold on life itself. It was also in keeping that he chose to write about it for a popular audience.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Advent Financial Chief Will Retire
description: Advent Software, which makes investment-tracking software used by firms like Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said Irv Lichtenwald, the chief financial officer, would retire at the end of August. The shares fell as much as 12 percent. Mr. Lichtenwald, 46, said he wanted to spend more time focusing on his properties in San Francisco and his 75-acre farm. Shares fell $4.21, or 8.2 percent, to $46.79 yesterday. Earlier, they fell as low as $44.65. Yesterday's drop is the biggest percentage decline since September. Advent, which is based in San Francisco, competes with companies like SunGard Data Systems Inc. and the Thomson Corporation. It has started searching for a replacement, Mr. Lichtenwald said.

title: Prosecutors Cite Lawyer's Notes About Andersen Papers
description: Federal prosecutors used a series of e-mail messages and a lawyer's notes today to bolster their case that employees at Arthur Andersen shredded documents related to Enron out of fear of a government investigation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAY, THOMAS J., JR.
description: FAY-Thomas J., Jr. On May 20, 2002. Formerly of The Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Beloved husband of the late Catherine M. Fay (nee Ridge). Loving father of Margaret M., Thomas J. III, and Catherine A. Fay. Devoted grandfather of Patrick, Timothy, Brian, and Brendan Fay. Also survived by daughter-in-law, Bernadette Darcy, and several nieces and nephews. Visitation Tuesday 7-9 P.M. and Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. at Joseph G. Duffy Funeral Home, 255 Ninth St, Brooklyn. Mass of Resurrection Thursday at Saint Francis Xavier R.C. Church.

title: Peter F. Cannell, 47, Publishing Director
description: Peter F. Cannell, a former director of the Smithsonian Institution's book-publishing division and an expert on songbirds' voices, died on Saturday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 47.

title: Enemies Of Reform
description: ''I would suggest to you that the single most important innovation shaping [America's] capital market was the idea of generally accepted accounting principles.'' So declared Lawrence Summers, then deputy secretary of the Treasury, in a 1998 speech. Mr. Summers urged troubled Asian economies, then in the middle of a disastrous financial crisis, to emulate American-style ''transparency and disclosure.''

title: Honing the Air Marshal Arts: Fire '2 to the Chest, 1 Upstairs'
description: EGG HARBOR, N.J., May 16  "I want another drink," complained the impatient man in an aisle seat in the fourth row of the wide-bodied jet's first-class cabin, addressing a flight attendant.

title: Quandary on Trade
description: How should the United States set its tariffs and trade rules, globally or country-by-country?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUWIRTH, LINDA HIRSCH
description: NEUWIRTH-Linda Hirsch. Died on Sunday, May 19, 2002, losing her final battle with cancer after a series of courageous victories over 20 years. Taken from us too soon, at 51 years of age. Courageous in death as in life. Beloved and cherished wife of Michael, loving and devoted mother of Evan, darling daughter of Bertha and David Hirsch, adored sister of Stanley and Gina Hirsch, caring sister-inlaw of Naomi and Jerry Neuwirth, and Louise and Bruce Magun. Professionally, Linda was a successful and highly respected psychoanalyst. She was active in the Institute for Psychoanalytic Training and Research, and held many positions in the society. At the time of her death, she was Associate Dean and the Director of Admissions. Always a strong support for friends and family, this came naturally and instinctively to her, no matter how ill or preoccupied she was at the moment. All of us who knew and loved her were inspired and comforted by her courage, dignity and remarkable strength. We have lost an irreplacable treasure, a woman of incomprable grace and beauty with a heart to match. Our darling Linda, we will love and cherish you forever. Funeral at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., NY, NY 10023, today at 10 AM.

title: New Leader Faces Entrenched Problems in Paterson
description: Almost a week after his election as mayor of New Jersey's third-largest city, Jose Torres cannot walk downtown without everyone stopping to congratulate him. Some greet him in Spanish, others in English. Some shake his hand, others grab him in an enthusiastic bear hug.

title: Long-Shot Winner Turns Dark Horse
description: Bill Simon Jr. beamed here the other day when he introduced a high-powered group of business and political leaders who had agreed to advise his campaign for governor. On the dais, standing rigid, were Rudolph W. Giuliani, former mayor of New York; George P. Shultz, former secretary of state; and several onetime state officials.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the On Horse Racing column yesterday, about War Emblem's prospects for the Triple Crown, misstated the number of Kentucky Derby winners trained by Bob Baffert. It is three, not two.

description: FINLAND: FORKLIFT MAKER REJECTS BID Partek Oyj, a Finnish maker of forklifts, rejected a 750 million euro ($691 million) bid from Kone Oyj, the world's biggest escalator company. Partek said that it was in talks with KCI Konecranes, a crane manufacturer, which was spun off from Kone in 1993. Kone, which said it would not increase its bid, has offered to buy the Finnish government's 30 percent stake in Partek. Finland is said to support the deal.

title: The Welfare Washington Doesn't Know
description: As Congress considers how to improve welfare reform, its members should understand what anyone with an ounce of common sense already knows: Most welfare recipients who left or were knocked off the welfare rolls are still struggling to survive.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Remec To Buy Spectrian For $160 Million
description: Remec Inc., which makes wireless communications equipment, said it would buy the Spectrian Corporation for about $160 million. Remec of San Diego said it would pay as much as $45 million in cash for the company, with the remainder being covered by shares of stock. The deal is expected to be completed during the third quarter of this year, Remec officials said. Spectrian, of Sunnyvale, Calif., designs and manufactures power amplifiers for wireless infrastructure equipment. Ronald Ragland, chief executive of Remec, called the agreement a ''strong synergistic transaction.''

title: New Cancer Drug Shows Early Promise
description: A new type of drug that interferes with the garbage disposal system of cells has shown early promise in treating cancer, scientists said here today.

title: Top Sprinter To Try Road Racing
description: Picture Maurice Greene, the world's fastest sprinter, running in the New York City Marathon. In a somewhat similarly unlikely scenario, Marty Nothstein of Trexlertown, Pa., the world's top-ranked bicycle track sprinter, will ride in the three races of the First Union road-race series.

title: Two Faces of a Season, One Sensibility
description: The Glyndebourne season has opened strongly with a vigorously revived ''Don Giovanni'' and a new production of Gluck's ''Iphignie en Aulide'' that mounts in power, following the curve of the work. Both presentations show the company's continuing high standards of musical preparation.

title: Teamsters At U.P.S. Agree to Plan For a Strike
description: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters announced yesterday that its members had voted overwhelmingly to authorize a strike against the United Parcel Service if no new contract was reached by Aug. 1.

title: Pop in Review
description: Giving a Couple of Faces to Electronic Dance Music

title: LANDRY'S TO BUY 39 RESTAURANTS FROM CHART HOUSE
description: Landry's Seafood Restaurants, a large operator of seafood restaurants, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 39 restaurants from Chart House Enterprises for $45.5 million. The transaction includes Chart House's Peohe's and Chart House restaurants, the companies said. The purchase, expected to close within 60 days, does not include Chart House's six Angelo & Maxie's steak houses. Chart House, which will change its name after the purchase, will use the proceeds to retire debt. Chart House is based in Chicago. Landry's is based in Houston.

title: BOEING CUTS PRICE FOR SALE OF PLANES TO SOUTH KOREA
description: The South Korean defense ministry said yesterday that the Boeing Company had cut $203 million from the price of 40 F-15K fighter planes that it had agreed to sell to South Korea, reducing the cost to $4.2 billion from $4.4 billion. The ministry said Boeing had also agreed to increase the percentage of the parts for the planes that would be produced by Korean companies to more than 80 percent from 65 percent. A Boeing spokesman, Arthur Park, confirmed the announcement, which came after intense negotiations that had threatened to scuttle the deal. Dassault Aviation of France has asserted in a lawsuit that the bidding was not transparent and that Dassault submitted a lower bid for its Rafale jet fighter. Last month, Boeing won the initial contract. The ministry said the final agreement would be signed next month. Don Kirk (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Stamford: Weapons Seized From Man's Home
description: A former employee of a technology company has been arrested after police officers found a cache of weapons, including pipe bombs, in his Fairfield home over the weekend, the police said. Officers searched the home of the arrested man, George Sandor, while investigating accusations that he had recently threatened colleagues who formerly worked with him at i3 Mobile, a Stamford technology company, the police said. Mr. Sandor was fired from the company earlier this year, the police said. Mr. Sandor, 49, is charged with nine counts of manufacturing bombs, two counts of possession of an assault weapon, possession of explosives and reckless endangerment. He was released on a $250,000 bond on Sunday.

description: Alligator ESP

description: New York, N.Y.

description: AUTO RACING

title: Cannes Notebook; Worldly Violence and Confusion Are Pervading the Realm of Celluloid
description: The Cannes International Film Festival is a world unto itself. For 12 days every spring this small, pretty Mediterranean city becomes a surreal, occasionally Felliniesque fantasy land of trashiness and glamour. Even here, though, the real world has a way of intruding. Reminders arrive each day as CNN and the morning papers bring news of the latest suicide attack in Israel, of a new terrorism alert in the United States and of escalating tension between India and Pakistan. A feeling of disquiet is also present in the streets of Cannes itself. In this part of France nearly one in three voters supported Jean-Marie LePen's right-wing National Front in the presidential elections.

title: Lenders' Ads Urge Senator To Drop Item From Debt Bill
description: With a showdown imminent in Congress on a bill to overhaul the nation's bankruptcy system, credit card companies and retailers tried today to save the bill by opening a last-minute lobbying campaign that includes radio advertisements intended to pressure a key lawmaker in the debate, Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York.
