title: Federal Welfare Rolls Shrink, But Drop Is Smallest Since '94
description: The number of people on welfare declined slightly in the final months of 2001 despite the sluggish economy and job losses caused by the Sept. 11 attacks, the Bush administration said today.

title: Marc USA to Close Its New York Office
description: Marc USA in Pittsburgh is closing its New York office on June 3, citing the loss of clients, particularly among dot-com companies.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Restaurant Owner Is Indicted
description: Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer announced the indictment yesterday of a Chinese restaurant in Brooklyn and its owner on charges of failing to pay six employees more than $16,000 in wages due them. Mr. Spitzer said the restaurant, Jade Plaza, and its owner, Chi Yung Lee, had failed to pay these employees some weeks and had paid them for just 40 hours for other weeks when they had worked 54 hours. The attorney general's office said it was New York's first felony prosecution of an employer on charges of failing to pay required wages. An employee who answered the telephone at Jade Plaza said Mr. Lee was not in, and two lawyers for Mr. Lee did not return calls.

title: Indictment Not Keeping Velella From Race
description: There are few developments in a political career as stinging as an indictment. And for the last two weeks, State Senator Guy J. Velella, the Bronx Republican Party chairman, has had to contend with a constant stream of news media and political attention after being charged with taking bribes in exchange for using his influence to help obtain financing for public works projects.

title: Hailing an Old Cry, 'Viva Cuba Libre!'
description: Many Cuban immigrants felt they had a lot to celebrate today: not only their homeland's centennial but also the growth of their political strength here in the new homeland they have adopted.

title: Despite a Year of Upheavals, Economic Optimism Is High
description: With a stock market bust, a recession that wiped out almost two million jobs and the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, Americans would seem to have plenty of reasons to worry about a diminished future. Instead, they have emerged from the nation's recent turmoil far more optimistic than after any other economic downturn in a generation.

title: Strong Interest in Stake in Maker of Nivea
description: Several companies have approached Allianz A.G., the financial services conglomerate, about buying its stake in Beiersdorf, the German maker of Nivea skin care products, people close to the companies said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARENSTEIN, SYLVIA L.
description: ARENSTEIN-Sylvia L. Formerly of New York, passed away in Delray Beach on May 19, 2002. Survived by husband Seymour, children Robert, Joy (Randy), Phyllis and grandchildren Marc, Lauren and Amy. Funeral May 22 10:30am Gutterman-Musicant 201-489-3800.

title: Merrill Lynch to Pay $100 Million to Settle Analyst Charges
description: Merrill Lynch will pay a $100 million penalty under a wide-ranging agreement settling charges that the company misled investors with ``tainted'' stock research, the New York State Attorney General's office said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLASTER, ZENA
description: FLASTER-Zena, 89. Passed peacefully on May 19, 2002. Loving mother of Bonnie and David. Wife of the late Irwin Goldberg. Cherished mother-in-law of Wilma. Adoring grandmother of Jonathan and Erica. Devoted and wonderful Auntie ZZ. She was a gracious, strong and wonderful lady, much loved by all who knew her. We miss you Mom. Services Tuesday, May 21, The Riverside, 1:00 PM.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Noel Da Costa, a composer and music professor, misstated his age. He was 72, not 82.

title: Need Special Shoes? Maybe Not
description: Foot ulcers can be the bane of diabetics, in many cases forcing doctors to amputate a lower limb to prevent further damage.

title: Right to Counsel Expanded By a Divided Supreme Court
description: The Supreme Court expanded the right to counsel today, ruling 5 to 4 that a state may not impose even a suspended sentence -- in which eventual imprisonment may be only a remote possibility -- on an indigent defendant for whom it has not appointed a lawyer.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Victory For Whaling Foes
description: Antiwhaling nations won a victory at the annual meeting of the International Whaling Commission in Japan by voting to deny Iceland's reinstatement as a voting member. Iceland, a nation with a centuries-old whaling tradition, resigned from the commission in 1991, saying it had been taken over by antiwhaling radicals. James Brooke (NYT)

title: He keeps embargo but relents on aid : Bush demands 'democratic' Cuba
description: WASHINGTON:  President George W. Bush said Monday that he would only support an end to the Cuban trade embargo if Havana undertook substantial political and economic reforms and held free elections in 2003.

title: Why choose Yellow? A publisher of phone books aims to explain how the pages differ.
description: EVER wonder, during a search for a plumber or a car service, just who publishes your yellow pages directory? Most likely, you would guess your local telephone company, but the thick, heavy book could easily have come from one of the increasingly prominent independent publishers.

title: Shares Surge 22% After Dynegy Tells of Proposals to Raise Cash
description: Shares of Dynegy Inc. rose 22 percent today after the company, an energy trader, said it might sell assets and tap loans to raise $1 billion and ensure that the company had enough cash.

title: Suicide Attacks Certain in U.S., Mueller Warns
description: The director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation warned today that suicide bombings like those that have left hundreds dead in Israel are ''inevitable'' on American soil.

title: New Twist in Booking Airline Tickets
description: THIS will probably cut my workload in half on some days and in general make life simpler,'' said Joan Battilana, a travel agent in the Phoenix suburbs who handles mostly corporate bookings.

title: Tyson Remains An Object of Fascination
description: Mike Tyson sits on the arm of a couch in his villa at a luxury hotel, the ocean just outside the door. He is wearing a T-shirt, shorts and white sweat socks, and he has a towel across his lap. His mood, as he trains for his heavyweight title fight with Lennox Lewis on June 8, is confrontational, perhaps mockingly so, perhaps not.

title: Negotiations No, Negativism Yes
description: So much for the new, improved relationship between baseball management and labor. That relationship, always contentious, always distrustful, had supposedly taken a turn for the better, but the improvement turns out to be as superficial as a strong early-season showing by the Pittsburgh Pirates and the Montreal Expos.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, RICHARD S.
description: CLARK-Richard S. An intellectual property law attorney died on Saturday, May 18 of heart failure. He was 59 and lived in Croton Falls, NY for the past 26 years with his wife Monika. Mr. Clark was born and raised in Fairview Park, OH. He graduated from Northwestern University in 1965 and Northwestern Law School in 1968. Upon graduating from law school, he accepted his first job with the law firm Brumbaugh, Graves, Donohue and Raymond in NYC, now Baker Botts, LLP, where he worked for the next 34 years as an intellectual property law attorney. In September 2001, he joined the international law firm, Dorsey & Whitney, LLP, where he headed the patent practice of the NY office. He was lead counsel in significant intellectual property litigations, including Group One v. Hallmark Cards, a landmark intellectual property decision redefining the law of bars to patentability, and Eli Lilly v. Barr which invalidated the Prozac patent. Mr. Clark was Vice President and Trustee of Operation Sail, which organizes tall ship festivals, including OpSail 2000 held in NY on July 4, 2000. He was a faculty member at the Practicing Law Institute in NY. In addition to his wife Monika, he is survived by his chocolate lab, Kahlua, his children Samantha Boege of Bedford, NY and Richard Clark of Charlotte, NC, his stepchildren, Mark Penta of Randolph, VT and Heidi Penta of Warren, VT, his siblings, Constance Lauderback of Bay Village, OH, Claudia Potter of Mabank, TX and Lewis Clark, and three grandaughters, Kendall and Harper Boege and Caden Clark. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, May 22 at 3PM at the South Salem Presbyterian Church in South Salem, NY.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Family Resists Efforts To Quit Adelphia Board

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Crowded Field For Parliament Race
description: The Interior Ministry said 8,633 people declared their candidacy in elections for 577 seats in the National Assembly by the midnight Sunday deadline, one-third more than in the last legislative elections five years ago. Two rounds of voting, on June 9 and 16, will determine the shape of the next government, and the record number of candidates could erode support for a majority behind President Jacques Chirac, who was re-elected this month in a landslide over the far-right leader Jean-Marie Le Pen. Mr. Le Pen's movement, the National Front, is running candidates for at least 563 seats, threatening to siphon support from Mr. Chirac's conservative Rally for the Republic party. The Socialists, too, face uncertainty from two Trotskyite splinter parties. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Chicago Loses Firefighters' Suit
description: A jury has ordered Chicago to pay $2.3 million to nine white firefighters who said their scores on a lieutenants' examination in 1986 were lowered because of their race. The award was decided three months after 10 firefighters were awarded $2.7 million, including interest, in a similar case. An additional 35 white firefighters have claims pending against the city, which is appealing the damage verdicts. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Miscellany
description: * Euro RSCG Worldwide, New York, part of Havas Advertising, acquired Dorfer Relationship Communications, Frankfurt, a marketing services agency. Terms were not disclosed. The agency will be renamed Euro RSCG Dorfer.

title: Want to Be a Male Model? Wear a Real Face
description: On Page 4 of the June issue of Esquire magazine, there is an advertisement for a new Calvin Klein men's fragrance bearing the uniquely contrived name Truth. The man in the ad looks as if he might think a 401(k) is something swallowed late at night on a dance floor with a margarita. His nose is long and straight, his lips are pneumatic and his chest is so glistening and unmarred it calls to mind a hockey rink that has just been smoothed over by a Zamboni.

title: Pakistan Seeks Monitors to Cool the Simmering Crisis in Kashmir
description: Pakistan sought to defuse its deadly standoff with India today by calling for international monitors to be stationed on their mutual border in the disputed Kashmir region.

title: Inquiry Finds 'Widespread Failure' at I.N.S. in Handling of Hijackers' Student Visas
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service mishandled paperwork pertaining to some of the Sept. 11 hijackers partly because of ''a widespread failure by many individuals'' in the agency, a Justice Department inquiry concluded today.

title: Babes Switched at Birth In Twain's World of Bigotry
description: Mark Twain's ''Pudd'nhead Wilson'' is a clever, prickly, multigenre book; it's a switched-in-the-cradle tall tale, a crime story and a parable of just deserts. The story of the fate of two children -- one of whom is white but raised as black, the other possessed of black blood but passed off by his mother as white -- and the untangling of their secrets by the title character, a bright man presumed to be a dolt, it has more plot per page than most novels, all of it in the service of the author's disparagement of the rationale behind slavery.

title: How the Settler Suburbs Grew
description: There is nothing that causes as much heated debate in Israel as the future of the settlements in the West Bank and Gaza. It is now clear to most Israelis that if there is ever going to be a final political agreement with the Palestinians, it will require that some, if not necessarily all, of the settlements be dislodged and evacuated. A permanent plan would have to create a Palestinian state that is compact and continuous -- unlike the disconnected wedges and enclaves of Palestinian autonomy areas that were created by the Oslo accord and that have left the settlements in place. Although this reality is undeniable, the practicality of settlement removal has largely been avoided by all Israeli governments, including those of the left, even as that avoidance makes the eventual uprooting of the growing settler population more difficult.

title: An Intimate Setting, Packed, but Intimately
description: The elegant, wood-paneled gallery room at the Kosciuszko Foundation on East 65th Street in Manhattan can accommodate at most about 120 people for concerts. It was packed on Wednesday night for the final program of the fourth season of the Lyric Chamber Music Society of New York.

title: A Touchy Subject
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Africa: Angola: President Seeks Help For Ex-Rebels
description: President Jos Eduardo dos Santos has issued an urgent appeal, saying the government needs immediate assistance to feed and house thousands of demobilized rebels and their families. Officials of the rebel group, Unita, have said they fear the guerrillas will resort to crime if their basic needs are not met in the demobilization camps. Angola's warring parties signed a cease-fire in April to end more than two decades of civil war. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: For Emergency Officials Touched by 9/11's Horrors, Fears of Creeping Complacency
description: A day after Vice President Dick Cheney warned that terrorists would strike again in this country, emergency officials who responded to the Sept. 11 attack warned their counterparts at a conference in New York City yesterday that complacency was creeping back into society.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: U.S. INDUSTRIES, Iselin, N.J., maker of Jacuzzi spas and Rainbow vacuum cleaners, said it would sell its Selkirk unit, a provider of commercial heating and air-conditioning, and its SuperVent operations in Canada to Tinicum Capital Partners, New York, for $40 million.

title: A New Snag for Accounting Legislation
description: Facing enormous opposition from the financial services industry and some Republican lawmakers, the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee postponed a meeting scheduled for Tuesday at which lawmakers would have considered an overhaul of accounting industry regulations inspired by the collapse of Enron.

title: Kings Missed Memo On Lakers' Coronation
description: Spotting Chris Webber and his teammates a double-digit lead, an under-the-weather Kobe Bryant and a foul-prone Shaquille O'Neal waited patiently for the fourth quarter to come around tonight to do what the Los Angeles Lakers always do to the opposition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YAVELOW, BERNARD
description: YAVELOW-Bernard. Age 86. Of New York City. Beloved husband of Vivian. Loving father of Mark, and Jonathan and his wife Joy. Adoring grandfather of Ivia. Devoted brother of Charlotte, dear uncle, great uncle and friend to many. Funeral service will be held at Plaza Funeral Home, 630 Amsterdam Ave, 1PM today. Interment will follow at Mount Eden Cemetery, Valhalla, N.Y. He will remain in our hearts forever.

title: In $40 Million Museum, Big Spending Is on Display
description: Nassau County's new Cradle of Aviation Museum, which formally opened today, is more than a tribute to Long Island's pioneering in aerospace. It also serves as an unintended monument to a big-spending era that the county is rapidly phasing out.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: National Semiconductor Raises Estimates
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation, the microchip maker based in Santa Clara, Calif., revised its revenue projections for the fourth quarter of its 2002 fiscal year, saying that stronger than expected chip orders would help the bottom line. The company now expects an increase of 12 percent to 13 percent over the third quarter's revenues of $369.5 million. Previous growth estimates were 6 percent to 9 percent. ''Overall orders and turns bookings both came in at a better rate than we had originally projected,'' Brian Halla, chief executive of National Semiconductor, said in a statement. Nevertheless, the company also said that it was simultaneously cutting 150 jobs, or less than 2 percent of its global work force. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Middle East
description: IRAQ: U.S. PLANES STRIKE American warplanes bombed an aircraft tracking site south of Baghdad after Iraqi air defenses fired at British or American jets patrolling the no-flight zone for the second time in 12 days, the Pentagon said. The military's Central Command said that Iraq had fired at coalition aircraft nearly 1,100 times since December 1998 and that Iraqi aircraft had violated the southern zone more than 160 times in that period. The latest in the decade-long exchanges between Iraqi air defenses and allied aircraft came as the United Nations discusses the return of weapons inspectors to Iraq and as speculation swirls over possible American plans to topple President Saddam Hussein.

title: Richard W. Zirinsky Sr., 86, Developer
description: Richard W. Zirinsky Sr., a real estate developer and owner active in Queens and Brooklyn since the 1940's, died on May 18 in Southampton, N.Y. He was 86 and lived on the East Side of Manhattan.

title: U.N. Loses Patience With Somali Custom of Kidnapping
description: Somali militiamen do not bite the hand that feeds them. Rather, they kidnap the hand, and the rest of the body, and hold the victim at gunpoint for ransom.

title: Government Says Pilots Can't Have Guns in Cockpits
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  After months of debate following the Sept. 11 terrorist hijackings, the Transportation Department has decided that airline pilots will not be allowed to have guns in the cockpits.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: NISSAN POSTS A PROFIT Helped by cost-cutting and the weakness of Japan's currency, the Nissan Motor Company earned 372 billion yen ($2.95 billion) in the year that ended March 31. The automaker, which was near bankruptcy in 1998, has also cut its debt sharply and increased its operating margins. The company, which is 44.4 percent owned by Renault S.A., expects its profit to rise another 2.2 percent this year and sales to increase 4.9 percent. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Financial Communications Society, New York, announced the winners of its eighth annual Portfolio Awards competition, honoring financial services advertising that appeared in 2001. There were three Best of Show winners in three categories. In the corporate image category, the award was presented to the MassMutual Financial Group, parent of the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, and its agency, Lowe & Partners Worldwide, New York, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, for a television campaign called ``Happily Ever After.'' In the consumer retail category, the award went to MasterCard and its agency, McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, New York, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of Interpublic, for three commercials in the ``Priceless'' campaign. In the business-to-business category, the award was presented to Marsh and its agency, Della Femina, Rothschild, Jeary & Partners, New York, owned by top managers and the Omnicom Group, for a print campaign carrying the theme ``Marsh solved all these risks.''

title: National Briefing | Washington: Trying To Combat Abuse Of The Elderly
description: Senator John B. Breaux, chairman of the Senate Special Committee on Aging, called for criminal background checks on all nursing home employees and said the government needed new powers to combat abuse of the elderly. ''Every year in America, somewhere between 500,000 and five million elderly citizens are abused,'' said Mr. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana. A bill that he drafted would create offices at the Justice Department and the Department of Health and Human Services to help investigate abuse, neglect and exploitation of the elderly and provide assistance to victims of abuse. Robert Pear (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUTSCH, ARTHUR
description: DEUTSCH-Arthur. The Trustees and staff of the Riverdale YMYWHA are profoundly saddened by the death of our esteemed colleague, benefactor and friend. Starting as a teen member of our Board, Artie helped guide our JCC for 50 years. Our hearts go out to Beulah, Peter, Michael and their families. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Judy Kaufthal, President Jeff Moerdler, Chair Harry Feder, Hon. Chair Diane Rubin, Exec. VP

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Guess Who Doesn't Back Fannie, Freddie And Farmer
description: Perhaps the only warning label more ignored than the one on cigarette packs is the one stamped on debt offerings issued by government-sponsored enterprises like Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac and Farmer Mac.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Leader For Judiciary Panel
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday appointed of Desiree Kim as the executive director of the mayor's Advisory Committee on the Judiciary. The committee evaluates and nominates judicial candidates for the New York City Criminal Court, Family Court and for interim civil court appointments. Ms. Kim is currently special inspector general for bias matters for the New York State Unified Court System.

title: Penthouse Settles Photo Suit
description: A woman who sued Penthouse magazine two weeks ago after it published topless pictures of her that it said were of the tennis star Anna Kournikova has agreed to a settlement, lawyers for both sides said yesterday.

title: Villany Journal; Harvesting the Fruits Of Capitalism: Grapes
description: The newly minted magnates of Hungary do, of course, make the pilgrimage to the vineyards here. But there is no shortage either of baggy jeans and fanny packs working their way down, then cheerily up, the steps of Villany's cellars. Now that capitalism has put some cash in their hands, the growing middle class is doing its part to revive one of Hungary's oldest traditions: making, and drinking, quite good wine.

title: ASHCROFT LEARNED OF AGENT'S ALERT JUST AFTER 9/11
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft and the F.B.I. director, Robert S. Mueller III, were told a few days after the Sept. 11 attacks that the F.B.I. had received a memorandum from its Phoenix office the previous July warning that Osama bin Laden's followers could be training at American flight schools, government officials said today.

title: Distractions and Diversions
description: With old and new warnings of terror attacks whizzing around Washington, it's becoming hard to follow what really matters, which is preventing another assault by Osama bin Laden and his followers. There's a place for debate about issues like whether Congressional committees or a special commission should investigate the government's response to terrorism before Sept. 11. But there is a danger that talk will become a substitute for action on the problems that desperately need fixing. That includes the performance of agencies like the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Central Intelligence Agency and even the Social Security Administration, which routinely assigns Social Security numbers to foreigners who submit fake documents.

title: Celtics Think They Survived Nets' Best
description: The Boston Celtics had four days off after their Eastern Conference semifinal series victory over the Detroit Pistons, and Coach Jim O'Brien spent that time drilling his team on the nuances of the Nets. The Celtics watched film and practiced among themselves, with the second unit running the Nets' motion offense, simulating the endless running attack.

title: New Effort To Develop Seaport Site At South Street
description: For the third time, officials have chosen a developer to rehabilitate more than a dozen dilapidated buildings within the South Street Seaport Historic District that have long been viewed as an eyesore and have confounded attempts to develop them, the city's Economic Development Corporation said yesterday.

title: A Massenet Oratorio Scaled to Its Site
description: Jules Massenet, the opera composer, made his breakthrough with sacred oratorios. And yet this young composer's ''Marie-Magdeleine'' seemed destined for oblivion until Massenet was invited to a dinner party that Pauline Viardot, the great singer, also attended. Viardot responded to excerpts from the piece with something along the lines of ''Marie-Magdeleine, c'est moi''; the work had its premiere in 1873, and Massenet went on to write more than 20 operas.

title: Loans to Poor At Tax Time Are Criticized
description: A federal tax credit intedned to lift millions of low-income families out of poverty has become a financial bonanza for the two leading tax preparation companies and the companies they work with to arrange high-cost loans, according to a study to be released today.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: U.S. Planes Strike
description: American warplanes bombed an aircraft tracking site south of Baghdad after Iraqi air defenses fired at British or American jets patrolling the no-flight zone for the second time in 12 days, the Pentagon said. The military's Central Command said that Iraq had fired at coalition aircraft nearly 1,100 times since December 1998 and that Iraqi aircraft had violated the southern zone more than 160 times in that period. The latest in the decade-long exchanges between Iraqi air defenses and allied aircraft came as the United Nations discusses the return of weapons inspectors to Iraq and as speculation swirls over possible American plans to topple President Saddam Hussein. Thom Shanker (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, DAVID T.
description: KRAMER-David T. Died suddenly on May 17, 2002 at age 51. Of Silver Spring, MD, formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Beloved husband of Karen, loving father of Miriam Kramer and Aaron Levy, Danny and Miri Kramer, and Adina L. Kramer. Adoring grandfather of Kayla and Rochel Kramer. Devoted son of Milton and Etta Kramer, cherished brother of Roberta Sigall and Allen Kramer. Funeral services were held on May 19 in Silver Spring, MD. Shiva will take place in Silver Spring, MD and will also take place beginning Wednesday afternoon in Woodmere, NY.

title: Rigas Family Said to Resist Leaving Board of Adelphia
description: Despite mounting pressure from outside directors, bankers and others aimed at forcing the Rigas family to resign from the board of Adelphia Communications, the family is strongly resisting giving up its five seats, people close to the situation said yesterday.

title: Political Memo; New York's Smaller Parties Cloud the Race for Governor
description: The rising influence and abundance of small political parties in New York is disrupting the election campaigns of Gov. George E. Pataki and his two Democratic rivals. The minor parties are moving to enhance their power and assure their very existence by playing a highly visible role in the governor's race.

title: Where Excellence Is De Rigueur; Training for the Paris Opera Ballet
description: At least once a year, a gala evening at the Palais Garnier here opens with the ''grand dfil,'' a solemn procession of some 280 dancers who start in the Foyer de la Danse behind the stage and walk slowly toward the audience to music by Berlioz. The parade begins with the youngest students at the Paris Opera Ballet School and ends 20 minutes later with the flamboyant bows and curtsies of principals.

title: As Arafat Critics Close In, Deputies Vie in the Wings
description: Yasir Arafat, for decades the very personification of Palestinian aspirations, is now in deep trouble with his own people, according to Palestinian political analysts and Israeli intelligence officials who see his authority challenged by a younger generation of street leaders who grew up fighting Israeli occupation.

(Include a postal address.)

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Attempted Baby Abduction
description: Two men posing as employees of the Department of Children and Families tried to abduct an 8-month-old but fled when the baby's mother asked for identification. The police in Miami said two men went to the house and told the girl's mother that they were there to pick up the child for medical tests. The police said they had no reason to believe that there was a connection between this case and that of Rilya Wilson, 5, whose grandmother said she was taken away 15 months ago by someone who she thought was an employee of the Department of Children and Families. Dana Canedy (NYT)

title: Defense Rests After One Day In '63 Bombing
description: Not a lot of bad things were said today about Bobby Frank Cherry.

description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Jeff Hasen was named president at Wong Doody Communications, Seattle, a new unit of Wong Doody specializing in public relations. He had been president at the Seattle office of Publicis Dialog, part of the Publicis Groupe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAY, LAURENCE MARCUSE
description: SHAY-Laurence Marcuse. Of New York, NY, died Sunday, May 19 at Norwalk Hospital. Mr. Shay is survived by his wife, Karen Weitzman Shay, his parents, Morrie and Christine, and his siblings, Russell Shay and Julie Shay, his sister-inlaw, Debby, his aunt, Rose Sutro, his cousins, Denise and Clet Hickey and their children. Poet and driver, Larry loved the Flint Hills.

title: A Physicist Considers the Cosmos, Through the Prism of 9/11
description: In a kind of writer's convalescence, I have come here to rediscover the intellectual pleasures of pure physics and cosmology.

title: Survival of the Fittest Microbes
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Jose Torres, the mayor-elect of Paterson, N.J., referred incorrectly to the status of a federal corruption case against his defeated opponent, Mayor Martin G. Barnes. Mr. Barnes has been indicted, has pleaded not guilty and is awaiting trial; he has not been convicted.

title: 'Ally McBeal' Ends, Not With a Bang but a Whimper
description: The series conclusion of ''Ally McBeal'' had enough shtick and sentiment to satisfy the constituencies that had stuck with the show through declining ratings until the bittersweet end. Those who loved it could indulge in a satisfying farewell wallow. Those who despised it (but watched anyway) could rail at the high-strung Ally's trademark ethereal ditsiness, as Calista Flockhart exited the public imagination -- at least in this incarnation -- with a final tremble.

title: Security Tightened in New York After Vague Threats of Terrorism
description: Federal and local law-enforcement officials yesterday issued a warning of vague and uncorroborated threats against the Brooklyn Bridge and the Statue of Liberty as the city imposed security measures not seen since the first months after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Carey International, Washington, a chauffeured vehicle service, named Stein Rogan & Partners, New York, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, as its first agency of record. Spending was estimated at more than $1 million.

title: Sunday Break Pointed for Belmont
description: Through the first two legs of the Triple Crown, 26 different horses have taken their best shot at War Emblem and none were good enough. But that hasn't stopped the trainers of several new horses from entertaining thoughts of running against him in the June 8 Belmont Stakes. War Emblem will face several challengers in the Belmont, but, perhaps, none more formidable than Sunday Break.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: CMGI Scales Back Its Forecast
description: The once- highflying Internet incubator, CMGI Inc., said yesterday that its financial results would be lower than previously expected and that it would buy the 25 percent of the Internet marketing firm Engage Technologies that it did not already own. CMGI, which has posted losses in 10 consecutive quarters, now expects to report a pro forma operating loss of $54 million, up from a previous forecast of $32 million to $37 million. ''We are not satisfied with the results for the third quarter,'' said George McMillan, chief of CMGI, in a statement. ''We are taking immediate and decisive actions to remedy the major contributing factors.'' Shares in CMGI, which once traded as high as $163, ended yesterday at 92 cents, down 12.3 percent. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Nonprofit Sector of City Economy Is Fastest-Growing Source of Jobs, a Study Reports
description: The nonprofit sector is the fastest-growing source of jobs in New York City, according to a new study of the sector's economic role.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EINSON, MARSHALL
description: EINSON-Marshall. Age 71 of Westport, CT, on May 20, 2002. Beloved husband of Natalie, devoted father of Sharon Periera, Beth Concors and her husband David, of CA., Dr. Michelle Einson of NC., and four grandsons. Services will take place Thursday May 23 at 11:00 AM from Temple Israel, 14 Coley Town Rd., Westport, CT

title: Cuomo Plans To Bypass Convention
description: With H. Carl McCall rolling up solid support among New York Democratic Party leaders in his bid for the gubernatorial nomination, Andrew M. Cuomo will bypass the Democratic State Convention that opens this afternoon, and will instead focus on winning the gubernatorial primary in the fall, Democratic officials said last night.

title: As Terror Fever Rises in America
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Scoops in Brooklyn and the East Village
description: What's your taste in ice cream? If it runs to classic old-fashioned flavors, then what Mark Thompson makes for the Brooklyn Ice Cream Factory, in a landmark fireboat house on a pier in the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge, is for you. Chocolate, vanilla, butter pecan, strawberry and a few others ($3 for two scoops) are made without eggs. One innovation is hot caramel sauce, made by Ellen Sternau, pastry chef at the River Cafe next door. This weekend, Mr. Thompson's ice creams and some sorbets will also be sold from a shed at the end of the pier.

title: From a Careful Populist, A Surprise Meant For a Few
description: STEPHEN HANSON has built a restaurant empire, B. R. Guest Inc., by pleasing crowds. His restaurants, notably Ocean Grill, Park Avalon and Isabella's, feed somewhere between 150 and 250 people at a sitting. Blue Water Grill, Blue Fin and Ruby Foo's Dim Sum and Sushi Palace on the Upper West Side can accommodate 400. That's a lot of food, and a lot of diners. B. R. Guest is the closest thing New York has to a major Hollywood studio turning out big-budget popular films with modest artistic goals.

title: That Rumbling Underfoot? It's Not a Subway, It's Art
description: Pedestrians hurrying over a grate in the triangular median where Broadway and Seventh Avenue converge in Times Square, just south of 46th Street, rarely seem to notice anything out of the ordinary. But Max Neuhaus hopes that, subliminally, their lives are being changed.

title: A Town Rich in Stolen Art, But Not Nosy Questions
description: This is a little town that can keep a secret. Not because it's such a tough town; it just seems to be the kind of place where people don't ask questions.

title: Ammunition in a Battle for Souls; Evangelical Latinos See Opportunity in Catholic Scandal
description: So far, the sexual abuse scandals involving priests have not provoked widespread defections among Hispanics, a bedrock of the Roman Catholic Church in America. But they have emboldened many Latino evangelicals to assert that their path is the righteous one.

title: Harvard Faculty Votes to Put the Excellence Back in the A
description: Bowing to criticism that too many students were receiving A's, the Harvard University faculty voted yesterday to overturn at least a generation of tradition by adopting a marking system more like that of most American colleges.

title: In Laos, a Regional Specialty Goes Global
description: ALONG the banks of the Mekong River here in northern Laos, rows and rows of straw easels, covered with dark green squares, baked in the abiding sun. From our low-slung wooden boat, they looked like solar panels. But they were kaipen, a curious local specialty made from kai, river algae that is harvested from rocks when the water is low.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WESTON, REV. M. MORAN, PH.D.
description: WESTON-Rev. M. Moran, Ph.D. The Board of Directors, staff and consumers of Weston United Community Renewal, Inc. deeply mourn the passing of our Founder and Chairman Emeritus, The Reverend M. Moran Weston, Ph.D. A visionary who ministered to the physical as well as spiritual needs of the people of Harlem, he pioneered the provision of housing with supports for the mentally ill and homeless of the community. Under his leadership, Weston United built Bishop House at 39 West 128th Street in 1985, and added Weston House at 203 West 113th Street and the Center for Hope (TLC) at 2262 Adam Clayton Powell, Jr., Blvd. His understanding of the cultural and economic needs of the community, led to the creation of Gallery M. at 123 West 135th Street and Visionary Bookstore at 2262 Adam Clayton Powell, Jr., Blvd., and job-training centers Club United at 321 West 125th Street and Casita Unida at 320 East 105th Street. Weston United has moved its headquarters to 321 West 125th Street which also houses Community Focus for people with AIDS and a Blended Case Management program. Dr. Weston was always a source of wisdom, history and values, providing inspiration and leadership. ''Hold fast to dreams'' was his watch word. The world is diminished by his passing. Weston United Community Renewal, Inc.'s, Board of Directors, Staff and Consumers

title: Accra Journal; No Mosh Pit, This, but Some Enthusiasm for Aid
description: To Bono, the rock star who has made alleviating African poverty his cause, Ghana is ''the birthplace of cool,'' a country so vibrant with its own metaphorical jazz that the right dose of aid and investment could secure it a place in the global economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, ROBERT M.
description: GROSSMAN-Robert M. Late of Southampton, NY died May 20, 2002 in CT Hospice. Born in 1922 in Philadephia, son of the late Isaac and Grace Grossman, he is survived by a brother and sister-inlaw, Jon and Joan Grossman of Stony Creek (Branford) CT, a nephew Perry Grossman and niece Linda Grossman, and his former wife and devoted lifelong friend, Laurel Posner Nader. He was predeceased by a sister, Nancy G. Hart. Bob attended the Philadelphia Museum School of Art before serving in the United States Army artillery during World War II, participating in action in Europe. His lifelong passion for automobiles took many forms. A pioneer in introducing foreign cars into the American market, he established a retail operation in Nyack, NY in the early 1950s. He later became a distributor and importer of various European makes. He enjoyed a notable 25 year career in automobile racing, earning consistent victories on both the US and international circuits. At an early age he began drawing automobiles; over the years this hobby developed into a distinct artform and source of income. Interment private; a memorial celebration will be held at a later date. title: High Plains Dust
description: For many people who lived through the 1930's, that decade's most potent symbol was the Dust Bowl. No one forgets a legendary drought or dust storms of biblical proportion. Now in the heart of the American West, people are harking back to what their parents or grandparents saw in the 30's because they're seeing a version of it themselves today. Much of the West, and especially the region running from eastern Montana south through the High Plains, is entering its fourth straight year of drought, and in places the dust has begun to blow again.

Oliver L. Brown, the chief plaintiff in the landmark Brown v. Board of Education ruling on school desegregation.

Casey Jr., Pennsylvania's auditor general, in the most expensive, television-steeped primary in state history.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Race-Neutral Student Programs
description: Gov. Jeb Bush and his cabinet agreed to stop the use of racial preferences for programs for gifted students in public schools. The move is intended to settle a suit filed in Miami that contended that two white children were denied admission to a program even though their I.Q. scores would have been acceptable if they had been black or Hispanic. School districts can still admit students with lower I.Q. scores if they are from ''low socioeconomic'' backgrounds or have trouble speaking English. Gary Fineout (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Leader Urges Calm For World Cup
description: President Kim Dae Jung called for a moratorium on strikes and political infighting from now through the end of the World Cup soccer finals on June 30. The tournament, which begins on May 31, will be held in South Korea and Japan. Labor Minister Bang Yong Seok warned that a strike by metal and chemical workers called for today would hurt the country's image. With a presidential election in December, the opposition Grand National Party hopes to capitalize on political scandals. Don Kirk (NYT)

The boy, Vili Fualaau, who was 12 when the relationship began in 1996, and his mother sought more than $2 million from Des Moines, Wash., and the school district, contending that officials should have done more to prevent the affair. The teacher, Mary Kay Letourneau, is serving a seven-year prison term for child rape. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: No. 1 In Interstate Garbage
description: Once again, the state ranks first in the nation as an importer of interstate garbage. Pennsylvania imported 10.7 million tons of municipal garbage last year, more than two times as much as Virginia, longtime runner-up, the Congressional Research Service in Washington has found. New Jersey and New York are the biggest exporters to Pennsylvania, where landfill capacity has doubled in the last decade. Blaine Harden (NYT)

title: Introduction and Garnishes
description: The citrus family of fruits is one of nature's great gifts to cooks. The citrus fruits most common to Western palates  lemon, lime, orange, grapefruit  have varying degrees of acidity and sweetness; when used as a flavor base, they give both savory and sweet dishes a wonderful balance of acidity. Used to brighten a recipe, they awaken other flavors in an almost magical way. And let's not forget that citrus fruits are more than just juice: citrus zest (the colorful outer portion of the peel, not to be confused with the bitter white flesh just under the skin, known as the pith) has an additional depth of flavor that is invaluable.

title: Protests, and Friends Too, Await Bush in Europe

Mr. Bush will be here barely 20 hours, the first stop on a European tour that takes him to Russia, France and Italy, but German demonstrators plan three days of protests.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: ABC News Show Wins Defamation Suit
description: A state appeals court ruled yesterday against police officers who charged the ABC network's ''Primetime Live'' of defaming them as racists on national television. The court ruled that the officers' traffic stop of three black men was unlawful and that the commentary was not defamatory. The 1996 program on racial profiling, narrated by Diane Sawyer, used a hidden camera to show Officers Louis Hornberger, Robert Tonkery and James Mennuti as they stopped and interrogated the black men. Neville L. Johnson, the lawyer for the officers, said the issue was ''not whether the search was unlawful, but whether the officers made a profile stop.'' Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Conviction Appealed In Sotheby's Case
description: Lawyers for A. Alfred Taubman, left, the former chairman of Sotheby's, have filed an appeal of his price-fixing conviction with a federal appeals court. They argue that possibly favorable testimony was excluded, denying Mr. Taubman a fair trial. In April, Mr. Taubman, 78, was sentenced to a year and a day in prison for leading a six-year scheme with Christie's that swindled customers of more than $100 million. Mr. Taubman is to begin his sentence on Aug. 2. Seth P. Waxman, a former solicitor general, has joined Mr. Taubman's lawyers. Carol Vogel (NYT)

title: Gap's Chief Executive Unexpectedly Calls It Quits
description: In an unexpected announcement, Gap Inc. said yesterday that Millard S. Drexler, its chief executive, would resign as soon as a successor was named.

title: Proud Citizen's Purse to Go to Towers Fund
description: Besides hoping to turn the tables on War Emblem in the Belmont Stakes on June 8, the owners of Proud Citizen announced yesterday that they would donate their share of the purse earnings to the Twin Towers Fund.

title: Library Overhaul in Doubt
description: Two years after the Robin Hood Foundation offered to help overhaul the city's 656 elementary school libraries, the project is under way, with the first 10 renovations almost complete and 20 more in the works. The Board of Education has earmarked $28 million for the first 30 renovations, including $7 million from Robin Hood, $5 million from the mayor's office and $16 million from its own coffers. But the city's budget crisis has put the project's future in doubt. LONNI TANNER, the foundation's director of special projects, said the first 30 redesigns would at least provide a blueprint for a larger-scale project. Part of the money is helping the librarians at each of the 30 schools get master's degrees in library science from Syracuse University.

title: U.S. Discloses That Use of Tax Evasion Plans Is Extensive
description: At least 152,000 Americans filed bogus tax returns last year saying they owed no taxes or seeking money from the government under a variety of tax evasions marketed by promoters, the government said yesterday in court papers filed in Florida.

title: The Warning du Jour Comes via Rumsfeld, But Worriers Abound
description: Each day, another senior Bush administration official has come forward with a dire warning. One by one, they have predicted, with near certainty, that terrorists will strike again in the United States -- culminating today with a warning that New York landmarks like the Statue of Liberty might be at risk.

title: Indoor-Outdoor Living for the Fleet of Foot
description: Alan Ayckbourn's ''House'' and ''Garden,'' are two plays that add up to one comedy of manners, but the theatrical calculus involved in staging them is far more complicated than that. Written to be performed simultaneously with the same cast and the same characters but on different stages in front of different audiences, they are the dramaturgical equivalent of Siamese twins, separate entities sharing the same trunk. The plays begin, end and break for intermission in tandem, and they take place during the same time span on a single day, at the same English estate, albeit one in the house and one in the garden. Got all that?

description: It sounds like the dream of an Amtrak rider the night after a really bad trip home.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: SUBPOENAS PLANNED FOR EXECUTIVES The California legislative committee investigating a $95 million no-bid software contract plans to subpoena executives at Oracle, the committee chairman said yesterday. Assemblyman Dean Florez, a Democrat, chairman of the Joint Legislative Audit Committee, said Oracle offered to send the company's legal counsel to testify about the contract, but Oracle officials told Mr. Florez they would not allow the employees involved in the project to testify. The deal was billed as a way for the state to save at least $16 million through volume purchases and maintenance of database software. But the state auditor said last month that the contract could cost the state as much as $41 million more than if it had kept its previous software supply arrangements, a conclusion Oracle disputes. (AP)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Bill Intended To Shield Children
description: Opting to carve out a corner of cyberspace for children rather than a separate domain, the House of Representatives passed a bill yesterday that would create a ''.kids.us'' Internet extension restricted to child-friendly material. The bill would require the operator of the .us domain, NeuStar, which is based in Washington, to create a subdomain limited to sites appropriate for children 12 or younger. NeuStar will be expected to monitor this extension and remove any objectionable material. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: Daschle Is Seeking a Special Inquiry on Sept. 11 Attacks
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  Headed for a confrontation with the White House and Congressional Republicans, the majority leader of the Democratic-controlled Senate called today for an independent commission to investigate government action before the Sept. 11 attacks. He said such a panel was needed for "a greater degree of public scrutiny, of public involvement, of public understanding."

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qualcomm Optimistic On Profit
description: Qualcomm, the largest maker of chips for Verizon Wireless phones, said it was on track to meet the fiscal third-quarter and second-half profit and sales targets it issued a month ago. Third-quarter profit, excluding certain items, will be 21 cents to 23 cents a share, in line with the 22-cent average estimate in a poll by Thomson Financial/First Call. The company, based in San Diego, had profit of 20 cents on that basis in the period a year earlier.

title: He Has No Use for Ashtrays or High Cigarette Taxes
description: WE are in rented office space at a White Plains law firm, gazing in ambiguous admiration at the upper shelves of Robert L. Shepherd's otherwise bland bookcase where, not books, but his carefully curated cigarette collection is displayed like cellophane-wrapped eye candy. Some of the cigarette packs are rarities, some are private label antiques, some are foreign, some purport to be herbal, some hail from Indian reservations, and none remotely tempt him. Not one puff has he taken, not even from the Virginia-grown brand Go to Hell that tickles him most. Honest.

The girl, 5, will be allowed to attend the Capital Christian School for the three remaining weeks of the school year, but only as long as her mother, Christina Silvas, 24, agrees not to work as a stripper. The school said that position violated a parental promise to uphold a Christian environment ''that involves the whole family.'' title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MYERS, ROBERT HOLT
description: MYERS-Robert Holt. 84. Died on May 11 at home in Chevy Chase, Maryland. He was born on March 2, 1918, in Washington, D.C. Mr. Myers practiced law as a partner of the Washington, D.C. law firm Williams, Myers & Quiggle. He served on the board of the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation and then became its Chairman. He was an avid hunter and occasional tennis player. He was a member of the Chevy Chase Club, the Rolling Rock Club, the Princeton Club of Washington and New York, the Metropolitan Club, the Oyster Harbors Club, and the Oglethorpe Club. He is survived by his four children.

title: Merrill Lynch's Deal
description: Eliot Spitzer, New York State's attorney general, has been investigating the scandalous conflicts of interest at Wall Street firms for almost a year. Once he stumbled across those now-famous e-mails in which Merrill Lynch Internet analysts referred to dot-com stocks they had recommended as ''pieces of junk'' and ''dogs,'' it was pretty clear that the firm would seek a settlement with Mr. Spitzer. The deal, announced yesterday, includes a mixed bag of worthy reforms to bolster the independence of Merrill's research; a modest, $100 million fine; and a rather disingenuous expression of regret by Merrill for past practices.
