description: To the Editor:

title: D.C. Police Identify Remains as Those of Chandra Levy
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  Human remains found this morning in a sprawling, thickly wooded park in the capital are those of Chandra Ann Levy, the former intern who disappeared more than a year ago, police officials said this evening.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a strike vote by Teamsters at United Parcel Service misstated the company's age. It is 94, not 86.

title: Energy Companies Told to Disclose Offsetting Trades
description: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission broadened its investigation today into the possible manipulation of energy prices, ordering traders to provide information on whether they engaged in fake trades and whether those transactions affected published electricity prices.

title: In New Focus on Quality of Life, City Goes After Petty Criminals
description: New York City's prosecutors, police and probation officials said yesterday that they would begin cracking down on a core group of as many as 9,700 people who repeatedly commit petty crimes like prostitution, public drinking and drug use, but serve little jail time.

title: Women, Children and That Book
description: To the Editor:

title: Kingsborough Teacher on Rise
description: SUSAN O'MALLEY, an English professor at Kingsborough Community College, has been chosen as chairwoman of the faculty senate of the City University of New York, which also makes her the faculty representative on CUNY's board of trustees. She replaces BERNARD SOHMER, a City College mathematics professor. Dr. O'Malley, who studied at Smith College and earned a Ph.D. at Tulane University, is the first professor from a community college to lead the faculty senate. Karen W. Arenson

title: Lettuce With Roots Firmly in the Earth
description: Field-grown mche is unlike most mche, or lamb's lettuce, that is sold in produce markets. Usually, mche is grown hydroponically, that is, not in soil but in nutrient-enhanced liquid, and is softer, leggier and less flavorful than mche grown in the alluvial earth near Salinas, Calif., by Epic Roots. Clusters of field-grown mche are sweet, but with a mineral assertiveness and enough texture to stand up to dressing. It's a year-round crop, and is sold in four-ounce bags for $5.99 at Citarella and Dean & DeLuca stores, and $4.99 at Agata & Valentina and Gourmet Garage.

title: Pataki Gets Teamsters' Support
description: Gov. George E. Pataki was endorsed in his bid for re-election by the Teamsters union yesterday, as he continued to draw an unusual amount of labor support for a Republican.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 4,000 Sign Petition In D.W.I. Case
description: Relatives of three people struck and killed by a drunken police officer presented a petition, signed by more than 4,000 people, to a judge yesterday, demanding that the officer receive the maximum time at his sentencing tomorrow, said David Galarza, a friend of the family. The officer, Joseph Gray, faces up to 15 years in prison when Justice Anne G. Feldman of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn sentences him for manslaughter in the deaths of Maria Herrera, her unborn son, her 4-year-old son and her sister. They died when Mr. Gray ran them down in Sunset Park last August after a daylong drinking binge with colleagues. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: Hingis Is Also Out Of Wimbledon
description: Martina Hingis, a former No. 1 player in the world, will not play at Wimbledon next month after ankle surgery that will require at least six weeks of rehabilitation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMITT, JULIUS HENRY
description: SCHMITT-Julius Henry, 93, of Franklin Lakes, NJ, died peacefully on Sunday, May 19, 2002. Before retiring in 1973, he was Director of Classified Advertising for The New York Times where he had worked for 50 years. He began working for The Times as an office boy at age 14 and assumed positions of increasing responsibility, contributing significantly to the growth of the newspaper. Henry Schmitt was the beloved husband of the late Margaret Schmitt (nee Hank), also an employee of The New York Times in the 1920s, who passed away in 1982. He is survived by his son Edward H. Schmitt of Glen Rock, NJ and by three daughters Ann Marie Schmitt of Franklin Lakes, Mary Ellen Kuhn of Southport, NC and Margaret L. Schmidt of Asbury, NJ. He is the grandfather of eight grandchildren and the greatgrandfather of two. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, May 22 at 9:30am at Vander Plaat Vermeulen Memorial Home in Franklin Lakes, followed at 10am by a Mass at Most Blessed Sacrament RC Church. Interment will follow immediately at Christ the King Cemetery in Franklin Lakes. Donations in his name may be made to Most Blessed Sacrament RC Church, 787 Franklin Lakes Road, Franklin Lakes, NJ 07417.

title: New School Adds a Vice President
description: SHERRY F. BRABHAM, the vice chancellor for budget, finance and administrative computing at CUNY, is moving to New School University as vice president and chief of staff to Bob Kerrey, the former Nebraska senator who is now president of the university. Ms. Brabham, 50, said that she had been chatting with JAMES MURTHA, a former CUNY colleague who is now executive vice president at New School, about wanting to try something new and that he put her in touch with Mr. Kerrey. After 18 years at CUNY, many in finance, ''I was interested in broadening out again,'' Ms. Brabham said. Karen W. Arenson

title: Clio Awards Honor DDB Worldwide
description: DDB Worldwide took top honors at the 43rd annual Clio Awards ceremonies, held this week in Miami.

title: Carnegie Names 11 Scholars
description: The Carnegie Corporation of New York has chosen 11 researchers for this year's class of Carnegie Scholars, including three from the New York area: Sharyn O'Halloran, a professor of political science and international affairs at Columbia University; Adolph Reed Jr., a professor of political science at New School University; and Ian Roxborough, a professor of sociology at the State University of New York at Stony Brook. Each scholar will get up to $100,000, for one to two years for research in the corporation's program areas, including education, international peace and security, and international development.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUWIRTH, LINDA
description: NEUWIRTH-Linda. Dear Linda, to our most treasured friend. Your intelligence, humor, insight, beauty, strength and compassion are irreplaceable. We will love, honor and remember you forever. Oursympathies to Evan and Michael for their profound loss. Love, Donna, Richard and Alexandra Khaleel

title: INSIDE
description: Cardinal May Sell Mansion

title: Cut Prison Budgets
description: To the Editor:

title: NBC to Make West Coast Executive an Adviser
description: NBC will announce today that Scott Sassa, who has led the network's West Coast division for four years, will leave that post next month to become a special adviser to the NBC chairman, Bob Wright, senior NBC executives said yesterday.

title: BORGWARNER RAISES ITS PROFIT FORECAST
description: BorgWarner Inc., a leading maker of automatic-transmission parts for cars and trucks, raised its profit forecast for the second quarter and for the year because increased car and truck demand led automakers to increase production. Earnings per share at the auto parts maker will be $1.55 to $1.65 a share this quarter and $5.50 for the year, a spokeswoman, Mary Brevard, said. The forecast exceeds the average estimate of $1.42 in the quarter and $5.11 for 2002 from analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call. Sales are expected to rise 10 percent this year, up from the previous estimate of 5 percent. BorgWarner attributed the expected gains this year to sales of parts to Volkswagen and its Audi luxury unit in Europe and more orders from the Honda Motor Company.

title: INVESTMENT FIRM IN DEAL WITH CONAGRA
description: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, the private equity firm, said late yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the fresh beef and pork processing business of ConAgra Foods for about $950 million. The business is comprised of ConAgra Meats, the third-largest processer of beef and pork; its Australia Meat Holdings unit; and its American cattle operations. Hicks, Muse will control 54 percent of the company, to be renamed Swift and Company, with its partner, Booth Creek Management, which will help manage the business. ConAgra Foods will retain 46 percent. Under the deal, Hicks, Muse and its partners will pay $800 million in cash and provide an equity stake of $150 million to ConAgra upon completion of the deal. The acquiring group will also assume about $430 million in debt. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: Dan Doerner
description: ART photographers have long fooled the eye with burning and dodging, effects that make portions of photos lighter or darker during the film development process. But with the advent of digital image editing, the 1990's produced a cottage industry of photo retouchers and compositors who altered photos for artistic or illustrative effect. Among the new crop of digital manipulators was Dan Doerner, 41, who studied photography at the State University of New York at Albany, learned literally to cut and paste images in a darkroom to create collages, and eventually worked with an early version of Adobe Photoshop in 1989 while living in Los Angeles.

title: The Celtics Control the Board, and the Nets Do Not Pass Go
description: Kenyon Martin was driving to the basket with a purpose, intent on opening up the middle of a Boston Celtics defense that had been locked like a safe. With Martin's great leaping ability and fearsome reputation, perhaps the entire crowd at the Meadowlands was thinking he could not be denied.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Loss At Phone Company
description: The former Dutch phone monopoly, Royal KPN, said it narrowed its first-quarter loss to 348 million euros ($320 million), including exceptional items, compared with a 539 million euro ($496 million) loss in the first quarter of 2001. The exceptional items included 477 million euros ($439 million) to reflect KPN's share of costs associated with KPNQwest, a joint venture with Qwest Communications International that provides high-speed Internet connections to corporations. Revenue grew 10 percent, to 3.3 billion euros ($3 billion). Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAHAMSEN, DAVID
description: ABRAHAMSEN-David. MD, On May 20, 2002 at age 98. Beloved husband of the late Lova Abrahamsen; loving father of Inger Elliott and Anne-Marie Foltz; cherished grandfather of Kari, Alec and Marit McCabe, and Peter and Jeremy Foltz; caring step-grandfather of Diana Lidowsky, Cynthia and Dorinda Elliott; proud greatgrandfather of Milo and Isobel McBride, Miranda Lee-Foltz, and Maya and Lucas McCabe. Memorial service Friday, May 24, 12:30 PM at Yale's Slifka Center for Jewish Life, 80 Wall St., New Haven, CT. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Lova Abrahamsen Scholarship Fund, Yale University, PO Box 2038, New Haven, CT 06521-2038.

title: Mets Return to the East Coast, but Leave Their Bats Behind
description: David Weathers fell into a crouch and stared down, picking away at the artificial turf in front of the mound at Veterans Stadium. He didn't need to see Pat Burrell's drive to left field bounce off the scoreboard above the Mets' bullpen to know the night was ruined.

title: Transportation Security Chief Says He Opposes Pilots' Carrying Guns Aboard Planes
description: The government's transportation security chief said today that he would not allow airline pilots to carry guns, and that if someone tried to hijack a plane, the pilots should try to land, or perhaps maneuver the plane to knock the hijackers off balance.

title: Saks Reports $25.4 Million Quarterly Loss
description: Saks Inc. had a first-quarter net loss of $25.4 million as it wrote down the value of its Saks Fifth Avenue chain of department stores.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Music Group Posts Loss
description: The EMI Group reported an operating loss of 101 million ($147.3 million), including exceptional items, for the year ended March 31, in contrast to a profit of 237.5 million ($346 million) in 2001. Revenue declined 8.4 percent, to 2.4 billion ($3.5 billion). The company, whose artists include Janet Jackson and Radiohead, whose lead singer is Thom Yorke, left, has experienced a string of setbacks at its recorded music division. Under Alain Levy, the new chief executive of EMI Recorded Music, the company has restructured its operations, eliminated nearly a fifth of its work force, and dropped Mariah Carey, after ''Glitter,'' the album and the movie, generated disappointing sales. EMI Recorded Music sales fell 11.1 percent, to 2 billion ($2.9 billion), and operating profit declined 63.5 percent, to 83.1 million ($121 million), the company said. EMI's global market share of recorded music fell 0.7 percent, EMI said. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Bosnia: Slain Reporter Honored
description: A street in Sarajevo was named after Kurt Schork, the Reuters reporter who covered the siege of Bosnia's capital during the 1992-95 war. Mr. Schork was killed in an ambush in Sierra Leone in May 2000, and part of his ashes are buried in a cemetery in Sarajevo. The new Kurt Schork Street connects the airport to the boulevard once known as Sniper Alley, where Serbian snipers shot at the people of Sarajevo during the siege. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: THE NETHERLANDS: A MILLION VOTES FOR DEAD MAN Pim Fortuyn, the maverick anti-immigrant politician who was shot to death nine days before last week's parliamentary elections, personally got more than 1.3 million votes  more than 14 percent of the total, final results showed. Under the Dutch system of proportional representation, a vote for an individual candidate is also a vote for the party, and Mr. Fortuyn's party  List Pim Fortuyn  finished second with 26 seats behind the Christian Democrats, who won 43. The People's Party for Freedom and Democracy was third with 24 seats and the Labor Party had 23. (Agence France-Presse)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about former Gov. Christie Whitman's absence from New Jersey politics since her appointment to head the Environmental Protection Agency misstated the year she first came to prominence by nearly unseating Senator Bill Bradley. It was 1990, not 1992.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Montana: Governor Curbs News Interviews
description: Gov. Judy Martz will no longer grant interviews to some beat reporters in Helena, even though just three news agencies regularly report on her. Speaking last week to a group from the timber industry, Ms. Martz said certain reporters were writing misleading articles about her, although she did not identify them. Last month, she asked that some news agencies submit written questions in advance. The Associated Press, citing its guidelines, refused to comply. Other news organizations have said they have no choice but to comply. Timothy Egan (NYT)

title: San Diego's High-Rise Slump Lingers
description: After 10 years without any high-rise office construction, this city's dormant downtown market showed signs of life last year. Two developers, using almost identical language, announced plans to build the first Class A office towers in San Diego in a decade.

title: Professor Gould's Gift
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUCK, TEMI
description: GLUCK-Temi. On May 21, 2002. Devoted mother of Joseph; mother-in-law of Mary and grandmother of Theodore, Rio and Daria. She will be remembered and enormously missed by all for her generous spirit and loving friendship. Memorial services Thursday 5pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: President To Study Rights Report
description: President Olusegun Obasanjo said he would look ''clinically'' at the findings and recommendations in a report submitted to him by a panel that has been investigating three decades of human rights abuses. The panel, headed by a former Supreme Court judge, Chukwudifu Oputa, recommended compensating victims of abuses from the first military coup in 1966 to the start of civilian rule in 1999. Mr. Obsanjo said: ''To me, the spirit of forgiveness is what we need now, not compensation. Money is not the answer.'' Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: 2 Retailers' Earnings Are Up
description: Two big retailers, Home Depot Inc. and the Target Corporation, said yesterday that their quarterly earnings rose as the companies reined in expenses and kept inventory levels low.

title: Nets Viewers May Lose Out
description: When the Nets start the 2002-3 season next fall, their games will in all likelihood be carried by the YES Network. By then, the Nets could be the defending champions of the National Basketball Association's Eastern Conference, or even of the whole league.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRENSAL, BEVERLY (NEE ABRAMOWITZ)
description: EHRENSAL-Beverly (nee Abramowitz). On May 19, 2002, from Boca Raton, FL, formerly of The Bronx, after a long illness. Survived by a son Kenneth Ehrensal. Funeral arrangements private.

title: Mexico City Gridlock
description: To the Editor:

title: Women, Children and That Book
description: To the Editor:

title: Brinkmanship in South Asia
description: India and Pakistan are once again firing shells and threats at each other. With a million troops along the border, there is also talk again of war. The United States needs to move quickly to persuade the two sides to pull back from what could slip into a nuclear confrontation.

title: Bono on the Road: Old Tune, New Duo
description: Ghana is Stop 1 on the Paul O'Neill-Bono Africa Tour 2002, nearly two weeks of fact-finding travel across the world's most ravaged continent by the well-starched former corporate chief executive who signs the dollar bill and the earring-laden, Grammy-collecting lead singer of U2.

title: Technology Briefing: Internet
description: CMGI SCALES BACK ITS FORECAST The once- highflying Internet incubator, CMGI Inc., said yesterday that its financial results would be lower than previously expected and that it would buy the 25 percent of the Internet marketing firm Engage Technologies that it did not already own. CMGI, which has posted losses in 10 consecutive quarters, now expects to report a pro forma operating loss of $54 million, up from a previous forecast of $32 million to $37 million. "We are not satisfied with the results for the third quarter," said George McMillan, chief of CMGI, in a statement. "We are taking immediate and decisive actions to remedy the major contributing factors." Shares in CMGI, which once traded as high as $163, ended yesterday at 92 cents, down 12.3 percent. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: DuPont Trial Wraps Up With Clashing Views Over Pollution
description: The jury hearing a lawsuit over the DuPont Company's shuttered explosives plant in nearby Pompton Lakes heard sharply conflicting arguments today about whether pollution from the plant caused residents' illnesses.

title: As Terror Fever Rises in America
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Court Strikes Down State Kosher  Laws
description: New York State's kosher food laws are unconstitutional, a federal appeals court panel ruled yesterday. The decision affirms a lower court ruling appealed by Gov. George E. Pataki. A call to Mr. Pataki's office was not returned last night. Under the kosher laws, state inspectors would visit restaurants and markets to ensure kosher conformity, with possible criminal prosecution if intentional deception was charged. But a kosher butcher shop on Long Island sued in 1996, saying the laws violated the rights of non-Orthodox Jews who have different kosher standards. Yesterday, Judges Roger J. Miner, Pierre N. Leval and Rosemary S. Pooler ruled that the kosher laws ''excessively entangle the State of New York and religion.'' Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, SYLVIA (NEE LEVINE)
description: FRIEDMAN-Sylvia (nee Levine). Wife of Sol, mother of Eileen Weinberg and Ronnie FriedmanBarone. Grandmother of Jason, Lara and Dimitry. Mother-in-law of Fred Weinberg and Joseph Barone. Services Thursday, 10:45AM, ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows. Shiva, Thursday and Friday at the home of Sue and Sam Friedman. Donations to Dr. Holland at Memorial Sloan-Kettering, 1242 Second Ave., NY, NY 10021, Gift of Life Adoption, 1053 Park Ave., Cranston, RI 02910. These donations honor Eileen and Dimitry. In doing so they honor her. For information call ''Sinai Chapels'', 1800-446-0406

title: Recipe: Kaipen With Jaew Bong Dip
description: Time: 30 minutes

title: Queens Travel Writer Who Vanished in Jamaica Is Declared Dead
description: A travel writer who lived in Queens before she vanished during a trip to Jamaica two years ago has been declared dead by a New Jersey judge who concluded that ''some kind of foul play occurred.''

title: Settlement Is a Good Deal for Merrill. How About Investors?
description: In its settlement agreement with Eliot L. Spitzer, the New York attorney general, Merrill Lynch has clearly won a fine deal for itself. But it remains to be seen whether a result will be as big a victory for investors looking to Merrill's research analysts for straight talk on stocks.

title: Oranges in Blackberry Sauce
description: Citrus slices are the star of this simple but immensely satisfying dessert that combines the tanginess of orange with the sweetness of blackberry. Any moderately acidic berry (raspberry or blueberry for example) can be substituted. The sauce can be prepared several days ahead, frozen (like a sherbert), and then melted.

title: City Scorns Report on Water Supply Safety
description: The Bloomberg administration yesterday dismissed a report by a state legislative committee that said the city had failed to protect its water supplies since Sept. 11.

title: Big Scoops in Brooklyn And the East Village
description: What's your taste in ice cream? If it runs to classic old-fashioned flavors, then what Mark Thompson makes for the Brooklyn Ice Cream Factory (above), in a landmark fireboat house on a pier in the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge, is for you. Chocolate, vanilla, butter pecan, strawberry and a few others ($3 for two scoops) are made without eggs. One innovation is hot caramel sauce, made by Ellen Sternau, pastry chef at the River Caf next door. This weekend, Mr. Thompson's ice creams and some sorbets will also be sold from a shed at the end of the pier.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Reserves Tapped For Debt
description: With a deadline today to make the first installment on repayment of a $2.5 billion loan from the World Bank, the Ministry of the Economy has elected to dip into Argentina's foreign reserves. The reserves, which have fallen nearly 20 percent this year, to about $11.7 billion, are currently at their lowest level in more than seven years. The government made the decision to use almost $800 million in reserves, rather than default on the loan and be denied further credits, only after the United States and the International Monetary Fund strongly urged President Eduardo Duhalde to abandon an earlier plan to ask neighboring countries for a bridge loan to make the payment. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREUND, CHARMIAN KAPLAN
description: FREUND-Charmian Kaplan, of New York, died on Tuesday after a long illness. Loving wife of 56 years to Dr. Seelig Freund, a surgeon at Beth Israel Hospital, she is survived by her husband; children, Deborah and John; and three devoted grandsons, Alexander & Nicholas Freund of Atherton, CA, and Willie Kniesner of Syracuse. She was a former fund chairman of the United Hospital Fund, and daughter of Louis and Minerva Kaplan of Trenton, New Jersey; Mr. Kaplan was the architect of the Soldiers and Sailors War Memorial in Trenton. Visiting hours at home between 6 pm and 9 pm on Thursday, May 23. Private funeral. Memorial service on Wednesday, July 17, at 5:30 pm, at a place to be determined.

title: PFIZER EPILEPSY DRUG EASES ANXIETY, STUDY SHOWS
description: An experimental epilepsy drug by Pfizer eased anxiety more quickly than the anti-anxiety medicine Xanax by Pharmacia and the Effexor antidepressant from Wyeth without the same side effects, research showed. Pfizer's pregabalin also is as effective as Effexor and Xanax, according to studies presented at the American Psychiatric Association conference in Philadelphia. Pfizer plans to file an application by the end of the year for Food and Drug Administration approval of pregabalin for use in treating generalized anxiety disorder, nerve pain and epilepsy.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Judges Want Courthouse Gun Ban
description: Setting up a legal fight between two state government branches, a board that represents the 70 district judges in the state has voted to ignore a new law that orders all courthouses to install storage lockers for people with permits for concealed weapons who wish to take guns into the buildings. The Board of District Judges voted to continue a policy of barring guns in courthouses, prompting Attorney General Mark Shurtleff to insist that judges obey the law or possibly face a suit. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Ending Bias in the Human Rights System
description: Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general, is searching for a new high commissioner for human rights to replace Mary Robinson, whose term expires at the end of the summer. In naming a new commissioner, he needs first to recognize the office's flaws and then to look for a leader who can address them and seize the office's opportunities.

title: Kings Counter Laker Size With Backcourt Sizzle
description: The lan and grace were gone. It was just Mike Bibby and a once-fluid offense, stalled, 24 feet from the basket, purple silhouettes of much larger men waiting for him in the middle.

title: Ailing Pope Visits Azerbaijan
description: BAKU, Azerbaijan, May 22  On his first foreign trip since sexual-abuse scandals wracked the Roman Catholic Church, Pope John Paul II arrived today in this battle-scarred former Soviet republic and vowed to continue his peace-seeking missions "as long as I have breath within me."

title: Women, Children and That Book
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, RICHARD S.
description: CLARK-Richard S. On May 18, 2002. The partners and staff of Dorsey & Whitney LLP mourn the sudden passing of our partner and colleague, Rick Clark. Rick was a leading member of the patent bar. He headed the patent practice of our New York office and was widely respected for his professionalism, great skill and unfailing courtesy. Our deepest condolences to his family; he will be missed. Dorsey & Whitney LLP

title: University Announces Ban on Fraternities and Sororities
description: Benjamin Klein was a 21-year-old junior from Putney, Vt., majoring in economics at Alfred University in western New York State. He sang, he was the principal second violinist in the university orchestra, and was a member of one of the university's eight fraternities, Zeta Beta Tau. In February, his body was found in a creek behind the town post office. The university suspended his fraternity as it looked into reports that fraternity brothers had beaten him.

title: Grapefruit Gratin
description: Gratin is a French term that refers to any dish covered with breadcrumbs, cheese or sugar and broiled to create a crust. Here, the broiling, which should be done just before serving to ensure a warm and toasty product, mellows the grapefruit's natural bitterness, while creating a soft, sweet crust from the buttery brown sugar.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Merrill Lynch in Agreement On $100 Million Settlement

title: Recipe: Tarragon Chicken
description: Adapted from Nigella Lawson

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: LEADER URGES CALM FOR WORLD CUP President Kim Dae Jung called for a moratorium on strikes and political infighting from now through the end of the World Cup soccer finals on June 30. The tournament, which begins on May 31, will be held in South Korea and Japan. Labor Minister Bang Yong Seok warned that a strike by metal and chemical workers called for today would hurt the country's image. With a presidential election in December, the opposition Grand National Party hopes to capitalize on political scandals.

title: Women, Children and That Book
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, ROBERT
description: FISHMAN-Robert. Of Irvington, NY on May 20, 2002. Loving husband of the late Lillian. Devoted father of Sylvia. Caring uncle of Emanuel Fishman and Sylvia Rubin. Retired after 35 years with the IRS in New York. Funeral today (Wednesday) 1:00PM EdwardsDowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue (exit 17 Saw Mill) Dobbs Ferry, NY. Memorials to U.J.A., 130 E. 59th St., NY, NY 10022 or Scholarship and Welfare Fund @ Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue, NY, NY 10021.

title: Report Finds Disparities In Hiring At U.S. Labs
description: An investigation by the General Accounting Office has found racial and sexual disparities in employment at the nation's weapons laboratories.

title: FAIRCHILD DORNIER ALLOWED TO SHIFT BANKRUPTCY FILING
description: The Fairchild Dornier Corporation was granted permission by a federal bankruptcy judge to switch its bankruptcy proceedings from Chapter 7, which calls for liquidation, to Chapter 11, which allows for a reorganization. Fairchild Dornier's German parent, Fairchild Dornier G.m.b.H. sought protection from creditors in Germany on April 2 after amassing more than $670 million in debt. On April 25, 12 former employees filed an involuntary Chapter 7 bankruptcy petition against the company's United States unit in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Alexandria, Va. Fairchild Dornier, a maker of regional jets, had earlier laid off 500 of its 700 workers in the United States. Judge Stephen S. Mitchell granted Fairchild Dornier's request to convert the Chapter 7 case to a voluntary Chapter 11 reorganization on Monday.

title: Silver Says Bloomberg Hinders School Deal
description: Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver accused Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday of crippling his own effort to win control of the New York City school system by asking the Republican-controlled State Senate to approve a plan that Assembly Democrats oppose.

title: A New York Official Who Harnessed Public Anger
description: Few people in New York politics knew what to expect of Eliot L. Spitzer when he won a razor-thin victory over the Republican state attorney general in 1998. He was a little-known former prosecutor who had financed much of his campaign with family money, and was criticized for it during the race.

title: A Gentle Embrace For Your Food
description: Slide these handsome flat tongs under a slab of fish in the broiler, slices of eggplant on the grill or a grilled cheese sandwich in the pan, and turning those foods becomes effortless. The design makes the tool work more like a double spatula than traditional tongs, which merely grasp without cradling. Easily mistaken for a whisk, they can also be used for serving. A button on the handle allows them to be locked together for storage. Made by Kuhn-Rikon, these brushed stainless steel tongs are $19.95 at Broadway Panhandler, 477 Broome Street (Wooster Street).

title: Recipe: Pasta Nioise
description: Adapted from Nigella Lawson

title: Technology Briefing | Software: S.E.C. Files Fraud Charges
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that it filed charges against former executives at three Northern California software companies accusing them of accounting fraud. The complaints filed in federal court in San Francisco named the former chief executive of Quintus, the former chief executive and chief financial officers of Unify and former senior sales executives of Legato Systems. In addition, the United States attorney's office for Northern California announced criminal charges of fraudulent business practices Monday against former officials at Quintus and Unify. Helane L. Morrison, administrator for the S.E.C. in San Francisco, said the executives forged contracts, purchase orders and other documents to increase revenue falsely.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Jobless Rate Rises
description: Hong Kong's jobless rate rose to a record in April as falling demand prompted companies to reduce costs by cutting workers. Unemployment rose to 7.1 percent last month from 7 percent in March, the government Census and Statistics Department said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROPPOLO, JONATHAN
description: ROPPOLO-Jonathan. January 12, 1966-May 14, 2002. Beloved son of Steve and Sondra, loving brother and brother-in-law of Peter and Barbara, cherished uncle, nephew and cousin. A friend to many, a hero to all. Burial held at Pinelawn Cemetery on May 16, 2002.

title: Orlando Hernndez Is Placed on the D.L.
description: The Yankees placed the right-hander Orlando Hernndez on the disabled list last night after a magnetic resonance imaging test revealed a strained upper back. David Wells had the same test and was found to have a strained lower back, but he is tentatively scheduled to pitch on Saturday in Boston.

title: Hip-Hop at Home With a Funky Live Band
description: It's still a happy novelty to see rappers backed up by a live band. The notion of rappers backed up by a live band that can replicate studio-made programming is better still: it forces musicians to play in ways that don't come naturally. title: Seeing Forsberg, Thinking of Payton

Like Payton challenging a linebacker, Forsberg sometimes initiates contact and delivers the blow. Like Payton, he sometimes changes tactics and darts around a defender to create offensive opportunities for himself or his teammates. Like Payton, he makes nervous pursuers lunge out of position and fall.

No one minds sitting on an upended laundry basket if the sun is shining; the chicken, split and roasted with tarragon, has a summer-meadow freshness; and the wine is cold. Come late spring, I find it's all too easy to discover that I've invited every other person I know, and their children, to Saturday lunch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIRINSKY, RICHARD W. SR.
description: ZIRINSKY-Richard W. Sr. 86, died suddenly in South Hampton, Saturday, May 18. He was a lifelong resident of New York City, where for more than fifty years, he was a prominent and highly respected real estate owner, builder and developer. He was also a most beloved husband, father, brother and grandfather. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Cynthia Zirinsky, a daughter, Susan Zirinsky of New York City, and a son, Richard W. Zirinsky Jr. of Sag Harbor, NY. His daughter Barbara Faden predeceased him. He also has two grandchildren, Cynthia Deutsch and Zoe Peyronnin, both of New York City. One brother Daniel Zirinsky surives him. His brother Ralph Zirinsky and his sister Betty Zirinsky predeceased him. Richard Zirinsky was born on October 20, 1915, in Brooklyn, NY. He graduated from Syracuse University in 1938 with a degree in business administration. He was a member of the Sigma Alpha Mu Fraternity. In WWII he served in the United States Navy, rising to the rank of Lieutenant J.G. and served in the Pacific on the USS Edwards as a communications officer. Following the war he, his brothers and a cousin, the late Lawrence Zirinsky, invested and built numerous industrial real estate properties in Brooklyn and Long Island City. In 1959, Richard and Lawrence teamed up to build Gracie Square Hospital in New York City, one of the largest private psychiatric hospitals in the United States. He later became the sole owner and ran the hospital with his wife until 1992, when New York Hospital acquired it. Richard was also a Trustee of the New York Institute of Technology, Old Westbury, NY, where he played a major role in that school's exspansion and received an honorary doctoral degree. He served on the Board of the Kildonan School for Dyslexic Children and he was on the Board of the Parkinson Disease Foundation at New York's Prestyberian Hospital. Visitation will be Tuesday, May 21, from 7-9 PM, at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 81st St and Madison Ave, in New York City. The funeral service will take place at 11 AM, Wednesday, May 22, at Temple Emanu-El at 5th Avenue and 65th St, NY, NY. The burial will follow at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Donations in his name can be made to The Barbara Zirinsky Fund at Beth Israel Hospital, NY, NY 10003; or the Parkinson Disease Foundation, New York Presbyterian Hospital, NY, NY 10032.

description: A committee that will help decide the future of the World Trade Center site will re-evaluate the top two proposals for the lead planning contract on the project. The decision comes after questions were raised about the process to recommend a winner, officials involved in the redevelopment effort said yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Lawsuit Over Apartment Murder
description: The survivors of a man who was killed in an attempt to steal his city-owned apartment last year filed a federal civil rights lawsuit against the city, its housing authority and the Police Department yesterday. Lawyers for the family of the dead man, Jerry Pollard, 49, said the killer had confessed to a role in a killing in the same building two days before, but had been released. Last year the man, Bernard Perez, 21, confessed to killing Mr. Pollard and Doris Drakeford, who lived two floors apart at the Dyckman Houses in Washington Heights, to steal their apartments, the police said. A city spokeswoman said its lawyers had not yet read the suit. The Police Department and the Bronx district attorney's office, also named in the suit, declined to comment yesterday. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

We have serious concerns about Judge Smith's interpretation of the Constitution, his fairness in employment discrimination and other cases against large companies, and his judicial ethics. We urge the committee to reject his nomination.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Yonkers: Mislabeled 'Salt' Led To Illness
description: The six people who were hospitalized in Yonkers last Thursday after eating contaminated food had ingested a large quantity of sodium nitrite, a food preservative, that was mistaken for table salt and added to a stew, the police said yesterday. One person remained in St. Joseph's Medical Center yesterday in stable condition. The guest who brought the sodium nitrite to the dinner party got it from the apartment of a friend who had recently moved. The friend, who cured meats and had stored the sodium nitrite in a bag labeled ''table salt,'' asked her to clean out his residence and to take what she wanted. Lisa W. Foderaro (NYT)

The trips will feature nature walks, snorkeling and Zodiac excursions. The longer sailing also stops at North Seymour Island to see blue-footed boobies and at James Island, with its fur seals and marine iguanas. Prices include all meals, sightseeing and airport transfers; air fare from Ecuador to the cruise and entrance fees to the Galapagos National Park are extra. Call (800) 527-2500 or visit www.metropolitan-touring.com .

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Vodafone Considers Write-Offs
description: The Vodafone Group said it would provide more details on whether it would write down the value of some recent acquisitions, including the April 2000 purchase of Mannesmann for $168 billion, when it reports earnings for 2002 next Tuesday. A spokesman said the company, in accordance with British accounting rules, was conducting a review to determine whether the value of the businesses was accurately reflected in financial statements. Vodafone's market valuation has eroded over the last year, as investors have become concerned about the industry's growth rates. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Zero Rate Unchanged
description: The Bank of Japan left its zero-interest-rate policy intact at its two-day board meeting that ended yesterday. With the economy showing signs of life, the bank has been under less pressure to ease monetary conditions. The bank has already driven short-term rates to near zero and it renewed its pledge to keep a surplus of up to 15 trillion yen ($119 billion) in the money markets and buy 1 trillion yen ($7.9 billion) in government bonds. Ken Belson (NYT)

description: The Librarian of Congress rejected proposed royalty rates that would have required Internet music broadcasters to pay record labels and performers a flat fee for each song they delivered online, the Copyright Office said yesterday. Internet broadcasters had argued that the proposed rates would force large numbers of them out of business. The recording industry requested higher rates. James H. Billington, the librarian, gave no explanation for his decision. He has until June 20 to make a final ruling on what fees will be imposed on Internet broadcasts. Amy Harmon (NYT)

description: For the jury, it has come down to a simple question. Either Bobby Frank Cherry hated black people so much that he was willing to plant a bomb in a church on a Sunday morning, or he was just like almost everybody else.

title: Leaving for Europe, Bush Draws On Hard Lessons of Diplomacy
description: President Bush leaves early Wednesday morning for Europe, where he is almost certain to be greeted by demonstrators who believe him a bully and by allies in the campaign against terrorism who are increasingly unhappy about everything from steel tariffs to his determination to topple Saddam Hussein.

title: Nets' Fan Favorite Who Isn't Named Kidd
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 21  As the lights rose after player introductions Sunday, the sellout crowd at Continental Arena still standing and cheering, cameras panned around the stands to find the various signs. There was the obligatory "Kidd Is the M.V.P." and one saying "Nets Beat Celtics," with the first letter of each word color-coded to catch the eye of the people working on the NBC telecast.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Governor's Adviser In Bribery Case
description: Three men, including an adviser to Gov. George Ryan, were indicted as part of a four-year investigation into corruption in the secretary of state's office. Federal prosecutors accuse Lawrence E. Warner of Chicago, an executive who is in Mr. Ryan's kitchen cabinet, of receiving $2.8 million and funneling money to others in exchange for arranging contracts. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Anthrax Scare at Bank; Lie Tests at Army Labs
description: Still looking for clues about who sent deadly anthrax through the mail last year, federal investigators plan to give lie detector tests to workers at two Army laboratories that handle anthrax, a spokeswoman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: KOHL'S PLANS TO INCREASE NUMBER OF STORES BY 27%
description: The Kohl's Corporation plans to open 112 department stores from the third quarter through next year, expanding by 27 percent, to enter new markets. Kohl's, which has opened 38 stores already this year, plans to add 32 in the third quarter and another 80 next year, the company said. The expansion allows Kohl's to enter markets in Boston; Houston; Phoenix; Las Vegas; Nashville; Providence, R.I.; and Southern California.

title: A 20th-Century Gloss on 19th-Century Ideas
description: It is easy to forget that Tchaikovsky wrote only three ballet scores: ''Swan Lake,'' ''The Sleeping Beauty'' and ''The Nutcracker.'' American Ballet Theater draws heavily on excerpts from these 19th-century ballets in the program it is presenting this season as ''Tchaikovsky Spectacular.'' Yet each of these mixed bills also hints at the range of nonballet music by Tchaikovsky that attracted major 20th-century choreographers.

title: Good Deal for Merrill. How About Investors?; Settlement May Not Easily Change A Culture that Created Conflicts
description: In its settlement agreement with Eliot L. Spitzer, the New York attorney general, Merrill Lynch has clearly won a fine deal for itself. But it remains to be seen whether a result will be as big a victory for investors looking to Merrill's research analysts for straight talk on stocks.

description: Despite the economic boom during most of the decade, Connecticut's median household income fell slightly between 1990 and 2000, according to Census data released today.

title: Library Overhaul in Doubt
description: Two years after the Robin Hood Foundation offered to help overhaul the city's 656 elementary school libraries, the project is under way, with the first 10 renovations almost complete and 20 more in the works. The Board of Education has earmarked $28 million for the first 30 renovations, including $7 million from Robin Hood, $5 million from the mayor's office and $16 million from its own coffers. But the city's budget crisis has put the project's future in doubt. LONNI TANNER, the foundation's director of special projects, said the first 30 redesigns would at least provide a blueprint for a larger-scale project. Part of the money is helping the librarians at each of the 30 schools get master's degrees in library science from Syracuse University.

title: How Broadway Bounced Back After 9/11; But Downtown Theater Lacked the Right Ties
description: These are healthy days for Broadway. The box office recently set records for several weeks in a row. The season is at its height. And competition over Tony Awards promises to draw even more money into producers' coffers.

title: Martin Wants To Finish As a Jet
description: Jets running back Curtis Martin said today that he planned to play for five or six more years, and he hoped they would be for the Jets. Martin has two years remaining on his contract, but the team was seeking to extend the deal to gain salary-cap relief. If Martin were to play out the two years, he would count for more than $20 million against the cap in the two seasons combined.

title: On Tape, Skakel Describes Being on Moxley Property on Night of the Killing
description: State prosecutors concluded their case against Michael C. Skakel today by playing an audiotape in which Mr. Skakel vividly recounted his activities on the night that Martha Moxley was bludgeoned to death in 1975. On the tape, Mr. Skakel said he was in a tree on the Moxley property that night but then ran home, afraid of the dark.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Council Approves Disputed Firehouse Plan
description: The City Council voted yesterday to proceed with a disputed Fire Department plan to move two companies about half a mile east from their dilapidated quarters on Rockaway Beach Boulevard to a new building that would also house Emergency Medical Service workers who also need new space. The plan was approved by a vote of 44 to 3 with one abstention. The firefighters' union charges that response time will be slowed, but some City Council officials suggest that the predominantly white male firefighters are resisting working with E.M.S. workers, nearly half of whom are ethnic minorities and women. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on May 16 about John Sharnik, a documentary producer and vice president of CBS News, misidentified some survivors and omitted others. His widow is the former Barbara Busse, not Barbara Busse Jones. Other survivors include Bronwyn Dunne of Washington and Pamela Jones of Hartsdale, N.Y., who are his stepdaughters, not his daughters; two sisters, Katherine Hoffman and Suzy Fromm; a brother, Mort Sharnik; three grandchildren; and four great-grandchildren. The obituary also omitted part of his work history. Before joining CBS, he was at The Hartford Times and The New York Times.

title: Merrill Lynch to Pay $100 Million to Settle Analyst Charges
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it would pay $100 million in penalties to New York and other states and change the way it pays stock analysts to end an investigation that its chairman said had damaged the firm's reputation.

title: Daschle Is Seeking a Special Inquiry on Sept. 11 Attacks
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  Headed for a confrontation with the White House and Congressional Republicans, the majority leader of the Democratic-controlled Senate renewed his call today for an independent commission to investigate government action before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Delay In Barbecue Ban
description: State parks and recreation officials in Orange County may have acted too soon to smother bonfires at state beaches. After learning that authorities in the county planned to close 800 beach fire pits because of budget cuts, officials in Sacramento halted the move. ''It's a very popular practice,'' a parks department spokesman, Steve Capps, said in Sacramento. ''I'm told it's unlikely it will happen, but still possible.'' Mr. Capps said a decision would not be made until the state budget had been finalized. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)
