Ships from the Navy's Atlantic Fleet as well as from the United States Coast Guard, Canada and Denmark will be open to the public at piers in Manhattan and Staten Island. Here are some of the 21 ships participating.

title: ICAHN OFFERS $13.50 A SHARE FOR MORTON'S GROUP
description: The billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn offered the shareholders of Morton's Restaurant Group $13.50 a share in a bid to gain control of the company. The offer was in a letter sent yesterday to Morton's board. The letter was included in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. At $13.50 a share, Mr. Icahn said, his proposal is 90 cents more per share than an offer of $12.60 a share, or $52.8 million, from Castle Harlan Inc. Castle Harlan, a private investment firm based in New York, owned Morton's until the chain went public in 1992 at $10 a share. Mr. Icahn reported a 6.9 percent stake in Morton's earlier this month. Morton's said in a March 14 statement that it had about 4.19 million shares outstanding. That would place Icahn's offer at $56.6 million.

title: Anti-U.S. Views at Pilot Schools Prompted Agent's Alert
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  At a closed-door Congressional hearing, an F.B.I. agent from Phoenix said today that he wrote a memorandum last July about a potential terrorist plot after conducting several interviews with Arab flight school students who expressed extreme animosity toward the United States, lawmakers said today.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: World Online Underwriters Cleared
description: Authorities in Amsterdam cleared ABN Amro Holding and Goldman, Sachs of any wrongdoing in underwriting the initial public offering of World Online International, the Internet service provider that collapsed nine months after a $2.5 billion share sale. Prosecutors determined that the two banks managing the share sale in March 2000 did not misuse privileged information or publish a misleading prospectus, said Robert Meulenbroek, a spokesman for the prosecutor's office.

title: U.S.-Led Panel Condemns Sudan for Allowing Slavery to Flourish
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan, May 22  An international commission led by the United States strongly condemned the Sudanese government today for allowing slavery to flourish in this war-wracked country.

title: Grilled Hams the Size Of Manhole Covers
description: The new Tuscan grilled hams at Agata & Valentina are so large they have to be cut in half to fit in the slicer. ''I've never seen hams this big, 32 pounds,'' Louis Balducci, an owner, said. ''I can't imagine what they feed these pigs.'' The pale rose meat, encased in creamy fat and with grill marks on the outside, is exquisitely moist, with a lavender fragrance and a nut-sweet flavor thanks to an infusion of rosemary, pepper and garlic. All a sandwich needs is a light lashing of good mustard or soft butter. The ham is $11.99 a pound at Agata & Valentina, 1505 First Avenue (79th Street) and at Grace's Marketplace, 1237 Third Avenue (71st Street).

title: A Taste of Alaska, in a Jar
description: THAT din you hear each May is the sound of salmon lovers awaiting their first taste of wild Copper River salmon, caught in the Alaskan waters where the fish return annually to spawn. The season is short, the catch is small, and long before you've had your fill, the wait until next year has begun.

title: Piazza Responds to Gossip Column
description: Responding to a gossip column on Monday that referred to ''a persistent rumor around town'' about a gay star player for the Mets, Mike Piazza felt compelled to hold an impromptu news conference today on the field at Veterans Stadium to discuss his sexuality.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the appointment of Lawrence F. Davenport as executive director of Hale House, the Harlem charity, referred incorrectly to the Milton Hershey School, in Hershey, Pa., where he worked from 1994 to 2000. It has been coeducational since 1976; it is not limited to boys. Its students come from low-income or troubled families; it does not admit children with serious emotional and behavioral problems.

title: Japan and South Korea Prepare for the Worst
description: One million soccer fans are expected to visit Japan and South Korea for the coming World Cup, which for the first time is being played in Asia and has two countries as hosts. But the monthlong event, which garners the largest television audience in the world, may also be remembered as the first in which security gets top billing. In fact, the hosts are not sure whether to roll out or roll up the welcome mat.

title: Slain Girl Used Internet To Seek Sex, Police Say
description: By day, she was Christina Long, a 13-year-old altar girl and a co-captain of the cheerleading team at St. Peter Roman Catholic School in Danbury, Conn., where the principal said she was ''a good student and well behaved.''

title: Study Notes Unbelted Teenagers
description: Barely half of teenagers use seat belts even when their parents are driving them to school, a survey at 12 New England high schools has found.

title: Law Professors Express Concern Over Pending Bankruptcy Bill
description: Dozens of law professors who are among the nation's leading bankruptcy specialists have told Congress that a pending bill to overhaul the bankruptcy system will lead to ''new headlines and new scandal'' because it will continue to permit high-income debtors to shield multimillion-dollar houses from creditors.

title: A nonprofit group is bringing large advertisers and ethnic newspapers together to benefit both.
description: NEWSSTANDS in New York are filled with ethnic newspapers, though many casual browsers never give them a second glance. These newspapers, with a small but loyal group of readers, compete with the more prominent newspapers and an abundance of national magazines for scarce display space and the fleeting attention of passers-by.

title: Letter Says Labor Deal Was Never Very Close
description: As negotiations between baseball club owners and players for a new labor contract remain stalemated, debate continues to boil over the fallout from secret talks the two sides held during a three-month period in the first half of last year.

title: National Briefing | West: California: No-Bid State Contracts
description: Gov. Gray Davis has ordered officials not to sign contracts of more than $100,000 unless they have been competitively bid. Regulations now let the state sign contracts without bidding in certain instances. The governor's order responds to reports that a technology official received a $25,000 contribution for Mr. Davis's campaign from Oracle shortly after the state and the software corporation signed a no-bid $95 million contract that auditors have called overpriced and unneeded. The governor said the ban on no-bid contracts was needed while the state developed new conflict-of-interest regulations. James Sterngold (NYT)

title: Hornets Leave, But the Sting Stays
description: The Charlotte Hornets of the National Basketball Association will be moving to New Orleans this summer, but the Charlotte Sting of the Women's National Basketball Association plans to stick around.

title: $100 MILLION FINE FOR MERRILL LYNCH
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it would pay $100 million in penalties to New York and other states and change the way it pays stock analysts to end an investigation that its chairman said had damaged the firm's reputation.

title: Cuba On My Mind
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Slide Show: More Summer Gifts
A Hideaway With a Latin Touch
description: David Rockwell's windowless space has become Noche, a restaurant and nightclub opening next month.

title: 2002 ICFF
Andy Warhol
Oil Company In Russia Cancels Deal
description: In a curious turn of events that raised more questions than it answered, a major Russian energy company, Tyumen Oil, canceled a half-billion-dollar bond sale after its auditor, PricewaterhouseCoopers, implied that it had made an accounting error in the company's books.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: 2 Indicted In Immigrant Smuggling
description: Two Egyptian men have been accused of attempting to smuggle family members and others through Brazil, Guatemala and Mexico, then into the United States. The men, Adel R. Nasr, 22, of Hamilton, N.J., and his brother, Gamal Abdalgalil Nasr, 22, of Queens, provided immigrants with smuggler contacts in foreign countries, according to court documents. The immigrants, many of whom came from Bata, Egypt, had paid $8,000 apiece. Neither of the Nasr brothers could be reached for comment yesterday. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: My Summer Vacation: Pictures With Soundtrack
description: Q. How can I make a slide show of my photographs that can be recorded onto compact disc with background music?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAHAMSEN, DAVID
description: ABRAHAMSEN-David. MD, On May 20, 2002 at age 98. Beloved husband of the late Lova Abrahamsen; loving father of Inger Elliott and Anne-Marie Foltz; cherished grandfather of Kari, Alec and Marit McCabe, and Peter and Jeremy Foltz; caring step-grandfather of Diana Lidowsky, Cynthia and Dorinda Elliott; proud greatgrandfather of Milo and Isobel McBride, Miranda Lee-Foltz, and Maja and Lucas McCabe. Memorial service Friday, May 24, 12:30 PM at Yale's Slifka Center for Jewish Life, 80 Wall St., New Haven, CT. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Lova Abrahamsen Scholarship Fund, Yale University, PO Box 2038, New Haven, CT 06521-2038.

title: Making the Case For Judge Smith
description: To the Editor:

title: When Drugs Fail
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets Run Into Third Straight Loss
description: Much of this season has been a combination of good and bad for the Mets. For every positive development they seem to produce, they always find enough to set them back.

title: With the Brilliance of Dye, The Staying Power of Pigment
description: ''Light Black'' may not have cracked the Crayola 64, but the color has at least found a slot in the palette of the Stylus Photo 2200, the latest inkjet photo printer from Epson. The Stylus Photo 2200 mixes and sprays seven different pigment inks from separate cartridges, the newest of which is Light Black, to yield a range and density of color that has up to now been available only by using dyes.

title: Five-Member Board Is Appointed To Run Roosevelt School System
description: Completing New York State's first takeover of a local school district, state officials appointed a five-member board yesterday to run the struggling Roosevelt school system on Long Island.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary by The Associated Press on Friday about a Cornell University physicist, Boyce D. McDaniel, who played a crucial role during the Manhattan project in determining the amount of uranium 235 needed for fission, misidentified the atomic bomb that used uranium 235. It was the one dropped on Hiroshima -- the world's second atomic bomb and the first used as a weapon. The bomb tested earlier at the Trinity site, in New Mexico, used plutonium.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Kyrgyzstan: Prime Minister Quits
description: Prime Minister Kurmanbek Bakiyev and his cabinet resigned after growing unrest that followed the death of five demonstrators in clashes with the police in March. Mr. Bakiyev submitted his resignation after a government commission completed a report that blamed the authorities for the shooting of the unarmed protesters.

title: Little-Known Romantic With a Passion For Uproar
description: Franz Schmidt's posthumous reputation continues to languish while those of colleagues like Mahler and Richard Strauss grow bigger by the day. Schmidt's coziness with the Nazis is one reason offered, but it is not enough. When the composer is good enough, politics fades to the background. Music can be beautiful or not beautiful, but it cannot be good or evil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEENAN, ANNIE (NEE CLARKE)
description: KEENAN-Annie (nee Clarke). 0n May 21, 2002 at the age of 96, native of Laragh, Cty. Cavan, Ireland. Beloved wife of the late Patrick of Ballybay, Cty. Monaghan. Loving mother of Rev. James Keenan, S.J., Rose and Louis Capezza and Mary and Edward Goutink. Also survived by grandchildren Ellen and James Gallagher, Maureen, and Edward and Peggy Goutink, two great grandchildren James and John, and nieces and nephews. Predeceased were son, Thomas J., sisters Ellen Gleason, Mary Fitzsimmons, Kathleen Erhling and brother Thomas Clarke. Reposing at Joseph V. McGrath Funeral Home, 91-20 37th Avenue, Jackson Heights. Visiting Thursday and Friday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Funeral Mass Saturday at St. Joan of Arc Church, 9:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers, donations to: Ozanam Hall Nursing Home, 42-41 201st St., Bayside, N.Y. 11361 or Jesuit Seminary Missions Bureau, 39 E. 83rd St., N.Y. N.Y. 10028

title: Up a Tree on an Island of Green
description: RIVES YOST is an avid environmentalist who considers clothes dryers a waste of electricity. So when she and her family rented a beach house in a development near here, she hoisted her portable clothesline on the porch. But a pair of guards wearing guns rang her bell and told her that the clothesline violated the development's regulations. She tried hanging the line in a more discreet location, and the guards returned with an even firmer warning.

title: Rescue Winding Down for Korea Banks
description: South Korea's rapidly mending banking industry has its sights set on a milestone moment expected six months from now, when the government-run Korea Asset Management Corporation will stop buying any more nonperforming loans and the industry will be certifiably off the disabled list.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bush Documents Show Broader Enron Contacts

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Monday about Richard Minsky, an artist and bookbinder who has created artworks representing the Bill of Rights, gave an outdated address for the Center for Book Arts, a nonprofit group he founded in New York. It is at 28 West 27th Street, third floor.

title: British Leave Pakistan
description: Britain urged its citizens today to leave Pakistan, ordered the departure of more than 150 personnel from its embassy and closed its consulates after warnings of bomb attacks.

title: Lenders Plan to Take Control of Hynix Board
description: The creditors that have kept Hynix Semiconductor on life support since the Korean economic crisis have decided to take control of the company's board, which has obstructed their efforts to sell Hynix's main businesses to pay off debt. The company's lead bank, the government-run Korea Exchange Bank, said today that the creditors would convert $2.3 billion in bonds they hold into shares of the company's stock on June 7.

title: Living Green
description: MANY organizations promote environmentally responsible building techniques, but it is hard to find a list of functioning residential ''green'' developments. The ROCKY MOUNTAIN INSTITUTE offers a CD, ''Green Developments, Version 2'' ($20), listing 200 or so developments, of which 20 are residential. Information: (970) 927-3851; www.rmi.org.

title: Indian Leader's Threat of War Rattles Pakistan and the U.S.
description: Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee told Indian soldiers along the tense frontier in Kashmir today to prepare for a ''decisive battle'' against terrorism, words powerful enough to rally his troops, threaten Pakistan and scare much of the world.

title: Body of Intern Found in Park In Washington
description: A man walking his dog today found remains that the police identified as those of Chandra Ann Levy, the 24-year-old Washington intern who has been missing for more than a year and was linked romantically to Representative Gary A. Condit.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: U.S. Terror Charge Denied
description: The Foreign Ministry dismissed the State Department's accusation that Iran is ''the most active state sponsor of terrorism,'' saying the charge, made Tuesday in an annual report, was baseless and in line with Washington's hostile policies toward Iran. Hamidreza Assefi, the foreign ministry spokesman, said that United States support for Israel showed the hypocrisy of America's claim to be fighting terrorism and that the Palestinians had the right to liberate territories occupied by Israel.

title: Mom, Have You Seen My Stolen Art?
description: Upon learning of his arrest, the mother of an art thief chopped up the oil paintings he had stolen, which were left for trash collection, and dumped other art objects in a canal. The stolen goods were worth $1.4 billion.

title: Executive's Role Stirs Rumors at Random House
description: Peter Olson, the chairman of Random House, boasted of a corporate triumph six months ago when he hired his good friend Phyllis Grann, the former chief executive of the rival publisher Penguin Putnam.

title: Charles W. Roll Jr., 73, Polltaker For Prominent Political Leaders
description: Charles W. Roll Jr., a political polltaker for prominent leaders like Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller of New York and co-author of a classic text on polling, died on May 12 at a hospital in Trenton. He was 73 and lived in Lawrenceville, N.J.

title: ANOTHER SHOT?
description: War Emblem is hardly scaring challengers off in his quest for the Triple Crown.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Action On Malpractice Premiums
description: Gov. Ronnie Musgrove said he would call a special legislative session this summer to deal with rapidly rising medical malpractice insurance premiums, which some contend have led some physicians to retire or move. Mr. Musgrove, a Democrat, acted in response to complaints that the insurance is no longer affordable because Mississippi juries have been too generous.

title: Abortion Debate Stalls Bankruptcy Bill
description: Congressional negotiators failed today to overcome sharp differences about an abortion-rights provision that is threatening to scuttle a bill overhauling the nation's bankruptcy system.

title: Williams Cos. Is Considering a Merger
description: The Williams Companies, a pipeline concern that has sold $2 billion in assets to raise cash, said today that it was considering a merger of its energy-trading business with a partner to reduce risks that could lead to a reduction in its credit rating.

title: Hiker From Queens Is Killed in Rock Slide
description: A 76-year-old hiker from Queens was killed and two of his companions seriously injured by a rock slide yesterday as they made their way along a treacherous slope of a mountain in Orange County.

title: National Briefing | West: California: State Not Liable For Crime
description: The State Supreme Court ruled that the children of a woman shot to death by her former husband at a Los Angeles courthouse in 1995 could not sue the government for not providing adequate security. Lisa Zelig, then 6, saw her father kill her mother at a support hearing. The court ruled that the government was generally not obligated to protect people from crime. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Seeking a Balm for a Jittery Land
description: To the Editor:

title: Durham Bulls Start to Show Potential
description: The Tampa Bay Devil Rays are often compared to a Class AAA team, but they can take some solace that at least their real AAA team, the Durham Bulls, is having success.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESSLER, ETHEL GERSON
description: KESSLER-Ethel Gerson, 80. On Sunday, May 19th in Sarasota, Florida, after a long battle with Alzheimer's Disease. Formerly of New City, NY. Ethel was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, and received a B.F.A. in Drama from Carnegie Institute of Technology. She worked as a social worker at the Educational Alliance in New York City, and taught kindergarten for 16 years in Rockland County. She collaborated with her husband Leonard on more than 45 books for young children, her latest, ''Stan the Hot Dog Man,'' for HarperCollins. She is survived by her husband, Leonard Kessler of Sarasota, Florida; daughter, Kim Kessler of Madison, Wisconsin (Rick Mundt); son, Dr. Paul Kessler of Frederick, Maryland (Dr. Betsy Nicholas); her sister, Freda Tanz of El Cerrito, California; brother, Mickey Gerson, of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania; four grandchildren, Matt, Joanna, Abby, Ally. The family would like to thank Dr. McCarren, the staff of Alterra Clare Bridge for compassionate care during the final stages of her illness. Per Ethel's request there will be no memorial services. Donations to Alzheimer's Association, 1230 S. Tuttle Ave., Sarasota, FL 34239, or Hospice of SW Florida, 5955 Rand Blvd., Sarasota, FL 34238 would be deeply appreciated.

title: Witness Cites Confusion In Shredding At Andersen
description: An Arthur Andersen investigator testified today at the firm's criminal trial that a partner who confessed to shredding documents related to Enron ''needed internal legal advice'' about what documents needed to be kept.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: W.N.B.A. Has Survived, But It Has Its Problems
description: When the Women's National Basketball Association begins its sixth season on Saturday, it will have much to celebrate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHASE, NORMAN L.
description: CHASE-Norman L. Died May 19, 2002. Husband of the late Adrienne Schafran Chase, son of the late Pam Chase and the late Gilbert Katz. Burial and graveside services at The Old Montifiore Cemetery, 121-83 Springfield Boulevard, St Albans, Queens on Thursday May 23rd at 1 P.M.

title: Hormone May Explain Difficulty Dieters Have Keeping Weight Off
description: Scientists say they may have found out why people get hungry at mealtime, why dieters who lose weight often gain it back and why a certain type of stomach surgery helps severely obese people lose a great deal of weight.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: A Call For Change At Vivendi
description: Claude Bebear, left, the chairman of AXA and one of France's most influential businessmen, called for a change in Vivendi Universal's strategy and the management of the chief executive, Jean-Marie Messier. In the most public call yet for a shake-up at the company, Mr. Bebear said that when the board meets next week, it should determine what strategy to follow and consider a change in management. Mr. Bebear, who made the remarks in an interview on Radio Classique, is not a member of Vivendi's board but AXA owned about 5.7 million Vivendi shares at the end of 2001. A spokesman for Vivendi, which owns Universal Studios, Universal Music and USA Entertainment in the United States, declined to comment.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHAIFETZ, CHARLOTTE
description: CHAIFETZ-Charlotte. Mom, 17 years have passed since you left us. You are always in our thoughts. Our love for you is everlasting. Rest in peace. Love, sons Barry and Alan, daughtersin-law Maureen and Lyn

title: Sportswriter Out of a Job Over a Column on Piazza
description: The rush of reporting on the Mets' Mike Piazza on Tuesday, with Piazza denying a rumor that he was gay, produced an internecine tabloid squabble at The New York Post yesterday, which resulted in the departure of the sports columnist Wallace Matthews.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESNIK, PAUL
description: RESNIK-Paul. 64. Died at his home in Santa Fe, NM, on May 20, 2002 from esophageal cancer. Mr. Resnik was born February 12, 1938 and grew up in Stamford, CT. He was the son of Dr. William Resnik, a well-known cardiologist, and Lorraine Smith Resnik, a musicologist. He is survived by a sister, Kate Resnik Adler, a retired psychologist, of Easton, MD. Mr. Resnik graduated from Brooks School, Yale College and Harvard Law School. He also attended the London School of Economics. In his early career he worked for the Agency for International Development, U.S.State Department, serving in Washington, DC and Uruguay. Later he was a corporate lawyer for ITT in the U.S. and Europe. He also founded The Wine Bar in New York City which he modeled after similar places in Paris. On the basis of his own experience he wrote a book called ''The Small Business Bible,'' which was subsequently translated into several different languages. He then incorporated the principles described in ''The Small Business Bible'' into a joint project with Yale University to help inner-city kids think and express themselves. Mr. Resnik moved from New York to Santa Fe in 1998 and immersed himself in an array of local artistic and philanthropic activities. Among the institutions he supported were the School for American Research and the Southwest Literary Center. In recognition of his contributions, the Southwest Literary Center has announced that a Paul Resnik Narrative Center will be established in his name. He was deeply interested in books and ideas and loved music, art, theater, movies, politics and history. His many friends considered him a man for all seasons, a renaissance man, with a strong social conscience and a searching inquiring mind, an irreverent wit and a deep humanitarian spirit. He was in the process of researching a bold new work on the 1912 elections at the time of his death. Friends are planning a memorial service on July 3 in Santa Fe. In lieu of flowers memorial gifts may be sent to Brooks School Library, North Andover, MA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAZ, WILLIAM A.
description: DIAZ-William A. Age 56. Passed away at his home in St. Paul, Mn. on May 18, 2002. A man of great strength, courage and generosity, he was born in New York City and received his undergraduate, M.S. and PhD at Fordham University. Bill was a Senior Fellow and professor at the University of Minnesota's Hubert H. Humphrey Institute of Public Affairs where he directed a program of research, teaching and writing on the relationship between public policy, philanthropy, and the non-profit sector, and taught public management. Prior to joining the Institute, Dr. Diaz was the Ford Foundation's first Latino program officer and he developed a special Foundation initiative concerning the Hispanic population described in ''Hispanics: Challenges and Opportunities''. His earlier professional experience included Senior Research Associate at Manpower Development Research Corporation and Program Officer at the Twentieth Century Fund. Dr. Diaz was a nationally recognized expert on the U.S. Latino population, and was the Vice Chairman of the Minnesota State Chicano Latino Affairs Council. Dr. Diaz has received the Premio Herencia Award from Hispanics in Philanthropy, which honors an individual whose longstanding leadership and vision has advanced philanthropic commitment to diversity and responsiveness in Latino communities. He had a lifelong commitment of service, working with non-profit and philanthropic organizations. At the time of his death, Dr. Diaz served as a Board member of Council on Foundations; El Fondo Diversity Fund, St. Paul Foundation; Family Services of St. Paul; The Disability Funders Network and was a trustee of the Puerto Rico Community Foundation. Beloved husband of Dorothy Thompson, father to Sarah and Alex, son of Margarita, brother to Yvette and uncle to Cara and Michael, Peter, Laura, and William, and cherished by the extended Thompson family. He will be missed deeply for his wonderful sense of humor, his spirit and his very loving demeanor with his family and friends and all whom he encountered. Visitation Thursday, May 23, 2002, 5-8PM at Bradshaw, 678 Snelling Avenue South, St. Paul, Mn. 55116 (651-698-3878). Service Friday, May 24, 2002, 4pm, at St. John's Episcopal, St. Paul, Mn. In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorials: Puerto Rico Community Fund, P.O. Box 70362, San Juan, Puerto Rico 00936-8362; El Fundo, St. Paul Community Foundation, 55 5th Street East, Suite 600, St. Paul, Mn. 55101; Family Services of St. Paul, 166 East 4th Street, St. Paul, Mn. 55101.

title: Pictures by the Numbers For E-Mailing or Printing
description: Anyone who has taken a large number of digital snapshots at a big family gathering knows how difficult it can be after the fun -- or duty -- is over to sort out which images were promised to whom by e-mail.

title: As Bush Heads for Russia, Hopes for an Investment Plan Fade
description: With President Bush barely a day away from Moscow, it began to appear today that he would not be bringing with him economic proposals to transform his first Kremlin meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin into anything more than a funeral service for the cold war.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ABU, LUGHOD, IBRAHIM
description: ABU-LUGHOD-Ibrahim 1929-2001 Miss you. Love you. Your family and Palestine recall your laughter and fire to send away our tears.

title: Security Council Tries to Ease Tensions Between U.S. and Iraq
description: Diplomats on the Security Council, even including the United States' European allies, are working quietly but persistently to head off American military action against Iraq by trying to persuade Saddam Hussein's government to reopen the country to arms inspectors.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Economic Growth
description: Malaysia's economy grew 1.1 percent in the first quarter compared with the first three months of 2001, the country's central bank said, as government spending helped stimulate domestic consumption. Economists said exports appeared to be on the rebound, pointing to data showing that exports rose in March for the first time since January 2001.

title: Japan Intervenes to Stem Yen Rally
description: Worried that the recent rise in the yen's value could snuff out the country's fragile economic recovery, Japan intervened in the currency markets today for the first time in nearly eight months, but failed to turn the tide.

title: An Insider-Out Primary
description: The race to be New York's Democratic candidate for governor drew its first breath of pure oxygen this week as Andrew Cuomo decided to boycott the party convention in Midtown Manhattan. Rather than watching the state comptroller, Carl McCall, get an easy majority of the delegates and having to scramble for enough support to assure himself a spot on the primary ballot, Mr. Cuomo declared himself liberated from the Democratic Party apparatus. His supporters will take the alternate route of gathering 15,000 signatures from voters around the state. This move, his people explain, positions Mr. Cuomo as the outsider and Mr. McCall as the candidate of the party regulars.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Challenge To Aid For Religion Is Back
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit has revived one of the first court cases in the nation to test the constitutionality of government financing for an overtly religious welfare program. Texas gave $8,000 to the Jobs Partnership of Washington County, which included Bible reading and prayers in its job training program. The Texas Civil Rights Project and the American Jewish Congress sued, contending that the grant violated church-state separation. The case is headed back to a federal district court that dismissed it because the program no longer receives state money.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: U.S. Lifts Mining Ban
description: The Bush administration is lifting a temporary ban on new mining claims in 1.2 million acres of federal land in southern Oregon. The moratorium, imposed by the Clinton administration in 2001 and scheduled to expire in 2003, was intended to give the government time to study the impact of mining on salmon streams and forests in the Siskiyou Mountains. In ending the ban, the Bureau of Land Management and the Forest Service said they would set aside about 100,000 acres of the most ecologically sensitive land in the Siskiyou National Forest and the Siskiyou Wild Rivers area for further study and protection. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: AIDING AFTER-SCHOOL PROGRAMS

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Ban On Deer And Elk Imports
description: The Wildlife Resources Commission has banned the importing of deer and elk to keep out chronic wasting disease, a brain disorder related to mad cow disease. The commission imposed the ban after biologists received reports that deer were being imported from Wisconsin to North Carolina for hunting. The disease has infected deer and elk in Wisconsin and seven other states: Colorado, Kansas, Montana, Nebraska, Oklahoma, South Dakota and Wyoming.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hempstead: Fugitive Arraigned
description: A fugitive murder suspect, captured in Canada, was arraigned yesterday in connection with a Feb. 21 drive-by shooting in the Searingtown area that left one teenager dead and another injured. The suspect, identified as Lorenzo Lochansingh, 19, of Queens, fled initially to Toronto, the police said. Canadian authorities arrested him in April and deported him Tuesday, handing him over to the Nassau police at Niagara Falls, said Detective Sgt. Dennis Barry. He said the shooting stemmed from a dispute at a party the night before. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Dan Doerner
description: ART photographers have long fooled the eye with burning and dodging, effects that make portions of photos lighter or darker during the film development process. But with the advent of digital image editing, the 1990's produced a cottage industry of photo retouchers and compositors who altered photos for artistic or illustrative effect. Among the new crop of digital manipulators was Dan Doerner, 41, who studied photography at the State University of New York at Albany, learned literally to cut and paste images in a darkroom to create collages, and eventually worked with an early version of Adobe Photoshop in 1989 while living in Los Angeles.

title: Belated Justice in Birmingham
description: With yesterday's conviction of Bobby Frank Cherry, 71, for his role in the 1963 bombing of Birmingham's 16th Street Baptist Church, an Alabama jury wrote the final page of one of the most heart-rending chapters in the United States' civil rights history. In a year when Gov. George Wallace stood in a schoolhouse door and Eugene (Bull) Connor sicced dogs on peaceful protesters, the bombing was the Ku Klux Klan's answer to court-ordered school desegregation. Timed for a Sunday morning, when the church would be teeming with worshipers, the explosion left four young black girls dead.

title: Niki de Saint Phalle, Sculptor, Is Dead at 71
description: Niki de Saint Phalle, a Franco-American artist internationally known for her colorful, monumental, cartoonlike sculptures and environments, died on Tuesday in San Diego, Calif. She was 71.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Saturday about an agreement by Bertelsmann, the German media giant, to acquire the assets of Napster, the song-swapping service, misstated the job of a Bertelsmann executive, Joel I. Klein, who was involved in the negotiations. He is chairman and chief executive of Bertelsmann Inc., which handles financial, legal and other issues, not of Bertelsmann's American operations.

title: What's in a Name?
description: When Lincoln Center's Philharmonic Hall opened in September 1962, Architectural Record published an article by the principal acoustical consultant, Leo L. Beranek. ''Whether history will award Philharmonic Hall a position among the world's finest environments for concert music,'' Mr. Beranek wrote, ''it is still too early for us to judge.'' Too early, alas, turned abruptly into too late. The hall opened, and its acoustics were reviled. Fourteen years later, Philharmonic Hall was almost entirely rebuilt, and it was rechristened with the name of the man, Avery Fisher, whose gift paid for the renovation.

title: Report Cites a Rise In Spending on Ads
description: In a sign that marketers may be gradually starting to spend again, advertising in major media increased 0.4 percent in the first quarter of 2002, compared with the period last year, according to a report yesterday from CMR in New York, a division of Taylor Nelson Sofres that tracks ad spending.

title: Proud Citizen's Purse To Go to Towers Fund
description: Besides hoping to turn the tables on War Emblem in the Belmont Stakes on June 8, the owners of Proud Citizen announced yesterday that they would donate their share of the purse earnings to the Twin Towers Fund.

title: Raising Shutterbugs In a Megapixel Age
description: LIKE many children, Rhianon Gill loves to take pictures. Her mother, Sue Gallien, had always tried to accommodate her by letting her snap a shot or two with the family's film camera from time to time. About two years ago, Ms. Gallien bought Rhianon a point-and-shoot film camera for her 11th birthday. But the processing and prints, she told her daughter, were on her.

title: Buffett's Negative-Interest Issues Sell Well
description: Warren E. Buffett's new negative-interest bonds sold rapidly yesterday, even after the size of the offering was increased to $400 million from $250 million, with a possible offering of another $100 million to cover overallotments.

title: Next Desk, Please
description: President Bush has come under critical fire because he supposedly received a warning of possible Al Qaeda attacks last August. The White House is deflecting the criticism as best it can, but the president is still feeling the heat. I think I can help. As a 20-year veteran of government bureaucracy, I suggest the following tried and true approaches, sure to work as well in Washington as they do in Ottawa:

title: Trying to Turn Likely Loss Into a Victory
description: For most of the past 25 years, Andrew M. Cuomo has been a player in government and politics in New York and Washington: chief political aide to a governor, enforcer for the state's Democratic Party, federal housing secretary. But yesterday, there was Mr. Cuomo presenting himself as the outsider bucking the party establishment, announcing that he would bolt the Democratic State Convention and take his campaign for governor directly ''to the people.''

title: Russia's Compass Points West
description: Ever since Peter the Great looked to Europe in the late 17th century as a model for modernizing Russia, the integration of Russia and the West has been an alluring but unfulfilled dream. This week, as President Bush visits Moscow and St. Petersburg, the splendid city by the Baltic that Peter founded, he can bring that dream closer to realization. Building on the political and economic changes that have rolled across Europe since the cold war ended, Mr. Bush and President Vladimir Putin of Russia have brought Russia to Europe's doorstep. With further work, they can guide it across the threshold.

title: Daniel Boone Does the Ramble
description: AS soon as the last American man entered Central Park, he breathed more easily. ''I'm feeling better every step we take,'' Eustace Conway said, staring at the light falling through the leaves of a beech tree. ''Better air, the presence of these plants -- do you hear the leaves?''

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Extradition To U.S. Blocked
description: A federal court blocked the extradition to the United States of an accused drug trafficker, Jess Amezcua, wanted for years in California on charges of money laundering and drug distribution. The decision followed rulings by the Mexican Supreme Court that have stopped the extradition of some 70 defendants facing life sentences in the United States. The Mexican Constitution, which says criminals are capable of rehabilitation, does not permit life sentences or the death penalty. A lawyer for Mr. Amezcua said a letter from the State Department saying American prosecutors would not seek a life sentence was considered insufficient by the court.

title: House Leaders Quell Revolt To Advance Spending Bill
description: House majority leaders quelled a rebellion by some Republicans and cleared the way tonight for passage of a $29.4 billion emergency spending bill to pay for military operations and domestic security.

title: Libraries Invite Young Readers to Check In
description: One reason that 60 percent of New York City public-school children read below grade level is that many elementary schools don't have libraries. Lonni Tanner, director of special projects for the Robin Hood Foundation, which seeks to eliminate poverty in New York City, visited 200 elementary schools three years ago. ''None had a complete library, none had a certified librarian, and if there were books, they were books that hadn't been touched,'' she said. So the foundation, the Board of Education and the mayor's office created the Library Initiative. It will bring libraries to 10 schools by the end of the summer and to 30 by 2003. Seven are already finished. In 1999, Ms. Tanner worked with Henry Myerberg, an architect at Helfand Myerberg Guggenheimer in Manhattan, to design the Beginning With Children library in Williamsburg. In 2000, he invited nine other architects to contribute work on the first 10. Zack McKown and Calvin Tsao, of Tsao McKown in Manhattan, designed one for Public School 19 in Corona, Queens, above left. ''The curtained area has a little stage where a teacher or student can read or act out a story or have a puppet show,'' Mr. McKown said.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Sherwin-Williams Will Use Linux
description: Linux, an operating system that is distributed free, is getting another corporate vote of confidence today, with the announcement that Sherwin-Williams will use Linux to run the point-of-sale computers at its 2,500 stores. To date, the rising popularity of Linux has been mostly as an operating system for the data-serving computers that power corporate networks and inside telecommunications gear and machinery, as a so-called embedded operating system. But Sherwin-Williams will run Linux on the personal computers that double as cash registers and data-entry devices used in its paint stores. Steve Lohr (NYT)

title: Witness Says Senator Urged Him to Lie
description: The New Jersey businessman who maintains that he gave Senator Robert G. Torricelli tens of thousands of dollars in cash and expensive gifts said in court papers filed today that Mr. Torricelli repeatedly urged him to lie to federal investigators and warned that his life would be in danger if he cooperated with prosecutors.

title: Dismal End for Race Dogs, Alabama Authorities Say
description: The last stop on the Florida greyhound racing circuit was supposed to be the Pensacola dog track, where over-the-hill racers hustled after the mechanical rabbit one last time.

title: Cruising the Web
description: Special pricing is offered by eWaterways.com for two seven-day barge cruises in France departing July 13. The 50-passenger Anacolouthe will cruise the Seine and Yonne Rivers with stops at Monet's home and gardens at Giverny, the Chateau Vaux-le-Vicomte, the palace at Fontainebleau and the Gothic cathedral at Auxerre in Burgundy. The price of $1,990 a couple is half the normal high-season rate. It includes all meals, wines, sightseeing and transfers between the barge and Paris. Air fare between most United States cities and Paris is included with a trip on the 50-passenger Provence, departing from Lyon on July 13 to cruise along the Rhone with stops at Avignon, the Roman ruins in Arles and St.-Remy de Provence, and the walled medieval city of Aigues-Mortes. Rates: $2,690 to $3,090 a person, double occupancy. For more information: (800) 676-6613 or www.bargespecials.com .

description: Digital cameras have been shrinking for a while, but in the past year some models have become almost wearable. The Casio Exilim EX-S1, due out in July, is built to be dropped into a pocket and carried everywhere. The metal case is the size of a credit card and less than a half-inch thick.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 2 Extradited In Extortion Case
description: Two men from Kazakhstan who prosecutors say tried to extort $200,000 from Michael R. Bloomberg before he became mayor have been brought to the United States to face charges, the authorities said Tuesday. The men, Oleg Zezov, 28, and Igor Yarimaka, 38, broke into the computer system of Bloomberg L.P. in 1999, from computers in Almaty, Kazakhstan, prosecutors said. Mr. Zezov then sent e-mail messages to Mr. Bloomberg, the founder of the media company, demanding $200,000 in exchange for information on how his computer system was compromised, prosecutors said. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: After 20 Days of Freedom, an Escapee From New York Is Found in Virginia
description: On May 2, Kevin Saxon, a convicted killer, kicked off his leg shackles and escaped from two armed investigators in a car stuck in traffic in the Bronx. It was at least the fifth in a string of embarrassing escapes from city authorities this year.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: 2 Music Services' Legal Woes
description: Two companies that have been accused of copyright infringement by the recording industry -- Kazaa and MusicCity -- appear to have financial difficulties that will hamper their ability to fight lawsuits. The major recording companies have sued both parties for distributing software used to exchange music free over the Internet. But in papers filed in federal court in Los Angeles, Kazaa, a Dutch company, said yesterday that it was withdrawing its defense because it had run low on financing. People close to the company said that it might soon shut. Matt Richtel (NYT)

description: Preceded by a barrage of superlatives and opened with Champagne and speeches, an exhibition of 107 works by Italian old masters is nevertheless encountering criticism and controversy here on a scale to match its blockbuster proportions.

title: Alyce Smith
description: WHILE photographers have been showcasing their work online for years, few have taken the time to make their Web sites artistic achievements in their own right. Alyce Smith, a recent graduate of the Rochester Institute of Technology, lacked the resources to promote her photography by creating multiple portolios and sending them around the country. Her Web site was a collaboration with Sean Barclay, another Rochester graduate, and used Macromedia Flash 5 to create a vibrant multimedia display.

title: Suspending Reality In Argentina
description: The economy has collapsed, half the population has slipped below the poverty line, and angry pot-banging demonstrations against politicians and bankers are a daily event. The panorama has been uniformly bleak here for months, but with the quadrennial World Cup finals looming, soccer-crazed Argentina suddenly has one source of hope: its national team.

description: Beyer Blinder Belle, the design firm that oversaw the restoration of Grand Central Terminal and converted Ellis Island into the National Museum of Immigration, was chosen yesterday as the urban planning consultant to oversee the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan.

description: LESLIE LIPPI and David Hamlin's budget for fame and fortune in New York was $4,000. That included Mr. Hamlin's $275 Hugo Boss trousers. It didn't include $50-a-head tickets to a Saturday night party at the Museum of Modern Art. Getting here woke them up quickly to how this town works. They spent the expensive night hugging the entrance, with a few forays into the heaving bowels of the hard-handshaking crowd.

title: A Hideaway With a Latin Touch, And Some Magic of Its Own
description: Seven years ago, David Rockwell designed a Copperfield's Magic Underground restaurant on Broadway, but the place never opened. Now the windowless space has become Noche, a restaurant and nightclub opening next month. Mr. Rockwell has come back, keeping Copperfield's industrial Piranesian dome, at bottom, and adding a rotating stage for musical performances. Mosaic tile murals are in the bathrooms, below, and a soaring 70-foot elevator tower is clad in cast glass of cobalt, amber and red.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Expanded Corruption Office
description: David Samson, the state attorney general, has created an expanded office for investigating corruption among government and law enforcement officials. Called the Office of Government Integrity, it will have a staff of about 50, or 20 more people than the agency's former investigative unit, the Office of Inspector General. The office will also monitor initial misconduct complaints. Stacy Albin (NYT)

The officer, whose name was not released, was in stable condition at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, Detective Cheryl Cox said.

Below, a Joan Esteba chest of drawers, Espiral, and an Eduard Samso mirror, Mirallmar. title: FRITO-LAY TESTS NEW SNACKS IN HISPANIC COMMUNITIES
description: Frito-Lay, the maker of Doritos tortilla chips and Fritos corn chips has introduced a line of snacks with flavors like chile, citrus and cheese, aimed at Hispanic consumers. Frito-Lay, a unit of PepsiCo, tested the products with consumers in Miami, New York, Los Angeles and Houston, PepsiCo said. PepsiCo has recently introduced other products, including the Xtremo line of the Gatorade sports drink, aimed at Hispanics. Frito-Lay is based in Plano, Tex.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Elizabeth: Pop Warner Football Sued
description: Three men are suing the Pop Warner football organization after their former coach was indicted in January on charges that he abused them sexually in 1991. The lawsuit, filed yesterday in State Superior Court against Pop Warner Little Scholars Inc., also names the City of Elizabeth, and the city's Police Athletic League. It seeks $30 million in damages. Criminal charges were filed against the coach, Tyrone Smith, after the youths accused him last June of molesting them during overnight stays at his home before games. Mr. Smith, who has a June 10 arraignment date but no lawyer, could not be reached. Messages left with Pop Warner, based in Langhorne, Pa., and with the Police Athletic League were not answered. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Shockey Shows He Means Business
description: There is a homespun simplicity to the way Jeremy Shockey goes about his life. He attended high school and junior college in Oklahoma, and after transferring to the University of Miami to finish college, friends teased him about the hours he would spend at the beach, about the distractions that would lure him away from football.

title: His 15 Minutes Are Still Ticking; A Warhol Retrospective Comes to Los Angeles With Fitting Hoopla
description: Andy Warhol lived in New York, but Los Angeles was his spiritual home. The Pop painter of iconic celebrity portraits -- Liz, Marilyn, Elvis and Jackie -- obscured the line between art and popular culture. He partied with the rich and famous. Even his shallowness mirrors a culture consumed with blockbusters and sitcoms.

title: Marriott Chain Sues Downtown A.C.
description: The financially troubled Downtown Athletic Club is being sued by the Marriott hotel chain, which says the Manhattan-based club owes $479,000 in fees over the last three years in connection with the hotel chain serving as host of the annual Heisman Trophy ceremony for the nation's top college football player.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDIS, MORRIS B.
description: LANDIS-Morris B. Of Highland Park, NJ and Aventura, FL. Beloved husband of Raye nee Rosenbaum. Devoted father of Mark, Alan, Diana, Ilene, Mitchell and Tefera. Father-in-law of Carolyn, Linda, Jeffrey and Linda Jean. Dear brother of Alex and Sam. Loving grandfather of 12 grandchildren and 2 great-grandchildren. Dad, Grandpa, Meish, Uncle Morris, ''The Producer''. Always a trendsetter, with a healthy diet and exercise, always years ahead of his time, the eternal overflowing optimist. Now at his passing, years ahead of his time. We will all miss our greatest cheerleader and supporter. We hope throughout our lives and those of future generations that Dad's very special being will live on. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Central New Jersey Jewish Home for the Aged, 732-873-2000 or to the Israel Emergency Fund of the UJA Federation, 212-980-1000. Services were held. For information ''Wein & Wein'', 800-322-0533.

title: 12 Palestinians Are Dispersed For a Year of Exile In Europe
description: Spanish authorities say all but one of the 13 Palestinian fighters exiled from Bethlehem after the Israeli siege at the Church of the Nativity have arrived in Western Europe where, in a deal brokered by the European Union, they are to spend the next 12 months as refugees.

description: After declaring a drought disaster for the entire state, Agriculture Secretary Ann M. Veneman predicted that Arizona farms could lose 90 percent of their crops this year. Some cattle ranchers have cut their herds 20 percent. The federal disaster declaration will enable farmers and ranchers to seek low-interest loans to cover losses.

title: Wanted: New Chief Executive for Gap; Prior Retail Experience Not Required

He fueled the movement toward casual dress in the American workplace by making khakis seem urbane and artistic, and white T-shirts as appropriate with $3,000 suits as French-cut dress shirts and ties.

description: THERE are few public buildings in New York City more inscrutable than 2 Columbus Circle, with its nearly windowless marble walls.

description: SRINAGAR, Jammu and Kashmir, May 23  Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee of India sharpened his bellicose tone today, declaring that India would not tolerate "any longer" what he called a 20-year campaign of terrorism by Pakistan.

title: Discovering Beauty in Precise Colorations
description: In 1992, Gerald Ranck, the harpsichordist, set out to perform all of Domenico Scarlatti's 555 Sonatas (using the Ralph Kirpatrick numbering), a project he expected would required 25 or 26 programs over three seasons. There has been a hiatus or two, but this year Mr. Ranck took up his project again, and last Thursday evening he presented the 14th program, which began with the Sonata in B flat (K. 331) and continued sequentially through the Kirkpatrick catalogue to the Sonata in F (K. 355), 25 works in all.

title: New Yorkers Try to Stay in Character
description: Manuel Lallave rode the subway with butterflies in his stomach and suspicion in his eyes. Janice Jacoby contemplated moving her family to their weekend house in New Jersey. Suppressing her fear, Rose Marie Seman came to Midtown, but steered clear of big crowds. Joe Kupfersmith greeted the latest terror alerts with a weary shrug and a roll of his eyes.

title: Embracing The Moonlight
description: Harlem Moon. What exactly does that mean? Moon is light over darkness. Janet Hill, a book publishing executive, found a small ink-drawn crescent moon on an old map of Harlem showing its speak-easies. She said it made her think of the artists struggling to create under that moon during the Harlem Renaissance of the 20's and 30's, and then of those who are working now on their manuscripts under that particular light.

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNET

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: American Couple Alive, Leader Says
description: An American missionary couple who were abducted a year ago by Muslim militants are still alive, the Philipoine president, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, said. Gracia and Martin Burnham of Rose Hill, Kan., remain in captivity although American soldiers went to Basilan Island, where the rebels are holding them, four months ago. But the Filipino leader said the soldiers went to train Filipino troops, not to rescue particular hostages.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Expulsion For Link To Terror Plot
description: An immigration tribunal in Montreal ordered the deportation of an Algerian refugee because of links to Ahmed Ressam, who was convicted of trying to bomb Los Angeles International Airport in 1999, and other conspirators. Mourad Ikhlef, 34, has one week to appeal the order.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary by The Associated Press on Friday about a Cornell University physicist, Boyce D. McDaniel, who played a crucial role during the Manhattan project in determining the amount of uranium 235 needed for fission, misidentified the atomic bomb that used uranium 235. It was the one dropped on Hiroshima  the world's second atomic bomb and the first used as a weapon. The bomb tested earlier at the Trinity site, in New Mexico, used plutonium.

title: Garment District Past for Sale; Hardware Store's Shelves Display a Bygone Era
description: The history of New York City's garment district is on display -- or at least jumbled in a heap in a corner -- at Simon Greenspan Hardware, on West 35th Street just east of Eighth Avenue.

title: Paints to Try Out
description: Can anyone really tell how paint will look by holding up a piece of paper? Luckily, some companies sell samples. Ring's End Lumber, with stores in Connecticut and in Lewisboro, N.Y., sells four-ounce cans of DeVoe paint in more than 2,000 colors for $2 apiece; (800) 390-1000. It also rents quart-size cans of Pratt & Lambert for three days for $2; 2,000 colors. Janovic Plaza stores in Manhattan and on Long Island sell six-ounce cans of Martha's Fine Paints by Schreuder; 87 colors, $6 a can, (800) 772-4381. The Silk Trading Company has 49 colors of paint in four-ounce jars; $9 at ABC Carpet & Home, 888 Broadway, or (800) 854-0396 for other locations. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREUND, CHARMIAN KAPLAN
description: FREUND-Charmian Kaplan, of New York, died on Tuesday after a long illness. Loving wife of 56 years to Dr. Seelig Freund, a surgeon at Beth Israel Hospital, she is survived by her husband; children, Deborah and John; and three devoted grandsons, Alexander & Nicholas Freund of Atherton, CA, and Willie Kniesner of Syracuse. She was a former fund chairman of the United Hospital Fund, and daughter of Louis and Minerva Kaplan of Trenton, New Jersey; Mr. Kaplan was the architect of the Soldiers and Sailors War Memorial in Trenton. Visiting hours at home between 6 pm and 9 pm on Thursday, May 23. Private funeral. Memorial service on Wednesday, July 17, at 5:30 pm, at a place to be determined.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAHR, MARIANNE (NEE WOLF)
description: BAHR-Marianne (nee Wolf). Died of natural causes on Tuesday, May 21, 2002 after a long illness. Formerly of Hanover, Germany, Mrs. Bahr was a resident of New York City since 1939. She was the beloved wife of her late husband, Julius Bahr, a coffee importer. The relatives from around the world in Milan, Italy, Sao Paulo, Brazil, South Africa, Mexico, Switzerland, London and Montevideo, Uruguay all mourn her passing. She was a long-standing member of Congregation Rameth Orah. She was an active Director-Trustee of the Wolf Foundation of Tel Aviv Israel, founded by her uncle Richard Wolf, former Cuban Ambassador to Israel. She will be greatly missed by those who had the privilege of knowing this fine human being.

title: Frail Pope Takes His Message Of Peace to the Azerbaijanis
description: On his first foreign trip since child abuse scandals racked the Roman Catholic Church, John Paul II arrived in this battle-scarred former Soviet republic in the Caucasus today and vowed to continue his peace-seeking missions ''as long as I have breath within me.''

title: Technology Briefing | Software: New Version Of Kazaa Is Issued
description: Users of Kazaa will soon have access to a network that will charge fees to download files. Sharman Networks, a company based on Vanuatu, an island chain in the South Pacific, that distributes Kazaa software, issued a new version of the software yesterday. The new version, which people download free on the Internet, will still allow users to trade and download music files free, but it will allow access to a parallel network, Altnet, that intends to charge users for access to music, videos and other content. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Dusty Black Boxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Shooting on the Edge; 4 Innovators Rethink Speed, Light, Color and the Studio
description: WHETHER in the studio or on location, professional photographers are rethinking the way they do their work because of digital technology. Photojournalists have largely moved to digital cameras, and studio and commercial photographers rely heavily on image-editing software like Photoshop to create the perfect shot. The four photographers profiled here use techniques and applications that put them in the vanguard of digital photography and imaging. MARK GLASER

title: Stocking Up for Sun or Storm
description: FLOWERS are nice. So is a good bottle of merlot. But if you really want to impress your weekend host, show up with something a little more useful. There are plenty of gifts that can help your host prepare for the summer ahead. And for those setting up their own homes for the season, there's something new for any summer need -- including a multifaceted emergency appliance with a battery-operated television in case summer thunderstorms (and September hurricanes) cut off the power.

title: Legal Advice on the Web
description: To the Editor:

title: FEDERATED PLANS TO SELL SOME FINGERHUT ASSETS
description: Federated Department Stores said yesterday that it had signed a nonbinding letter of intent to sell some Fingerhut assets to the former chief executive of Fingerhut, the Internet and catalog retailer. Federated signed the letter of intent with Theodore Deikel, the former chief executive, and a wholesaler based in Eden Prairie, Minn., Thomas Petters, a Federated spokeswoman, Carol Sanger, said. Assets include distribution centers in Minnesota and Tennessee; the unit's headquarters in Minnetonka, Minn.; and the Fingerhut name and Web site, Federated said. Federated is based in Cincinnati.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: MANHATTAN: AIDING AFTER-SCHOOL PROGRAMS Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday that the city would provide $10.5 million to sustain 87 after-school programs that might otherwise have closed. Mr. Bloomberg did not include the $10.5 million in his January budget proposal. The programs, which are in all five boroughs and serve about 23,000 students, are overseen by the After-School Corporation, financed partly by the philanthropist George Soros. Mr. Soros's Open Society Institute has pledged $20 million, which, combined with other sources of funds, will allow 70 additional programs to continue.   Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: Seeking a Balm for a Jittery Land
description: To the Editor:

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: PHOTOGRAPHY has met its pixel-perfect match in the Web. Photos -- profound, profane or merely pretty -- abound online. Never has the general public had such broad access to the photographic record, from historical images to news photos to microscopic ''beershots.'' And did you hear the one about the funny captions?

title: Image Drive and Viewer Lets Photographers Snap Away
description: Even amateur digital photographers come up against seemingly unavoidable storage constraints. After all, it is pointless to take a digital camera on vacation if you are forced to delete that great shot of the Louvre to make room for one of the Arc de Triomphe.

title: Eleanor Seibold -- Gallery Founder, 86
description: Eleanor Stoddard Seibold, 86, who founded the Gallery of Graphic Arts on York Avenue in Manhattan, died on May 7 of heart failure at her home on the Upper East Side, her family said. She opened the gallery, near 84th Street, in 1963 and in the 1970's expanded it from graphic arts to framing and mounting unconventional items like quilts, kimonos, head dresses and buffalo hides for museums and other clients. She sold it in 1997 but continued to work there until last December. A native of Iowa City, she is survived by her husband, Frederick C. Jr.; a son, Mark; a daughter, Emilia S. Parker; a sister, Caroline deMar; a brother, Philip Stoddard; and a granddaughter.

title: The War Is Long Over, But Vietnam Continues
description: It's an old journalist's trick, especially among foreign correspondents, to find revelation in the wisdom of cabdrivers. David Lamb, of The Los Angeles Times, had one of those perception-altering taxi rides on his most recent tour in Vietnam, 25 years after he'd covered the war there as a young reporter.

title: A Missing Minority
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Baseball Focuses On the Trivial
description: ''I'M heterosexual,'' Mike Piazza declared Tuesday in response to insinuation in a tabloid gossip column that he -- assuming he was the unnamed Met referred to in the so-called report -- might soon be coming out of the closet.

title: Fingers Crossed Downtown As Firms Consider Moving
description: The third largest accounting firm in the world, KPMG, is negotiating a deal to move its offices downtown, from Park Avenue in Midtown, a relocation that would buoy a business district still suffering from the Sept. 11 terrorist attack.

title: Boston Hangs Hopes On Stellar Pitching
description: The simmering questions surrounding another hopeful season with the Boston Red Sox always gravitated toward Pedro Martnez. Naturally. Would his valuable right shoulder be healthy? Would he still be the intimidating pitcher who could help turn the Red Sox from solid to scintillating? Could the mighty Pedro finally guide Boston by those damn Yankees?

title: London Journal; Look Out, the Gurkhas Have Come! With Lawyers
description: Padam Gurung was a teenager with little education and few prospects in the rural foothills of the Himalayas when the British came recruiting, back in 1958.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASKIN, DR. SAMUEL
description: BASKIN-Dr. Samuel. Passed away suddenly on May 20, 2002 after an eight month recuperative period following a car accident. Dr. Baskin spent his entire professional life in the education field, and was a pioneer in creating and developing alternative life study programs. Dr. Baskin was a native of Brooklyn, NY and was a graduate of Brooklyn College and New York University. After being a faculty member at NYU and Stephens College in Columbia, MO, he moved to Antioch College in Yellow Springs, OH. There he progressed from Professor of Psychology to Director of Educational Planning and Development. His greatest achievement was his developing and leading as Founding President, the Union for Experimenting Colleges and Universities, Union Graduate School, Universities Without Walls (UWW), a non-traditional, higher educational study plan through the UWW. He also founded the Goodwin Watson Institute for Research and Development, a doctoral degree program with special focus in institutional change, program development and research in higher education. In his later years, Dr. Baskin was a Senior Consultant for University Consultants, Dayton Communication Corp. and Ford Foundation, among others. Among his many awards was the Distinguished Alumni Achievement, New York University. Dr. Baskin is survived by his loving wife of 55 years, Florence; devoted sons Robert and David; daughter-in-law Miriam; grandchildren Avshalom, Adit Zisel and Moshe of Israel; and numerous nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Association for Retarded Citizens.

title: Photofinishers Go the Silicon Route, Too
description: PHOTOFINISHING customers at Dan's Camera City in Allentown, Pa., still drop off conventional photographic film and pick up prints made with conventional photographic paper. What many of them do not know, however, is that between those two acts their snapshots are being converted and processed as digital images.

title: SUICIDE BOMB HITS OUTSIDE TEL AVIV, KILLING 2 ISRAELIS
description: Hours after the Israeli military killed a well-known Palestinian militant and two of his comrades, a young man with bleached-blond hair and a hidden bomb blew himself up at a park gazebo here, killing at least 2 Israelis and injuring 27 others.

title: Sarah Silver
description: THAT bedeviling pause after you press the shutter release on many digital cameras has discouraged their use by photographers shooting fashion and movement for magazines. But Sarah Silver is out to change that perception. Ms. Silver, a 26-year-old New York photographer, shoots almost exclusively with a Sinar digital back, an add-on that converts medium-format cameras to digital, on her Hasselblad cameras and is known for capturing graceful dance movements by fashion models.

title: Verizon Selects Kirshenbaum To Handle SuperPages Account
description: Verizon Information Services in Dallas, a division of Verizon Communications , said today that it had selected Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York, part of the Kirshenbaum Bond Creative Network, to handle the account for the SuperPages brand yellow pages directory and an online directory at SuperPages.com.

title: Successful Surgery For 76ers' Claxton
description: Guard Speedy Claxton of the Philadelphia 76ers had successful arthroscopic surgery on his left shoulder today but should be ready for the start of his third season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TREVATHAN, HERMAN ALBERT
description: TREVATHAN-Herman Albert. Of Bronx, NY, tragically departed this life, May 18, 2002 at the tender age of 21. He brought a sense of drama, comedy and passion to all he met. Loved by all and respected by many. Services, Friday, May 24, 11 AM at Pressley Memorial Church, 38 Warburton Ave., Yonkers, NY, 914-423-8345.

title: Shooting 'Star Wars,' Bit by Bit
description: TELEPHONE calls are still dialed, even though there are hardly any dials left. A car's glove compartment rarely stores any gloves. And eventually, many in the motion picture industry believe, most of the world's films will be made without using any film.

title: Yesterday, Prada; Tomorrow, the World
description: THE Dutch architect Rem Koolhaas may seem an unlikely choice for the overhaul of the European Union's image. Mr. Koolhaas, of course, is best known for his recent design of Prada's SoHo fashion emporium and for manifestoes like ''S, M, L, XL'' (Monacelli, 1995). So when it came to creating a new flag for the European Union, some asked, How would an architect handle the tricky task of reinventing a brand?

title: Bomb Blast at Israel Fuel Depot, but Major Explosion Is Averted
description: JERUSALEM, May 23  A remote control bomb blew apart a tanker truck in Israel's biggest fuel depot today, only hours after a suicide bomber killed two Israelis and wounded dozens more. But an automatic sprinkler system and nearby workers quickly put out the blaze, averting a huge explosion in a densely populated area near Tel Aviv, officials said.

title: Format's Redesign Yields Faster Image Files
description: THE compression format that reduces the file size of most photographs for transmission over the Internet is getting a long overdue face-lift this year, which should be a relief for Web users frustrated by lengthy download times and blurry images. It also promises plenty of new features for Web designers.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: All 43 On Burning Submarine Saved
description: All 43 people aboard a Navy research submarine were rescued after it caught fire and partly flooded while surfaced in the Pacific Ocean about 100 miles from San Diego, officials said. The crew of the submarine, the Dolphin, was evacuated by small boats to another ship, with only minor injuries. All hatches were sealed before the submarine was abandoned to smother the fire, Navy officials said, and the submarine was to be towed to San Diego. The Dolphin holds the depth record for operating submarines, in excess of 3,000 feet.

title: Across America, New Warnings Draw a New Set of Responses
description: It was just the kind of spring day here to suggest that all was right with the world, a sparkling clear sky, warm temperatures, throngs filling the 16th Street shopping mall and the outdoor restaurants along it.

title: Text: Letter from Archbishop to Graduate Student in '80
description: Following is an 11-page handwritten letter from Archbishop Rembert G. Weakland to Paul J. Marcoux, dated Aug. 25, 1980, which was first obtained by The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel A handwriting analysis conducted for The Journal Sentinel found that the letter was in Archbishop Weakland's handwriting.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Ex-Firefighter Sentenced In Arson
description: A former volunteer firefighter was sentenced yesterday to at least a year in jail and ordered to pay more than $500,000 after pleading guilty to setting fire to his own firehouse. The former firefighter, Clifford Seaman, 20, pleaded guilty to arson charges for setting the Bellmore station house on fire twice last spring. The first blaze, on April 28, damaged a kitchen. The May 3 fire burned through two floors and drew more than 100 firefighters. At the time, Mr. Seaman, a volunteer firefighter for a year and a half, was commended for being the first to arrive on the scene. Joseph Falbo, Mr. Seaman's lawyer, said his client denied setting the fires but did not want to face trial. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Assesses Unions $19 Million for Political Efforts
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s leaders voted yesterday to assess the nation's trade unions $19 million over three years toward labor's political efforts.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Executive In Cross-Fire Of Battle Over Gemstar
description: Elsie M. Leung, look out for your job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDFARB, ELLA KABACK
description: GOLDFARB-Ella Kaback. On May 21, 2002, in her 85th year. Cherished and devoted wife of the late Norman J. Goldfarb; beloved mother of Susan Wallach and Warren Goldfarb; beloved sister of Jennie and Julius Glenn; loving grandmother and great-grandmother. Retired schoolteacher, P.S. 152, Manhattan; resident of Lake Worth, Fl since 1978.
