title: Salomon to Alter Research Unit Along Lines of Merrill Settlement
description: Salomon Smith Barney, the brokerage subsidiary of Citigroup, said yesterday that it was changing the structure of its stock research department to mirror the changes agreed to by Merrill Lynch in its settlement with the New York attorney general, Eliot L. Spitzer.

title: Gould's Serious Fun
description: To the Editor:

title: BOEING'S SATELLITE UNIT MAY HAVE ANOTHER WRITE-DOWN
description: The Boeing Company may have a further write-down in a satellite unit struggling with cost overruns and technical breakdowns, said James Albaugh, the head of the company's space and communications unit. ''I'm not going to tell you that we aren't going to have to write down a little more there,'' Mr. Albaugh told analysts and investors at a company-sponsored conference in St. Louis. Boeing had a $1.8 billion write-down last month that led to its first quarterly loss in four years, mainly because of a decline in the value of the satellite business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, GLORIA A.
description: ABRAMS-Gloria A. of Syosset, NY and Tampa, FL on May 15, 2002 after a long illness. She was the beloved wife of the late Stanley Abrams, the cherished mother of Andrew Abrams and daughterin-law Claudia Abrams of Irvington, NY and Karen Walczuk and son-in-law John Walczuk of Syosset, NY and Alison Okun of Tampa, FL; devoted grandmother of Sean Cooper and Harrison Abrams, Matthew, Jesse and Alix Walczuk, Lee, Max and Molly Okun. Born in Brooklyn in 1922, daughter of Abraham and Theresa Harrison. Gloria and Stanley, childhood sweethearts, were married in 1944. They resided in Great Neck, NY, where they raised their three children. They were members of Temple Beth-El in Great Neck and Congregation Schaarai Zedek in Tampa. While in Great Neck, Gloria was a driving force in the fledgling volunteer organization at Long Island Jewish Hospital. In addition, she was a dedicated supporter and volunteer at North Shore Animal League in Port Washington. After their retirement to Tampa, she was a member of the Tampa Library Board and a member of the Hillsborough Literacy Council, where she served as President for several terms. Her continuing devotion to family, friends and animals will be truly missed. Donations may be made to American Cancer Society or North Shore Animal League.

title: Woods Would Join Legends By Winning the Memorial
description: Jack Nicklaus might be the host for the Memorial Tournament, but Tiger Woods dominates it.

title: Cuomo Decision Roils Party's Convention
description: New York Democrats tried yesterday to generate some excitement for their party and the coming election, but Andrew M. Cuomo's decision to skip the party's convention threw a long shadow over the political theatrics.

title: Turning The Page
description: BILL BAKER'S digital camera has helped solve quite a few problems around the house.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WESTON, DR. M. MORAN
description: WESTON-Dr. M. Moran. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine and The Mount Sinai Hospital mourn the passing of Dr. M. Moran Weston, an outstanding and compassionate business and civic leader, who served on the Mount Sinai Board of Trustees with dedication for more than 30 years. Dr. Weston was deeply committed to health care at Mount Sinai and to the well being of all the members of our New York community. His thoughtful and steadfast generosity, which included support of programs in patient care, research and medical education, will long be remembered. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Miriam, his son Gregory, his daughter Katherine Weston, and the entire Weston family. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Board The Mount Sinai Medical Center Kenneth I. Berns, M.D., PhD., President and Chief Exec Officer The Mount Sinai Medical Center Nathan G. Kase, M.D., Interim Dean Mount Sinai School of Medicine Barry R. Freedman, President The Mount Sinai Hospital

title: How Masters Can Solve Unexpected Problems
description: For three decades nearly all the winning teams in the top American championships have had six players, the maximum. One of the six has almost always been a sponsor who subsidizes the team and plays the minimum number of deals, 50 percent.

title: Sports of The Times; Bad Time for Starters To Be Suddenly Shaky
description: NO matter how many runs the Yankees are ahead when they're playing in Fenway Park, Don Zimmer has a constant reminder for Joe Torre.

title: Colangelo Puts Perspective on the Kidd Trade
description: Jerry Colangelo, the owner of the Phoenix Suns, has watched with interest as Jason Kidd, the point guard he traded last June, has taken the Nets to the Eastern Conference finals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINSTONE, EMANUEL
description: FEINSTONE-Emanuel. The Officers and the Members of Old Oaks Country Club mourn the passing of their dear friend and fellow member Emanuel Feinstone. Heartfelt sympathy is extended to his wife Lorraine and to other members of his family. Paul J. Konigsberg, President

title: Editors' Note
description: Two headlines in Business Day on Monday exceeded the facts of the articles on which they appeared.

title: Bush Urges Germans to Back Tough Action Against Terrorism
description: BERLIN, May 23  President Bush stood in the well of Germany's reconstructed Reichstag today and told the nation's Parliament that the terrorist groups the United States and its allies are hunting down constitute a "new totalitarian threat."

title: TRUMP CASINOS UNIT GETS AN INCREASE IN DEBT RATING
description: The debt rating of Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts Inc. was raised for the second time in five months by the Standard & Poor's Corporation after the company made a $73 million interest payment to bondholders this month. The rating company raised the corporate credit rating on Trump Hotels, which is based in Atlantic City and is led by the developer Donald J. Trump, two notches to CCC from CC. The debt ratings remain in the junk category.

title: A Sentence of Housework
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: Steel Tariff Challenge
description: The United States government has blocked the European Union's request for a panel of World Trade Organization experts to investigate whether the Bush administration's tariffs on steel imports conform with global trade rules. The request, which will be reconsidered on June 3, would set in motion a review of the disputed tariffs that, with appeals, can take the global trade arbiter up to two years to resolve.

title: When Still Meets Video, Can One Camera Do All?
description: DURING the consumer tech boom of the late 1990's, it wasn't hard to imagine how electronics companies dreamed up new products. You could just picture two product managers from different divisions jostling in the hallway. ''Hey, you got your MP3 player in my cellphone!'' ''You got your cellphone in my MP3 player!'' And lo, a product was born.

title: A Photo Program for the Home, And One for the Road
description: Although some professional image-editing programs may cost more than a digital camera, plenty of photo programs are designed to give consumers a lot of feature bang for their buck. Among the offerings is PhotoSuite Platinum Edition by Roxio, which provides users with an easy-to-use interface to edit, modify and get creative with their digital pictures.

title: Portland Voters Endorse Curbs On City Growth
description: Voters in the Portland metropolitan area have turned down an initiative that would have severely weakened how elected officials can determine the shape of new urban areas. It was an endorsement of land-use restrictions that have made Oregon a national model for controlling growth.

title: 3 Democrats Join Senate Panel in Approving a Criticized Judge
description: WASHINGTON, May 23  A federal district judge who has been criticized for some of his rulings and for his membership in an all-male club was endorsed for an appeals court post today. The approval came after three Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee gave President Bush's nominee their support.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUTCH, BARNET M.
description: DEUTCH-Barnet M. On May 21, 2002. Beloved brother of Edward. Also survived by three nieces and a nephew, and dear friend Danuta. Visiting Thursday 2-5pm, Stout Funeral Service Inc., 352 E. 87 St, NYC. Interment private.

title: Sudden Departure At Porter Novelli
description: David Copithorne, global chief executive at Porter Novelli International in New York, a public relations unit of the Omnicom Group, is unexpectedly leaving after less than six months in that post.

title: Hyperactivity Drug
description: Eli Lilly & Company's experimental drug Atomoxetine treats attention deficit hyperactivity disorder in children and teenagers without some of the drawbacks of standard treatments, research has shown.

title: Residential Sales
description: MANHATTAN

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Ventura Vetos Mandatory Pledge
description: Saying that ''patriotism is voluntary,'' Gov. Jesse Ventura vetoed a bill requiring schools to have students recite the Pledge of Allegiance at least once a week. ''A patriot shows their patriotism through their actions, by their choice,'' Governor Ventura, an independent, wrote in a letter explaining his decision. The governor also vetoed money for a new Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis. The Guthrie is a major regional theaters.

title: Chasing Rainbows From the Sky
description: Stripes aren't reserved for tigers or bar codes. They can revive furniture like this bureau, right, that was ''just a frumpy piece of furniture, a dark brown walnut,'' said Barbara Richardson, director of marketing at Glidden Paints in Cleveland. A soft lead pencil was used to mark the stripes, which were painted lightest colors first. Each stripe was allowed to dry before it was covered with masking tape and the next stripe begun.

title: Jack Kruschen, 80, a Stalwart Of Radio, TV and the Movies
description: Jack Kruschen, a versatile character actor whose six decades in movies and television included an Oscar nomination for best supporting actor for his 1960 role in ''The Apartment,'' died on April 2. He was 80.

title: Collection Chronicles A Digital Revolution
description: DIGITAL cameras are a hot new gadget for some, a fixation for others. But for Rodger L. Carter of Xenia, Ohio, they are historical objects -- ones that are disappearing fast.

title: Recharing Batteries and Common Sense
description: Magazine photos of movie stars never show them without makeup. Frozen-food package photos always show the cooked food on a plate, never in its microwaveable plastic dish. And photos of high-tech products never, ever show the power cords.

title: Welfare in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Report Says Al Qaeda May Be Diversifying Its Finances
description: Stymied in part by global efforts to freeze their bank accounts, members of Al Qaeda may be turning to trade in gold, diamonds and gems to finance their terror network, a United Nations monitoring group said in a report issued today.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: DENMARK: CUT LINK TO SWEDEN, MIGRANT FOE URGES The far-right People's Party, which the government depends on for support in Parliament, wants to close the bridge connecting Denmark with Sweden in a move to halt illegal immigration, the party's president said. Pia Kjaersgaard said closing the 10-mile road bridge and tunnel over the Strait of Oresund would prevent illegal immigrants, in particular Islamic immigrants, from entering Denmark. She said Sweden's immigration policies had turned its cities into "Scandinavian Beiruts" with "gang warfare, honor crimes and gang rapes." (Agence France-Presse)

title: STANDARD & POOR'S CUTS QWEST CREDIT RATING
description: The credit rating of Qwest Communications International was cut to junk by Standard & Poor's, which said the company might not be able to fend off competition as it faces a cash squeeze. Qwest's senior unsecured debt rating was cut two levels, to BB from BBB-. The grade may be lowered further, S.& P. said. The downgrade comes as Qwest is selling its yellow pages directory business to raise cash, and is asking bidders to pay $1 billion upfront to help it avoid a loan default. Falling sales and losses pushed Qwest to borrow $4 billion from banks earlier this year because money market investors refused to lend. The cut to junk will probably cause investment funds to sell Qwest bonds because many are restricted from holding speculative-grade debt. Moody's Investors Service still rates Qwest as investment grade, at Baa3, one level above junk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPEARS, JOAN BOGARDUS
description: SPEARS-Joan Bogardus, 63, of Greenwich, CT died Wednesday May 22 at home. She was the wife of William G. Spears; mother of William G. Spears, Jr, Dorothy Spears, Brian Spears, and Wendy Connors; sister of Carol Howell and grandmother of nine. Mrs. Spears was on the music staff of St. Catherine of Siena Church in Greenwich for over 20 years. A Mass of Christian burial will be held Tuesday, May 28, at 11:00 AM in St. Michael's Church, 469 North St, Greenwich, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to the Healthcare Chaplaincy, 307 East 60th Street, NY, NY 10022 or the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, Inc, 1 Pennsylvania Plaza, Suite 1610, NY, NY 10119.

title: Commencement; Columbia University's President Is Moving On, Along With His Graduates
description: Columbia University's commencement ceremony yesterday was an important moment not only for about 10,000 students, but also for several top Columbia officials, including its departing president, George Rupp, and its incoming president, Lee C. Bollinger.

title: Senate Panel Votes to Include More People in Sept. 11 Relief
description: A Senate panel approved a measure today that would expand the number of New Yorkers eligible for emergency housing aid as a result of the attack on the World Trade Center.

title: INSIDE
description: Call to Battle in India

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALLEY, JEREMY
description: PALLEY-Jeremy. Funeral scheduled for Friday, May 24th, 1:30PM at Temple Israel of the City of New York, 112 E. 75th St. Please call Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home 212-288-3500 Friday AM for confirmation.

title: Displaying Dexterity, Diffusing Warmth
description: Alexander Fiterstein, a clarinetist with a warm tone and a powerful technique, was a winner of the Young Concert Artists auditions last year and was presented by the organization in his New York debut recital on Tuesday evening at the 92nd Street Y.

title: Don't Panic
description: Weekly highlights from 150 forums  from reactions to the new threats of terrorism to questions and answers about gardening.

title: White House Asked F.B.I. About Unreported Threats
description: The White House asked the F.B.I. and several intelligence agencies within days after the Sept. 11 attacks whether they had had information about a threat by Al Qaeda that should have been reported to the National Security Council, current and former officials said yesterday.

title: Searching for Clues in the Land of the Blue Dog
description: IT is de rigueur that an actor stepping into a long-running show speak graciously of his new colleagues, and so it is with Donovan Patton of ''Blue's Clues.'' His remarks concerning Slippery Soap and Mr. Mailbox and Side Table Drawer and others have been consistently insightful and respectful. And yet, one cannot but wonder.

title: Deleting Snapshots, Not Your Air Supply
description: Although Joseph Ifi works for a company that produces waterproof film cameras, he admits that underwater photography can be frustrating. With lighting problems and unwanted particles in the water, he said, ''you can often shoot a roll of 24 and only get one good picture.''

title: Women's Qualifiers Set for World Cup
description: The eight-team Concacaf Women's Gold Cup tournament, to be played Oct. 27-Nov. 9, will serve as the qualifying competition for the 2003 Women's World Cup, which will be played in China.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Siemens Cuts Jobs
description: The German electronics and engineering group Siemens said it would cut 2,000 jobs and sell nonprofitable activities of its industrial services unit, affecting another 5,000 jobs, after the division posted a first-half operating loss. The industrial unit, which has 30,000 employees, said demand for its products and services was weakening. About two-thirds of the jobs will be cut in Germany. The restructuring plan aims at saving more than 500 million euros ($464 million) and increasing the division's earnings in the remaining core businesses.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PHILIPPINES: AMERICAN COUPLE ALIVE, LEADER SAYS An American missionary couple who were abducted a year ago by Muslim militants are still alive, the Philipoine president, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, said. Gracia and Martin Burnham of Rose Hill, Kan., remain in captivity although American soldiers went to Basilan Island, where the rebels are holding them, four months ago. But the Filipino leader said the soldiers went to train Filipino troops, not to rescue particular hostages. James Brooke (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about a house in Toronto designed by Brigitte Shim and Howard Sutcliffe misstated the given name of an Italian architect who influenced their work. He was Carlo Scarpa, not Carlos.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Aiding After-School Programs
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday that the city would provide $10.5 million to sustain 87 after-school programs that might otherwise have closed. Mr. Bloomberg did not include the $10.5 million in his January budget proposal. The programs, which are in all five boroughs and serve about 23,000 students, are overseen by the After-School Corporation, financed partly by the philanthropist George Soros. Mr. Soros's Open Society Institute has pledged $20 million, which, combined with other sources of funds, will allow 70 additional programs to continue. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: Inside Out and All Around, A Blueprint Goes Digital
description: How many people understand a blueprint? Not many. Enter the architects John Bennett and Gustavo Bonevardi of Proun Space Studio. They have made a video tour of Aqua, a residential project being built in Miami. The design, by the urban planners Duany Plater-Zyberk, combines New Urbanist principles with modern architecture. The five-minute cyberjourney, left, conveys the feeling of visiting the buildings close up. ''We want to capture the spirit of place, to evoke the feeling of Miami,'' Mr. Bonevardi said. The men recently did another slight-of-eye project -- the towers of light, the World Trade Center memorial. The video tour is to be at www.aqua.net this week. DONNA PAUL

title: Seeking a Balm for a Jittery Land
description: To the Editor:

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Jennifer Connorton, senior account supervisor at the MWW Group, New York, was promoted to vice president. Also, in the consumer marketing practice at the East Rutherford, N.J., office of MWW, Anne Tramer, senior account supervisor, was promoted to vice president, and Tamara Z. Turse, senior account executive, was named account supervisor. MWW is part of Golin/Harris International, part of the Advanced Marketing Services division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Editors' Note
description: Two headlines in Business Day on Monday exceeded the facts of the articles on which they appeared.

title: Treaty of What's Its Name
description: The Kremlin and the White House are portraying the summit meeting that begins here on Friday as the start of a beautiful friendship, the last shovelful of earth on the grave of superpower rivalry and cold war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, AARON J.
description: GROSS-Aaron J. Loving husband of Joanne. In his heart, caring father of Michael, Andrew and Elizabeth, and loving father-in-law to Lynn, Fred and Suzanne. Cherished uncle to Toni, Hilary, Eric, Susan, Mindy and Adam. Adoring grandfather to Kristen, Alex, Matthew, Kevin, Nicholas and Brian. You always said, ''Life was a process of turning corners.'' In this final one, we wish you a peaceful rest. You will be missed.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: Athlete Challenges Law
description: A former tight end for the Pittsburgh Steelers has challenged the state's workers compensation system, saying it improperly limits compensation for professional athletes. Mitch Lyons, whose seven-year career ended with a knee injury, contended in Commonwealth Court that the program is discriminatory because it limits compensation for athletes injured in major league football, basketball, baseball and hockey but permits full compensation for athletes injured in professional soccer and lacrosse and minor league sports. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: An Opera In Which Instruments Are Singers
description: When James Levine asked the composer William Bolcom to write something for the Met Orchestra, he requested that the work include prominent solos for as many of the ensemble's excellent first-chair players as possible. Mr. Bolcom has fulfilled that request, and then some, with his ''Seventh Symphony: A Symphonic Concerto,'' which received its premiere under Mr. Levine in the Met Orchestra's Sunday afternoon concert at Carnegie Hall.

title: Sexuality on Display, Repeatedly
description: THE SEXUAL LIFE OF CATHERINE M.

title: Similar Graphs Raised Suspicions on Bell Labs Research
description: What had been hailed a few months ago as a breakthrough in molecule-size electronics is now in doubt, and a rising star at Bell Laboratories is under suspicion of improperly manipulating data in research papers published in prestigious scientific journals.

title: White House Acknowledges More Contacts With Enron
description: White House officials had more extensive contacts with Enron executives in 2001 than previously disclosed, according to a document released by the Bush administration today in response to a request for information from a Senate committee.

title: Seeking a Balm for a Jittery Land
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk; Liberals Try to Reshape Welfare Debate
description: The fight over welfare legislation moved into the Senate this week, much to the relief of the liberals. Their experience in the Republican-controlled House of Representatives was not pleasant.

title: Even in a Moonscape of Tragedy, Beauty Is in the Eye
description: Is it unseemly now or ever to talk about the beauty of the World Trade Center's ruins? When the towers collapsed, the photographer Joel Meyerowitz was 300 miles away, on Cape Cod. Twelve days later he was closer than any other photographer. He now has thousands of photographs documenting the rescue, recovery and raking of the site, and admits to an obsession.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATHAN, HELEN Y.
description: NATHAN-Helen Y. At home, May 19, 2002, 84 years. 30 year employee of Schrafft's. Retired to New Orleans. Loving mother to Jeanne Nathan of New Orleans; Gail Nathan of NYC; mother-in-law to Robert Tannen; step grandmother of Billie, Erica and Snow Tannen; step great-grandmother of Bobbie Semple. Memorial in New Orleans on August 2nd.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Nine Injured In Building Fire
description: Three children were seriously injured last night in an apartment building fire in Washington Heights that also left three adults hospitalized in stable condition, fire officials said. The two-alarm fire, at 161st Street and Fort Washington Avenue, damaged a third-floor apartment. Three firefighters were treated for minor injuries at the scene. The cause of the fire was under investigation. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Britain and Spain Seek Backing for European Policy on Migrants
description: In moves that appear to be direct responses to the rise of anti-immigrant parties in Europe, France's new government is cracking down on undocumented refugees, and Britain and Spain have called for a Europe-wide policy to get tough on illegal migrants.

title: BB&T AGREES TO BUY REGIONAL FINANCIAL IN FLORIDA
description: The BB&T Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Regional Financial Corporation, a closely held Florida bank holding company, for $275 million in stock, in a move to enter the Florida market. Regional Financial, based in Tallahassee, Fla., is the holding company for First South Bank, which operates 11 retail branches, 3 limited-service branches and 8 mortgage loan production offices. Under the agreement, expected to close in the summer, BB&T of Winston-Salem, N.C., will issue 7.265 million BB&T shares for Regional Financial. BB&T, with annual revenue of $973.6 million last year and total assets of $70.87 billion, has more than 1,100 banking offices in the Carolinas, Georgia, Virginia, Maryland, West Virginia, Kentucky, Tennessee, Alabama, Indiana and Washington, D.C.

title: SOME PLAINTIFFS REJECT SULZER SETTLEMENT
description: Sulzer Medica will have another nine days to persuade plaintiffs to accept its $1 billion settlement of lawsuits over defective hip and knee implants after lawyers said too many people had opted out. A lawyer for Sulzer Medica said the company would probably abandon the accord unless fewer patients opted out. About 100 plaintiffs have dropped out of the settlement to pursue their own claims against the company. Judge Kathleen O'Malley of United States District Court in Cleveland consented to a request from both sides to extend today's settlement deadline to May 31.

title: Skip-the-Ads TV Has Madison Ave. Upset
description: Digital successors to the VCR that eliminate the frustration of recording television programs have crossed a popularity threshold, raising alarm among advertisers and TV executives who see the devices as a threat to the economics of commercial television.

title: Hoping DNA Will Discover Columbus, Post-Mortem
description: In death as in life, it seems, Christopher Columbus could never stay in one place. The many journeys made post-mortem by Columbus, or Cristbal Coln as he is known in Spain, has led to doubt and confusion over his last resting place, with rival tombs claimed by authorities in Seville and Santo Domingo.

title: Top Executive Steps Down At ImClone
description: Samuel D. Waksal, the beleaguered chief executive of ImClone Systems, resigned unexpectedly yesterday on the eve of the company's annual shareholders' meeting. The resignation came after months of questioning about his communications with investors and about the clinical trials of his company's cancer drug, Erbitux.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MAIL-WELL INC., Englewood, Colo., a commercial printer and maker of envelopes, sold its adhesive label unit to Arsenal Capital Partners, New York, and Gregory Mosher, who will operate it as Renaissance Mark Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bank's Profit Rises
description: Royal Bank of Canada, the country's biggest bank, said second-quarter profit rose 12 percent as it cut compensation costs at its investment banking unit and narrowed losses in the United States. Net income climbed to 677 million Canadian dollars ($440.5 million), from 602 million Canadian dollars a year earlier. Revenue in the period, which ended April 30, increased 12 percent, to 3.93 billion Canadian dollars from 3.50 billion Canadian dollars.

title: Latin America holds both risk and reward : A lively Southern exposure
description: CARACAS  Latin America offers considerable opportunity for the bold offshore investor who is willing to stomach a large dose of risk. But growth forecasts of a respectable 3.8 percent for the region for next year come with some caveats.

title: Reform That Leads to Chaos
description: With the possible exception of the I.R.S., the Immigration and Naturalization Service is the least popular agency in the federal government. Congress is so fed up with I.N.S. blunders that it is near a bipartisan agreement on a law dividing the immigration service into separate divisions for services and enforcement. The Bush administration, recognizing this political juggernaut, also favors this plan.

title: Subject: A Firm Goodbye
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasured Images, Baked or on a Stick
description: I WAS in denial for a long time about my inability to handle the terrible responsibility of having sweets in the house.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Woman Killed By School Bus
description: A woman was fatally injured at about 3 p.m. yesterday when she was struck by a school bus as she crossed the street at 68th Street and 19th Avenue in New Utrecht, the police said. The school bus drove away, and it was not known whether the driver knew that someone had been hit. The woman was identified as Tom-Kam-Ngon-Ng, 64, of 70th Street in Brooklyn. She was taken to Maimonides Medical Center, where she died at around 6:30 p.m. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: QAEDA TIP CAUSED ALERT IN NEW YORK
description: The source of a tip this week that terrorists might strike at the Brooklyn Bridge or the Statue of Liberty was Abu Zubaydah, the highest-ranking Qaeda operative captured since Sept. 11, a senior law enforcement official said yesterday. That is one reason New York officials put the city on high alert and publicized details of the threat, something the Federal Bureau of Investigation never intended to do.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Deutsche Telekom Posts Loss
description: The largest telephone company in Europe, Deutsche Telekom, reported a wider-than-expected loss in the first quarter. Earnings for the company fell in Germany and it wrote down the value of investments in other countries. The company said it lost 1.8 billion euros ($1.66 billion), which was up from a loss of 358 million euros a year earlier, according to a spokesman, Hans Ehnert.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nokia To Buy 10% Stake In Redback
description: Nokia, the world's biggest maker of mobile phones, said it would buy a stake in Redback Networks, a fiber optics company in San Jose, Calif. Nokia's infrastructure arm, Nokia Networks, will pay about $36 million for 10 percent of unregistered Redback common stock -- about $2 each for more than 17 million shares -- with an option to buy up to 20 percent of the company's common stock. In addition, Ari Lehtoranta, senior vice president of Nokia Broadband Systems, will take a seat on the Redback board, company officials said. Nokia, based in Finland, and Redback said they would cooperate on technology and product development. Shares of Redback rose 42 cents, to $2.69.

title: Tapping Into Its Strengths, the Empire of Film Strikes Back
description: WHEREVER he goes, Chip Simons usually takes a compact digital camera along in case he needs to grab a quick snapshot. But when it comes time for real work, Mr. Simons, a magazine and advertising photographer who lives in Bosque Farms, N.M., reverts to film.

title: Tipping Off Another Season
description: A look at the W.N.B.A.'s 16 teams, listed in their predicted order of finish. (Records and finishes are for last season.) By FRANK LITSKY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUCKETT, RICHARD B.
description: DUCKETT-Richard B. 79. Died May 5, 2002. He attended the U.S. Naval Academy and George Washington University. During WWII while a pilot on the U.S.S. Intrepid he was awarded the Navy Cross, and a Silver Star. He is survived by his wife, Lemeau ArrottWatt Duckett, NY, NY; and five children and six grandchildren

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sharp Plans New Plant
description: The Sharp Corporation plans to spend as much as 100 billion yen ($805 million) on a new liquid-crystal-display plant to stay competitive with Korean and Taiwanese rivals in the $22 billion market for flat screens. The factory, in western Japan's Mie Prefecture, will be Sharp's most advanced, a director, Shigeo Nakabu, said in an interview.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Suspect In Police Shooting Surrenders
description: A second suspect in the shooting of a rookie police officer surrendered early yesterday, the police said. The suspect, Terrence Harris, 21, of 1750 Prospect Place in Brooklyn, left, surrendered at the 70th Precinct station house in Brooklyn, the same precinct house where Officer Crystal Jeffrey was shot twice by a sniper on Friday. Mr. Harris was charged with attempted murder, assault and gun possession after he turned himself in about 2 a.m., the police said. The first suspect, Damion Henry, 21, was captured on Saturday. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Quality Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Pierce Is Confident Despite His Struggles
description: Paul Pierce and Kenny Anderson believe the Nets should be scared, and who can blame them?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESSER, SANDRA ANN
description: MESSER-Sandra Ann. On May 19, 2002. Loving daughter to the late Mildred V. Banks. She leaves a husband, Paul B. V. Messer; two sons, relatives and friends. Visiting Friday, May 24, 3-7PM. Funeral Mass on Saturday May 25 at 10AM at the Cathedral Church of Saint Thomas, 147 West 144 St., NYC

description: WHATEVER happened to Lisa, Mary, Karen, Susan and Kimberly?

title: Severe Water and Land Loss Predicted Over a Generation
description: Expansion of cities, destruction of forests, erosion of fields and rising demand for water are likely to threaten human and ecological health in many countries for at least a generation, according to a new United Nations report on environmental trends.

description: Merkin Concert Hall

title: Priest Charged From Old File On Sex Abuse
description: Investigators arrested the first Roman Catholic priest yesterday to be charged in New York based on the old case files that the church recently turned over to sex-abuse prosecutors. The priest, the Rev. Francis X. Nelson, 38, was handcuffed near his Harlem church and charged with molesting a 12-year-old girl at her home in Brooklyn three years ago.

title: Changes to Sept. 11 Fund Would Extend Aid to Victims of Past Terror Bombings
description: Democrats and Republicans in the Senate are nearing agreement on changes in the Sept. 11 Victim Compensation Fund that would allow scores of American families from past terrorist attacks to receive hundreds of millions of dollars collectively in compensation.

title: Man Dies in Suspicious Blaze, and Son Is One of Firemen at Scene
description: A Brooklyn man was killed in a suspicious fire that destroyed three residential buildings Wednesday night, and his son was among the first firefighters to respond to the blaze, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, MILDRED
description: ROSENBERG-Mildred. On May 22, 2002. Beloved mother of Jonathan Birnbaum, Avi Birnbaum and Dorit Rosenfeld. Cherished grandmother of Daniel, Alex, Adam, Aliza, Michaela and Sydney. Services Sunday 11:30 am at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, N.J.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Police Dept. To Add Nonlethal Weapons
description: In an effort to change the Detroit Police Department, which has been tarnished by a continuing federal inquiry, Chief Jerry A. Oliver Sr. has said he plans to give officers additional nonlethal weapons. The effort is intended to pre-empt a Justice Department report expected this year that will look into fatal shootings by officers over several years. John Carpenter (NYT)

title: Selling Something? Please Don't Call
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Online Advertising Slipped In 2001
description: Internet advertising revenue in the United States fell 7.5 percent in the fourth quarter of 2001, to $1.7 billion, the Interactive Advertising Bureau announced yesterday. It said the results were ''not unexpected'' considering the overall decline in advertising and the economic slowdown. For all of 2001, marketers spent $7.2 billion on Internet advertising, down 12 percent from 2000. The figures were compiled by PricewaterhouseCoopers for the Interactive Advertising Bureau, an industry trade association. The report also noted that consolidation in the online advertising market had continued, with the top 10 media companies garnering 76 percent of Internet advertising revenue last year. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ALBERTSON'S, Boise, Idaho, an operator of supermarkets and drugstores, said it would spend $1 billion in Southern California over three years to remodel 82 Albertson's groceries and open 30 new ones and to remodel 20 Sav-On drugstores and open 96 new ones.

title: Israelis Consider New Limits on West Bank Palestinians
description: The Israeli Army is stringing barbed wire around this city as part of what aid workers fear are sweeping new restrictions that will further squeeze the Palestinians' already crippled economy and perhaps stoke more violence.

title: SYMMETRICOM AGREES TO BUY DATUM INC. FOR $112 MILLION
description: Symmetricom Inc., a phone equipment maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Datum Inc., a maker of electronic devices, for about $112 million. Symmetricom will issue about 18.4 million common shares for all of the shares of Datum, based in Irvine, Calif. Each Datum share will be exchanged for 2.7609 shares of Symmetricom, the companies said. The value is based on Symmetricom's closing price Wednesday of $6.10 a share. The transaction is expected to add to earnings in the second half of 2003 and save Symmetricom, based in San Jose, Calif., $14 million a year, the company said.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: NTT'S Ratings Cut
description: Moody's Investors Service cut the debt ratings of the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, the world's largest telecommunications company, citing growing competition. The decision will affect 1.9 trillion yen ($15.2 billion) of NTT's obligations. The former government monopoly, which lost a record $6.5 billion in fiscal 2001, is struggling to trim its bloated work force and budget as rivals cut prices and offer new broadband services. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Pakistan Prepares to Shift Troops From Afghan Border to Kashmir
description: Pakistan is preparing to shift troops from the border with Afghanistan, where they are engaged in the hunt for Qaeda and Taliban fighters, to the front in Kashmir, where tensions with India are quickly rising, the government said today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts on Tuesday about the Paris Opera Ballet School referred incorrectly to the production of ''La Fille Mal Garde'' presented this spring. It was by the school's director, Claude Bessy, based on versions that can be traced to 1789; it was not the version choreographed by Sir Frederick Ashton.

title: Residential Real Estate; Preservation Group's Campaign Ruffles Feathers
description: A new kid on the block among the city's landmark preservation organizations has been gathering easements from homeowners in historic districts in exchange for charitable tax deductions, all in accordance with Internal Revenue Service codes. And at the same time, it has rankled the preservation establishment.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Fund Group Acquired
description: The Man Group, a British hedge fund, said it agreed to buy the RMF Investment Group of Switzerland for $833 million in cash and stock. The enlarged group would be the largest hedge fund in Europe, with assets under management totaling $20 billion, the companies said. Hedge funds have been one of the fastest-growing investment categories in recent years. Man said it would finance the acquisition, which is not expected to affect earnings this year, with $250 million in cash, the issuance of 23.3 million ordinary shares and the placing of $260 million worth of new shares. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Times Reporter Is New Washington Editor
description: Richard L. Berke, the national political correspondent of The New York Times for the last nine years, has been appointed the newspaper's Washington editor, the No. 2 executive in a bureau with more than 50 reporters and editors.

title: Ready to Play a Mind Game?
description: Don't bother poking the menu key on a new DVD edition of Christopher Nolan's "Memento," released this week by Columbia TriStar. Neither of the two discs has a menu, or one that lists features in standard fashion. Instead, one gets to the contents through a "mental health battery," or series of questions and exercises to measure contextual retention, comprehension skills and the like. Respond the right way, and you will find the feature you seek. Answer another way, and you won't.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Still Defiant In Beef Dispute
description: The new agriculture minister, Herv Gaymard, said he would not lift the six-year-old embargo on British beef despite an order to do so from the European Court of Justice in December. A British government spokesman said that the decision was ''misguided and wrong,'' and that Britain would press for fines on France. France banned British beef in early 1996 for fear of mad cow disease. Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)

title: McCain's Battle Against Big Money in National Politics
description: CITIZEN McCAIN

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Encounters On a Stroll By Twilight
description: The fifth entry in the Diamond Project, the New York City Ballet's current showcase for new works, is ''Twilight Courante'' by Stephen Baynes, resident choreographer of the Australian Ballet.

title: Politics And Power, Done as Myth
description: With ''Sia: The Dream of the Python,'' the African filmmaker Dani Kouyat continues the project he began in 1995 with his first feature, ''Keita!'': to find a cinematic equivalent for the voice of the griot, the traditional singer-storyteller whose responsibility it was to convey the history and culture of his people in the absence of a written language.

title: Many Visions for the West Bank
description: To the Editor:

title: The World's Game Is Not Just a Game
description: In early 1994, Osama bin Laden spent three months in London, where he visited supporters and bankers and went to watch the famous soccer club Arsenal four times. Before returning to Sudan just a step ahead of being extradited to Saudi Arabia, he bought his sons gifts from the club's souvenir shop. His affection for the game did not stop him from getting involved in a plot to massacre the American and British teams at the 1998 World Cup in France; still, bin Laden told friends he had never seen passion like that of soccer fans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VESELY, ERNST L.
description: VESELY-Ernst L. 94. Died Wednesday, May 22, 2002 at his residence in Fearrington Village. Ernst came from Germany at the age of 17 and was a successful fur broker. A memorial service is planned for a later date. Mr Vesely is survived by his partner, Joan Glacken of the home, son, Paul David Vesely of New Jersey, daughters Virginia Bohnaker of Lynchburg, VA and Barbara Brown of Sykesville, MD; sisters Ursula Globig of Portugal and Erna Floch of Tequesta, FL; nine grandchildren and eleven great grandchildren. In lieu of flowers the family requests memorial contributions be made to UNICEF, 333 E 38 St, NY, NY 10016; email condolences may be sent to info@griffinfuneral.com

title: Martin Puryear
description: McKee Gallery

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Uncrossed Paths

title: Mischa Maisky and Martha Argerich
description: Carnegie Hall

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 29 about reaction by members of Most Holy Redeemer Catholic Church in San Francisco, a largely gay parish, to the issue of sexual abuse by priests referred incorrectly to the church's pastor. The priest, who was not named in the article, does not discuss his sexual orientation. He is not openly gay.

title: Ex-Classmates Recall Efforts To Coerce Skakel to Confess
description: Two classmates of Michael C. Skakel's at a school for troubled youths in Maine testified today that Mr. Skakel was repeatedly beaten, paddled and intimidated in an effort to make him say he had killed Martha Moxley. But the classmates said that despite the pressure, they never heard Mr. Skakel confess.

title: The Christies Are Keeping Temptation On the Ropes
description: In the final minute of an N.B.A. playoff game on Monday night, Doug Christie raised his left fist, extending his pinkie and index fingers toward the rafters of Arco Arena. Christie, a lanky swingman for the Sacramento Kings, appeared to be calling out a play for his teammates.

title: Guthrie Theater Plans Are Imperiled by Veto
description: By vetoing $24 million to build a new home for the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis, Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota has made that theater the latest victim of a wave of state and local budget cuts that are reducing arts programs across the United States.

title: U.N. Extends Tenure Of Afghan Forces
description: The Security Council extended the tenure of international troops in Afghanistan today for another six months but chose not to expand their ranks, as Afghanistan's interim government and some senior United Nations officials had urged.

title: National Briefing | Consumers: Dispute Over Thongs For Youths
description: Abercrombie & Fitch, the casual-clothing chain that has frequently buoyed its profile and sales through provocative advertising and products, is courting controversy again. The chain's thong underwear aimed at 7- to 14-year-olds, with some items emblazoned with ''eye candy'' and ''wink wink,'' has prompted a protest e-mail campaign from two Christian groups, the American Family Association and the American Decency Association. The company denied reports that it had withdrawn the items from its shelves. Leslie Kaufman (NYT)

title: U.S. and Russia Sign Nuclear Weapons Reduction Treaty
description: MOSCOW, May 24  President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia signed a treaty in the Kremlin today that commits both nations to the most drastic nuclear arms reductions in decades.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTSCH, THOMAS W., SR.
description: BARTSCH-Thomas W., Sr. 100, of Williamsburg, VA and formerly of Pelham Manor, NY died on May 21, 2002. Mr. Bartsch was a member of the New York Stock Exchange with the firm of Travers & Bartsch. He was a member of the Pelham Country Club, the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick, the Knights of Malta and the Knights of the Holy Sepulcher. He served on the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity and on the Board of the Mount Loretta Home in Staten Island. Mr. Bartsch was most proud of receiving, for his humanitarian services, the Brotherhood Award from The National Conference of Christians and Jews. He was predeceased by his wife, Ida Becker Bartsch in 1992. He is survived by his sons, Thomas, Jr.(Margaret) of Williamsburg, VA, Robert (Avda) of North White Plains, NY and Donald (Martha) of Weston, VT, and his daughter Marylou (Anthony) D'Onofrio of New Rochelle, NY, 15 grandchildren and 21 great-grandchildren. Reposing at Hawthorne Funeral Home, 21 Stevens Avenue, Hawthorne, NY (914769-4404), Monday 3-7 pm. Funeral mass St. Francis of Assisi Chapel at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY on Tuesday 11:30 am. Interment to follow. In lieu of flowers, donations to Catholic Charities would be appreciated.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: U.S. Offers Missiles
description: The Pentagon has offered to supply medium-range air-to-air missiles to Brazil, marking the first time the United States has authorized the sale of the weapons, recently denied to Chile, in Latin America. The action is seen as an attempt to gain an edge for the American F-16 in the intense competition to sell as many as 24 new fighter planes to the Brazilian Air Force; Brazil is believed to favor the French-made Mirage. Larry Rohter (NYT)

description: ON THE STREET

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: John Gaffney, president at ArnoldMPG, Boston, part of the Media Planning Group, was named to the new post of chief operating officer for the United States operations of the Media Planning Group. The Media Planning Group is part of Havas. Mr. Gaffney will also work from New York.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: National Briefing | New England: Judge Reverses Her Decision On Fishing
description: A federal judge, in a case on cod and haddock fishing off New England, reversed her decision that she said could have caused ''grave economic and social hardship'' for fishing communities and inadequately protected fish. The ruling, by Judge Gladys Kessler of Federal District Court in Washington last month, would have sharply limited the days many boats could put to sea and chose a formula that includes a 20 percent cut in the days when boats can fish, reductions in the number of nets and a requirement to monitor fishing to ensure that just sanctioned species are caught. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Cuba: Terror Designation Rejected
description: The government said the State Department's inclusion of Cuba this week on a list of nations that sponsor terrorism was an arbitrary act intended to garner Cuban-American votes and prevent any congressional moves toward easing American policy. The Communist Party newspaper, Granma, responding to to President Bush's statements this week rejecting an end to the United States trade embargo, said American policies amounted to ''more expenditures, measures and technologies to sow poison in our country.'' David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITCHEL, JESS
description: WITCHEL-Jess. On May 22, 2002. Died peacefully after a long battle with Alzheimer's. An active and dedicated teacher, coach and administrator in NYC high schools and at CCNY, Jess' contribution to his colleagues, students and public education was inestimable. He leaves his loving wife, Ruth, his son Carl, his daughter-in-law Lucie Rodrigue, his grandsons Alexandre and Simone RodrigueWitchel as well as family and many friends. Donations in his memory can be made to the Alzheimer's Association. Services Sunday 11:15 am at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment to follow at Mt. Judah Cemetery, Glendale, NY

title: City Wants Stock Exchange To Invest More for Complex
description: The Bloomberg administration has asked the New York Stock Exchange to double its investment, to $900 million, in a plan for a heavily subsidized trading complex that former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani once called a ''Christmas gift to the city.''

title: Congress Plans to Investigate F.B.I. Agent's Complaints
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  Lawmakers vowed today to look closely at an F.B.I. agent's complaints that a pre-Sept. 11 investigation of Zacarias Moussaoui, the so-called 20th hijacker, was hindered by the Washington headquarters of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Sam Snead, Smooth-Swinging Winner of Record 81 PGA Tour Events, Dies at 89
description: Sam Snead, who used golf's smoothest swing to win a record 81 PGA Tour events and about 70 other tournaments, died yesterday at his home in Hot Springs, Va. He was 89.

description: WHETHER you are opening a summer house or vacating the one you own in anticipation of the renters, you will need to do a lot of pushing and pulling. Sliders, grippers and haulers are definitely the way to go.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day last Friday with an article about trades by energy companies that sought to develop a market in high-speed communications capacity misstated the number of trades made in two directions on the same day at identical prices by Reliant Resources with each of two other companies -- Enron and Aquila. And a correction in this space on Saturday again misstated the Aquila figure. From December 2000 through October 2001, Reliant had 18 such trades with Enron not 19. Reliant had 5 with Aquila over the same period, not 12 or 11.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Belarus: Crackdown On McDonald's
description: The authorities in the capital, Minsk, said they would no longer allot land there to build McDonald's restaurants because the Health Ministry has declared its food dangerous to the nation's citizens. McDonald's is one of the few visible symbols of American culture in Belarus, whose autocratic leader, Aleksandr Lukashenko, has been ostracized by the United States and most of the West. The Health Ministry has urged Belarussians to patronize local fast-food shops. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Kosovo: U.N. Governor Overrules Assembly
description: The province's fledgling assembly tried to assert its independence by refusing to recognize a border treaty signed by Yugoslavia and Macedonia but was immediately overruled by the United Nations governor. Michael Steiner, who heads the United Nations administration that has run Kosovo since NATO's war in 1999 to stop Yugoslavia's repression of ethnic Albanians in the province, which is part of Yugoslavia, told the assembly the move exceeded its limited self-rule powers. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: Ex-Officer Sentenced to Maximum for Crash That Killed 4
description: After hearing tearful pleas from both sides, a Brooklyn judge sentenced a former veteran police officer to the maximum of 5 to 15 years in prison yesterday for getting drunk in a station-house parking lot last August and driving his speeding minivan into a pregnant woman and her family, killing four people.

title: In the Green Lap of Spring
description: In early spring, entering Central Park is like walking into an emerald. I go there every chance I get in this season, usually in the morning, slipping into its greenness alone after dropping a child off at school, before heading to work.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Conflict At Whaling Meeting
description: The International Whaling Commission voted to deny Japan a return to commercial whaling and Japan responded by organizing a vote to deny Alaskan and Russian indigenous people the right to hunt whales. Masayuki Komatsu, Japan's Fisheries Agency counselor, said, ''America should feel the same pain that Japan has felt for 15 years.'' Facing the first denial of aboriginal quotas by the whaling group, Americans and Russians worked on a compromise for today, the last day of the commission's meeting. James Brooke (NYT)

title: The Objects of Their Desire
description: THOUGH some cars are coveted simply because of their emotional resonance, still others deserve their place in the pantheon for the historic role they played in automotive design. Here, based on interviews with collectors and historians, is a Top 10 ''wish list,'' drawn from cars produced in the last 50 years.

title: Panel Approves Bush Appeals Court Pick
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee approved one of President Bush's appeals court nominees today after a debate that was less about the usual issue of the candidate's ideology than about his membership in an all-male fishing club.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PFEFFER, RICHARD
description: PFEFFER-Richard. 65. Of Baltimore, MD., on May 20, 2002. Johns Hopkins Professor, Attorney U.S. Department of Labor. Son of Syril Pfeffer and the late Harry Pfeffer of Woodmere, NY.

title: Rehovot Journal; Cluck! Cluck! Chickens in Their Birthday Suits!
description: Soft and warm as babies, more naked than jaybirds, two mutant, featherless chickens gamboled on the close-cropped lawn.

description: NEW YORK

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bankers' Workweek Cut
description: Bank workers got a five-day workweek, which will begin on July 1 after they threatened to go on strike next week before the opening today of the World Cup soccer tournament. The government suggested that the workweek be cut from its existing six or five and a half days. The Korean Employers Federation warned, however, that the five-day workweek would have ''a far-reaching impact on our economy.'' Bank representatives said they agreed, since so much business is conducted by Internet banking and automated teller machines. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDIS, MORRIS B.
description: LANDIS-Morris B. Of Highland Park, NJ and Aventura, FL. Beloved husband of Raye nee Rosenbaum. Devoted father of Mark, Alan, Diana, Ilene, Mitchell and Tefera. Father-in-law of Carolyn, Linda, Jeffrey and Linda Jean. Dear brother of Alex and Sam. Loving grandfather of 12 grandchildren and 2 great-grandchildren. Dad, Grandpa, Meish, Uncle Morris, ''The Producer''. Always a trendsetter, with a healthy diet and exercise, always years ahead of his time, the eternal overflowing optimist. Now at his passing, years ahead of his time. We will all miss our greatest cheerleader and supporter. We hope throughout our lives and those of future generations that Dad's very special being will live on. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Central New Jersey Jewish Home for the Aged, 732-873-2000 or to the Israel Emergency Fund of the UJA Federation, 212-980-1000. Services were held. For information ''Wein & Wein'', 800-322-0533.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about efforts to keep businesses in Lower Manhattan misstated the current location of Richards Spears Kibbe & Orbe, a law firm that signed a lease for space at 1 World Financial Center. Its offices are downtown in Chase Manhattan Plaza, not in Midtown.

title: Rare Proxy Vote Fails in Japan
description: Shareholders of the Tokyo Style Company, a midsize maker of apparel, rejected proposals today that would have forced management to return nearly half its cash to investors, dealing a setback to Japan's small but growing band of shareholder activists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORD, WALTER
description: LORD-Walter. Walter was a founding trustee of the Ocean Liner Museum. Historian par excellence, wise colleague and beloved friend, Walter will be sorely missed by all who served with him. His long suffering from the Parkinson's disease that killed him was endured with extraordinary patience and uncommon grace. The officers, trustees and members of the Ocean Liner Museum of New York lament his passing.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day on Tuesday about an agreement by the Bank of New York to acquire a New York trading firm, Francis P. Maglio, carried an erroneous credit. It was by Bloomberg News, not The Associated Press.

description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey's Senate Hopefuls Save Their Fire for Torricelli
description: With less than two weeks before the New Jersey Republican primary for United States Senate, the three candidates yesterday spent what was billed as a debate agreeing more often than arguing -- cheering on President Bush, denouncing taxes and lashing the Democratic incumbent they each hope to face in November.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOLAN, MARGARET P.
description: NOLAN-Margaret P. The trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of Margaret P. Nolan, who was a devoted employee of the Museum for 48 years. At the time of her retirement in 1985, she was Chief Librarian of the Photograph and Slide Library, and had authored a number of respected publications in her field. She will be missed. Philippe de Montebello, Director

title: Hiding a Television Commercial in Plain View
description: An NBC-owned talk show is offering marketers the chance to buy guest spots for their products and executives, further blurring the line between programming and advertising.

title: Pakistan to Test Missiles, but Tensions With India Decline
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 24  A day after India indicated that the military standoff between their two countries was easing, Pakistan said today that it would conduct a series of missile tests this weekend, but it denied any provocative intention.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Proposal To Ban Smoking In Bars
description: Health officials in 12 cities and towns, including Boston, announced a plan to try to ban smoking in bars and nightclubs. In many cities, bars are the last remaining public sites where people can light up. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: U.S. Soccer Team Lands in Seoul and Is Put Under Tight Security
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 24  Amid extraordinary security in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the United States soccer team arrived here today to begin preparations for the World Cup finals.

title: The Celtics' Walker Grows Into His Starring Role and Offers More in the Process
description: It is easy to get the wrong impression of Antoine Walker. After all, he does not appear selfless when engaging in a wiggle dance near midcourt, and the two or three reckless 25-footers he hoists each game make him look like anything but a basketball sage.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Another Flying Season Begins
description: With the arrival of Memorial Day weekend, the traditional kickoff of the summer travel season, Americans are expected to take to the skies in numbers not seen since the days before the terror attacks of Sept. 11. Because of the continuing federal takeover of security at airports, travelers will face delays and disruptions. They shouldn't complain. The long lines, careful baggage checks and other obstacles are healthy signs that the government is working hard to make flying safer.

title: Florida Files Reveal Harsh Life of a Missing Girl
description: Rilya Wilson, the 5-year-old missing Miami girl, has not been seen for more than a year. But glimpses of her harsh early life are revealed in her state child welfare file, which was made public by court order today.

description: SOUTH KOREA: BANKERS' WORKWEEK CUT Bank workers got a five-day workweek, which will begin on July 1 after they threatened to go on strike next week before the opening today of the World Cup soccer tournament. title: Plates on the Wall? One Decorating Motif
description: A FEW years ago, in a moment of weakness, I did something I usually hesitate to do: I tried to match an interior decorator with some potential clients that I did not know very well. I took the risk because I felt that the New York-based designer Victoria Hagan had the right style -- a sophisticated informal elegance -- to strike the perfect note with people whose taste tended toward the traditional, but who wanted to try something a bit younger. It seemed a good match.

title: Verizon Unit Picks Kirshenbaum Bond
description: Verizon Information Services in Dallas, a division of Verizon Communications, said yesterday that it had selected Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York, part of the Kirshenbaum Bond Creative Network, to handle the account for the SuperPages yellow pages directory and an online directory, SuperPages .com. Billings were estimated at $30 million to $40 million.

description: Debate Grows Over Links In Government to Business

title: Green Ends Slump in a Big Way By Hitting Four Home Runs
description: Of all of baseball's one-game glamour feats, hitting four home runs is the rarest. It's so rare that until this season, players had achieved it only 12 times. Never had 2 of those 12 players hit four home runs in a game in the same season.

title: GLAXO LOSES EXCLUSIVE RIGHT TO AN ANTIBIOTIC
description: A federal judge invalidated GlaxoSmithKline's patents for Augmentin yesterday, clearing the way for rivals to introduce low-cost versions of the antibiotic. The generic drug makers Teva Pharmaceuticals Industries; Geneva Pharmaceuticals, a unit of Novartis; and Ranbaxy Laboratories sued to invalidate three patents that protect Augmentin from generic competition through December. Judge Henry Coke Morgan Jr. of United States District Court in Norfolk, Va., said the patents did not contain new inventions and should be invalidated. His decision will cost Glaxo its exclusive right to sell the antibiotic, which brings the company $2 billion a year in sales. A Glaxo spokeswoman said the company, based in Middlesex, England, would appeal.

title: Durham Bulls Starting To Show Their Potential
description: The Tampa Bay Devil Rays are often compared to a Class AAA team, but they can take some solace that at least their real AAA team, the Durham Bulls, is having success.

title: Knicks to Take a Look At Connecticut's Butler
description: Caron Butler, a small forward from the University of Connecticut, will work out for the Knicks today. A 6-foot-7 sophomore with strength and athleticism, Butler is considered a definite lottery pick in next month's draft.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Wishful thinking might bring comfort, but not security.''

title: Land of the Fjords
description: Norwegian Coastal Voyage has reduced the prices of various packages that include cruises along the Norwegian coast, hotels in Oslo and Bergen, rail travel between those cities and air fare from New York. For example, a 15-day plan that includes a round-trip cruise aboard the Finnmarken or Trollfjord from Bergen has been discounted $115 to $125  to $3,570 to $4,535 a person, double occupancy  through this year. Each ship carries cargo in addition to about 650 passengers. Both are new for 2002. Information: (800) 323-7436 or www.coastalvoyage.com .

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: FAMILIES OF 9/11 VICTIMS PLAN CEREMONY

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: TV Ad Portrays Governor As Rat
description: A television commercial that depicts Gov. Roy E. Barnes as a giant crowned rat scaling the Capitol dome has brought attention to an obscure opponent. But it has also embarrassed other Republican challengers. The advertisement, by former State Senator Sonny Perdue, plays on the nickname King Roy, used by many Republicans to describe the Democratic governor's tactics in changing the state flag and education system. David Firestone (NYT)

title: Bush, in Berlin, Calms Some European Fears With Talk of Partnership and Aid
description: President Bush delivered a well-prepared speech here today that pleased his supporters and surprised some of his critics, touching on sensitive topics without belaboring them and emphasizing the shared values and risks of the trans-Atlantic alliance.

title: Military Would Be Stressed By a New War, Study Finds
description: A top-secret Pentagon war game has revealed that expanding the campaign against terrorism to a country like Iraq would place severe strains on personnel and cause deep shortages of certain critical weapons, senior officials say.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Theater Parties In a Tony Chase

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Wounded Policeman Out Of Hospital
description: An undercover police officer shot during a gunfight was released from Jamaica Hospital Medical Center yesterday and is expected to make a full recovery, said Tara Fleming, a hospital spokeswoman. The officer, Artie Marquez, was shot in his left hand on Wednesday as he tried to buy 10 9-millimeter handguns for $750 each, the police said. The gun battle erupted about 10 p.m. in a hallway of the Langston Hughes Houses in Brownsville. Four suspects were arrested and a fifth is still at large, the police said. Officer Marquez is part of the Narcotics Division's Firearms Investigation Unit, which has taken 89 illegal guns off the street since the start of the year. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Racehorses, On the Run And in Repose
description: When Christie's scheduled its sporting art sale for next Thursday, it did not know that an obscure thoroughbred racehorse named War Emblem would capture the public's imagination by winning, against all odds, both the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes, the first two legs of the Triple Crown. Still, the auction date is not an accident.

title: A Doctor Is Charged With Fraud in Eye Surgery on the Mentally Ill
description: An ophthalmologist accused of conducting unnecessary eye surgery on mentally ill residents of adult homes in New York City surrendered to the authorities yesterday and was charged with health care fraud, officials said.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: EUROPE RUSSIA: COMMUNISTS WANT TO PURGE A LEADER The Communist Party leadership has recommended that Gennadi Seleznyov, speaker of the lower house of Parliament and one of the party's most prominent figures, be expelled, the Interfax news agency reported. Leading Communists urged last month that Mr. Seleznyov be expelled after a coalition of moderate and liberal Parliament members stripped the Communists of most of their committee chairmanships. Mr. Seleznyov, among the more moderate Communist leaders, has largely cooperated with President Vladimir V. Putin to the dismay of party members.    Michael Wines (NYT)

title: School Board Set to Vote on Levy's Contract
description: With Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg still struggling to win control of the public school system, the Board of Education announced yesterday that it planned to vote next week on Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy's contract.

title: Kmart Loses $1 Billion in Five Weeks
description: With some stores closing and shoppers avoiding others, the Kmart Corporation lost more than $1 billion during the five weeks ended May 1, according to a regulatory filing released yesterday.

title: Golfers Recall One Who Set the Standard
description: As word of Sam Snead's death reached the Memorial Tournament today, players remembered the beauty of his swing, his earthy sense of humor and his lasting contributions to golf.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Politician Seeks Asylum
description: Pedro Carmona, the Venezuelan businessman-turned-politician who replaced President Hugo Chvez during his two-day ouster last month, sought political asylum at the Colombian Embassy in Caracas, officials in both countries confirmed. Mr. Carmona, who had been under house arrest, was secluded in the Colombian Embassy residence, said Colombia's foreign minister, Guillermo Fernndez de Soto, who planned to discuss the issue with Colombia's president, Andrs Pastrana. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Red Sox and Yankees Never a Regular Series
description: THE chants about the Yankees essentially being inferior, although a much more derisive description is routinely used, filled the sticky and crowded Fenway Park last night, last month and for the last century. The Yankees hover over the Boston Red Sox and their loyal, beleaguered fans even when nestled in the Bronx. But when the Yankees are in the house? Think obsession.

title: Bill for Emergency Spending Bogs Down in Partisan Rancor
description: A $29.4 billion emergency spending bill for military operations and domestic security was caught up in a partisan firestorm in the House today, and the result was a session that headed deep into the night as Democrats dragged out debate in a dispute over the national debt.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Accused of Sexual Assault, Archbishop Seeks to Retire
description: Archbishop Rembert G. Weakland of Milwaukee asked the Vatican yesterday to speed up his retirement, hours after a man gave a television interview saying the archbishop had sexually assaulted him when he was a 33-year-old graduate student, then paid him $450,000 in 1998 in a confidential settlement.

title: 'Artists to Artists' -- 'A Decade of the Space Program'
description: Ace Gallery

title: Calpers to Vote Against Auditor Choices
description: The California Public Employees' Retirement System will vote against reappointing auditors at companies including Exxon Mobil, Home Depot and McDonald's because they pay the accountants for nonaudit services.

title: Weekender | Sea Girt, N.J.
description: SPEND some time in the borough of Sea Girt, about 90 minutes south of Manhattan, and sooner or later you will find yourself sauntering into Ray's Cafe for a cup of coffee. A fixture on the main street of this New Jersey shore town, Ray's offers standard grill fare and the kind of low-key, welcoming atmosphere you might think has gone the way of Mayberry R.F.D.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: ARGENTINA: PRESIDENT THREATENS TO QUIT President Eduardo Duhalde has threatened to resign unless Congress moves more quickly to approve legislation necessary to get crucial financing from the International Monetary Fund. "At this pace, I'm not interested," the president told legislators from his Peronist party, according to his spokesman. The lawmakers have held up repeal of a law that allows the government to hold bankers responsible for Argentina's economic crisis.    Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKER, ESTHER ROSE. (NEE BILLET)
description: ZUCKER-Esther Rose. (nee Billet) Died peacefully at home in Brooklyn on May 21, 2002 two days before her 89th birthday. She was an inspiring leader and loving and devoted to her people through her service as both President of Boro Park Hadassah and Vice President and fund raising chair of the Hadassah Brooklyn Region. She is survived by her children Reva Sharon, David Zucker and Dan Freeman, her grandchildren and great-grandaughter. Contributions can be made to Boro Park Chapter of Hadassah, 4802 15th Ave, Brooklyn, NY 11219. Services will be held at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'', 1895 Flatbush Ave (at Avenue L), Brooklyn, Sunday at 11:30 AM.

title: Notes From San Jose; Silicon Valley Grows Up
description: On some stretches of Highway 880, curling around the east side of San Francisco Bay, you can drive by row after row of pristine office buildings, constructed just before the bust, never occupied by a single tenant. These days, Silicon Valley's traffic, like the valley's ambitions, isn't as ferocious as it used to be. Sometimes it's even possible to get from San Francisco to San Jose in less than 90 minutes.

title: Profit at Foot Locker Falls 46%
description: Foot Locker said yesterday that its first-quarter profit fell 46 percent because of a decline in the value of some assets sold last year. The company, the largest athletic-shoe and clothing retailer in the nation, raised its profit estimate for the current quarter.

title: Little Ones, Are You Haves or Have-Nots?
description: Around the turn of the century, there was Lewis Hine (1874-1940), who photographed children toiling in mills and factories. And then there were the Pictorialists, led by Alfred Stieglitz (1864-1946), who took charming, romantic pictures of children in the toils of middle-class privilege. Which children were really better off? This is one of the questions raised by an insightful show with a cumbersome title, ''Priceless Children: American Photographs 1890-1925 -- Child Labor and the Pictorialist Ideal,'' at the Grey Art Gallery of New York University.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Communists Want To Purge A Leader
description: The Communist Party leadership has recommended that Gennadi Seleznyov, speaker of the lower house of Parliament and one of the party's most prominent figures, be expelled, the Interfax news agency reported. Leading Communists urged last month that Mr. Seleznyov be expelled after a coalition of moderate and liberal Parliament members stripped the Communists of most of their committee chairmanships. title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: DirecTV To Test Video-On-Demand Services
description: In an attempt to match cable companies' expanded digital offerings, the satellite television service DirecTV will begin testing subscription video-on-demand services with Starz Encore, a premium movie provider. DirecTV is part of Hughes Electronics, which General Motors is selling to EchoStar Communications. The Starz Encore Group is part of Liberty Media. Because satellite companies do not have a direct two-way connection with customers, DirecTV will use digital video recording technology from TiVo. Movies will be stored on the subscribers' TiVo hard drives and refreshed every week. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: CROWN CORK TO SELL NOTES AND A STAKE IN PLASTICS UNIT
description: The Crown Cork and Seal Company said yesterday that it planned to raise about $350 million by selling notes and a stake in a unit that makes plastic bottles. Crown Cork, the maker of about a fifth of the world's cans, said the proceeds would be used to reduce debt. It filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a $150 million initial public offering for the unit, Constar International, and as much as $200 million of notes due in 2012 for the unit. Crown Cork, based in Philadelphia, has had losses in five of the last six quarters and has been burdened with asbestos claims. The company's stock rose $1.67, or 21 percent, to $9.51 a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGMAN, ETHEL GARBER
description: BERGMAN-Ethel Garber. The Jerusalem Foundation, Inc. is saddened by the passing of Ethel Garber Bergman, beloved mother of Sandra Rubin, Executive Director of The Jerusalem Foundation, Inc., Lila Halpern and Marjorie Rappaport; mother-in-law to Alan Rubin and Seymour Rappaport; loving grandmother to seven grandchildren and five great grandchildren. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and of Jerusalem. Kenneth J. Bialkin, Acting Chair Teddy Kollek, Int'l Chairman Ruth Cheshin, Int'l President
