description: There is evidence that the man accused of trying to blow up a Paris-to-Miami flight with bombs hidden in his sneakers did not act alone, according to court documents filed today.

title: To Russia, With a Message
description: To the Editor:

title: F.D.A. Panel Recommends Approval for Psoriasis Drug
description: A federal advisory panel recommended approval of Biogen's psoriasis drug, potentially clearing the way for the marketing of the first new type of treatment in years for this skin condition and lifting beleaguered biotechnology stocks.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: No Voodoo In Union Vote At Nursing Home
description: A judge with the National Labor Relations Board has rejected a nursing home's assertion that union supporters illegally used voodoo signs to intimidate workers into voting for a union. In his decision, Judge David Weitzner found that organizers might have used voodoo signs and rituals at the home, but he said the signs did not affect the outcome of the unionization election in which workers at the Mount-Sinai-St. Francis Nursing and Rehabilitation Center near Miami voted to join the Service Employees International Union. Many of the workers are immigrants from Haiti, where voodoo is a traditional religion. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Time to Get Even
description: In Michael Apted's ''Enough,'' Jennifer Lopez, below, plays a waitress who marries a rich, vicious abuser. But she learns to fight back.

title: Torricelli Donor Gets 18-Month Term for Illegal Contributions
description: David Chang, the immigrant businessman whose largess as a political donor helped him win access to the most powerful officials in Washington, was sentenced today to 18 months in prison for making $53,000 in illegal contributions to Robert G. Torricelli's successful 1996 campaign for the United States Senate.

title: America The Scofflaw
description: Early in the Reagan administration I spent a year on the staff of the Council of Economic Advisers. While there I got a disillusioning look at how economic policy is really made. But one favorable surprise was how seriously U.S. officials took our international trade agreements.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Steel Maker's Profit Falls
description: The German steel maker ThyssenKrupp A.G. said its pretax profit fell in the second quarter to 96 million euros ($88.4 million), down 40 percent from the previous year. Sales in the quarter fell 4.3 percent to 9 billion euros ($8.3 billion). Its profit included a one-time gain of 91 million euros from the sale of assets. ThyssenKrupp said the results, which had been expected to be weak, resulted from poor demand in the United States and Europe and low steel prices. The company also lowered its forecast for full-year profit to 400 million euros ($369 million) because of $100 milion in anticipated revamping costs. Petra Kappl (NYT)

description: WALLMAN-Natalie. May 22, 2002 at age 82. Cherished wife of Pete Wallman; devoted mother of Barbara Fass and Bill Wallman; loving grandmother of Bob Fass; beloved sister of Phoebe Horowitz and Herb Levin. She touched many lives, and will be greatly missed. Burial and graveside service on Sunday, May 26, 11:00 AM at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Route 109 and Southern State Parkway (Exit 33), Lindenhurst, NY.

description: ''Bartleby'' was shown as part of last year's New Directors/New Films Series. Following are excerpts from A. O. Scott's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 23, 2001; the full text is online at nytimes.com/movies. The film opens today at the Angelika Film Center, Mercer and Houston Streets, Greenwich Village.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: ECONOMY PULLS OUT OF RECESSION Germa- ny's economy grew 0.2 percent in the first quarter of 2002, pulling out of a mild recession, according to government figures. The Federal Statistics Office said that while gross domestic product picked up slightly compared with the previous three months, it shrank by 1.2 percent compared with the first quarter of last year. Exports were largely responsible for the slight increase. With the election set for Sept. 22, Chancellor Gerhard Schroder is facing heavy fire over the economy. (AP)

title: Martnez Strikes Out 10 to Cool Red-Hot Yankees
description: Jorge Posada hunched over the dugout steps in the seventh inning, snapping on his catcher's gear while staring and shouting at the home plate umpire, Mark Hirschbeck. Posada had just been struck out again by Pedro Martnez, the Boston Red Sox ace who made the Yankees swing through and stare at his pitches tonight.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Grows
description: Japan's merchandise trade surplus grew 26.6 percent in April as exports rose for the first time in more than a year. The 837 billion yen ($6.7 billion) surplus was less than economists expected, but shipments overseas rose 1.6 percent, the first gain since March 2001. Japan's trade surplus with the United States slipped 3.5 percent, with exports of steel falling 27 percent. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: A Sidekick Finds the Open Man
description: MY boyfriend, Alejandro, an immigrant from Uruguay, works as a mover 10 to 12 hours a day, six days a week. On Sunday, his one day off, I like to declare how much I am looking forward to spending the whole day watching him be handy around the apartment. That is when he cracks up laughing.

title: Trial Ending for Boston F.B.I. Agent Accused of Mob Ties
description: John Connolly was a decorated Federal Bureau of Investigation agent, but he was actually corrupted into being a prized informant for Boston mobsters, ''functioning as a member of a criminal enterprise,'' a federal prosecutor said today in closing arguments at Mr. Connolly's trial for racketeering and obstruction of justice.

title: Scientists Develop the Universe's Baby Pictures
description: Using a radio telescope so high in the Andes that they needed oxygen masks to visit it, astronomers have taken what they described yesterday as the most detailed pictures yet of the birth of the universe, resolving for the first time the seeds from which clusters of galaxies grew.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Burning Bright In the Bronx

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Families Of 9/11 Victims Plan Ceremony
description: Members of several families who lost relatives in the Sept. 11 terror attack plan to hold their own ceremony on June 2, a Sunday, to mark the end of efforts to recover remains from ground zero. The city, which will hold its official ceremony next Thursday, will issue a permit to the group as long as it complies with safety regulations, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. Mr. Bloomberg has pointed out that next Thursday was chosen because it will not interfere with religious observances, while the families want a weekend observance. Mr. Bloomberg said he did not know if he would be invited to the group's ceremony, but he added that ''if people want to have other days that's perfectly appropriate.'' Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Multiculturalism at Monticello
description: The White House made an important statement last year when President Bush spoke at a gathering honoring Thomas Jefferson's birthday that included both black and white descendants of the founder's family. The multicultural nature of the celebration underscored a dramatic shift that has taken place in Jefferson scholarship since 1998, when genetic studies linking Jefferson to Sally Hemings's youngest son, Eston, gave fresh import to circumstantial evidence that had always pointed to Jefferson's paternity.

description: Ethical Culture Society

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The robed monks have disappeared from what used to be Belgo Nieuw York, but the religious overtones linger. Butter, Belgo's successor, has abandoned the monastery look and created in its stead a cathedral of nature, with a vaulted red cedar ceiling and an illuminated photograph of a pristine birch forest filling the entire back wall.

title: A Jewish Family's Stolen Legacy; Heirs Seek Restitution for Retail Empire Lost to Nazis
description: Barbara Principe remembers little of her early childhood in Nazi Germany. After her parents fled with her in 1939, traveling through Britain and Cuba to a chicken farm in South Jersey, they spoke only fleetingly of her Jewish family's old life in an opulent home outside Berlin.

title: How the Trial Of Andersen Could Hurt A Fraud Case
description: The criminal trial of Arthur Andersen has highlighted the hurdles that federal prosecutors may face if they seek to bring accounting fraud charges related to the collapse of Enron -- and indeed may have created a few new ones.

description: Shock mixed with outrage today as church leaders here learned of accusations of sexual misconduct against Archbishop Rembert G. Weakland.

title: Online DVD Rental Service Performs the Best of 3 Initial Offerings
description: For the first time in almost 20 months, three technology companies went public on the same day yesterday. Of the three, the best performer was Netflix, which operates an online DVD rental service.

title: Rally Pits Cars Against Pollution
description: TWO cars were offered for sale near the starting gate of the Tour de Sol, an annual race that shows off pioneering solar-, battery- and hybrid-power vehicles. One was a new Honda Civic gasoline-electric hybrid, in a silvery color that Honda calls Opal Blue. A decal on the side said, ''50 Miles Per Gallon, Available Now.'' A throng of curious spectators admired the car's turquoise digital dashboard and its plush interior. The sticker price: $20,010, including shipping.

description: When Bob Tway won the Memorial Tournament in 1989, he did not have to worry about beating Tiger Woods. After all, Woods was just 13 then, one of many current players who were not on the PGA Tour when Tway was in his prime.

title: In Intern Case, Police Consider Assault Convict
description: In their search for clues in the death of Chandra Ann Levy, the police turned their attention today to a man convicted of assaulting two other female joggers in Rock Creek Park. The judge who locked him up called the man ''predatory,'' and prosecutors said he had used the park as a ''hunting ground.''

title: Revisiting the Open Road, With a Hitch
description: LONG before recreational vehicles, or R.V.'s, came into the language, Americans were on the road, packing tents, beds and cooking utensils.

title: Bomb Explodes at Israeli Fuel Depot, but Disaster Is Averted
description: A remote-control bomb blew apart a tanker truck in Israel's biggest fuel depot this morning, but an automatic sprinkler system and nearby workers quickly put out the blaze, averting a huge explosion in a densely populated area near Tel Aviv. The blast came just one day after a suicide bomber struck nearby, killing two Israelis and wounding dozens.

title: Rigas Family Is Giving Up Voting Control Of Adelphia
description: It wasn't supposed to turn out this way for the Rigas family.

title: Van Horn's Struggles Coincide With the Nets'
description: Keith Van Horn propped himself in front of his locker after Game 2. His comments to reporters were as baffling as his 2-for-12 shooting night in Tuesday's 93-86 loss to the Celtics. That ugly a performance has been rare for Van Horn in the postseason, but what is familiar is that when Van Horn struggles, so do the Nets.

title: Enron Creditors' Law Firm to Remain
description: The law firm representing the creditors' committee in the Enron bankruptcy will not be disqualified because of legal work done for Enron before it sought Chapter 11 protection last year, a bankruptcy judge ruled today.

title: Neighborly Rivals
description: PERCHED side by side on the Santa Monica shoreline, Shutters on the Beach (1 Pico Boulevard; 310-458-0030) and Casa del Mar (1910 Ocean Way; 310-581-5533) are similar in many ways. But their starkly different physical presences -- a seven-story brick-and-sandstone Renaissance revival-style structure opposite a slate-gray shingled building with flower-covered trellises and striped awnings -- give an indication of the experience that awaits inside. STUART EMMRICH

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day last Friday with an article about trades by energy companies that sought to develop a market in high-speed communications capacity misstated the number of trades made in two directions on the same day at identical prices by Reliant Resources with each of two other companies -- Enron and Aquila. And a correction in this space on Saturday again misstated the Aquila figure. From December 2000 through October 2001, Reliant had 18 such trades with Enron not 19. Reliant had 5 with Aquila over the same period, not 12 or 11.

title: Alan P. Bell, 70, Researcher Of Influences on Homosexuality
description: Alan P. Bell, a Kinsey Institute researcher who helped conduct a pioneering large-scale study that countered the notion that homosexuals were maladjusted, died on May 13 in Bloomington, Ind., where he lived. He was 70.

description: Why didn't the Bush administration connect the dots and take aggressive measures before 9/11?

title: AGENT COMPLAINTS LEAD F.B.I. DIRECTOR TO ASK FOR INQUIRY
description: The F.B.I. director, Robert S. Mueller III, said today that he was ordering an internal inquiry into complaints by a senior agent in Minneapolis that officials at headquarters repeatedly held back agents in Minneapolis who sought to investigate Zacarias Moussaoui aggressively in the days before the Sept. 11 hijackings.

title: The Downside of Paradise: Fitzgerald's Final Days
description: Someone involved in casting ''Last Call,'' a film about the final days of F. Scott Fitzgerald that has its premiere tomorrow on Showtime, had the courage to be counterintuitive. The outcome is an affecting study, both of a novelist struggling to regain his form and of the gantlet run by anyone trying to cope with an alcoholic.

title: Sailors Sprayed With Nerve Gas In Cold War Test, Pentagon Says
description: The Defense Department sprayed live nerve and biological agents on ships and sailors in cold war-era experiments to test the Navy's vulnerability to toxic warfare, the Pentagon revealed today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JASPER, GERTRUDE RATHBONE, PHD.
description: JASPER - Gertrude Rathbone, PhD. of Hampton Bays, NY and formerly of New York City died May 22, 2002 at age 94 in Westhampton, NY. Born July 7, 1907 in New York City, she was a graduate of St. Agatha's School and Wells College. She held a Doctorate degree in French and a Master's degree in Library Science. In addition to teaching at Hunter College in New York and Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, she was co-owner of the millinery business, Toby Coppock, Inc. She is survived by her cousin, Martha Dwyer, along with many other cousins. Predeceased by her sister, Juliet Absolom. Visiting hours 9-10 AM, Saturday, May 25, followed by a service at 10 AM at the J. Ronald Scott Funeral Home, Hampton Bays, NY. Interment private. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Wildlife Trust, 61 Route 9W, Palisades, NY 10964 or The Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, NY 11238

description: Gordon M. Bethune, chief executive of Continental Airlines, said yesterday that the carrier had been in ''fruitful'' talks with US Airways over a partnership that would allow the two airlines to link their routes.

description: AT&T announced yesterday that Charles H. Noski, its widely respected No. 2 executive, would leave the company after it completes the sale of its cable television operations to the Comcast Corporation, expected late this year.

title: IN REICHSTAG, BUSH CONDEMNS TERROR AS NEW DESPOTISM
description: President Bush stood today in the well of Germany's reconstructed Reichstag and told Parliament that the terrorist groups the United States and its allies are hunting down constitute a ''new totalitarian threat,'' and in a clear reference to Hitler, compared the current struggle to a past generation's battle against those who ''killed in the name of racial purity.''

title: J.P. Morgan Shakes Up A Key Unit
description: J. P. Morgan Chase announced yesterday that Geoffrey T. Boisi, brought in two years ago to invigorate the company's investment bank, was departing after what executives described as clashes with management.

title: Murdoch's Son Assumes Role Of Publisher at New York Post
description: Lachlan Murdoch, the son and possible corporate heir of the News Corporation chairman, Rupert Murdoch, is becoming the publisher of The New York Post, succeeding Ken Chandler, who has been a top executive at The Post since 1993.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Dairy Company Overhaul
description: The scandal-ridden Snow Brand Milk, Japan's largest dairy, asked its main creditors for another 50 billion yen in financial aid and announced an additional 1,300 job cuts by September. The company will also sell part of its ice cream and baby foods businesses. Snow Brand has been under attack since some of its milk products sickened thousands of customers last year. Its meatpacking subsidiary is also suspected of repackaging beef to gain favorable government subsidies. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CONCEPCION, RENE
description: CONCEPCION-Rene. Six years went by without you, but your smile and your courage will always stay with those you loved. You'll be in our hearts forever. Love, Steven and Adolf

title: Water Crisis Grows Into a Test of U.S.-Mexico Relations
description: Half a century ago this town was drowned. The United States and Mexico built a huge reservoir by damming the Rio Grande, under a treaty to divide the water of the mighty river.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Brooklyn Bridge Celebration Is Canceled
description: A celebration of the 119th anniversary of the Brooklyn Bridge's completion scheduled for June 2 has been postponed indefinitely because of a government warning this week that the bridge could be a target of terrorists. ''Even a false alarm or rumor could put people's safety at risk,'' said Marty Markowitz, left, the Brooklyn borough president, who had planned the event. Glen von Nostitz, a spokesman for Mr. Markowitz, said the event was canceled after law enforcement officials recommended reducing its scope. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

description: KPNQwest N.V., the Dutch provider of data services, said today that it would file for protection from creditors and that it was in talks with rivals that could lead to a takeover of the company.

description: SPEARS-Joan Bogardus, 63, of Greenwich, CT died Wednesday May 22 at home. She was the wife of William G. Spears; mother of William G. Spears, Jr, Dorothy Spears, Brian Spears, and Wendy Connors; sister of Carol Howell and grandmother of nine. Mrs. Spears was on the music staff of St. Catherine of Siena Church in Greenwich for over 20 years. A Mass of Christian burial will be held Tuesday, May 28, at 11:00 AM in St. Michael's Church, 469 North St, Greenwich, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to the Healthcare Chaplaincy, 307 East 60th Street, NY, NY 10022 or the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, Inc, 1 Pennsylvania Plaza, Suite 1610, NY, NY 10119.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Oil Contract
description: A Russian company, Amur Shipbuilding, was awarded a $140 million contract by Exxon Mobil to refurbish an oil drilling rig that Exxon Mobil will use to develop the rich oil fields off Sakhalin, an island off the Pacific coast of Russia. The contract is part of Exxon Mobil's planned $12.3 billion investment in the oil fields, known as Sakhalin I. The project had been stuck for years in Russian bureaucracy until the Russian government of President Vladimir V. Putin cleared the way for it last fall. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: U.S. Strikes Again
description: For the second time this week American warplanes attacked Iraqi air defense sites south of Baghdad after British or American jets came under fire, military officials said. The United States Central Command said two targets, a combat control center and an antiaircraft missile system, had been destroyed by precision-guided munitions. Iraq said the raids had killed two. Thom Shanker (NYT)

title: National Briefing | West: Nevada: Casino Company In Accord With Union
description: The likelihood of a strike against Las Vegas hotels eased slightly when the culinary union, which represents 45,000 housekeepers, cooks and other workers, reached a preliminary agreement with a hotel group on a five-year contract. Four groups representing other hotels continued talks. Union leaders and Park Place Entertainment, which owns Bally's, Caesars Palace, the Flamingo, the Las Vegas Hilton and Paris, said the deal could lead to others. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Laughs to the Left, Laughs to the Right
description: Heaven only knows what sort of mischief and deviltry takes place at Congressional Christmas parties. But occasionally a hint of the goings-on has escaped in the form of ''Capitol Steps,'' the irreverent show that traces its origins to the entertainment provided by a group of aides asked to enliven a Senate Foreign Relations Committee Christmas party in 1981.

title: Offshore Oil Pollution Comes Mostly as Runoff, Study Says
description: Most oil pollution in North American coastal waters comes not from leaking tankers or oil rigs, but rather from countless oil-streaked streets, sputtering lawn mowers and other dispersed sources on land, and so will be hard to prevent, a panel convened by the National Academy of Sciences says in a new report.

title: Tension Between Andersen Trial Lawyers
description: Tensions flared again today in the criminal trial of Arthur Andersen, and a Texas agency took the first step toward barring the firm from practicing in the state.

description: MEDICUS-Rose (Davy). Age 74 of White Plains, NY; May 22, 2002. Loving mother and grandmother. Predeceased by her husband Philip and son Stephen. Survived by her son Robert Medicus, daughter Joanne Squires, son-in-law Scott Squires, grandsons Douglas and Daniel and her special friend Juliet Warshauer and her devoted companion Albert Gabay. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions to Congregation Kol Ami, WJCS, or the American Cancer Society. The family will receive friends at BallardDurand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave, White Plains, NY Saturday evening 7-9pm.

title: O.K., Buster, Now It's Your Turn
description: ''Enough,'' a jarring thriller packed to the gills with cheap shocks, suggests the emergence of a new Hollywood subgenre: the male yuppie horror film. The unspoken premise behind it suggests that a new generation of cold young men has arisen who are so obsessed with fattening their portfolios and chiseling their abs that they have forgotten to grow souls. And yes, that premise probably contains a tiny grain of truth.

title: In New York, a Long Way From Here to Here
description: New Yorkers who are smug about not having to spend hours on traffic-jammed highways to get to work may be surprised by some sobering news yesterday from the Census Bureau: that people in four of the five boroughs fritter away more time getting to work than those anywhere else in the state.

description: TUSS, the so-called matriarch of the elephants at the Bronx Zoo, passed away last week, and given her 26-year history of welcoming generations of visitors, and what all agree was a gentle and generous nature, it would be callous to lead off with the question that nonetheless looms large:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNIDERMAN, ELEANORE
description: SNIDERMAN-Eleanore. The officers, Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Eleanore Sniderman, beloved mother of Abby Milstein, a cherished friend of UJA-Federation. Abby and her husband, Howard, are exemplary leaders in the UJA-Federation community who support many agencies within our social-service network. Abby is the president of the New York Legal Assistance Group (NYLAG), one of our beneficiary agencies. Howard is a member of our Board of Directors and is chairman of our Jewish Leadership Forum. Together, they express an unwavering devotion to Jewish and humanitarian causes through their extraordinary generosity and commitment to those in need. We extend our deepest sympathies to Mrs. Sniderman's husband, Marvin; to Abby and Howard; and to the entire Sniderman & Milstein families. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Loss Widens As Sales Tumble At Ciena
description: Battered by the spending cutbacks of major phone companies, Ciena, a leading supplier of networking equipment, said that revenue in the quarter ended April 30 had fallen to $87.05 million, down nearly 80 percent from the period in 2001. Ciena's net loss soared to $612.2 million, or $1.86 a share, from $50.7 million, or 17 cents a share, a year earlier. Most of the widened loss was attributed to tax accounting and the cost of previously disclosed layoffs and other programs to reduce expenses. But $223.2 million of the loss was attributed to writing off products that Ciena has little hope of selling. ''We cannot pretend to know when the telecommunications industry will recover,'' said Gary B. Smith, the chief executive, during a conference call in which he advised against expecting growth to resume in the current quarter. Ciena shares, which fell 36 cents, to $6.08 yesterday, have tumbled 90 percent in the last year.

title: A Painter Who Reads, A Reader Who Paints
description: Ed Ruscha may be an exemplar of California cool in both his person and his art, but stylistically, he's more like Switzerland. Two exceptional shows of his early and recent work, at C & M Arts on East 78th Street on the Upper East Side and at the Gagosian Gallery in Chelsea, suggest that he has maintained his neutrality while surrounded by Pop, Color Field painting, Realism, Minimalism and Conceptual Art.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Court Won't Let Inmate Ship Sperm
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, ruled that a prisoner did not have a constitutional right to send sperm to his wife for artificial insemination. The prisoner, William Gerber, proposed to send the sperm by overnight mail or with his lawyer. Three of the dissenting judges in the 6-to-5 decision wrote that married people's constitutional right to procreate may not be denied ''on nothing more than the personal opinion of prison bureaucrats that we would be better off as a society if the Gerbers were prevented from parenting an offspring.'' Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Editorial Observer; A French Philosopher Talks Back to Hollywood and 'The Matrix'
description: The French philosopher Jean Baudrillard seemed to fight off a yawn when I asked him recently about the celebrity that has come to him through ''The Matrix,'' a futuristic cyber-thriller that hit the screen three years ago and became one of the hottest movies of all time. Before this movie, Mr. Baudrillard's dense little book ''Simulacra and Simulation'' was studied mainly by cloistered graduate students and theory-heads. Because ''The Matrix'' cribbed from the book for its dialogue and gave a full-screen shot of the title, ''Simulacra and Simulation'' has become a cult hit, even though it is difficult to pronounce and not easy to read. The book's profile is likely to rise even higher when the first of two sequels hits the screen next year.

title: AVON TO CLOSE PLANT IN NEW YORK STATE AND CUT 260 JOBS
description: Avon Products said yesterday that it would phase out its plant in Suffern, N.Y., over the next 12 months as part of a realignment of manufacturing operations in the United States. The majority of the production will be transferred to a larger and more efficient plant in Springdale, Ohio, the company said. Avon said that about 260 jobs would be eliminated at Suffern, about 35 miles northwest of Midtown Manhattan, but that it expected to add about 200 jobs at Springdale. Avon also said it planned to build a research and development center to replace the Suffern plant.

title: Likely Opponent Emerges For Connecticut Governor
description: After nearly a year, the race between two Connecticut Democrats to oppose Gov. John G. Rowland this November has reached a critical turn, with one candidate poised to capture the nomination, political analysts and party leaders say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUTCH, BARNET M.
description: DEUTCH-Barnet M. On May 21st, 2002. The Board of Trustees and the staff of the American Red Cross in Greater New York mourns the passing of Barnet Deutch, distinguished colleague, volunteer and friend. Barney's 59 year career with the American Red Cross included international positions in China, Burma and India and as a fund raiser for national headquarters. As Director of Financial Development for ARC/ GNY, Barney established the first planned giving program. He continued to provide invaluable expertise after his retirement. Our deepest condolences to the family. Jonathan O'Herron, Chairman Robert M. Bender, Jr., Chief Executive Officer

title: Pope Banishes a Shadow Left By Bulgaria's Tie to Shooting

description: Like its title, Jill Sprecher's ''Thirteen Conversations About One Thing'' is both straightforward and enigmatic: four fables of modern urban dissatisfaction woven into a fabric whose pattern is enchantingly elusive. What, for instance, is the ''one thing'' this collection of morose New Yorkers is supposedly talking about? It seems intuitively identifiable but strangely resistant to precise definition. Synonyms multiply by the dozen: chance, fate, coincidence, serendipity, the order of the universe -- or, to give some human dimension to these chilly mathematical conceits: happiness, good fortune, kismet, grace, the meaning of life.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Extortion Of Dock Workers Charged
description: Seven men linked to the Genovese crime family and the International Longshoreman's Association were indicted yesterday on charges of extorting dock workers who were forced to pay for favorable positions and lucrative overtime assignments, the authorities said. No estimate was given of the amount of money prosecutors contend was extorted. The authorities identified Nicholas Furina, 70; Ralph Esposito, 49; Anthony D'Errico, 62; Aniello Bello, 62; Nicholas Romano, 47; and John Timpanaro, 45, as members of the Genovese family. Also indicted was Carlo Bilancione, the Longshoreman's local president, who is said to be a Genovese family associate. The seven men, who are free on bail, are charged with racketeering and extortion. Stacy Albin (NYT)

Williamstown, Mass., in the northwest corner of the state, is a pastoral, historic town where great art is housed in intimate settings, where academics mix with outdoorsmen, and where a weekend escape can involve everything from eavesdropping on world-famous professors in a village coffee shop to walking the northernmost reaches of the Appalachian Trail. title: Junk Food Jitters

A Senate committee held hearings this week on a bill designed to combat the obesity epidemic in this country, where some 60 percent of all American adults are either overweight or obese. And the annual meeting of the World Health Organization heard reports of an alarming increase in overweight children in developing countries, some of which are fast closing the gap with the traditionally fatter industrialized nations.

My normally bouncy three-year-old was standing motionless on the sidelines while the other kids at her Austrian kindergarten ran and played. Twenty minutes later, she still hadn't moved. She stood silent and forlorn. When I finally went to her, the look on her face said loud and clear: "Mom, get me out of here!"

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page on Thursday about advertising spending in the first quarter of 2002, as reported by the tracking company CMR, misstated the percentage change in several categories compared with figures in the quarter a year earlier. For media that showed increases, Spanish-language network television gained 21.2 percent, not 17.5 percent; network radio rose 14 percent, not 12.3 percent; and Sunday newspaper magazines were up 13.5 percent, not 11.9 percent. For those with declines, cable television fell 13.8 percent, not 16 percent; syndicated television dropped 12.6 percent, not 14.4 percent; and the Internet was down 12.4 percent, not 14.2 percent.

title: RECORD INDUSTRY GROUPS FILE SUIT AGAINST MUSIC WEB SITE
description: The major record companies and a trade group representing songwriters and music publishers filed a copyright-infringement lawsuit yesterday against Audiogalaxy Inc., which operates Audiogalaxy.com. The Web site allows people to exchange music files free over the Internet. The lawsuit, filed in federal court in New York, asserts Audiogalaxy encourages people to copy copyrighted music files. The assertion is similar to the one that record companies and songwriters made against Napster. Audiogalaxy, based in Austin, Tex., urges users on its Web site to respect the intellectual property of others. Matt Richtel (NYT)
