title: National Briefing | West: California: Court Rules Against A Dress Code
description: A state appeals court ruled that the Sonoma County Fair violated the state constitution when it ejected a member of the Hells Angels from the county fairgrounds in 1998 because he was wearing a vest that carried the logo of the motorcycle club. Officers said the vest was not allowed under the fair's dress code, which barred clothing ''intended to provoke, offend or intimidate'' others. As part of the unanimous decision for a three-judge panel, Justice Anthony Kline wrote that the dress code violated free-speech rights because it was vague and too broad, giving law enforcement ''almost unfettered license'' to decide what violated the code. Evelyn Nieves (NYT)

title: A Fight for the History Books
description: President Bush showed little respect for history, and even less for the illuminating work done by presidential historians, when he issued an executive order last November making it significantly harder to gain access to a former president's official papers. Now a worthy bipartisan attempt to overturn that order is being stalled by the White House, which is scrambling to portray its new rules as a benign attempt to tidy up the system for releasing presidential records.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Indian Tribe May Hunt Whales
description: The International Whaling Commission has renewed the right of the state's Makah Indians to hunt gray whales, maintaining a quota of 20 whales over the next five years. An 1855 treaty with the federal government secured the small tribe's whaling rights; in 1999, the Makahs killed their first whale in more than 70 years. Nathan Tyler, vice chairman of the tribal council, said that several families were training to hunt Pacific or California grays in the waters off the Olympic Peninsula. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Federal Court Ruling Is Victory for Regional Bells

title: To Muffle the Guns of South Asia
description: To the Editor:

title: Schoolchildren Need Our Undivided Attention
description: To the Editor:

title: Miami Police Investigating 2 Overseers Of Missing Girl
description: The Miami-Dade police are conducting a criminal investigation into the caseworker and guardian who were supposed to protect the missing 5-year-old Rilya Wilson, court documents released today show.

title: Booker Prize Is Tempest-Tossed: Will It Go to U.S.?
description: It started innocuously enough last month with word that the Booker Prize for Fiction, Britain's riposte to the Pulitzer, had signed a new sponsor.

title: U.S. Team Arrives Amid Show of Force
description: Amid extraordinary security, the United States soccer team arrived here today to begin preparations for the World Cup.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Developer Bought Out
description: Saville Gordon Estates agreed to a $723 million deal with Morgan Stanley Dean Witter to revert to private ownership because of concerns that Saville's share price does not reflect the value of its properties, which include warehouses and industrial sites. Other property companies have taken similar steps. Saville said a company called Chambercroft, formed by Morgan Stanley, would pay 121.3 pence for each Saville Gordon share, a premium of 17 percent over Thursday's close. Chambercroft will also assume about $420 million in debt. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: U.S. TERROR ALERT LED TO NO CHANGE IN STATES' SECURITY
description: Despite this week's ominous warnings from the Bush administration about the threat of additional terrorist attacks, the nation's new coterie of state homeland security czars said they took no action because the alerts were too vague and their overburdened agencies already stand at heightened readiness.

title: Inquiry Undermined, F.B.I. Agent Charges
description: A senior F.B.I. agent in Minneapolis has accused a supervisor at the agency's headquarters of altering a report about Zacarias Moussaoui, the so-called 20th hijacker, in a way that stymied efforts to obtain crucial evidence in the case before the Sept. 11 attacks, government officials said.

title: F.B.I. Agent Says Superior Altered Report, Foiling Inquiry
description: A senior F.B.I. agent in Minneapolis has accused a supervisor at the agency's Washington headquarters of altering a report in a way that made it impossible for investigators to obtain crucial evidence in the case of Zacarias Moussaoui, the so-called 20th hijacker, before the Sept. 11 attacks on New York and Washington, government officials said today.

title: Cameras to Seek Faces of Terror In Visitors to the Statue of Liberty
description: In response to a warning of a potential terrorist attack on the Statue of Liberty, the National Park Service activated a face recognition surveillance system yesterday that takes pictures of visitors and compares them with a database of terror suspects.

title: HUGO BOSS SUSPENDS U.S. OFFICERS AFTER WEAK QUARTER
description: Germany's biggest clothing company, Hugo Boss, placed the chief executive and chief financial officers of its United States business on ''paid administrative leave'' as of May 14 after first-quarter sales fell at the unit. A spokesman for Hugo Boss declined to give details or say when the chief executive and the chief financial officer would return. The two could not be reached for comment.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Visas Tied To Drivers' Licenses
description: To prevent foreigners from overstaying their visas, officials plan to require visas and drivers' licenses to expire simultaneously. The policy would replace a law that lets visitors receive four-year licenses regardless of their visas.

title: Leonard and Frazar Aren't Going to Play Just for Fun
description: Justin Leonard and Harrison Frazar often play golf together for fun, but this weekend, the stakes will be much higher.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INSLER, STANLEY
description: INSLER-Stanley. Young Israel of Oceanside mourns the passing of its beloved member, Gabai, and member of its Board of Directors. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jay Yaacov Schwartz, Rabbi Joel Felderman, President

title: Reporter's Notebook; As Summits Go, a Pinnacle of Good Will
description: True, they didn't call it the Pootie-Dubya show. But Vladimir V. Putin and George W. Bush went to some lengths today to make the point that this meeting of the Russian and American presidents, so heavily promoted as the aprs-cold-war summit meeting, has a mellower and warmer feel to it than any of its predecessors.

title: After Spate of Political Sparring, House Approves an Emergency Spending Bill
description: After two days of fierce political sparring, the House early this morning approved a $29 billion emergency spending bill to pay for military operations, domestic security and aid to New York City.

title: Fleeing a Disaster While Waiting for One
description: Nine characters in Joe Calarco's ''. . . In the Absence of Spring . . .'' are haunted by premonitions of a catastrophe. But when the promised event occurs, it is something none of them anticipated. It is difficult to avoid the conclusion that all of them may have had jobs in the White House or in the Washington intelligence community before last Sept. 11.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Revised Data Show Slower Pace of Growth
description: The economy expanded at a slower pace in the first quarter than previously estimated, the government reported today, but still recovered sharply from last year's slowdown.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Political Truce For Soccer
description: Responding to President Kim Dae Jung's plea for a truce, the opposition Grand National Party promised to refrain from criticizing the government during the World Cup soccer championship, which opens in Seoul on Friday. But it said it would resume its efforts to expose corruption if prosecutors slowed down their investigation of Mr. Kim's relatives and aides. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Japan Cuts Whaling Rights For Native Peoples of Arctic
description: Frustrated by a string of defeats at the International Whaling Commission meeting here, Japan retaliated today, leading a successful movement to deny Alaska and Siberian native peoples a renewal of permission to hunt whales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPEARS, JOAN BOGARDUS
description: SPEARS-Joan Bogardus, 63, of Greenwich, CT died Wednesday May 22 at home. She was the wife of William G. Spears; mother of William G. Spears, Jr, Dorothy Spears, Brian Spears, and Wendy Connors; sister of Carol Howell and grandmother of nine. Mrs. Spears was on the music staff of St. Catherine of Siena Church in Greenwich for over 20 years. A Mass of Christian burial will be held Tuesday, May 28, at 11:00 AM in St. Michael's Church, 469 North St, Greenwich, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to the Healthcare Chaplaincy, 307 East 60th Street, NY, NY 10022 or the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, Inc, 1 Pennsylvania Plaza, Suite 1610, NY, NY 10119.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIPKINS, MILTON
description: LIPKINS-Milton. Happy Birthday, darling. We miss and love you very much. Edna, Judy, Stephen and Stacey

title: Mixing Martial Arts With Modern Steps
description: DanceBrazil took two festivities to the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night. Each was choreographed by Jelon Vieira, the troupe's artistic director, for a cast of 12, and each blended traditional Brazilian dance forms with North American modern dance. But what was most striking about these creations was not their stylistic origins, but theatrical immediacy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REITER, HELEN ROBINSON
description: REITER-Helen Robinson. Survived by husband Hyman Reiter. Beloved mother of A. Jeffry Robinson (Harriett) and Steven C. Robinson (Connie), and wife of the late Dr. Hyman M. Robinson. Cherished grandmother of Joni Robinson Helfman (Steven), Homer Robinson, Howie Robinson and Lyle Robinson, and greatgrandmother of Daniel Justin Helfman and Bodhi Robinson Stergion. Loving step-mother to Joan Michel and Suzanne Krueger and dear to their families, especially Maggie Krueger. Thanks for the gifts of life, laughter and tears. Memorial contributions may be made to the Howie Robinson Scholarship Fund, at the Michael Ann Russell JCC, North Miami Beach, FL.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Arrest In Oil And Politics Case
description: The federal authorities made their first arrest in an investigation of charges that the former governing party siphoned money from the state oil company, Pemex. Manuel Gomezperalta, Pemex's former administrative director, was detained on charges of authorizing illegal disbursements. Prosecutors say up to $170 million in Pemex funds was diverted to the Institutional Revolutionary Party's coffers. Earlier this month a judge issued an arrest warrant for the company's former director, Rogelio Montemayor, who has apparently gone into hiding. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about Charles Lindbergh's first trans-Atlantic flight referred incorrectly to the first flight of the Wright brothers' plane at Kitty Hawk. Their plane flew over 120 feet of ground, not at a height of 120 feet.

title: CONSUMER CONCERNS ON AUTO RELIABILITY CITED
description: An internal General Motors Corporation report shows that a quarter of United States consumers avoid its vehicles because of reliability concerns, even though complaints by new-car owners fell 10 percent in the last year. The automaker is taking steps to improve quality as it prepares to replace 43 percent of its models next year. Its market share has slipped to less than 30 percent from 50 percent four decades ago.

title: Fortunate Lives and Late-Blooming Fears
description: May is the season not only for commencements but also for reunions. And just as commencements are a time to look forward, reunions are a time to look back. My undergraduate classmates and I did that at our 50th reunion at the University of Pennsylvania a few days ago.

title: Despite F.B.I. Memo, Students In Phoenix Went Unchecked
description: Although an F.B.I. agent here sent a memorandum to Washington last July urging a nationwide check on Middle Eastern students at flight schools, managers at several schools in the Phoenix area said the local F.B.I. office did not ask them for tips on suspicious students before Sept. 11.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLUTSKY, PATDS
description: SLUTSKY-Patds. On Thursday, May 23, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Louis Slutsky. Devoted mother of Bette Slutsky and the late Marsha Slutsky. Sister of Faye Orenstein. Second mother of Libby Brynien. ''Loved and will be deeply missed.''

title: A Subject That May Appear, Stupidly, to Need No Explanation
description: There is no safe way to write about stupidity, the Austrian writer Robert Musil once suggested. Anyone attempting to examine stupidity, he argued, ''must assume about himself that he is not stupid'' -- and that is sure proof that he is.

title: S.E.C. Inquiry On Hedge Funds
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is reviewing whether there is fraud in the $500 billion hedge fund industry, after several enforcement cases involving the funds, the S.E.C. chairman, Harvey L. Pitt, said today.

title: Virtual Labs: Young Tinkerers at Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on May 17 about New York University's commencement misidentified a graduate who was standing on a chair above the rest of the crowd, speaking on a cellphone. She is Elizabeth Falconi, not Fabienne Leys.

title: The Giant Killer Trains An Eye on War Emblem
description: He is responsible for the blemishes, however slight, on the records of great horses like Kelso, Secretariat and Skip Away. Allen Jerkens, a Hall of Fame trainer, has sent out horses to beat them all and now he has an eye on preventing War Emblem from running away with horse racing's 12th Triple Crown.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Plan To Apply To NATO
description: The government plans to tell NATO's secretary general, Lord Robertson, that it is beginning the process of applying for membership in the alliance when he visits Kiev in July, the nation's security minister, Yevhen Marchuk, said, adding, ''There is no future for Ukraine if it remains outside the bloc.'' The NATO leader will visit to mark the fifth anniversary of a charter declaring a special relationship between Ukraine and NATO. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAMPLEMAN, HENRY
description: STAMPLEMAN-Henry. Of New Rochelle, NY on May 22, 2002 at the age of 86 after a short illness. Marketing consultant to Coca-Cola, Pepsi-Cola, General Foods and US Steel, among others. Founding member of Larchmont Temple. Beloved by his wife Doris, sons Jed, Paul and Steven, daughtersin-law Laura and Fern, grandchildren Luc, Lesley, Hannah and James (and his wife Elizabeth) and great-grandchildren Sean and Sophia. Services, Sunday, May 26, 11a.m. at Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Ave., Larchmont, NY.

title: Unlikely Partners: Ex-Governor and Ex-Spy Overcome Their Suspicions
description: They would seem, at first glance, one of the oddest couples in global diplomacy: the American president, who never set foot in Russia until Thursday, and the Russian president, who speaks German but little English and had no discernible interest in ranch life or Texas barbecue until he visited the president in Crawford last November.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: AMERICAS ARGENTINA: CONGRESS DEFIES PRESIDENT Defying President Eduardo Duhalde, the lower house of Congress voted against modifying an "economic subversion" law that has been used to prosecute bankers. The International Monetary Fund has made revisions a condition for resumption of aid to Argentina, and this week Mr. Duhalde threatened to resign unless Congress, controlled by his own party, sped up action on amendments he submitted.    Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Economy Grows
description: The French economy grew 0.4 percent in the first quarter of 2002, helped by spending on manufactured goods, the government statistics office, Insee, reported yesterday. For 2001, growth was 1.8 percent, slightly less than the 1.9 percent figure Insee had predicted. Consumer spending grew 0.2 percent, slightly weaker than the 0.3 percent rise in the prior quarter; overall investment also grew 0.2 percent. President Jacques Chirac, above, has pledged to cut taxes by 5 percent this year assuming the French economy grows at least 3 percent. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Man Living In Building Faces Charges In Fatal Fire
description: A man who investigators say smoked crack in the gutted first floor of a Brooklyn apartment building was charged yesterday with sparking a fire that killed a 63-year-old man Wednesday night.

title: From Insurance Denier to Health Care Crusader
description: ''Damaged Care'' makes its point early on. Dr. Linda Peeno (Laura Dern) takes an emergency telephone call from a surgeon. A heart donor has been found, the patient is on the table and the doctor is ready to perform the transplant. All that's needed now is the insurance O.K. And Dr. Peeno, the managed care company's medical reviewer, has to make the decision.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Shifts In Extremism
description: The government said that membership in right-wing and left-wing extremist groups declined in 2001 but that there was an increase in Islamic extremism. ''Our biggest concern right now is the global threat of Islamic terrorism,'' Interior Minister Otto Schily said. ''We need to remain alert, without breaking into panic.'' Desmond Butler (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUSCH, BENJAMIN
description: BUSCH-Benjamin. 81. Died on Monday, May 20, 2002, in Lake Worth, FL, after a long illness. For many years, the owner of Symphony Music Shop in Yonkers and an employee of Walter Kane Music Publishing, he was also an accomplished singer of opera and musical comedy. He is survived by his wife Irene, his children Elizabeth Busch-Le Ne, Margaret Busch and the playwright, Charles Busch, and his grandson James Stull. Interment will be at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, N.Y. He will be missed by all who experienced his wit, affection and joyous spirit.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in Weekend yesterday with the Art Guide, showing a detail from Peter Halley's painting ''Panic Room,'' was reproduced sideways. The left edge should have appeared at the bottom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOMMERFIELD, MELVIN
description: SOMMERFIELD-Melvin. On May 23, 2002, of Syosset, L.I. Beloved husband of Miriam. Devoted father of Paula and Gary Schoer, Leland and Carol Sommerfield. Dear brother of Ruth Weiner. Loving grandfather of Jamie and David Schoer. Services Sunday, 12:00 Noon at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Accusation Leads to Suspension Of High-Level Priest in New York
description: The sexual abuse scandals in the Roman Catholic Church reached the highest levels of the Archdiocese of New York yesterday, when the archdiocese announced it had ordered the suspension of the monsignor in charge of fund-raising after he was accused of having an ''improper relationship'' with a minor 20 years ago.

title: Son Is Charged in Man's Death After Fight at the Family Home
description: A Bergen County man has been charged with killing his father, who died after he intervened in a fight and was punched by the son, officials said today.

title: DISNEY AND HOME DEPOT SIGN THREE-YEAR AGREEMENT
description: The Walt Disney Company and Home Depot have signed a three-year advertising and merchandising agreement, estimated to be worth $100 million. Home Depot will buy commercials on Disney television networks like ABC, and will introduce in its stores products that carry the Disney brand. Disney will buy products from Home Depot for various operating purposes. Stuart Elliott (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROFFE, RUTH
description: ROFFE-Ruth. 82. Died at home on May 23, 2002. Loving wife of the late Hal Roffe. Devoted mother of Ken, Andrew and Barbara; cherished grandmother of Peter, Michael, Sarah, Lucas, Amanda and Matthew. Beloved mother-in-law of Valerie and Anna. She will be forever in our hearts. Funeral service-Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 10 AM, Sunday, May 26, 2002. Memorial contributions may be made to Senior Rabbi's Discretionary Fund, Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 1000 Pinebrook Blvd, New Rochelle, NY 10804

title: A Long Road To Party Unity
description: If H. Carl McCall and Andrew M. Cuomo agreed on one thing as the Democratic State Convention adjourned this week, it was that the party was -- or at least would be -- unified behind the effort to unseat Gov. George E. Pataki in November. Mr. McCall was chosen by acclamation as his party's gubernatorial designee; Mr. Cuomo preached unity even as he boycotted the convention.

title: Trying to Figure the Odds In New York's Redistricting
description: Negotiations over new Congressional districts intensified today after a federal court said it would impose its own plan unless the State Legislature acted soon. At the same time, Vice President Dick Cheney called the Republican leader of the State Senate to express worries about the lines the court has drawn.

title: Cash Aside, Is That Prize Meaningful?
description: Danny Hillis was sitting at his desk in Los Angeles when he got a telephone call with big news. Mr. Hillis, a computer designer and the chairman of the technology company Applied Minds, had been nominated for something called the Dan David prize. His qualification: nothing less than contributing ''to the improvement of the world.''

title: Schoolchildren Need Our Undivided Attention
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPECTOR, ALBERT
description: SPECTOR-Albert. On May 22nd, of Bayside. Beloved husband of Paula. Devoted father of Dr. Michael and wife Marcia. Loving brother of Paul and the late Jean. Cherished grandfather of David. Graveside services at Temple Beth Shalom Cemetery. Route 114, Danvers, MA., on Sunday May 26th at 11AM. Expressions of sympathy in his memory may be donated to the American Cancer Society. He shined his grace on thee.

title: U.S. Suggests, Without Proof, Stock Adviser Knew of 9/11
description: A San Diego stock adviser who is accused of bribing an F.B.I. agent to give him confidential government information may have had prior knowledge of the Sept. 11 attacks, a federal prosecutor said yesterday. But a judge disregarded that contention and the adviser's lawyer called the allegation ludicrous.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, CHESTER L., JR.
description: FISHER-Chester L., Jr. Of Williamsburg, VA, died May 21, 2002. Survived by wife Grace, two children, seven grandchildren. Colonel USAF; Senior VP MetLife; Mayor Briarcliff Manor, NY.

title: Rudeness And Nuisance As Revenue
description: O.K., all together now: taxes are bad, fees are good. Again: taxes are bad, fees are good. Got that? Splendid. You are now qualified to work in City Hall.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Budget Balanced Through Cuts
description: By cutting the budgets of most state agencies more than 3 percent, state lawmakers closed a $930 million deficit, ending the state's worst fiscal crisis. The final $6.1 billion package included several new initiatives, including one requiring developers to pay school construction costs until new residents move into an area and are able to begin paying taxes. That effort is expected to save the state $260 million. Lawmakers also delayed until the next fiscal year about $190 million in payments to public schools. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Mike Piazza's Answer
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLLERSTEIN, ISIDORE
description: WOLLERSTEIN-Isidore. On May 23, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Irene. Loving father of Alan, Roni and Marc. Cherished grandfather of Jeffrey and Sondra, Lisa and Scott, Nicole, Neil, Alison, Andrew and Marissa. Great grandfather of Cosette. Dear father-inlaw of Felicia and Janice. Service Sunday 10AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Lehman Is Said to Make Offer For Tyco Unit, Then Cancel It
description: In a development that further complicates matters for Tyco International, Lehman Brothers Holdings, an adviser to the company, bid about $5 billion in cash for Tyco's CIT finance unit but then appeared to withdraw the offer, executives close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Beacons In The Desert
description: Newly erected signal beacons in the state's desert are expected to reduce the number of illegal aliens who die trying to cross into the United States from Mexico. Each 30-foot beacon has instructions in English and Spanish and a button that sets off a strobe light that blinks every 10 seconds. The beacons were installed by the Immigration and Naturalization Service in areas where border patrol agents have found aliens sick or dead in scorching summer heat. More than 300 people die each year after crossing the border, many from dehydration. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Car Dealer In Settlement
description: A car dealer in a Chicago suburb will pay $300,000 to settle a class-action suit by temporary employees who said managers had demanded sexual favors or dances in exchange for job security and pay raises. The settlement, which will pay $3,000 each to 66 women, also provides for antiharassment programs at the dealership, Bob Watson Chevrolet in Harvey. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Money matters : Staying in home pension may be best bet
description: LONDON  When deciding what to take with them and what to leave behind before their big move, most expatriates would be better off placing their retirement savings in the "leave behind" category. Remaining in home social security systems and occupational and personal pension plans can produce a number of benefits, including lower tax bills and higher benefits at retirement.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cruise Acquisition Opposed
description: The European Commission's antitrust regulators said they officially informed the Carnival Corporation, the world's biggest cruise line, of objections to a $5.4 billion hostile bid for P& O Princess P.L.C. The regulators did not say what was contained in the formal ''statement of objections,'' but they were thought to relate to businesses in Britain and Germany. P& O Princess is resisting the Carnival bid in favor of a merger with Royal Caribbean Cruises. Both deals are being scrutinized by antitrust regulators in Europe and the United States in advance of rulings expected later this year. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: To Muffle the Guns of South Asia
description: To the Editor:

title: Charges of Payola Over Radio Music
description: One of the scandals that defined the 1950's was payola, payments to radio disc jockeys to push certain records. Congress outlawed the practice in 1960, making it a federal crime to play for pay unless the financial arrangement was announced on the air.

title: Israel Thwarts Bomb Attack, but Fears More to Come
description: After three terror attacks in 28 hours, including a thwarted car bombing early this morning, Israeli officials warned today of a new phase of Palestinian attacks that might include a shift toward making targets of strategic sites with methods more sophisticated than those used by lone suicide bombers.

title: Subsidies to Settlers
description: To the Editor:

title: The Church Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRAGER, IDA GOTTFRIED
description: PRAGER-Ida Gottfried. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY; she was born in New York City on January 4, 1908. She has two daughters, Judy Schwartz, of Philadelphia, and Bambi Granovsky of New York City and Lake Mohawk, NJ. Ida's husband was Louis S. Prager. Services Sunday, May 26 at 1:00 PM at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'', 1895 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, NY.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the trial of John Connolly, an F.B.I. agent accused of having mob ties, misstated the judge's middle initial and referred incorrectly to his decision to let the agent sit in the spectator section. The judge is Joseph L. Tauro, not A. He indeed explained his decision at the trial, saying that federal rules let the defendant choose where he would sit.

title: Corrections
description: Three pictures in Weekend yesterday with the continuation of an article about the artist Philip Pearlstein, showing the progress of his painting ''Mickey Mouse Puppet Theater, Jumbo Jet and Kiddie Tractor With Two Models,'' carried an erroneous credit. They were from the Robert Miller Gallery.

title: Skakel's Defense Confronts Witness Who Disputed Alibi
description: A prosecution witness who disputed Michael C. Skakel's alibi for the night Martha Moxley was killed in 1975 was called back to the stand by the defense today, and she testified that she never actually saw him at a time when she insists he was home.

title: Princeton to Face Johns Hopkins Next
description: As invariably happens, there were arguments this year about why some teams were chosen for the Division I men's lacrosse tournament and why others were not. But the selectors proved correct in one respect: the top four seeded teams will play in the semifinals today at Rutgers Stadium in Piscataway, N.J.

title: Holiday on Monday; Memorial Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Thanks For the Heads-Up
description: Cheney, Rumsfeld, Ridge, Mueller. Is there anyone who has not warned us of Armageddon over the past week? As far as I can tell, the only slacker in this White House game of Wag the Dog is Spot.

title: A Tiny Shift Rings Bells
description: In most New York City boroughs, and major cities in New Jersey, marriage rates have declined while divorce rates have risen. In Manhattan, the opposite is true.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, HANNAH
description: MILLER - Hannah. Eighty - nine, Born September 11, 1912. Passed away May 19, 2002 in Mahtomedi, MN. Hannah was born to Sarah and Max Finkelstein in Manhattan's Lower East Side, the third youngest child in a family of five boys and five girls. Hannah is survived by her daughter Marylin, her grandchildren Dan, Viv, and Zach, her great-grandchild Jacob, and numerous nieces and nephews. We will always remember Hannah for her marvelous sense of humor, her practical no-nonsense approach to life, and her devotion to her family and especially to her grandchildren. A memorial service will be held Sunday, May 26, 2002, 2pm at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to the Alzheimer's Association, 800-272-3900 or www.alz.org.

title: U.S. Olympic Chief Quits Over Her Lies On College Degrees
description: Sandra Baldwin, the first woman to become president and chairman of the United States Olympic Committee, resigned yesterday, a day after she acknowledged that she had lied on her rsum about her academic credentials.

title: Coast Guard's Harbor Chief Urges Boaters To Be Alert
description: The Memorial Day weekend is the traditional start of the boating season in the New York region, but concern about terrorism has some people worrying whether the waterways are safe. The answer from the Coast Guard's captain of the port for New York and New Jersey is a qualified yes.

title: Florida Counties Try to Avoid U.S. Suit on Voting Violations
description: Officials in three Florida counties have confirmed that they are facing potential Justice Department lawsuits charging voting rights violations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTER, SYLVIA
description: WINTER-Sylvia. Beloved wife of the late Milton. Devoted father of Michael and Lloyd. Adored grandmother of Barbara, Steven, Marc and Hallie. Great grandmother of Nicole, Alexandra and Dorothy. Services Sunday at ''BoulevardRiverside Chapels, 1895 Flatbush Av (Ave L), Bklyn, NY, 12:15pm

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Unemployment Rate Rises
description: Brazil's jobless rate unexpectedly surged in April to its highest level in almost two years, as construction and retail companies laid off workers and a weak economy failed to absorb an increased number of people seeking work. The unemployment rate rose to 8.2 percent from 7.8 percent in March and from 7 percent in April 2001, the government's statistics agency said.

title: Improved Liberty Set For Opener
description: The Liberty reached the championship round three times in the first five seasons of the Women's National Basketball Association without winning the title. Breaking through will not be easy this year, but Liberty Coach Richie Adubato likes what he sees in his team so far.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Postmodernist Of the 1600's Is Back in Fashion
description: A puckish question was raised on Thursday night at New York University: ''Was Athanasius Kircher the coolest guy ever, or what?'' For those who have no idea who Kircher was, let's begin with the ''or what.''

title: Defense Is Driving The Celtics' Surge
description: They have bumped cutters and smothered slashers for 94 games now, yet it still surprises some people when the Boston Celtics win because of their defense.

title: Sports of The Times; Blurring Line Between Conferences
description: THE Sacramento Kings ran the defending champion Lakers out of their own arena last night; this is potentially big news, in Los Angeles and beyond.

title: Iris, Fashion Plate Of Horticulture; Gardens Reflect 75 Years Of Changing Styles
description: The language of irises is the same used to describe fine wines, fast horses or the naughty bits in romance novels.

title: Heading Off Nuclear Terrorism
description: Warnings by federal officials that terrorists may strike again in this country have ratcheted up concerns about everything from suicide bombers to explosions in apartment buildings or at prominent landmarks. But the most frightening prospect of all is that terrorists will someday lay hands on or fabricate a nuclear weapon and explode it on American soil, causing devastation that would dwarf any terrorist act yet seen. This is a danger that demands a much more urgent response than it has thus far received.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a bombing at a fuel depot in Israel referred erroneously at one point to the day of the most recent suicide bombing in the city of Rishon le Zion. It was Wednesday, not Tuesday.

title: Vatican Accepts Resignation Of Milwaukee's Archbishop
description: The Vatican yesterday accepted the resignation of Archbishop Rembert G. Weakland of Milwaukee, who acknowledged on Thursday that he had paid $450,000 to settle a claim that he sexually assaulted a man two decades ago.

title: Medical Marijuana in Court
description: Whether marijuana can be used for medicinal purposes in California and several other Western states is about to be decided by a federal appeals court in San Francisco. The court is to rule on a challenge by doctors to a federal policy prohibiting them from recommending medical marijuana. The federal campaign, which is designed to block a California state referendum on the issue, is mean-spirited and unconstitutional. The appeals court should not delay in calling an end to it.

title: National Briefing | Washington: House Approves Expansion Of Customs Searches
description: The House passed a bill to let customs agents open international mail without a search warrant. Customs agents may already open inbound packages they deem suspicious; the new bill expands their right to inspect incoming and outgoing mail. The Postal Service opposes the bill, on privacy grounds. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Bushels of Bad News for Growers
description: Hurricanes, drought, hail Steve Clarke and his fellow Hudson Valley fruit growers have seen it all in the last few years. But not a gyrating thermometer, at least not until now. The way their luck's been running, though, it was just a matter of time.

title: Council Appears to Accept Defeat Of Plan to Raise Taxes This Year
description: City Council members are beginning to concede privately that they have all but lost the fight to raise taxes this year, even as they maneuver to stake out a negotiating position with the Bloomberg administration over the budget.

title: INSIDE
description: Afghan Battle Reviewed

title: Go West, Mr. Putin
description: To the Editor:

title: Critic Is Described as Scrupulous and Determined
description: Former colleagues described Coleen Rowley today as a conscientious and scrupulous agent who has often found herself in the middle of the biggest cases in the F.B.I.'s office here in her past role as spokeswoman and her current position as general counsel.

title: Critic's Notebook; Cannes Has Echoes of Polanski and the Man Himself
description: Since this year's film festival has been so much about alienation, it seems fitting that the competition includes Roman Polanski, whose early work in plumbing the chilliest depths of the human soul probably set the pace for many other filmmakers in the competition.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Cuts In Planned Parenthood Financing
description: Governor John Engler, a Republican, has signed legislation that scales back financing for Planned Parenthood clinics. The new law requires the state Department of Community Health to give clinics that do not perform abortions first priority for state funds. Although Planned Parenthood performs abortions in some clinics, the group argued that it does not do so with state money that is allocated specifically for family planning.

title: The Story of Your Family, in Numbers
description: Family historians and academic researchers have swarmed into regional branches of the National Archives this spring to get the 70-year-old news of the 1930 census, newly opened to public view. Most of these people probably have no memory of the year they are researching. But for those who do remember, the dry facts of census data can leap off the crumbling pages, preserved on microfilm, with a startling vibrancy.

title: A.I.G. Operations in China
description: The American International Group, the world's biggest insurer, said yesterday that its American International Assurance unit had been granted a license to sell life insurance in Beijing. The company, which is based in New York, said that it was the first foreign insurance company to be licensed for sales in Beijing. At the end of 2001, A.I.G. was granted approval to set up wholly owned life insurance operations in Beijing and Suzhou, and two sub-branches in Dongguan and Jiangmen in Guangdong Province.

title: Sihung Lung, 72, Film Actor Who Starred for Ang Lee
description: Sihung Lung, the Taiwanese actor best known to Western audiences for deft portrayals of conflicted fathers in the Ang Lee films ''Pushing Hands,'' ''The Wedding Banquet'' and ''Eat Drink Man Woman,'' died on May 2 in Taipei. He was 72.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZWECKER, SAUL
description: ZWECKER-Saul. Beloved husband of Marie. Adored father of Jordan, Sam, Roberta and Michael. Loving grandfather of Zoe, Samantha and Benci. Dear brother of Florence Schwartz and Irving Zwecker. Services Sunday 1PM at ''Gutterman's'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST CALIFORNIA: COURT RULES AGAINST A DRESS CODE

title: Montana Senator Gets a Second Wind
description: Republicans all but cheered when Senator Max Baucus, a moderate-to-liberal Democrat, announced that he would seek a fifth term this year. The time was ripe, they figured, to send him packing.

title: Dr. Richard Mudd, 101, Dies; Grandfather Treated Booth
description: Dr. Richard D. Mudd, who waged a campaign for seven decades seeking to clear his grandfather of complicity in the assassination of Abraham Lincoln, died on Tuesday at his home in Saginaw, Mich. He was 101.

title: The Yankees Go Down, Come Up, Then Fall
description: The Yankees were in trouble. Bases loaded, one out, bottom of the 11th inning at Fenway Park. Steve Karsay was working his fourth inning, trying to wiggle out of another jam. Carlos Baerga sizzled a liner to center field.

title: Revelation About Payment Leaves Catholics Uneasy
description: Roman Catholics in Milwaukee were still reeling yesterday from the disclosure that Archbishop Rembert G. Weakland had been accused of sexual misconduct and that the Milwaukee Archdiocese had paid his accuser a $450,000 settlement.

title: In Final Republican Debate, Torricelli Is Again the Target
description: Their differences were often slight, but in their third and last debate, New Jersey's three candidates for the Republican nomination to the United States Senate revealed some disagreements on stem cell research and the use of troops to guard a Middle East peace settlement.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Congress Defies President
description: Defying President Eduardo Duhalde, the lower house of Congress voted against modifying an ''economic subversion'' law that has been used to prosecute bankers. The International Monetary Fund has made revisions a condition for resumption of aid to Argentina, and this week Mr. Duhalde threatened to resign unless Congress, controlled by his own party, sped up action on amendments he submitted. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a bombing at a fuel depot in Israel referred erroneously at one point to the day of the most recent suicide bombing in the city of Rishon le Zion. It was Wednesday, not Tuesday.

title: Mt. Sinai Liver Transplant Plan Approved
description: The State Health Department has accepted Mount Sinai Hospital's plan to improve care in its liver transplant service, which was closed for six months after the death of a healthy donor in January. The donor, Mike Hurewitz, 57, a reporter for The Times Union of Albany, died three days after donating part of his liver to his brother, a doctor, who recovered.

title: Bush and Putin Sign Pact for Steep Nuclear Arms Cuts
description: In a day devoted to celebrating what President Bush called ''an entirely new relationship'' with Russia, he and President Vladimir V. Putin signed a treaty today to commit their nations to the most dramatic nuclear arms cuts in decades. But both men tried to smooth over a disagreement about continued Russian exports of nuclear technology to Iran.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''At some point, you have to feel comfortable with the level of preparedness where you're at. Have we done absolutely everything that we could physically, possibly ever do? Probably not. How much is enough?''

title: Harlem Pays Tribute to Older Jazz Dancers
description: The motto of the annual Harlem Jazz Dance Festival is ''celebrate dance, celebrate life.'' That sense of celebration filled ''Harlem Renaissance Tribute,'' the festival's culminating event on Sunday night at the Marcus Garvey Park Amphitheater.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: VISTEON CORP., Dearborn, Mich., a maker of auto parts, said it would spend about $300 million to build a new headquarters on a 265-acre site in Van Buren Township, Mich., to complete its move from Dearborn, the home of its former parent, Ford Motor Company.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Thursday about an Indonesian government investigation into trading by Merrill Lynch in the shares of Indosat, a phone company, misstated the location of a Merrill spokesman who said there was no evidence of insider trading. He was in Hong Kong, not Singapore.

title: Japan's Four Big Banks Move Toward a Recovery
description: Japan's huge, troubled lending institutions are often lumped together like a basket of bad apples. But after years of losses, deregulation and realignment, the four big banking groups are now being forced to abandon their one-size-fits-all business model and start differentiating themselves to revive their sagging fortunes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHMAN, ARTHUR MORDECAI
description: ROTHMAN-Arthur Mordecai. Beloved husband of Esther. Devoted father of Amy. Dear son-in-law of Michael. Loving grandfather of Ellis Arthur and Jacob Jerome. Services Sunday, 12 Noon, Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Ave. (East 10th St.)

title: State Finds That a Series of Health Care Violations Led to an Infant's Death
description: New York State investigators have concluded that the tenfold medication overdose that killed a 6-day-old boy at a Long Island hospital stemmed from a series of serious health care violations.

title: Chief of AOL Time Warner Makes First Executive Shifts
description: Richard D. Parsons made his first significant personnel moves as AOL Time Warner's new chief executive yesterday. The moves did not bring any new executives to the company or entail any departures, but they appeared to represent a first step toward Mr. Parsons's goal of streamlining management.

title: Bush Pledges Partnership With Russians on Energy
description: President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin agreed today to begin what Mr. Bush called a ''major new energy partnership,'' with more American investment in Russia's oil and gas industry and faster ways for its products to reach world markets.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Lawmakers Approve Castration Bill
description: Repeat sex offenders convicted of first- or second-degree rape or forcible sodomy may face chemical or surgical castration under a bill passed by both the House and Senate. A spokesman for Gov. Frank Keating said a veto was possible. Texas allows surgical castration for repeat sexual offenders; California, Georgia, Montana, Florida and Louisiana allow chemical castration. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPEVACK, EDWARD
description: SPEVACK-Edward. On May 23, 2002 of Huntington, L.I. Beloved husband of Barbara. Devoted father of Sue Graze, and Neal Spevack. Dear brother of Ruth Kobren. Loving grandfather of Johanna and Alex Graze, Jesse, Mollie and Nathan Spevack. Services Sunday 9:30AM at Huntington Jewish Center, 510 Park Avenue, Huntington, L.I.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: A Woman On The Ticket
description: In an effort to energize his flagging campaign for the presidency, Jos Serra, the candidate of the governing Social Democratic Party, has named a woman as his running mate. Rita Camata, 41, a member of Congress who belongs to a center-left party that is also part of the government coalition, would be Brazil's first woman vice president if they were to win in October. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Harking Back to Miles Davis, But With a Drive of His Own
description: In form if not in content Dave Douglas's New Quintet, which plays through Sunday at the Village Vanguard (178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, West Village), pays homage to the Miles Davis Quintet of the 1960's, just before Davis's first jazz-fusion records: mysterious melodies, a Fender Rhodes keyboard, plenty of heated improvising. Hearing the sound, one of the bedrock prototypes of modern jazz, you expect Miles Davis's short, gelatinous notes, his distressed tone. What you get instead from this ambitious, fearsomely talented trumpeter are lines that drive like bullets.

title: Colorado's Rain and Snow Ease Fire, but Not Drought
description: Rain and snow, rare visitors to drought-stricken Colorado, tamed a scorching wildfire today in the Pike National Forest, but did little to quell apprehension about the effects of severe drought here and in many parts of the West this summer.

title: In Pakistan, U.S. Embraces Friend of a Foe
description: The Bush administration has embraced this country as one of its most important allies in its campaign against terror. But like nowhere else, South Asia highlights just how murky the world of friends and enemies has become since Sept. 11.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Bank To Write Off Loss
description: Santander Central Hispano S.A., Spain's biggest bank, said second-quarter pretax profit would be cut by 700 million euros ($643 million) because of losses from selling its unprofitable Latin American Internet unit. The write-off almost equals the 714 million euros that Santander earned in the second quarter of last year and will make it more difficult for the bank to meet its 2002 goal of a 10 percent profit increase.

title: Bad Break? No Problem. Trump Lead? Problem.
description: Most of New York's experts gathered Tuesday at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 64th Street, for the world's most successful charity event. This 39th annual effort, with an organizing team headed by Marci Miron, raised more than $85,000 for UJA-Federation.

title: A Showcase for Masur In Schnittke and Bruckner
description: Like the programs of most music directors, Kurt Masur's have been influenced by ticket sales, but Mr. Masur is making no compromises in his final weeks with the New York Philharmonic.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: ECONOMY GROWS The French econ- omy grew 0.4 percent in the first quarter of 2002, helped by spending on manufactured goods, the government statistics office, Insee, reported yesterday. For 2001, growth was 1.8 percent, slightly less than the 1.9 percent figure Insee had predicted. Consumer spending grew 0.2 percent, slightly weaker than the 0.3 percent rise in the prior quarter; overall investment also grew 0.2 percent. President Jacques Chirac, above, has pledged to cut taxes by 5 percent this year assuming the French economy grows at least 3 percent.   Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: U.S. Appeals Court Order Is Victory for Regional Bells
description: A federal appeals court ordered regulators to reconsider two important rules today intended to spur competition in the local phone and high-speed Internet markets. The decision was a victory for the regional Bell companies and a setback to their competitors that rely on leasing equipment to challenge the incumbents.

title: Huge Deficit May Lead Connecticut to Borrow
description: Since Connecticut's legislative session ended on May 8 without a balanced budget for the next fiscal year in place, Democratic state lawmakers and Gov. John G. Rowland have had a hard time agreeing on when to sit down and resume discussing the problem, much less solving it.

title: Unions Mostly Negative, So Far, on US Airways' Call for Cuts
description: US Airways ended a week of talks with its six unions yesterday during which it asked for substantial cuts in wages and benefits to help the airline obtain a federal loan guarantee. But the largest unions left the table with mixed reactions to the demands, ranging from ''more than necessary'' to ''totally unacceptable.''

title: New Jersey Electric Utility Asks for Rate Increase
description: The Public Service Electric and Gas Company asked permission yesterday to increase rates for its two million electricity customers in New Jersey beginning in August 2003.

title: Pay the Victims, Protect the Church
description: The child sex abuse scandal that has roiled the Catholic Church for the past few months has entered a crucial stage. Lawsuits against the church have been filed in several cities, and settlement talks have collapsed in the highly publicized suits against the archdiocese of Boston over child abuse charges against John Geoghan.

title: Radically Different 2-Wheels
Breifing: Health; CANCER AMONG ELDERLY
description: Cancer rates among New Jerseyans 65 and older are nearly 13 percent higher than the national average, according to statistics released this week by the state Department of Health and Human Services. Officials said they did not know the reason for the rates. Wendy Ginsburg

title: Reader's Digest Acquires Reiman and Its Readers
description: The finalization of Reader's Digest Association's acquisition of Reiman Publications LLC, last Monday may go unnoticed by the readers of Taste of Home, Birds & Blooms and the 10 other magazines owned by Reiman. But the $760 million purchase of the profitable Wisconsin-based publisher is intended to invigorate Reader's Digest with an estimated $300 million in revenue, in addition to new marketing opportunities. The company also completed $950 million in syndicated financing that was partly used to finance the Reiman purchase. J.P. Morgan Chase & Company and Goldman Sachs Group Inc. arranged the financing.

title: Ideas & Trends: Variations on a Theme; Hold the Bloody Mary
description: THERE is no record of Vlad the Impaler's golf handicap, but one might guess -- if the game had been played in 15th-century Transylvania -- that he would have always won anyway. So why not build a golf course, a Ferris wheel or two, a petting zoo for the little ones, and a variety of other family attractions near Vlad's hometown of Sighisoara, Romania?

title: Corrections
description: An art review last Sunday about an exhibition at the Silvermine Guild Galleries at New Canaan misstated the title of one painting and misidentified the artist who made it. The work, which depicted a hat and an umbrella, was ''Still Life'' by Michael McCabe. (''Aftermath,'' by Richard K. Miller, is an abstract painting.)

title: In Person; Rutgers's Good Right Hand
description: IT is not hard for Bobby Brownlie to think back to that cool May night three years ago, the one that probably changed his life forever.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COWIN, DANIEL
description: COWIN-Daniel. Dearest Daniel: Incredibly, it's been 10 long years. Everything is precisely as you left it. Would that you could return. Those who knew you best, miss your encouragement, wisdom, good sense, good taste, kindness and courage! We think of you daily with love and remembrance. Joyce and Family

title: Kitt Shapiro, Allan Rothschild
description: Kitt Shapiro, the daughter of the singer Eartha Kitt of Weston, Conn., is to be married today to Allan Bruce Rothschild, the son of Rita and Stanley Rothschild of Merrick, N.Y. Rabbi Mark Lipson will officiate at the couple's house in Westport, Conn.

title: Mary Ann Azzolina, Paul Orzechowski
description: Mary Ann Azzolina, a daughter of Lynn Azzolina of Long Branch, N.J., and Assemblyman Joseph Azzolina of Middletown, N.J., was married yesterday to Paul Edward Orzechowski, a son of Elizabeth and Edward Orzechowski of Red Bank, N.J. The Rev. Russell Abata performed the ceremony at St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church in Long Branch.

title: Randi Kornbluth, David Sultan
description: Dr. Randi Aviva Kornbluth, a daughter of Joan Kornbluth and Dr. David Kornbluth of Hollywood, Fla., are to be married today to David Mark Sultan, a son of Pearl and George Sultan of East Brunswick, N.J. Rabbi Edward Davis will officiate at the Doral Country Club in Miami.

title: Footlights; A Playwright's Response
description: The Artist's Sept. 11th Response Show in Pelham is being shown in a town that lost nine of its residents in the World Trade Center tragedy.

title: Tinguely in Basel
description: To the Editor: ''What's Doing in Basel'' (May 5) highlighted some of that city's notable modern architecture, including the Theaterplatz, which features a Jean Tinguely mobile sculpture.

title: Bronx Man Arrested In Five Sex Attacks
description: A suspect in five Manhattan sex attacks and robberies in which the victims were lured into desolate buildings with the promise of a job, or ambushed in lobbies or on elevators, was arrested after investigators received an anonymous tip, the police said yesterday.

title: Opinion; To Tell the Truth . . . or Maybe Not
description: I HAVE always attempted where humanly possible to lead a moral life. Among those things that define this devotion is truthfulness, and when truthfulness seems impractical or impossible, one should always seek remedy in earnest confession. So this is my confession, and also my opportunity to report that I have now removed a pebble in my shoe that impaired my ability to walk with my head completely erect.

title: A Dog's Life; London Church; Tucson Cottage
description: ADog's Life

title: May 19-25: NATIONAL; BIG FINES
description: Two of Americas biggest corporations, Merrill Lynch & Company and Schering-Plough, agreed to pay penalties that were among the biggest of their kind. Merrill Lynch, the Wall Street giant, said it would pay $100 million into state treasuries to end an inquiry by the New York attorney general, which revealed e-mail messages in which Merrill Lynch analysts disparaged companies whose shares they were recommending to investors. Schering-Plough will pay the U.S. Treasury $500 million, for failing to fix problems in the way it made dozens of drugs, including the Claritin allergy medicine, the largest financial penalty ever paid by a pharmaceutical company. Patrick McGeehan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUWIRTH, LINDA
description: NEUWIRTH-Linda. A Wife, a Mother, a Daughter and a Lady. Maxine and Joel Hirsch

title: Financial Course in Spanish
description: An investor education program is being offered in Spanish by a foundation affiliated with the Investment Company Institute, which represents the mutual fund industry.

title: Brave New World: My ID, Your ID
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets Collapse in Epic Fashion
description: BOSTON, May 25 — Stunned, sickened and spent, the Nets staggered off the court, paralyzed by their epic unraveling.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction and Poetry
description: SPARROW NIGHTS

title: Film; When There's Too Much of a Not-Very-Good Thing
description: CHICO EJIRO, whose nickname is Mr. Prolific, directed 15 movies last year. He boasts of shooting a movie in a single weekend. At times, he has directed several movies at once. But for the last three months, Mr. Ejiro has not worked. Neither have Lancelot Imassie (called the Governor), Akwila Ajama (the Whiz Kid), Arinzi Egbon (A to Zed) or any other bigwigs in Nigeria's growing English-language movie industry. In March, the industry declared a ''recess'' to combat what it sees as a threat to its future: too many movies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORMAN, SYDNEY
description: KORMAN-Sydney. Died peacefully at the age of 96, on May 17, 2002. Survived by son Tom. Any donations in her memory may be sent to Pines Nursing Home, 301 N.E. 141 Street, Miami, FL 33161.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column last Sunday about Priceline.com vacation packages referred incorrectly to a similar service by Expedia.com. Expedia indeed tells customers the name of the airline before a vacation package is purchased.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, HERMAN J.
description: COHEN-Herman J. On May 21, 2002 in Florida, age 79. Bronx native. Professor of Mathematics at City College, 1954-1998. He loved teaching and was dedicated to his students. Beloved brother of Sidney and Bea. Graveside service Baron Hirsch Cemetery, Staten Island, Tuesday, May 28th, 10:30AM.

title: Midtown Car Chase Yields Serious Injury
description: Adriver fleeing from the police struck three cars and seriously injured one driver on Friday night in a car chase through Midtown Manhattan, the authorities said yesterday.

title: 'Wish You Were Here'
description: They took Arlene's car because it had air-conditioning and Emily wasn't sure the Olds would make it. That and Arlene's was bigger, a wagon, better for bringing things back.

title: Private Sector; The Chinese (Insurers) Are Coming
description: The menu featured Peking duck and steamed dumplings, and the ballroom at the Waldorf-Astoria was festooned with red roses. The occasion was the opening of the New York offices of China's largest insurer.

title: London Church
description: To the Editor: To add to ''Australian Chefs Broaden London's Culinary Horizons'' (April 14), Smiths of Smithfield is in an interesting neighborhood definitely not on the tourist trail. Across from Smithfield's wholesale meat market is a 400-year-old half-timbered Tudor arch, which some may remember from the film ''Shakespeare in Love.'' It leads into London's oldest church, St. Bartholomew the Great (St. Bart's), small and intimate and founded in 1123.

title: Dance; Where Is the Heartbeat in the Balanchine Legacy?
description: GEORGE BALANCHINE died in 1983. He left a world class dance company, dozens of ballets and a great school. He made New York the mecca of classical ballet in the 20th century. It was here that he and the New York City Ballet revolutionized classicism. For four decades, New Yorkers were treated to some of the most extraordinary performances of our time. To spend an evening at City Ballet was to enter a gloriously entertaining world. For two hours, you lived in a heightened state, and left the theater knowing that humanity was capable of wit, beauty and grandeur.

title: Behind Hedgerows, The Caddy
description: AS May brings golf back to Westchester's country clubs, the golfers come out to play, the golf bags come out of storage, and the caddies come out of the woodwork.

title: Jill Cremer, Joseph Gall
description: Jill Cremer and Joseph Edward Gall were married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Jan Carlsson-Bull, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, at the Armour-Stiner House, a national historic landmark in Irvington, N.Y.

title: 3 North Koreans in Beijing Defect to Seoul
description: The South Korean Embassy in Beijing said today that three North Koreans had sought refuge there, and the South Korean government demanded that Chinese authorities treat the case ''in a humanitarian manner.''

title: Soccer League and Its Landlord Cry Foul
description: AT the Long Island Soccer Park, disputed calls are usually resolved quickly so play can continue. But disagreements over the Plainview property's lease have dragged on for nearly two years.

title: 'At the Hands of Persons Unknown'
description: Smartly dressed, with his walking cane in hand, W.E.B. Du Bois left his home in Atlanta on April 24, 1899, and began walking downtown along Mitchell Street. He was carrying a letter of introduction to Joel Chandler Harris, the white author of the Negro dialect tales known as the Uncle Remus stories and an editor at The Atlanta Constitution. At thirty-one, Du Bois was himself an acclaimed author, with degrees from Harvard and two years' study at a prestigious German university to his credit. In addition to his teaching duties as a professor of economics and history at Atlanta University, he also supervised an ambitious program of social research there.

title: Sociology in Trouble
description: To the Editor:

title: Sara Sherwin, Joshua Sapire
description: Sara Kate Sherwin, a daughter of Leslie Sherwin and Dr. Robert Sherwin of Orange, Conn., was married last evening to Dr. Joshua Michael Sapire, a son of Frances Fine and Dr. David Sapire, both of Houston. Rabbi Alvin Wainhaus officiated at the Yale Club in New York.

title: Trying to Foreclose on Foreclosure
description: THURSDAYS can be busy days for Joseph Bonner.

title: Up And Away
Join the Navy and See the Light
description: TWO young sailors walked into the cool darkness and took off their caps. The quiet saloon grew quieter. Two men hunched over their bottles squinted toward the light of the door and nodded to the sailors.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 29 of Arts & Leisure today about outdoor murals in Los Angeles includes a misspelled given name in some copies for the director of arts and culture at the Rockefeller Foundation, which is involved in conservation efforts. He is Raymund Paredes, not Raymond.

title: Music; Good as It Is, The Met Has Gaps to Fill
description: THE recently completed season of the Metropolitan Opera began less than two weeks after Sept. 11. Like other deeply shaken arts institutions, the Met began with a healing public ceremony: a preview of the opening-night Verdi gala, featuring Plcido Domingo, performed as a benefit for victims of the World Trade Center bombing and shown on closed-circuit video in Lincoln Center Plaza for thousands of grateful opera lovers.

title: Music Listings
description: Opera

title: All Fronts: Unsafe Havens; Around the World, Hints of Afghanistans to Come
description: PANKISI GORGE hardly looks like the next capital of radical Islam. Duisi, the largest of the four villages in the remote part of the Caucasus Mountains, is home to a few thousand Chechen refugees living in poverty and about 1,500 Chechen rebels who are not much better off.

title: An Impossible Occupation
description: Your article offers a refreshingly nuanced account of the difficulties all people in the region are facing in their struggle for security and identity. Those who speak in terms of moral clarity fail to see how innocence and culpability can wear the same face.

title: Investors Want Cops On the Street
description: HAVING run the first lap of his investigation of Wall Street research, Eliot L. Spitzer, attorney general of New York, secured $100 million in penalties from Merrill Lynch, changes to the way it compensates analysts to blunt the influence of investment bankers on them and an apology from the firm for the now-public frat-house chatter of its Internet analysts.

title: Clinic Calls It A Day, and So Do Pickets
description: IT may take a month or two before the residents of Dobbs Ferry get used to Saturdays without protests outside the Women's Medical Pavilion. For the first time in decades, Ashford Avenue will be free of ''Abortion Is Murder'' and ''Pro-Child, Pro-Choice'' pickets. Children will be able to play in the Ashford Park without glimpsing pictures of aborted fetuses and police officers will have time to talk to downtown merchants and ticket double-parked cars.

title: Soapbox; In a TV Studio Near You
description: I AM a local television talk show host. Not local as in Fox Five or News 12. Local as in Channel 26-PCTV, Pleasantville public access. Not that I am totally unknown. The seniors in my village call me ''the TV girl.'' Once a woman standing in line at the A&P said to me, ''You're that person on TV.'' She paused for a moment then added, ''Your hair looks good today.'' On a recent visit to my gynecologist, my doctor looked up at me and said, ''By the way, I love your show.''

title: L.I. @ Work; Cablevision Downplays Its Adelphia Exposure
description: Cablevision (NYSE: CVC) of Bethpage says it is confident the precautions it took last year will adequately preserve the value of its investment in Adelphia Communications, whose stock price has plummeted in recent weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LENNARD, FLORENCE
description: LENNARD-Florence. In life you were always there. It's been 16 years since you left-you are still here. Everlasting love, Jules

title: Annette Oestreicher, Arthur Grollman
description: Annette Oestreicher and Dr. Arthur P. Grollman are to be married today in the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Rabbi Earl Grollman, a cousin of the bridegroom, is to officiate.

title: 102 MINUTES: Last Words at the Trade Center; Fighting to Live as the Towers Died
description: They began as calls for help, information, guidance. They quickly turned into soundings of desperation, and anger, and love. Now they are the remembered voices of the men and women who were trapped on the high floors of the twin towers.

description: THE PARADOX

title: Shari Markowitz, Daniel Savitt
description: Shari Hope Markowitz, a daughter of Linda and Malcolm Markowitz of Merrick, N.Y., is to be married today to Daniel Cory Savitt, a son of Susan Schenkel-Savitt of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Harvey B. Savitt of Centerport, N.Y. Rabbi Jeremiah Wohlberg will perform the ceremony at Temple Emanuel in Kings Point, N.Y.

description: This

title: Always the Bridesmaid: Tales of Taffeta and Travail
description: THE SETTING -- The Halo Restaurant and Lounge, at Grove and Bleecker Streets, for a meeting last weekend of Ronit Ray's Bridesmaids Anonymous, an organization that caters to the groomless and gaudily gowned. Seven former bridesmaids, spaghetti-strapped into ugly evening wear and staggering on stilettos, crowded around the white-veiled Ms. Ray, whose Miu Miu bridal gown still had its price tag dangling down the side.

description: GOD'S FOOL

title: Nuclear Nightmares
description: Not If But When: Everybody who spends much time thinking about nuclear terrorism can give you a scenario, something diabolical and, theoretically, doable. Michael A. Levi, a researcher at the Federation of American Scientists, imagines a homemade nuclear explosive device detonated inside a truck passing through one of the tunnels into Manhattan. The blast would crater portions of the New York skyline, barbecue thousands of people instantly, condemn thousands more to a horrible death from radiation sickness and -- by virtue of being underground -- would vaporize many tons of concrete and dirt and river water into an enduring cloud of lethal fallout. Vladimir Shikalov, a Russian nuclear physicist who helped clean up after the 1986 Chernobyl accident, envisioned for me an attack involving highly radioactive cesium-137 loaded into some kind of homemade spraying device, and a target that sounded particularly unsettling when proposed across a Moscow kitchen table -- Disneyland. In this case, the human toll would be much less ghastly, but the panic that would result from contaminating the Magic Kingdom with a modest amount of cesium -- Shikalov held up his teacup to illustrate how much -- would probably shut the place down for good and constitute a staggering strike at Americans' sense of innocence. Shikalov, a nuclear enthusiast who thinks most people are ridiculously squeamish about radiation, added that personally he would still be happy to visit Disneyland after the terrorists struck, although he would pack his own food and drink and destroy his clothing afterward.

title: Fact-Finding and Its Limits
description: It's not surprising that many officials in Washington are talking about convening an independent panel to investigate the federal government's actions before the Sept. 11 attacks. We now know that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was warned by an agent in its Phoenix office in July 2001 that operatives of Osama bin Laden could be studying at American flight schools and yet President Bush was not told until recently about the warning. We also know that Mr. Bush was shown a daily intelligence report in August 2001 indicating that Qaeda members were threatening to hijack American planes, but we do not know much about its context. Given these revelations, we will see various investigations -- within the F.B.I. and other agencies, by Congress, and perhaps even by a blue-ribbon commission of the kind appointed by Lyndon Johnson to study the John F. Kennedy assassination and by Ronald Reagan to study the Challenger disaster. It's a sign of our democracy's health that Americans tend to question government even during national crises; a half-dozen Congressional, military and other panels investigated Pearl Harbor while Americans were still dying in World War II.
