description: Martin Whitman, 77, who has prospered through long-term investments in deeply discounted companies, has agreed to sell a 60 percent stake in Third Avenue Value Management to the Affiliated Managers Group.

title: Worth Noting; That So-and-So Said . . . At Least It Was Clean
description: Steve Adubato, an Assemblyman turned talk show interviewer, has been hawking his new book, ''Speak From the Heart: Be Yourself and Get Results,'' a how-to book for making a personal connection with an audience. But it seems that certain New Jersey politicians do not need such pithy advice, since they usually say exactly what they mean. Take Joe Doria, the mayor of Bayonne who also happens to be a member of the Assembly.

title: Elaine Coonrod, Gabriel Dichter
description: Elaine Elizabeth Coonrod, a daughter of Dr. Betty Wolf and Dr. J. Donald Coonrod of Lexington, Ky., is to be married today to Gabriel Sviatoslav Dichter, a son of the concert pianists Cipa Dichter and Misha Dichter of New York. Rabbi Mark Schiftan will officiate at the Riverwood Mansion, a historic house in Nashville.

title: Martha Turner, Neil Fein
description: Martha Axler Turner, a daughter of Judith Turner and Dr. Lester Turner of Washington, is to be married today to Neil Frederick Fein, the son of Carol Sue Fein of Monroe Township, N.J., and the late Bernard Fein. Rabbi Ethan D. Seidel will perform the ceremony at Tifereth Israel Congregation in Washington.

title: Music; A Composer Thinking Globally, Acting Locally
description: THREE decades ago, the music of Stefan Wolpe stood like Mount Everest before New York's contemporary-music ensembles. Nearly impossible to scale yet irresistible, unforgiving yet glorious, replete with legends of performers who had tried and (sometimes ignobly) failed, his work was virtually their raison d'tre. For the established Group for Contemporary Music or the start-up Speculum Musicae, Wolpe exemplified what was most exciting about new music and about being a performer able to cut it.

title: States Pursue Cloning Laws as Congress Debates
description: After nearly a year of emotional arguments in Congress but no new federal laws -- the national debate over the future of human cloning has shifted to the states. Six states have already banned cloning in one form or another, and this year alone 38 anticloning measures were introduced in 22 states.

title: 'Flaubert'
description: Achille-Cléophas Flaubert, doctor of medicine and father of Gustave Flaubert, was a man whose whole life could be read as an illustration of the bourgeois virtues. Born in 1784, he survived the heroic high-mortality decades of Revolution and Empire by cultivating a modest public rectitude. He worked hard and won prizes, and soon accumulated a large fortune in the pursuit of his profession. Achille-Cléophas Flaubert became one of the princes of the new realm of scientific medicine. It would surely have dismayed the good doctor if anyone had ventured to tell him that he would be remembered principally as the father of a boy whose only obvious talents were for writing odd, disreputable novels, spending other people's money, and generally satirising the bourgeois virtues.

title: Repairing Water Damage in a Co-op
description: Q Several months ago, I repaired significant water damage to my co-op apartment's bathroom ceiling. The leakage apparently came from outside my unit. When evidence of continued leaking appeared, I asked the managing agent to investigate and to require the responsible party to make the necessary repairs. The agent refused, saying that I must deal directly with my upstairs neighbors. Since I have neither the authority nor the expertise to determine who in the six stories above me is responsible for the leak, this approach is destined to fail. Who is responsible for finding out who is responsible and for assuring that a repair is made? . . . Douglas L. Beards, Hartsdale, N.Y.

title: Bush and Latin America
description: To the Editor:

title: America's Best Shot
description: Suddenly, Clint Mathis is the man everybody wants. They want him in Germany. They want him in Italy. And after he plays for the United States national team in South Korea at the World Cup, which starts this week, they may want him in several other countries as well. But the place they need him most is the United States, where, oddly enough, he is least likely to end up.

title: At Hearing, A Resolve To Rebuild Twin Towers
description: Given a chance to tell the people who will oversee the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan what they want to see there, hundreds of New Yorkers and others responded on Thursday with a surprising answer: rebuild the twin towers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLLERSTEIN, ISIDORE
description: WOLLERSTEIN-Isidore. Sutton Place Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of our longtime member, devoted Trustee and noble Benefactor. He will be sorely missed. Our heartfelt condolences to the bereaved family. May their precious memories of this dynamic gentleman comfort and sustain them. Allan Schranz, Rabbi Robert W. Berend, President

title: Theater; Opposites Make Use Of Their Differences
description: WHEN they met at Southern Methodist University in Dallas in 1996, Craig Lucas was a visiting playwright and screenwriter invited for a weekend literary festival and David Schulner was an undergraduate half his age. Mr. Lucas's best-known work, ''Prelude to a Kiss,'' had been both a popular play on Broadway and a Hollywood movie. But more intimidating for Mr. Schulner -- whose life had been, as he puts it, ''privileged and untouched'' -- was that Mr. Lucas had just suffered through the deaths of his partner and his mother, and his longtime director was dying of AIDS.

title: Mosque and State
description: JIHAD

title: Looking at Celebrities Through a Wider Lens
description: THE WORLD of high fashion, the Statue of Liberty and a Puerto Rican demigod are the subjects of three shows at the Jersey City Museum. All of them feature black-and-white photographs, and are absorbing because of the extended treatment these varied subjects receive.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DRAYER, STEVEN J.
description: DRAYER-Steven J. Happy 47th birthday, you are missed and loved. The world smiles less without you. Dad, Michelle, Joe, Emily, Billy, Caroline

title: Kangaroos In the Mist
description: SKEPTICISM is not my forte. Still, when I planned a visit to the Kangaroo Conservation Center in the small town of Dawsonville, Ga., last June, I wasn't convinced that the experience would be worth the ticket price or the four-hour drive from my home in Charlotte, N.C. What if this turned out to be a mere roadside zoo or only a quick glimpse of the animals promised in the brochure? Having never been Down Under, how could I gauge the ''only such wildlife park outside of Australia''? What's more, menacing thunderstorms that had ravaged the muggy Southeast for several days were reportedly headed my way.

title: Around Town
description: Music

title: FRONT LINES
description: FEAR -- The nation grappled with the return of raw anxiety over terrorism after a series of grim statements out of a Bush administration scorched by criticism that it might have missed clues to the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAVOURAS, HARRIET
description: KAVOURAS-Harriet. Of Whitestone, NY, died on May 24, 2002, at the age of 57. She was an incredibly generous woman to all who knew her. Survived by her husband Evangelos, daughter Tina Keriazes and her husband John, daughter Evi Kavouras, granddaughter Kayla Keriazes, brothers and sister, cousines, nieces and nephews, and many friends. Visitation Sunday, 7-9 PM, and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at the Antonopoulos Funeral Home, 3808 Ditmars Blvd, Astoria, NY. Funeral services to be held on Tuesday, 9:30 AM, at St. Catherine's and George Greek Orthodox Church in Astoria, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. Catherine's and George Greek Orthodox Church, 30-11 30th Drive, Astoria, NY 11103; or the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation, 3 Forest St., New Canaan, CT 06840.

title: Jennifer Schantz, Andrew Gould
description: Jennifer Ellen Schantz, a daughter of Nancy and Robert Schantz of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., is to be married this evening to Andrew Stephen Gould, the son of Jane Gould of New York and Dr. Franklin Gould of Lyme, N.H. Rabbi Matthew D. Gewirtz will officiate at the Hammond Museum in North Salem, N.Y.

title: May 19-25: NATIONAL; IT TOOK 38 YEARS
description: The last living defendant in the 1963 bombing of a Birmingham church was convicted of killing four girls: Addie Mae, Denise McNair, Cynthia Wesley and Carole Robertson. All were black, none was older than 14. Bobby Frank Cherry, a 71-year-old former Klansman, received an automatic life sentence for each victim. The conviction brought to a close one of the most notorious episodes of the civil rights era.

title: Am I My Brother's Keeper?
description: I think that when the dust settles on this overdue national examination of child sex abuse by priests, we will all be better able to see the courage of those who have come forward.

title: All Fronts; After Months of War, Long Fights Still to Wage
description: AFTER the attacks of Sept. 11, President Bush declared war on terrorism. In the immediate aftermath of the destruction of the twin towers, the concept seemed starkly simple: send out the Marines, rally the world, warn the slackers and fellow-travelers that America is really angry and crush the evildoers.

title: Victoria Meistrell, Christian Pouncey
description: Victoria Ann Meistrell, the daughter of Janet B. Meistrell of Charlottesville, Va., and Dr. Malcolm E. Meistrell Jr. of New York, was married yesterday to Christian Lintilhac Pouncey, the son of Bethanne Pouncey of Palm Beach, Fla., and Dr. Peter R. Pouncey of New York. The Rev. Vincent Raj, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Ventana Inn in Big Sur, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARAN, HARRIET
description: MARAN-Harriet. Peacefully, on May 25, 2002. Beloved wife of the late George E. Devoted companion of the late Capt. Jerome Levy. Loving mother of Barbara Joan. Dear grandmother of James, Andrew and Jill Goldberg. Graveside service Sunday, June 2, 2002, 11:15 AM, at New Mt. Carmel Cemetery, Glendale, NY.

title: Corrections
description: The Strategies column last Sunday, about a new rating system from Morningstar Inc. for mutual funds, misstated the weighting it gives to three-year performance figures in rating funds that are at least 10 years old. It is 53 percent, not 71 percent.

title: Lydia Fan, Calvin Wong
description: Lydia Lucy Fan, a daughter of Dr. Lucy L. Fan and Dr. Mark J. Fan of Franklin, Tenn., was married yesterday to Calvin Glenn Wong, a son of Anna L. Wong and James Y. Wong of Tucson, Ariz. The Rev. Dr. Andrew Y. Lee, a Southern Baptist minister, officiated at the Puck Building in New York.

title: Fences Make Good Gardens but Angry Neighbors
description: The Queens Botanical Garden is what its director, Susan Lacerte, calls a living museum of plants, trees and flowers. That is why she has recently stepped up enforcement of the garden's ban on bike-riding, dog-walking, ball-playing and picnicking.

title: Displaying Dexterity, Diffusing Warmth
description: Alexander Fiterstein, a clarinetist with a warm tone and a powerful technique, was a winner of the Young Concert Artists auditions last year and was presented by the organization in his New York debut recital on Tuesday evening at the 92nd Street Y.

title: Why I Won't Turn Off The Air-Conditioning
description: ''Turn Off the Air-Conditioning'' [May 19] is on the money concerning Long Islanders' over-the-top overconsumption. But appealing suggestions that Long Islanders emulate the summer lifestyle of Greeks and Italians by turning off the air-conditioning neglects our significant difference in climate. In Italy and Greece, the heat is dry. Here on Long Island, the high humidity makes hot weather oppressive.

title: Walking the Walk, Inventively
description: If all your sandals look alike, give or take a grommet or two, it may be time to seek professional help. This summer, sandal lovers can design their own footwear. At Arturo's Shoe Repair Shop in Beverly Hills, Calif., (310-278-9585), old Dr. Scholl's shoes can be spruced up with new straps made from vintage handbags by the likes of Louis Vuitton and Gucci ($75 if the material comes from the customer's handbag, $125 if the shop supplies it). Jack Rogers fans who crave a bespoke variation can choose Stephen Bonnano's Palm Beach sandal, made to order in myriad color combinations, with or without monogram ($110 at C. Orrico in Palm Beach, Fla., 561-659-7820).

title: Theater Listings
description: Approximate running times are given at end of Broadway and Off Broadway listings.

title: Executive Life; Redesigning the Management Psyche
description: IN 1999, John Bearden sold his real-estate franchising business, Coldwell Banker Affiliates of Canada, in Toronto, moved back to his home town, Nashville, and decided to gain some perspective on how to have ''a relevant rest of my life and career.''

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: The Pet Shop Boys; Not an 80's Act (Really)
description: THE show was a smashing success, a near sellout. Friends were popping in, and a second bottle of Mot had been uncorked. But backstage at the Hammerstein Ballroom last Tuesday evening, Neil Tennant and Chris Lowe -- the English duo known as the Pet Shop Boys -- were not planning a late one.

title: Wells Was Wilder Than His Pitches
description: David Wells burst off the mound as if he were heading for last call at the $9.99 buffet yesterday, waving his hands and shouting profanities. He could have been pushing his way to the front of the carving station. Wells had thrown only eight pitches against the Boston Red Sox, but as he lumbered toward Umpire Jim Reynolds and groused, it seemed he was one expletive away from never throwing his ninth.

title: Breifing: Courts; DRUG COMPANY SETTLEMENT
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation agreed last week to pay the federal goverment $500 million because of failure to fix manufacturing problems at its plants in Kenilworth and Union, and at two plants in Puerto Rico. The Food and Drug Administration said the company must also submit a plan to United State District Court in Newark to improve manufacturing practices. Edwin Lake

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: EMPIRE FALLS, by Richard Russo. (Vintage Contemporaries, $14.95.) A writer whose fiction is grounded in the aches and dreams of bumptious, blue-collar New Englanders sets his new novel (which won a Pulitzer Prize) in a dying mill town in Maine, where a large cast of finely observed characters -- chief among them the likable, if unfulfilled, manager of the Empire Grill -- play out their lives with as much grace and gusto as they can muster. ''Russo is brave enough to conceive a large ambition but too smart to overreach,'' A. O. Scott wrote in the Book Review last year. ''His humane sympathy for weakness and self-deception . . . does not rule out stern satiric judgment.''

title: Carrying Their Weight
description: L. L. Bean's new L. L. Bear and Friends day pack is the perfect camp carryall for smaller children who teeter under a traditional-size child's backpack -- and for parents who cringe at Scooby Doo-shape accessories. Designed for 3- to 7-year-olds, the 14.5-by-11-inch bags ($19.50 at www.llbean.com) come in high-visibility brights; each is embroidered with a tiny raccoon, bear or moose.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Houdini's Sunday Dip

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICHOLS, ROBERT E. JR. ''CHIP.''
description: NICHOLS-Robert E. Jr. ''Chip.'' On Friday night, May 17th, 2002. He was an artist. His love of painting was second only to his love of those around him. Generous in giving of himself, he made a difference in many lives. Unique in his vision he challenged mediocrity. His vitality was contagious. Chip was Chip. He was real. One of a kind. A masterpiece. He is missed, though his spirit shines in the hearts of those who remain. His life companion Linda. His two sons Jordan and Kristin. His brother Arthur. His two sisters Dawn and Jerilee. And his favorite cat, Jimmy.

title: Connecticut Is on Road Again, and Again
description: FOR years driving to work for Timothy Desmond meant negotiating the quiet streets of New London as he traveled from the city's southern end to Education Works, his school supply store, in the downtown area.

title: Jennifer Sudul, Gavin Edwards
description: Jennifer Alexandra Sudul and Gavin Edwards are to be married today at the Chateau Sonesta Hotel in New Orleans. Robert Rossney, a Universal Life Church minister and a friend of the couple, is to officiate.

title: Recruiters and Consulting
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dog's Life
description: To the Editor: While living on the Island of St. Maarten eight years ago, my husband and I fell in love with an island dog. We had become accustomed to seeing the flea-bitten, malnourished dogs that populated the island, and would on occasion feed them and try to get the really sick ones to the local veterinarian. We had a rule though: no dog came home with us.

title: Faced With Success, Mets Fall Apart at the Seams
description: If the Mets were a shirt, they would be polyester, shiny and gleaming and ugly, division leaders who look like first-place fakes right now.

title: Am I My Brother's Keeper?
description: Frank Bruni's article (May 12) about David Clohessy's struggles with the Catholic Church, both as a kid and an adult, left me with a knot in my stomach. As in most cases, the coverup is on a par with the crime. But Bruni should not have been talking to the mother of a 61-year-old priest about the priest's alleged sex crimes. This is a tale of crimes and insensitivity, and your writer should be careful not to duplicate part of the story to get the story.

title: The Trials of Job Hunting Beyond a Certain Size
description: When 390-pound Robert Diaz goes on a job interview, he goes to almost desperate lengths to appear smaller.

title: How Banks Chased a Mirage
description: PIERRE OLIVIER SARKOZY was one of a hundred bankers at Credit Suisse First Boston, a division of Credit Suisse, the Swiss bank, who had been guaranteed a one-time bonus of $4 million, plus a salary of at least $3.5 million for two years. Credit Suisse had hoped that the money would keep top bankers like Mr. Sarkozy from leaving after its purchase of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, an investment bank, for $13.5 billion in November 2000.

title: New Significance for a Day of Mourning
description: EACH year the National Memorial Day concert in Washington is a poignant blend of music, dramatic readings and grainy black-and-white film of wars fought long ago and far away. Tonight's concert will also recall a day of infamy fresh in memory: Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITKIN, RADOVIC, DR. MILDRED HOPE FISHER
description: WITKIN-RADOVIC-Dr. Mildred Hope Fisher. On May 18, 2002. Internationally known pioneer sex therapist, author and professor. Assistant Clinical Professor of Psychology in Psychiatry at the Cornell-New York Hospital Medical Center, she was the Associate Director of the Human Sexuality Training Program and Faculty in the Family Therapy Program. Dr. Witkin also maintained a private practice in psychotherapy specializing in individual psychotherapy, marital therapy and sex therapy. Her books include ''45 and Single Again.'' Dr. Witkin is listed in ''Who's Who in the World,'' ''American Women'' and ''2000 Women of Achievement.'' Dr. Witkin was an internationally known lecturer. A resident of New York City and Westport, CT, she is survived by her husband Dr. George Radovic, her daughter Dr. Georgia Hope Witkin, Fox News Channel host, her son Dr. Roy Witkin, D.D.S., and daughter-in-law Luarie, of Westport, CT, her grandchildren: Kimberly Hope Pauley, Esq., Joshua, Scott, Jennifer and Nicole Witkin and her great-grandson Jacob. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Mt. Sinai Hospital Stress Program, c/o Pauley, 301 East 69 Street, New York, NY 10021.

title: Music; Wagner Still In the Wings
description: Christoph von Dohnanyi has accomplished much in his 20 years with the Cleveland Orchestra, perhaps even improving on the lofty standards that had been more or less maintained since George Szell's death in 1970. Yet he leaves with a reminder of unfinished business.

title: Seles Downs Rubin In Madrid Final
description: Monica Seles routed Chanda Rubin, 6-4, 6-2, yesterday in Spain to claim her 53rd career singles title at the Madrid Open.

title: A Priest's Moral Crisis, Underexamined
description: MORE than 10 years ago, the playwright Joe Pintauro was talking about his new ''startling and controversial'' unfinished play, ''The Dead Boy,'' saying it was about a sex scandal involving a priest and a boy. In its evolving state, the play had staged readings at London's Royal Court, with Ian McKellen among the actors, and in New York, with Calista Flockhart participating before an all-male cast was decreed.

title: May 19-25: INTERNATIONAL; TOUGH ON CUBA
description: President Bush refused to lift a 40-year-old trade embargo against Cuba unless Fidel Castro undertakes democratic and economic reforms. In Miami, in front of thousands of wildly cheering Cuban-Americans -- voters critical to the president's reelection -- Mr. Bush also called Mr. Castro a brutal dictator who had done nothing for the Cuban people. Even so, Mr. Bush and former President Jimmy Carter, who urged easing the embargo during his recent visit to Cuba, met quietly at the White House. There was no other word from the White House on the tenor of the talk. Elisabeth Bumiller

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARKS, RUTH
description: MARKS-Ruth. Happy Birthday, Mom. Her song has ended, but the melody lingers on. Love youJoyce, Jason, Greg, Jordana

title: Monaco Grand Prix Has All the Plot Lines
description: MONACO, May 25 — One of the most popular, expensive and dangerous pieces of theater begins its 60th annual engagement on its most glamorous stage this weekend in front of an audience that has been pushed into an anticipatory froth.

title: Ivanchuk Is Impressive As He Topples Kasparov
description: One of the most intriguing players in the Eurotel Trophy Knockout Tournament in Prague was Vasily Ivanchuk of Ukraine. Long listed among the world's best, he has disappointed himself and the chess world by staying near the bottom of the 10 best players.

title: The End of The Affair
description: The idea behind the show was role reversal. Kicking back in a semicircle on a sound stage around a stand-up comic turned social critic, minor celebrities played political journalists and minor political journalists played celebrities. The program was called ''Politically Incorrect'' to warn people that it would often offend them and to urge them to lighten up and play along. And for several seasons people did, though never in numbers large enough to raise the show to the ranks of Leno's and Letterman's straight comedy. Then one night last autumn, the banter died. Bill Maher, the host, who despite his vow of fearlessness had yet to scare off a major corporate sponsor or incite a boycott of anything, finally said something worthy of the show's title and sent his more sensitive advertisers scurrying. He called the American military ''cowardly'' for fighting its wars with remote-control cruise missiles and implied that the terrorists of Sept. 11 were comparative bravehearts for dying in their attacks.

title: Breifing: Transportation; SCHOOL BUS FAILURES
description: The state Department of Transportation last week reported that during the current school year, routine inspections of school buses found violations serious enough to force 40 percent of the buses off the road for repairs. An additional 30 percent of the 20,300 buses were in violation for paperwork or less serious infractions. Karen DeMasters

title: DataBank; Anxiety, On and Off the Trading Floor
description: The stock market started last week amid worry about possible terrorist threats and was not able to recover.

title: Wyoming's Plate
description: To the Editor:

title: Art/Architecture; Weavers of Genius, Long Peru's Secret
description: THE motifs have all been seen before: thin and fat stripes, radiating diamonds and sticklike figures, some with two heads. But none are quite so compelling as those in ''Hidden Threads of Peru: Q'ero Textiles,'' a dazzling exhibition of 39 color-splashed shawls, ponchos, wrapping cloths, hats and festival bags on view here at the Textile Museum.

title: Susan McMichaels, Robert Sacher
description: Susan Washburne McMichaels and Robert Paul Sacher were married yesterday at Grace Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. David M. Rider performed the ceremony.

title: Letters
description: The Israeli commandos featured in Scott Anderson's cover article drew many letters praising their restraint. A report in our medical issue on the personal -- but pricey -- attention promised by boutique medicine prompted readers to blame H.M.O.'s, not doctors, for what most called a bad idea.

description: Art

title: Andersen Jury Allowed to Consider Past Audit Transgressions
description: Lawyers sparred today over whether jurors hearing the criminal case against Arthur Andersen should be told that some of the firm's employees have refused to testify. The judge gave prosecutors a victory, however, when she agreed to tell the jurors to take Andersen's earlier transgressions into account.

description: THE COUNT AND

title: BENEFITS
description: Evening at the Zoo

title: Kristin Schaefer, Michael Schiumo
description: Dr. Kristin Danelle Schaefer, the daughter of Dr. Maryann B. Schaefer Indinemao and the stepdaughter of Joseph F. Indinemao of Manhasset, N.Y., is to be married today to Michael Joseph Kain Schiumo, a son of Patricia R. Schiumo of South Beach, Staten Island, and the late Louis J. Schiumo. The Rev. Christina Maria Bladh, a nondenominational minister, is to perform the ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: Destined For Oysters
description: Lucien Crochet's 2000 Le Chne is a model white Sancerre: flinty, zesty, herbaceous, appley. This sauvignon blanc's mission is to be sipped, moderately chilled, with oysters (hold the lemon) and a buttered baguette. The $20 charged at Chambers Street Wines, the city's top Loire specialist, 160 Chambers Street (West Broadway), Manhattan, buys nuances and finesse found in $50 Burgundies. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: After Annapolis, Sailing Comes Naturally to Aho
description: When he first arrived at the Naval Academy from his hometown of Gardiner, Mass., four years ago, the midshipman Rob Aho was in the same figurative boat when it came to sailing as majority of his classmates. He barely knew a thing about it.

title: Your Home; How to Keep Gutters Free Of Debris
description: FOR some homeowners, the long-awaited recent heavy rainstorms may have provided notice that their gutters were filled with unwelcome materials or were precariously attached and that it was time to investigate the options for repair or replacement. And, as is the case in trying to tackle almost any seemingly straightforward project, they may have been reminded of the first rule of home improvement: nothing is as simple as it first seems.

title: What Your Child Isn't Telling You About S-E-X
description: AS a gynecologist for more than 20 years, Dr. Hilda Hutcherson has seen just about everything. So it hasn't surprised her in the least to have younger and younger girls come into her office at the New York Center for Women's Sexual Health at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center to ask for birth control advice.

title: Dining Out; A Manhasset Standby Gets a Makeover
description: STRESA is coming on strong. The nearly decade-old Manhasset restaurant, not to be outdone by the family's newest arrival, Stresa East in Woodbury, has had a major makeover and emerged more sleek and sophisticated than ever.

title: All Fronts; Getting More Than One Step Ahead of an Attack
description: FORGET, for the moment, what we knew and when we knew it. Assume that we knew it all -- and even, by some miracle, had kept hijackers with boxcutters from turning airliners into missiles. Where would the United States be now in the fight against global terrorism?

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.

title: The Nets Dig a Big Hole for the Celtics, and Then Fall In
description: Stunned, sickened and spent, the Nets staggered off the court, paralyzed by their epic unraveling.

title: Urgent Plea Made for Data On Lost Girl, Papers Show
description: A lawyer representing the Florida Department of Children and Families made an urgent plea last August for information about Rilya Wilson, a Miami girl under state protection who had vanished seven months earlier, child-welfare records show. Even with the plea, however, the girl's absence went unnoticed by the state for eight more months.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for JOHN S. KAVULICH II; Room for Whom on Cuba's Ground Floor?
description: THERE were cheers in Havana when former President Jimmy Carter said the American trade embargo should be lifted before Fidel Castro's government makes democratic reforms. A few days later, there were cheers in Miami when President Bush vowed to keep the embargo unless Mr. Castro first makes democratic reforms.

title: How to Avoid A Slow Burn
description: News from the sun-protection front: Those who like to put on a T-shirt in lieu of slathering on sunscreen may not be keeping themselves fully covered. It's a question of sun-protection factor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATTRIDE, ROY RONALD BUXTON, JR.
description: ATTRIDE-Roy Ronald Buxton, Jr., 59, died peacefully but unexpectedly on May 16, 2002. He was born in New York City on November 24, 1942 to parents Roy Ronald Buxton Attride, Sr. and Anne Earle Attride of Cold Spring Harbor, NY. Mr. Attride is survived by his family and loved ones. A memorial service to celebrate the life of Mr. Attride will be held in Raleigh, NC on June 22, 2002.

title: Subway Card Meant for Tourists Is Bargain for Locals
description: When they were introduced in the subway system three years ago, Fun Passes -- which cost $4 and offered a whole day of unlimited rides -- were only slightly easier to find around the city than a cheap rent-stabilized apartment.

title: Brave New World: My ID, Your ID
description: To the Editor:

title: Gimme a Head With Hair, Again
description: FROM his home in Cincinnati, Bootsy Collins was trying to explain about the funk the other day. The taxonomy of the funk, he said, was life-sustaining, almost like natural law. But these days, alas, the young do not know. ''It's like when I say, ''Glory be, da funk's on me,' '' he said. ''A lot of people don't know what the heck I'm talking about.'' Mr. Collins was happy for the opportunity to translate. What it means, he said, is, well: ''Glory . . . be . . . da funk's . . . on . . . me. It kind of says exactly what I'm feeling.''

title: . . . And That's the News From Rockaway Point
description: Here's a test. Which of these headlines appeared in The Rockaway Point News during the 15-year tenure of Don and Margaret Ryan as publishers, and which appeared in the latest issue put out by Noreen and Michael Schramm, who bought the paper from the Ryans in January?

title: Alice Chen, Joshua Plotkin
description: Alice Siau-In Chen, a daughter of Dr. Lin-Lin Chen and Dr. Ching-Jygh Chen of Jackson, Miss., is to be married today to Joshua Benjamin Plotkin, a son of Janet Bufe Plotkin and Dr. Irving H. Plotkin of Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. F. Washington Jarvis, an Episcopal priest, will officiate at a ceremony blending elements of Judaism and Buddhism at the Harvard University chapel in Cambridge.

title: Private Sector; A Tax-Refund Check That Just Keeps Shrinking
description: Donald H. Neustadt, the chief executive of Ace Cash Express of Irving, Tex., boasted recently that his company's cash flow had been growing 31 percent a year.

title: The Substance of Style
description: Q: You've been designing clothes for more than 35 years, and your sense of style has remained consistent. Do you think most of today's styles come from past styles?

title: Keeping a Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Stamford Journal; Diner Stands Its Ground Amid the Redevelopment
description: For the last three years, a tiny diner named Curley's has stood in the way of the latest phase of a huge urban renewal project here among the corporate office towers that dominate this city's downtown business district.

title: Peering Into World of Dwarfs and Seeing It Through Their Eyes
description: IN 1997, John H. Richardson, a journalist who is more than six feet tall, got an assignment from Esquire magazine to write an article about the Little People of America convention. He admits to being ''strangely unsettled'' when he walked into the Atlanta hotel where a thousand dwarfs of all sizes -- from three feet tall to the official dwarf cut-off of 4 feet 10 inches -- were gathered for a week of bonding, socializing, romance and support. He also wasn't sure if his tall stature and a tape recorder were going to inspire the dwarfs to open up and tell their life stories.

title: Talking the Talk His Own Way, by Golly
description: Ask Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld about hunting for Osama bin Laden, and the subject invariably turns to poultry.

title: The Magic Fling
description: THE SERIOUS GAME

title: Postings: Design Competition at 55 Water Street; Renovating A Public Plaza
description: One of the least public acres in New York City's empire of privately owned public space -- the elevated brick-top plaza at 55 Water Street in Lower Manhattan -- is to undergo a long overdue renovation.

title: More Than Mopery
description: To the Editor:

title: Agent's Role In Inquiries Is Questioned
description: A bipartisan group of senators has demanded that the Federal Bureau of Investigation explain why a senior agent who had access to two important strands of counterterrorism information never put the information together in a way that might have helped thwart the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Talks Collapse on $750 Million Takeover of Global Crossing
description: Two Asian companies said yesterday that they had failed to reach an agreement in talks on acquiring the troubled fiber optic network operator Global Crossing.

title: An Impossible Occupation
description: Does Anderson seriously believe that under his watchful eyes -- one of the rare times when a journalist has been allowed to accompany Israelis during their reoccupation of many West Bank cities -- soldiers would actually behave as they normally do in the latest siege? Perhaps ''Yaniv Sagee Can't Win,'' but it certainly appears that the apologists for the latest phase of Israel's war have scored an overwhelming public-relations victory.

title: Why Big Ideas Often Fall Flat
description: IN the spring of 2000, I interviewed Richard A. McGinn, then the chief executive of Lucent Technologies. Lucent had missed one quarterly earnings estimate in January, so I asked Mr. McGinn whether that was the beginning of a long-term problem or a one-time event. He assured me that Lucent was back on a positive earnings path and wowed me with all the technological marvels in Bell Labs, which Lucent owns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REEVES, CLIFFORD BATCHELDER, JR.
description: REEVES-Clifford Batchelder, Jr., of Pelham, NY, died on Thursday, May 16, 2002. He was 74. Mr. Reeves worked as Manager of Film and Tape Operations for WCBS-TV in NY. He was with the company for 43 years before retiring in 1996. Mr. Reeves was born March 7, 1928 in Yonkers, NY to Clifford and Mary Chisholm Reeves. He was educated in Pelham and graduated from Pelham High School in 1947 and Emerson College, Boston, MA, in 1951. He is survived by his sister, Barbara Winston, and brother-in-law, Lee Winston, nephew, Christopher Winston, all of Pelham, and his niece, Hilary Oskam of Pittsford, VT. Friends may send donations to Pelham Public Library, 530 Colonial Ave., Pelham, NY 10803.

title: Mary Dardis, Bruce Barket
description: Mary Katherine Therese Dardis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Dardis of New Orleans, was married yesterday to Bruce Anthony Barket, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Barket of Middletown, Conn. The Rev. Gerald Blaszczak, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Holy Name of Jesus Church in New Orleans.

title: New Travails for a Struggling California Museum
description: The long-troubled Southwest Museum, the country's largest and most important collection of Indian artifacts outside government hands, is suddenly facing new uncertainties that could accelerate a steady, if little understood, deterioration of its finances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, MARK W.H.
description: THOMPSON-Mark W.H. An international concert pianist and composer, born December 27, 1953 in NYC; died February 17 in Paris. NYC memorial held St. George's Episcopal Church. Attended the Mannes College; recipient of Marlboro Fellowship, appeared with the late Pablo Casals. Survived by parents, Professor and Mrs. R.M. Montgomery; two beloved sons: Brian Thompson and spiritually adopted French son, Joy Dormoy.

title: Jersey Footlights; The Lure of the Pines
description: The Pine Barrens of southern New Jersey, 17,000 square miles of marshy grasses, sandy soil and acidic water, was named by early settlers for its inability to sustain livestock and traditional crops. But after one visit in 1974, the Philadelphia-based artist and art teacher Roswell Weidner began a love affair with the Pine Barrens that lasted until his death in 1999. During that time Weidner created a series of richly toned pastels based on an area a mile and a half square near a campsite in the Wharton State Forest. Twenty of these pastels are on view at the Noyes Museum of Art in Oceanville through Sept. 8. ''When you hear the name Pine Barrens, you might think of Colorado's tall aspens or a Christmas tree farm,'' said Larry Schmidt, the executive director at the Noyes. ''But the type of pine that grows here defies being used in any particular way. They're bent and scrappy. It really attracted Ros Weidner to the place.'' Information: (609) 652-8848 or www.noyesmuseum.org.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the 75th anniversary of Lindbergh's trans-Atlantic flight misstated the location of a monument marking the spot where he took off. As the article pointed out, it is behind the Source Mall's parking lot, on the site of the former Roosevelt Field airfield -- not in the Roosevelt Field shopping mall, which is actually on the site of the old Curtiss Field.

title: Dr. Levine's Dilemma
description: Why criticize doctors who want to provide excellent care to a small group of patients rather than cursory care to an outrageously unmanageable ''panel size of 4,200 patient lives''? Why not put the blame instead on the managed-care bureaucracy that insists its roster doctors see 24 patients a day and then spend more time handling the overwhelming paperwork? If some physicians want to opt out of this unsatisfying situation, I say kudos to them for refusing to bow down to a dangerously demoralizing system. Let the H.M.O.'s answer for the plight of patients who can no longer afford quality care.

title: The Guide
description: Classic Cars and Boats

title: Superman Loses His Cape: Kidd Falters at End
description: The whole thing was unfathomable: a team dominates for three quarters, taking a 21-point lead into the fourth, and loses. But for that team to have Jason Kidd, the league's best playmaker, on the floor during the collapse is even harder to conceive.

title: Footlights; From One, an Anthem for Many
description: A school anthem endures for decades, if not forever, so it is understandable that Purchase College had some false starts in choosing music for its 30th anniversary. At the end, however, the job fell to a student in the Conservatory of Music, Alana Da Fonseca, who wrote both the words and the music.

title: Toughest Job in Cannes: Working the Parties
description: GIORGIO ARMANI was lounging at a table on the terrace of the Htel Martinez Tuesday afternoon with an entourage that functioned as a sort of tanned and beautiful barrier separating him from the masses. A woman nearby, wearing a crisp denim skirt, made plans for Mr. Armani's big party that evening, whispering into her cellphone. ''Oh, darling, don't worry,'' she cooed. ''It's casual! I'm just going to wear black satin pajama pants.''

title: Private Sector; Helping the Poor, Phone by Phone
description: IN the early 1990's, when Iqbal Z. Quadir was looking for investors to back his idea for a mobile phone network in Bangladesh, he said he was turned down by an executive at a cellular telephone company in New York who told him, ''We're not the Red Cross.''

title: Anderson Leaves 'Selfish Ways' Behind
description: BOSTON -- There was a time just some three years ago when, in anticipation of an N.B.A. lockout, Kenny Anderson said that if the situation wasn't settled, the financial strain could be ruinous. Why, he might have to sell one of the eight cars he owned - and he wasn't talking about being the proprietor of a used-car lot.

title: The Cosmetician
description: Jo Malone -- has no use for bells and whistles. ''I hate fussiness,'' she said. Ms. Malone, a former British beautician, created the cultish fragrances and stores that carry her name. ''I like things to be clean-cut and versatile,'' she added.

title: Theater; Not So Good: Goodspeed Revives A Revival
description: IN size and in theory, Goodspeed is just the right theater for ''Dames at Sea,'' but is ''Dames at Sea'' the right show for Goodspeed?

title: Seeking Trade, Africans Find Western Barriers
description: This country's exports of automobile parts to the United States tripled last year. Uganda's government is making a big push to sell more coffee abroad. In Ghana, Awurabena Okrah is finding more American buyers for her small apparel company's traditional African clothing.

title: All Fronts; Seeing Strength, Too, In an Open Society
description: THE F.B.I. Director, Robert S. Mueller III, had a stark assessment last week of the likelihood of Palestinian-style suicide bombings on American soil: ''Inevitable.''

title: Angels, Amid the Aridity of Office Life
description: TAKE a glance over at the person in the next cubicle. The one you see every day or have lunch with once a month, or maybe share a cab with in rainy weather. Do you like her? Really like her?

title: Suddenly, Pitching Has Come Back Into Style
description: Who are those guys and why are they doing what they're doing?

title: Discovering Beauty in Precise Colorations
description: In 1992, Gerald Ranck, the harpsichordist, set out to perform all of Domenico Scarlatti's 555 Sonatas (using the Ralph Kirpatrick numbering), a project he expected would required 25 or 26 programs over three seasons. There has been a hiatus or two, but this year Mr. Ranck took up his project again, and last Thursday evening he presented the 14th program, which began with the Sonata in B flat (K. 331) and continued sequentially through the Kirkpatrick catalogue to the Sonata in F (K. 355), 25 works in all.

title: L.I. @ Work; BOLI Award Winner
description: Welch Nehlen Groome Advertising of Garden City has won the Campaign of the Year award in the Long Island Advertising Club's Best of Long Island competition. The agency was cited for its ''Setting New Standards in Healthcare'' ads for the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System.

title: Footlights; A Visual Feast and More
description: The Children's Learning Center at the Katonah Museum of Art is about eye fun: visual games, art activities, books and art exhibitions for children from 3 to 12.

title: Katharine Smith, Eric Knuppel
description: Katharine Southworth Smith, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. K. Smith Jr. of St. Louis, was married yesterday to Robert Eric Knuppel, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert A. Knuppel of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Michael Blewett, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Michael and St. George in St. Louis.

title: Obscured License Plates Show Enforcement Failures
description: A May 12 letter refers to a problem that I've also noticed on the Belt Parkway: vehicles that are obviously commercial, but with the proper license plate designation obscured. Enforcement is the crux of the problem. This is also true for those who continue to flout the prohibition on cellphone use while driving.

title: No Looking Back For Americans
description: Having finished last among 32 teams at the 1998 World Cup in France, the United States can take encouragement from this simple fact: It can only get better in 2002.

title: Arizona Town Divided on Road's Future
description: With four million tourists annually driving through to gaze at the towering red rocks that surround this town of 10,000, it is clear that the two-lane highway they all use is not sufficient to meet everyone's needs.

title: A Birthday Party in a Trailer Park Is Completely Different in Aspen
description: WHILE Aspen is known for its excesses, it is still a place where many people appreciate understatement, even frugality; where athletic feats are more prized than enormous fur coats; where one's cholesterol level is considered a more telling detail than one's income; where the rich and famous invite their ski instructors, yoga teachers and favorite bartenders to dinner parties, and vice versa.

title: Slug it 'Tout'
description: Headline writers -- at their best, the language's poets of the succinct -- sometimes give in to the urge to accentuate a minor sense of a temptingly short word. In response to the television news producers' ''If it bleeds, it leads,'' some writers of our headlines are in danger of adopting its counterpart: If it fits, it hits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPENCER, HELEN W.
description: SPENCER-Helen W. Of Darien, CT, on May 24, 2002. Wife of Henry Spencer. Mother of Samuel Spencer, Russell Champa and Anne Martin. Sister of Nathan M. Walter and Lisa Homrig. Grandmother of two. Memorial service will be held Wednesday, May 29, 2002, at 11:30 AM at St. Luke's Episcopal Chapel, Darien, CT 06820. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Rosenthal Hospice Residence, c/o VNA Hospice Care, 1029 East Main Street, Stamford, CT 06902. For information, contact the Edward Lawrence Funeral Home, Darien, CT.

title: Romance, in Cosmo's World, Is Translated in Many Ways
description: Forty magazine editors came from all over the world to a conference room in the TriBeCa Grand Hotel in Lower Manhattan last week searching for thoroughly American alchemy. They sat quietly, even reverently, waiting for that one white-hot piece of the puzzle that would put their magazine over the top. Before them stood Kate White, the editor in chief of the American version of Cosmopolitan. In their world, she is a demigoddess, the editor of a mothership with a circulation of 2.76 million.

title: A La Carte; Small Operation Yields Thai Treasures
description: SIX years ago life was not easy for Chang and Jan Thongsanga. They came to this country from Southeast Asia, worked in Chinatown and lived well out on Long Island. That changed eight months ago when they opened the Hongpanchang Thai Restaurant at 59 Montauk Highway in Blue Point (631-363-0507), an 18-seat storefront with a staff of three.

title: Prosecutors Hope New Study of Handwriting Analysis Will Silence Skeptics
description: Handwriting analysis was the first investigative discipline developed specifically to help courts resolve disputes, and for most of the last century judges accepted it uncritically in cases involving contested documents like wills, ransom notes and forged checks. In the last decade, though, prompted by a United States Supreme Court decision on ''junk science,'' federal courts have grown increasingly skeptical.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAUNDERS, DERO AMES
description: SAUNDERS-Dero Ames. 88. On May 22, 2002. Veteran financial writer who also edited works by Edward Gibbon and Theodor Mommsen. Born in Starkville, MS; B.A. Dartmouth, 1935; M.A. Columbia, 1937. During WWII he served in the State Department and afterwards joined Fortune. He moved to Forbes in 1960, serving as Executive Editor and in other capacities until 1998. Forbes Editor Emeritus James Michaels said, ''When we were stumped for an historical anecdote or an appropriate quote to make a story come alive, Dero came through. More than anyone I've known, he could put a business story into broad perspective.'' Many young reporters he hired and nurtured over lunches at The Players Club rose to prominence. He also served as Chairman of Dartmouth Magazine's Editorial Board and the college's Alumni Council. He was proudest of the Portable Gibbon, a 1951 edition of The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire, in print for 40 years. Preceded in death by his son Dr. David N. Saunders, he is survived by his wife Beatrice Nair Saunders; his son Dr. Richard A. Saunders; two daughters-in-law, four grandchildren, and one greatgrandchild. Memorials to the Bishop Gadsden Fund, 1 Gadsden Way, Charleston, SC 29412.

title: Alice Wei, Brent Williams
description: Dr. Alice Wei and Dr. Brent Allan Williams are to be married today by the Rev. James Covington, a Unitarian Universalist minister. The nondenominational ceremony, which is to incorporate a Chinese tea ceremony, will be held at the Brooklyn Loft, a photo studio in Brooklyn.

title: Personal Business; Visits Cost Parted Couples a Tax Break
description: UNDER a federal tax court ruling, older couples who stay married but live apart can face higher taxes if one spouse pays an extended visit to the other.

title: Watching Soccer: In Focus for 90 Minutes
description: The best way to watch soccer is up close and in person, because then you can see the overall flow and sudden shifts of fortune that produce goals. But watching on television, which is how 99.99 percent of the world's fans will see the World Cup, can also be exciting and informative, particularly if the camera crew knows anything about soccer. (The games seen in the United States will come from international soccer crews, a good sign, because they will avoid the American fascination with crowds, coaches and human-interest features smack in the middle of a game.)

title: Separating Analysis From Investment Banking
description: To the Editor:

title: All Fronts: Nuclear Poker; At the Brink in Kashmir
description: TO the knotty complications that have helped make the India-Pakistan face-off over Kashmir the world's scariest crisis, the United States' war on terror has become yet one more devilish twist.

title: But the Ceremony Will Be Just as Long
description: Can't make it to your grandson's college graduation? Depending on the school he attends, you may be able to watch him receive his diploma on the Internet.

title: A Little More Money for Farmers Who Put Milk on the Table
description: MAVIS COLLINS, an Enfield dairy farmer, has been in love with cows and the farming life for most of her 55 years. But lately, running the Powder Hill Farm, an average-size Connecticut farm with 85 cows on 240 acres, has been a bittersweet money-losing experience.

title: Footlights; Sculptures Here and There
description: Susan Manspeizer's striking, color-saturated sculptures seem to be everywhere this spring.

title: About a Boy Who Isn't
description: Standing in a circle under the shade of a tall, skinny palm tree, five boys smile in unison as they recount a particularly absurd scene in the teenage comedy ''Don't Be a Menace to South Central While Drinking Your Juice in the Hood.'' The boys -- who have watched it countless times on video -- agree that it's a comedy classic, but they can't seem to settle on its funniest scene. ''Man, the whole movie is dope,'' says the tallest of the five, who wears a heavy Starter jacket even though it's 70 degrees outside.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; In Spring, Montclair's Talk Turns to Housing Prices
description: MAY is the finest month in Montclair, or so they say in this town of 39,000 about 12 miles west of Manhattan. The Presby Memorial Iris Garden unfurls its floral rainbow on a hill, signaling the start of a season of jazz concerts, downtown dances, block parties, school talent shows, craft fairs, sidewalk sales, ball games and tennis matches.

title: May 19-25: HEALTH; XXL NEWS
description: Dieters who complain that their bodies seem to fight weight loss may be right. A study in the New England Journal of Medicine found that people who lose weight make more of a hormone, ghrelin, that causes hunger, slows metabolism and reduces the body's ability to burn fat. If a drug that blocked ghrelin could be made, it might help people lose weight, researchers said. And drugs that mimic ghrelin might help those who need to gain. Denise Grady

title: Jennifer Yoder, Thomas Prescott
description: Jennifer Jan Yoder, the daughter of Lora and Kenneth Yoder of Hicksville, Ohio, was married yesterday to Thomas Shade Prescott, the son of Augusta and T. Gene Prescott of New York. The Rev. Donna Schaper, United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the Coral Gables Congregational Church in Coral Gables, Fla.

title: An Impossible Occupation
description: Scott Anderson's fascinating article (May 12) succeeds in presenting the conflict in the Middle East in a way few other articles have. His time spent with the soldiers of the Israel Defense Forces allows us to see some of the real challenges and paradoxes of this conflict. The soldiers in this intimate portrait, while not eager for war, operate with professionalism, caution and a strong awareness of the limits of military force.

title: May 19-25: HEALTH; THE SURGICAL OPTION
description: Women at high risk for inherited breast and ovarian cancer can sharply reduce the chances of developing either disease by having surgery to remove their ovaries and fallopian tubes. Two studies found that the surgery can detect early cancers in the ovaries and prevent future breast and ovarian cancers among women who inherit the genetic mutations, BRAC1 and BRAC2. Lawrence K. Altman

title: War Toons: Daffy on the Home Front and the Hare Over There
description: Before he coaxed children to read, he taught men to march. Before he became famous as Dr. Seuss, Theodor Geisel put his words in the mouth of Private Snafu, a well-intentioned soldier who made very poor decisions in more than two dozen training films created to teach United States military troops what not to do.

title: A Line in the Water
description: EACH day, thousands of cargo ships and tankers from around the globe glide into and out of ports from Delaware Bay to Napatree Point in Connecticut -- all with the capacity to be the vehicle of the next terrorism disaster.

title: Cracking Down On Petty Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Filling Goody Bags For the Beach-Bound
description: A new venture promises to marry manufacturers of things gourmet and high-end to consumers headed for long weekends to the Hamptons. Jane Ubell-Meyer, who lives in Chappaqua, and Debra Scott are the creators of the Hampton Buzz Bags, designer goody bags that contain sunscreen, bottled water, makeup, fragrance, reading material and other beach-friendly items to be distributed beginning Memorial Day weekend to travelers boarding the Hampton Jitney, the bus that travels from Manhattan's Upper East Side to the East End of Long Island. Companies pay a fee to be included in the bag and Ms. Ubell-Meyer and Ms. Scott pay commission to the salespeople who bring the products to them. Their plans are to alternate products each week. Jeanine Prezioso

title: Dr. Levine's Dilemma
description: As a primary-care physician, I believe that the doctor's dilemma described in Friedman's article may be even more complicated than your writer suggests. And those of us who are patients and insurance beneficiaries are implicated also.

title: Alice Wei and Brent Williams
description: Dr. Alice Wei and Dr. Brent Allan Williams are to be married today by the Rev. James Covington, a Unitarian Universalist minister. The nondenominational ceremony, which is to incorporate a Chinese tea ceremony, will be held at the Brooklyn Loft, a photo studio in Brooklyn.

title: Tucson Cottage
description: To the Editor: The ''What's Doing in Tucson'' (Jan. 13), by Judith Anderson, contained a description of the Ghost Ranch Lodge, saying ''the real deals are the eight cottages in four separate buildings.'' Intrigued, we made a reservation by telephone through an on-line company, Lodging.com.

title: Going Home After the Caps Are Thrown
description: For parents of college students, graduation often means the end of tuition bills, and the chance to remodel that now-vacant room in the house. But in this tough job market, more new graduates will be moving back in with their parents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUCK, LILLIAN S. (NEE SALTZMAN)
description: GLUCK-Lillian S. (nee Saltzman). On May 23, 2002. Beloved daughter of the late Morris and Edna Saltzman. Adored mother of Jonathan Howard, Amy Phyllis Soricelli, Robert Soricelli and Jeanette Gluck. Cherished grandmother of Elizabeth Marie Soricelli. Devoted sister of Jerome and Loretta Saltzman. Lillian Gluck lived a rewarding life surrounded by the warmth of her family and friends. Her love of music, art, literature, her devotion to her career, her strength and courage, and her dignity in the face of adversity will serve as a loving inspiration always. Her spirit will remain in our hearts forever. ''It is art that makes life, makes interest, makes importance, and I know of no substitute whatever for the force and beauty of its process.''-Henry James. Special gratitude to the doctors, nurses of 4N and staff of Calvary Hospital, Bronx, NY. Your compassion and kindness will never be forgotten. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Rd, Bronx, NY 10461; and Women in Need: www.winfoundation.org

title: Theater; Three Actors Are One Another's Other Audience
description: ONE doesn't usually think of ensemble acting in a play full of monologues, but what the three actors in Horton Foote's ''Carpetbagger's Children'' achieve is a master class in ensemble work. The secret is in the listening.

title: Holiday Weekend Begins With Sunshine, Crowds, Music and Heavy Security
description: They thronged piers to inspect warships, deadpanned for security cameras at the Statue of Liberty ferry, and moved like tides through the narrow streets of SoHo. They jammed parks, beaches and ball fields. They searched for sin in Times Square and took in the songs of the city: the madrigal of traffic, the ukuleles and steel drums rendering Beethoven, the wind in the rigging of a tall ship.

title: Young, Carefree and Hooked on Sun Lamps
description: SHE calls herself Miss Mary Sunshine. Not because she is popular teenager, which she is, or because she can make a boy's day just by saying hello, which she can, but because of the maple-syrup hue of her skin. Whether she has just been to the Caribbean on a family vacation or has spent the last couple of months cooped up in her Upper East Side apartment with SAT tutors, Miss Mary Sunshine is never without a deep, dark tan.

title: Factoring In an Oak Cask
description: The Peconic Bay Winery helpfully telegraphs the style of its 2000 chardonnay. It is called La Barrique.

title: The Right Way Of Administering Botox
description: ''The Botox Party Arrives on the Island'' [May 12] trivializes a medical treatment. As a surgeon who administers Botox injections, I can personally vouch for its effectiveness. But it is important to remember that a Botox injection is a medical procedure that must be accompanied by the care accorded to any medical procedure. I wonder whether the ''spa setting'' is conducive to producing an environment in which this procedure can be carried out safely and effectively. Is the medical history of the patient taken down and are medications to treat allergic reactions kept in stock, or are these precautions cast aside at the expense of creating a seemingly hassle-free and relaxing atmosphere?

title: Introduction
description: The Israeli commandos featured in Scott Anderson's cover article drew many letters praising their restraint. A report in our medical issue on the personal -- but pricey -- attention promised by boutique medicine prompted readers to blame H.M.O.'s, not doctors, for what most called a bad idea.

title: Breifing: Transportation; SECAUCUS DELAYS
description: New Jersey Transit officials are considering a delay in opening a Secaucus transfer station because of a surge in train passengers since the World Trade Center attacks. The $450 million transfer station, originally scheduled to open in December, may not open until 2003, according to a transit spokesman. It would allow about 16,000 passengers from Bergen and Passaic Counties to ride directly into Manhattan without a stop in Hoboken. Jeremy Pearce

title: Missing Wilde's Point
description: To the Editor:

title: Business; Bertelsmann's Quest to Harness the Napster Genie
description: THE headquarters of Napster Inc., the headline-grabbing music distribution service, are across a parking lot in Redwood City, Calif., from the office of Gerald W. Kearby, the president and chief executive of Liquid Audio, which makes software for online music distribution. ''I can look out my window and see their front door,'' he said.

title: Drills and Blowdryers Rendered as Still Lifes
description: ''The Spring Show''

title: Bronx Parish Is in Shock As Scandal Touches Home
description: The accusations were shocking -- and there was shock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEICHER, SHELDON
description: LEICHER-Sheldon, 77, on May 24, 2002. Peacefully, after a long and courageous battle. Beloved husband of Renee. Cherished father of Susan. Dear father-in-law of Tony and stepfather of Juliette, David and Audrey. Adoring grandfather of Nina and Lucy. Devoted brother of Seymour, Joan and the late Arlene. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the Eastern Paralyzed Veterans Association 718-803-3782. Rest in peace, dear Soul. We love you.

title: For All Travelers
description: To the Editor: I was pleased to see the information about an online city guide for travelers interested in African-American culture, www.souljourn.citysearch.com, in ''A Web City Guide for Black Travelers,'' (Travel Advisory, May 5). I was offended, however, by the headline, implying that only African-Americans would be interested in African-American culture.

title: Angela Pinto, Sean Wee
description: Angela Marie Pinto, the daughter of Leonilde and Jos Pinto of Sayreville, N.J., was married yesterday to Hian Hsin Sean Wee, a son of Elizabeth G. Tan of West Roxbury, Mass. The Rev. John M. O'Sullivan, of the Federation of Christian Ministries, performed the ceremony at Bretton Woods Manor in Morris Plains, N.J.

title: Music; Buffeted by Love, and Breathing Hard
description: Though the first two albums from Kevin Tihista's Red Terror were released separately, they were originally intended as a double-album. So perhaps it makes sense to look at them together.

title: Sports of The Times; Pierce Heeds the Call And Carries the Celtics
description: OF course there was no hope. Of course it was impossible. No way the Celtics were going to make a comeback and win the game. No way Paul Pierce was going to take over the game this time and destroy the opposition, as he had done on numerous occasions this season.

title: Colombia Voters Are Angry, And Rebels May Pay Price
description: Clara Elsa Galvis, a school administrator, describes herself as ''completely supportive of peace,'' and that is why four years ago she helped vote into office a presidential candidate who had pledged to negotiate with leftist rebels to end Colombia's grinding civil conflict.

title: Music; A Pianist Who Is Building The Literature for Lefties
description: FOR all the physical demands it makes on a performer, the piano can also be a forgiving instrument. A player who loses the use of the seemingly crucial right hand -- and there have been several notable cases -- can still find things to do with the left. Thanks in large part to the efforts of the Austrian pianist Paul Wittgenstein, who lost his right arm in World War I, there are several fine piano concertos with solo parts for the left hand alone.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on May 12 in Summer Movies with a listing for ''13 Conversations About One Thing'' gave an erroneous identification from the distributor for the actress shown with John Turturro. She was Barbara Sukowa, not Barbara Andres.

title: Police Ask Parents to Hover When Their Children Log On
description: SGT. ANDREW RUSSELL of the Connecticut state police said his record is two minutes. That is the shortest time it took him to be propositioned by adults when posing as a preteen in an Internet chat room. The state police coordinates investigations on Internet crimes against children with local police officers and federal agents and presents online safety programs in schools. But the sobering lesson of a Danbury sixth grader who was murdered last week after a meeting with a man she met online is that sting operations, school visits and undercover police work aren't enough.

title: Theater; City and Set: A Skyline That's Made For the Stage

title: Jersey Footlights; One and Only
description: In the 19th century, Trenton was the center of ceramics production in the United States, and the Burroughs and Mountford Co. of Trenton was known for producing high-quality pottery for hotel use from its founding in 1879 until it closed in 1901. In 1892, the firm produced what many consider one of the best ceramic pieces made in America: a three-foot refined earthenware covered vase glazed a brilliant blue and decorated in gold and silver Asian-inspired motifs made from tooled paste. These included chrysanthemums, peacocks, peonies, pomegranates and a hawk with a duck in its talons. The vase, thought to have been executed by a Japanese artist, was displayed at the World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago in 1893 and was regarded as a masterpiece. A black-and-white image appeared in a ceramics magazine that year; then the vase disappeared for over 100 years. Recently, the curator of American decorative arts at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Alice Cooney Frelinghuysen, received a call from an art dealer: The vase had turned up at an antique shop in Providence, R.I. ''I was thrilled,'' Ms. Frelinghuysen said. ''It vies with the best of European wares.'' The Met immediately acquired the vase, which is now in conservation. It will be on display in October in the Deedee Wigmore Gallery of Late 19th and Early 20th Century Art at the museum. ''There was only one vase made,'' said Ms. Frelinghuysen. ''No one dreamed it really survived.''

title: QUICK BITE/Ewing; Feeding the Troops, Bike Riders and You
description: On the eve of the the first weekend of this month, Steve and Colleen Vincent were preparing to feed 140 hungry United States marines at the West Trenton Marine Barracks. That's just one of the challenges they have pursued as owners of the combination restaurant-catering business at Kriste's Kafe in Ewing. The couple opened the restaurant seven years ago, taking over what Mr. Vincent described as a ''gutted out'' building. The marines are not the only recipients of the catering services. Office and wedding parties also are served. The office party luncheons begin at $6.25 per person. Items from a ''create your own buffet'' catering menu includes chicken Marsala, the house specialty, at $75 per pan (serving 25), with other chicken, beef, pasta dishes costing anywhere from $29.95 to $81.25. Each August, the Vincents feed participants in a Princeton 100-mile bicycle event. The principal fare for the returning pedalers: six-foot hoagies. Inside the restaurant, which seats about 60 in two rooms, diners order breakfast platters, sandwiches and house-made soups, salads and charcoal-broiled burgers, and much more. Prices range from $1.65 to $6. The most popular item, according to Mr. Vincent, is his all-white-meat chicken salad, costing $4. ''I've always wanted to own my own place,'' said Mr. Vincent, a former chef at the Hyatt Regency in Princeton. Now that he has one, in the Glen Roc Shopping Center, he's named it for his two children, Kri(sten) and Ste(ve).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEVILLE, HUBERT TURNER
description: MANDEVILLE-Hubert Turner. Known as ''T'', of New York City, previously of Fairfield, CT died peacefully in New York City on Monday, May 20th, with his family present. He was 79 years old. Mr. Mandeville was born in Utica, NY on September 11, 1922 to Ernest W. Mandeville and Ruth Turner Mandeville. He is predeceased by his wife Ann Adams Mandeville and his brothers Michael Lloyd Mandeville and Charles L. Mandeville. He is survived by his brother Ernest W. Mandeville, Jr., his sister Margaret Mandeville, his second wife Deborah L. Bowers, and his eight children, Christopher, Meredith M. Hollis, Matthew, Kempton, Jonathan, William, Morgan and Ross. He is also survived by 17 grandchildren, Erinn, Ariel, Krista, Amanda, Julia, Turner, Adelaide, Elizabeth, William, Allison, Courtney, Kempton, Henry, Estelle, Paulina, Michael and Carlos. He attended Ridley College, St. Catharine's, Ontario, from 1935 to 1940. He earned his undergraduate degree in Engineering from Yale University in 1944 and his law degree from Yale University Law School in 1947. He was a longtime member of the Yale Club of New York City. Mr. Mandeville married Ann Adams of Redding Ridge, CT in July of 1948. He was a partner with Pennie, Edmonds, Morton, Barrows and Taylor, Attorneys at Law, in New York City until January, 1961 when he established the patent law firm of Mandeville and Schweitzer with Fritz L. Schweitzer, Jr. Mr. Mandeville was on the governing boards of several educational, philanthropic and corporate organizations including Ridley College in St. Catharine's, Ontario, Westover School, St. Lawrence University, St. Barnabas College of Johannesburg, South Africa, Up With People, White Consolidated Industries and Tally Industries. Mr. Mandeville established The Mandeville Foundation, Inc., a private family foundation, in 1961, of which he was President and Treasurer from 1961 to the present. Mr. Mandeville had a great interest in providing seed support for organizations with limited opportunities for funding. He was also a supporter of many educational institutions and youth organizations including the Outward Bound School and the Andrew Glover Youth Program of New York City. Mr. Mandeville requested that there be no funeral or memorial service held on his behalf. In lieu of flowers, he would be pleased if you made a gift to a charity of your choice.

title: Ideas & Trends; The Aid Debate: Helping Hand, or Hardly Helping?
description: ''Happy to receive you, World Bank,'' sang dozens of mostly shoeless youngsters as a group of journalists and bank representatives approached a rural Ugandan school earlier this month on a trip sponsored by the World Bank. There's something jarring when local politicians, teachers and children genuflect before minor bank officials. But it's hard to blame them. Western donors wield oversize influence because they provide vital money to an H.I.V.-ravaged country where people live on a dollar a day and 40 percent of the children are stunted from malnutrition.

title: Fuel Rods and Brass Tacks; Reality Overtakes Rhetoric in Nuclear Power Debate
description: For many years, the argument over the Indian Point nuclear power plant here in New York City's northern suburbs was one of the great evergreens of Northeastern environmentalism. It could always be counted on and it never really changed. The positions on both sides, repeated by rote for decades, became a liturgy that was sure to inflame passions without much risk of anything actually happening as a result.

title: Habitats/East 57th Street; Providing a Roommate With an Urge to Decorate

title: Public Schooling for Profit
description: The for-profit education movement got under way a decade ago when ambitious entrepreneurs became convinced that they could succeed where public educators had failed and make money in the bargain. Ten years later, Edison Schools Inc., the largest for-profit company in the business, has yet to find its way into the black. After a bruising battle to get control of schools in Philadelphia, Edison is struggling financially and besieged by critics who argue that the company has overstated its academic performance. The decline in Edison's fortunes is attributable in part to questionable management and overly rapid expansion. But the broader message may be that there is no quick, profitable way to turn around schools.

title: 'The Count and the Confession'
description: What do you take to prison? Beverly Monroe had no idea. But her attorney had given her a list of some basic items she was supposed to bring—white underwear, rubber-soled shoes—and during the weekend before she was scheduled to surrender, in addition to setting aside money to pay her estimated taxes and signing papers giving her daughter Katie power of attorney, she packed. Each of her three children wanted her to have something personal of theirs to take with her. Her younger daughter, Shannon, gave her a blue thermal Patagonia she’d gotten for Christmas. Katie had Beverly take her plaid flannel L. L. Bean pajamas. Gavin, her oldest child and only son, bought her a necklace, which she wasn’t sure she would be allowed to keep.

description: By the tranquil waters of this old whaling port, foreigners trying to curb Japan's annual whale harvest got a taste this week of the Japan that can say no.

You get Katie Holmes as the obnoxious rich girl, too beatiful and arrogant for her own good; Keanu Reeves as a short-tempered redneck wife beater; and J.K. Simmons as the grouchy local sheriff, whose top priorities are coffee and eclairs. The film's center, however, is Cate Blanchett's card-reading psychic. Half the town considers her the rural Georgia equivalent of a psychotherapist; the other half thinks she's a witch. Despite that, she's asked to help with a missing persons case. Sam Raimi directed a cast that also includes Greg Kinnear, Hilary Swank and Giovanni Ribisi. Too bad about that thoroughly unchilling ghost-story ending -- Monday at 11:30 p.m. on Showtime.

title: The World's Game Is Not Just A Game

Before returning to Sudan just a step ahead of being extradited to Saudi Arabia, he bought his sons gifts from the club's souvenir shop. His affection for the game did not stop him from getting involved in a plot to massacre the American and British teams at the 1998 World Cup in France; still, bin Laden told friends he had never seen passion like that of soccer fans.

title: Art/Architecture; A Social Critic Who Makes the Ordinary a Weapon
description: SINCE the Finnish painter Tyyne Esko began making art 30 years ago, at the age of 52, she has created a body of work full of biting social commentary simply by recording aspects of everyday life in the port city of Kokkola, where she lives, some 300 miles northwest of Helsinki. Now, with her first solo show in New York, at the Luise Ross Gallery in SoHo, an audience far from Finland can examine an intriguing selection of 18 paintings that have been as controversial in their homeland as their maker has been unknown beyond it.

She had become known for her minimalist style in women's clothing; some people called her the ''queen of less.'' Her fashion house, the Jil Sander Group, a public company based in Hamburg, was selling her collections in seven of its own stores and 60 franchise stores worldwide.

description: CHARLOTTE and Jim Whitescharver were walking back to their office at Xanthus Inc., a software company on Lock Street in Newark, when Ms. Whitescharver spotted two familiar faces in a most unfamiliar context.

title: No More Animal Acts On Greenburgh Town Property
description: The town board of Greenburgh voted Wednesday evening to ban entertainment acts involving wild or exotic animals, citing ethical and safety issues raised by circuses and rodeos. A crowd of more than 100 impassioned residents and advocates attended the hearing.

title: May 19-25: NATIONAL; INTERN'S REMAINS FOUND
description: A man walking his dog in a Washington park found the skeletal remains of Chandra Levy, the 24-year-old government intern who disappeared a year ago. The police said there were few clues as to how she died; they prepared to question a man who assaulted two joggers in the same park. The case destroyed the career of Representative Gary Condit, the California Democrat linked romantically with Ms. Levy. Katharine Q. Seelye

title: Theater; Myth, Magic And Us Mortals
description: NOW that so many theater artists are revisiting the gods and mortals of ancient Greece and Rome (Phaedra, Oedipus, Apollo and Phaethon, Orpheus and Eurydice), we should revisit the Greek concept of ''playwright.''

title: May 19-25: INTERNATIONAL; THEM TWO
description: It is not quite a jam session, but Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill is on a nearly two-week tour of Africa with Bono, the lead singer of U2 and an increasingly influential advocate for doing more to alleviate poverty. ''He's the man in charge of America's wallet,'' Bono said. ''I want to open the wallet.'' They visited urban slums and a woefully underequipped rural hospital in Ghana, talked about trade with South Africa's president, Thabo Mbeki, and saw examples of where foreign aid has worked. They still have big differences over how to help. But Mr. O'Neill said he has been struck by how little money it would take to address some pressing needs, like clean water, while Bono said he has a new appreciation of the importance of business. Richard W. Stevenson

description: MOST of the young women involved agree that the frenzy all started because there were so many cute teenage boys singing and dancing in one place.

Smith and the stepson of Charles J. Smith of Upper Saddle River, N.J. The Rev. Allan Lokos, an interfaith minister and a friend of the bride, is to officiate at the Bryant Park Grill in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODDY, JOSEPH JAMES
description: RODDY-Joseph James. A former senior editor of Look magazine and staff writer at Life magazine, died on Thursday at the age of 81. A resident of Croton, NY, Mr. Roddy was born in St. Paul, MN, December 25, 1920. He attended The College of St. Thomas Aquinas. During World War II he served in the US Coast Guard. In 1948 he married Suzanne Eger and moved to New York, where he joined the staff of ''Look' magazine as a writer. In the 1960's he worked at Life magazine, returning to Look until it closed in 1970. He also wrote for the New Yorker, the New York Times Magazine and Harpers magazine. He leaves his wife, two sons, two daughters and eight grandchildren.
