description: Courtesy Counts

title: Shades With Tints
description: Whether in rimless -- rectangles or encased in aviator frames, super-pale, shimmery lenses are suddenly the definitive look in sunglasses. Surprisingly transparent or delicately tinted, the new lenses are treated with a gradient flash-mirror coating to impart a subtle sheen, rather than the heavy mirrored look of yore. At Robert Marc in New York, pale lavender, amber and coral lenses abound, although the store's biggest seller is its so-called ghost lens -- clear lenses treated with the flash-mirror coating, for an ethereal, silvery effect ($295 for all models, 212-319-2000). Christian Dior makes gray aviators ($200.95), and Ocean Drive's Gotham frame has light blue lenses ($80.95), both at For Eyes, (800) 367-3937. Michael Kors's gray-lens version is $185 at Henri Bendel's; Saks Fifth Avenue's Private Label collection includes silver frames with lavender lenses ($98). As a bonus, the glasses are unusually transparent, making them appropriate for rainy weather and nighttime, too.

title: Webbed, Wired and Worried
description: Ever since I learned that Mohamed Atta made his reservation for Sept. 11 using his laptop and the American Airlines Web site, and that several of his colleagues used Travelocity.com, I've been wondering how the entrepreneurs of Silicon Valley were looking at the 9/11 tragedy -- whether it was giving them any pause about the wired world they've been building and the assumptions they are building it upon.

title: Investing; No Stampede, Yet, to Technology
description: JONATHAN COHEN, the director of investor relations at Mercator Software, has received several calls recently from portfolio managers wanting to ''kick the tires'' of that small company, which helps other businesses integrate their computer systems.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Crestwood, N.Y.; Yonkers Area With Small-Town Feeling
description: CRESTWOOD -- a 415-acre pocket of well-kept colonial, Tudor and Victorian single-family homes in Yonkers -- is situated in the city's northeast corner, with Eastchester and Tuckahoe directly to its east and Bronxville south of them. At the center of the neighborhood, where 3,182 people live, is the Church of the Annunciation and its school, which have served generations of Crestwood residents, some of whose children return as adults to raise their families there.

title: Mendoza Comes to the Rescue To Right the Faltering Yankees

title: The Past as Prelude

President Bush and Congress should move immediately to establish an independent investigative commission with the authority, expertise and financial support necessary to determine why Washington failed to recognize that Osama bin Laden was on the hunt in America last summer.

title: Postcoital Aesthete
description: Darius Halloway, an urbane professor of French literature at a Toronto college, knows he's struck gold in Emma Carpenter, his young, unpredictable and sexually ravenous lover. She's as much trouble as she is a joy, but when she finally leaves him, he's stunned: what can matter now that Emma's gone? The Canadian writer David Gilmour's new novel, SPARROW NIGHTS (Counterpoint, $24), is a chronicle of erotic obsession after the fact, a grown-up version of Scott Spencer's ''Endless Love.'' We barely know Emma herself; she appears in flashback vignettes, potty-mouthed and inscrutable. It's Darius's rampaging mind that really interests Gilmour, who creates a professor simultaneously prim and outrageous. Without Emma, his nerves are raw, and everything starts to bother him: the incessant flapping of a German flag raised by his next-door neighbor, another's barking dogs, a noisy air conditioner in a Caribbean hotel. He lectures, chats with students and goes out to dinner (on what seems to be a remarkably lavish academic salary), but inside he's roiling with pain. It's not long before he acts on his annoyances, as well as his pent-up desire: he begins to frequent seedy massage parlors, whose employees become part of his life in ways therapeutic and -- at the book's end -- sinister. Gilmour's prose has flashes of bright metaphor, and his dialogue is alert and alive. Darius is a believable aesthete -- he's consumed with status, the impression he's making and the gnawing power of the past. Emily Gordon

title: Bird Song
description: To the Southerner, there is simply no other food that possesses the stature of fried chicken. It cuts across class lines. (When I was growing up, if we were dressed in church clothes, we'd eat it at the country club; if not, we'd stand in line at KFC and take home a bucket from the Colonel.) It cuts across regional lines (unlike say, gumbo, which is enjoyed in other states but does not retain the same exalted rank outside Louisiana, or pilau, which is relatively unheard of beyond South Carolina). It can also be the subject of intense debate. For example, should the chicken be marinated overnight in milk and seasonings before being coated with flour, or simply washed and dried and coated with seasoned flour? And what should the seasonings be? Also, what should the chicken be fried in, lard or oil? Most cooks I know have passionate, unequivocal answers to these questions. And just about everybody I know has his or her own highly personal benchmark, the standard against which all other fried chicken must be measured.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATHEWS, SIDNEY
description: MATHEWS-Sidney. Died on Tuesday, May 21st at his home on North Lake Way in Palm Beach where he lived with his wife, Phyllis, for the past 22 years. He was 90 years old. Mr. Mathews was born September 28, 1911 in Brooklyn, NY. He graduated from Salisbury School in Salisbury, Conn., and from Princeton University in 1933. He joined Commercial National Bank in New York City in 1934, which subsequently became Bankers Trust Co. He specialized in trusts and estates in the investment Advisory Division. He served in the U.S. Army as a major during World War II, stationed in India on the South East Asia Command staff, where he assisted in administering the U.S. Lend Lease program. He was awarded the Bronze Star. Following his retirement from Bankers Trust in 1974, Mr. Mathews became board chairman of the Kohler & Campbell Piano Co., in North Carolina. He moved to Palm Beach in 1979, where he headed the local office of the investment firm Roanoke Asset Management, with offices on Royal Palm Way and in New York City. Mr. Mathews was an honorary trustee of The Childrens' Aid Society in New York and Treasurer and Chairman of its investment committee. He was a member of the Bath and Tennis Club of Palm Beach. He is survived by his first wife, Dorothea Street Smith, and their three daughters-Carol Cameron of Washington, DC; Beatrice Francais and Louise Bozorth both of New York City. He is also survived by his fourth daughterSarah Albamonte of Herndon, VAfrom his second marriage to Rita White in 1956. His present wife, Phyllis Dickinson Mathews of Palm Beach, also survives. A memorial service will be held Thursday, May 30th at 11:00 AM at Bethesda-by-the-Sea Church, Palm Beach, FL. In lieu of flowers, the family asks donations be sent to Salisbury School in Salisbury, Connecticut.

title: This Old Hat

Five hundred neighbors and friends enjoyed an afternoon in a setting that seems to have changed little from the 19th century, when painters immortalized the scenic splendor of the area and affluent New Yorkers built grand country houses, many of which have been turned into museums. The guests took in the sweeping views of the river as they ate shad and drank a local pear cider. Their clothes were low-key and traditional. Some of the women called to mind the Bostonians who have their hats; they had saved their Lester Lanin giveaways from winter dances for summer shade. Skakel is on trial for murdering her daughter, Martha, and heads out back to the courthouse parking lot. Many days she stops to talk to the large encampment of reporters and television crews. Some days she leaves quietly. But when Mrs. Moxley, who turns 70 next month, climbs into her car, a champagne-colored Mercedes sedan, she gets behind the wheel. On I-95, as on the road to justice, Dorthy Moxley does the driving herself.

title: Art/Architecture; Where Miles of Murals Preach a People's Gospel
description: IN a tree-shaded building at the University of California campus here, Judith F. Baca queues slides for undergraduate students in her seminar ''Beyond the Mexican Mural.'' Ms. Baca, 56, a professor and muralist, is illustrating a lecture with examples of her own works, created over more than 30 years. Today she is focusing on ''The Great Wall of Los Angeles,'' 1976-83, choosing it from among many other projects that range from ''La Memoria de Nuestra Tierra,'' her recent commission by the Denver International Airport, to her ''World Wall'' panels that have toured the globe.

title: Contrary St. Petersburg in Limelight
description: Volodya Putin loves his hometown. But like any love, this is a complicated relationship.

title: Liberty Drops Opener As Sparks Pull Away
description: The rings came first for the Los Angeles Sparks, in a pregame ceremony, the spoils from last year's Women's National Basketball Association championship.

title: Kristin Schaefer and Michael Schiumo
description: Dr. Kristin Danelle Schaefer, the daughter of Dr. Maryann B. Schaefer Indinemao and the stepdaughter of Joseph F. Indinemao of Manhasset, N.Y., is to be married today to Michael Joseph Kain Schiumo, a son of Patricia R. Schiumo of South Beach, Staten Island, and the late Louis J. Schiumo. The Rev. Christina Maria Bladh, a nondenominational minister, is to perform the ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: Linger in Rome
description: The Cavalieri Hilton, on 15 acres near the Vatican, will add extra nights for multi-night stays through Sept. 15. Pay for three nights and get four. A five-night stay earns two more nights. And for the cost of a one-week stay, you get 10 nights. Doubles start at $348 a night, with V.A.T. and buffet breakfast, at 1.12 euros to the dollar. The 372-room hotel has an indoor and outdoor pool and a spa. Children 12 and under stay free in the same room as their parents and get a Teddy bear and rubber duck; they can also visit the hotel's Montgelana hens, which lay low-cholesterol green eggs. Rates, like the eggs, are subject to availability. Call (39-06) 35091 or visit www.cavalieri-hilton.it .

title: Shira Asekoff, Ariel Meyer
description: Dr. Shira Leah Asekoff, a daughter of Cecille J. Asekoff and Rabbi Stanley L. Asekoff of West Orange, N.J., is to be married this evening to Dr. Ariel Meyer, a son of Chaya and Steven Meyer of Leonia, N.J. The bride's father is to perform the ceremony at the Atrium Country Club in West Orange.

title: Labor's Political Voice
description: To the Editor:

title: Travel Advisory; British Airways Prefers Clicks, Not Calls
description: Most airlines would be delighted to find themselves swamped by calls from travelers wanting to make a reservation. But with the summer travel season to Europe approaching, British Airways cannot keep up with the calls.

title: Postings: A Gallery, a Foundation and a Partnership, for West 13th Street Building; Purchasing and Sharing
description: Two years ago, when a partnership of three Manhattan developers offered to buy the three-story building at 415 West 13th Street, between Ninth Avenue and Washington Street, it found that the Sperrone Westwater Gallery in SoHo also had its eyes on the building. So did the Bohen Foundation in Manhattan, which supports the arts.

title: Extramarital Bliss
description: ACCIDENTS

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Amanda Blackburn and Justin Carrier, April 5, 2002, Daytona Beach, Fla.

title: Practical Traveler; Consolidators, Online and Off
description: TEN years ago, desperate for a last-minute airline ticket from Denver to Philadelphia, I scanned the pages of the local newspaper for a deal. When I found an advertisement for ''cheap tickets anywhere,'' I called and was directed to an office building on the edge of town. An hour later I was handing a shifty-looking man $200 in cash, sure that the ticket he gave me would elicit giggles at the airport counter.

title: Passing the Torch
description: NEW YORKERS take for granted the essentials of city life: takeout, MetroCards, yellow cabs, all part of the daily thrum. For decades, New Yorkers haven't thought twice about waking up at 3 a.m. with a longing for kiwi or popcorn because they know the Korean-owned delis are there.

title: Corrections
description: A listing on May 12 in Summer Movies, Part 2 of this section, for ''Minority Report,'' scheduled to open on June 21, referred incorrectly to the plot. It depicts a future world in which with the help of seers, people are arrested before they commit murders; they are not executed.

title: East Hampton Will Dim Its Street Lights
description: ON a recent night flight to Europe, Patricia Ferrin of East Hampton looked down toward home and saw Main Street all too well.

title: Commercial Property/Westchester; Builders Are Moving to Fill Demand for Lab Space
description: IN response to a growing demand for biomedical laboratory space in Westchester County, a 30-year-old, 700,000-square-foot research park in Greenburgh and Mount Pleasant is planning to expand by as much at 570,000 square feet.

title: Music; Ironic and Detached Long Before Fashion Caught Up
description: WHAT ever happened to the Kinks? It's a question that apparently isn't asked often: unlike other darlings of the British Invasion, the Kinks don't have a boxed set retrospective or even a ''Behind the Music'' documentary to their name. And as 1960's nostalgia, they are wholly unsatisfying. In the era of flower power, the group's frontman, Ray Davies, was an ironic, world-weary sort who thumbed his nose at the record industry and made florid pop about the decline of the British Empire. In 1969, the Kinks made a concept album that was set in World War II.

title: For Aaron Williams, Tale of Many Cities
description: The professional basketball odyssey of Nets forward Aaron Williams has taken him through Italy and Greece, as well as eight cities in the United States, before he finally found a home with the Nets two seasons ago. Compared with Milan and Athens, he said, "New Jersey's not too exotic."

title: No Man Is Coney Island, but Mr. Wallace Is Close
description: George Wallace has spent half his life painting storefront awnings, menu boards, wall murals and amusement park game stalls around Coney Island. On any given day, from Palm Sunday, when Astroland Park opens for business, through Labor Day, he might be found touching up the bright block lettering on the facade of Ruby's Bar and Grill on the boardwalk, applying a coat of linseed oil to the roller coaster cars on the Cyclone or changing the prices on the menus at Nick's Greasy Spoon on Surf Avenue. Visitors to Coney Island may catch a glimpse of Wallace at work around Memorial Day weekend when the crowds first flood the beaches and the amusement park.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 12 about the comedian Bernie Mac and his television show referred incorrectly to the location of a gun shop visited by the reporter and by Mac, who collects guns. Harvey, Ill., is a suburb of Chicago, not a neighborhood of it.

title: An Impossible Occupation
description: In the midst of a national obsession with the superhero named Spider-Man, Scott Anderson has stumbled upon a most unlikely real-life hero for our times: Yaniv Sagee. Anderson writes of a mild-mannered former schoolteacher who is a member of the elite unit, Palsar Tzanhanim. But every hero has an archenemy, and the one facing Sagee and his countrymen is formidable. As Anderson asserts, there is no way to fight an enemy who plasters pictures of suicide bombers in classrooms as ''a pantheon of heroes for the 5- and 6-year-olds to look up to.'' These children are being taught to seek out heroes where they don't exist. A hero must value his own life in order to respect the life of another, super or otherwise.

title: The View From/New Fairfield; After Years of Effort, 10 Eagles Soar From One Scout Troop
description: WHEN Timothy Taylor joined the Boy Scouts several years ago, the idea of becoming an Eagle Scout seemed like a distant dream.

title: Unfinished Business
description: RALPH ELLISON

title: Spring Break, All Summer
description: MTV is back.

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: After Success Story, A Brutal Relapse

title: Katherine Park, Andrew Jacobs
description: Katherine Jin Park, the daughter of Kyu J. and Young S. Park of McLean, Va., was married last evening to Andrew Seth Jacobs, the son of Marion A. Jacobs and Chancellor Jack B. Jacobs of Wilmington, Del. Rabbi Leonard A. Schoolman performed a ceremony that combined Jewish and Korean traditions at the Greenville Country Club in Wilmington.

title: A Dog's Life
description: To the Editor: I would like to thank Hope Reeves (''A Dog's Life, Act II,'' April 14) for reminding vacationers that they can adopt great dogs from some Caribbean islands. American Airlines has been particularly helpful in getting dogs out of San Juan.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 12 about the comedian Bernie Mac and his television show referred incorrectly to the location of a gun shop visited by the reporter and by Mac, who collects guns. Harvey, Ill., is a suburb of Chicago, not a neighborhood of it.

title: A High-Strung Roddick Is Harnessing His Talent
description: In a meticulously kept Florida home, where the white carpet met the white furniture in a color scheme fit for angels and art dealers, a nervous real-estate agent surveyed the teenage client in front of him.

title: Facing A Tough Audience
description: MERCEDES EDWARDS, 14, holds a stuffed bear to her heart and calls it baby. It better be good or she'll beat it, she says. She coos at it, then suddenly starts beating her baby against the floor. She says she learned how to beat her baby from the way her mom beat her.

title: The City As Movie Star
description: A record number of independent films and videos were submitted to ''Reel New York,'' an eight-week showcase, and 40 short and full-length works by, about and for New Yorkers (below, Sara Varon's animated short, ''The Tongue'') will be shown starting June 7 at 10 p.m. on Channel 13.

title: Sarah Dodds, Henry Brown
description: Sarah Caroline Arrington Dodds, the daughter of Barbara Arrington Dodds and R. Harcourt Dodds of New Rochelle, N.Y., is to be married today to Henry Bradford Brown, a son of Ellen C. Anderson of Rumney, N.H., and Henry Brown Jr. of Berkeley, Calif. The Rev. Phillip S. Washburn will perform the ceremony at the Scarsdale Congregational Church in Scarsdale, N.Y., with H. Carl McCall, the New York State comptroller and a United Church of Christ minister, taking part in the ceremony.

title: INSIDE
description: Taiwan Jet Crashes in Sea With 225 People on Board

title: L.I. @ Work; Shareholders' Rights Plan
description: The BioSpecifics Technologies Corporation (Nasdaq: BSTC) of Lynbrook said Monday its directors had adopted a shareholder rights plan that would protect investors in the event of a takeover attempt. ''The rights are intended to enable all shareholders to realize the long-term value of their investment,'' the company said.

title: Chilling Out And Down
description: To help weather the hot months that lie ahead, cosmetic counters are introducing summer coolers: gels and lotions that use ingredients like alcohol, silicone and menthol to chill the skin on contact.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUBER, HERMAN J.
description: TAUBER-Herman J. 91, of West Palm Beach. Widower of Ruth Tauber. He is survived by sons Arthur (Sandra) Tauber and Richard (Barbara) Tauber, daughter Judith (Jim) Gordon; grandsons Daniel, Jeffrey, Michael, Charles, and Matthew; great - grandchildren Maddie, Becky, Mickey, Justin and Jeremy. Mr. Tauber was President of Temple Beth El in Bellmore, NY, and a longtime member of Temple Beth Tikvah of Greenacres, FL. A graveside service will be held Sunday (today), 1:30 PM, at Wellwood in Pinelawn, NY. A memorial service will be held in Florida on Wednesday, May 28. For further information, please call Riverside-Gordon 1800-844-0980.

title: Sunday Break and Puzzlement Outclass the Field in Going 1-2 in the Peter Pan
description: The field for the Peter Pan Stakes was divided into two camps: the owners and trainers who were trying to determine if their colts were ready to try to deprive War Emblem of the Triple Crown, and those wondering whether their horses were even good enough to show up in the starting gate for the Belmont Stakes.

title: Breifing: Historical Preservation; MOST ENDANGERED SITES
description: The Essex County jail in Newark (shown above), the George L. Pease Memorial Library in Ridgewood and barns throughout the state representing several architectural styles are among the most recent list of historic structures in danger of being lost to disrepair or destroyed.The eighth annual list of most endangered historic sites from the nonprofit Preservation New Jersey, released last week, also included the Bayley-Ellard Carriage House and Bellwood Stables in Madison, the Covenhoven Farm in Colts Neck, the Maxwell House complex in Hoboken, the Army Signal Corps' Camp Evans in Wall Township, the Finlaw building in Salem City, the Ramsayburg Homestead in Knowlton Township and the Old Stone Bridge between Bound Brook and Middlesex Borough. Karen DeMasters

title: May 19-25: NATIONAL; A COLD WAR EXPERIMENT
description: Nerve gas and a biological toxin were sprayed on U.S. sailors in the 1960's to test protective gear and decontamination procedures, the Pentagon revealed. The Department of Veterans Affairs is contacting hundreds who could be eligible for health-care benefits because of exposure to poisons used during Project Shipboard Hazard and Defense, or SHAD. Three tests used sarin, a nerve agent, or VX, a nerve gas; one used staphylococcal enterotoxin B, known as SEB, a biological toxin; one used a simulant later found to be dangerous. Thom Shanker

title: L.I. @ Work; How the Hamptons Auto Classic Recast Itself
description: AS the caterer for the Hamptons Auto Classic last Memorial Day weekend, John Kowalenko had more time on his hands than he would have liked. A downpour turned the three-day vintage car auction and show into a soggy disappointment. Attendance plummeted, and organizers missed their $50,000 fund-raising goal by about half.

title: Artful and Stylish, It Must Be France
description: There is no repeating what happened in France in 1998. Only once can you win the world's biggest sporting event for the first time. And when that first time happens to be in your own country and comes by way of an unequivocal 3-0 victory over Brazil -- Brazil! -- the uniqueness becomes even more obvious.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTNER, SETH DAVID
description: BARTNER-Seth David. 68, of Great Neck, NY, on May 25, 2002. Loving husband of Barbara. Beloved father of Lynn, Mark and Sarah, Laura and Bob. Pop Pop of Emily, Kelcey and Hannah. Cherished brother of Clare Bierman and uncle of Karen and Peter Hirsh. Services Wednesday, 12 noon, at Temple Beth-El, 5 Old Mill Road, Great Neck, NY.

title: Spano's Spokeswoman Becomes Chief Adviser
description: THE top spokeswoman for Westchester County government, Susan Tolchin, has been appointed chief adviser to the county executive and, among other duties, will supervise a new emergency management plan for evacuating the area surrounding the Indian Point nuclear power plant in Buchanan.

title: Fear Not, But Fret Plenty
description: TO ensure my safety at this time of national alert, I plan to move to a remote bunker in Montana -- as soon as I find gainful employment there. In the meantime, here's how I spend a typical day.

title: Taiwanese Airliner With 225 Aboard Crashes in Sea
description: A Taiwanese airliner bound for Hong Kong with 225 people aboard suddenly disappeared from radar in clear weather and crashed into the sea on Saturday between southern Taiwan and China. Rescue workers quickly reached the wreckage of the Boeing 747 and retrieved at least 16 bodies but found no survivors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WESTON, REV. DR. M. MORAN
description: WESTON-Rev. Dr. M. Moran. The Board of Directors, Staff, Friends and Families of the Greater Harlem Nursing Home are deeply saddened by the loss of one of its founders, Rev. Dr. M. Moran Weston and extend sincere condolences to his wife Miriam and family. Dr. Roscoe C. Brown, Jr., Chairman Rodney Alexander, President Reita Fuller, Administrator

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVER, HARRIET G.
description: SILVER-Harriet G. In her 97th year, on May 23rd. Adored wife of the late David. Beloved by her sister, Marjorie Rappaport; her sons, David (Linda) and Michael; her granddaughters, Nicole and Valerie; Bill Grant and all of her ''kid cousins,'' and her faithful friends, Grace Hoffman and Saad Hajidin. A family service has been held. Tootsie had a long and fulfilling life, and served her country in war and the children and the elderly of her city all her life. In her memory, contributions may be made to Camp Vacamas, West Milford, NJ 07480, or the Sirovich Center, 331 E. 12 St., NY, NY 10003.

title: BUSH JOINS PUTIN IN URGING PAKISTAN TO CURB MILITANTS
description: President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia jointly stepped into the India-Pakistan crisis today during their one-day tour of this imperial Russian capital. Mr. Bush urged Pakistan's president to ''stop the incursions'' of Islamic insurgents into Indian-administered Kashmir, while Mr. Putin deplored Pakistan's decision to conduct new missile tests and encouraged the Indian and Pakistani leaders to attend regional talks next month.

title: Our Towns; So Many Automobiles, So Little Turnpike
description: HIS name is George and he is a car-aholic.

title: Corrections
description: A map on May 5 with an article in some regional copies about a campaign to promote living in South Orange and Maplewood, N.J., misidentified a town adjoining South Orange to the north. It is West Orange, not East Orange.

title: Private Sector; My Mozzarella Can Smother Your Software!
description: A feud between two Detroit business heavyweights could soon be played out in the quest for hockey's holy grail. Michael Ilitch, owner of Little Caesars pizza, also owns the Detroit Red Wings. Peter Karmanos Jr., co-owner of Compuware, owns the Carolina Hurricanes. Now both teams are just one step away from the Stanley Cup finals. The enmity between the men can be traced back to the 1980's, when their rival youth hockey teams battled for supremacy in Detroit-area ice arenas. At one point, the story goes, Mr. Ilitch even booted the Detroit Junior Wings, a team supported by Mr. Karmanos, from the Red Wings' Joe Louis Arena.

title: Dr. Levine's Dilemma
description: I have a suggestion for a concierge-care doctor (Devin Friedman, May 5). He should forget the hassle of even 300 patients and find just one aging billionaire patron on whom he can focus all of his apparently excellent medical attentions.

title: Read This Before Your Barbecue
description: To the Editor:

title: Compressed Data; Hewlett Using Inkjets To Cool Hotter Chips
description: Computers generate a lot of excess heat. To reduce the problem at its source, researchers at Hewlett-Packard Laboratories are using the company's inkjet printer technology in a novel application: spraying cooling streams of liquid onto the surface of semiconductor chips.

title: A Bid Too Far, Saved by an Errant Double
description: In any discussion of America's best partnerships Bobby Levin and Steve Weinstein must come into consideration, because they have regularly been first or second in major championships in recent years. Two weeks ago they won the prestigious Cavendish Pairs in Las Vegas for the second time in four years.

title: Brooklyn Summer Festival With a Global Heartbeat
description: Egyptian pop, Caribbean dance music, big-band jazz, reggae, merengue, hip-hop and alternative rock will be heard during the 24th Celebrate Brooklyn series this summer at the Prospect Park Bandshell, at Ninth Street and Prospect Park West.

title: This Week
description: Maestro's Farewell

title: TWO AMATEUR TITLES
description: Joe Horowitz, after shooting a 77 in the morning, bounced back with a 68 and finished with a 54-hole total of 210 to win the New York City Amateur Championship at the Latourette Golf Club in Staten Island.

title: Series Evened With a Slap, Catch and Shoot
description: The ball was delivered perfectly to Robert Horry, like a bounce pass in a pregame drill -- into his warm hands, 25 feet from the rim. Catch and shoot, just like practice.

title: Coulthard Wins in Monaco
description: MONACO, May 26 - As every racer knows, half the job in winning the Monaco Grand Prix is to be first through the first corner. For David Coulthard today, that came down to little more than pressing a button.

title: Market Place; As Jupiter crumbles, its pieces may help build a new order of Web researchers.
description: IN the whirlwind of the Internet economy, amid the frivolity.coms and e-nough-already business models, there were a bunch of companies that filled real needs but that were nonetheless swept away by the storm.

title: Fine Wines Are Hot Lots for Auction Houses of New York
description: Bang! Jamie Ritchie's gavel cracked the 10:10 a.m. silence in Sotheby's main salesroom on a recent Saturday, and a 12-bottle case of 1982 Chteau Cheval Blanc, a St.-milion, fetched $11,750 at auction.

title: Reliant Trading Unit Gets U.S. Subpoenas
description: Reliant Resources, the trading arm of Reliant Energy, said that it had received subpoenas from two United States attorneys requesting documents pertaining to round-trip electricity trading.

title: British Clinics Are Said to Be Sold for $420 Million
description: Priory Healthcare, a chain of drug and alcohol rehabilitation clinics where musicians, supermodels and the superrich go to receive treatment, has agreed to be sold to a group of its managers for 288 million ($420 million), people close to the company said today.

title: Hard-Liner Elected in Colombia With a Mandate to Crush Rebels
description: Bitter after three years of fruitless peace talks, voters gave a resounding victory today to a hard-right candidate for president who promises a sharp buildup in the armed forces to battle two rebel groups that have been waging war for 38 years.

title: 12 Million Could Die at Once in an India-Pakistan Nuclear War
description: An American intelligence assessment, completed this week as tensions between India and Pakistan intensified, warns that a full-scale nuclear exchange between the two rivals could kill up to 12 million people immediately and injure up to 7 million, Pentagon officials say.

title: INSIDE
description: Ailing Pope May Curb Travel

title: How to Keep Cargo Safe, and Rolling
description: When shipments of auto parts were held at the Canadian border for two days after the Sept. 11 attacks, Detroit shuddered. In the end, the halt in cargo shipments at the nation's borders and ports proved a brief hiccup. But it was a vivid reminder of just how dependent the modern economy had become on the efficient transportation of goods and parts that arrive just in time for assembly.

title: In New Era, Corporate Security Looks Beyond Guns and Badges
description: HELP WANTED: Chief Security Officer.

title: Unexpected Takeover Bid Is Made for AurionGold
description: Placer Dome, the Canadian gold mining company, made a $1.1 billion takeover offer yesterday for AurionGold Ltd. of Australia, an unexpected bid aimed at its partner in some significant joint ventures.

title: Read This Before Your Barbecue
description: To the Editor:

title: Bob Grossman, 79, Automobile Enthusiast
description: Bob Grossman, an automobile enthusiast who drove racing cars, sold foreign cars and liked to draw cars, died last Monday in a hospice in Branford, Conn. He was 79 and had lived in Southampton, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOOTENBERG, LORRAINE S.
description: GOOTENBERG-Lorraine S. Real Estate Broker at Willaim B. May, on May 25, 2002, at age 62. Loving mother of Jay Gootenberg and Debra Alpert and her husband Daniel. Adoring grandmother of Jack and Benjamin. Devoted daughter of Ida and the late Morris Suskind. Dear sister of Dennis Suskind and niece of Ann and Frank Suskind. Services at Congregation EmanuEl of Westchester, 2125 Westchester Ave East (corner of Kenilworth Road), Rye, NY, Tuesday May 28, 11 AM. Interment to follow at Westchester Hill Cemetery. Contributions in her memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: To Build a Country, Build a Schoolhouse
description: Isaiah Berlin has argued: ''Men do not live only by fighting evils. They live by positive goals.'' The advice was not aimed at the leaders of the war on terror: Berlin was speaking more than 40 years ago. But his idea is worth the attention of current world leaders. And one of the most important positive goals has already been identified by the United Nations: universal primary education by 2015.

title: Critic's Notebook; Top Prize to Polanski At Cannes Festival
description: The jury at the 55th Cannes International Film Festival awarded its top prize tonight to Roman Polanski for ''The Pianist.'' Shot in the director's native Poland, the film, based on the memoirs of Wladislaw Szpilman, a Jewish pianist who survived the Warsaw ghetto, was an unusually personal project for Mr. Polanski, and the award represents his return to the first rank of international filmmakers.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: North Koreans defect to embassy in China
description: SEOUL:  Three North Koreans have sought refuge in the South Korean Embassy in Beijing and the South Korean government has demanded that Chinese authorities treat the case "in a humanitarian manner."

title: Read This Before Your Barbecue
description: To the Editor:

title: A Man for the Men Who Stay Up Late; Letterman Devotee Will Now Face Off With His Idol
description: Had you tuned in to the May 19 episode of ''The Man Show'' on Comedy Central with Jimmy Kimmel and Adam Corolla as hosts, this is what you would have seen: a hypnotized college student chasing a midget in a flesh-colored body suit, a skit featuring two pornography fans attending an adult film fantasy camp and a half-dozen women dancing in bikinis while being cheered on by a rowdy beer-chugging audience.

title: Sports of The Times; Loss Can Be a Memory or a Turning Point
description: THE Nets decided not to practice yesterday, and who was going to blame them? The basketball would have felt like a medicine ball, if only for the weight they were carrying in their heads and deep in their hearts.

title: An Academic Ready to Take the Plunge Into Novelistic Success
description: Stephen L. Carter, William Nelson Cromwell Professor of Law at Yale University, tall, slender, elegantly dressed in his beautifully cut sports jacket and silk tie, is so good he could be boring were he not the author of one of the season's biggest novels, ''The Emperor of Ocean Park,'' a legal thriller about black upper class America, to be published next month.

title: Metro Matters; 2 Questions For an Insider Just Reborn
description: IT being a holiday, just two fundamental questions for Andrew M. Cuomo, who decided last week to be the reformer and skip his party's nominating convention in favor of circulating nominating petitions in a ''people's campaign'' for governor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFF, STACEY JILL
description: LEFF-Stacey Jill. Age 31, on May 24, 2002. Beloved and adored daughter of Erna and Barry. Loving sister of Ken and Aimee, Michael and Cindy. Devoted aunt to Zachary, Jared and Jordan. She was a brave and courageous, beautiful young woman who fought the good fight right to the end of her all too short life. She will be missed by everyone she touched. Services Tuesday, May 28, 10 AM, at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: Cheaper Body Scans Spread, Despite Doubts
description: The middle-aged men and women begin arriving before 7 a.m., coming to a trailer in a church parking lot here for screenings that they say could save their lives.

title: F.B.I. Inaction Blurred Picture Before Sept. 11
description: The day of Aug. 6, 2001, broke in the capital with the steamy torpor of deep summer. Congress was in recess, and President Bush, away on a working vacation at his Texas ranch, was out jogging before the temperature began its climb above 100 degrees. He later hacked brush in a sweltering gulch and fished for bass in a stocked pond. Maybe, later, his aides said, he would finish reading a biography of John Adams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEONARD, JAMES G.
description: LEONARD-James G. Retired investment banker, died May 21, 2002, at the age of 83. He graduated from Yale, class of 1939, and served four years in the Pacific in WWII. He was the recipient of the Silver Star while executive officer of the destroyer USS Benion in the vicinity of Okinawa on April 30, 1945. He is survived by his wife Anne Butler Leonard, two children, Victoria Hambleton and Geoffrey Leonard, three step-children, Geoffrey Henning, Alyson Henning Walker and Kimberly Henning Brack, a sister, Elizabeth Mabach, and six grandchildren. He was predeceased by his first wife Georgine Fawcett Leonard, who died in 1982. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Yale Clas of 1939, Association of Yale Alumni, attn: Janet Cappiello, 232 York St, New Haven, CT 06511, or the Scranton Memorial Library, 801 Boston Post Rd, Madison, CT 06443. There will be a memorial service, Saturday, June 1, 2002, at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, Madison, at 11 AM.

title: Geese Love This Land of Lush Lawns, but the Residents Are Fed Up
description: Four years ago, when Raymond S. Petronko was running for a City Council seat here, he kept hearing one complaint from voters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINN, PATRICIA HAVENS
description: FINN-Patricia Havens. 81, died peacefully after a brief illness on May 25, 2002. Born in London, she grew up in Brooklyn, attended Packer Collegiate and graduated from the Yale Drama School. She designed costumes for the Barter Theater, the Poet's Theater and the Hasty Pudding Club, and taught costume design at Emerson College. A longtime resident of Marion, MA, she volunteered for the League of Women Voters, the Marion Arts Center and the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston Ladies Committee. She is survived by her children, Mark Finn of Chappaqua, NY, Lucinda Tobin of Ashland, MA, Perdita Finn of Woodstock, NY, and five beloved grandchildren. A memorial service will be held this summer in Marion. Contributions in her name may be sent to the Marion Public Library.

title: Man Charged After Dog Is Hurled Off Balcony
description: A Brooklyn man who was arguing with his girlfriend yesterday threw her dog off the balcony of her 23rd-story apartment in TriBeCa, killing it, the police said.

title: On This Memorial Day
description: We have had the good fortune in recent years to find ourselves reminded mainly of past wars on Memorial Day. But this day is different, not only because the nation is at war in Afghanistan, but also because this war began at home last September in New York, in Washington and in the skies over rural Pennsylvania. Today we set aside the distinction between military and civilian, uniformed and un-uniformed. With the soldiers who have died in Afghanistan since September, with the police officers and firefighters who died at the World Trade Center, and the military personnel who died at the Pentagon, we inevitably honor the civilians who died on Sept. 11. This war is theirs, too, theirs especially, and their participation in it came at the same extreme cost.

title: John de Lancie, 80, an Oboist And Curtis Institute Director
description: John de Lancie, the longtime principal oboist of the Philadelphia Orchestra and then director of the Curtis Institute of Music, died on May 17 at his home in Walnut Creek, Calif. He was 80.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Knife Attack Wounds Woman and Daughter, 11
description: A man stabbed his wife and daughter early yesterday during an argument at the Sunset Park home of the man's mother, the police said. The police said they were still looking for the man, Abraham Lucero, 39, of Brooklyn, last night. description: MANDEVILLE-Hubert Turner. Known as ''T'', of New York City, previously of Fairfield, CT died peacefully in New York City on Monday, May 20th, with his family present. He was 79 years old. Mr. Mandeville was born in Utica, NY on September 11, 1922 to Ernest W. Mandeville and Ruth Turner Mandeville. He is predeceased by his wife Ann Adams Mandeville and his brothers Michael Lloyd Mandeville and Charles L. Mandeville. He is survived by his brother Ernest W. Mandeville, Jr., his sister Margaret Mandeville, his second wife Deborah L. Bowers, and his eight children, Christopher, Meredith M. Hollis, Matthew, Kempton, Jonathan, William, Morgan and Ross. He is also survived by 17 grandchildren, Erinn, Ariel, Krista, Amanda, Julia, Turner, Adelaide, Elizabeth, William, Allison, Courtney, Kempton, Henry, Estelle, Paulina, Michael and Carlos. He attended Ridley College, St. Catharine's, Ontario, from 1935 to 1940. He earned his undergraduate degree in Engineering from Yale University in 1944 and his law degree from Yale University Law School in 1947. He was a longtime member of the Yale Club of New York City. Mr. Mandeville married Ann Adams of Redding Ridge, CT in July of 1948. He was a partner with Pennie, Edmonds, Morton, Barrows and Taylor, Attorneys at Law, in New York City until January, 1961 when he established the patent law firm of Mandeville and Schweitzer with Fritz L. Schweitzer, Jr. Mr. Mandeville was on the governing boards of several educational, philanthropic and corporate organizations including Ridley College in St. Catharine's, Ontario, Westover School, St. Lawrence University, St. Barnabas College of Johannesburg, South Africa, Up With People, White Consolidated Industries and Tally Industries. Mr. Mandeville established The Mandeville Foundation, Inc., a private family foundation, in 1961, of which he was President and Treasurer from 1961 to the present. Mr. Mandeville had a great interest in providing seed support for organizations with limited opportunities for funding. He was also a supporter of many educational institutions and youth organizations including the Outward Bound School and the Andrew Glover Youth Program of New York City. Mr. Mandeville requested that there be no funeral or memorial service held on his behalf. In lieu of flowers, he would be pleased if you made a gift to a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINKRAUS, COHEN, RUTH
description: STEINKRAUS-COHEN-Ruth, 81. Of Westport, CT, and London, England, died peacefully on May 26, 2002, after a valiant fight against cancer. Beloved daughter of the late Herman and Gladys Tibbetts Steinkraus, and loving wife of the late attorney Herbert L. Cohen, Ruth is survived by her cherished sister Marjorie de Roquemaurel, of Paris, France, her devoted brother Bill, of Darien, CT, and her dear step-daughters MaryLou Weisman and Carol Becker. After attending Vassar, Mrs. SteinkrausCohen became an outstanding Juilliard-trained pianist and teacher. She was also a singer, editor, radio host, bibliophile, activist and multi-award winning ''Point of Light'' in the quest for global peace. In 1956, Ruth attended the World Federation of the United Nations Association (UNA) where she acted as secretary to Eleanor Roosevelt and developed a burning desire to serve as an advocate for the UN. Shortly thereafter she organized the UNA-CT and UNA of Southwestern CT and eventually became a National Board Member of UNA-USA and Vice President of UNA-UK, Westminster. After founding the International Hospitality Committee of Fairfield County and creating Westport's June Day celebration, for more than 40 years she spearheaded the effort to provide learning experiences for UN ambassadors, diplomats, staff members and their children by arranging for them to visit with American families in their homes. More than 50,000 individuals have participated in this program since it began in 1958. In 1987 Ruth became Editor-Publisher of the ''United Nations Calendar for Peace,'' which has been distributed globally, sometimes in translation. Ruth was co-founder and music chairman of the Friends of Music for almost 40 years and a co-founder and/or Board member of the New York Chamber Soloists, Performers of Connecticut, the Opera Company of Boston, Opera New England, Young Audiences of Connectict, and Westport's Art Advisory Committee, among many others. She was also a founding member and Secretary of the Hugo Grotius Society. Whether she was chatting in her book filled office, working with one of her many committees or playing chamber music in her music room, many were warmed by her unstinting generosity of spirit and the glow of her many talents. A private funeral service will be held for her immediate family, and a short memorial service will be conducted on June 8th (which would have been her 82nd birthday), at the Westport Town Hall Auditorium, from 10 to 11 AM. Donations to honor her memory and support the programs she helped create may be made to UNA of Southwestern Connecticut, Inc, c/o Attorney Greta E. Solomon, Cohen and Wolf, PC, PO Box 1821, Bridgeport, CT 06601.

The university will hold a ceremony on Fridayto acknowledge the gift. Mr. Baker was also secretary of the treasury under President Ronald Reagan and White House chief of staff under Presidents Reagan and Bush. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: Quirks and Microtones For Antics of Peer Gynt

In the 1980's, he was known for works like ''The Cry of Clytaemnestra'' (performed at the San Francisco Opera) or ''The Tempest'' (Santa Fe); since 1993 his operas have been crafted for his own chamber troupe, the Pocket Opera Players. This Chicago-based company, accompanied by the New York New Music Ensemble, made its New York debut last Tuesday evening at Symphony Space in Manhattan with a double bill of two of Mr. Eaton's works: ''Peer Gynt,'' already heard in New York in the 1990's, and ''. . . inasmuch,'' a premiere. They were creative, antic, quirky and enchanting.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Muslims In Afghanistan
description: Three hundred Uighur Muslims from China's western province of Xinjiang were captured in Afghanistan fighting with Taliban forces, and hundreds more Chinese Muslim separatists remain hidden in Afghanistan and Pakistan, a Chinese official said. These estimates are far higher than those previously given by Chinese scholars and the American military, which has captured only a few Chinese Muslims in Afghan operations. The claim was made by the Communist Party Secretary of Xinjiang in a meeting with foreign journalists, but he offered no corroborating details. Pakistan has turned over to China a leading Uighur separatist it captured, the official also said. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Somalia: U.N. Worker Freed
description: A United Nations worker kidnapped in Somalia last month was released on Saturday after almost a month in captivity, officials said. The United Nations said renewed fighting in the country could delay the resumption of aid programs recently suspended to push for Mr. Abukar's release. In a continuation of chaos in the capital, at least seven people were killed in Mogadishu on Friday when militiamen loyal to a warlord attacked the house of the interior minister in Somalia's transitional government. The soldiers ransacked five villages and the market town of Zaki-Biam, apparently in reprisal for the murder of 19 peacekeeping soldiers in the area the previous month. Taiwan military officials ruled out any missile attack, while President Jiang Zemin of China offered his condolences and the help of Chinese authorities. At least 80 bodies have been recovered; all 225 people aboard the flight are feared to have perished. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Corrections

(Marie was James's second wife and the subject of another Corneille portrait. Mary Queen of Scots was the daughter of Marie and James.)

title: When a Writer's Brain Is Turned Inside Out

Rather, as exemplified by Ellen Lauren's highly stylized performance as Woolf, it is a theatrical representation of the writer's mind, an abstraction painted with theater's animated tools.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCHBERG, ABRAHAM S., M.D.
description: BUCHBERG-Abraham S., M.D., age 82, beloved husband of Vera Lacob, resident of Waterside Retirement Estates of Sarasota, FL, formerly of Ardsley, NY, died after a long battle with renal disease on May 25, 2002. Dr. Buchberg was a Pulmonary Specialist at Montefiore Medical Center, New York City for over 50 years serving as a practitioner and teacher. He was Clinical Professor of Medicine at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University in New York where he was a revered teacher of generations of medical students. He was honored in 1998 for five decades of dedicated and caring service to the Pulmonary Service Division of the Montefiore Medical Center and its patients. Despite his long illness, he persevered with courage and fortitude. Dr. Buchberg served as a Captain in the US Army in Japan after WWII. He was a lover of classical music and a long-time devotee of the opera. He enjoyed travel and good books. A devoted husband, father and grandfather, Dr. Buchberg is survived by his wife Vera, his twin sister Irene Siegel of Boca Raton, his son Karl Buchberg of NYC, his daughter Dr. Lisa Buchberg and her husband Dr. Ralph Kaywin of Berkeley, CA and two granddaughters Emma and Nora. A memorial service will be held at Waterside Retirement Estates, 4540 Bee Ridge Rd, Sarasota, FL on Wednesday, May 29 at 1 PM. Donations in his memory to the Sarasota Opera Company, 61 N. Pineapple Avenue, Sarasota, FL. 34236, will be appreciated.

This is because these drivers were blasting early pirated copies of the album, which was scheduled to be released next week.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Angola: Aid Appeal For The Demobilized
description: More than 60,000 guerrillas and armed supporters have reported to demobilization camps as part of the cease-fire agreement, the state news agency reported. The number is higher than initially expected, and government officials are urgently appealing for relief aid from wealthy nations so they can feed and shelter all the rebel soldiers and supporters. The cease-fire was signed in April, ending a civil war after more than two decades. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Britain's Besieged Transport Secretary Resigns

title: Putting Lyrics First and Giving a Soft Sell to Love and Loneliness

Then the Pet Shop Boys showed up, and soon the beat had been relegated to the background. Neil Tennant's voice took over as he sang a sad song about life on the road and lovers separated by ''dark and frantic trans-Atlantic miles.''

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: SUSPECT IN FRANCE WAIVES EXTRADITION An American suspected in the killing of a New York doctor who performed abortions has decided to return to the United States to prove his innocence, his lawyer said yesterday. The American, James Kopp, left, is charged in the October 1998 sniper-style killing of Dr. Barnett A. Slepian in his home near Buffalo. He was arrested in Dinan, in western France, in March 2001 after a two-and-a-half-year search and is being held in Rennes. Mr. Kopp, 47, formally waived his right yesterday to appeal an extradition ruling, saying he wanted to clear his name. No extradition date has been set. (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEVILLE, HUBERT TURNER
description: MANDEVILLE-Hubert Turner. Known as ''T'', of New York City, previously of Fairfield, CT died peacefully in New York City on Monday, May 20th, with his family present. He was 79 years old. Mr. Mandeville was born in Utica, NY on September 11, 1922 to Ernest W. Mandeville and Ruth Turner Mandeville. He is predeceased by his wife Ann Adams Mandeville and his brothers Michael Lloyd Mandeville and Charles L. Mandeville. He is survived by his brother Ernest W. Mandeville, Jr., his sister Margaret Mandeville, his second wife Deborah L. Bowers, and his eight children, Christopher, Meredith M. Hollis, Matthew, Kempton, Jonathan, William, Morgan and Ross. He is also survived by 17 grandchildren, Erinn, Ariel, Krista, Amanda, Julia, Turner, Adelaide, Elizabeth, William, Allison, Courtney, Kempton, Henry, Estelle, Paulina, Michael and Carlos. He attended Ridley College, St. Catharine's, Ontario, from 1935 to 1940. He earned his undergraduate degree in Engineering from Yale University in 1944 and his law degree from Yale University Law School in 1947. He was a longtime member of the Yale Club of New York City. Mr. Mandeville married Ann Adams of Redding Ridge, CT in July of 1948. He was a partner with Pennie, Edmonds, Morton, Barrows and Taylor, Attorneys at Law, in New York City until January, 1961 when he established the patent law firm of Mandeville and Schweitzer with Fritz L. Schweitzer, Jr. Mr. Mandeville was on the governing boards of several educational, philanthropic and corporate organizations including Ridley College in St. Catharine's, Ontario, Westover School, St. Lawrence University, St. Barnabas College of Johannesburg, South Africa, Up With People, White Consolidated Industries and Tally Industries. Mr. Mandeville established The Mandeville Foundation, Inc., a private family foundation, in 1961, of which he was President and Treasurer from 1961 to the present. Mr. Mandeville had a great interest in providing seed support for organizations with limited opportunities for funding. He was also a supporter of many educational institutions and youth organizations including the Outward Bound School and the Andrew Glover Youth Program of New York City. Mr. Mandeville requested that there be no funeral or memorial service held on his behalf. In lieu of flowers, he would be pleased if you made a gift to a charity of your choice.

title: Paralysis in Health Care
description: Early this year Congress and the White House entertained dreams of passing all kinds of health care legislation. President Bush and Senator Edward Kennedy were supposedly working on a patients' ''bill of rights.'' There was even talk of enacting a prescription drug benefit for the elderly. But such talk has vanished. Instead a sober recognition has settled in Washington that little can be done to expand or improve health coverage while health care costs spiral out of control and the federal budget sinks deeper into deficit. Lawmakers seem to be betting that voters will not punish them for inaction. But they cannot put off the issue forever.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Tenafly: 2 Explosions Described As Pranks
description: Two small explosions early yesterday, in a mailbox and on a front porch, were probably acts of vandalism rather than terrorism, the police said. No one was injured, and there was little damage. Lt. Dan Regino, a police spokesman, described the incidents as juvenile pranks and said no letters or messages were found at the two houses or at a third where an unexploded device was found in a mailbox. A powerful firecracker believed to be an M-80 exploded in the mailbox of a home about 2 a.m. and a similar device exploded on the front porch of a nearby home about 15 minutes later, the police said. Several hours later, an unexploded M-80 was found in a mailbox in the same neighborhood. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Officer Accused Of Sex Assault
description: A New York City police officer was arrested early yesterday and charged with burglary and the sexual assault of a 24-year-old woman at a beach house in Belmar, N.J., the police said. The police said that the officer, Frank Loguidice, 24, spent much of the day with a man who was staying at the house, and went home with him, and groped the woman as she slept on a couch. Officer Loguidice, who works for the Manhattan Traffic Task Force, has been suspended without pay and is under investigation by the Internal Affairs Bureau, the police said. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Losing the Intelligence War Overseas
description: The controversy over who knew what when before Sept. 11 reveals at least one thing clearly -- it is very easy to get lost in a side debate. While it is important to know whether the Federal Bureau of Investigation mishandled information, that inquiry should not keep us from having the far more important public inquiry into whether the Central Intelligence Agency has learned through failure how to collect information on Islamic terrorist groups. If Washington is going to win the war on terrorism, it will have to do so overseas.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Stabbing And Building Fire
description: A man was arrested yesterday in connection with the stabbing of a femalie acquaintance, the police said. They said that the two had argued and that the man, Zheng Zheng Chang, later set fire to the building in Sunset Park where he and the woman lived. Two others who live in the four-story brick building on 45th Street, off Fort Hamilton Parkway, were rescued and taken to Staten Island University Hospital with second-degree burns, the authorities said. The wounded woman, whose name was not immediately released, was stabbed in the shoulder and lower back and is listed in stable condition at Maimonides Medical Center, the police said. Mr. Cheng, 27, was charged with assault, the police said. Fire marshals are still investigating the fire, and Mr. Cheng has not been charged with arson. Al Baker (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Noranda Executive Resigns
description: Noranda Inc.'s chief executive, David Kerr, left, will step down after a decade in the post and be replaced by Derek Pannell, his second promotion this year. Mr. Pannell, 55, is also the chief executive of Noranda's Falconbridge unit, and had been picked by Noranda's board to establish closer links by the companies. He is combining their copper operations under Noranda and letting Falconbridge focus on nickel. Noranda owns 57 percent of Falconbridge, the world's fourth-largest nickel-mining company. The change takes effect on June 1.

title: Heroics for Humble Broccoli

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, JOHN ZADOCK
description: KATZ-John Zadock. Passed on at home on May 26, 2002 after a valiant fifteen-year struggle with kidney cancer. Beloved husband of Dorothy Ann Kurilla of Jessup, PA and father of John Andrew and Walter, who left us August 4, 1996. Also survived by two sisters and their husbands, Deborah and Howard T. Hermann of Newtonville, MA and Mary S. and W. Richard Burack of Jackson, NH, and sixteen nieces and nephews. Born in Baltimore, MD, December 30, 1928 to the late Amalie Sonneborn Katz and M. Shakman Katz. Graduated from The Park School, Baltimore (1946), Haverford College (1950) and Harvard Business School (1958). Interned in the oil business in London for one year after college, and then enlisted in the U.S. Army during the Korean War for three years. Honorably discharged from the Army Security Agency as a Sergeant (1954). After business school worked for several years in family oil business, L. Sonneborn Sons, Inc. In 1962 began as a Security Analyst in The Equity Research Department of Burnham and Company, and became a firm partner in 1971. The firm later became Drexel, Burnham, Lambert, Inc. Eventually became Department Manager and then Associate Director of Research and remained with the firm until its demise in 1990. The following two years served as a Supervisor Analyst in the Institutional Research Department of Kidder Peabody & Co. Member of Board of Trustees of the New York Society for Ethical Culture from 1972 to 1997, and Treasurer from 1979 to 1986. On Board of Governors of the Ethical Culture Fieldston Schools from 1976 to 1986, and member of The Board of Mount Pleasant Westchester Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY from 1972 to 2000. Memorial contributions may be made to The Kidney Cancer Association, 1234 Sherman Ave., Suite 203, Evanston, IL. 60202-1375. A Funeral Service will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., NYC, Friday, May 31, at 11:30 AM.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Outlook Improves At Silicon Graphics
description: Standard & Poor's raised its outlook on Silicon Graphics to positive from negative, citing the company's progress in ''stabilizing its operations.'' Standard & Poor's maintained its CCC- rating on the corporate credit of the company, whose computers have been used to create images for films like the Oscar-award winning ''Shrek.'' Silicon Graphics generated positive cash flow from operations in the fiscal third quarter, which ended March 29, halted the erosion in its cash balances and its near-term liquidity is sufficient, Standard & Poor's said. title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Telekom Cuts Jobs

Facing angry investors at the company's annual shareholders' meeting, Telekom's chief executive, Ron Sommer, promised to cut costs about $9 billion a year and return the company to a solid financial footing. Deutsche Telekom suffered a first-quarter net loss of 1.8 billion euros, or about $1.6 billion, stemming from declining sales in its fixed-line business and costs from its huge investment in wireless networks in Europe and the United States. The company has more than $60 billion in debt. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: The Rural Life; Out of the Wild
description: The other morning I lifted a bale of hay from a loose pile of bales on the barn floor, and a fox jumped out from under it. The fox ran to the back of the barn and turned to watch me. It paced a few steps, uncertain, and then scurried under the door and out into the cold rain. It was a moment of pure transgression. All the old story lines broke apart -- the ones about farmers and foxes and chickens -- and just when the old story had been going so well. The fox had stolen a couple of our chickens. I had chased it off several times. It would lope up the hill in the middle pasture and sit on the ridge looking back at me, waiting for my next move. We hated to lose the chickens, and we hated the fox for taking them, but it was a conventional hatred, a part we knew we were supposed to play.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Dual Treatment For Prostate Disease
description: Benign prostate disease can be relieved far better with a mix of the two usual treatments than with either separately, a study has found. The two drugs, finasteride and doxazosin, are used for benign prostate hyperplasia, a disorder that causes swelling and blocks the urinary tract. Each drug cuts the chances of worsening by about a third. Together, the two reduce progression 69 percent, according to research on 3,000 men sponsored by the federal National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases. Philip J. Hilts (NYT)

title: A Narrow View of Federal Power
description: Chief Justice William Rehnquist and his fellow conservatives have made no secret of their desire to alter the balance of federalism, shifting power from Washington to the states. Yesterday the Supreme Court took another step in that direction, ruling 5 to 4 that federal agencies may not hear complaints by private parties against states. The decision finds little support in the Constitution's text; it is the sort of interpretive leap that, were it taken by liberal judges, conservatives would denounce as ''activist.'' And its cramped view of federal power could harm vulnerable people who need federal agencies to protect them from abuse by states.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Verisign Sued By Consumers

No injuries were reported. The Police Department's Hate Crimes Task Force is investigating the incident, which was directed against a white man and a black woman, whose names were not released. Two brothers from Dobbs Ferry, C. J. O'Sullivan, 21, and Robert O'Sullivan, 22, face charges that include resisting arrest, the police said. The two others are Chris O'Neill, 20, and Mark Fanelli, 19, both of Yonkers, the police said. Mr. Fanelli was charged with criminal possession of marijuana. Al Baker (NYT)

title: In Many Churches, Icons Compete for Space; Multiple Shrines to Patron Saints Testify to a Rivalry of the Devout
description: St. Cecilia Roman Catholic Church, housed in a 19th-century building in East Harlem, has run out of space. Not for parishioners, but for their icons.

title: W.'s Spaghetti Western
description: As Jacques Chirac droned on and on beneath the capering sylphides at lyse Palace on Monday, orating about consequences and consultations, dialogues and divergences, President Bush's face transparently -- and hilariously -- reflected his thoughts. (And mine.)

title: Mayor Says Gerald Levin Might Be Fine Schools Chief
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he would be willing to consider Gerald M. Levin, the recently retired chief executive of AOL Time Warner, as a candidate for New York City schools chancellor, calling Mr. Levin a ''quality guy.''

title: Train Wrecks and Other Headaches: A British Minister Quits
description: Stephen Byers, Britain's transport secretary responsible for the country's ailing rail and road systems, resigned today after a turbulent one-year tenure marred by crashes and service disruptions on the trains, increased tie-ups on roads that are already Europe's most congested, and high-profile scandals in his own office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHORE, ALLAN E.
description: SHORE-Allan E. On May 27, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Carol Tilles. Devoted father of Allan E. Shore Jr. and his wife Jill, William T. Shore & Marylu Simon. Cherished grandfather of Jennifer, Christopher, Beth, Michael and Julie and great-grandfather of Benjamin Yaakov and Dovid. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Service Thursday, May 30, 11:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Donations in his memory may be made to the Junior Achievement of Palm Beach, Florida.

title: After the Food Is Prepared, Gloss It
description: A gloss in a flavor like Nantucket Cranberry might be from a cosmetic counter. But Aztec Chili-Lime? Gloss, a new product made by Crane's Creamery in Elka Park in the Catskills, is a flavored butter that comes in 11 savory, spicy and sweet varieties. All are made with nonfat yogurt as well as butter. The balance of seasoning, especially in the savory flavors, is excellent, with golden Thai Curry and tangy Portofino with olives among the winners.

title: Fakery Is Nothing New
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Protest Set For Verizon Headquarters
description: The communications workers union has scheduled a demonstration today in front of Verizon's headquarters to protest what it says are plans to lay off 2,100 workers in New York State. The protest is scheduled for 5 p.m. on 42nd Street and Avenue of the Americas. The union says such layoffs would violate its contract, but Verizon officials deny planning layoffs in New York. The company says it has 2,100 surplus workers and is negotiating with the union to try to trim that surplus without resorting to layoffs. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Police Say Intern Was Slain, But They Do Not Know How
description: The police said today that Chandra Ann Levy was murdered but that they did not know how.

title: Luck Deals An Amateur $2 Million
description: YOU'VE got to know when to hold 'em and know when to fold 'em. That may seem a tired old line, but it is a fundamental rule of poker. It also happens to serve pretty well in life, which Robert Varkonyi will tell you has a way of resembling what the poet-songwriter Leonard Cohen once called ''the holy game of poker.''

title: Rock Star With a Cause
description: To the Editor:

title: Last Steel Column From the Ground Zero Rubble Is Cut Down
description: It was a night for the working people, a brief, private moment to reflect on their 37 weeks spent together at ground zero. A night to mark the end.

title: Creighton Miller, 79, Lawyer And Notre Dame Halfback
description: Creighton Miller, an all-American halfback who was a member of a prominent Notre Dame football family and later helped organize the National Football League Players Association as its lawyer, died last week in Shaker Heights, Ohio. He was 79.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPER, HARRY L.
description: ALPER-Harry L. At age 97. On May 27, 2002. Beloved husband of Lillian. Funeral services private.

title: Environmental Group Protests Mosquito Controls in Suffolk
description: Environmental advocates are suing Suffolk County to stop insecticide spraying and the digging of drainage ditches in the effort to control mosquitoes, charging that those techniques are illegal and harmful to nature.

title: Visions of Downtown
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Teamsters Strike At 2 Disney World Hotels
description: About 400 workers at two hotels on Walt Disney World property near Orlando struck. The housekeepers, laundry workers and some attendants at the Swan and Dolphin hotels walked out after rejecting a three-year contract. Tishman Hotel owns the hotels. Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide manages them. The workers, members of the Teamsters, seek assignments based on seniority and a 40-hour workweek. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: City College Film Festival Peers Inside Many Cultures
description: There will be no films here about rich-kid romantic angst, no lighthearted comedies, no expensive visual pyrotechnics and production values.

title: National Briefing | New England: New Hampshire: Denial For Hells Angels
description: The Hells Angels have sued the Laconia licensing board, which denied the group permits to set up booths to sell T-shirts, jackets and other items at the city's Motorcycle Week rally, starting on June 8. The board cited security concerns stemming from recent violence that involved the Angels and rival gangs. The club has sponsored booths at past Motorcycle Weeks.

title: Sports of The Times; The Most Important Referee
description: MANY years ago, the identity of the referee at a big fight was never known until he climbed into the ring. He was often one of three referees who had been ordered to report to the officials' dressing room, the one who got the main event after the other two had worked on the undercard. In an era when mobsters controlled some boxers, secrecy was understandable: if the gamblers didn't know who the referee would be, they couldn't try to bribe him.

title: A Sichuan Place That Puts Its Name on the Line
description: SOMETIMES you just have to go on instinct. I had been craving a good Sichuan restaurant, and a friend had mentioned a small, neat place he wanted to try in Flushing, Queens. This restaurant, which had been open several years, went by the piquant name Spicy and Tasty. On our way, we found that a new Sichuan restaurant had opened just a few weeks earlier not far away. It was called Szechuan Gourmet. We had to consider changing our plans.

title: When All the Characters Are in a Sense Prisoners
description: It's hard enough to write a one-act play that lingers in the mind: so little time to develop characters, so many of the form's artifices long since co-opted by television. Pity, then, three of the four playwrights on Ensemble Studio Theater's current bill. Their middling works would not have been especially memorable in any case, but juxtaposed against the beautifully written, beautifully acted fourth play of the evening, they practically disappear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, ISABEL JULIE (NEE CUNNINGHAM)
description: FRIEDMAN-Isabel Julie (nee Cunningham). May 27, 2002. Beloved mother of Leigh Sprimont, loving sister of Beth Cunningham and Georgia Gibbons, devoted aunt of Damien and Darin. She will be deeply missed. Service Thursday, May 30, 2 PM at the chapel of Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY.

title: President at York Is Leaving
description: The trustees of the City University of New York announced yesterday that CHARLES C. KIDD SR. will step down as president of York College in Queens on June 30, and that RUSSELL K. HOTZLER will serve as interim president while CUNY searches for a replacement. Dr. Hotzler has been interim president at Queens College for two years but could not be considered for the job at Queens, despite strong support from professors and political officials, because of a CUNY policy that prohibits acting presidents from getting the permanent post.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It is a terrible position to put us in. You could give me $50 million, do you think I'm going to betray my kid's memory and suddenly become a cheering section for the Libyans?''

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: ILLINOIS: GOVERNOR OFFERS SMALLER BUDGET Gov. George Ryan proposed a new budget to help address a $1.4 billion revenue shortfall. Mr. Ryan laid out a plan that would cut financing for higher education; reduce the state work force by 6,500, laying off 400 corrections officers; and raise cigarette and casino taxes. Mr. Ryan's $22 billion spending plan is $260 million smaller than the one that he offered in February. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBOFF, HARRY
description: LIEBOFF-Harry. Cedar Park Cemetery graveside service held May 28, 2002. Died May 25, 2002 at age 94. Loving and devoted husband to Janet (pre-deceased). Loving brother, uncle, grand uncle, and companion to Natalie. Beloved friend to many. Veteran serving during WWII. He practiced law in New York City since 1933 in private practice and for the City of New York. Administrative Law Judge for the City of New York.

title: Excerpts From Justices' Ruling in Sovereignty Case
description: WASHINGTON, May 28  Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court ruling today in Federal Maritime Commission v. South Carolina State Ports Authority, in which the court expanded the concept of state sovereignty. Justice Clarence Thomas wrote the majority decision. Justice Stephen G. Breyer wrote a dissent in which he was joined by Justices Ruth Bader Ginsburg, David H. Souter and John Paul Stevens, who also filed a separate dissent. The full text is online at nytimes.com/national.

title: Vodafone Posts Huge Loss for Year
description: Once the unchallenged spearhead of the global wireless business, the Vodafone Group announced today that it had a net loss of almost $24 billion in the year ended in March, largely a result of write-downs in the value of the same deals and takeovers that once fueled its growth.

title: New Transport Secretary Named for Britain's Troubled System
description: LONDON, May 29  Prime Minister Tony Blair today named his little-known work and pensions secretary, Alistair Darling, to the high-profile job of running Britain's dilapidated transportation system.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Icann Chief To Retire
description: M. Stuart Lynn, the president and chief executive of the nonprofit corporation that oversees the Internet's address system, announced he intended to retire next March at a board meeting held last weekend in Garden City, N.Y. Mr. Lynn has led the nonprofit Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, or Icann, since March 2001. Earlier this year, he released a somewhat controversial proposal to overhaul its structure. Separately, Icann's chief policy officer, Andrew McLaughlin, announced his resignation effective July 1. The announcements come at a time when Icann is under pressure to manage its own organizational reform, lest the Department of Commerce rescind Icann's contract to manage the address system and hand those responsibilities to another contractor. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: Cadbury Schweppes Stops Using 7Up Ad
description: The Dr Pepper/Seven Up Company division of Cadbury Schweppes has stopped running a television commercial for its 7Up soft drink after various groups complained that the spot made light of the issue of rape in prison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEVENEY, KENNETH
description: DEVENEY-Kenneth. Of Manhattan, former senior art restorer at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died on May 25 after a courageous and dignified battle with lung cancer, as reported by his Friend of 39 years, Dr. Prospero Sanidad.

title: Castroneves Loves Indy, and New York
description: About the only thing that took Hlio Castroneves by surprise in his tour of New York yesterday was how loud the closing bell at the New York Stock Exchange was.

title: Pouty Pancake of Passion and Fruit
description: SOME desserts are delicate and restrained -- prim little packets decorated with precise swirls of chocolate and neatly placed sprigs of mint. Others follow a more exuberant model, laying siege to the senses with a dramatic interplay of intense flavors and garnishes.

title: TEPPCO, A DUKE ENERGY UNIT, TO BUY ANOTHER GAS PIPELINE
description: Teppco Partners, an owner of pipelines for oil and natural gas, agreed yesterday to buy a gas-gathering system in New Mexico from Burlington Resources Inc. for $444 million, its fourth pipeline purchase since September. The company expects the purchase to generate $60 million in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization annually. Teppco plans to increase its yearly cash distribution by 10 cents a unit. The transaction is expected to close by June 30. Teppco is a unit of Duke Energy Field Services, 70 percent owned by the Duke Energy Corporation.

title: Rock Star With a Cause
description: To the Editor:

title: Being Someone Else: It's a Career Move
description: It's an all wind that blows no good.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about a debate over superconductor research at Bell Labs misstated the affiliation of Dr. Arthur P. Ramirez, a researcher who has reproduced part of the work. He is a scientist at Los Alamos National Laboratory, not Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory.

title: Despite All, Vietnam Still Likes Americans
description: VIETNAM, NOW

title: Bush Touts Protection of Florida Everglades
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 — President Bush and his brother Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida took part in a White House ceremony today to celebrate the protection of the Everglades and miles of beaches from oil and gas drilling.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Minority Groups In Suburbs
description: Minority groups have increasingly moved to suburbs of Chicago, but most in those groups still live in segregated areas, a study shows. Using the 2000 Census, the Civil Rights Project at Harvard found that 27 percent of blacks and 39 percent of Hispanics in the metropolitan region lived in the suburbs, up from 19 and 29 percent, respectively, in 1990. Half the black suburbanites live in 13 of the 264 towns, and half the Hispanic suburbanites live in 17 towns. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Gould Memorial Service
