description: A memorial service for Stephen Jay Gould, the evolutionary theorist who died on May 20, will be held at 4 p.m. tomorrow at the Tishman Auditorium of New York University, in Vanderbilt Hall at 40 Washington Square South in Manhattan. Friends and associates of Dr. Gould, including the constitutional expert Alan Dershowitz and the writer Oliver Sachs, are scheduled to speak at the service, which is open to the public.

title: Rock Star With a Cause
description: To the Editor:

title: Footlights
description: Into History

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Monday about President Bush's visit to France referred incorrectly to a comment by President Jacques Chirac, who said, "The United States and Europe are the two major economic powers in the world." He was correct: although Japan indeed has the second-largest national economy, after that of the United States, it is smaller than that of the European Union, which comprises 15 countries.

title: Budget Gap Puts Pressure On Legislators In New Jersey
description: New Jersey's projected budget deficit has grown by more than half a billion dollars, the state treasurer announced yesterday, leaving legislators scrambling even further to close an already yawning shortfall.

title: Sweet Deal for M.T.A. Home Turns Sour, Beset by Cost Overruns and Indictments
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's decision to lease a downtown building at 2 Broadway was heralded in 1998 as an award-winning real estate deal that would provide huge savings on a new home for the agency's far-flung operations.

title: UNITED DEFENSE TO BUY MARINE REPAIR FOR $316 MILLION
description: United Defense Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the closely held United States Marine Repair Inc. for $316 million. Marine Repair is the largest provider of nonnuclear ship repair, modernization, overhaul and conversion services to the United States Navy. The company, based in Norfolk, Va., has ship-repair operations in Norfolk; San Diego, San Francisco and San Pedro, Calif.; Pearl Harbor, Hawaii; and Ingleside, Tex. In the 12 months ended March 31, Marine Repair reported revenue of $431.7 million and earnings of $12.3 million. United Defense is acquiring Marine Repair from affiliates of the Carlyle Group, which also owns about 49 percent of United Defense. United Defense is based in Arlington, Va.

title: Before We Lecture Cuba
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CHEF
description: IN a restaurant it's good to have base sauces -- combinations of ingredients prepared in advance and ready to use. A West Indian Creole base made with tomatoes, seafood stock and Scotch bonnet chilies is a favorite. The base is not complicated. It takes less than 30 minutes to prepare, and it's incredibly versatile. It's just as useful for home cooks as for a chef.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: If the Vikings Had Discovered Sushi
description: The season for fresh matjes herring is here, and Marcus Samuelsson, the chef at Aquavit, is making sushi with it. And you can, too. Cook a cup of short-grain Japanese white rice, then season it with one-fourth cup rice vinegar warmed with one tablespoon mirin and two tablespoons sugar. Form ovals of the rice, dab on some wasabi and top with a slice of herring. Or spread the rice on nori on a sushi mat, smear with a little wasabi or mustard, add pieces of the herring, roll it up and slice it into sushi rolls. Sometimes Mr. Samuelsson uses mashed potatoes seasoned with wasabi instead of rice.

title: New Medicines Seldom Contain Anything New, Study Finds
description: Two-thirds of the drugs approved from 1989 to 2000 were modified versions of existing drugs or even identical to those already on the market, rather than truly new medicines, according to a new study.

title: Bikers Take Plea Deal in Fight With Hells Angels
description: Three months ago, prosecutors say, a group of bikers burst into a Long Island catering hall where Hells Angels were holding a motorcycle and tattoo exposition, wielding bats and knives and dressed in denim vests denoting their allegiance to the Pagan Outlaw Motorcycle Club.

title: Bay Area Real Estate Prices Too Hot for Some to Touch
description: The ranch-style house, on a corner lot in this Silicon Valley suburb, was listed for sale at $1.1 million. It was a fixer-upper that needed a lot of work, assuming it would not be torn down. But within three days the house had 18 offers, most from buyers eager to pay cash. It sold for $1.45 million.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: OUTLOOK IMPROVES AT SILICON GRAPHICS Standard & Poor's raised its outlook on Silicon Graphics to positive from negative, citing the company's progress in "stabilizing its operations." Standard & Poor's maintained its CCC- rating on the corporate credit of the company, whose computers have been used to create images for films like the Oscar-award winning "Shrek." Silicon Graphics generated positive cash flow from operations in the fiscal third quarter, which ended March 29, halted the erosion in its cash balances and its near-term liquidity is sufficient, Standard & Poor's said. Improvements in operating income and cash flow could lead to ratings improvements in the intermediate term, the ratings service said. (Bloomberg News)

title: National Briefing | West: California: Fines For Internet Prescriptions
description: The State Board of Pharmacy fined a Los Angeles pharmacy and two pharmacists $88.7 million for filling prescriptions over the Internet from doctors who were not licensed in California. The board said the violators had filled more than 3,500 prescriptions for ''style of life'' drugs, including Viagra for male impotence, Propecia for hair loss and Xenical for weight loss. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: DRS TECHNOLOGIES TO PAY $92.2 MILLION FOR EATON UNIT
description: DRS Technologies Inc., a maker of military computer-display systems, agreed yesterday to buy the assets and some liabilities of the Eaton Corporation's Navy Controls Division for $92.2 million in cash to add products for ships and submarines including nuclear-powered vessels. The transaction is expected to add about $90 million to sales and 20 cents a share to earnings in the first 12 months under DRS ownership, the chief executive, Mark Newman, said. DRS, which is based in Parsippany, N.J., plans to buy the business with cash currently invested in short-term securities. Eaton's Navy business, which has 600 workers at plants in Milwaukee and Danbury, Conn., makes electrical power conversion and control systems for the Navy's combat fleet. The transaction is expected to close by June 30. Eaton is based in Cleveland.

title: Nancy White, 85, Dies; Edited Harper's Bazaar in the 60's
description: Nancy White, the white-gloved editor of Harper's Bazaar during the 1960's, when it captured the spirit of the decade with evocative photographs of models in bikinis, boots and big watches, not to mention spacesuits, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 85.

title: Corrections
description: A Reporter's Notebook article yesterday about President Bush's trip to Europe misstated the title of Gerhard Schrder of Germany, who appeared with him at a press conference. Mr. Schrder is chancellor, not prime minister.

title: Dodging Oak Bullets in $12 Chardonnays
description: FOR years now, Americans have loved California chardonnay, a full-bodied, fruity and slightly sweet wine with lots of alcohol and enough vanilla-like flavors to justify chardonnay as the name of a new flavor of ice cream.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Capital's Workers Go On Strike
description: Nearly 100,000 municipal workers in Mexico City started a 72-hour strike, halting garbage collection, waterworks management and many hospital services for almost 20 million people. Unionized municipal workers called the strike after failing to reach an agreement with the government of Mayor Manuel Andrs Lpez Obrador. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCHBERG, ABRAHAM S., MD.
description: BUCHBERG-Abraham S., MD. The President and Trustees of Montefiore Medical Center are profoundly saddened by the passing of Abraham S. Buchberg, MD, an esteemed colleague and friend. Dr. Buchberg was a devoted teacher and senior attending physician in the Division of Pulmonary Medicine when he retired in 1998. He served as director of the division from 1965 until 1972 and was on the medical staff for over 50 years. Dr. Buchberg inspired three generations of pulmonary physician scientists and was one of a select group of Clinical Professors of Medicine at Montefiore. He was honored by the Medical Center's Staff and Alumni Association in 1994 for his superb clinical skills combined with genuine compassion and integrity. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his dear wife, Vera; his children Karl and Lisa; his two grandchildren, and his sister, Irene. Spencer Foreman, MD, President Jay B. Langner, Chairman Board of Trustees Montefiore Medical Center

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REDMOND, MARY ROSE (NEE LYNCH)
description: REDMOND-Mary Rose (nee Lynch). Died on May 28, 2002 at Richard L. Rosenthal Hospice Residence in Stamford, CT. Beloved wife of the late Robert W. Redmond, loving mother of Michael D. Redmond, Regina E. Lynch & Roberta (Bobbie) Ventre, sister of Margaret, Thomas P. and the late James Lynch. Also survived by ten grandchildren. Funeral Mass at Church of St. Cecilia, 1184 Newfield Ave, Stamford, Friday, May 31 at 10AM. Relatives and friends may call: Leo P. Gallagher Funeral Home, 2900 Summer Street, Stamford, Thursday, 24 and 7-9 PM. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Darien, CT. Memorial donations may be made to Trinity Catholic High School, 926 Newfield Ave, Stamford, CT. 06905, or Richard L. Rosenthal Hospice Residence, Shelburne at West Broad Street, Stamford, CT. 06902.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Global Crossing To Reorganize
description: Global Crossing said yesterday that it was preparing a self-contained restructuring plan after Hutchison Whampoa of Hong Kong and Singapore Technologies Telemedia pulled out of a deal last week to acquire the company, which filed for bankruptcy protection in late January. The plan, which some of Global Crossing's creditors said they supported, underscores the perception that it has become harder to sell the company after other communications companies recently filed for bankruptcy protection, devaluing Global Crossing's network in relation to the growing pool of distressed fiber optic assets. In the meantime, Global Crossing is seeking to sell its shipping unit, conferencing division and network in Britain in an effort to raise cash. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABADY, JOSEPHINE
description: ABADY-Josephine. The League of Professional Theatre Women mourns the loss of its dedicated member. Her directing talents and presence will be missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERSEN, JORGEN A.
description: PETERSEN-Jorgen A. 7/4/39-5/25/ 02. Former Olympic (Danish national team silver medalist 1960) and international professional soccer player. Successful global businessman. Recipient of French Legion of Honor award in 1994. Served as member of Rebild Society, Gunnar Nu Fund, Danish American Society, and American Scandinavian Foundation. Beloved husband, father and friend. Survived by Monika, Marcia and Alanna.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, SOL
description: SILVERMAN-Sol. Died May 22, 2002 in Delray Beach, FL. Age 90. Loving and devoted husband of Frances W. Beloved father of Philip and Carl. Grandfather of Eli, Jenny, Lucianne and Isaac. We will all miss you.

title: Fordham University President Plans to Step Down Next Year
description: The Rev. Joseph A. O'Hare, who expanded Fordham University significantly as its president since 1984, announced yesterday that he will step down on June 30, 2003.

title: Weak Bats Lose Out To Weak Pitching
description: The Philadelphia Phillies have been one of baseball's biggest disappointments, entering Shea Stadium last night 10 games under .500. Of course, that's good enough to be within striking distance in the National League East because teams like the Mets have failed to capitalize on the division's mediocrity.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: RACIAL HARASSMENT ARRESTS Four men were arrested in Upper Manhattan yesterday, accused of shouting racial epithets and smashing the windshield and side mirror of a car belonging to an interracial couple on Monday night, the police said. No injuries were reported. The Police Department's Hate Crimes Task Force is investigating the incident, which was directed against a white man and a black woman, whose names were not released. Two brothers from Dobbs Ferry, C. J. O'Sullivan, 21, and Robert O'Sullivan, 22, face charges that include resisting arrest, the police said. The two others are Chris O'Neill, 20, and Mark Fanelli, 19, both of Yonkers, the police said. Mr. Fanelli was charged with criminal possession of marijuana. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, FLORA SMITH
description: JACKSON-Flora Smith. Beloved mother of Stephen J. Smith and Alan M. Smith. Cherished grandmother of Jesse and Samantha. Services Friday, 11:30 AM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about President Bush's visit to France was incorrect in suggesting that President Jacques Chirac was wrong to have said, ''The United States and Europe are the two major economic powers in the world.'' He was correct: although Japan indeed has the second-largest national economy, after that of the United States, it is smaller than that of the European Union, which comprises 15 countries.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SELVERNE, MARTIN M.
description: SELVERNE-Martin M. Your wisdom, wit, and warmth are forever missed. Your Famil

title: Seeking a Film Deal, McCain Found Producers With a Dramatic Past
description: As all Hollywood knows, there is no single recipe for turning a book into a movie, but one of the key ingredients is to find a producer with vision, access to money and a proven track record.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Bulletin Board column of the Education page last Wednesday about the selection of Susan O'Malley, a professor at Kingsborough Community College, to be chairwoman of the faculty senate at the City University of New York credited her erroneously with a first. She will be only the second community college professor to lead the body.

title: Hartford, To Carolina, To Finals
description: The Hurricanes' captain, Ron Francis, led his teammates into the locker room tonight after their thrilling 2-1 overtime victory over the Maple Leafs, a victory that earned them a berth in the Stanley Cup finals. The parade was a happy one, but it was not boisterous.

title: Miller Beer Expected to Be Sold to South African Breweries
description: LONDON, May 29  The boards of South African Breweries and the Philip Morris Companies met separately today to vote on an agreement that would enable South African Breweries to buy two-thirds of the Miller Brewing Company from Philip Morris for about $3 billion in stock, people close to the companies said.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Bonus For Airport Screeners
description: To keep airport security running through a federal takeover on Nov. 19, the government is offering $500 bonuses to entice privately hired screeners to stay on the job until then. The Transportation Security Administration has to hire 57,500 people to screen passengers and check luggage. Blaine Harden (NYT)

title: Arts Abroad | Thwarting Art Thieves On a Budget; Small European Museums Heighten Their Security
description: The administrators of the Chteau de Blois are still shaken by what happened on July 19, 1996. At the height of the tourist season, with more than 2,000 daily visitors to the medieval chteau and its museum of fine arts, a small 16th-century portrait was removed from an ornate frame and disappeared. It was the museum's first such loss in memory and it exposed weaknesses in the chteau's security.

title: With Late Shot, Bibby Puts Kings Step From Finals
description: When Mike Bibby took the court in the final seconds, he and Chris Webber and 17,317 of their friends were no longer playing with house money, young adults beating the system on a weekend binge. The Sacramento Kings were trailing by a point in the crucible of their season, down to their last shot, facing possible elimination away from home on Friday.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: The Well-Dressed Ambassador
description: The Italian fashion designer Giorgio Armani, who has worked to help Afghan refugees, will take on an official role as good-will ambassador for the United Nations refugee agency, the organization announced. Other agency ambassadors include the actress Angelina Jolie and the soprano Barbara Hendricks. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Harris's Play Is a Walk In the Park
description: There is much talk about the nuances of basketball, how an almost unseen eye contact can signal a play or the slightest change in positioning can make the difference between victory and defeat. With the Nets-Celtics game on the line Monday, Lucious Harris shunned the discreet signals.

title: EDO, A MILITARY CONTRACTOR, TO BUY RIVAL'S ASSETS
description: The EDO Corporation, which makes military and aerospace electronics, agreed to buy the assets of a bankrupt rival, Condor Systems Inc., for about $112 million in cash. Condor's board approved the sale last week after EDO concluded negotiations with the closely held company, which is based in Morgan Hill, Calif., along with its bank lenders and unsecured creditors, EDO said yesterday. Condor had 450 employees and listed $86.5 million in assets and $175.7 million in debt when it filed for Chapter 11 last November. EDO will not assume Condor's debt associated with the bankruptcy case. Condor makes antennas, receivers and signal-analysis software, according to its Web site. EDO's products include systems for thwarting radar systems and mines.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Sea Isle City: 3 Missing After Boat Capsizes
description: The Coast Guard ended a search yesterday morning for three brothers thrown from their high-speed catamaran when it capsized Monday afternoon. Life preservers were found on board the vessel, which can reach speeds of 100 miles or more, and the authorities believe the brothers were not wearing life jackets. Jeffrey, Joel, and James Malia, ages 35, 32 and 20, were from Williamstown, N.J. The Coast Guard searched a 22-square-mile area off Sea Isle City after the boat capsized, said Lt. John Hall, a Coast Guard spokesman. ''We have basically exhausted our reasonable expectations'' of finding any survivors, he said. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Giants Already Missing Armstead
description: Jessie Armstead has left this part of the world and moved on to his next life with the Washington Redskins, but he seems to have left keepsakes behind for many of his former Giants teammates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, MARTA
description: GREEN-Marta. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its cherished member and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Patricia Lampl, President Michael Z. Cahana, Rabbi

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Taxi Group Protests
description: Members of a cabdrivers group protested what they called a refusal of financial aid by charitable funds and government agencies after their businesses declined following the Sept. 11 terror attack. The group, the New York Taxi Workers Alliance, said that unlike other businesses hurt by the decline, cabdrivers had received little, if any, public attention. The group, which demonstrated in front of City Hall, is also seeking a fare increase of about 17 percent from the Taxi and Limousine Commission, said Chaumtoli Huq, general counsel for the alliance. The commission is considering an increase. The group says it represents more than 3,000 of the city's roughly 12,000 cabbies. Marcos Mocine-McQueen (NYT)

title: Police Say an Illegal Immigrant Imprisoned and Raped Two Girls
description: A 21-year-old illegal immigrant from Mexico was in police custody last night, facing charges that he coaxed two teenage girls there to travel to New York with him, raped them and held them as sex slaves, the authorities said.

title: Honors at Harvard
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IMBER, ROSE
description: IMBER-Rose. Of Longwood, FL, died in NYC on Sunday May 26, 2002. Wife of the late George Imber. Mother of Susan Natale and George Imber. Grandmother of Evan Natale and Peter, Jason and Gregory Imber. She was loved by all. Her unfailing love, deep devotion to her family, and good humor are irreplaceable, and will be missed by all. Services, Wednesday 11:30AM at ''The Riverside'' 76 St and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Lighthouse International, 111 East 59 St, NY NY 10022. The Family of Rose Imber

title: Lower Manhattan Revival
description: The area around ground zero continues its economic rebirth. The 463-unit Embassy Suites, across from the World Financial Center, reopened this month after being extensively refurbished since Sept. 11. Besides Hudson River views and a 15-story atrium, each two-room suite has Web TV. The reopening rates, which start at $249 weekdays and $159 weekends, include a daily breakfast and manager's reception. The hotel is adjacent to a 16-screen movie theater. Call (800) 362-2779 or visit www.embassysuites.com .

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DEREZEAS, GEORGIA
description: DEREZEAS-Georgia. ''We'll be friends forever, won't we, Pooh?'' asked Piglet. ''Even longer,'' Pooh answered. And so it is, my dearest friend. Love, Shaun

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Former I.B.M. Executive Named Xerox Finance Chief

title: NATO and Russia Shake Hands, but Will They Come Out Sparring?
description: Anyone who doubted that today's formation of a new NATO-Russia Council was something of a diplomatic triumph needed only to listen to leader after leader calling it historic.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Killed In Hit-and-Run
description: Police are seeking information from the public about an automobile that struck and killed a pedestrian in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn and then drove away. The police urged anyone with information about the incident to call 1-800-577-TIPS (1-800-577-8477). The victim, who was not immediately identified, was struck at 6 p.m. Monday by a maroon four-door sedan as he walked diagonally across Fourth Avenue from a corner on 56th Street, according to witnesses. The man, believed to be in his 20's, was taken to Lutheran Medical Center where he was pronounced dead. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Chilean Sea Bass: More Than an Identity Problem
description: ABOUT four years ago, Eric Ripert, the chef of Le Bernardin in Manhattan, took Chilean sea bass off his menu, prompted by reports that its meteoric popularity was causing it to be overfished.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OPPENHEIM, PEARL
description: OPPENHEIM-Pearl, 93. Beloved wife of the late William. Mother of Stanley and the late Dr. Richard Oppenheim. Beloved mother-inlaw of Susan and Judy. Grandmother of Wendy (Larry Badash), Lori (Craig Dacher), William (Jennifer), Daniel, and Joshua. Great grandmother of Richard, Hannah, Samara, Matthew, Olivia, and Samuel. A woman of exceptional character, dignity and self-respect. The Matriarch of our family for over 60 years, influencing the lives of succeeding generations of children and grandchildren with sound advice, criticism when needed, and the best example of high personal values always. Services today at 11:15, Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam at 76 St. Contributions in Pearl's memory would be appreciated to: The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale, Attn: Development Office, 5901 Palisade Ave, Riverdale, New York 10471.

title: LIBYA IS OFFERING TO PAY $2.7 BILLION FOR PAN AM BLAST
description: Libya has offered to pay $2.7 billion in compensation to the families of the 270 people killed in the 1988 crash of Pan Am 103, according to government officials and a lawyer representing the families. But the lawyer said the offer was made on the condition that the United States and the United Nations dropped their sanctions against Libya.

title: Allies' Focus in Afghanistan Turns Toward Militant Islamic Leader
description: BARGRAM AIR BASE, Afghanistan, May 29  The remnants of Al Qaeda and Taliban's senior leadership are attempting to build ties to a prominent militant Islamic leader, Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, with the goal of attacking American-led forces and undermining the interim government in Kabul, senior American and British military officials here said today.

title: KMART HOLDERS WIN REPRESENTATION IN BANKRUPTCY CASE
description: The Kmart Corporation's shareholders won formal representation in the company's Chapter 11 bankruptcy case, with a Justice Department official's decision to name a committee of equity security holders. Ira Bodenstein, the United States trustee for Illinois, Michigan and Ohio, said he would announce his decision to name the shareholder panel at a hearing today before Judge Susan Pierson Sonderby of bankruptcy court in Chicago. Formal representation may give shareholders a better chance to win more in Kmart's recovery plan.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Governor Offers Smaller Budget
description: Gov. George Ryan proposed a new budget to help address a $1.4 billion revenue shortfall. Mr. Ryan laid out a plan that would cut financing for higher education; reduce the state work force by 6,500, laying off 400 corrections officers; and raise cigarette and casino taxes. Mr. Ryan's $22 billion spending plan is $260 million smaller than the one that he offered in February. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Progress in Negotiations, But Read the Fine Print
description: When Commissioner Bud Selig meets with club owners in Chicago today, he can report on progress in labor negotiations. But before the owners get too excited, they should wait and hear that the progress is on matters like bus travel in Florida and in-season exhibition games.

title: From the Files of a Country Store
description: IN 1987, when Carrie Brown and John Werner, the authors of ''The Jimtown Store Cookbook'' (HarperCollins, $32.50), happened upon the abandoned Jimtown Store on a back road in Sonoma County, Calif., ''it appeared frozen in time,'' they write. ''Many of the original items still sat on the shelves, covered in dust and cobwebs. An antique cash register, pyramid displays of dry goods, and boxes of fishing lures were stacked in place on the worn wooden floor.''

title: Specter of High-Level Anti-Semitism Taints German Campaign
description: The German election campaign, so far relatively somnolent, has become embroiled in accusations of anti-Semitism and right-wing populism aimed at the liberal Free Democratic Party, which hopes to be the kingmaker in the next government coalition.

title: Walters Donates to Alma Mater
description: The broadcast journalist BARBARA WALTERS donated $1 million to Sarah Lawrence College, her alma mater, for a public exhibition gallery in the college's new 61,000-square-foot visual arts center. The announcement was made last week at the ceremonial groundbreaking for the visual arts center, which is part of a $25 million building project. Sarah Lawrence has a $75 million fund-raising campaign to pay for the center, as well as for scholarships, professors, technology and the renovation of residential and classroom space.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWTON, ANNE RODGERS WALKER
description: NEWTON-Anne Rodgers Walker. On May 26, 2002, at her home in Rye, NY. She is survived by her children, Blake and Belle Newton of Garrison, NY, Anne and Roger Walther of San Francisco, CA, and Julia Newton and Michael Feibish of Los Angeles, CA; her grandchildren, Jad and Christina Dunning of San Francisco, CA, Beau and Patrick Kealy of Washington, DC, and Samuel Newton of Garrison, NY, and by one great-grandchild, Mason Dunning of San Francisco, CA. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, May 30, 11 AM, at Christ Church in Greenwich, CT. Interment will be on Monday, June 3, 11 AM, at the Newton family graveyard in Hague, VA. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Robert E. Lee Memorial Association, Stratford, VA 22558; the Newton Family Professorship at The College of William and Mary, Office of Development, PO Box 8795, Williamsburg, VA 23187-8795 or Christ Church, 254 East Putnam Ave., Greewnich, CT 06830. For information, call the Graham Funeral Home in Rye, NY, or Welch Funeral Home in Montross, VA.

title: For That Someone Who's Very Special, Say It With Asparagus
description: Slender, delicate wild asparagus with tightly clustered tips are pretty enough for a nosegay.

title: India Calls a Speech by Pakistan's President 'Dangerous'
description: On a day when Pakistan test-fired a missile capable of carrying a nuclear warhead, India said today that Pakistan's president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, had delivered a ''dangerous'' speech Monday that offered no new steps to relax tensions between the countries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENOCH, LEE A.
description: ENOCH-Lee A. Died May 25, 2002. Of Teaneck, N.J., formerly of Bronx, NY. Beloved husband of Minna (nee Gordon), devoted foster parent of Lynn Plumacher, dear brother of Robert, Betty Ann Little, and the late Richard. Loving uncle of Susan and Kevin Hayes, Lisa and John Renzulli, Robert Enoch Jr., Richard Enoch Jr., Ann Marie Enoch and John Wademan, Lee Michael Schramm (in Heaven), Tracy Loftus, Michael Enoch and Joseph Little. Greatuncle of Leigh Ann, Jonathan and Ryan. Godfather of Sabrina and Brandon Wu. He was a member of Local #

title: FIFA chief silences critics over finances : Soccer power struggle boils over in Seoul
description: SEOUL:  In its 98-year history FIFA, the world authority for soccer, has grown to 204 member nations, and built up a prestige to rival the United Nations. On Tuesday in Seoul's Grand Hilton Hotel, the organization destroyed what remained of its credibility during a five-hour extraordinary congress called to examine FIFA's finances.

title: Elegy for the Doomed of Sept. 11
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, FRANK, SR.
description: ROSS-Frank, Sr. The board and staff of the New York City Chapter of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society mourn the loss of a dedicated trustee and friend. His support and commitment to the fight against MS were invaluable to our work. We extend heartfelt sympathies to his family and many friends and colleagues at HRH Construction and Starrett Corporation.

title: Truly Short Shortcake
description: THE bakery-counter version of strawberry shortcake, which at its best is a layer cake bound by whipped cream and filled and topped with strawberries, is children's food, more akin to a Twinkie than to the real thing. Traditional strawberry shortcake is far faster and easier to make -- the entire process should run no more than 30 minutes -- and at the end you will be able to serve a crowd a humble, simple form that is far more sophisticated than a huge layer cake.

title: Excerpts From Justices' Ruling in Sovereignty Case
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court ruling today in Federal Maritime Commission v. South Carolina State Ports Authority, in which the court expanded the concept of state sovereignty. Justice Clarence Thomas wrote the majority decision. Justice Stephen G. Breyer wrote a dissent in which he was joined by Justices Ruth Bader Ginsburg, David H. Souter and John Paul Stevens, who also filed a separate dissent. The full text is online at nytimes.com/national.

title: Mueller Plans To Turn Focus Toward Terror
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation, facing intense criticism over its performance before Sept. 11, is planning a series of changes intended to alter its mission fundamentally, from solving crimes like bank robbery to countering terrorism, government officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSE, AARON H.
description: ROSE-Aaron H. Passed away May 27, 2002, age 93. Loving and devoted husband for 60 years of the late Frances K. Adored and honored father of Elihu I. & Gail Rose and Judith F. & Robert Scheibe. Cherished grandfather of Melissa and Michael McClammy, Heidi and Brian Dodds, Alexandra Scheibe and Gabrielle Scheibe. Revered brother of the late Neomi Goodstein and of Benjamin L. Rose. Teacher, counselor, advisor and administrator at Jamaica High School from 1932 through 1971. Graveside service New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York, Wednesday, May 29 at 11:00AM. Memorial contributions may be made for the benefit of Hadassah Hospital, Jerusalem, Israel, 50 W. 58 St, NY, NY 10019.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Cameroon: Work Resumes On Chad Pipeline
description: Construction resumed on the Chad-Cameroon oil pipeline after workers in Cameroon ended a two-week strike over pay and working conditions. The 650-mile pipeline, which will carry crude oil from Chad to Cameroon's Atlantic coast, is scheduled to be completed in less than two years. The project, backed by the World Bank, is expected to yield $2 billion over 25 years to Chad, a landlocked nation with few other resources. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: Phone Industry Slump Hurts Canadian Banks
description: The slump in the telephone business is taking a heavy toll on Canada's banks. Three of the industry's five leaders have reported sharply lower profits in the latest quarter, with big hits from their exposure to troubled borrowers in the North American telecommunications sector.

title: Justices Expand States' Immunity in Federalism Case
description: WASHINGTON, May 28  The Supreme Court, its justices as bitterly divided as ever over where to draw the line between federal and state authority, today expanded the concept of state sovereignty to shield states from having to answer private complaints before federal agencies.

title: Graduate's Planned 'Jihad' Speech Raises Protest at Harvard
description: BOSTON, May 28  A Harvard senior who will speak at the university's 351st commencement next week plans to urge his fellow students to apply the Islamic concept of jihad to their lives, and some are angry about it.

title: President at York Is Leaving
description: The trustees of the City University of New York announced yesterday that CHARLES C. KIDD SR. will step down as president of York College in Queens on June 30, and that RUSSELL K. HOTZLER will serve as interim president while CUNY searches for a replacement. Dr. Hotzler has been interim president at Queens College for two years but could not be considered for the job at Queens, despite strong support from professors and political officials, because of a CUNY policy that prohibits acting presidents from getting the permanent post. Karen W. Arenson

title: Times When Life Grows Dark and Still
description: The Ensemble Sospeso's chamber concert on Thursday at Tenri Cultural Institute in Greenwich Village included three strongly persuasive performances. Ccile Daroux gave a supple and haunting account of ''Lecture d'une Vague'' by Franois Paris, music of looping lines and succulent chords created with electronic overlap.

title: Pataki Aide Seeks to Broker Deal on Rebuilding Television Tower
description: Gov. George E. Pataki's top aide has agreed to try to broker an agreement between New York City television stations and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg over building a television tower to replace the antenna destroyed atop the World Trade Center's north tower.

title: Clemens Is Not Talking About His Return to Shea
description: The Yankees had to know the issue would arise. Even now, it is explosive, the unfinished business of Roger Clemens and Mike Piazza. If the Yankees' rotation holds, Clemens will pitch on Friday, June 14, or the next day, at Shea Stadium against the Mets. He will face Piazza. And he will have to hit against the Mets' pitchers.

title: Paris Opera Ballet Students In Return Visit to New York
description: Anyone who remembers the United States debut of the Paris Opera Ballet School in New York in 1988 will recall the sensation created by its treasury of unfamiliar ballets and exciting young performers. The distinctly French repertory, especially the neo-Classical style of Lo Staats, was a revelation, and the student dancers were exceptionally talented.

title: Vivendi Likely to Give Up Its Effort to Overturn Vote
description: Amid the continuing turmoil at Vivendi Universal of France, the company's board is scheduled to meet today in Manhattan to try to resolve some of the uncertainties.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Don't Ask for a Cup of Sugar

title: Corrections
description: A brief art review in Weekend on Friday about ''I Kept All Your Letters,'' a group show at Rivington Arms on the Lower East Side in Manhattan, misstated the street address and the given name of an artist. The gallery is at 102 Rivington Street, not 192. The artist is Clay Weiner, not Carl.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EXACT HOLDING NV, Delft, Netherlands, a maker of business management software, said it would buy Kewill ERP Inc., a Minneapolis-based unit of Kewill Systems, Leatherhead, England, for $19 million in cash.

title: City Seeks To Close Gap By Using Disaster Aid
description: The Bloomberg administration wants to use some of the federal aid that has been earmarked to help New York recover from the attack on the World Trade Center to close the city's roughly $5 billion budget gap, officials said yesterday.

title: President at York Is Leaving
description: The trustees of the City University of New York announced yesterday that CHARLES C. KIDD SR. will step down as president of York College in Queens on June 30, and that RUSSELL K. HOTZLER will serve as interim president while CUNY searches for a replacement. Dr. Hotzler has been interim president at Queens College for two years but could not be considered for the job at Queens, despite strong support from professors and political officials, because of a CUNY policy that prohibits acting presidents from getting the permanent post.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORNBERG, SAMUEL
description: KORNBERG - Samuel. Beloved husband of Edith Elaine, devoted father of Cheryl Lefkovits and Jill Turquet, loving grandfather of Ari, Lauren, David & James. Services Thursday, 11:30 AM, ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel'', 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Centers visiting Knicks
description: The Knicks will work out three centers today, most notably Melvin Ely of Fresno State, a 6-foot-10, 260-pound senior who averaged 23.3 points, 9.1 rebounds and 3.2 blocks last season. Ely will be joined by Tennessee's Marcus Haislip, a 6-10 junior, and 6-9 Darius Songaila of Wake Forest. Chris Broussard

title: World Briefing | Africa: Somalia: Fighting In Capital
description: Heavy fighting erupted in Mogadishu as forces loyal to the transition government clashed with militia allied with various rival warlords. Hospitals counted at least 26 dead and 52 wounded, mainly noncombatants. The authorities saw the clashes as an attempt to discredit the government before peace talks set for summer. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Vintner to America? Think Warehouse
description: Alois Lageder, a renowned winemaker from Alto Adige in northern Italy, stood at the front of a tasting room, glancing from side to side as a group of American buyers tasted his wines. Elegantly dressed in a camel-colored check coat, he had traveled more than 200 miles to Tuscany for a 20-minute presentation. It was his chance to impress the buyers.

title: Generational Shift: Brokaw Announces He'll Retire in '04
description: Signaling the start of a generational change among the television networks' news anchors, NBC yesterday named Brian Williams, the 43-year-old cable newscaster, to succeed Tom Brokaw at the end of 2004 as the anchor of its nightly news broadcast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABBOTT, GEORGE
description: ABBOTT-George. Died peacefully on Saturday, May 25, 2002. He is survived by his wife Janice, their two sons Gregory and Christopher and seven grandchildren. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Thursday, May 30th, 5 PM. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to The New York Hospital, in the care of Dr. Joseph G. Hayes.

title: INSIDE
description: Gunman Kills 3 in Israel

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: More Autos Built
description: Japan's five largest automakers increased production at their plants overseas last month to meet growing demand in North America and elsewhere and to take advantage of lower costs. The Toyota Motor Corporation, the country's largest carmaker, increased production overseas by 37 percent in April, while Nissan raised output 23 percent. The Honda Motor Company, the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation and the Mazda Motor Corporation also raised production. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, JOHN ZADOCK
description: KATZ-John Zadock. Passed on at home on May 26, 2002 after a valiant fifteen-year struggle with kidney cancer. Beloved husband of Dorothy Ann Kurilla of Jessup, PA and father of John Andrew and Walter, who left us August 4, 1996. Also survived by two sisters and their husbands, Deborah and Howard T. Hermann of Newtonville, MA and Mary S. and W. Richard Burack of Jackson, NH, and sixteen nieces and nephews. Born in Baltimore, MD, December 30, 1928 to the late Amalie Sonneborn Katz and M. Shakman Katz. Graduated from The Park School, Baltimore (1946), Haverford College (1950) and Harvard Business School (1958). Interned in the oil business in London for one year after college, and then enlisted in the U.S. Army during the Korean War for three years. Honorably discharged from the Army Security Agency as a Sergeant (1954). After business school worked for several years in family oil business, L. Sonneborn Sons, Inc. In 1962 began as a Security Analyst in The Equity Research Department of Burnham and Company, and became a firm partner in 1971. The firm later became Drexel, Burnham, Lambert, Inc. Eventually became Department Manager and then Associate Director of Research and remained with the firm until its demise in 1990. The following two years served as a Supervisor Analyst in the Institutional Research Department of Kidder Peabody & Co. Member of Board of Trustees of the New York Society for Ethical Culture from 1972 to 1997, and Treasurer from 1979 to 1986. On Board of Governors of the Ethical Culture Fieldston Schools from 1976 to 1986, and member of The Board of Mount Pleasant Westchester Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY from 1972 to 2000. Memorial contributions may be made to The Kidney Cancer Association, 1234 Sherman Ave., Suite 203, Evanston, IL. 60202-1375. A Funeral Service will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., NYC, Friday, May 31, at 11:30 AM.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Kim Corrigan was named executive vice president and worldwide account director on the J.P. Morgan Chase account at the New York office of Foote, Cone & Belding, part of the FCB Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. She succeeds Bill McDonough, who continues as executive vice president for United States and global new-business initiatives. Ms. Corrigan had been executive vice president and managing partner at Young & Rubicam Advertising, New York, part of the Young & Rubicam unit of the WPP Group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAND, HERMAN
description: BRAND-Herman. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its honorary trustee and devoted servant and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Patricia Lampl, President Michael Z. Cahana, Rabbi

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Summer School For Almost Half The Students
description: Nearly half the students in the Baltimore public schools may go to summer school. Of the 95,000 students, 35,000 to 46,000 will have to take remedial work before being promoted, Dr. Carmen V. Russo, the district's chief, said. Dr. Russo attributed the surge to tougher academic requirements and the end of ''social promotion'' based on age, not achievement. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: A Little of This, a Little of That, a Mountain of Sweets
description: Some restaurants are allowing dessert-lovers to compile their own assortments of mini-sweets. At Theo, 325 Spring Street (Greenwich Street), the desserts, in identical little cups, are layered treats combining cake, mousse, cream, fruit and sauces. The selections include apple crumble, banana-banana, Jell-O and cream, and pistachio jubilee. Each is $4. At Compass, 208 West 70th Street, the pastry chef, Jehangir Mehta, offers his desserts, including chocolate-banana flan, lemon-grass panna cotta, and basil cake with mint sorbet in miniature for $4.50 each. And at Isla, 39 Downing Street (Bedford Street), a pick-and-choose tasting plate can be ordered for the table, $9 a person.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Rebels Attack Army Camp
description: Maoist rebels attacked an army camp 250 miles west of Katmandu just hours after King Gyanendra extended a state of emergency for three months to give the army and government broad powers to battle the insurgency. The Defense Ministry said that soldiers had recovered the bodies of 100 rebels and that only 5 soldiers had been killed. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: A Natural Progression, From Ball Field to Bench
description: HERE comes the judge, and he's not old school. He is, he says, into ''demystification.'' He wears Top-Siders, khakis and hip wire-rimmed glasses, and tends to remove his tie on neighborhood strolls. Holding its own right beside the wooden gavel that tames the paperwork on his desk at the Harlem Community Justice Center, the court where he practices his newfangled brand of justice as problem solver, is an autographed baseball enshrined in plexiglass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, ALEX
description: MITCHELL-Alex. Devoted widower, father and grandfather, died peacefully at home with his family on Tuesday, May 28, 2002. His loyalty, compassion and determination will be greatly missed. Mr. Mitchell was owner and CEO of Parkell Inc., a manufacturer of dental products. Services will be held Thursday, May 30 at 10:00 AM at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY. Private burial has been arranged. Donations may be made in his memory to Cancer Research Institute, United Jewish Appeal and Baruch College.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Automaker Looks At Plants
description: The MG Rover Group said it was looking at offshore production sites, including the troubled East European plants of the Daewoo Motor Corporation, the bankrupt Korean carmaker. MG-Rover, which is owned by a group of British investors who bought the MG and Rover car lines from BMW of Germany in May 2000, has been struggling to regain market share, but it has been troubled by the strength of the British pound against the euro. Daewoo-FSO in Poland, with a capacity of 200,000 cars a year, has wage costs about one-fourth those in Britain. ''Discussions have taken place; nothing has been decided,'' an MG-Rover spokeswoman, Katie McPhilimey, said. Ms. McPhilimey would not say whether MG-Rover was planning to shift production from its plants in Longbridge, England, or if it was looking for additional production capacity. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Judge Upholds Akamai Patent
description: A federal judge upheld a jury verdict that Digital Island infringed Akamai Technologies' patent for expediting data transmission to Internet users, Akamai said. Digital Island had asked United States District Court Judge Rya Zobel to rule the patent invalid and overturn the jury verdict, which was reached in December after a two-week trial in Boston. The judge rejected Digital Island's request on Friday, Akamai said. The judge also denied a request for a new trial, according to electronic court documents.

title: JUSTICES EXPAND STATES' IMMUNITY IN FEDERALISM CASE
description: The Supreme Court, its justices as bitterly divided as ever over where to draw the line between federal and state authority, today expanded the concept of state sovereignty to shield states from having to answer private complaints before federal agencies.

title: Long Shot Scores For Two Breeders
description: He was bred better than he ran, and his progeny, for the most part, were mediocre and so central Kentucky's most prominent breeding operation finally gave up on Our Emblem. Allen and Audrey Murray, owners of a modest breeding operation, were not thinking of a big score when they purchased the stallion from Claiborne Farm last fall and took him to Maryland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRD, ROBERT W.
description: BIRD-Robert W. Of Hilton Head, S.C. died on May 27th from idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. He served in the US Army from 1945 to 1947, returned to Dickinson College and graduated in 1950. He subsequently graduated from NYU Law School in 1953 and was admitted to practice in 1954. He worked on Wall Street in the banking and investment banking fields and retired from Integrated Systems Solutions Corp., an IBM subsidiary in 1996. Survived by his wife Abby and five children by a former marriage, Robert of Littleton, CO., Lara of New York City, Christopher of Newtown, CT., Pennel of Los Angeles, CA. and Cameron of London, England and six grandchildren. The Island Funeral Home.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: 10th Grade, Four Courses and Dessert
description: ON a typical Friday evening, Tessa Roush, 18, a senior at St. Ann's School in Brooklyn Heights, makes the rounds of SoHo groceries, leather-bound recipe journal in hand, gathering provisions for the dinner party she'll throw the following night.

title: Hairpin Turns on a Road to Maturity, Each Sex to Its Own
description: Self-consciousness just isn't what it used to be. Gone are the days when it was regarded as a simple, unhappy state of watching yourself that dominated adolescence and then erupted only occasionally, at things like job interviews and parties with dress codes. Now self-consciousness is an attitude, a philosophy and a lifestyle to be carried into adulthood, and it's O.K. -- even preferable -- to be self-conscious about being self-conscious.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERVIS, GERTRUDE
description: MERVIS-Gertrude (1915-2002); retired employee of Grossinger's Resort. Sister of Ruth Roper and the late Irwin and Florence, and sister-in-law of Jack Roper and Molly Mervis. Fondly remembered by her nieces, Laurie and Jamie Roper, and her nephews, James and Richard Mervis. Rest in peace, darling.

title: Dynegy's Chief Quits as Unrest Is Reshaping Energy Industry
description: The Dynegy Corporation, which was prepared just last fall to take over its bigger rival Enron, announced the resignation yesterday of its longtime chairman and chief executive, Charles L. Watson.

title: Where Israelis Grieve, Some Arabs Are Proud
description: Someone hung an Israeli flag today over the patio of the cafe here that was attacked on Monday by a suicide bomber. People lighted candles at a makeshift shrine near the spot where Sinai Keinan, 15 months old, and her grandmother, Ruth Peled, 56, were killed.

title: A Little of This, A Little of That, A Mountain of Sweets
description: Some restaurants are allowing dessert-lovers to compile their own assortments of mini-sweets. At Tho, 325 Spring Street (Greenwich Street), the desserts, in identical little cups, are layered treats combining cake, mousse, cream, fruit and sauces. The selections include apple crumble, banana-banana, Jell-O and cream, and pistachio jubilee. Each is $4. At Compass, 208 West 70th Street, the pastry chef, Jehangir Mehta, offers his desserts, including chocolate-banana flan, lemon-grass panna cotta, and basil cake with mint sorbet in miniature for $4.50 each. And at Isla, 39 Downing Street (Bedford Street), a pick-and-choose tasting plate can be ordered for the table, $9 a person.

title: New York's Benefactors
description: To the Editor:

title: A Cold Helps to Sink Henin During a Rainy Day in Paris
description: Justine Henin awoke on this drizzly, miserable day with symptoms fit for the label of a Nyquil bottle. Instead of pulling the bed covers over her head today, Henin grabbed the nasal spray, a tissue box and her racket.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, DORIS A.
description: FRANK-Doris A. On May 28, 2002. Died peacefully at her home in Manhattan at the age of 93. Lifelong resident of New York City and Elberon, New Jersey. Predeceased by her adoring husband Richard L. Frank, Sr, M.D. and her son Richard L. Frank, Jr. She is survived by her daughter Linda Frank Sicher, four grandchildren Jennifer and Andrew Wilder, and Vali and Joel Frank. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions in her name may be made to the Nightingale Bamford School, 20 East 92nd Street, N.Y. N.Y. 10128. Family will be receiving at the home of Linda Sicher on Wednesday and on Thursday evening 5-8 P.M.

title: Elegy for the Doomed of Sept. 11
description: To the Editor:

title: He's a Long Way From Long Island
description: Before he was a soccer man, Bruce Arena played lacrosse, America's original game. And when he was not carrying a stick, Arena would go on scouting expeditions with his coach, Mike Candel.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fifth Suspect In Officer's Shooting
description: The police are seeking a fifth suspect in the shooting last Wednesday of an undercover police officer during a gunfight in Brooklyn, the authorities said yesterday. Four suspects were arrested, but a fifth man, whom police have identified as Gamel Cherry, left, who lives at 301 Sutter Avenue, is still at large. The police released a photo of Mr. Cherry, 26, who has convictions for robbery and attempted murder and is known by the nickname Mel Mel, they said. They urged anyone with information to call 1-800-577-TIPS (1-800-577-8477). The wounded officer, Artie Marquez, was shot in his left hand as he and a partner tried to buy handguns in the Langston Hughes Houses in Brownsville. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Celtics Look for Answer To Yo-Yo Performances
description: They have turned it into an art form, a dramatic, awe-inspiring spectacle that was at its brightest in Game 3 of the Eastern Conference finals. Essentially treating the Nets like an overmatched younger brother, the Boston Celtics have opened lethargically, spotting double-digit leads before recovering to create late-game, must-see-TV suspense.

title: Identity Theft, and These Were Big Identities
description: A Tennessee man who devised an audacious identity-fraud scheme to bilk jewelers and corporate executives out of $730,000 worth of diamonds and Rolex watches was sentenced to eight years in prison yesterday by a federal district judge in Manhattan.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Eli's Wine

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KIRSHNER, NATALIE B.
description: KIRSHNER-Natalie B. Forever in my heart. Happy Birthday. Kathy

title: City Teachers Union Poll Gauges Public Support for Possible Strike
description: In between its strained and sporadic contract talks with the Bloomberg administration, the union representing New York City teachers has quietly been gauging public support for a strike and considering whether and when the city's 80,000 teachers should walk off the job.

title: As Shadows Lengthen on the Faun
description: Listening to Derek Jacobi read from the writings of Vaslav Nijinsky in Paul Cox's impressionistic film based on the diaries of that legendary dancer and choreographer, it is impossible not to contemplate with a shudder the shadowy line between art, ecstasy and psychosis. Over and over, Nijinsky, whose flaming peak lasted barely a decade, compares himself to God in language that most psychiatrists would call dangerously grandiose. ''I'm not an ordinary man, I'm a dancer,'' he exclaims. ''You will understand me when you see me dance.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDERS, JULIA (BAUM)
description: SANDERS-Julia (Baum). Beloved mother of Fran Pollack, Rhonda and Joel Baum. Stepmother of Robert and Jerry Sanders and Rochelle Saffer. Sister of Edith Lew and Rose Kron. Beloved grandmother and great-grandmother.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Helping With Talks On TV Tower
description: Gov. George E. Pataki's top aide has agreed to try to broker an agreement between New York City television stations and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg over building a television tower to replace the antenna that was on top of 1 World Trade Center. The governor's chief of staff, John P. Cahill, agreed on Friday to arrange talks among television executives, state officials and Mr. Bloomberg. The mayor has opposed building a tower on Governors Island, which tops the broadcasters' list of choices. Station executives are also considering the Liberty Science Center in Jersey City. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Order Yields to Lawlessness As Maoism Recedes in China
description: More than three years later, Li Lan still breaks down as she describes how her daughter was killed, an innocent victim of warfare between two villages that the local police made no effort to control.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Anti-Semitic Violence
description: Justice Minister Yuri Chaika said an explosion on Monday near Moscow was ''a manifestation of extremism and nationalism'' that should be punished. A 28-year-old woman suffered serious eye injuries when she stopped on a highway to remove a handmade sign reading ''Death to Yids,'' which turned out to be booby-trapped. Racist and skinhead violence has been growing in Russia in recent months. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Sapanta Journal; You'll Die Laughing, if You're Not Already Dead
description: Death, when it visits this isolated town in a forgotten corner of Europe, comes laughing -- in the guise, almost, of a comic book.

title: They Weren't Careful What They Hoped For
description: THE header jumped out from among the business and junk messages in the e-mail In box: ''Subject: May 2002 Science Fair Project.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILLMAN, BEATRICE
description: GILLMAN-Beatrice, 89. On May 28th. She leaves three daughters, Justine, Stephanie and Cathy, her late son Michael and husband Dr. Jac. Gillman, 5 grandchildren, two great grandchildren, sister Ruth and brother Abe. A former NYC special ed teacher, she brought love, laughter and life to all who knew her. Bea's presence inspired those at Daughters of Miriam. She was proud of her accomplishments from President of the Tenants Association to Editor of their newsletter. A true lexicographer, Bea brought her love of learning to all and nobody did the Sunday New York Times crossword puzzle (in pen) with greater speed. For information, call ''GuttermanMusicant'', 1-800-378-1892.

title: Six Wars And Counting
description: It's clear now that the Israeli-Palestinian clashes that erupted in the spring of 2002 qualify as the sixth Arab-Israeli war -- going down in history with the 1948, 1956, 1967, 1973 and 1982 wars. The 2002 war doesn't have a proper name yet (the Suicide War?). But like all previous Arab-Israeli wars, it is having a proper aftermath -- shaking up Arab, Israeli and Palestinian politics as much as the five previous wars did.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COLEMAN, CAPTAIN JOHN E.
description: COLEMAN-Captain John E. Three years have passed, my son, and I miss you just as if it was yesterday. That will never change. Lovingly your mother, Elayne.

title: Stoking the South Asian Fire
description: At a time when the world is pleading for statesmanship, Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee of India and Gen. Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan have irresponsibly escalated threats of war. Last week Mr. Vajpayee sounded as if a nuclear confrontation were acceptable when he spoke of winning a ''decisive battle'' over Kashmir. General Musharraf declared on Monday that Pakistan would ''respond with full might.'' Such inflammatory language was no doubt meant partly for popular consumption at home, but it reflects a disturbing lack of comprehension about the danger of war and contempt for outsiders like President Bush and his aides who have been trying to coax the two countries toward dialogue.

title: New Dean for Business School
description: THOMAS COOLEY, the chairman of the economics department at the Leonard N. Stern School of Business at New York University, will be the school's next dean, N.Y.U. announced yesterday. He will succeed GEORGE DALY starting Aug. 15. Before N.Y.U., Dr. Cooley taught at the University of Rochester, the University of Pennsylvania and the University of California at Santa Barbara.

title: Writers and the Truth
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Well-Guarded Nests
description: In an effort to thwart egg-stealing criminals, the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds plans to employ the Gurkhas, the British Army's fierce Nepalese regiment, to train its members in surveillance and camouflage. Using techniques taught by the Gurkha signals brigade, which is trained to operate behind enemy lines, officials from the group will hide in the undergrowth and photograph thieves trying to pocket the eggs of birds like the endangered marsh harrier. The society's spokesman, Graham Madge, said the thefts were puzzling because there was no significant market for stolen eggs. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Kidd Says Celtics' Fans Crossed Line With Taunts
description: What was brewing is now boiling. Tied at two games apiece and with a trip to the N.B.A. finals only two victories away, the Nets and the Celtics have moved the Eastern Conference finals into the realm of a bitter rivalry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHTER, MILTON
description: RICHTER-Milton. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with deep sorrow the passing of the beloved father of Janet Hershaft, a vice president of the New York Chapter Executive Board of our National Women's Division, and fatherin-law of Arthur Hershaft, member of our Board of Overseers. We extend heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Yeshiva University Dr. Norman Lamm, President Robert M. Beren, Chairman Board of Trustees Albert Einstein College of Medicine Robert A. Belfer, Chairperson Board of Overseers Dr. Dominick P. Purpura The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Alice Kent, President National Women's Division

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORIARTY, EUGENE M.
description: MORIARTY-Eugene M. Formerly of New York City. Died Monday, May 27, 2002. Beloved son of the late Joseph M. and Margaret Moriarty. Cherished husband, adored father and loving grandfather. U.S.M.C., WWII Veteran. Member N.Y.C. Fire Department for 34 years. Friends may call at the Burr Davis-Sharpe Funeral Home, 584 Gramatan Avenue, Mount Vernon, N.Y. Wednesday and Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saint Peter and Paul Church, Friday, 10AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Uniformed Firefighters Association Widows and Childrens Fund.

title: The Greening of the Herd
description: EARLY May weather in Vermont is predictable in its unpredictability. In one of the state's most beautiful farming communities, wintery gusts of wind were blowing across the Flack Family Farm while budding trees promised spring. Occasional shafts of sunlight broke through the clouds to light the chickens, pigs, sheep and cows grazing on fields of luscious green grass.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Deloitte Is Said To Face Inquiry Over Adelphia
description: The fiasco at Adelphia Communications is posing its own set of thorny problems for Deloitte & Touche, the firm that audited Adelphia's books.

title: Republicans, in a Show of Unity, Vote as One to Nominate Candidates
description: In a show of unity and allegiance to Gov. George E. Pataki, state Republican Party delegates voted unanimously yesterday to designate John J. Faso as their candidate for state comptroller and Dora Irizarry, the first Hispanic woman to be nominated to statewide office, as attorney general. Each was the only candidate nominated.

title: After a False Start, a Big Building Awaits Its Tenant
description: A big industrial building in North Bergen, N.J., that sat unused for two years after it was outfitted with $35 million worth of high-technology equipment that was never used is to become the headquarters of a fast-growing retailing chain.

title: Tasting Report: All Over the Map, Literally
description: Firestone $12

title: Elegy for the Doomed of Sept. 11
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Loss For Telecom
description: Japan's third-largest telephone carrier, the Japan Telecom Company, lost money in fiscal year 2001 as it wrote down the value of its subsidiaries and posted other restructuring costs. The company, which is two-thirds owned by the Vodaphone Group of Britain, lost 66 billion yen ($528 million), its first loss since it went public in 1984. Vodaphone has been trying to sell Japan Telecom's less profitable units, including its fixed-line operations, and preserve the company's more profitable wireless subsidiary, the J-Phone Company. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Military Flexes Muscles In Amazon
description: In what is described as the biggest military exercise ever held in the Amazon, the Brazilian military has begun maneuvers in a remote area that borders Colombia. Colombian guerrillas and drug cartels have occasionally crossed into Brazil, but a government spokesman said the exercise had been planned long in advance and was not related to concerns of increased violence after Colombia's presidential election last Sunday. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: COLONIAL BANCGROUP TO PURCHASE PALM BEACH NATIONAL
description: Colonial BancGroup Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Palm Beach National Holding Company for about $105.5 million in stock to expand in Florida. The transaction values Palm Beach National, the parent company of Palm Beach National Bank and Trust Company, at about $50 a share, according to a statement. Palm Beach National has about 1.7 million shares outstanding, a Colonial spokeswoman, Lisa Free said. Palm Beach National has eight branches in Florida. Colonial BancGroup has 97 branches and 2 loan production offices in the state, Ms. Free said. It has 236 offices total in Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Nevada, Tennessee and Texas.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Resignation At Gazprom
description: In a surprise move, the Russian gas monopoly Gazprom replaced its chief financial officer with a government official. The executive, Vitaly Savelyev, a pro-market reformer with a banking background, resigned, reportedly over differences with Gazprom's chief executive, Alexei Miller. Boris Yurlov was appointed to the post. The Russian daily Vedomosti reported that relations became tense when Mr. Savelyev opposed Mr. Miller's strong-handed actions to reclaim Gazprom's lost property. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Elegy for the Doomed of Sept. 11
description: To the Editor:

title: Fiat Reaches Agreement With Banks On Its Debt
description: Fiat and its major creditor banks reached agreement tonight on a major financial plan for the struggling company, refinancing short-term debt totaling 3 billion euros ($2.8 billion).

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank Raises Loss Estimate
description: Barclays said provisions to cover bad loans in the first quarter of 2002 were higher than in the quarter a year earlier. The news sent the shares tumbling 27 pence, or 4.4 percent, to 5.93 ($8.64.) The amount set aside to cover bad loans at Barclays Capital, the investment bank, was greater than expected, the bank said. For the entire bank, the provisions are similar to those taken in the final six months of last year. Investors have become increasingly nervous about the number of bad loans banks have as more companies default, file for bankruptcy protection or go out of business. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Don't Look for Walleye In a Place Called Wobegon
description: WHEN I was growing up in the Midwest more than half a century ago, mahi-mahi had not yet made it from the tropics to the flatlands, except occasionally in frozen form. To taste the real thing, you had to travel to Hawaii. To taste fresh red snapper, you had to go to Florida or New Orleans. To taste swordfish at its best, you had to visit Boston or New York.

title: U.S. REJECTS LOAN APPLICATION FOR VANGUARD AIRLINES
description: Federal officials said yesterday that they had rejected an application by Vanguard Airlines for a $13.5 million guarantee on a $15 million loan. The rejection was the first by the Air Transportation Stabilization Board, which was set up by Congress last fall to administer a $10 billion loan guarantee program. The program is part of a $15 billion bailout package that the government put together for the airline industry after the Sept. 11 attacks. Seven airlines have applied, and America West is the only one to have been approved, getting $380 million in backing in December. Vanguard, which is based in Kansas City, Mo., and serves 17 cities, said yesterday that it would revise its current application and refile it, as well as seek private financing. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Internet
description: ICANN CHIEF TO RETIRE M. Stuart Lynn, the president and chief executive of the nonprofit corporation that oversees the Internet's address system, announced he intended to retire next March at a board meeting held last weekend in Garden City, N.Y. Mr. Lynn has led the nonprofit Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, or Icann, since March 2001. Earlier this year, he released a somewhat controversial proposal to overhaul its structure. Separately, Icann's chief policy officer, Andrew McLaughlin, announced his resignation effective July 1. The announcements come at a time when Icann is under pressure to manage its own organizational reform, lest the Department of Commerce rescind Icann's contract to manage the address system and hand those responsibilities to another contractor. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: Ex-I.B.M. Executive to Fill Top Finance Job at Xerox
description: The Xerox Corporation has hired Lawrence A. Zimmerman, a former top I.B.M. finance executive, as its chief financial officer.

title: Holding a Plan For a Surprise In a Senate Race
description: John Matheussen says he is going to surprise a lot of people when the votes are counted in next week's Republican primary for the United States Senate.

title: Cisco Systems Picks 2 DarkGrey Offices
description: Cisco Systems in San Jose, Calif., has selected the New York and San Francisco offices of DarkGrey, the technology unit of the Grey Global Group, to handle its account, with spending estimated at $50 million to $60 million.

title: CONOCO TO BUY REST OF GULF INDONESIA FOR $329 MILLION
description: Conoco Inc. said yesterday that its Conoco Canada Resources unit agreed to buy the rest of the oil and natural gas producer Gulf Indonesia Resources Ltd. that it did not already own for $329 million. Conoco will pay $13.25 a share in cash for the 28 percent stake, a Conoco spokesman, Peter Hunt, said. The price is 23 percent more than Gulf Indonesia's closing price on Friday. Conoco last year bought Gulf Canada Resources Ltd., which owned 72 percent of Gulf Indonesia, for $6.3 billion in cash and assumed debt to increase its oil and natural gas reserves. The purchase was the largest ever of a Canadian oil company.

title: Irene Worth Memorial
description: A memorial for Irene Worth is to be held on Monday at 5 p.m. at the Joseph Papp Public Theater (425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village). Edward Albee, Christopher Walken, Mercedes Ruehl, Meryl Streep, Bernard Gersten, George C. Wolfe, Gene Saks and Alan Rickman are among those scheduled to speak. There will also be music by the flutist Paula Robison and the pianist Horacio Gutierrez. Ms. Worth died on March 10. The memorial is open to the public.

title: Seoul Feels Like Home, Only Nicer
description: There were 24 wicker baskets of white and purple orchids lining the stairway at the Itaewon subway station.

title: The True Purpose of Welfare Reform
description: The welfare measure signed into law by President Bill Clinton in 1996 expires this year, so a new law is needed to extend or modify it. The House of Representatives, acting mainly along party lines, has passed a bill that is pretty much what President Bush asked for; it will soon be taken up by the Senate.

title: Accounts
description: * Vignette Corp., a maker of software for Web sites, named the San Francisco offices of three agencies owned by the WPP Group to handle assignments with billings estimated at $10 million to $12 million. Young & Rubicam Advertising will handle creative duties; Wunderman, direct marketing; and Mediaedge: CIA, media services.

title: Paper Fights for Its Name (No, Not Figuratively)
description: It was John R. Triplett, one of this old coal town's keener Main Street lawyers, who first noticed the lapse by The Mountain Citizen, a weekly newspaper that has been crusading furiously with front-page articles severely critical of Martin County Water, the utility that has Mr. Triplett, a prominent citizen, as its chairman.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Day Care Baby Dies
description: A baby found unconscious in her crib at a small day care center in Flushing died yesterday, the police said. The baby, identified as Tiffany Liang, 3 months old, was found shortly before 11 a.m. at the Little Swan Kindergarten Day Care Center at 46-23 Union Street and was taken to Flushing Hospital Medical Center, where efforts to resuscitate her failed. The death was not deemed suspicious and an autopsy was to be performed today. The center was licensed by the city, according to police and Health Department officials. A spokeswoman for the city's Health Department said that there were no apparent violations by the day care center, but that its operations would be reviewed. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Elegy for the Doomed of Sept. 11
description: To the Editor:

title: Cisco Picks 2 DarkGrey Offices
description: Cisco Systems Picks

title: People
description: * Mary Moudry, managing partner and chief operating officer at the San Francisco office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, was named to the new post of president.

title: Bismarck's Lessons for Bush
description: Europeans love to reach for the imagery of the B-movie Western when criticizing a new American president -- especially if he is a Republican from Texas. Accordingly, President Bush is portrayed as a dolt on a stallion, emptying his six-shooter every which way, mainly at peace and global understanding.

title: F.B.I. Agent Linked to Mob Is Guilty Of Corruption
description: John J. Connolly Jr., a decorated Federal Bureau of Investigation agent famed for bringing the bureau underworld informers, was convicted by a federal jury today of racketeering and obstruction of justice for secretly aiding organized crime leaders.

title: Amtrak Counts Its Assets
description: Under threat of liquidation by Congress, the National Railroad Passenger Corporation, or Amtrak, is trying to generate revenue from its real estate holdings, and the proposed office tower at the 30th Street Station in Philadelphia is among the most prominent examples of these efforts.

title: Blatter Is Expected to Win Today
description: When a high-flying company suddenly loses money amid allegations of accounting irregularities and mismanagement, it is often time for the chief executive to start packing.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Toughening On Migrants
description: China demanded that South Korea hand over several North Korean migrants holed up in its embassy in Beijing and asserted that they had no legal right of asylum. Seoul is under domestic pressure to support such refugees in their quest to reach South Korea, and diplomats said there could be a lengthy standoff. Last Thursday and Friday, a single man and a couple from North Korea dashed past guards to the embassy, and on Monday another man got inside, diplomats said. The growing stream of North Koreans seeking refuge in foreign embassies has posed a quandary for Beijing, which treats North Korea as an ally and has formally agreed to repatriate such migrants. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WACHTEL, ELISABETH
description: WACHTEL-Elisabeth. The members of the Board of Directors, staff and volunteers of East End Hospice and the East End Open tennis committee extend heartfelt sympathy to the family of our devoted friend and supporter Elisabeth Wachtel upon her untimely death. Our sincere condolences to her loving husband David, their infant child Elisabeth, her family, friends and loved ones. Susan Katz East End Open Founder Priscilla Ruffin Executive Director W. Michael Pitcher, President of the Board of Directors East End Hospice Westhampton Beach New York

title: Justices Bolster Patent Holders' Rights
description: The Supreme Court today gave inventors more power to sue competitors for making modified versions of patented products. The 9-to-0 ruling partly overturns a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit.

title: 3 Groups Sue State, Saying Mentally Ill Are Neglected in Jail
description: Charging that the state has ''persistently ignored the serious mental health needs'' of prisoners, three advocacy groups filed a lawsuit yesterday that calls for changes in how mentally ill prisoners are treated.

title: Florida Governor Backs Most Proposed Child-Welfare Changes
description: Gov. Jeb Bush vowed today to carry out most of the recommendations of a blue-ribbon panel for fixing Florida's troubled child welfare system in response to the disappearance of a 5-year-old girl in the state's care.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in The Arts on May 21 about this year's Martin E. Segal Awards to rising young musicians included an erroneous reference from Lincoln Center about their origin. The awards were established by friends and colleagues of Mr. Segal when he retired as chairman of Lincoln Center in 1986; he did not establish them.

title: A Strain, Not a Tear, Saves Valentin's Season
description: John Valentin heard he might need surgery on his injured right shoulder two weeks ago and knew it would mean missing the rest of the season. He has been deprived of too many games over the past two years to go through another extended layoff. Valentin was determined to return from the injury to his right shoulder, initially diagnosed as a torn rotator cuff, by the end of his stay on the 15-day disabled list.

title: A Frump Does Something About It
description: FOR what seems like decades, the Carlyle Restaurant has occupied the back of the Carlyle Hotel like a rich widow who managed to wrest control of the premises and won't leave.
