On my rare visits to the place, I was always shocked to find that the food was not at all bad, which is to say, it was a lot better than the threadbare surroundings.

title: A Whale of a Difference
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Inside the Merry Cemetery
description: In Sapanta, Romania, epitaphs are upbeat, thanks to a Master poet-carver, Ioan Patras Stan.

title: Wright is Better Late Than Almost Never
description: A 125-foot spire, designed by Frank Lloyd Wright, will be the most prominent feature at the Promenade development in Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: New Architecture in Old Vienna
Slide Show: Camp Accessories
World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: 'Black Boxes' From Crash Located
description: Officials said they had had pinpointed the seafloor location of the data and cockpit voice recorders from a Hong Kong-bound China Airlines Boeing 747 that broke into four pieces in midflight on Saturday afternoon, apparently killing all 225 people aboard. A large piece of wreckage lies near the recorders and searchers will try to raise it today with fishing nets. Taiwan officials have said twice before, however, that they had found the so-called black boxes and then backed away from these claims. American aviation safety experts have arrived to help in the investigation. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINOT, DR. HERBERT S., ESQ.
description: MINOT-Dr. Herbert S., Esq., 89 years of age, passed away on May 25, 2002. Dr. Minot was an attorney in private practice for many years in Manhattan. He resided in Ocean Ridge, FL, and formerly resided in Palm Beach, Florida, and Harrison, New York. Beloved husband of the late Rachel Levinsky Minot. He is survived by his sister Sylvia Schwartz (residing NY, NY), five children, eight grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Devoted father of Gloria R. Evans (Boca Raton, FL), Jeffrey R. Minot, Esq. (NY, NY), Hazel J. Pitkin (New City, NY), Dr. Michael J. Minot and his wife Janice (Andover, MA.) and Ira H. Minot (White Plains, New York), and eight grandchildren, Matthew Bader, Heather Spadafino, Melissa A. Minot, Todd J. Minot, Adam Pitkin, Jordan Pitkin, David H. Minot and Stephen R. Minot, and two great grandchildren, Jodi Brook Bader and Amanda Rachel Spadafino. He was buried at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ, on Tuesday, May 28th. A prayer service in Florida is planned.

title: Putting Skyscrapers Back Into the Bigger Picture
description: DARN those news people.

title: F.B.I. Chief Admits 9/11 Might Have Been Detectable
description: WASHINGTON, May 29  The director of the F.B.I., Robert S. Mueller III, acknowledged today for the first time that the attacks of Sept. 11 might have been preventable if officials in his agency had responded differently to all the pieces of information that were available.

title: Summer Place Of Reality and Caviar Dreams
description: I've made four trips to the Hamptons. Once, long ago, was for pleasure; twice were for business; and finally, last year, for the funeral of someone I loved very much.

title: Nicotine-Laced Water May Soon Be in Stores
description: Sometime in June, drugstores and convenience stores around the country could begin carrying Nico Water, bottles of nicotine-laced water that are the latest entry in a long line of products intended to help smokers get their nicotine fix through less carcinogenic means.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Suit In Drunken-Driving Deaths
description: Maria Pea, whose 14-year-old daughter Dilcia was killed by Joseph Gray, left, the Brooklyn police officer who ran down three people after a day of extensive drinking, filed a federal lawsuit yesterday against the City of New York, the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association and others. Victor Herrera is expected to sue on behalf of his pregnant wife, Maria, their 4-year-old son, and the baby who was delivered after the accident and died a short time later. Ms. Pea accuses the city of supervisory neglect, failure to intercede and conspiracy to impede an investigation, and seeks $200 million in damages, said her lawyers, Johnnie L. Cochran and Derek Sells. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Intelligently, Arthurs Dissects Roddick in Five
description: Inside the intimate setting of Court No. 2, where fans can all but press their noses against the sidelines, it was as if Andy Roddick had been placed under inspection at Roland Garros.

title: Respectful and Rebellious but Hemmed in by a Style
description: Everyone has a role to play in the Jon Spencer Blues Explosion. The ``Explosion'' is Russel Simins, the drummer; on May 17 at Irving Plaza, he appeared first, bashing out an energetic rhythm. The ``Blues'' comes mainly from Judah Bauer, who contributed fractious guitar licks. And Jon Spencer stars as ``Jon Spencer,'' a hammy showman who delivers his lyrics with a snarl and a shiver.

title: Diane Allen in New Jersey
description: Republicans in New Jersey have an opportunity next Tuesday to choose among three candidates to challenge Senator Robert Torricelli, a Democrat, in November. G.O.P. voters can expect to have a real contender in this Senate race only if they nominate a candidate who is both moderate and independent, able to appeal to voters outside the narrow conservative base that tends to dominate primary elections. For that reason we believe State Senator Diane Allen is the best choice on the Republican line.

title: Experience Is Mellowing Anderson
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 29  Kenny Anderson, with the same sort of jab and dart that he uses to penetrate through the lane, has openly issued barbs at the Nets since the Eastern Conference finals began last week. While he has willingly entered into the trash talk between the Nets and Celtics, Anderson insists it has all been in fun.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Chief Resigns Over Rsum
description: Fire Chief Ronnie Few resigned after a month of criticism over an inaccurate rsum. The rsum Mr. Few submitted when he was nominated for the post in June 2000 included a college degree and professional honors that he had not received, The Washington Times reported. Mr. Few contended that the errors were made by an aide with his former fire department in Augusta, Ga., then suggested that the mayor's office had added the errors. Mayor Anthony A. Williams said he planned to name an interim fire chief within two weeks.

title: The Last Steel Column
description: Manhattan's skyscrapers have always been an emblem of the city's power. But there has never been a more powerful emblem of New York's strength than the way in which the remains of the World Trade Center were taken away. On Tuesday, workers at ground zero cut down the last piece of structural steel from the ruins, wrapped it in black muslin and an American flag, and prepared it for removal during a ceremony today.

title: Rice's Star as Bright as Ever
description: As Oakland receiver Jerry Rice enters his 18th season of pro football, he is as popular as ever. At the N.F.L. Golf Classic, a Senior Tour event at the Upper Montclair Country Club that began today and features 54 N.F.L. players and 78 pro golfers, he was swarmed by fans seeking his autograph, and Rice did his best to oblige them all.

title: Wes Westrum, 79, Longtime Giants Catcher
description: Wes Westrum, a superb defensive catcher for the New York Giants' pennant-winning teams of 1951 and '54 and later the manager of the Mets and the San Francisco Giants, died Tuesday in Clearbrook, Minn. He was 79.

title: Auditors Back Andersen In Testimony On Documents
description: A succession of Arthur Andersen auditors testified today that they did not consider the urgings they received last fall to comply with the firm's document policy to be a code for shredding records.

title: War Emblem's Sire Is Sold
description: Our Emblem, the sire of the Triple Crown hopeful, War Emblem, was sold yesterday by his Maryland breeders, Allen and Audrey Murray, to a partnership of the prominent Kentucky breeding operations WinStar Farm and Taylor Made Farm.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Teacher Arrested On Sex Charge
description: A science teacher at Intermediate School 33 in Bedford-Stuyvesant was arrested yesterday on charges that he sexually abused a female student in his classroom, the police said. The teacher, Darwin Bailey, 50, was taken into custody after the girl told her mother that Mr. Bailey had rubbed himself against her in the classroom, the police said. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: An Exhibition Celebrates 10 Years Of Free Studio Space for Artists
description: What do visual artists in New York City need most? Space. That was the answer that 26 artists who met in Philip Pearlstein's studio came up with 14 years ago, when the question was put to them by an arts foundation based in Colorado Springs.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Measure On Mascots Fails
description: A bill that would have made California the first state to ban the use of Native American team mascots by public schools was soundly defeated by the State Assembly. The effort to phase out names like Chiefs and Indians had early support, sailing through two committees before failing on the Assembly floor. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: Giambi's 3-Run Homer Fuels Yankees' Rally
description: Jason Giambi crushed a home run to center field at Fenway Park last week and returned to the dugout, acting sheepish. He found Joe Torre and could not resist tweaking his manager. ''I tried to hit a single, Skip,'' Giambi said.

title: U.S. Defends Anti-Bias Law on College Sports
description: The Bush administration expressed at least limited support yesterday for the federal law prohibiting sex discrimination in college sports, asking a federal court in Washington to dismiss a lawsuit by coaches of men's college teams who said enforcement of the law was hurting opportunities for male athletes.

title: Europe Police Likely to Get Longer Access To Records
description: Despite fierce opposition from civil rights groups, telecommunications companies and Internet service providers, the European Parliament is expected to vote on Thursday to approve a new data protection law that will make it much easier for the police in the 15 European Union countries to obtain and use communications records in investigations.

title: The Most Dangerous Place in the World
description: The present Kashmir crisis feels like a dj vu replay of the last one. Three years ago a weak Indian coalition government led by the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party had just lost a confidence vote in India's Parliament and was nervously awaiting a general election. At once it began to beat the war drums over Kashmir. Now another coalition government, still led by the B.J.P. and deeply tainted by B.J.P. supporters' involvement in the massacre of hundreds of Muslims in Gujarat State, may be about to lose another general election. So here goes the government again, talking up a Kashmiri war and asking India to stand firm behind its leadership.

It is not the double-digit deficit that has become as much a part of their game as the 3-point shot, but a three-games-to-two deficit that has them on the verge of being eliminated from these Eastern Conference finals.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nortel To Cut 3,500 More Jobs
description: North America's second-biggest maker of telephone equipment, Nortel Networks, said yesterday that it would cut 3,500 more jobs and might sell its optical-parts business amid new projections of flat to lower second-quarter sales. Nortel, which has cut about 50,000 jobs since the beginning of last year, now expects its work force to bottom out at 42,000. The company said it did not expect a meaningful recovery in the long-haul optical market before late 2003 or early 2004. The company said that the measures would help reduce the amount of quarterly sales it needed to break even, to $3.2 billion from $3.5 billion. Second-quarter sales will be unchanged to as much as 5 percent lower. Nortel's primary customers -- mainly the big telephone carriers -- continue to cut spending to deal with financial difficulties of their own. Shares in Nortel fell 17 cents, to $2.35.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCHBERG, ABRAHAM S., M.D.
description: BUCHBERG-Abraham S., M.D. The faculty and staff of the Pulmonary Medicine Division at Montefiore Medical Center and Albert Einstein College of Medicine mourn the loss on May 25 of Abraham Buchberg, Professor, accomplished physician, and former Division Director. During his halfcentury of service to Montefiore, which saw the development of Pulmonary Medicine as a specialty, Abe shared his gifts of teaching and caring for patients with countless medical students, residents, fellows, and attending physicians. His gentle wit, courteous demeanor, clinical acumen, and deep wisdom inspired all of us. Our heartfelt sympathies go to his wife, Vera, his children, Karl and Lisa, his grandchildren, Emma & Nora, and his sister, Irene.

description: The director of the F.B.I., Robert S. Mueller III, acknowledged today for the first time that the attacks of Sept. 11 might have been preventable if officials in his agency had responded differently to all the pieces of information that were available.

description: A 37-year-old former seminarian yesterday detailed the allegations he had made that led to the suspension of an influential monsignor in the New York Archdiocese -- describing an intense spiritual tie that he said grew sexually charged and emotionally abusive.

title: The Be-All: 2 New Tries To End All

Trash collectors are now ''sanitation engineers,'' stewards and stewardesses became ''flight attendants'' and phone reps blossomed into ''customer care specialists.'' It's only a matter of time before we writers rebrand ourselves as ''literature service providers.''

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: U.S. Bounty For Militants' Arrest
description: The United States is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information leading to the arrest of the five top leaders of the militant Mulsim group Abu Sayyaf, the American Embassy in Manila announced. The group is holding two American missionaries hostage, Martin and Gracia Burnham of Rose Hill, Kan. Deputy Secretary of Defense Paul D/ Wolfowitz is scheduled to visit the southern Philippines early next week to check on the progress of rescue operations as well as military exercises involving Filipino soldiers and nearly 1,200 American troops. Carlos H. Conde (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: AIRSHIP MAKER STRUGGLES CargoLifter A.G., which has raised and spent nearly $300 million to develop giant helium-filled dirigibles, said it could no longer pay its bills and would have to declare bankruptcy if it failed to raise new money within three weeks. CargoLifter's cash reserves have evaporated in the last year, and the company has repeatedly been unable to attract new investors. Boeing has expressed interest in Cargolifter's technology, but has not signaled any imminent interest in investing.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Alcatel Plans To Buy Telera
description: The biggest maker of telecommunications equipment in Europe, Alcatel, said yesterday that it planned to buy the closely held Telera Corporation for about $136 million in stock. Telera makes technology that uses voice extensible markup language, or VoiceXML, to make Web content accessible by telephone. The companies expect the deal to close in July, subject to approval by Telera's shareholders. ''Voice access to the Internet will be the spark for a powerful transformation in the way the Web is used,'' said Olivier Houssin, president of Alcatel's e-business group, in a statement. ''The acquisition is a critical link in our strategy to build the applications that will drive the transition to converged voice and data networks.'' Although Telera does not disclose its revenues, Alcatel said the company's $30 million in cash would finance its own development. Telera, based in Campbell, Calif., employs 75 people. Late last month, the company reported its fourth consecutive quarterly loss and said it saw no sign of a recovery in demand for network equipment. This month, Alcatel said its United States unit would cut about 450 jobs, or about 5 percent of the work force, because of the economic slowdown.

The award honors young craft artists, and each year five schools are invited to submit handmade objects. The second- and third-place winners are Sarah Alford from the Nova Scotia College of Art and Lorena Barrezveta from the Parsons School of Design. The question of what happened to the .38-caliber revolver used by Ms. Saldivar was settled this week. The gun, which disappeared after the trial, turned up at the apartment of a court reporter. Grandfather of Mary Elizabeth Elkordy, Arbas Octavius Elkordy, Hannah Marie Parker & Margaret Agnes Parker. Resident of Forest Hills Gardens and Point Lookout, NY. title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Echo Of The Cold War
description: Three former East German border guards went on trial for attempted murder in the shooting of a 14-year-old boy in 1962 as he tried to flee to West Germany. One defendant pleaded not guilty; the other two refused to address the judge. The boy was severely wounded as he swam across a Berlin canal but the West German police saved him after firing on their East German counterparts. Dozens of former border guards have been tried on similar charges since the fall of the Berlin wall in 1989. Desmond Butler (NYT)

The man, Neal Horsley, operated a Web site that listed abortion doctors, crossing out their names after they were killed. Mr. Rivera called Mr. Horsley ''an accomplice to homicide.'' title: F.D.A. APPROVES GUIDANT'S POSTOPERATIVE HEART DEVICE
description: The Guidant Corporation said yesterday that the Food and Drug Administration had approved a device to treat postoperative atrial fibrillation, or a rapid heart beat. Atrial fibrillation is one of the most common complications after heart surgery, occurring in as many as half of patients two to four days after their operations, Guidant said in a statement. Guidant's Syncrus system delivers a low-energy shock to the upper chambers of the heart to restore normal rhythm immediately. The device has already been approved in Europe and Canada. It is an alternative to drugs, which can take days to work and have potential side effects, Guidant said.

description: SURGEONS once had the ultimate hands-on job: spreading the rib cage to gain access to the heart, feeling for lumps in a deflated lung, sewing up blood vessels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REED, ARTHUR PATTERSON JR.
description: REED-Arthur Patterson Jr. Husband of the late Sylvia (Martinique) Reed died May 16. Mr. Reed had worked as an editor for the New York Times and other various news publications throughout his life. He is survived by a brother Dr. John J. Reed of NJ and his family. Services will be held Sunday, June 2 in CT.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: New Job Cuts At Bank
description: Barclays, the British bank, plans to shed about 1,000 consumer banking jobs, or 4 percent of the unit's staff, after profit stagnated last year. The reductions are in addition to 1,800 job cuts announced in February.

title: The Particular, the General And Then a Championship
description: The most predictable winner of the Goldman Pairs was the first. In 1929 the title went to Oswald Jacoby, perhaps the greatest figure in the history of the game. The least predictable, when the competition ended Sunday at the New Yorker Hotel Ramada Inn and Plaza in Manhattan, was Boris Merson of Paramus, N.J. He learned the game inductively 12 years ago, reading this column and inferring the rules.

title: Law Merger Spans U.S.
description: Bingham Dana and McCutchen, Doyle, Brown & Enersen are expected to announce amerger today, forming a firm with more than 800 lawyers. The combined firm, to be called Bingham McCutchen, will give Bingham Dana, based in Boston, a presence on the West Coast; McCutchen is based in San Francisco.

title: Dear Mom and Dad: Camp's Got Everything
description: IT'S a familiar rite of summer: in late June, children leave for camp in fleets of charter buses. As always, they can look forward to cookouts and capture the flag, mosquito bites and overnight hikes. But they no longer have to make do with bare essentials. Campers can now make their bunk, or even their tent, as comfortable as home. Well, almost.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Openwave Will Acquire SignalSoft
description: Openwave Systems Inc., which makes wireless Internet software, said that it would buy the SignalSoft Corporation for about $59 million in an effort to expand its line of wireless data services. In addition, Openwave said that it would buy downloading technology to enable the delivery of Java applications for games and multimedia content from Ellipsus Systems Inc. for about $17.5 million. SignalSoft, which is based in Boulder, Colo., develops wireless location-service software that allows consumers to receive information via a mobile phone based on their physical location. For example, a subscriber could get directions to the nearest A.T.M., theater or post office through a cellular phone. Openwave of Redwood City, Calif., said it offered SignalSoft $2.26 a share for each share of outstanding common stock. Company officials said that they expected the agreement to be completed in the third quarter this year.

title: New Jersey Details Plan To Raise Tax On Business
description: As state tax revenue continues to drop, even below Gov. James E. McGreevey's pessimistic projections, his administration today spelled out the details of a tax plan that would lean heavily on large corporations to close the budget gap.

title: AT&T LONG-TERM CREDIT RATING IS CUT TWO NOTCHES
description: The long-term credit rating of AT&T was cut by two notches yester day by Moody's Investors Service, because of what Moody's called ''weakened revenue prospects for the long-distance voice and data industry.'' The ratings agency also said that AT&T, the nation's largest long-distance telephone company, was likely to face additional competitive pressures from regional Bell operating companies and from technology substitution, like e-mail messaging and the Internet. Prices of AT&T bonds moved down two to three points. Moody's cut AT&T's rating to Baa2, the second-lowest investment grade rating, from A3, after beginning a review of the rating in October. Moody's maintained a negative outlook. AT&T has about $25 billion in outstanding debt securities, Moody's said.

title: Your Money Where Your Modem Is
description: J. ALEX SLOAN could not care less whether his bank has an office nearby. It does -- a Wells Fargo branch within blocks of his San Francisco apartment -- but the only reason he has his account there is that he likes the way the bank's online system works with his Quicken software.

title: Bloomberg Says Repairs Go Before a Memorial
description: A day before the last beam was to be removed from ground zero, signaling the transition from recovery to rebuilding, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that Lower Manhattan's most immediate need was infrastructure repair, and that a memorial and rebuilt office space would come later, after some wounds had healed.

title: Big Financiers Are Jostling To Acquire Unit of Qwest
description: John C. Malone is bidding. So is Leon Black. Henry Kravis has dropped out, but Thomas H. Lee is back in.

title: The Body Scan, for Good or Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: World Briefing | Africa: Madagascar: New Effort To End Crisis
description: International mediators scrambled to bring Madagascar's new president, Marc Ravalomanana, and his predecessor, Didier Ratsiraka, together for another round of talks in Senegal aimed at ending the Indian Ocean island's political crisis, which has crippled the economy and killed dozens of people since the beginning of the year. Tensions mounted this week after soldiers loyal to Mr. Ravalomanana stormed the prime minister's compound, seized Mr. Ratsiraka's appointee and installed Mr. Ravalomanana's. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Steel Sale
description: The Czech government accepted a 25 billion koruny ($765 million) offer from the Indian-born steel entrepreneur Lakshmi Mittal to buy and restructure the Nova Hut steel mill in the northern city of Ostrava. Mr. Mittal's closely held Dutch-based LNM Holdings and its sister company Ispat International form the world's eighth-largest steel group. Mr. Mittal already owns steel mills in Kazakhstan and Romania, as well as in Western Europe, the United States, Canada and Mexico, and specializes in turning around money-losing mills. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: UNIT OF ALEXANDER & BALDWIN TO BUY TWO SHIPS
description: Alexander & Baldwin Inc., a shipping and real estate company, said its Matson Navigation unit ordered two diesel-powered container ships for $220 million to replace 30-year-old steam-powered vessels. Matson expects to add one of the new ships to its Hawaii fleet late next year and the other in 2004. The ships, which will be built by the Kvaerner Philadelphia Shipyard unit of Kvaerner of Norway, will be faster, more reliable and more fuel efficient than the old vessels and will cost less to operate, said Alexander & Baldwin, which is based in Honolulu.

title: Excerpts From Director's Briefing on Plans to Transform the Bureau
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference yesterday at which Director Robert S. Mueller III of the Federal Bureau of Investigation discussed plans to transform the bureau, as recorded by the Federal News Service Inc. A full transcript of the news conference, which included comments by Attorney General John Ashcroft, is online at nytimes.com/national.

title: HILTON EXPECTS SECOND-QUARTER REVENUE TO FALL 5%
description: Hilton Hotels said its room revenue would fall 5 percent in the second quarter, a further sign that the industry's recovery will be delayed until business travel picks up. Revenue per available room, a measure of average occupancy and room rates, will fall more than the decline of 1 percent to 2 percent Hilton forecast in April, said Marc Grossman, a spokesman. Marriott International Inc., the largest hotel company in the country, said last week that its room revenue might fall as much as 7 percent in the quarter, on the lower end of previous estimates. Revenue per room for hotels in the United States fell in five of the last six weeks, according to Smith Travel Research.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, FRANCIS BRANDT
description: KELLY-Francis Brandt. Of Beverly Hills, Florida. Born in New York City died on Saturday, May 18, 2002. Former employee of The New York Times until 1989. He served in the United States Army Air Force during the Korean War. Survivors are his wife Ann, three daughters, Judith Kelly, Barbara Braithwaite and Muriel KellyCharboneau and granddaughter, Ariana Braithwaite.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Ex-Chief May Run For Council
description: Bernard C. Parks, who was denied a second term as police chief, filed papers announcing his intent to raise money and run for the Los Angeles City Council. Mr. Parks, who is black, is one of nine candidates who have said they expect to run in March for a seat in a heavily black and Latino neighborhood that has long been held by black politicians. James Sterngold (NYT)

title: Versatile Projector From Dell Offers Portability at a Low Price
description: Dell Computer's latest foray beyond its core PC market is into portable projectors. While such machines are used mostly for business presentations, a growing number are being pressed into service in home theaters. Unlike the standard home theater units, most of which are fixed, the portables can easily be carried from room to room or even outdoors.

title: Down to Raucous Wire, Osbournes Ink MTV Deal
description: The negotiations over "The Osbournes," MTV's biggest hit series ever, turned out to be every bit as bizarre as the series itself, featuring such plot developments as demands by the Osbournes for a new house and lifetime psychotherapy for the family's herd of cats and dogs; promises by the Osbournes to sign the contracts in blood; and offers from competing networks looking to steal the show away from MTV.

title: Hispanic networks hone an edge in a race for TV ad dollars.
description: AS advertisers begin deciding where to spend more than $7 billion for commercial time ahead of the fall television season, some networks are feeling less anxious than their competitors, and not because they have prescriptions for extra-strength Xanax.

title: Doing for Native Blooms What Johnny Did for Apples
description: ASK William Cullina about the future of gardening, and he will give a one-word answer, ''natives,'' the way the word ''plastics'' was delivered in ''The Graduate.'' Native plants have given him a career, and the subject of his two books. They have also been the focus of Garden in the Woods, a public garden here that displays the largest landscaped collection of native plants in the Northeast. It is here that Mr. Cullina now works.

title: The Body Scan, for Good or Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: Peca Likely to Need Next 6 Months Off
description: Michael Peca, the Islanders' center and captain, is expected to spend the next six months recovering from reconstructive surgery performed yesterday on his left knee.

title: Chrtien Vies With Critics as Scandals Multiply
description: TORONTO, May 29  Struggling to contain the worst ethics controversy to face his party in years, Prime Minister Jean Chretien has in recent days frozen dozens of government contracts, reorganized his cabinet and issued new rules on political donations and conflicts of interest.

title: Pakistan Asks U.N. Council For Action On Kashmir
description: Pakistan renewed a call today for Security Council action on Kashmir, where a United Nations-sponsored plebiscite to determine the future of the region has been stalled for more than half a century by India.

title: Kasparaitis May Not Stay in Colorado
description: DENVER, May 29  In the combat of a hockey game, Darius Kasparaitis of the Colorado Avalanche may actually pull an opponent's leg  or his arm or his head or his stick. He is a rugged defenseman for a team that held a 3-2 lead in the four-of-seven-game Western Conference finals against the Detroit Red Wings going into Game 6 tonight at the Pepsi Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOOTENBERG, LORRAINE
description: GOOTENBERG - Lorraine. The William B. May Company deeply mourns the loss of its dear friend and esteemed colleague. Lorraine was loved and respected by all who were privileged to work with her. Her courage and determination continue to be an inspiration to us all. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family. Peter R. Marra, President

title: Debuts Keep the Balanchine Repertory Young
description: Although the New York City Ballet is emphasizing new productions this season, it still appears to be paying careful attention to its basic repertory of works by George Balanchine. The dancers in its all-Balanchine program on May 17 at the New York State Theater were satisfying for both their technical skills and their interpretative nuances.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dynegy Chief Much Richer For Being Forced Out

title: Moving To Catch A Muse
description: MOST people writing a memoir visit their hometown to refresh their memories. Most people are not Bob Smith. In order to write ''Hamlet's Dresser,'' the 60-year-old self-described ''intensity junkie'' sold the contents of his Brooklyn Heights apartment, moved back here six years ago and furnished a house from scratch.

title: U. of Iowa's Chief Takes Helm at Michigan
description: Mary Sue Coleman, president of the University of Iowa, has been chosen the new president at Michigan, one of the nation's largest and most selective public universities. She succeeds Lee C. Bollinger, who moved to Columbia University as president this year.

title: HANSON BUYS PIPE MAKER FOR $135 MILLION
description: Hanson P.L.C., the world's largest producer of crushed rock used in construction, said yesterday that it bought Choctaw Inc., a concrete pipe maker based in Memphis, for $135 million. Choctaw, which also makes steel pipes, operates 17 production plants in the South, with sales of $92.3 million in the year that ended last June. Hanson, which is based in London, bought it from the building products group Amatek Holdings Ltd. Christopher Collins, Hanson's chairman, said earlier this month that the company would channel some of its profits into North American expansion. Choctaw will be merged into the Dallas-based Hanson Pipe and Products.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: China Rebuffed On Refugees
description: The Foreign Ministry rejected China's demands to surrender four North Koreans who have sought asylum in the South Korean embassy in Beijing. It said saying China should treat them as it had 38 North Korean refugees who have recently entered embassies or consulates of other countries and were permitted to leave China. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Wrong Way on Energy
description: An administration staffed with aggressive corporate executives might normally be expected to embrace cutting-edge solutions to the country's energy problems -- especially when those solutions are accessible and affordable. Yet such is the Bush administration's ideological suspicion of anything resembling top-down government that it recoils from using timely federal regulation to encourage technological advance. The obvious example has been its reluctance to pressure Detroit for more fuel-efficient vehicles. A more recent example is its decision last week to roll back Clinton-era energy efficiency standards for air-conditioners. Seven states have sued to reverse the decision, and one of them, California, is seeking to impose its own, stricter standards. That is a course that New York's governor, George Pataki, should consider.

title: An Era Approaches Its Coda
description: Kurt Masur arrived at the New York Philharmonic in 1991 as an unapologetic conductor of the old school: authoritarian, exacting, caustic when dissatisfied and stinting with praise. The musicians were shaken by the German maestro's demanding ways. But before long they accepted Mr. Masur's tough love. They knew they needed him.

title: Deal in Drug Software
description: ATLANTA, May 29 (Bloomberg News)  The NDCHealth Corporation has bought a controlling interest in the pharmacy-software developer TechRx Inc. for $52 million and paid Arclight Systems $81 million for pharmacy claims-processing software, expanding its automated prescription-drug processing services. The company said that it paid $40 million in cash and $12 million in stock to increase its stake in the closely held TechRx, and paid cash for some assets of the closely held Arclight's ScriptLINE business.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Sentences In Deliveryman Murder
description: The case against five teenagers accused of murdering a Queens deliveryman in 2000 ended yesterday with the sentencing of the last two defendants. Stacy Royster, 19, the only girl among the four teenagers and the one who admitted ordering the food to lure the deliveryman to an abandoned house, received a 17-year sentence. Jamel Murphy, 19, who testified against the others, received an 11-year sentence. All five teenagers had pleaded guilty, four to first-degree robbery and one to second-degree murder, after admitting a plan to steal $65 worth of Chinese food from Jin-Sheng Liu, 44, who was bludgeoned to death with a brick. Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

title: Delicacies and Divertissements: A Sampler Set to Tchaikovsky
description: American Ballet Theater reopened its box of choreographic pastries on Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House by once again offering its program of little goodies to music by Tchaikovsky. Several unreviewed dancers appeared in the presentation, which emphasized excerpts from longer pieces.

title: Technology Briefing: Internet
description: LESS COMPENSATION FOR DELL CHIEF Compensa- tion for Michael Dell, left, chairman and chief executive of the Dell Computer Corporation , fell sharply in fiscal 2002, according to documents filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Dell, who founded the company in 1984, chose to be given discounted options for 307,000 Dell shares, valued at $4.7 million, in lieu of a $347,000 cash bonus, on top of an annual salary of $925,962 in the fiscal year that ended Feb. 1. That compares with a bonus of $1.7 million, taken in the form of stock options, the previous fiscal year. As part of his salary, Mr. Dell also received stock options on 1 million common shares, down from 1.25 million a year ago. (AP)

title: Life Since Sept. 11
description: This week, Debates comprises posts from the Life Since Sept. 11 forum.

title: Victims of Terror, 16 Years Apart
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; A boardroom battle at the expense of shareholders.
description: BOARDROOM brawls are usually kept discreetly private, with the losers ''resigning to pursue other interests'' or something equally unilluminating.

title: National Briefing: South
description: GEORGIA: SUIT DISMISSED AGAINST GERALDO RIVERA The United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit, in Atlanta, dismissed a libel suit against Geraldo Rivera arising from an interview with an anti-abortion campaigner on CNBC. The man, Neal Horsley, operated a Web site that listed abortion doctors, crossing out their names after they were killed. Mr. Rivera called Mr. Horsley "an accomplice to homicide." The court ruled that the statement was rhetorical hyperbole protected by the First Amendment. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Almost as Promised, Burberry Stock Sale Advances
description: A bit late but otherwise keeping a promise made 18 months ago, GUS P.L.C., a British retailer that owns the Burberry fashion house, said today that it would sell as much as a quarter of Burberry to the public by the middle of July in an initial stock offering.

title: Israelis Bury 6 Terror Victims as Angry Cabinet Meets
description: In grief and rage today, this Israeli settlement buried its first-born, Netanel Reahim, a 17-year-old yeshiva student in what he believed to be the land of Israel who was killed by a Palestinian gunman who believed the land was his.

title: Subway Train Kills Man Who Fell Onto Tracks
description: A 54-year-old mechanic who apparently fainted and fell off a subway platform yesterday morning was killed by a train, whose motorman was unable to stop despite the efforts of onlookers to alert him, the authorities said.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: European Commission Sets New Goals
description: The European Commission has set new targets for broadband Internet penetration in the European Union, especially in the public sector, Erkki Liikanen, the commissioner for enterprise and the information society, said yesterday. But he warned there would be little extra money to help finance the introduction of high-speed Internet distribution. In a paper titled ''E-Europe 2005,'' the commission has called for the 15 member states of the union to have broadband connections for all public administrations by 2005.

title: Sitting Pretty in New Jersey: 200 New Rail Cars
description: Hoping to ease the overcrowding that has become a reality of commuting since Sept. 11, New Jersey Transit officials announced today that they would add new rail cars and expand schedules on Manhattan-bound trains so that riders can find a seat.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Stamford: Big Client For Giuliani's Company
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani's consulting company has taken on Purdue Pharma, a pharmaceutical manufacturer in Stamford that has hired the firm to help it detect abuse of its drugs. Purdue Pharma makes the prescription pain reliever OxyContin, which has become a popular street drug. Giuliani Partners is organizing an independent panel of experts and establishing monitoring technology for Purdue Pharma. In addition, Bernard B. Kerik, the former police commissioner who is the senior vice president of Giuliani Partners, is examining security at Purdue Pharma's main manufacturing plant in Totowa, N.J. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Memphis Rolls the Dice by Taking Tyson-Lewis Fight
description: MEMPHIS, May 26  To a national identity that comes from Elvis Presley, the blues and barbecue, local political and business leaders are hoping to add something new: boxing.

title: Putting the Full Spotlight on Three Young Artists
description: The Young Concert Artists season ended on May 22 at Alice Tully Hall with a concert of concertos, featuring three of the organization's recent beneficiaries.

title: Less Spraying for West Nile Virus This Year
description: The Bloomberg administration will spray insecticide to kill adult mosquitoes this year only if health officials find birds that have died from the West Nile virus or if the virus is detected in a set number of mosquitoes.

title: City Seeks to Oust Church's Homeless Camp
description: Arguing that a homeless haven outside a Fifth Avenue church had become a nightly nuisance, City Hall asked the United States Court of Appeals in Manhattan yesterday to lift a ban on using the police force to roust the homeless from the site.

title: Libya's Incomplete Amends
description: Libya's unofficial offer to pay $2.7 billion to the families of the 270 people killed in the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, though denied yesterday by Libya's state news agency, could turn out to be genuine. If so, it would be more than a theatrical gesture by Libya's flamboyant ruler, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. For the past several years Tripoli has been trying, in an erratic and incomplete way, to meet the conditions demanded by the United Nations for permanent removal of the economic sanctions imposed after Lockerbie as well as those imposed by Washington for terrorist offenses in the 1970's and 1980's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERGOLIZZI, ROSE M.
description: PERGOLIZZI-Rose M. On May 26, 2002. Beloved mother of Frank. Reposing Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Thursday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Patrick's Cathedral, Friday 10AM. Entombment St. John's

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSTNER, AUDREY S.
description: GERSTNER-Audrey S., 95. On May 26. Mother of Judith Gutmann and John Israel. Memorial service will be held on Sunday, June 2, at Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Avenue, Larchmont, NY, at 1 PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to Sarah Neuman Center, 845 Palmer Ave., Mamaroneck, New York 10543.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Missing Cyanide Found
description: The army said most of a 10-ton shipment of sodium cyanide stolen 18 days ago had been recovered on a rural road 80 miles north of Mexico City. Six drums of the poison, weighing about 1,200 pounds, are still missing. The hijacking of the truck carrying the cyanide spurred fears of terrorism but federal authorities said they believed the theft was a common crime. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Airship Maker Struggle
description: CargoLifter A.G., which has raised and spent nearly $300 million to develop giant helium-filled dirigibles, said it could no longer pay its bills and would have to declare bankruptcy if it failed to raise new money within three weeks. CargoLifter's cash reserves have evaporated in the last year, and the company has repeatedly been unable to attract new investors. Boeing has expressed interest in Cargolifter's technology, but has not signaled any imminent interest in investing.

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: Governor Appeals For Drought Relief
description: Gov. Angus King is appealing the federal government's refusal to give disaster relief to families affected by a persistent drought. Governor King, an independent, cited the drought's economic effect and said at least 1,500 families had reported going without running water. ''Our water-rich state is experiencing an unprecedented disaster,'' the governor wrote to the Federal Emergency Management Agency. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRARY, CALVERT H.
description: CRARY-Calvert H. Of Kendal at Hanover, NH, died on May 29, 2002. Age 94. He is survived by his wife, Pamela and his children Susan C. Strubel, Caroline C. Nordmann and Calvert D. Crary and by eight grandchildren. His former wife Catherine Snell died in 1974. He was a graduate of Amherst College and Harvard Business School. He had served as Senior Vice President of Legg Mason Wood Walker, Inc. and previously resided in Scarsdale, NY. A memorial service will be held at a date to be announced.

title: In Gaza Hotel, Bombers and Antibombers Discuss Democracy
description: Leaders of the militant group Hamas, known of late for their defense of suicide bombing, were talking about the importance of free elections. The head of the Palestinian intelligence service was going on about the need for accountability in government.

title: Beverly Brown, 61, Modern-Dance Choreographer
description: Beverly Brown, a modern-dance choreographer and longtime lead performer with the Erick Hawkins Dance Company, died on May 17 in Kansas City, Mo. She was 61. A longtime resident of Manhattan, Ms. Brown moved to Kansas City two months before her death.

title: Van Horn Gets Chance to Show Fire
description: Continental Arena was already starting to shake when Keith Van Horn caught the ball outside the arc midway through the fourth quarter and fired in a 3-point field goal. He raised his arms, inciting the crowd, and when the Nets raced upcourt the next time, he was waving his arms again, this time imploring Jason Kidd to give him the ball again.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Battling Invasive Plants

title: Moving to Catch a Muse
description: STRATFORD, Conn.  Most people writing a memoir visit their hometown to refresh their memories. Most people are not Bob Smith. In order to write "Hamlet's Dresser," the 60-year-old self-described "intensity junkie" sold the contents of his Brooklyn Heights apartment, moved back here six years ago and furnished a house from scratch.

title: Beyond Diego Rivera: Latin American Art and Its Avant-Garde
description: To those only casually acquainted with it, Latin American art may call to mind Pre-Columbian artifacts, folk art or the figurative tradition represented by Diego Rivera and his colleagues, with scant attention to the region's relationship to modern European and North American avant-garde movements.

title: Gifts of Gauguins and Other Art for Chicago Museum
description: A collection of 41 drawings, watercolors and other works on paper by the Post-Impressionist Paul Gauguin is among a trove of art that has been donated to the Art Institute of Chicago.

title: INSIDE
description: Osbournes Returning to TV

title: Energy Trader Plans Layoffs
description: The El Paso Corporation, the natural gas pipeline owner, reduced its profit forecast today, and announced plans to lay off about 300 employees in its trading unit and to sell assets and $1.5 billion in stock to raise cash and trim debt.

title: Going Where Vegas Wouldn't
description: To a national identity that comes from Elvis Presley, the blues and barbecue, local political and business leaders are hoping to add something new: boxing.

title: Next Anchor For NBC News Not Drawing Big Audiences
description: Each night at 8 Eastern time, about 322,000 people settle in to watch ''The News With Brian Williams'' on MSNBC -- a small audience even by the slight ratings standards of cable.

title: South African Breweries Near a Deal to Buy Miller
description: The boards of South African Breweries and the Philip Morris Companies met separately today to vote on an agreement that would allow South African Breweries to buy two-thirds of the Miller Brewing Company for about $3 billion in stock, people close to the companies said.

title: Carbon Fiber, From Fighter Jets To Tables, Chairs and Lamps
description: ''If a material could be a superhero, carbon fiber would be it,'' Giovanni Pagnotta said. Mr. Pagnotta, below, was born in Italy and went to Yale to study architecture on an Eero Saarinen scholarship for design excellence. His new Prototype line of furniture uses the carbon fiber material normally used in the manufacture of fighter jets to form lithe tables, chairs and a cordless lighting system, above. The complex process involves weaving the fibers, much like cloth, into a type of twill, then baking them with an epoxy resin. The intended effect, he said, is that of a scarf frozen as it falls gently through space. Such complexity comes at a high price. The lamps, which last 40 to 50 hours on one eight-hour charge, are $8,000 apiece. Issey Miyake liked the new line enough to show it at his TriBeCa store. Other pieces can be seen at giovannipagnotta.com;for information on ordering, (914) 935-1490.

title: Shortage of Nurses Hurts Patient Care, Study Finds
description: In hospitals with low numbers of registered nurses, patients are more likely to suffer complications like urinary infections and pneumonia, to stay in the hospital longer and to die from treatable conditions like shock or gastrointestinal bleeding, researchers report today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIEN, ROBERT L.
description: BIEN-Robert L. Distinguished architect. Our loyal friend of 35 years & co-worker. Our sympathy to his wife of 58 years, Lynn; daughter, Deborah; grandchildren, Jocelyn and Robert; sister, Phyllis McGovern; brother-in-law, Pete; nephews, Michael and Scott. We will forever miss his professionalism, wise counsel and genuine sense of humor. Memorial Service at St. George Episcopal Church 3rd Avenue and 16th Street, noon, Tuesday, June 4, 2002. Staff of Allan Riley Co. Inc.

title: On Taliban's Old Turf, A Campaign of Disruption
description: Barefoot and shackled, a former Taliban loyalist stepped from his cell to discuss his part in the killing of four soldiers in what Afghan officials say was an attack on the political process of choosing a new government for Afghanistan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, ALEX
description: MITCHELL-Alex. Devoted widower, father and grandfather, died peacefully at home with his family on Tuesday, May 28, 2002. His loyalty, compassion and determination will be greatly missed. Mr. Mitchell was owner and CEO of Parkell Inc., a manufacturer of dental products. Services will be held Thursday, May 30 at 10:00 AM at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY. Private burial has been arranged. Donations may be made in his memory to Cancer Research Institute, United Jewish Appeal and Baruch College.

title: Halliburton And Inquiry By the S.E.C.
description: The Halliburton Company -- which disclosed Tuesday that it was under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission for a change in its accounting practices in 1998, while Vice President Dick Cheney was its chief executive -- adopted more aggressive policies last year about recording sales and postponing potential losses.

title: Diplomats Are Flocking to Israel, but No Peace Plan Seems in Sight
description: JERUSALEM, May 30  A covey of diplomats began arriving here today in renewed efforts to find a way out of the increasingly violent struggle between Israel and the Palestinians, although no one seemed to have any concrete idea of how to break the impasse.

title: Americans Playing in Israel Face Their Fears
description: Ryan Stack is 6 feet 11 inches and a force in the paint, and he played two years with the Cleveland Cavaliers. That is why Ironi Ramat Gan, a team in the Israeli Premier League, wanted him. But Stack didn't want Ironi Ramat Gan or anything to do with playing basketball in a country where political tensions and fears of suicide bombings are unfortunate parts of daily existence. Not, at least, when his phone first rang.

title: In Old Austria, The Shock Of the New
description: THE architects Christian Jabornegg and Andras Palffy sat outside a coffee house in the Judenplatz here this month talking about the granite paving stones under their feet. As the eye travels toward the center of the square, they explained, the stones grow slightly larger. It is a subtle game of forced perspective --the kind of understated game they are known for.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLENBACH, FRANK J.
description: HOLLENBACH-Frank J. On May 28, age 85, predeceased by his beloved wife, Eleanor. Survived by his loving children, Doris, Paul, John, Kenneth, and Catherine. Also survived by five cherished grandchildren and his dear sister, Mary, and brother, Bob. Frank was a decorated veteran of WW II. Visiting at the Oyster Bay Funeral Home, 261 South St., Oyster Bay, Long Island 11771 on Thursday, 7-9 PM, and Friday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. There will be a service at the First Presbyterian Church, Saturday at 10 AM. A private interment in Pennsylvania will be held at later date. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Cumberland College, 6191 College Station Drive, Williamsburg, KY. 40769-1372.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Labor Dispute Ends Quickly
description: A 72-hour strike called by nearly 100,000 municipal workers in Mexico City ended after just one day as unions reached agreement with the city government on most of the issues dividing them. The strike had halted garbage collection, street cleaning and other services in the city, home to nearly 20 million people, creating health and safety concerns. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Output Edges Higher
description: Japanese industrial production rose in April, the third consecutive monthly gain, confirming that the economy is slowly pulling out of recession. Output grew an expected 0.2 percent compared with March, thanks to growing demand for Japanese products overseas. The April figure was less than economists expected, but the government forecasts a 5.1 percent surge in May. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Bosnia Tries to Stitch Its Unwieldy Fabric Back Together
description: When classes break at the two elementary schools in this ethnically mixed village in central Bosnia, children from both schools play on the same strip of gravel. But not with each other.

title: E-Diaries (Tap, Tap) Aid Drug Trials
description: AFTER 10 years as a research psychiatrist, Margaret Spinelli is used to having an office stuffed with paper, which fills every cabinet, closet and shelf.

title: Johnson at Ease With Move From Coach to Manager
description: HOWARD JOHNSON has vivid memories of the managers he liked and disliked in his 14-year big league career. He hopes to imitate the good and learn from what he considered the bad as he moves from hitting coach to skipper of the Brooklyn Cyclones, the Mets' short-season Class A affiliate.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Monday about the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music this fall misstated the origins of ''Galileo Galilei,'' a new opera by Philip Glass and Mary Zimmerman. It is based on Galileo's letters and other historic documents, not on Dava Sobel's book ''Galileo's Daughter.''

title: Peace Plan In Boulder Bans Sofas On Porches
description: The college tradition of lounging on old couches in the open air may become a mere memory here, at least if students want to avoid jail.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: STAMFORD: BIG CLIENT FOR GIULIANI'S COMPANY Rudolph W. Giuliani's consulting company has taken on Purdue Pharma, a pharmaceutical manufacturer in Stamford that has hired the firm to help it detect abuse of its drugs. Purdue Pharma makes the prescription pain reliever OxyContin, which has become a popular street drug. Giuliani Partners is organizing an independent panel of experts and establishing monitoring technology for Purdue Pharma. In addition, Bernard B. Kerik, the former police commissioner who is the senior vice president of Giuliani Partners, is examining security at Purdue Pharma's main manufacturing plant in Totowa, N.J. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: NORTEL TO CUT 3,500 MORE JOBS North America's second-biggest maker of telephone equipment, Nortel Networks , said yesterday that it would cut 3,500 more jobs and might sell its optical-parts business amid new projections of flat to lower second-quarter sales. Nortel, which has cut about 50,000 jobs since the beginning of last year, now expects its work force to bottom out at 42,000. The company said it did not expect a meaningful recovery in the long-haul optical market before late 2003 or early 2004. The company said that the measures would help reduce the amount of quarterly sales it needed to break even, to $3.2 billion from $3.5 billion. Second-quarter sales will be unchanged to as much as 5 percent lower. Nortel's primary customers  mainly the big telephone carriers  continue to cut spending to deal with financial difficulties of their own. Shares in Nortel fell 17 cents, to $2.35.

title: The G.O.P. Is Confident, Maybe Too Confident, About the Race
description: The consensus among Republicans as they wrapped up their convention yesterday is that George E. Pataki is a juggernaut on course to become the fourth New York governor in a century to win a third term. His approval ratings are higher than ever, even among Democrats, and his war chest is brimming with at least $16 million, twice what either of his two Democratic opponents has raised.

title: GEMSTAR-TV GUIDE TO BUY DIGITAL VIDEO COMPANY
description: Gemstar-TV Guide International Inc. said yesterday that it agreed to acquire the assets of the Diva Systems Corporation. Diva, a provider of digital video systems, has filed for Chapter 11 protection in United States Bankruptcy Court for the Northern District of California. Diva, which is privately held, is based in Redwood City, Calif. Gemstar, the publisher of the TV Guide magazine, said it would integrate certain Diva technology into its interactive TV guide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WACHTEL, ELISABETH (KLEBANOFF)
description: WACHTEL-Elisabeth (Klebanoff). We mourn this tragic and untimely loss. Elisabeth's wit and friendship will be greatly missed. Our heartfelt condolences to her husband, daughter and family. Howard and Patty Silverstein

title: National Briefing | West: California: Nurse Wins Back Pay In Rights Case
description: A federal jury ordered a Riverside County public health clinic to pay $47,000 to a nurse who was fired for refusing to dispense ''morning-after'' contraceptives. The nurse, Michelle Diaz, said that dispensing the pills would violate her religious beliefs. The jury found that the clinic had violated her civil rights. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Pataki Outlines Glowing Vision and Ignores Rivals
description: Utterly ignoring his two prospective Democratic opponents in the race for governor, Gov. George E. Pataki embraced the unanimous support of the New York State Republican Party in his bid for a third term yesterday, setting out a sunny if vague vision of where he wanted to take his state should he win re-election this November.

title: Chief of Effort For TV Tower Is Dismissed, Signaling Shift
description: Signaling a shift in strategy, New York television station managers have dismissed the man they had hired to lead their coalition's efforts to build a television tower to replace the antenna destroyed at the World Trade Center, according to several executives involved in the discussions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ETTER, RUSSELL FORREST
description: ETTER-Russell Forrest. Born Grosse Pointe, MI, on August 15, 1933. Died in Athens, Greece, on May 15, 2002. Wayne State University 1955. Fulbright Scholar, Milan, Italy. Graphic arts-Arnold Saks Associates. International collage artist. Resided upstate New York and Naxos, Greece.

title: Data Is Found To Be Lacking On Reactions Of Chemicals
description: In a review of 167 industrial accidents since 1980 in which chemical reactions caused deaths, injuries or serious damage, federal safety experts have found that more than half involved substances that are not regulated by worker safety and environmental agencies.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: New Dome Owner
description: London's hapless Millennium Dome has finally found a new owner. Lord Falconer, the minister responsible for the dome, which became a national embarrassment soon after it opened on New Year's Eve 1999, told the House of Lords that the site would be turned over to a consortium that includes the Anschutz Entertainment Group, controlled by the billionaire Philip F. Anschutz, whose holdings include a stake in the Los Angeles Lakers basketball team. Themed exhibits will be replaced by a 20,000-seat sports and entertainment complex. The government is hoping that getting a share of the complex's future revenue will let it recoup some of the $898 million of taxpayer money invested in the project. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Bush Sending Rumsfeld to Ease Tensions of India and Pakistan
description: WASHINGTON, May 30  President Bush said today that he would send Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld to India and Pakistan next week to try to head off war between the two nuclear powers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 13 about the Hindu nationalist movement in India referred imprecisely to the relationship between the Vishwa Hindu Parishad of America, a private nonprofit Hindu expatriate organization, and the World Hindu Council in India. The groups share a vision for Hindu nationalism and the American group raises money to support World Hindu Council programs, but the American organization is not a branch of the world council.

title: CUMMINS SHARES DROP ON GENERATOR SALES CONCERNS
description: Shares of Cummins Inc. fell 4.5 percent on concern that demand for power generators and truck engines would be lower than expected. The stock of the largest maker of heavy-duty diesel engines fell $1.49, to $37.91, its biggest one-day decline in six weeks. Andrew Casey, an analyst for Prudential Securities, lowered his 2002 earnings estimate to 28 cents a share from 70 cents. Truck dealers reduced projections for a fourth-quarter rise in engine prices to 15 percent from as much as 35 percent, lowering projected revenue for Cummins, Mr. Casey said. The higher prices will result from new federal requirements to cut pollution.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: G.M. Drops Michelin
description: General Motors, which is pressing suppliers to cut costs, said it had dropped Michelin as a provider of premium tires in Europe because the French company's products are too expensive. Michelin said it decided not to renew the agreement. General Motors still has contracts with Michelin in the United States, which last until 2006 and 2007. Michelin makes about one-fifth of the world's tires. Continental A.G. said it would take over part of the contract to supply tires to General Motors' European division.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: Driver Charged In McDonald's Deaths
description: The man who the police say smashed his car through a McDonald's restaurant this month, killing three employees, was charged yesterday with aggravated manslaughter. Prosecutors say the man, Frank R. Nastasi, 52, of Haddon Heights, was trying to commit suicide when his car jumped the curb in front of the McDonald's in Mount Ephraim and plowed through to the back of the restaurant. Joanne Bowen, 52, and Cindy Molino, 45, both of Mount Ephraim, and Nancy King, 49, of Audubon, were killed. Mr. Nastasi, who was in critical condition after the crash, survived.

title: Bright Enough to See Your Menu and Dinner Guest
description: The owners of That Bar, including Lincoln Clark, its designer and builder, decided that Smith Street in Brooklyn, already full of bars and bistros, needed something more hip, conceptual and gay. Their translation: something that offered brunch food all night, great lighting and cocktails like the archly named Tai Mai Up. The interior features a shellacked concrete bar and sliding frosted-glass cabinet doors with exposed rollers, above right. Near the windows are Zelda lamps, above left, made from Imago, a material from Knoll Textiles composed of fabric sandwiched between sheets of resin. The lamps, from 100 Watts in SoHo (www.100watt.net; $695 each), were so crucial that the opening was delayed until they were ready. Completing the dcor are a kitschy waterfall mirror in the bathroom and an outdoor garden. That Bar, 116 Smith Street; (718) 260-8900.

title: Squalid Dead End for Migrants' Hopes
description: FUERTEVENTURA, Canary Islands  There are two arrival lounges at the airport in Fuerteventura, an arid island in the turquoise waters of the Atlantic off Africa, where the long, sandy beaches attract tens thousands of visitors every year.

title: Georgia Senior Wins Third Hammer Title
description: In a dramatic last-round finish, Andras Haklits, a University of Georgia senior from Hungary, won the men's hammer throw for the third time at the N.C.A.A. outdoor championships in Baton Rouge, La., yesterday.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: President Rejects Talks With U.S.
description: The country's reformist president rejected talks with the United States and called on Parliament to submit to policies decided by the country's supreme religious leader. President Mohammad Khatami said that the possibility of talks could not be considered ''when a power uses bellicose and threatening tone against us.'' Parliament, which is dominated by reformers, has begun a campaign to negotiate with Washington to ease 23 years of tension, but the religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, has denounced the efforts. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Women, 79 and 77, Are Charged in Drug Sales
description: For months, neighbors said, there had been a suspicious amount of teenage traffic in the first- and fourth-floor hallways of 125 Brighton 11th Street in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, a high-rise populated largely by elderly Russian-Americans.

title: Outside U.N., A Secretary So Social; Annan's Diplomacy Extends Into the Night
description: He has a daytime job like no other in the world -- and now, the evening hours to go with it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOWBIN, MOLLY GRINGER
description: TOWBIN-Molly Gringer. Age 87, passed away in Rancho Santa Fe, California, May 27. A frequent contributor to the Metropolitan Diary column of The New York Times. Widow of Carter A. Towbin. Loving mother of Marion Fredi Daitch. Grandmother of David Daitch and mother-in-law of Fred Daitch. Loving sister of Jerry Gringer and sister-in-law of A. Robert Towbin and deceased Belmont, Phoebe and Jess Towbin. Funeral private.

title: Sex Sells, but Can It Sell a Museum?
description: For about five years, Daniel Gluck has been consumed with opening a Museum of Sex in New York, what he saw as a sort of ''Smithsonian of sex'' that would allow some serious study of the subject and also be a pretty interesting place to visit.

title: Down to Raucous Wire, Osbournes in MTV Deal
description: The Osbournes, stars of the most surprising success on television this year, agreed to terms of a new contract with MTV yesterday that will extend for at least 20 more episodes the real-life adventures of the raucous, crude-talking family headed by the longtime rocker Ozzy Osbourne.

title: Giants Preparing for Changes
description: Giants tailback Tiki Barber, who was drafted five years ago, glanced around at teammates during the first veteran minicamp workout today and mentioned with astonishment that there were only a few players who had been around longer than him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIGGINS, EDWARD J.
description: HIGGINS-Edward J. 63, of New Canaan, Ct. died suddenly but peacefully watching the sunset on May 24, while vacationing in Hawaii with his wife Mary and eldest son Bartley. Widowed by Margot Brill in 1974, he was blessed to share his heart with beloved wife Mary Bailey for the last 24 years. Devoted and adored father of Margot, Bartley and Charlie, Ed is remembered fondly for the wisdom, charm and unconditional love that he shared with others. He is also survived by his younger brother Peter. He was a graduate of both Lafayette College and Georgetown Law School, and president of his own investment firm, Higgins Advisory. He was actively involved in community affairs, serving on the boards of the New Canaan Inn and the New Canaan Community Foundation as its treasurer. An avid tennis player, he was a longtime member of the Meadow Club in Southampton, NY. Services will be held at 11am on Friday at St. Aloysius in New Canaan. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Capital Campaign Fund of the New Canaan YMCA. For information Hoyt Funeral Home, New Canaan, Ct.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Company To Sell Wetlands
description: In what could become the nation's largest wetlands restoration outside of the Florida Everglades, the Cargill Company has agreed to sell 16,500 acres of ponds around San Francisco Bay to the state and federal governments. Cargill will sell the ponds for $100 million, though the Manhattan-size area has been appraised at $243 million. Evelyn Nieves (NYT)

title: CALENDAR
description: Art in Brooklyn

title: A Big Screen Whose Footprint And Appetite Are Dainty
description: One oddity of flat-screen computer monitors is that they seem to be growing bigger even as they get smaller. Planar's large new monitor, which has an enormous 23.1-inch screen, takes up only 25 percent as much desk space (and consumes a quarter as much energy) as a 26-inch C.R.T. monitor with the same viewable screen size.

title: In Reshuffle Of Cabinet, Blair Chooses Black Official
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair today appointed the first black cabinet member in Britain's history as part of a reshuffle touched off by the resignation of Transport Secretary Stephen Byers, who saw a once-promising political career crumble over failures in the dilapidated rail and road network and after scandals among his staff.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Pataki's Wife To Appear In Tourism Ads
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has pledged not to appear in any more state advertisements before the November election, but two new tourism ads on radio feature his wife, Libby. ''This is not an ad; it's a public service announcement,'' said Michael McKeon, the governor's spokesman. The difference, he said, is that the state does not pay to broadcast them, but gives them to stations to use if they like. Mr. Pataki said this year that he would not appear in any state ads in the six months before the election -- a period that began three weeks ago. ''The broken promises just never end,'' said the state comptroller, H. Carl McCall, one of the Democrats running against the governor. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: Outside U.N., a Secretary So Social
description: He has a daytime job like no other in the world  and now, the evening hours to go with it.

title: The Body Scan, for Good or Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: Government Will Ease Limits On Domestic Spying by F.B.I.
description: As part of a sweeping effort to transform the F.B.I. into a domestic terrorism prevention agency, Attorney General John Ashcroft has decided to relax restrictions on the bureau's ability to conduct domestic spying in counterterrorism operations, senior government officials said today.

title: HOLDER FILES SUIT TO BLOCK NABORS MOVE TO BERMUDA
description: Nabors Industries, the nation's largest onshore oil and natural gas driller, said yesterday that a shareholder had sued to block the company's plan to move its headquarters to Bermuda. The lawsuit, which also seeks monetary damages, says Nabors misled investors about the risks of reorganizing overseas, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The suit was filed last week in United States District Court in Houston by Steven Rosenberg, a shareholder. Nabors, which is based in Houston, expects to vote on the move at a special shareholders' meeting June 14.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: ECHO OF THE COLD WAR Three former East German border guards went on trial for attempted murder in the shooting of a 14-year-old boy in 1962 as he tried to flee to West Germany. One defendant pleaded not guilty; the other two refused to address the judge. The boy was severely wounded as he swam across a Berlin canal but the West German police saved him after firing on their East German counterparts. Dozens of former border guards have been tried on similar charges since the fall of the Berlin wall in 1989.

title: U.S. Fund for Tower Victims Will Aid Some Gay Partners
description: Some of the gay men and lesbians who were partners of Sept. 11 victims are poised to collect substantial awards from the federal fund set up to compensate bereaved families, according to Kenneth R. Feinberg, special master of the fund, and lawyers familiar with the process.

title: Ceremony Without Words Ends Recovery Effort at Twin Towers
description: There were no prayers, no speeches, only the mournful ringing of a New York City fire department bell.

title: Reimagining the F.B.I.
description: Robert Mueller, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said many of the right things yesterday in outlining his plan to transform the crime-fighting organization into a counterterrorism force. He spoke of the need to redefine the bureau's purpose, to strengthen intelligence gathering and analysis, to divert money and manpower to preventing terrorist attacks. He acknowledged past failures and even thanked a dissident agent in Minneapolis for a scalding letter she recently sent him complaining about the bureau's mishandling of warnings last summer. Yet Mr. Mueller's reorganization plan falls short of the thorough overhaul that the agency clearly requires.

title: The Fun of Being Old Friends Playing Embattled Lovers
description: On a misty, decidedly English Sunday morning, Alan Rickman and Lindsay Duncan are sitting at a Manhattan theater district restaurant, looking anything but the high-toned sophisticates they play in the Broadway revival of Nol Coward's ''Private Lives.''

title: 2 Fighters Share Mutual Respect
description: Here was a news conference before a major heavyweight bout and everyone was so civil, it might have been mistaken for a lawn party.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Playing the Bad Cop on the African Tour
description: In his 16 months as treasury secretary, Paul H. O'Neill has developed a reputation as a straight shooter, in the view of his admirers, or a loose cannon, as his detractors see it.

title: Rock and the Queen to Celebrate Each Other
description: Rock 'n' roll may not be Her Majesty's cup of tea, but even Queen Elizabeth would probably concur that pop music has been Britain's main cultural ambassador during her 50-year reign. So to celebrate her Golden Jubilee, she has invited a few knights of the realm -- Sir Paul McCartney, Sir Elton John, Sir Cliff Richard -- and a score of their fellow rock 'n' rollers for a gig at the palace.

title: For an Arizona City, Wright Is Better Late Than Almost Never
description: Although Frank Lloyd Wright spent about half his time in Scottsdale, Ariz., the city has only one of his buildings -- Taliesin, his winter residence and home to the Frank Lloyd Wright School of Architecture. A new project will remedy that shortcoming. The Promenade (above right) will provide a visitors' center, offices and restaurants while serving as an enticing entrance to the city. A 125-foot spire, designed by Wright for the Arizona State Capitol in the 1950's but never built, will be the most prominent feature. (The drawing, above, is his original sketch.) The spire, made of latticed copper painted a verdigris color, is being constructed off-site and will be erected late this year. It will feature polycarbonate glazing and will be lighted from within. The remaining structures, some based on Wright's designs for a drive-through bank that was never built, are scheduled to be completed by fall. Approval for the construction was a bit of a ''community outreach project,'' said Arnold Roy, the Taliesin architect in charge of the project. Scottsdale has a height limit of 100 feet, and the tower exceeded that. The center, being built by the Pederson Group, will save the city from having another block of cookie-cutter retail stores (for which the area was originally zoned). In keeping with Wright's philosophy, the Promenade will include open space in which to celebrate the union of architecture and its environs.

title: Nets in Driver's Seat With Finals in Sight
description: The Nets may have bent and swayed tonight, but remembering their fateful collapse in Game 3, they sprang back undaunted, catapulting themselves onto the doorstep of a most unfamiliar place.

title: Josephine Abady, 52, Director Of Plays on and Off Broadway
description: Josephine R. Abady, a theater director who staged plays on and off Broadway and was a leader in the nonprofit theater movement, died on Saturday in her home in Manhattan. She lived in Manhattan and Stockbridge, Mass. She was 52.

title: AARP Joins Three Lawsuits Against Large Drug Companies
description: AARP joined three lawsuits against large drug companies today, saying the companies had kept prices artificially high and thwarted competition from lower-priced generic drugs in violation of federal antitrust laws.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLEIMER, SOL E., M.D.
description: GLEIMER-Sol E., M.D. Formerly of Brooklyn, died May 28, 2002. Husband of Rosalyn (nee Heyman), father of Ellen (Richard) Hustead and Dr. Barry (Ahuva) Gleimer, brother of Jack Gleimer, grandfather of Jeffrey Gleimer, Natali Gleimer, Evan Gleimer and Tessa Hustead. Funeral services Friday, 12:15 PM, Menorah Chapels, 2145 Richmond Avenue, Staten Island. Interment United Hebrew Cemetery. The family will return to the home of Dr. Barry and Ahuva Gleimer. Contributions may be made to Hadassah.
