description: An article on May 13 about the Hindu nationalist movement in India referred imprecisely to the relationship between the Vishwa Hindu Parishad of America, a private nonprofit Hindu expatriate organization, and the World Hindu Council in India. The groups share a vision for Hindu nationalism and the American group raises money to support World Hindu Council programs, but the American organization is not a branch of the world council.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Loss At Mobile Concern
description: Shares of MMO2, the mobile phone company spun off from the BT Group, declined about 12 percent, to 42.5 pence, after the company reported disappointing financial results for the year that ended March 31. Although MM02's net loss narrowed to 850 million ($1.24 billion), compared with a 3.5 billion loss last year, revenue grew slower than expected and customers in its home market of Britain spent less. Customers in Britain spent an average of 231 during the three months ended March 31. That is 8 percent less than the 251 they spent during the three months that ended June 30, 2001. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Limits Set On Paternity Challenges
description: The State Supreme Court set limits for challenges to paternity. In a unanimous ruling, the court said that a man who acknowledged his paternity in 1988 without blood tests could not years later seek genetic testing to prove that he was not the child's father. The court declared that all challenges to a court ruling establishing paternity must take place within six months of the ruling. The man, known by his initials, R.L.C., began to question the paternity in May 2000. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: From Where I Sit, the Commute Is Fine
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Self-Criticism and Its Risk
description: WASHINGTON, May 29  For nearly two hours today, Director Robert S. Mueller III delivered a painfully candid mea culpa for the embattled Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Official Says L.I. Should Have Plenty of Electricity This Summer
description: Each time the temperature spiked last summer, the chairman of the Long Island Power Authority issued a stern warning that without new power plants, there could be rolling blackouts. Today, he stood in front of a year-old power plant here, and next to two under construction, and announced that thanks to several new projects, Long Island's lights would in all likelihood remain on this summer.

title: Vision Festival Opens With Purpose and Poetry
description: The opening of the seventh annual Vision Festival last Thursday night at the Center in the East Village delivered both ends of the spectrum in free jazz: music conveying grandiose social ideals and flat realities, and music that quietly earned its special, hand-crafted feeling.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: OUTPUT EDGES HIGHER Japanese industrial production rose in April, the third consecutive monthly gain, confirming that the economy is slowly pulling out of recession. Output grew an expected 0.2 percent compared with March, thanks to growing demand for Japanese products overseas. The April figure was less than economists expected, but the government forecasts a 5.1 percent surge in May. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Youth Will Be Served, Wirelessly
description: JOSH BUESSELER, an industrial designer with spiked hair and half-inch-wide ear piercings, stood before a room filled with teenagers and flipped through a series of his sketches.

title: Metro Matters; The Home Of the Brave, Or the Timid?
description: NEW YORK glimpsed two versions of its future last week. We present them for your consideration, with no pretense of objectivity.

title: Western Companies Warm to Russia
description: The seals of approval are coming thick and fast for President Vladimir V. Putin's Russia these days.

title: 12 Bids? Goodbye, Old Rust Bucket
description: AT the risk of hurting my 1989 Honda Civic's feelings, let me remind you of how unsightly the car was.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, MARGARET
description: MILLER-Margaret. On May 29, 2002. Predeceased by her husband Samuel M. Miller and her son Peter Shaw. Loving mother of her sons Stuart R. and daughter-in-law Charlene and David Shaw, Denise Schure and son-in-law Louis; her grandchildren, Joshua, Julianna, Alec, Andre, Nina, Miriam, Elias, Stephen, and Jennifer and two great-grandchildren. Teacher and humanitarian. Services Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave, May 30th at 11 AM. Family will sit Shiva at her home at 5:30.

title: Custom-Made Sofas, Soft on Your Wallet
description: Looking for an economically priced traditional sofa? In Brooklyn, Nova Zembla offers custom-made sofas by Cisco Brothers, a Los Angeles manufacturer, at 30 percent less than at many stores. There are 60 styles of frames to choose from. The sofas can be upholstered or slip-covered, drawing on more than 2,000 fabrics, including wools, cottons, chenilles and leathers. There are three choices of cushion fillings. Prices vary, but expect a 60-inch love seat to start at $970 and an 84-inch sofa at $1,200. Many are available as sofa beds. All floor samples are on sale at a further 10 percent to 40 percent off. Nova Zembla is at 117 Atlantic Avenue (Henry Street); (718) 222-5705. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Bills Seek to Help Pedestrians Maneuver Down Sidewalks
description: A City Council committee took a step yesterday toward helping pedestrians, passing measures regulating bicycles and newspaper boxes on the city's increasingly congested sidewalks.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 10 about poor scores by American students on a national test in history referred incorrectly to the description of Helen Keller in the 1995 book ''Lies My Teacher Told Me: Everything Your American History Textbook Got Wrong,'' by James W. Loewen, a sociology professor. Keller, cited in the book as an example of the way textbooks drain historic figures of their complexity, openly supported the Communist revolution in Russia and was a member of the radical socialist Industrial Workers of the World. But the book did not say that she was a lifelong Communist. (She never joined the American Communist Party.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, DORIS A.
description: FRANK-Doris A. On May 28, 2002. Died peacefully at her home in Manhattan at the age of 93. Lifelong resident of New York City and Elberon, New Jersey. Predeceased by her adoring husband Richard L. Frank, Sr, M.D. and her son Richard L. Frank, Jr. She is survived by her daughter Linda Frank Sicher, four grandchildren Jennifer and Andrew Wilder, and Vali and Joel Frank. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions in her name may be made to the Nightingale Bamford School, 20 East 92nd Street, N.Y. N.Y. 10128. Family will be receiving at the home of Linda Sicher on Wednesday and on Thursday evening 5-8 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAUNDERS, DERO A.
description: SAUNDERS-Dero A. We mourn the loss of our distinguished life member. Writer, scholar, journalist and gentleman, Dero was wonderful company and a great conversationalist. His courtliness elevated the atmosphere of every hall he walked into. Our deepest sympathies to his wife, Beatrice, their son, Richard, and the family. A memorial service will be held at The Players, 16 Gramercy Park, on Thursday, June 13, at 5:30 PM. The Players

title: PLANNED MEETING ON MIDEAST PEACE MAY BE DELAYED
description: Bush administration officials said today that a conference on Middle East peace first planned for early summer now may be delayed until at least late summer, and that they had not even decided whether to propose a timetable for a final settlement.

title: Crashing PC's in Frankfurt, The Art World's New Bad Boys
description: Spread the word. A museum exhibition devoted to computer viruses opened last week at the Museum of Applied Arts in Frankfurt. But for visitors to the ''I Love You'' exhibition, which takes its name from the virus that zapped countless data files in 2000, the danger level is low. The only wild viruses being demonstrated are on a computer that is not online. Visitors can activate them and crash the computer. ''It's like a virus mantra,'' said Franziska Nori, director of the museum's digital-culture department. ''We constantly reboot, reboot, reboot.''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Back Taxes Sought
description: Japanese tax authorities are seeking as much as 7 billion yen ($56 million) in back taxes from some of Morgan Stanley's real estate funds based in the United States, according to local media reports. The funds, which are all registered in Delaware, invested in Japanese property in 1999 and 2000 and did not pay taxes on 18 billion yen in income, Yomiuri Shimbun reported. Morgan Stanley, a big buyer of nonperforming loans, said it had ''no dispute with the Tokyo tax authorities.'' The Tokyo Regional Taxation Bureau declined to comment. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Innocence Lost in a War-Weary World
description: Timeliness in a play is not generally something to complain about, but ''One Shot, One Kill'' by Richard Vetere at Primary Stages takes unsavory advantage of our current concern for national defense. It may not even be deliberate; I don't know whether the play was written before or after Sept. 11. The references to Osama bin Laden and the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon might be recent addenda. But in any case this is a moment when the sacrifices made by men and women for their country loom unassailable, and our sympathy for those who are willing to serve America ahead of their families, themselves or their consciences is fervent and instantaneous.

title: President Formally Seeks Halt to Crusader Artillery Program
description: President Bush took the first formal step late today toward terminating the Army's Crusader artillery program, sending Congress a request for a budget amendment that would reallocate all $475 million in proposed 2003 spending for that howitzer to Army weapons described as ''more transformational.''

title: Nets a Quick Study in Gaining Playoff Confidence
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 29  The Nets signed up for a crash course on playoff experience five weeks ago with little to guide them but their grit and their captain.

title: Al Qaeda Provoking War
description: The emergence of terrorism as a global threat has forced nation-states of the world to adopt a new view of sovereignty: If a governing body cannot stop terrorists victimizing others from its territory, then governments of the victims will reach across borders to do the necessary stopping.

title: Plan Sharply Tightens Airport Screening
description: A draft plan by the consultants advising the government on how to take over airport security calls for more thorough screening of selected travelers farther away from the airplanes, and a special card for prescreened frequent travelers that would allow them to pass more easily through security.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORNBERG, SAMUEL
description: KORNBERG-Samuel. The Officers, Members of the Board of Directors, Trustees and Staff of The Jewish Guild for the Blind are deeply saddened by the death of Samuel Kornberg, beloved father of Cheryl Lefkovits, former President of the Women's Division and longtime supporter of The Guild. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to the Kornberg family. Pauline Raiff, Chairman Alan R. Morse, President & CEO

title: World Briefing: Middle East
description: MIDDLE EAST IRAN: PRESIDENT REJECTS TALKS WITH U.S. The country's reformist president rejected talks with the United States and called on Parliament to submit to policies decided by the country's supreme religious leader. President Mohammad Khatami said that the possibility of talks could not be considered "when a power uses bellicose and threatening tone against us." Parliament, which is dominated by reformers, has begun a campaign to negotiate with Washington to ease 23 years of tension, but the religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, has denounced the efforts. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Jets Lineman Injures Knee Seriously
description: Dave Szott, a left guard the Jets picked up as a free agent to complete a radical revamping of their offensive line, injured his right knee seriously in a noncontact drill on Tuesday and will be lost for at least most of training camp.

description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Shows Great Promise Against Juvenile Diabetes
description: An experimental drug appears to stop juvenile diabetes in its tracks, allowing patients to reduce insulin injections and control their disease better, according to a small study to be published today.

description: To the Editor:

title: Shuttle Flight Today to Carry New Crew to Space Station
description: The space shuttle Endeavour is to lift off on Thursday on a 12-day mission to deliver a new crew to the International Space Station and install critical components of the station's $600 million robotic arm.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Margaret Baxter Helmig, senior vice president for strategic development at the Eden Communications Group, Maplewood, N.J., was named to the new post of president. Eden is a division of the Omnicom Group. Amazing Media, Fairfax, Va., named two top executives to new posts. Melissa Boasberg joined as chief operating officer; she had been vice president for development at Opion, (note: cq) Herndon, Va. Also, Jennifer Johnson joined as vice president for sales, based in Chapel Hill, N.C.; she had been regional vice president for sales at Return Buy, Chapel Hill. Duane Bruner, regional director for the European operations of MediaCom Worldwide, based in London, was named regional director for Latin America, to be based for now in Mexico City. He succeeds Otavio Bocchino, who becomes executive vice president and regional director for Latin America at Universal McCann, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. MediaCom is part of the Grey Global Group. Lori Collins, associate media director on the Owens Corning account at Doner, Southfield, Mich., was promoted to vice president. Connie Gallo was named a New York sales representative at Parade, New York, owned by Advance Publications. She had been advertising director at Allure, New York, published by the Condé Nast Publications unit of Advance. Four executives were named to posts at Markitecture, Norwalk, Conn. Brian Gordon was named vice president for business development; he had been executive vice president at YouthStream, New York. Heather Nelson was named director for research; she had been director for advanced analytics at Digital Idea, Westport, Conn. Doug Parent was named partner; he had been vice president for business development at Bigfoot Interactive, New York. And Cathy Peterson was named managing partner; she had been vice president at Modem Media, Norwalk.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Governor Seeks Tax Increase
description: Faced with a dire new revenue forecast, Gov. John Kitzhaber called for a three-year increase in income and corporate taxes and restated his interest in raising the cigarette tax by 50 cents per pack. Economists said Oregon's tax revenue would drop by $550 million in the current two-year budget cycle. The Legislature plans a special session on the budget next month. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Maybe It Was the Blue Light's Hypnotic Effect
description: Kmart may have lost more than $3.7 billion over the last year or so while shoppers defected to its competitors. But there are still people out there like Susan G. Jaggard, a Freehold, N.J., woman so thrilled with Kmart she wrote a poem about it.

title: Nicotine-Laced Water May Soon Be in Stores
description: Sometime in June, drugstores and convenience stores around the country could begin carrying Nico Water, bottles of nicotine-laced water that are the latest entry in a long line of products intended to help smokers get their nicotine fix through less carcinogenic means.

title: Judge Rejects U.S. Policy of Secret Hearings
description: A federal judge in New Jersey yesterday rejected the government's policy of holding only secret hearings for immigrants detained after Sept. 11.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: COLOMBIA: SAFE HAVEN FOR VENEZUELAN Pedro Carmona, who temporarily replaced Hugo Chavez as president of Venezuela during his brief ouster in April, arrived in Colombia after being granted asylum. Mr. Carmona, who had faced charges of rebellion, sought refuge in the Colombian ambassador's residence last week after slipping away from house arrest in Caracas. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Steroid Use Becomes a Topic of Discussion in Clubhouses
description: The statements by the former All-Star Ken Caminiti that half of major league players take steroids reverberated yesterday at Shea Stadium, with Mets pitcher Al Leiter saying he was favor of testing even though he thought the players might vote against it.

title: Labor Dispute to Halt Most Aer Lingus Flights
description: The drastic plans of a management trying to stave off bankruptcy and the resolve of a union determined to hold its own are set to collide Thursday, largely grounding Aer Lingus, the state-owned Irish airline.

title: Rock and the Queen to Celebrate Each Other
description: LONDON  Rock 'n' roll may not be Her Majesty's cup of tea, but even Queen Elizabeth would probably concur that pop music has been Britain's main cultural ambassador during her 50-year reign. So to celebrate her Golden Jubilee, she has invited a few knights of the realm  Sir Paul McCartney, Sir Elton John, Sir Cliff Richard  and a score of their fellow rock 'n' rollers for a gig at the palace.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MIRRER, ESTHER
description: MIRRER-Esther. You are missed by me, not only on your Birthday, but forever. My eternal love, Al Holl

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Labor To Lobby Against Cuts
description: The New York City Central Labor Council announced yesterday that it would aggressively lobby the City Council not to allow budget cuts for education, cultural organizations and children's services. The labor federation also said that it would lobby for a so-called living-wage bill, which would lift the wages of employees working for city service contractors to $8.10 an hour, and to $10 after five years. Brian McLaughlin, president of the labor council, said that the city's labor unions would lobby to protect these budget items because they were so important to working people. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: An Organizer From Treo Adds Color but Skips the Phone
description: Handspring has clearly staked its future on devices that combine mobile phones with hand-held computers. It has not, however, completely abandoned the stand-alone organizer.

title: Rating Goes Up For Kings-Lakers
description: The Sacramento Kings' 92-91 victory Tuesday night over the Los Angeles Lakers in Game 5 of the N.B.A. Western Conference finals on NBC generated a 9.9 Nielsen rating, the highest nonfinals rating for a game in two years. Richard Sandomir

title: Libyan Money For Flight 103 Isn't Remorse, U.S. Says
description: An offer by Libya to pay $2.7 billion to the families of those killed in the bombing of Pam Am Flight 103 was thrown into doubt today when the United States rejected a key part of the deal and the Libyan government reportedly denied that it had anything to do with the offer.

title: Sports of The Times; Yellow Card to Blatter For Smugness at Cup
description: AS a rule, I refrain from making sports predictions, but here is a prognosis for the opening game of the World Cup tomorrow:

title: Wait, You're Not Chinese?
description: I RECENTLY married and took my husband's name: Chang. I am white and I am Jewish and now I am Chinese -- at least on paper. I grew up on 1970's feminism; I went to law school, became a professional, and always imagined I would keep my birth name to celebrate my selfhood. Yet when I married a Chinese man, I realized that I could support our marriage best by changing my name to his.

title: Twins Avoid Contraction for 2003 Season
description: The Minnesota Twins are safe for the 2003 season, but another team, perhaps Tampa Bay, may not be.

title: Roy's Gaffe Helps Red Wings Force Seventh Game
description: One of the most interesting and best-contested playoff rounds in modern hockey history will end just as it should: with Game 7 between the two best teams in the National Hockey League. The Detroit Red Wings ensured that with a 2-0 victory over the Colorado Avalanche tonight at the Pepsi Center to tie the Western Conference finals at three victories apiece.

title: Sports of The Times; Prime Time Brings Out Nets' Best
description: YOUR regularly scheduled programming, ''The West Wing'' and ''Law and Order,'' could not be seen last night. In its place, NBC was proud to present, after roughly a quarter-century of being booed, blacked out and the butt of a million basketball jokes, the New Jersey Nets, in prime time, with their magnificent Kidd Show.

title: Prosecutors Attack Skakel Alibi And Call a Surprise Witness
description: Prosecutors today stepped up their efforts to attack Michael C. Skakel's alibi on the night Martha Moxley was bludgeoned to death. They also called a surprise witness to corroborate testimony that Mr. Skakel confessed to the killing while attending a school for troubled youths in the late 1970's.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Friday about the initial public offerings of three companies omitted attribution for a paraphrased comment about Merrill Lynch's promotion of the offering for Netflix, which operates an online DVD rental service. It was Randall Roth, a research analyst at Renaissance Capital and the Renaissance Capital IPO Plus fund, who said Merrill had not gone out of its way to promote the offering.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: JOHN NUVEEN CO., Chicago, a manager of municipal bond funds, said it would buy NWQ Investment Management, a specialist in stock investing, from Old Mutual, London, an insurer, for $140 million in cash.

title: European Colonies Sprout Downtown
description: Since opening in 1997, Totem in TriBeCa has been a force in modern design. Now the Swedish design firm of Claesson, Koivisto and Rune is making its American debut with a redesign of Totem's original Franklin Street shop (above), which will house merchandise from Scandinavian designers. A second Totem store, which recently opened in SoHo and was designed by Karim Rashid, will offer Dutch, Italian and other European designs, including Covo tableware and accessories from Italy. Items from the Covo line shown are the Vigavi dish ($33), Bicox food containers ($41 for a set of 3) and the Aioi small cup ($82 for a set of six). Totem TriBeCa is at 71 Franklin Street; (212) 925-5506. Totem SoHo is at 83 Grand Street; (212) 219-2446.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Bridgeport: Rape Victim, 11, Gives Birth
description: An 11-year-old girl who was raped by a 75-year-old man last year has given birth while in the custody of the Department of Children and Families, the police said. Capt. Lynn Kerwin of the Bridgeport Police said that the man, Jimmy Kave of Bridgeport, was arrested on April 17, after the girl's mother reported the pregnancy to the police. Mr. Kave, who has a previous sexual assault conviction, told the police that his relationship with the girl began last year, Captain Kerwin said. Mr. Kave, who does not have a listed telephone number, could not be reached for comment. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Levy May Stay As Chancellor, For a While
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg met yesterday with Harold O. Levy, the city schools chancellor, and asked him to stay on the job until some point after Mr. Bloomberg wins control of the school system, officials familiar with the conversation said.

title: Dynegy Chief Is Much Richer for Being Forced Out
description: The chairman and chief executive of the struggling energy company Dynegy, whose departure was announced on Tuesday, is entitled under his contract to a huge severance check -- one that is about $33 million more than he would have made had the company allowed him to serve out the eight months remaining on the contract.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Eclipsys Hires New Chief Executive
description: The Eclipsys Corporation, a health care software company based in Delray Beach, Fla., said Paul Ruflin would become its chief executive in mid-July, replacing Harvey J. Wilson, who founded the company. Mr. Wilson will remain as chairman, the company said. Mr. Ruflin, 48, had been chief operating officer and director of the health and managed care consulting unit at Cap Gemini Ernst & Young until this month. Under Mr. Ruflin's leadership, the consulting practice grew to become the largest in the industry, company officials said. ''It takes the right combination of technology, software and services to achieve sustained results,'' Mr. Wilson said.

description: GALLER-Solomon. On May 29, 2002. Cherished father of David, loving brother of Jack. Dear uncle. Services Friday, 2 PM at Union Field Cemetery.

title: Sheriff Battles Budget Cuts In Los Angeles
description: The sheriff of Los Angeles County said today that he would start to cut critical programs and release hundreds of inmates if the County Board of Supervisors did not increase his budget by $100 million.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Easing Nurses' Licensing
description: Gov. Jeb Bush has signed a bill to ease the nursing shortage. Under the law, nurses moving to Florida from states with comparable standards will be permitted to obtain Florida licenses after completing background checks. The legislation also provides money to repay loans for nursing school. The state has 9,000 nursing vacancies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, DAVID
description: COHEN-David. On May 30, 2002, of Medford, NY and Delray Beach, FL, formerly of Rockville Centre, NY. Beloved husband of Blanche nee Schwartz. Loving father of Howard and Rosanne, Shirley and Jeffrey Schefter, and Allen and Melissa. Adored grandfather of six and great-grandfather of seven. Mr. Cohen was the Founder of the John's Bargain Store chain which was the forerunner of the modern discount store chains. Funeral services Friday, 1 P.M., at ''Gutterman's, Inc.,'' 175 Long Beach Rd, Rockville Centre, L.I. The family will be sitting Shiva at the Schefter residence in Bellmore, New York.

Lorraine was loved and respected by all who were privileged to work with her. Her courage and determination continue to be an inspiration to us all. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family. Peter R. Marra, President

title: Turning to Renewal
description: In a poignant, wordless ceremony yesterday morning, recovery workers carried an empty stretcher draped with an American flag out of the empty place where the World Trade Center once stood. They were followed by a truck bearing the last steel column to be removed from the site and then a long file of men and women, all of whom had helped in the recovery effort. What remained, as the procession moved up West Street, was an enormous hole and a solemn obligation to use it wisely.

description: We may think of weaving as women's work, but in 19th-century Central Asia it was almost always the men who wove ikats, the wildly colorful patterned silk textiles used to make precious robes and hangings.

description: Serene Ross, a senior at Purdue, set an American record in the women's javelin with a toss of 195 feet 8 inches at the N.C.A.A. track and field championships yesterday in Baton Rouge, La.

description: Jerome Robbins's ``Interplay'' has breezed back into the repertory of the New York City Ballet. And last Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater it was performed by a new cast of young dancers.

title: NEWFIELD PLANS TO SELL SOME ASSETS AFTER BUYING EEX
description: Newfield Exploration, an oil and gas explorer that agreed on Wednesday to buy a rival, the EEX Corporation, plans to sell $70 million in offshore assets after the acquisition is completed, its chief executive said. Newfield will pay $640 million in stock and assumed debt for EEX, giving it access to deep-water fields in the Gulf of Mexico. The assets to be sold, which include a floating oil and natural gas production platform and 53 miles of underwater pipelines, were valued by EEX last year at $70 million, Newfield's chief executive, David A. Trice, said. Newfield will pay 0.05703 share for each EEX share, or a total of 7.1 million shares, and assume $360 million in debt.

title: Creations Small in Scale but Towering in Impact
description: Art is about control. At a basic level, the control is physical; an artist puts certain materials together in a certain way to create a new form. More or less simultaneously, conceptual control is at play: the new form is intended to communicate ideas or elicit emotions. All of this is part of the public side of art, the side geared to reception, the side art schools teach.

title: Equity Chief Is Chosen
description: The Bank of America Corporation said yesterday that it had named Jon Sandelman as its head of global equities, a new position created to help the bank win back stock underwriting business lost in the last year to Citigroup and other rivals.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: PERU: COURT TO SEEK FUJIMORI EXTRADITION The Supreme Court has agreed to ask Japan to extradite former President Alberto Fujimori, who has been accused of rights violations in the massacres of Peruvian political opponents, a court source said. The extradition bid is Peru's latest attempt to shake Mr. Fujimori from his self-imposed exile in Japan and bring him to trial. Justice Minister Fernando Olivera said the Supreme Court and government officials were preparing the request, which will eventually be forwarded to Tokyo. "Fujimori is acting like a delinquent trying to evade justice," Mr. Olivera said. (Agence France-Presse)

title: 4 Sets of 5 Rings Honor All Lost and Never Found
description: The hush at ground zero was broken yesterday at 10:29 a.m., as four sets of five rings resounded across the empty pit. The ringing signaled to firefighters to carry an empty stretcher to a waiting ambulance, a ceremony to honor all the people lost Sept. 11 and never found.

description: For most of its 36 years, the Caisse de Dpt et Placement du Qubec has seen no conflict between its role as a government agency promoting economic independence for Canada's French-speaking province and its obligation to seek the highest returns for millions of Quebecers who entrust their retirement savings and auto insurance premiums to government-sponsored plans.

title: Overseers Warn Nassau to Get Moving on Proposals in Albany
description: State overseers warned Nassau County today that its fiscal recovery is at risk unless county officials get cracking now on crucial requests to the State Legislature before it adjourns in June.

title: SHARES OF OLD MUTUAL FALL 5% AFTER ST. PAUL SELLS STAKE
description: Shares of Old Mutual P.L.C. fell nearly 5 percent yesterday in London after the company, South Africa's top money manager, said the St. Paul Companies, a United States business insurer, sold its 5.1 percent stake. Old Mutual paid St. Paul about $300 million in stock and $335 million in cash last year for Fidelity and Guaranty Life Insurance. St. Paul got the shares on Sept. 28 and agreed to keep them for at least a year. The shares have risen 24 percent this year, and Old Mutual is letting the company sell early, recouping an earlier loss.

description: To the Editor:

title: State Dept. Advises 60,000 Americans to Leave India
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  The Bush administration warned today that "tensions have risen to serious levels" between the nuclear powers of India and Pakistan, and it urged the estimated 60,000 Americans in India for business, study or tourism to leave immediately and advised all but essential diplomats and their dependents to depart.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Setback For MobilCom Executive
description: Shareholders of MobilCom handed a vote of no confidence to the company's chief executive, Gerhard Schmid, after a inquiry ordered by France Tlcom found that a stock option plan he proposed broke German securities rules. MobilCom's shares fell 14 percent after Mr. Schmid admitted that he violated German securities rules by failing to give the finance chief, Thorsten Grenz, enough information about the option program. The vote further erodes Mr. Schmid's credibility and gives France Tlcom's chief executive, Michel Bon, the upper hand in a battle for control of MobilCom.

title: Unlucky in Her Loves, Lucky in Her Songs
description: To be wowed by Sophie Tucker, maybe you had to be around in 1906, when she broke into show business in a movie theater on 116th Street and Lexington Avenue, singing show after show after show for $20 a week while the projectionist rewound the reels. Or maybe in 1909 when she was a Ziegfeld girl. Or maybe in that more inhibited era when she could get herself arrested for a bit of a suggestive wiggle and naughty songs like ''There's Company in the Parlor, Girls, Come on Down,'' which enabled her to claim the title Last of the Red Hot Mamas.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Data Rule Arouses Concern
description: The European Parliament passed a data protection law that civil liberties campaigners, telecommunication companies and Internet industry representatives condemn. The law allows the 15-member European Union states to force Internet and telecommunications service providers to retain data on their customers' online and phone activity beyond the one or two months the information is normally stored for billing purposes. It also bans spam, or unsolicited e-mail advertisements. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Bush Presses Pakistan on Kashmir And Orders Rumsfeld to Region
description: President Bush said today that he would send Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld to India and Pakistan next week in an effort to defuse the threat of nuclear war between the longtime enemies. He also made his strongest demand yet that Pakistan's president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, crack down on the infiltration of terrorists into India.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Wallkill: Convicted Rapist To Be Released
description: A man sentenced to more than 3,000 years in prison for a 1982 crime spree of raping and robbing patrons in an Old Westbury diner is scheduled to be released from prison on June 30. The man, Robert Williams, and four others were convicted of more than 800 felonies, but because of state limitations on sentencing, Mr. Williams is being released from Shawangunk Correctional Facility in Wallkill after serving 20 years. Two convicted accomplices, Michael Williams and Bruce Garrison, were denied release after refusing to participate in therapy for sexual offenders, prosecutors said. Two other accomplices, James Martin and Robert Samuels, are serving life sentences for an unrelated case. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: National Briefing | West: Nevada: Plan To Help Doctors On Malpractice Policies
description: In an effort to stop doctors from leaving the state because of the high cost of malpractice insurance, Gov. Kenny Guinn, a Republican, announced changes for the Medical Liability Association of Nevada, a state-run company that provides temporary insurance. The revisions include a $250,000 cap on damages for pain and suffering, a possible suit against a Minnesota insurer that dropped nationwide malpractice insurance and an offer to cover doctors for malpractice that occurred while under other policies. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: New Climate Sensors for Earth Malfunction on Aqua Satellite
description: A vital instrument on a new billion-dollar satellite designed to resolve questions about the changing climate is malfunctioning, NASA officials said today.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Mexican food has come to New York in fits and starts. It's only recently that small neighborhood restaurants, the kind that diners in Los Angeles take for granted, have gained a foothold in ethnic neighborhoods. The city is still waiting for places dedicated to specific regional Mexican cuisines, although Danzn took a stab at the food of Veracruz. Saln Mxico blazes a third trail, Mexican fusion.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; To Stay Young Always, A Lost Cause Even at 30
description: In a world where the quest for eternal youth continues to accelerate with ever more sophisticated combinations of surgery, drugs, diet and exercise, it is little wonder that increasing numbers of people want the erotic fun and games of their teens and 20's to go on forever. The restless characters, especially the men, in Gabriele Muccino's stinging contemporary comedy, ''The Last Kiss,'' are all gripped by the fever to remain forever young.

description: To the Editor:

title: Watch It, Austin Powers, The Funk Is Back
description: ''Undercover Brother'' is the latest parodic tribute to the black popular culture of the 1970's, the heyday of blaxploitation heroes, deep-fried funk and 10-inch Afros. According to a rather selective montage that serves as the prologue to Malcolm D. Lee's winningly silly new movie, that golden age of style and self-assertion was quickly wiped away by Mr. T, Urkel and Dennis Rodman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAILEY, HELEN PHELPS, PH.D.
description: BAILEY-Helen Phelps, Ph.D. May 28, 2002. Professor Emeritus of French and French Literature and former Dean of Studies, Barnard College. Frank Patti Funeral Home, 327 Main St., Ft Lee, N.J., Monday, June 3, 2-4, 7-9PM; funeral at St. John's Church, Leonia, N.J. Broad Ave and Harrison St., Tuesday, June 4th, 10:30AM.

title: U.S. Considers Requiring Cameras Providing Cabin Views
description: The Sept. 11 hijackings have left pilots wanting more knowledge about activity in the passenger cabin, without stepping through their newly fortified doors. Now the Transportation Department, with encouragement from Congress, is considering requiring video cameras that will provide images of passengers to the cockpit.

title: Son Is Born to Widow of Reporter Killed in Karachi
description: Mariane Pearl, whose husband, the Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl, was killed by Islamic militants in Karachi, Pakistan, gave birth yesterday in Paris to a son, Adam D. Pearl.

title: The Celtics' Plan Is to Adjust, Not to Concede
description: The Boston Celtics know what it looks like. They know that on the eve of Game 6, they appear to be an overmatched team that has had its haughty attitude knocked back in its face like a Kenyon Martin rejection. They know that with their porous defense and sputtering offense, they look inferior to the Nets.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Would that we wouldn't have to pay this price for our own safety and national security. But we do.''

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: McGreevey Urges Early Retirement
description: In an effort to reduce the number of state employees, Gov. James E. McGreevey signed into law yesterday a bill encouraging state employees to retire early. The program, which offers early buyouts, is expected to save the state about $46 million in the 2003 fiscal year by eliminating about 1,000 state employees.

title: An Erosion of Civil Liberties
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft has a gift for making the most draconian policy changes sound seductively innocuous. He was at it again yesterday, describing new domestic spying powers for the Federal Bureau of Investigation as nothing more than the authority to surf the Internet or attend a public gathering. That is profoundly misleading. In reality Mr. Ashcroft, in the name of fighting terrorism, was giving F.B.I. agents nearly unbridled power to poke into the affairs of anyone in the United States, even when there is no evidence of illegal activity.

title: Spend a Day at the Races (Just Don't Blink)
description: SUMMER is the high season for drag racing's major professional events. The National Hot Rod Association, the dominant race-sanctioning body, stages its meets across the country; the most prestigious is the U.S. Nationals on Labor Day weekend in Indianapolis.

title: INSIDE
description: Schools Chief Stays, for Now

title: Canadian Leader Attacked In a Loud Ethics Brouhaha
description: Struggling to contain the worst ethics controversy to face his party in years, Prime Minister Jean Chrtien has frozen dozens of government contracts, reorganized his cabinet and issued new rules on political donations and conflicts of interest.

title: West Wayne Buys Breathe Interactive
description: West Wayne in Atlanta said yesterday that it had acquired Breathe Interactive in Atlanta, a direct and interactive marketing agency with billings estimated at $2 million to $3 million from clients like Circuit City. Terms were not disclosed.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Stable Economic Growth
description: The Philippine economy expanded 3.8 percent in the first three months of the year compared with the first quarter of 2001, propelled by bumper sugar and rice crops as well as by new sources of crude oil from southern islands off Borneo. Economists had expected growth nearer to 4 percent, but the pace was hindered by a decline in semiconductor exports and lower industrial power consumption. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Broadway Season Results
description: The Broadway season that recently ended, hurt by the tourism decline after Sept. 11, was not as bad as nearly everyone expected. The League of American Theatres and Producers, the trade association for the commercial theater industry, reported yesterday that 2001 attendance dropped 7.9 percent, while total revenues, helped by higher prices, fell only 3.4 percent. An accompanying study showed that Broadway's impact on the economy had risen each year until the record results of 2000, when the shows grossed $666 million on the sale of 11.5 million tickets. In the 2001-02 season, Broadway shows grossed $643.4 million and sold 10.95 million tickets. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: NINTENDO SAYS PROFIT IS RUNNING AT A RECORD HIGH
description: Nintendo, maker of the GameCube video console, said yesterday that profit rose to a record high in the six months that ended March 31. The company said it earned 72 billion yen ($577 million) in the period, with sales jumping 21 percent. Nintendo expects sales to rise an additional 15 percent this year if it meets its goal of selling 12 million GameCubes and 36 million software titles. Nintendo is battling the market leader, Sony, which markets its PlayStation 2 console, and Microsoft, which intro duced its Xbox last year. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Another Call for an Overhaul of Air Fares
description: Airlines have to narrow the gap between walk-up fares and leisure fares that has widened in the last several years and has driven more business travelers to buy cheap tickets, the chief of US Airways said yesterday.

title: Woody Allen Goes to Court, But the Scenario Is Not a Comedy
description: Looking as painfully afflicted as one of his film personas, Woody Allen appeared in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday during the opening arguments in his civil case against his longtime friend and producer, her boyfriend and their production company.

title: Investigating 'Should Feel' And 'Did Feel'
description: In her insightful, deeply personal new cabaret show, ''Falling in Love With Love: The Rodgers and Hart Story,'' the singer Mary Cleere Haran distinguishes in the most succinct terms the difference between Richard Rodgers's collaborations with Oscar Hammerstein II and his work with Lorenz Hart. Hammerstein's lyrics, she suggests, described how ''we should feel'' while Hart's expressed what ''we did feel.''

title: Jim Hodges
description: CRG

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: COMMUNIST LEADER DENOUNCES SUMMIT The leader of the Communist Party denounced last weekend's summit meeting between President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin as a sellout of Russia's national interests and security, saying Mr. Putin allowed Mr. Bush to "walk all over him and gave in on everything," and "humiliated the country and himself." Gennadi Zyuganov also said Mr. Putin had "effectively destroyed the Russian nuclear shield" by agreeing to a two-thirds reduction, to between 1,700 and 2,200, of the number of deployed strategic nuclear warheads in each nation. With the support of between a quarter and a third of the electorate, Russia's Communists have been doomed since the Soviet collapse a decade ago to a vocal, but seemingly permanent minority in Russian politics. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, JUDITH
description: GOLDMAN-Judith. Beloved wife of Harold. Adored daughter of Rabbi Gilbert and the late Libby Klaperman and stepdaughter of Susan Klaperman. Cherished sister of Joel and Renee Klaperman, Frieda Klaperman, Carol and Ira Morrow and step-sisters Beth Alter and Shira and Tuvia Book. Devoted aunt of Gabriel, Jeremy, Jessica and Harrison. Loving niece of Bernice Wigder and Sylvia and Irving Tuchman. Always caring, giving and gracious, she charmed all who knew her and illuminated their lives. Judy was our dearest treasure and a constant source of joy and blessing. Her courage and determination and love for God, her people and Israel are her eternal legacy. Funeral today, 11:30AM at Congregation Beth Sholom, Lawrence, NY. Shiva at the Klaperman residence, 64 Muriel Ave, Lawrence.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: ADVANCED MICRO CUTS CHIP PRICES Advanced Micro Devices Inc. , following its rival Intel , has cut prices on nearly all its microprocessors by 7 percent to 52 percent to remain competitive and to make room for new chips it will introduce next month. Advanced Micro, with about 18 percent of the market for microprocessors, the brains of personal computers, said the price cuts apply to processors that go into laptop computers. Advanced Micro shares fell 22 cents, to $11.38. The price cuts are something of a spring ritual for both Advanced Micro Devices, which is based in Sunnyvale, Calif., and Intel. (Reuters)

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Public Money For Green Party Candidate
description: The Green Party candidate for governor could be the first third-party candidate to receive taxpayer money to run for office. The candidate, Jill Stein, is close to qualifying for up to $3.4 million under the new Clean Elections Law. A candidate has to have 6,000 campaign donations. Ms. Stein's campaign said it had exceeded that number. If Ms. Stein receives the money, her campaign could damage Democrats' chances of regaining the governor's post by siphoning liberal votes from a Democratic contender. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: J.P. Morgan Cited in Failure Of a Global Crossing Bid
description: The collapse of an agreement last week for two Asian companies to make a bid for Global Crossing is being attributed to actions by J. P. Morgan Chase that may have soured the transaction, people close to Global Crossing said yesterday.

title: Driving Miss Mitzi: A Road Tale
description: IT has been called a tin can, a junker, a death trap and, in one particularly nasty case, ''an embarrassment to the neighborhood.'' The object of such scorn is our car, a 1990 Mitsubishi Mirage with 129,000 miles on her axles but, admittedly, none of the weathered grace one might expect of someone of her advancing age.

title: Lawmakers Say Misstatements Cloud F.B.I. Chief's Credibility
description: With admissions this week that the F.B.I. might have been able to foil the Sept. 11 attacks and that it had bungled additional clues, Robert S. Mueller III has contradicted much of his past public defense of the bureau, raising new concern today on Capitol Hill about his leadership of the embattled agency.

title: Away From the Uproar, Before a Strong Wind
description: From my midship perch on the sharply slanted deck of the 80-foot schooner Adirondack as it slices the swift crosscurrents of the Upper Bay of New York Harbor, gritty Manhattan is transformed into the shimmering silver city of our dreams. Only the view from the troposphere in a passing jet offers a comparable perspective.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Monsey: E. Coli Outbreak Reported
description: Rockland County officials are puzzled about the source of a large outbreak of E. coli poisoning, the county's health commissioner said yesterday. Fifteen confirmed and suspected cases -- mostly among children -- in and around the town of Monsey, about 60 miles north of Poughkeepsie, have been reported since Sunday, with four victims hospitalized. Typical symptoms include fever, dehydration and diarrhea. A majority of the victims are under 7, though the father and older siblings of one victim seem to have the same symptoms, the commissioner, Dr. Joan Facelle, said. Complicating the investigation is a case outside Monsey reported yesterday morning in Orangetown, Dr. Facelle said. E. coli bacteria are usually spread through undercooked meat, unpasteurized milk or contaminated water. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Gregory Crewdson
description: Luhring Augustine

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about federal compensation awards to the same-sex partners of Sept. 11 victims referred imprecisely to legislation shelved by Congress that would have guaranteed compensation to survivors of the public safety officers who died without immediate next of kin. The legislation would have provided death benefits to the estates of 10 officers who died without spouses, children or living parents; it made no mention of their sexual orientation.

title: Just How Far Can Trading Of Emissions Be Extended?
description: For once, Washington secured a bargain.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: Deer Hunters React To Wasting Disease
description: A survey finds that 56 percent of the deer hunters in the state, though aware of chronic wasting disease, are not concerned about eating wild venison. Four out of five of those surveyed by St. Norbert College said they would be willing to have their prey tested, though more than half said they would not pay for testing. And 36 percent of the hunters said the disease that is plaguing deer had made them reconsider hunting. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Estimates Affect Genesis Shares
description: Genesis Microchip Inc. shares fell sharply yesterday and set a new 52-week low after some analysts slashed their earnings estimates on the company, the Toronto-based chip maker. Genesis Microchip shares closed the day at $16.70, down $6.66, or 28.5 percent on the Nasdaq board, surpassing its 52-week low of $19.70 set on Sept. 18. Earlier yesterday, US Bancorp Piper Jaffray issued a research report in which an analyst, Ashok Kumar, said he believed that the company's earnings and revenue targets for the June quarter were at risk. According to the analyst, Genesis Microchip will be able to maintain its market share position in the shortterm only at the expense of ''significant'' price cuts.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on May 19 about the future of NATO, particularly after its expansion next fall, discussed whether the alliance is still relevant. It quoted a joke said to be making the rounds in Washington -- ''Keep the myth alive!'' -- and attributed the remark to Douglas J. Feith, under secretary of defense for policy.

title: Corrections
description: A letter on May 23 about minority caucuses in Congress misstated the number of American Indians in Congress. It is two, not one, according to the National Congress of American Indians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, FRANK, SR.
description: ROSS-Frank, Sr. The Metropolitan Council on Jewish Poverty mourns the untimely loss of our dear friend and supporter Frank Ross, Sr., Co-chair of HRH Construction. Frank was a pioneer in construction and the development of housing for the elderly poor. Our condolences to his loving family. We will miss him. Merryl H. Tisch, President Joseph C. Shenker, President-Elect William E. Rapfogel, CEO Rabbi David Cohen, Senior Executive Consultant

title: New Immigration Plan in Britain Would Restrict Asylum Seekers
description: Britain announced today that it intended to tighten its immigration laws by ordering failed asylum seekers to leave the country within days and to file any appeals from their home country or whatever country they had last been in before arriving here.

title: New Location, But Favorites Are Familiar
description: Security is heavy, the ball is light, schools here are closed and pubs in England are open early as the world's largest sporting event comes to Asia for the first time.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Guilty Verdict In Foot-And-Mouth Case
description: The pig farmer thought to have caused the epidemic of foot-and-mouth disease that devastated England's farm animals last year was found guilty of failure to notify the authorities that his animals were showing symptoms of the illness. The man, Bobby Waugh, 56, who runs a pig-fattening farm in Northumberland, was also convicted of treating his animals cruelly by keeping them in filthy conditions and feeding them unprocessed swill, including leftovers from local restaurants. The pigs had probably been ill for at least 12 days before the authorities found out, which gave the highly contagious disease ample opportunity to begin its spread. Sentencing in the case is to occur in late June. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: The Odds Improve for an Increase in the Minimum Wage
description: Last year and the year before, the New York State Assembly voted to increase the state minimum wage by $1.60 an hour, but those efforts died quietly in the Senate.

title: Kim Collmer
description: White Columns

title: Ladies and Gentlemen, Ignite Your Engines
description: THERE was drag racing then, and there is drag racing now. Then, drag racing was about bad boys on back roads, rebels with cars, fights over girls, ''American Graffiti.'' Now, drag racing is about professional, high-tech speedsters topping 300 miles an hour on a straight quarter-mile track and may the best endorsement win.

title: U.S. Troops Release 50 Men From Afghan Village Raid
description: American forces released 50 prisoners and the body of their tribal leader today after six days of detention and negotiation that raised widespread anger among villagers and townspeople here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, CHARLES
description: BLUM-Charles. Beloved husband of Gertrude. Devoted father of Kerry (Karen) and the late Sandy. Adored grandfather of Dylan. Services 1:30 PM Sunday at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapel'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., NY.

title: Mets' Makeover Has Not Helped Their Offense
description: The Mets resemble the Wall Street investor who refuses to acknowledge a changing market. As their numbers on offense remain low, they have shown unyielding faith in an inevitable turnaround.

title: Worker Is Sentenced for Lie That Jailed Egyptian Student
description: A federal judge in Manhattan sentenced a former hotel security guard to six months of weekends in prison yesterday for making up a story that caused an Egyptian student to be jailed for a month in the wake of the Sept. 11 attack.

title: Ireland Buys a Trove of Joyce Notebooks
description: In a sort of homecoming for this country's most famous exile, the National Library of Ireland has acquired a sprawling collection of manuscripts by James Joyce, including, in a total of some 700 pages in six notebooks, 16 drafts from ''Ulysses'' and typescripts and proofs of ''Finnegans Wake.'' Discovered two years ago, they were kept secret until today.

title: Defendant Yields on Refusal to See Psychiatrist
description: Zacarias Moussaoui, the only person arrested so far in the Sept. 11 terror attacks, has met with a court-appointed psychiatrist who is helping a federal judge determine if he is mentally competent to defend himself at trial, according to court papers made public today.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: ANALYSTS WARY OF MANUGISTICS Shares of the Manugistics Group , a software company in Rockville, Md., fell about 4 percent after industry analysts expressed concern that the company would not perform as well as other information technology companies over the next 18 months. At the close of trading, Manugistics was off 37 cents, to $8.63, but it had declined to $7.50, its lowest price since October 2001. A spokeswoman for the company said that Manugistics would not discuss its finances until after its first quarter ends today. Manugistics makes software that helps companies share inventory, pricing and planning information with customers and suppliers over the Internet. The company ended a mandatory unpaid leave program in March for its work force of more than 1,000; at that time, the company said its fourth-quarter earnings would exceed company and Wall Street estimates.

title: Jets Will Start A Rookie Guard
description: The Jets' fifth-round draft pick, Jonathan Goodwin, who played for Michigan, will be listed as the starting left guard when training camp starts July 26, General Manager Terry Bradway said yesterday.

title: F.B.I. Covered Up for Boston Mobsters, Lawsuits Assert
description: There is the family of a Tulsa high-tech multimillionaire who was executed gangland-style as he left his country club after a round of golf. Also the mothers of two young women whose bodies were found in shallow sandy graves along the outer reaches of Boston harbor. Not to mention the widow of a small-time mobster missing for many years.

title: Soccer Fans to Land Amid Ambitions
description: The battalions of soccer fans arriving for World Cup games in June will have an easier time landing here than Gen. Douglas MacArthur's marines did more than half a century ago to turn the tide of the Korean War.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: Cuts In State Programs
description: Hoping to reduce a budget deficit expected to grow to nearly $1 billion by next year, Gov. Frank L. O'Bannon, a Democrat, announced plans to cut $203 million from state programs, mostly from social services, effective July 1. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EDELMAN, HILDA W.
description: EDELMAN-Hilda W. ''Sempre con noi.'' Mort, Diana, Robert, Nancy and Alex

title: World Business Briefing: Australia
description: AUSTRALIA: GOLD MINER CONSIDERS OPTIONS The Australian gold miner AurionGold appears prepared to reject Placer Dome's $1.13 billion takeover bid unless it is raised. AurionGold's managing director, Terry Burgess, said that market reaction suggested that Placer Dome, the Canadian precious metals company, would have to raise the offer it presented Monday. AurionGold is still assessing Placer's bid and faces a June 11 deadline for issuing a formal response and recommendation to shareholders. (Dow Jones/AP)

title: A New Direction for the F.B.I.
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Theft Accusation In Primary Campaign
description: The contest between former Gov. James J. Blanchard and Attorney General Jennifer M. Granholm for the Democratic nomination for governor grew nastier as a Blanchard supporter filed a theft report that accused a Granholm worker of stealing finance documents. The Granholm campaign released the documents last week, saying they showed that Mr. Blanchard was planning aggressive fund-raising tactics even as he criticized Ms. Granholm for not sticking to spending limits. The documents, Granholm officials said, were found by a worker at an unattended copy machine at the Wayne County executive's office in Detroit. The Detroit police are investigating. Jeremy Peters (NYT)

title: Storm Clouds Delay Shuttle's Launch
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 31  The space shuttle Endeavour will remain grounded until at least Monday as a result of a dismal weather forecast that calls for thunderstorms throughout the weekend here at the Kennedy Space Center.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: Edison Trying To Add Schools
description: Already designated to overhaul 20 failing schools in Philadelphia, Edison Schools Inc., the largest commercial manager of public schools, said it was seeking a management role in up to eight other schools in the city. A state panel that oversees the district is considering applications from community organizations that want to run charter schools. Some groups have indicated that they would be inclined to enlist Edison to help them. Jacques Steinberg (NYT)

title: Havana Journal; Cuban Reporter Travels a Bumpy Path to Deadline
description: Omar Rodrguez Saludes chases the news around Havana on a battered, child-size bicycle. He can make his deadline if he does not have a flat tire, which can take a long time to repair, and if a corner policeman does not confiscate his notes, tape recorder and camera.

title: Knicks Look at an M.V.P. And a Junior College Player
description: Qyntel Woods and Jared Jeffries, who worked out today for Knicks coaches and management, come from vastly different backgrounds, with Woods having spent three years at junior colleges and Jeffries having led Indiana to the national championship game this season.

title: At Meeting, U.S. Agency Says Indian Point 2 Safety Has Improved
description: Nuclear Regulatory Commission officials said today that they had seen significant improvements at the troubled Indian Point 2 reactor, but added that they would reserve final judgment about safety at the nuclear power plant until on-site inspections could be held in June and July.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: New Ideas For Next Season

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KOPLIK, KENNETH E.
description: KOPLIK-Kenneth E. For all that you gave us...for the pride we had in being your family...we remember you with gratitude and devotion. Sharing your life was a blessing...living the love you left us is an everlasting gift. Diane and Davi

title: Classical Music and Dance Listings
description: Aselective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Schumer Sees Excess Cleanup Aid Paying for Rail Links to New Hub
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer said yesterday that he believed that the federal money allocated for rebuilding Lower Manhattan included enough to pay for the extension of the Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North commuter lines into a new downtown transportation hub.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: ANOTHER SECESSION IDEA new study has determined that Hollywood could sustain itself as a city apart from Los Angeles. A vote has already been scheduled for November on secession by the San Fernando Valley. The regional commission that conducted the study, the Local Agency Formation Commission, said it would recommend next week whether Hollywood voters should have the same opportunity. One sticking point is the community's fabled hillside sign. Los Angeles officials say they would fight any effort to change its ownership. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: F.B.I. Director's Comments
description: Following are public comments by the F.B.I. director, Robert S. Mueller III, on whether the bureau had prior indications of the Sept. 11 attacks:

title: At Washington's Lavish Art Buffet
description: ARCHITECTURALLY, Washington looks like a very large bank. The granite facades that line its streets are vaultlike. The pilastered pile known as the Capitol -- so blindingly white that you need dark glasses to look at it on a sunny day -- speaks of Olympian stability and corporate wealth.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Hostage May Be Freed
description: A militant Muslim group holding two American missionaries and a Filipino nurse hostage said the nurse would be released ''any moment.'' In a broadcast, the group's spokesman taunted the United States for offering a $5 million reward for the capture of the Abu Sayyaf leadership, saying the offer was a ''good sign, a sign that we are important to the Americans after all.'' The spokesman made no mention of the fate of Martin and Gracia Burnham, missionaries from Kansas who were abducted a year ago. Carlos H. Conde (NYT)

title: House Shares: Dysfunction On the Beach
description: AFTER just one weekend at his summer share house in Spring Lake, N.J., Matt Brown fired off a corporate-style memo to the other 16 members of the house, alerting them to a meeting.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Famine Warning For Four Countries
description: Despite repeated calls for assistance, the United Nations said four countries in southern Africa were facing potential famine. Malawi, Zimbabwe, Lesotho and Swaziland have been hit by two successive years of poor harvests caused by natural calamities, coupled with economic crises and disruption of farming in some places. Over the next year, nearly four million tons of food will need to be imported to meet minimum needs.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: Architect Wins Yale Seat
description: Maya Lin, the architect of the Vietnam War memorial in Washington, has won election to the alumni seat on Yale University's governing board, easily beating back a challenger who mounted a rare campaign for the position, the university announced yesterday. Ms. Lin was selected by an alumni nominating committee. Her challenger, W. David Lee, a New Haven minister, was nominated by petition and raised more than $50,000, much of it from clerical and custodial unions, for his campaign. Such tactics are rare in governing board elections. Although Mr. Lee won high-profile endorsements, including that of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, he received less than 20 percent of the vote. This year's election attracted nearly 50,000 ballots, almost three times the usual number. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: New Problem For Disputed Cable
description: Weeks before a new underwater cable was to begin carrying electricity from Connecticut to Long Island, the plans have hit a snag. Because of particularly resistant bedrock, sections of the cable in New Haven Harbor could not be buried at the minimum depth required by permits, or 48 feet below sea level, said Rita Bowlby, a spokeswoman for Cross Sound Cable Company, which built the cable. Yesterday, the Army Corps of Engineers and the state Department of Environmental Conservation met with cable company officials to discuss the matter. Ms. Bowlby said that the company would inspect the problem but that she expected the cable would begin importing electricity in July, as planned. Critics of the project argue that the cable should not be used until it complies with the conditions of its permits. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, BERNARD HOWARD
description: LEVY-Bernard Howard, 69, formerly of New York City and Egremont, MA. Died on May 29, 2002. He was the brother of Alan Leonard Levy, the father of Wendy Levy, Debra Camal and Jessica Fauci and the grandfather of Tommy, Michael and Jenna Camal and Julianna Fauci. Services will be on Friday, May 31, 11:30 AM at I.J. Morris in Hempstead, NY.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: For Alan Bates, A Role's a Role

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MONSEY: E. COLI OUTBREAK REPORTED Rockland County officials are puzzled about the source of a large outbreak of E. coli poisoning, the county's health commissioner said yesterday. Fifteen confirmed and suspected cases  mostly among children  in and around the town of Monsey, about 60 miles north of Poughkeepsie, have been reported since Sunday, with four victims hospitalized. Typical symptoms include fever, dehydration and diarrhea. A majority of the victims are under 7, though the father and older siblings of one victim seem to have the same symptoms, the commissioner, Dr. Joan Facelle, said. Complicating the investigation is a case outside Monsey reported yesterday morning in Orangetown, Dr. Facelle said. E. coli bacteria are usually spread through undercooked meat, unpasteurized milk or contaminated water. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico City: Delay On Two-Level Highways
description: The city will postpone plans to make its busiest roads into double-decker highways, officials announced. The proposal is to be put to a popular vote later this year. Mayor Andrs Manuel Lpez Obrador had planned to start the project this month, saying a second tier would cut pollution and unsnarl traffic, but opponents protested the cost and the potential chaos of construction. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Deal for Miller Brewing May Be First in a Series
description: South African Breweries agreed today to buy the Miller Brewing Company from the Philip Morris Companies for $3.6 billion in stock, moving a step closer to surpassing Anheuser-Busch as the world's largest brewer, which analysts see as its ultimate goal.

title: Weekender|New London, Conn.
description: ONE of the best things about New London, beyond its location on the shore of Long Island Sound at the mouth of the Thames River, is its total lack of congestion and pretension compared with the nearby towns of Stonington and Mystic. While they are primarily tourist destinations, New London is a city, with all of the benefits and drawbacks that cities have to offer. It is a complex place with ethnic and economic diversity, with both low-income housing and exclusive enclaves that have restricted access to pristine beaches and spectacular waterfront views. These days, New London appears to be in the process of reinventing itself, partly as a result of Pfizer's new global research and development headquarters on a previously abandoned 22-acre brownfield peninsula.

title: WESTERN RESOURCES TO SELL ITS 44.5% STAKE IN ONEOK
description: Western Resources, a Kansas utility owner, said yesterday that it had notified Oneok, a natural gas utility, of plans to sell its 44.5 percent stake in the company, valued at about $1 billion. Oneok has the right for 90 days to buy Western's 4.9 million shares for $21.77 each, Western said. Western said in a filing that it had ''lost faith'' in Oneok's management. Oneok's earnings fell 30 percent last year. Western, which reported a $21.8 million loss in 2001, is raising cash after writing down the value of its 84 percent stake in Protection One, a security and alarm business. Shares in Oneok fell 44 cents, to $21.05.

title: For G.I.'s in Afghanistan, War Is Hellishly Boring
description: Pvt. David Cardwell was just six weeks out of basic training when his unit of the 101st Airborne Division was sent to Afghanistan in January. He was nervous about the prospect of combat, but thrilled as well.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Back to 'NYPD Blue'

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC, Natick, Mass., a maker of medical devices, said it had agreed to buy the closely held Enteric Medical Technologies, Foster City, Calif. Terms were not disclosed.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Strike Grounds Airline
description: Pilots at Aer Lingus, Ireland's state-owned airline, staged a one-day strike as planned to protest cuts in the minimum rest period they have between flights, one of many changes that the airline is putting in place as part of a plan to avoid bankruptcy. The airline's management responded to the strike by hiring outside planes and pilots to fly a handful of flights, including its shuttle service to Heathrow Airport in London and its flagship flight to New York. The carrier also canceled all flights on Friday and Saturday. For each day that its planes are grounded, Aer Lingus loses nearly $2 million, and travel plans for 20,000 passengers are disrupted, it said. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Low Price Hurts Oil Concern

Oil production, however, rose 17 percent last year compared with the year before. The company also announced it had increased its oil and gas reserves by 6 percent through discoveries in Siberia. title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: All Cyanide Recovered
description: The police said they had now accounted for every one of 96 containers of sodium cyanide stolen in a bungled truck hijacking. The remaining missing containers were recovered along a dirt road 80 miles from Mexico City. Officials said they were stolen in a common crime, not as part of a terrorist plot. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: BRITISH POWER COMPANY POSTS LOSS FOR FISCAL YEAR
description: National Grid, Britain's electricity carrier, reported a net loss yesterday after writing down the value of telecommunications businesses by the equivalent of $1.1 billion. The loss, its first since it became a public company seven years ago, was $712 million for the fiscal year that ended March 31, the company said. National Grid has expanded significantly in the United States, where it completed the $8.9 billion acquisition of Niagara Mohawk Power, based in Syracuse, in January. The company's shares declined slightly, to 499 pence. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Where Nitty Met Gritty On Jampacked Canvases
description: Ignoring the high-flown concept of less being more, Ralph Fasanella (1914-1997) packed everything into his paintings of city people, places and events. Strikes, storefronts, skyscrapers, tenements, sweatshops, baseball games, domestic scenes, neighborhoods, churches, religious rituals, festivals, political rallies, union doings and his own past were all grist for his prolific brush. A labor activist turned self-taught painter, he became the most celebrated American ''outsider'' artist outside of Grandma Moses.

title: Bronco-Buster for an Errant Buildings Department
description: DON'T fall for that demure strand of pearls looped around the neck of Patricia J. Lancaster, the authoritative architect just sworn in as commissioner of the chronically derelict and defamed New York City Department of Buildings. She does not possess the pair of kid gloves to match the necklace. A pair of steel-toed work boots and a hard hat are more like it.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: NEW HAVEN: ARCHITECT WINS YALE SEAT Maya Lin, the architect of the Vietnam War memorial in Washington, has won election to the alumni seat on Yale University's governing board, easily beating back a challenger who mounted a rare campaign for the position, the university announced yesterday. Ms. Lin was selected by an alumni nominating committee. Her challenger, W. David Lee, a New Haven minister, was nominated by petition and raised more than $50,000, much of it from clerical and custodial unions, for his campaign. Such tactics are rare in governing board elections. Although Mr. Lee won high-profile endorsements, including that of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, he received less than 20 percent of the vote. This year's election attracted nearly 50,000 ballots, almost three times the usual number. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: DECLINING SALES AT KMART TAKE TOLL ON FOOTSTAR PROFIT
description: Footstar, owner of the Just for Feet and Footaction chains, said second-quarter profit would be unchanged or less than a year earlier because of declining sales at its shoe departments in Kmart stores. Profit will be 68 to 78 cents a share, Footstar said. The company earned 78 cents a year earlier and was forecast to earn 79 cents by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Sales dropped 12 percent, to $178.4 million, in May, hurt especially at Kmart stores. Footstar said it sold fewer sandals and canvas shoes at Kmart because of cooler weather. The company expects to lose 283 Kmart outlets as the retailer closes stores in the next month. Footstar's shares fell $1.61, or 6.3 percent, to $24.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Less Frigid Relations With U.S.
description: The United States has posted a resident diplomat in Khartoum for the first time since 1996, a sign of thawing relations with Sudan. Jeffrey Millington is the United States' charg d'affaires in Khartoum, replacing Raymond Brown, who had traveled frequently to Sudan from his base in neighboring Kenya. Sudan remains on the State Department's list of state sponsors of terrorism, and officials said there were no plans to put a full ambassador there. Still, relations have warmed since Sept. 11, with Sudan providing some antiterrorism assistance to Washington. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Going Backstage At Two Operas
description: Documentaries about musical productions don't come along every week, but now there are two. In both cases, extravaganza would be a better term. Ron Frank's ''Eternal Road: An Encounter With the Past,'' from Ergo Media, tells of an epic musical drama about the history and plight of the Jews, which was written in 1934, performed in 1937 in New York and revived in 1999 in Chemnitz, Germany. Allan Miller's ''Turandot Project,'' released this week by Zeitgeist Video, follows a huge production of Puccini's ''Turandot'' as it is mounted in Florence in 1997 and travels to Beijing in 1998. Different in era, locale and artistic provenance, the musical productions are similar in scope and ambition.

title: A Visit to the DMZ
description: Just hours before the French and the Senegalese would start kicking the first ball of the World Cup, the American contingent visited something vastly more important than a soccer tournament  the demilitarized zone, the DMZ, amazingly just an hour north of bustling modern urban Seoul.

Dear sister of John and Tom and their wives, Marge and Nancy Fahey. Reposing at Chas. Peter Nagel Funeral Home, 352 E. 87 St, NY, NY Friday 2-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial 10am Saturday at Our Lady of Good Counsel R.C. Church. Interment St. John's Cemetery. Donations in lieu of flowers to Memorial SloanKettering Hospital, 1275 York Ave, NY, NY 10021.

description: Americans who are anxious about the state of tomorrow -- that is, roughly 99.9 percent of sentient Americans -- will not find reassurance in the prophecies of ''This Thing of Darkness,'' the new play from the Atlantic Theater Company that opened last night.
