description: A helicopter trying to rescue eight people trapped in a crevasse on glacier-covered Mount Hood crashed into the mountain today and rolled nearly a thousand feet, injuring at least three of its crew members.

title: COSTCO SAYS PROFIT ROSE 24% IN THIRD QUARTER
description: Third-quarter profit at Costco Wholesale rose 24 percent as costs related to the expansion of its warehouse clubs declined and sales increased. Net income climbed to $130.4 million, or 28 cents a share, from $105.3 million, or 23 cents, a year earlier. Revenue in the period, which ended May 12, including membership fees, rose 12 percent, to $8.62 billion, the company said. Costco slowed expansion, adding four stores in the quarter, down from nine in the period a year earlier. That helped reduce expenses related to store openings by about half. Sales at stores open at least a year rose 6 percent. Costco operates 389 stores, charging consumers a $45 annual membership fee. Shares of Costco rose 86 cents, to $39.32.

title: Who Wants to Buy Stock? Not the Insiders
description: BY and large, most Americans appear to be bullish on the economy and at least neutral on the stock market. Mutual fund sales are going well, and housing and consumer spending statistics show an economic recovery that is on track.

description: A film review of ''Thirteen Conversations About One Thing'' last Friday referred incorrectly to the type of Schubert composition it evoked for the reviewer. It was a piano sonata; Schubert did not write a piano concerto.

title: P.S.A.L. Final Four on Deck

Monroe of the Bronx will play Port Richmond of Staten Island and Lehman of the Bronx will face John Adams of Queens in Game 1 of a two-of-three-game series. The winners will play for the city championship next Friday at Shea Stadium.

title: Libya's Incomplete Amends
description: Libyan negotiators are offering to pay $2.7 billion to the families of the 270 people killed in the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, although the Libyan government denies any official connection with the proposal. It seems safe to assume that these theatrics are being orchestrated by Libya's flamboyant ruler, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. For the past several years Tripoli has been trying, in an erratic and incomplete way, to meet the conditions demanded by the United Nations for permanent removal of the economic sanctions imposed after Lockerbie as well as those imposed by Washington for terrorist offenses in the 1970's and 1980's.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Moody's Cuts Qwest Credit Rating
description: The credit rating of Qwest Communications International was cut to junk yesterday by Moody's Investors Service, which said the company had too much debt and might face a cash squeeze by the end of this year. Moody's lowered its rating on Qwest, which is trying to sell assets to pay off some of its $26.4 billion debt, two levels to Ba2 from Baa3, the lowest rung of investment grade. Standard & Poor's dropped Qwest's rating to junk last week. Qwest officials were not immediately available to comment.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Boeing Challenge Dismissed
description: The Seoul District Court rejected a suit by the French manufacturer Dassault Aviation demanding disqualification of the Boeing Company as the winner of a contract to build 40 fighter planes for the South Korean Air Force at a cost of more than $4 billion. The court said there was no reason to disqualify Boeing just because it raised the price of its bid and did not guarantee that South Korean manufacturers would produce as much of the plane as stipulated by South Korea's defense ministry. President Kim Dae Jung has formally approved the selection of Boeing's F15K, an advanced version of the F15. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Pakistan to Pull Troops From Afghan Front
description: In a move that could reduce Pakistan's contribution to the American-led campaign against terrorism, President Pervez Musharraf said today that he would begin withdrawing troops from the border of Afghanistan and move them to the increasingly volatile region of Kashmir.

description: Maurice Greene, the world record-holder in the 100 meters, said yesterday that he would run in the national outdoor track and field championships, June 21-23 in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: Where Twin Towers Stood, a Silent Goodbye
description: Until yesterday, there was little room for silence at the World Trade Center. In the decades before its collapse, the streets echoed with the wanted bustle of its commerce; in the eight months after, with the haunting roar from the haul of its rubble and the hunt for remains.

description: RollsRoyce, the world's second-biggest manufacturer of aircraft engines, said there had been no change in earlier forecasts that profits from its civilian aerospace businesses would be halved in 2002. Airlines have canceled orders for airplanes and engines as air travel has declined after the Sept. 11 attacks. The company's chairman, Sir Ralph Robins, above, told shareholders that the downturn would not ''materially affect the long-term value of the business.'' Its shares fell 2.4 percent. title: Terrorism That's All Too Real

It was just days ago that United States officials suggested that suicide bombings are inevitable on American targets. And as the film's fictional depiction of events leading up to a small nuclear blast (in Baltimore) unfolded at a recent press screening, the audience sat riveted in silence.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Gold Miner Considers Options
description: The Australian gold miner AurionGold appears prepared to reject Placer Dome's $1.13 billion takeover bid unless it is raised. AurionGold's managing director, Terry Burgess, said that market reaction suggested that Placer Dome, the Canadian precious metals company, would have to raise the offer it presented Monday. AurionGold is still assessing Placer's bid and faces a June 11 deadline for issuing a formal response and recommendation to shareholders.

description: General Motors rose to third place in this year's quality ranking surveys by J. D. Power & Associates, the best performance for a domestic manufacturer since the study's methodology was changed in 1998.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Directors Penalized
description: Three senior figures at HIH, the insurer that collapsed last year amid accounting irregularities, were punished by a Sydney court yesterday in a civil prosecution over efforts to manipulate HIH's stock using company money. Rodney Adler, a director of HIH and prominent entrepreneur, drew the harshest penalty, fines totaling $450,000 for himself and his family's company and a 20-year ban from corporate directorships. HIH's chief executive, Ray Williams, was fined $125,000 and banned for 10 years. Dominic Fodera, financial director of HIH and a former partner at Arthur Andersen, HIH's auditor, was fined $2,500. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Vermont Retreat
description: Through Sept. 12, the 15-room Three Mountain Inn, in Jamaica in south-central Vermont about 30 miles east of Manchester, is taking 20 percent off two- and three-night packages. The two-night plan, starting at $395 a couple (up to $595 for a suite), includes daily breakfast, a dinner for two, afternoon snacks and all taxes and tips. A third night (with another dinner) is $195 regardless of room choice. The inn, in a building dating from 1791, was renovated three years ago and has a pool; (800) 532-9399 or www.threemountaininn.com .

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Palm Predicts Loss In 4th Quarter
description: Palm Inc., the largest maker of hand-held computers, said yesterday that it would have a loss in the fourth quarter as consumers spent less than forecast on its electronic organizers. Revenue will be about $230 million in the period ending today, less than the $290 million to $300 million Palm estimated in March, the company said in a statement. Palm, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., had expected to break even in the quarter. Palm shares, which traded as high as $165 in March 2000, fell 11 cents, to $2.21 yesterday.

title: Militants Recruiting Young Dutch Muslims for Foreign War
description: A network of Islamic militants has been recruiting young Muslim immigrants at mosques in the Netherlands, urging them to join the ''holy war'' in places like Afghanistan or Kashmir, the Dutch Internal Security Agency said in a report this week.

title: Endeavour Flight Delayed
description: A band of electrically charged clouds forced a delay tonight in the launching of the space shuttle Endeavour.

title: Animosities Flare In the Struggle Over Adelphia
description: A behind-the-scenes battle that has been raging for several days between Leonard Tow, the largest shareholder of Adelphia Communications outside the Rigas family, and the company's board culminated in an angry exchange of letters yesterday between Mr. Tow and Adelphia's interim chief executive.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Paterson: Dupont Jury To Deliberate Longer
description: After six days of deliberations, the jury in the trial of the DuPont company, accused of causing pollution that sickened residents of Pompton Lakes, will spend an additional 40 minutes a day evaluating the case, starting today. The presiding judge, Frank M. Donato, proposed an additional hour of deliberations each day, to seven hours, but the jury said it preferred 40 minutes, and the judge agreed. Out of the jury's presence, the judge told lawyers his superiors were pressuring him to wrap up the trial. The jury is trying to decide if 10 past and present residents of Pompton Lakes deserve damages for illnesses they attribute to contamination at a former DuPont munitions plant in Pompton Lakes. Robert Hanley (NYT)

description: Alan Bond, a former money manager, told a federal jury yesterday that he did not cheat pension funds out of millions of dollars.

title: Lois Gould, a Writer on Women's Inner Lives, Dies at 70
description: Lois Gould, a best-selling novelist, essayist and memoirist known for her acutely observed portrayals of the emotional complexities of women's lives, died on Wednesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. She was 70 and lived in Manhattan.

title: 36 HOURS | 5 Half Moon Bay, Calif.
description: IT is only a short drive south from Silicon Valley, but Half Moon Bay, Calif., could not feel more low tech. Main Street in this small beach town (population: 11,842) dates from the 1800's. In nearby fields, tractors kick up dust while preparing the ground for artichokes and brussels sprouts. Still, like the occasional warm flow off the ocean, some of the dot-com largesse has blown in over the Santa Cruz range. Upscale eateries, knickknack shops and galleries have recently taken over historic buildings, and million-dollar digs are sprouting along the beach. Part Mayberry, part Burberry -- Half Moon Bay seems perched between two extremes. And, like the fortunes in nearby Silicon Valley, the temperature rises and falls at any time of the year. So grab your sunscreen and a sweater, and head out for the weekend. DEBRA A. KLEIN

description: The story has enough drama for a movie script -- and in fact it has already been turned into one.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Limit On Medicaid Drugs
description: Hoping to save $15 million a year, the State Department of Health and Human Services said it would create a preferred-drug list for Medicaid patients. A panel of doctors will recommend the best drugs in each class, and the state will choose the two cheapest. A doctor who wishes to prescribe drugs not on the list would first have to obtain approval from Medicaid officials. The plan faces likely opposition in the General Assembly. Drug companies say it would limit access to drugs and tie doctors' hands. David M. Halbfinger (NYT)

title: The Factory Tour Redrawn With a Box Of 64 Colors
description: IT is a little after noon on a cloudy Sunday and my son Samuel, who is 4 1/2 years old, is nearly finished with his masterpiece. Drawing with markers on a projector slide, my little Jackson Pollock has created a riot of colorful squiggles -- a bold cobalt line intersecting with razor-thin slashes of green, golden and orange -- and is now projecting an oversized image on the opposite wall.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: BLOOMFIELD: INQUIRY INTO DETAINEE'S DEATH The family of a man who died after suffering an epileptic seizure while in police custody has been told that evidence in the case will be presented to a grand jury in July. The man, Santiago Villanueva, 35, left, died on April 16 when police officers responding to an emergency call in Bloomfield found him to be combative and wrestled him to the ground, according to the officers. Last week, Mr. Villanueva's death was classified as a homicide. Susan M. Karten, a lawyer for Mr. Villanueva's family, met with the Essex County prosecutor, Donald Compolo, yesterday and said that she was promised a thorough investigation. Ms. Karten said that the New Jersey attorney general's office and the F.B.I. had requested relevant documents. A spokeswoman for Mr. Compolo did not return calls seeking comment. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: Israel Moves Into West Bank City as Envoys Start New Peace Bid
description: JERUSALEM, May 31  Israeli tanks and troops stormed into Nablus and its neighboring Balata refugee camp before dawn today, rounding up around 100 Palestinians, in the largest of the daily raids since its virtual occupation of most West Bank cities in April.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Another Secession Idea
description: new study has determined that Hollywood could sustain itself as a city apart from Los Angeles. A vote has already been scheduled for November on secession by the San Fernando Valley. The regional commission that conducted the study, the Local Agency Formation Commission, said it would recommend next week whether Hollywood voters should have the same opportunity. One sticking point is the community's fabled hillside sign. Los Angeles officials say they would fight any effort to change its ownership. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

Ask about the two years he spent studying in a religious seminary while serving as mayor of West Windsor Township, N.J., and Mr. Forrester expounds on the theologian Reinhold Niebuhr's theories about morality and the use of political power.

title: Cuomo Hires Heckled Creator Of a Knockout Bloomberg Ad
description: Last year, Bill Knapp, a Washington political consultant, was hired by Michael R. Bloomberg to produce television advertisements attacking the Democratic nominee for mayor, Mark Green. By Election Day, Mr. Knapp, a Democrat, had been publicly denounced by Terence R. McAuliffe, the party's national chairman, for an ad that Mr. McAuliffe described as distorted and unfair, and he vowed that Mr. Knapp would never work for his committee again.

title: Analyst Expects Rise in Ad Spending
description: A leading advertising industry analyst has modestly upgraded her forecast for ad spending in 2002 and modestly downgraded her medium-term outlook for an agency company.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GEORGE, SALLY
description: GEORGE-Sally. 5/31/91. Your love of life and spirit live on in the hearts and minds of all who knew you. Oh, how I miss and love you. All My Love, Catherine

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Big-Screen Adventures

title: Philip Morris Drops Beer To Concentrate Elsewhere
description: After agreeing to sell the Miller Brewing Company to South African Breweries yesterday, Louis C. Camilleri, the president and chief executive of the Philip Morris Companies, told analysts that the deal would allow Philip Morris to focus on its core food and tobacco businesses.

title: From the Many Uninvited, an Outpouring of Respect
description: They set aside ground zero for the honor guard yesterday. It was the place for the rescue workers, the firefighters, the government officials and the grieving relatives who had lost a mother or a child.

title: Examining a Life Defined by Loves and Pleasures Lost
description: A SIMPLE HABANA MELODY (From When the World Was Good)

title: California Loses in Effort for More Power-Crisis Refunds
description: Federal energy regulators examining whether companies overcharged California for electricity during the state's power crisis rejected an attempt by California officials today to expand their claim for refunds by as much as $2.8 billion.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Bush's Decision on Oil Angers Californians
description: California officials, who have been locked in a legal battle with the Bush administration to halt offshore oil drilling, responded angrily today to what they described as President Bush's highly political announcement that the federal government was seeking to buy out oil drilling leases in Florida but not California.

title: Text: Statement by Archbishop Weakland
description: Dear Friends in Christ,

title: Nets Out to Stop Another Celtic Comeback
description: For 10 seconds on Wednesday night, a frenzy struck Keith Van Horn, sending him charging up court to high-five fans along the baseline in Continental Arena.

title: Police Seek Robber Who Preys on Elderly
description: Detectives yesterday asked for the public's help finding a man who in six weeks has robbed seven elderly women in Chinatown and the Lower East Side, including a 98-year-old whom he throttled and an 85-year-old whom he punched five times.

title: Wallace Markfield, 75, Writer With a Humorous Sarcasm
description: Wallace Markfield, the author of ''To an Early Grave,'' ''Teitlebaum's Window'' and other satirical novels that earned him critical praise as a Brooklyn literary descendant of James Joyce, died last Friday at a hospital in Roslyn, N.Y. He was 75 and lived in Port Washington, N.Y.

title: String of Diplomats Begin Arriving for New Mideast Effort
description: A covey of diplomats began arriving here today in renewed efforts to find a way out of the deadly impasse between Israel and the Palestinians, as the Israeli Army continued what have by now become nearly daily raids into Palestinian territory.

title: A Gritty Drug World, From All Sides
description: Baltimore's travel bureau, if Baltimore has a travel bureau, might just want to give up and adopt the slogan ''Danger! Don't Come Here!'' Barry Levinson's Baltimore films, a series of backhanded compliments to his hometown, have been relatively benign, but there has also been that nasty crime wave featuring the city: ''Homicide: Life on the Street'' in the 1990's; the HBO mini-series ''The Corner,'' about drug dealing, in 2000.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Employees Told To Take Days Off
description: VeriSign Inc. has directed its employees to take some vacation days during the second and third quarters of the year, as the company tries to cut costs. A company spokesman, Tom Galvin, confirmed that the company, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., asked its approximately 3,000 employees to take three paid vacation days during the second quarter, which ends June 30. Some employees have already taken the days off. In addition, VeriSign asked workers to take three days off during the third quarter. The company expects workers to take these days off during the first week of July, which would give them a full week off because the company had already planned to close July 4 and July 5, Mr. Galvin said.

title: World Cup Viewing Suitable Only for Die-Hards
description: This must be a ''Fear Factor'' or an MTV ''Jackass'' stunt. You know, roast crunchy roaches, squeeze yourself into a model ship bottle, dive from 60 feet into a bucket with a foot of water -- and watch the World Cup at 1:25, 2:25, 4:55 or 7:25 a.m.

title: Skakel Prosecution Rethinks Lesser Charge
description: Prosecutors sought briefly today to allow the jury in the Michael C. Skakel murder trial to consider whether Mr. Skakel committed the crime under extreme emotional disturbance, a legal determination that would sharply reduce any potential prison sentence. But the prosecutors abruptly withdrew the request this afternoon, saying it raised a thicket of complex legal issues.

title: A Narrowed Right to Challenge the States
description: If a state violates your federal rights, are you allowed to sue it in court? In a society proudly committed to the rule of law, you might think that the answer would be yes. But the Rehnquist court has often said no. In a series of remarkable decisions, the Supreme Court has created a sweeping new principle of state sovereign immunity against private lawsuits.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: National Briefing | West: California: Court Approves State Workers' Minimum Wage
description: A state appeals court in Los Angeles ruled on Wednesday that the state could pay 250,000 state employees the minimum wage if the Legislature did not pass a budget by July 15. The Second District Court of Appeals ruled in a suit that the Howard Jarvis Taxpayers Association filed in 1998. Controller Kathleen Connell warned that state workers and schools would bear the brunt of the decision. Ms. Connell said she would appeal the decision.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: ANTITERROR DRUGS GET TEST SHORTCUT
description: Departing from longstanding practice, the Food and Drug Administration will allow some drugs and vaccines designed to counter biological, chemical and nuclear terrorism to be approved without being tested in people to prove they work.

title: International Hoops
description: The current professional basketball season has challenged the phonetic abilities of fans and broadcasters alike. Teams in the National Basketball Association now feature 45 non-Americans, and half of the league's top 10 rookies arrived without having played so much as a minute of American college or high-school ball. The Dallas Mavericks fielded a Canadian, a Chinese, a Frenchman, a German and a Mexican -- or did so until the Sacramento Kings, with two Serbs and a Turk, bounced them from the playoffs.

title: The Dangers In Militarism, As Observed On the Left
description: ''The Mad Songs of Fernanda Hussein,'' which opens today in Brooklyn, is a long, excruciatingly earnest attempt to look beneath the patriotic bombast that surrounded Operation Desert Storm and to examine the war's more sinister implications. Using nonprofessional actors and mixing documentary and fictional techniques, the director, John Gianvito, has assembled three stories about residents of New Mexico whose lives are turned upside-down by the culture of militarism.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Insurer Acquires Rival
description: Societa Assicuratrice Industriale will buy La Fondiaria Assicurazioni, ending a 10-month takeover battle, to create Italy's biggest casualty insurer, with annual premiums of 7.7 billion euros ($7.2 billion). Societa Assicuratrice will pay one share for every four Fondiaria shares, the equivalent of 4.46 euros a share, or 1.5 percent less than the insurer's closing price Wednesday. That values Fondiaria at 1.86 billion euros.

title: Presidential Language
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Brookfield: Asbestos At Elementary School
description: Officials have decided to keep an elementary school, closed twice because of the discovery of possibly dangerous asbestos fibers, shut indefinitely until the asbestos can be completely removed. The 751 students from grades 2, 3 and 4 who attend the Huckleberry Hill Elementary School will be taught at the town's middle school for the remainder of the school year, said James Chittum, the school superintendent. School administrators closed the Huckleberry school on May 22 after dust collected by a teacher tested positive for asbestos. Asbestos was found in the school two years ago and was thought to have been eradicated. Brookfield is about 40 miles northeast of Stamford. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Johnson at Ease Moving From Coach to Manager
description: HOWARD JOHNSON has vivid memories of the managers he liked and disliked in his 14-year big league career. He hopes to imitate the good and learn from what he considered the bad as he moves from hitting coach to skipper of the Brooklyn Cyclones, the Mets' short-season Class A affiliate.

title: Pick a Style, Add Ice, Then Chill
description: COOLERS are like potential housemates: you know which ones might work out as soon as you see them.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Take These Pies, Please; Inviting Thieves to a Window Where Art Imitates Lore
description: Clouds of apple scent drift across the concrete plaza, drawing young and old alike to the tiny white cottage recently sprung up in front of the main branch of the Brooklyn Public Library. Scrunching noses to the windowpane, they peer past the gingham curtains, as if looking back in time, to see a woman in a dotted red dress and an apron leaning over a counter and rolling out a crust.

title: Liberal Reality Check
description: As we gather around F.B.I. headquarters sharpening our machetes and watching the buzzards circle overhead, let's be frank: There's a whiff of hypocrisy in the air.

title: New U.S. Allies, the Uzbeks: Mired in the Past
description: Two years ago, Poul Jahn employed 140 people as an importer of products like candy from Germany and Legos from Denmark.

description: Cheim & Read

description: From left, Chris Messina, Larry Keith and Daniel Eric Gold in Craig Lucas and David Schulner's new Off Broadway play, ''This Thing of Darkness.''

description: Harry Potter and The Sorcerer's Stone

title: World Briefing | Africa: Ivory Coast: Cocoa Exports Questioned
description: The International Labor Rights Fund, a workers rights group based in Washington, has filed a petition with the United States Customs Service, demanding that it enforce American laws that bar the importation of goods made with child labor. The petition focuses on accusations of the widespread use of child labor and child slavery in producing cocoa from the Ivory Coast. Federal law prohibits importing goods produced with forced or indentured child labor. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: IRELAND: STRIKE GROUNDS AIRLINE Pilots at Aer Lingus, Ireland's state-owned airline, staged a one-day strike as planned to protest cuts in the minimum rest period they have between flights, one of many changes that the airline is putting in place as part of a plan to avoid bankruptcy. The airline's management responded to the strike by hiring outside planes and pilots to fly a handful of flights, including its shuttle service to Heathrow Airport in London and its flagship flight to New York. The carrier also canceled all flights on Friday and Saturday. For each day that its planes are grounded, Aer Lingus loses nearly $2 million, and travel plans for 20,000 passengers are disrupted, it said. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Spadea Is Attempting To Return to the Top
description: Scrambling across the clay in the fourth set, Vince Spadea found himself in the doubles alley of an obscure court today, on the edge of disappearing from a tournament, in a position of desperation.

title: Justice Dept. Accused of Politics in Redistricting
description: Last winter, the Justice Department took months to decide whether a redistricting plan for Congressional seats in Mississippi that was supported by blacks and Democrats met the requirements of the Voting Rights Act. The effect of the delay was to block the Democratic plan and allow a plan drawn by federal judges and favorable to Republicans to go into effect.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Bloomfield: Inquiry Into Detainee's Death
description: The family of a man who died after suffering an epileptic seizure while in police custody has been told that evidence in the case will be presented to a grand jury in July. The man, Santiago Villanueva, 35, left, died on April 16 when police officers responding to an emergency call in Bloomfield found him to be combative and wrestled him to the ground, according to the officers. Last week, Mr. Villanueva's death was classified as a homicide. Susan M. Karten, a lawyer for Mr. Villanueva's family, met with the Essex County prosecutor, Donald Compolo, yesterday and said that she was promised a thorough investigation. Ms. Karten said that the New Jersey attorney general's office and the F.B.I. had requested relevant documents. A spokeswoman for Mr. Compolo did not return calls seeking comment. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Cal and Wisconsin Advance at Nationals
description: Wisconsin, the Eastern Sprint champion, and Cal-Berkeley, the Pacific-10 champion, won their opening heats yesterday in the 100th Intercollegiate Rowing Association men's national championships in Pennsauken, N.J.

title: Residential Real Estate; 5 Market-Rate Rentals Planned for East Harlem
description: Work has begun on the first of five largely market-rate rental buildings that are in various stages of development in East Harlem, with construction of two more to start within the next few weeks. The buildings, being put up by several developers, would produce more than 1,000 new apartments in the area between 96th and 103rd Streets and Lexington and First Avenues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWENSTEIN, L. FRANKLYN, CPA.
description: LOWENSTEIN-L. Franklyn, CPA. At age 87. Loving and beloved husband of Louise and brother of Helen. Died peacefully on May 27 after a long bout with respiratory illness. Services Monday June 3rd, 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

description: Seventh Regiment Armory

title: An Avenger Rampages, and Chop! Chop! Heads Roll (or Rather, Fly)
description: You have to have some affection for the near-great ''Master of the Flying Guillotine,'' if only because this summer movie runs a scant 93 minutes in its newly restored original version. The opening credit sequence of this 1975 martial-arts-and-mayhem adventure is almost as long as some of the diced-up versions of it that have been broadcast on television, where it seems to have been edited with a guillotine. (Some truncated edits have been as short as 60 minutes.)

title: Family Says Church Knew Of Allegations
description: Family members of a former seminarian said yesterday that Cardinal John O'Connor and officials of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York knew at least 15 years ago about allegations of a sexually charged relationship between the young man and a prominent monsignor who was suspended last week.

title: The Navy and the Marines join forces for a campaign with Madison Avenue.
description: FOR two centuries the United States Navy and the Marine Corps have worked as a joint fighting force, but despite their long history they have always advertised separately -- until now. Since February the Pentagon has been promoting the Navy and Marine Corps together in television and print advertisements to imprint the ''Power of Teamwork'' on a more patriotic America united by the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Play Factories: Touring the Totems of Childhood
description: THE Crayola Factory isn't the only place that seeks to market capitalism as a child-friendly outing. Hershey's Chocolate World Visitor Center in Hershey, Pa., and Kellogg's Cereal City USA in Battle Creek, Mich., are huge, Disneyfied theme-park attractions with simulated factory tours apparently intended for children who are so enthralled by American industry that they yearn to see a pretend version of it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, JOHN ZADUCK
description: KATZ-John Zaduck. The Board of Directors and staff of the Mount Pleasant Cemetery of Hawthorne, NY, mourn the loss of our former longtime director. John Katz served with distinction for 28 years, significantly contributing to the Cemetery's preservation, financial strength, and beauty. We will not forget his sound judgement and gentle manner. Our condolences are extended to his wife Dorothy, his son John Andrew, and the family. Louis Sapir, Chairman Bruce Feld, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRIGGS, JAMES W.
description: BRIGGS-James W. Of Greenwich Village, N.Y. Died May 28, 2002. Age 72. Graduate of Yale, M.S. Harvard and Ph.D. N.Y.U. Retired mathmetics teacher and past President of the Village Independent Democrats. Survived by brother Thomas Briggs of Oklahoma, nephew Thomas W. and nieces Mary Courtney and Jacqueline Muriel. Friends will gather at the home of Frieda Bradlow, 43 Charlton St., Sun, June 2nd, 4PM.

title: Law's Sponsors Fault Draft Of Campaign Finance Rules
description: The principal sponsors of the new campaign finance law have told the Federal Election Commission that its proposed regulations for the campaign system ''would severely undermine the new law.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEIN, BARRY
description: KLEIN-Barry. On your birthday and everyday, I miss you and love you more than words can say. Love and Kisses, Sherry

title: Getting Everybody Moving
description: An entire hemisphere's dance music is fair game for Kinky, the five-man Mexican band that performed on May 24 at the Knitting Factory. Its credo might be summed up by ``Mas,'' in which Gil Cerezo chants, in Spanish, ``We want more and more.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Communist Leader Denounces Summit
description: The leader of the Communist Party denounced last weekend's summit meeting between President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin as a sellout of Russia's national interests and security, saying Mr. Putin allowed Mr. Bush to ''walk all over him and gave in on everything,'' and ''humiliated the country and himself.'' Gennadi Zyuganov also said Mr. Putin had ''effectively destroyed the Russian nuclear shield'' by agreeing to a two-thirds reduction, to between 1,700 and 2,200, of the number of deployed strategic nuclear warheads in each nation. With the support of between a quarter and a third of the electorate, Russia's Communists have been doomed since the Soviet collapse a decade ago to a vocal, but seemingly permanent minority in Russian politics. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Howard Sternheim, 70, Head of Thriftway Drug
description: Howard Sternheim, longtime president of the Thriftway Drug Corporation, a chain of 13 New York City drugstores including the East Side landmark Zitomer's, died on April 22 at New York-Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. He was 70 and lived on the Upper East Side.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Analysts Wary Of Manugistics
description: Shares of the Manugistics Group, a software company in Rockville, Md., fell about 4 percent after industry analysts expressed concern that the company would not perform as well as other information technology companies over the next 18 months. At the close of trading, Manugistics was off 37 cents, to $8.63, but it had declined to $7.50, its lowest price since October 2001. A spokeswoman for the company said that Manugistics would not discuss its finances until after its first quarter ends today. Manugistics makes software that helps companies share inventory, pricing and planning information with customers and suppliers over the Internet. The company ended a mandatory unpaid leave program in March for its work force of more than 1,000; at that time, the company said its fourth-quarter earnings would exceed company and Wall Street estimates.

title: Rhythms of the Ancestors Are Pulsating Still
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music may well have been the most jubilant place in New York City last Friday night. DanceAfrica celebrated its 25th anniversary, and it was an occasion for cheering.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about federal compensation awards to the same-sex partners of Sept. 11 victims referred imprecisely to legislation shelved by Congress that would have guaranteed compensation to survivors of the public safety officers who died without immediate next of kin. The legislation would have provided death benefits to the estates of 10 officers who died without spouses, children or living parents; it made no mention of their sexual orientation.

title: Trial Excites Town Used to Colorful Cases
description: Charges of mob influence and political corruption are nothing new in this blue-collar town, where Al Capone once lived. Still, the fraud trial of Cicero's town president, Betty Loren-Maltese, has stirred the public's interest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATHEW, RAYMOND F.
description: MATHEW-Raymond F. Renowned poet, playwright and author, passed peacefully in his sleep, May 28, 2002, at his home in New York on Fifth Avenue in New York. Born in Australia, Mr. Mathew spent the last 30 years between his homes in London and New York. He will be terribly missed by the art community worldwide.

title: Street Game Stretches Out
description: No English, no friends from the old country, not even his own sport coat to wear for the N.B.A. draft. It was 1989, and Vlade Divac had his height and his skill but little else to prepare him for life abroad as a professional basketball player.

title: Leader of Frankfurt Ballet Losing His Post
description: William Forsythe, the acclaimed New York-born choreographer who has headed the Frankfurt Ballet since 1984, said today that he had learned that Frankfurt's city government had decided not to renew his contract in 2004 and might be planning to replace his experimental dance company with a classical ballet troupe.

title: Levy to Stay On As Mayor Seeks New Chancellor
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday that he and Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy had agreed that Mr. Levy would stay on for a while, perhaps until the end of the calendar year, as the mayor searches for his successor.
